column2: The annual Grand Circuit meeting for light harness horses will be inaugurated at the mile track in Goshen, N. Y., tomorrow afternoon at 2 o'clock, to continue through Friday afternoon. In case of postponement because of unfavorable conditions, racing will be carried over to Saturday.

The compromise bill for "procedural" reforms in the lower courts, embodying the mild provisions salvaged from President Roosevelt's original program for complete reorganization of the Federal judiciary, was whipped through the Senate in 59 minutes this afternoon.
Miss F. Natalie Richardson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Richardson of Montclair, was married at noon today to Robert Merrill Bent, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold A. Bent of Gardner, Mass.

Motorists penalized during the two weeks ending July 24 totaled 812, Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, has announced. Their licenses to drive were either revoked or suspended. Of the number, 229 must show proof of financial responsibility before new licenses can be considered.
The of Minister of Agriculture said today that the Canadian Government was tio winning its three-way war against drought.

Mr. and Mrs. Monroe Davenport Morton of this city have announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Fleet Morton, to Harry Douglas Forsyth, also of Lynchburg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Forsyth of Arrowhead, Albemarle County.
The Senate approved today a census of unemployment, partial employment and occupations, to be taken by April 1, 1938. The measure acted upon, a resolution by Senator Black, went to the House,

Sterling continued today to gain strength against virtually all currencies. The dollar, after opening at $4.98 7-16 to the pound, weakened further to $4.98 11-16, showing a decline of 3/8 cent on the day.

WITH the French making test flights preparatory to their first commercial flight to the United States, competitive developments in the North Atlantic and a, crash in the Caribbean Sea continued to hold the aviation spotlight on international transport lines during the last week.

ACAMPAIGN to secure ultimate State and national legislation to curtail radio interference with particular reference to noise generated by automobile ignition systems, has been instituted by the National Association for Preven tion of Radio Interference, accord ing to Frank Carter, president and founder of the association.

Henri Lebasque, one of the leaders of the French impressionistic school of art, died today at his villa at Le Gannet near Cannes. Mr; Lebasque was born in 1865 at Champignh, Maine et Loire, and his works became popular in the epoch of Monet, Manet and the impressionists.
FLYING PADRE: Catholic missionaries, scattered in African jungles and Arctic wastes, know well the name of the Rev. Paul Schulte.

Speaking of the value of competent real estate management, W. G. Ruggles of Evanston, Ill., president of W. G. Ruggles Associates, builders and engineers, declares in The Journal of Real Estate Management that adequate maintenance has an important relation to value, as physical value in turn affects mortgage and insurance value.

LIFE in Camp Angka was far from dull, for if nothing of interest was being brought in, there was always activity among the camp pets. Minnie, a young macaque loved to eat our soap and to destroy the roofs of our shelters. Cinder, the bear cub, who slept in a hollow log, romped with the monkeys by the hour.

The marriage of Miss Marie Newsom, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Newsom of Shawnee, Okla., to William Forbes Morgan Jr. of this city, son of the late W. Forbes Morgan, took place yesterday morning in Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Gramercy Park North.

Jesse S. Raphael, chairman of the legislation committee of the Progressive City Committee, charged yesterday that the Sullivan-Lyons bill for the abolition of the office of Sheriff in the five counties of New York City was a piece of "stage trickery" in flagrant disregard of the constitutional mandate for the consolidation of county offices directed by the voters last year.

One hundred and twenty-five drivers of Yellow cabs went on strike last midnight here, tying up the company service. They said the company had refused their demand for a guaranteed $18 weekly minimum for ten hours a day, six days a week, and 40 per cent commission on earnings over $45 a week.

The Government said tonight its troops had fallen back on Badenas, forty-five miles north of Teruel, abandoning some positions but holding most of those it claimed to have recently captured on that front. The retreat on Badenas was ordered by the government high command, the report said, in view of "continuous Insurgent pressure on the road from Bea to Badenas."
The United States riders made a great bid in the military jumping at the Dublin Horse Show this evening, but failed to win.

There are seven stages in a man's life, Shakespeare contended in his play, "As You Like It." That, of course, does not hold for male Summer-session students at Teachers College, Columbia University, who go through an eighth stage every year at their traditional men's steak dinner when they tackle hundreds of huge T-bone steaks, sans knives, sans forks, sans napkins, sans everything.
Tonight the Reds are in sixth place alone, the Dodgers are in the doldrums as well as a short downward step from the cellar, and Burleigh Grimes is in a state of mind better left undescribed.

After almost forty-six hours of survival under a makeshift oxygen tent and in a new air-conditioped incubator, Frances Mary Boccawsini, the baby delivered Friday by post-mortem caesarian section, died at Philadelphia General Hospital at 1:07 o'clock this morning.

NEW YORK is slow to acquire a taste for exotic fruits and vegetables, but in recent years the city has learned the virtues of certain foods that have long been staples in tropical lands. At the moment the markets are filled with avocados, or alligator pears.
A gentle old woman of this village recently had an experience which has severely strained her faith in human nature. She was a strong believer in the virtue of helping her fellow man.

Miss Sally Skinner, daughter of William Converse Skinner of Farmington, was married to Franklin Patrick Kearney, son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. D.Kearney of Farmington, this afternoon in the garden at the Skinner home. The ceremony was, performed by the Rev. L. M. Brewster.
Uncensored news reaching Paris today from Spain throws an entirely new light on the mysterious disappearance and supposed escape from his Madrid prison of the anti-Stalin radical leader, Andres Nin.

Although very much interested in the fate of the housing bill, now pending in Congress, the Producers Council will bend its chief efforts during the Fall to support the activities of the Home Owners Loan Corporation in stimulating residential building, John Gowen of the council said here yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Owen Roberts and Mrs. Roberts are here from Philadelphia, visiting E. Clifford Potter at Ar-Y-Mor. Their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Roberts, and Robert Stott of New York are week-end guests of Mr. and -Mrs. Dickson B. Potter.

The second concert of the Berkshire festival was given tonight at Tanglewood and many guests here for the event are being entertained at country places. Most of the hotels, -especially in Southern Berkshire, are filled.

Close-of-play scores in English first class cricket matches started today: Surrey 170 (Gregory 52, Squires 51 Owen-Smith five for 52), Middlesex 138 runs for nine wickets, at the Oval. Leicestershire 404 (Berry 153, Prentice 59, Astll 56), vs. Hampshire, at Basingstoke.

Members of the lumber industry found many factors of interest, which, it is said, will lead to considerable discussion in the future, in the report recently made public by the President's National Resources Committee.

Chairman Pittman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee sought passage today of a bill forbidding picketing of embassies, arguing that such a law was "necessary to protect the lives of foreign representatives."
LAKE PLACID.--The eighth annual Lake Placid Horse Show, which will be the feature of next week-end, will open on Friday afternoon and continue that evening and Saturday and Sunday afternoons.

J. Newman Carey, chairman of the executive committee of the Taxpayers party, announced yesterday that a questionnaire had been sent to members of the Board of Estimate and the Legislature and to candidates for those offices. The replies, he said, would be a prime factor in determining endorsements by the party. The questions follow:

Little Nymph, 4-year-old filly owned by Mrs. R. J. Murphy of Evansville, Ind., and ridden by W. L. Johnson, won the Inaugural Handicap at the opening of the fourteenth annual Summer meeting today. The Pelican, the favorite, was second and Candlelight third. The time for the six furlongs was 1:12 2-5 over a slow track.

Captain David Kite has joined the staff of the Cunard White Star Line in New York as assistant marine superintendent, under Captain Harry McConkey. He is 44 years old and, starting as an. apprentice, has served his entire time at sea with the Cunard Line.

Prompted by the "rapidly growing need for trained public servants" and by "Mayor La Guardia's leadership in raising the public service standards in this city," the New York University division of General Education, in cooperation with administrative departments of the New York City and State

Miss Janet Taylor, daughter of Mrs. Howard Metcalfe Taylor of this place and the late Mr. Taylor, has chosen the afternoon of Aug. 28 for her marriage to Joseph Walter Miller Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Miller of Princeton, N. J. The ceremony will take place in the garden of Bay Crest, the home here of the prosnective bride's mother.

Pickets were photographed in an innovation of subpoena serving today in a labor controversy involving union pickets and nonunion salesmen of an automobile company. Restrained by a temporary order yesterday from-picketing the company, pickets appeared today near the automobile building.

J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, stated today upon his return from the West that he was giving "serious consideration to the suggestion that I submit my name to the voters next August for the Gubernatorial nomination" in his home State of California. He added:

The Hugenot Yacht Club of New Rochelle will hold a championship regatta in the Yacht Racing Associtation of Long Island Sound series on Saturday. The first division craft are slated to start at 2 o'clock:

Men's store executives are looking forward to a new type of sports shirt for 1988, which to a certain extent will replace the "bush jacket" during the warn weather. Such a shirt would be of linen, or simulating linen, short-sleeved, out in jacket style with vents at the side and wearable in or outside the trousers.

At the end of 1936, prediction of continued industrial recovery was all but unanimous; but confidence in that result was tempered by knowledge, first that so prolonged an advance as had occurred since the Spring of 1935 would usually invite reaction, second, that some unfavorable event, not expected beforehand, was apt to happen. Both expectations were fulfilled.

Institution of a cooperative program for increasing contractors' prices in knitted outerwear by Aug. 23 was announced yesterday by Harold R. Lhowe, executive director of the National Knitted Outerwear Association, following a meeting of the links contractors of the association.
Perole String Quartet, directed by Joseph Coleman, begins a cycle of Mozart and Schubert compositions: WOR, 11:30 A. M.-12:30 P. M.

A labor leader disclosed to- wants tonight that charges of violation of the Wagner act had been lodged with the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board against the Belle plant of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Corporation and the Electro-Metallurgical Corportion which has plants at Glen Ferris and at Alloy.
With bumper yields from the important farm crops of the United States expected this year, there have been renewed demands for Federal loans to producers and restriction on future production.

Britain's heat wave seemed to be abating tonight but not before the high temperatures had caused damage. Five deaths were reported. Heat buckled railroad tracks between Weymouth and Portland, stopping holiday traffic two hours.

Hollywood motion pictures have been cast in a new school room role by the Progressive Education Association. Specially edited sequences from well-known films will be flashed across the screens of seventeen selected schools and colleges throughout the land as a means of helping adolescents solve their personal problems and develop a keen insight into human relations and needs.
Batavia police are seeking honey thieves who made a night raid on hives of the Cohocton Apiaries here and made off with nearly a ton of honey. Edwin W. Frisby, owner, estimates his loss at $300.

Despite the Boy Scout Jamborees and the increasing number of tours taken by American students, far less educational travel is being provided this Summer for our youngsters than for those in Europe, according to a survey just made by the writer under the auspices of the International Institute of Teachers College, Columbia University.
THE Papineau - Mackenzie Company of 400 young Canadians in arms in Spain upholding the cause of the Loyalists is one reminder of the Rebellion in Upper and Lower Canada exactly 100 years ago.

Samuel Calsnick, owner of a candy store in South Philadelphia, looked into his cash register tonight and said neighborhood children with a flair for labor union tactics had failed to put a dent in his profits by a brief attempt to picket his business.
The Textile Workers Organizing Committee, a C. I. O. organization of which Sidney Hillman is chairman, announced yesterday that an agreement had been signed with the Hafner Associates Inc. of Long

A. G. Newhall, Assistant Professor of Plant Pathology in Cornell University's College of Agriculture, took to the air to find an onion blight that "flies from place to place and threatens to destroy half of New York State's $3,000,000 onion crop." He used an airplane on a "patrol" over the Montezuma marshes at the north end of Cayuga Lake and reported finding fungus spores traveling with the wind at altitudes up to 1,500 feet. [1/4]

Of general interest at the twetyseventh annual convention of the National Association of Gardeners in Philadelphia, Tuesday to Thursday, inclusive, will be the offering and acceptance of a memorial to the late William Kleinheinz.

ALL types of interior, from those of the budget apartment to the more spacious ones of the country home, have been considered in making up the season's new wallpapers. As much thought seems to have been given to the lowerpriced examples as to those in the upper ranges.
The New Jersey State committee of the American Legion, at a meeting here today, decided to ignore the alleged Nazi activities at the camp of the Germai American Bund at Andover, Sussex County.

Reviewing at length the financial situation of France, Finance Minister Georges Bonnet tonight in the name of peace begged the French people to give him unstinted cooperation in his work of restoration. Refusal, he hinted, might mean war or, at least financial dictatorship.

Lady Tree, famous actress and widow of Sir Herbert Beerbohm Tree, died today at University College Hospital in London at the age of 72 where she had undergone an operation. She first appeared on the stage in 1883 in "Sweethearts" and sprang to fame with her playing of Lady Teazle in "School for Scandal."

THE observer who happens to be on the shores of Long Island Sound, Buzzards Bay, Vineyard Sound or the ocean off Rhode Island during the next three weeks and sees the white sails of fifty or sixty boats in the offing will be witnessing one of the great mass movements of American yachting.

President Roosevelt has told Governor Cross that he will not approve any interstate flood control compact that deals with the water resources of the nation or their development. "It is my profound conviction that these matters are properly the subject of Federal legislation and not of interstate compacts," he stated in a letter received by Governor Cross today.

Coinciding with the arrival here yesterday of the Japanese Ambassador, Shigeru Kawagoe, to initiate negotiations for a Sino-Japanese settlement, a statement made by a spokesman for the Chinese Foreign Office indicated the door leading to such a settlement was ajar, however slightly.
"Nobody likes a strike. For the first week, maybe, it's a good vacation. But after that -well, the first pay check looked mighty damn big."

STEADILY growing in popularity is the Boy Scouts' newest camp ing technique-the moving camp. As its name indicates, the moving camp combines a tour by auto, horseback, canoe or foot with regular camp craft.
Professor Harold Hotelling of the Economics Department of Columbia University has purchased the residence at Mountain Lakes, near Boonton, N. J., formerly owned by Palmer Clingman.

Fighting it out in the last furlong with all the gameness of the true thoroughbred, John Hay Whitney's Pumpkin today won the thirty-fifth Saratoga Special before 20,000 persons who made up the Spa's largest crowd in years.

EITHER IS LOVE. By EliSabeth CralgH. 8VIo. New York: Harcourt Co. $2. A personal record of two types of love. WORLD REVOLUTION, 1917-1936. By C. L. R. James. 8vo. New York: Pioneer Publishers. 3.50. The rise and fall of the Communist International.

Those who expected to catch a glimpse of members of the victorious Davis Cup team in action on the opening day of the Eastern turf court tennis championships were not entirely disappointed this afternoon.

THE Medieval Academy of America has published recently the "Historia Destructionis Troiae" (History of the Destruction of Troy) of Guido de Columnis, edited by Dr. Nathaniel E. Griffin, at Harvard University.

Homesteading, 1937 style, soon will be put to test in Knox County, where 160 workmen are rushing construction of farm buildings for one of the first groups of rural families to receive. new Indiana homes under the Resettlement Administration's homestead program.
Several properties in Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau Counties have been sold recently by the Mortgagees Realty Service, the real estate division of the Home Title Guaranty Company.
Feverish patriotism marked the closing today of Japan's special two weeks' parliamentary session. Premier Fumimaro Konoe, in a statement from his sick-bed, where he was prostrated by heat, said:
Christopher D. Sullivan-"Christy," the last of the Big Four of the once-powerful Sulllivan clan-is in no comfortable spot as the new leader of Tammany.

Pope Pius XI called down "woe" today upon any nation which would obstruct Catholic education, and associates interpreted his remarks as a warning to Germany. Addressing Belgian pilgrims, he said he saw happiness for the Belgian people as long as they remained faithful to their Catholic tenets, but disaster for those who forgot or attacked those teachings.
The price of pork is hitting an eleven-year high, and latest market reports indicate that it will go still higher. Other meat cuts--beef especially--are showing a tendency to rise "in sympathy."

The Manursing Island Club of Rye was the scene of a dinner dance here tonight. Among those who entertained were Mr. and Mrs. James N. Hynson and Mrs. J. K. Herrmann of Scarsdale, and Mrs. M. de la Chesnaye, Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Eyre and Mr. and Mrs. Roger Walcott of Rye.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick James Hancock of this place have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Judith Batiste Hancock, to Herbert A. Preiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Preiss of Brooklyn, on July 24 in the Bushwick Avenue Congregational Church, Brooklyn, of which the bride's grandfather, the late Rev. William Tavener Stokes, was founder and pastor for many years.

The third annual national awards of the McMullen Regional Scholarships in Engineering at Cornell University to thirty-four outstanding graduates of high schools and preparatory schools throughout the country were announced today by President Day.
Three young grandchildren of Supreme Court Justice Louis D. Brandeis, who are spending their vacation on Cape Cod, are putting out a bi-monthly four-page hectographed newspaper.

WHEN the caterpillar of the Large Blue Butterfly is sti very young it gets restless. It drops off the flowerhead where it has been living, and starts to walk. It "walks as though it wanted something and did not know what.

German avaition circles are jubilant over the feat of the Hamburg aviator Herr Huth, who succeeded in covering the distance from Wasserkuppe to Berlin and return in a glider. Although several halts were made, the distance of 475 miles is acclaimed as significant in this phase of aviation by the German press generally.

Japanese naval forces wiped out 150 Chinese bandits today on the Sungari River, forty miles east of Harbin, in the first fight on that river involving naval craft since the Japanese protectorate of Manchukuo was established.

One of the minor sports, or petty annoyances in Loyalist Spain today involves obtaining small change. It takes two seconds to break a fifty, a hundred or even a thousand peseta note. But if one goes into a cafe for a sixty centimos drink with nothing smaller than a five peseta note, not infrequently it will take half an hour or more to get change.

Reforms amounting almost to a general reorganization were ordered in the agricultural system of White Russia today by the Communist party and the Soviet Government in a decree signed by Joseph Stalin and Premier Vyacheslaff Molotoff. The motive stated is to liquidate the results of wrecking.
It was the same old story of California tennis domination in the finals of the national junior and boys championships at the Culver Military Academy today.
Mayor S. Davis Wilson of Philadelphia indicated yesterday his belief that Mayor La Guardia would be re-elected. He came here for the intercity municipal employes' ball game at the Polo Grounds.

Mlle. Jadwiga Jedrzejowska's second week of competition on American tennis courts was crowned with success today as the champion of Poland carried off the prized Woodin Gold Cup at the Maidstone Club.

Whatever the fate or the form of legislation at this session of Congress covering the subject of hours and wages of labor and prohibition of children working in industry, this much can be said: It will by no means end Congressional debate in the field.
The only patient in a yet uncompleted $1,000,000 hospital, Charles Hunt, 24-year-old infantile paralysis victim, fretted tonight over his enforced stay in an "iron lung" on which his life depends.

The Coast and Geodetic Survey is trying to chart its way around an art tempest involving the work of James Abbott Whistler, its onetime employe. In 1854 the painter, a gangling youth of 20, was doing engravings for the government agency. His work was map-making, but he had a hard time confining himself to its rigid restrictions.
Arthur W. Danziger, founder and president of Meyer Danziger, Inc., furniture firm, died yesterday at the Harkness Foundation, Medical Center. His age was 55.

Work started last week in the easterly section of Queens borough on a housing project which, on completion, will represent, according to the developers, practically $9,000,000. The tract under improvement involves a large acreage in the Jamaica area facing the
Frederick Schoen, 50 years old, of 52 Florida Street, here, was drowned- while swimming with friends in the surf off Georgia Avenue between 8:30 and 9 o'clock tonight.

H. Eliot Kaplan, secretary of the National Civil Service Reform League, said today that personnel provisions of the Robinson Government Reorganization Bill were "vague and contradictory." He testified at hearings held by a special Senate committee.
IN London the feeling prevails that British television programs now can be compared favorably with the average home-movie show for clarity, brilliance and diversity of program material.

After scoring 143 for the loss of one wicket and then declaring the innings closed, the Hudson County eleven of the Brooklyn Cricket Club dismissed the team of the Bloomfield Cricket Club for 68 and gained another victory in the championship series of the New Jersey State Cricket League on the grounds of Stevens Institute today.

BELGIAN CONGO might well be termed Africa's laboratory of fauna. For not only have all the wellknown species diffused in other parts of the continent lived there at one time or another, but, hidden in the depths of this region's evergreen jungles, are strange creatures found only there which seem to have been created by nature in an experimental mood.
Mead Memorial Chapel at Middiebury College will be remodeled this Summer to increase the seating capacity by 25 per cent.

In a race necessitating four heats, Rosalind, bay mare, daughter of Scotland-Alma Lee by Lee Worthy, captured the Champion Stake, a handicap mile race for trotters, at Agawam Park today as the first Grand Circuit meeting here in fortyfour years ended. The purse value was $5,500.

The battle of the hollyhocks continues. It has now got outside the garden wall, and the experts of the Botanical Gardens and -even the church have become involved. We are endeavoring-in vain, quite likely-to keep it localized.

Fred Jacoby, scenic artist from North Bergen, N. J.; Clint Ferguson, Tabor Academy athlete from Wban; Gar Wood Jr., son of the world-famous speed-boat racer, and Mrs. Mary Daller of Chester, Pa., were headliners on the opening day of the motor boat regatta today on the Charles River Basin.

WHETHER or not his decision to take a three months' rest was occasioned by the fact that he has just finished directing a picture for Samuel Goldwyn--who is noted for his unique ability to run amuck while sitting down--the fact

Fingerprints taken during an army enlistment more than a decade ago resulted today in identification of the victim of a "roadside killing" near Kingdom City on July 22 as Charles W. Padgett. The name checked with the initials "C. W. P" on the slain man's clothing.

Seven "observers" keeping a constant check on daily police complaints and a staff of experts who study the reports for signs that a racket is starting or operating in industrial and business circles constitute the answer of business men, corporations and individuals to conditions exposed through the activities of Thomas E. Dewey, Deputy Assistant District Attorney.

SHANGHAI. THE nationalistic fires now flaming in China are being fanned by a campaign of educa tion through posters. Newspapers, books and pamphlets, on which Western countries can rely to teach patriotism, are of no use in a country where hundreds of millions of children and adults are illiterate. Decades must pass before they can be taught to read and write.

Officials of the Plymouth Motor Car Company and representatives of the United Automobile Workers of America' announced a "basis of settlement" tonight which, they predicted, would result in resumption of normal operations in the Plymsouth plant Monday morning. Details were not disclosed.

In anticipation of a busy Fall season many stores in the Fifth Avenue shopping section, between Thirty - fourth and Forty - second Streets, are undergoing extensive changes. According to Milton Rosenbluh of Vought, Campbell Ward Co.,

One of the most valuable factors in the rapid upbuilding of the suburban home communities in Queens Borough and the adjacent sections of Nassau County has been the splendid system of motor roads and parkways which have been built and opened during the last ten years.

Scoring eight points out of a possible nine, Hermann Helms, former New York State champion, took first prize in a field of ten in the weekly rapid transit tournament at the Marshall Chess Club. Herbert Seidman of the Kings Chess Club of Brooklyn was a runner-up with a score of 7--2.

Several British metal firms were understood tonight to have their eyes on the old Leviathan, the United States' largest liner. The vessel, now out of service, would be brought to shipyards on the Firthof Clyde and broken up so that her metal might be used in Britain's rearmament Program.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The business men of this country, as I meet their opinions at Pittsburgh, are in accord in believing that America is now privileged to enter upon the greatest prosperity of her history if only her labor population can be restored to their former spirit of loyalty by satisfaction and contentment through a cordial concession to their just and humane demands.

The C. I. O. strike at the Sunshine Silver Mine ended suddenly tonight. Announcement of the settlement followed--the hanging in effigy today of Thomas McGuire, C. I. O. organizer, by non-union miners and a demand for a showdown between the union and non-union men.

J. W. Hugill, Attorney General of Alberta since the present government took office nearly two years ago. was asked today by Premier Aberhart to resign and did so. Mr. Hugill has been one of the four Calgary Social Credit members in the Legislature. He is the fourth Cabinet Minister to be deprived of his office since the Aberhart government was elected In August, 1935.

To the Art Editor: WE, the undersigned abstract artists, received with enthusiasm the news that the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, to be devoted mainly to the enlightenment of the public in abstract art, has been established.

Dick Shaughnessy, Boston's 15year-old national skeet shooting champion, using a new twentygauge shotgun presented to him by his father, broke ninety-eight targets today to defeat thirty of the best gunners in the East.
Five hundred Grange leaders from New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Maryland and Delaware will meet here Tuesday for the eleventh annual Grange lecture conference that will continue for four days.

ROUBEN MAMOULIAN, the Armenian who has made a career of interpreting the American saga in lyric terms for the stage and screen, sailed on the Normandie Wednesday for five-week vacation abroad, firing as he left a Parthian shot in defense of Hollywood.

Mrs. Charles E. Stuart, widow of Judge Stuart, one-time Speaker of the Virginia House of Delegates, died last midnight at the age of 83. She had made her home at Virginia Cottage, Baileys Bay, for thirty years and her residence was a meeting place for Virginians here.

Rear Admiral L. V. Wells, commanding the Third Cruiser Squadron, delivered a strong protest today to the Spanish Rebel air base at Palma, Majorca, against the attack by three planes yesterday off Algeria on the British oil tanker British Corporal, in which a French and an Italian freighter were also targets.

Patrolman Arthur H. Chalmers, attached to Troop B of Mounted Squad 1, was booked on a charge of homicide at 9 o'clock last night in the shooting of Miss Irma Louise Pradier, French servant, whose body was found on the Harlem River Speedway on the morning of July 20.

The last topographical problem of the Athenian Agora, the exact location of the Temple of Ares, was solved this year by excavations of the American School of Classical Studies in the market place of ancient tra Athens, according to Dr. T. Leslie Shear, the school's field director.

Jews in this country never have thought about government, or shared in it, except as Americans, Rabbi Abraham L. Feinberg said yesterday in a sermon at Mt. Neboh Temple, 130 West Seventy-ninth Street. Declaring that group political action "runs absolutely contrary to Jewish tradition," he maintained that "the so-called Jewish vote is a myth."

The mill at Sherritt-Gordon Mines, Gold Lake area, Northern Manitoba, resumed operations this week. Production was suspended slightly more than five years ago. The mill is being operated at 1,000 tons daily, with an increase to 1,500 tons to be made before the end of the year.
President Lazaro Cardenas today began breaking up Yucatan's great henequen estates and, at the same time, appealed to labor to refrain from strikes which might obstruct the agrarian program.

Eight of the twenty-five policemen trapped by gambling raiders in a Harlem flat on May 28 have been disciplined on charges growing out of the raid, it became known yesterday in the department's Special Orders dated Aug. 7.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Emery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Emery, to Lester Warner Meehan, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Meehan of Fitchburg, Mass., took place here this afternoon at the home of her parents. The Rev. J. Jack Sharkey of St. Paul's Church Derformed the ceremony.

A private airplane overshot the Municipal Airport in dense fog tonight and crashed in the waters of Frenchman's Bay, injuring its two occupants, Hollis Bragdon, 28 years old, formerly of Hartford, Conn., pilot and owner, and Rodney Lawrence, also of Bar Harbor.
The American Football League, which will include a club from the Pacific Coast for the first time in major sport history, has arranged a forty-one-game schedule for the Fall campaign.
A VETERAN in his seventies, Sir Charles Oman of Oxford stands second to no living historian in learning, experience and ability to express his meaning.

One of the important East Side deals of the present season has been closed through the realty firm of Wood, Dolson Company in the sale of the five and one-half story building at 7-15 East Seventy-third Street, formerly the residence of the late Joseph Pulitzer, editor and owner of th old New York World.

A LANGUAGE created specifically for broadcasting pur poses which is said to be without grammar or idiom, and capable of being understood in all civilized tongues without prolonged study, will be introduced for international broadcasts in a series of test programs to originate from WMCA, according to representatives of the station.

New York has come to the fore during the last few years as the world's leading leather goods market, according to M. Frank, managing director of N. V. Lederwarenfabriek Rijnveld, Amsterdam, Holland, who has spent the last week in New York purchasing handbags, belts and other leather goods for the chain of fifteen specialty shops operated by his organization.

For adding color and interest to the borders in midsummer no perennial surpasses the phlox, P. decussata. One of the most brilliant and effective of garden flowers, if well grown and planted it will dominate the garden through a long blooming period with lovely, varied hues.

Mr. and Mrs. Ewald H. Schniewind of Greenwich, Conn., today gave a large cocktail party which was followed by several dinners. Entertaining at a supper dance in the Mount Washington Cave Grill tonight at Bretton Woods were the Misses Ann Degnon, Peggy Sanderson,* Ruth Gregg and Mildred Kadel.

Abbe Pierre d'Armailhacq announced tonight he was authorized to state that former King Alfonso of Spain and former Queen Victoria Eugenia had been "fully reconciled." The former King now is in Lausanne for the wedding Aug. 16 of Princess Dolores of the House of Bourbon and Prince Auguste Czartoryski of the Lithuanian house.

Emil Troxler of 49 Mertz Avenue, Belleville, who was known in his youth as the "Strong Man of Newark," died yesterday. Mr. Troxler was the brother of Gus Troxler, credited with being the -first boxing promoter here.
Mrs. Katherine Hollhan Murdock, widow of James Willis Murdock, official of public utilities firms, died here yesterday in her seventy-eighth year after several months' illness.

Roy Wenzlick, president of Real Estate Analysts and who published a book a year ago predicting a coming boom in real estate, says that in view of the recent rising costs in building construction he has received many inquiries asking if that condition may not seriously affect future real estate activities.

Although the Minister of National Defense has not yet made a definite decision regarding purchases of material for the military aviation service, it is understood that a special commission now in Europe has recommended the purchase of twelve modern Junkers bombers in Germany and some airplanes of the Breda type and amphibians now used by the Italian forces.

MOST people who write funny pieces produce slowly because they baby themselves into thinking that it is necessary to have an idea before starting to write. For example, a Frank Sullivan feels better if he has some such idea as dinner at the captain's table on a Staten Island ferryboat, or a Christmas gift from an elevator man.

DETROIT AR manufacturers are in the final stages of production for the 1937 model year. General Motors and some Chrysler divisions still are operating at or close to full capacity, but before the end of the month some of them will have completed their current runs.

New York has been one of the world's most lavish cities in the building of monuments. More than 300 are under Park Department jurisdiction alone. Many of its sculptural tributes to heroes and heroic events were in poor condition before the Federal Government, with the Park Department cooperating, set up a project for their renovation.

LONDON. -- A grotesque imp carved among a band of angels in England's famous Lincoln Cathedral was blamed when "the flower of English Gothic architecture" threatened to collapse after 600 yearn because of weakened foundations. Now that the edifice has been put in sound condition there are those who wonder whether the imp will again make trouble.

Portland reports that the waterborne commerce over its docks in July totaled 165,018 short tons, exclusive of coastwise trade. It is something like 55 per cent better than the same month a year ago. The largest gain was registered in outbound foreign shipments.

Miss Marion Louise Chase, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gilman Leeds Chase of this place, was married here this afternoon in the Church of the Good Shepherd to William Henry Wulp of Newburgh, N. Y., son of Mrs. William C. Wulp of East New Market, Md., and the late Mr. Wulp. The Rev. Kirby Webster performed the ceremony.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Evatt of Boston entertained tonight with a dinner-dance for colonists of the Bald Peak Club. Tomorrow they will be hosts at a tea and croquet party at Robin Hill, their Summer home here. With Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Dean Lounsbury of New York at Sunnymede are Mr. and Mrs. B. V. M. La Rue of New York.

The epidemic of defaults that has dotted the victorious march of Robert L. Riggs across the turf of Eastern tennis aided the 19-yearold Los Angeles youth in another conquest today as he established the first leg on the costly new Southampton Cup at the Meadow Club. .

The Virginia Democratic "organization," deemed in some quarters to be almost on its last legs, has just staged a striking "come-back." In this week's primary its prestige was definitely involved in three important contests, and it won all of them.

THIS is a book about England. In a sense, it is a supplementary guide book to England, with notes, too, on Wales. It bears the subtitle, "England's History in Her Buildings and Countryside." And it is a useful, interesting and altogether satisfactory book of its kind.

Duquesne Light Company-Twelve months to June 30: Net income, after all expenses and charges, $10,613,987, compared with $10,704,462 in twelve months to June 30, 1936; gross revenues, $30,154,493, against $26,139,028.

By defeating the 1935 winners, William S. Meany Jr. and Bobby Grant, in a twenty-hole match, the New Jersey team of Dr. R. R. Lauckner and his. youthful partner, Wilson Flohr, gained the final round of the John G. Anderson memorial tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.
THERE are so many individualists in the book collecting community that the task of providing a magazine that will please all hands is not to be envied.

Sixty-one boats took part ing the regatta of the yacht-racing squadron of the Country Club of Westhampton Beach on Moriches Bay today. The wind was southsouthwest and of fair strength, sending the craft around the usual championship course in excellent time.

Things have been going so badly for British sport lately that, as one commentator put it the other day. it is a good thing there are not more cups to lose, because they would surely be traveling west this year.

Bonds called last week for redemption prior to maturity were in somewhat larger volume than in the preceding week and included several large issues of foreign, industrial and public utility concerns. Except for small amounts of municipal and realty bonds called last

Determined and healthy growth of the curbhopping business, long viewed with mingled suspicion and envy by young women in other professions, has recently led investigators to look into the secrets of a curbgirl's life, with an eye toward its sociological significance, if any.

The Communist party newspaper Pravda today denounced chief editors of the new Academy of Science dictionary for "political dishonesty." "expounding Trotskyist ideas," and using quotations from the Bible. Pravda declared that Editor-InChief N. S. Derjavian, and Professor S. Obnorsky failed to include in the dictionary a single quotation from Karl Marx or Maxim Gorky,

Jerome Summerfield, a mere youth of 40, couldn't quite keep up with his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Summerfield, 84 and 76 years old, respectively, on their fifty-third "honeymoon" trip on an Old Dominion Line steamer from New York to Norfolk.

The marriage of Miss Jane Braitmayer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto E. Braitmayer of Ridgewood, N. J., to William Henry Howell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Howell of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., took place here this afternoon in the garden of her parents' Summer home. The Rev. Edwin Carson officiated.

A portfolio of original manuscripts of toasts and signatures of a group of internationally known chemists who took part in a Paris dinner April 22, 1867, at the time of the Paris Universal Exposition, has been acquired by Dr. Charles L. Parsons, secretary of the American Chemical Society, the society announced yesterday.

Check clearings of the Westchester County Clearing House Association, in the week ended on Aug. 6, amounted to $3,086,561, compared with $2,599,268 in the previous week, and with $2,515,699 correspondingly last year.

One year after his coup d'etat, which changed the Greek constitutional monarchy into a military dictatorship, Premier John Metaxas is still firmly in the saddle despite many rumors and prophecies against his holding out in the early days of his regime.
Textile manufacturers reached an agreement today establishing a minimum wage plan for Argentina's 22,000 textile workers.

IT is not often that the theatre pays the literary critics of dramatic literature the tribute of taking their theories seriously. This, however, is what Michael MacOwan has done in his production of "Hamlet" at the Westminster Theatre.

The former Flanagan-Nay Brewery plant at 448-462 West Twentysixth Street, running through the block to 441-457 West Twenty-fifth Street, with additional frontage at 262-266 Tenth Avenue, will be sold at auction tomorrow in the Vesey Street salesrooms.

GRASSE, France. LANDING in Europe after a year and a half spent in different regions of the United States, I received the immediate impression of a universal and startling shabbiness. Shabbiness of things-wharves, docks, railway stations, hotels, shops and public buildings. I do not regret that edifices should be small and old, but that they should be crying aloud for a coat of paint and an air of brightness is painful.

The new Soviet-American commercial agreement, that went into effect yesterday, was greeted with satisfaction here as further strengthening the relations between the two countries. Such relations have been important to the Soviet Union ever since Japan began her aggressive policy toward China with the occupation of Manchuria, bordering directly on Soviet territory.
One thing must be said for the America's Cup contest. It was not a very exciting fight, but at least it was a recognizable fight.

New home mortgages accounted for 48 per cent of the value of total mortgages accepted for insurance by the FHA during the first six months of this year in the ten States furnishing the largest volume of such business, Stewart McDonald, administrator, announced yesterday.
Senator Copeland told 250 fruitgrowing members of the State Horticultural Society today that 80 per cent of the nation's farmers were receiving a $165 annual bonus from the Government.

In railroading last week the dominant note was one of labor peace. Fourteen non-operating railroad brotherhoods, representing more than 750,000 men, had threatened to strike, but under the Railway Labor Act of 1934, which amended an earlier Railway Labor Act of 1926, the union or the employer must give thirty days' notice of a desire to change an existing situation.

Federal supply awards in the week ended on Aug. 5 totaled $4,620,283, with twelve agencies concluding ninety contracts under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

Although there were indications of a seasonal letdown in retail trade activity in some of the Federal Reserve districts last week, wholesale figures mounted sharply as the result of special Fail market week events in some of the leading centers.
Virgin Islanders whose small incomes have forced them to live in flimsy huts will now have an opportunity to occupy PWA housing projects with rents of $3 to $6.40 monthly.

Country clubs and yacht clubs have come to the rescue of the Summer colonists of the North Shore who will remain through August in their homes, for social life this month centers largely around the activities of Piping Rock, the Creek, Nassau, the Woman's National Golf and. Tennis Club,- Seawanhaka Corinthian. Yacht, Manhasset . Bay Clubs and others in which the membership is made up of wellknown society men and women.

Consummation yesterday of the sale of the holdings of Errett Lobban Cord in the Cord Corporation to a group including Emanuel Co., in cooperation with interests for which Schroder Rockefeller Co., Inc., is acting,

Despite the official "cold shoulder" given last Spring to the Russian commission seeking to arrange the construction of battleships in this country, the commission is still negotiating with American steel concerns and shipbuilding companies, it was learned yesterday.

Dr. David Harrower, eye and ear specialist here for more than fifty years and one of the foremost physicians in Worcester County, died today at his home here. He began practice in Worcester after being graduated from Harvard Medical School in 1881 and spending three years studying medicine abroad at the Universities of Glasgow, Edinburgh, Vienna, Berlin and Paris.

Three men who said they were organizers and officials of the United Rubber Workers of America a C. I. O. affiliate, told police tonight that they were beaten by men who chased them from a new plant of the Goodyear Tire Rubber Company here during formal opening ceremonies today.
IT is difficult to read any criti cism of Thomas Mann's without being acutely aware that behind the critic stands the creative writer.

Daniel Taylor Wilson, former carriage builder and a member of the board of directors of the Brooklyn Eye and Ear Hospital and the Brooklyn Home for Children, died yesterday evening of a heart malady after an illness of three weeks at his home, 70 South Merrick Avenue.

The office of Controller Frank J. Taylor was notified yesterday that Valentine F. Keller, chief clerk of the Finance Department, bad died suddenly in Wurzburg, Bavaria, early yesterday. His age was 62. Mr. Keller was a member of the Arion Choral Society, which was making a tour of Europe. He sailed from here on the liner Berlin on June 30.

A recent survey by the Brooklyn Better Housing Committee revealed that of 246,897 residential buildings in Brooklyn, 46,839 were from ten to nineteen years old, 40,695 from twenty to thirty-four years and 101,851 thirty-five years and over.

MANHATTAN CLEARY, MARGARET M. (July 3). Estate, less than $5,000. To Charles F. Getman, executor, 40 E. 54th St. COBLITZ, ROSA W. (July 26). Estate, more than $10,000. To Emil Coblitz, husband, 785 West End Ave., $2,000; Fannie Spandauer, Baltimore, Md., $1,000 and income from $4,000 trust; Harry Strauss, nephew, executor, Baltimore, $300 and one-third residue;

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity in the closing week of July regained a portion of its previous -sharp loss, advancing to 107.8 for the week ended July 31 from 107.1. For the corresponding week last year the number was 102.9.

Two stars of Dartmouth's 1937 football team, Fullback Johny Handrahan and Left Tackle Dave Camerer, have accepted invitations to play on Andy Kerr's Eastern All-Star team against the New York Football Giants Sept. 8.

IT was a rosy picture of automobile expansion which ' Alfred Reeves, vice president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, painted on his return from Europe last week. He found European manufacturers, like those on this side of the water, operating at a record pace; producing more cars although 40,000,000 motor vehicles are now-registered in 153 countries.

Four boys were born tonight to Mrs. A. M. Lingwood, 26 years old, Thetford, in Norfolk. They were born sixty-eight miles from St. Neots, Huntingdonshire, where the only British born "quads" to survive were born on Nov. 28, 1935.

PROVINCETOWN. ART on the two neighboring capes--Cape Cod and Cape Ann--seems to be in reasonably robust health this Summer. To speak of materialistic matters first, the market, one gathers, maintains its gradual improvement.

Home owners whose mortgages have been insured by the FHA have set new standards of promptness with installment payments in amortization of their debt, and the insured mortgage has become one of the most attractive forms of investment for financial institutions, George F. Byrnes, district director of the administration, told the delegates at a Brooklyn mortgage conference last week.

THE political life of any nation, if it is a free political life, seems to alternate between periods in which the citizens have to deal with constitutional questions--that is, with the very form of government itself-and periods in which they find themselves at liberty to deal merely with legislative problems, such as tariffs, currency and reforms or changes of one sort and another.
One hundred members of the Society of Stukely Wescott Descendants of America elected as their president today Joseph Rogers Wescott of Binghamton, N. Y.

From a Buffalo Y. M. C. A. physical director to America's No. 1 goat man is Don N. Allen's record in the last five years. He conducts a furniture business and has a herd of purebred Alpine goats at his home here.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Young of New York, who for the last three Summers have occupied Beechwood, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Astor, held the center of the social stage tonight.

The first blue marlin ever caught off the coast of Texas was brought in last night by R. J. Montgomery and proved the sensation of the fishing rodeo here, which already has taken the limelight in definitely establishing this as a sailfish area.

In these days of uncertainty along the shores of the Mediterranean, France is looking with increasing concern toward her "lifelines" of empire, which join North Africa with her southern coast. Half way along these "lifelines" are the Balearic Islands, where the Italians landed soon after the Spanish civil war started. An ideal base for air and sea attack against the AlgiersMarseilles line could easily be created there. For that reason France feels her safety threatened.

Following a unanimous vote by all parties in the Althing to take affairs of state wholly into its own hands in 1943, Iceland is now preparing for the new conditions that may arise if a final referendum of the people should support this decision.

Dr. Ferdinand Canning Scott Schiller, died yesterday at his home in suburban Palms at the age of 73. Funeral services were held today. Dr. Schiller, who was Professor of Philosophy at the University of Southern California and Corpus Christi College, Oxford, England, was an outstanding humanist philosopher.

Miss Alice Ruffin Mebane, descendant of the late Judge Thomas Ruffin, who was for many years Chief Justice of the North Carolina Supreme Court, was married to John McArthur Rianhard yesterday afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church, New Brighton, S. I. The ceremony was performed by the acting rector, the Rev. Hugh McCandless.

THE event of the week in the literary world has been a decease. and that not of an author but of a library. The news that Mudie's has closed its doors has been the subject of nearly as much editorial comment in the leading organs of

ANCOKER--Louis, Aug. 6. 1937, beloved husband of Anice Ives Ancker. Funeral services at the Campbell Funeral ChurCh, Broadway and 66th St., Monday, Aug. 9, 2 P. M. AXENZOFF--Aug. 7, Lena, beloved wife . of Max, devoted mother of Isaac, Sammie and Dora.

Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn, making his debut in the harness race field at the weekly matinee of the Putnam County and West Terrace Driving Clubs today, trailed in all three heats of the Class D trot and pace his bay gelding Earl Brooke broke twice in each heat.
WHY a large number of drivers disobey certain road signs and traffic signals, and what can be done to correct this, are questions receiving increased attention in many communities today.

THE part which radio plays in the development of public opinion will be the subject of discussion by broadcasting, religious and educational leaders during the 1937 Williamstown Institute of Human Relations at Williams College, Williamstown, Mass., from Aug. 29 to Sept. 3. Networks linked with WABC, WEAF and WJZ will carry significant parts of the proceedings to a nation-wide radio audience.

Soviet representatives here received word fom their polar camp today that it had drifted 138 miles from the Pole, apparently in the direction of Spitzbergen. Whether the earth's rotation had anything to do with the Arctic drift was undetermined.

MUCH of the material in this book is not particularly new, especially the material dealing with the danger of inflation through deficit financing. But apart from the fact that the authors bring the facts and figures up to date, they have contributed to the discussion of the nation's fisc two things which will help to resolve popular misapprehension and confusion.

Another audience of about 5,000 persons turned out for the second concert of the Berkshire Symphonic Festival at Tanglewood tonight. It would have been larger but for a rainstorm that broke three hours before concert time.

Nurses and internes in the emergency department of Rochester General Hospital were forced to take to rubber boots shortly before midnight tonight as heavy rainfall overloaded. sewers and backed water into the hospital basement.

During the absence of diplomats on vacations the problem of the painted fingernail has been injected into the columns of The Times of London to agitate the public mind. It all arose through George L. Massy,

BARRICK--THEILHEIMER--Aaron Barrick of Albany, to Lottie Thellheimer(nee Abrams), Brooklyn, Aug. 5. Albany papers please copy. FOX--HARTMAN--Mrs. Pauline Hartman, 325 East 57th St., happily announces the marriage of her daughter, Lillian, to Barnett S. Fox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Fox, Sunday, Aug. 1, at the Hotel Astor.

Fuel wood, next to lumber, reports the National Lumber Manufacturers Association, is making the biggest utility inroads on the forests. The consumption of wood as fuel, it is pointed out, has increased since 1929 and it is likely to persist.

MODERN France, since the romantic and symbolist movement has enriched her sensibility and sharpened her psychological acumen and since the Franco-Russian alliance in the Eighteen Nineties and the Russian immigration in

Miss Barbara Babcock is visiting Mrs. William T. Payne at The Anchorage, St. Andrew's-by-the-Sea, N. B. Mrs. G. Macculloch Miller of New York and Aiken, S. C., is expected to arrive today at the St. Regis.
Cleveland at New York-Whitehill vs. Pearson or Chandler. Chicago at Boston (2)-Marcum and McKain vs. Kennedy and Whitehead. St. Louis at Philadelphia (2)-- Bonetti and Hogsett vs. Ross and Kelley.
The army worm is "on the loose" in New Jersey, but there is no reason to fear the pest will devastate farming areas in the East as it ofen does in the Middle West.

Champion Vigow of Romanoff, attractive white and lemon borzoi owned and handled by Louis J. Murr of Spring Valley, N. Y., scored one of his most notable victories today as he captured the special for the best in show award at the twelfth annual Lackawanna Kennel Club fixture at the Skytop Club.
Younger members of the Summer colony here are preparing for the 1937 edition of "Bay Head Bubbles" which will be.presented Friday and Saturday nights at the Point Pleasant Borough Grammar School.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 6: Weishaar, Major H. T. J., Inf.-Q.M.C., relieved from assignment Quartermaster Corps, Presidio of San Francisco, Calif., to sail about Oct. 1 for Hawaiian Dep't. Seamon, Major W. W., Inf., orders from Columbus, Ohio, to Ft. Wayne, Mich, revonked.
The departure of the King and Queen and the two Princesses for Balmoral Castle to pass a long holiday brings Scotland into social prominence.

WHEN the late Geo Gershwin played at Lew isohn Stadium the nigh of Aug. 16, 1982, in one of the programs devoted to his own works, the event attracted an audio ence which, until Jascha Heifetz' appearancee last Tuesday night, set in Stadium record.
Despite their hatred of war, few Americans can view the situation in the Far East without desiring that China find the strength to repel-by force if necessary-the unwarranted advances of Japan.
The good news from here is that Mathilde Doehner and her two sons, Werner, 8 years old, and Walter, 10, have quit Boro's Beach Hospital and have boarded a train today for their home in Mexico City.

WASHINGTON. KARL CROWLEY, solicitor for the Postoffice Department, and his legal colleagues are puzzling over a plan submitted to them last week by W. A. Patterson, president of United Air Lines, and Alvin B. Adams, president of Western Air Express.

The fifteenth annual three-day rural and industrial conference of St. Francis Xavier University will be held here Wednesday through Friday at the institution. The Rev. D. J. MacDonald, president of the university, will preside at the opening session Wednesday afternoon.

Edmund Lester Pearson, widely known as a writer on criminology, died at 1:30 o'clock this morning at the Harkness Pavilion, at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, Broadway and 168th Street. Mr. Pearson, who was 57 years old, had been ill for some time. He had been at the hospital since the middle of June.

Almost all the important foreign currencies advanced against the dollar in the foreign exchange market. The pound sterling rose to T $4.99 3/8, the highest price since last Sept. 25, and closed at $4.995-16, up 13-16 cent net. Compared with B a week ago the British exchange was up 1 1/2 cents.

Apparel manufacturers are being divided into two groups, one to supply chains and other "mass merchandisers," and another to supply independent retailers, by reason of the reaction to recent price actions in the garment field, Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., and acting chairman of the Popular Priced Coat and Suit Stabilization Committee, said yesterday.
A thorough investigation of the charge by John P. Knapp, financial writer, that he was beaten by a patrolman who falsely accused him of robbery, was ordered yesterday by Commissioner Valentine.

Replying to proposals made by the newly created Bureau for the Construction of Workers' Dwellings, the principal Chilean industries said today they could not obligate themselves to cooperate in the vast program designed to give adequate housing to the majority of the workers.
The thirteen - story apartment building on a plot 150 by 100.8 feet at 1,145 Fifth Avenue, corner of Ninety-sixth Street, will be sold at auction tomorrow in the Vesey Street salesrooms.

THE passion for correct speech is more marked in America than in any other nation, according to Dr. W. Cabell Greet, editor of American Speech Quarterly and Columbia University linguistic expert, who recently joined the staff of the Columbia Broadcasting System as consultant on speech.
Relentlessly the cost of living for the families of the wage-earners of the United States is climbing toward the average for the years 1928-25 upon which statisticians base their indices.
Informed officials said today that President Roosevelt might select two new members of the Federal Communications Commission with an eye to patching up internal diffrences in the agency.

Twenty-one historical paintings of the men and women whose efforts made possible the colonization of Virginia, which have been bequeathed to the University of Virginia by Thomas Fortune Ryan, have been hung in the University Museum of Fine Arts, where they may be seen by the public for the first time in thirty years.

President Roosevelt arrived here today to spend a quiet week-end at his mother's house. Except for the White House staff which set up to temporary offices at Poughkeepsie in charge of Marvin H.McIntyre, one of the President's three secretries, he came here alone. Mrs.

The trawler Foam reported to Coast Guard headquarters tonight that she had sighted the four-masted schooner Herbert L. Rawding, two weeks overdue in New York, 120 miles east of Provincetown, her crew "without food or water for a week."

Outstanding women golfers in the Empire State will. travel to Syracuse this week to compete in the annual New York State women's championship tourney which will be contested on the Onondaga Country Club course.

LONDON. WITHOUT waiting for the Government to complete its [pound]100,000,000 road repair program, British motorists are calling on it to take heroic measures and give the United Kingdom four and six lane highways of the type that have been so successful in. the United States, Germany and Italy.
NO more than two decades ago the bells of 50,000 camels used to sound each year through the cobbled streets of Erzerum,

Rector, 7-year-old brown gelding, standing over 16.2 hands, was the hunter of the day at the annual equine exhibition of the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club, which brought society and show enthusiasts from this end of the island to the picturesque grounds outside the town.
The first suicide from recently opened Golden Gate.Bridge was reported to State police today by Dr. Lewis Hastings Naylor, Professor of Languages at Trinity College, Hartford, Conn.

Accused of having forged fifty checks totaling more than $25,000, an accountant who described himself as Robert Gray, 55 years old, or 243 Riverside Drive, was held in $10,000 bail yesterday by Magistrate Harry G. Andrews in the Felony Court.
A House subcommittee on postoffices has reported to the full committee three bills by Representative Barry of New York City to reduce postage rates.

THE Asbury Park tournament, largest contract bridge event of the year, is still in progress, with the principal team and pair contests yet to be settled. While no new attendance record was established, except in the masters' pair event, this Summer's renewal kept pace with the previous successful Asbury Park tournaments.
In these days it is not easy to recapture the mood of the Psalmist when he wrote that "the heavens declare the glory of God; and the firmament showeth His handiwork."

CHARLOTTE CARR now moves on from the Emergency Relief Bureau in New York to Hull House in Chicago, where a different set of problems awaits her. More than two years have elapsed since the death of Jane Addams, founder of Hull House, but the directors of that famous social settlement--one of the oldest in the United States--did not hurry themselves to choose a successor.

Herring gull colonies in the Bay of Fundy are on the decline. Kents Island, with one of the largest colonies in North America, has less than two-thirds as many young birds as last Year. On other islands in the same region eggers reported collecting small fractions of former harvests.

Lieut. Comdr. James Chapman, supply corps, United States Navy, died yesterday at the Naval Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 46 years old. Widely known in naval circles, he had been disbursing officer of the Brooklyn Navy Yard from 1933 until last year when, on routine orders, he was assigned to the U. S. S. Nitro.

Miss Jessie Lucille Griffin, daughter of Mrs. Gerald Griffin of this city and the late Dr. Griffin, was married here this morning in the Church of St. Vincent de Paul to Dr. Hugh Francis Leahy, a prominent physician, son of Mr. and Mrs. High F. Leahy, also of Albany. The Rev. William R. Charles performed the ceremony.

Following a steady and quiet opening, stocks showed yesterday marked improvement over Friday's prices, particularly among coppers, steels and motors. Trading was light, reflecting the week-end exodus, transactions amounting to 314,863 shares, compared with 389,590 shares on the previous Saturday.
Brazil reported for July the destruction of 2,197,000 bags of coffee, almost three times the amount it exported in that month, the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchanige disclosed yesterday.

Members of the Military Order o? the Purple Heart met in the Constitution Room of Independence Hall today and later placed a wreath on the statue of George Washington, who founded the or ganization 155 years ago.

Movements involving 5,500 New York State National Guardsmen will take place tonight and tomorrow as the various units, which inelude 2,500 infantrymen from the metropolitan area, move out of the State cantonments, Camp Smith and Pine Camp, to make way for incoming units.

Shrewsbury and the Burnt Mills Ramblers were drawn today to meet in the first game of. the Northeastern intracircuit polo tour nament, a handicap event open to teams with ratings of twelve goals or less.

THIS book is revealing of the penetrative power of the Irishman Ever since the Irish policy of Elizabeth made him an emigrant and a wanderer, he has invaded, and brightened, the life of the English-speaking world, not only in England and the United States but also in Canada, Australia and the rest of the British Empire.

While Washington grows wearier day by day coping with such perplexing problems as tax avoidance and crop control, not to mention tropical temperatures and overdue vacations, the sponsors of another piece of legislation have hurried to the fore, urging that it be marked "must."
REPORTS on retail trade from most sections of the country last week more or less agreed that it was dull and "not up to expectations."
Major and Mrs. J. B. Thompson of Washington and their daughter, Miss Jacqueline Cameron Thompson, are guests at the home here of Mrs. Thompson's parents, General and Mrs. George H. Cameron.
The A. A. U. board of governors has decided to hold its 1937 meeting at the Copley Plaza Hotel in Boston, Nov. 13-15.

The Buooklyn Bureau of Charities issued the following statement yesterday on the death of Mr. James: "The bureau -suffers a great loss in the passing of Mr. James. Under his presidency the society grew in public confidence and in service to the people of Brooklyn.

The Bees, after-Bill Lee was forced from the Chicago mound with a side injury in the sixth, fell on three relief hurlers for all their runs in the same inning today to defeat the league-leading Cubs, 8 to 6, before 9,465 spectators. The defeat reduced the Bruin's margin over the idle Giants to five games.

IF it isn't already in his strong box Robinson Smith should awake any morning now to find a contract for A. A. Milne's latest play, "Gentleman Unknown," reposing there. For, just a few days ago, the papers which would give Mr. Smith the production rights to the play were all drawn up and in order, just waiting to be signed.

IT may have been the shining success that Shakespeare enjoyed on Broadway last season, the clamorous crowds that cheered John Gielgud's Hamlet and Maurice Evans as Richard II, that inspired the broadcasters to turn their attention to the Bard's works in a serious way.

The Senate Finance Committee heard a few witnesses today on the Jones Sugar Quota Bill, passed yesterday by the House, and Chairman Harrison said that the committee would complete its hearings on the measure Monday in order to join the drive for quick adjournment.

With nearly 2,000 pieces of mail stamped with a special twentyfifth anniversary mark aboard, a modern plane of the.Eastern Airlines retraced today the route between here and Stone Harbor over which the first New Jersey air mail was carried in 1912.

Paced by Lou Gehrig's twentyseventh home run of the season, the Yankees yesterday scored their seventh consecutive victory, beating the Indians, 6 to 3, for the second time in a row before 15,442 sweltering fans at the Stadium.

New Zealand's Socialist New Deal suffered a heavy blow when by a 3-to-1 decision the Appellate Court this week toppled the elaborate organization on which the wage-fixing and hours-limitation policy is based.
A museum of the Order of the Cincinnati, the fraternalorganization founded by George Washington and the French and American officers of the Revolutionary War, has been opened in Versailles.

MORNING EVENTS Class 16, Lightweight Hunters-First, Rolling Rock Farms' br. g. Gone Away; sec ond, Rolling Rock Farms' gr. g. Night Flight;- third, Mrs. M. Robert Guggenheim's b. m. Firenze Brumanna: fourth, Mr. arid Mrs. Alvin Untermyer's br. g. Hexameter. Class 2 Limit- Bridle Trail Hacks Over 14.2-First, Miss Theresa Schey's br. g. Prince Carmen: second, Miss Theresa Schey's ch. g. Celebrity; third,. Joseph B. Murray's.ch,-m. -Erica; fourth, Miss Virginia King Petree's b. g. Major.

Displaying the form that has made him the champion of the handicap brigade this season, Mrs. C. S. Howard's Seabiscuit won the $70,530 Massachusetts Handicap today in an international field in the nation's richest Summer race.

Mrs. William H. Carpenter and Mrs. Philip G. Cole will give a luncheon on Wednesday at the Lake Placid Club for Mr. and Mrs. Edward King, who are expected to arrive on Tuesday. Mr. King is to manage the three-day horse show, which will open here Thursday.

The Spanish Government today authorized resumption of religious services throughout Loyalist Spain but stipulated that for the present they must be held "in private." Minister of Justice Manuel Irujo, who obtained Cabinet approval for the step, said he was empowered to issue licenses permitting priests and nuns to exercise their profession.
Mrs. Harrington Mills of Washington and New York has sent out invitations to one hundred at the camps and the inn for a bridge tea to be given Wednesday in Saranac Inn Casino.

It was a pity that because of the unsettled weather a larger audience did not attend the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Willem van Hoogstraten at Lewisohn Stadium last night. For the event proved one of the most thoroughly enjoyable of the entire series offered this season.

THE first "European Chamber Music Festival Weeks" will be inaugurated in Trentschin-Teplitz, Hungary, this Saturday. The programs will consist of duos, trios and quartets by important ensemble organizations of the Continent.

Arthur Louis Lee Jr., manager of the Hotel Bancroft, at 40 West Seventy-second Street, and descendant of an old Colonial family, died of a streptococcus infection on Friday at his apartment at the hotel. He was 31 years old.

The Garden Pier, historic structure which extends into the ocean at the foot of New Jersey Avenue, will go under the anctioneer's hammer on Aug. 19. Louis and Alfred Burk, Philadelphia meat packers, built the pier in 1912 at a cost of $1,500,000.

Charles George, organizer of the Marine Workers and Shipbuilders Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, charged yesterday that the police were escorting and protecting organizers of the rival International Long-shoremen's Association,

The Utilities Power and Light Corporation has tentatively set Sept. 10 as the date for a special stockholders' meeting to consider the revision of its capital in accordance with the plan of recapitalization presented by the Atlas Corporation.
Counsel for the National Electric Products Company tonight charged "the National Labor Relations Board apparently is nothing more nor less than an agent for the C. I. O."

The Japanese exodus, marked by the abandonment of the concession at Hankow, has now spread to South China. Many of the nationals are coming in from Yunnan province in the far Southwest. They are also leaving the Canton district.

NEWPORT, R. I.--The flower show, an annual three-day midsummer fixture, is expected to be one of the interesting events of the week here. Staged at the Casino under the auspices of the Newport Horticultural Society in cooperation with the Newport Garden Club and the Federated Garden Clubs of Rhode Island, the show promises to be one of the best held at the Casino in a number of years.

Believing that good business sense dictates a reversal of the trend to extension of installment sales terms started in 1935, the Commercial Investment Trust, Inc., has launched an educational campaign to curb the granting of excessively long terms, Arthur O. Dietz, president of the company, revealed here yesterday.

Two pitchers from the Gainesville, (Fla.) State League, team were added to the Pirates' roster today. They are Elbert Padgett, a righthander and Andy Sierra, a southpaw, who will train with the Buccaneers next Spring.

Leon GrosJean, superintendent of the Glen Works of the International Salt Company, is one of the most unusual of collectors. He speoializes in packages of salt from all over the world. His collection is believed to be the only one of its kind anywhere.

The marriage of Miss Ann Bellows, daughter of Mrs. Emma S. Bellows of New York and the late George Bellows, artist and lithographer, to Maynard Skinner Kearney, son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Kearney of Spuyten Duyvil, took place here this afternoon at the country home of her mother.

Whatever fate may be awaiting Tommy Farr In his battle with Joe Louis for the heavyweight title at the Yankee Stadium Aug. 26, he at least goes toward it with the official approval and good wishes of the New York State Athletic Commission.
The first Fall accessories, just beginning to appear in the shops, portend an entirely new feeling in the accents of a woman's costume.

UNCONVENTIONAL: Rules of dress are rigid at the Royal Yacht Squadron in Cowes, England. Last week rules were shattered when the Viscountess Hinchingbrooke appeared on the club lawn wearing blue linen trousers. Among the startled spectators was Princess Beatrice, daughter of Queen Victoria. The club quickly took action to prevent a repetition of such an incident.

Inaction sometimes speaks louder than words. Japanese spokesmen, military and civilian, still threaten a campaign to bring Nanking to terms by force; yet the army which would have to be dispatched for such a task remains at home. Chinese spokesmen still speak of a fight to the death to prevent the alienation of North China, yet Nanking's armies still remain at a respectful distance from the Japanese forces of occupation.

Detectives considered the possibilities today that Doris Major, 27-year-old hotel cigarette girl, missing for a week, might be a victim of amnesia or had decided to go away for a rest as she had done before.

Mrs. Samuel Schiffer's Kilkare Farm entry from Elberon, .N. J., Centre Colonel, a handsome brown gelding, captured first honors in the fine-gaited saddle horse class at the fourth annual Sagamore show today.
A "shipwreck party" will be held at the Atlantic Beach Club here on Wednesday night as the second in the series of invitation dinner dances for younger members of society.
Mr. and Mrs. Homer Saint-Gaudens have announced from Cornish, N. H., the engagement of Mr. Saint-Gaudens's daughter, Miss Carlota Saint-Gaudens, to John E. Dodge of Stonington, Conn.

The Senators rallied in the late innings today to defeat Detroit, 8 to 7, in the second game of a double-header, after losing the opener, 3 to 2. As a result of the even break the Tigers gained third place.
Walter D. Edmonds revealed today that Adam Helmer, the Revolutionary scout who figures in his historical novel, "Drums Along the Mohawk," is really a combination of two characters.

The marriage of Miss Gladys Candler Hinckley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Leonard Hinckley, to Arnold Porter, son of Dr. Emery M. Porter and Mrs. Mary B. Porter, took place here this afternoon in St. Peter's-by-the-Sea. Dean Philemon F. Sturges of Boston performed the ceremony.

ONE thing every woman knows is that she wants "another dress" to give her that back-in-town feeling the moment she returns to the sidewalks of New York or her own home town, whatever it may be. She will be exhilarated when she inspects the Autumn offerings.

General business inventories are now held at fair prices and in good proportion. Accounts receivable are "clean." While there has been a some slowing up of collections, it i not of great significance. Liquidity is satisfactory, and credits extended are in line.
Three gunmen, who disabled a police cruiser car with shots' and held two officers at bay with guns and sped away in a fast coup, eluded a police net tonight.

Fifty-two Summer students at Columbia University have been elected to head the State and regional clubs which form the backbone of the institution's inter-session extra-curricular program. Every State in the Union and thirty-five foreign countries, as well as Puerto Rico, the Hawaiian Islands and the Canal Zone, are represented in the 1937 membership of these organizations, founded twenty-seven years ago.

Charles S. Lochridge of New York and S. Garton Churchill of Great Neck, L. I., staged a brilliant finish today to come from behind and win the masters' pair championship of the American Bridge League at its annual Summer tournament here.

IN "Salvage," a vigorous and exciting sea story, Roger Vercel last year revealed himself as a master of physical action and melodramatic situation In this new novel, although the wild frontier of Macedonia is substituted for the sea, the same qualities stand out.

THERE was a time, years and years ago, when an Englishman could ask: "Who reads an American book"? and echo would not have a word to say. But it is different now. according to V. F. Calverton, who has been in England for some time gathering material for his new book on nationalism. which will probably be called "The Great Madness." Mr. Calverton writes to his publishers,
Miss Dorothy Marshall

The district qualifying rounds for the Metropolitan Handicap Golf Championship will be played on Wednesday, it has been announced. For Westchester and Fairfield the site will' be the Quaker Ridge Club, in Mamaroneck,

Vacationland is calling to Tne dog show folk and during the next fortnight and more the schedule of exhibitions presents unusual opportunities for delightful excursions into New England.
