Moreover, each event will be staged in widely diversified environment, presenting a succession of attractions in coastal and inland scenery.

New York City, with its slums, reclaimed Knickerbocker Village, modern sanitation system, antinoise campaign, parks and playgrounds, subways, tunnels and factories, is being used this Summer as a combination textbook and giant laboratory by 250 girls and boys from approximately twenty States.

Sales at special market events in leading cities in the last two weeks have shown gains ranging from moderate figures on some types of merchandise to sharp increases on others, and there was a general tendency on the part of retail buyers to anticipate heavy Fall volume by reason of bumper farm crops and in some areas easing of labor disturbances.

Matt I. Sullivan, former Chief Justice of the California Supreme Court and law partner of United States Senator- Hiram W. Johnson, died last night after an illness of three months. He was 79 years old.

Mrs. Lydia Regan, mother of Donald Horst, 2 1/2 years old, signed papers today consenting to his adoption by his foster parents, Mr. and Mrs. Otto Horst, from whom she and the boy's father, John Regan, took him on Tuesday.
Arthur de Souza Costa, Brazilian Finance Minister, arrived here today from the United States and said Brazilian-American relations were more solidly cemented than ever.

Making motion pictures of gardens in color is the latest development of amateur photography. When bleak Winter comes, gardeners will in consequence have a lively record of plants and blooms in natural hues, swaying in the breezes of balmier days. Such transcripts are projected on the screen for entertainment or instruction.
THE Normandie, France's sleek greyhound of the seas, made maritime history last week by being the first passenger ship to complete an eastwest passage of the Atlantic in less than four days.
Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Barret of New York entertained with the largest party of the evening -at the Bar Harbor Club weekly dinner dance which was held there this evening.

To the Music Editor: In "A Glance at Native Scores," the article of Olin Downes in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 25, there is offered another of the ever-recurring wish-pictures of the great American music that continue to plague and weigh down the souls of American musicians and critics.

Professor Glenn M. Blair, University of Washington psychologist, today credited chubby 5-year-old Barbara Sherley, daughter of a textbook salesman, with an intelligence quotient of 170, or 30 points higher than the minimum rating for a genius.

Gladioli hereabouts are now at the height of their bloom. Growers' fields are a blaze of color, the "glad" patch in the cutting garden daily gives its quota of beautiful spikes of unfolding buds, and florists' windows are filled with brilliant blossoms, available at the year's lowest prices.

Building boards made from sugarcane proved stronger than wood in tests recently completed by the Department of Civil Engineering In Columbia University. The material is being used as a substitute for wood' in frame construction.

The weather man and engineering science are doing strange things to long-distance flight: commercial flying boats no longer follow "routes," pilots sometimes prefer headwinds to no winds at all, and the best course across an ocean more often than not is considerably farther than the shortest route.
THERE are not so many shudders in Georgette Heyher's murder mysteries as there are in those of some other writers, but there is a lot more fun.

MANY books that attempt to interpret science to the layman suffer from over-dramatization. They abound in metaphors and poetic images, leaving the reader with a vivid impression that something marvelous has been accomplished, but often with little precise understanding of what the accomplishment is.

Justice Josiah Alexander Van Orsdel, Associate Justice of the United Itates Court of Appeals at Washington, died today at the age of 76. He was a former Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of Wyoming and a former AssistantAttorney General of the United States. Mrs. Van Orsdel was at the bedside at his death. He became ill three weeks ago.

The prehistoric hunter who trailed the mammoth and smaller game on the North American continent 10,000 or 15,000 years ago carefully chose his weapons to fit his quarry, according to evidence reported today by the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia.
APPEARING on the nees George Preeby's biogra phy of Mary Wollstonecraft this little group of four letters, with the careful notes and explanations of the editors, is of special interest.

Legislation for Government insurance of wheat crops, already passed by the Senate and endorsed by President Roosevelt, won approval today of the House Agriculture Committee. Chairman Jones said that the vote was "by no means unanimous."

FOR a book dealing with the hardships and horrors of the Spanish civil war. "Single to Spain" has a measure of sprightliness that is surprising. It is the spirit of Tommy Atkins come to life again in circumstances and surroundings different from those of the great war.

On their way to Ottawa to compete in the Dominion of Canada Rifle Association meet at the Connaught rifle ranges, members of the Australian Bisley team arrived today aboard the liner Duchess of York. In charge of A.
Lemuel Ladd of Boston won the "race around the .houses" today, leading a field of eleven amateur automobile pilots in Alexandria Bay's unique street speed classic.
PRSIDENT ROOSEVEELTS recently published letter to President Ataturk of Turkey drew the attention of stamp collectors to the attractiveness of many Turkish issues. Mr. Roosed velt said in part:
President Roosevelt said recently that the "sugar lobby" active in Washington was the most powerful pressure group that had descended on the national capital during his lifetime.

About 700 New Jersey boys and girls have qualified to take the examination for scholarships at RutNew Jersey Legislature at its last gers University and New Jersey College for Women, for which $50,000 was appropriated by the session. This was announced today by Dr. Fraser Metzger, dean of men at Rutgers and chairman of the scholarship committee.

PARIS. MUSIC by D. Milhaud contributes interesting background for another of the "Fetes de la Lumiere" in Paris, thus enlarging the repertory of outdoor "operas" conceived and brought to successful realization by the architects Baudoin and Lods for the Paris Exposition.

Walter Greenwood, 39 years old, a house painter of First Street, Mamaroneck, was killed early today when he stepped from a friend's parked automobile and was struck by another car on Barry Avenue near his home.
With Japanese and Chinese troops clashing in China, there has been some demand that President Roosevelt declare Japan and China at war and thereby bring the 1937 Neutrality Act into play.

Legal tangles anticipated by women opposing passage of the Equal Rights Amendment, in the event of its ultimate adoption by Congress, involve loss of various rights they now enjoy, according to Miss Dorothy Straus, New York attorney.

SPONSORED by the Saratoga Springs Authority a music festival will be held Sept. 5 to 18 at Saratoga Springs, N. Y. The eight festival programs will be given by a string orchestra of twenty-four members of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, under F. Charles Adler, assisted by numerous soloists.
Treasure Hall, veteran trotter owned by Anthony Provenzano of New York City, took the Class A event, the feature of today's harness racing program at Weequahic Park.
During the annual convention in Pittsburgh from Oct. 18 to 23 of the National Association of Real Estate Boards the following meetings of its various divisions will be held:

It's cotton pickin' time in Texas and the man who shuns the back-breaking labor is liable to a term in jail. With a crop of 150,000 bales, or only 10,000 less than the State's 1926 record, forecast, the Rio Grande Valley desperately needs pickers--at 60 cents to $1 per hundred pounds. Similar calls for labor are heard elsewhere.

Several hundred members of the Summer colony and their tennisweek guests attended the annual ball held tonight in the Colonial ballroom and the Japanese Room of the Meadow Club to mark the close of the club's invitation tennis tournament. The visiting tennis stars were guests of honor.

The Rev. and Mrs. Barton Lee Hoffman of Birmingham and Fairhope, Ala., have announced the engagemelt 'of their daughter, Miss Virginia Dell Hoffman, to James Bartlett Gregg of Waterbury, Conn., eldest son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. James E. Gregg of hat city.

A little romance of industry is contained in a four-line item buried in a column of unheadlined notes on the back page of Za Industrializatsiu today. It simply records the appointment of Jacob Yussim to be managing director of the Kaganovitch ball-bearing plant here--one of the Soviet
ROCKWELL KENT'S letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Sunday, saying that the Bureau of Engraving and Printing "has degraded postage stamp design" to a low

Running one of her greatest races, Tom Taggart's 4-year-old filly Marica scored a three-length victory in the tenth running of the Crete Handicap at Lincoln Fields today before nearly 20,000, the biggest crowd in several years. Coming from behind the dizzy pace set by Bien Fait, Marica equaled the track record, running six furlongs in 1:10 2-5.
Among new members of the St. Regis Yacht Club, admitted at the annual meeting held at the Birch Island camp of Commodore William S. Spaulding of Boston at Upper St.

The exchange of letters between Prime Minister Chamberlain of Great Britain and Premier Mussolini, which put ItaloBritish relations on an entirely new footing, came as complete surprise to almost every one both in Italy and abroad, but in reality it crowned a period of most intense diplomatic activity on the part of the two Foreign Offices.

Ohio has unofficially challenged Iowa's claim to being the State where the tallest corn grows. With a stalk 17.3 feet tall strapped to a board in the State Capitol, State Treasurer Clarence H. Knisely said he would write a letter to Governor Kraschel of Iowa, laying claim to the title.

The marriage of Miss Anne Rigney, daughter of Peter R. Rigney of Riverdale and the late Mrs. Rigney, to Eugene R. Sullivan of Yonkers, son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Sullivan of Norwich, Conn., took place yesterday morning in St. Margaret's Church, Riverdale.

The feats of a 63-year-old automobile racer turned speed-boat pilot and a bad spill of the boat owned by a Metropolitan Opera star thrilled thousands of spectators today as the sixteenth annual Miles River regatta ended.

After winning twice by wide margins earlier in the week, the San Jose polo quartet of Argentina today nad to be content with a 7-all tie in its third practice match in preparation for the national open championship tourney to be contested here next month.
As the United States goes more deeply into experiments in social legislation the experiences of other countries which have traveled the same road ahead of us begin to receive closer attention here.

Accused of possessing twenty counterfeit $10 bills, Amedeo Straface, 41 years old, a laborer of 18 Fort Greene Place, Brooklyn, was arraigned yesterday before United States Commissioner Martin C. Epstein and held in $2,500 bail for further hearing on July 17.

Secretary Hull asked Congress today to bolster the national defense of other American republics by leasing. to them warships which the navy no longer uses. He said he was acting at President Roosevelt's request.

Governor Horner has no hesitancy in acknowledging he was opposed to the President's Supreme Court bill, but he smiles wisely and' says nothing when asked whether he considers the threat of the Social Security Board to cut off Federal funds for old-age pensions in Illinois a measure of political reprisal. Many of his friends so regard what seems to them an invidious treatment of this State.

Miss Eleanor Talcott, daughter of Mr. ta and Mrs. Charles D. Talcott of Talcottville, was married here this afternoon to Vladimir Ivanovitch Orloff of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Orloff of Helsingfors, Finland, in the Galilee Chapel, which adjoins the Summer place of her parents on Eastern Point.

The corporation of certificate holders which recently took title to the apartment house accommodating thirty-two families at 1,322-30 St. Marks PI., Brooklyn, in Schackno proceedings, has sold the property to the St. Marks Realty Corporation,

Debits to individual accounts as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Aug. 4 aggregated $8,933,000,000, or 7 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week, and 5 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.
Mrs. Elizabeth A. Cuskley, who has owned the "old-law" tenement at 203 East Sixty-second Street for about fifty years, is altering it to provide modern suites.

Since the Robinson-Patman act "combines breadth of application with minuteness of control and vagueness of implication," its ambiguities should be cleared up rapidly and intelligently by the courts, according to Burton A. Zorn and George J. Feldman, in a new book, "Business Under the New Price Laws," to be published on Tuesday by Prentice-Hall, Inc. Saul Nelson was collaborating economist. The price of the book is $5.

An impetus to moves to reorganize railroads in receivership or bankruptcy is foreseen in Wall Street as a result of the Interstate Commerce Commission's entry into the Western Pacific Railroad situation by announcing a plan of recapitalization for the line.

Rogers Hornsby had a batting average of .313 in The Denver Post baseball tournament. Playing first base for the Denver Refiners, who were erased from the tourney by their second defeat today, Hornsby was in four games altogether.
Superintendent T. O. Sleyton of the State prison camp here said tonight that a prisoner had confessed to the slaying of Florence Barton in Kansas City in 1920.

Governor Elmer A. Benson of Minnesota led 10,000 anti-Fascist demonstrators in a parade yesterday afternoon through Yorkville to Harlem, under the sponsorship of the American League Against War and Fascism.

Skippers of motor cruisers and especially those who have completed the United States Power Squadrons' courses of instruction and pride themselves on their ability as deep sea navigators, are beginning to take sides in a controversy over in New Jersey and Staten Island.

Savings, building and loan associations placed in June mortgage loans totalling $126,095,800, the largest volume in any month since recovery set in, according to the United States Building and Loan League.

Eddie Gerard, who played on four Stanley Cup teams in the National Hockey League, died early today. He was 47 years old. Once a great defense man and pilot of a' championship team when his playing days were ended, he succumbed to a throat ailment.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am one of the great majority of business men who are deeply concerned at the recent action of Congress in attaching the Miller-Tydings price-maintenance rider to the District of Columbia tax measure. If this rider is enacted into law it will mean price-fixing, pure and simple. It that event, woe betide the poor consumer!

OSHEN, N. Y.--From Monday through Friday this quiet seat of Orange County will play host to many thousands of visitors from the metropolitan area and the Catskill resorts when followers of harness racing gather at Good Time Park to witness the annual August grand circuit meeting, and to view the contest for the world's richest harness stake for 3-year-olds, the Hambletonian, on Wednesday.

THE TRIAL OF DR. BECK-Opening tomorrow evening atMaxine Elliott's Theatre. The Federal Theatre Project is sponsoring this court-room melodrama from the pen of a Negro playwright, Hughes Allison. It already has been seen in Union City and Newark. Its visit here is announced for only two weeks. In the cast will be Frank Harrington, Earl Sydnor and Clifford Dempsey.

A sum aggregating $8,827,000 has been paid to the United States Government in dividends on its investments in savings, building and loan associations, reports the Federal Home Loan Bank board following receipt of a preliminary report of dividends from those associations for the first half of 1937.

The predictions made in this column last week in respect to changes which would be sought by the Joint Congressional Committee on Tax Avoidance in the surtax law as affecting personal holding companies, predicated on evidence submitted at the inquiry, proved to be correct.

The yawl Elizabeth McCaw, owned by Richard J. Reynolds of WinstonSalem, N. C., and the only American entry in the 600-mile Fastnet Rock yacht race, was disqualified today when she failed to answer the recall signal after starting a few seconds too soon.

Building costs at the present time, despite the rise in some materials, are not excessive, according to The American Builder which declares that all building products have not advanced alike, and the average home on sale today actually costs less than those on sale in 1926 or 1929.

Miss Jean McKinley Strait, daughter of Ernest C Strait of this place and the late Mrs. J. McKinley Strait, has chosen Oct. 23 for her marriage to Chester T. Birch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Birch of New York. The prospective bride attended Smith College and Northwestern University.

ON the banks of the narrow and winding River Rouge close by Detroit is being enacted a gripping industrial drama--the attempt of the Committee for Industrial Organization to unionize the Ford industrial empire. The leading characters are Henry Ford (called Henry the V-Eighth by unionists) and C. I. O. Generalissimo John L. Lewis.

The real estate auction business headed by Major William Kennelly celebrates this month the ninetieth anniversary of its founding. Its beinnings are traced to August, 1847, when William Kennelly, grandfather of the present head of the concern, with Thomas Addis Emmet opened an office in Pine Street under the firm name of Kennelly Emmet.

Darwin Rush-James, New York banker and president of the Bureau of Charities of Brooklyn, died at the Summer home of a friend, Charles F. Kingsley, at Roanoke, near here, today. Mr. James, who had been Ill for two weeks, was 64 years old.

Fred Sitler, a 36-year-old giant, died tonight at Hahnemann Hospital, where he had undergone two operations in an effort to end hi abnormal growth. A blood-clot followed the first operation and doctors performed another last night in an attempt to save his life.
David Polland of Brooklyn was assured of the New York State chess championship tonight when he defeated B. Garfinkel of Buffalo. This triumph gave Polland a score of 7 1/2--1/2.

Events of the week brought acutely to the forefront the importance of the vacancy which has existed on the Supreme Court bench since June 2. These events chiefly concerned whether President Roosevelt would immediately fill the vacancy, and thus hazard confirmation by the Senate, or whether he would make a recess appointment.

The Federal Housing Administration points out that universities, churches, hospitals, other incorporated institutions and certain building companies are eligible borrowers under the rules of the FHA and may obtain insured mortgages.
Charles S. Hosford Jr., chairman of the Bituminous Coal Commission, declared today that an attempt was being made "to hinder" the administration of the Coal Control Act.

IT was at the beginning of this year that Musicraft announced its existence and issued a first release. The customary declaration of intentions which seems to be expected on such occasions was as simple as the sponsors' aims appeared to be.

JUNEAU, Alaska. ALASKA calls in varied moods this Summer to the adventurous traveler. From the time one shakes hands with Ketchikan, the first Alaska port, just forty-eight hours off Seattle and thirty-six hours from Vancouver, one steps into a new world.

With the general upward trend of all commodities, rising rentals are inevitable, points out Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York. He also holds that recovery of the construction industry will be retarded until rents have risen to a point which will make it worth while for builders to undertake new work.

Jersey City and Montreal divided a double-header today, the Royals winning the first, 7 to 2, and the Jerseys the second by 3 to 2 when Johnny Meketi doubled to drive Jackie Redmond home from first base with the winning run.

A further slight decline occurred in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the list ended with net losses of 3 to 13 points. While spot interests put out hedges against purchases of the new crop, houses with trade and speculative connections took contracts from the market.

Leaders of the Salvation Army from eleven Eastern States opened a three-day religious program in the Ocean Grove auditorium tonight with a music festival by the territorial staff band. Commissioner Alexander M. Damon, commander of the Eastern territory, will deliver the main address tomorrow. More than 200 members attended a reception for officers this afternoon. The sessions will continue tomorrow and Monday.

Camp McMahon, operated by the works Progress Administration since 1935, has been taken over for operation by the camp directors, sponsored by the Hunterdon County board of Freeholders. The camp, used as a home for transient workmen employed on dirt-road projects, reverted from WPA to private management this week when the Federal Government discontinued reponsibility for living expenses for the men.

A proposed city ordinance, which would permit. the use of canopies at all times, regardless of the weather, at the main entrances of apartment houses, churches, hospitalks, schools and funeral parlors is being sponsored by three civic organizations.

Strong efforts were in progress yesterday to draft Thomas E. Dewey, who has won a nation-wide reputation in his successful prosecution of rackets, for the Fusion nomination for District Attorney of New York County.

Discussion of the well-organized Japanese and the ardent Chinese air forces, which may have active roles in the event of development of hostilities in Northern China, is contained in the following articles.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 5: COMMANDERS Hogg, W. S.. 9th Naval District, to instruction at the Army War College, Fort Humphreys, D. C. Petzold. M. ., uncompleted portion orders May 29 revoked; to the West Virginia.
Benny Kaufman, dirt-track motorcycle racing star, will return to competition tomorrow night at Bay Ridge Stadium in Brooklyn.

Two hundred tons of dynamite today blew up the ruins of the Third Infantry Regiment barracks, which is the scene of a bloody battle in the 1935 uprising. Several hundred bodies are buried under its fallen walls.

Philip Dix Becker of New York and Brunswick, Ga., married here this afternoon Miss Mildred Virginia Peacock of Charleston. Mr. Becker is a son of Alfred Leroy Becker, New York lawyer. The wedding took place in St. Andrew's Lutheran Church with the Rev. Decmon A. Sox officiating, assisted by the Rev. Clarence K. Derrick, pastor.

The United States Lines announced yesterday the transfer of Captain George V. Richardson from command of the Panama Pacifio liner Virginia to the United States liner President Harding and the appointment of Captain Harry Manning to succeed him on the Virginia.
Hardy folk of this old Atlantic port who for more than 300 years have watched their men "go down to 'the sea in ships" will pause tomorrow to honor the memory of fishermen who never returned.

This year is to see the doubling of the number of girls in the Reich Labor Service, according to advices just received from Germany. Where today there are only 10,000, by April 1, 1938, it is planned to have 25,000 in special work camps.
HASS-KASSID-Mr. and Mrs. Morris D. Kassel of 1,749 Grand Concourse, New York City, announce the engagement of their daughter, Selma, to Dr. Harold Hass, son of Mr. and Mrs. Adolf Hass of Long Island.

In her annual report to Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, Mrs. Mildred K. Parker, secretary of student activities, yesterday reported a 45 per cent increase in the number of student organizations functioning in the various schools and colleges of the university.

In spite of the number of lives lost during the heat wave in July and a death rate higher than any for the same month in the last seven years, health records for the month show several encouraging improvements, according to the report by Thomas J. Duffield, register of records in the New York City Health Department, which was made public yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD. FOUR comics in one picture--any four--will tend to enliven the day of a producer. But when four of the stature of Bert Lahr, Jimmy Savo, Billy House and Mischa Auer are assembled for a film, more than nominal patience, understanding and diplomacy are required to keep the thread of

The engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Mary Cary Nicholas, daughter of Mrs. Harrison Trent Nicholas of this city, to Pelton Phelps, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Phelps of- Winsted, Conn., has been announced by her mother. The ceremony will take place here on Oct. 16 in Grace Memorial Church.

Notwithstanding the fact that a lease signed by a tenant exempted the landlord from certain types of negligence, Justice Thomas C. Kadien Jr. of the New York Supreme Court recently gave a verdict in favor of a tenant for $2,955 on the ground that the landlord was guilty of affirmative negligence in failing to remedy a defect after it had been called to his attention.
A nature museum displaying live snakes, frogs, salamanders and even birds is becoming a regular feature of children's camps in this country.
Members of the Ausable Club and their friends were present today in large numbers for the annual water sports. Dinners were given later in the clubhouse in honor of both competitors and guests.
Legal advisers dropped part of Georgia's fugitive convict problems back into the lap of Governor Rivers today with an opinion that Federal authorities could not help in extraditions.

The list of more than 100 real estate holdings of six defunct national banks in Westchester County, which will be sold at auction as announced last week by Joseph P. Day, reveals that most of these offerings will be residential properties.
The South County Art Association, of which Henry Garfield Clark is president, will open an exhibition of figure paintings at the Neighborhood Guild Tuesday.

The Pan American Clipper III completed its second round-trip crossing of the Atlantic Ocean at Port Washington, L. I., at 4:23 P. M. yesterday. Captain Harold E. Gray logged the flight, 6,836 miles from New York to Southampton and back, in 49 hours and 35 minutes.

STORIES which have appeared in the daily press within the past ten days announcing an apparent realignment of labor groups in the entertainment field and foretelling the eventual formation of one vast cooperative organization embracing all have

A discussion of the Wagner Labor Relations Act by Edwin S. Smith, a member of the National Labor Relations Board, will be a feature of the twelfth annual Rutgers University Industrial Conference Sept. 9. The program was announced today by Professor Norman C. Miller, director of the University Extension Division, which is sponsoring the affair.
Vladimir Matchek, leader of the Croat Peasant party, said today that the Croats were not very much interested in the discussion over the signing of a concordat with the Vatican.

Assemblyman Thomas Glynn Walker of Hudson, Speaker of the Assembly, said today he would be a candidate for re-election in November. Mr. Walker told the 1936 Legislature he would not return next year, but it was known that Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, Democratic State leader, had urged him to make the race.

Among the passengers who sailed for Europe yesterday on the Italian liner Rex was Hal Roach, independent producer, who said he was going to arrange for the production of grand opera motion picture in the new $4,000,000 "Hollywood," which has been constructed a few miles outside of Rome.

Will Tripp, formerly a local resident, who now spends his Summers in camp at Willoughby Lake, has devised a novel and interesting way of ridding his place of skunks. Mr. Tripp's camp and surrounding grounds are very neat and attractive and the lawns are wellkept.

Counter-feiting was reduced during the fiscal year ended June 30, to less than two-thirds of the previous year's volume, 500 more moonshine stills were seized, and liquor smuggling was kept down to a negligible figure, the Treasury announces in reporting on the work of its various enforcement agencies.

It was one of those cases where the police emergency squad members wished they had had a previous engagement. An engagement with a cyclone would have done, or with fifteen wildcats loose from the zoo, or maybe with a nice, howling mob of sit-down strikers armed with brickbats and clubs.
Persons of prominence in society entertained at their homes and the clubhouse for the races today. Many had guests at the track, and several large parties were held during the day.

The choice of Christopher D. Sullivan as leader of Tammany Hall restores to high position a name that has long been redoubtable in New York City politics. There have been many minor members of the "Sullivan clan." The major bearers of that name in local Democratic councils have been:

A SELECT group of scientists, headed by Dr. Irving Langmuir of the General Electric Company's research laboratories, is blazing the trail in a new field of science which promises to become a powerful aid in biology, medicine, physics, physiology and chemistry.

The Joseph Milner Company of this city announces the opening of a branch office in Queens, at 117-18 Queens Boulevard at Union Turnpike, in Forest Hills. It is in charge of M. H. Blackwell, who was associated with the development of Jackson Heights for the Queensboro Corporation.

A good demand for small estates in Connecticut is reported by brokers in various sections of the State. Rolfe Floyd Jr., assistant treasurer of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company of New York, purchased from the Cruikshank Construction Corporation a new Colonial-style

Commenting upon the provision in the new building code permitting fusion welding in steel building construction, W. J. Donald, managing director of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, states that the attitude of organized labor which has had experience with fusion welding is distinctly favorable.

The marriage of Miss Jean Ogden, daughter of Dr. arid Mrs. George Stewart Ogdenof Brooklyn, to Dayton McCue Kohler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin D. Kohler of Wormleysburg, Pa., took place here this afternoon in the garden of her parents' Summer home. The Rev.

HANOVER, N. H.--Northern New England is witnessing the liveliest vacation season in its history. Along many highways there are more out-ofState than local automobiles. Forest trails in both the Green and White Mountains teem with hikers.

Delivery rather than the placing of orders for Fall merchandise engaged the attention of retailers last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc., resident buyers. While there is as yet no emergency, manufacturers in many apparel and accessories divisions and in most price brackets are asking for a time consideration. The report continues:
On an arch over the presiding officer's dais in the California State Senate Chamber at Sacramento appears the Latin motto," Senatus Libertatis Est Tueri," sometimes faces tiously translated:

The Merchants Association of New York, in a letter made public yesterday, attacked the Black-Connery Wages and Hours Bill as an ".experiment" which would "deliberately impose harmfully excessive operating costs upon employers, and reduce real wages of workers." Copies of the letter were sent to all New York State members of the House of Representatives.

None the worse for their experience, four young persons, three of whom were believed early yesterday morning to have been drowned when the 26-foot motor dory Mary Ann was capsized in the rough seas off Far Rockaway, were safe at home yesterday.

One of the important subjects discussed at the recent International Housing and Town Planning Congress in Paris was the necessity of providing proper accommodations for the working class, states Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards who was one of the delegates from this country.

Twenty young Girl Guides will arrive here tomorrow on the Queen Mary, for the opening of ceremonies celebrating the Silver Jubilee of Girl Scouting in this country. Each girl is the representative of a different nation.

Representative Alfred F. Beiter of Williamsville, N. Y., asked President Roosevelt today to include an appropriation of $1,000,000 in the next deficiency bill to cover this country's share of the cost of preserving the beauty of Niagara Falls.

Banking and business conception of the consumer goods industries must be adjusted to the realization that the world has entered a period in which the chief problem is distribution instead of production, according to a brochure entitled, "How to Make the Consumer into a Customer," prepared on behalf of the International Chamber of Commerce by Lloyd R. Coleman, managing director of J. Walter Thompson Company (France) and just received in this country.

Miss Sarah Cornelia Lawton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Mack Lawton of Plainfield, N. J., was married in the First Church here this morning to Dr. James Scott Mansfield, son of Dr. and Mrs. George Rogers Mansfield of Washington, D. C. The Rev. Dr. Charles E. Park of Boston performed the ceremony.

Slow but definite progress is being made by this municipality in its efforts to liquidate more than $800,000 worth of real property acquired through tax title lien foreclosures, according to Fred B. Handlon, Deputy Director of Public Property, and the town's real estate representative.

Two young farmhands from North Ferrisburg, Vt., who came here with the idea of making good in the big city, did not fare so well yesterday. Officials of the Vermont village were notified last night that the young men had been arrested here for violation of the Sullivan Law.

Four new champions swept to victory in the national rowing regatta today, with the Lafayette High School eight of Buffalo furnishing the big thrill as it nosed out the defending Shrewsbury (Mass.) oarsmen on the last stroke of the mile event for the United States junior crown A crowd of 5,000 lined the course.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow:
In a fast exhibition game which attracted a large gallery to the Narragansett Polo Club. today the Meadow Brook Pelicans came from behind in the last period to turn back Bostwick Field, 7 to 6.

The annual bridge party for the benefit of St. Lawrence Church will be held on Wednesday at the Hotel Cedarshore here. Mrs. John E. Biggins is general chairman and is assisted by Mrs. Francis A. Young as co-chairman.

Mrs. Ruth Thau Teitelbaum, wife of Max Teitelbaum, New York attorney, died on Friday at the Goshen Hospital, Goshen, N. Y., from injuries suffered the day before when a hot water heater at her country home at Monroe, N. Y., exploded. She was 28 years old and lived at 283 East Fifth Street, Brooklyn.
Mrs. Gertrude Pardee Keller, window of Dr. Harry Melick Keller and daughter of the late Ario Pardee, pioneer anthracite operator, died at her home in Hazleton today.

President Lazaro Cardenas has decided to permit railroad workers to operate 13,000 miles of railroads recently expropriated by the Mexican Government, it is stated by Juan Gutierrez, chief of the railroad unions.

Strict regulations, intended to prevent an uprising, were issued today by Governor J. Antonio Milla of the Honduras State of Cortes, which is a rich banana and sugar section centering around San Pedro. "In view of recent seditious activities," the circular says, "the following regulations are in force:

Threatened squalls, light variable airs, a short period of real hull-down sailing and the inevitable scrambling of positions through wind shifts gave 129 starters in the American Yacht Club regatta, fourteentL in the Y. R. A. championship series, their usual merry Saturday today.

Municipal Court Recorder Cyril M. Joly ruled today that spanking a child for stealing apples was an "unreasonable" means of protecting property. He found John R. Dean, 23, guilty of assault and battery on 7-year-old Florence Veilleux.

The British Home Office's order compelling three German newspaper correspondents to leave England tonight appeared likely to open a prolonged Anglo-German controversy. Two of the three already have left for Germany. As Berlin dispatches told of German official threats of retaliation there were indications the German Embassy here was preparing for some action in the matter.

George Dorvee, 13, was held today on a warrant charging first degree murder after the fatal stabbing of his brother, Claude, 15, in a ,quprrel over a squirt-gun. Chief Edward H. Usher said the warrant was issued last night on information filed by Grayford R. Smith, State police sergeant.
Thomas Olive Mabbott, New York educator and author, was divorced here today by Mrs. Maurine C. Mabbott. She charged cruelty.

Miss Katherine Alice Wilmarth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin L. C. Wilmarth of this place, was married here tonight in the First Presbyterian Church to William John Holding of Larehimont, son of Mr. and Mrs. Claude J. Holding of Albany, by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. John Lyon Caughey.

Analysis of Government statistics by the American Retail Federation revealed yesterday that the rise in national income in the year ended June 15 was about 9 per cent greater than the increase in the cost of living. Income in June, calculated by the Department of Agriculture, was 91.7 per cent of the 1929 average, and about 12 per cent above 1936.
IN the greater events which have hung upon the siege of Madrid the defense of the Alcazar at Toledo, very much in the news less than a year ago, has probably been almost

WHEN teachers turn. to the microphone they are warned that broadcasting is primarily entertainment.. Since radio, is. so closely allied with entertainment the educators are told that' the more showmanship they use in planning their programs the more intriguing they are to listeners.

William George Arthur Ormsby-Gore, British Secretary of State for Colonies, has come and gone and the Mandates Commission remains, facing a batch of those questions on Palestine which most people prefer to dodge.

Dr. Charles H. Elliott, State Education Commissioner, reversed today the action of the trustees of the State teachers' pension fund in refusing to award $21,844 to the estate of the late Miss Elizabeth I. Hussey, a former teacher at Bayonne.

Only eight gunners reported at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. They decided a team race with four men on each side. The winning squad, under the leadership of M. Zilinski, had a total of 179. W. A. Ketcham's unit had 172. A high-over-all cup went to W. J. Bode.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson, before going to New York today to be a guest of Mayor La Guardia, ended the "state of emergency" which he proclaimed here on Wednesday to give him extraordinary police powers to cope with a sympathy strike of 10,000 truck drivers and warehouse employes.
HUNTING birds with a camera is an increasingly popular vacation sport. It has full approval of public and private conservation agencies; there is no closed season.

The intelligence services of foreign General Staffs have made good use, for their own purposes, of business concerns having anything to do with some branchor other of socialist building in the Soviet Union. Gestapo [German Secret Police] agents are to be found in many of these firms.

Gertrude Berg, who achieved success on the air as the creator of "The Goldbergs" has signed a contract which will bring her familiar characters back to the air on an NBC network over a five-year period beginning Sept. 13. Mrs.

Two exhibition apartments in the Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South, are now open for inspection. They are of one and two rooms. Dorothy Draper did the decorations. Taking advantage of the large casement windows, Miss Draper has placed large mirrors on the walls of both suites in such a manner as to reflect the park and create the effect of greatly enlarged space.

More than 230 boys and girls who otherwise would be obliged to seek Summer fun on the city streets are attending the Ethical Culture Summer Play School, according to an announcement yesterday by the Ethical Culture Schools.

Frank Morrison, secretary-treasurer, said today the American Federation of Labor has a membership of 3,143,016, exclusive of suspended unions of the Committee for Industrial Organization. This figure, he added, was a gain of 702,940 over the average membership of the year.ended Aug. 31, 1936.

The Yale University golfers were defeated today by the Royal Liverpool Club, seven matches to three, with two halved. Liverpool won the foursomes, 2 to 1, with one match halved, and the singles, 5 to 2, with one halved.

Henry Gregor, Russian-born composer, and his bride, the former Mrs. Alfreda Mitchell Bingham, who were married here on Friday in the Municipal Chapel in civil ceremony, were wed yesterday in a religious service at St. Mark's-inthe-Bouwerie, according to The Associated Press.

Urging immediate construction of a nationwide series of high3/4 speed highways to provide for the mounting increase in passenger vehicles and trucks, Governor Richard W. Leche today called upon national, State and civic officials to coordinate their efforts in a national highway planning board.

In the Summer diplomacy in which, by personal letters and polite invitations to pleasant gatherings by sea and lake, international relations are kept from going altogether to sleep, Germany sees herself as still sitting pretty. And she is.
A rise of 0.9 per cent in living costs for families of wage-earners and lowsalaried workers in thirty-two large cities during the quarter ended June 15 was reported today by Secretary Perkins.

Vince Renzo, one of the outstanding left halfbacks of the 1935 campaign, will be back with the Temple eleven this Fall. His return has brightened the prospects for the Owls. He is a clever open-field runner.
Home runs by Joe Medwick and Johnny Mize led the Cardinals today to a victory over the Phillies, 11 to 4.

Miss Mary Alma Matthews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Matthews of 54-19 Ninety-fourth Street, Elmhurst, Queens, was married to Robert Woodling Downing, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Downing of Ben Avon, Pa., yesterday afternoon in St. James's Episcopal Church, Elmhurst, by the rector, the Rev. C. Lawson Willard.
THE new Italian series of coins struck in 1936 to commemorate the date of the Ethiopian conquest and the fourteenth year of fascism have recently made their appearance in this country.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Ruth M. Anderson of New Britain, Conn., daughter of the late Mr.. and Mrs. Svening L. Anderson, to Francis W. Clinton, son of Mrs. Francis W. Clinton of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Clinton.

It's a long perilous journey from the rarefied heights of the Andean slopes to a sunny, flowery valley in Southern California. Yet the chinchilla, whose beautiful French. gray pelt brings top prices in the world's fur markets, is as contentedly at home here as in his native villages in Chile and Bolivia.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today no representations had been made to the State Department by the Japanese Government concerning recruiting of United States citizens for Chinese service in the Far Eastern hostilities.

William Hillyer, C. I. O. field agent, said today that Harry Bridges, International Longshoremen's Association leader, will personally lead a strike of C. I. O. workers at the Grand Coulee Dam project.
Eleven-year-old Eugene Kelly has 3,832 lollypops and a tennis racquet today as well as the title of champion Japanese beetle collector of the borough .

A party of fourteen New York cricketers sailed for Bermuda yesterday on board the Furness liner Monarch of Bermuda. Six matches have been arranged against the leading clubs of the island, a combined eleven representing the army and navy and the Bermuda Cricket Association.

While his wife looked on from shore, Charles Softye, 43-year-old investment broker, drowned in the Sumpwams River here about 6 P. M. today in saving the lives of his 5year-old twins, Charles and Richard, after their twelve-foot sailboat, in which they had just put out from shore, capsized.

Mrs. Babette Marcus of 1,580 East Forty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, one of the founders of the Babette Marcus Aid Society, died on Wednesday evening, after a long illness. She was the wife of User Marcus.

One of the most active thoroughfares at the present time in building operations is Twenty-third Street in the two blocks from Seventh to Ninth Avenues in the heart of the old Chelsea residential district.

Mrs. Laura Elms Morris, 44-yearold rural school teacher, one of whose pupils said she taught that humans "came from monkeys," spent today in the living room of her home reading poetry to her 9-year-old daughter. The veteran teacher was dismissed from her position at the white frame, one-room school eight miles from town on charges by the Whiteley Township School Board that she disciplined pupils with a baseball bat and poker and was incompetent.

Exports of refined sugar from the United States in the first six months of 1937 amounted to 77,900,000 pounds with a value of $1,643,000, compared with 50,153,000 pounds valued at $1,162,000 in the same period in 1936, the Department,of Commerce announced today.

With electric power output now running at record high levels throughout the country, fear has been expressed in certain quarters that the utility industry will not be in a position to meet the demand for electricity which is expected to materialize within the next few years.

The United States. chess team, making a clean sweep against Denmark, gained four points in the twelfth round of the international team tournament tonight and moved to within half a point of Poland, the leaders, with much the better percentage.

Manufacturing operations of John B. Stetson Company (Canada), Ltd., have been removed from Brockville because of failure to settle the strike which held up production for six weeks, the management said today.

SOUTHAMPTON.--The varied social activities at this time give every indication of an unusually strenuous program during the remaining weeks of the Summer. House parties, particularly among the younger members of the colony, promise to be numerous next week-end.

Nathan Halparin reports that in the first group of twenty homes completed in his development at East Forty-eighth Street and East Forty-ninth Street and Lenox Road, Flatbush near Utica and Church Avenues, sales have been made to Hyman Stein, L. A. Magnani,

Miss Marilyn Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertrand Brown of 547 Riverside Drive, was married yesterday afternoon at the Women's Faculty Club of Columbia University to Walter Blaine Manson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Manson of East Orange, N. J.

A prodigious clout into the left field bleachers by Charles Keller, former University of Maryland star, broke up a thirteen-inning game today and gave the Newark Bears a 5-to-4 victory over the Rochester Red Wings.

ROME. AN outstanding revival of the Italian season was G. B. Pergolesi's neglected opera, "L'Olimpiade," produced recently in the leading theatre of Jesi, the composer's birthplace, as the climax in a series of celebrations for the bicentenary of his death. A significant exhumation.
Sixteen members of the Police Department were questioned at headquarters by Inspector Michael Murphy, confidential aide to Commissioner Valentine, on matters pertaining to ambulance chasing.
IT was an aged seaman who had served under him that said at the funeral of Stephen Decatur: "He was the friend of the flag, the sailor's friend; the navy has lost its mainmast."

The American Government, for more than a month, has been striving to get safe conduct from the Japanese and Chinese officers in North China for American citizens it wants to evacuate from the danger zones, Senator Pittman told the Senate today.

Miss Harriet Hausdorff of this city has announced the engagement of her sister, Miss- Else Hausdorff, to Samuel Kislak of Hoboken. Miss Hausdorff is associated with the Hebrew Immigration Aid Society of New York.

Seven hundred singers from three States joined tonight with Chautauqua Institution's symphony orchestra for a choral festival presentation of Haydn's "Creation." Maxine Stellman, Metropolitan soprano, was the featured soloist.

The Browns won their third straight game today, coming from behind to beat the Athletics, 4 to 1, behind the two-hit pitching of Jack Knott. The game was called at the end of the sixth because of rain and the second game of a scheduled double-header postponed. The box score:
A steel tower about 600 feet high has been ordered from the American Bridge Company by Major Edwin H. Armstrong, radio inventor and professor of electrical ,engineering at Columbia University.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Louise Teague, daughter of Mrs. Anna Louise Teague of this place and the late George Teague, to Paul Walter Schmidtchen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul F. Schmidtchen of Metuchen and Jersey City, took place here this afternoon in the Boonton Methodist Episcopal Church.
Sir Edward Davson, the empire trade expert who advised the Government on colonial commerce at the 1932 Ottawa Conference and at the London Economic Conference of 1933, died today.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

By RUTH GREEN HARRIS HE Federal Art Project has been supporting experiment in the difficult field of color lithography, and. as good citizens we all hope that pink slips given to serious students in this field have not too completely menaced the renaissance of a fascinating medium.

An eight-story apartment building is nearing completion at the northeast corner of the junction of Northern and Pinehurst Avenues and West 187th Street. Sam Minskoff Sons are the builders. Boak Paris were the architects.

Treasury officials said today they have imposed countervailing duties against nine countries to check imports of subsidized products. The tariff laws authorize the Treasury to levy additional duties against articles on which foreign countries grant subsidies.

The late President Eliot of Harvard was fond of making inscriptions, some of which found their way to the walls of public buildings. In one of these succinct writings he said that the security and elevation of the family are the prime objects of civilization, and the ultimate ends of all industry and work.

Because of the thinness of the market in many securities listed on the Stock Exchange, the practice of using over-the-counter facilities rather than those of the Exchange to distribute large blocks of stock is increasing.

AN exhibition called "Seven Centuries of Russian Icon Painting" opened last Monday at the Hammer Galleries, 682 Fifth Avenue, where it will continue until the end of August. The catalogue lists just short of 200 examples. A few of these are dated fourteenth century and fifteenth;

Approval of the bill reducing city water rates before any consideration is given to non-compulsory increases in the 1938 city budget is urged by Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., in a letter to the Mayor and 'the other members of the Board of Estimate.

Now that the Shakespearean feud is at an end, since John Barrymore's graceful with-drawal from the contest, drama lovers find themselves in another ticklish Predicament on Monday nights, with the Bard pitted against Eugene O'Neill.

Max A. Lazarus, president of the L. R. Manufacturing Company at 54 Clinton Street, Newark, makers of watch-cleaning machines, died early yesterday morning at his home here, 77 South Munn Avenue. His age was 70.
Miss Mary A. Benjamin, a Chautauqua Institution lecturer, said today that "on two different occasions, the Federal Government has shamefully destroyed priceless papers," she said.

Jeering and yelling, about 400 pickets caused a pedestrian traffic tie-up for an hour last night from 5:20 to 6:20 o'clock in front of an Automat restaurant at 1,557 Broadway, in Times Square between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets.

The thermometer of amity between Italy and Britain has had its ups and downs-mostly downs-during the last two years. It soared in the Spring of 1935, when the two nations, together with France, presented the now-forgotten Stresa front against Germany.
Louis J. Ritter, a farmer, is having more trouble. In 1935 lightning struck and burned his barn. Later in the same year death claimed his daughter, Margaret.

Death in a jail bed today saved Dr. Armen Greenhut from possible execution on the gallows for attacking a 13year-old schoolgirl patient. The 39-year-old physician, Austrian-born, was convicted late yesterday.
IT was an aged seaman who had served under him that said at the funeral of Stephen Decatur: "He was the friend of the flag, the sailor's friend; the navy has lost its mainmast."

The American Government, for more than a month, has been striving to get safe conduct from the Japanese and Chinese officers in North China for American citizens it wants to evacuate from the danger zones, Senator Pittman told the Senate today.

Miss Harriet Hausdorff of this city has announced the engagement of her sister, Miss- Else Hausdorff, to Samuel Kislak of Hoboken. Miss Hausdorff is associated with the Hebrew Immigration Aid Society of New York.

Seven hundred singers from three States joined tonight with Chautauqua Institution's symphony orchestra for a choral festival presentation of Haydn's "Creation." Maxine Stellman, Metropolitan soprano, was the featured soloist.

The Browns won their third straight game today, coming from behind to beat the Athletics, 4 to 1, behind the two-hit pitching of Jack Knott. The game was called at the end of the sixth because of rain and the second game of a scheduled double-header postponed. The box score:
A steel tower about 600 feet high has been ordered from the American Bridge Company by Major Edwin H. Armstrong, radio inventor and professor of electrical ,engineering at Columbia University.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Louise Teague, daughter of Mrs. Anna Louise Teague of this place and the late George Teague, to Paul Walter Schmidtchen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul F. Schmidtchen of Metuchen and Jersey City, took place here this afternoon in the Boonton Methodist Episcopal Church.

Thirty-seven nations scattered all over the world, have formally agreed with Secretary Hull's declaration of July 16 that wars anywhere in the world would have an impact upon the fate of all countries and that therefore treaties must be rigidly regarded, obligations 'maintained.

Senator Barkley, discussing the outlook for the 1940 campaign in an exclusive interview, said that the Republican party could not hope to be anything but "a mere party of opposition" unless it presented a definite, constructive and. aggressive platform to- the voters.

Officials closed most public schools here today in an attempt to check the spread of infantile paralysis. The children will be taught in their homes by radio. The disease was spreading at the rate of five cases a day, officials said. It broke out July 26.

Wheat fluctuated erratically within a range of about 2 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade here today, the bulges bringing in hedging sales while eastern shorts and brokers who frequently act for mills were buyers on the declines.

Local labor leaders with Democratic sympathies were. revealed today as divided on the question of intra-party tickets. in the city-county primary election this Fall. Some observers were inclined to read into the situation the existence of a political battle here between the American Federation of Labor

HE could "communicate his own disenchantment" with supreme skill, as Stevenson has said. And something of disenchantment lay-if only in a shadow of wistfulness-over all his brief, glorious hour. But what an hour it was! It has dazzled poets and lesser folk ever since, that brief hour of Francois Villon.

Several houses are under construction on the former Johnston estate in Plainfield and North Plainfield, N. J., owned for many years by the first president of the Central Railroad of New Jersey. Plots have been sold to C. W. Keller
A wild dash for freedom ended today in the death of two convicts and the probable fatal wounding of a third at the Western Kentucky State penitentiary.

DURING the days of the Mexican revolution three true descendants of medieval troubadours used to travel on Pancho Villa's troop trains. There was a tall, sad, cadaverous Don Quixote, a short, merry Sancho Panzo, and a "betwixt and between" with a repulsive harelip.

Arthur Hanney, 40 years 'old, accused of escaping from a Michigan penitentiary fourteen years ago, was arrested tonight after he had sent a young girl to the postoffice here to call for mail. Detectives Newman Stone and Mack Porecki said Hanney was sentenced to the South Michigan Penitentiary at Jackson, Mich., in 1923 to serve two and a half to five years on a charge of receiving stolen goods.

A mixed undertone ruled in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The trading pace was dull and price swings were restricted mostly to a narrow range. Total transactions amounted to $2,616,600, compared with $2,712,100 on Saturday the week before.
Moving ahead on the windward leg, Voyaguer led home the Class A craft in the first race of the Atlantic Coast canoe sailing chanmpionship series on Jamaica Bay yesterday.
SARATOGA SPRINGS. N August, motorists bound north from Albany or south from Canada have a hard time threading their way through the clogged traffic of Saratoga Springs.

The Pendleton Club of New York, took- opening-day honors at the two-day national championships of the American Canoe Association at Lake Quinsigamond today. Pendleton, which scored all its 18 points in three races, was followed by the favorite, Yonkers of New York and the Washington Canoe Club.

Vivian D. Corbly of Cincinnati, storm center of the national convention of Disabled American Veterans of the World War, was reappointed national adjutant today by the organization's executive committee for a period of sixty days.

C. I. O. workers on the Government's $120,00,000 Grand Coulee dam rallied today in preparation, it was asserted, for a strike Monday and the shutting down of work on the largest hydro-electric and reclamation project ever attempted. The C. I. O. asserts it can close the project through "100 per cent membership of 150 pipefitters" on the dam.
In a secret meeting in Tammany Hall, at Union Square and Seventeenth Street, the Democratic district leaders of Manhattan agreed last week upon a "boss" to succeed the late James J. Dooling.

A substantial rise in the volume of business, loans is expected by cal banks in the next few months, bankers indicated last week. Normally the seasonal expansion of commercial borrowing gets under way about this time, but in the present case, as also a year ago, the rise seems to have started about a month early.

In an effort to make up for the slow business of the last three weeks, men's - wear stores have slashed prices on furnishings, particularly for the August sales, retail executives pointed out here yesterday. Shirts formerly $1.65 and $1.95 are now down to $1.18, with quite a few stores promoting the $1 retailers.

Samuel M. Gayley, a real estate dealer, died in Germantown Hospital yesterday in his seventy-ninth year. He was born here and, since 1883. had been associated with the firm founded by his grandfather and carried on by his father.

Eric Schuler, an employee of the Copyright Office in the Library of Congress, Washington, and former secretary and treasurer of the Authors League of America, died on Friday at St. Luke's Hospital-after a short illness. He was 48 years old.

Baron Constantin von Neurath, German Foreign: Minister, has arrived at his Tyrolean estate, where he will spend a few weeks. He will see Dr. Guido Schmidt, Austrian Foreign Minister, while there. Field Marshal Werner von Blomberg, German War Minister, is expected within a few days at Bad

Several million industrial workers were given large concessions in a contract Signed today by the Confederation of Industrialists and the Confederation of Industrial Workers. Minister of Corporations Ferrucio Lantini took part in the negotiations toward the pact,
THE Duluth Symphony Orchestra, which started as a voluntary group rehearsing in a garage, is preparing for its fifth season beginning Oct. 20, under Paul Lemay, conductor.
BAR HARBOR, Me.--Varied outdoor activity combined with social functions will occupy Summer colonists of Mount Desert Island for the remainder of the month.

IN comparing American radio comedians with those of Canada, Joseph J. Weed, radio station representative, believes that the humor of the Canadian comedians is more developed than that of the American microphone funsters.

Ray Wilson of Mount Prospect, Mich., and Ben Kitchen of West Branch, Ill., were rescued from an automobile when it caught fire after rolling over near the foot of a hill at Camillus this afternoon. Deputy Sheriffs Edward Hoffmire and John Tailby reported that both men were unconscious when they were pulled from the machine by Lorain S. Clark of Rochester, vice president of the Clark Stove Company.
A war of words between George Washington and James Monroe, with each stating his opinion carefully in writing, was revealed today in a collection of books from the private shelves of the Presidents.

Dr. Samuel Basch of 905 West End Avenue; oto-laryngologist, died on Thursday of a heart attack in his country home at Montela, N. Y., according to word received here yesterday. He was junior surgeon of the Manhattan Eye. Ear and Throat Hospital, consultant at the Lynn Memorial Hospital and otolaryngologist at Fordham Hospital.

Sitting on a full rigger's poop deck, under the towering mizzen mast full of billowing canvas, watching the dolphins chase the flying fish is more fun than the movies and bridge parties. Mrs. Addie Morine of Rockaway, Queens, says so and she is in a position to know,

ONE morning not long ago Vice President Garner got off the elevator on the fourth floor of the Senate Office Building and walked briskly down the hall. Halfway along the corridor he turned quickly in at a door, to face a tall, rather handsome man, with thinning reddish brown hair, seated at a desk piled high with papers.

One opportunity open to Congress at this session has been permitted to go begging. Congress might well have taken advantage of an "off" year in national politics and an improved business outlook in order to go back over the record of its many enactments at recent sessions and perfect those measures which were adopted under presssure.

Directors of the New Orleans Cotton Exchange endorsed Secretary Hull's reciprocal trade treaties and opposed bonuses and benefits to cotton farmers in a resolution adopted today. Charles E. Fenner, president of the Exchange, wrote the secretary that the board also desired "to aid you in every way we can in extending your foreign trade policy."

Two Western Senators said today they would ask the Indian Affairs Committee on Monday to expedite an investigation of the Indian Service "with a view to taking action to remove Indian Commissioner John Collier. if charges against him are substantiated."

OF all the remakes thus far attempted, and there have been more of them than we liked shaking the critical stick at, Samuel Goldwyn's "Stella Dallas" is by far and away the most successful. It is rather puzzling, too,
Whatever the explanation may be, French names, many of them old French, and particularly nicknames, are undergoing an Americanization process.

Adolph Wein, 41 East Eleventh Street, New York, trading as American Toy Works, was ordered today by the Federal Trade Commission to cease representing that any of the toys he sells which are made in Japan or any other foreign country are manufactured in the United States.

Surprising sensitivity to the beauty of new surroundings is being displayed by small regular fellers" from New York at the Children's Aid Society's Bowdoin Camp near New Hamburg, N. Y., according to a society account of a visit there, made public yesterday.

Army Air Corps engine experts came forth today with a suggestion to vacationing motorists, that if and when they enter high altitudes, they keep their gasoline tanks full to assure smooth - running performance.

The extension this week of the old-age insurance system to white-collar workers-and the word "worker" here means anybody in useful employment from clerk to commissar-invites comparison between capitalism and State socialism in this field, both to the advantage and disadvantage of the latter.

Miss Eleanor Septima Cohen, prominent for many years in Jewish and non-sectarian benevolent activities, died yesterday at a Baltimore hospital at the age of 79. Her grandfather, Benjamin I. Cohen, was one of the founders and president of the Baltimore Stock Exchange.

If the North Shrewsbury River cruise to Red Bank isn't the prettiest in the metropolitan area of waterways it will have to do until a chamber of commerce in some other near-by harbor comes along to prove otherwise.

Miss Eleanor Septima Cohen, prominent for many years in Jewish and non-sectarian benevolent activities, died yesterday at a Baltimore hospital at the age of 79. Her grandfather, Benjamin I. Cohen, was one of the founders and president of the Baltimore Stock Exchange.

If the North Shrewsbury River cruise to Red Bank isn't the prettiest in the metropolitan area of waterways it will have to do until a chamber of commerce in some other near-by harbor comes along to prove otherwise.

A heavy truck crashed into an automobile it was following down a steep hill into this city today, killing two persons and injuring five others. Angelo Guimento and his wife of Scranton, riding in the automobile, were killed.

The United Automobile Workers of America, which asked the city of Dearborn for "legal protection" when it attempts again to distribute union literature at the Ford Motor Company plant next Wednesday, has been informed by the city's attorney that he has been unable to find that any such organization as the U. A. W. A. exists.

War games to demonstrate many phases of the revitalized French Army began today in the upper valley of the Rhone in the Department of Haute-Savoie. Special emphasis was placed on infantry advances across rivers with the aid of engineers.

Several Koreans trained at Columbia University are among the hundreds of students and intellectuals jailed by the Japanese in Korea within the last month, according to a letter received here yesterday by Ahn Seungwa, a Korean writer, of 506 West 122d Street.

LONDON. ONCERTS and operas are no longer numbered among the amenities of the town. But Sir Thomas Beecham's Philharmonic Orchestra is still hard at work providing musio for the dancers of Colonel de Basil's troupe at Covent Garden.

The following Foreign Service changes since July 31 were announced by the State Department today: E. Allen Lightner Jr., Mountain Lakes, N. J., assignment to San Salvador as Vice Consul and Third Secretary of Legation canceled; Mr. Lightner to remain in Buenos Aires. Overton G. Ellis Jr., Tacoma, Wash.. Vice Consul at Buenos Aires. assigned San Salvador as Vice Consul and Third Secretary of Legation.

Boston's rampaging Red Sox came from behind three times today, twice with home runs, to defeat the White Sox, 5 to 4, for their eleventh victory in twelve starts. One of the twelve games ended in a tie.

Scattered returns from 341 of Kentucky's 4,310 precincts gave a majority of the candidates backed by the administration of Governor A. B. Chandler a slight lead tonight over their opponents in today's offyear primary.

William Bingham 2d has pledged a gift of $300,000 to the Boston Dispensary to complete the building of its Diagnostic Hospital and finance its operation. The donation, supplementing a previous gift of $400,000 made by him in April, will be devoted to the creation of a medical center for the rural physicians of New England, which will be the only one of its kind it is said.

Manuel Quezon, President of the Philippine Commonwealth, accompanied by John Van A. MacMurray, American Ambassador to Turkey, arrived here today for a short visit. After a day of sight-seeing in Tokyo, they will continue their journey to the Philippines. Mr. Quezon said:

Mrs. Charles Lewis, now residing in Princeton, has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Anne Carey Lewis, to the Rev. Paul Rutherford Winn of Livingston Manor, N. Y. The wedding will take place here on Oct. 2.

Miss Mary Frances Kemper, daughter of Mrs. Frere Kemper of this city and Charles Delaware Kemper of Franklin, La., was married here last night in Grace Church to John Martyn Gunn, son of Mrs. Alice Townsend Gunn of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Percy Pickard Gunn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. E. Felix Kloman.

An appeal to all Germans with knowledge of one or more foreign languages has been issued through the so-called Reich interpreters' office of the "Jurist Front." This office will keep permanent records of those registered and the exact character of each individual's training in other tongues.

The McCrory Stores Corporation reported yesterday for the year ended on June 30 an estimated net profit of $2,419,552 after depreciation and amortization, interest on debentures, amortization of bond discount and other charges.

Dr. Joseph Leggett Miller, 69 years old, Clinical Professor of Medicine at the University of Chicago Medical School, died of a heart attack yesterday at a mountain ranch near Great Falls, Mont. His body was removed to Great Falls by means of stretchers, boats and wagons, and prepared for transfer to Chicago.
An old parliamentary habit perfected during his House Speakership enabled Vice President Garner to whip through the Court Bill today, literally before the Senate knew what had happened.

The Belgian Channel steamer Princesse Marie Jose struggled to shore in a sinking condition early today with 600 passengers aboard after a collision with the British steamer Clan Macneil off Dunkirk. The damaged Belgian vessel, aided by Dunkirk authorities, discharged her passengers outside the port, apparently unable to reach a wharf. Four of the pasWngers were rushed to a Dunkirk hospital.

In a letter to Marvyn Rathborne, president of the American Radio Telegraphers Association, Harry Bridges, leader of the West Coas longshoremen, asked permission yesterday to challenge to a debate Joseph P. Ryan,

The ninety-five experts representing the nineteen countries competing in the team tournament of the International Chess Federation enjoyed a well-earned rest today when they were the guests of the Swedish Chess Federation on an all-day sight-seeing excursion.

The terrific typhoon that seriously damaged Shanghai and then killed more than 130 persons in Korea last week also dealt a blow of the utmost seriousness to Japan's plans for pushing her military advantage in North China.

Returning from a prolonged visit to the Far East as one of the leading members of the Chilean trade mission that made a complete study of the possibilities of opening new markets, Disiderio Garcia, who also holds the post of Under-Secretary of Commerce, declared today he was satisfied with results of the trip.
Dr. R. B. von Kleinsmid of the University of Southern California will arrive in Sydney tomorrow with proposals for regular exchanges of professors and students with Sydney and Melbourne Universities.
Indications that steel buying will be heavy for the remaining months of 1937 have convinced steelmakers that requirements will take all their ability to produce, according to the magazine Steel.

W. J. Kennedy's chestnut gelding Erin's Son captured first prizes in three important events at the fourth annual Sagamore Horse Show today, taking the championship hunter event and the hunter and jumper stakes.

Governor R. E. Quinn of Rhode Island and Mrs. Quinn; Sir Robert Craigie, British Ambassador to Japan, and Lady Craigie; H. D. Armstrong, Minister of Labor for New Zealand and Mrs. Armstrong, are among the passengers due today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.
Two days in school was enough for Mrs. Eunice Winstead Johns, East Tennessee's 9-year-old child bride, her teacher, Wade Ferguson, revealed here today.

As the site for a new building to house its out-patient department the nine brownstone houses at 51 to 59 East 123d Street and 52 to 58 East 124th Street have been bought by the Hospital for Joint Diseases, which occupies the adjacent blockfront in Madison Avenue, between East 123d and 124th Streets, facing Mount Morris Park. The houses ing to an announcement yesterday by Frederick Brown, president of the institution.

With the arrival here today at Camp Smith of about 600 replacements made up entirely of staff officers' headquarters detachments, special troops and brigade headquarters companies, bands and arms practice will give way for two weeks to the study of tactical principles and command post exercises in the reservation and in the bivouac areas.

The Agriculture Department indicated today that only 1,000 to 2,000 tenants could hope to become farm owners during the first year of the new Federal tenancy program. With $10,000,000 to spend for this purpose during the first year and an estimated 3,000,000 tenants, farm laborers and sharecroppers, department officials have decided to limit operations to 500 counties.

Cooperative newspaper advertising by independent retail grocers will be given a sharp impetus this Fall as a result of the campaign to be launched by the National Association of Retail Grocers of the United. States, according to Charles E. Smith, president.

Government action on the French money market has been increased by the support given to government bonds on the Bourse by the recently created fund made possible by revaluation of the gold holdings of the Bank of France.

The Rev. Warren E. Darnell of the Little Neck Community Church, Little Neck Parkway, Queens, preaching yesterday morning at a union service at Christ Lutheran Church, 47-14 Glenwood Street, Queens, warned against the danger of nervous breakdowns in middle life, the liability of personal public disgrace and a possible "lonely old age" for those who refuse to admit mistakes they have made.

A crowd of 3,000 today watched the King and Queen, accompanied by their two daughters, drive to church from Balmoral in an open carriage. The crowd first cheered them on their arrival; then, realizing it was Sunday, subsided.
Newspapers today carried a press release saying the United States had lent to Brazil six destroyers. The Correio da Manha used almost an entire page featuring the reported deal.

The Rev. Robert James Murphy, chaplain of the Howe Military School, Howe, Ind., described the Kingdom of God in daily life as a gentle state in which "love gets busy and wins through," in a sermon yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, "the Little Church Around the Corner," Twenty-ninth Street east of Fifth Avenue.
Striking employes of the Horn Hardart Company, operators of a chain of Automats, again staged noisy mass picketing demonstrations in the Times Square section yesterday.
Sir Frederick Crombie Gardiner, who was president of the Glasgow Chamber of Commerce, 1919-21, died yesterday at his home in Balfron, Stirlingshire, at the age of 82.

The engagement of Miss Edna Maria Dudley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Leonard Dudley of Hearthstone, this place, to Burr Vanderburgh Brower, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Henson Brower of New York and Cleveland, has been announced by her parents.

A new instrument for under-water dredging was prepared by the police yesterday to gather evidence against Arthur H. Chalmers, a member of the department's Mounted Troop B, who is held on a charge of having murdered Irma Louise Pradier, a hospital domestic.

The marriage of Miss Jean Mobaldi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Mobaldi of this city, to Charles Gerald Parillo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Parillo of Newark, took place this afternoon in St. Michael's Church, Newark. The Rev. Felix M. O'Neill officiated.
Germany's wholesale price index on July 28 stood at 106.5, unchanged from the week before. The cost-of-living index for July was 126.2, against 125.3 for June.

The hunt for "Trotskyist wreckers" blamed for the recent lag in Soviet production today reached the automobile and tractor industry. Pravda, organ of the Communist party, denounced the management of Gutap, headed by Stepan Debets, the organization which embraces that part of Soviet industry.

Arrangements for the collective bargaining referendum among the 3,200 taxicab drivers, garage men and mechanics of the Parmelee Transportation System tomorrow were announced yesterday by Michael J. Quill president of the Transport Workers Union.
Two deaths in the city area were attributed to the heat as the sultry weather continued yesterday. Both victims, residents of Jersey City, were overcome in their homes.

While 150 Nazi sympathizers listened to speeches inside the GermanAmerican Club today, seventyfive pickets paraded outside with banners attempting to sing "America," and chanting that the United States must be preserved for democracy.

Theodore A. Peyser, Democratic Representative from the Seventeenth Congressional District of New York State, died at 4:20'A. M. yesterday in his apartment at the Hotel Warwick, 65 West Fiftyfourth Street. Death was due to coronary thrombosis. Mr. Peyser was 64 years old.
The German driver, von Brauchitach, piloting his racing car around Monaco's crooked streets at an average speed of more than sixty miles an hour, won the Grand Prix de Monaco today.

Bound to a chinaberry tree in the front yard of his accuser, Oscar Kay, 47 years old, a WPA worker, was publicly flogged here last night by Eloise Willis, 17, who charged him with spreading "false tales" about her.
Farmers disregarding the decrees ordering the placing of all wheat and rye at the disposal of the government marketing organization will be subject to fines ranging up to 100,000 marks.
The Newark Bears whipped the Rochester Red Wings in both ends of a double-header today, taking the first game by 8 to 4 and then turning back the visitors by 4 to 1 in the abbreviated nightcap.
