Efforts of steamship lines to adjust the wage and working demands of their seagoing personnel have been complicated in recent weeks by new alignments of unions that have come out of the shipping strike of last Fall and the renewed activity of union organizers on the piers.

Buffalo's West Side rowers played poor hosts to the National Oarsmen Association's championship regatta today and won the two most highly prized trophies with a team point victory and the senior eight-oared title.

Sharply attacking the group hospitalization plan now in operation in New York as "not acceptable to the Philadelphia medical profession," the Philadelphia County Medical Society recorded emphatic protest today against the proposed adoption of a similar plan by thirty-two hospitals in this city and vicinity.

Governor Hoffman played host today to 500 members of the Lambs Club of New York at the "Little White House." The club members have been his annual guests for the last three years. They participated in a program of lawn games and other entertainment.

An evernormal cash box or reserve fund for the relief of the unemployed is being studied by the Commerce Department's Business Advisory Council. Officials disclosed today that the council was drafting recommendations that money be stored in the Treasury during prosperous years for public works during depressions.
With manufacturers displaying a passive attitude, leaders of the Textile Workers Organizing Committee look for a 100 per cent response to the national silk strike call here tomorrow morning.
Stocks higher on the week; turnover, 4,378,683 shares. United States Government bonds firm; domestic bonds irregular; foreign issues steady; transactions, $32,170,750.

If a customer buys annuity insurance and dies soon afterward, that is his loss and the company's gain, Circuit Judge Horace Baker indicated in a decision handed down in a test case here late yesterday.

Between twenty-eight tand thirtysix members of the new city council will be elected in November, with Brooklyn having three or four more Councilmen than Manhattan, according to computations made by the Merchants Association's bureau of research and released yesterday.
This afternoon's concert at Tanglewood rounded out the first half of the Berkshire Symphonic Festival. More than 5,000 were in the audience.
Mental nimbleness, which traditionally gives a woman the right to change her mind, protects her against stuttering, says Dr. Robert Milisen, director of. Indiana University's speech clinic.

IT must be the backwash from the recent attack on the United States Supreme Court that has left the baseball umpires jittery. When the highest judiciary is threatened, the inferior courts probably feel that the benches may be yanked right from under them if their decisions are not pleasing to local politicians or an enraged populace.
Election of the President of the Ecuador Republic by popular vote will be repealed in the proposed new Constitution which will be placed before the Constitutional Convention opening here on Tuesday.
Members of the United Automobile Workers of America today ratified a truce between the union and the Chrysler Corporation paving the way for reopening of the Plymouth plant tomorrow.
It may be several weeks before little Donald Horst gets a permanent home, and then it may not that of either his foster or his actual parents.

Services commemorating the 150th anniversary of the appointment of Bishop Charles Inglis as the first Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Canada were held yesterday at St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, West Sixty-ninth Street near Broadway. The sermon was preached by Dr. Samuel H. Prince of Halifax, N. S.
President Albert Lebrun today formally opened the Vosges Tunnel, which provides a new access of commercial and military importance .to the recovered province of Alsace.

The Athletics twice defeated the Browns before 7,500 today, coming from behind to win the first game, 5 to 4, and breezing through the second, 7 to 3. Bill Werber's double, scoring Chubby Dean with two out in the ninth inning, was the deciding blow in the opener.

The marriage of Miss Alice F. Wolfe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee J. Wolfe of 1,125 Park Avenue, to Brian F. Turner, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Turner of London, will take place today in London. After a wedding trip to Scotland, the couple will make their home in London.
Edward C. R. Bagley, for the last 15 years deputy commissioner of the State Department of Correction, died tonight at his home in Winthrop. His ag was 62.

Rose Mary Doran, 3 years old, of 133 Beach Ninety-fifth Street, Rockaway Beach, was injured seriously yesterday by a miniature electric train In a children's ride at Beach Ninety-sixth Street and the Boardwalk, Rockaway Beach.

The Government's industrial policy and the abnormal report of the Reichsbank induced a setback for stocks this week. Early in the week, corporations owning ore fields which had not exploited their claims received summary notification that their claims had passed into the possession of the new Reich iron company and that compensation would be fixed later, apparently unilaterally.

Jagged prongs of one great fork of lightning killed three persons near Beach 169th Street in the Rockaway Point area at 1:25 o'clock yesterday afternoon, struck down fourteen others and led to a massing of emergency apparatus at the shore while panic spread and a driving rain squall lashed the rescuers.

Joe McCluskey, New York A. C. star and national A. A. U. 5,000meter champion, won the threemile special handicap race at the metropolitan A. A. U. athletes' development track and field meet at Macombs Dam Park yesterday.

If the Christian religion is nothing more than a code of ethics or a philosophy, it does not relate itself to the main purpose of religion, Bishop Irving Peake Johnson of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Colorado said yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

With no windward work at all and not much wind, either, Donald Millar's Brendy gained a close decision today among the International One-Design Class sloops, which provided the highlight of the Echo Bay Yacht Club's second special Sunday regatta.

The historic national junior pole championship cup was won by a California team today for the second time in its history, which covers more than a quarter of a century. It was presented to Charles H. (Pete) Jackson Jr., leader of Santa Barbara, after his quartet had fought its way t a 12-to-7 victory over Gerry Dempsey's Narragansett team in the final.

Lard futures declined to new low levels for the season in the early part of last week in sympathy with grains and cottonseed oil, only to advance rapidly later on the continued small receipts of hogs and urgent demand for the cash product. Hogs were in high ground since 1926, with only sufficient coming forward to take care of the fresh meat trade.

Patrolman John Ryan of the Second Police Precinct, who was shot accidentally on the Grassy Sprain Golf Club on Central Avenue Saturday afternoon, was resting comfortably today in St. John's Riverside Hospital here.
The sharpshooters who guard the life of the President will shoot it out in friendly matches, starting tomorrow, with marksmen from other agencies in the Treasury Department.

Nova Scotia, once the abode of the herring-choker, has become a mecca for those deep-sea anglers whose leisure and bank balances allow them to make the tuna pilgrimage. But next month will see the interest of the entire salt-water brotherhood, rich and poor alike, centered on those waters where the International Tuna Fishing Tournament will be held.

For the first time in California history, Reina Del Mar Parlor, Native Daughters of the Golden West, was called upon today to designate two of its younger members to be enshrined as Santa Barbara. For the old Spanish days fiesta held here in the light of the August moon, the selection was Miss Florence Longawa, comely school teacher in the county town of Buellton.

Jumpers-First, George M. Holley Jr.'s ch. g. Brynmaur: second, Jackson Johnson 3d's ch. g. Gay Pete; third, Troop A's ch. g. Air Flow; fourth, John Vass's b. g. Adara. Children's Challenge Trophy (presented by Arthur H. Bradley)-First, Miss Jane Kiernan; second, Miss Betsy Mercelis: third, Miss Nancy Green; fourth, Peter Kiernan.

George Bijur, formerly vice president of Fletcher Ellis and director of advertising and sales promotion of the Columbia Broadcasting System, will establish his own advertising and sales promotion agency at 9 Rockefeller Plaza, to be known as George Bijur, Inc., on Aug. 20.
Two of the four sons born yesterday to Mr. and Mrs. A. M. Lingwood died tonight in the hospital at Thetford, Norfolk, a few minutes after a photographer had taken their pictures.

Lawrence Marks, 49 years old, of 748 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, an unemployed hospital orderly whose police record shows two previous convictions for crimes against little girls, confessed yesterday, according to the police, that he strangled and assaulted Paula Magagna, 8 years old, a week ago Saturday in the cellar of her home at 349 Stockholm Street, Brooklyn.

Abraham Wishkofsky, oldest In mate at the Home of the Daughters of Jacob, 167th Street and Findlay Avenue, the Bronx, is preparing for a celebration in his honor. A birthday party will be held tomorrow afternoon.

Mr. and Mrs. W. Halsey Johnson of this place and 1,148 Fifth Avenue, New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Loriel Martens Johnson, to William Livingston Desloge, son of Mr. and Mrs. Firmin Desloge of St. Louis and Nantucket.

Resumption of Strauss's "Elektra" at the festival this evening after years of neglect enabled scores of Americans who had heard Rose Pauly in her New York performance of the work last season to check up and verify their impressions of the artist.

The efforts of the German pastor, the Rev. Dr. Martin Niemoeller, to lead the German people along the paths of spiritual progress that he believes to be those of their religious destiny were praised yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Andrew R. Osborn, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Edmonton, Canada, in a sermon at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, in a surprise flight from England, came to France today for his third visit in five weeks to Dr. Alexis Carrel, his collaborator in the invention of the "artificial heart."

Ben Johnson, Columbia University captain and intercollegiate champion, won the 100-meter dash in the international meet at Heysel today. Johnson was timed in in 0:10.6, with J. S. Duncan of Great Britain second.

Authorizations and commitments of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in the recovery program through July 31, including disbursements of $898,170,006 to other governmental agencies and $1,799,984,' 880 for relief, have amounted to $11,813,479,922, Jesse H. Jones, chairman, announced today.

Mrs. Angelica W. Frink of New York was hostess at a buffet bridge party at Tenedos, her Northeast Harbor home, this evening. The guests included Mr. and Mrs. William Rodman Fay, Mrs. C. B. Bradley, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Prout, Mr. and Mrs. John Van Pelt, Mr. and Mrs. John Newbold, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Norris and Mr. and Mrs. R. E. Wigham.

The Safford, Biddulph Company, Inc., has been formed by George Safford, C. Ashmead Biddulph, Raymond Seabrook, Alison J. Safford and William O. Pettit to do a general investment business in municipal and corporate securities at 40 Wall Street.

Horse and dog racing, among the biggest of Massachusetts industries, has prompted wagers of $40,253,620 since the first of the five regular tracks started operation May 24. A record total of $50,000,000 before the race year ends Nov. 1 is indicated by figures from the State Racing Commission.
Held even for four periods, the Governors Island Yellows conquered the Blind Brook Esquires, 9-6, yesterday at Morris Memorial Field with three goals in the fifth chukker.

The Government is asking for bids on five aged employes-some old gray steeds that admittedly aren't what they used to be. On form No. 215, surplus property bid sale No. 269, which is a pretty lengthy document, they are described as:
The Government received new reports today of a revolt among Spanish Insurgent troops at Toledo, and it was said that Italian fighters had aided in ?? the disorders.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes, depreciation and other charges, but before provisions for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures, in many cases, are subject to final adjustment.
The Government is coming to the rescue of owners of radios in San Salvador by a decree intended to eliminate all kinds of interference with reception.

Speeding to a second world record in as many days, Clinton Ferguson of Waban, Mass., provided the most spectacular performance of the outboard and inboard racing regatta on the Charles River basin today before a crowd estimated at 50,000.

Speaking in German, Dr. Hans Heinrich Dieckhoff, German Ambassador to the United States, addressed several thousand German-Americans at Geneses Park this afternoon. The occasion was celebration of "German Day," sponsored by United German singing societies.

Appointment of Joseph B. Maclean as consulting actuary of the Church Pension Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church was announced yesterday by William Fellows Morgan, president of the fund. He succeeds the late Henry Moir, who served from 1922 until his death on June 8, last.

If the people of Brooklyn had been asked to name their first private citizen, the response would have been no doubt overwhelmingly for Darwin R. James. A son of Brooklyn, he ever showed a filial interest in all its affairs and gave a loyal service to its highest good.
Administration leaders in the House labored over the week-end to perfect plans for so speeding action on important measures set for passage this session that Congress may adjourn by Aug. 21.
The Ministry of Justice issued a statement today that sharp watch still is being kept for Andres Nin, leader of the P. O. U. M. (United Marxist Workers party), who disappeared last Spring.
The Spanish Government, highly reliable informants said today, is considering removing several Ministries to Barcelona.

A plea for greater trust in God and less trust in human ingenuity was voiced tonight by Commissioner Alexander M. Damon, territorial commander, at the evening auditorium services of the second day of the annual Salvation Army visitation to Ocean Grove.

Dr. Kills Campbell, Senior Professor of English at the University of Texas, died at his home here early today after a long illness at the age of 65. He was known as a leading authority on Edgar Allan Poe.

Reports reaching here today are to the effect that in all Belgrade Orthodox churches the Holy Synod's decree was read announcing that Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch and eight other members of the Cabinet, with the Speaker and fifteen other members of Parliament, had been denied all church rites and privileges pending trial by the chief ecclesiastical court.

After as dramatic a finish as any match ever had, Eddie Driggs Jr. and W. Neal Fulkerson, playing from the Cherry Valley Club at Garden City, today annexed honors in the fourth John G. Anderson Memorial tournament, one of the year's high spots, played annually on the east course of the Winged Foot Golf Club.

The Austrian Foreign Minister, Dr. Otto Schmidt, conferred with Baron Constantin von Neurath, the German Foreign Minister, for an hour lapd a half today at Baron von Neurath's vacationing place at Bard in Voralberg. Hans-Georg Viktor von Mackensen, German Foreign Under-Secretary, was also present.

George A. Gordon, newly appointed United States Minister to The Netherlands, returned from Washington yesterday and joined Mrs. Gordon at the Ambassador. They will sail aboard the Manhattan on Wednesday, and after a stay in Paris, will go to The Hague.
A large social function of the racing season was the second luncheon given by George H. Bull, president of the racing association, this afternoon at the Saratoga Golf Clubhouse.

Two high-goal exhibition matches in this area today provided lively action for poloists preparing for the coming national open championship tourney, with victories being recorded by the Aknusti and Long Island quartets.
Opening of summation arguments based on forty-two days of testimony will usher in the eleventh week tomorrow in the trial of eight men for the kidnapping in 1933 of John J. O'Connell Jr.

While civilization is merely what we use in our lives, our culture and spiritual development is what we actually are, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church.
Charles S. MacGregor, member of an old Scottish family, died here last night after a long illness. He would have been 77 years old next Wednesday.

The Police Department's only land plane was disabled yesterday, and a patrolman at its controls was injured when the motor stalled and the ship crashed into a fence at the north rim of Floyd Bennett Field at 10:30 A. M.

Frank J. Tappen, former deputy chief of police of Nassau County and former Receiver of Taxes of Oyster Bay, died suddenly late this afternoon in his Summer bungalow on Center Island Beach. He had passed the afternoon in his motor boat with a friend. His age was 46.
For the better part of two hours the Giants today promised to make quite a success of their job of salvaging something from the wreckage of a rather disastrous venture in the West.

A sustained drive that carried the Red Sox from fourth into second place ended today when the White Sox let loose a sixteen-hit fusillade to capture the second game of a twin bill, 13 to 0, after Boston took the opener, 7 to 6.

Heiner Henkel, Germany's No. 2 tennis player, added the German national championship to the French title he had won earlier this Summer when he defeated Vivian McGrath of Australia in a hard five-set final today. The scores were 1-6, 6-3, 8-6, 3-6, 6-1.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Linda Leeds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Starr Leeds of 1,075 Park Avenue, to Thomas Reginald Bassett, also of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas O. Bassett of Dover, N. J.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter to THE TIMES from J. Carlisle Peet calls attention to the plight of the older unemployed man hitch-hiking in search of work. While his letter points to the necessity for the acceptance of these men by industry, it also brings to mind the problems faced by transient persons and families and the community problems resulting from their movement from place to place.

Mrs. Mary Alida Bonynge, wife of Robert W. Bonynge, New York attorney and counsel for the United States Government to the German-American Mixed Claims Commission, died yesterday at her residence, 230 Central Park West. Her age was 77.

The Shrewsbury four, paced by the veteran Texan, Rube Williams, advanced to the semi-finals of the Northeastern circuit intra-circuit polo tournament at the Burnt Mills Polo Club today by scoring an 8-6 victory over the Burnt Mills Ramblers.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:
Hundreds of armed men hunted through the sawgrass on the edge of the Everglades today for Will Akrey, 30-year-old Negro accused of slaying Patrolman Louis A. Conner.

The police arrested, but later released, 115 demonstrators who marched through the tree-lined streets of suburban Dahlem tonight in protest against a ban on public prayer meetings for imprisoned pastors who had opposed Nazi church restrictions.

The five-day Grand Circuit meeting at William H. Cane's Good Time Park opens tomorrow, with the rich Hambletonian Stake set for Wednesday. A special handicap trot for amateur drivers and the Langhorne Stake for 2-year-old pacers will feature the four-race program on the opening day.

Dick Floyd scored six goals to lead South Shore to a 12-4 victory over the Ramapo Blues of Tallman, N. Y., today in an Eastern Polo League contest at Hazard Field. Miss Marjorie LeBoutillier rode with South Shore for the first time this season and tallied thrice.

Thomas F. McGuire, C. I. O. organizer who left the Coeur D'Alene mining district of Idaho under protest after collapse of the strike at the Sunshine Silver Mine last night, denied here tonight the union had "lost completely" in the district.

The effectiveness of the Health Department's control of malaria in the Panama Canal Zone is shown in a report that the rate :for 1936, 12 cases per 1,000 employes, was the lowest since a rate of 11 per 1,000 was established in 1927.

The defenses of vital London areas against bombing attacks will be tested tomorrow and Tuesday night, when 170 "enemy" planes will attempt to break through from the west. There will be 220 defending planes and a ring of observation stations and anti-aircraft batteries fully manned by
Belgium paid tribute to the United States today as one memorial chapel and two tablets were unveiled on different Belgian battlefields where American soldiers had fought and died in the World War.

Graying and visibly aged in the last few years, General Tsai Ting-kai returned here yesterday to the scenes of his 1932 exploits when he directed the Nineteenth Route Army as field commander and for five weeks waged a successful resistance against the Japanese attack.
Frank Traeger, who shoots for the Roseland, N. J., Gun Club, captured the championship in the annual Eastern States Skeet Tournament that ended today on the Ludlow Rod and Gun Club ranges.

In a world which is dangerously irrational in so many matters it is comparatively a relief to learn, by means of the dispatches from Paris, that women are probably going to continue to be harmlessly irrational in the matter of dress.

Mr. and Mrs. Sellar Bullard of Santa Barbara, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol, to Richard Hubbard Howland, son of Carl Badger Howland and the late Mrs. Howland of Providence, R. I.

An increased budget for the Municipal Civil Service Commission to make possible greater efficiency and a substantial expansion in the administration of civil service was urged yesterday by the Citizens Union in a report of its civil service committee.

John B. Kelly, chairman of the Democratic City Committee, today insisted on adhering to his own plan of "keeping the Philadelphia judges out of politics" by rejecting a proposal of the Committee of Seventy which ostensibly had the same end in view.
Concern over the approach of Finsler's comet is measurably less than it would have been a couple of thousand years, ago.

As Congress enters what is apparently the last stretch of the long session which began last January, little is heard of the President's ambitious plan for a reorganization of the executive departments of the Government from top to bottom.

The Welsh National Eisteddfod, the festival of music and literature, ended yesterday with keen rivalry in the competition for male choirs. Two entries from Swansea, Wales, placed first and second. These groups were composed mostly of steel and tinplate workers, while the six other competing choirs were all miners.
For ten hours here today police were convinced that Robert E. Walden Jr., 9-year-old adopted son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Walden of 599 Cedar Lane, had been kidnapped.

Unemployment in the United States declined between May and June by more than 100,000 persons to a total of 6,082,000, according to a report made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.
John F. Thomas, believed to have been the oldest surviving member of the Union Army in Baltimore, died suddenly last night at his home. He was 95.

Hollywood will turn two of its "super specials" loose on Broadway this week, one opening tonight and the other on Wednesday. Tonight's premiere will be that of Paramount's "Souls at Sea," a nautical matter involving Gary Cooper, George Raft, Frances Dee and Olympe Bradna, and directed by Henry Hathaway, who not so long ago was commanding "The Lives of a Bengal Lancer."

It would be unfortunate, as it would be easy, to exaggerate the significance of the United States-Russian trade pact announced by the State Department on Friday. This new agreement, if made with any State other than Soviet Russia, would have attracted scant public attention.

For the first time in the country's history the note circulation of the Bank of England has exceeded the [pound]500,000,000-mark, the increase last week of [Pound]5,538,746 raising the total to [Pound]503,877,456.

In many of our mental and spiritual ills, the condition of our bodies is tremendously important, the Rev. Dr. Henry Hallam Tweedy, professor at Yale Divinity School, said yesterday in a sermon at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

The American Museum of Natural History announced yesterday the departure from Seattle of the ClarkKissel Alaskan Expedition for Ketchikan, in the southeastern corner of Alaska. The project represents the first active field work for the new Hall of North American Mammals, it was explained.

It is "scandalous," Park Commissioner Robert Moses declared yesterday, that-"so many of the school recreational facilities should be closed to the general public outside of school hours, and especially in the summertime, when there is such a tremendous demand for them, particularly in congested and underprivileged neighborhoods."

Solution of the world's ills cannot be found in any plan which denies the existence of God, the Rev. Charles O. Sloane declared in a sermon yesterday morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral. The need for being unselfish in our prayers was also stressed by Father Sloane.

Financial circles-in the Netherlands are fully satisfied with the present working of the triparte agreement, although they would prefer replacing its frail machinery with something stronger and more permanent.

Charles E. Havens, superintendent of the studio at 10 West Eighth Street, New York, of Mrs. Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, sculptor, died yesterday at the Physicians Hospital in Jackson Heights, at the age of 64.

Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, will be in charge of the eleventh annual international lifeboat races to be held on Sept. 11 off Bay Ridge, it was announced yesterday by the International Lifeboat Racing Association.
The favored Governors Island Blues met with a 10-4 reverse from the Blind Brook Knights today at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club in their Eastern Polo League game.

One-hit pitching by Tex Carleton in the opener and timely hitting by young Phil Cavarretta in both games enabled the league-leading Cubs to sweep a double-header from the Bees, 3 to 0 and 3 to 2, before 28,072 fans today.

The failure of the Democratic organization to designate David C. Lewis, Municipal Court justice in the Seventh District, for re-election has been condemned by the ?? association's committee on municipal courts as "a direct challenge to the ideals of the bar of the City of New York for an independent and capable judiciary," it became known yesterday.

The announcement in yesterday's TIMES of a gift to make possible the establishment in Boston of a medical center at which the development of "rural medicine" may be planned and supervised calls attention to one of the greatest of needs in all the wide field of health service.

A wild pitch by Mike Ryba in the ninth inning of the second game cost the Cardinals a double victory over the Phillies today, and after playing three scoreless extra innings, the game was called because of darkness with the count knotted at 6-all. St. Louis won the first game, 3 to 2.

In a press conference last week the President remarked that his immediate plans hang on developments in two places-on "the Hill" and around Peiping. The two battlegrounds are a long way apart, but bracketing the two together emphasizes the range of the responsibilities of the head of the American Government.

Two twenty-family apartment houses at 29 to 39 Seventh Street, Weehawken, N. J., have been sold by the New Jersey Title Guarantee Trust Company to the Newman Realty Corporation. They occupy a plot 150 by 100 feet and were sold for cash over a first mortgage of $180,000. J. B. Wolfe, Inc., was the broker.

Class 6, Bridle Trail Hacks-First, Suzanne Mary and Thomas Fields Long's ch. m. Bronze Lady; second, Miss Helen Curran's ch. m. Diana; third, Edwin R. Teevan's ch. m. American Girl; fourth, W. Royden Klein's ch. g. Thistle. Class 9, Horsemanship For Children Under 14-First, Miss Joan McGrath; second, Miss Ann Fennessey; third. Miss Florence Dorothea Taylor; fourth, Miss Alice Jackson 'Bailey; fifth, Miss Marilyn Menschik; sixth, Miss Jane Renwick St. John.

Although defeated in their efforts toprolong life for the Boccawsini baby, delivered by Caesarian section after her mother's death on Friday, physicians at phila'delphia General Hospital said tonight that they would not hesitate .to follow the same course in a similar case in the future.

Dr. Vernon Lyman Kellogg, scientist and author, died this afternoon at the Neuro-Psychiatric Hospital and Institute. His age was 69. With him at his death were his wife, Charlotte Kellogg, and his daughter, Jean Kellogg.

The United States gold hoard, which amounted on Thursday to $12,470,651,718, should be applied toward reduction of the national debt, the six Republican members of the House Committee on Banking and Currency urged today in a joint statement.

Representative George H. Tinkham of Massachusetts announced today that he was planning to introduce a resolution in the House authorizing the Foreign Affairs Committee to ask whether President Roosevelt had reached an understanding, in his conferences last January with Walter Runciman, president of the Board of Trade of Great Britain, for a joint British-American policy in Far Eastern affairs.

The Seaside Park Yacht Club Sunday regatta was interrupted today by a series of wind and rain squalls from the northwest and southwest which caused two yachts to capsize and many others to withdraw. Winners were: Norton Ludwig's Bay Spray, in the race for Sneak Boxes; Dr. John Musser's Duckling, among the Junior Catboats; Clifford E. Grover's Teaser, in the Star Class, and H. F. Rommel Jr.'s Shooting High, among the Comets.

The favored Yonkers (N. Y.) Club, scoring heavily in six of the nine scheduled events, won the eighth annual national paddling championships of the American Canve Assocation today on Lake Quisigamond with point total of 42.

Hal Lee's single in the thirteenth inning drove in a run today to give the Jersey City Giants a 1-to-0 victory over Montreal in the nightcap and an even break in a doubleheader. The Royals won the opener, 2 to 0.

Because the recent book "Was College Worth While?" by John R. Tunis, gave such a "depressing picture of the material and cultural values of a college education," the administration of the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance of New York University has made a similar investigation among its own graduates, the results of which were announced yesterday.
Charles H. Wilson, business man anal civic leader, died here this morning at his home from a heart attack suffered yesterday after he returned from his Summer camp at Lake George. His age was 51.
Captain C. W. Archer won a race against disaster today in his excursion steamer Mildred while twenty-five passengers on a Muskoka Lakes trip remained ignorant of their danger.

A supporter of Mussolini who selected an inauspicious occasion to give the Fascist salute, was struck on the head with a piece of pipe during the peace parade on Saturday, it was revealed yesterday in Felony Court. Donald Grassi,

Mr. and Mrs. G. Whiting Hollister entertained for more than 200 this afternoon at their Drew Lane residence following the christening of their daughter, Hope, which took place at St. Luke's Church, the rector, the Rev. William Grainger, officiating.

Prompt work by the police prevented a panic among an audience of more than 400 persons in the Costello Theatre, a moving picture house at 23 Fort Washington Avenue, near 160th Street, shortly after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon when fire broke out in several empty barrels stored in a shed in an alley adjoining the theatre.

The new Montauk Riding Club opened with a buffet supper last night. Among those present were Mrs. Marion Bragg Aubert, Mr. and Mrs. C. M. Keyes, Mr. and Mrs. Oswald McCarthy, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Ringwood, Mr. and Mrs. Adolf Garni, Mr. and Mrs. Paul M. Maxwell, Miss Emily Carson, Mrs. E. L. Naiden, Anthony Fokker, Lawrence Gould and W. J. Rich.

From the greater steadiness now being displayed by the United States dollar 'it appears likely either that the authorities consider that the time to give support has arrived, or that the main factors recently operating to depress the dollar now are losing their influence.

The answer to every bitter experience and perplexing problem is to be found within man's own soul, the Rev. Austin Pardue said yesterday in a sermon at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street. Mr. Pardue is rector of Gethsemane Church in Minneapolis.

Helen Moller sold to a builder a plot at the northwest corner of Broadway and Herrick Drive, Lawrence, L. I., through Monroe Miller, broker, who arranged building loans for houses to be erected on the property.

The new Franklin K. Lane High School, a huge Georgian building with seats for 5,000 students, will be ready for acceptance by the city today. The school cost $3,500,000, was designed by Walter C. Martin, architect for the Board of

The Essex County Bar Association announced here today that it would work in close cooperation with the Newark Chamber of Commerce and the New Jersey Association of Credit Men in an advertising campaign intended to induce the settlement of commercial disputes by arbitration rather than by court procedure.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Terlinde, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Terlinde of Glen Ridge, to T. Wesley Wright, son of Mrs. T. Wesley Wright of West Orange, and the late Mr. Wright, will take place Sept. 11 in Christ Episcopal Church, Glen Ridge. The Rev. Dr.

Spanish Inurgent officers declared today that Generalissimo Francisco Franco's attacks on the Albarracin front were being organized into an offensive designed to paralyze the whole system of Government communications east of Madrid.

The "League for a Woman for President and Other Public Offices" has compiled a list of ninety-five women in the five boroughs considered eligible to hold public office. The list was sent yesterday as a "challenge" to all political parties in the city.

The action of the wheat market of late has been most unsatisfactory from the standpoint of the speculator who looks for higher prices. From a low level of $1.06 1/4 a bushel on June 21, the September delivery advanced to $1.29 3/4 on July 16, the highest level of the season, largely as the result of enthusiastic speculative buying based on sensationally bullish crop damage reports from the Northwest, both United States and Canadian.
James Ransom Walker, retired real estate broker of Chicago, died this afternoon of a hemorrhage at his Summer home, Fair Acres, Prospect Hill. He was 72 years old.
Dick Corroon's short thrust for a goal

Holland's foreign trade is increasing sharply, imports in June amounting to 140,000,000 guilders, against 125,000,000 in the preceding month and 77,000,000 in June of last year.' Exports were worth 95,000,000 guilders in June, 90,000,000 in the preceding month and 53,000,000 in June, 1936.

Mystery surrounded the collision early today of the Belgian steamer Princesse Marie Jose and the British freighter Clan Macneil in the English Channel off this port. Although the weather was clear, the vessels came together with such force that the Belgian ship began to sink immediately, and none of the 709 passengers rescued from her could account for the accident.

The Dodgers lost to the Reds in the first game of today's double-header, 6-4, with misplays in the eighth inning, and then escaped defeat in the second only because the contest was called at the end of the tenth on account of darkness, with the score tied at 1-all.

State Department heads have been invited to a conference Wednesday with the Temporary Salary Standardization Board, recently named by Governor Lehman. On Aug. 23 representatives of State employes will be heard.

A man accused by a 13-year-old girl of accosting her on Wyckoff Avenue near Himrod Street, about two blocks from the scene of the slaying of 8-year-old Paula Magagna, was arrested by the crew of a police radio patrol car at 11 o'clock last night after he had been surrounded by a group of fifty residents of the neighborhood.

For the third successive year, Glen Cove Sea Scouts of the ship Barracuda won the fourth annual regatta of the Nassau County Sea Scouts, this afternoon at the HIempstead Harbor Yacht Club at Garvie's Point.

Nordland, the German-American Bund camp, in the Sussex County hills near here, which has brought protests from anti-Nazi members of Congress and military organizations, will have a protest day" of its own Sept. 5,

Jack Smith of Columbus, O., won today the national Amateur Athletic Union junior highboard diving championship. Smith scored 124.54, more than three points higher than his nearest rival, Paul R. Hines of the Lakeside A. C. -in Louisville, Ky., who had 121.13. Sol Schrebnick of the St. George Dragon Club, Brooklyn, was third with 116.57 points.

Governor George D. Aiken today charged that the Federal Government, in a policy he said was shown on a proposed interstate flood control compact for the Connecticut River, seeks to dominate the "people of every State through the control of every dollar's worth of national resources within those States."

This city's police force, which will yield to none in its ability to enforce law and order, found itself. ii somewhat of an embarrassing position today as the city ordinance which closes grocery stores on Sunday between 1 P. M. and midnight--but permits I delicatessen stores to remain open went into effect for the first time.

Discovery of a dented steel plate on one rail spurred an investigation tonight of a possible plot to wreck the Diplomat, fast Baltimore Ohio passenger train which was derailed near here late in the day.

The first invitation regatta held by the Narrasketuck Yacht Club of Amityville since joining the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association was sailed over the course of the club today under divers weather conditions.
Miss Annie Horniman, who, after what she called "fruitful failure" in London, successfully carried on repertory theatres in Dublin and Manchester. died on Friday at the age of 76.
The Coast Guard cutter Algonquin today took in tow the crippled four-masted schooner Herbert L. Rawding, 120 miles east of Cape Cod, food and water to her steamed for Vineyard Haven Vineyard Haven.

Addressing a crowd of nearly 10,000 persons at Lake Ariel today in celebration of Lackawanna' County's annual Irish Day, Grover A. Whalen of New York paid tribute to the achievements of Ireland's sons and daughters in America.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alling Prudden Beardsley of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Blackstock Beardsley, to Buckley Crist, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harris M. Crist of New York and Vineyard Haven, Mass.

Terrific northwest gales, first encountered on the morning of July 30 off the coast of Baffinland, have blown the General A. W. Greely, carrying the MacGregor Arctic Expedition, over to the coast of Greenland.
Glenn Stufflebeam, organizer for the Progressive Miners of America, was shot and killed early today while driving his automobile in the northern section of the city.

A few days before departing temporarily from Spain the writer was received at Valencia by President Manuel Azafia and had with him a friendly conversation on various aspects of the Spanish problem, some parts of which the writer is permitted to publish.

With Vincent Leary and John Hanlon leading the attack behind Dempsey's effective hurling, the New York Athletic Club baseball team downed the Hoboken Club, 4-0, on the Winged Footers' diamond at Travers Island yesterday.

A BRITISH officer, Major Geoffrey McNeillMoss, writes of "The Siege of Alcazar" (Knopf, $3.50) with the professional enthusiam, though with little of the essential detachment, of a visiting surgeon who has viewed a delicate brain operation that was successful despite a series of desperate complications and obstacles.

Surrounded by American flags and banners bearing the swastika, Ernest E. Hausamann, head of the United German Societies of North Hudson, told members of the Plattdeutsche Volkfest Verein of New York today that a tremendous feeling against the German people had been created in the United States
Tsune-chi Yu, Chinese Consul General in New York, declared yesterday in a radio talk from Station WABC on the "Conflict in China" that it is Japan's "current undedared war."

Twenty-eight sailors were rescued today from the Greek freighter Nereus, stranded in fog on the rocky coast of Vancouver Island, but the captain and five other officers elected to remain aboard. Salvage vessels were steaming to aid the freighter.

Dr. Fernando de los Rios, Spanish Ambassador to the United States, is to be the speaker at a Spanish fiesta Saturday on the estate of Adolph Zukor, about a mile north of New City here, under the auspices of the Rockland County Spanish Milk Fund.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the . public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,669,268,400. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:
Albert E. Ehler, president of the State Restaurant Liquor Dealers Association, died at St. Elizabeth's Hospital Saturday following a brief illness. He was 52 years old.
Government experts said today that the Sino-Japanese conflict had caused uncertainty about the future of American trade aggregating nearly $500,000,000 yearly.

The Women's City Club condemned yesterday the Lyons-Sullivan County Reform Bills now before the Municipal Assembly as a political gesture and an act of defiance to the electorate. This stand was taken in a letter sent to all members of the Board of Estimate and the Board of Alderman.

Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Holmsen gave a luncheon today at Stoneacre. Mrs. Casimir De Rham and Mrs. Dudley Davis also gave large luncheon parties and Mrs. James Laurens Van Alen had luncheon guests at Wakehurst.

Roulette croupiers at the Promenade Casino are on a sit-down strike out of sympathy with fifteen fellow-workers whom the management decided to lay off temporarily owing to seasonal slackness in the roulette business.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 91.8, which compares with 92.3 a week before, 92.3 two weeks before, 92.5 three weeks before and 92.9 four weeks before.

Making his first tournament appearance since his return as a member of the victorious Davis Cup team a few days ago, Frank Parker, seeded No. 1, began his quest for the Eastern turf court tennis crown with an opening-round triumph at the Westchester Country Club courts today.
Northern New York dairymen began the second week of their boycott of the Sheffield Condensed Milk Company today with the declaration that they were "prepared to hold out indefinitely."

Brookhaven, a gray gelding owned by Mrs. Samuel C. Register of Glen Cove and jumped by John Maloney, was awarded the hunter championship today in the final competition of the fourth annual Brookhaven Horse Show, held on the C. Oliver Wellington estate in this town.

The Shrewsbury Polo Quartet defeated a Monmouth County Country Club team today on Shrewsbury Field, 5 to 2. Shrewsbury held the Monmouth riders scoreless in all but the fourth period, when Allison Stern tallied twice.

The Federal Trade Commission has announced that Frank L. Miller and Alfred C. Schmidt, trading as Artist and Models Studio, Memphis, Tenn., engaged in the sale of art studies and a correspondence course in art, have stipulated to discontinue using "false and misleading advertising."

One of the best quality oats crops in recent years is believed to have been obtained this season, and virtually all of the receipts grading No. 3 or better, with an average test weight of more than 39 pounds a bushel, making them decidedly desirable from a milling standpoint.

Germany's official return on "concern constructions," by which is meant the capital participation of one corporation in another, shows that the United States comes first among nations holding capital in German enterprises.

The French liner Normandie set a new record for a transatlantic crossing when she passed Bishop's Rock at 3:43 P. M. (New York time) today, having made the trip from Ambrose Light in 94 hours 7 minutes.

Thomas E. Dewey, rackets prosecutor, continued firm yesterday in his apparent determination not to run for District Attorney of New York County on the Fusion ticket. Strong efforts were being made to get him to reconsider, and hope was expressed by those seeking to persuade him that he finally would consent to run as a matter of publie duty.

Colin Ross, German journalist, who has been serving up American observations to newspaper readers here lately, predicts that John L. Lewis will succeed in establishing a workers' and farmers' party and seek the Presidency.

The women's service committee of the American Chemical Society announced yesterday the award of three. graduate scholarships in chemistry. totaling $1,200. They were provided by. Francis P. Garvan, president of the Chemical Foundation of New York.

As a result of the owner's refusal to sign a collective contract with workers and to pay them $90,000 in back wages claimed to be due, President Lazaro Cardenas has ordered the confiscation of a small local railroad operating between three points in the State of Mexico.

The expansion shown in the Reichsbank's return for the last week in July, while due in part to seasonal causes, is attributable mainly to the unloading of bills on the Reichsbank by the Gold Discount Bank, which needed cash for the redemption of its promissory notes.

That topical musical comedy which Norman Bel Geddes has said he expects to produce this season is apparently intended to be quite a novel affair. "Sing Out the News" will be its title, and it will be written (and staged) in journalistic terms by a veritable staff of authors, including Edward Byron, Nancy Hamilton, Harold J. Rome, Michael Tegner, Madelaine Mendelsohn and Mr. Geddes himself.

An offering of 140,000 common shares of Basic Dolomite, Inc., of Cleveland will be made today at $12.50 a share by Hallgarten Co., associated with Otis Co.; A. G. Becker Co., Inc.; Curtiss, House Co. and Bull Eldredge.

Activity on the Berlin Boerse in the week just ended was dull, with sagging prices. Trading was marked with no feature save the move in banking corporation securities induced by the return to private hands of the shares of the Dresdner Bank and the Commerz und Privat Bank, plus the repatriation of the Handelsgesellschaft, acquired by United States interests in 1931.

Ever since the present Administration came into power efforts have been made to secure Congressional legislation which would mitigate the cruel hardships attendant upon the deportation of aliens whose children or other close or dependent relatives are American citizens.

Mr. and Mrs. Fulton Cutting gave a supper party tonight at A-WeelY-Moor, their place on the ocean, for Mr. and Mrs. Harold Stirling Vanderbilt, who arrived here last night on their yacht, Vara, from Newport. Earlier in the day Mr.

Roy Avery porter Jr., 11-year-old farmer, regarded his bumper crop of yellow globe. onions today and pondered on marketing problems. Young Porter, son of the chairman of the State Soil Conservation Commission, said he expected. to clear between $50 to $70.
Tass (Russian news agency) said today the secretary of the Japanese Embassy at Peiping had expressed regret for the recent raid upon the Soviet consulate in Tientsin by White Russians.

Seven hundred and fifteen law students passed the State bar examinations in June, the State Board of Bar Examiners, composed of John Kirkland Clark of New York, Philip J. Wickser of Buffalo and Rollin B. Sanford of Albany, announced tonight. A total of 1,372 took the examination.

This South Berkshire town was a center of entertainments for Berkshire Music Festival visitors over the week-end. At Aston Magna Mrs. Albert Spalding gave a luncheon today in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Fisher Jr. of Westover, Va., and Mr. and Mrs. Olin Downes, who are spending a few days with her and Mr. Spalding. Among others in the company were Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence White and Dr. and Mrs. Warfield T. Longcope.

The Maritime Commission's ambitious plans to restore to the United States some part of that sea supremacy which vanished with the clippers are taking shape in blueprint form, according to the latest announcement from Washington.

Dr. A. V. Williams Jackson, Professor Emeritus of Indo -Iranian Languages at Columbia and one of the four or five leading scholars of the world in his field, died of heart disease yesterday morning in his apartment at 600 West 116th Street. He was in his seventy-sixth year.
President Roosevelt talked today with Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State of New York and Democratic leader of: the Bronx, and it was assumed that the New York Mayoralty race came up for discussion.

The Detroit Tigers made it three out of four over Washington today in a game halted by rain after five innings. The score was 5 to 1. Cletus Poffenberger rewarded Williamsport (Md.) fans, who came to present a gift to him, by outpitching Jimmy DeShong.

Accused of slashing and slightly wounding a conductor on the Independent Subway, a man who described himself as Robert Keehan, 22 years old, of 306 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, was booked on a charge of felonious assault yesterday at the Wadsworth Avenue police station.
William H. Tuck, the controller for twenty years of the Ludlum Steel Company, died here today after a year's illness. He was 70 years old.

" The Jewish people's answer to Britain must be not 'yea' or 'nay,' but 'non possumus'-we cannot," Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, president of the Zionist Organization of America, told the World Zionist Congress here tonight in his losing fight against Dr. Chaim Weizmann's Palestine partition policy.

The musical comedy "Of Thee I Sing," music by George Gershwin, begins a week's run tonight at Jones Beach Stadium, in a production by Fortune Gallo and J. J. Shubert. The cast includes Vivienne Segal, Jack Sheehan, John Cherry, Diana Gaylen, Douglas Leavitt, Demetrios Vilan, Harry K. Morton, Truman Gaige, Dave Jones, Lee Kohlmar and Frederick Mannett.
Armand Tokatyan, tenor of the Metropolitan Opera Association, opened the fourth season of White Mountain music festivals in the Chase Barn Playhouse here this afternoon.

Dr. Francis Charles L. Schreiner, for fifty-six years a member of the faculty of Seton Hall College, South Orange, and for fifty-eight years organist at St. John's Church here, died last night in Orange Memorial Hospital, where he had undergone an abdominal operation. He was 76 years old.

Honors in the fourth annual show of the Wyoming Valley Kennel Club at the 109th Field Artillery Armory today went to Mrs. Henry A. Ross's Nonquitt Notable. The champion cocker spaniel was judged best among 500 dogs.

Lou Whitman's Aloha, in Class A, Wallace Harvenak's Knee Deep in Class B, and Al Thomas's Slats, in Class C, annexed the Atlantic Coast canoe-sailing titles on Jamaica Bay yesterday in a regatta conducted by the Associated Canoe Clubs of Sheepshead Bay.
Miss Judith Freda Chausmer, daughter of Mrs. Bella E. Chausmer of Newark, was married tonight to the Rev. Irving H. Perlman of Newark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Perlman of Chicago.

After declining to levels lower than those in more than a year, cotton prices made fair advances last week. On the New York Cotton Exchange, prices for futures moved about 40 to 45 points, but net changes for the week were 8 points down to 7 points up.

Some women apparently can keep se-crets better than men, at least in Congress. Chairman Mary T. Norton of the House Labor Committee kept a tight-lipped silence all last week on the committee's treatment of the Wages and Hours Bill.

The French general wholesale price index on July 31 was 579, against 576 on July 24. The native product index was 584, against 583; the import products index 570, against 563; the food index 556, against 558, and industrial materials 601, against '593.

The South Shore Polo team, unbeaten in the Long Island League, conquered the Squadron C Yellows, 6-2, today at the Woodbury Avenue Field. The victory marked the third in as many tournament starts for the Cedarhurst four. Arthur Kaye and Bernie Blausen led the attack, each with two goals.

Esperanto enthusiasts of thirty countries gathered in Warsaw today to celebrate the jubilee of the international language. It is fifty years since Dr. L. L. Zamenhof, a Warsaw oculist, published the first Esperanto grammar here and the jubilee is being celebrated on the occasion of the twenty-ninth World Esperanto Congress under the patronage of President Ignaz Moscicki and the Polish Government. Louis Dormont of Brooklyn heads a strong American delegation of thirty members.

Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia plans to attend the meeting of the League of Nations Assembly in September to protest against recognition of the Itallian conquest, it was reported in diplomatic quarters tonight.

People who go to Coney Island Land similar beach resorts to escape the "sordid commercialism" of the city must face the same commercialism in the resort areas, the Rev. C. Norman Hogle said yesterday in a sermon at the Broadway Temple Methodist Church, 174th Street and Broadway. Mr. Hogle is pastor of the Park Methodist Church of Brooklyn.
The Japanese army impressively took Peiping under its protection today. The former capital of China became for all practical purposes a Japanese city.

Insurance in force of the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia increased $1,771,000 in July to $955,909,000, according to Franklin C. Morss, manager of agencies. New paid insurance amounted to $6,409,000 last month, an increase of $939,000, or 17.2 per cent, from July, 1936.

The new Holy Cross parish playground on West Forty-third Strfet, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, will be opened with formal exercises at noon on Aug. 17, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Joseph A. MdcCaffrey, pastor of Holy Cross Church, 333 West Fortysecond Street, which acquired the site and is installing the equipment.

Speculative interest in the grain markets last week was about on a par with that of the preceding week, aggregating 343,100,000 bushels of all grains, but the total was almost nearly 142,000,000 less than in the same period in 1936, when the markets were boiling as the result of sensational reports of damage to the prospective crops.

Christianity will bring a true appreciation of the need for individual responsibility in every man and woman to better the conditions in the world, the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

With the adoption of three white persons into the United Indian Tribes of the Americas as fullblood brothers the two-day Indian powwow here on the grounds of the Shinnecock Indian Reservation, about two miles west of Southampton Village, came to a close today.

Lord Tweedsmuir descended a mine shaft here, 500 feet below the ground and beneath a hill where the vice-regal standard flew before a little cottage where the Governor General is billeted, during his visit today to the Great Bear Lake radium and silver country.

Both Sir John Simon, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, and the Archbishop of York have expressed regret to Bishop William H. Heard, 87-year-old American Negro, who was reported to have been asked to move from a hotel in Edinburgh, where he is attending the World Conference on Faith and Order.
Mme. Sun Yat-sen, widow of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, Chinese Nationalist leader, expressed the opinion in an interview today that war with Japan was virtually certain.

Funeral services for Edmund Lester Pearson, noted crime writer and librarian who died at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center from bronchial pneumonia early yesterday morning, will be held at his birthplace, Newburyport, Mass., tomorrow.

Philip H. Fleck, water commissioner of Ossining and a former village trustee and a well-known figure in the political, business and fraternal life of Ossining, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 68.

Supported by resolutions signed by officials of eight Hudson County municipalities, Charles Herschenstein of Jersey City, assistant corportion counsel, will go to Washington tomorrow to apply to the Interstate Commerce Commission for a public hearing on the 10-cent tube rate announced recently by the the Hudson Manhattan Railroad between downtown Manhattan and points in Hudson County.
The Petroleum Industry Exhibition Inc. has been organized to present an institutional exhibit at the World's Fair, it was announced yesterday. Thirteen American oil companies will participate.

Confirmation was obtained here today of the fact that an executive of one of Britain's largest firms of shipbreakers is arriving in New York aboard the Queen Mary tomorrow to bid on several American ships about to be junked, including, possibly, the Leviathan.

The renewed confidence in the security markets that first became definitely manifest early in July is being maintained in a degree that has surprised many market observers, although it is conceded that there are good reasons for changed sentiment and development of activity at a time when, because of the holidays, public interest usually falls to the year's lowest level.

Concern is being felt here about the Bermuda cedars which are currently being attacked by a disease called "hichs." The cedars are one of about sixteen indigenous trees and plants that were extensively used in building sailing vessels in the days when Bermuda commanded practically the entire North Atlantic trade.

Steve O'Neill's Indians stopped the Yankee home-run barrage yesterday, crushing Lou Gehrig's ambition to tie Babe Ruth's mark of seven in five games, and upsetting the possibility of the McCarthymen equalling an American League mark by hitting one or more roundtrippers in eleven consecutive games after they had banged a total of nineteen in ten straight skirmishes.

A politically separated world may be united through the pull of a common spiritual ideal like Christianity, the Rev. Dr. Roland H. Bainton of Yale Divinity School declared in a sermon yesterday at the Broadway Tabernacle Congrenational Church, at Fifty-sixth Street.

M. J. Shiner, 51 years old, and his wife, Zian Shiner, 45, of Dallas, Pa., were killed and four others were injured, one seriously, in a collision between two cars operated by Joseph Shiner, 24, and Milton Howard, 31, of 15 West Holly Street, Cranford, at Route 29 and Mountain Avenue, Mountainside, early today.

Five persons were killed and three critically injured tonight in a head-on automobile collision eleven miles north of this city. The dead, identified by Coroner Thomas A. Cox, were: Gilbert Young, about 45, of Washington, D. C.
Former Premier Francisco Largo Caballero has taken an attitude strongly critical of the Spanish Government's conduct of the civil war, the newspaper Independent of Perpignan, France, said today.

Due to uncertain weather conditions last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Willem van Hoogstraten, was given in the Great Hall of City College. 'An audience of 2,000 attended.
Four firemen were injured early today when a blaze of suspicious origin wrecked the two-story frame building of the Samuel Argush Embroidery Company factory at 91416 Twenty-first Street.

Money market conditions have been easier since the month-end settlement. In the last week money scarcity compelled many holders of sterling and dollars, both in cash and for forward delivery, to sell part of their commitments. These sales contributed to strengthen the franc, while easing the money market.

E. L. Cord and several of his associates announced today their resignations as members of the board of directors of the Cord Corporation, the holding company which Mr. Cord built up to control automobile, aviation and other interests.

Two New York teams won their way into the finals of thelinockout team-of-four championship of the American Bridge League here today and will meet in the forty-eightboard final match to determine the championship here tomorrow.

This city received a further eighteenhour respite tonight from a threatened tie-up of its taxicab system. Union drivers employed by the Yellow Cab Company voted to extend their truce for negotiations of a new employes' contract until 6 P. M. tomorrow, but coupled their action with a warning that a citywide strike for their original demands would be called if the cab management meanwhile failed to meet the terms of a compromise offer.
The British destroyer Thracian arrived here with eight survivors of a wrecked China National Aviation Company airliner that had been forced down on the sea eighty-five miles from Hong Kong.

The third concert of the current Wagnerian series of the Federal Music Project was presented before a large audience last night at the WPA Theatre of Music. On this occasion the Federal Symphony Orchestra, under Eugene Plotnikoff, was assisted by Gina Pinnera and Ruth Peter, sopranos;

Generation of electric power is not distinguishable from its transmission and distribution when generating facilities are connected to transmission lines that extend across State borders, the National Labor Relations Board ruled today on the question of its jurisdiction over employes of the Appalachian Electric Power Company of Glen Lyn, Va.

The international executive board of the American Newspaper Guild announced yesterday that it had ordered a referendum on seven decisions of the recent St. Louis convention of the Guild, including affiliation with the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Ideal sailing conditions marked the first day's program of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's twenty-second annual race week cruise which started today and will continue at five other ports, ending Saturday.

The Rev. Frederick Stirling Griffin, rector of St. Saviour's Episcopal Church, Fifty-eighth Street and Fifty-seventh Road, Maspeth, Queens, died yesterday in St. John's Hospital. Brooklyn, after being treated there as a patient for fifteen months. His age was 81.

Counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission succeeded yesterday in getting into the record of the hearing of the Austin Silver Mining Company case testimony that sales and deliveries of the company's stock were made at prices below those quoted on the New York Curb Exchange.

Both Great Britain and France protested today to the Spanish Insurgent Generalissimo, Francisco Franco, against attacks on the British tanker British Corporal and the French cargo vessel Djebel Amour last Friday off the coast of Algeria.

A Central Reserve Bank for Brazil is now as good as an accomplished fact, and the Government soon will introduce in the House a bill creating the organization, Minister of Finance Souza Costa said today on resuming the post after a trip to the United States.

Guatemalan soldiers shot Generals Justo Umana and Miguel Angel Zapata, both Honduran leaders of the opposition to President Tiburcio Carias Andino, last Tuesday on the outskirts of Guatemala City, according to reports brought here.

Verdi's "La Traviata" will be presented the opening night of the New York Hippodrome Opera Company's fifth season on Aug. 27. The same composer's "Aida" and "Rigoletto" will follow on the nights of Aug. 28 and. 29.

An appeal to Jeremiah T. Mahoney and Senator Royal S. Copeland, candidates for the Democratic Mayoralty nomination, to repudiate the action of the Democratic organization in Manhattan in failing to designate Municipal Court Justice David C. Lewis for renomination was made yesterday by Samuel K. Maccabee, chairman of the Civic Policy Association. He urged both Mayoralty aspirants to come out in favor of Justice Lewis's renomination.

Spanish Rebel soldiers boarded the French steamer Marechal Lyautey today at Las Palmas, Canary Islands, and removed three Spanish passengers. The French ship, bound from Dakar, Senegal, to her home port, Marseilles, took the Spaniards on with other passengers at Las Palmas. When she started to leave,

Five Hudson County municipalities joined with Jersey City today in filing Protests with the. Interstate Commerce Commission against the increase from 6 to 10 cents of fares on the Hudson and Manhattan tubes between Jersey City and Hoboken and Cortlandt Street, New York.
Japanese military and diplomatic officials here continue most pessimistic concerning any diplomatic negotiations which might permit a peaceful settlement of the Sino-Japanese sitiiation.

John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, made public today a letter he had written to William S. Menden, president of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation. According to Mr. Lewis, Mr. Menden had requested him to state his position on the corporation's relations with its employe representation plan.

Miss Stella Jackson Condon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Grattan Condon of 15 West Sixty-seventh Street, was married yesterday afternoon in St. Stephen's Church, 122 West Sixty-ninth Street, to Floyd Dwight Rodgers Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Floyd D. Rodgers of Columbia, S. C.

The current hesitancy among retailers on Fall buying is bringing forth an increasing number of predictions that many stores will find themselves "caught short" later in the year and that deliveries will become jammed when these stores try to catch up.

Mrs. Dorothy Ryder, 22 years old, of West Haverstraw, and Miss Louise Blake, 22, of Haverstraw, were killed and two sailors, who apparently had hitched a ride with them, were critically injured here early this afternoon when the automobile in which the four were riding swerved off New York State Highway 9W and struck a tree.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Isabel Piedra, daughter of Mrs. Pedro N. Piedra of New York and the late Mr. Piedra, to Dr. Arthur M. Faris, son of Mr. and Mrs. I. M. Faris of Houston, Texas.

Among the leases for residential space reported by brokers yesterday was one taken by Carlos Davila, former Chilean Ambassador to the United States and now connected with the Editors Press Service, on an apartment in 106 East Eightyfifth Street. Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc., negotiated the lease, Details of other rentals follow:

Statistics made public yesterday by Fifth Deputy Police Commis sioner Martin H. Meaney showed decreases in automobile accidents, deaths and injuries for last week, last week-end and last month, as compared with the corresponding periods in 1936.

Charles Romano, actor, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 29 West Tenth Street. He was 38 years old. Until late Sunday night he had rehearsed for his part as Captain Somerset in the forthcoming musical production, "Virginia," at the Centre Theatre.

Mayor La Guardia, before leaving the Summer City Hall in Queens last night to attend the George Gershwin memorial concert, took action to block profiteering by speculators in the tickets for the concert.

The report of Walter Powers as master, finding the trustees of the Old Colony Trust Associates were liable to the trust only in an amount, including interest, of somewhat more than $40,000 for losses by the trust, instead of being liable for about $2,000,000 damages to the trust, was sustained in findings, and an order for final decree handed down today by Judge Edward T. Broadhurst of the Superior Court.

The motor car industry swung back into a production program promising close to 100,000 assemblies this week with the reopening of the Plymouth division of the Chrysler Corporation, closed last week because of labor troubles, and the twoscore branch plants of the Ford Motor Company which had been closed for three weeks for inventory taking.

The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today the application of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railway Company to acquire the North Platte Valley Railroad and incorporate it in the Burlington system.
Neutrality in the city primary race was pledged by Roosevelt following reports that he would support Jeremiah T. Mahoney for Mayor. Page 1.

Malcolm S. Parcell, nationally known artist, who early in his career won the Saltus gold medal of the National Academy of Design for a portrait called "Miss Gallagher," today applied for a marriage license for himself and the subject of his picture. She is Miss Helen L. Gallagher, a teacher in Washington's Eighth Ward School.
Graduates at Princeton University this Spring carried away with them a total of eighty-nine varsity letters, the University Athletic Association reported today.

Larry Kelley of Yale will have an old team-mate from Peddie with him when the Eastern College AllStars play the New York Football Giants at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 8 under the direction of the New York Herald Tribune, with the Tribune Fresh Air Fund sharing in the proceeds.
The Japanese Army has driven out your wicked rulers. * * * Although Nanking is preparing to wage a destructive war, do not be afraid. The Japanese Army will protect you.

With a plea for the reorganization of schools and colleges of this country on "more democratic lines," Dr. William Heard Kilpatrick, Professor of Education at Teachers College, delivered a valedictory address last night before a gathering of more than 3,000 educators in the Columbia University gymnasium.
James Douglas Colman, former executive director of the Hospital . Service Plan of New Jersey, today was ap!pointed executive director of the new Associated Hospital Service of Baltimore.

Shirley Carter, chairman of the Virginia State Hospital Board, died at his home here last night. He was 79 years old. He was an officer or director of the Virginia Woolen Company, the Berkley Woolen Company, the National Fruit Produets Company, Inc., the Colonial Brick Corporation and the Northern Virginia Power Company. He was a founder in 1882 of the insurance firm of Hansbrough Carter.
Consolidated net earnings of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and its subsidiary companies for the six months ended on June 30 amounted to $8,068,352 after taxes, depreciation and interest,

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, charged yesterday that former Governor Alfred E. Smith, actuated by spite against President Roosevelt, was trying to turn over Tammany Hall to the Liberty League.
Formal recommendation for the passage of the Wages and Hours Bill, with fifty-nine suggested modifications, was filed with the House today by its Labor Committee.

A bill containing provisions to reduce interest rates on loans by the Home Owners Loan Corporation from 5 to 31/2per cent, and to extend the amortization period from fifteen to twenty years soon will be introduced in the House,

Observing his birthday, Joseph V. McKee, former Acting Mayor of New York, gave a supper last night in the cave grill at the Mount Washington. Miss Mildred Kadel of New York also celebrated her birthday at a supper for the younger set.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation on Aug. 1 had received repayment of $50,238,316 of principal of the original $90,000,000 loan made to the Central Republio Bank here shortly before it closed in 1932, Charles E. Albers, receiver, disclosed today. Interest amounting to $15,126,584 also has been paid.
Stock Exchange Stocks closed fractionally higher; turnover, 752,190 shares. United States Government and domestic bonds irregular; foreign issues slightly higher; transactions. $5,292,400.

Leading from start to finish and at the end making it a runaway race, Wise Mentor today demonstrated that he could overcome not only his opposition but also weight and a leg injury and still win handsomely.

Dr. Francis W. Shepherdson, national president of Beta Theta Pi fraternity, died tonight on a bus on his way from Newark, Ohio, to Columbus. The fraternal writer and organizer suffered a heart attack. His age was 76.

" Next year we will come to America every two weeks with new helium-inflated Zeppelins," Captain Max Pruss, commander of the airship Hindenburg, said yesterday as he planned to leave the New York Medical Center to return to his home in Germany.

The drive to end the present session of Congress not later than Aug. 21 was begun in earnest today. Although both Senate and House spent the day considering and passing upon minor matters, committees and conference groups pushed ahead with the remaining tasks before Congress,

The United States chess team encountered the Netherlands quartet, headed by Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, world champion, in the thirteent round of the international tournament tonight. Only one of the four games scheduled reached a decision. It was recorded as a draw at the third table between Frank IJ. Marshall, the American captain, land Scheltinga.

Sales of General Motors cars to dealers in the United States and Canada, together with shipments overseas, totaled 226,681 in July, the third best month of the year, comparing with 204,693 in July, 1936, and with 203.139 in June. April sales totaled 238,377 cars and in March a record of 260,965 cars was set.

Petitions designating Frederick F. Greenman for the nomination for Representative for the Seventeenth Congressional District to fill the vacancy created by the death of Theodore A. Peyser were circulated yesterday by the local Republican organization.

A charge that the Koppers United Company, a large coal corporation, "violated the spirit of the law" in its relationship with the Virginian Railroad brought a quick denial today at the Senate's rail inquiry.

Benjamin Kasseo, 22 years old, a WPA worker of 122 Ludlow Street, was arrested last night after he is alleged to have cut away fifteen feet of telephone cable while seeking lead to sell. Service to more than 200 telephones was disrupted in the vicinity of 124 Ludlow Street where he was caught. He was charged with burglary and grand larceny.

Miss Margaret Claire Weber, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Clarence Weber of this place, was married to Melvin Diem, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Diem of St. Louis, at the home of her parents here this afternoon.

Today brought the return of normal operations in this industrial center as 1,000 employes of two plants that were on strike were back to work and 3,000 workers of the Ford plant resumed work after the usual three weeks' Summer layoff.

The Pulitzer Prize winner of the season 1931-32, "Of Thee I Sing," the work of George S. Kaufman and Morrie Ryskind, lyrics by Ira Gershwin and music by the late George Gershwin, opened a week's engagement here tonight on the water stage on Zach's Bay before a near-capacity audience of 10,000.
The Textile Workers Organizing Committee of the C. I. O. struck the first blow of its campaign when 30,000 silk and rayon workers in several States walked out. Page 1.

Two C. I. O. organizers told the National Labor Relations Board today of "fear" among Republic Steel Corporation employes, and the board was told that the company had refused to sign an agreement with the leaders of an employee representative plan.

When two youths from Jacksonville, Fla., appeared in the Felony Court yesterday, charged with stripping an actor-playwright of his wearing apparel, even to his hat and shoes, in a hold-up before dawn in East Fifty-eighth Street, near Park Avenue, Magistrate Dreyer waxed indignant at the boldness of the crime.

Senator Royal S. Copeland, commenting today upon published reports that President Roosevelt favored the nomination of Jeremiah T. Mahoney in the New York Mayoralty race, attacked the President for his reported interference and asserted that the "Government is no longer democratic, but largely personal, dictated by the White House."

Among the passengers who arrived yesterday from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary were two British dealers in scrap metal. They are J. Napier, representing Metal Industries, Ltd., and J. Douglas, who declined to give the name of his firm.

The application of the PepsiCola Company for an order staying the examination before trial of the company's books and certain of its officers was denied yesterday in Brooklyn by Supreme Court Justice Peter P. Smith.

Three men under arrest on charges of, operating a still near Hammonton which exploded last Thursday, killing one man and injuring another, were held in $1,000 bail each today for a further. hearing Monday.

Stockholders of the A. B. See Elevator Company met yesterday afternoon at the Jersey City plant of the company and voted unanimously to dissolve the,corporation, founded fifty-four years ago by Alonzo B. See and now headed by Alva B. See, his son.

Manufacturers' sales of wallpaper in the coming year will run 10 per cent ahead of the 1929 volume of $30,000,000 and in two to three years will reach the record figure of $45,000,000 to $50,00,000, Walter L. Carver, secretary of the Wall Paper Institute, said yesterday at the formal opening of the industry's 1938 patterns at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The conedition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading A cities shows the following principal in changes for the week ended Aug. 4. at a An increase of $124,000,000 in loans and a decrease. of $38,000,000 in has holdings of United States
S. E. Stanford, chief of Fire Department at Crawley, Sussex, was embarrassed today when he learned that after driving fire engines for twenty-eight years he did not know how to drive.

With Congress planning next January to consider a general revision of the nation's taxing system, officials of the American Taxpayers League met in Chicago today to discuss ways in which the tax situation can best be brought to the attention of American citizens so that they can impress their views on their Congressmen.

The rolling gait usually associated with seafaring men betrayed Terrence (Terry) Roberts, 26-year-old ex-convict, to the crew of a radio patrol car early yesterday, an hour after he allegedly had shot and killed a man during a hold-up in a rooming house at 206 West Ninetyfifth Street.

Sterling Products, Inc., reported yesterday consolidated net earnings for the six months ended on June 30 of $5,172,680, after all charges, including normal Federal taxes. No provision, however, has been made for the surtax on undistributed profits.
