Charging that his wife, Mrs. Emeline Harriman Spencer, filed a series of suits in a "conspiracy" to embarrass him and malign his character, Howland Spencer of Newport and Palm Beach today filed suit for absolute divorce in Circuit Court here.

Mrs. Adolf Ladenburg, socially prominent New Yorker, died at 10:30 o'clock tonight at her country home here. With her when she died was her daughter, Mrs. Preston Davie, who hurried from Europe several weeks ago when her mother's illness became acute.

The acquisition of real estate and construction of a chemical plant near Mount Pleasant, Maury County, Tenn., will account for the use of $1,000,000 of the proceeds of the sale of 75,000 of the 696,000 shares of $5 par value stock of the Victor Chemical Works of Chicago,
Dr. H. H. Kung, China's Finance Minister, quietly completed today the second series of loan negotiations on his European tour to reorganize his nation's finances.

Eight naval officers and four civilians will be in charge of football at the Naval Academy this Fall under coaching staff assignments announced today by Commander Andrew C. McFall, graduate manager of athletics.

An audience of 20,223 people-the largest in the history of the Lewisohn Stadium concerts-thronged last night to the uptown amphitheatre to honor the memory of the late George Gershwin,. who, better than any composer living or dead, captured in sound a spirit and a tempo uniquely American.

Mayor La Guardia intervened yesterday in the strike of employee of the Horn Hardart Automats to the extent of warning them that they must not conduct their picketing in a manner interfering with pedestrian traffic.

With Selena Royle, Grant Mills, Wilette Kershaw and Charles Farrell heading the cast of forty players, John Haggart's latest play, "Reno," was given its premiere tonight by the Lakewood Players. "Reno" is the story of a gently bred woman forced to seek a divorce who falls in love and marries a cowboy, only to find she has not achieved happiness.

Answering Park Commissioner Moses' criticism of the Education Department for keeping closed "so many of the school recreational facilities" during the Summer, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, said last night that the school budget did not permit the operation of more than 386 supervised playgrounds now open.

Miss Marion Miley of Cincinnati, who scored triumphs in 1935 and 1936 as a Lexington (Ky.) lass, made an impressive start toward her third straight women's Western seventytwo-hole medal play golf derby today by clipping four strokes off par for the Onwentsia Club course with a brilliant 34, 42-76 round.

A lease on an entire floor at 114-16 East Sixteenth Street taken by the Review of Reviews Corporation, which recently took over The Literary Digest, featured the contracts for commercial space reported yesterday. The Cross Brown Company was the broker in the deal. Carstens, Linnekin Wilson, Inc., is the agent.

For thirty-seven years Drake's Restaurant at 119 W. Forty-second Street has been ready at any hour of the day or night to serve anything from apple fritters to boiled beef and horseradish. On its menu appears the boast of its proprietor, William Richters, that "Drake's Never Closes."

With a promise of recommendations for a general revision of the tax structure by November, Treasury officials went before the House Ways and Means Committee today to ask that loopholes in the present law be closed by legislation at this session of Congress.

Production of candy in the United States set a new all-time high record in 1936, when 2,054,000,000 pounds, with a value of $309,291,000, was manufactured, the Foodstuffs Division of the Commerce Department reported today.

In confident expectation that the Senate will follow the House in voting to grant him six new secretaries, the President is casting about for eligibles.- But being a practical man (except when he is beguiled by some new and peculiar idea), doubtless the President does not expect to find six who will live up to that passage in the Brownlow-GulickMerriam report, so remindful of a subdebutante's dream, which describes them.

In Ambassador Joachim von Ribbentrop's absence on leave, the German Charge d'Affaires, Dr. Ernst Woermann, called at the Foreign Office today to state the views of the German Government regarding the refusal of the Home Office authorities to renew the permits of three
Mayor La Guardia launched a new plan yesterday aimed at the elimination of sex crimes against children through the incarceration of convicted offenders whose sanity is in doubt.

In Texas, so it seems, you can't have a contest unless you call it a rodeo; even though it's the Gulf that does the bucking instead of a broncho. The three-day Lower Rio Grande Valley Fishing Rodeo, which closed Saturday, opened new possibilities for the big game fishermen of that State by producing a 325-pound blue marlin, reputed to be the first ever caught on the Gulf Coast.

A. F. of L. outdoor iron and steel erectors struck today against fortytwo North Jersey contractors in sympathy with an estimated 400 indoor employes of the contractors' fabricating plants who have been on strike for two weeks for wage increases, a closed shop and other benefits.

Despite the easing in imports into the United States of chemicals and related products during May and June, receipts during the first half. of 1937 were almost 42 per cent greater on a volume basis than for the corresponding period of 1936, and were only 20 per cent under the level recorded in the first half of 1929, the Chemical Division of the Commerce Department reported today.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to put in operation a short-term refinancing plan that would provide for a reduction in its $4,000,000, 3 per cent note to the Manufacturers Trust Company.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Gassaway Davis are coming from Sands Point, L. I., to spent next week-end with Mr. and Mrs. Dickson B. Potter. Mrs. Davis has entered several horses in the East Hampton Riding Club's horse show to take place next Saturdav.

The first sale of a part of the $9,052,000 loan for general construction purposes voted at the last session of the Maryland State Legislature will take place today when the State Treasurer at Annapolis will consider proposals for $3,408,000 State of Maryland 23/4 per cent bonds.

An official forecast of the largest American cotton crop in six years caused feverish activity in both houses of Congress and at the Department of Agriculture today and brought a concerted demand from cotton States Senators and Represent- atives that the Federal Government renew its commodity loan program to protect farmers from declining prices.

The Puerto Rico Distilling Company and the Distileria Serralles, the island's biggest rum makers, received permission today to intervene in a suit by the Bacardi Corporation of America for an injunction to prevent the Treasurer of Puerto Rico from enforcing liquor laws that the Bacardi company
Eight nations have approved, and two have rejected, a proposed interAmerican monetary conference, the Pan-American Union announced today.

The fifth world Boy Scout Jamboree closed at Vogelenzang this afternoon with 28,000 Scouts once more marching past Lord Baden-Powell, their Chief Scout. As on the opening day, contingents marched into the arena with their colors flying. Scouts from the United States. as usual, provoked adirztiin with their red Indians.

Kenneth MacLaren, 49 years old, head of MacLaren Company, Ltd., investment brokers in Toronto, surrendered to Acting District Attorney Hastings yesterday on an indictment returned on July 1 in the alleged theft of about $46,000 in 1933 and 1934 from the William von Bremen Company, Inc., formerly at 60 Broad Street, now defunct.

The international match race that has trotting circles completely agog-Greyhound vs. Muscletonemoved a step nearer completion yesterday when Giovanni Maiani, owner of the American-bred and European-trained Muscletone, arrived in New York on the North German Lloyd liner Europa.

The Illinois section of the Professional Golfers Association of America, at odds with the national organization's policies for a year or more, opened a campaign today to oust President George R. Jacobus of Ridgewood, N. J.

The Philadelphia Orchestra, conducted by Jose Iturbi, was cut off the air after thirty-five minutes of a seheduled one-hour broadcast from Robin Hood Dell tonight. The radio program was part of a benefit concert for the Musicians Relief Fund.

Still within sight of the pace-setting Cubs, the Giants will open a short home stand at the Polo Grounds today, faced with an excellent opportunity to improve their chances in the National League pennant struggle, which has reached the point where the Terrymen must come through now or virtually be counted out.

The brightest comet visible here since 1927, that strange wanderer of the sky discovered on July 5 by Dr. P. Finsler, Professor of Mathematics at the University of Zurich, is expected to reach its nearest point to the earth some time today.

Miss Frances Isabel Tomes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Austen Tomes of Brooklyn, N. Y., announced today that her wedding to Paul Sanford Lee Seward would take place. in the Stockbridge Congregational Church on the afternoon of Saturday, Sept. 18.

Having done his road work early in the morning, Shufflin' Joe Louis shuffled off for a picnic with some New Jersey State Troopers and gave his sparring partners a breathing spell. No boxing today. It was rest for the weary. For several brisk days the Dark Destroyer had them bobbing and bouncing around the ring like a canoe on a wind-whipped river.

Thefourteen-storyapartmenthouse on a plot 150 by 100.8 at 1,148 Avenue, southeast corner of Ninetysixth Street, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. The New York Life Insurance Company, plaintiff, bought in the structure for $200,000.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for altering several structures in Manhattan and Brooklyn. Architects also filed for several small homes in Queens.

The navy announced today that the scheduled cruise of the flagship cruiser Augusta of the Asiatic fleet and four destroyers to Japan had been "indefinitely postponed." The flagship and destroyers were scheduled to visit Japanese ports during the next two months.

A general increase in transportation fares in Paris went into effect today. Taxi drivers owning their own cars, who for the fourth time in a year have been forced to have their taximeters altered, protested. In other respects the capital accepted the change without much grumbling. Bus and subway fares rose 25 per cent.
Britain tested London's vulnerability to attack from the skies tonight with the greatest air-defense manoeuvres in her history.

Joseph B. Eastman, member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, said today that three safeguards which Congress had placed around the commission were threatened by the Robinson Government Reorganization Bill. The Senate Special Reorganization Committee was told that the threatened safeguards were:

Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. F. McCann of New York entertained with luncheon today aboard their yacht, Chalena, which arrived from Newport yesterday. Guests included Mrs. Harold A. Fitzgerald, Mr. and Mrs. E. T. Stotesbury, Mr. and Mrs. A. Atwater Kent, Mr. and Mrs. E. Victor Loew, Mr. and Mrs. William McNair, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bell Sweeney and Mr. and Mrs. De Forest Grant.

Norfolk St. 71, n w cor Broome St, 75x42: Max Wertheim and another to Wertheim Holding Corp, 305 Broadway ($10). 78th St, 131 W. 18x102.2; Vincent D. da, referee, to Mabel Castelberry. trix of Annie Huston, 210 W 101s St; foreclosure ($15). 2d Ave, 107-13, 90.1x100; Saul Birns Improvement Co, Moe D. Rabinowitz, vice president, to 111 2d Ave Corp,
A suit seeking an accounting from the trustees of the residuary estate of Henry C. Bohack and their removal was filed yesterday in Queens County Supreme Court.

Announcement has been made by Martie Schreiber of 336 West End Avenue and Marksville, La., of the engagement of his sister, Miss Naomi Schreiber, to Jack Spring, son of Mrs. Meyer Spring of 473 West End Avenue and the late Mr. Spring.

Governor Robert E. Quinn of Rhode Island returned yesterday in the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary with Mrs. Quinn after a month's motoring in England. He went abroad to represent his State at the dedication of the American monument at Montfauron inFrance. He said that Europe seemed to be improving economically. Though he declared himself to be a "great Roosevelt man," he said he would be opposed to a third term for any President.

Banging out a sensational 67, five under par, Don Erickson of Alhambra, Calif., led at the half-way mark today in 36-hole qualifying trials for the national public links golf championship. Erickson set a new record for the Harding Park course.
Peasants in the Bosnian town of Bjelina rioted against the Government after an Orthodox priest had incited them by a political speech at a church fair, a Government communique said today.

Edward Yardley of Montana, an attorney in the American agency of the General Claims Commission of the United States and Mexico, was appointed today chief clerk of the State Department and administrative assistant to Secretary Hull. He succeeds Clinton E. MacEachran, who has been appointed Consul General in Halifax.

Roger W. Babson, in an address as Moderator of the National Council of Congregational-Christian Churches, told a laymen's conference at Isle of Shoals, N. H., today that figures on Protestant church membership in the United States were incorrect and that Protestant church attendance had been falling off for many years.

Severe criticism of an amendment to the Wagner-Stegall Housing Bill restricting the cost of housing to $4,000 a family unit or $1,000 a room was expressed yesterday by the National Public Housing Conference in a letter to Representative Henry B. Stegall, co-sponsor of the bill.

After standing shame-faced before fellow-officers in the criminal lineup at Police Headquarters yesterday, Albert Chalmers, 34 years old, patrolman in Troop B of the city's mounted division, was held without bail by Magistrate Alexander Brough in Homicide Court for hearing on Friday on a charge of "suspicion of homicide."

Richard Llewellyn's "Poison Pen," which opened tonight at the Richmond Theatre, gives a fine study of the havoc wrought in a happy village by anonymous letters sent, as it turned out, by the rector's respected sister.

" Conquest," formerly "Marie Walewska," the Greta Garbo-Charles Boyer venture which was thought completed a. month ago after twenty weeks of shooting, was thrown onto the retake stage at Metro today with the probability that the film will be delayed a month.

Dan Galgano of Gedney Farm and his amateur partner; Fred Pagano of Amawalk, turned in a card of 31, 34-65 to tie Myles Coen and Ray L. Korndorfer of Scarsdale for first place in the best-ball event at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.

Violence burst anew today in Quebec's week-old province-wide strike of 10,000 workers of the Dominion Textile Company when pickets and sympathizers attempted to block truck shipments from the company's T. Henri plant.

Miss Ina Claire, the actress, is the buyer of the residence at 124 East Sixty-second Street, the sale of which was announced several weeks ago by Pease Elliman. The property is assessed at $39,000 and was bought by Miss Claire for occupancy, but this latter contingency is said to depend upon the signing of a Hollywood contract.

The available records for strikes within any comparable period in the history of American industry were broken in the first half of 1937, according to a report made public yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, on the basis of a study just completed by its special committee on industrial problems and relations.

The Government made plans today for additional commodity-control measures to meet the economic and financial burdens of the North China campaign and the adverse trade balance, which amounted to 720,000,000 yen at the end of July.

John Klein, 22-year-old shotmaker fromLancaster, Pa., turned in a 77 today to set the pace in the first eighteen-hole round of the Union Printers International Golf Association's fourteenth annual seventy-two-hole championship here.

The Bellicourt American Memorial was dedicated this morning in the presence of General John J. Pershing, Josephus Daniels, United States Ambassador to Mexico; Brig. Gen. J. B. P. Clayton Hill, Brig. Gen. Bernard Kearney, commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, and Congressman J. Walter Lambeth.

Miss Natalja Willard, daughter of the late Colonel and Mrs. Joseph H. Willard, was married to Captain James C. White, U. S. A., attached to the Twelfth Infantry at Washington, late this afternoon at Fairhaven, the Willard homestead here.

The Department of Agriculture estimated today that this year's cotton production would be 15,593,000 bales3,194,118 more than were grown in 1936. Production in 1936 was 12,398,882 bales. The ten-year-192736-average production was 13,200,857.
The international stock market indices for Aug. 7, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:
The Newark Bears increased their International League lead to twentyfive games today as they defeated the Montreal Royals, 11 to 1, behind four-hit pitching by young Joe Beggs.
The Los Angeles Examiner said tonight it has learned "nearly 20,000,000 gallons of aviation gasoline were contracted for here today for the Chinese Government."

Patronesses and members of the dance committee have been announced for a dance to be given Aug. 27 at the Beach Club, Belle Haven, for the benefit of the surgical and orthopedic ward of the Post-Graduate Hospital in New York.

The marriage of Mrs. Vera King Wagener Park, daughter of Mrs. Christian Wagener of Buffalo and the late Mr. Wagener, to Francis Gregory Curtin, son of Mrs. David Curtin of Syracuse and the late Mr. Curtin, took place here yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William J. Kenealy, associate rector.
Colonel Walter C. Babcock, U. S. A. retired, died here today at Walter Reed. General Hospital. He was born in Boston and would have been 65 years of age on Aug. 16.

The five-stry apartment house for forty-eight families at 1,161 Elder Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by the Pact Realty Corporation to Union Nidich Properties, Inc. It is on a plot 100 by 100 feet and was sold by Elroy-Clark Co., Inc., brokers, who have been appointed managing agents.

Old Babe, the zoo's ancient elephant, is dying and her best friend, Director William M. Mann, is in far-off Sumatra. "We all hope," said Ernest P. Walker, acting director, "that she lives until he gets back. They had quite an affection for one another."
The Vatican newspaper published today an address in which Pope Plus told 1,000 pilgrims including a large group of Americans, that newlyweds were the hope of society.

Miss Helen Pedersen of Stamford, runner-up for the women's title last year, was eliminated from the Eastern turf court tennis championships at the Westchester Country Club today and Frank Shields of Hollywood survived in the men's singles only after he, had stood within two strokes of defeat.

The bondholders' representative committee of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., headed by Joseph P. Ripley, mailed yesterday proxies to holders of registered first-mortgage bonds of the company,

Newcomb Carlton of New York, chairman of the board of Western Union, was on the witness stand several hours today as hearing of the complaint of the Seattle Telegraph Messengers Union against the company opened before Patrick H. McNally, trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board.

The Board of Elections prepared yesterday for today's last-minute rush.in the. filing of designating petitions for the primaries in which contesting slates are expected in several boroughs. The board offices, as the law required, will stay open until midnight tonight, which is the deadline for filing petitions.

After three years of negotiations during which time efforts were made to discontinue a foreclosure started in May, 1934, the fiveand-a-half-story walk-up apartment house for sixty-five families at 74-78 Post Avenue in the Dyckman section has been sold by the Albany

Ten thousand members of the International Longshoremen's Association in the five California locals were suspended from the California State Federation of Labor tonight due to their affiliation with the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Representative James W. Wadsworth of New York was appointed by Speaker Bankhead today to be a member of the New York World's Fair Commission, completing the Congressional membership on that organization. Others who will serve are Senators Robert F. Wagner, Royal S. Copeland and Frederick Hale, and Representatives Sam D. McReynolds of Tennessee and Matthew J. Merritt of New York.

Although the estimate by the Department of Agriculture of the probable production of cotton in the United States this year was about 500,000 bales more than the average of private estimates, the trade generally accepted as reasonably accurate the Government's forecast of 15,593,000 bales.
Fifty-two yearlings from the breeding farm of Willis Sharpe Kilmer passed through the sales ring tonight for $161,600, an average of about $3.107. It was one of the largest sales so far.
With delegation from twelve countries and observers from three others in attendance, the second Pan American Coffee Conference was inaugurated here tonight at the National Hotel.

Money in circulation in the United States on July 31 amounted to $6,460,099,147, or $49.92 per capita, the Treasury Department reported today. Both items were higher on July 31 than on June 30, circulation $12,966,505 up and the per capital 7 cents higher.

The suggestion of the six Republican members of the House Committee on Banking and Currency that the United States Government use its stock of monetary gold to retire part of the public debt and that the Treasury cease buying more gold until currencies have been "harmonized" through international agreement, was strongly criticized in Wall Street banking circles yesterday.

The Summer colony was well represented in the large audience that filled Rogers High School tonight to witness the presentation of the Gilbert and Sullivan opera "Pinafore," by the Swanhurst Choral Society, one of the activities of the Newport Art Association.

Mrs. Ruth Baker Pratt, former Republican Representative in Congress from New York, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa after spending a month abroad for her health. She said she did not know of any woman capable of being a candidate for President or for Mayor of New York City.

The Toronto Maple Leafs batted Leo Mangum, starting Jersey City pitcher, out of the box today to gain an early lead and coast to a 7-to-2 victory over the Jersey City Giants in the opener of a three-game series. Frank (Bots) Nekola, former Yankee hurler, who started for the Leafs, went the entire route, limiting the Jerseys to eight hits.

Strong opposition to the renewal of the Federal 12-cent loan to cotton growers, with the possibility that the loan may be linked to crop reduction, was voiced on behalf of exporters yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council.

Enactment of a city ordinance to prohibit the employment of hostesses by Newark taverns and to make it illegal for women to accept such employment was recommended this afternoon by Police Chief John F. Harris and Deputy Police Chief Philip Sebold.
Boston at New York-MacFayden vs. Schumacher. Pittsburgh at Chicago-Lucas vs. French. Brooklyn at Philadelphia-Henshaw vs. Walters. Cincinnati at St. Louis-Davis vs. Warneke.

Plans for a fifteen-story apartment house were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of 955 Fifth Avenue by the Thornton Realty Company to a builder. The property, a six-story dwelling on a plot 32.6 by 120 feet just south of East Seventy-seventh Street, is assessed at 340,000, including land and building, and was sold through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc.

Queens chose its representatives in the Park Department's city-wide harmonica contest at a borough elimination contest last night in the Jackson Heights Playground, Eighty-third Street and Thirty-firstAvenue.

Mrs. Louis Lombard, formerly of the Castle de Trevano at Lugano, Switzerland, was the honor guest at a reception this afternoon by Miss Anna W. Peck at her home here. Mrs. George Allen Holloway of New York and Mrs. Cornelius Boardman Tyler of Plainfield, N. J., poured tea and assisting were Miss Nancy Barker, Mrs. Norman Churchill Hull and Mrs. Thomas F. Plunkett of Pittsfield.

Several luncheons were given today for guests at various estates. Mrs. Archibald M. Brown gave one at the Studio, her home on the ocean, for Mrs. Duncan S. Ellsworth, Mrs. Cameron Clark, Mrs. Stevens Baird and Mrs. Brown Hale.

A plan of reorganization of the eighty-five-year-old Brown Company, one of the principal pulp and paper manufacturers of the United States, employing more than 7,500 persons in New Hampshire and Quebec, was filed yesterday in the Federal court in Portland, Me., by Orton B. Brown, vice president and treasurer.

Louis (Lepke) Buckhalter and Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, reputed terrorists of the garment manufacturing trade, New York City's largest industry, were indicted with fourteen others yesterday for conspiracy to extort money from clothing manufacturers.

An American Federation of Labor union today threatened contempt of court action to force the National Electric Products Corporation of Ambridge, Pa., to carry out a closed-shop contract signed with the union last May 27. The contract is disputed by a C. I. O. union before the National Labor Relations Board.
E. B. McGehee's Tinder Box today won the Brookline Purse, one-mile feature at the Suffolk Downs program, over a track made muddy by torrential rains.

Officers of the 602d and 607th Coast Artillery warned all ships today to clear a danger zone in the Atlantic Ocean off Sandy Hook tomorrow between the hours of 2 and 7 P. M., when firing practice with 12-inch railway mortars and 155-mm. guns will be held.

More than 500 persons, many of them prominent in financial and charitable circles and also members of the bench and public officials, attended funeral services for Darwin R. James, president of the East River Savings Bank and head of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities, who died Saturday at the Summer home of Charles F. Kingsley at Roanoke, L. I.

A British court turned a deaf ear today to the plea of an American girl two-time stowaway to "send me to jail but don't send me back to America-I hate America." The prosecutor, who described the girl as Elizabeth Schwartz of Chicago, said she stowed away on the liner California to marry an Englishman in answer to a matrimonial advertisement. Previously, he said.

Alfred M. Landon, Republican candidate for President last year, has turned to practical farming incidental to one of his enterprises. In Topeka newspapers this classified advertisement appears: "Dressed frys for sale. Landon."

Samuel Hurwitz, broker, has sold to investing clients the following mortgages on Manhattan properties: $27,000 on the two three-story dwellings at 319-21 W 27th St; $13,500, on the three-and-one-half-story brownstone house at 302 W 28th St; $22,000 on the five-story tenement at 2,376 Eighth Ave; $9,000 on the four-and-one-half-story house at 418 W 18th St, and $11,000 on the four-story house at 1,492 Fifth Ave.

An eight-family house at 963 Jefferson Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold for Frances Lipsky to Stanley Geminder through his office, Grattan MacMahon, broker, reported yesterday. The same broker also sold the vacant plot at the southwest corner of Bridge and.Talman Streets, to a client for cash above a first mortgage of $4,500. William Rohe was the seller.

Leicestershire defeated Hampshire by nine wickets in a county cricket match concluded today. Other matches will end tomorrow. The scores: Lelcestershire 404 and 32 for one; Hampshire 180 and 254 following on (Flamnson six for 61, McCorkell 50, Herman 91 not out), at Basingstoke.

After watching the steamship Manhattan of the United States Lines since last November a customs searching squad found twenty-two pounds of heroin, estimated to be worth more than $150,000 in the retail traffic, on board yesterday. Johann Murken, a steward, was arrested.

Paramount's "Souls at Sea," which had its premiere at the Globe last night, is not the sort of film which stands up under coldblooded analysis. Nor, probably, was it meant to bear it. A generously produced bit of make-believe, accenting action and a wide sweep of camera it is not to be confounded because its tale-spinning has left a fringe of loose ends or because its narrative fretwork is a mesh of crossed motivations.

Mr. and Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart gave a luncheon at the Gideon Putnam today for Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords, H. Teller Archibald and Walter M. Jeffords Jr. Mr. and Mrs. John R. Fell Jr. had as supper guests at Arrowhead Inn last night Mr. and Mrs. Thomas I. Laughlin.

Lady Gollan, wife of Sir Henry Cowper Gollan, arrived yesterday on the Europa and is at the Waldorf-Astoria before going to St. Louis, where she formerly resided. Colonel Morris E. Locke, U.S.A., (retired) and Mrs. Locke, who returned yesterday on the Queen Mary, are at the Plaza.

Bow To Me, one of the bargain horses of the year, scored his sixth consecutive victory at Lincoln Fields today. But it may have been Bow To Me's last, as the son of Epinard-Beginner's Luck pulled up lame in the front forefoot.

The giant seaplane Nordmeer will take off on the first of eight projected German North Atlantic survey flights at 6 A. M. Wednesday (midnight Tuesday, Eastern standard time), Lufthansa officials an-. nounced today.

The trial of the Rev. Martin Niemoeller, Protestant oppositional leader, which was to begin tomorrow, has been postponed until more evidence has been procured, it was announced today. Probably the severe defeat suffered by the Reich Church Ministry through the acquittal last Friday of the Rev. Dr. Friedrich Dibelius, another Confessional Church leader, made the postponement inevitable.
Simmering in the Summer heat of Washington, our Senators and Representatives are said to have developed a collective case

Dispatches from Sakhalin Island, off the Siberian coast, said today the Soviet Government had intervened to save the lives of girl quadruplets born to the wife of a worker, named Yashin, in the Sakhalin oil fields.

Although bound together by common interests and ties of international sisterhood, seventyfive American Girl Scouts and twenty-six foreign Girl Guides and Scouts had difficulty in conversing this afternoon when they met here at Camp Andree at the opening of their first international encampment in America, which marks the silver jubilee of Girl Scouting.

Wellman Ave (18-5387). n s, 128 ft e of Mayflower Ave, 33x9.5; Hyman Leff to Henry V. Alline, 2,871 Wellman Ave. White Plains Rd (14-3758). w s. 82 ft n of Watson Ave, 25x99: Valentine D. Wilder to Josephine M. Offinger, 97 Magnolia Ave, Mount Vernon, N. Y. 166th St (9-2437), s e cor of Morris Ave, 95x149; Lena Siegel to Frank Krakauer, 247 Wadsworth Ave; mtg $55,000.

After nine truck drivers had been fined $1 in Bay Ridge court yesterday, A. J. Portenar, director of the division of industrial relations of the State Labor Department, said further arrests would be made under Section 167 of the State Labor Law intended to prohibit more than ten hours' consecutive operation of a truck by one driver, or more than ten within any fourteen.

The pound sterling weakened slightly in foreign exchange yesterday following its advances of last week to the highest levels in eleven months. It fell to $4.98% and closed at $4.98 13-16, off ,1/2 cent.

Adolf Hitler's book "Mein Kampf, strictly banned in Austria for four years, appeared today in the windows of Vienna bookstores, in front of which large crowds gathered. The Government had ordered the customs to allow the book to pass, and several thousand persons awaited its distribution at the Vienna Custom House.

World industrial production, measured by the output of ten leading international trade countries, reached the highest level in history in the first half of this year, Norman J. Wall reported today in the monthly publication of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

Current indications for Spring wheat are the lowest in thirty years, the Dominion Crop Bureau report said today. The crop on July 31 was only 35 per cent of the long-time average yield to the acre, compared with 51 per cent on June 30 and 45 per cent on July 31, 1936.
A threatened strike of nearly 1,100 drivers of the Yellow Cab Company was averted today, four hours before the "deadline" set by the union for the completion of negotiations.

The Merchants Association Yesterday urged all New York members of Congress to support a bill spon- its scored by Representative E. A. Kenny which provides for an amendment to the Federal Motor Carrier Act to exempt motor truck operations within the metropolitan district from all provisions of the act other than those concerning safety.

The musical comedy "Gay Divorce" will open tonight at the Municipal Stadium at Randall's Island, continuing through Sunday, Aug. 15. Dorothy Stone and Charles Collins will head the cast; the Fokine Ballet will offer entr'acte selections. "Of Thee I Sing,"

The Appella Division of the New York Supreme Court has issued a stay restraining the New York Trust Company, trustee for National Public Service Corporation debentures from selling at auction 712,411 common shares of Jersey Central Power and Light Company, which is collateral securing the debentures.

Colonel William J. Crookston, executive secretary of the Medical Bureau to Aid Spanish Democracy, an organization extending medical aid to the Spanish Leftists, died of complications following an operation yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. le was 57 years old and lived at 35 East Thirtieth Street.

The Senate passed the bill creating an administration for the Bonneville Dam, a measure for liberalizing regulations governing pension payments to World War widows, and a substitute for the invalidated Municipal Bankruptcy Act and adjourned at 5:06 P. M. until noon tomorrow.

Franklin A. Schriver, former District Attorney of Orange County, found his wife's birthday today to be his good luck day, for, going to the tee on the 135-yard fifth hole of the Forest Hill Field Club, he sank his second shot for an ace in the first day's session of the sixth annual World-Telegram hole-in-one contest.
Abraham A. Wiener, an agent with the New York Life Insurance Company, who was prominent in Masonic circles, died yesterday at his residence, 601 West 168th Street, at the age of 52.

Included in the last foursome to finish, Joe Katz, Oceanside amateur, and Joe Phillips, Links Club pro, came in with a 32, 33-65 to tie Pete Variro and Ferdy Catropa of Peninsula, who had 34, 31-65, for' the honors in the Long Island Golf Association's one-day amateur-pro bestball event held over the Shelter Rock Country Club course today.

John David Biggers, president of the Libby-Owens-Ford Glass Company of Toledo, is understood to have been selected for appointment to the Federal Communications Commission, to succeed Anning S. Prall, the chairman, who died July 23.

Steel ingot production for the current week is scheduled at. 84.6 per cent of capacity, against 85.5 per cent last week, a decrease of .9 point or 1 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports. A month ago the rate was 82.7 per cent.

The estimate issued by the Department of Agriculture yesterday that current indications are for a cotton crop of 15,593,000 bales, against a final crop last year of 12,339,000 bales and an estimate a year ago of 12,481,000 bales, brought no immediate reaction in dry goods prices, but there were definite predictions that some prices would be lowered within the next week or more.

Renewing their supremacy in the contract bridge world, the Four Aces won the knockout team-offour championship of the American Bridge League as its annual Summer tournament came to a close this afternoon by crushing their opponents by 3,190 points. In the forty-eight-board final the Four Aces, consisting of Howard Schenken, David Burnstine and M. D. Maier of New York, Oswald Jacoby of Dallas, Texas,

The Treasury's weekly issue of 273-day bills sold today at an average interest rate of 0.478 per cent, compared with 0.467 per cent last week, and the companion issue of 129-day bills went at an average rate of 0.211 per cent, compared with 0.228 per cent last week, Acting Secretary of the Treasury Roswell Magill announced tonight.

With a record entry of ninety-three, the eighth annual New York State women's golf championship will get under way tomorrow morning at Onondaga. Miss Jean Bauer of Providence will not defend her title, but there are many strong contenders, with Syracuse's Miss Virginia Guilfoil one of the favorites.

The word "scandalous" is not too strong for the conditions which Park Commissioner Moses describes in his vigorous demand that school recreational facilities be thrown open during vacation periods for proper public uses. One of New York City's major problems is to get its children off the streets. The school authorities ought to be eager to cooperate in solving that problem, and in theory they probably are eager to do so.

Both china and glassware markets were active here yesterday as buyers for. retail stores continued filling requirements for next month's sales and for the late Fall. In the glassware market buying emphasis was on glass dinner sets in the lowerprice brackets and on highball, cocktail and water glasses.
Whether or not to shorten men's shirttails is a problem agitating serious-mind- ed textile experts of Germany. They want to save precious fiber to help in the Four-Year Plan.

The Independent Labor Federation of America announced as its purpose today: "To preserve the right of the American workingman to work without paying tribute to a racketeer and without fear of violence, coercion or intimidation."
A robbery and two burglaries involving theft of $3,500 in cash and an estimated $7,500 in business machine equipment were reported to police today.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Scythia, due today from Liverpool via Dublin and Galway, includes Dr. and Mrs. Lynn Stratton Abbott, W. Baliol Scott, R. H. Brand, Mrs. William T. Cooper, Prentice Cooper, Dr. and Mrs. Robert R. Hampton, Miss Grace M. Davis, Miss Emily Wheeler and William Brown.

FIRST GRADE DETECTIVE-Vincent F. 1215th During, from 18th Division, main office division, Brooklyn, to 108th Precinct, designation as first grade detective revoked. SECOND GRADE DETECTIVES-From 18th Division, 15th Detective District to precincts indicated, designation as second grade detectives revoked:
Trading in bonds on-the New York Stock Exchange produced yesterday a highly selective market and, with activity approximating the turnover of Friday, closing prices were irregular.

The release of two freighters of the American West African Line was effected yesterday afternoon when a temporary settlement of a libel action by the line against the crew of one of the ships was reached in Federal court in Brooklyn.

The marriage of Miss Winifred Francis Glenn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred Glenn of Rockville Center, and Ensign John Robert Middleton Jr., U. S. N., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. R. Middleton of Sebastian, Fla., took place at noon today in St. George's Episcopal Church here.

The Weizmann policy on the partition of Palestine took textual form today in the draft of a resolution submitted to the political resolutions committee of the World Zionist Congress here. This body, elected today, started what promises to be an all-night secret debate on this resolution, particularly on the last two and most crucial points, which read:

A moderate recession took place in automobile production last week, at a time when a sharp drop was seasonal, and the adjusted index has advanced to 119.3 from 104.9. It was 128.0 for the week ended Aug. 8, 1936.

The fourth attempt by officials of the Bike Web Manufacturing Company to reopen its strike-bound plant here failed today when 200 singing pickets recruited from other unions massed before the gates to prevent thirty non-union employes from entering.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes, depreciation and other charges, but before provisions for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

The picked team representing the New York and New Jersey Cricket Association arrived this morning on the Monarch of Bermuda and tomorrow will open a six-match tour against representative Bermuda teams. The final contest is listed for Aug. 20.

Japanese residents have been evacuated from Yangtze River ports in China with a thoroughness deemed unnecessary even when Japanese warships shelled Shanghai in 1932 or during the Manchurian fighting. The explanation officially offered here is that they are being withdrawn to avoid any risk of another Tungchow massacre, which, it is asserted, would immediately extend hostilities to the heart of China.

A tentative agreement to allow the resumption of immigration to New South Wales was reached today by the State and Cbmmonwealth Governments. First arrivals were expected before 1938, the Government announced. It was added that strenuous efforts would be made to avoid flooding the labor market and that migration from Southern Europe would be discouraged.

A heavy volume of business was reported in the export copper market yesterday at prices ranging from 14.70 to 14.825 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports. This compares with 14.70 to 14.80 cents on Saturday.

It is as a geneticist, past secretary of the National Research Council, and above all as a writer on evolution, that Dr. Vernon L. Kellogg will be remembered by scientists. To the rest of huvanity he was the great humanitarian, the passionate contender for world peace.

Nothing is likely to come from the protest of Republican members of the House Banking and Currency Committee against the Government's buyingup of imported gold with borrowed money and storing it in idleness. It is well enough to say that this "inactive gold" ought to be used for redemption of public debt.

The Consolidated Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries show a net profit of $9,434,917 for the first six months of this year, after interest, depreciation and depletion, provision for the normal Federal income tax and other charges, but before the surtax on undistributed profits.
The Merry Widow" plays a considerable role in the evening mode at Maggy Rouff's showing of her new collection. Princess dresses flare extravagantly below the knees.

Supreme Court Justice Albert Conway yesterday issued a temporary injunction in Brooklyn restraining members of Local 171, Hospital Employes Union of Greater New York, from calling a strike, picketing or interfering with the patients, the employes or visitors at the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn. He directed the hospital to post a $2,500 bond and prepare for an immediate trial after the answer was served.

The Interstate Commerce Commission has refused the application of trustees for the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company' to do away with the automatic train-control devices the road now uses and substitute for them an "absolutepermissive" block signal system using .three-position color light signals. The road now uses,

Taking command of the situation in the last few hundred yards on the leeward leg of a windward and leeward race, Charles Stetson and his Pequot Yacht Club crew of Robert Gordon and William Watkins took a step toward successful defense of the Long Island Sound junior sailing championship and the Pequot Cup in the first of a five-race series today.

Counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission contended at a hearing today that investors who put $15,000,000 into the American Utilities and General Corporation in 1929 wound up "without a nickel" in 1933.

The vanguard of the great crowd of light harness racing enthusiasts expected to descend on Good Time Park tomorrow and Wednesday for Greyhound's trial against the world record and the Hambletonian Stake, this afternoon enjoyed the first day's competition in the annual Grand Circuit meeting at the mile track.

Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn awarded $1,423,632 yesterday to the owners of eighty-three acres of land to be used as a parking area near the World's Fair site in Flushing Meadow Park.

Senator Harrison, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said tonight that he would discuss with President Roosevelt tomorrow a plan for a compromise settlement of the dispute over limitation in the Sugar Control Bill of refined sugar shipments from Hawaii, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.

Nothing much going on in town for the moment, the Federal Theatre has ferried one over from New Jersey, "The Trial of Dr. Beck," which was put on at the Maxine Elliott last evening. It is what the cynical book trade terms a "whodunnit," written by Hughes Allison, a Negro playwright, and acted by a New Jersey Federal Theatre company under Louis M. Simon's direction.

Lawrence Marks, 49 years old, twice convicted of offenses against children and who was released from prison on court order less than two months ago, pleaded not guilty to first-degree murder before County Judge Peter J. Brancato in Brooklyn yesterday.

Striking residents of the Tygart Valley homesteads, supervised by the Resettlement Administration, said that they were ready to return to work today, but W. H. Eubank, resident engineer, awaited orders from Washington before resuming construction work which was halted by the strike July 28.

This Camden County borough of 700 residents appealed today to the National Labor Relations Board to intercede in a local labor dispute so that its 150 school pupils might return to their books at the scheduled opening of the Fall term next month.

Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme called today a hearing for Aug. 25 on an application by mortgage trustees for permission to sell property of the Saxon Woods Hunt Club here for $17,500. It is assessed at $34,000.

At long last the Senate has approved a census of unemployment. Though such a census would involve a comparatively negligible expenditure, it would constitute, if properly taken, a step forward of the first importance. At last the country would know the real dimensions and much more of the nature of its chief economic problem.

After a six-weeks tour of the WPA "stands" in Long Island, the Federal Theatre Project's threering circus returns to Dyckman Street and the Harlem River Speedway tomorrow night for a fourday stay. "Savage Africa," a new spectacle prepared by Hallie Flanagan, national director of the Federal Theatre Project, and staged by Burns O'Sullivan, and five new acts headed by the Martian Troupe, have been added to the show.

Government labor battalions rushed to the Teruel front in Northeastern Spain tonight to throw earthworks and fortifications across the path of the Insurgents' steadily lengthening salient. The whole town of Cafiete, which straddles the Cuenca-Teruel highway, apparently was to be transiormed into a fortress for a stand in defense of the vital Government communications between Madrid and Valencia.

The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today the applications of the San Francisco Curb Exchange for extension of the unlisted trading privilege to Atlas Corporation 6 per cent preferred stock $50 par and Berkey Gay Furniture Company stock purchase warrants.
Showers yesterday afternoon had the unusual effect of adding to the oppressiveness of the weather. The rain did not lower the temperature, as it does normally, and it did increase the humidity.

The College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, will receive a legacy of more than $200,000 under the will of Mrs. Sara M. Frank, widow of Moses Frank, who lived at 68 East Eighty-third Street, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Mrs. Frank, who died on Aug.
John Alban Burns, a former New Jersey State Assemblyman, former Mayor of Garwood, N. J., and retired New York Harbor pilot, died here Friday at his home. He was 84 years old.

Reports were renewed here today that William O. Douglas, -a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, would be elected chairman of the commission to succeed James M. Landis, who is expected to retire about Labor Day to take over his new duties as dean of the Harvard Law School.

Developments today in the financial sensation created by the abdication of Errett L. Cord from control of his holding company included announcements that the Federal District Attorney here had begun a study to see if there has been any misuse of the
The Evergreen Farms team of the Monmouth County Country Club easily defeated Rumson, 15 to 8, in a Northeastern intra-circuit polo game at the Burnt Mills Polo Club this evening.

The big news this morning i that Maxwell Anderson's new play, which has been tentatively listed as a late season probability on Guthrie McClintic's schedule, will be along much sooner than expected-will open, in fact, at the Empire Theatre on Sept. 29 as the first of Mr. McClintic's seasonal offerings.

Acco Products, Inc., Thirty-ninth Avenue and Twenty-fourth Street, Long Island: City, said to be the largest paper fastener manufacturer in the United States, and Daniel A. Brennan, 10 LaSalle Street, Chicago, an inventor, were charged today in a complaint filed by the Federal Trade Comnmission with an alleged combination and conspiracy tending to "suppress competition and create monopoly in the sale of paper fasteners."

Fortyeight cows were burned to death and several others were so badly injured that it was necessary to destroy them when fire swept the large stock and storage barn on the farm of George Lewis, in Fredon Township,

The reported suggestion of former President Hoover that the Republican party hold a convention in advance of the 1938 elections to take stock of the party's position has aroused strong opposition from former Governor Landon, according to his friends here.

Gross assets, $97,666; net, $93,968. To Helen M. Cregan, sister, life estate in residue; one specific and three remainder bequests. Chief assets, property previously identified as taxed, $78,356. Bainton, McNaughton Douglas, attorneys. 40 Wall St.

Samuel M. Hastings of Chicago, chairman of the delegation of the Illinois Manufacturers Association to the International Chamber of Commerce meetings in Berlin, arrived here on the Queen Mary yesterday.

Four youths and three girls were rescued by Police Launch 9 yesterday afternoon after the sixteen-foot sloop they were sailing tipped over in Long Island Sound at a point a quarter of a mile north of Stepping Stone Light and threw them into the water.

Estate more than $10,000. To Hamilton Adler, son, executor, King St., Port Chester, N. Y. BAUMANN, CECILIA (July 27). Estate, more than $20,000. To Hebrew Orphan Asylum of the City of New York, Hebrew Home for the Aged, Hebrew Infant Asylum, Hospital for Joint Diseases, Lebanon Hospital and Montefiore Hospital and Home, one-sixteenth residue each: Temple Emanu-El, 1 E. 65th St.,

The Senate passed today the McNary bill setting up administrative machinery for the new Federal Bonneville Dam project on the Columbia River. Since the bill passed by the House differs in minor particulars, there must be a conference.

John P. Carmody, assistant secretary of the New York City Tunnel Authority for the last year and formerly an employee of New York construction companies, died here Saturday at his home. His age was 45.

Business failures in the United States numbered 156 for the week ended on Aug. 5, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The figure compared with 156 the week before and with 145 for the corresponding week a year ago. Last week's figure was 7.6 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of 1936.
Cincinnati and Suburban Bell Telephone Company-July 31: Stations in operation numbered 173,624, a gain of 588 for the month and of 11,347 for twelve months.

As a result of higher prices, prevailing labor conditions and prospective shortages in some agricultural crops, business conditions continued irregular and unsettled in Mexico during July, the Commerce Department has been advised by its commercial attache.

The Eastern Yacht Club sent out 392 boats in its second open event of the midsummer series today, ten less than a world record, as more than a score of available boats hesitated to start because of threatening squalls.

Sidney J. White, Special partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of E. A. Pierce Co., at 40 Wall Street, died yesterday in New Orleans, according to word received here by business associates. His age was 64.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary arrived yesterday from Southampton via Cherbourg with 1,844 passengers, making the voyage of 3,092 miles from Cherbourg Breakwater to the Ambrose Lightship in four days twelve hours, at an average speed of 28.68 knots.

Justice Department officials declared today that .the recent arrest of Clair Ralph Gibson, 31, near Roseburg, Ore., had cleared up twenty-two bank robberies, three attempted bank robberies and the hold-up of an Ohio automobile finance company.

Attorney General Cummings has informed Representative Snell that the Department of Justice is investigating the legality of sales by the Democratic National Committee to corporations of souvenir books of the last national convention.

A man and two women, one of whom was armed, entered and ransacked the home here of Saul Gold, New York dress manufacturer and Commander of the Lawrence-Cedarhurst Post of the American Legion, shortly after noon today, for reasons that are yet undisclosed.
Believed by its makers to be the fastest in the world, a new photographic lens has just completed taking pictures of light rays which left distant stars before dinosaurs trod the earth.

The verbal orders directing Capt. MalcolmK. Beyer, USMCR, to proceed from CCC Co. 210, Camp SP-9, Katonah, N. Y., to Governors Island, N. Y., reporting to the Corps Area Inspector General on Aug. 6, for temporary duty in connection with CCC activities, and return Capt. Beyer to his proper station, CCC Co. 210, Camp SP-9, upon completion of this temporary duty, are confirmed and made of record.

International Mining CorporationJune 30: Net asset value, $8,550,646, equal to $15.23 each on 561,373 common shares after all charges and taxes but before surtax on undistributed profits. This com pares with $17.31 a share on Dec. 31 last.

Brazil's cotton exports in the first half of this year were greater in volume than correspondingly in 1936 by more than 21 per cent. Official figures show in the first six months of 1937 exports netted 322,732 contos, against 254,000 contos similarly in 1936.

In two recent editorials, "Crop Control" and "The Farm Question," you set forth the considered objections of those who must deplore the strange insistence of the Administration in passing another AAA. You quote extracts from Mr. Roosevelt's agricultural Sioux City speech which were then and now the essence of common sense.

Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe reported today that four of the Dionne quintuplets have developed "mild colds." Emilie, who was isolated for five days with a sore throat, is now "quite well," the physician said, but the others, Yvonne, Annette, Cecile and Marie, have now caught Golds.

Two more of the season's crack 3-year-olds-Flying Scot and Pompoon-are through with racing for the year, it became known today. War Admiral, the champion, also is in temporary retirement following an injury suffered in the running of the Belmont Stakes.
Otto Timme, president of E. F. Timme Sons, textiles, 1 Park Avenue, New York, died of a heart attack here today at his Summer home. He Was 64 years old and lived at 75 Central Park West in New York.

The German Government expressed general accord today with the appeal for peaceful settlement of international disputes enunciated July 16 by Cordell Hull, United States Secretary of State. The brief statement said Mr. Hull's proposals had received "due consideration" and that "the Secretary of State's ideas coincided with those of the German Government."

SHANGHAI--A serious incident was created by the slaying of a Japanese naval officer and seaman by Chinese soldiers guarding the Hungjao airport outside the city. The Japanese forces, while refraining from reprisals, demanded satisfaction. Page 1.
Mayor La Guardia was praised yesterday by former Representative Frederick M. Davenport of Oneida County, who returned on the Europa from a trip to England and Germany.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Louise DeWolf, daughter of Mrs. Edward Arthur DeWolf of this place and the late Mr. DeWolf, to Emil Arthur Kratovil of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil Stephan Kratovil of Springfield and Southwick.

A serious political crisis is developing in Spain between the Negrin Government, supported by the Communists, and the Anarchists, led by former Premier Francisco Largo Caballero. The Government is striving hard to avert an open rift, but every indication points to an inevitable showdown that will probably provide difficult weeks for Loyalist Spain.

Wheat prices declined to new low levels for the movement today on the Board of large Trade here on scattered liquidation which disclosed a lack of support, except such as came from shorts and from mills removing hedges against flour sales. Closing trades wera at about the lowest levels of the day. with net losses of 21/2 to 25/8 cents a bushel.

The Mexican mining industry plans to present to the Government within a week a comprehensive list of objections to the new mining law, which President Lazaro Cardenas is empowered by Congress to promulgate by executive decree prior to Aug. 31.

The drifting ice floe in the North Polar Basinon which a Soviet party is taking scientific observations-is now 123 miles from the North Pole, having jogged north again since July 31 from a further distance from the pole, 225 miles.

ALL out for the Hambletonian! That's the big event of the harness hoss year. It's easy to get to William Cane's Good Time Park at Goshen, N. Y. Just tootle over the George Washington Bridge and follow the crowd. And don't forget the basket lunches.
Albert Bollschweiler, former Sheriff of Middlesex County, former United States Marshal here, and former Mayor, died today at his home. His age was 74.

ADAMS-Suddenly, Ridgewood, N. J., Aug. 9, 1937, William R., beloved husband of Anna Wildung. Services Wednesday, 8 P. M., at Christ Episcopal Church, Franklin Ave., Ridgewood, N. J. Interment private.
Mrs. Angeline Krech James of New York obtained a divorce today from Oliver B. James. An agreement was made concerning custody and supporof their five children.
REPUBLICANS LA GUARDIA TICKET For Mayor-Fiorello H. La Guardia. For Controller-Joseph D. McGoldrick. For President of the CouncilNewbold Morris. For District Attorney--Irving Ben Cooper.
Patrolman John O'Donnell, attached to Traffic J, and two civilians were in the Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday before Magistrate Vincent Sweeney on charges of grand larceny.

Miss Marion Miley of Cincinnati fashioned another sub-par round today over the Onwentsia Club course to hold the lead in the Women's Western 72-hole medal play golf derby with a total of 154 strokes. Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis gained second place at the halfway-mark by establishing a new course record.

Monmouth County, favored by many to gain the honors in the Northeastern intra-circuit polo play under way at the Burnt Mills Polo Club, made its tourney bow this evening and defeated Governors Island, 12 to 7.

Joe Louis, preparing for the initial defense of his world's heavyweight crown against Tommy Farr at the Yankee Stadium on Aug. 26. today went through a stiff drill at Dr. Bier's training camp. After an hour of heavy work there was no question as to Joe's physical fitness.

Governor Lehman is one of the respondents in a suit started in Supreme Court here today by Joseph F. Myers of Clifton, N. J., in an effort to lift a ban recently placed on a greyhound racetrack he operated at the Orangeburg Fair Grounds in Rockland County under the name of the Orangeburg Kennel Club.
Rudolph W. Birdsell, a retired tinware manufacturer, died at his home in Germantown yesterday in his eighty-eighth year.

Mr. and Mrs. Milton l'Ecluse of East Neck, Huntington Bay village, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Julia Manley l'Ecluse, to L. Livingston George, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. George of Englewood, N. J.
Bishop Simeon of Sabac, Yugoslavia, injured during recent Belgrade anti-concordat street demonstrations, had an audience today with Prince Paul, the Regent, at Castle Brdo in Slovenia.

William Leslie Edison, son of the late Thomas A. Edison, died today at his Westover Hills home after a six-week illness. He was 58 years old and had retired from active work two years ago. At his bedside was his wife.

Mrs. Dorothy Kyle Woodward, widow of Judge Jesse M. Woodward, and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Kyle of Cleveland, was married here last evening in the First Presbyterian Church to Wylie Brown, son of Mrs. Edward W. Brown of Plainfield, N. J., and the late Mr. Brown.

High on aocky hillside, Pennsylvania will build a $2,000,000 "streamlined" prison for hardened criminals, first of its kind in the nation. A prison within a prison, it will consist of three circular towers, overlooking a barren enclosure.

John W. Cravens, for forty-one years registrar of Indiana University, died tonight of heart disease and diabetes. He was 72 years old. Mr. Cravens retired in June, 1936. and was made secretary emeritus.

Recalling the recent killing of a woman in Bay Ridge as a result of the shooting of a rifle in a public street, Magistrate Troy in Coney Island court yesterday fined Irving Zion, 17 years old, of 1,818 Avenue P, Brooklyn, $10 for firing a rifle at Avenue P and East Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn, on Monday night.

Rex Flag, who went up in the betting under indifferent support, was something of a surprise today as the winner of the fortyeighth Kenner, one of Saratoga's traditional stakes which goes back to 1870. Driving on strongly at the end of the mile and three-sixteenths, the gelded son of Omar Khayyam scored by a length and a half over Burning Star, the 11-to-10 favorite.

Mrs. Leonard Cushing of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club led a field of 102 starters with a fine score of 82 to capture low gross honors in the one-day Women's Metropolitan Golf Association tournament over the North Hempstead course today.

Two Massachusetts pros, Bob Crowley of the Norfolk Country Club, Dedham, and Charles MacAndrew of Albeyarle, Newton, today blazed their way to the final of the New England Professional Golfers Association championship at the Martha's Vineyard Country Club.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, will open the second half of the current Berkshire Symphonic Festival at Tanglewood, between Lenox and Stockbridge, Mass., tomorrow evening with an all-Wagner program. After a Saturday night concert the festival will close Sunday afternoon with a program devoted to works of Brahms.

The first step in what may develop into national distribution for the private brand products of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., was taken yesterday when Fowler, Dick Walker, retail store of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., put on sale forty-eight drug and cosmetic items made by or for Macy.

Picketing by striking employes of the Horn Hardart Company was continued yesterday at many automats in Manhattan and Brooklyn. About forty pickets paraded for half an hour at noon in front of the company's office and bakery at 600 West Fiftieth Street.

Play was started in the fifteenth round of the international team chess tournament tonight. The American experts struck another snag when they met Estonia and Paul Keres of Reval defeated the United States champion, Samuel Reshevsky of New York. I. A.

Mayor La Guardia, Senator Robert F. Wagner and other political leaders of the nation, State and city were among 500 persons who attended a funeral service yesterday afternoon for Representative Theodore A. Peyser in Temple Emanu-El, Sixty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, announced yesterday that balloting by unlicensed personnel of the International Mercantile Marine Company on the choice of a labor agency for bargaining matters would be completed by Aug. 31.
John Hodge, veteran trade union leader and Great Britain's first Minister of Labor, died at Bexhill-on-Sea today at the age of 81.

Arousing considerable interest the world over, but none of that superstitious dread of impending disaster with which a visit by a comet was once regarded, the recently discovered Finsler's comet made its closest approach to the earth last night.

Two lions severely clawed Fritz Menn, 27, of this city, a chef in a restaurant zoo, as he attempted to photograph them yesterday. He was rescued from between their cages by two motorists who heard screams as they drove past the place.
Warring Spaniards fought today on three fronts, but failed to make headway in the civil war, now in its thirteenth month.

The Cole Porter musical comedy, "The Gay Divorce," the third in the Shubert operetta productions of the current season, was presented last night at the Randalls Island Stadium by Fortune Gallo. The heavy shower in the late afternoon kept the audience down to the small number of 5,000.

Four new directors were elected today bythe Skelly Oil Company. They are associated with J. Paul Getty interests and are Emil Kluth and Fero Williams, directly associated with the Getty interests; Harold L. Rowland and Arch H. Hyden.

The Paterson police were confronted with an unusual theft today. In the absence of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cooper of 699 East Twenty-eighth Street, who were on vacation, a woman entered their home, changed to house clothes and posed as a housewife doing her cleaning.
F. Nathaniel Perkins, treasurer of the x Boston Wool Trade Association and so a widely known. wool merchant, DR died today. 'He was 75 years old.

The German-American Bund was defended yesterday as a "patriotic, law-abiding American organization" by its national chairman, Fritz Kuhn. Mr. Kuhn made public a letter he sent to John H. Bankhead, Speaker of the House of Representatives.

Mrs. Emma Elizabeth Lane Stoddard, widow of George C. Stoddard, a civil engineer, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage at her home, 245 East 207th Street, the Bronx, after a brief illness. She was born in Westminster, Vt., eightytwo years ago.

A cloudburst today washed out the scheduled opening of the Yankee-Red Sox four-game series at Fenway Park. Before sun replaced the clouds it was decided to play today's game as part of a double-header Thursday.

Senator Barkley, the new majority leader, was the guest of honor of the Senate Democrats at a dinner tonight. President Roosevelt decided not to attend, but instead sent to Vice President Garner a letter extolling Senator Barkley and his services to the nation and the party.

William R. Adams, a lawyer who specialized in real estate and Surrogate's Court work and was senior member of the firm of Adams, Ryan Hayes, 39 Broadway, died suddenly of a heart attack on Monday in Wilmington, Del., while on a business trip.
The Oil Burner Institute, which eighteen months ago established a seal to be placed only on approved appliances, issued its 125,000th label yesterday,' according to an announcement by the institute.
Sir David Orme Masson, one of Australia's leading scientists, died today. He was 79 years old.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Aug. 9, Unless specified: At San Francisco-Arctic, Drayton, Flusser, Lamson, Marblehead, Perkins. San Francisco to Bremerton: Cincinnati, Humphreys, King, Lawrence, Sands.
There has been a mix-up in the American Legion's European dates for this Fall and Legion officials, headed by Commander Harry W. Colmery, are now trying to reconcile Italian appointments,

The opening date for "Blow Ye Winds," in which Henry Fonda and Doris Dalton will play the leading roles, was announced yesterday by Arthur Hopkins as Tuesday evening, Sept. 21, at a theatre yet to be named.

For the first time in the history of the merchant marine the Government, through the Maritime Commissipn, is undertaking a comprehensive survey of the industry, its troubles, financial, economic and industrial; its possibilities and uses, commercial, social and as a part of the national defense, and finally its costs, both for the present and for the future.

Charles H. blo Hammill, counsel for the trustees of we Insull Utility Investments, Inc., ple said today that an agreement has No been reached for settlement of suits by brought against bank creditors for the recovery of collateral.

The Rev. Dr. Harold Davis Emerson, head chief of the United Indian Tribes of the Americas, announced yesterday that the general council and the council of chiefs of his organization had unanimously adopted a resolution opposing the candidacy of former Suprene Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney, who is seeking the Democratic Mayoralty designation.

Neither dress manufacturers nor silk and rayon converters had felt any appreciable effects yesterday from the strike which started Monday in the silk and rayon industry as a result of the call by the Textile Workers Organization Committee, a C. I. O. unit.

Police Chief Philip T. Smith ordered today that all New Haven police officers work a ten-hour day without extra pay in an effort to end the most recent wave of burglary and robbery, which in the last thirty-six hours netted thieves a total of $11,000 in cash and goods.

Modern highways and automobiles are a threat to the solidarity of. rural life and the rural home, long noted for its character-building - influences, Professor Frank G. Helyar, Acting Dean of the New Jersey College of Agriculture, declared here tonight.
The Forty Niners opened the second half of the Summer season tonight when Lennox' Robinson's "The Whiteheaded Boy" was presented here at the Chase Barn Playhouse.
Two golfers today shared top honors as the World-Telegram holein-one tournament reached the halfway mark after competition in the Westchester and New Jersey districts.
Coloring of Vermont milk to relieve the surplus production in Rhode Island was ordered stopped tonight by Governor Quinn.

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin H. Denby of New York entertained with luncheon at the Bar Harbor Club today. Mr. and Mrs. William McNair of New York were hosts at a dinner party tonight at Leeward, their Bar Harbor residence.

Shipments of finished steel products by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation in July amounted to 1,186,752 tons, a gain of 235,901 tons, or 24.8 per cent, compared with the same month of last year, but a decline of 81,798 tons from June.

For more than twenty years the triangular park surrounding the statue of Giuseppe Verdi, just south of Seventy-third Street, between | Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue, has been a favorite gathering place for pigeons.
The Rev. Gregor Watschle, a Catholic priest, was sentenced today to pay a $60 fine or serve ten days in jail for "insulting a newspaper."

Attorneys for the family of Dr. Armen Greenhut, who was found dead in jail after being convicted of an attack on a 13-year-old school girl patient, studied today the question of whether it is possible to take an appeal for a dead man.
Pope Plus today continued his policy of keeping American dioceses filled, appointing the Right Rev. Mgr. Duane G. Hunt, Vicar General of Salt Lake City, Utah, as Bishop of the Salt Lake Diocese.

Otis Barton, deep-sea explorer and co-inventor of the bathysphere in which Dr. William Beebe has made his studies of under-sea life in tropical water, arrived yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Elena with a completed series of motion pictures of sea battles between tiger sharks, sawfish, marine crocodiles and mantas.
James A. Thompson, newspaper publisher, died in a hospital at Covington, Ky., today. His age was 62. Mr.

" The Life of Emile Zola," Warner Brothers' film biography of the crusading French novelist, with Paul Muni in the title role, will have its premiere at the Hollywood Theatre tonight. Assisting Mr. Muni in this re-enactment of the Dreyfus case will be Gale Sondergaard, Gloria Holden, Joseph Schildkraut, Donald Crisp, Grant Mitchell and Morris Carnovsky.
A world featherweight championship bout between Petey Sarron of Birmingham and Henry Armstrong of Los Angeles was approved yesterday by the New York State Athletic Commission.

Joe Balestri, bookbinder from the Government Printing Office in Washington, and Bobby Peters, Grand Rapids (Mich.) linotype apprentice took the lead at the thirty-six-hole mark of the Union Printers' international golf tournament today with 159s.

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan in Brooklyn declared yesterday that he was in full accord with Mayor La Guardia's plan to eliminate sex crimes against children through the incarceration of convicted offenders whose sanity is in doubt.

With only the slightest qualification, President Roosevelt said today that unless Congress passed general farm legislation at the present session to prevent a recurrence of price-wrecking surpluses he would not sanction a renewal of commodity loans to protect farmers against price declines.

The new navy flying boat, secretly built at the Sikorsky aviation plant here for the past two years, will have its first test-flight over Long Island Sound tomorrow, officials of the company said today. The plane.

Because he paused to kiss a woman whom he is alleged to have robbed of $2.50, James Fioretti, 16 years old, of 2,446 First Avenue, was arrested yesterday morning and with two of his companions was charged with robbery and possession of a pistol.
Frederick W. Eldridge, for more than twenty years managing editor, editor and vice president of The Los Angeles Examiner, died last night of a complication of ailments. He was 60 years old.
Vincent Astor's effort to stock Bermuda's waters with lobsters from Newport was unsuccessful, it was revealed today. He has transported

Former District Attorney Elvin N. Edwards of Nassau County, attorney for John Drennan, newspaper photographer, in his civil suit for assault against Enzo Fiermonte, husband of Mrs. Madeline Astor Force Dick Fiermonte, filed today in Supreme Court discontinuance papers in the suit and announced the matter had been settled, Drennan receiving a sum of "four figures."

Relatives and fellow office workers of Robert Gray, 55 years old, an accountant, of 243 Riverside Drive had gathered in the Felony Court at 10 o'clock yesterday forenoon for his hearing for forgeries totaling $25,000 when, in answer to the call of his name, a detective announced to Magistrate Andrews: "Your Honor, he's dead."

Eleven witnesses, including three members of the police force, testified before the grand jury yesterday in the case of Arthur H. Chalmers, patrolman in Troop B, mounted division, held for the murder of Irma Louise Pradier, an employee at Mount Sinai Hospital.

Times Square the modern, the Times Square of the movie palaces and their air-cooled multitudes, paid no heed yesterday as Times Square the ancient, the little old Times Square of Eleopulos's fruit stand, of Di Bella's barber shop and of Sullivan's cafe, suffered the amputation of two of its early-day domains.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Joan Pine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. E. Pine of this city, to H. Theodoor van Marken of Baarn, Holland, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. J. V. van Marken, took place yesterday afternoon in the chantry of Grace Church.
A bill designed to prevent picketing of Embassies and Legations of foreign nations in Washington, was passed by the Senate today and sent to the House.

The freighter West Irmo of the American West African Line, which had been held at her Brooklyn pier for two weeks because of an argument between two unions of ,officers and sympathetic action by unlicensed personnel, again was deplayed yesterday when her crew demanded payment for the time spent in port.
About 5,500 convicts who recently received an amnesty as a reward for good work on the Moscow-Volga Canal will not lack jobs.

Edwin C. Washburn, railway executive, manufacturer, author and son of the late United States Senator William D. Washburn of Minnesota, died here today at his home, 96 Dwight Place, of a lingering heart ailment. His age was 67.
Alberta's 2 per cent sales tax, which applied to articles used from the "cradle to the grave," and brought the Provincial Government a monthly revenue of $80,000, was suspended tonight.

The Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce continued today its investigation of the proposed consolidation of the Alleghany Corporation, which was the top holding company in the Van Sweringen network of railroads and other properties, and the Chesapeake Corporation, another of the major holding units in the Van Sweringen system.

The Association of American Railroads announced yesterday the formation of a division of engineering research to expand and unify efforts by the railroads of the country to improve equipment. The department will absorb the division of equipment research organized several years ago.
Daald Douglas, president of the Douglas Aircraft CorpottioTtold the National Labor Relath?? Board today that he had discovered evidence of sabotage in his factory.

A country school board recessed at midnight for 15 minutes after deciding to stay here through the night, "if necessary" to complete hearing of charges of cruelty and incompetence against a teacher. Testimony was completed, however, an hour later.

Miss Nelly Sheer upset the first seeded player, Miss Helen Bernhard, 6-4, 6-0, today on the courts of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club to gain the semi-final bracket of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association junior girls' championship.

A Negro robber, dressed in a gray suit and panama hat and armed with a nickel-plated revolver, held up four persons in the ninth floor showrooms of Sperling Spector, Inc., women's hat manufacturers, at 39 West Thirty-seventh Street, and escaped with $1,746 yesterday afternoon.

The difference of opinion between James E. Finegan, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, and John T. Eagan, executive secretary of the Board of Child Welfare, over salary increases for certain board employes was resolved, temporarily at least, in Mr. Finegan's favor yesterday.
President Roosevelt spent most of this afternoon in going over applications for Public Works Administration funds for the replacement of firetrap schoolhouses.
