Prompt enactment in New Jersey of three industrial relations bills, providing definition of illegal strikes and lockouts, "proper" systems of accounting by unions and "nonpolitical" arbitration of labor con-i troversies, was recommended today by the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce.

Following the usual July trend, employment in factories in this State dropped 1 per cent and payrolls were approximately 1 1/2 per cent lower than a year before, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, revealed today.

The attraction of Adolf Hitler to the German masses is that he has a solution for everything, "a sort of intellectual patent medicine which gives a cure for every evil," Dr. Hans Simons of the New School of Social Research declared today in addressing the Canadian Institute on economics and politics.

Six candidates for commander of the New York State Department, American Legion, were bidding for votes tonight as the vanguard of 20,000 delegates marched into Troy for a four-day convention opening tomorrow. The election will be held Saturday.

Max Turrer, as a stockholder in the Green Bus Lines, Inc., brought suit yesterday in Supreme Court to set aside the election of the cornpany's entire board of directors. The directors were chosen in June at a special meeting of stockholders after their predecessors had resigned in a body in settlement of a suit brought in Queens Countyj according to their attorneys.

Victor Krucher, 23 years old, of 142 Hackensack Avenue, died at Hackensack Hospital today of a spinal injury received yesterday when he struck another. youth while diving off a bridge at Pompadour swimminsr iool. Route 4. Paramus. N. J.

Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, announced yesterday the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission of a registration statement covering the issuance of $48,000,000 of new convertible debentures, to be offered to common stockholders.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Marion Vallender of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard Vallender to John Eichler Heintz, son of Mrs. John C. Heintz of Mamaroneck, N. Y., and the late Mr. Heintz, which took place on Saturday at the home of John M. Raymond in Hamilton, Mass.

The two five-story apartment houses at 3,031 and 3,041 Holland Avenue, the Bronx, were sold to an investing client of Max G. Koenig, attorney. Sale of the properties, each of which is on a plot 116 by 100 feet, was subject to a mortgage of $261,200. The Soflor Realties.
Having been acclaimed the "greatest master of German art," Chancellor Adolf Hitler also has been proclaimed "history's greatest physician."

Mayor Wilson announced settlement this afternoon of strikes of milk wagon drivers and street paving workers. The city's third major strike, that of drivers for grocery hauling contractors of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, was virtually settled, with the actual signing of contracts scheduled for tomorrow morning.

A new angle of attack on the Wages and Hours Bill, as reported by the House Labor Committee, was made on the floor of the House today by Representative Griswold of Indiana, a Democratic member of the committee.

The three-story taxpayer at 272-76 Flatbush Avenue and 101-3 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, was purchased by the Horman Realty Corporation, Maurice Epstein, president, from the South Brooklyn Savings Bank.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following order today, dated Aug. 7: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Neuberger, J. F., Med. Corps, 3d Nava District to Navy Recruiting Station, DeMoines. Iowa. Fields, J. A., Receiving Ship, San Francisco, Calif., to the Holland. Schnotala, T. M.. Navy Yard, Washington D. C., to the Wyoming.

Four men were killed today and five other persons injured by the crash of an Eastern Air Lines plane into a power line erected overnight near the airport here. Two crew members and two passengers died in the wreck, the first fatal accident in the history of the company.

A plea for international understanding of the "moral purposes" of China in her present conflict with Japanese troops was made yesterday by the Chinese Ambassador, C. T. Wang, in a statement issued at the Lotus Club.

For five days' fun at Coney Island, for which they had run away from home, the four Lauritsch children of 260 Prospect Avenue, Brooklyn, Elsie, 10 years old; William, 6; George, 8, and Edwin, 12, were remanded yesterday by Justice Peter B. Hanson in Brooklyn Children's Court to the custody of the Brooklyn Children's Society for hearin tomorrnow.

The Admiral Hotel, 350-room fireproof structure on the beach front at Cape May, must be closed tomorrow because it is "hopelessly insolvent," Vice Chancellor W. Frank Sooy ordered in New Jersey Chancery Court here today.

In an attempt to minimize favoritism and to extend the merit system the law committee 'of the Board of Education will recommend to the board at its meeting today that all applicants for positions as assistant directors of bureaus be placed in a competitive classification.

The important disclosures made in Mr. Matthews's dispatch describing the internal conflict in Loyalist Spain are three. First, despite the re rganization of the people's army into an effective, well-equipped military machine, disorder continues behind the lines and the prosecution of the war waits while two irreconcilable factions wage a struggle for power almost as desperate as the deadlock between the two Spains.

All leading foreign currencies weakened in terms of the dollar in the local exchange market yesterday. Indications of a renewal ofthe inflow of gold from Europe, and especially England, were seen in foreign exchange circles.

Harry Pelham Robbins, architect, leased from the Nalpak Corporation the four-story American basement dwelling with electric elevator at 67 East Seventy-seventh Street. Douglas Gibbons Co. were the brokers and Pease Elliman, Inc., represented the owner.
Seven Spanish Government militiamen escaped to France from an Insurgent prison camp today by seizing an Insurgent trawler at pistol point and forcing the captain to take them away.
ZEPPELIN: THE STORY OF LIGHTERTHAN-AIR CRAFT, by Captain Ernst A. Lehmann. (Longmans, Green, $3.) The history of airships by an authority who died in the Hindenburg disaster.

The number of boats competing in the second series of contests in the annual Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association regatta was cut today as a southwester of more than twenty miles velocity hit the fleet. Several boats were capsized, masts toppled and sails were rent by the wind.

Two officials and six other members of Local 12 of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C. I. O. affiliate, were indicted yesterday by the Richmond County Grand Jury on charges brought by employes of the United Shipyards plant at Mariners Harbor, S. I.
Prealdent Roosevelt today outlined his views on the Tight of government employes to organize, strike and picket.

The Board of Elections contracted yesterday for the use of four National Guard armories as votecounting points in the balloting for Councilmen in the boroughs under the proportional representation system of voting.

Donald M. Davidson, 15 years old, 100-yard and 220-yard free-style swimming champion of Westchester County high schools, is suffering from an attack of infantile paralysis that has affected both legs, Mrs. F. A. Davidson, his mother, said today at their home.
70th St, 18 W. 9-story apartment house, 83x100.5; New York Life Insurance Co against Mosilaw Realty Corp; due. $436,314; to plaintiff for $50.000.
The Sterling National Bank and Trust Company has been appointed trustee under mortgage indenture of Harcou Estates, Inc., securing an issue of $160,000 of first mortgage bonds due July 1, 1949.

Broadcasting impressions of Ecuador, Peru and Chile, which he has already visited in the course of a South American good-will tour, Carl W. Ackerman, Dean of the Graduate School of Journalism ofColumbia University, said the LatinAmerican press was in a privileged position to help in creating better understanding among American peoples.
Federico Paez, military dictator of Ecuador since September, 1935, was elected Provisional Constitutional President today by the National Assemblv.

Two of the leading radio set manufacturing companies yesterday announced enlarged campaigns for the Fall season. At a. joint showing of new lines by the Westinghouse Electric Supply Company and R. H. McCann, Inc., newly appointed Eastern distribute, an extensive newspaper campaign for Westinghouse radios was outlined.
The National League pace-setting Cubs lost the services of their star first baseman, Jim (Ripper) Collins, today as they bowed to the Pirates, 6 to 5, in the first game of a series.

The number of persons receiving public old age assistance in this State has increased by 64.7 per cent in the last twelve months, according to figures made available yesterday by the State Department of Social Welfare.

The United States ski team returned yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Clara, bringing back the Newell Bent Jr. Trophy for perpetual competition between nations of North and South America which it won in July at Farellones, Chile, in the first Winter sports meet ever staged below the Equator.
Lewis Helm, said to be the oldest police chief in the United States both in point of service and age, died today at his home. He was 84 years old.
A local crop expert, who returned today from a 1,000-mile trip in Northern Illinois and Eastern Iowa, said he was astonished at the average height of the corn this year.

Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer entertained at a dinner followed by bridge tonight at Leelands, her home in Water Mill. Another dinner also followed by bridge was given by Mrs. Charles Henry Mellon at The Shutters.

If Congress goes through with the schedule that its leaders have outlined for it, most of the important legislation that it passes in the next week or ten days before adjournment is certain to be ill-considered. Individual Congressmen will not possibly have time to inform themselves concerning the merits of the series of bills upon which they are asked to act.

Jacob Weintraub sold to an investing client of Moffa Orbach, brokers, the apartment house for sixty families at 31-43 Landeum Street, Yonkers, N. Y. The building has just been completed and was sold for cash over a mortgage of $220,000.

Acting District Attorney Harold W. Hastings began an investigation yesterday of charges attributed to Nicholas Montana, who is awaiting a new trial in the Tombs on a compulsory prostitution indictment, that before and since his conviction and twenty-five-year sentence on the same indictment in 1935, "the cops and the District Attorney's office shook me down plenty."

Promary petitions insuring contests for the control of the Yonkers, White Plains and Mount Vernon Republican machine and for occupancy of a few Democratic and Republican committee posts scattered through the county were filed tonight with the Westchester County Board of Elections.
Edward J. Vass, a traveling representative for Thomas Nelson Sons, book publishers, and well known in Masonic circles, died on Monday at his home, 885 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, at the age of 65.

Contests for the nomination for Mayor in both Republican and Democratic primaries, which are likely to be unparalleled in bitterness in the political annals of New York City, were indicated last night by the filing of designations for party nominations with the Board of Elections.

Jose Iturbi, the conductor, denied yesterday that he had changed the program of the musicians' benefit concert, which included some popular American songs, given under his direction Monday night at Robin Hood Dell, Philadelphia, part of which was cut off the WJZ network "because of possible copyright restrictions."
Further details of the perilous situation in which the Loyalist Government of Spain finds itself were received here today in uncensored reports.

A bearish construction was placed today by the trade on the Government's report showing a prospective wheat crop of 890,000,000 bushels, compared with the recent private returns, which averaged 841,000,000 bushels. The estimated yield would be the largest since 1931.

First sales of flue-cured tobacco on the 16 markets of the South Carolina belt and the North Carolina border belt today led sales supervisors and warehousemen to estimate that the day's average price would be around $25 a hundred pounds.

Thirty - seven large interstate trucking companies, all members of the Highway Transport Association, began action yesterday in Federal Court under the Wagner Labor Act and the Federal Motor Carrier Act of 1935 to avert a possible stoppage of transportation service here.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Guy E. Hargreaves of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Adele E. Hargreaves, to Theodore D. Woolsey of Rye, N. Y.

The Federal Caravan units offer the following free presentations for tonight: Brooklyn, ten vaudeville acts, at Gravesend Park; the Bronx, "Just Ten Days," at Crotona Park; Queens, "Pirates of Penzance," at Forest Park; Richmond, "Riddle Me This," at Robin Hood Field. All performances begin at 8:30 P. M.

It was to be expected that, in Congress at any rate, the Agricultural Department's high estimate on the cotton crop of 1937 should have caused some commotion. During several years the Administration's efforts have been applied to keeping down the American cotton yield.

Fairfield Ave. (13-3408B) s w c of 231st St. 127x100; Aurora Realty Corp to Colcan Holding Corp. 551 5th Ave. 205th St, 197 E, (12-3312). Central Savings Bank to Vitantonio Abbatantuono, 197 E 205th St.

Mr. and Mrs. John J. Geiger of this place and Spring Lake have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hilda Ruth Geiger, to Philip J. Bowers 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Bowers, also of East Orange.

Captain Max Pruss, commander of the airship Hindenburg, which burned at Lakehurst, N. J., sailed for Germany last night on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Swathed in bandages, the result of burns received during the destruction of the Zeppelin, he went at once to his stateroom after he had boarded the ship and refused to see interviewers.
More than sixty persons are believed to have died when a holiday excursion boat, the Ana Cecilia, foundered in Lake Maracaibo yesterday.
Funeral services for Dr. Abraham Valentine William Jackson, Professor Emeritus of Indo-Iranian Languages at Columbia University, were held yesterday morning in St. Paul's Chanpel on the campus.

The Ninth International Conference of the Boy Scout Movement was opened here today. Such conferences are held every two years to deal with general Scout problems. Today's meeting was presided over by Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden.

Discovery of ice fields estimated to cover 1,000 square miles in the Nahanni country of the Northwest Territories, just north of the British Columbia boundary, 'was reported today by Harry Snyder, a Montreal and Chicago mining capitalist.

A number of things marred the homecoming of the Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday. For one thing, one of those itinerant electrical storms threatened to crack down and wash out the show before it had a chance to get started. But it never did crack down and so did nothing more than hold the attendance to less than 5,000.

Preliminary plans for the Cord Corporation under the regime which gained control last week will be made on Aug. 20 at the first meeting of the new board of directors, L. B. Manning, who replaced E. L. Cord as president. announced tonight.
Baron Constantin von Neurath, German Foreign Minister, left Bad Gastein today, where he was supposed to stay a couple of weeks for the cure, and went to his Summer estate in Wuertemberg, Germany.

On the outcome of the 1937 Mayoralty election in New York City may depend the future of the New Deal and the ability of the President to choose his successor in 1940 and keep control of the Democratic party label for Democrats of his own way of thinking. That fact, plain to political observers, accounts for the heat and fury of the preliminaries.
Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., headed the successful banking group which bought yesterday $3,408,000 of State of Maryland 2 3/4, per cent certificates of indebtedness on a bid of 106.662 Per cent.

Michael Murphy, Department of Justice agent detailed to guard the family of James Roosevelt, son of the President, died tonight at Mr. Roosevelt's Summer home at Little Boar's Head, near here. He was 38 years old.

Designating petitions for about 175 up-State candidates for Democratic and Republican nomination as members of the constitutional convention were on file at the office of Secretary of State Flynn tonight. The time for filing petitions expired at midnight.

William S. Menden, president of the B. M. T., wrote to the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, yesterday asking its representatives to come to his office this afternoon to discuss contract negotiations. In his letter, however, Mr.
Two deaths and six prostrations were caused by the heat yesterday that touched 88 degrees, the highest in twenty-five days.

In his trips between San Juan and Washington Governor Blanton Winship has flown enough miles to circle the globe, it became known today when he started for Washington for the thirteenth time-the eleventh by plane since he became Governor.

The long and bitter fight over the proposal for a Jewish State on the basis of the partitioning of Palestine came down to two resolutions-one of them on the line that Dr. Chaim Weizmann desires, the other against it-in the world Zionist Congress last night.

Matching Harding Park's par 72 today to- add to his sensational 67 in the first round, Don Erickson, husky sharpshooter from Alhambra, Calif., won the medal in the national public links championship. His thirty-six-hole total of 139 equaled the tournament record established in the first championship by George Aulbach fifteen years ago at Toledo.
Although the. most conspicuous price swings in bonds yesterday were on the downside, those specific movements did not affect the general undertone of the market to any marked degree.

Sixteen-month-old Lydia Ochs died in Jamaica Hospital at 6 o'clock last night from a concussion of the brain received when she fell two stories to a rear yard at her home, 94-28 Ninety-sixth Street, Ozone Park, Queens.
Despite the death of two airmen, officials announced today that London had successfully demonstrated its power to resist a mass air raid.

Justice James Clark McReynolds of the United States Supreme Court will sail for Europe today on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. Also on the liner will be Felix Warburg, banker, who heads an American Jewish committee that will attend a conference on Palestine at Zurich. In the group are Sol M. Stroock, Dr. Solomon Lowenstein, Dr. M. J. Karpf and Joseph A. Marks.

Donald Edgar, former third secretary of the United States Legation at Ciudad Trujillo, Dominican Republic, accompanied by Mrs. Edgar and members of their family, will leave the Waldorf-Astoria today to sail on the Manhattan for his new post at Geneva.

A heavy volume of business was reported in the copper export market early yesterday, with the price at 15 cents a pound, c. i. f. European base ports. This was a new high record for the current movement and 1 cent a pound above the domestic level.

MANHATTAN BRODERICK, ALICE (June 18). Estate, $8,200. To Patrick Healy, Sea View, Castletown, Berehaven, Ireland; Lillie Lavelle, Dublin, Ireland; Kathe Meehan, Sea View, Mt. Chaille, Donegal, Ireland; Ellen O'Hanlon, Central Islip, L. I.; Elizabeth Tyrell and Bridget Cummings, Garnish Town, P. O. Castletown, Berehaven, Ireland; Anastasia Healy, Sea View, Castletown, Berehaven, Ireland, and estate of Elizabeth Broderick and Mary Ellen Dunnion, equal interests in residue. John Sillivan Sr., executor, 560 W. 149th St.. $100.

After the Court of Pardons had issued today a brief statement defending the parole granted to Herman G. Mulock Jr., who served seven years of a life sentence for the murder of a Newark cafe proprietor, as "entirely justified and in line with both the law and traditional practices of the court," Governor Hoffman gave out a long statement as a member of the court.
One of the saddest little stories of the year comes to us from Budapest. It concerns Anton Kertesz, an estimable and well-to-do farmer
The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the first half of this year, issued yesterday, showed a net income of $2,132,233 after all expenses and -charges.

Assailing the increase in scrap iron exports, which, he said, were principally to Japan, Senator Nye today told the Senate that "the only return we may expect from this exportation, aside from the munificent return in dollars to the several exporting companies, is the probability that one day we may receive some of our own metal embedded in the bodies of our sons."

Farmstead, Inc, milk bar, in Empire State Building. 350 5th Ave; James Felt Co, Inc. broker. Safford, Buddulph Co, securities, in 40 Wall St; Winmaur Coat Co. Miss Criterian Coat Co, Falk Ginsberg, Gangel Kitay, additional space, in Mulqueen Building, 241 W. 37th St; E. S. Willard Co. brokers.

Leaders of two independent employes groups at the Weirton Steel Company aligned themselves today against the National Labor Relations Board which will hold a hearing next Monday on charges of company interference with union labor.

Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hope' A. Gimbel of Chieftans, Greenwich, Conn., to David M. Solinger of this city, son of Mrs. Morris D. Solinger and the late Mr. Solinger.

A steady drop in world gold hoardings in the last six months, amounting in all to more than $1,000,000,000 of the metal, was disclosed today in a table published in the current number of the Federal Reserve Bulletin.

A prisoner exchange was begun today at the Insurgent-held port of Palma in the Balearics. Seventeen hundred government prisoners are to be returned to the Insurgents in an even exchange when the transfer is complete.

Exports and imports of the United States by classified groups of merchandise in June, as announced by the Department of Commerce, are compared below with those of the preceding month and with June, 1936.

In a surprising revival from what had been considered a state of suspended animation, the special House Committee on Governmental Reorganization voted late today to recommend for passage a bill giving President Roosevelt broad powers for two years to abolish, consolidate or readjust the regular departments of the government, but keeping out of his reach the regulatory, quasijudicial agencies.
Former Lieut. Comdr. John Semar Farnsworth, convicted last February of selling Government secrets .to Japan,. sought release today from the Federal Penitentiary here. on a writ of habeas corpus.

They say anglers are reactionaries--although this label is usually applied to the dry-fly fraternity-and hate to credit any theory which refutes a belief mellowed by time. If this is so, Dr. E. S. Russell, director of fishery investigations to the British Ministry of Agriculture, has let himself in for trouble.

Charles Stetson of the Pequot Yacht Club struck two telling blows in defense of the Long Island Sound junior sailing championship and the Pequot Cup today but young Butler Whiting Jr. from Larchmont matched him, with the result that these two are leading the parade in the five-race series.

The Eastern Yacht Club's midsummer regatta brought 388 yachts to the three starting lines today-fortysix small fry in the morning and ninety big Craft and 252 mediumsized boats in the afternoon. The series total now is 1,165 yachts, compared-with 1,112 in 1936.

Mr. and Mrs. Martin Moore Foss, who have returned to East Hampton after passing two years in Europe, will entertain at the horse show dinner to be given at the Maidstone Club on Saturday night, for their week-end house guests, Mrs. Lust Moss and Tevis Huhn.
Joseph H. Hough, former manager in charge of material supplies for the Pennsylvania Railroad, with headquarters in New York, died at his home here last night after a long illness.

American exporters and investors have at least $80,000,000 tied up in Spain, twice the. sum first estimated when trouble broke out there, according to a report which will be submitted to a special committee today by. Harry A. Tipper, yice president of the National Foreign Trade Association.
Chicago's charter jubilee art exhibition opened today on Navy Pier. A full mile of pictures and many pieces of sculpture were on view, and no matter what school the visitor liked it could be found.

Mayor La Guardia of New York, president of the United States Conference of Mayors, urged Congress today to forbid the dismissal of WPA workers who cannot find "suitable" employment in private industry.

James Galatka of Mississippi and James Poole of Mississippi State, considered two of the best ends in the South during the 1936 campaign, have been signed by the New York Football Giants, it was announced yesterday by John V. Mara, president of the club.
Frank H. Smith, former State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, died today at his home here after an illness of several months. He was 68 years old.

More than 100 women residents of Queens, many of them leaders in civic, social and political organizations, have qualified to serve as jurors under the provisions of the Kleinfeld bill, which becomes effective on Sept. 1, according to figures on file in the County Clerk's office at Long Island City.
Sister Anna Gertrude Forsyth, a member of the Order of Sisters of Charity for thirty-fiver years, died today at St. Elizabeth Hospital after a long illness.

Johnny Horstman, 147, East Side, beat Pete Koloff, 138 1/2, Bronx, in the main eight-round bout at the New. York Coliseum last night before 5,000 spectators. The decision ended a streak of eleven consecutive knockouts to Koloff's credit.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora fixed bail yesterday at $35,000 each for Samuel Weiner and Joseph Miller, two of the sixteen men indicted on Monday on charges of conspiracy to extort money from clothing manufacturers.
Government experts increased their estimates today of this year's yield of corn, wheat, rye, oats and other major crops.

Trapped in an automatic elevator between the third and fourth floors of his home at 1,290 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, Arthur Levy, 10 years old, was rescued yesterday by a patrolman who let himself into the lift through a trap door in its roof.
Coward - McCann are hurrying through the press "Stanley Baldwin: A Tribute," by Arthur Bryant, biographer of Pepys. More than 30,000 copies have been sold in England within a month of publication.

Public officials acted today to avert repetition of May 26 violence, in which a score of unionists were injured, when the United Automobile Workers of America undertakes tomorrow another distribution of handbills and leaflets at the gates of the Ford Motor Company.
Mrs. Eleanore Leake Plater, formerly of New York, wife of Richard C. Plater Jr. of Nashville, Tenn., died yesterday at North Adams, Mass., according to word received here.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the listing under authority previously granted, of 2,216,748 shares of $13-par common stoek of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, part of it upon termination of the voting trust for the stock.

Representative Seger, New Jersey Republican, said in a statement today that a constituent had "put $500 on the line" for a souvenir book of the Democratic National Convention and never received his copy.

Many luncheon parties were given at the Gideon Putnam today by members of the New York colony here. Mr. and Mrs. Oscar C. Huffman entertained Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. McMullen. Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Howard had Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt as a guest. Mrs.

Athletic Director Harry Stuhidreher of the University of Wisconsin announced today that George T. Fox, who was graduated from Villanova College in June, would be the Badger end coach in football this year. He succeeds Fred Twomey, resigned.
German press attacks on Czechoslovakia for refusing to let 6,000 children of the German minority spend three weeks' vacation in Germany has aroused the Czechoslovak press.
More than 150 screaming girl strikers charged at police today and started a riot at the Bonner Worth plant here of Dominion Woolens and Textiles, Ltd.

Receipts 10,000, including 1,000 direct. The market was mostly steady to 10 cents lower than Monday's average and late 10-15 cents off a top of $13.70. The bulk of good and choice 180-230 pounds, $13.30-60; 240300 pounds, $12.50-$13.25; bulk good and choice 140-160 pounds, $12.50-$13.25, but supply limited. Most good packing sows,

A union: agreement was signed last night at the Hotel New orker between the. Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, and representatives of more than 100 coat, apron, towel and .linen supply companies.

The general death rate for the city rose to 8.5 to 1,000 of population during the week ended Aug. 7, an increase of four-tenths of a point over the preceding week, Dr. John .L. Rice, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday.

Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State and Bronx Democratic leader, disclosed yesterday that he was serving without salary as Federal Commissioner for the World's Fair. Senator Royal S. Copeland, whose nomination for Mayor Mr. Flynn is opposing, on the preceding day had characterized Mr. Flynn as a "political cowboy," who lassoed every job in sight.
Deposits with the Bank of Canada on Aug. 4 increased more than $4,000,000 from the week before, according to today's weekly statement. The total was $200,687,291, compared with $196,254,295.

The first serious violence in the silk and rayon strike conducted by the Textile Workers Organizing Committee occurred yesterday as the strikers extended and consolidated their lines in the battle area covering New Jersey, Pennsylvania, New York and New England. The flare-up was at Hazleton, Pa., where the City Hall was the scene of a fist fight between strikers and a crowd of opponents.

Frederick D. Rothenbusch, one of the leading artists at Rookwood Pottery, died at his home here today at the age of 61 years. Mr. Rothenbusch's work was done principally on what Rookwood Pottery calls vellum glaze. Examples have been 10.

Struck by a miniature railroad train at a Rockaway Beach concession last Sunday when she toddied on the railroad's right-of-way, which was not fenced at that point, 3-year-old Rose Mary Doran of 133 Beach Ninety-fifth Street, Rockaway Beach, died yesterday in Rockaway Beach Hospital as the result of injuries she received in the accident.

The Senate Finance Committee late today voted a favorable report on the Jones Sugar Control Bill, after approving a compromise amendment fixing quotas on refined sugar for the United States mainland, Hawaii and Puerto Rico.

Business failures increased in three groups in the week ended Aug. 5 in comparison with the figures for the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The last formalities incident to the ending of the bitter Senate fight over President Roosevelt's judiciary reorganization program took place today when the Senate-House conference report on the bill for "procedural" reforms in the lower courts was approved unanimously.

Mrs. Sara Solis Nathan, a descendant of early American settlers of Spanish and Portuguese descent, and the widow of Edgar J. Nathan, New York lawyer and Jewish leader, died suddenly today at her country home here on Orienta Avenue. Her New York home was at 441 West End Avenue.

The National Supply Company of Delaware reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a consolidated net income of $4,768,139 after charges, interest, depreciation and taxes but before surtax on undistributed profits.

Between fifty and sixty members of the Actors Equity Association, who joined a demonstration by 10,000 WPA workers on May 27 against the curtailment of Federal relief appropriations for the 1938 fiscal year, were fined $50 each and received suspended sentences yesterday at a hearing of the Equity Council.

American and British petroleum companies with an investment of close to $500,000,000 in Mexico will be forced to cease operations if President Lazaro Cardenas endorses his special investigating committee's

The Department of Labor and the National Labor Relations Board began today an effort to settle the inter-organization labor controversy which has developed at Grand Coulee Dam, and so avert the calling out of the more than 5,000 men at work on the project.

Griefstricken at the news of a second death in her family while awaiting the funeral of her son, Mrs. Mary Schwarz, 46 years old, died of a heart attack today at her home, 519 South Seventeenth Street. Mrs.

49th St, 310 W; to 5-story apartment; 310 West 49th Street Corp., owner; David S. Lang, 200 Broadway, architect; cost, $10,000. 12th St, 20 W; to 4-story triplex apartment; Louise Ryals Arkell, 15 W 10th St. owner; Magill Smith. 232 Madison Ave, architect; cost, $15,000.

As a result of Monday's unexpectedly large Government crop estimate, cotton prices declined again yesterday, but after an early loss of 10 points the market steadied to close only 3 to 6 points lower.
The Treasury Procurement Division today announced the award of contracts for 1,503,450 yards of textile goods for the Works Progress Administration as follows:

Expressing satisfaction over renewal of the commercial agreement between this country and the Soviet, David A. Rosoff,. chairman of the board of the Amtorg Trading Corporation, trading representative in this country for the U. S. S. R., said yesterday that he was particularly pleased that the new agreement accords unconditional most favored treatment to Russia.

Middlesex remained at the top of the county cricket table today by defeating Surrey by three wickets. Yorkshire, a close second in the standing, beat Warwickshire by nine wickets and Derbyshire, in third place, downed Northamptonshire by the same margin.

Eight divisions of enlisted men, including about forty officers, in the naval reserve will embark Saturday on the battleship Texas and the destroyers Leary and Decatur to participate in manoeuvres and target practice on their annual two-week training cruise.

The marriage of Miss Agnes M. Corry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Corry of 167 Quincy Street, Brooklyn, to Edward Vincent Murtaugh Jr., son of Edward V. Murtaugh, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mrs. Murtaugh, took place yesterday morning in the Church of the Nativity, Brooklyn. The Rev. John O'Donnell of Bristol, Conn., performed the ceremony.

A bridge, tea and fashion show was held at the Outpost Inn here today under the auspices of the Connecticut Pioneer Branch of the National League of American Penwomen. Colors and designs of Autumn leaves predominated in the gowns shown in the fashion revue, which was entitled "Leaves From Fashion's Book."

The opening social event in connection with the eighth annual Lake Placid Horse Show, to be held here Friday, Saturday and Sunday, will be an informal luncheon at Lake Placid Club tomorrow to be given by Mrs. William H. Carpenter of New York and Mrs. Philip G. Cole of Tarrytown, N. Y., in honor of Ned King of the National Horse Show Association, manager of the local show, and Mrs. King.
A residential landmark in midtown Manhattan passed to new control yesterday when the sale and plans for demolition of the Procter mansion were announced.

The marriage of Miss Mary Frances Rheinberger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richmond James Rheinberger of this place, to Dr. Diego Benigno Martinez of Pittsburgh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richmond James Martinez of New Orleans, took place this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.

Dr. S. A. Roman y Reyes, Nicaraguan Consul here for the last year, was robbed of $700 early yesterday morning as he rode in a self-service elevator at 10 Monroe Street, he told the police. He gave a description of his three assailants.

The campaign of the Illinois section of the Professional Golfers Association of America to oust George R. Jacobus of Ridgewood, N. J., as national president, drew this terse comment from Jacobus yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

Trading was generally only fair to slow. The veal and calf markets were steady to lower. Lamb sold considerably below Monday's asking prices. Other classes were unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated prices in most classes to be steady to weak and trading slow, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
Schumann's Fourth symphony in D minor was the main offering of the program given last night at Lewisohn Stadium by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Willem van Hoogstraten.

At a bridge party and tea given today in the garden of their home here, Judge and Mrs. Nathan Belcher announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Matilda Anne Belcher, to M. Righton Swicegood of New York, son of Mrs. Stephen Preston Swicegood of Savannah, Ga.

Mr. and Mrs. Martin Moore Foss, who have returned to East Hampton after passing two years in Europe, will entertain at the horse show dinner to be given at the Maidstone Club on Saturday night, for their week-end house guests, Mrs. Lust Moss and Tevis Huhn.

From the Central Savings Bank Mr. Doing bought the five-story tenement house on a lot 26 by 100 feet at 1,486 Fifth Avenue for cash over a purchase money first mortgage of $19,250, which was taken back by the seller.

Miss Majorie Harrison of Ausable Forks, 19-year-old student at Green Mountain Junior College and runner-up in the state tournament at Bluff Point two years ago, today won the Dor. M. Parker medal with a 78, one under women's par, in the qualifying round of the eighth annual women's tournament of the New York State Golf Association at the Onondaga Country Club.

The ground and second floors and basement of the building formerly occupied by the Maison Blanc at 540 Fifth Avenue have been leased by Stouffers, a restaurant chain with stores in Detroit, Cleveland,

Johnny Pena, 126, veteran Washington Heights featherweight, and --Al Reid, 125 3/4, the Bronx, fought to a draw in the- feature eightround bout before 2,000 persons at the new Queensboro Arena last night.

Mrs. John Dodge Peters will entertain a luncheon party at the Wyantenuck Country Club, Great Barrington, tomorrow in honor of her sister, Mrs. Marion K. Kerr, and Mrs. Balfour Miller of Natchez, Miss., who are staying with her and Dr. Peters at Edgeholm.

Third Round Miss Alice Marble defeated Mrs. Maud Blumenthal, 6-3, 6-2; Miss Jane Stanton defeated Miss Edith Blackman, 7-5, 6-2; Miss Barbara Winslow defeated Miss Eleanor Dawson, 6-3, 6-2; Mme. Sylvia Henrotin defeated Miss Virginia Hollinger, 6-3, 6-4:

The Pure Oil Company announced today its intention to offer to holders of common stock of record of Sept. 3 rights to subscribe to $44,244,300 of new cumulative convertible preferred stock of $100 nar value.

Miss Louise J. Anthony, daughter of Mrs. Mark Anthony of this place, and the late Mr. Anthony, has chosen Sept. 18 as the date for her marriage to Henry G. Castor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Castor of Philadelphia.

The San Jose poloists of Argentina took anotehr step in their training for our national championship today when they cantered easily through a practice gameon Whitney Field of the Meadow Brook Club to turn back a Blue team consisting of their two spares, Juan Castex and Hugo Backhouse, as well as Bobby Strawbridge and Billy Reynolds. The score was 10 to 3.

With steel-ingot production unchanged last week when a decline was seasonal, the adjusted index has continued its forward movement to a new recovery high, 128.4, compared with 126.9 in the previous week and 111.0 in the week ended Aug. 8, 1936.
Captain Harry R. Swift of Mount Vernon, retired marine officer and veteran of three wars, died yesterday at his Summer home at Sargentville, Me., at the age of about 73.

The Communist party leadership is showing concern at the slowness with which local party organizations are inducting new members to replace old ones who have been expelled by the thousands for various offenses, ranging from inactivity to disloyalty to the Stalin regime.
John Weld Peck, former United States district judge for Southern Ohio and long an outstanding figure in political, legal and civic circles, died at his home here today. He was 63 years old.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Your editorial "Whittling Down the Housing Bill" you state: "We cannot depend on a PWA staff, accustomed to think in terms of grants and centralized control, to carry on a new program in which local initiative will be the motive power and an annual subsidy applied directly to keep rents down will be the principal instrument of Federal control."
Tomas Penton, wanted for shooting a man in a drunken affray a month ago, was killed here today after he opened fire with a pistol in Correctional Court, wounding the judge, a defendant and a witness.

More than 300 members of the Summer colony from Sugar Hill and many surrounding resorts filled Peckett's playhouse in the hayloft tonight for "Lady Audley's Secrets or Murder in the Lime Tree Walk," presented by the New Jitney Players of New York.

The John Barrymores' reconciliation became legal today with dismissal of the divorce suit Elaine Barrie Barrymore filed last April. The 21-year-old Brooklyn girl and the 57-year-old actor were married Nov. 8, 1936, and separated last New Year's Eve. A few weeks latter they "made up."

Aaron Kaplan, opera singer and for twenty years cantor of Temple Judea, died today in Mount Sinai Hospital. He' was 68 years old. Mr. Kaplan' started his career with a traveling: troupe in Russia at the age of 19.
Taxpayers in Colonie, Albany County, are going to get a refund of $30,000. The Albany County Board of Supervisors adopted a resolution asserting that taxes in that amount had been "illegally,

King Carol returned today from his visit to London and Paris and immediately after his arrival there were rumors that the Cabinet would fall and that there would be a complete change in Rumania's polities.

Argentina is frankly disturbed by the project of the United States to lease six destroyers to Brazil. Leading newspapers denounce the plan vigorously and it is understood in diplomatic quarters here that the Argentine Government has asked explanations from the United States and Brazilian Governments.
Boston at New York-Bush vs. Castleman. Brooklyn at Philadelphia-Cantwell vs. La Master. Pittsburgh at Chicago--Lucas vs. Bryant. Cincinnati at St. Louis-Davis vs. Johnson.

A CAPSTONE to Gibbon's deserved celebrity after the appearance of "The Decline and Fall"-volume one-was the selection of a snuffbox worthy so brilliant, so accomplished a little man. Tapping a snuffbox was perhaps the eighteenth century's most characteristic gesture. And Gibbon was becoming its foremost historian, carrying its manner back through other centuries to Rome.
Eustace Cardinal Ilundain y Esteban, Archbishop of Seville, died of bronchial pneumonia today at the age of 74. A native of Pamplona, he received the Cardinal's hat in 1925.

Nathan Rubin of Detroit held the championship of the National Checker Association today. He defeated William Ryan of New York, two games to none, in the final of the national tournament which began here a week ago.
Hunters in four counties will be allowed to shoot all the deer they see between Sept. 10 and Dec. 31, because Florida wants to get rid of the bluish, blood-sucking "cattle fever ticks."

Gross revenues of omnibus companies affiliated with the Greyhound Corporation were $18,908,759 in the six months ended on June 30, against $17,278,082 in the same period last year. The Eastern railroads reduced coach fares to 2 cents a mile on June 1 of last year.
The double-play combination of Charlie Gehringer, Bill Rogell and Hank Greenberg functioned in four innings today, but failed to prevent a White Sox victory over Detroit, 6 to 4.

The Federal Trade Commission today announced that two New York dealers, one selling watches and rings and the other dealing in rebuilt watches, have agreed to discontinue "certain false and misleading representations" in advertising their products.
President Roosevelt returned from Hyde Park, signed the Interior Department Appropriation Bill and issued a statement criticizing some of its provisions;

Arms stretching heavenward to herald the "vision of the future" at the World's Fair, the figure of a woman in decorative relief, draped from the waist down in a veil of dull gold, was set in place yesterday on the facade of the Administration Building on the Flushing Meadows.
Today, if forecasts in New York Stock Exchange circles are to be believed, the law committee of that body will recommend a higher scale of commissions.

Charles A. Levine, who became the first transatlantic airplane passenger when he flew with Clarence Chamberlin from Roosevelt Field to Germany in June, 1927, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of smuggling.
The League of Nations published today a letter from the Government of El Salvador announcing its withdrawal from the League "for economic reasons."

The entire block front bounded by Brookside and Virginia Avenues on California Avenue, Freeport, L. I., has been purchased by a client of Monroe Miller, broker in the deal. The Warranty Realty Corporation, Sam Cohen, president, was the seller.

President Roosevelt announced today that he had signed the $132,732,000 Interior Department Appropriation Bill "with much reluctance" because Congress had exceeded the budget estimates by $10,000,000 in appropriating for Federal aid for vocational training.

Proximity to the National League cellar, upon which the Phils are supposed to have a season's lease, put dynamite in the Brooklyn bats and new skill into Roy Henshaw's left arm today. Roy scattered nine hits, while the Dodgers made fourteen to win the series opener, 7-3, at Baker Bowl.
There was a ducking in a Venice canal today-but it was not the former Barbara Hutton, Woolworth heiress and now Countess Haugwitz-Reventlow, as first reported by rescuers.
The brisk pace in apartment leasing for Fall occupancy set earlier in the Summer is being maintained, reports from brokers disclosed yesterday.

Miss Elizabeth Congleton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Irving Congleton of Beaver Run, was married here this afternoon in the Church of the Good Shepherd to John Hallowell Ohly, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Henry Ohly of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Aubrey H. Derby.

Directors of R. Hoe Co., Inc., are notifying holders of the company's securities that sums will be set aside for payment of current interest and interest in arrears on the first-morgage bonds, amended 7 per cent notes and new notes, and that dividends in payment of accumlated arrears have been declared on the 6 1/2 per cent cumulative prior preferred and 7 per cent preferred stocks.

With his doubles partner and business associate, Wilmer Allison, forced to return home because of an injury, John Van Ryn of Austin, Texas, served notice today in the Eastern grass court tennis championships at the Westchester Country Club that he is prepared to uphold the standing of the combination in a manner befitting his rank and experience.

The improved relations between Italy and Great Britain caused Premier Benito Mussolini, as soon as he landed at Messina, Sicily, today, to witness ?? games, to deny that this year's combined exercises of the army, navy and air force have any antiBritish character.

George D. Widener of Whitemarsh and his sister, Mrs. Eleanor Widener Dixon of Elkins Park, have inherited their share of the $26,978,118 estate of their maternal grandfather, the late William L. Elkins, traction owner,. following the death in Paris last month of their mother, Mrs. Alexander Hamilton Rice of New York and Newport.
New Jersey has been penalized in the amount of $250,000 because of diversion of motor vehicle revenues from highway purposes.

The expulsion of additional foreign correspondents from Germany was predicted today in an officially inspired article in the Berlin Boersen Zeitung. It was printed in connection with the official announcement of the German Government's request for the recall of Norman Ebbutt, the Berlin correspondent of The Times of London, served on the British Government yesterday.

The daily average crude oil production in the United States last week reached a new high record of 3,651,150 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This represents a gain of 59,250 barrels over the daily average of 3,592.900 in the preceding week, which also was a high record.

The National League's great "one-two punch"-Johnny Mize and Joe Medwick-drove in three runs in the third inning today to give the Cardinals a 3-to-2 victory over the Reds. With two out and two on base, Mize singled off Lefty Lee Grissom to score one run and Medwick tripled to drive in two.

George L. Cooper, who for a quarter century was in the newspaper business in New York, first with Hearst publications, then as managing editor of both The New York Evening Telegram and The New York Herald, died Saturday night at the Summer cottage of his sister, Mrs. B. F. Butler, near New Castle, Pa. He was 64 years old.
Colonel Phya Phahol Pholphayuha was reappointed Premier today after Siam had been without a government for a week as the result of the King's privy purse scandal.

Edwin L. Singleton, former vice president of Talbot J. Taylor Jr., Inc., and Charles L. Hanscom, former president of Midtown Underwriters, Inc., have opened a general real estate and insurance brokerage business at 12 East Forty-fourth Street.
Washington swept both ends of a double header with the Athletics today, 15 to 7 and 8 to 6. The victories moved the Senators to within a game of the fifth-place Indians, who were idle.

Four residential properties in Jersey City were sold by the Excelsior Mutual Building and Loan Association. The structures involved were the six-family houses at 97 Old Bergen Road and 103, 105, 107 Ege Avenue.
A protest against the proposed partitioning of Palestine, signed by forty

1st Lt. Charles W. Stark, Med.-Res., 230 East 69th St., New York, N. Y., unassigned, is ordered to active duty for a period of six months, Aug. 13, at Fort Douglas District. CCC, Fort Douglas, Utah, for duty in connection with CCC activities.

Having spent all yesterday investigating the Hungjao incident, in which two uniformed Japanese marines and a Chinese airfield guard were killed, Japanese and Chinese officials began today negotiations for a settlement.
The Federal Reserve Board reported tonight that current net earnings of the twelve Federal Reserve Banks were $5,791,603 in the first half of this year.

A dinner was given last night on the Roof Garden of the Astor by Mr. and Mrs. Lucius J. Hall. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Samuel K. Browne, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Mallory, Mr. and Mrs. Jacques H. Benedict, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Wheeler, Mr. and Mrs. F. Osborn Larned, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur D. Rogers and Lieut. Col. Edgar Sherman St. George.

A man was instantly killed and another man and his sister critically injured here this morning when the automobile in which they were riding was struck by a passenger train of the Pennsylvania-Reading Seashore Railroad at a crossing on the Woodruff-Finley Road.

Brig. Gen. Henry H. Denhardt paused today as he directed the Seventy-fifth Brigade of the Thirtyeighth Division in mock war manoeuvres to predict that his second trial on a charge of murdering his fiancee, Verna Garr Taylor, would not be held as scheduled this Fall.
Although the number of buyers attending the domestics and linen show at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday increased sharply to about 500, a cautious policy ruled their covering operations.

To help relief recipients keep "well-nourished and healthy" on a subsistence budget, the Health Department suggested yesterday some ways in which a family of five might advantageously spend its relief food allowance of $8.05 a week. In making public the sample menus and food orders,. officials of the department made clear that the lists were meant to be suggestive rather than all-inclusive.

Officials of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the Transport Workers Union held a second conference yesterday in the negotiations for a contract affecting more than 1,200 employes of the company at the company's offices, 605 West 132d Street.

Fear that the 1939 World's Fair would 'bring an influx of two-story trailers and autos to clog Long Island highways was voiced tonight at a meeting of the Nassau County Village Officials' Association here. Mayor Henry Waldinger, president of the group, which includes every incorporated area of the county, recommended the adoption of a uniform trailer ordinance to curb possible congestion.

In a decision without precedent since it began functioning on April 27, the Wisconsin Labor Relations Board ruled today that it has jurisdiction over employers in this State engaged in interstate commerce.

The Santa Barbara four, winner of the national junior championship last Sunday, defeated San Mateo, 11-5, in a semi-final match of the Rathborne Memorial tournament today. The contest was played before 1,100 persons on the No. 2 field at the Narragansett Polo Club.

The excavations being made in Greece by the American School of Classical Studies have brought to the light of day fresh fragments of an ancient glory which has not departed and will not so long as the Parthenon stands on the Acropolis of Athens, or Pausanias walks in its agora.
Two bills designed to modernize existing bankruptcy laws were passed today by the House of Representatives and sent to the Senate.

The public, as represented by parents' and civic organizations and special groups, turned out in force last night in spite of the heat to express themselves at a public hearing on the Board of Education's record budget of $159,074,222, representing an increase of $14,583,658 over last year's. The unvarying tenor of the demands was, "We want more."
Another Harvest Moon ball is to be held this year for the benefit of the Rocky Farm Camp for Crippled Children on Sept. 10.

The Merchants Association sent a letter to members of the Committee on Banking and Currency of the House of Representatives yesterday stating that while it favored solution of the housing problem, the association did not believe the Wagner housing bill, in the form in which it passed. the Senate, would answer the purpose.
Greyhound, 1:57 1/4, today failed in his attempt to beat the world trotting record of 1:56 3/4, established fifteen years ago by Peter Manning over the mile track at Lexington, Ky.
Albert E. E. Short, orchestra leader for the National Broadcasting Company, died today of apoplexy in a hospital here.

Supreme Court Justice Raymond E. Aldrich expressed sympathy today for thirty-one residents of Lawrence Park West in Yonkers, who complained their slumber' was being disturbed by the construction near their homes of shaft 23 of New York City's new Delaware aqueduct.

Mrs. Mary Jennings Ryan of 509 Riverdale Avenue, Yonkers, widow of Thomas P. Ryan, who had been president of the New York Society of Certified Public Accountants, died today at the Summer home of her daughter, Mrs. Edwin K. Daly, in Spring Lake, N. J.

A total of $66,350 was paid tonight for fifty-one yearlings, an average of about $1,302. Top price of the night was $10,000, by Max Hirsch, for a bay son of On Watch and Kippy. This youngster is a full brother to On Post and Sortie, crack thoroughbreds trained by Hirsch. The seller was Mrs. M. Y. Kaufman.
Development of the Government's I case Against the Austin Silver Mining Company proceeded here yesterday on several fronts. Pierce W.

General Joseph Roja, one of the late Marshal Joseph Pilsudski's best-known officers, was arrested and held in Military Hospital today for attacking President Ignaz Moscicki and accusing General Edward Smigly-Rydz of setting up a dictatorship.

South St, 162-63, 40.3x65.11; Howard Pl to Longrea Realty Corp. 154 South St; purchase money. mtg $18,000 ($20). Carmine St. 72-74 1/2, 50.5x60; William F. Wund, executor of Frank Hitscherich, to Berthold and Clara Hitscherich. 610 Concord Ave, three-fourth part; Katie Working, 25 Hawthorne St, Brooklyn, onefourth part ($30).

Curran C. McConville, coach of the University of Wisconsin crew at the Pougkeepsie race in 1899, died of a heart attack today in an automobile factory where he was superintendent. He was sixty years old.
The Greenland Board today received from Angmagssalik, East Greenland, news of the death yesterday of Colonial Supervisor Georg Rasmus Rassow at the age of 54.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Annelise Bernhardt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernst Bernhardt of Berlin, Germany, to Henry G. Salomon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Salomon of this city.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt urged the foreign and American delegates to the international encampment of Girl Scouts and Guides yesterday to use their influence for peace. She spoke at the opening ceremonies held in the outdoor theatre at Camp Andree, Briarcliff Manor.

With the administration of relief almost certain to become an issue in the municipal election campaign, leading social workers in this city have shown no disposition to have their names considered as candidates for the vacant post of executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau.
Captain Thomas J. Delaney, who was twice cited for bravery during his twenty-three years as a member of the New Haven Fire Department, died at his home here today.

Leslie HoreBelisha, Secretary of State for War, who during his career as Minister of Transport at least made things interesting for the British motorist, today issued a comparatively tame program for building up the strength of the army.

Accused of attacking and seriously injuring a. 13-year-old girl with a milk bottle while she was asleep in her home, Jeremiah Mapp, 22, a Negro, who was released on probation in June for another crime, was held here today by police on charges of atrocious assault and burglary.

The commercial division of the Chilean Foreign Office will attempt to reach another trade agreement with a South American country when a special Chilean mission meets an Ecuadorian group of experts Monday.

The United States Lawn Tennis Association announced yesterday that Miss Alice Marble, Miss Helen Hull Jacobs, Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan, Miss Carolin Babcock, Mrs. Marjorie Gladman Van Ryn and Miss Dorothy May Bundy have been selected as members of the Wightman Cup team. The combination will defend the cup against the British players Aug. 20 and 21 at Forest Hills.

Following a tabulation of the voting of the employes of the Parmelee System, Inc., one of the major taxicab companies, last night, it was announced that the drivers had elected the Transport Workers Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, as their collective bargaining agent.

Dr. I. Harvey Brumbaugh, former president of Juniata College and second cousin of the late Governor Martin Brumbaugh, died last night from a heart attack while on an outing in near-by Diamond Valley. He was 67 years old.

Major George L. Gillon of 243 Ryerson Street, Brooklyn, died yesterday at the age of 71. Major Gilion had held commissions in both the Twenty-third and Fourteenth Regiments, New York National Guard, retiring from the latter after twenty-five years of service.

Eighteen Republican National Committeewomen are here for the meeting tomorrow at which plans will be made for the appointment of a chairman of the women's division and for conducting an intensive campaign in 1938.
Former President Hoover took time out from a trout-fishing trip today to say that he had "heard" of a proposed 1938 rally of Republican party leaders.
Henry Cotton, British open golf champion, today said he was too busy in Europe to consider a return match with Denny Shute, American professional champion, in Boston this Summer.

ASTEL--Isidore. The Shomrim Society of the Potice Department of the City of New York announces with deep sorrow the death of Brother Isidore Astel on Aug. 11, 1937. Funeral from Park West Memorial Chapel, 115 West 79th St., Friday, Aug. 13, at 10:30 A. M. Interment at Shomrim Field, Monteflore Cemetery, Springfield, L. I.

Patrolman John Bosworth, 34 years old, of 762 Olmstead Avenue, the Bronx, attached to the Westchester Precinct, who was struck and knocked down by a trolley car at 163d Street and Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, early last Monday morning, died of his injuries at 8 o'clock last night in Lincoln Hospital.

The Maritime Commission today offered for sale, under competitive bidding, nine steel cargo vessels from its laid-up fleet for conversion into colliers to be used exclusively in the American trade. Bidding is limited to American citizens.

Many members of the Summer colony turned out this afternoon for the opening of the annual flower show at the Newport Casino under the auspices of the Newport Horticultural Society, made up for the most part of gardeners on the large Summer estates.

Chief of Police William McClain, 40 years old, of Alpine, N. J., was found guilty yesterday of driving an automobile while intoxicated by Acting Chief Magistrate Alexander Brough in Intoxication Court here.
A determination of independent operators of movie theatres in Eastern Pennsylvania, Southern New Jersey and Delaware to boycott films of Paramount Pictures, Inc.,
George Watts's Silverette led from the start today to account for a victory in the six-furlong Grade B Handicap at Lincoln Fields.

A working combination of conservative Democrats opposed to further extensions of New Deal policies and Republicans out for mischief had the Administration leadership in Congress tied in a knot tonight. With the Senate well launched in a bitter controversy over the Wagner-Van Nuys anti-lynching bill and the House Rules Committee in revolt against the Black-Connery

The Chicago C. C. engaged in the first match of its Eastern cricket tour against an eleven of the Staten Island C. C. at Walker Park, Livingston, yesterday. Due to the late start because of inclement weather the result was a draw, somewhat favorable to the visitors.

The House passed and .sent to the Senate today legislation to authoran appropriation to rebate about $30,000,000 of unemployment insurance taxes to States which were late in complying with the Social Security Act.

The American Automobile Association decried today the theory that women drive cars better than men. "Brushing chivalry and mythology aside," said Burton W. Marsh who, as a traffic engineer, has spent a year conducting drivers' tests, "Mr. Average Man is better equipped to handle the wheel."
Francis I. Daly, assistant treasurer of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania, died at his home in Germantown tonight in his sixtieth year.

The engagement of Miss Eleanor Bovenizer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Wallace Bovenizer of this place, to George W. Armstrong Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Armstrong of Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents.

Despite the insistence of the Halpern Neckware Company, here, that it had signed a contract three weeks ago with the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C. I. O. affiliate, all the 200 employes of the necktie manufacturing firm went on strike today for increased wages, stating they had never joined the union.

Contracts were awarded by the Navy Department today for the construction of two 1,600-ton destroyers to the Bath Iron Works of Bath, Me., and two of the same type to the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corpora tion, Ltd., of Quincy, Mass.

Continued hot weather again affected trading and business was only fair to slow on most classes of fresh meats. Lamb prices were lower, calf weak to lower, steer and fresh pork cuts uneven. Trading again opened slow on kosher meats with beef about steady, veal and lamb steady to weak, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Counsel for the Austin Silver Mining Company and the Securities and Exchange Commission continued yesterday to battle over the testimony of Howard N. Lary, mining engineer for the commission, who reported that his visit to the mine property in May had disclosed inaccuracies in the registration statement filed for an issue of 225,000 shares of $1 par value stock.

Following closely upon an increase of 5 per cent in railway fares and freight rates, expected to yield additional revenues of ??5,600,000, the Railway Staff National Tribunal granted today wage increases and other concessions amounting to [Pound]2,900,000.

George Haines today sailed Mariette to an easy victory over Chance, sailed by Robert Campbell, in the H-23 foot class at the regular Wednesday Fishers Island Yacht Club regatta. The course of 14 1/2 miles was the longest of the season.
The engagement of $3,984,000 gold abroad for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of the amount $2,093,000 was secured in Canada, $700,000 in Belgium,

Manhattan Alterations Delancey St. 150: to 4-story stores and office; Beathe Realty Co., 415 Lexington Ave, owner; Alfred A. Tearle, 155 E 44th St, architect; cost, $5,000. 62d St, 135 E; to 5-story apartment; Ethel A. Thacher, 135 East 62d St. owner; Harry M. Clawson, 139 E 53d St, architect; cost, $15,000.

Wire trouble at the southwest kiosk of the I. R. T. at Ninetysixth Street and Broadway caused the metal parts of the booth to become charged with electricity yesterday and resulted in injury by shock to a man when he grasped the wooden hand-rail leading down the steps.

George Raft, motion picture star, said tonight he was negotiating for a syndicate of movie celebrities and others to bring Babe Ruth to Hollywood to manage a Pacific Coast League baseball club in 1938.
Grover A. Whalen filed yesterday with the Board of Elections a formal declination of his designation for the Democratic nomination for Mayor and Jeremiah T. Mahoney was substituted.

Spanish Insurgent authorities in Irun today announced General Francisco Franco's troops had smashed an attempted Government offensive on the Asturian front in Northern Spain. Government losses were described as "extremely heavy."

Arrangements have been completed by Morris O. Alprin, director of Foreign Trade and Exposition Tours, Inc., of New York, for a good-will tour of Italy next year by 700 American wine merchants, restaurateurs and hotel men.

The World Conference on Faith and Order sent today a message of "Sympathy to suffering Christians" in Germany. The Archbishop of York had moved that the conference, representing churches of the world, dispatch the message.

The veteran Italian hospital ship Helouan, whose most recent task had been the return of wounded Italian soldiers from Spain, was wrecked by fire early today in Naples Harbor. One fireman was asphyxiated, but no other casualties were immediately reported.

The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the Cleveland Mahoning Valley Railway Company today to issue not to exceed $2,936,000 of first-mortgage 4 per cent bonds to be sold at par and the proceeds applied to payment on Jan. 1, 1938, of outstanding 5 per cent gold bonds.
A temporary injunction blocking the proposed merger of the two principal holding corporations in the Van Sweringen rail empire was granted today by Circuit Court Judge Edwin T. Dickerson.

President Roosevelt's determined stand against a renewal of crop loans without accompanying legislation to control surplus production threatened today to cause an open breach between the Administration and cotton States Senators and Representatives fearful of the political consequences of further dedines in prices of the staple.

The House Rules Committee deadlocked today over bringing the Wages and Hours Bill to the floor, with the result that the Democratic leadership, after a hasty council of war, called off a meeting of the committee to consider an application by the Labor Committee for a rule.

Reiterating that the Department of Justice is making an inquiry into the sale of the 1936 convention books autographed by President Roosevelt, Attorney General Cummings said today that he had asked Representative Snell, the Republican leader, to furnish him with evidence of violation of the law but had received none.

Two buildings in the Chelsea district will be altered into modern suites as the result of the 'leasing yesterday of the five-story houses at 345-47 West Twenty-third Street by the Robert R. Rainey Company, as broker, for the Leopold Schepp Foundation. They occupy a plot 50 by 98.9 feet and were leased for twenty-one years at a rental of about $200,000 for the period of lease.

Taking a first and a second in the final two races today, Charles Stetson and his Pequot Yacht Club crew of Robert Gordon and William Watkins successfully defended the junior sailing championship of Long Island Sound by the convincing margin of nine points.
The Senators won their third straight game from the Athletics today, but lost the services of Shortstop Cecil Travis for an indefinite period. The score was 5 to 4.

Germany is first among the nations in the post-depression era which has not only solved its unemployment problem but is already beginning to suffer a labor shortage and which is replacing measures for creating jobs with measures for obtaining additional workers.

The more the matter is argued, the more clearly does it appear that the burden of proof rests upon those officials who now would have the United States initiate the unprecedented procedure of leasing naval vessels to other American republics.

Giusseppe Queirola, a restaurant worker who lives in a rooming house in West Twenty-seventh Street, was taken to Bellevue Hospital for observation yesterday after he had been arraigned under an indictment charging that he had sent threatening letters to the late John D. Rockefeller two years ago.
Governor Lehman reserved decision today on pleas for commutation of death sentences imposed upon two convicted slayers awaiting execution in the Sing Sing death house.

French bombing planes and motorized infantry went into action today to suppress a rebellion of Mohammedan Kurds against French rule in Syria. Several Christians were injured, villages were pillaged, and civil authorities who tried to restore order were fired upon by bands of Kurdish tribesmen in Northeastern Syria.

The Rev. Patrick O'Brien, pastor of St. Joseph's Church here, was elected today abbot of St. Mary's Abbey, Order of St. Benedict, at a meeting at St. Mary's Abbey in Newark. He succeeds the late Abbot Ernest Helmstetter, who died July 9.

President Roosevelt discussed crop control legislation with Agriculture Commissioners of thirteen Southern States; conferred with Senator Byrnes on the Government Reorganization Bill, and received from Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, a report on the labor situation through the country.

The red parrot fish, the silvery pompanos and the horseshoe crabs that live in a 14-foot tank on the main floor of the Aquarium were startled just after the closing hour on Tuesday night by having a newcomer dumped in their midst.

On the heels of the estimate of a 15,593,000-bale cotton crop this year, Government experts forecast a corn crop of 2,659,000,000 bushels, a wheat crop of 890,000,000 bushels, and 1937 harvests in general more than 10 per cent above average. There was a time when an announcement of this sort would have been gratefully welcomed.

The latest actions of the Japanese-approved Chinese officials of Peiping is evidence that the broadest interpretation is being placed upon the clause of the 1935 North China pact dealing with "the suppression of all anti-Japanese and communistic activities in North China."
Jeremiah T. Mahoney, four-county aspirant for the Democratic Mayoralty nomination, threw down a challenge of party loyalty yesterday to his primary opponent, Senator Royal S. Copeland.

With one more day for voter-enrollment under the new Permanent Registration Law, Republicans are holding their lead.The Republican City Committee said today that returns from all but three of the city's 1,300 divisions at the end of yesterday's registration

Testimony of three witnesses was heard by Surrogate James A. Delehanty in the suit of Marjorie Browning, 22 years old, of New Rochelle, N. Y., who is seeking an award of $1,000,000 from the estate of Edward S. Browning, realty man,

Slipping on wet flooring, Frederico Cobri, 45 years old, of 606 Ninth Street, Union City, fell into a vat of boiling dye this morning and suffered burns from which surgeons said he had little chance to recover.
A resolution for a sweeping investigation of the radio broadcasting industry by the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee was reported today by that committee.

Preliminary figures on department store sales in July, taking the country as a whole, show a gain of 4 per cent over the totals for the corresponding period last year, according to a report issued today by the Federal Reserve Board.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Butler Whiting of Sutton Manor, this place, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Day Whiting, to Lieutenant John J. Hyland Jr., U. S. N., son of Captain John J. Hyland, U. S. N. (retired), and Mrs. Hyland of Port Washington, L. I.
Common Pleas Court Judge Palmer M. Way ordered the Admiral Hotel here today to remain open for the remainder of the season under the management of the Admiral Hotel Company.

William L. Thacher of the Ojai Valley, formerly of New Haven, Conn., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Edith Thacher, to Francis S. Dane Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis S. Dane of Lexington, Mass.
The volume of business on the stock market here was smaller today and profittaking caused a further setback in several sections. The demand for gilt-edge issues slackened; among the foreign loans,

At a press conference today Arthur de Souza Costa, Brazilian Minister of Finance, gave a detailed account of his actions in the United States, stressing the good will toward Brazil that he had found. He said the Brazilian press was erroneous in its interpretation of the financial entente as Brazil did not contract

Charging that the police in Brooklyn were guilty of "inexcusable brutality" against striking shipyard workers, the American Civil Liberties Union submitted a report to Mayor La Guardia yesterday urging disciplinary action against the responsible police officers.

Premier Benito Mussolini today stressed a two-point doctrine of military life and social justice for the Italian people. Speaking before 100,000 cheering Sicilians, II Duce exalted "everincreasing military preparation of the people" as the only alternative to misery and slavery.

Miss Carol Elizabeth Wheeler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar C. Wheeler, will be married the afternoon of Aug. 28 to Donald William Easier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry D. Easier of Manchester, N. H. The wedding will take place in Trinity Church here and the Rev. H. J.

109 St, 22 E, 30x100.11; Maxwell Shapiro to Greenwich Savings Bank; foreclosure ($19). 114 St, 108 W, 26.3x100.11; Max Krupp, referee, to Greenwich Savings Bank; foreclosure ($16). 158 St, 503 W, 25x99.11; Samuel Plumer, referee, to Greenwich Savings Bank; foreclosure ($16).
The duty on imports of cattle weighing 700 pounds or more under quota provisions of the Canadian trade agreement will be increased tomorrow from 2 to 3 cents a pound, according to the Customs Bureau.

Jim (Ripper) Collins, the Cubs' star first baseman who suffered a fractured right ankle in the first inning of yesterday's game with the Pirates, will leave for his home in Rochester, N. Y., Saturday or Sunday.

The marriage of Miss Wilhelmina Hebald, daughter of Mrs. Nathan Hebald of 41 West Ninety-sixth Street, and the late Mr. Hebald, to Clarence Epstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Barnet Epstein of Harmonie Lodge, Richmond, Mass.,

Sales of two plots and a lodge on Candlewood Lake, near Danbury, Conn., were reported yesterday. Candlewood Isle, H. J. Carroll Jr. purchased a rustic lodge and Russell M. Raub bought a plot. Both are on Lake Drive.

Expressing disappointment at President Roosevelt's opposition to Congressional ratification of the New England interstate compacts for flood control, Governor Hurley asked tonight for a conference with the President and the Governors of the four States interested in the compacts.

The World Zionist Congress unenthusiastically adopted today by a vote of 300 to 158 a resolution that "empowers the executive to enter negotiations with a view to ascertaining the precise terms of His Majesty's [British]-Government for the proposed establishment of a Jewish State" in Palestine.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today denied the motion of Alpha Shares, Inc., United Standard Oil Fund of America, Inc., Monthly Income Shares, Inc., of New York City, and Monthly Income Shares, Inc., of New Jersey, for dismissal of the commission's order for a study and investigation of these companies.

Banks here and in New York will lose ultimately less than one-third on the $59,000,000 that they lent to Insull Utility Investments, Inc., and the Corporation Securities Comnpany, twin Insull investment companies, it was estimated today.

The Federal Power Commission has directed five officers of companies affiliated with the Associated Gas and Electric System to show cause here on Sept. 20 why they should permitted to hold "interlocking" directorships.

Colin Melhado, a witness in the Securities and Exchange Commission's action against the Trenton Valley Distillers Corporation for a faulty registration statement, fainted yesterday morning in the midst of an examination by E.

James F. C. Hyde Jr. of 340 West Fiftyseventh Street, New York City, was designated today by President Roosevelt for the examination on March 1, 1938, for admission to the Military Academy on July 1, 1938.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday announced the appointments of Thomas Tyson Cook as assistant vice president in charge of advertising and of Harry M. Wilcox, formerly assistant advertising manager,

The Warners, who have achieved the reputation of being Hollywood's foremost triflers with history, paid their debt to truth last night with the presentation of "The Life of Emile Zola" at the Hollywood Theatre.

Contracts for the construction of three new high schools in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens at a total cost of $4,399,420 were awarded by the Board of Education at its meeting yesterday. The cost of the new buildings will come out of the capital outlay budget for 1936-37. Each of the three schools will provide accommodations for 4,180 pupils, or a total of 12,540.

Making her move on the far turn, the Aeolian Stable's Donna Leona today overpowered the pace-setting Stage Beauty, from Mrs. P. A. Shaw's stable, to win the $5,000 added Governor's Handicap, six-furlong juvenile feature at Suffolk Downs.

Four Carmelite nuns who were detained by immigration inspectors yesterday on their arrival from Marseille on the Dollar liner President Hayes were admitted to the country later in the day after a hearing on Ellis Island.
