The $8,000 mortgage on the 5-story house at 214 E. 7th St. has been sold by Samuel Hurwitz, broker, to an investing client. The same broker arranged a new mortgage of $4,750 on the 4-family building at 1,737 54th St, Brooklyn, and a new mortgage of $5,000 on the 2-story dwelling at 2,357 Elmore Pl, also in Brooklyn.

The Imperial Rayon stock scandal, one of the most sensational Japanese trials in recent years, entered its final stage today. The case involves former Cabinet members, several high Treasury officials and bank and company presidents and directors. The judge postponed sentence.

The New York Telephone Company will refund about $200,000 to New York City business concerns in the near future for excessive charges since Jan. 1, 1930, on interoffice dialing systems, the company revealed yesterday.
Subject to certain modifications, the new schedule of commissions to be charged by members of the New York Stock Exchange, which was prepared by a special committee headed by E. A. Pierce,

The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows: In the Cotton Belt temperatures were abnormally high in the west and northwest and moderately above normal in other sections. Rainfall was mostly light to moderate in the form of local showers with very little in western portions of the belt.

Felix M. Warburg, banker, sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary at the head of a delegation that will represent no -Zionists at a meeting in Zurich, Switzerland, of the Council of the Jewish Agency for Palestine.

A railroad wreck on the Trans-Siberian Railway in which fourteen persons were killed and more than forty injured, thirty seriously, resulted in the execution of seventy-two persons as spy-saboteurs in the service of the Japanese.

State Banking Commissioner Carl K. Withers disclosed today there were 851 unclaimed accounts totaling $261,032 in twenty-one New Jersey savings banks. They range up to $12,362, although many are relatively small.

Negotiations between leaders of the five brotherhoods and the country's railroads seeking a settlement of the union demand for a 20 per cent increase in wages were begun here today. About 300 general chairmen of the brotherhoods met with fifteen delegates of the Carriers Conference Committee, representing the principal railroads.

Following a tip that the Brady gang had had a package delivered to a building in the business district here, police late today found a small arsenal of grenades and machinegun ammunition, as well as the belt and holster of an Indiana State trooper murdered last May by bank robbers.

The New York County grand jury, after hearing twelve witnesses, handed up a first-degree murder indictment yesterday against Mounted Patrolman Arthur H. Chalmers in the shooting last July 20 of Miss Irma Louise Pradier, a former Mount Sinai Hospital employee.

Less than twenty-four hours after he allegedly held up a driver and stole his automobile, Chester Spiewack, 23 years old, formerly of Jersey City and Newark, was sentenced here today in Special Sessions Court to a term of eight to twelve years in Trenton State Prison on a charge of robbery.

Final steps were taken yesterday to complete the reorganization of the Vertientes Sugar Company and the Camaguey Sugar Company, operators of sugar properties in Cuba. Under the terms of the plan of reorganization, the VertientesCamaguey Sugar Company has been formed and now owns and operates all the properties formerly belonging to both companies.

Willoughby Lane Webb, former New York lawyer and for years a leading business man in Dukes County, died yesterday at the age of 65. He was manager of the Seven Gates Farm Corporation, which he organized in 1922.

Miss Rosalie J. Imhoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Imhoff of this place, was married here this afternoon in the rectory of St. Aedan's Church to Hugo K. Bader, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Bader of Stuttgart, Germany, by the Rev. Francis Sullivan.

The re-election of Mayor La Guardia on the basis of his past record, particularly in regard to his efforts for the extension of recreation facilities in the city, was urged yesterday by three speakers at the thirteenth of a series of forum Luncheons of the Progressive City Committee at the Town Hall Club.

In their desire to break into the lucrative American market, European manufacturers will spend increasingly larger sums for advertising in this country, Rudolph Guenther, chairman of the board of Albert Frank-Guenther Law, Inc., said here yesterday.

This city became the focal point for 20,000 members of the American Legion today as delegates arrived for their State convention. The vanguard found the welcome mat out for the former service men, who will have a four days' gathering.
Often as "The Marriage of Figaro" is featured on the Salzburg Festival programs, it was not until tonight, incredibly enough, that it was heard in the original Italian.

To the chagrin of elder yachting crews and the approval of a majority of the younger sailors, the scheduled race on the annual cruise of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association to be sailed today off Point o' Woods was postponed because of inclement weather.

Transfers and Assignments PATROLMEN--Leo A. Greene, from 43d Precinct to 20th Precinct: Edward T. Gro gan, from 62d Precinct to Traffic N James E. King, from 105th Precinct to 18th Division, assigned to duty as Chauf feur; Edward L. Wardell, from Motorcycli Precinct 1 to 70th Precinct, assignment to clerical duty discontinued; William H Lindsey, from 88th Precinct to 18th Divi sion, designated as Third Grade Detective.

Prices of wheat futures in North American markets broke 3 to 4 cents a bushel in the early trading today to new low levels on the current downturn on the bearish construction placed on the domestic crop estimate of 890,000,000 bushels, issued yesterday after the market had closed.

The audience which attended the opening performance of "The Life of Emile Zola" in Warner Brothers' Hollywood Theatre-reopened for the first time since the 1935 gala premiere of "A Midsummer Night's Dream"-was probably the most brilliant of a hitherto dullish Summer.

The group of ends available when Coach Andy Kerr's Eastern AllStars meet the New York football Giants at the Polo Grounds Sept. 8 was completed today when Maurice Patt, 190-pound Carnegie Tech wingman, accepted a bid to play with the collegians.

The third day's activities at Camp Andree for the first international encampment in America of Girl Scouts and guides were disrupted by rain today, although the weather failed to dampen the spirits of the 101 girls who are assembled here from all parts of the world.
The fifth of the ten concerts of the current Brahms series of the Federal Music Project was given at the WPA. Federal Theatre of Music last night before a responsive audience of good size.

Miss Alice Cox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis James Cox of East Haven, was married to Joseph Francis Garvin Shields of Dublin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Shields, this morning at St. Bernadette's Church, Morris Cove.
More drastic regulation of securities salesmen, as a basis for new legislation to be submitted to Parliament in the Fall, was recommended today by the Government's committee on "share-pushing."
The Chesapeake Ohio Railroad was accused before the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce today of various questionable activities dating back as far as 1926.
C. B. Goodspeed, treasurer of the Republican National Committee, announced today the adoption of a plan aiming to place the party's finances on a solid foundation for the next three years.
Dr. Anthony M. Bacevicz, physician and surgeon here for twenty-five years, died yesterday at his home after a brief illness.

Impossible racing conditions prevailing at Good Time Park today necessitated a postponement of the twelfth trotting of the $37,912 Hambletonian Stake and the whole of the third day's card of the annual Grand Circuit meeting.

Expulsion from the Socialist party of Max Schachtman, Leon Trotsky's personal representative in this country, and fifty-one other supporters of the Fourth, or Trotskyist, International, has precipitated a new split in Socialist ranks here, it was learned last night.
Harold Bauer, pianist, and Albert Spalding, violinist, will be the soloists in tonight's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Lewisohn Stadium. Willem van Hoogstraten will conduct.

With Dawn Play on the sidelines, Regal Lily today won Saratoga's championship test for 3year-old fillies when she was three lengths in the clear at the end of the mile and a quarter of the fiftyeighth Alabama Stakes.

John L. Kuser, treasurer of the People's Brewing Company and Lenox, Inc., here, and formerly an official of the Walter and Mercer automobile companies, died today at his home in Bordentown, six days after the death of a brother, Frederick. His age was 76.
The Packard Motor Car Company and the Nash Motors Division of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation joined yesterday the companies to announce increases in the retail prices of their products.

The Polish Government has expelled from Upper Silesia three German pastors of the United Evangelical Church named Schneider, Schiller and Vanzlaff. All are German citizens. They have only until Sunday to settle their affairs and leave.
The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., mailed yesLerday to shareholders its statement of earnings for the second quarter and the first six months of this year.

In the first of a series of meetings to "revitalize" the Republican party, John Hamilton, chairman of the National Committee, told committeewomen from seventeen States today that the drive to win back voters who have strayed away must come from women workers.
A seven-year record for capitalization of new stock corporations formed in any month was broken in July, when 1,313 new concerns listed capital amounting to $46,736,600.

Thirty-eight Rutgers football players have been invited to attend pre-season practice starting Sept. 1, Coach J. Wilder Tasker announced today. Practice will be held this year on Field F, on the new River Road campus, where the Rutgers Stadium is rising. This will mark the first formal use of any of the units of the million-dollar Rutgers athletic project.

A total of 388 yachts in forty-two classes crossed the three starting lines today in the Boston Yacht Club's single regatta in the midsummer series, a mark thirteen short of the record established by the club in its regatta a year ago.

With no certainty that Mayor La Guardia will continue as a candidate in the Republican primary, although designated for nomination, party leaders sought yesterday for an alternative candidate, in case the Mayor should withdraw.

Sun, thunder, rain and the Red Sox imperiled the uninterrupted procession of the Yankees today, but the world champions overcame these obstacles and swept on to their longest succession of victories of the year before one of the largest weekday crowds in the history of Fenway Park.

Mark Ambient, dramatic author, who, in 1909, wrote "The Arcadians" in collaboration with A. M. Thompson, died here today at the age of 77. He took the script to Robert Courtneidge, who, with Mr. Thompson, produced the play at the Shaftesbury Theatre, where it ran for 809 performances.

Four Greene County farmers and a mechanic will decide next Friday whether a country "schoolmarm" should get her job back despite the statements of some of her pupils That she taught evolution and beat them.

The readings taken by Dr. Rollo N. Harger, State Toxicologist, on his "drunkometer" were accepted as evidence in Municipal Court today and Mr. and Mrs. Ray Gordon of Denver were fined $5 each for intoxication.

Pan American Airways today resumed its international air mail service in Mexico after four weeks' interruption, although a strike is continuing against the Compania Mexicana de Aviation, a subsidiary.

St. Lawrence Ave, 1,436, 25x95; Dollar Savings Bank of the City of N. Y. against James S. Reynolds; due, $5,566; taxes, etc., $134; to plaintiff for $4,500. By HENRY BRADY Hollywood Ave. 1,533, 25x95: HOLC against Donato Masiello; due, $10,782; taxes, etc., $116; to plaintiff for $3,100.

After a two-day trial, a general court-martial on Governors Island yesterday acquitted First Lieutenant Roland O. S. Akre of the Air Corps of charges that he had falsified a certificate of proficiency to qualify Captain Greff Allen of the Air Corps Reserve for promotion to major.

Arthur H. Young, vice president of the United States Steel Corporation in charge of industrial relations, will retire on Oct. 1, the company announced yesterday. He will be succeeded by William Beye of Chicago, a member of the law firm of Knapp, Beye, Allen Cushing, division counsel of the corporation in Chicago for thirty-five years.

The French Government made Grover A. Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair of 1939, a Commander of the Legion of Honor yesterday in recognition of his "extensive cooperation in the success of the Paris Exposition of 1937, and for having greatly stimulated American interest in it."

Clarence L. Watts, associate defense counsel in the Scottsboro case, announced today a motion for new trials for three of the five convicted Negroes had been filed with the court clerk at Decatur, Ala.

Solly Krieger, Brooklyn middleweight, and Walter (Popeye) Woods of the West Side will meet in a tenround bout heading the weekly boxing program at Madison Square Garden tonight. With popular admission prices still prevailing, another large turnout is anticipated.

Shipments from automobile factories in the United States and Canada in July amounted to 445,550 units, a decrease of 1 per cent under the same month last year, according to a preliminary estimate issued yesterday by the Automobile Manufacturers Association. Automobiles shipped in June numbered 521,139.
Announcement was made by the Navy Department today of the death in Warner Springs, Calif., yesterday of Rear Admiral Noble Edward Irwin, retired, at the age of 67.

The first American survivors from the steamship Southern Prince, rammed amidships by a freighter way from Montevideo, Uruguay, to Buenos Aires, Argentina, arrived last night on the Munson liner Southern Cross, which docked at Montague Street, Brooklyn.

Dissolution of the Brookly Life Insurance Company and liquidation of its assets by the State Insurance Department were approved yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti. The company, according to the Insurance Department, is entirely solvent and all its capital stock is owned by the Equitable Lif Assurance Society.

Mrs. Libby Levine, 102 years old, who lived with her only child, Mrs. Rose Kramer, at 2,932 West Seventeenth Street, Coney Island, and who for thirty-one years had devoted most of a $1,000 annual income to charity, died yesterday in the Kings County Hospital, in Brooklyn.

Tex Ritter, singing cowboy of the radio and screen, makes his first cinema appearance on Broadway to today, in Grand National's "Mystery of the Hooded Horseman," which opens at the Republic Theatre...

Plans for a boycott by organized labor of Horn Hardart Automats and cafeterias in the city and for increased picketing were set in motion yesterday by the Hotel, Restaurant and Cafeteria Employes Organization Committee, which is directing the strike against the company. Picketing on a minor scale was in progress during the day.
Following the arrest of two more alleged Japanese poachers by a Commonwealth patrol boat, Japanese pearlers have decided jointly to patrol their own fleets to prevent infringement of Australian laws.

Federal officials admitted with embarrassment today that some one had apparently misplaced the historic check with which the United States bought Alaska. Treasury employes had rot seen it for thirty years, and said the General Accounting Office had it. G. A. C. officials said it could not be found right now.

A dozen or more of fifty-four persons who were indicted recently as smugglers of more than $1,000,000 worth of diamonds a year have renewed their illegal operations, Charles Murphy, Assistant United States Attorney, charged yesterday.

The total value of chemicals and related products exported during the first half of 1937 amounted to $90,000,000, as compared with $75,600,000 in the corresponding 1936 period, and was only $15,500,000 less than the record established in the first half of 1929, the Commerce Department's Chemical Division reported today.
A cholera epidemic raging in Canton and on Hainan Island, southwest of Canton, has spread to Hong Kong, resulting in fifty-nine deaths in the past twenty-four hours.

Certain passages in the message with which the President accompanied his reluctant signature to the Interior Department Appropriation Bill may be deserving of more attention than the average citizen will spontaneously give them.

Expansion of Hearns-Bronx to meet the demands resulting from material increases in sales volume was announced yesterday by Hearn Department Stores, Inc. Gross sales of the Bronx unit, which occupies the location at 149th Street and Third Avenue formerly held by the Adams-Flanigan Company,
The Wyoming, twelve-story apartment structure at 849-55 Seventh Avenue, southeast corner of Fiftyfifth Street, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms for $200,000.

Except for a bequest of $10,000 to the First Presbyterian Church and provision for family burial plots, Miss Semantha Mill left her estate, estimated at $1,000,000, to the city of Nanticoke for a public park and library, her will, filed here, disclosed today.

Eight thousand taxicab drivers struck this morning in protest against the increased fares imposed by the Government, so Paris had few taxicabs today. Ninety-five per cent of the salaried drivers are participating in the strike.

John Meier. Jr., Toledo, Ohio, defeated Harry Umbinetti, Seattle, 1 up; Robert McGlashan, San Francisco, defeated Robert Abeles, Santa Monica, 1 up; Patrick Abbot, Pasadena, Calif., defeated Ralph Presby. Sacramento, Calif., 4 and 3; Andrew Szwedko, Pittsburgh, Pa., defeated Merlin H. Luther, Buffalo, N. Y., 2 up; John Mescall, Los Angeles, defeated George Bradley, Philadelphia, 2 up; Einar Hanson. Daly City, Calif.,

George H. Houston, president of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, which is in bankruptcy, received $104,082 in salary and bonuses from the company in 1936. a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday.

A terrier pup went to jail with its master yesterday and caused enough commotion to provoke a call to the A. S. P. C. A., but left court with its freed owner before the dog-wagon arrived. Things began to happen soon after midnight in the Yankee Tavern at 352 Ninth Avenue near Thirtieth Street.

The formal opening of their new building at 12 West Fortieth Street this afternoon will mark the first change of address in twenty-three years for W. H. Hall, Inc., retail furriers. The four-story building is completely air - conditioned and

Representatives of the International Club of America, composed of prominent American and foreign tennis figures, defeated the visiting Oxford-Cambridge team in an indoor match at the River Club yesterday.
Isadore Astel, a Police Department hero, died yesterday in the Hospital for Joint Diseases as the result of wounds he received last Dec. 23 in a duel with a hold-up man whom he killed.

Frederick Strauss, senior partner in the banking firm of J. W. Seligman Co., died at 5:30 A. M. yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion after a short illness. The day of his death was also his seventy-second birthday. He had made his home at 115 East Sixty-seventh Street.
Victorious in the first two matches of their visit to Western Canada, the touring Marylebone cricketers left for Regina tonight. They will play a one-day game in the Saskatchewan capital tomorrow.

The strike of 125 drivers for grocery contract haulers of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, which precipitated last week's sympathy strike of 10,000 truck drivers and warehouse employes, was settled this afternoon, leaving the city free of a major walkout for the first time in weeks. Higher wages, better hours and improved working conditions were granted.

With one of its attractions--"Amphitryon 38"--already destined for a Shubert house, the Theatre Guild has turned again to those familiar theatrical property holders and has booked the Plymouth Theatre in which to locate its "Madame Bovary."

Many firms are expanding their quarters owing to increased business during the last year and in anticipation of even further gains in the Fall, reports from brokers indicated yesterday. The Lerner Stores Corporation leased an-additional floor, consisting of 20,00 square feet, and extended its lease on 180,000 square feet in the Mills Building, 354-60 Fourth Avenue.

A lease taken by Miss Annie M. Hegeman of Lenox, Mass., on a twelve-room apartment in 31 East Seventy-second Street, which completes the renting of this thirteen-story building for Oct. 1, was included in the long list of contracts for residential space reported yesterday. Byrne Bowman, Inc., negotiated the lease.

The track-laying race between the Pennsylvania Railroad and the Central Railroad of New Jersey on the flats leading to the "booming" factory area of Linden became complicated again today when the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners ordered the Public Service.Corporation, on whose right of way the Pennsylvania is laying its tracks, to halt the construction.

Organization of the American Communications Association as a union of radio, telegraph and telephone operators, affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization, was announced yesterday after a conference at the HIeil Edison, 228 West Forty-severm% Street.
Six persons were injured yesterday afternoon when an automobile, unable to stop quickly because of the rain-swept streets, ran into a bus at East Tremont Avenue and Dock Street, the Bronx.

T. O. M. Sopwith, owner of Endeavour II, unsuccessful challenger for the America's Cup, is ill aboard his yacht Philante at Block Island. it was made known today. He -is suffering from a severe cold and colitis. Mr. Sopwith and his party had gone to Block Island for a few days of swordfishing.

Stockholders of the Northern Securities Company approved yesterday its dissolution by a vote of 88 per cent of the stock outstanding. This action, taken in a small office near the Hoboken waterfront, marked the end of the first of the great railway holding companies. For a few years after its formation in 1901 it controlled the Northern Pacific and Great Northern Rail ways.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. F. McCann entertained aboard their yacht Chalena this afternoon with a cocktail party for Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Langhorne, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Rinehart Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Henry O. Tallmadge, Mr. and Mrs. Charlton Yarnall, Mrs. Clement

Although some secondary industries of Canada have shown decines, there has been a continuance or increase of activity in forest products, pulp, paper, iron, steel and the heavy industries generally, according to the Canadian Bank of Commerce.

A House Elections Committee voted today to recommend that Representative Arthur B. Jenks of New Hampshire be unseated and that his Democratic opponent in the election of 1936, Alphonse Roy of Manchester, be seated in his place. The vote was five to three.
The German flying boat Nordmeer reached Lisbon, Portugal, today on the first leg of a transatlantic survey flight for a passengermail route between Germany and the United States.

The Allegheny Steel Company has added 36,000 tons to its annual production capacity on high-alloy stainless and corrosion-resisting steels through the installation of a twenty-five-ton electric furnace at its plant at Brackenridge, Pa., it has announced. During the last eighteen months the company has added. 156,000 tons a year to its steel-making capacity.

The Transcontinent Shares Corporation, successor to Bank Insurance Shares, Inc., sponsors of Deposited Bank Shares and Deposited Insurance Shares, announced yesterday that Deposited Bank Shares Series B-1 and Series N. Y., offerings of which were discontinued in 1931, may be deposited in escrow or orders accepted subject to confirmation pending accumulation of a full unit for liquidation.

A California woman, blocked from her fiance by the war in Spain, took legal steps today to marry him by proxy in Barcelona. Informed that the war would keep her from going-to Barcelona, Mrs. Florence Lois Holden, 41 years old, of Berkeley, filed here a notice of intention to wed Veiner Miller, 37 years old, British consular attache at Barcelona.

Continued publication of The Seattle Star was assured today when men wearing teamsters' union buttons escorted union printers into the newspaper plant and forced American Newspaper Guild pickets to retreat a block and a half.

Brown, wiry, young Harry Shumaker lay on his cot in Bellevue Hospital yesterday, and between spasms of pain wished he was back below the Mason and Dixon line and puzzled over the following question: "What I can't understand is how I come from down Memphis, Tenn., where them black widow spiders are at, and I have to come up North to get bit by one."

Mayor Henry S. Wheeler tonight named Henry Howard, prominent sportsman, chairman of a committee to arrange for a special race between the five English and American J-boats for a cup offered by the city of Newport on Aug. 25.

While Mary Livingston, 2 1/2 years old, was jumping on a bed with her brother last evening she lost her footing, plunged through a window screen and fell five stories at her home at 510 West 136th Street. She was rushed to Harlem Hospital, where she died at 7:30 o'clock, an hour after her fall.

SHANGHAI--The Japanese massed thirty-two warships at Shanghai and landed sailors as an aftermath of the killing of a Japanese naval officer and a seaman on Monday. Page 1. NANKOW--This ancient city at the Great Wall, twenty-five miles northwest of Peiping, was set afire by Japanese artillery.

Representatives of the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, and officers of the B. M. T. met yesterday afternoon to discuss the possibility of new contracts as a result of the election of the union as the collective bargaining agency of the system.

A diamond and platinum brooch, valued at $4,000, which disappeared in 1928 while the subject of an action in Supreme Court, has been found in the salesrooms of Greenleaf Crosby Company, Inc., jewelers, according to a replevin petition filed yesterday in the Sheriff s office.

Mrs. Carmen I. Kennedy, wife of Walter B. Kennedy, former director of the Fordham Law School, appeared today in Special Sessions Court here on a charge of assault in the third degree and was paroled for further hearing Aug. 18 by City Judge Jacob A. Bernstein.

Three straight hits in the ninth inning, including a single by Pitcher Si Johnson, gave the Cardinals the winning run today in a second straight 3-to-2 victory over the Reds. Alex Kampouris hit a home run with Ernie Lombardi on base in the second inning, but otherwise Johnson held Cincinnati scoreless, although he allowed ten hits.

A general softening in United States Government bonds on a trading volume more than three times that of recent sessions was the feature yesterday of an otherwise quiet and listless day in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange. Declines throughout the Treasury list ranged from 1-32 to 10-32 point in transactions amounting to $1,103,900, compared with $345,875 on Tuesday.
Candidates backed by John L. Lewis's C. I. O. unionists emerged victorious today in the Democratic Mayoralty primaries at both Akron and Canton.

Among the deals involving Long Island properties reported yesterday was the purchase of a parcel of land in the Malba Estates, Malba, L. I., by the Villett Homes, Inc., Anthony Villett, president. The purchasers will begin immediate construction on the site of several one-family homes.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ending July 31 totaled 308,250,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.
The Archer-Daniels Midland Linseed Oil Company here instituted a general 15 per cent wage increase among 400 employes, according to announcement today by Hunter Goodrich, manager.

Viscount and Viscountess Mandeville of Huntington, England, who had been at the St. Regis after a stay in Washington, left yesterday to visit William A. Julian, Treasurer of the United States, at Glens Falls. Mr. and Mrs. Norrie Sherman Sellar of Unionville, Pa., are at the Plaza.

British public opinion has accepted the fact of the expulsion of three German journalists as not needing explanation. Britons are satisfied that the Home Office acted on solid reasons and that ends the matter.

The United States Lines has applied to the Postoffice Department for a time preference of seven days over foreign shipping companies and in favor of vessels flying the American flag for parcel post, circulars, advertising matter and other publications except daily newspapers.

The Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill permitting the sale, with approval of the United States Munitions Board, of helium in "non-military" quantities. The roll-call vote was 37 to 26. Senator Lodge led the opposition, contending that the bill failed to protect the United States against the use of the non-inflammable gas for war purposes.

Senator McNary, the Republican leader in his branch of Congress, is going home to Oregon. He might as well. What elements the Republicans have been able to contribute to prolong the sit-out strike in which the President and the Democratic Congress majority are engaged have already been given.
All available copies of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's book, "Mein Kampf," were torn up and stamped on today by fifty members of the pro-government Fatherland Front when they stormed a bookshop here.

Because of the uncertainty over what action, if any, Congress may take to offset the effects of a large crop of cotton, prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated yesterday over a range of 1/4 cent a pound to end with losses of 2 to 4 points.

Among a group of diplomats and consular officers who sailed for their new posts yesterday on the Manhattan of the United States Lines was John Cudahy, United States Minister to Poland since the Fall of 1933, who recently was appointed Minister to the Irish Free State.

Despite a deluge that drenched the Quaker Ridge links and discourage many of the eligible contestants from taking part, two golfers turned in net scores of 71 to lead the Westchester and Fairfield qualifiers in the Metropolitan Golf Association's annual handicap championship today.

The Real Estate Board of New York in a letter to the House Banking and Currency, Committee made public here yesterday, commended Senate amendments to the Wagner Housing Bill which it said met the objections of the board to the measure in its original form and recommended further amendments for consideration by the House.
Mrs. Ethel V. Mars of Chicago, owner of the Milky Way Farms, spent about $70,000 of a total of $192,600 realized for fifty-one yearlings at tonight's sale. The average per head was about $3,776.

The Associated Buying Offices has suggested to members that they ask manufacturers of garments made from crush-resistant velvet to guarantee not only color fastness but also protection from any unpleasant odors that might result from humidity or perspiration. The suggestion followed discovery that some of the processed velvets now on the market have produced an odor when subjected to moisture.

Part of the United States delegation to the Boy Scouts International Jamboree marched past Princess Juliana at the Summer palace today. With them were 100 British, Polish and Czechoslovak Scouts. Several of the United States troops have left.
Miss Elise W. Woodward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Graham Cox Wood-ward of 1,304 Pine Street, was married today to Anthony Outhberg Hopkins, son of Mrs. E. Gerald Honkins of Haddenfield N. J.

The horses were auctioned off in the betting tent, but the crowd was sold by the weather man. Big game postponed: wet grounds. No Hambletonian today. Better luck tomorrow if William H. Cane, owner of the Good Time Track here, will post some tall fellows on the hills west of the track to reach up and sweep back any threatening clouds coming in from that direction.

3d Ave (11-2929), e s, 204 ft n of 172d St, 203x100; Conmet Holding Corp to Metropolitan Casualty Co, 59 John St, 1 year, 6 per cent; $100,000. Kelly St, 838 (10-2710), Marion Molander to Grace D. Goldsmith. trustee, 755 Park Ave, installments, 4 per cent; $17,500. 141st St. 626-630 E (10-2553); Rosengarten Realty Corp to State Mortgage Commission, extends mtgs to July 10, 1940, at 51 per cent; $152,500.

Stressing the danger of having new motorists learn to drive automobiles on regular city streets, J. R. Crossley, vice president of the New York Automobile Club, yesterday requested Corporation Counsel Paul Windels, chairman of the City Traffic Commission, to hold public hearings to consider the need for a training and testing area convenient to the city.

Because of misappropriation and mismanagement the City College cooperative store has lost more than $54,000 during the last five years, according to a report submitted to the Board of Higher Education yesterday by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts.

Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff has gone on a vacation, and during his absence Vladimir Potemkin will be Acting Foreign Commissar, according to an official announcement tonight through Tass, Soviet news agency.

David Hall Rowland, retired New York banker, died last night at his home here. He was born in New York eighty-two years ago. Before his retirement fifteen years ago he was president of the National Butchers and Drovers Bank and vice president of the Columbia Bank, both of New York, which have since been merged with other metropolitan banks.

Clay Bryant's pitching and an eleven-hit attack off Red Lucas that included Augie Galan's seventeenth homer and Gabby Hartnett's eighth, the National League-leading Cubs defeated the Pirates 5 to 1, before 11,363 today to even the series at one game apiece.

The United States chess team, competing in defense of the HamiltonRussell Trophy in the tournament of the International Chess Federation at the Grand Royal Hotel today, divided three points in the games held over from the match with The Netherlands in the thirteenth round.

Some details of the huge experimental bombing plane built for the navy by the Sikorsky division of the United Aircraft Corporation were revealed by the Navy Department today as arrangements were completed for the builders' trials in the vicinity of the plant in Bridgeport, Conn. Later acceptance trials will be run from Bridgeport or in the Washington-Norfolk area.
Edwin (Rit) Goddard, All-America halfback at Washington State, has been signed by the Brooklyn Dodgers of the National Football League, it was announced by Coach George (Potsy) Clark yesterday.
Favorites toppled like tenpins today as a dwindling field went through the first and second rounds of the national public links golf championship.

Representative Fish resigned today from the Republican Policy Committee of the House, in protest against the appointment by Speaker Bankhead of Representative Wadsworth as minority member from the House on the New York World's Fair Commission.

George McCullough, 57 years old, a Pennsylvania Railroad engineer, who was burned by 22,000 volts of electricity from a high tension wire last Saturday, died this afternoon at the Jersey City Medical Center.
The last twilight flicker of the Victorian era has died out in London with the passing of Mudie's famous circulating library

The office of Senator Harrison, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, tonight confirmed the receipt of a letter from President Roosevelt "setting forth his views" on sugar legislation "in its present form."
The city of New Rochelle moved today to levy taxes on more than $1,000,000 of property owned by Westchester County when City Assessor Paul A. Bankson announced his tax roll for next year.

While twenty convicts were at work today in the chemical laboratory at the State prison here manufacturing insecticides for use of other institutions, a flare-up of chemicals ignited wooden rafters of the one-story structure.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Perhaps the Board of Education will be moved to do something about opening many more school yards which are suitable for play and recreational purposes for children as well as adults.

Nine persons were killed and three others injured last night when two small frame dwellings on Staten Island crashed as though hit by a bomb during a severe electrical storm accompanied by heavy rainfall. The buildings, nearly fifty years old, at 1 and 3 New Street, New Brighton, within a few blocks of the Kill van Kull,

The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved the application of six railroad and terminal companies operating about 700 miles of lines through Illinois, with their apex at St. Louis, to consolidate into one company to be known as the Illinois Terminal Railroad Company.

Miss Joan Sterling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Sterling of this place, has selected the afternoon of Sept. 25 for her marriage to Newton Buckner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Buckner of New York. The ceremony will take place in Christ Church here.

The list of the motorship Vulcania of the Italian Line, incoming from Mediterranean ports, includes Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Betts, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Edwards, Mr. and Mrs. J. Lee Barnes, Miss Emily Lord, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin S.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange has authorized the listing of the following securities: Allied Stores Corporation 5 per cent preferred stock, $100 par value, in the amount of 5,894 additional shares;

A bill to require fabric manufacturers to label their products so as to show percentages of fiber contents won the approval today of the Senate Commerce Committee. The measure, offered by Senator Capper of Kansas, would authorize the Federal Trade Commission to outlaw misbranding of woven and knitted fabrics.
The National Association of Chain, Drug Stores has arranged to hold its semi-annual meeting at the Hotel Biltmore on Oct. 13, 14 and 15, it was announced yesterday by Fred Griffiths, secretary.

The American Chamber of Commerce announced today its opposition to any suggestion for withdrawal of United States Army troops from Tientsin. Such a possibility has been rumored, without any official confirmation.

The drive for stern measures to check sex crimes against children received practical support yesterday from County Judge Peter J. Brancato in Brooklyn. He sentenced Raymon C. Rodriquez to twentyfive years to life imprisonment on his plea of guilty of assaulting two 10-year-old girls.

Pushing its campaign to organize the Ford Motor Company's 150,000 employes, the United Automobile Workers of America distributed union pamphlets at the gates of the vast Rouge plant today without a semblance of disorder.

Harold I. Sewall, 66 years old, a Harvard graduate and long a resident of Puerto Rico, is recovering at the Presbyterian Hospital from a grave infection caused by the bite of one of his twelve Siamese cats two weeks ago. His temperature, once reaching 105 degrees, has subsided to normal following a second blood transfuzion.

Attorney General Charles J. Margiotti declared today that the Federal Government was trying to take from the State the power of appointing employes of the Unemployment Compensation Board, with a threat to withhold social security grants.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates being Aug. 10 unless specified: San Francisco to San Pedro: Arizona, Astoria, California, Chicago, Colorado, Concord, Idaho, Indianapolis, Louisville, Maryland, Minneapolis, Mississippi, Medusa, New Orleans, New Mexico, Northampton, Pensacola, Portland, Quincy, Salt Lake City, San Francisco, Tennessee, Tuscaloosa, West Virginia.
The Canadian Department of Mines and Resources today announced migratory bird regulations for the 1937 hunting season, extending the 1936 restrictions, imposed to meet serious depletion of waterfowl.

Rain yesterday washed out the second game of the series between the Giants and Bees at the Polo Grounds and deprived the Terrymen of the chance to make swift amends for the defeat they suffered in the opening contest with the Boston club on Tuesday.
Four grocers in the Bronx were robbed last night in a period of two hours. Two pairs of thugs, one white and the other Negro, are believed to have committed two thefts each. The loot totaled $182.
Cornelius Corkery of 35-20 Ninetysecond Street, Jackson Heights, a deputy tax commissioner in Queens for twenty-two years, was found dead yesterday in bed at his home. His age was 62.
I. A. Hirschmann, vice president of Saks Fifth Avenue, returned yesterday on the French liner Champlain from a five-week visit to Europe, during which he visited France, Switzerland and Italy.

A motion to strike out portions of the evidence in the Securities and Exchange Commission's case against W. E. Hutton Co. for alleged manipulation of the stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation was argued yesterday at 120 Broadway before Edward C. Johnson, the trial examiner.

Close-of-play scores in first class cricket matches started today follow: Sussex 257 (Cox 31, Hollies 5 for 43); Warwickshire 127 for 2. at Hove. Galamorgan 310 (Turnbull 124, Duckfiled 69, Smart 67, Herman 4 for 53); Hampshire 29 for 2, at Southampton. Nortghamptaonshire 115 (Park 5 for 54, Martin 5 of 50); Worcestershire 134 for 2, at Worcestershire.

Miss Lucrezia Bori, who arrived yesterday to visit Miss Fanny Cottenet, was guest of honor today at a luncheon given by her hostess and later at a tea given by the directors of the Studio of Acting at the water garden at Greycroft.
Almost one-fourth of the Princeton athletes who won letters in varsity sports this year are on the university's academic honor roll, according to figures released today by the athletic association.

A freight train steamed into Reading today about a dozen lengths behind the flying hoofs of a 6-year-old thoroughbred horse. Patrolman Frank Amaroso, who captured the horse, said the animal had raced ahead of the train for several miles.

The governors of the New York Curb Exchange approved yesterday the transfer of the regular membership of L. M. Kohn to T. F. Bernstein of Carl M. Loeb Co. The governors approved the listing, subject to registration under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, of 654,600 shares of common

The Senate will not act on any part of President Roosevelt's program for reorganization of the executive structure unless the current session of Congress is prolonged beyond present expectations, Senator Byrnes, chairman of the Special Senate Committee handling the matter, said today after a conference with the President.

The annual shower of Perseid meteors, believed by some astronomers to be the remnants of comets, will be seen at their most spectacular phase today and for the next few nights. Dr. Clyde Fisher, head of the Hayden Planetarium, and Dr. Charles P. Olivier, head of the American Meteor Society has asked that watchers of the heavens count the number of meteors they see and report to them.

Headed by Miss Kay Stammers, the entire British Wightman Cup tennis squad will play here in the Pacific Southwest tennis championships Sept. 16-26 and the Pacific Coast championships at San Francisco shortly afterward.

The Book - of - the - Month Club choice for September is "Animal Treasure," by Ivan T. Sanderson, a story of life in tropical Africa where the author went on a zoological expedition. Viking is the publisher.
The proposed partitioning of Palestine was termed "outrageous" today by Senator Royal S. Copeland in a short speech in the Senate, the second time he has spoken in opposition to the British proposal.

Joe Balestri of Washington clung to a one-stroke lead in the union printers international golf tourney today, but shared the day's honors with Ed Gabelman of Cincinnati, twotime association titleholder.

William Harvey Walter, a past commander of G. A. R. Post 21, died at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Florence Reynolds here yesterday at the age of 94. He enlisted in the 188th Pennsylvania Volunteers at the outbreak of the Civil War.

Members of the Joint Legislative Committee created to study the State's fiscal problems met with Governor Lehman this afternoon to discuss informally the work of the committee as regards methods and scope.
Stocks closed irregularly lower; turnover, 571,890 shares. United States Government bonds lower; other issues mixed; transactions, $6,760,900.

FINANCIAL NOTES Robert G. Hutchins has been elected a director of the Rutland Railroad to succeed the late Edward Milligan. C. A. Schroeder, manager of the local retail sales department of Falvey, Waddell Co., Inc., has been elected a vice president.

The report of the Cities Service Company and subsidiaries for the first half of this year, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after interest, depreciation, amortization, profit and loss adjustments, Federal income taxes and other charges, of $4,398,736.

The State Department moved today to reassure Argentina and Chile, which have been critical of the project for leasing six United States destroyers to Brazil, through explanations given their Ambassadors orally by Sumner Welles, UnderSecretary of State.

A Board of Officers is appointed to meet at Buffalo, N. Y., at the call of the presldent thereof, to examine such persons as may be properly ordered before it to determine their fitness for appointment or certificate of capacity In the Officers Reserve Corps.

The tails of most pigs turn to the left, but some are reactionary and swing to the right, Fred W. Jackson of the Department of Agriculture today advised a farm girl of Whitehouse, N. J., who had asked: "Which way does a pig's tail curl?" A pig whose tail turns in neither direction is a pig of low vitality, Mr. Jackson added.

Carding an 82 on the rain-soaked Deal Golf Club course, Dr. Walter F. Barry of Essex County, the association champion, today won the midsummer tournament of the New Jersey State Seniors' Golf Association.

Whether the $10,000-a-year cost of maintaining the gardens in the Edward T. Bedford estate at Green Farms may be deducted from the gross income of the Bedford estate for Federal income tax purposes is in dispute between the administrator and the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

The appointment of a European committee with headquarters in Paris to look after the interests of American exporters and others whose funds have been tied up in Spain was decided upon yesterday at a meeting of the National Foreign Trade Council's committee on Spain. The decision to set up a foreign branch of the committee here followed a report that funds tied up are considerably larger than was first estimated and may exceed $80,000,000.

Miss Marion Miley of Cincinnati all but shook off the opposition today in her quest for a third straight Women's Western 72-hole medal play golf derby crown by firing another sub-par round over the Onwentsia Club course.

With retailers and manufacturers cooperating, plans were pushed last night at a meeting at the Governor Clinton Hotel to set up standards to guide the industry and prevent the use of incorrect names in the selling and advertising of fur gariments. Trade practice and advertising standards were proposed.

IT is my guess that Walter Duranty set out to write the "Uncle Tom's Cabin" of Communist revolution. His novel, "One Life, One Kopeck" (Simon Schuster, $2.50), is a naive but colorful product of a new age of faith. The novel is a Red shocker, drawn along strictly Party lines, fiercely moralistic a la Marx.

The flock of pigeons that frequents Verdi Square, south of Seventy-third Street, between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue, fed there tranquilly yesterday although it had been depleted by poison which. killed at least seventy birds.

Raymond Massey, English actor, was feeling blue today, his tenth in a hospital, nursing a leg ailment which had interrupted work on a picture. He had wanted to get back to his wife in London before their third child was born. Then the telephone rang; it was London.

The inside story of Ernst F. S. Hanfstaengl's mysterious flight from Germany last March is that it was prompted by his discovery that a detachment of the Hitler Elite Guards was assigned to take him for a one-way ride in an airplane.
Japanese gunfire shook the Great Wall of China yesterday when the vanguard of the Chinese forces moving toward Peiping from the north were driven out of Nankow.
Many arrived at Berkshire hotels today for the start tomorrow night at Tanglewood of the second series of Boston Symphony Orchestra concerts. An all-Wagnerian program will be given.

Favorites marched through the first round of match play in the eighth annual New York State women's amateur golf championship at the Onondaga Country Club today, paced for the second successive day by 19-year-old Miss Marjorie Harrison of Ausable Forks.
Leopold A. Spier, for many years a retail coal merchant here and a member of an old New Haven family, died at his home here today after more than a year's illness. He was 60 years old.

In spite of all that has been said and done about the American merchant marine, it cannot be said that we have ever had a shipping policy based on an accurate knowledge of what a merchant marine is for.

A jagged bolt of lightning struck the Edison Memorial Tower here today and toppled the 130-foot structure to the ground, but miraculously did not extinguish the little model incandescent light set in the base of the tower as a perpetual memorial to the late inventor.

J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, has announced completion of the liquidation of twenty-six bank receiverships in July, making 735 receiverships closed or restored to solvency since the bank holiday of March, 1933. Total disbursements were $249,982,631, or an average of 79.11 per cent of total liabilities.

Sir Michael Keane, former Governor of Assam, died here today after a short illness. He was 63 years old. Sir Mhael's Governorship of Assam was remarkable. In the short space of four years he reorganized the country's government, finances and health service, and improved the lot of native women and rebuilt roads. The bridge over the Surma River was named after him.
Mme. Toti dal Monte, a leading coloratura soprano of the Italian operatic stage, was injured in an automobile accident en route to the sea resort of Rimini.

Miss Anita Pohndorff entertained today at her cottage in honor of the birthday of Miss Jane Morton. Mr. and Mrs. Harold Anderson, Mrs. W. Scott Cameron and Mrs. H. C. Gray gave luncheons today at the Gideon Putnam.

All signs tonight pointed to some rail-down sailing as yachts entered in one of Long Island Sound's leading longdistance events rode at anchor here waiting for the start of the American Yacht Club's annual racing cruise to the eastward.

Turpentine firm, 31c bid. No sales. Receipts. 394 barrels; shipments, 69 barrels; stock, 35,125 barrels. Resin firm. Sales, 864: receipts, 1,321; shipments. 2,623; stock, 61,289. Quote: 'B. D, E, $7.50; F to WG, S7.60; WW, 8x, .40.

Revolutionary days and the early history of ope of Long Island's residential landmarks were brought to mind by an important realty purchase announced yesterday. The entire block, comprising lots, bounded by Twenty-eighth Twenty-ninth Avenues,

Steel ingot output for the country is estimated for this week at 84 1/2 per cent, a decrease of half a point from last week, but further slight adjustment downward is possible this month prior to the resumption of buying on a larger scale for early Autumn requirements, according to the weekly summary of The Iron Age.

A Soviet flight around the top of the world along the Arctic Circle, with Pilot Mikhail Sheveleff in charge, was proposed today in the Communist party newspaper Pravda. The 12,000-mile flight would be routed by way of Alaska, Hudson Bay or Baffin Land, Greenland, Iceland and the northeastern Russian coast.

The fate of the paintings contained in Munich's exhibition of "degenerate art" is still uncertain. Zealous apostles of the Nazi form of art "which everybody can understand" suggest an auto-da-fe. The Schwarze Korps.
Hunting "tanks" will roll across Scottish moors tomorrow as the grouse-shooting season opens. King George VI will be among the hunters.

Police Commissioner Valentine declared yesterday that he would ask for a 1938 budget appropriation large enough to bring the department's personnel to the full charter quota of 19,331. The request for an enlarged force will be discussed at a hearing to be held by Budget Director Leo J. McDermott on Aug. 25.
A plan for establishing a colony in Costa Rica for Jewish refugees from Nazi Germany, beginning with several hundred families, has just been revealed.

R. H. Macy Co., Inc., by entering the field of national distribution of its private brands, has accepted the principle, of price maintenance within trading areas, Crichton, Clarke, counsel for the American Booksellers Association, declared a statement issued yesterday.
ONE LIFE, ONE KOPECK, by Walter Duranty. (Simon Schuster, $2.50.) A novel of Russia. PRESBYTERIAN PIRATE: A PORTRAIT OF STEVENSON, by Doris N. Dalglish. (Oxford, $3.50.) A new biography.

Four young Chinese-born pilots who have been flying in the metropolitan area for two years revealed today that they intended to sail within a month for the Far East to enlist in the Chinese Air Corps in the hostilities with Japan.

Parliament will convene Monday in special session to deal with steamship subsidies in the New York service. It also is believed possible that the legislators will be asked to allow the Governor to use an automobile in the performance of his duties.

Mayor La Guardia appointed Nathan Frankel, a lawyer, yesterday as his counsel in labor relations. Mr. Frankel will take the place of Burton A. Zorn, former executive secretary of the City Industrial Relations Board, who has gone to the State Board of Mediation in a similar capacity.

A sailboat, believed to-be the Scud, owned and skippered by G. Wallace Thorpe, an engineer of the State Highway Department, residing at 56 Asylum Street, New Haven, upset tonight off Stratford. Mr. Thorpe and a woman companion were missing and it was feared they were drowned.
That the flow of capital to this country from Europe has been resumed definitely, after a pause of about a month, seems to be indicated by yesterday's increased gold engagements abroad.

Timely clouting produced a double victory for the Indians today over the Browns, Bob Feller taking the opener, 5 to 2, and Denny Galehouse the second, 7 to 2. Returning to League Park after a disastrous Eastern invasion, Cleveland spoiled the start of the first St. Louis trip here under Jim Bottomley's management, aided by home runs by Lyn Lary and Billy Sullivan.

American farmers have no reason to fear unlimited production, Louis J. Taber, Master of the National Grange, declared here tonight. Although Mr. Taber's statement directly contradicts the viewpoint President Roosevelt insisted upon yesterday, he refused to take issue openly with the President, confining himself to a statement of principle, namely, that limitation of crop production was unsound.

Two Clearview huskies, Joe Kelly, a school teacher, and Ray McDonnell, a contractor, annexed the Long Island best-ball championship by the unusual process of producing a net thirty-sixhole total of 129 on the Sands Point course with the aid of only three birdies.

There was no man better known to the college fraternities with their 500,000 members than Francis W. Shepardson, whose sudden death has ended a varied career of extraordinary activity in promoting scholarship in America.

Settlements in the silk and rayon strike that permitted 8,000 workers in Pennsylvania to return to their jobs were announced yesterday by spokesmen for the Textile Workers Organizing Committee here and elsewhere, while 6,000 strikers in the Paterson-Passaic area in New Jersey were hoping to resume work as a result of negotiations.

One hundred and thirty inhabitants of the Valley of Simodalen, in Western Norway, raced for their lives up steep mountainsides yesterday as a million-ton section of glacier, melted by the Summer heat, broke off and fell into a small mountain lake, raising a tidal wave 200 feet high.

More than 800 students and eighty members of the faculty of the Juilliard Summer School will be introduced to Oscar Wagner, new dean of the Juilliard School of Music, at a reception in his honor this afternoon at 5 o'clock in the garden of the school.

Members of the Summer colony and their guests filled Parrish Memorial Hall tonight when the Southampton Players under the direction of Donald Blackwell opened their fifth production for this season, "Step Into My Parlor," a new melodrama by John and Mary Risiean.

Reporting upon the financial operation of the State of New York for the fiscal year ended on June 30, last, Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, submitted today in condensed but comprehensive form a picture of the State's financial condition.

The national women's champions of Poland and the United States, one of the leading players of France and Miss Gracyn Wheeler of Santa Monica, Calif., advanced to the semifinals of the Eastern turf court tennis championships at the Westchester Country Club today before rain washed out the men's matches.

The Pennsylvania taxidermist who puts grouse eyes in a woodcock or daubs too much color on a mounted trout not only will have to brave the fury of an angry sportsman but will stand a good chance of losing his license.

Frank Ladd, owner and manager of the Old Griswold House at Essex for thirty-eight years, died yesterday at the hostelry at the age of 83 pears. Mr. Ladd was born in Tolland and before acquiring ownership of the Griswold House conducted a restaurant in Providence.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Bavier of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margery Anne Bavier, to John H. Donald, son of Mrs. Hugh C. Donald of Paisley, Scotland, and the late Dr. Donald of Edinburgh.

American farmers have no reason to fear unlimited production, Louis J. Taber, Master of the National Grange, declared here tonight. Although Mr. Taber's statement directly contradicts the viewpoint President Roosevelt insisted upon yesterday, he refused to take issue openly with the President, confining himself to a statement of principle, namely, that limitation of crop production was unsound.

Settlements in the silk and rayon strike that permitted 8,000 workers in Pennsylvania to return to their jobs were announced yesterday by spokesmen for the Textile Workers Organizing Committee here and elsewhere, while 6,000 strikers in the Paterson-Passaic area in New Jersey were hoping to resume work as a result of negotiations.

One hundred and thirty inhabitants of the Valley of Simodalen, in Western Norway, raced for their lives up steep mountainsides yesterday as a million-ton section of glacier, melted by the Summer heat, broke off and fell into a small mountain lake, raising a tidal wave 200 feet high.

More than 800 students and eighty members of the faculty of the Juilliard Summer School will be introduced to Oscar Wagner, new dean of the Juilliard School of Music, at a reception in his honor this afternoon at 5 o'clock in the garden of the school.

Members of the Summer colony and their guests filled Parrish Memorial Hall tonight when the Southampton Players under the direction of Donald Blackwell opened their fifth production for this season, "Step Into My Parlor," a new melodrama by John and Mary Risiean.

Reporting upon the financial operation of the State of New York for the fiscal year ended on June 30, last, Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, submitted today in condensed but comprehensive form a picture of the State's financial condition.

The national women's champions of Poland and the United States, one of the leading players of France and Miss Gracyn Wheeler of Santa Monica, Calif., advanced to the semifinals of the Eastern turf court tennis championships at the Westchester Country Club today before rain washed out the men's matches.

The Pennsylvania taxidermist who puts grouse eyes in a woodcock or daubs too much color on a mounted trout not only will have to brave the fury of an angry sportsman but will stand a good chance of losing his license.
Undisturbed by a heavy rainstorm, Captain James Coles of Winsloe, Prince Edward Island, today won the Macdonald Brier match at the annual meeting of the Dominion of Canada Rifle Association.

Cut off from transportation to the south, Chinese officials and wealthy Chinese are experiencing great difficulties in evacuating North China areas now under Japanese control. The exodus now under way comprises every class of Chinese, coolies and peasants going to Manchukuo, while intellectuals, former leaders and propertied families are traveling southward.

The promotion of J. Howard Miller, formerly assistant director of the Federal Theatre Project for the western region, to Deputy National Administrator, was announced today by Mrs. Ellen S. Woodward, assistant Works Progress Administrator, in charge of women's and professional Projects.

The current annual cruise race week of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association is creating new records daily. This morning, after the start of a race at 10:45, scheduled to be sailed yesterday but postponed because of inclement weather, Albert Van Winkle, chairman of the race week committee, announced a record high entry list of 161 boats.

Many Summer residents of the Berkshires entertained tonight at the fourth Boston Symphony Orchestra concert at Tanglewood. Mr. and Mrs. Owen Johnson had as box guests Mrs. Johnson's sonin-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue Livingston Jr., and Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Cromwell. In Miss Mabel Choate's box were Mr. and Mrs. Geoffrey Platt and Miss Mary Putnam Hayden of New York and Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Harrison Jr. of Washington.

Two new Japanese freighters, making their maiden voyages between the Orient and the United States, are due to arrive in port Aug. 23 and 27. Both have docked at Pacific Coast ports to land freight before proceeding to New York and other ports on the Atlantic Coast.
Hearings will be begun in Pittsburgh on Sept. 3 before a full court of three judges on exceptions filed against the opinion of Judge Elder Marshall in the Pittsburgh United Corporation case.

Employment and payrolls of the American steel industry during June declined sharply from May, as a result of strike conditions prevailing throughout a large part of the month in plants of four major companies, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Great pressure is being brought upon Thomas E. Dewey to give up his post of Special Prosecutor and run for District Attorney of New York County on the Republican and subsequently the Fusion ticket in order to assure a harmony now lacking among those groups whose fusion is essential for the continuance in office of the present city Administration.

A but ninth-inning single by Third Baseman Buddy Lewis scored the winning run for Washington today and gave the Senators a 5-to-4 victory over the Athletics. Lewis's single scored Mel Almada from second base.

Describing the Supreme Court as the bulwark for the preservation of liberties granted by the Constitution, Senator Burton K. Wheeler, Montana Democrat, today declared "yes men" could never solve the problems of society.

The Spanish Ambassador, Fernando de los Rios, Mrs. de los Rios and their daughter, Miss Laura de los Rios, will attend the Spanish Fiesta to be given tomorrow afternoon and evening at the Adolph Zukor estate near New City, N. Y., under the auspices of the Rockland County Spanish Milk Fund to relieve the distressed children of Spain.

Gerald Balding, playing in his first game since his recent return from England, was back at his old No. 2 position as Greentree, the national champion, vanquished Delray in a keen polo match at Phipps Field today, 10--8.

J. W. N. Sullivan, essayist and interpreter of modern science, died today at Chobham at the age of 51. He was an outstanding mathematician and when the theory of relativity was introduced shortly after the World -War he was one of the few people in Britain able to penetrate behind its symbols.

No mention of his two screen star brothers, Ralph and Frank Morgan, is made in the will of Adolph Edward Wuppermann, president of the Angostura Bitters Corporation, who died at his home, Calhoun Drive, Greenwich, on July 31.

Eight hours after two Negroes were captured yesterday in an early morning, hold-up in a Harlem apartment, in which one of three alleged Negro confederates was shot and killed by a Negro detective, they were indicted by the New York County grand jury.
The Japanese Cabinet has decided to negotiate with the Chinese authorities for the cessation of hostile or provocative movements in Shanghai.

Transfers and Assignments SERGEANT-Edward M. J. Regan, from 64th Precinct to office of the Police Commissioner. PATROLMEN-Philip B. Korher. 1st Precinct. assigned to duty as attendant. Timothy' J. Hushion. 18th Precinct. assignment to duty as attendant discontinued. George W. Baker. from 22d Precinct to 18th Precinct, assigned to duty as attendant.
Senate safety-at-sea investigators recommended today that Congress outlaw the "hiring halls" through which maritime unions control the selection of ship personnel.

The Department of Agriculture reported today that fewer cattle were being fed for market in the Corn Belt at the start of this month than any time in many years. A survey by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics showed that 29 per cent fewer cattle were being fattened for the market on Aug. 1 than a year earlier.

Sales of General Motors cars and trucks to dealers in the overseas markets in July amounted to 31,341 units, a gain of 23 per cent over July last year. In the first seven months, sales of 219,162 cars and trucks represented an all-time high for the period, and a gain of 10.2 per cent over sales for the same period in 1936.

Emanuel Lowinson, the retired printer and stationer who had been confident that he would live to be 100 years old, died yesterday morning, at 99, seated in his favorite armchair in his apartment at 601 West 112th Street.

Two alleged leaders of an arson ring which has destroyed more than $400,000 worth of Westchester County and Connecticut property were convicted this afternoon of firstdegree arson by a jury after less than three hours' deliberation.

The marriage of Mrs. Agnes Maas Lewyn of 1,148 Fifth Avenue, widow of Oswald M. Lewyn and daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gustavus Maas, to Alfred Benjamin of Scarsdale, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Benjamin of 29 East Sixty-fourth Street, took place yesterday morning in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building. The ceremony was performed by Deputy City Clerk Philip A. Hines.

If the present rate of increased demand for higher priced radios maintained, the 1937 average Philco sale will be close to the $100 mark, Thomas A. Kennally, national sales manager of the Philco Radio and Television Corporation of Philadelphia, announced yesterday.

Frederic H. Hoe, president of the Airedale Terrier Club of America and well-known dog fancier and exhibitor, died here today at his residence, 972 George Street. He was 78 years old. For many years Mr. Hoe had exhibited at leading dog shows in New York, Boston and other cities.

Middlesex defeated Essex by 307 runs today to keep its place at the head of the first-class county cricket championship standing. Glamorgan, Surrey, Gloucestershire, Lancashire and Worcestershire were other winners in matches ending today, a day ahead of the series.

Nineteen bodies were recovered yesterday from the mud-packed debris at 1, 3 and 5 New Street in New Brighton, S. I., where rainstorm floodwater swept away the foundations at 10 o'clock Wednesday night and sucked poverty-stricken tenants, brick walls, beams and furniture anywhere from 50 to 100 feet northward, toward Kill Van Kull.

Shipments of hard coal in July, as reported to the Anthracite Institute, amounted to 2,421,504 net tons. This is a decrease, compared with June, of 1,618,859 tons, and, compared with July, 1936, of 923,805.

The volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding at the end of July was $351,556,950, a decrease of $12,646,893 in the month and $36,028,510 above a year before, according to the monthly survey issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The stock market generally was quiet today, with prices easing in most sections. Gilt-edge issues were slightly lower and Far Easterns continued weak among the foreign. In the transatlantic group some easiness developed in International Nickel, but others on the dollar list were better on Wall Street advices.

Mayor La Guardia will be the guest of Electrical Workers Union, Local 3, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, at a celebration by the union on Aug. 30 to mark the first anniversary of the six-hour day in the electrical industry in New York.

Officials of the State, War and Navy Departments regard the force of 1,100 officers and men of the Fourth Regiment of Marines in the International Settlement at Shanghai as sufficient protection for Americans in the event of a Japanese attack on that city.

At the request of many who were unable to attend the Gershwin memorial concert last Monday at Lewisohn Stadium, the Stadium Concerts Committee announces that tomorrow night's concert will offer as much of the original Gershwin program as possible.

A thousand residents of the Flushing area attended the third annual track and field meet held yesterday under the auspices of the Police Athletic League of the Juvenile Aid Bureau, at Memorial Field, 149th and Bayside Avenues.

The German flying boat Nordmeer will leave Lisbon at 8:30 A. M. (3:30 A. M. Eastern standard time) tomorrow for the Azores on the second leg of her transatlantic survey flight, it was decided here tonight. Officials of Deutsche
William Perry Doing, as president of the Fanpardo Realty Corporation, bought from the Chemical Bank and Trust Company the sixstory walk-up apartment house at 539 East 138th Street, the Bronx.

William Hartz, traveling auditor for the I. R. T. Company and formerly chief accountant for the Long Island Railroad, died on Tuesday at his home, 285 Lefferts Avenue, Brooklyn. He was born in this city seventy years ago and had lived in Brooklyn most of his life.

ASTEL--Isidore. The Shomrlm Society of the Police Department of the City of New York announces with deep sorrow the death of Brother Isidore Astel on Aug. 11, 1937. Funeral from Park West Memorial Chapel, 115 West 79th St., Friday, Aug. 13, at 10:30 A. M. Interment at Shomrim Field, Monteflore Cemetery, Springfield, L. L.

President Roosevelt today nominated Senator Hugo Black of Alabama, an ardent supporter of the New Deal and co-author of the BlackConnery Wage-Hour Bill, to be Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, filling the vacancy caused by the retirement of Justice Van Devanter.
With the time for filing, declinations for party nominations expiring at 12 o'clock tonight, the following declinations were filed yesterday with the Board of Elections:

The Myron Arms Apartments, fourteen-story multi-family building at 2,280-2,286 Broadway, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. The structure, which has frontage of 102.2 feet on Broadway and 142.4 feet on Eighty-second Street, was bought in by the Gramercy Park Apartments, Inc., for $55,000.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., announced yesterday that it had leased for twenty-five years the building to be erected at the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street. The structure,

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 7,000. Including 2,000 directs. 170-210 pound averages steady to weak; others and sows steady to 10c lower than Wednesday's average; top, $13.50; bulk good and choice 180-230 pounds. $13.15-45;

Manna, famous since biblical times, when it formed an important part of the rations of the tribes of Israel wandering in Syria's deserts, is beginning to feel competition's pinch, the Commerce Department revealed today.

Ordinances putting a 2 per cent tax on all premium payments on insurance written by mutual fire and life companies on Philadelphians or on property inside the city, were passed today by the City Council. The tax applies to companies with some offices here.

Asserting that thousands of employes of telegraph and other communications companies face dismissal in the near future because of improved labor-saving devices, John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, urged them last night to organize in order to protect themselves against this threat.
When the Senate sent the nomination of Senator Black to the Judiciary Committee today it was the first time since 1888 that it had taken such procedure with a member or former member.

Gold imports totaled $175,623,720 during July, compared with $262,102,813 in June and $16,073,990 in July a year ago. In making this report the Commerce Department said today $44,459,042 of the July imports came from Japan, which has been shipping gold to maintain the stability of the yen.

Helen Woodward, author of "Three Flights Up" and "Through Man Windows," for long a copywriter and advertising executive, is spending the Summer in San Francisco, where she is at work on a new book about the influences of advertising on modern living. Dodd, Mead will publish the book in the Spring.

Miss Grace Ann Schwing, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Schwing of Mount Vernon, was married this afternoon to Edward Maurice Saunders Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Maurice Saunders of Bronxville, in St. Joseph's Church here. The Rev. Joseph McCann, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

Al bert Ulrich of North Bergen, parachute jumper, swung through a window pane into a bedroom in the Summer home of Mr. and Mrs. Edward K. Whitmore here this afternoon, as the unscheduled feature of Governor Hoffman's third Governor's Day celebration at Camp Hoffman.
Paul V. McNutt, High Commissioner to the Philippines, has informed friends here that he expects to relinquish his post at Manila and return to Indiana by May or June next year, it was learned today.

Trading was slow on most classes of fresh meats. Veal and calf cuts continued to sell lower. Some grassy steer cuts were lower, but better grades were mostly unchanged. Lamb appeared to strengthen slightly. Fresh pork cuts were steady to slightly lower, while other classes were mostly steady.

Driving a well-conceived and perfectly executed race, Henry Thomas, noted Western reinsman, today won the twelfth trotting of the Hambleto, nian Stake, classic of the light-harness turf, with Shirley Hanover.
Reaping is general throughout the Prairie Provinces of Canada and threshing has been started in some districts, according to the Bank of Montreal.

The Marine Corps announced today the following changes for the week ended Aug. 10: CAPTAINS Lee, W. H.; orders modified: about Sept. 15 detached from Pearl Harbor and ordered to Norfolk. Va., via the Chaumont. Watchman. M.; un arrival at San Francisco ordered to Norfolk Navy Yard Detachment Portsmouth. Va.

Patrolman William Menninger, 41 years old, attached to the Ozone Park precinct in Queens, who had been picked out at 8 A. M. yesterday by an unidentified citizen as the policeman who had once assaulted him, was found at 11 o'clock last night, shot fatally through the head, at his home at 116-14 Sutter Avenue, Ozone Park.

Press reports released today disclose that the Chinese forces defending Chinghochen made a desperate resistance for three days against the Japanese attackers. The Japanese began their, attack on the afternoon of July 28 by cutting a clear space in the high Kaoliang.

Former Representative Charles G. Bond announced last night that he would decline the designation for the Republican nomination for Mayor in favor of Senator Royal S. Copeland, Tammany's candidate for Mayor in the Republican primary, and would act as the Senator's Brooklyn campaign manager.

Bryan M. Grant Jr. of Atlanta, third in the national ranking, was eliminated from the Eastern grass court tennis championships at the Westchester Country Club today and his Davis Cup team-mates, Donald Budge and Gene Mako,
French Army planes and motorized infantry dispersed concentrations of rebellious Kurds at several points in Northeastern Syria today in an effort to end more than a month of disorders.
The Insurgents renewed their "drive of obliteration" against Santander today, while Government air forces repeatedly raided Insurgent-held cities west and southwest of Madrid.

Troops of the Chinese Eighty-ninth Division today held the strategic Nankow Pass, mountain gateway to Chahar, against a mechanized Japanese force, which advanced to deserted Nankow City, thirty miles northwest of here. Japanese estimated 4,000 soldiers faced them at the entrance to the narrow defile.

The world premiere of "American Primitive," a three-act play by Ernest Pascal, was presented tonight by Arthur J. Beckhard at the Lobero Theatre. The drama is built around an incident of the Oregon Trail in 1853, with all action in Indian Territory.

A shrinkage of $105,000,000 in the total of their outstanding credit, composed of a $35,000,000 drop in loans and a $70,000,000 fall in investments, was reported for the week ended on Wednesday by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City in their condition statement issued yesterday.

Sir Malcolm Campbell, British speed king, left today with his craft Bluebird for Italy, where he plans an attempt to beat the motor-boat speed record of the American, Gar Wood. He will make his attempt at Lake Maggiore.

By strict party vote, 9 to 3, the House Rules Committee today tabled Representative Snell's resolution for an investigation by the House into the sale by the Democratic National Committee of its 1936 convention books autographed by President Roosevelt.

The commissioners of the Port of New York Authority decided yesterday to proceed at once with the issuance of $15,000,000 of general and refunding bonds, and will consider bids for the issue on next Wednesday, according to an announcement made by Frank C. Ferguson, chairman.

Committee assignments for 19371938 of the New York County Lawyers Association were made public yesterday by Charles Evans Hughes Jr., president or the organization. The list of the committees and the officers of each follow:

The concert of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra scheduled for last night at the Lewisohn Stadium with Harold Bauer, pianist, and Albert Spalding, violinist, as soloists, was postponed until tonight on account of rain.
