GOVERNORS ISLAND 2d Lt. Theodore J. Feimer, lnf.-Res., 31.4 50th St., Brooklyn, N. Y., 16th Infantry, ordered to active duty Aug. 16 at Camp Dix, N. J., for training. He will be relieved irom active duty Aug. 29. So much of paragraph 21, Special Orders 175, July 30, 1937, as relates to 2d Lt. Russell F. Kaiser., av.-Res., s revoked.

Four witnesses testified yesterday before Surrogate James A. Delehanty that the late Edward West Browning, wealthy real estate-operator, had promised to support, educate and name as his heir Marjorie Browning, his wife's adopted daughter. Miss Browning is seeking $1,000,000 from his -estate because of his failure to do so.

" London by Night," which had its formal opening at the Rialto Theatre yesterday after sundry impromptu previews during the last two days, is a Class B-minus mystery film screened in a persistent fog which apparently affected every one involved. Every one, that is,

ONE of the brightest spots in the current realty picture, still clouded by the effects of mortgage difficulties of the depression era, is the improvement in the real estate position of banks and other lending institutions.

Additional engagements of $2,782,000 gold abroad for shipment here were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. All of the metal was taken in England, $672,000 of it having been bought yesterday and $2,110,000 on Wednesday.

Verbal battles over an option agreement for shares of the Austin Silver Mining Company dominated yesterday the Securities and Exchange Commission's hearing on charges that the company filed a faulty registration statement.

Railroad labor chiefs as part of their case in negotiations on their demand for a 20 per cent wage increase for more than 250,000 members of five operating brotherhoods, are contending that the production efficiency of the workers in these crafts has

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher in training in Gregg and Pitman stenography and typewriting in day secondary other -than junior -high schools. he issued. as of Aug. 9,. 1937, to the following applicants:

The SpanCentral Government issued a decree today making it an offense to molest a priest of any religion in the administration of a sacrament. The decision followed authorization Aug. 7 of resumption of "private religious services" in Spain.

Unofficially and informally, but with unmistakable zest, organized women of New York State today set about plotting a maximum of coverage for instruction in the processes of jury service under the permissive law enacted last Spring.

A proposal to settle 200,000 Jews in Palestine within the next three years, involving an investment of about $175,000,000, was laid before the World Zionist Congress today. The proposal was made by Elieser Kaplal, treasurer of the Zionist executive committee, who said American Jewry was expected to contribute $2,000,000 to the Zionist movement and Palestine fund in the current fiscal year.

Building projects, submitted yesterday included plans for altering several buildings in Manhattan. The fourteen-story structure at 253 Broadway will undergo changes to cost $100,000. The plans were drawn by Ely Jacques Kahn, architect.

On its own motion, the Interstate Commerce Commission ordered today an investigation of the Alleghany Corporation, the Chesapeake Corporation and the plans of Robert R. Young, Frank F. Kolbe and Alan P. Kirby, new owners of the far-flung Van Sweringen railroad system, for merging the two principal holding companies of the railroad properties.
The White Sox and Tigers split a thrillpacked twin bill today, a pinch sin*gle by Manager Jimmy Dykes with two out and the bases full in the tenth salvaging the nightcap for the visitors, 6 to 4.

After a sweltering eight-hour session the Board of Education adopted late last night the highest edunational budget request in the city's history. The final figure was $159,243,957.97, or $169,735.58 more than the budget proposed on Tuesday by the board's finance committee.

Boiling across the finish line off the harbor here in a spanking breeze from south-southwest, Sam Pirie's thirty-footer Oriole, 32 years old, saved her time from newer and bigger vessels to be one of the winners in the American Yacht Club's cruise today.
J. Edward Breuer will offer at auction about 500 lots on Copake Lake in the Berkshire Mountains tomorrow and Sunday. The parcels are near Camp Copake.

J. P. Morgan Co., as paying agents, will notify today holders of Nord Railway Company (France) 6 1/2 per cent bonds, due on Oct. 1, 1950, that $563,000 of the bonds has been drawn for redemption at par on Oct. 1 through the sinking fund.

The French Government has asked Baron Frantz von Goss, the German News Bureau correspondent at Salamanca, "to cease his journalistic and diplomatic activities on French soil and to transfer them to the government to which he is accredited." The request, however, is not an expulsion order.

Thomas E. Dewey, special rackets prosecutor, was urged yesterday to run for District Attorney in a telegram, sent to him by a "citizens committee," members of which announced their intention of calling on him today.
Facial surgery was the subject of one of the papers read at the four-day convention of the American Dental Soicety of Europe, which has just ended here.
The weakness in United States Government bonds, which began in a moderate way on Wednesday, became accentuated in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:
Fred E. Deubert of the Deubert Merchandising Service, Chicago, will join the executive staff of Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., manufacturer of hard-surface floor coverings, at Kearny, N. J., starting Monday.

The Hamburg-American liner New York, arriving today from Hamburg and Channel ports, has among her passengers Wallace Morgan, Albert von Bonstetten, Countess Dagmar von Zedwitz, Professor Leo von Hibler, Miss Alice L. Ryan, Mrs. W. H. Streat, Gilbert S. McChintock, Mr. and Mrs. E. H. Holtorff, Mr. and Mrs. George Lee, Miss Sarah Lewis, Mrs. John L. Walther, Wirt Hoew and Mrs. William L. Ransom.

Weather permitting, the Federal Caravan units will patrol the following regions in the metropolitan area tonight: Manhattan, "The Emperor's New Clothes," at Washington Square Park; Brooklyn, a vaudeville bill, at the Prospect Park Bandstand; the Bronx,
Government departments, responding to instructions from President Roosevelt, have locked up in reserve funds about $400,000,000 of their appropriations.

One of the largest audiences ever attending an artistic event in Southampton was present at the recital given by Yolanda Mero, pianist, tonight at the home of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Clark on Ram Island. It was announced during the evening that the artist is donating the proceeds of the recital to the Musicians Emergency Fund, of which she is a founder and executive director.

The controversy that has developed between the Administration and Congress on the question of sugar can be understood only in the light of a complex history that goes back at least to World War days. During the war the domestic beet and cane industries, and those in our insular possessions, were encouraged to produce to their maximum capacity.

Southern Blvd, 651 (10-2683); Confield Estates, Inc., to Bowery Savings Bank; extends rntgs to Jan. 1, 1940, at 4 to 5 per cent; $100,851. Mosholu Pkway N, .8.5-87 (12-3331); Esther Franklin to Bowery Savings Bank; extends mtgs to June 1, 1940, at 4 per cent; $150,000.

Maurice O'Connor, Branch Brook public links pro, and his amateur partner, Peter Rizzolo, shattered par by nine strokes to capture an eighteenhole pro-amateur best-ball tournament, prelude to the New Jersey P. G. A. championship, which starts tomorrow, with a 62 at the Suburban Golf Club.

Miss Margaret V. Kiely, nationally known educator, has been chosen to be dean of the city's new Queens College, it was learned yesterday, when she resigned her position as principal and director of the City Normal School of Bridgeport, Conn.
Mayor La Guardia gave a group of old persons living in the Old Folks Home on Welfare Island a check for $100 yesterday to help defray the expenses of their public forums.

Leading home a field of fiftyseven starters, Mrs. Edward Stev-, ens of Round Hill won the low gross honors with a card of 86 the one-day tournament of the Westchester-Fairfield Women's Association over the Siwanoy links today.

A. J. Chanter, president of the Pierce-Arrow Motor Corporation, yesterday advised stockholders "a person of national importance will be invited to become the executive head of the new corporation" which is to result from the reorganization to be voted on at a stockholders' meeting on Sept. 2.

The Navy Department awarded a contract today to the Goodyear-Zeppelin Corporation of Akron, Ohio, for the construction of two non-rigid airships at a total cost of $284,821.29. They will be replacements for two ships now in service..

As the result of a visit to Barcelona by Prime Minister Juan Negrin with the avowed purpose of strengthening the relations between the Barcelona and Valencia Governments, the Valencia Government may now be considered the real master in Catalonia.
Australia's gold production in the year ended on June 30 was 1,290,849 ounces valued at [Pound]11,219,319, compared to 1,059,048 ounces valued at e9,195,191 in the 1935-36 period.
The merry-goround on which the Yankees have been riding since July 31 broke down with a crash at Fenway Park today.

Answer to a suit seeking to block a merger of Van Sweringen holding companies was filed today in the State Circuit Court No. 2 here by the Chesapeake Corporation, which would be merged with the Alleghany Corporation.

Mr. and Mrs. James Gilbert Broderick of Mount Vernon gave a dinner last night on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis at which they announced the engagement of Mrs. Broderick's sister, Miss Frances MacDonnell, to John Wesley Morrow of this city.

Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas charged tonight that the proposal to lease six American destroyers to Brazil contradicted the neutrality policies of the United States, violated several international pacts and threatened to start a naval race among South American nations.

The national reputation of Senator Black of Alabama, selected by the President yesterday to succeed Mr. Van Devanter as a Justice of the Supreme Court, has been wholly made as a bitter and uncompromising advocate of extreme New Deal measures. His attitude in pressing these bills has been almost evangelical.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 11: COLONELS Jarman, S. (Coast Artillery Corps), General Staff Corps., 2 days' leave, Aug. 16. Ryan. L. S., FA, to duty with organized reserves, 8th Area, in addition to other duties at Oklahoma City, Okla.: effective Dec. 21, and will report by letter to tile commanding general, Sth Corps Area, for instructions.

An amusing new book called "Dear Mr. President" consists of selected examples of White House mail received from anxious voters. Nine out of ten of them are begging letters, but many are comic and some pathetic.

Charles A. Kahl, in 39 5th Ave.; Isabelle and Hazeltine Whitney, in 12 W. 10th St.: Catherine Oglesby, in 44 W. 10th St.: Hazel James, Ethel McIntosh, in 5 W. 15th St.; Oscar Rarrell, in 23 Perry St.; William A. White Sons, brokers.

Now that wind and water have conspired to keep most of our coastal charter boats tied to their docks, we can take a few glances inland. For the past few days most of the boats from Montauk to Ocean City have returned to their berths after a brief churn in the open water, and rain checks are being passed out port and starboard.

From The Herald Tribune (Ind. Rep.) Not even those closest to the President on Capitol Hill dreamed that he would make the defiant gesture of nominating Senator Black to the Supreme Court. The tradition in the Senate of ratifying forthwith the name of a fellow-member could not possibly apply here.

Today was "cook's day out" at Camp Andree here and the foreign Girl Scouts and Girl Guides, assembled for their first international encampment in America, displayed their culinary skill by preparing dishes for their American hostesses.

Alabama rang today with the story of Senator Black's meteoric rise from farm boy to a nomination to the Supreme Court bench and also with conjecture as to his successor in the Senate. That he was headed for a hard fight next year to keep his Senate seat was conceded throughout the State.

MANHATTAN BODY, SAMUEL F. (Aug. 4). Estae, more than $10,000. To Jenie E. Boyd, widow, executrix, 127 W. 79th St., residue. BRETTELL, JULIE B. (Aug. 4). Estate, $7,500 To Clinton B. Brettell, 78 Kings-burs Road, New Rochelle, N. Y., $500; Charles F. Brettell, brother, 1,164 Cromwell Ave. Bronx, $500 and one-half residue;

Tenders for two series of Treasury bills aggregating $100,000,000, half of the amount in 122-day bills and the balance to run for 273 days, were invited tonight by Acting Secretary of the Treasury Roswell Magill. Because of the Treasury's improved

With the United States still ahead, the struggle for supremacy in the team tournament of the International Chess Federation narrowed to a rivalry between the federation champions and the Hungarians, who finished first last year in the Olympic contest at Munich.

John J. Drumm, former postmaster of this village and long active in local and New York politics, died yesterday of pneumonia in the Nassau Hospital, Mineola. He was 62 years old and lived at 46 Cedarhurst Avenue.

Urging a concerted demand for reduced assessed valuations by property owners throughout the city, the Twenty-third Street Association has prepared and distributed in its district an analysis of actual real estate transactions in the past year which illustrates the wide variance existing between assessed valuations and selling prices, it was announced yesterday.

The substitution of a City Council for the Board of Aldermen, under the provisions of the new charter, will mean an annual salary saving of $129,943, according to data submitted yesterday at a budget hearing held before Assistant Budget Director Kenneth Dayton.

The forces backing the Democratic primary candidacy of Jeremiah T. Mahoney and his -running mates, Controller Frank J. Taylor and Max J. Schneider, scored a telling technical victory yesterday when they named Abraham Kaplan, Tammany stalwart, as the Mahoney campaign manager.

Movements vessels follow; all dates are Aug. 11 un less specified: At Port Townsend, Cincinnati, Humphrey King, Lawrence, Sands. Acushnet, Indian Head, to Naval Operatin Base, Norfolk. Badger, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk Aug. 12.

The Committee for Industrial Organization and the Detroit and Wayne County Federation of Labor, composed of American Federation of Labor unions, definitely broke company in Detroit today by supporting rival Mayoralty candidates.

A plea to Jews throughout the country for greater support of the $4,500,000 United Palestine Appeal during the high holidays of Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur, Sept. 6, 7 and 15, was made yesterday by leaders in the Orthodox, Conservative and Reform rabbinate in the United States.
The Pennsylvania Joint Stock Land Bank of Philadelphia will redeem on Sept. 1, at par, $460,500 of its 5 per cent registered bonds, $60,500 of which will be retired out of cash on hand.

John M. Hayes, New Jersey sportsman, was free today to continue his -journey to his home in Mahwah, which was interrupted on Aug. 1 when he arrived here by plane from San Francisco, accompanied by his daughter Patricia, 28 months old. Patricia, too, can take the trip.
THE WINDING ROAD UNFOLDS, by T. S. Hope. (Putnam, $2.50.) Based on a diary kept on the Western Front in 1917. ELEPHANT DANCE, by Frances H. Flaherty. (Scribner, $2.75.) Letters from India.
A full brother to -Discovery was sold for $20,000 tonight and evoked practically all the excitement in the yearling sales paddock, where other prices were comparatively low.

Sir Robert Borden, Canada's war-time Prime Minister, who died June 10, left an estate valued at $665,163, it was shown today when application was made for probate. The will, dated May 5, 1936, made Lady Borden the chief beneficiary and listed bequests to former soldier and benevolent organizations in Ottawa and Halifax.

Calhoun Ave. 237 (18-5591); Lina Einstein to Ellee Realty Corp, 551 5th Ave. Calhoun Ave, 238 (18-5590); Lina Einstein to Ellee Realty Corp, 551 5th Ave. Findlay Ave, 1.312 (11-2782); A. Virginia Schramm to MIayfair Acres, Inc, 53 South Broadway, Yonkers.

The league-leading Newark Bears were held to a total of eight hits in two games with the Montreal Royals today and suffered a twin reverse, the second-place club winning the opener by 8 to 2 and then gaining a 2-1 decision in the nightcap.
The State Board of Education ruled today that teachers cannot collect their salaries in Georgia schools which fall to display the American flag each day schools are in session, beginning this Fall.

House action today sent to the White House legislation authorizing a total of $53,701,525 in new rivers anc harbors projects. The Senate completed action on the measure yesterday by concurring in a Senate-House conference report.

When the Senate, on the retirement of Justice Van Devanter, unanimously "nominated" the late Senator Robinson to succeed him, many of those joining in the movement thought they had put the President in a hole. They were pressing upon the chief New Dealer a moderate, and upon the advocate of young blood in the Court a man nearing 65.

Steelworker Andrew Szwedko of Pittsburgh upset predictions and made himself a favorite today when he defeated Pat Abbott of Pasadena, defending title-holder, 3 and 1, in the quarter-finals of the national public links golf championship.

Miss Marion Miley of Cincinnati, Ohio, plodded over the Onwentsia Country Club course today to shoot her fourth successive sub-par round, 39, 38-77, and become the first player to win the 9-year-old women's Western golf derby three consecutive times.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Kahler of New York opened the Barn at their estate here today for the White Mountain Garden Club's annual flower show. Mrs. John W. Guider, president of the club, received the many visitors from surrounding resorts. Members alone exhibited.

A $30.000 mortgage on the three-story building at 130 E 45th St has been arTanged for the Shorebluff Corp by Butler Baldwin, Inc, broker. The $65,000 mortgage on the 5-story apartment house at 60-62 W 183d St, Bronx, has been extended for five years with interest at 41 per cent and quarterly amortizations; the Valcon Realty Corp, James Donnelly. president, is the mortgagee. Roeser-Feltner, Inc, negotiated the extension in conjunction with Armstrong Bros.

The Bureau of Navigation ?eleased the following orders today, dated Aug. 10: CAPTAIN Furlong, V'. R., Staff of the Commanding Chief of the United States Fleet, to report to the Secretary of the Navy, Washington, D. C., about Aug. 16.

Miss Margaret Schroth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Schroth, was married today to William R. Piper of Trenton, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joseph J. Nallin in St. Peter's Cathedral. The bride was attended by her sister, Mrs. William Brant Kolb of Overbrook, Pa. The best man was James McKeever of Trenton.

Forecasting Mayor La Guardia's re-election by a landslide vote, A. A. Berie Jr., City Chamberlain, urged all independent Democrats yesterday to enroll in the American Labor party, which has designated the Mayor as its candidate.

Edward Sumner Rapallo, retired New York lawyer and member of a socially prominent New York family, died today at his residence here at the age of 83. Born at Cambridge, Mass., onSept. 18, 1853, he was the son of the late Charles A. Rapallo, a judge of the New York Court of Appeals, and Mrs. Helen Sumner Rapallo, member of a distinguished Boston family.

During the week ended Aug. 11 member bank reserve balances increased $45,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from a decrease of $56,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and an increase of $11,000,000 in reserve bank credit, offset in part by increases of $14,000,000 in money in circulation and $8,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.
The Indians landed on Elon Hogsett, who relieved Jack Knott, for five hits and five runs in the eighth inning today to defeat the Browns, 7 to 0, and make a clean sweep of the three-game series.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman and Mrs. Lehman motored here from the Executive Mansion, Albany, and occupied a box tonight at the "Night of Stars" with program furnished by the Saratoga Lake night clubs at Convention Hall for the benefit of the United Palestine Fund.
Trends of prices of commodities at wholesale were mixed in the week ended on Tuesday, The Annalist says, and its index slipped 0.1 point to 94.8 from 94.9 on the Tuesday previous.
The fourth thunderstorm in two days swept over the city last night, bringing at least temporary relief from a day in which high humidity made moderately hot weather acutely uncomfortable.

Albert W. Wenzel, president of the U. S. Hammered Piston Ring Company of Baltimore, died last night at his home here after a twoweeks' illness. He was 57 years old. Mr. Wenzel developed fundamental principles in piston rings and held patents on equipment used by aircraft motor manufacturers.
Philip Hochstein, editor of The Newark Ledger, announced tonight the signing of a collective-bargaining contract between the Newark Newspaper Guild and the newspaper.

Despite a recession from the preceding week's total, which included first-of-the-month settlements, the volume of bank clearings in the latest period continued higher than its 1936 comparative for the third week in succession.

Ed Gabelman, bespectacled compositor from Cincinnati, won the 1937 Union Printers international golf tournament today, and with his victory took permanent possession of the Walter Hagen Trophy. A closing eighteen-hole score of 82, which gave him a record 321 for the seventy-two holes of tournament play, gave the championship to Gabelman for the third time. He won in 1931 and 1935 to gain two legs on the trophy.

The Bennington Festival opened the final gala series of dance performances in its fourth annual event at the Vermont State Armory here tonight before an audience of cheering enthusiasts who jammed the little hall to its utmost capacity in spite of rainy weather.
Burleigh Grimes took his Dodgers to Boston tonight only two one-thousandths of a point out of a tie with the last-place Phillies.
President Roosevelt sent to the Senate the nomination of Senator Hugo L. Black to be an associate justice of the Supreme Court, and signed the Bankruptcy Bill.

The Canadian Pacific liner Duchess of Atholl swung northward toward Quebec city tonight with the rescued crew of the Danish freighter Maine, which sank off the New England2 coast -today several hours after the vessels crashed together on a fogenshrouded sea.

Orders were light for both men's and women's wear fabrics in the wool goods markets this week and some slackening in the rate of machinery activity was noted as contracts for Fall started to expire, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

Despite the apparent restoration of business confidence in recent weeks, national advertisers are act ing somewhat cautiously on Fall and Winter advertising budgets. While quite a few schedules have been approved in recent weeks all of them calling for substantial increases in expenditures, manufacturers are slow in making up their mind about particular media to be used, agency heads remarked,

With characteristic pageantry, color and fanfare, 20,000 legionnaires completed their siege of Troy tonight and will settle down tomorrow to the more serious business of the nineteenth convention of the American Legion of the Department of New York.

Mayor La Guardia chuckled yesterday over a high school entertainment program of the Prescott Grammar School in Arizona thirtynine years ago which featured an oration entitled "The Office Seeker's Platform" by one Fiorello La Guardia.
Everything seemed to happen in less than a jiffy at the Polo Grounds as the Giants swung in line to conclude their two-game series with the annoying Bees of Boston.

William H. Wilson, a lawyer, former member of Congress and a leader in Philadelphia Republican organization affairs, died of heart disease last night at his temporary home at Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 59 years old.

Dr. Mark E. Penney, president of James Millikan University at Decatur from 1924 to 1930, died at a sanitarium here today, following a long illness. His age was 56. He was born at Western Bay, Nfld. He started teaching shortly after receiving A. B. and Ph. D. degrees at Cornell University.

American manufacturers and exporters are warned to use extreme care in marking articles for export to Ceylon, in a letter which the foreign trade bureau of the Merchants Association of New York has received from Robert L. Buell,

The store property at 1,029 Broadway, Bayonne, N. J., has been sold by George J. Heimberger to Victor Palmisano, who will alter and occupy it for a candy store. Max Druz was the attorney for the seller. J. I. Kislak, Inc., negotiated the deal.

As the site for four one-family houses, a plot 75 by 100 feet on Forty-seventh Street, between Broadway and Thirty-fourth Avenue, Astoria, L. I., has been sold by Mary Strining and Joseph Tvrdy to a builder. Lee Harris Co. were the brokers.

Patrolman Attollo Maskavich, 36 years old, of Linden, a member of the Union County Park Police Department, was seriously wounded this afternoon when he was accidentally shot in the abdomen on the Elizabeth Police Department rifle range in the meadows here.

The favorites progressed through the quarter-final round of the eighth annual New York State women's amateur golf championship today, but fbr the third successive day 19-year-old Miss Marjorie Harrison, Ausable Forks girl, proved outstanding. .

James F. Levens and Louis C. Greenman have been elected president and treasurer, respectively, of George W. Millar Co., Inc., paper and paper mill supply dealers, to succeed the late J. C. Mallalieu, who held both offices. J. C. Mallalieu Jr. has been named a director.

A survey among sixty presidents and fifty senior vice presidents of the nation's largest banks in forty-four cities made by Reuben A. Lewis Jr., executive vice president of the Metropolitan Trust Company of Chicago, reveals that they look for continued ease in short-term money.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis Meredith Blagden of 176 East Seventieth Street and Sterlington, N. Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Blagden's daughter, Miss Cornelia Waldo Blagden, to Henry Lowrey Pierson, son of- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Haines Pierson of Sterlington.

The yawl Elizabeth McCaw, owned by Richard J. Reynolds of Winston-Salem, N. C., and only American entry in the 600-mile race from Cowes to Fastnet Rock and back to Plymouth, today was placed fifth on an elapsed time of 90 hours 9 minutes.

Attorneys and court clerks searched the six floors of the Westchester County Court House today for a Bible, but could find none. Counsel for the proprietor of an Grangeburg, N. Y. dog race track said he needed one to prove that both dogs and horses are beasts and that bookmaking at his client's track consequently should be permitted the same as at other race tracks.

Minister of Justice Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares was asked today to permit the return to Brazil of Mme. Olga Prestes, now in a German internment camp. Mme. Prestes is the foreign-born wife of Luis Carlos Prestes, an alleged member of the Comintern [Communist International] and head of the 1935 Leftist revolt in Brazil.

A pacific settlement of the anti-lynching bill filibuster in the Senate and the perceptibly growing lassitude of the House of Representatives made it appear today that the end of this session of Congress is distant not more than ten days or a fortnight.

S. J. Aronsohn, Inc, textiles, floor in 187 Madison Ave; Perlstein Sprei, Inc. ladies' sportswear, floor in 28 E 22d St: Christine Cantanzaro, dress models, in 17-19 W 34th St: Joseph Nyburg, china and glass repair, in 507 5th Ave; Cross Brown Co, broker.
France had an unfavorable trade balance during the first six months of this year of about 9,000,000,000 francs, or approximately $405,000,000, the Commerce Department announced today.

Wholesale prices declined fractionally in the week ended on Aug. 7, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The drop was attributed to a continued falling off in the market prices of farm products, a sharp drop in cattle feed and chemicals, and a slight easing in food and textiles.

Shareholders of the Dominion Steel and Coal Corporation, Ltd., approved today a by-law increasing the capital stock by 80,000 Class B common shares in completion of financing necessary for the purchase, announced two weeks ago, of four Ontario subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation.

Miss Nancy Dickinson Buell, daughter of Fisher Ames Buell of 485 Park Avenue and Old Lyme, Conn., and of the late Mrs. Buell, has completed plans for her marriage to James H. Brewster 3d, which will take place on Aug. 21 in the Old Lyme Congregational Church. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Dr. Ernest MacGregor of Norwalk.

George Wallace Thorpe of New Haven, staggered ashore at dawn today after his sailboat had capsized in Long Island Sound, and told of having left his companion, a 35-year-old Bridgeport school teacher, lashed to an oyster stake off Walnut Beach.

Nanking's action in continuing to move large reinforcements northward along railways, highways and canals is inviting an armed clash of the first magnitude with the Japanese Army. This was made clear during a discussion of the North China situation by Lieut. Gen. Kiyoshi Katsuki, Japanese Army chief in North China, with the writer.

Acceptance by creditors and security holders of the Brown Company's reorganization plan filed in the Federal District Court at Portland, Me., was urged yesterday by business leaders of Berlin, N. H., in an announcement made here.

Lady Huntingfield, wife of Lord Huntingfield, Governor of Victoria, Australia, is expected to arrive today at the Commodore. J. Butler Wright, Ambassador to Cuba, Mrs. Wright and the Misses Edith and Mary Wright, who have been at the Weylin, will leave today for Havana.

Dry goods selling agents yesterday were preparing to adjust prices on several key items to the lower raw cotton market which has resuited both from anticipation of the crop report issued last Monday and from the estimate itself.

Study of photographic records of the recent solar eclipse indicates that science must revise its conception of the corona and may lead to a new understanding of the sun's structure, particularly those mysterious sunspots that have an appreciable effect on human destinies, it was announced yesterday jointly by Harvard University and the American Museum of Natural History.

Vacation playtime ended yesterday for most of the 1,000 Brooklyn youngsters who viewed and participated in the presentation of "The Pageant of Our Lady," a series of tableaux describing the life of the Virgin Mary, in the Music Grove of Prospect Park.

Sometimes those of us who shoot through the Manhattan labyrinth in subways or ride the dawn on silver wings must wonder if perchance we are not living in a mythologic world. And when lightning struck the Edison Memorial Tower at Menlo Park the other day, felling to the ground the unfinished monument to the genius who

Determination of the small Baltic States to collaborate to maintain peace in North Europe and to remain aloof from any military alliances designed to upset the present situation were stressed in talks between the Finnish Foreign Minister, Dr. Rudolf Holsti, and the Estonian Foreign Minister, Dr. F. Akel, yesterday and today.

Solly Krieger of Brooklyn scored a spectacular knock-out victory over Walter Woods of the East Side at Madison Square Garden last night. Woods had been jabbing and clouting his way to victory when Krieger sent a right cross to Woods's jaw to end the scheduled ten-round feature in 2:32 of the eighth.

Moves for settlements in the silk and rayon strike which may send 15,000 workers back to their jobs early next week were under way yesterday here and in Paterson as additional reports of individual settlements in Pennsylvania were received at the office of the Textile Workers Organizing Committee. C. I. O. affiliate, which is directing the strike.

To the Editor of The New York Times At present Congress is wisely trying to inform itself on the needs of agriculture, and meanwhile there is a demand by the agricultural bloc for government loans, first on cotton and probably on other crops which the Administration appears only too willing to grant, if combined with government control and limitation of crops.
Stocks closed fractionally higher, following early irregularity; turnover, 793,200 shares. Domestic bonds irregularly higher; Government issues lower; foreign loans steady; transactions, $6,610,300.

Edith Wharton survived several literary generations. It is easier to realize how much of change she spanned in her creative life when one recalls that four of her poems, written at the age of 15, won the approval of Longfellow and, through his recommendation, appeared in The Atlantic of 1880. She herself, long afterward,

A situation which threatened to prolong this session of Congress indefinitely and at the same time imperiled the enactment of the Administration program now pending before Congress was cleared up late this afternoon when the Senate voted to

Reports Company Commanders shall forward a report giving the names of members of their companies who have been detailed from their company to other companies for a continuous period of fourteen days or more, trom Jan. 1, 1937, up to the present time. Members detailed to Battalion Chiefs. as temporary drivers, shall not be considered. Company Commanders of units to which such details have been made, as above, shall also forward- a report.

Police of the Fifth Avenue precinct in Brooklyn revealed yesterday that the fire siren stolen from the Music Grove in Prospect Park some time last week was recovered at Fifteenth Street and Ninth Avenue, Brooklyn, on Tuesday.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson, an avowed candidate for Governor next year, made known to the voters today the "type" of candidates seeking nomination at the city-county primary next month who, he declared, were "best fitted to represent the people."

An Iraqi soldier, reliably stated to be a distant relative of General Jafar Pasha al-Askari, Iraqi Minister of Defense, whose murder prepared the way for General Bakr Sidky Pasha's coup d'etat last October, assassinated the dictator last night at the airport at Mosul.

A consolidated balance sheet of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation for June 30 shows total assets of $713,041,618. according to the registration statement for $48,000,000 of convertible debentures filed this week with the Securities and Exchange Commission, against $676,060,838 on Dec. 31, 1936. Fixed assets were $483,762,110 after reserves, against $470,037,620 at the year-end.
Further trials to select the defender of the Seawanhaka Cup were. decided upon yesterday by the flag officers of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay, L. I.

Universal's "The Road Back," the picturization of Erich M. Remarque's novel with John King, Slim Summerville, Richard Cromwell, Andy Devine and many others, will have its first showing as a general release at the Roxy today. .

Lumber output increased last week against a downward seasonal trend, and the adjusted index rose to 91.8 from 87.2. It was 87.4 for the week ended Aug. 8, 1936. Shipments and orders were lower in the week, according to the special reports wired to THE NEW YORK TIMES by the various regional associations.
The vacant plot on the northwest corner of Tulip and Plainfield Avenues, Floral Park, L. I., has been bought by Schurmer Strauss, who intend to improve the parcel with stores.
Five persons, four of them children, frolicking in the water of the Sinepuxent Bay while on a Sunday school picnic, stepped into deep water today and were drowned.

Henry Rose, author of a play, "Burrow, Burrow," which he says was copyrighted on July 3, 1934, filed suit yesterday in Federal Court against the Metro-Goldwyn Pictures Corporation, alleging that the motion picture "Man of the People" was a plagiarism of his work. Other defendants are Frank Dolan, author of "Man of the People,"

The grave of Captain Donald McPhee of Oban, Scotland, a member of the original crew of T. O. M. Sopwith's Endeavour II, is to be marked in Island Cemetery here with a weeping heather plant as a reminder of his homeland.

Price movements of commodity futures were mixed yesterday in active trading on the local Exchanges. Rubber, copper, lead, hide and sugar futures declined, while silk, tin, zinc, cocoa and pepper futures advanced. In the cash markets, cocoa, tins and silk were higher, but all the grains, rubber, cotton and lard fell.

Dr. Edward King Root, retired medical director of the Aetna Life Insurance Company and recognized as an early authority on preventive medicine, died today of a heart attack at his Summer home in wick, on Long -Island Sound, at the age of 79.

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday the resignation of Richard A. Brennan as president of the Mortgage Corporation of New York, to become executive vice president of the Brevoort Savings Bank in Brooklyn.

Add to the list of those who will be pretty busy this season the name of Marc Connelly. In addition to that new play of his own, which Mr. Connelly has been reported preparing for production by himself and Bela Blau, he also has been enrolled by the Theatre Guild to prepare an adaptation of the French play, "Dame Nature,"

Chartered banks' deposits with the Bank of Canada decreased $4,100,000 in the week ended on Aug. 11, it was shown today in the weekly report of the bank. The total was $178,386,389, compared with $174,260,807.
Mel Walker, Negro high jumper on the touring American track and field team, today bettered the world record for the second time within a week when he leaped 6 feet 10 inches (209 centimeters).

This was one day when the adage "the last shall be first" held true for Mark J. Stuart of Winged Foot, two-time winner of the metropolitan amateur championship, last to tee off in the tenth annual Green Meadow invitation tourney, came in medalist with a score of 73, three over par.

The first reaction following President Roosevelt's nomination of Senator Black to the Supreme Court today indicated that another bitter fight might further complicate the last days of this session of Congress.

The completion of the $900,000 Administration Building for the New York World's Fair in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens, will be marked by exercises at noon today. Grover Whalen, president of the exposition. will unveil a 27-foot sculptured panel above the entrance and open the two-story, white stucco structure for official inspection.

The report of the International Hydro-Electric System and subsidiaries for the June quarter, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $480,117 after interest, depreciation, amortization, taxes and other expenses and charges.

Stars from South America took a long lead over the United States in the Pan-American boxing games tonight, scoring eight victories eleven mathches. Three of the visitors moved into the finals along with two United States representatives.

Fifty-five leading manufacturers of home-building materials and equipment have cooperated in the preparation of ar illustrated book designed to give prospective builders information to help them decide on features to be incorporated in their new dwellings.

The life, in brief, of Senator Hugo Black of Alabama, nominated today to the Supreme Court: 1886--Born in Clay County, Ala. 1906-Graduated from the University of Alabama Law School. 1910--Birmingham police judge.

In one of the tightest finishes of the Saratoga meeting, Joe W. Brown's Spillway was just up to win the Sanford Stakes today with Maetall at his throatlatch, and Quick Devil and Wise Mentor only ,noses farther away.

The Corinthian Yacht Club, in the first of its trio of regattas in the midsummer series, sent 398 yachts across the three starting lines today, the high-water mark of the Week so far and only four short of a new world record.

In an effort to establish Polish grain prices at the world level, Warsaw's restrictions on the export of wheat, oats and rye have been continued through June, 1938, a report to the Department of Commerce from Ambassador Biddle indicated today.
Jersey City closed its home stand today by dividing a doubleheader with the Toronto Maple ' Leafs, winning the first, 1 to 0, but dropping the second, 4 to 3.

Complete plans for the climax events of polo, the national open championship and the Waterbury Cup tournament, have been announced by the United States Polo Association and indicate a gathering of more of the world's ranking polo players than our championship has seen in many years.

From a quiet and irregular start, the stock market firmed up gradually yesterday, with increased trading and closed near the best levels of the day. The improvement was fairly general throughout the list, with leading issues of the steel, motor, petroleum and amusement groups making the best showing; several of the leading railway shares also did well.

Member banks of the Reserve System made only modest progress in the week ended on Wednesday in regaining the reserves that they had lost in the previous statement week. The excess of reserves over requirements rose $40,000,000, contrasted with a fall of $110,000,000 the week before.

Mrs. Herbert Vos opened Zeeiust today for a song recital by Miss Emma Beldan, dramatic soprano of Newport and a member of the Juilliard Opera Company of New York. There was a large gathering of the members of the Summer colony Present.
With a total of $45,348,000, engineering construction awards this week showed gains of 3 per cent over last week and 10 per cent over the same period in 1936.

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday that application has been made to the State Banking Department for approval of the organization of a trust company to be known as the Real Estate Trust Company of New York.

Breaking new ground, the Marylebone Cricket Club triumphed over a Regina eleven today. The visitors compiled 202 runs against 50 for their third successive victory in Western Canada. Welcomed by T. C. Davis,

The coast Guard announced the following changes for the week ended Aug. 11: Professor A. A. Lawrence having executed oath as professor (T) (Lieutenant) Aug. 6, is assigned duty at the Coast Guard Academy.

Oddlot transactions on the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday as summarized today in an announcement by the Securities and Exchange Commission showed that 10,943 more shares were sold than purchased in the day's trading.

Striking employes of the N. G. Taylor tin mill, a Republic Steel subsidiary, returned to work today under an arbitration agreement, but union leaders and municipal officers differed on whether the agreement was between the company and the union.
Pink, green and almost black gladiolus blooms stood out among the 10,000 flowers at the opening of the eighth annual Gladiolus Show yesterday afternoon at Rockefeller Center.

The Senate, starting consideration of the Jones Sugar Bill today, adopted all Finance Committee amendments despite the objections of President Roosevelt that the measure still carried discriminatory quota provisions on refined sugar against Hawaii and Puerto Rico.
Witnesses told the. Securities and Exchange Commission today that

The Democratic forces throughout the city, despite their present differences, must unite after the primaries behind the victorious candidate if Mayor La Guardia is to be defeated at the polls on election day and the party restored to political power in the city, Jeremiah T. Mahoney, four-county designee for the Democratic Mayoralty nomination, declared last night.

The Mystic Power Company of Stonington, Conn., a subsidiary of the New England Power Association, a registered holding company, seeks exemption from the requirement of filing a declaration covering an issue of 3,500 shares of $100-par capital stock, in an application filed under the Holding Company Act, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.
The New York Stock Exchange has admitted to dealings R. H. Macy Co., Inc., rights "when issued," and Baldwin Locomotive Works voting trust certificates for common stock, $13 par, also "when issued."

Miss Lucile Slocum Joseph, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Oscar L. Joseph of Paterson, was married here today in the rectory of St. Peter's Church to Mayor William H. Williams of Belleville, son of Mrs. Ellen Williams of North Dighton, Mass., by the Rev. Joseph M. Kelly.

The le Cubs looked like anything but league leaders today as the Pirates, led by Lloyd Waner and Wilb Brubaker, pounded four pitchers for fifteen hits and profited by Chicago errors for a 16-6 victory before 10,977 fans.

The John Drew Memorial Theatre will be the scene tomorrow of the third in the series of four plays being given there this season by the Young Drama Students in the studio of acting, of which Leighton Rollins is the director. Judge and Mrs. Edward Finch of Southampton are bringing a theatre party.

Blond Sigismund Levanevsky, whose appearance and accomplishments have won for him the sobriquet "the Soviet Lindbergh," took off last evening at 6:13 o'clock [10:13 A.M., Thursday, Eastern daylight time] in a gigantic four-motored airplane for the United States via the North Pole.

Joseph H. Weis, prominent furniture merchant and Catholic layman, died at his Summer home in Forest Lawn last night. He was 79 years old. For forty-nine years Mr. Weis was head of the Weis Fisher Company, which he founded and also served as treasurer. On March 19, 1931,

Enemies of National Socialist State who have fallen foul of National Socialist law will be barred from driving automobiles in Germany in the future, according to a decision by the Prussian Supreme Administrative Court.

If the Hollywood motion-picture magnates will Iermit the borrowing of a phrase, those Yankees are terrific. They are the Spoilers of the ivory industry. No sooner does it appear that they may have a little rivalry to gladden the hearts of onlookers who like a fight than McCarthy's merry men move in to crush the opposition flat.

Hamilton Ter. 37, 18x85.10x18x84.?; August Llppmann to Alex H. Fraser, 401 Clinton Ave, Bklyn, mtg $10,000 ($10.50). Walker St, 88-90, 49.3x88.3x49.7x82.7; Bertrand Bowltz, referee, to East River Savings Bank, foreclosure ($25.50).

Eight men, said by the Government to compose "the nation's last organized kidnap ring," tonight were convicted of the abduction in 1933 of John J. O'Connell Jr., Albany, N. Y., and promptly sentenced to prison terms ranging from twenty-eight to seventy-seven years.

Mayor La Guardia wrote yesterday to the Board of Estimate recommending appropriations for large rewards for three fugitive racketeers, and smaller rewards for other fugitives, after receiving a letter requesting. the rewards from Thomas E. Dewey, special rackets prosecutor.

Pending a decision in Washington on the question of assistance to cotton growers, prices declined again yesterday and ended with losses of 14 to 17 points. It was the lowest closing since December, 1933,

T. O. M. Sopwith, unsuccessful America's Cup challenger, who has been ill with a cold aboard the Philante at Block Island, was reported as better today. He was up and about the yacht, which probably will return here tomorrow.

The $1,500,000 left with the Morgan Bank by the late Russian Admiral Alexieff was paid "by mistake" to one Simeon Khasine, now thought to be "somewhere in Venezuela" and a local court is considering charges to be preferred against the persons involved in this "mistake."

Edith Wharton, American novelist, died yesterday afternoon at her villa, Pavilion Colombes, near Saint Brice, Seine-etOise. She had been In fairly good health until she suffered an apoplectic stroke early yesterday morning and did not recover consciousness.

Turpentine firm, 31 1/2c. Sales, 134 barrels; receipts, 499 barrels; shipments, 247 barrels; stock. 35.377 barrels. Resin firm. Sales, 619; receipts, 1,983; shipments, 4.787; stock. 58.485. Quote: B, D, $7.50; E, $7.55: F. G, H. r, $7.65; K, M N, $7.67 1/2; WG, $7.75; WW, X, $8.40.

Resentful of President Roosevelt's stand against a resumption of cotton loans without accompanying authority to prevent crop surpluses, the Senate Agriculture Committee decided tonight "to give him another chance to revive the 1935

The National Labor Relations Board refused today a petition of employee representatives of Weirton Steel Company to postpone for thirty days its hearing on charges of company interference with the S. W. O. C.

THERE ought to be rejoicing over the fact that day before yesterday our Senate finally passed and sent to the House a bill breaking down the monopoly on helium gas. Not that all the opponents of the measure are merely dogs in the manger, even if some of them are.

The Household Finance Corporation reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on June 30, a net income of $5,730,518 after interest, minority interests, Federal and Canadian income taxes and a provision of $446,500 for surtax on undistributed profits.

FRANK MASSIMO FOOTE, INC., manufacturers of coats and suits, 512 7th Ave., by Hyman Schrager and thirteen other employes with claims aggregating over $500. SAM KAWER, doing business as Tuckahoe Glass and Paint Supply Co., 24 Columbus Ave., Tuckahoe, by A. Sklar Sons, Inc., on a claim for $574.

Governor Lehman tonight directed William C. Martin, District Attorney of Onondaga County, and Thomas H. Munro, Sheriff, to see that his order of June 23, directing enforcement officials to discharge their duties against all who "illegally participate in betting and gambling atdog race tracks" was obeyed.

Sailors from the United States destroyer Kane formed a guard of honor as the memorial, in the form of a lighthouse, was dedicated at Brest, France, today to the services of 600,000 American sailors of the United States Navy during the World War.

Dr. Joseph A. Blake, formerly a consulting surgeon at four New York City hospitals, died today at the home he purchased here five months ago. His age was 72. He was born in San Francisco on Aug. 31, 1864.

Captain Felix Gary of the Spanish Government tanker Campeador reported to French officials tonight his vessel was torpedoed and sunk by the Italian destroyer Saetta. Twelve members of the tanker's crew were lost, five of them dying when the first torpedo hit the engine room. Two other torpedoes struck the vessel.

W. S. (Bill) Farnsworth, for many years sports editor of the New York Evening Journal, yesterday became vice president and general manager of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, resigning his newspaper position for the boxing post. The burden of handling his new responsibilities at Madison Square Garden after Oct. 1 caused Promoter Mike Jacobs to seek assistance, Farnsworth was his choice.

Cardinal Hayes was reported last night to be resting comfortably at St. Vincent's Hospital, where he was brought early yesterday after an ambulance trip at night through a driving rain from his Summer residence near Monticello, N. Y.

In what will be the largest single utility financing operation in almost two months and the third largest issue of the year to date, the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., announced yesterday that it intends to issue an aggregate of $80,000,000 of debentures,

Even though it may no longer mean anything, it should be reported, to keep the record straight, that today is Friday the thirteenth. It is the only Friday the thirteenth of the year; yesterday was the only Thursday the twelfth of the year.

About half of the gain in business reported in the Pittsburgh district in the final week of July was lost in the first week of August, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Daniel O'Connell of 20 East Eighty-eighth Street, this city, and Shore Front Park, South Norwalk, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen Patricia O'Connell, to William Parker Rousseau, son of Mrs. Henry Harwood Rousseau, also of this city, and Blue Hill, Me., and the late Rear Admiral Rousseau, U.S.N.

Engineering contracts totaling $1,698,454.10, which were awarded by the War Department today, included the following: Great Lakes Dredge and Dock Company of New York, for dredging Hog Island channel, Buzzards Bay, Mass., $302,579;

The twenty-six-story office building and two adjoining structures at the southeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Forty-first Street have been sold by the Dry Dock Savings Institution to an investing company formed by Webb Knapp, Inc., realty consultants.

SHANGHAI--Fighting began in Shanghai between the Japanese naval patrol and Chinese. Foreign troops prepared to defend the International Settlement in' an expected extensive battle, because Chinese troops are converging on the city. Page 1.

The rate of increase in chain store sales continued to narrow in in comparison with a year ago, the first twenty-five groups to report showing sales of $235,391,280, a gain of $20,072,627, or 9.3 per cent, over the 1936 period, according to the monthly survey issued yesterday by Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc.
Charles ! M. Smith, Governor of Vermont, 1934-36, died this morning at his home here after an illness of six weeks. His age was 69.

Assistant Chief Inspector John A. Lyons announced yesterday that the police are compiling a list of all known degenerates for future use in cases of murder such as that charged against Lawrence Marks. Already more than 300 names have been placed on the list in Brooklyn alone.

One of the games audiences in the annals of concert-going sat through a concert by an equally courageous orchestra and conductor at Tanglewood tonight as the second half of the Berkshire Symphonic Festival began under enormously trying circumstances.

The four-story apartment and store building at 1,496 Dean Street, corner of Albany Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold by E. Polokoff through Samuel Hurwitz, broker. It is 19 by 90 feet and is assessed at $13,000.
The Stone Webster Engineering Corporation announced yesterday that it had- received a contract from the:

Hugo Lafayette Black, President Roosevelt's nominee for the Supreme Court, is a liberal from the heart of the deep South. A product of a farming community in Alabama, he came by his liberalism the hard way. Before his appearance on the national scene as a Senator in 1927 there was litle to set him apart as a believer in progressive liberal ideas.

Solar Hawk came with a rush in the stretch to overtake Miss Dolphin at Lincoln Fields today, carrying Emerson F. Woodward's colors to victory in the featured Lake Calumet Purse. Solar Hawk wore down the pacemaker to win by one length, with Virginia J. five lengths back in third place.

Kid Chocolate of Cuba, former world lightweight ruler, encountered strong opposition before defeating Joe Marciente, Canadian fighter, in the feature ten-round bout at the Fort Hamilton Arena in Brooklyn last night. A capacity crowd of 5,000 saw the show. The main bout boxers each weighed 129 pounds.
Buhl's "sinking canyon," steadily devouring a rich farming section, threatened to swallow a life-giving irrigation stream, adding another to Idaho's many lost rivers.

Moving yesterday to keep the Works Progress Administration out of politics, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA administrator, posted warnings on the official bulletin boards of the WPA throughout the city.

Police Department officials, led by Mayor La Guardia and several hundred patrolmen, paid final tribute yesterday to Detective Isidore Astel for his heroism in line of duty which caused his death on Wednesday in the Hospital for Joint Diseases.

The bodies of the five young victims of a Sunday school picnic drowning tragedy were taken to their homes near here today for burial. A mass funeral will be held Sunday. Coast Guardsmen recovered three of the bodies this morning.

The liquidation of the Bank of United States by the State Banking Department was praised yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente in approving an accounting for the period from Nov. 30, 1935, to April 30, 1937.

Forsaking his stand against crop loans without accompanying power to control farm surpluses, President Roosevelt today capitulated to demands of the Congressional cotton bloc and agreed to place a "floor" of twelve cents a pound under the farm price of cotton for all producers who agree to abide by whatever production-control program is evolved at the next session of Congress.
Sources close to Pope Plus XI reported today the Pontiff was suffering somewhat from the intense heat but was continuing his duties "with courage."
Hank Greenberg paced the Tigers to a 7-to-6 victory today in the opener of a four-game series with the Browns. Detroit went into a tie for second place with the Red Sox as a result of the triumph.

The Indians ran their winning streak to four games today as Mel Harder held the White Sox to five scattered singles and his team-mates bunched ten hits for a 7-to-3 victory. A wild throw by Catcher Billy Sullivan helped the White Sox score two runs in the first inning.

Calumet Evelyn, owned by the McConville Brothers of Ogdensburg, N. Y., won the Progressive Stake at Good Time Park today, heading a field of nine of the season's fastest trotters, including last year's Hambletonian winner, Rosalind.

The psychiatry divisions of Bellevue and Kings County Hospitals having reached capacity operation, the Department of Hospitals announced yesterday it would ask the Board of Estimate to provide two mental clinics, one for the Bronx and the other for Queens.
Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 765,000 bales, against 780,000 a week ago, 819,000 two weeks ago, 855,000 three weeks

"Kliou the Killer," the first Technicolor jungle picture, filmed in French Indo-China by the Marquis de la Falaise as a cinema record of the Moi tribe, is the new feature at the Cameo today. On the same bill is "Song of Ceylon,"

A scuffle between six loyal workers of the Robins Dry Dock and Repair Company and about 300 striking shipyard workers was stopped by the police under Inspector Harry Lobdell just before quitting time yesterday afternoon.
Members of the Seventh Battalion of the Naval Reserve, comprising 250 officers and men from Hudson County, will embark tomorrow on a two weeks' training cruise to the West Indies.

Reinforcements to the New York Stock Exchange's "fourteen bond rule," which forbids members to handle deals in fewer than fifteen bonds off the floor of the Exchange except in certain cases, were added yesterday by the committee on bonds.
President Roosevelt started tonight from Annapolis on board his yacht, the Potomac, for a week-end cruise on Chesapeake Bay and the Potomac River.

The National City Bank of New York will open on Monday morning at 9 West Fifty-first Street its seventy-third branch office in New York City, it was announced yesterday. The new branch is to be under the direction of Donald McK. Blodget, assistant vice president, whose executive colleagues will be John M. Potter and Harold Dwyer, assistant cashiers.
James S. Mattimore, vice president of the Walworth Company, manufacturers of pipe fitting and valves, died on Thursday in the Long Island College Hospital after a long illness.

BUILDERS and developers throughout the country have become convinced that their chief prospect for increased business in the years just ahead lies in the erection of small homes. A few years ago this market, in the New York district at least, was largely neglected for the more lucrative and more impressive work of building skyscrapers or large residences.

Commenting on an announcement from London that the British Board of Boxing Control had declared his Welsh heavyweight title vacant because of his failure to defend it, Tommy Farr, training for his heavyweight title bout with Joe Louis Aug. 26, today declared his willingness to meet any opponent named by the board.

President Roosevelt today vetoed a joint resolution providing for the submission to Congress of a comprehensive plan by army engineers for flood control, development of water power, and the conservation of soil and water.

The oldest race now renewed in the United States, the Travers, which goes back to 1864, will be run here tomorrow, with a field of five 3-year-olds entered to go the mile-and-a-quarter route for a prize of $20,000 guaranteed.
There will not need to be a Senatorial investigation of what took place outside Mr. Ford's River Rouge plant on Wednesday afternoon. There was no riot.

Three military men, Major Gen. Leon B. Kromer, Brig. Gen. Guy V. Henry and Brigadier W. H. P. Elkins are included among the judges appointed for the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden, which starts on Nov. 3. The three army men will officiate in the international military jumping contests.

Johnny Kinder, who won the title twice at match play, today took the lead at the halfway point in the seventytwo-hole New Jersey Professional Golfers Association championship at the Suburban Golf Club with a card of 142, even par. For the last three years the championship has been decided at medal play.

Just before she was to sail on a threeday cruise to Scotland with 1,000 tourists, the crew of the French liner Ile de France struck because the company was unwilling to pay "overtime" which the personnel claims the cruise involves.

Five armed thugs invaded this village shortly before noon today and held up the First National Bank, escaping with the payrolls of four concerns here which employ most of the 2,500 persons living in the community and the surrounding vicinity.

Lieut. Gen. Sir Henry Keary, who brought his brigade of Indian troops to the western front at the outbreak of the World War and afterward took them through some of the most bitter fighting in Mesopotamia, died today at Surbiton, Surrey,

Although labor costs in manufacturing, as represented by average hourly earnings, have increased more than 300 per cent above the 1899 level, prices of products have risen only 67 per cent above that year. due to mechanization and improved methods of production, it was announced yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Two men were hurled into the water last night when a 22-foot cabin cruiser which had taken on sixty gallons of gasoline at the publie dock in Crocheron Park, foot of Thirty-fifth Avenue, Bayside, exploded and burned to the water's edge.

Patrolman Leonard J. Smith, testifying yesterday at the hearing into charges of unprofessional conduct filed by the Queens County Bar Association against Scott Sanders, Jamaica attorney, admitted that he had written a letter to Mr. Sanders in which he said, "I will see you soon and have a very good homicide for you."
Colonel Theodore Roosevelt Jr. disclosed today that his wife and their son Quentin, 19 years old, are in Shanghai, but expect to sail for home Tuesday on the liner President Jefferson.

For the third consecutive week new bond financing this week was restricted exclusively to tax-exempt issues, although the appearance of two sizable loans lifted the total to $8,076,500, represented by five separate issues. This compares with a total of only $2,288,000 in new bonds placed last week and with $29,523,500 marketed during this week a year ago.

According to The Daily Express the Duchess of Penaranda, wife of the famous polo player, has escaped from Madrid and reached Gibraltar on the British cruiser Arethusa. She had the bulk of her jewels with her.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for altering structures in Manhattan and Brooklyn and for new homes in the latter borough.

James E. Pinkney, a mechanical engineer, who was superintendent of the Bergenport acid manufacturing plant of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey at Bayonne, N. J., before his retirement more than two years ago, died yesterday at his home here.

The Mayor, Clerk, Treasurer and Board of Trustees of the village of Hempstead, L. I., were adjudged guilty of contempt of court yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Albert Conway in Brooklyn. The court ruled the officials had violated a mandamus order issued last

Works Progress Administration purchases of project materials reached a cumulative total of $446,378,503 as of June 30, Aubrey Williams, Acting Administrator, announced today. Of this amount 41 per cent represents funds contributed by local governmental agencies sponsoring the projects.
Unaccustomed as they are to playing single games, the Yankees today bowed to the Athletics, 4-3, at Shibe Park before a Ladies' Daygathering of about 7,500.

Again flagpoles are going up along the Unter den Linden and across the great green-clad highway through the Tiergarten colored lamps are being strung from trees, for another of the picturesque festivals in which the new Reich excels is being prepared.

The Ways and Means Committee of the House completed today a bill intended to carry out the recommendations of President Roosevelt and Secretary Morgenthau regarding prevention of evasion and avoidance of existing income-tax laws.

The building accommodating twenty-two families at 825 East 167th Street, the Bonx, was sold by , Goldie and Rose Lerner and Nettie Nowak. It occupies a plot 40 by 125 feet and is assessed at $33,000. Montague S. Mendelsohn, attorney, represented the buyer and Isidore Lowenbraun the sellers.

Nathan Myers, a Newark architect, died here yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital at the age of 62. Among the buildings designed by Mr. Myers were Temple B'nai Abraham in Newark, the Hersh Tower in Elizabeth and the power station formerly used by the Bamberger Broadcasting Company, operators of WOR at Kearny.

A compromise settlement plan to end litigation between creditors of the two defunct Insull investment companies and ten banks over collateral for loans was filed today in the court of Federal Judge Charles E. Woodward.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 12: COLONELS Case, R. W., Ordnance; detailed as member Joint Army-Navy Board for purpose of considering specifications for manufacture and test of gun forgings, etc.; Vice Col. Charles T. Harris Jr., Ordnance, hereby relieved.

Motion pictures of the total eclipse of the sun on June 8 in Peru, showing the globular corona, the discovery of which was announced publicly on Thursday, will be shown to the public tonight and Sunday at the Hayden Planetarium, it was announced yesterday by the American Museum of Natural History.

China's financial position has been strengthened, it was reported in financial circles today, through a loan negotiated by her Finance Minister, Dr. H. H. Kung, with a group of Swiss and Netherlands banks.

Undismayed by the refusal of the House Rules Committee to approve his resolution to investigate the sale of convention books by the Democratic National Committee, Representative B. H. Snell, the Republican floor leader, plans to present evidence of what he charges are violations of the law to Attorney General Cummings.

Arthur Schading, business agent of Local No. 1 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, called a strike today of union electricians employed by Radio Station KSD, owned by The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, in retaliation for the taking of his picture by one of the newspaper's photographers.

Joan Kuleba, a 4-year-old girl with blond curls and dark eyes, was found murdered just inside the creaking cellar door of a deserted house in the middle of a silenI swamp near South Beach, S. I. yesterday morning. She had been strangled by a cord and an attempt had been made to assault her criminallv.

The Chinese troops that are facing the Japanese in Chapei, Kiangwan and Woosung belong to the crack German-trained Eighty-eighth Division, long stationed thirty miles from Shanghai just outside the truce zone established after the 1932 hostilities.

The Berkshire Symphonic Festival, which completes its fourth season with concerts tomorrow night and Sunday afternoon, will have to be abandoned unless funds can be raised for the building of a permanent structure for the audience, it was learned today.

Efforts to show that Paul Klopstock, chairman of the board of the Austin Silver Mining Company, and Edward N. Wilkes, a director, had circulated misleading information for the purpose of influencing the market for the company's stock were made yesterday by counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission at the SEC's inquiry in its offices here into the affairs of the mining company.

Dr. George Perkins Clinton, retired State botanist of the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station here and a national authority on diseases of grains, died at his home here early today following a stroke last month. He was 70 years old.
Lord Runciman, millionaire shipowner and the father of Viscount Runciman, president of the Board of Trade in the Baldwin Cabinet, died today.

Retail sales in metropolitan department stores varied this week, according to estimates last night. Stores handling largely apparel lines found their sales were about 5 per cent lower than in the corresponding week of 1936.
Four Iowa National Guardsmen were injured, none seriously, today when a "dud" shell exploded within a foot of where they stood during military manoeuvres. The injured men lived in Sheldon.

Two British corporations that advertised here that they conducted an international money-lending business were ordered yesterday by Justice Charles Poletti, to appear at 10 A. M. Thursday morning in Part II,
The Prudential Insurance Company sold to Mendel Herman of New York the apartment house at 76-90 vn Reypen Street, southeast corner of Academy Street, in the Journal Square section of Jersey City.

Two men were killed and eleven persons injured early yesterday when fire swept through a fivestory rooming house at 625 West End Avenue, between Ninetieth and Ninety-first Streets. Firemen rescued a number of the twenty-five residents in the house by ladders, and two top floors of the building were destroyed.

Burton K. Harris, Director of Agriculture, Chief John H. Gibbons of the division of animal industry and milk control, and their agents were restrained by court order today from further coloring Vermont milk entering the State for distribution, interfering with distribution of Vermont milk in Rhode Island, or prosecuting violations of the act under which they dumped red vegetable dye into 5,000 quarts of Vermont milk on Tuesday.

Louis Kenedy of New Rochelle has been elected president of the National Council of Catholic Men, a division of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, to succeed Dr. Thomas E. Purcell of St. Louis, who has served since 1932. Mr.

Three more men were charged late today with possession of explosives in connection with bombings during the Republic Steel Corporation strike here. Eight had been charged previously, and four of them were sentenced to penitentiary terms after pleading guilty.

The body of an unidentified man about 28 years old, who had been shot through the head, was found at 12:05 A. M. today on Eait Eighty-ninth Street between Church Lane and Avenue J, in a thinly populated part of Canarsie, Brooklyn. The man was believed by the police to have been a "ride victirn."

When Frank Pacsay, 48 years old, was held without bail as a suspect yesterday in the Felony Court, Detective.Vincent DeGuido revealed how, in the space of three hours last Aug. 5, an elderly man and woman were robbed of a total of $6,654 in different parts of the city, supposedly by the same three confidence men.

Fairchild N. Ferry, an executive in the Crowe Nameplate Company of Chicago, died today at his home here of a stroke suffered yesterday. He was 67 years old. Mr. Ferry was a graduate of the New York College of Pharmacists.

Charles G. Bond, Republican designee for Mayor who announced his withdrawal from the primary fight Thursday evening in favor of Senator Royal S. Copeland, filed his formal declination yesterday with the Board of Elections. No substitution has as yet been filed to fill his place.

When Secretary Seward bought Alaska seventy years ago last March, the Russian.Government put on its hat and went straight down to the bank to cash his check for $7,200,000 before he changed his mind. Later the canceled check got back to Washington, and in time the General Accounting Office seems to have got it.

Governor Josef Buerckel of Saarpfalz ordered today a Nazi counter-demonstration in the cathedral city of Speier on Assumption Day because the Bishop of Speier has scheduled a pilgrimage and extra trains have been ordered to bring pilgrims to the city.
Mr. and Mrs. Erling Cornelius Ostby of Providence have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Brown Ostby, to Samuel Bernard Dick Speer of Goshen Plantation, Augusta, Ga.

A swimming race, wherein all the participants were members of the Cabinet or Under-Secretaries of State, was started by Premier Benito Mussolini, as umpire, this morning off the small, secluded La Maddalena beach, near Syracuse, where the head of the Italian Government and his entourage broke an arduous tour of Sicily for a sea dip.

The North Shrewsbury's newly dredged channel into Red Bank harbor had a long parade of week-ending yachts this afternoon forming the vanguard of the spectator fleet arriving for the National Sweepstakes Regatta which is attracting America's high scoring speed boat drivers for tomorrow, Sunday and Monday.

The postponed concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra featuring Harold Bauer, pianist, and Albert Spalding, violinist, as soloists, was given last night at Lewisohn Stadium before an audience of 12,000 persons.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today. as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow; HOGS Receipts 5,000, Including 2,000 directs. The market was mostly 10c-15c lower than Thursday's average. A few early sales were strong to higher, with the top $13.60
The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered Eastern railroads serving the anthracite coal fields in

The financial editor of The London Times, in commenting tonight on reports that Dr. H. H. Kung, Chinese Minister of Finance, had an agreement with a group of Swiss and Netherlands banks for substantial credit to China, in addition to a 100,000,000 franc credit, says:

Movements vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 12, unless specified: At Norfolk, Acushnet, Salinas. At Hampton Roads, Arkansas, New York, Wyoming. At San Pedro, Bridge, Medusa. At Puget Sound Yard Cincinnati. Humla hrevs. King. Lawrence, Sands.
French inspectors, digging into an innocent-looking case of apricots at the Aleppo railway station, today uncovered a shipment of munitions for rebellious Kurdish tribesmen.

The United States, with Samuel Reshevsky showing the way, defeated Iceland, 4-0, today in the eighteenth and penultimate round of the International Chess Federation team tournament, thus clinching the championship for the fourth time in a row.

The Paper Novelty Manufacturing Company, Inc., of 225 East Thirty-sixth Street, Manhattan, has leased from the Continental Baking Company the buildings at 505 Carroll Street, running through to President Street, near Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn.
Bills authorizing $31,000,000 worth of barracks and other buildings for the army and navy passed the Senate today.

Two young women art students and a man companion owed their lives today to a wind which blew their capsized dory ashore at Truro. They were Miss Helen Wires of Wellesley Hills, Mass.; Miss Dorothy Nelson of Chicago and Rowland'Lyon of Washington. D. C.

Coming from behind with five goals in the last two periods, the Monmouth County Country Club four defeated Blind Brook, 8-4, at the Burnt Mills Polo Club today to gain the final/of the northeastern intracircuit polo tournament.

The navy's new aerial dreadnought, the Sikorsky XPBS-1, built here for two years with great secrecy, received its first test flights today and performed "perfectly," according to Sikorsky officials and Eddie Allen, test pilot.

The touring Marylebone Cricket Club team emerged victorious against a strong Alberta eleven today. After dismissing their opponents, who included players from Edmonton and Calgary, for 129 runs, the Englishmen compiled 185 for six wickets.

Robert Leon (Lee) Woody, who began his career on a predecessor of The Richmond Times-Dispatch almost fifty years ago and remained with the same newspaper all his life, died last night at a hospital here at the age of 64.

Frederick A. Rakestraw, president of the Hyde-Rakestraw Company, cotton yarn merchants, died in his office yesterday at the age of 62. Associated with the cotton yarn business more than forty years, he was a former president of the Cotton Yarn Merchants Association.

There was a new winner in the big racing division of the American Yacht Club's annual cruise today, W. Roy Manny's 12-meter Night Wind not only winning on corrected time for the thirty-one nautical miles from Port Jefferson to this island off Clinton but also being first of the thirty-seven starters to finish.

Secrecy tonight surrounded the Government's immediate plans for ten men facing prison terms as convicted or confessed members of a kidnap gang which in 1933 seized John J. O'Connell Jr. in Albany and obtained $40,000 ransom from his politically prominent uncles.

Major Ceylon 0. Griffin of Constantia, retired cavalry officer and recipient of the Croix de Guerre of France and three United States military honors, died early this morning in University Hospital. Death was due to coronary thrombosis.

American Boy Scouts who have been participating in the fifth world jamboree broke camp today and scattered for vacations throughout Europe. The 800 Americans were part of the 28,000 Scouts gathered from all parts of the world.

The New York Telephone Company has come out in a flatfooted repudiation of one of the oldest traditions associated with the invention. In a booklet entitled "You and Your Telephone," a treatise on telephone usage, the following paragraph occurs:

William A. Stephany, a South Shore real estate man, died of a heart attack this morning at his home here at the age of 62. Mr. Stephany was active in real estate operations in this vicinity for the last twenty-five years.

The Indiana Public Service Commission ordered today a reduction of approximately 25 per cent in the rates for electricity supplied to Rural Electric Membership Corporations by private utility companies.

Butch Meyers, Buffalo third baseman, belted a homer with two out in the ninth inning tonight to give the Buffalo Bisons a 4-3 victory over Jersey City.
