Meyer's boundary belt ended a game that had seen Shortstop Otto Bluege of the Jersey Giants make a pair of errors, with two down in each case, that let in three Buffalo runs.
A coalition of mythical foreign powers, taking advantage tonight of the concentration of the American Navy in Pacific waters, menaced New England's vast industrial centers and heavily populated area.

Evidences of fraud have been discovered in the petitions designating Senator Royal S. Copeland, Frank J. Prial and Samuel Levy for the Republican nominations for Mayor, Controller and President of the Council, the law committee of the New York County Republican Committee, of which Gabriel L. Kaplan is chairman, announced yesterday.
Invitations have gone out for the marriage of Miss Josephine Taylor Terry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Taylor Terry Jr. of 340 East Seventy-second Street and Tahawus, N. Y., to William Hude

Stocks of refined copper in the United States, exclusive of consumers' stocks at their plants and warehouses, at the end of July amounted to 117,741 tons, compared with 111,020 at the end of June, an increase of 6,721, according to the Copper Institute. Blister stocks were up 5,958 tons, making the total increase 12,679.

President Roosevelt today said that there was no truth in published reports that he would propose a constitutional amendment as a remedy for what he thinks is wrong with the Supreme Court. He was asked at his press conference whether such a drive was planned and replied that it was not.

The House voted today to confide broad powers in President Roosevelt, for two years, to reorganize the regular departments of the Government, although withholding from his activities the independent, regulatory agencies.

Captain Stephen Dunn, pilot of the Pan American-Grace airliner which plunged into the ocean off Panama Aug. 2, with a loss of fourteen lives, was cleared of blame today by army and naval flying authorities. Pilot Dunn was among those killed.

A halfdozen widely known amateur golfers today shot their way into the quarter-final round of the eighth annual Syracuse Yacht and Country Club's invitation tournament, paced by Frankie Strafaci of Brooklyn and Chuck Kocsis of Detroit, two of the favorites.
Forty-seven years ago The Emporia Gazette was born into the newspaper world with "Volume 1, No. 1" on its trustful

We must look at the sun with different eyes, now that Major Albert W. Stevens's airplane photographs of last June's total eclipse have been hailed by Dr. Harlow Shapley of Harvard as revelations of the' corona's true form.

The South Penn Oil Company reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a net income of $3,278,744 after depreciation, depletion and Federal and State income taxes but before profit and loss items, including a $75,830 refund of Federal income taxes. This was equivalent to $3.28 a share on 1,000,000 shares of outstanding capital stock.

A combined increase of nearly 30 per cent in passenger traffic and air mail and express business at Newark Airport for the first six months of this year over a similar period in 1936 was reported today by officials of the field. The report, compiled from the records of commercial air lines,
President Roosevelt signed today a bill granting the consent of Congress to the minimum wage compact ratified by the Legislatures of Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Rhode Island.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with great interest your presentation of the sugar fight in the editorial "Bitterness in Sugar," and while I heartily agree with you that "the real need is * * * to work toward an orderly termination of the quota system itself"

Emil Schwartz of Detroit started another term today as president of the National Association of Retail Meat Dealers. He was re-elected at the closing session of the annual convention which selected Milwaukee for its 1938 meeting. Others elected included George Steindl of Chicago, first vice president; Huston Brewster of Pomona, Calif., second vice president; Edwin Jansen of St.
Suit has been instituted here to obtain possession of the estate left by Mrs. Eugenia Gifford, nee Sutherland, of Chicago, who died here last June at the age of 53 years.

One of the hopeful trends of the times is the replacement of the concept of "relief" with that of "social security." It would be over-optimistic to say that we have passed the need for relief or that we have achieved social security, but we are moving in that direction.

Faithful to long-held tradition, the grouse season in Great Britain opened on Thursday with King George, whose father was one of England's notable shots, among the gunners. A bit out of the traditional picture, perhaps, was the new shooting "brake" of the monarch so lately crowned-described as a luxurious mobile lounge with gun racks, drop windows and space enough so that luncheon may be served in comfort to ten persons.

Mrs. Fulton Cutting gave a large dinner tonight at her home on the ocean for her niece, Mrs. Wilmerding Montgomery, who is passing the season with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lucius Wilmerding, at Seaward.

Dr. Louis A. Martucci, medical director at Columbus Hospital here, died at the hospital this afternoon after a brief illness at the age of 47. Born in Italy, Dr. Martucci was graduated from the Medical School of the University of Naples.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Fairchild of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Fairchild, to Robert C. Leclair, son of Mrs. Charles Leclair of Peekskill, N. Y.

Final adjournment of the present session of Congress by next week-end appeared today to be in easy reach, barring any more surprise moves from the White House, when the only controversial matters thought to be standing in the way were suddenly dissolved.

No doubt the plan for leasing half a dozen over-age destroyers to Brazil seemed a bright idea when it was first thought of. Brazil needs ships, not only for training purposes but to reinforce an inadequate navy. Should any power have naval craft to sell, she could not buy them outright without contravening the London Treaty of last year.

As a preliminary to the rededication of the East Poultney Baptist Church and the unveiling Sunday of a tablet in memory of George Jones, one of the founders of THE NEW YORK TIMES who was a native of East Poultney, a reception was held at the church tonight with Governor and Mrs. George D. Aiken of Putney among the guests.

Federal Judge Merrill E. Otis accused the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union today of waging a war of destruction against the Donnelly Garment Company. owned by Mrs. Nell Donnelly Reed, whose kidnapping drew nationwide attention in 1932.
A Negro trusty attired in a silk hat, a red-and-white zebra-striped shirt and white trousers caused a traffic jam today as amazed motorists stopped to watch him mow the county jail's lawn.

Senator Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, asked the Senate today to find out whether political contributions from the Committee for Industrial Organization had any bearing on the Postoffice Department's refusal to deliver "irregular" mail to strike-bound plants.

Carrying banners reading, "Chicago will stamp out syphilis," 1,500 boys and girls, volunteers from the National Youth Administration, paraded through the Loop at noon today to the City Hall, where speakers hailed the parade as a children's crusade against the plague.

The biggest concentration of the International Brigade seen on this front in the last two months launched a surprise night attack on Insurgent positions between Porcuna and Lopera, thirty-four miles east of Cordoba.

While retail sales this week failed to equal the figures of the week preceding in some of the leading centers of distribution, the general average was higher by 1 to 3 per cent, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The gain over last year was also shortened, taking the country as a whole, the increase being estimated at 6 to 18 per cent.

Exemption from the requirement of filing a declaration in connection with the issuance of 96,000 shares of $25-par value capital stock was asked of the Securities and Exchange Commission today by the Webster and Southbridge Gas and Electric Company of Webster, Mass., a subsidiary of New England Power Association, a registered holding company.

The Canadian Pacific Railway proposes to establish a new steamship line between Port McNicoll on Georgia Bay, Ontario, and Milwaukee and Chicago, provided authorization can be obtained from the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Classes for hunters featured the first session of the three-day Lake Placid Horse Show today. The entries of Miss Fredericka Fry of Greenwich, Conn., were outstanding. Her Trade Mark won the novice hunter and green hunter classes.

For the first time in the many years that the Commodore George Corry Trophy has been in competition during the annual cruise of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association, a West Coast. Star crew has threatened to carry it home.

The plan of the United States to lease six over-age decommissioned destroyers to Brazil for training purposes was indefinitely postponed today after a conference between Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Felipe A. Espil, the Argentine Ambassador.

More than 1,000 persons have visited the eighth annual Gladiolus Show in Rockefeller Center since its opening Thursday afternoon. This Summer's exhibition, under sponsorship of the Metropolitan Gladiolus Society, is the largest ever held, the organization announced.

Six sturdy sons of Argentina led their South American buddies to another convincing conquest of United States boxers tonight, gaining all but two of their team's eight victories in eleven bouts at the Pan-American games: Added to last night's eight triumphs, the invaders have a score of sixteen victories to the United States' six.

SOME years ago people began to talk about William Saroyan because he was a strange fellow (Armenian) from California who seemed to think that he had the world by the tail and knew all there was to know about writing short stories.

The Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation of Rochester, N. Y., has filed a registration statement covering an issue of $3,000,000 of 3 3/4 per cent general-mortgage bonds, Series H, 1967, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today. The issue, to be underwritten by the First Boston Corporation,

Engagements of $1,828,000 gold abroad for shipment here, $1,156,000 in India and $672,000 in England, were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Imports of $2,612,700 of the metal were received here of which $2,069,600 came from Canada and $543,100 from England and $1,125,

King Victor Emmanuel, Crown Prince Humbert and Premier Benito Mussolini braved a broiling sun today to witness an "enemy" landing on the shores of this Italian island, the opening phase of Italy's annual war games.

A communique tonight reported four Insurgent airplanes bombed and sank the 1,566-ton Danish freighter Edith in the Mediterranean thirty miles south of here. It said the ship's crew of twenty and a French non-intervention control official took to lifeboats and after being picked up by fishing vessels were taken to Barcelona, where the Danish consul awaited them. One seaman was injured.

If you see a man tramping the fields this Fall with a hooded falcon on his arm instead of a gun, don't be surprised. As a result of the missionary work by Captain R. L. Meredith in New Jersey and Egbert Pfeiffer in New York, this ancient sport is winning many converts in the East.

The stock market continued quiet today, and, although activity was at a low ebb, prices, when changed, were lower. Gilt-edge issues lost ground, and among the foreign loans Far Easterns again softened.

The West Penn Railways Company of Pittsburgh, Pa., filed today an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for orders declaring it not to be a holding company and that the West Penn Power Company is not its subsidiary. Both companies,

FIRST MILITARY AREA Staff Sergt. Fred C. Laurenzo, 6101890. D.E.M.L.-O.R., is relieved from tempora-, ry duty in connection with the training of Organized Reservee at Pine Camp,. N. Y., and will proceed, on or about Aug. 16, to his proper station at Syracuse, N. Y., for duty with the Organized Reserves.

The Agriculture Department reported today that a "living standards study" of 1,030 families at Moberly, Mo., Showed an average income of $1,332 to cover annual expenses of an average family of 3.5 persons. Moberly, the Department said, is one of nineteen small cities selected for a study. Dr. Louise Stanley of the Bureau of Home Economics, is in charge of the work.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Of all sports baseball evokes the most-comment and divergent views. In a letter in THE TIMES last week some one wrote that the big league pennant predictions favored the two New York "teams. The Yankees are living up to expectations, but the Giants are going awry, the letter stated. Well, as a fan, I want to say something.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $18,098,271, of which $15,000,000 will be accounted for by the offering on Wednesday of the Port of New York Authority 3 1/4 per cent bonds.

The Mexican agrarian code was changed today in order to enable the Government to go farther in seizing landed estates for division among peasants. Modifications of the law are carried in the Official Gazette under the signature of President Lazaro Cardenas, who is empowered to change virtually any legislation except the Constitution while Congress is not in session.

Several Tammany district leaders pledged to support the Mayoralty hopes of Senator Royal S. Copeland have decided to transfer their allegiance to the four-county ticket headed by Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Abraham Kaplan, Mr. Mahoney's campaign manager, declared yesterday.
Controller Frank J. Taylor asked the Board of Education yesterday to make an early selection of a site for the new Fort Hamilton High School in Brooklyn.

Boston Rd (16-4738); s e cor of Corsa Ave, 100x117; Jupiter Realty Corp to Albert W. Pross, 20 Claremont Rd. Scarsdale, N. Y, installments, 3 to 4 per cent; $19,000. Morris Ave, 1470 (11-2787): Mayfair Holdings, Inc, to C. C. S. Realty Corp, 31 Union Sq, installments, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent; $32.500.

Although thirty runs behind in the total, but with one wicket in hand, the touring players of the Chicago Cricket Club succeeded today in drawing the third match of their Eastern trip with a team of twelve representing the New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association on the grounds of the Crescent Athletic Club.

Arthur H. Chalmers, 34 years old, suspended mounted patrolman, entered a formal not guilty plea before Judge Freschi in General Sessions yesterday on the first-degree murder indictment charging him with the shooting of Miss Irma Louise Pradler, hospital worker.

Mel Walker failed to equal his record-smashing high jumping feats today but the touring American track and field team continued its triumphal invasion of Sweden by winning six events despite a rain which caused a slow track.
The Dionne quintuplets have learned to pull hair. Dr. A. R. Dafoe disclosed today that they have been separated from each other all week as much as possible to eliminate outbursts of quarreling.

Cardinal Hayes, stricken with an attack of indigestion at his Summer home at Monticello and rushed 100 miles by ambulance to St. Vincent's Hospital Wednesday, is expected to return to Monticello within a few days. Last night his indisposition was described as "definitely passed."

The Southern Cross of the Evening Star Yacht Club fleet monopolized honors today as the international mothboat regatta opened. Stansbury Cramer, veteran skipper of the local club, won the feature race of the day, sailing the Southern Cross to the Middle Atlantic States individual championship.

Lucian A. Eddy, president of the Investors Fund of America, charged today in an inquiry before the Securities and Exchange Commission that Donald F. Kenyon, former chairman of the fund, refunded $30,000 to three Midwestern brokers upon their demand for return of investments because of irregularities in Mr. Kenyon's management of the fund.

The Soviet Foreign Office announced tonight that Japan had rejected a Russian proposal that an impartial commission be named to investigate the raid on Aug. 1 on the Soviet Consulate in Tientsin, China.

Out front from the break, Bubblesome, sixyear-old gelding who runs in the colors of Mrs. L. Pallidino, captured the Cynwyd Purse by half a length today at Suffolk Downs. Hard ridden throughout, Bubblesome finished the mile in 1:37 3-5 under Jockey Wimmer's urging to score his fifth victory in twentyfive starts this season. He paid $10.40 for $2 in the mutuels.
George Robert Kerr, vice president and treasurer of the Canadian Westinghouse Company, Ltd., died at his home here tonight. He was 55 years old.

The Jones Sugar Bill, continuing production quotas similar to those in effect for the past three years under the Jones-Costigan Act, was passed by the Senate today and sent back to the House with a compromise flu amendment on refined quotas which President Roosevelt declared was a discrimination against Puerto Rico and Hawaii.

MANHATTAN Gross assets. $200: net, a deficit. Choate, Larocque Mitchell, attorneys, 41 Broad St. ETTLINGER, SAMUEL (June 1. 1934). Gross assets, $10; net, a deficit. Leo Sandler, attorney, 88 WV. 40th St. GILDER, JOSEPH BENSON (Dec. 9, 1936). Gross assets, $54,466: net, $50.346. To Gwendolen Gilder, widow, $2,500 by right of election and life estate in residue. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $51,903. Spencer. Ordway Wierum, attorneys. 72 Wall St.

Celia Weinshanker's embroidered puppet and hook-stitched cushion won the acclaim of several hundred "hobby enthusiasts" yesterday at the annual contest conducted for the children of the lower East Side at the roof-garden playground o?? the Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway.

The King arrived today at Glamis Castle, historic seat of the Earl and Countess of Strathmore, parents of Queen Elizabeth. King George drove to the castle from Balmoral, accompanied only by his personal detectives.

A wreath decorated with the colors of Bulgaria and, the United States was placed yesterday at the base of the statue of George Washington in front of the Subtreasury Building by J. P. Doycheff, Royal Bulgarian Consul in New York.

Defending the practice here of not using Bibles in administering oaths to witnesses, attorneys and jurists asserted today that swearing with one hand on the Bible was "merely one of several ways" in which the court oath might be given in New York State.

Walton Ave (9-2477), w s. 146 ft. n of 164th St, 50x100; Herman Weiss to 1011 Walton Ave Corp, 2,388 Amsterdam Ave. Southern Blvd (11-2977), w s, 412 ft. n of Jennings St, 37x100; Mollie Pintel to Tanlawi Realty Corp, 482 E. 180th St; mtg $31,500.
The Rev. Dr. Norman G. Dunning of Rivercourt Methodist Episcopal Church, London, England, will be guest preacher the next three Sundays at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

Mrs. Arthur W. Hartt of Brookline, Mass., chairman of the silver jubilee camp projects committee of the Girl Scouts, said today full consideration would be given to a proposal made last night by a committee of American Girl Scouts at the International Encampment at Camp Andree here.

The largest week-day gathering that has turned out for tennis in years at the Westchester Country Club saw the stage set today for an exceptionally attractive program tomorrow in the Eastern turf court championships.

President Roosevelt reached an agreement with Senators on the cotton loan issue, vetoed a bill for a comprehensive flood-control report by army engineers and departed for a week-end cruise on Chesapeake Bay and the Potomac River.

Edith Wharton, American novelist, who died on Wednesday, has left her beautiful garden villa here to be sold and the proceeds used to continue the committee she established for the aid of the needy and helpless.

From Stockbridge, Mass., comes ?? considerable item this morning in the way of literary and theatrical news, to wit: that Sinclair Lewis, the Nobel prize-winning novelist, is now writing a straight play, singlehanded, which he hopes to have ready for showing within a month or so.

Total volume of round-lot transactions on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on July 17 was 4,921,500 shares bought and sold, compared with 5,412,820 in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Sergeant William Ewing, Montreal sharpshooter, today was recrowned Canada's most consistent marksman after statistics showed he won the grand aggregate event at the annual meeting of the Dominion of Canada Rifle Association.

Thanks to an assist from the Giants, the Dodgers today retained a loose hold on that tiny fraction that prevents them from tumbling into last place in the National League. They did nothing to aid themselves, tossing away a game to Lou Fette and the Bees

The Bennington Festival tonight gave the first presentation of "Trend," a new composition by Hanya Holm for large group and soloists, with music written chiefly by Wallingford Riegger but also utilizing for its final section Edgar Varese's "Ionization." The work is on a colossal theme, the survival of society out of a state of decadence and collapse, and at present it is rather a series of sketches than a finished work.

Progress toward a settlement of the silk and rayon strike, affecting about 40,000 workers in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and New England, was indicated by Sidney Hillman, chairman of the Textile Workers Organizing Committee of the C. I. O., last night, following negotiations with a group of manufacturers.
Judge William H. Holly in the Federal District Court today continued until tomorrow a hearing on appointment of a receiver for the Utilities Power and Light Corporation.

With Pete Appleton pitching his best game of the year, the Senators won their fifth straight victory today, turning back the Red Sox in a series opener, 3 to 0. It was the second shut-out registered by a Washington pitcher this season.

Trading was generally slow for Friday. Excepting price changes on a few miscellaneous cuts, the markets were mostly steady on traefa meats. Kosher meats opened steady to higher, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Pounding out twenty-one hits and aided by eight errors, the league-leading Cubs frolicked to the largest score of the major league season today as they pummeled the Reds to win by 22 to 6 before a ladies' day crowd of 25,932 fans.

A poll of unlicensed personnel of the fourteen ships of the Luckenbach Steamship Line to determine the agency which will represent the men in negotiating labor agreements with the company showed 436 for the National Maritime Union, C. I. O. ally and only eight for the International Seamen's Union, A. F. of L. organization.

THERE was some talk of the Yankees across the luncheon table and the stout Mr. Bill Brandt, Public Relations Counsel for the National League, looked up and said: "Don't mention them. I can't enjoy my food." It was natural that a loyal National Leaguer should be embarrassed at any mention of the Yankees. A mere five of them had made the whole National League look a trifle sickly in the all-star game.
The Burgos [Spanish Insurgent] consulate, which has functioned semi-secretly here for a year, has been ordered by the British authorities to close.

What a family of five on relief should eat to be well nourished and the cost became a moot problem yesterday as the public challenged and the Health Department defended its one-week menu to cost $7.801/2, as published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Wednesday.
Owing to "abnormal conditions" in Shanghai, telephone service between San Francisco and the Chinese city has been indefinitely suspended, according to The Associated Press.

A first mortgage of $170,000 at 4 1/2 per cent for three years on 238 West 106th Street has been obtrained from the Franklin Savings Bank by a client of Charles Berlin, broker, who also arranged a first mortgage of $136,000 at 49s per cent for three years with the Dry Dock Savings Institution on the apartment at 518 West 111th Street.
France informed the British Government today it could not shelter more Spanish refugees until some part of the 50,000 now living in France were repatriated or sent to other countries.
Siebel C. Harris, first vice president of the Chicago Board of Trade, died today at the Highland Park Hospital following an operation for a knee injury.

Ernest Hemingway says he slapped Max Eastman's face with a book in the offices of Charles Scribner's Sons, publishers, and Max Eastman says he then threw Hemingway over a desk and stood him on his head in a corner.

Mr. and Mrs. William C. Morgan gave a dinner at the Devon Yacht Club's weekly dinner dance tonight in honor of the visiting judges for tomorrow's horse show. Mr. Morgan is president of the Riding Club of East Hampton, which is holding the horse show on the club grounds in Pantigo Lane.

Mrs. Hugo L. Black, wife of the Supreme Court nominee, is still going to school. She attends university classes for two hours every morning to get the degree she sacrificed when she left Sweet Briar College to join the yeomanettes during the World War.

The Newark Bears ran into their longest losing streak of the year tonight when the Toronto Maple Leafs downed the International League pace-setters, 3-2, in twelve innings. The Bruins suffered their third successive setback.

With the completion of testimony yesterday, Surrogate James A. Delehanty closed and reserved decision in the suit of Miss Marjorie Browning, 22-year-old adopted daughter of Mrs. Edward West Browning, of New Rochelle, who brought suit against the estate of Edward West Browning for $1,000,000 on the ground that Browning had promised to support, educate and name her his heir after her adoption by his wife.
Frank E. Hering of South Bend, Ind., urged the Fraternal Order of Eagles today to "combat radicalism." Addressing the fraternity's convention, the former national president said that radicalism

With one exception, the first- and second-round matches in the tenth annual Green Meadow. invitation tournament ran true to form today. Left in the running for the title vacated by young Charley Mayo Jr. of Lido are Howard Schanzer of the Metropolis Club, a protege of Paul Runyan and an ex-Syracuse captain;

A fireman, Bruce McCormick of Los Angeles, and a gas works employe, Don Erickson of Alhambra, Calif., will fight it out tomorrow over thirty-six holes for the national public links golf championship. They reached the final with decisive semi-final victories in thirtysix-hole tests today.
The Prudential Savings Bank sold to Rose Rivkin for occupancy the new seven-room dwelling at 531 Hanson Court, Far Rockaway, Queens, through the Lewis H. May Company, broker.

A torpedo fired from the submarine Cachalot at a target in Newport harbor veered from its course, dodged between the yacht Nourmahal of Vincent Astor and the Lone Star, Frederick H. Prince, swung on a tangent and struck the shore.
An outburst of firing in areas adjoining the British Concession, where the majority of Americans in Tientsin live, today provoked temporary alarm among foreigners.
The General Electric Company announced today a 1 per cent wage increase for all employes, under the company's "cost-of-living adjustment" plan.

Al Capone lost his fight today to slice one year and $20,000 from his sentence of eleven years in prison and $50,000 fine imposed on him by Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson for violation of the Federal income tax laws.

Two consecutive victories by Middlesex this week sent the county into a commanding lead in the English county cricket competition. In one of six matches concluded yesterday Middlesex defeated Essex by 307 runs.

MANHATTAN Estate, more than $20,000. To Hannah N. Bierhoff, widow, executrix, .88 Central Park West, household furnishings, works of art, life use of estate, "The Ledges" at South Blue Hill, Me., and life estate in one-half of residue or until remarriage; Jeanette Bierhoff, sister, 39 W. 91st St., $3,000 and $2,000 annuity from one-half residue; Alan Frederic Bierhoff. nephew, 156 W.

E. T. Weir's Weirton Steel Company challenged the right of the National Labor Relations Board today to conduct a hearing on charges that the company intimidated its employes in opposing the Steel Workers Organizing Committee.
A new world record for competitive yachting was established today when 436 craft crossed three starting lines in the Corinthian Y. C.'s second regatta in the annual midsummer series.
Special military police precautions were taken throughout Iraq today following the assassination of Major Gen Bekr Sidki Pasha, Iraq's strong man. The country was described as quiet.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 11: CAPTAINS Kilpatrick, W. K., upon discharge, treatment at the Naval Hospital and when directed by the commandant of the 14th Naval Dist. ordered to treatment at the Naval Hospital. Brooklyn, N. Y.

July returns and tax payments for the new State utility tax due Aug. 25 will be received without penalty not later than Sept. 15, Mark Graves, Commissioner of Taxation, announced tonight, adding that his department was without authority to extend the time for filing.

The Maritime Commission today notified the twenty-three steamship companies which are receiving operating-differential subsidies that they must supply to the commission complete details of their proposed long-range programs for the replacement of all vessels now over 15 years old. The information must be submitted by Sept. 1.

The sale of 90,000 shares, or 45 per cent, of the common stock of the Alan Wood Steel Company, with a large plant in Conshohocken, Pa., has been made to a holding company affiliated with the Hillman interests of Pittsburgh. The remaining 110,000 shares, or 55 per cent, is owned by the Koppers Company.

The text of the amendments to the by-laws of the General Motors Corporation that were adopted by the directors on May 3 was made public at the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Irving Ben Cooper, designee of the New York County Republican executive committee for the nomination for District Attorney, filed his declination of that designation last night, leaving the way clear for the substitution of Thomas E. Dewey, whose successful prosecution of racketeers has given him nationwide prominence.

The volume of outstanding commercial paper rose sharply in July to $324,700,000 at the end of the month, from $284,600,000 at the close of June, according to the monthly survey of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which is based on reports from dealers in commercial paper.

Paul V. McNutt, Governor of the Philippine Islands, today denied a story in The Indianapolis Times that he was returning to the United States to assume the presidency of Indiana University. He said he intends to finish the task that brought him to the Philippines.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

John Steinbeck will return to this country from Europe today, docking at Albany. He is on a freighter that brought him from Oslo, Norway, and that goes up river direct to Albany, with no stop here. Mr.

The plight of tenant farmers will be the basis of a series of morning lectures Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday of next week at the Institute of World Missions at Chautauqua Institution, Chautauqua, N. Y., under the auspices of the Council of Women for Home Missions and the Foreign Missions Conference Committee of Woman's Work.

Resignation of the Paraguayan Cabinet was forced today by a military coup that left President Rafael Franco in office. A manifesto issued by Lieut. Col. Paredes, commander of the army, stated it was a movement "to confirm" the revolution of Feb. 17, 1936, during which President Franco came into office.

A temporary agreement under which grocery stores will remain closed all day and delicatessens until 3 P. M. on Sundays was announced yesterday by the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association, Inc., and the Metropolitan Delicatessen Grocers Association, Inc. The agreement, settling a long-standing feud over Sabbath closing,

Phil T. Chinn was the principal seller of yearlings tonight, and in addition there was a second consignment from the farm of Willis Sharpe Kilmer. Forty-nine head passed through the sales ring for a total of $105,575. Of this amount $88,600 was represented by the Chinn stock consisting of thirtyfour head.

At the Pleasant Valley Bird and Wild Flower sanctuary at Lenox today Mrs. Henry A. Francis of Pittsfield gave a luncheon in honor of William Miles, manager of the Berkshire Playhouse; Miss Edith Barrett, the actress; Mrs. Alvan T. Fuller and Mrs. Franklin W. Hobbs of Boston, who are at the Curtis Hotel.

Colony Lingerie Shop (additional space); L. F. Berger. Inc, in 666 Madison Ave; Eugene E. Bogart, broker. Manlee Mfg. Co., boys' pajamas and polo shirts, in 693 Broadway; Reuben B. McKay, in 354 4th Ave; M. L. Hess, Inc., brokers.
It was learned today that the government was ready to appoint Brazilian delegates to the BrazilianAmerican mixed committees with jurisdiction over the trade agreement between the two nations.
Irving O. Freedman is the lessee of the two five-story buildings at 345-7 West Twenty-third Street, leased recently by the Robert R. Rainey Company for the Leopold Schepp Foundation.

With Summer still very much in our midst but with Fall creeping steadily upon us, the French Casino will begin a hopeful rush upon the new night club season on Friday evening when it reopens its genial doors for the premiere of its new "Folies Bergere," sixth in the brilliant succession of Continental revues presented there.

Dr. H. Beattie Brown died today at his home here. He was 74 years old. His daughter, Mrs. Kenneth Beattie of Summit, N. J., was with him when he died. Dr. Brown was born in New York Nov. 23, 1862, the son of the late John and Abigail Beattie Brown.

Mrs. Marion Turpie, women's metropolitan champion, and 18-year-old Miss Betsy MacLeod of Buffalo won their way today into the final round of the New York State women's golf championship. Both won by 4 and 3. Mrs. Turpie defeated 19year-old Miss Marjorie Harrison of Ausable Forks by shootingspar golf for the fifteen holes of the match. Betsy was one under par for the same route to beat Mrs. Sylva Annenberg, 1934 and 1935 titleholder.

An offer to buy for $750,000 the three, six-story apartment houses at 750-60 Pelham Parkway South, near Bronx Park, has been submitted in contract form by the Plemes Realty Corporation of 122 East Forty-second Street to Daniel W. Blumenthal, trustee in reorganization proceedings,

Japanese troops battered in vain at Nankow Pass today, failing to dislodge 4,000 Chinese stubbornly defending this important gateway through the mountains from the Peiping plain to the broad plateau of Chahar.

Artists and writers of the South Mountain Road colony, supported by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Representative Caroline O'Day, decided tonight to go ahead with their plans for a charity fiesta tomorrow on behalf of Spanish refugee children despite the protests of leading Catholic laymen.

World production of motor cycles, including three-wheeled vehicles, amounted to 316,810 units during 1936, as compared with 260,811 units in 1935, and was the largest number produced in any year since 1930, when the total amounted to 351,529, the Commerce Department announced today.

Federal Judge Murray Hulbert yesterday asked the United States Attorney's office to request Federal authorities along the Mexican border to be on the lookout for Charles A. Levine, former junk dealer, who was indicted last Tuesday for conspiracy to smuggle tungsten powder into the United States.

THE PROPHETS AND THE RISE OF JUDAISM, by Adolphe Lods (Dutton, $5). M. Adolphe Lods, Professor at the Sorbonne, here carries on the history of Israel from the middle of the eighth century, when an outstanding figure was Amos, through 600 years of conflict, political and religious, to the time of Judas Maccabaeus.

The United States has moved to safeguard her position in Palestine and the rights of her nationals in that area, in the event the British mandate is terminated as proposed in the report of the British Royal Commission, through an exchange of diplomatic correspondence with Great Britain.
The nomination of Senator Hugo L. Black of Alabama to be an associate justice of the Supreme Court received the swift approval today of a Senate subcommittee appointed to investigate his fitness.

Developments in Shanghai are obliging the Japanese Government to contemplate the prospect of war on two fronts in China. Although the killing of Sub. Lieut. Iaso Ohyama of the Japanese Navy-like the Lokouchiao clash-was unforeseen, it may be said to present to the Chinese Government an opportunity of deranging Japan's strategy in North China.

Excess reserves of $553,655,000, representing 18.03 per cent against the required 15.63 per cent of reserves against net demand plus time deposits, were held by the 5,299 active national banks of the Continental United States, Alaska, Hawaii and the Virgin Islands on June 30, J. F. T.. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, announced today.

Mr. and Mrs. P. J. Kaniut. at 865 Boulevard; Mr. and Mrs. G. C. Barton, at 770 Central Ave; Mr. and Mrs. W. A. Clark, at 631 Hanford Pl; Commander and Mrs. S. G. Mayfield, at 321 St. George's Pl; Mr. and Mrs. C. L. Barnum, at 534 Hillcrest Ave: Mr. and Mrs. C. P. Speaker, at 744 Central Axe: Westfield, Conn.. rentals by T. B. and N. F. Reynolds, brokers.
More than 500 members of the Seventy-eighth Lighting Division Veterans Association arrived here this afternoon for their annual reunion.

Except for a moderate pick-up in trading volume, there was little, if any, change in the character of the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Speculative interest continued to center among the secondary and lower-priced railroad issues, which were marked up again in fairly active trading.

Loadings of revenue fregiht for the week ended on Aug. 7 amounted to 796,706 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 12,954 cars, or 1.7 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, but 41,335 cars, or 5.7 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 187,629 cars, or 32.2 per cent, more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

New life insurance production for the first seven months of this year by forty companies having 83 per cent of the total life insurance outstanding in all legal reserve companies in the United States was $5,505,941,000, against $5,122,778,000 in the corresponding period last year, an increase of 7.5 per cent, according to a report made yesterday to the Department of Commerce by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents.
Before the end of the month the Government will introduce in the House of Deputies a bill to create a Central Reserve Bank, which, it is expected, will be in full operation by next March.
Scores of parties are being given here on the eve of the running of the Travers, the midsummer Derby of racing.

NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Mrs. Loring Washburn of Old Orchards, Greenwich, and Riverdale, with Mrs. Washburn's daughter, Miss Mary Aylett Royall, and son, William L. Royall 3d, are visiting Mrs. Washburn's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Bucknero, at the Ocean House, Swampscott, Mass.
Dr. Aaron Silkman, former chief veterinarian of the New York City Department of Health, died today at his home here. He was 63 years old.

Edgar B. Hammond, architect, civic leader and yachtsman, died yesterday at his home here. He was 83 years old. In recent years Mr. Hammond had devoted most of his time to the New Bedford Vocational School, of which he had been chairman of trustees since its founding twentynine years ago.

A plan of reorganization of the West Ohio Gas Company of Lima, Ohio, an operating subsidiary of the trustees of the Midland Utilities Company, was submitted today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for approval. It is to be filed also with the Federal court in Toledo, Ohio. The capitalization of the reorganized company would consist of $1,353,000 of 3 per cent

Warning against cynicism or indifference toward the Administration in Washington or that at Albany, Governor Lehman called on American Legionnaires here today to participate more actively in fundamental community affairs, declaring that the effectiveness of government was "entirely dependent" onthecharacter of its citizens.
The House Banking and Currency Committee today favorably reported the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill with an amendment raising the limit on costs of construction from $4,000 to $5,000 a family unit.
The British Far Eastern Army command today ordered a battalion of Welsh fusiliers rushed to Shanghai to reinforce the British garrison there.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Scattered trading on a very limited scale has marked the week in the Eastern seaboard wool markets. Wools seem to have been relatively most active.

Fortune Harbor's sea monster, still unidentified a day after it was killed in a forty-eight-hour battle against fishermen's guns and harpoons, tonight was lying lashed to Captain Earl Noble's motor vessel Golda awaiting an offer of purchase.

Fred W. Hilton, principal of the Weymouth High School since 1911 and former president of several teachers' associations, died shortly before midnight at his home, 24 King Oak Terrace, Weymouth Heights. He was 62 years old.

The United States liner President Harding, arriving today from Hamburg, Channel ports and Ireland, has among her passengers Brig. Gen. Bernard Kearney, commanderin-chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, who participated in Europe in ceremonies attending the dedication of monuments to Americans lost in the war.

Squelching all rumors, Horace Stoneham, president of the Giants, flatly denied yesterday that a new contract had been offered to Manager Bill Terry. Summoning to his office at the Polo Grounds the baseball writers at yesterday's game, Stoneham commented on all angles of the report that Terry had signed a new two-year contract.
Alfred Eastman Lunt, former president of the National Republican College League and City Solicitor of Beverly, 1909-13, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 59.

Investors were active yesterday in deals involving housing properties in scattered sections of Manhattan. The Union Square Savings Bank sold to an investor the two remodeled buildings containing thirty apartments at 62-64 West Ninetyeighth Street, between Columbus Avenue and Central Park West. Assessed at $40,000, the property was sold for cash over a mortgage of $41,500 at 3 percent for five years.

Twenty-nine employes or sons of employes of the General Electric Company will receive a total of $5,550 in loans from the Gerard Swope Fund at Union College and the General Electric Educational Loan Fund for students either attending or desirous of attending any accredited college.

Regardless of what substitutions mechanical science may devise, a machine somehow still works a little better with a spark plug restored to its proper place. And so the Giants, with Dick Bartell back on the job as full-time shortstop, swung sharply back on their course at the Polo Grounds yesterday after weeks of careening across unchartered seas.

Magistrate Matthew J. Troy, sentencing Mrs. Louise Anderson, 36 years old, of 513 Sixty-second Street, Brooklyn, in Coney Island Court yesterday morning for fortune telling, observed that "you should have known a man wearing Ea black robe would enter your life on Friday the Thirteenth."

President Roosevelt said today that four New England Governors or other officials would confer soon with the Federal Power Commission in an effort to get Congressional approval of a Connecticut River flood control agreement.
John Jacob Astor will be 25 years old tomorrow and this evening he and Mrs. Astor entertained forty young people at dinner at Chetwode in honor of the anniversary. They will entertain again tomorrow.
The Cardinals won their sixth straight game today, with Johnny Mize giving Bob Weiland superb fielding support in a 4-1 victory over the Pirates.

In what Coroner George S. John son believed was a sudden fit or insanity, Michael Horbachewskl, years old, landscape gardener, shot and killed his two younger daugh. ters at 10:15 P. M. tonight, seriously wounded his eldest daughter, and then slashed his own throat with a razor. He died instantly.

Shanghai, the largest and most important commercial city of China, is on the brink of tragic developments. Recent events, in nature and sequence so ominously like those which introduced the weeks of terror in 1932, have aroused the deepest anxiety in the Chinese and foreign sections of the city and in the capitals of all the interested Powers.

Henry Armstrong, miniature brown bomber from California, scored another sensational knockout victory at Dyckman Oval last night. A crowd of 9,032 saw the Coast Negro hammer into submission Eddie Brink of the Bronx in 2:36 of the third round.

The methods and recommends tions of the special committee or maritime personnel which was cre ated in May, 1936, to study prob lems in connection with safety at sea were criticized yesterday in a minority report submitted by How ard S. Cullman. Mr. Cullman made public his report following the in production by Senator Copeland o: a bill based on the majority report of the committee.
The Senate's Crime Committee recommended today that investigating agencies of the Federal Government be consolidated in a single bureau.
Veteran Alaskan pilots prepared tonight to search for six Russian transpolar fliers, long overdue here from Moscow on a flight over the course of a possible airline to America.
A squad of 150 tired business men squatted in Frankfort Square today for a five-hour "squatfest," which was supposed to rout the Friday the 13th jinx.

Mrs. Thomas M. James of Cohasset saw her sporting tandem Blue Ridge and Magic with the F. Harold Tollman Trophy at the Cohasset horse show today. This gave Mrs. James permanent possession of the prize, her entries having won legs on it in 1934 and in 1935.
James M. Doubleday of the New York Trust Company bought the Property of the late Dr. George G. Shelton on West Lane Road, Ridgefield, Conn., through William R. Keeler, broker.

Rutgers Pl, 11, 26x110; Anna Mf. Goebel, et al., trustees of Julius Goebel, to Esther C. Goldstein, 31 E 31st; mtg $10,500 ($12). Suffolk St, 136, 25x99.10; Ely Simpson. executor of Sigmund I. Herschmann, et al. to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; mtg $15,000, held by grantee ($16).

Announcement has been made by of Mr. and Mrs. M. Maurice Beck of Belle Harbor, Queens, of the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Alic E. Beck, to Norman S. Simmons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving C. mons of Mount Vernon, N. Y.

The first real attempt by Britain to punish untidy motorists and others leaving litter after al fresco meals at beauty spots is being made by the West Sussex police. Forty motorists are to appear before Arundel magistrates on Aug. 23 charged under an ancient law reading:
The wheat market on the Board of Trade here fluctuated today in an erratic manner within a range of more than 2 cents a bushel and closed with a net gain of 1/4, cent.

Steve (Crusher) Casey, 225, Ireland, pinned Abe Goldberg, 215, New York, in 17:46 with a body slam and body press in the main match of a wrestling show at the Coney Island Velodrome last night, The Associated Press reported.

The Foreign Press Association asked German officials today to justify sweeps ing charges of misconduct made against foreign newspaper correspondents accredited to the German capital since the expulsion of Norman Ebbutt of The London Times this week.
The rural mail carrier passed up his customers today and it was just what most of the customers wanted. More than fifty owners of rural mail boxes took them down to balk the carrier.

The five-man school board of near-by Whitely Township confirmed tonight its dismissal of Mrs. Laura Elms Morris, teacher for eleven years in the one-room Kirby School, charging her with cruelty and "advising" her pupils that "the human race originated from monkeys."

Brigadier Charles M. Van Leusen, for the last thirty-six years in the service of the Salvation Army, died yesterday of a heart attack on a INew York, New Haven Hartford Railroad train which he had boarded in New York to go to his home in Mount Vernon.

The American Ambassador presents his compliments to His Majesty's Principal Secretary ofState for Foreign Affairs and has the honor to inform Mr. Eden that the United States Government would be glad to receive at the earliest possible moment a detailed elucidation of the official British position, having regard to the terms of the American-British Convention of Dec. 3, 1924,

Trial Results Fireman 1st grade Henry G. Engel. H. L. 151-Charge: Disrespect to superior officer: guilty; fined one day's pay. Ununiformed Fireman John J. Macek, H. L. 151-Charge 1: Neglect of duty; guilty; sentence suspended. Charge 2: Absence without leave; guilty; sentence suspended. Note-The total period of absence without leave of 1 hour and 45 minutes to be without pay.

Mrs. Inger C. Matthews, Robert C. Fulton, Frances Cushing Hall, A. F. White, Margaret Kenny, Evelyn S. Turner, Alice M. Boland, Lena F. Vanner, T. J. Neville, J. W. Wilde. Kenneth A. Hopwood, S. R. Livingston. Mary Little Spear, Schuyler B. Knox, Arthur Schiller, in Fifth Ave. Hotel, 24 5th Ave.
Resumption of assembly operations by the Ford Motor Company and the Plymouth Motorcar Company sent production totals up above the 100,000-unit level this week.

The July total for all classes of construction in thirty-seven Eastern States amounted to $321,602,700, it was learned, yesterday. This is an increase over the $317,842,100 reported for June of this year and a gain of 8 per cent over the total of $294.734.500 reported in July,. 1936.

A free-for-all fight in which a one-and-a-half-ton truck was overturned and two policemen and three other men were injured, disrupted traffic and attracted a large crowd at Ninth Avenue and Twenty-third Street last evening.

The Treasury opposed today a proposal by Senator Thomas of Oklahoma to create a monetary authority to regulate the value of the dollar. Acting Secretary Wayne C. Taylor wrote Chairman Smith of the Senate Agriculture Committee that his department objected to having the proposed agency "proceed without delay" to adjust the dollar's value to the 1926 price level, without prior investigation.

The Federal Government, through the Securities and Exchange Commission, took action today in connection with the proposed merger of the Alleghany Corporation and the Chesapeake Corporation, when the SEC announced that the corporations had acquiesced in its demand for additional information.

Mr. and Mrs. Neil E. Bosworth have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Abbie Louise Bosworth, to Laidlaw Onderdonk Williams, son of Mrs. Jesse Lynch Williams of Carmel, Calif., formerly of Princeton and New York, which took place on July 31 at Carmel.

Patrolman John J. Focacci, 37 years old, attached to the Maspeth, Queens, precinct, was arraigned before Magistrate Giorgio yesterday in Queens Felony Court on an extortion charge in connection with the alleged "shakedown" of an automobile accessory dealer. He was held in $2,000 bail for a further hearing on Aug. 20.
The first major building of the New York World's Fair, the $900,000 administration structure, was formally dedicated yesterday afternoon by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair.

A postoffice substation in a drug store here has been closed because in the last six months it has done a startling amount of business in money orders, all payable to the same man, it was disclosed here tonight by Postmaster Phillip L. Fellinger.

A warrant charging Mrs. Anna Hahn with the murder of George Gsellman, 67, was issued today as police pushed their investigation into four other deaths of elderly German acquaintances of the 31-year-old former German school teacher.
Ratifinations were exchanged today by Secretary Hull and Sir Herbert Marler, the Canadian Minister, of the income taxation convention which was signed here last Dec. 30.

Johnny Mirabella, 129 1/2, Brooklyn, battled to a six-round draw with Willie Davis, 134, Mexico, in the main boxing bout of six rounds at the Long Beach Stadium tonight. A crowd of 2,500 was present. In other sixes Ted Christy, 126, Yorkville, outpointed Al Gillette, 127, West Side;

Daily average sales of variety stores during July of this year were the same as for July, 1936, when sales were the highest on record for that month, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce reported today. Compared with June of this year, July sales showed a decline of 3 1/2 per cent,

The championship committee of the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews today announced that the 1938 British open championship would be held on the Royal Cinque Ports course at Deal and the British amateur at Troon. Scotland.

Mr. and Mrs. F. Hamilton McCormick-Goodhart of Washington were hosts at a luncheon in the Kebo Valley Golf Club today preceding the weekly tombstone tournament. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Pike. Mr. and Mrs.

Judge Freschi, in General Sessions, yesterday deferred acceptance of a plea from Wilbur Rothar, 42 years old, the former seaman, on two indictments in the attempted extortion of $2,000 last week from George Palmer Putnam, the publisher.

The brief lull that fell over the Shanghai war front at 9 o'clock last night following almost all-day sporadic hostilities was broken at midnight when the booming of heavy guns and the steady rattle of machine-gun and rifle fire bespoke resumption of the Sino-Japanese conflict on a scale that to all appearances relegates yesterday's clashes to the category of mere skirmishes.
Germany's huge transatlantic survey plane, the Nordmeer, completed an uneventful hop from Lisbon to the Azores today, making the 980-mile flight in six and a half hours.
General chairmen of fourteen non-operating railroad brotherhoods formally ratified a wage agreement here today providing for a five cents an hour increase for more than 750,000 members of the unions.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange rallied more than $1.50 a bale yesterday following a statement by Senator Bilbo that an.agreement had been reached in a conference at the White House to insure growers 12 cents a pound for cotton of the current crop, part bonus and part outright loan.

Reports in the financial district indicated yesterday that $10,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds of the new Duluth, Missabe Iron Range Railway Company might be offered to the public next month, following the effective date of a registration statement to be filed soon with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The crew of a 16-pounder battery in training at Watchet, Somerset, today with their second shot brought down from a height of 4,500 feet one Queen Bee, a radio-controlled airplane now used in antiaircraft practice over the sea.

Argentina's polo forces today met the strongest team they have been called on to face in this country and had to stage a strong rally in the final period to win, 6 to 5. The San Jose quartet rode in its regular line-up of Luis and Heriberto Duggan, Andres Gazzotti and Manuel Andrada, and was opposed to a 26-goal team on which three Americans rode in front of Hugo Backhouse, Argentine spare.
Anthony Quesada of New York City led artillery students of the Citizens Military Training Camp in winning awards today at final exercises of the thirty-day training period held at Madison Barracks.

A total of $58,976 in expenses and counsel fees of firms and persons involved in the reorganization of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway Company was denied by Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks here today. The Court did, however, allow fees of $11,500 and expenses of $1,064 sought by Graham, McMahon,

Everlast Suitcase and Bag Company, 130 West Bleecker Street, New York, and Israel Zaveloff and Harry Bernstein, proprietors, were ordered today by the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue stamping the words "genuine leather" or "leather" on bags made from the underlayers or flesh side of hide,

Total advertising linage in newspapers of fifty-two cities had a fractional gain of less than 1 per cent in July over the corresponding month of a year ago, according to Media Records yesterday. The exact figure was 0.7 per cent, with four divisions showing increases and four declining.
High Commissioner Paul V. McNutt, army officials and Philippine insurrection veterans celebrated Occupation Day today, thirty-ninth anniversary of the occupation of Manila by United States troops.

The eighth annual horse show of the Lake Placid Horse Show, Inc., opened here today. Riding in the old coach to the show grounds were Dr. George C. Owens, Mayor of Lake Placid and president of the association;

Holding that a municipal tax board and a board of assessments for local improvements, appointed last May by the majority on the Board of City Commissioners, were in office illegally, City Commissioner Vincent Murphy, Director of Finance and Revenue, inducted today his own appointees to the two boards.

The campaign committee of the Ontario Conservative party issued a statement on the party's attitude toward labor today, following a speech of Premier Hepburn at St. Thomas last night, regarded as the opening gun in a Provincial election campaign.
Hundreds of Summer residents from all the Hamptons attended the thirteenth annual horse show, held at the Riding Club of East Hampton today.
It is necessary to know something of the Rev. Martin Niemoeller's parish in the Berlin suburb of Dahlem to realize what an astounding event the near riot there on last Sunday night really was.

Meeting here for the first time in eighteen years, the pharmacists of the nation will hold their eightyfifth annual convention beginning tomorrow. About 1,000 pharmacists from all parts of the country are expected to attend the various sessions at the Hotel Pennsylvania, which will continue until Saturday, Aug. 21.

The United States Army is engaged at present in the third of its largescale war games since 1918, with a mammoth Fourth Army manoeuvre in the Seventh and Ninth Corps Areas, comprising seventeen States in the Midwest and Far West.

Aubrey Williams, assistant Works Progress Administrator, told a House labor subcommittee today that Congress had overemphasized consideration of the cost of unemployment relief instead of seeking a solution of the problem.

A retired business man who lost $36,620 gambling on the high seas was defeated yesterday in his first effort to get the money back. He still has a chance, however, for Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell found an old moralistic statute in his favor if he first irons out a technicality.

The popular ballad, "Wagon Wheels," is the favorite song of Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky. He has sung it before President Roosevelt many times, and a couple of years ago, a paper cap on his head, a stein in his hand, he sang it at a German Embassy party. Often, after a hard day's work,

Bruce McCormick, Los Angeles fireman, became national public links champion today with a 1-up 36-hole victory over his fairway buddy, Don Erickson of Alhambra, Calif. The winner tapped the ball into the cup for a first-hole par 4. It

Repossessed homes valued at more than $400,000 have been sold since March 1 by the Serial Federal Savings and Loan Association of New York City, reports George E. Palmer, secretary and manager of the organization. "This sales volume presents a striking object lesson that the real estate market is on an upward trend," states Mr. Palmer. "Sta-

A general sit-down strike on all American merchant vessels in Eastern ports was called yesterday by the National Maritime Union, a e C. I. O. affiliate, but the order was rescinded so speedily that it never reached most ships.
LAURENCE HOUSMAN. author of "King John of Jingalo" and other most delightful books, insists he is the most censored modern British author. He commenced

Cordell Hull, Secretary of State; James Roosevelt, son of the President, and Percy S. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., will be among the speakers at the ninth Boston Conference on Distribution, to be held Sept. 20 and 21 at the Hotel Statler, Boston, it was announced yesterday.

Funeral services were conducted today for Miss Mary Swain Wagner, former school teacher and formerly director of the Wagner Inn apartments here. Miss Wagner, who died Thursday in Bowne Memorial Hospital, was 73 years old.

The spread last week of the Sino-Japanese conflict from the northern mountain pass through the Great Wall at Nankow to Central China's metropolis, Shanghai, increases sharply the probability of a large-scale war between the two countries. At last the Chinese Central Government is resisting with some of its best troops and airplanes the advance of Japan.

Trade figures dropped to lower levels in many of the leading centers of distribution last week, and, taking the country as a whole, business conditions generally were spotty. With buying power sharply increased as the result of bumper crops, agricultural districts made the best showing for the week.

Johnny Allen made his first start since illness retired him June 18 and scored his fifth victory of the season today as the Indians defeated the White Sox in the second game of their series, 4 to 3. Allen limited the Sox to six hits in seven innings and was at his best with men on bases. He retired for Pinch Hitter Frankie Pytlak in the last of the seventh and Earl Whitehill finished.

IF the records of the United Scenic Artists mean anything-andthey always have in the past-this season is going to be quite- slow in getting under way. Up to the middle of last week only four contracts for scene designs had been signed by members Of this -all-inclusive union since July 1. And, in view of

Its Congressional sponsors now declare that the Wages and Hours Bill is unlikely to be enacted at this session. The temporary burial of the bill in committee is reassuring. It may lead to that mature consideration and debate which the measure could otherwise not possibly have received.

Eugene Gooch Currin, retired tobacconsist, who had been widely known in the industry for forty years, died here today. He was 69 years old. Mr. Currin was for several years a leaf tobacco buyer in Greenville, Tenn., for the American Tobacco Company.

Testimony was completed today in two suits seeking to block a proposed merger of the Chesapeake Corporation and the Alleghany Corporation, top holding companies of the Van Sweringen railroad interests. Judge Samuel K. Dennis announced that he would give his ruling on Monday.

The marriage of Miss MargaretAllen Broadhead, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Almet Broadhead of this place, to Richmond Bentley Shreve, New York banker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richmond Harold Shreve of Hastings - on - Hudson, N. Y., took place here this afternoon in St. Luke's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Myles Vollmer

Even if there had been no Hindenburg disaster, we needed a well-defined helium policy. The one existing pertinent act, passed originally in 1925 and revised in 1927, was based on the supposition that the available resources of the gas should be husbanded.

Reservoirs and artesian wells owned by Westchester County water districts provide only 62 per cent of the water required in normal years by 560,000 residents. In dry years only 53 per cent is supplied.

A studied policy of treading softly and leaving its big stick at home has enabled Wisconsin's Labor Relations Board to settle thirty-three of its thirty-four completed cases without resort to formal order.
The list of the North German Lloyd liner Columbus, due today from the Channel ports, includes E. E. Barth, New York banker, and Mrs. Barth, Mr. and Mrs. J.. D. Williams, Dr. and Mrs. Charles E.

NEWPORT, R. I.--This port, having witnessed the decisive defense of the America's Cup, is now prepared for the New York Yacht Club cruise this week. The harbor will be filled with the club's fleet on Tuesday, preliminary to the sailing of the Astor Cup race Wednesday, when all eyes will be centered upon the performance of the five Class J sloops.
A rare Himalayan bear cub, which Henry Trefflich, New York animal dealer, never expected to see was on the way to him today aboard the steamer City of Christ Churchthanks to Egyptian Coast Guardsmen.

Replying to Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas of Argentina in regard to the proposed leasing of six United States over-age destroyers to Brazil, the Brazilian Foreign Office released a statement today saying the idea that such a deal clashed with the Pan-American neutrality convention was astounding.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Max Lipkowitz of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Maxine Lipkowitz, to Edward Samuel Joseph, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Joseph, also of Brooklyn.

The Barber Shop Quartet contest, conducted in the last two Autumns by the Park Department, will be held again during the latter part of this month, it was announced the other day. Elimination contests will be held in the varoius boroughs as follows:

The marriage of Miss Mary Augusta Bates, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Delaplaine Bates of this place, to Walter Lucien Graves, son of Mr. and Mrs. Merle Dixon Graves of Gravesleigh, Pittsfield, took place here this evening in the garden of the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Edward Upson Cowles, pastor of the First Congregational Church, Westfield, performed the ceremony.
Joe McCarthy made a move to strengthen his faltering Yankee pitching staff today when he bought Ivy Paul Andrews from the Indians for the American League waiver price of $7,500.

AFFENS-Charles A., beloved husband of Celia, devoted father Wilbur. Funeral services at the West End Funeral Chapel, 200 West 91st St., Monday, Aug. 16, 10 A. M. ALPERT-Joseph L.,, beloved husband of Susan. devoted father of Dr. Irwin W., Ida, Rose and Ellen.

PERMISSION to operate an additional, 10,000-watt shortwave transmitter to supplement the 20,000-watt transmitter already in use at Station W1XAL, Boston, has been requested of the Federal Communications Commission by Walter S.

An attendance of several hundred persons is expected at the dance to be given at the Belle Haven Beach Club here on the night of Aug. 27 for the benefit of the children's surgical and orthopedic wards of the Post Graduate Hospital of New York.

The Eastern All-Star eleven which is to encounter the New York Football Giants at the Polo Grounds the night of Sept. 8, in the second annual Tribune Fresh Air Fund benefit game reached its quota yesterday as the thirtieth player, Bobby LaRue, Pittsburg star, accepted an invitation to join the collegiate team.

IT is thirty years since Labby died and a generation has arisen that hears not the lilt of his once familiar nickname. This book has to be read, therefore, not as one more biography of the already known, but like a novel on which we take a chance. We learned about the Barretts of Wimpole Street and liked it. So let us learn about the no less famous and much

Lawrence Pabst, veteran pilot for Eastern Air Lines, testified today before a Federal investigating board that a light on the power pole which wrecked a transport plane here Tuesday would have prevented the crash.

Miss Marguerite Boss and her sister, Miss Elizabeth West Boss, daughters of Professor Benjamin Boss, director of the Dudley Observatory, and Mrs. Boss, were married in a double ceremony this afternoon in the Westminster Presbyterian Church. Miss Marguerite Boss was married to John Hammond Munier,

The usual interruptions taking place when business recovery reaches a certain level and family budget changes are the two chief reasons for the current slowing down of retail activity, economists and store executives agreed here yesterday.

The engagement of $280,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York as the price of the metal in London again equaled $34.76 or about one cent below the gold shipping parity.

Decisions that mean war with China were taken by the Cabinet Council which ended its session at 1 A. M. today. The reports of Foreign Minister Koki Hirota and Navy Minister Mitsumasa Yonai were discussed. An extraordinary session of the Diet will be summoned to vote the expenditures required.
Thirty-three members of New York City's League of Physically Disabled promised today to "sit here as long as it takes" to obtain promises of white collar WPA jobs.

Speculation over a Senate successor to Hugo L. Black, nominated to the Supreme Court, was enlivened today with mention of Mrs. Dixie Graves, wife of the Governor, among possibilities for a "temporary" appointment.

Members of the debutante set here will display their talents at a "miniature cabaret" to be presented together with a dance by the Sea Girt Junior Auxiliary of Fitkin Memorial Hospital at the Stockton Hotel on Aug. 24. The program, arranged by a committee led by Miss Barbara Stanyer of New York, president of the auxiliary unit, will include a fashion show and entertainment by members of the charitable organization.

Talking pictures in which prominent legal authorities will discuss aspects of their profession will be a feature of the next semester of the John Marshall College here, Dean Alexander F. Ormsby announced today. Felix Frankfurter, John Henry Wigmore,

ULTRA-MODERN railway stations, with vastly improved facilities for beguiling the time of waiting passengers, are beginning to make their appearance in Britain. At present Waterloo and Victoria Stations in London are the only ones with news-reel cinemas, but the stations now being rebuilt in London, Leeds, Birmingham and Liverpool are to be equipped not only with such attractions but in some cases with sports arenas, reading rooms, better restaurants and many more shops.
William Weaver, a theatrical costume designer, died yesterday at the Beekman Street Hospital after a brief illness. He was 42 years old and lived at 421 East Fifty-second Street.

Mortgages accepted for insurance by the Federal Housing Administration on houses inspected during the course of construction in the first six months of the present year showed an increase of 57.4 per cent over the similar period of 1936.
One hundred members of the Summer colony were guests of Mrs. Harrington Mills of Washington and New York at her annual bridge and tea given in Saranac Inn Casino on Wednesday.

The widespread sales of radios put the public bands out of business in Utica and other up-State cities and villages. Now the bands are coming to life again and crowds are flocking around the bandstands to hear them. Many sit in their automobiles,

Henry Zenick, whose description of his crime as a "watermelon" theft brought down a storm of protest on the heads of Michigan officers seeking to return him from Wisconsin as a prison fugitive, received a parole today.
The Works Progress Administration had up to June 30 undertaken 940 airport projects, Aubrey Williams, acting administrator, announced today.

Guarded and nursed as though it were the Holy Grail of old, a gigantic disk which scientists have termed "the world's most valuable chunk of glass" is slowly being transformed into the precious mirror which, three years hence, will rest atop Palomar Mountain as the seeing eye of the world's largest telescope.

Frederick W. Reohr, last surviving Civil War veteran in Albany, died last night after a short illness. His age was 89. Mr. Reohr, who enlisted at 16 in Company K, New York Engineers, had served until four years ago as a guide at the State Capitol, giving up the job because of failing health. He participated in the Memorial Day exercises last May.

SYDNEY. YEARS ago Sydney Smith asked, with heavy irony, "Who reads an American book?" The Australians have lately been subjected to somewhat similar treatment with the significant difference that the attack was launched, not by a

Exporters last week rallied to the support of the State Department in the international controversy aroused by the proposal to lease six de-commissioned destroyers to Brazil, although the plan was indefinitely postponed after a conference between Secretary Hull and the Argentine Ambassador at the close of the week.

Exchange of ratifications yesterday by the United States and Canadian Governments, putting in effect the first income tax convention between the two nations, was hailed today by a high Treasury official as laying the ground work for a worldwide approach to the vexing problem of 'hot money."

The marriage of Miss Candace Carstens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christian Carl Carstens, to Dane Farnsworth Smith of Albuquerque, N. M., and Mount Pleasant, Tenn., took place yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents, 16 Middlemay Circle, Forest Hills, Queens.
Prince Fumimaro Konoe, the Premier, and his National Cabinet have emerged from their first encounter with the Imperial Japanese Diet in a far stronger position than before.

Recent research has elicited the fact that within an eight-mile circle of his biological station at Nonsuch are a third of the known species of deep-sea fishes of the world, Dr. William Beebe told an audience last night at Somerset.
The home of a non-striking employee of the Apex Hosiery Company was invaded early today by eight men, who routed members of the family from their beds, beat them and partly wrecked the dwelling.

Ernest Hemingway, author, sailed for Spain yesterday on the French liner Champlain. He reiterated his denial that Max Eastman had knocked him down last Wednesday in the offices of the editor of Scribner's.

Indications that some comprehensive plan will be presented to the lawmakers of this State when they convene in Albany for the next legislative session by real estate interests toward certain limitations in the present mortgage moratorium law are presented by Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York in the current issue of Real Estate and Building Management.

The curious case of the multitudinous money orders was solved today when detectives here unfolded a tale of precarious book-balancing and patient friendship of which the druggist-postmaster was both hero and victim.

Joseph P. Day has moved his small-homes division from its former quarters at 55 Liberty Street to his Queens office on Horace Harding Boulevard at Main Street, Flushing, near the World's Fair site. The amount of sales and

The auction sale of more than one hundred real estate holdings of six closed national banks in Westchester County is the first of a number of auctions planned for the liquidation of the assets of banks in New York and Pennsylvania, according to Joseph P. Day, one of the three cooperating realty firms handling the sales. The other firms are William A. White Sons and Albert M. Greenfield Co.

DETROIT. THE advance in passenger-car prices by Ford and General Motors, a step in which the remainder of the industry is following suit, is not difficult to understand when one investigates what has happened to car-production costs in recent months.

ADDISON, Vt.-The new head quarters of the Daughters of the American Revolution of the State of Vermont will be opened on Aug. 24 in the fine old Colonial mansion of General John Strong on the shores of Lake Champlain at Addison. The house, which

Dr. Harold Lynn Hough, former president of Northwestern University and now dean at Drew Theological Seminary, told a Chautauqua Institution audience today that "overwork never sent men to psychopathic hospitals." "It is because we moderns have lost our capacity for spiritual fellowship," he said.

As a result of his sensational umph in the metropolitan amateur championship, staged a few weeks ago at the Metropolis Country Club, Willie Turnessa, young Holy Cross senior who now enjoys national ranking in golf circles, has had his handicap reduced by one stroke. according to the new Fall

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity was slightly higher for the week ended Aug. 7, moving to 107.9 from 107.8. It stood at 103.1 for the corresponding week a year ago. Four series advanced, one was unchanged and two declined for the week.

With the passing of years Arturo Toscanini's performance of the Verdi requiem becomes one of the most devastating emotional experiences conchivable. But the Salzberg Festspielhaus, crowded with fashionables and sensation seekers is hardly the ideal frame for it.

Fifteen more American tourists have been barred from entering the Soviet Union on their arrival at Leningrad. They are passengers on the SwedishAmerican liner Gripsholm which arrived at Leningrad Wednesday

The New York Stock Exchange has admitted the following securities to the list: Allied Kid Company--Common stock, $5 par value. Bond Stores, Inc.--Common stock. $1 par value. Bower Roller Bearing Company--Common stock, $5 par value.

The Merchants Association of New York made public yesterday the report of its committee on taxation which has raised objections to parts of the report of the Joint Congressional Committee on Prevention of Tax Evasion and Avoidance.

The following WPA Federal Art Project exhibitions are on view this week: Community Sports Council, Parent-Teachers Association, 1,729 Pitkin Avenue, Brooklyn - 3 easel paintings, 16 graphic prints, 17 posters, 17 photographs, 2 mural sketches.
The Senate passed and sent to the House today legislation to give soldiers in future wars death and disability benefits at least as large as those granted to veterans of the World War.

I read with interest the letter of Samuel Harden Church, president of Carnegie Institute, in THE TIMES of Aug. 8, stating that "America is now privileged to enter upon the greatest prosperity of her history if only her labor population can be restored to their former spirit of loyalty by satisfaction and contentment through a cordial concession to their just and humane demands."
If you are afrai mosquitos will spoil your vacation try a remedy invented by Count Maurice Maeterlinck. All you need is a live rabbit.
The combined North CarolinaPrinceton tennis team opened its two-day tournament with the Oxford-Cambridge players today with a 9-3 victory.

Penitentiary sentences are being imposed, under the Virginia AntiLynching Law, on strikers convicted of taking part in a melee at the gate of the Industrial Rayon Corporation's mill at Covington on July 7.

The Senators, aided by errors, scored their sixth straight victory today, defeating the Red Sox, 8 to 3. For the second time since he was traded to Boston in June, Buck Newsom was beaten by his former mates. He went the route, giving nine hits, but errors by Buster Mills and Pinky Higgins gave the Senators four unearned runs.
