THE Crystal Palace was the great-grandfather of all subsequent World's Fairs, including the one which is beginning to sprout on the Flushing Meadows. It seems that in the year 1849 there was a great and good queen named Victoria, who was married to a great and good prince named Albert. Albert was then a man of 30 years of age. 'He was," says Mr. Hob-
State Trooper John J. Broske died today ten hours after he had been shot down in a hold-up without being able to assist his fellow officers in identifying the bandits.

EVER since rereading my review of "Souls at Sea," the new two-a-day show at the Globe, I have been suffering recurrent pangs of remorse which have not been alleviated by the friendly, but reproachful, letters re-
Ann Cooper Hewitt, San Francisco heiress, charged in a $50,000 damage suit today that she had been spied upon by an apartment house owner and private detectives until she suffered a nervous collapse.

The activity of the mortgage market in the sale of FHA insured loans is very beneficial for the man who wishes to build or buy a new house or who desires to refinance under the FHA plan, points out Donald K. Vanneman, president of the Housing Associates Corporation, Brooklyn.
Two men walked into a pool room here early today, shot to death Alfred Panepinto, 35-year-old undertaker, while he sat in a card game and escaped through a side door to a waiting car.
Mrs. Virginia Lincoln Rogers was married to Alfred Waters, assistant sales manager for the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company of Youngstown, here today.
To the Art Editor: THE very fact that so many of us are moved to enter this continued discussion of abstract art proves better than any other thing that, whatever else it is, it is not dead.

The United States Government is willing to undertake construction of lowcost housing units to rent at an average of $5.32 per month per room under the general formula of the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill, but not with the limitation of $1,000-per-room cost which was stipulated in the Byrd amendment to that measure when it passed the Senate recently.

One of the larger of several noteworthy realty transactions of the season in Jackson Heights, Queens, has been closed in the sale by the Queensboro Corporation of the northeast corner of Eighty-first Street and Thirty-seventh Avenue to Benjamin Gottfried, through Tankoos, Smith Co., brokers.

SOMETHING has happened to Mr. Saroyan Something, coming upon him between the publication of his third and fourth volumes of short stories. has pricked the bright bubble of his bluster and trickiness. It is a very much subdued Mr. Saroyan that we have before us-and a very much more effective one. Whether the change stems from increasing maturity or from some other chastening influence, it has

High- Senate can way departments of the forty-eight States received $1,145,590,000 for highway purposes during 1936, or $243,580,000 more than in the preceding year, and expended $1,131,151,000, the Bureau of Public Roads of the Agriculture Department reported today.

A moonlight dance and swimming carnival will be held Thursday at the Montauk Surf Club for the benefit of the Montauk Community Church. Miss Mary Hoerger, youthful diving champion, will appear with other stars in a water waltz, swimming races and diving contests.
ACTORS appearing in microAphone dramas may now "see" their voices on an illuminated screen while rehearsing to get exactly the right pitch, tone color, intonation and balance into their soken lines.

Mrs. Marion Turpie of Plandome, L. I., added the New York State women's amateur golf championship today to her metropolitan women's title by wielding a magic putter and defeating Miss Betsy MacLeod of Buffalo, 6 and 5, in a 36hole match.
At the mention of this title, we have noticed some wry expressions which seemed to say: "Why be so polite and conservative? Why so esoteric and dignified?

Barring a better than seasonal increase in activity in the stock market in the next few weeks, this season will rate as the slowest Summer, marketwise, since 1923. Some firms consider themselves fortunate to be able to claim commissions on a few hundred shares daily.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in somewhat smaller volume than during the preceding week and, with the exception of a few small blocks of the State, municipal and foreign loans called for payment this month, the announcements desig nated payments in future months.

Madison Square Garden, the huge sports arena on Eighth Avenue between Fiftieth and Fifty-first Streets, is now completely air conditioned, it was announced yesterday. The duct work of the new system is more than a mile in length and more than 300,000 pounds of sheet metal went into its construction.
Two new printing typewriters, designed to overcome the use of an equal amount of space for all characters as in the conventional typewriter, will be placed on the market shortly.

Frederick M. Barden, associate security analyst in the registration division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has resigned, effective on Sept. 9, to become secretary of the Pennsylvania Securities Commission, it was announced here today.
New York State's milk production is running above normal this Summer as a result of the best pasturage conditions in ten years, the State Department of Agriculture and Markets said today.

SEVERAL scores of college students are putting in eight hours a day at hard physical labor this Sum mer vacation and paying their own expenses while doing it in the Volunteer Work Camps conducted by the American Friends Service Committee. Their evenings are devoted to lectures and discussion of social and economic problems.

Fifty-three graduate scholarship awards were made public by Fordham University yesterday as the six-week Summer session of the Graduate School and Teachers College came to a close. Students of sixteen colleges other than Fordham were included in the awards

The much-heralded "hundred best books" of ancient and modern thought, which are to be the basis of the whole curriculum at St. John's College in Annapolis, were announced yesterday by Dean Scott Buchanan. By actual count they total 126, ranging chronologically from Homer to Freud,

Dr. Bayard T. Crane, founder of the Central New England Sanatorium and a tuberculosis specialist, died at his home tonight after a heart attack. His age Was 59. He formerly was connected with the State sanatorium here and the State of Maryland sanatorium. Dr. Crane was a graduate of the Harvard Medical School.

RADIO engineers in England are endeavoring to perfect a system of short-wave reception which promises ultimately to eliminate "fading." The system, known as "diversity reception," amounts to picking up a given signal with a number of different aerials and
THE great mystery that astrophysicists travel far to see whenever a total eclipse of the sun occurs is the corona. What is it? No one knows. It I

The unusually warm North Polar Summers now have drawn to a close, and authorities of the great northern sea route are confident they have discredited predictions by Arctic explorers of other countries that the ice floe, on which the four Soviet scientists are drifting in the polar basin, would break up, with possibly disastrous results to the men and equipment.

A seven-story addition to St. Clare's Hospital, 415 West Fiftyfirst Street, is under construction on the adjoining vacant plot to the west of the present six-story structure. Excavation work has been completed and the foundation work started. Upon completion the new

LAKE PLACID.--Proceeds of the third annual flower show to be held in the Olympic Arena on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, sponsored by the Garden Club of Lake Placid, will go to the Lake Placid General Hospital. The

The British flying boat Caledonia took off at 5:37 A. M. (11:37 P. M., Eastern Standard Time Saturday) today on a transatlantic flight to Botwood, Newfoundland, along the northern route of the projected regular passenger and mail service across the Atlantic.

In a thrilling "photo finish," which decided the metropolitan senior A. A. U. one-mile swimming championship in the Jerome Cascades Pool yesterday, Harry Tresnak of the New York Athletic Club conquered Joseph Lucas, unattached Yonkers natator, by so narrow a margin that the stop watches were unable to split the pair.

PHILATELY presents the in triguing anomaly of being the collective author of requests to Washington for new commemorative stamps and of letters to Washington protesting against so many commemoratives.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Nelson Street of 22 East Thirtysixth Street, this city, and Watch Hill, R. I., to Ivy L. Lee Jr., son of Mrs. Ivy Lee, also of this city, and the late Mr. Lee, took place yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Incarnation. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward M. Pennell Jr.

Goldstein Handball Champion Harry Goldstein, 1934 champion, egained the national A. A. U. onevall handball championship by eating his Trinity Club mate, Prank Gluckler, 21-9, 21-20, at Ravenhall, Coney Island, yesterday.
Heads of twenty railroad brotherhoods, representing 1.100,000 rail workers, framed a new legislative program today and approved Senator Black's appointment to the Supreme Court.

The forthcoming "little season" on the North Shore gives promise of being one of the gayest in many years and prospective hostesses are conferring with each other in an effort to get all the important parties into the calendar in September before the students return to college and the dates begin to be taken with horse shows, race meetings and other later Fall activities.

Jock Sutherland announced today the University of Pittsburgh football squad would begin drills Sept. 6. The tall Scotsman will be embarking on his fourteenth season at Pitt and his nineteenth as a college coach.

Growers in the Cape Cod cranberry district, which produce nearly three-fourths of the world's supply, are preparing to harvest what may be a record crop. Unofficial estimates set the 1937 yield on Southeastern Massachusetts bogs at better than 500,000 barrels.
In the last six weeks the Emergency Relief Bureau has received applications for home relief from 23,684 relief workers dropped recently from the WPA, it was disclosed by the ERB yesterday.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Harold G. Cutler of this city and Seven Pines, South Hamilton, Mass., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Patricia Winifred Preston, to Farley Wilder Wheelwright, son of Mrs. Wilder Wheelwright of Boston, and of William Bond Wheelwright of Chicago.

Saskatoon today was the centre pf a scientific experiment to explore the effects of the cosmic ray on the higher atmosphere. Dr. Robert Millikan of the California Institute of Technology, sent up by small balloons a highly sensitized electroscope, which, twenty miles above the earth's surface, was expected to measure the cosmic ray penetration into the upper layers of the atmosphere.

The Census Bureau today reported that cotton consumed during the cotton year of 1936-37, which ended July 31, totaled 7,944,803 bales, breaking all previous records. Heaviest consumption in any year previously was 7,189,585 bales in 1926-27. Last year 6,351,160 bales were consumed.

August is, of course, a "betweenseasons" period in the garden. Often weather conditions are such as to be anything but an invitation to carry on garden activities. It is not difficult to let things slip a little.

Fifteen New York students have received admission cards to Indiana University, according to Dr. David A. Rothrock, director of admissions. About 1,900 students will enter Indiana University for the first time next month. Four of the New York State students.

The performance in actual service of a steam locomotive of a new type recently manufactured by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad shows that the advantages of streamlining or electrification may be approximated with steam at only a small percentage of the cost entailed in the adoption of these innovations, according to engineers of the railroad.

Johnny Kinder of the Plainfield Country Club today won the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association championship for the third time, finishing with a 284, even par for four rounds over the Suburban Golf Club course. Kinder had rounds of 71, 71 yesterday to which he added a 70 this morning and a 72 this afternoon.

The Pittsburgh-Corning Corporation, organized last March by the Corning Glass Works and the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company to deal with the development, manufacture and sale of glass for architectural and building fields, will establish a New York office at the new Corning Glass Works Building at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street, it was announced yesterday.

THE continuing popularity of the Federal style of interior decoration, attested by its use in many of the season's exhibit rooms now being placed on public view, is undoubtedly due to the fact that it is so characteristically American. In it many different styles
RICHARD COCKBURN MACLAURIN, President of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 1909-1920. By Henry Greenleaf Pearson. nlustrated. 302 pp. New York: The Macmillan Company. $3.

THE three little English girls who vowed with solemn intent on birthdays to put the Fossil name in history books were not really sisters. They were orphans. and the byproduct of Great Uncle Matthew's passion for collecting.

Miss Mary Radford Henry of this city was married to Howard Brooker Seeley, also of this city, in the First Methodist Church today. The Rev. Fred Hoskins of the United Church and the Rev. Robert J. Beach of the First Methodist Church officiated.

To the Drama Editor: I have just finished reading a long article in The Sunday TIMES by one i Mr. Kennedy anent his -touring venture with his one-act plays and cannot help but raise my voice in protest. His is a rather disarming letter. but "facts is facts." When he

The acceptance by Thomas E. Dewey of the post of District Attorney on the Republican ticket now assures the independent voters of this city that the cause of Fusion is not dead and that a strong and genuinely bipartisan ticket will be placed in the field in the municipal election.

The Treasury Department notified Philippine headquarters today that $47,753,613.65 coconut oil trust funds had been transferred to time deposits bearing 2 per cent interest for the Philippine Government.

Tennessee's Public Utilities Commission announced tonight that it had decided to permit the Tennessee Electric Power Company, over the protest of protagonists of the Tennessee Valley Authority, to build a $2,000,000 steam-generating plant here in an area all but encircled by the TVA's hydroelectric lines.
The Senate Crime Committee asked the help today of "an aroused public opinion" to trim the nation's crime bill, which it estimated at nearly $13,000,000,000 a year.

WHEN broadcasting started the program directors had a choice of two reservoirs of music, the classics and jazz. The latter flowed more rampantly into space for several reasons,. chiefly because the early broadcasting contraptions could not do- justice to the classical tunes and, therefore, the artists of distinction frowned upon broadcasting.

Home owners in various sections of Westchester County purchased eight single-family dwellings last week from the Bowery Savings Bank. The houses are being offered by the bank in its campaign to dispose of all the one-family homes which it was obliged to take over during the depression period, before the Winter season.

A total of eighteen departments registered gains in New York and Brooklyn department store advertising during July, compared with the like month last year, according to the breakdown" issued yesterday by Media Records. Total advertising for the month, however, declined slightly, the figures being 1,868,078 and 1,916,540. respectively.

The engagement of Miss Lillian Marjorie Jester, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Godwin Jester of Highland Park, Dallas, to Percy Seldon Straus Jr., son of the New York merchant and philanthropist and Mrs. Straus, was announced here today at a luncheon given by Mrs. Fred Jester of Dallas, sister-in-law of Miss Jester, at the Brook Hollow Country Club.

Miss Alice Eugenia Merrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Lansing Merrick of this place, was married here at noon today at the home of her parents of John J. Dougherty, son of James T. Dougherty of Penn Grove, N. J., and the late Mrs. Dougherty. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Jacob Cole.

The marriage of Miss Veronica Sharkey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dominick Sharkey of this city, to Francis B. Bataille, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil Bataille of Maplewood, took place this morning in St. Michael's Church here. The pastor, the Rev. Felix O'Neill, performed the ceremony and was the celebrant of the nuptial mass which followed.

Hundreds of society notables were in the throng that today watched the historic Travers, called the midsummer derby of racing. Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt had among his guests Mr. and Mrs. Philip Ammydon of Palm Beach, Fla., and Miss Eleanor Young, Randolph F. Burke and Herbert Bayard Swope Jr. of New York. He entertained them at luncheon in the Terrace restaurant
Mrs. E. Bond Stearns of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Isabelle Stearns, to Samuel Carlyle Monroe, son of Mrs. Edward D'Oize of New York.

Miss Norma June Hollister, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Hollister of this place, was married to Irving E. Andrews, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. I. Andrews of South Norwalk, this afternoon in the Noroton Presbyterian Church. The Rev. George R. Montgomery, pastor, performed the ceremony.

A brand new college curriculum to which the experience of sixteen major colleges and universities has contributed, goes into effect this Fall at Hofstra College, Provost Rufus D. Smith of New York University announced yesterday. The college, which is the university's Long Island affiliate at Hempstead, hopes ultimately to become a model suburban coeducational college for the East.

The engagement of Miss Edythe Kranz, daughter of Mrs. Alice A. Kranz of the Windermere, this city, to Saul Jacobs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Jacobs, also of this city and Hackettstown, N. J:, has been announced by her mother.

Two of the thorniest economic problems now facing the country-the record-high holdings of gold and the record-high public debt-were linked together last week when the Republican members of the House Committee on Banking and Currency in a joint statement urged that the gold be employed to reduce the debt.
The polo team that C. V. Whitney has entered in the national championship moved up and down Waterbury Field at the Meadow Brook Club to score twenty-three times in an impressive test match today.

Victor J. Emanuel, head of the real estate and insurance brokerage concern of Emanuel Co., 7 Third Avenue, this city, died today of a heart attack at his home, at the age of 53. He attended to his business this morning and was stricken when he returned home for lunch.

A German shepherd dog proved the hero in saving the life of Thomas Norton, 55, a farmer, in the town of Steuben, according to Dr. Preston Clark, coroner. This was after an infuriated bull had fatally gored another hired man, Albert James, 59.

The wedding dress of the Duchess of Windsor is going to college this Fall. The gown with high neck and high-waisted effect that the former Wallis Warfield wore when she was married to the abdicated King of England has influenced Fall fashions, as noted in current style shows for Betty Co-ed.

ON the 350th anniversary of the founding of the first English colony in America the people of Roanoke Island, off the coast of North Carolina, are staging a commemorative pageant. It is a particularly inspiring event to the citizens of North Carolina and Virginia, who have been attending in increasing numbers. To others less familiar with the details

The completion, according to schedule, of the first building for the New York World's Fair, makes auspicious beginning of the vast undertaking. The city may look upon this as the handsel, the earnest, of a readiness for the opening, as planned, on April 30, 1939, the 150th anniversary of the day on which George Washington became President of the United States.

One thousand high senool graauates qualified for admission to the next freshman class at the Pennsylvania State College have already been turned away-refused because of the limitations of the college plant.

Three hundred and forty-five reserve officers of the Seventyseventh Division demobilized here today and returned to their homes in the metropolitan New York area after participating in one of the most important mimic wars held this Summer within the Second Corps Area of New York, New Jersey and Delaware.

Ernest T. Weir will meet the Government Monday in the second major contest of his career to run his huge steel properties without Federal intervention. The National Labor Relations Board will open a hearing here on its complaint that the Weirton Steel Company, subsidiary of the National Steel Corporation, employed terrorism against the Steel Workers Organizing Committee.

Secretary Wallace began work today on a crop-loan schedule to carry out President Roosevelt's share of a bargain with worried members of Congress from the Cotton Belt. Mr. Roosevelt agreed yesterday to order the price-bolstering loans, which in effect will peg cotton at 12 cents a pound.

Simon Elmore, 57-year-old WPA project house painter with a police record of drunken brawling and wife beating, was reported by police to have confessed last night to the murder of 4-year-old Joan Kuleba near South Beach, S. I., Thursday.

President-Commissioner Santiago Iglesias of Puerto Rico said today that he had received assurances indicating that he may obtain social security legislation for Puerto Rico during the present term of Congress.

Prison systems in the United States were hailed yesterday as superior to those of Japan by the Rev. Dr. B. Ikuta, assistant to the head of the social department of the Honganji Temple, which ministers to 10,000,000 persons and has headquarters in Kyoto, Japan.

BAR HARBOR, Me.--The remainder of the month on Mount Desert Island will be devoted to yachting, golf, tennis, swimming, the annual dog show and considerable social entertaining, besides picnics, dinner dances and musicals.

Fourteen-year-old Peter Villa, popular Mayor of the Junior City Government, dropped a political bombshell yesterday that rocked Christodora House, the Junior City Hall, to its very foundations. Peter walked out on his job and a twomonth governmental career.
General Tsai Ting-kai, looking older and grayer but still ardently vowing that China must offer military resistance to Japan, arrived last week in Shanghai, once again a war-torn city.

An Issue of 325,000 shares of $1 par value common stock to be sold for $2,406,250 through Clarence Hodson Co., Inc., as underwriter, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the American Business Credit Corporation of New York.

BROWN--HYMAN--Mrs. Nathan Hyman, Park Royal Hotel, announces engagement of her daughter, Helen, to Mr. William Brown. COHAN--BURGER--Mr. and Mrs. Arthur O. Burger, 670 West End Ave., announce the engagement of their daughter, Esther, to Mr. Leo J. Cohan.

" THERE is no retreat." That was the gist of my recent "audience" with "His Majesty, the King and Emperor Otto II." "If, like myself," the Archduke explained, "you have only one overpowering desire in life, you cannot make other plans for your future."
The third regatta of the Corinthian Yacht Club today closed the annual midsummer series, with 424 yachts crossing the three starting lines. This brought the total
The boards of strategy of the rival Democratic camps were busy ' yesterday completing final preparations for the opening this week of active campaigning for nomination in the primaries.
The Quebec Bureau of Mines has just issued a report on gold production of the Province in the first six months of 1937, showing the output of principal gold mines.

Pope Pius XI urged today the construction of at least one parochial school in every American parish in an address to 200 Italo-American boys he received this morning together with about 1,100 other persons in his last public audience before the beginning of the official Vatican vacation season.

Virtually every member of Kennedy Post, American Legion, has volunteered to enlist in a "blood donors' battalion" as a part of the post's contribution to civic welfare. Card indexes of the names and physical data relative to forty-eight veterans have been prepared for the Board of Health and for the Springfield hospitals.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Martha Blake, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Minot Blake of this place, to William W. Walcott, son of former Senator Frederic C. Walcott of Norfolk, Conn., and the late Mrs. Walcott.

The widespread criticism and longrange inferences which arose from the proposal to lease six over-age American destroyers, now decommissioned, to the Brazilian Government came as a distinct surprise to those interested in the scheme and in the end obliged the State Department to announce that the loan of the ships would be indefinitely postponed.
Subdued for eight innings and apparently beaten. the Pirates surged back today with a surprise five-run attack to defeat the Cardinals, 6 to 5.

Three New Yorkers, members of 244th Coast Artillery, are in the hospital here with injuries suffered when they were raked from the side of army trucks this afternoon near here by a passing junk truck. The injured are Aaran Rivenavich of 119 Sutter Avenue, Brooklyn, Thomas Luzzo of 495 Ninth Avenue, New York, and Michael Malito of 1,142 Seventieth Street, Brooklyn. All were badly cut, and Luzzo is believed to have a broken arm.

Faint radio messages indicated today that six missing Soviet fliers were safe somewhere in the Arctic between Alaska and the North Pole. Three planes bearing Russian agents left Fairbanks to search for the fliers.
For the first time this year, shoe production in July showed a decline under the corresponding month of 1936, according to estimates in the local trade yesterday.

The Rollins Technical School of Mechanical Optics, now situated here, will be transferred to the Blue Ridge College at New Windsor, Md., to become a department of the college, Dr. Harold Rollins, director of the school, announced today.
Seven members of the band which kidnapped John J. O'Connell D Jr. and collected $40,000 ransom in 1933 went toward four widely separated prisons today.

INTERLOCHEN, Mich. AT the National Music Camp at Interlochen, Mich., high school students, college students, teachers in service, and faculty, 350 strong, have gathered together to make music for the tenth consecutive Summer. For eight solid weeks they come to enjoy the woods with its tall, virgin pines and massive oaks and the waters of the twin. lakes Wah-be-ka-netta and Wah-be-kah-ness on the shores of which the camp is located.

Miss Patricia Gatehouse, daughter of Mrs. George A. Gatehouse of New Rochelle and the late Mr. Gatehouse, was married here this afternoon to Herbert Freeman Taylor, son of Mrs. J. Ostram Taylor of New Rochelle and the late Dr. Taylor, at Trinity Episcopal Church. The Rev. Wendell Phillips, pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

Declaring that the wage-hour bill must be taken out of the hands of professional politicians, Mortimer Fishel, attorney, who was responsible for the introduction of the Ashurst-Summers law governing prison-made goods, yesterday urged that the maximum-hour proposition be treated separately and the simplest possible statute prepared on it.

Leonard H. Pomeroy of 55 Rugby Road, Brooklyn, has been named the first recipient of the scholarship established at Columbia University by Major John Vernou Bouvier in the name of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York,

A dinner dance took place this evening at the Apawamis Club of Rye. Among those who entertained were Mr. and Mrs. Paul Fitzpatrick, Mr. and Mrs. Clinton S. Lutkins, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Swift, Miss Virginia Snyder, Mr. and Mrs. H. F. G. Wey Jr., Mr. and Mrs. W. Murray Lee, Miss Frances Crawford, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Conley and Mr. and Mrs. Eugene F. Humphrey.
RETAIL trade continued to drag last week in most sections. Small improvements were reported here and there but the general comment was that sales were not up to expectations.

In one of the largest recent transactions involving industrial properties in Connecticut, G. F. Heublein Bro., makers of sauces, gin and mixed drinks, have purchased the plant of S. K. F. Industries, Inc., at Hartford. Joseph P. Day was broker, with Slack-Middlebrook of Hartford as associate.

The writer of the following article, a British journalist who has just returned from a tour of Central and Western Europe, for several years was head of the Press Department of the British Foreign Office, and from 1910 to 1920 was chief correspondent in the United States for The Times of London.

Asserting that "only those who can meet the tests of character are to be given positions of commanding authority," Rabbi B. Benedict Glazer, applying his sermon at Temple Emanu-El yesterday morning to recent municipal and national problems affecting the judiciary, said that corrupt courts were more to be-feared than "manifestations of communism or fascism."

The fact that the first half of last night's program of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Lewisohn Stadium was devoted to compositions by the late George Gershwin attracted an audience of 6,313 persons to the outdoor amphitheatre.

Prompt deliveries of Fall merchandise, especially staples, are now available in the New York wholesale market, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers, and the trade in general is anxious to see Fall purchasing gain momentum so that consumer preferences may be determined.
Dr. George L. Bird of 2,137 Locust Street, Philadelphia, has been appointed as assistant professor in the School of Journalism at Syracuse University, Dean M. Lyle Spencer announced today.

Declaring that China is duty bound to defend her territory and existence and never will surrender any part of her territory, the Foreign Minister early this morning released a lengthy communique from Nanking justifying her actions thus far in the conflict.

In a large bare room at the Department of Agriculture early this week a few newspaper men dashed across a white line to shout into waiting telephones that the United States was about to have its biggest cotton crop in six years.

Five and a half years ago Shanghai was the scene of a bloody unofficial war, which in thirty-five days of fighting was estimated to have cost at least 12,000 lives and caused more than $300,000,000 in property damage, the scars of which still remain in China's international city.
Foreign cotton prices have advanced about $2 a bale following reports that an agreement had been reached in Washington to insure 12 cents a pound to growers for this year's harvest.

SYDNEY, Australia.--Federalism in Australia is beginning to creak, and the close grip of State's rights is causing Commonwealth leaders to consider how the situation can be brought into line with modern conditions.

Two brothers, who, until they met last Spring, had not seen each other since they were separated in an orphanage forty-one years ago, had their second reunion in New York yesterday and revealed plans to make an intensive search for a third brother, who has been missing for thirty-three years.
One day this week some eight or ten large Rhode Island milk dealers found themselves in possession of 5,000 quarts of pink milk.

Between 6,000 and 8,000 of the 40,000 workers affected by the strike in the silk and rayon industry of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and New England are expected to return to work early this week under an agreement signed by the Textile Workers Organizing Committee, ...

PEOPLE who sail the seven seas for pleasure have plenty of spare time to write letters to their friends back home. Because of this, the hobby of col. lecting sea post and packet boat marks has become widespread since the adoption of international agreements for the handling of mail posted on shipboard.

Dr. Robert Karl Reischauer of Princeton University, one of three known American dead in yesterday's Chinese-Japanese fighting in Shanghai, was conducting a group of American students on a tour of the Orient, Princeton associates said yesterday. They left at the close of the school year in June.
A deep-well irrigation project, viewed by its sponsors as the forerunner of a vast watering system for the drought area of the Southwest, was dedicated here today in a mild dust storm.

The Boerse, although calm, reflected a good tone today, but activity continued on a strictly limited scale. Heavy Industrials, chemicals machines 2nd other leaders were quiet, with scattered evidence of strength. Potashes were resistant, textiles mixed and somewhat more variable than other stocks.

Some 250 officers and members of headquarters companies of the New York National Guard and army instructors stationed at Camp Smith completed today the first stage of two weeks of command post exercises that will end next week with five days of manoeuvres in the bivouac area ten miles from the reservation.
Frederick T. Macfarlan, a retired official of the Treasury Department, died on Friday in his home at 993 Summit Avenue, the Bronx, after a long illness. He was 81 years old.
" Pay dirt," dumped in Western North Dakota by mother nature during her glacial push ages ago, is giving up gold in paying .amounts through modern scientific process.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy May Danielson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Danielson of Utica, N. Y., to Alfred E. Skeats, son of Mrs. Wilfred S. Skeats of Orange and the late Mr. Skeats, took place here this afternoon in the Union Methodist Episcopal Church. The Rev. Chester Ham performed the ceremony.
Recent United States diplomatic movements are causing much speculation in international circles regarding the future handling of American relations with the League of Nations.
AWAY back in 1908 the late Hank O'Day, A famous baseball umpire, took about an hour to make up his mind that Fred Merkle had failed to touch second base at the Polo Grounds.

Social justice is no recently acquired idea with Senator Hugo L. Black, the new nominee to the Supreme Court. He was already thinking and proceeding in that channel twenty-five years ago, when he was assigned to the job of cleaning up a badly congested police court docket in Birmingham.

Of the 3,284,723 workers in retail employment in 1935, 30.5 per cent were women, according to a recent report of The Census of Business. The percentage varies widely among different businesses. There are more than twice as many men as women in the entire field; the proportion of women ranges from a low of 3.5 per cent in garages to a high of 92.9 per cent in millinery stores.

THERE is nothing surprising in having an article about the restoration of the Old First Church in Bennington written by two Vermonters--novelist and architect--instead of one. To fit the occasion it should have many more authors--housewives, farmers, storekeepers, lumberjacks, factory workers and

Use of crude rubber by manufacturers in the United States in July amounted to 43,650 long tons, cormpared with 51,798 in the preceding month and 48,250 in July, 1936, the Rubber Manufacturers Association reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON. THERE has been in recent days a good deal of agitation, mostly under cover, against the "monopoly" which by reason of its forehandedness and pioneering Pan American Airways enjoys in foreign aviation service. At least one important air-

A BACKWARD glance at recent Lewisohn Stadium history reveals that the largest crowds have been attracted by events that concerned Jascha Heifetz or the late George Gershwin. For both the figures have steadily increased, starting, that from the night of Aug. 16, 1932, when the composer's appearance drew 17,835-a record for those days. Three years later, on Aug. 5,

Content with having established a reputation as one of the nation's most efficient relief administrators, Dr. William Haber, Professor of Economics at the University of Michigan, is going back to the classroom.

An official coup de grace given to the Wages and Hours Bill by Speaker Bankhead today was interpreted by leaders on both sides of the Capitol as .an indication that little stood in the way of terminating the current session by the end of next week.

Marica, 4-year-old black filly owned by Tom aggart's French Lick Springs Stable, ran away with the one-mile Francis S. Peabody Memorial Handicap at Lincoln Fields today. It was Marica's second stake victory on successive Saturdays and tightened her claim to the filly championship of the nation.

The Rev. Francis J. Meyer, former treasurer of Xavier University, died of a heart attack here today. Father Meyer, a native of Chicago, where he was born sixty-two years ago, received his early education there and later entered St.

The stock market threw off its usual midsummer dullness for the Saturday session yesterday, and with the -largest turnover for the abbreviated session in a month, prices moved to their best levels of the week.

THE current season of concerts at the Stadium by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra comes to a close Tuesday night. Efrem Zimbalist, who will be heard tomorrow night, will be the final soloist of the season. The last Goldman Band concert for the season will be heard tonight in Central Park.

SMALL talk: if small talk were in actuality like this, there would be no complaints of the lost art of conversation. Brilliant and often deeply searching, these essays of Harold Nicolson's are easily perceptive and as easily entertaining. Their wit is urbane and evocative. They are very good company. It is a guest to be welcomed-a book of such "small talk" as this.

The Chamber of Commerce of the United States urged today that pending wage and hour legislation be junked. In a special committee report the chamber said that any wage and hour abuses should be corrected by State legislation, with Congress enacting some Federal law to give support to State programs.

PHILADELPHIA. HISTORIC Ephrata Cloisters, monastic settlement founded more than two centuries ago on the banks of Cocalico Creek, sixty miles west of Philadelphia, and now visited annually by some 8,000 tourists, has moved a step nearer to becoming a Stateowned shrine.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Claflin gave a dinner tonight at their place in the Shinnecock Hills for the Rev. Dr. Donald B. Aldrich, rector of the Church of the Ascension in New York, who will conduct the service here tomorrow at St. Andrew's Dune Church and who is passing the week-end with Mr. and Mrs. Claflin. Among the other

Now that the major parties have momentarily disposed of the New York Mayoralty conflict by filing designations for the primaries, the importance of the 168 delegates to be chosen for the State Constitutional Convention begins to achieve due recognition.

Representative Gerald Boileau of Wisconsin said today that he will attempt to amend the Bilbo Cotton Laboratory Bill, under consideration by the House Agriculture Committee, to include all agriculture products. The Senate has passed the bill.

WASHINGTON. ONCE more the question of preserving Niagara Falls in all their majestic beauty, to be enjoyed by the millions who visit them annually, has attracted public attention. The other day Representative Alfred F. Beiter of Williamsville, N. Y., asked President Roosevelt to include an appriation of $1,000,000 in the next deficiency bill to cover the share of the United States in the cost of preserving the Falls.
General Pershing will arrive in London tomorrow to take part in the dedication of the memorial at Brookwood cemetery to American soldiers who died in England.

Narrow and mixed price movements were the rule yesterday in another listless session for bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. Scarcely sufficient trading volume developed to establish definite price trends, even among the pivtotal issues, with the result that the group price averages showed only minor changes on the day.

The most extensive exhibition of paintings and decorative arts ever sent out of Sweden will be shown in this country, beginning next month, the Swedish American Tercentenary Association, 630 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday. The display will be'opened Sept.

A dramatic daylight shooting and probably fatal wounding of two Japanese sailors here this afternoon put this city of almost 600,000 population in a state of tension. Residents expect a rapid development of events similar to those in Tientsin and Shanghai.
Mrs. Drexsel Dahlgren gave a large dinner at her Bellevue Avenue Summer home this evening to introduce to society her granddaughter, Miss Sheila Emmet.
Winning the mile medley relay. the last event on the program, Great Britain defeated Germany, 69 to 67, in an international track and field meet today.

There is great satisfaction in Austria over the volume of this year's tourist traffic, which is so important for Austria's monetary situation. The number of foreign visitors has increased about 12 per cent compared with last year, despite the devaluation of the currency of Austria's two greatest competitors, Switzerland and Italy.

Miss Evelyn Elizabeth Johnston, daughter of Mrs. Bertha Johnston of Mamaroneck, was married here today in the Reformed Church to A. William Spence Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. A. William Spence of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William H. McCance, associate pastor.

HOLLYWOOD. THE return of Norma Shearer to the screen appears likely in the early Autumn in "Marie Antoinette," which she has contemplated for two years and which was to have been made early in the season had she not retired upon the death of Irving Thalberg, her husband. A produc-

Although a number of British casualties are reported among the Shanghai dead it became known tonight that the British are still determined to confine any action to the defense of her own area in the stricken city.
Chicago's trumpets of jubilee will be muted tomorrow to bring back the echoes of a dead march-the prelude to the Fort Dearborn massacre.

Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Minister of the Interior, addressing the Foreign Germans' Institute here today, declared that the minorities question in Eastern Europe constituted "the most dangerous explosive element in the present international situation."

Thomas Edmund Dewey, who made his decision to run for District Attorney yesterday, is a deliberate, slow-moving man of 35 with a baritone voice of near-operatic quality whose career at the bar has been strikingly successful.

UPON the cover of its August issue The Magazine of Art reproduces William Gropper's strikingly beautiful sketch for an Interior Department mural, and the leading piece'this month is one that deals with Gropper and his work, written by Ernest Brace. The article is well illustrated, one of the plates, "Combat," being in full color.

The search for Mrs. Charlotte L. Lucas, believed drowned in Long Island Sound after a companion tied her to an oyster stake, ended today with police and firemen who joined in it returning to routine tasks. Grappling operations had been in progress since George W. Thorpe of New Haven,

Noted Chinese Author PEIPING is to Nanking as Kyoto is to Tokyo. Both Peiping and Kyoto are ancient capitals, around which hang an aroma and mystery and historic charm which the younger capitals, Nanking and Tokyo, cannot possibly have.

Thirty-nine American warships and about 7,000 soldiers, sailors and marines stood ready tonight to protect the lives and property of United States citizens in the zones of the Chinese-Japanese conflict.
Charles Michie, leader of the New Zealand eclipse expedition to Canton Island, in a statement today regarding the alleged New Zealand-United States rivalry there during the eclipse observations,

The old cell block of Sing Sing Prison, condemned time and again by inspectors of the Commission of Correction, came in for another criticism in the report filed yesterday by Commissioners Samuel H. Miller and Cecilia D. Patten. A few days prior to the inspection there were 2,601 inmates in the prison, the report showed,

Elimination of fixed-price ranges in the coat and suit industry will be attempted for the next Spring season by presentation to the annual convention of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board on Aug. 30 and Sept. 1

The Governor General of Australia, Lord Gowrie, who is concluding a tour of Papua, a mandated territory of New Guinea, to celebrate the coronation, had many curious experiences. Papuan chiefs warmly welcomed him, declaring they were proud to be British subjects.

FOR a variety of reasons, among which is not that I'm bored by an endless procession of smash hits, I have resolved to abandon the business of theatrical producing. The decision itself was simple; indeed, in view of the fact that I like to eat, almost inevitable. But the contributing motives and my attitude of mind in bowing out are of darker, subtler stuff.
District Judge Thomas F. Moran granted a divorce today to Manuel Komroff, New York author and editor, from Mrs. Elinor M. Barnard Komroff, British artist. They were married in New York Dec. 23, 1918.

Detailed plans for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's School of Architecture, as part of the institute's original plans for gradual expansion to keep pace with advances in science and engineering, have been announced.

One hour after he registered at the Hotel New Yorker Louis Levy, 47 years old, owner of an army and navy store in Mount Holly, N. J., plunged thirty-two floors to his death from his room on the thirtyseventh floor shortly before 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

Professor John Gordon Thomson, world authority on tropical diseases, died today at the age of 60. A frequent visitor to the United States, he was exchange lecturer at Johns Hopkins University in 1926.

With a total attendance for the Summer of about 22,000 persons, representing every State east of the Mlississippi, besides Minnesota, Missouri, Colorado and California, the Mohawk Drama Festival ended its third season on Union College campus tonight.

Twenty-seven nations are represented by delegates at the international encampment marking the silver jubilee of the Girl Scout movement now in session at Camp Andree, Briarcliff Manor, N. Y. At the opening ceremonies the girls heard Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt tell them that the reason for international misunderstandings was .that "we don't bring them down to the level of our personal reactions-that is, the way you feel

The fourth anual Berkshire symphonic festival which has had more need thus far for weather reporting than music reviewing, enjoyed its first taste this season of a perfect day and evening for tonight's concert.

The report of the Columbian Carbon Company and subsidiaries for the first half of this year, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after Federal income taxes, depreciation, minority interest charges and other expenses, of $2,520,686, equal to $4.69 each on the 537,406 shares of capital stock outstanding at the end of the period.

The Tigers undisputed possession of second place in the American League today, pasting five pitchers for forty hits that included eight home runs and taking both ends of a double-header from the Browns, 16 to 1 and 20 to 7. With the Yankees losing, Detroit cut the league leaders' margin to ten games.

THE WEST CHAMBER, or Hsi Hsiang Chi-a Chinese play of the thirteenth century by Wang Shih Funow for the first time translated into English by Henry H. Hart, is considered by Oriental critics the best specimen of Mongol drama.

Four furiously punching Argentines and one Uruguayan gave South America a 5-to-3 edge over the United States in the finals of the Pan-American boxing games tonight. The Argentines won four, the United States three and Uruguay one of the eight championship battles.

NEW ROCHELLE'S third annual model home, erected as a preliminary to the community's Better Homes Show, was opened for public inspection yesterday with informal ceremonies in which FHA and civic officials participated.

Whalen, nephews, $25,000 each, life estate in $50,000 trust fund, one-half interest In furniture business at 221-27 Grand St. and 677 Driggs Ave. and one-third of residuary estate: niece, May Whalen Sullivan. $10,000 and one-third residuary estate;

Miss Alice Marble of Los Angeles, women's national tennis champion, met with her fourth defeat of the season at the hands of Mlle. Jadwiga Jedrzejowska of Poland today in the final round of the Eastern turf court title tournament at the Westchester Country Club.

Despite a strike wave and financial difficulties, Mexico is a carnival country now as the tourist influx from the United States daily breaks alltime records. Carefree, gay travelers spending money right and left are making this nation forget the slump in its regular trade and other difficulties.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company of Alabama charged the United Rubber Workers of America today with "coercion, intimidation and terrorism" in a membership campaign.

THE second Berkshire Symphonic Festival to be given by Dr. Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra, and the first to be held in the glorious new home bestowed upon orchestra and festival by Mrs. Gordon Brooks, comes to an end today. CHIEF SCOUT: At Vogelenzang in The Netherlands last week 28,000 Boy Scouts closed their world jamboree by marching before their founder and leader, Lord BadenPowell.
He's got everything and he'll give you a good show," was Bill McKechnie's comment in the dugout before his 30year-old rookie right-hander, Jim Turner, went out to face the tottering Dodgers today.

The fabrication of silk and its rival, rayon, constitutes approximately onetenth of the American textile industry. Last week the Textile Workers Organizing Committee, which has set out to enroll all textile workers under the C. I. O. banner, embarked on its first major strike by calling out about half of those employed in the silk and rayon mills.

The Fishers Island Yacht Club fleet departed this morning on its annual cruise. The fleet will race home from Duck Island, N. Y., with the fleet of the American Yacht Club of New York and return to Fishers Island Tuesday evening.

Dr. Chengting T. Wang, the Chinese Ambassador, issued the following statement here tonight: "Since the outbreak of the Lukouchiao incident on July 7, my Government has deliberately refrained from the use of aircraft for fear that such weapons may likely endanger the lives and properties of civilians.

Coffee futures last week were subject to a series of constructive news flashes from Havana, where the second Pan American Conference now is in session. However, the response by the local futures market was unfavorable, occasioned primarily by the weakness in Brazilian coffee prices.

THE bicycle having pedaled to an old-time high in national popularity, cycling enthusi asts in the meantime discovered that certain games can be played on wheels, lending additional zest to their favorite recreation.

The Insurgent adio at Salamanca said tonight their "big push" to capture Santander and the remainder of Government territory in Northwest Spain already had resulted in the capture of several villages in North Palencia Province.
Thomas E. Dewey, whose success as a special prosecutor has checked racketeering in New York City, announced yesterday that he would run for District Attorney of New York County.

The Hedgerow Theatre closed its annual Shaw festival of four weeks with a performance of "Too True to Be Good" at its Rose Valley Playhouse tonight. This play, written in 1932, was the 123d production added to the Hedgerow repertory

A special yachting dance was held in the Pine Orchard Yacht Me and Country Club tonight in connection with the three-day regatta of the Connecticut Yacht Racing Association. Over three hundred couples attended.

From the periodic assaults on Mount Everest to the Sunday expeditions starting from the end of the subway line, mountain climbing affords sport for every degree of skill. Thousands of vacationists in the mountains of New England and New York match other thousands drawn to the higher altitudes in the West.

STROUDSBURG, Pa.--The eighth annual Pocono Mountain Horse Show will open at Mount Pocono on Thursday and continue throughout Friday and Saturday. Every effort has been exerted to make this the greatest show in the history of the Horseshow Association.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Frances Becker, daughter of Mrs. William Becker of Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Becker, to William J. Lyons, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Lyons, also of Fort Hamilton, took place yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Church, Fort Hamilton. The Rev. Joseph Kelly performed the ceremony.

The marriage of Miss Anna Bode Kiehm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Kiehm of South Orange, to Donald Langston, son of Mrs. Alma M. Langston of Los Angeles and Lloyd H. Langston of Maplewood, took place here today at the bride's home. The Rev. Fred E. Miles, pastor of South Orange Methodist Episcopal Church, officiated.

Buffalo scored its third straight victory tonight, defeating Jersey City, 3-1, behind the brilliant pitching of Fabian Kowalik. The triumph. coupled with the double defeat of Syracuse this afternoon, moved the Bisons into a tie for third place with the Chiefs.

Apartment vacancies are growing less every month in Jackson Heights, L. I., and if the present rental activity is maintained through August and September comparatively few apartments in that section will be vacant on Oct.
Motor Cycle Patrolman A. Douglas Poole was suspended today for twentynine days for "manhandling" E. Cutler Dawes, a nephew of former Vice President Charles G. Dawes.

WELLINGTON, N. Z. IN Australia film production on a large scale and involving tens of thousands of pounds has resulted in the creation of some features which it is hoped to place on the world market, but in New Zealand movie development has proceeded in another direction.
The Senate Commerce Committee recommended today approval of a Federal program of measures against stream pollution, including grants and loans to local governments and individuals.

Carrying forward the movement launched by the Citizens Committee of Johnstown, Pa., during the recent steel strikes, the Citizens National Committee announced yesterday from its national headquarters, 41 East Forty-second Street, that it would undertake a "merciless expose" of Red racketeers.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation assumed charge of the Fort Greene National Bank, 118 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, at the close of business yesterday. Insolvency was given as the reason for the action.

A MONG the china pigs and wooden donkeys his friends contribute to the collection parading on the Pres ident's desk to add to the gayety of the executive office stands one lonely elephant. It is a very small elephant made of white flannel, the ears flopping and the wobbly underpinning inclining him to list.
Now on the Atlantic and headed this way are three European speedboat drivers who are worrying the home-breds into gray hairs and premature old age.

Miss Sidney McGiffert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julian E. McGiffert of this city, was married here tonight in the Colton Memorial Chapel of Lafayette College to Dr. William W. Watt, son of Dr. and Mrs. Homer A. Watt of Glen Ridge, N. J., by the Rev. Dr. John E. Mertz.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Ann Callahan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Callahan of Orange, to Gordon F. Price, son of Frederick R. Price of West Orange and the late Mrs. Price, took place this morning in St. John's Church here. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, Mgr. Paul T. Carew.

One hundred and eleven survivors of the nation's wars who are living today will be dead tomorrow, according to estimates of the Veterans Administration.
WASHINGTON.--When Congress adjourns, Senators and Representatives, in theory, will have about $109,000 to pay the cost of their transportation home.
A new "sinking canyon," seventy-five feet deep, appeared today beside the larger one that formed suddenly two weeks ago and alarmed this productive farm section of Southern Idaho.

Federal troops have been moved into the entire east coast Poza Rica oil field, one of the richest, petroleum districts in the world, and a condition equivalent to martial law has been quietly established, it was learned in the capital tonight.

Interest in American-styled readyto-wear is growing by leaps and bounds in England and the Continent, according to William Delit, production manager for C. A. Brenninkmeyer of Amsterdam, Holland, who is here on his Fall trip to buy American models.

Six hundred persons, including three Americans, were killed and 1,000 were injured yesterday when Chinese airplanes twice bombed the foreign concessions north of Soochow Creek. The bombed areas were teeming with war refugees and the normal populace.

Jewish Board of Guardians Reports Results of Two Years of Experiment Summer camps are far more successful in straightening out the tangled lives of problem, pre-delinquent boys when psychiatric techniques are employed, the Jewish Board of Guardians reported yesterday after two years of experiment.

The President's appointment of Senator Black to the United States Supreme Court was one of those masterful strokes of political diplomacy which hearten his friends in the belief that the President will extricate himself from the bog which seems to be slowly engulfing his second term.

Delegates will attend in the nude the sessions of the sixth annual convention of the American Sunbathing Association, formerly the International Nudist Conference, at Sunshine Park, near here, next Saturday through Monday, Aug. 23, it was announced today.

The General Motors Corporation, which recently opened its $5,525,000 assembly plant here, this week acquired the last of five parcels of land which now give the company 1,100 feet frontage on the northerly side of Pleasant Street, near State Highway Route 25.

A building boom in these resort islands led the Government today to relax its strict immigration laws to permit a limited number of skilled workmen to be brought here from the United States for several major construction projects.

Adolph Kiefer of the Lake Shore A. C., Chicago, twice broke the Japanese record for foreigners in the 50-meter back-stroke today in the preliminaries of the American-All Japan swimming meet at the Meiji Shrine pool.

Elwood Woodling of Ohio State University set a new record today in winning for the second straight year the three-and-a-half-mile marathon swim for the George Pawling Trophy in the Schuylkill River at Miquon.

A writ of habeas corpus for John S. Farnsworth, former naval officer under sentence of from four to twelve Years for violating the Espionage Act, was taken under advisement, by Federal Judge E. Marvin Underwood today.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Rosemarie Huberty, daughter of Mrs. Edward Kennedy of 2,516 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, and of the late Henry L. Huberty, to James C. Digney, son of Mrs. Charles Digney of 201 East Thirty-second Street, Brooklyn. and the late Mr. Digney.

The new Interborough News Building at 525 West Fifty-second Street, running through to 520 West Fifty-third Street, is nearing completion for occupancy by Sept. 1. This loft structure, containing more than 75,000 square feet of loft space, is built on the new New York Central underpass running through the West Side business and manufacturing districts.

Business and professional men artisans and laborers, enrolled in the United States Naval Reserve, who had waited five years for service at sea on a battleship, had their wish fulfilled yesterday when the U. S. S. Texas steamed out of the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, accompanied by two destroyers.

College boys and girls who are still on vacation, with no thought of tomorrow's lessons, may feel that it is too soon to talk about luggage and clothes for the back-toschool trek, but with that New York shopkeepers do not agree.
DURING the next four or five weeks motor traffic on American highways is expected to reach its highest peak for 1937, if not for all time.

Baron Stratncarron, who as Ian MacPherson was Chief Secretary for Ireland during one of the most turbulent periods in Dublin, fell dead today of a heart attack while lunching in a London restaurant. His age was 57.

A warning to home owners against unscrupulous and "high pressure" salesmen who appear to have been going about the country, usually in groups, defrauding and misleading owners into signing contracts requiring payment of large sums for home repairs and modernization was issued yesterday by the National Better Business Bureau.

The crews of both the American and British Bermuda Airliners will be guests of honor at a reception and entertainment to be held Wednesday afternoon and evening at the Sands Point Bath Club. Mrs. W. Alton Jones of Forest Hills, L. I., who is chairman of entertainment for the eighth an- c ual Lake Placid Horse Show, and Mr. Jones entertained members of their house party at the show this afternoon and at the dinner dance at the barn tonight.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul Frankfurter of 425 Riverside Drive of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy M. Frankfurter, to Stanley D. Hart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vivian S. Hart, also of New York.

Richard K. Mellon's brown gelding Rector proved again today his dominance among Eastern timbertoppers by being judged champion hunter at the thirteenth annual horse show of the East Hampton Riding Club.

Chicago cricketers were successful today in the fourth match of their Eastern tour when they defeated an eleven of the Brooklyn Cricket Club of the New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association by 127 to 72 on the grounds of Stevens Institute.

THE Guggenheim School of Aeronautics of New York Univer sity has gone into the Middle West to fill the new chair of air transport which the school recently decided to create. The United States Government has made every possible representation to the warring sides in the Sino-Japanese dispute, asking that Shanghai be not made a base of military operations or a theatre of war, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today.
The Dover Fishing Club of Philadelphia today won its third successive surf casting championship and retained the Ocean City Cup. The

The largest crowd ever to visit isolated Roanoke Island is expected here Wednesday for the celebration of the 350th anniversary of Virgains Dare's birth. President Roosevelt will speak at the celebration.

The election of Jeremiah F. Cross of the Bronx in a three-cornered battle for State commander brought to a close today the convention of the American Legion, Department of New York.

After this country has spent billions of dollars on unemployment relief the Senate has finally decided that it is worth $5,000,000 to have some facts to go on.

SURVIVOR: Captain Max Pruss, commander of the ill-fated Hindenburg on her final flight last Spring, returned to Germany last week. Though still swathed in bandages, the officer was ready to talk about the future of lighter-than-air craft. "Next year," he said, "we will come to America every two weeks with new helium-inflated Zeppelins."

Two present-day youngsters, blond-haired, blue-eyed Richard Regan, 8 years old, and his brownhaired, brown-eyed brother, Robert, 11, no longer dream of the mighty beanstalk famed in the nursery tale of "Jack and the Beanstalk."
Twelve thousand Japanese soldiers were authoritatively reported to be moving hurriedly into this war-shattered section of North China today from Mukden, Manchukuo.
DURING July 217 "bona fide" sales of Manhattan real estate were recorded, involving considerations totaling $10,906,458, according to figures compiled by the Real Estate Board of New York.

The most important event for women on the sporting calendar this week is the Wightman Cup team match between the United States and England at Forest Hills on Friday and Saturday.

The Osservatore Romano, official Vatican newspaper, published today a manifesto by Cardinal Faulhaber, Archbishop of Munich, warning Catholics to beware of a German Government questionnaire.
Cardinal Hayes was reported resting comfortably last night at St. Vincent's Hospital, where he 'was taken Wednesday after a 100-mile ride in an ambulance from his Sum mer home at Monticello, N. Y.

There is no immediate prospect of a change in the status of the United States liner Leviathan, which was retired from service in September, 1934, and since then has remained tied up to a pier in Hoboken, according to officials of the line.

STRONG support has been expressed by the American Auto mobile Association of a bill introduced in the Senate by Senator Harry S. Truman of Missouri and its companion in the House introduced by Representative Wilburn Cartwright of Oklahoma.

With the press of the South almost unanimous in opposition and with nine of twenty-three Southerners in the Senate deserting the Administration to vote against it, the Wages and Hours Bill has divided this region against the President to an even greater extent that the Supreme Court proposal did.

Little interest was taken in the grain markets today and prices fluctuated irregularly. Although wheat showed a relatively firm undertone because of some buying attributed to mills and shorts, its close on the Board of Trade here was within a fraction of the bottom, with net losses of 7/8 to 1 cent a bushel.
