Blizzard, executive director, and Howard Butcher Jr., honorary president of the association, announced yesterday.
The National Bureau of Standards has developed an intentionally clumsy package in which radium can be shipped without danger of injury to handlers.

Miss Gladys Marie Henderson of 415 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, laughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. I. Milton Henderson, was married here yesterday morning in the Church of the Transfiguration to Kenneth Reade, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Reade of Newark, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert J. Murphy.

Distribution of consumers' protection labels by the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board last week were higher than in the corresponding week of any of the years in which they have been sold, F. Nathan Wolf, executive secretary, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON. A NEW aid to searches for aviators lost at sea was recently developed in France, and might have been given its first test in the search for Amelia Earhart, had it been utilized, it was disclosed last week.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 13 unless specified: At New London: Cachelot. R-2. At NOB, Norfolk: Vega: on 14th: Owl. Sharp's Island to Rappannock Spit, Aug. 14: Cuyahoga Potomac.

Thirty-seven years ago today United States forces and troops of European nations and Japan helped to open the door to China by crushing her single great effort to put an end to the existence of foreigners within her borders.

The derisive shouts of 12,500 Athletic rooters dinned in the ears of the Yankees at Shibe Park today as the champions absorbed a second straight set-back at the hands of the Mackmen, 12 to 6. It was the third in the last four games for the New Yorkers.

GREATER value to the consumer is indicated in the new radios designed for the 19371938 season, despite a general upturn in the price level, an analysis of 1,200 receivers recently made by Radio Today discloses.

A judiciary fight marked by charges that the Democrats have shifted the scenes in a "court-packing" drama from Washington to Philadelphia is enlivening the pre-primary manoeuvring for the city-county election.

Campers on the St. Regis chain of lakes have revived the custom of Sunday night hymn "sings," and many are expected for the next in the series, to be held tomorrow night at Camp Underpines, Upper St. Regis camp of Mr. and Mrs. F. Louis Slade.
Dr. F. Walter Carruthers, Littie Rock specialist, said today he had discovered on the shoulder bone of Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe's ailing pitching arm a small growth, which he believed was hampering

Miss Muriel Dorothea Whitney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J. Whitney of Mamaroneck, was married to Rushmore Royall Houghton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert R. Houghton of this place, this afternoon at the Methodist Episcopal Church here. The cere-

In the present Far East crisis one hears of mobilizations and war preparations, but there is little word of what the women are doing or will do if the North China disturbances develop into a prolonged conflict. The Japanese women in
A crowd, estimated at more than 8,500 persons, converged on this community by automobile tonight as the charity fiesta to raise funds for Spanish refugee children got under way.
The Spanish civil war has reached one of those lulls during which it is useful and convenient to take stock, and here in Paris, away from all censorship, it is possible to get a better perspective.

THE newest "crash cover," as they are popularly called, has been received. The envelope is one which was carried by the Pan-American Grace Airways airliner flying from Cali, Colombia, to, Cristobal, C. Z. The

The world's leading authorities on the use of X-rays and radium in treatment of diseases will meet in Chicago next month at the Fifth International Congress of Radiology. Dr. Arthur C. Christie, president of the congress, said today that the group of more than 2,000 would include 500 to 600 specialists from

Miss Jane Elisabeth Conrad, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Carl John Conrad of this city and Fayson Lake, was married here this afternoon to G. Raymond Christensen, son of Mrs. Thomas Christensen of Brooklyn, formerly of Kingston, N. Y., and the late Mr. Christensen, in Our Saviour's Methodist Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father, who was assisted by the Rev. Arne Nielson.

Miss Honor Spingarn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Elias Spingarn of Troutbeck, this place, and New York, was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents to Carl King Tranum by Judge Daniel J. Gleason, .surrogate of Dutchess County.

MYSTIC, Conn. SEVERAL. of the art colonies have tried out this year the Scheme of combining in their exhibitions oils and the lighter media-with, upon the whole, marked. success. The director's show at Woodstock perhaps carried the idea a trifle too far, since it is difficult indeed to mix oils and prints. At Rockport, however, the

MANHATTAN Estate, $5,000. To Maria Imperato, widow, executrix, 185 Bleecker St., residue. KATZENSTEIN. HATTIE (July 16, 1926). Estate, less than $5,000. To Bertha Rothschild, sister. 107 Elliot Pl., Bronx, Fanny Kahn, sister. 76 Thayer St., jewelry, personal effects and one-half residue, each: four minor bequests. Alfred H. Rothschild, nepbev, executor 107 Elliot Pl., Bronx.

Two committees representing certificate holders controlling about $51,000 of mortgage certificates have been formed in the New York Title and Mortgage Company Series N-93 and N-95, to further the plan to have trustees appointed for these issues. Jules Adell is chairman and

Rain, which was countrywide, interrupted the start of the third cricket test match between England and New Zealand today, and when stumps were drawn the New Zealanders had scored 20 runs for no wickets.
A former American newspaper man saw wholesale death and terror in Shanghai today. An American co-ed stood near the bombardment of a Japanese warship.

Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of New York University, announced that $1,000 graduate scholarships in architecture had been awarded to Julian von der Lancken, 7 Charles Street, New York, and William Taparauskas, 14 Watson Street, Paterson, N. J.,

Expulsions of newspaper correspondents by governments seldom create international situations in themselves, but the circumstances surrounding the events of this week, involving British and German actions of this sort, give every indication of widening the breach which statesmen have been exerting their best efforts to close.
Two dissertations, "New GuidePosts for Jewish Music," by Joseph Yasser, and "Some Jewish Contributions to the Art of Music," have been published by the Jewish Academy of Arts and Sciences.

Mrs. John Weimer ventured the opinion today that the world was "not so good as it was fifty years ago," but the champion surviving spinning-wheel operator of the United States was sure that "my granddaughters will not have to spin to get themselves husbands."

Sewell Cup Day at the Seaside Park Y. C., the thirty-seventh annual regatta for the most coveted of Barnegat Bay's yachting trophies, attracted a fine entry today. Races in ten classes were sailed, with eighty-four craft competing.

DEPRESSING news for epicures comes from the United States Bureau of Fisheries. Lobsters are scarce and getting scarcer. The bureau confirms a report from New England that this famous shellfish is even in danger of extermination in our North Atlantic waters, chief source of our native supply.
Definition of Edward J. Flynn by senator Royal S. Copeland: "Mr. Flynn is not a leader-he is a political cowboy, lassoing all the salaries for his own political benefit."

The marriage of Mrs. Jean Wallace Irvine of this city and New Canaan, Conn., widow of Walter Ellis Irvine, to Edgar Seaton Hassard of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Hassard of Newtown, Conn., formerly of New Rochelle, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Marble Collegiate Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. George C. Moor.

The New York offices of the Corning Glass Works, Steuben Glass, and the Macbeth-Evans Glass Company, recently acquired by the Corning concern, will be combined under one roof with the offices of the newly organized Pittsburgh-Corning Corporation upon completion of the Corning glass-constructed building at 718 Fifth Avenue, southwest corner of Fifty-sixth Street. The offices of...

GOVERNORS ISLAND Leave of absence for six days, effective on or about Sept. 1, is granted 2d Lt. Bosworth E. Spofford, Fin.-Res. Leave of absence for twenty-two days, effective on or about Aug. 27, is granted Lt. Dean A. Baldwin, SC-V-(S), U. S. N. R. Upon expiration of this leave Lt. Baldwin is, at his request, relieved from further active duty and will proceed to his home, 60 Elm Rd., Caldwell, N. J.

The marriage of Miss Jean Marshall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Marshal of Lloyd Neck, Huntington, to Charles Titus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles V. Titus of Melville, took place this afternoon in the Old First Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was per-

Real estate financing in Manhattan during July and for the first seven months of this year showed an increase over the same periods of last year. During July, however, institutional lenders placed fewer mortgages, but the aggregate volume was greater than a year ago. Extensions increased, and
The issue of Tide Magazine dated today contains an editorial insert printed on the much discussed slash pine newsprint, now being made experimentally from Southern pine in a Savannah laboratory.

Harry V. Dougherty, Register of Wills, withdrew from the Democratic party, with which he had been aligned for many years, and registered today as a Republican. With this action he assailed the Democratic leaders for their alleged attempt to "pack" the Common Pleas and Orphans Courts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The new court bill is divided into five sections. The first section gives the Government the right to intervene through the Attorney General in a lawsuit between private persons where either the plaintiff or defendant draws in question the constitutionality of an act of Congress.

An Alleghany County jury today found R. E. Benson, picket captain, guilty of assault and battery and fixed his punishment at nine months in jail. The sentence was much lighter than in the cases of three other union rayon workers convicted here in the past several weeks on charges of "assault and battery while members of a mob."

Murray Jackel allowed only one hit to enable the Shirley Silks nine to defeat the Bronx Missions, 13 to 0, yesterday as the first round of the surviving sixteen teams in the New York City Baseball Federation tourney opened. The contest was

A tear-gas attack on delegates to the Zionist Congress caused Zurich police today to take new precautions to protect delegates. The attackers, who escaped police pursuit, scattered members of the congress from a tea room last night by throwing a tear-gas bomb into their midst. No one was hurt.

Featured by an increase of 18,000 ounces in the output of placer gold, mining in the Yukon Territory in 1936 recorded a notable improvement over the previous year, particularly in the dike and Mayo areas, according to a review of the industry published by the Department of Mines and Resources.

THE week's most interesting news was the hint from Hollywood that Mervin Leroy, who has had marked success in the last few months with a production unit of his own at Warners, may become a United Artists producer at the expiration, in a week or two, of his Warner contract.

THE most expensive book ever published by the Derrydale Press will be "Atlantic Salmon Fishing," by Charles Phair. It will be in two volumes illustrated with color plates, etchings, photographs and maps, and the second volume will contain many of the author's actual salmon flies mounted in the book The edition will be

The Reds avenged yesterday's 22-to-6 rout by pounding out three homers, each with a mate on base, and fourteen other hits to beat the Cubs, 10 to 5, before 10,607 today. The setback cut the league leaders' margin over the Giants to five and onehalf games.

Miss Josephine Louise Mahoney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Mahoney of this city and Greenwood Lake, N. Y., will be married to John J. Cassidy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Cassidy of Tuxedo Park, on Sept. 25. The ceremony will take place in Holy Rosary Church, Greenwood Lake, and will

The only likely way the President at this time could put on the Supreme Court an aggressive New Dealer to succeed Justice Van Devanter was to appoint a Senator. Therefore the President did just that, and in choosing Hugo L. Black of Alabama he selected as convinced and aggressive a New Dealer as could have been found.

Jane Horbachewski, 5 years old, died in the Long Beach Hospital early today, the third of the three daughters of Michael Horbachewski of 9 Parma Road, Island Park, who last night shot and killed Nina, 3, and Sonia, 3 months, his other two children, and then killed himself by slashing his throat with a razor.

Hugh J. Gormley, Indiana organizer for the American Federation of Labor, asserted today that the Committee for Industrial Organization was "misrepresenting labor." He accused C. I. O. organizers of telling non-union Indiana workers in various occupations that the A. F. of L. would not give them membership.
Senator Clark, Democrat, of Missouri, told the Senate today that a "steamship lobby" was blocking Senate action on a bill to alter rules for the measurement of vessels using the Panama Canal.

Thomas Spencer Sprague, traffic manager of the Panama Railroad and Steamship Company, with offices in New York City, died last night at Mountainside Hospital following a long illness. Mr. Sprague, who lived at 88 Inwood Avenue, was born in Detroit sixty years ago.

The Duluth, Missabe Iron Range Railway Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to acquire by capital-stock purchase two affiliated railroads operating in Minnesota and Wisconsin.

The New Zealand All-Blacks defeated South Africa, 13-7, in a rugby test match before 50,000 persons today. The New Zealanders won by a try, drop goal and two penalty goals against a try and drop goal.

The Woman's Club of Greenwich has a varied program arranged for the coming season. The president is Mrs. William Burnham Ball of Old Greenwich. A membership drive in the late Summer and early Fall will be one of the features. Mrs. Charlotte F. Richardson is chairman of the committee.

The appointment of Zdenek Fierlinger, head of the Czecho- to slovak Foreign Office's Political Deapartment, as Minister to Moscow, announced today, is considered to indicate that Czechoslovakia intends to maintain if not develop her present agreement with Russia.

The murder of General Bakr Sidky Pasha, chief of the General Staff of the Iraqi Army this week at the Mosul Airdrome has had no effect on the political situation either within Iraq itself or in any other Arab countries.

Most gardeners are interested in iris, but usually they grow only a few varieties. Recently they have learned what a wealth of material, suited to Northern gardens, is comprised within the genus iris. They

Barney Kowaloff, Newark wholesale butter and egg dealer, found the first yolkless egg ever recorded in this section today. Mr. Kowaloff, president of the Colonial Butter and Egg Company at 211 Wright Street, has been candling eggs for thirty-five years.
THE late Senator Penrose belongs definitely in the line of memorable American personages. He was the last -and perhaps the frankest-exponent of plutocratic piracy in the councils of the Republic. He
" BE sure that you know what you want to do. If you are sure of that success will probably take care of itself--so long as you do not want to write poetry."

Although Representative Mary Norton of New Jersey, chairman of the House Labor Committee, is the first woman to win a major chairmanship in the present Congress, her female colleagues also hold responsible posts.
The definite announcement today of the departure tomorrow of Gustavo Ross, former Minister of Finance, for Europe has marked the culmination of a 16ng period of bitter attacks on him from the masses.

Crown Princess Juliana today officiated at the launching of a motor yacht representing the second half of the Netherland peopole's wedding gift to her, the other half having been the modernization and refurnishing of Soestdyk Castle.

Slim lines softened by shirring and draping characterize the majority of Fall dresses in the lines of member firms of the Dress Creators League of America, Inc., according to a survey and analysis of the new designs.

Arrangements for the second annual international Yale alumni gathering to be held Aug. 28 at the Westport Inn and Country Club are under the direction of a committee headed by R. Bruce Ferguson of Keeseville, N. Y., a member of the class of 1923 at Yale.

IN the late Summer of each year travelers from other States swell New York State's resident population of some fifteen million. As outsiders come more and more to recognize the vacation possibilities of its 49,204 square miles, the State itself becomes increasingly aware of the variety of its attractions. It is said that William

Calumet trotter owned by William Parkhurst of Maplewood and driven by Peter Van Cleef, won the feature event of the weekly matinee sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

William Phillips Hall, president of the American Tract Society, revivalist, inventor and retired. president of the Hall Signal Company, died here today at the Masonic Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at Rowayton, Conn.
Leading members of the Paris International Society attended the funeral today of Edith Wharton at Gonards Cemetery at Versailles. Dean Beekman of the American Cathedral read prayers.

BENNINGTON, Vt. THOUGH as these lines are written the principal events of the fourth annual Bennington Festival have not taken place, dance activity of more than passing moment has not been lacking hereabout. The presentation, yet to come, of a large new work

ABELOFF--Dr. and Mrs. George (rec Jullette Brown), announce the birth of a daughter, Aug. 13. ALPERT--Mr. and Mrs. Harold Alpert announce birth of a son Friday, Aug. 13, at the Woman's Hospital. BAIIES--A son to Mr. and Mrs. Irving Bailes on Aug. 10, 1937, at Park East Hospital.
Many members of the Ausable Club have timed their arrival for the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the Adirondack Mountain Reserve, of which the Club is the social center.

Marked demand for better merchandise characterizes consumer response to August cloth coat and suit offerings. As reports continue to come into the market, it is apparent that in the majority of cases any gains in volume made by stores will be due not to an increase in the number of units sold but to the greater acceptance of higher-priced garments.

" There's wit in these Vermont hills," says Robert Davis, exchange professor at Middlebury College, who for years has been collecting world-wide specimens of humorSlavic, Gallic, Latin and AngloSaxon.

Home development methods have undergone great changes during the last ten or fifteen years, points out Theodore M. Lay, vice president of the Whitson Improvement Corporation, builders of the Montfort Hills home community at Port Washington, N. Y. These changes, he de-

A fleet of eighteen international Star yachts competed today in the final of a series of five races for the Commodore George Corry Cup, emblematic of the Star championship of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association.

Pensioned On his own application: Lieutenant-John L. Travers, Motorcycle Precinct 1. at $2,000 per annum. Appointed March 4, 1902. Temporary Assignments For 16 days, from 8 A. M., Aug. 16: LIEUTENANTS-From commands indlcated to Police Academy:

Horse Racing-The Shandon Farm's Burning Star, 6-5 favorite, won the historic Travers before 25,000 at Saratoga yesterday. The victory was worth $14,550. The Wheatley Stable's Merry Lassie, 9-5 shot, captured the Spinaway.

THIS is, in point of size, much the most impressive novel Sylvia Thompson has yet given us-and that is to say, not in length alone but in number of characters and intricacy of structure. It covers the years from the end of the war to the present, and gives us a varied and rather cosmopolitan picture of the events of those years, as they
The American Battle Monuments Commission will wind up its tour of honor for 30,000 American World War dead tomorrow with services at Brookwood, their only memorial in Great Britain.

The American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on June 30 a consolidated net income of $12,883,501, after interest Depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges.

Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr., telegraphed an. appeal tb Mme. Chiang Kai-shek yesterday following the air bombardments of Shanghai, pleading that further bombing of these areas be stopped pending the completion of arrangements for the safety of foreigners.

Miss Margaret R. Landers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Landers of this place, was married today to Dr. Emil J. De Cesare, also of Roselle Park, at St. Joseph's Catholic Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward G. Murphy. the rector.

A granite block, ten feet tall, soon will supplant a small stone which marks the grave of Samuel L. Clemens. The monument also will honor Clemens's son-in-law, the late Ossip Gabrilowitsch, pianist, symphony conductor and composer.

CHAZEN--BERNSTEIN -- Mr. and Mrs. Harry Bernstein, 309 West 104th St., announce marriage of their daughter, Julie, to Jerry Chazen of New York, Brazil. GREENBERG--EPSTEIN--Mr. and Mrs. Louis Epstein, 395 Riverside Drive, announce marriage of their daughter, Ruth, to Mr. Albert Greenberg, son of Mrs.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Aug. 11, aggregated $7,489,000,000, or 16 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and slightly below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

An election will be held tomorrow among artists employed by the Fleischer Studios, Inc., to determine whether or not the Commercial Artists and Designers Union will represent them as collective bargaining agent.

To one who viewed the Congressional situation here this week and looked at it in the light of events of the last seven months, the thought that anything might happen in American politics could hardly be suppressed.

The work of the New York City Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association will be benefited by the seventh annual meeting of the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association on Labor Day on the grounds of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club here. There will be six races, featured by the test for the Connecticut Cup.

A letter-writing contest through which it is intended to acquaint residents of the metropolitan area with the advantages of living in Freeport, L. I., is under way. It is sponsored by the Freeport Chamber of Commerce and will close Sept. 15.

Science is showing nature how to ripen fruits in half the usual time by putting back into fruit the gas it gives off in natural ripening. Dr. R. B. Harvey, plant physiologist, who directed development of the ethylene gas process, said today that even the new ripening speed may be cut in half.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Kathleen Faughnan of the Hotel St. Andrew, New York, daughter of John Faughnan of this place and the late Mrs. Esther Rowley Faughnan,. to Cadet Jacob Rippert of the United States Military Academy at West

NOTHING will be gained by pretending that Toscanini's new "Magic Flute" is 100 per cent. It is not. It has some exceptional qualities and in many respects it gives a new slant on Mozart's opera and places it in an unaccustomed perspective. But taken by and large it is disappointing, and the audience which sat through the greater part of the first performance in stony silence was manifestly chilled by something

Japan's new offensive in the Peiping region is her answer to the question upon which the future of Asia apparently hinges: Who is to use the abundant raw materials of the Chinese provinces which lie west of Peiping? Both China and Japan greatly desire these materials.

Consolidation of Universal Service and International NeWQs Service, both owned by William Randolph Hearst, was announced yesterday through King Features Syndicate. Universal Service has been operated as a news feature service for mornIng newspapers and International News Service as a news service for evening papers.

Mrs. Barbara Bergotz, 42 years old, of Frankfort Avenue, Egg Harbor City, was killed tonight and three persons were seriously injured in an automobile collision on Farm Road here. Police said Mrs. Bergotz was in a car driven by her father, Charles Schwartz, 65, of the same address,

To the Radio Editor: Many people have advanced theories about the numerous uses of radio. It seems pretty well agreed that it serves as an excellent entertainment medium. However, my attention has been focused upon a new endeavor undertaken by radio broadcastersnamely, the Radio Re-employment Forum conducted during- the week on one of the metropolitan stations.

Willoughby G. Walling, president of the Personal Loan and Savings Bank, was appointed today trustee for the $400,000,000 Utilities Power and Light Corporation by Judge William H. Holly in the Federal District Court here.

Miss to Louise E. Rebmann, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Victor L. F. Rebmann of Yonkers, was married at the home of her parents here this afternoon to Edward J. Quirk Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Quirk of Yonkers. A reception followed the ceremony.

This community has a "future farmer" candidate it believes may some day rival in prowess the mythical Paul Bunyan of lumberjack legend. He is Dean Rose, who at the age of only three years milks the cows, drives a span of mules and corrals a stubborn calf with the skill and aplomb of an old-time cowboy.

Turning in the fastest mile ever run in New England, A. C. Compton's Clingendaal today won the $5,000 added Constitution Handicap in 1:36 by a length and a half from Mrs. Emil Denemark's War Minstrel. The previous record of 1: 37 2-5 was made by Stand Pat, under a 120-pound burden, in 1935, and equaled by Clingendaal July 31.

The large cotton crop indicated by the Government estimate of 15,593,000 bales issued last Monday will in the long run be beneficial to cotton mills, the distributive system and the country as a whole, according to trade opinion widely expressed by selling agents and others in Worth Street yesterday.

R. L. McKallip, president of the Pittsburgh Real Estate Board, has appointed chairmen of a number of committees including hotels, sports, entertainment and registration to take care of the needs and various activities of the delegates who will attend the annual convention in that city of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, Oct. 19 to 23.

The Westchester County Clearing r House Association reported yesterday that clearings for the week ended on Friday aggregated $3,002,913, compared with $3,086,560 in the preceding week. In the corresponding week of last year clearings amounted to $2,463,838.

The roar of heavy guns shook Chicago's front yard tonight. Air raiders swooped down on the Lake Front sector in a mass attack. Powerful searchlights limned the fleeting planes against the night sky. Anti-aircraft artillery let go a "deadly" fire.

Mrs. Mary Jean Dolbier, wife of Frank W. Dolbier of 177 Monmouth Road, prominent in several women's organizations and a member of the Ocean Township Board of Education, died this morning in Monmouth Memorial Hospital, Long Branch, where she underwent an operation on July 26. Her age was 54.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--Swimming, boating and fishing are holding the spotlight in Atlantic City during the next few weeks. Outstanding among the boating events is the national moth boat championship regatta, which closes on the Back Bay here today with forty skippers from all sections of the country competing for the Antonia Trophy, emblematic of the world's title.
RIO DE JANEIRO.--Brazil, largest coffee producer in the world, has for years been burning surplus coffee to keep it off the market and so avoid depressing prices.

Miss Margaret W. O'Connor, retired New York State Public Health Nurse Supervisor, who served as a nurse with the American Expeditionary Forces in France during the World War, died here today at the Benedictine Hospital after a brief illness.

DRESSING shop windows has become an important American enterprise. Lectures, schools, even books are now devoted to the art of baiting the public eye. The rank outsider might prefer calling the window dresser a craftsman rather than an artist and it is conceivable that he himself, in frank moments, would choose the more work-a-day title.

Miss Lillian Marie Oelschlager, daughter of William F. Oelschlager of Ridgewood, N. J., and the late Mrs. Oelschlager, was married to of Lieutenant Charles Andrews Sprague, U. S. A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Sprague of this city, in the United Congregational Church today. The ceremony was

" ALL gone!" shouts. Captain Tom Greene. A gangplank clatters and the last of the Ohio River packets, the Gordon C. Greene, backs away from the Cincinnati wharf, swings slowly in a wide arc and is off on a 1,500-mile round trip to Muscle Shoals, Ala. The cruise follows the

The men interested in fly-casting just for the sake of throwing a fly have no more need of water than Switzerland has of a navy. As a matter of fact, some of the best fly-casters in the country have never caught a sunfish, let alone a trout.

Disregarding Friday the 13th superstitions, Captain T. F. Smellie last night pointed his ship, the R. M. S. Nascopie, out into Hudson Bay, amid salutes from other vessels in this northland port, to begin an extended cruise of the Arctic archipelago, scheduled to last until the end of September.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Fitzpatrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Fitzpatrick of this city, to John Hodgins of New York took place this morning in Our Lady of All Souls Church here. The Rev. Maurice Leo McManus, assistant rector, performed the ceremony and was celebrant of the nuptial mass which followed.

A world record of more than forty years' standing was broken at Good Time Park on the final program today when Thomas Walsh drove a three-horse hitch of trotters, Calumet Dubuque, Mac Aubrey and Hollyrood Doris, owned by Mrs. Florence Dibble of Newbury, Mass., a mile in 2:10 1/4. The
There must be some good and compelling reason why Chart No. 578 is the best seller at the New York Field Station, in Room 741 Custom House of the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey.

The Federal Reserve Board, created nearly a quarter of a century ago to bring the banks of the nation together into reciprocally beneficial harmony, got itself together this week and for the first time in its history occupied a building all its own.

Wilson Flohr, 18-year-old New Jersey junior champion who has been cutting quite a swath in metropolitan golf circles this season, added the Green Meadow invitation honors to his list today when he defeated Arthur F. Lynch, veteran Winged Foot amateur, 3 and 2, in the eighteen-hole final.

Tonight there is a boat in the barFor ready to depart "for Europe." Nearly the whole of this northern capital, Reykjavik, appears to be on foot, and the tempo of the city streets quickens as young and old swing down toward the waterside to see friends embark for Bergen, Copenhagen, Leith or Hull, the first ports of call.
Mrs. Robert E. Christie Jr. of Scarsdale gave a party tonight at the Maplewood Club, at which guests included Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Muenzen, Mr. and Mrs. J. William Dodge, Mr. and Mrs. Howard,

Judge Frederick H. Bryant of the Federal District Court today denied a plea of the Salt City Greyhound Association for a temporary injunction to restrain Onondaga County and State authorities from interfering with dog racing at its track at North Syracuse.

W. G. Phillips, Queens builder, has purchased sixty lots on the east and west sides of Eighty-fifth Avenue, Eighty-fifth Road and Eightysixth Avenue, 100 feet west of 244th Street, Bellerose Grove, L. I., according to an announcement yesterday by the Halleran Agency, broker in the transaction. Each

TO come upon this "Life of John Keats" by his friend Charles Armitage Brown, now, after the lapse of 100 years. published for the first time, is to catch something of the wonder and exaltation and delight of Browning's imaginary character encountering one who had seen and talked with Shelley. Brown and the poet met during the Summer of 1817 when Keats and his two brothers, George and Tom, were living in Well Walk.

Dedication exercises for the "theme center" of the New York World's Fair-the 600-foot plaza in which-the $1,700,000 perisphere and trylon will be erected-will be held at 2:30 o'clock tomorrow afternoon.

Andrew Keogh, librarian at Yale University and Sterling Professor of Bibliography, received the degree of Doctor of Letters at the commencement of Middlebury College Bread Loaf School of English last night.

An extensive aerial search for thieves who took $34,000 in furs from the Fort Nelson (B. C.) Hudson's Bay Company post two years ago was ordered today following discovery Wednesday of nineteen bales of stolen furs cached three miles down-river from the fort, according to information received at United Air Transport offices here.

Clair Gibson, who had confessed looting twenty-two banks of $87,000, jumped three floors to his death in the Ramsey County jail today. He dashed from his second-floor cell when the jailer opened it to permit him to talk with his attorney, ran to the third floor and, finding his way barred, leaped over the railing to the areaway.

Dean Milton E. Loomis of New York University's Washington Square College, Washington Square East, announced yesterday that 205 students had been commended for high scholarship in the second term of the 1936-37 academic year.
THIS is a book of singular interest, made from material largely drawn from an English family's household accounts. And in case such sources

Leon M. Estabrook, prominent retired Agriculture Department scientist, died today after a long illness. His age was 68. Mr. Estabrook was last employed at the department as a conservation specialist of the Agriculture Adjustment Administration until October, 1934.

BAUDETTN, Minn. BAUDETTE, International Falls and Ely, starting points for canoeists who wish to traverse Minnesota's Rainy River and Arrowhead country, are crowded with canoe parties checking their equipment and guides waiting to be hired.

The major mutual fire insurance companies of the United States have reported continued gains in volume of premium income for the second quarter of 1937, according to a survey made by the American Mutual Alliance and announced yesterday.

Miss Mary Frances Hill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bayard Hill of New Rochelle, was married here this afternoon to Dr. John William Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Smith of Little Rock, Ark., in the North Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Robert Gardner McGregor, pastor, performed the ceremony. A reception at the Hill residence followed.

AROUND the delicatessen shops of New York a verbal storm has raged for the last few weeks. Reverberations of the conflict have been heard in many homes--and apartments--of the metropolis. The storm was brewed when the grocers, who dutifully observe the Sabbath by closing their stores, complained that the delicatessen dealers were taking their trade. The grocers did not object

While representatives of the union and of 100 independent cafeterias in the Affiliated Restaurateurs Association, Inc., negotiated yesterday on the union's demands for higher pay and improved working conditions, striking employes of the Horn Hardart Automat chain looked to the American Federation of Labor to mobilize cafeteria workers in other cities to support the New York Automat strike.

Mrs. Lenore King of St. Clair, Mo., a mother held on charges of poisoning her 6-year-old son, listened calmly today, her eyes downcast, as a young shoe worker told a coroner's jury that she had threatened to kill herself and two children when he informed her that a love affair must stop.
Mr. and Mrs. E. Francis Bowditch of Boston are at the St. Regis. Thayer P. Draper has arrived at the Commodore from the Homestead, his home in Hastings-on-Hudson.

ONE of the most difficult situations in contract bridge arises when the declarer shows his hand and claims all or a part of the remaining tricks. No entirely satisfactory rule covering such a case has ever been formulated.

The Newark Bears shaded the Toronto Maple Leafs in both ends of a double-header today, winning the first game 6-3 and the second 4-2, to give the league leaders a 14-8 edge on the season against the Leafs.

China, whose naval strength is trifling, has been building for the past five years a fleet of aircraft that is modern and efficient, and includes pursuit, bombing and other types of planes. While estimates of the number of planes available in an emergency vary, the figure is somewhere above 400 and below 1,000.

A spectacular riverfront fire, the third in three months, destroyed toda, half of the Pennsylvania Railroad's freight pier on the Delaware River at the foot of Walnut Street, a few blocks from the downtown business district.

Risking his neck in the always dangerous sport of speed-boat racing, a 57-year-old, white-haired grandfather stole the show from the reckless youngsters in the annual National Sweepstakes regatta today.

WIDE interest is reported in the Silvermine Symphonic Festival to be held this Friday night at 8:30 o'clock at Norwalk, Conn., under the auspices of the Silvermine Guild of Artists. The festival will consist of a concert by seventy-five members of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Jose Iturbi,which will be given in the wooded dell on the Guild grounds.

Real estate in New York City is afflicted with many troubles which might be avoided if the various State and city departments which have certain dealings with the regulation of real estate, chiefly buildings, were coordinated into one controlling board, declares Robert T. Lyons, assistant vice president of the Mortgage Commission Servicing Corporation.

One day early this week an unknown brewer making out his excise tax check for the Federal Internal Revenue Collector of his district paid into the United States Treasury beer's billionth tax dollar since the end of bone-dry prohibition.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 13: COLONEL Bowen, W. S., C.A.C., Second C.A.C. Dist., New York, about Oct, 1, to duty as President, Coast Artillery Board, Ft. Monroe, Va. LIEUTENANT COLONELS McKie, A. B., Med. Corps, detailed a member Central Medical Dept. Board, vice Maj. D. H. Mebane, hereby relieved.

To reveal to members of adult English classes their faulty accents, Schenectady evening schools are town a making use of the telephone. Pupils talk to each other from different class rooms or even from different schools. This avoids all possibility of lip reading and makes gestures useless. Pupils must make themselves understood solely by their voices, not by loudness but by clear speaking. It is usually arranged
THIS arresting novel is a strange book to come out of contemporary France--a strange book, indeed. to appear anywhere in the

Americans and other foreigners began evacuating portions of the International Settlement today as fighting between Japanese and Chinese increased in intensity and the American emergency committee met to consider further measures of safety.
LONDON. IN his Saturday article in The Manchester Guardian Ivor Brown makes a slashing at tack on a growing tendency in the literary world. He recalls

The War Department announced today that these residents of New York State have accepted appointment as first lieutenants in the Reserve Corps: Aurelius J. Bambara, Brooklyn, Medical. Abraham S. Bonenson, Jamaica, Medical. Meyer S. Blick, New York City, Medical. Basil Blumenthal, Brooklyn, Medical.

THE word Zeppelin must produce many emotions in those who see it. Although the kindly and stubborn old Count who gave his name to rigid dirigibles intended them for peaceful activities, they aroused an impotent horror by the early bombings of England during the war. And despite some remark-

Marvin Hecht and Sam Feuer, Trinity Club, conquered Sidney Stein and Leonard Pervil, TriBeach A. C., 17-21, 21-9, 21-10, as competition in the annual national A. A. U. senior one-wall handball doubles championship began on the Manhattan Beach courts yesterday.

Juno II, owned by G. Dvorak, captured the Star Class event yesterday in the Eastchester Bay Yacht Racing Association event off City Island. In second place was No. 51 owned by H. B. Aiken. Prelude, the property of R. Smith, was third. The course was six miles.

Feathery breezes that were as variable as they were weak left the greater part of the Long Island Sound fleet becalmed today, with the result that only twelve of ninety starters were able to straggle across the finish line in the regatta staged by the Huguenot Yacht Club.

With the general outlook for the remaining months of the year definitely described as optimistic by business and financial leaders, both groups are turning to an appraisal of the effects of the Robinson-Patman Act on business generally and speculating as to the ultimate disposition of this law by the courts.

TELEVISION, although not on the calendar for discussion at the recent meeting of the International Radio Consulting Committee at Bucharest, Rumania, nevertheless, was a "live topic of conversation in the corridors" among the delegates of many nations, according to Dr. C. B. Jolliffe, engineer, of the Radio Corporation of America, who attended the meeting.

Premier Joseph A. Lyons presiding at a conference on national insurance yesterday presented proposals by Sir Walter Kinnear, Controller of Insurance In the British Ministry of Health, for health, pensions and insurance covering 1,800,000 persons between the ages of 16 and 65 receiving less than [pound]7 weekly.
Bond financing through the private sale of corporate issues directly to life insurance companies without the usual underwriting procedure is, in the opinion of certain investment bankers,

New Jersey State Fair at Trenton, Sept. 25 to Oct. 2, will celebrate its golden jubilee. Aside from presenting the newest developments in material matters, progress in inventions and agricultural technique and production, the fair will pay exceptional attention to estheticsto decoration, entertainment and floriculture. Prizes will be awarded
Two men charged with being the principal civilian leaders in the military uprising of February, 1936, were sentenced to death today.
The laboratories of the Hackensack Water Company will be completely remodeled within the next few weeks. Operations are now under way at the company's purification works in New Milford, N. J.

Purchases of houses in Brooklyn by investors featured realty deals reported yesterday. The four-story apartment house for twenty-three families at 2,239 Eighty-fifth Street was bought by the Hensuel Realty Company, represented by Henry Scheibel, attorney. The South Brooklyn Savings Bank made a mortgage loan of $35,000 on the property.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers Union of America, said today that the executive board of the union had transferred George Edwards, a Detroit organizer, from the headquarters of the West Side Local in Detroit to the Ford Organization Committee.

Miss Elizabeth Alucia Nichols, daughter of Mrs. William E. Nichols of White Plains, and the late Mr. Nichols, was married to Guernsey Read Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Read Jewett of White Plains, today in the Hitchcock Memorial Church here. The Rev.
Captain Ray Spear, U. S. N., and Mrs. Spear of Washington and Towanda, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Mowry Spear, to Lieutenant Roderick S. Rooney, U. S. N., son of

From a subterranean kiva of this ancient village there came tonight the low chants of Hopi priests singing' to their little brothers, the rattlesnakes, with which they will dance this week in thanksgiving for rain and bouritiful crops.

With sporadic increases in prices in evidence since 1935, the automobile industry this month has initiated new price schedules representing the first definite general upturn in years. The brief markups of a few producers in 1934 should be excepted because of the failure of the movement to become general.

The marriage Wednesday at Old Greenwich, Conn., of Miss Enid Constance Straw, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Zatae L. Straw of Manchester, to Dean Chamberlain, Dartmouth College professor, has been announced by the bride's mother. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Alden Mosshammer in the First Congregational Church.

John Miller, 48-year-old advertising solicitor of 52 Woodward Street, Roslyn, L. I., was booked last night at Queens police headquarters in Jamaica on a charge of extortion. Miller, the police alleged, was the "brains" of a ring that was victimizing Queens merchants.
Southern educational institutions, whose athletic programs are sponsored no little by football receipts, will spend nearly a million dollars this Fall providing new stadia and improving the old.

Increases in both imports from and exports to all grand divisions of the earth during June, compared with w the corresponding month in 1936, were reported today by the Department of Commerce. The exports amounted to $265,363,000, against $185,693,000 a year ago, an increase of $79,670,000. The imports were valued at $285,946,000, against $191,077,000, a gain of $94,869,000.

MID-AGUST marks the tusning point that lifts broadcasting out of the Summer doldrums. While many of radio's stellar performers were away from the microphone during the. warm weather, the feeling no longer prevails among sponsors that it is necessary to sign off for the Summer, and substitute artists. are now engaged to fill their berths during vacation days.
Sales of oil burner equipment this year will gain at least 25 per cent, compared with 1936, according to predictions made yesterday by G. Harvey Porter, managing director of the Oil Burner Institute.
Fourteen-year-old Diane Smith of the Newark Women's Athletic Club retained her title today in the 300meter independent women's medley race at the National A. A. U. junior

President Franklin W. Johnson of Colby College will set off a charge of dynamite next Wednesday afternoon when ground will be broken for the Lorimer Memorial Chapel on Colby's new Mayflower Hill campus. Bainbridge Colby of New York, former Secretary of State.

Many persons of prominence, including Barzilla W. Clark, the Governor of Idaho, and Mrs. Clark, are here to attend the Sun Valley rodeo which began today. Mr. and Mrs. W. Averell Harriman of New York, with their daughters, the Misses Mary and Kathleen Harriman, arrived recentlv and will remain through August.
Debutantes who will be feted during September include Miss Amy Rothe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Otto Rothe of Devon, who will be formally introduced by her parents at a dance on Sept. 10. That same
Lieut. Col. Cyril McNeile, who under the pen name of "Sapper" created Bulldog Drummond, one of the most popular heroes of post-war fiction, died today in Pulborough, Sussex, at the age of 48.

John H. Kocher, former Mayor of this village, died yesterday at his home here of a heart attack. His age was 59. A native of New York City, Mr. Kocher moved to Suffern twentyeight years ago. He served as village trustee from 1917 to 1919 and later from 1923 to 1925.

A museum room has been set apart for the display of Indian relics, including arrow heads, pieces of pottery and other articles in the model home to be formally opened today in the Longhill Country Club Estates, a new home community at Chatham. N. J. The Indian relics

Sir Walter Monckton, who, as Attorney General to the Duchy of Cornwall, was the Duke of Windsor's adviser during the abdication crisis, has resigned his office as Recorder of Hythe-the chief judicial officer of a borough or city with a ranking as judge.

With the resumption last week of substantial engagements of gold for shipment here, after a period of about a month in which the gold movement from Europe had dried up, there was renewed discussion in Wall Street and Washington of measures to arrest the flow of "hot money" to this country.

MEXICO CITY. FEET stumbling down the centuries, tired feet uncovered by shoes or stockings, set the rhythm of Mexico's now peaceful social revolution. They are the feet of Mexican Indians and mestizos, who for 400 years were the slaves of Spaniards, the bondsmen of Mexican landowners, or the oppressed servants of others.

Miss Jacqueline Galway of Rochester won the champion's cup in the Good Hands event at the Lake Placid horse show today. In addition, her Highland Fling took the blue ribbon in the touch-and-out event and placed, second in the open jumper class.

John R. O'Hanlon, assistant attorney general of New York, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that an investigation by his office indicated that Donald P. Kenyon had "siphoned" $850,000 out of a group of small investment trusts which he controlled in most of 1936.

The 105-year-old Cold Brook Hotel was destroyed early this morning by fire of undetermined origin which razed two near-by barns, damaged several other buildings and at one time threatened to sweep the entire business section of the village.

Because thirteen of their fellow-workers were tired of eating lunch "with a lever in one hand and a sandwich in the other," 125 employes of the Barber Company, Inc., roofing manufacturers, were on strike today. R. T. Boaz,
Anappeal for aid of Federal agents in solving what Prosecutor Dudley M. Outcalt termed "one of the biggest mass murders in the country" went to Washington tonight.

John W. Heller Jr. of York, Pa., was nom- n inated as Grand Worthy President of the National Aerie at the thirtyninth convention of the Fraternal Order of Eagles today. Mr. Heller, a member of the organization for n thirty-five years, now is Grand o Worthy Vice President.

The Commonwealth Edison Company filed today with the Secretary of State in Springield an amendment to its charter changing the par value of its stock from $100 to $25. Trading in the $25-par shares will start on Monday on the Chicago Stock and New York Curb Exchanges.
The subject of whales is obviously a large one for this column. But the International Conference on Whaling,

EDWARD GIBBON was born just 200 years ago. We are not likely to think he was born any later: had he been. he must certainly have led not quite the same life, have developed not quite the same personality, have written in not quite the same style.

The United Mine Workers of America, headed by John L. Lewis, and the foundation on which he built Ca the Committee for Industrial Organization, had a balance of $3,563,772 in its treasury on June 1. An auditor's report published today showed a gain of $808,790 over the balance last Dec. 1.
SAN SALVADOR.-By deciding to tender its resignation to the League of Nations, El Salvador has given another demonstration of the increasing tendency of dictators about the world to stand together.
Two infantile paralysis deaths here prompted a health officer to issue a warning to night to the public to avoid crowds.

IN the streets of Jerusalem and Haifa feeling is tense. A British Royal Commission has recommended "a sur gical operation" on Palestine, the creation of a Jewish State, an Arab State and a new British mandate over Jerusalem with a corridor to the sea. The re-

Beyond the personal and political questions raised by President Roosevelt's nomination of Senator Hugo L. Black to be an associate justice of the Supreme Court lies a constitutional question of eligibility.

THE lure of an Indian legend and the spectacle of one of nature's odd geological caprices-saltwater springs in the midst of the Middle Western prairies-are causing many west-bound motorists to detour a few hundred feet from Highway No. 24 as they drive through central Kansas this Summer.

All further, doubts as- to whether Hank Leiber, the Giants' bronzed and dashing Adonis of Arizona, has fully recovered from the whack he received on the head from one of Bob Feller's pitches last April were dispelled at the Polo Grounds yesterday when he whacked a baseball so hard he flattened it on two sides in practically world record time.

The International One-Design Class Sloop Frolic remained a model of consistency today in making it three straight for the squadron runs of the American Yacht Club cruise, while among the big universal rule yachts the Q boat Hornet came through for the first time. A. W. Page's Rampage II, a 32footer, won in the cruising club rule section and Gilbert Warner's gaff-rigged sloop Wasaka again saved her time from the Sound schooner Lark.

Co-operating with the new observatory established on the island of Tahiti, with which it will maintain daily radio contact, the El Salto meteorological station, situated on the summit of Mount San Cristobal on the outskirts of Santiago, will endeavor to establish for the first time a regular weather forecast covering the whole Southern Pacific, it is announced.

Plans for the speedy development of North Beach Airport in Queens as a first-rate terminus for land land sea planes were announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, who said the project would involve a cost of $12,762,500 for initial work, to be spread over a period of almost two years.

Another notable episode in the brilliant career of the stately borzoi Champion Vigow of Romanoff, climaxed the thirty-third annual Rhode Island Kennel Club all-breed exhibition today on the spacious Glen Farm estate of Mrs. Moses Taylor.

The "plain people" of the "hex" country are making a last stand today against the devil. With bearded chins set like granite rocks and broad black hats planted firmly on their heads, they have gone to law to save their children from the sin of pride and the worldliness of the public school.

Senate consideration of the nomination of Senator Black to the Supreme Court was set tonight by the Administration leadership for Tuesday, with the prediction that confirmation would be' made speedily with from seven to twenty dissenting votes cast.

Gardeners interested in the curious find pitcher-plants weirdly entertaining. The plants live on insects. To enable them to follow this regimen their leaf stems are modified into hollow pitchers containing a liquid in which are drowned any insects that may be so unfortunate as to enter the trap. The materials

Miss Marguerite Estelle Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Thompson of this place, was married this morning to Robert Stanley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Stanley, also of this place, at the Methodist Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Richard Hegarty officiated.
Enrico Fioretti, a 50-year-old Italian laborer, and his wife Chiana, also 50, were cooking tomato ketchup over an open fire this afternoon in their back yard at 122 Liberty Street.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Spencer Chain Stores, Inc., has been called for Aug. 23 to approve the issuance of 60,000 shares of new $20-par convertible preferred stock and 120,000 new common shares to be available for conversion of the preferred shares.

Urged by the State Mediation Board to end the "economic waste" attendant on the two-month-old strike of shipyard workers in a score of plants here, the strikers, affiliated with the C. I. O., offered yesterday to go back to work under two conditions.

Miss egina Celia McCarthy, daughter Mr. and Mrs. Albert G. McCarthy this place and the Bronx, was carried today to James Francis Donnelly of Elmhurst in St. Gariel's Church here. The Rev. John yan officiated.
The Real Estate Association of the State of New York will hold its annual convention in Niagara Falls from Sept. 30 to Oct. 2, Ray Hofford, executive vice president, announced yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Nathalie Miner Wolff, daughter of Mrs. Henry Felix Wolff of New York and the late Mr. Wolff, to John Lee Marsh, son of Arthur M. Marsh of Southport, Conn., and the late Mrs. Marsh, took place here this afternoon in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church. The ceremony was

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Cornelia Macy Walker, daughter of Mrs. L, Swan Walker of this place, and Brooklyn, and I. Henry Walker of Putney, Vt., to John Galt Piper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence B. Piper of Pasadena, Calif.

The picture in today's Rotogravure section of THE TIMES tells better than words how happily at home, with the real world and with one another, are these sturdy, smiling girls from places as far apart as China and Iceland, Greece and Brazil.

LONDON. AT this time of the year musicians' fancy turns to thoughts of open-air performances, even though in England the air is frequently not only open but also moist. And often these performances by able amateurs and pro. fessionals whose reputation has still to be made have uncommon interest. Unquestionably interesting was the recent revival at Alessandro Scarlatti's

Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum granted yesterday an order permitting a bondholders' protective committee of Central Manhattan Properties, Ino., to obtain an audit of the books of various D. A. Schulte interests.

PORTLAND. BUSY construction gangs pushing through the forests of Oregon's Coast Range, lying between Portland and the Pacific Ocean, are opening two important new cut-off highways in the West Coast road system. Portland, reach-

Mrs. Henry D. Holmes of this capital city of Vermont receives "fanmail" from all over the United States and is rapidly gaining the reputation of being Vermont's most widely known woman, although she is not listed in "Who's Who" and is a most unpretentious person.

A message tossed from a speeding automobile near here which urged the finder to "call police-they have kidnapped me and I can't get away" sent State and Cumberland County police off on a possible kidnap search today.

THE slightly stuffy atmosphere of British Colonial officialdom which threatens to permeate this novel is quickly dispelled with the arrival on the scene of the head of the local C. I. D., a Canadian named Vachell. a breezy individual who has very little respect for sacred cows of either sex.

AIRMEN will watch with much interest for the official Bureau of Air Commerce finding of the cause of the airplane crash at Daytona Beach, Fla., last week. Preliminary reports stated a power line was strung up during the night at the end of a runway unknown to airport or airline officials. Taking

The Meadow Brook Pelicans defeated a Narragansett four today, 6-5, at the Narragansett Polo Club. F. S. (Skiddy) von Stade Jr., No. 3 for the Pelicans, starred, scoring three goals and turning many Narragansett attacks.

The following Foreign Service changes since Aug. 7 were announced today by the State Department: Francls C. Jordan of North Carolina, vice consul, Colon, assigned to Buenos Aires as vice consul. North Winship, Macon, Ga., counselor of legation, Copenhagen, designated counselor of embassy, Warsaw.

The latest of the large East Side apartment buildings to undergo complete rehabilitation is the twelve-story house at 320-30 Park Avenue, occupying the blockfront between Fiftieth and Fifty-first Streets, opposite St. Bartholomew's Church.
All five of the Class J sloops in these waters will participate in the special race for the City of Newport Cup on Aug. 25.

Professor William Adams Brown of the Presbyterian Church of the United States made strenuous efforts today to save the proposal for a world council of churches that the present World Conference on Faith and Order, under the presidency of the Archbishop of York, had approved earlier in the week.
The fates that changed King Edward VIII from monarch to private citizen played a strange trick, too, on the $350,000 railway car in which he toured the United States as Prince of Wales in 1924.

TAMMANY HALL is waging a life and-death struggle. Disorganized and racked by internal strife and shaken' by the recent loss of its leader, James J. Dooling, it has put its fate in the hands of Christopher D. Sullivan. This new leader faces the task of restoring harmony to the organization and strengthening a weakened Tiger at a time when it is engaged in the hard fight for the Mavoralty.

DESIGNED for safe and comfortable transportation of invalids, convalescents or persons suddenly stricken ill while at work, on the street or away from home, a fleet of seven-passenger Plymouth cars, converted to serve as ambulance and taxicab, was recently put into service in Philadelphia by the Yellow Cab Company.

NOT all visitors to the West Coast make the trip solely to see a motion-picture star and go bathing in the Pacific Ocean. A large percentage of them are scientifically and historically minded. If a thirst for knowledge is a sign of intellect, the Summer visitors to California, while a cut financially under the average run of Winter tourists, rank a shade higher in mentality.

Holding the attention of the Narragansett Summer colony this weekend is a special tennis match at the Point Judith Country Club between the Oxford-Cambridge and North Carolina-Princeton teams. At the Narragansett Polo Club tomorrow afternoon the Santa Barbara polo team, national junior championship titleholders, will meet the Meadow Brook Pelicans for the final event in the Rathborne Memorial Cups competition.

An assemblage of 10,000 persons filled every available seat in the Randalls Island Stadium last night for the performance of Cole Porter's musical comedy "The Gay Divorce." After the stadium attendants had permitted 1,000 more to stand, the police turned away 4.000.

Consumers who planned to substitute poultry for the high-priced meats find poultry costs on the rise. Increased demands, caused by the advance in pork and beef prices, are one factor; the other is that the supply of poultry coming in from the farms is diminishing.

It is said that as much as 70 per cent of British income tax revenue is paid at the source. Income taxes paid by English corporations may be deducted by them from regular dividenils paid to shareholders. This practice has given rise to the question of who is the taxpayer-the corporation or the recipient shareholder.

Schools for Eskimos in the Central Canadian Arctic mark a twenty-fifth anniversary next Friday when Arsene Turquetil, Roman Catholic Bishop of the Arctic, opens the celebration of the founding of the first mission there, at remote Chesterfield Inlet on the west coast of Hudson Bay.

Authorities of two adjoining counties dug deeper tonight into the mystery surrounding the unsolved killing of 11-year-old Mildred Best, the arrest of her brother and the subsequent unexplained death of Orla Shaw, the farmer uncle with whom they lived.

The palatial apartment of the late Arthur Brisbane, one of the largest and most impressive of Manhattan's roof dwellings, has been placed on the market for rent because of the death of the wellknown editor.

A new trade agreement between Germany and Generalissimo Franco, head of the Rebel forces in Spain, which became effective this month, places special importance on delivery of iron ore to Germany, and through its provisions the Reich will also receive immediate shipments of copper and pyrites.

The Canadian Pacific Railroad plans to make San Francisco a major port M of call, according to word received pa here. The company is having two 24,000-ton liners built on the Clyde to enter the trade connecting Vancover, San Francisco and Australasia, with Tahiti a likely stop.

Interest on the bank loan of the Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company was reduced from 6 per cent to 5 per cent under a contract dated July 16, according to a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public yesterday.

The St. Louis Post-Dispatch published today a photograph of Arthur Schading, business agent of Local No. of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, which had caused him to call a short-lived strike of electricians yesterday at radio station kSD, operated by the newspaper.

Miss Helen Emily Truesdell, daughter of the late Dr. Hobart G. Truesdell, for many years headmaster of the Suffield School for Boys in Suffield, Conn., was married today to Elton Pryne Huyck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Huyck of Herkimer, N. Y., in St. Peter's Episcoppal Church here. The Rev. Alfred J. Martin officiated.

AMONG the critics who mingled with the starched and silken throng at the dampish premiere of "The Life of Emile Zola" at the Hollywood Theatre Wednesday night, there was one to whom Warner Brothers, and the

Miss Louise Wheeler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight C. Wheeler of this place, and Bishop Von Wettberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. F. Von Wettberg, also of Bridgeport, have selected attendants for their wedding which will take place the afternoon of Sept. 3 in the garden at the bride's home.

In a ball game that looked like a preview of the writers' contest at Huntington tomorrow, the Bees outfumbled the Dodgers in the opener of today's double-header and allowed them to score their first triumph here this season, 7 to 5.

The Pan American Airways base here was notified by radio today that the German four-engined seaplane Nordmeer left the Azores at 3:10 o'clock (D. S. T.) this afternoon on a proposed transatlantic exploratory flight to New York. At 10 P. M.

Max Eastman, replying here today to the parting remarks of Ernest Hemingway, made Saturday as he sailed for Europe, asserted that beyond doubt their "little literary disagreement" at Scribner's last week ended with "Ernest on his back, both shoulders touching the floor, and me on top of him."

The Roman Catholic Church's unalterable opposition to the "evil" of divorce was reaffirmed yesterday by Mgr. J. Francis A. McIntyre, chancellor of the Archdiocese, who occupied the pulpit at the high mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Delegates and visitors to the annual international convention of the Knights of Columbus opening here tomorrow, thronged San Antonio's downtown streets and hotels tonight, following an afternoon session of the order's board of directors.

The engagement of Miss Sarah Adams Whiting, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Butler Whiting of this place, to James Robert Baylis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert W. Baylis of Scarsdale, N. Y., and Noank, Conn., has been announced by her parents.
A few hardy survivors of yesterday's drifting match assembled on Long Island Sound again today for the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's special regatta, only to meet with the same distressing conditions.

Single blessedness is not for the Hilter youth. Like the sorrows that do not come as single spies but in battalions, Germans of the new dispensation cannot get anywhere as individuals. To arrive, they must come in families. This, among other things, is what is meant by totalitarianism: as many as possible and all for one.

Miss Elizabeth Ann Atkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Jefferies Atkins of this place, has completed plans for her marriage on Wednesday to Samuel Howard McCain Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. McCain, also of Kittanning.

Stocks closed higher after earlyweek irregularity. Trading was the smallest in many weeks; turnover, 4,311,520 shares. Bonds irregular; domestic issues steady, foreign obligations lower and United States Government list weak; transactions, $35,012,900.
Solomon Wander, one of the first Jewish immigrants to form the Jewish community in Albany, died last night. His age was 71.

Word was received here tonight of the death at Upper St. Regis Lake, N. Y., of William. Stuart Spaulding, socially prominent Boston business man. Mr. Spaulding, who lived at 45 Beacon Street and had a Summer home at Prides Crossing, was on a vacation in New York with his family. He was 73 years old.

Dr. Judson Daland, widely known diagnostician and consultant, medical writer, teacher and world traveler, died yesterday in his apartment at Ventnor, N. J., in his seventyeighth year.

Traffic on Seventh Avenue near 113th Street was tied up for an hour early yesterday morning as hundreds of passers-by, attracted by pistol shots, watched Detective Joseph Reynolds of the safe and loft squad capture a Negro whom he accused of attempting to pick his rockets.

As a prelude to Ernest T. Weir's second struggle with New Deal labor legislation, several thousand persons, employes of the Weiron Steel Corporation and their friendss and sympathizers, staged a rally here this afternoon to show that they shared his opposition to the National Labor Relations Board.

Mr. and Mrs. Willing Spencer/are expected at the St. Regis today from Newport. Mr. and Mrs. James Rockwell Sheffield will arrive today on the Normandie and will be at the Plaza. The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. S. Delancey Townsend, who are passing the Summer at York Harbor, Me., are expected at the Carlyle.

Two young men standing on the westbound tracks of the Pennsylvania-Reading Seashore lines watching an eastbound freight train rumble past, were struck and killed here tonight by an express train, bound from Wildwood to Camden.

Mr. and Mrs. William Ernest Graves of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rebecca Willis Graves, to Reginald Geary Conley, son of Major Gen. Edgar Thomas Conley, U. S. A., and Mrs. Conley of Greenridge, Silver Springs, Md.

The New York A. C. tennis team triumphed over the Orienta Beach Club netmen, 7 to 4, today. The Winged Foot squad captured three out of five doubles matches and four out of six singles encounters. The summaries:

The twentieth season of outdoor concerts by the Goldman Band, Edwin Franko Goldman, conductor, was concluded last night with a concert at the Central Park Mall heard by an audience estimated at 50,000. Dr. Goldman addressed the audience briefly, expressing his thanks for its enthusiasm,

The skidding Red Sox dropped into fourth place today as the Senators won both ends of a double-header for a sweep of a four-game series. Washington now holds an eightgame winning streak, its longest of the year.

Major M. J. Kelleher, officer in charge of the motor transport section of the United States Marines here, got up from his chair in marine headquarters on Haiphong Road at 4 o'clock today to answer the telephone.

The Postoffice Department announced today that the recent convictions of twenty-four persons in connection with promotion of a mythical "Baker" estate had broken up a swindle which netted its promoters $1,000.000.

St. Paul's Epistle to the Galatiane warning them not to forsake the living faith of Jesus Christ for a "second-rate moral code and system of observances" stands out as a message of paramount importance to every modern Christian, the Rev. Lewis Nichols declared yesterday morning at Trinity Church,

The Bank of England's circulation has passed its Summer peak and is falling rapidly, with the last week's decline amounting to ??6,010,180. This drop was about ??2,000,000 larger than that of the same week last year, although, because of a much larger total circulation, wider variations must be expected.

Lyon Cohen, who was president of the first Canadian Jewish Congress in 1919, died today in Old Orchard, Me., at the age of 89. He was co-founder with S. W. Jacobs, M. P., of The Jewish Times, first Jewish paper in Canada.

The National Tuberculosis Association has authorized the use of Christmas Seal sale funds for syphilis control activities in this State, it was announced yesterday by the State Committee on Tuberculosis and Public Health of the State Charities Aid Association.

The German wholesale price index for Aug. 4 stood at 106.8, against 106.5 the preceding week. Industry again was quieter. Unemployed at the end of July numbered 563,000, against 1,170,000 at the same date in 1936.

The beginning of the second week of the silk and rayon strike, affecting plants in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and New York, will see the return to work of about 8,000 of the more than 30,000 strikers under agreements closed over the weekend.
William Stevens of Dawson explained today how he fights hay fever sniffles and sneezes, but, he said, the program took determination.
The Browns, aided by walks that forced in two, put on a five-run rally in the seventh inning today to defeat the Tigers, 9 to 7, in the series finale.
A three-day strike of the crews of three Stndard Oil Company tankers, the Mobiloil, the Java Arrow and the Paulsboro, which have been tied up here since Friday, ended this afternoon.

The crowning humiliation came to the Yankees at Shibe Park today before a delirious gathering of 32,346 fans, the second largest crowd of the year here. The Athletics beat the champions, 5 to 4. As if that were not enough, the Ruppert siege guns were muffled by Edgar Smith, a fork-hand flinger who, until today, hadn't won a ball game this season and had suffered eleven defeats.

BECAUSE of the writings of Jean Giono, author of "The Song of the World," published today (Viking, $2.50), a kind of cultish back-to-the-land movement has grown up in France, in the rarely remembered Departement of the Basses-Alpes, where city people go to become either full- or part-time farmers and herders, look at what they consider the unspoiled world about them and attempt to cultivate the same feeling for it that Giono has.

Charley Greenockle, former Hempstead High star twirler, made an impressive debut for the New York A. C. baseball team by pitching the Winged Foot to an 11-3 victory over the Lexington Baseball Club yesterday at Travers Island.

A tiny 225 class boat, pooh-poohed and laughed at by the haughty and smug Gold Cup lawmakers as too small for their big-time racing when they legislated their minimum at 600 cubic inches of piston displacement, today performed the impossible on the North Shrewsbury to score an upset in the National Sweepstakes Regatta.

This week's markets here were uncertain. The optimistic official forecast of the Reich's foreign trade, however, was well received, and imports, at least, ought to benefit from this week's decree amending the price regulations.

Christianity is committed to the spreading of a gospel of love, and stands or falls today on this point, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, the pastor, said yesterday morning in his sermon in the Riverside Church, 120th Street and Riverside Drive. He said:

In Vienna and Graz movies members of the Patriotic Front last night noisily demonstrated against a, German newsreel showing the recent choral festival at Breslau. The demonstrations were so violent that police intervened.

It is possible to accept Christ as one's Saviour and to reject Him as one's Lord, the Rev. Dr. W. Graham Scroggie of Edinburgh, Scotland, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventyninth Street.

Miss Frances Jane Cornwall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Cornwall of this-place, will be married to John Sleght, son of Mrs. Miary W. Sleght of Rochester, N. Y., )n Sept. 4 in the Hitchcock Memoial Church, Scarsdale.

Radio Commissioner Payne, in a letter made public today and written on Aug. 14 to Powel Crosley Jr., president of the Crosley Radio Corporation, cited a suggestion made on the Senate floor that radio broadcasting stations "be declared to be public utilities and be subjected to a control in rates and practices to which they are not now amenable."

Miss Helen Preston Ellis, daughter of Mrs. Edwin Howard Baker of this place and the late Reuben Mor rix Ellis, will be married to Dv, Lewis Thorne, son of Samuel Thorne of Rye, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Thorne, on Saturday afternoon in the Church of the Good Shepherd, Waban.

Police studied a list of eleven deaths covering eight years tonight, and Lieut. George W. Schattle of the Homicide Squad said that "they all lead, directly or indirectly, to Anna Hahn." Three mysterious illnesses were also under scrutiny.

The 1937 Forum on Current Problems, of which The New York Herald Tribune is sponsor, will be held on Oct. 5 and 6 at the Waldorf-Astoria on the theme, "The Second Discovery of America," Mrs. William Brown Meloney, chairman and organizer, announced yesterday.

A man was burned to death and eight persons were injured yesterday in a Brooklyn rooming-house fire. One of the injured was a 31year-old woman who leaped downward fifteen feet across a threefoot airshaft to the roof of another building with her 1-year-old
Bradford Washburn, explorer and mountain climber, today recorded with camera nature's changing story in a vast glaciated area in the mountainous borderlands of Alaska and Canada.

An emergency council of ranking United States authorities decided today on immediate evacuation of all American women and children from Shanghai, where their lives are endangered by the battle raging between Chinese and Japanese troops.

The commercial drug store, selling sandwiches, cosmetics and gadgets, is gradually losing its prescription business to the professional pharmacy, Dr. E. Fullerton Cook, chairman of the general committee of revision of the Pharmacopoeia of the United States and professor at the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and Science, said yesterday.
The Armstrong Cork Company reports a net income of $3,089,360 for the first six months, equal to $2.56 a share on the common stock, against $1,676,399, or $1.38 a share, correspondingly in 1936.

Three institutions here supported by the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities were inspected today by twenty-five members of the Workmen's Circle, a fraternal organization having 40,000 members in New York City.
Margaret Deland, and her publishers, Harper Brothers, say that for years they have received four or more letters weekly asking where certain favorite tales of Old Chester may be found.

Ingram Sharpe's entries took point honors at the eighth annual Lake Placid horse show, which was concluded today. Repeated victories in the saddle classes gave the Lake Placid Club Trophy for members to Sharpe. He also won the second leg on the point prize offered by Dr. Philip C. Cole. Ardpatrick, chestnut gelding tack owned by the Ridgewood Stables of Derby, N. Y.,

Grief and regrets were expressed by Mme. Chiang Kai-shek over the bombing of innocent Chinese and foreign non-combatants in the foreign concessions Saturday by Chinese planes, in a telegram received late yesterday by Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr.

Certain high Treasury officials, who do not regard the new tax loop-hole-closing bill as a solution to some of the fundamental shortcomings of the Federal income tax system, have been giving close study to what Professor Lrving Fisher of Yale describes as a "practical schedule for an income tax."
Reports on August coat sales received in the wholesale market here last week continued conflicting, although it was agreed that the bulk of demand fell in the higher price ranges.
