Through a Presidential decree, effective from Aug. 10 through Dec. 31, rates of import duty into Cuba on hulled and semi-hulled rice were modified by decreasing the preferential rate to the United States and increasing the minimum rate to rice imports from all other sources, the Department of Commerce has been advised by its commercial attache.

City of Paris, Ltd., 878 Broadway, York, selling toilet powders and perfumes, has agreed in a stipulation with the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue the use in its corporate name of the word "city," printed in script so as to simulate the word "Coty," thus tending to cause customers to believe its products are those of a competitor. Les Parfums Coty, the commission announced today.

The residence containing twelve rooms at 38-17 149th Street, Flushing, Queens, has been purchased by Theodore Junkes. The house occupies a plot 65 by 100 feet and a twocar garage is on the property. . Albert Johntra acted as broker in the sale.
Sr Arthur Rose, who completed a distinguished career of public service as commissioner for special areas in Scotland, died here yesterday at the age of 61.

John Regan, the defending titleholder, conquered Stephen Eisenberger, 21-4, 21-3, in the quarterfinals of the New Jersey State A. A. U. one-wall handball singles championship tournament yesterday at Palisades Park. Fred Dreher beat Abe Pashkow. 21-16.

Scattered liquidation developed here in the September and October deliveries of lard last week and prices declined to new love levels for the season. The break in cottonseed oil more than offset continued high prices for hogs and small receipts, and a reduction of about 25,000,000 pounds in cold storage stocks for the country in July. The latter compared with an increase of about 10,000,000 pounds in 1936.

Our entry upon a new phase of Works Progress Administration activity seems to be an appropriate occasion for a brief review of developments in New York City during the last two years. Such a look into the record might be variously angled, depending upon the individual interest of the observer.
The Cubs' National League lead was cut to of the four games today-the lowest in more than two weeks-when Cincinnati outslugged the Chicagoans to take both ends of a double-header before 31,155.

Mrs. Ludwig Lindenmeyr of this place, formerly of New York, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Dorothy Lindenmeyr, to James B. Brown, son of Mrs. David R. Brown of Concord, N .H. and the late Dr. Brnwn.
A trio of Chicago pitchers baffled Cleveland's leading hitters today and the White Sox won both games of a double-header from the Indians, 5 to 3 and 3 to 2, before 32,000 spectators.

Silvio, American and Canadian quarter mile single scull champion, the New York Athletic Club won the annual Greenwood Lake rowing regatta today, garnering 24 points to win the Chamber of Commerce Trophy. The Active Boat Club of Edgewater, N. J., was second with 18.

The estate of Edwin B. Young sold the buildings at 951-55 Bergenline Ave and the vacant parcel at 510 47th St. Union City, to the Liberty Realty Co. Inc. The stated consideration was $52,500. The buyer gave back in part payment a purchase money mortgage for $45,000, due Aug. 1. 1947, at 4 per cent.

Complaints from contractors are steadily increasing, according to Myron L. Matthews of the Dow Service, against the practice that has become general in recent years of requiring contractors to pay for plans and specifications in figuring on building construction projects.

Intent upon sine die adjournment by next Saturday night, Congressional leaders announced today that if necessary night sessions would be held to push through the three remaining measures on the "preferred" program and clean up many loose odds and ends.
THE SONG OF THE WORLD, by Jean Giono. '(Viking, $2.50.) A novel by a French writer of reputation. 1851 AND THE CRYSTAL PALACE, by Christopher Hobhouse.

Dr. Frank O'Brien, Charles Ray, in 200 W 83d St; Louis Carreau, Inc, broker. Herbert Adler, in 160 W 73d St; Dorothy McCusker, in 175 W 73d St; Mrs. Burgie Gilbert, in 307 W 79th St; Margaret C. Murphy, Grace M. Baker, Maynard S.
Miss Opal Sturgell, 18-year-old Berea College sophomore, was shot and fatally wounded tonight while walking on the college campus with a male companion.

Neil Zullo, 25 years old, of Port Reading, N. J., was sentenced last night in Night Court to serve five days in jail or pay a fne of $10 for having thrown lighted cigarettes into the chimpanzee cage of the Bronx Zoo.

President Roosevelt has conferred with Treasury officials in the last few days on the state of the Federal budget, leaving with them a strong impression that he is trying in earnest to accomplish his goal of a balanced budget in the present fiscal year.
Miss Carolyn Baum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Baum of Maplewood, has chosen next Saturday as the date for her marriage Lo Lieutenant Carl Freeman Lyons Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl F.

Opinion gains that the low point of the Summer is here or has passed, so far as the steel market is concerned, according to the magazine Steel, which finds that production is continuing at a high rate and there are few signs of a reduction before Fall business comes to buttress mill books.

General Francisco Franco's long expected drive against the Government stronghold of Santander burst with fury today, sweeping through a dozen towns in one of the major onslaughts of the Spanish civil war.

The MacGregor Arctic Expedition put into the shelter of Umanak Fiord, Greenland, stopping at Igdlorsuit to make repairs to the ship after she had been blown to the-Greenland coast from the coast of Baffinland by terrific gales.

Phil Weintraub's home run with a mate on in the third was the decisive blow as Jersey City scored a 5-3 victory over the Bisons in the opening game of a double-header today. The triumph, credited to Leo Mangum, former Bison, interrupted a local winning string of three straight.
Steel production in July amounted to 1,059,200 tons, only 47,200 tons under the June record of 1,106,400 tons, despite holiday stoppages, while it exceeded the total for July, 1936, by 85,100 tons.
Charting the course of the flight of the condor will be a new task for lookouts, rangers and other field employes of the Federal service of Los Padres National Forest beginning tomorrow morning.
Mrs. Frederic P. Sands has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Mrs. Elizabeth Sterret Sands Elliott, to John Harlin O'Connell of New York.

William Claiborne Hall of Louisville, Ky., and East Hampton died here early today at the age of 56. Mr. Hall was born on Staten Island, N. Y., July 10, 1881, the son of the late William Cornelius and Mary Suzette Thomas Hall.

The Delaware and Hudson Railroad police won the sixth annual International Police Pistol Tournament which ended today after two days of competition in which 121 teams representing police of the United
Racing commissioners of twenty-two States discussed tonight a proposed plan to bar inexperienced riders from the country's tracks.

Rolling up a total of 109 points, the athletes representing the First German Sport Club of Brooklyn annexed the team crown at the annual German-American track and field championships staged at the Brook lyn Grand Stadium yesterday. The event was held under the auspices of the First German S. C.

Robert L. Riggs added another notable conquest to his long string of victories on the courts today to bolster the conviction that he has no superior in American tennis with the exception of Donald Budge.

Mrs. Sigre A. Smith, 35 years old, estranged wife of Ward Smith, an automobile salesman of 150 West Fifty-fifth Street, was killed last night when she leaped or fell from the kitchen window of Smith's sixth-floor apartment.
Alarge number of the Summer colonists turned out for the regular Sunday night buffet supper at the Bar Harbor Club this evening. Among those entertaining guests were Mr. and Mrs. E. Victor Loew,

Paul Thompson, 28 years old, a Negro, living at 107-19 Fern Place, Jamaica, shot and killed Elsie SiIons, 19 years old, of 104-17 171st Street, South Jamaica, at her home late last night and then fatally shot himself.

M. F. Taylor, in Ridgewood Dr., Rye, N. Y., from Mrs. Ross St. John McClelland; Blakeman Quintard Meyer, broker. Dr. J. I. Margolis, in Raymond Place, Hewlett, L. I., from W. S. Vandewater: Robert P. Newton, in Adams Rd., Hewlett Neck, from Kiliaen Van Rensselaer; Maurice L. Gaffney, in Smith Lane, Hewlett Neck, from S. Althause; De Forest Van Slyck, in Cedarhurst, from Michael Keller; Burr McAuley, Inc., brokers.

Hugo Oehler, national secretary of the Revolutionary Workers League, announced last night the receipt of a telegram from Secretary of State Cordell Hull with the information that the United States Consul at Barcelona reported the release from prison of Wolf Kupinsky, New York Socialist and garment worker who had gone to Spain to fight for the Loyalists.

Hoodlums early today applied a coat of salmon pink paint to the heroic-sized bronze statue of Admiral Farragut on the Strandway at Farragut Road, South Boston, overlooking Castle Island and the harbor.
The strike of students of both sexes in all secondary schools in Bogota, which started Friday, became a sitdown strike in the streets yesterday. It blocked all vehicular traffic for several hours.

Miss Norma Margaret Franzen, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Franzen of this city, was married this afternoon to Orlando E. Farina of San Francisco. The ceremony was performed in Sacred Heart Church, Vailsburgh, by the Rev. Father Connell.

Beyide (71)--Final round for President's Cup: John Beyer defeated Jack Mandell, 10 and 8. Brookville (72)-Thirty-six-hole final round for Governors' Trophy: S. Mott defeated E. Meredith, 4 and 2. Best-ball competition: Dr. M. J. Dunne and C. Parr, 75-9-66.

A consistent atheism is more admirable than the superstition and polytheism that frequently hide behind modern religion, the Rev. Dr. Herman Sidener, rector of St. Paul's Church, Canton, Ohio, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church,

The State Labor Relations Board will hold a hearing at 2 P. M. today at its offices, 342 Madison Avenue, on the charges of violation of the Wagner Act brought by Cafeteria Workers Union, Local 302, against the Horn Hardart Comapny,

Foreign tourists coming to visit the Paris International Exposition bring in foreign exchange, but financial circles in general feel that such sales of foreign exchange are relatively small and that the tourists now here are not spending much money.
A weather-beaten Canadian patched up his tiny ketch-rigged boat today for the last leg of a 20,000-mile voyage from Halifax, N. S., to Vancouver, B. C., by way of the Panama Canal.

Last-minute charges and statements flew tonight as Maine's voters prepared to write their verdict tomor row on a proposed 1 per- cent sales tax to finance old-age pensions and aid the State educational system.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the editorial "Whittling Down the Housing Bill," that appeared in your issue of Aug. 7, you deprecate the fact that an amendment to the Wagner Housing Bill was adopted by the Senate which conferred jurisdiction upon the Department of the Interior.
A crowd of 4,000, one of the largest in recent years, saw a powerful Blind Brook Polo 'Club quartet put on a brilliant exhibition in conquering the First Division team of Brooklyn, 12-5,
Birdsall Sweet, 19-year-old infantile paralysis victim, today won another round in his six-year fight to escape from an "iron lung."

God is enough for everybody in the hours of salvation, suffering and sorrow, the Rev. Dr. Norman Dunning declared yesterday in Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street. Dr. Dunning, pastor of the Rivercourt Methodist Episcopal Church of London, delivered the first of a series of sermons as guest preacher.

The first international encampment of Girl Scouts which opened here last Monday at Camp Andree permitted visitors today for the first time. More than 250 persons, mostly friends and relatives of the Scouts, were entertained during the day.

The five-and-one-half-story apartnent house at 12-28 Sickles Street, n the Dyckman section at the northern extremity of Manhattan island, has been purchased by an investing client of William L. Rosan, attorney, through Nehring Brothers, brokers.
Mr. and Mrs. John Edgar Rose Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth McCaw, to James David Jameson of Washington, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Mason,Jameson of Roanoke.
Joseph Cortese, 37 years old, a concert violinist and taxidermist but of a job, killed his wife early yesterday in their home at 74 Aveue U, Brooklyn, as his 5-year-old daughter Antoinette looked on.

Offering to the public, by means of a prospectus, of 70,000 shares of common stock of the Pyridium Corporation out of 150,000 shares registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission will be made today by a group composed of Wright, Bergen Pistell, Inc., Jersey City; John J. Bergen Co., Ltd., New York, and George T. Leach Co., Inc., Chicago. The stock will be priced at $15.50 a share.

A committee of technicians of the Maritime Commission will start tomorrow an inspection of the 155 vessels receiving Federal operating differential subsidies to determine what improvements are necessary in the crews' quarters to make them conform with the Merchant Marine Act.
Government supply awards under the terms of the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Aug. 12 amounted to $3,854,373, according to the Department of Labor.
Another in his series of large luncheons for members of the racing colony was given this afternoon at the Saratoga golf clubhouse by Geroge H. Bull, assoication president.

The Stock Exchange's tendencies here generally were steady this week, although the volume of trading was much smaller, due to the approach of the Aug. 15 holiday. This period of the year usually is unfavorable to a strong price rise, capitalists being virtually out of the market.
A Negro climbed into a fourth-floor room of a Loop hotel today, beat a young white woman over the head with a brick, criminally attacked her, and escaped by the window.

Four completely transformed youths, once defendants in the famous Scottsboro case, restless in new clothes, with their hair slicked to a bright polish-two of them even sporting canes-admitted yesterday that they were going on the stage.

The Works Progress Administration in this city spent $409,195,154 on work relief projects sponsored by the city, the State and Federal Governments between Aug. 1, 1935, when the program was started, and July 1 of this year, according to a report submitted by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local administrator, to Harry L. Hopkins, Federal WPA chief, and made public yesterdav.

As the fourth Berkshire Symphonic Festival came to an end at Tanglewood this afternoon a campaign was launched for a fund of $100,000 to be used for the construction of a permanent music shed. Next year's festival is contingent upon the success of this drive.

Signalizing our entry upon a new phase of Works Progress Administration, Colonel Somervell, the Administrator for this city, has written a twenty-eight-page letter to Harry Hopkins, the National Administrator, reviewing the WPA achievements here from Aug. 1, 1935, when the program was inaugurated, to July 1 of this year.

Excerpts from all four music dramas of the "Ring" were offered at the fourth and final concert of the Wagner series sponsored by the Federal Music Project, which was given last night at the WPA Theatre of Music. The event attracted the largest audience of the series,

The number of passengers arriving in this country by airplane in the fiscal year 1937 showed an increase of 26.2 per cent over the previous year and was almost double the average for the five-year period 1930 to 1934.

The Princeton-North Carolina tennis team added seven more match today to yesterday's ten to defeat the Oxford and Cambridge players, 17 to 4, in the two-day tournament at the Point Judith C. C. In one of the closest matches of the day, Archie Henderson of North Carolina defeated W. H. Earle of Oxford, 6-4, 12-10.

Motion picture producers are beginning to watch with some concern the rapid rise in the development of commercial shorts and may eventually bring pressure to bear on exhibitors to prevent the showing of any undue proportion of advertising films to regular productions, according to comment in the advertising field.

An epic softball game was played here this afternoon in Flaucher's Meadows between two hand-picked teams of well-known Summer residents for the benefit of the local volunteer fire department. After a frantic three-and-a-halfhour struggle it was believed- that the "Nine Old Men," headed by Lowell Thomas,

ALPERT-Mr. and Mrs. Harold Alpert announce birth of a son Friday, Aug. 13, at the Woman's Hospital. GRAY-Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Gray, 2,785 University ve., announce the arrival of a daughter, Saturday, Aug. 14, at New York Infirmary for Women.
We left the cove at this port shortly after dawn this morning aboard Captain Louis Singer's dory, hoping to get a good idea of just what this Peconic Bay fishing is like.

A conference of representatives of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers and officials of shipyards in the New YorkNew Jersey area affected by the nine-week strike of the union is scheduled to be held this afternoon at the office of the State Mediation Board, 165 Broadway.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art the will place on exhibition this morning a valuable Mortlake tapestry presented by Christian A. Zabriskie, New York collector. This tapestry, which will hang temporarily in the museum's room of recent accessions, is believed to portray "The Seizure of Cassandra by Agamemnon," and dates from about 1660-80.
British and American requests that Shanghai be excluded from the sphere of military operations cannot now be accepted by Japan, according to the Foreign Office.
Washington was watching the Sino-Japanese situation closely tonight, with the posssibility of invoking the embargoes of the Neutrality Act against China and Japan always in mind.

A crowd of 3,500 today welcomed the return of polo to the Sands Point Club. The open championship teams og Greentree and Aknusti galloped through a test match, the first contest on the famous field this season.

Because of its preoccupation with impending Reich loans and signs of a tighter money market, this week's stock market here was dull and, except for the last two days, mainly reactionary. On the whole, prices this week changed little.

The next Congress may be asked to overhaul financing provisions of the social security program, fiscal officials said today. The major change being considered would avoid the accumulation of huge reserves, a point on which there has been much criticism of the Social Security Act.
91st St, 116 E; Rutlyn Realties, Inc, Otto Dreifus, president, to John C. Steuer, executor John C. Steur, 106 W 69th St; prior mtg. $5,000; 5 years 5 per cent; $6,000.

"Fin" Petrie sat on a purple couch in a fifteenth-floor suite at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, held a cigarette in his left hand and told the metropolitan press how he had won the third annual award of $200 and a trip to New York for being the nation's "best country correspondent."
Harry W. Colmery, National Commander of the American Legion; General Bernard W. Kearney, National Commander- of Veterans of Foreign Wars; Robert R. McCormick, publisher of The Chicago Tribune:

Two persons were killed and three injured early this morning when a car driven by Vincent Perrussa, 19 years old, of 318 Suydam Street, Brooklyn, was in collision with another machine operated by John Parkerson, 25, of Mill Street, West Creek, N. J., on the Shore Road, about ten miles north of here.

Discretion murmured, "Make no friend in haste," And pride reminded me of bitter fruit That I had snatched before the vital root Had nurtured it to ripeness. With the taste Of this remorse still pricking me;

First Heat, Five Miles-Won by Douglas C. Fonda, Orange, N. J.; second. Gar Wood Jr., Algonac, Mich.; third, Clinton R. Ferguson. Waban, Mass.; fourth, Garson. R. Feinstein, Holyoke, Mass.; fifth, James Mullen. Richmond, Va. Time-6:17. Speed-47.745 m. p. h. (world record).

Adolph Kiefer of Chicago bettered the Japanese swimming record for foreigners for the third time tonight when he won the fifty-meter back stroke in an international meet in 30.4 seconds. Kiefer was timed in 30.4 and 30 seconds in the heats yesterday.

After serving forty-five years with the White Star Line and the International Mercantile Marine Company in this city, Anton G. Christensen, general passenger agent, will retire from the service next month with a well earned pension.

The American Federation of Labor intends to start a counter-attack on C. I. O. organizing efforts among agricultural and white-collar office workers, William Green, A. F. of L. president, announced today. Mr.

Little change has occurred in the world's wheat situation in the last two weeks, and latest estimates from various countries in the Northern Hemisphere indicate a total crop of around 3,263,000,000 bushels, or about 200,000,000 bushels more than in 1936.

Marie Brown, 26-year-old feminine lead of the local presentation of "Brother' Rat," was married to Barry Sul- , livan at Tia Juana, Mexico, on Friday, it was announced here today. Mr. Sullivan played a feature role in the New York company producing the same play.

A procession of the seven centuries of Berlin's history, five miles long, swept through the streets of the capital today as 3,000,000 persons, in admiring astonishment and with much riotous rejoicing, contemplated the progress of the city since it had issued from a primitive fishing village on the banks of the River Spree.

The musical comedy, "Anything Goes," begins a week's run tonight at Jones Beach in a production by Fortune Gallo. and J. J. Shubert. Diana Ward, Charles Kemper, Ann Barrie and Jack Whitteridge will head a cast of 200 players, singers and dancers.
Miss Sarah Patterson Foster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Taylor Foster of this palce, has selected the afternoon of Sept. 18 for her marriage to Arthur O. Fulton of Boston and Oyster
Criticizing legislative action which resulted in the Federal Government withholding $250,000 of New Jersey's share of road aid, David H. Agans, master of the New Jersey State Grange,
The annual circulation of the Free Library of Philadelphia has declined by nearly 2,000,000 volumes in the last few years, the annual report of Franklin- H. Price, librarian, revealed today.

Robert L. Gerry Jr. and John Lowry have been elected trustees of the Central Savings Bank. Kidder, Peabody Co. will open today an office in Chicago under the direction of Maurice H. Bent, with Willard T. Grimm as manager of sales. Other offices of the firm are here and in Boston and Philadelphia.

Celebrating its annual "visitors day," the Twenty-seventh Division Special Troops, commanded by Major John H. Mansfield, were hosts to more than 1,000 friends and former members of the various units of the command here at Camp Smith today.

Chinese said today that 1,500 troops died in the battle for Nankow Pass, gateway to Inner Mongolia thirty miles northwest of here. Five hundred were Chinese officers and men, it was stated here. The Japanese lost 1,000, the Chinese claimed.
The great Anglo-Saxon countries, which have chosen to continue along the road of democracy in the face of
An upward trend in Peru's overseas trade for the first six months of this year is disclosed in preliminary figures issued today by the statistical section of the Customs.

AFFENS-Charles A., beloved husband of Celia, devoted father Wilbur. Funeral services at the West End Funeral Chapel, 200 West 91st St., Monday, Aug. 16, 10 A. M. ARNOLD-Dan Hinckley, 49, Aug. 14, in Washington. Conn., husband of Mildred Culver. Funeral Tuesday, Aug. 17, 11:30 at St. John's Church, Washington, Conn. Burial Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, N. Y.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange last week; also the new highs and lows and total number of issues for the last three weeks:

A quiet-looking young man, sitting listless in a police station after he had led the police in a wild chase through the Bronx, admitted yesterday morning that he had deliberately run down a young woman with his automobile, robbed her of $5 after pretending to help her and then thrown her out of his speeding car, according to George Tilzer, assistant district attorney of the Bronx.

Seasoned fliers from both sides of the North Pole pressed toward the Arctic wastes today in a search for Sigismund Levanevsky and five other Soviet airmen missing since Friday in an attempted 4,000-mile hop over the polar cap from Moscow to Fairbanks.
Nation wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 85 per cent of capacity, down 1 point from the preceding week, but equal to the rate in the week before.

The Democrats have cut further into Republican registration totals in this city, according to a tabulation, including incomplete figures from the final enrollment day before the city-county primaries next month.

Charles Coburn declared here tonight that if Americans want actors under the age of 40 or 45 to play such classical roles as Romeo, Hamlet or Mercutio they must train talented young men and women in the professional art of acting, just as Americans have helped England to train English boys and girls in the Old Vic and the Stratford-UponAvon Festival.

Last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Willem van Hoogstraten, brought an audience of 3,000 to the Lewisohn Stadium. The chief number of the program was the Schubert symphony in C major.

In What is usually the dullest season of the year for finance and industry, most of last week's markets moved little. Prices on the Stock Exchange went somewhat higher; the week-end averages were nearly 15 points above the year's lowest and only 8 below the highest.

A Catholic pilgrimage to this ancient cathedral city on the occasion of the twentieth episcopal and seventy-fifth birthday anniversary of Ludwig Sebastian, Bishop of Speier, had to be called off because of a counter-demonstration today by 150,000 National Socialists. Joseph Buerckel, Governor of the Saar-Palatinate region, hurriedly organized the Brownshirt demonstration last week when he learned of the Catholic plans.

That hitherto unassailable Kremlin of the motion picture, the Cameo Theatre, this week pulls off its marching boots, extracts its sturdy Siberian muffler from its campaign overcoat, fans out its admirably Marxist beard and proceeds to dispense a little culture and rest in the shape of two idyllic films extremely distant in locale, spirit and tempo from the rattle of the Stakhanoffist wars.

Senator Royal S. Copeland, candidate for both the Republican and Democratic nominations for Mayor, will arrive in New York City this morning for conferences with his Democratic supporters, preliminary to the actual opening of his campaign.
Confidenee Confidence in the cotton market was shaken by the United States Department of Agriculture's estimate of the new crop.

The Bronx office of the Department of Parks will be moved today from the Zbrowski Mansion in Claremont Park to the new park administration and garage building at Bronx Park East and Birchall Avenue, in Bronx Park. The telephone number of the new office is WEstchester 7-5200.

With the Summer vacation season at its peak, financial activity here is at a low ebb. European politics have ceased to worry the markets, but the Sino-Japanese situation is becoming unsettling in its influence, while Iraq's political assassination did not pass entirely without notice.

Peter Birmingam, 30 years old, of 1,451 Amsterdam Avenue, accused of trying to commit a burglary in a vacant apartment, was held without bail yesterday by Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in Fellony Court for examination tomorrow.

Two lawyers, two professors and a newspaper editor have been entrusted by the Canadian Government with the difficult task of finding a new economic and financial basis for Canadian confederation, the present one having proved inadequate during the depression.

Acceptance by Thomas E. Dewey, rackets prosecutor, of designation for the Republican nomination for District Attorney was acclaimed yesterday by leaders of the other parties and groups in the Fusion movement.

Members of the Lake Placid Horse Show Association and their guest exhibitors adjourned at the conclusion of the eighth annual show this afternoon to Lake Placid for a "floating cocktail party" aboard the steamer Doris on a cruise about the lake.

An airplane crashed today, killing its pilot, William C. Winters, 23, and seriously injuring a passenger, C. Leroy Shepp, 33. Both lived in West York. The plane nose-dived near a baseball park in West York, striking in a field adjoining the pilot's home.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman told members of Carle-Anderson Post 559, American Legion of Harrison, today, that he hopes to parade up Fifth Avenue with them when the Legion holds its nineteenth national convention in New York City Sept. 20-23.

Ernest Schoedsack and Merian C. Cooper, co-producers of "Grass," "Chang," "Four Feathers" and "Rango," regarded as milestone films in the cinema's progress, have been reunited by Metro-GoldwynMayer and will make a Technicolor film in the jungles of the East Indies with a native cast.

Tired and heavy-eyed after being stranded on a sand bar in the Mississippi River for more than twelve hours, 1,600 passengers of the excursion steamer President were taken ashore early today by tugboats after an all-night vigil.
The Richmond County grand jury will begin an investigation this morning into the collapse of the building at 1-5 New Street, New Brighton, S. I., Wednesday, in which nineteen persons were killed.
Jasper W. Cornaire, for nine years a member of the Assembly from Jefferson County, died this morning at his cottage on the St. Lawrence River near Cape Vincent. His age was 60.

By turning away from reading to the perusal of picture magazines people are reducing their capacity for thinking, said Bishop James E. Kearney of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rochester, in a sermon yesterday afternoon at the Convent of Our Lady of the Cenacle, Riverside Drive and 140th Street.
New favorable records for birth and death rates were made in New York State in June, Dr. J. V. De Porte, director of the Bureau of Vital Statistics of the State Department of Health, reported today.

The report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidaries for the twelve months to June 30, issued for publication today, shows a net income of $12,679,292, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges.
The outstanding development in the cotton market last week was the issuance on Monday of the Government's crop estimate of 15,593,000 bales, or about 500,000 above the ideas in the trade generally.
Edward C. Moore Jr., a retired lawyer and member of an old New York family, died here yesterday. at his residence, 43 East Fifty-first Street. He was in his eighty-second year.

Edison Ave (18-5309), n w cor Eastern Blvd, 157x25; H. Levin, Inc, to Elizabeth L. Gilmartin, 60 E 183d St. Teller Ave (11-2782), w s, 461 ft n of 169th St, 36x100; Philip J. Fried to Benjamin H. Fried, 1,269 Grand Concourse. 167th St (9-2456), s w cor Sheridan Ave, 100x100; Jacob Levy to Drake Operators, Inc. 1.440 Broadwav: mtge. $12.857.

The Rev. Verlynn Sprague, pastor of the Memorial Methodist Church of Nepperhan Heights, was arrested here last night on a disorderly conduct charge by Patrolman Cecil Cooper when he protested against the policeman interfering with a boy who was shining his shoes on the sidewalk on South Broadway. Mr.

The Rev. Edward L. Tibbals, pastor of the Homecrest Presbyterian Church at Avenue T and East Fifteenth Street, Brooklyn, died yesterday at his residence, 2,198 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

Four men aboard the 35-foot cabin cruiser Cantiquel, owned and operated by Charles A. Long Jr. of Philadelphia, narrowly escaped injury here last night when the vessel burst into flames in Long Island Sound near the Echo Bay Yacht Club anchorage. The fire was caused by the backfiring of the boat's engine.
Dr. Rudolf J. Kremer, pathologist and director of the clinical laboratory at the Augustana Hospital, died in that hospital yesterday of a heart ailment. He was 40 years old.

Almost without notice in the newspapers, a company went practically out of existence last Wednesday which three decades ago had filled a great place in the financial scene. The circumstances under which the Northern Securities Company was organized in November, 1902, with $261,000,000 of Northern Pacific and Great Northern stock in its possession, are one of Wall Street's best-remembered traditions.

The Monmouth County Country mat Club gained the right to represent the northeastern sector in the national inter-circuit championships in Chicago next week by downing Shrewsbury, 10-6, in the intra-circuit final at Schley Field today. Two big periods, the first and the fourth, won for Monmouth, which rated a two-goal handicap. They went scoreless in every other period.

Mr. and Mrs. J. E. McCauley of Peckett's, Sugar Hill, gave a dinner at the Mount Washington Cave grill here last evening for Mr. and Mrs. J. Cameron 2d, Miss Polly Le Boutillier, Miss Mary McCauley and Hugh C. Woolverton of New York.

The recent improvement in the tone of the market has a background of political as well as labor conditions. Only very few strikes have been reported recently and they have been confined to certain factories, and did not extend to any whole industry.

John H. Jouett, American aviation expert who laid the founnation for the Chinese Air Force now waging bitter warfare with Japanese foes, said today the Shanghai bombings, "was most un"most unfortunate-probably the result of over-enthusiasm and overconfidence."

Reassertion of the "romantic streak that lies latent within all of us" was urged by the Rev. Philip Cowell Jones in his sermon yesterday morning at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street.

The favorite American pastime is confessing the other fellow's sins, the Right Rev. Irving Peake Johnson, Bishop of Colorado, said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Religion should be taken in a large way as a "continuous process from the beginning of creation," he said.

Laying the world's ills to a critical, distrustful attitude in people, Dean George D. Edwards of the University of Missouri urged yesterday that we bear an appreciative love toward one another. He was guest preacher at the Central Church of Disciples of Christ, 142 West Eighty-first Street.
The Quebec strike situation both as regards five steel plants in Sorel and the nine factories of Dominion Textiles, Ltd., in various parts of the Provsince is growing daily more violent and bitter.
The city ordinance forcing grocery stores to close between 1 P. M. and midnight Sunday and permitting delicatessen shops to remain open gave Newark police not the slightest trouble today.

Can a family of five live on $8.05 a week in the City of New York? For thousands of families that problem still blots out the questions of personal, national and international import that nag the well-fed and give them headaches and indigestion. The Health Deapartment is trying to work it out by suggesting nourishing menus for people obliged to live on an emergency relief allowance.

Arrow II, sailed by Joe Morris Jr., formerly of the Corinthian Yacht Club of Philadelphia and now of the Island Heights Yacht Club, won the fleet championship for International Star Class sloops today after the closest race of the season.

The nation's armed forces completed their military coup today when Provisional President Rafael Franco resigned. Leaders of the army and navy forced his Cabinet to resign last Friday, but they said then that Colonel Franco would be continued in the office that he gained in a revolution in 1936. Lieut. Col.

A decline of more than $30,000,000 in the value of farm exports for the 1937 fiscal year compared with the year previous has been indicated by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, which says shipments of farm products for the year to June 31 were valued at $732,839,000, against $766,548,000 the previous vear.

Reports on the corn crop last week were slightly less favorable than earlier in the month, but the Government report of a prospective yield of 2,659,000,000 bushels suggested that there was more than ample grain to take care of the domestic demand during the 1937-38 season and prices declined moderately.

It is impossible for a nation or an individual to find advantage in a selfish life, the Rev. Dr. Andrew R. Osborn said in his sermon yesterday at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

They are announcing the last three weeks for "Brother Rat," which will be closing at the Biltmore Theatre on Sept. 4. A road tour is scheduled to begin two nights later-Labor Day, that will be-in Providence, R. I. A second company of the play, which has been touring since last Winter, will open a Chicago engagement next Sunday night.
After five years of stormy existence, the Pacific Coastwise Lumber Conference has dissolved, mainly because of the inroads of independent competition.

Appendicitis, one of the commonest human troubles requiring surgical treatment, is apparently a hereditary disease, according to Professor E. G. Stanley Baker of Wabash College. He announced in The Journal of Heredity that he had found that infection of the appendix, resulting in inflammation, soreness and rupture, "runs in families."

Aircraft manoeuvres, in which two blimps from the Lakehurst Naval Air Station and several dozen airplanes will take part, will mark the ceremonies at 3 o'clock this afternoon in the center of the Theme Plaza at the New York World's Fair, dedicating the site of the exposition's Perisphere and Tryion at Flushing Meadow, Queens.

The Ministry of Finance announced today that the bank holiday had been extended another day and that only the four Government banks, namely, the Central Bank, the China Bank, the Bank of Communications and the Farmers Bank of China are now opening on Tuesday. All other Chinese banks are remaining closed.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on Aug. 11 at 84.2, compared with 84.7 a fortnight before, 85 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

After two weeks of brilliant play that brought their fourth consecutive triumph, the five members of the United States chess team, who successfully defended the Hamilton-Russell trophy, were lionized today at a dinner at the Grand Royal Hotel.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, guest speaker at the family gathering at the Catholic Summer School of America at Cliff Haven tonight, assumed for what he said was the first time in his life the role of travelogue artist, recounting incidents of his recent visit to Europe.

The nineteenth annual report of the Church Pension Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church, estabwished more than twenty years ago as an outgrowth of the old General Clergy Relief Fund, disclosed yesterday that the book value of the fund's investments in 1936 had in creased by $1,455,135.

A military tribunal has been created to inquire into the murder of General Bakr Sidky Pasha, the Dictator of Iraq, and Major Mohamed Ali Jawad, commander of the air force, while strict measures will be taken against persons who endeavor to disturb peace and order, it was announced today.
The Real Estate Board of New York has announced the addition to its roster of thirty memberships through election by the executive committee of the board of governors.

The Monsanto Chemical Company earned $1,441,405, or $1.29 a common share, in the second quarter of this year, compared with $1,035,730, or 93 cents a share, in the June quarter of 1936, Edward M. Queeny, president announced today.

The Three Cardinals announced tonight that Paul Dean, who recently underwent a shoulder operation in an effort to bring his pitching arm back to normal, had decided to apply for voluntary retirement for the remainder of the season.

Speaking here today on world religious problems in his annual address at the First Methodist Episcopal Church, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, issued a warning that unless the modern totalitarian state forbore its suppression of religious beliefs,

The shortest squadron run of all and the longest in sailing time brought the American Yacht Club's cruise to an end in this port late today with the Q boat Hornet, the thirty-two-footer Apache, the Interclub Night Hawk and the Sound schooner Lark winners in their respective divisions.

Isaac M. Hubbard, descendant of an old Greenwich family, Fire Chief of the two central fire stations here and well known in firemanic and fraternal circles, died early today of a heart attack at his home here.

Violent Orthodox Church demonstrations against the Stoyadinovitch government occurred in Yugoslavia today, while in almost all Serb towns and villages Orthodox priests attacked the concordat with the Vatican and all those who had voted for it.

John Russo, 26-year-old student pilot, of Ridgefield, N. J., was injured fatally here tonight when the small Aeronca monoplane in which he was flying solo crashed near the CCC barracks at the southwest end of the Bendix Air Field.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 91.9, which compares with 91.8 a week before, 92.3 two weeks before, 92.3 three weeks before and 92.5 four weeks before. The average for the first week of April, 94.7, was the highest of the year to date; the lowest was 90.1,

J. Frederic Byers gave a luncheon today at Sandy Mount, his place on the ocean, for his brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. J. Denniston Lyon of Locust Valley, L. I., who have joined him and his daughter, Miss Nancy Byers, for a visit. Among the other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue Livingston, Mr.

Pounding the Royals' pitching for a total of 22 hits, the Newark Bears took both ends of a double-header from the second-place Montrealers today, 6-0 and 10-6, and moved into a 24%-game lead in the International League.

The marriage of Miss Ann Marie Sullivan, daughter of Commissioner John Sullivan of the State Liquor Authority of 2,268 Hampden Place, the Bronx, and the late Mrs. Sullivan, to Timothy J. Kavanagh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Kavanagh, also of New York, took place yesterday afternoon in the Church of St. Nicholas of Tolentine, the Bronx.
The marriage of Mrs. Helen Thompson Russell, daughter of Mrs. George Edwin Thompson of Brooksvale, Mount Carmel and this city, to William Wood Wren, son of Mrs. Oliver Wren of Frederick,

Ten thousand persons attended the four worship services held here today as the Dwight L. Moody centenary observance came to a climax with the close of the Northfield General Conference. This morning Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary,

Mrs. Cora G. Briggs Bowes, wife of A. K. Bowes, vice president of the People's National Bank and Trust Company of White Plains, died today in her home at 131 Longview Avenue after a long illness. She was 45 years old.
In an optimistic survey of the export industrial goods field, the Trade Research Institute estimates that this branch employs 2,000,000 operatives, which is about 500,000 above the figure for 1934.

Simon Elmore, 57 years old, of 37 Metcalf Street, Stapleton, S. I. who, according to police, confessed Saturday night to the murder of 4-year-old Joan Kuleba near South Beach, S. I., on Thursday, was formally charged with homicide yesterday at Staten Island police headquarters at St. George.

The French general wholesale price index at the end of July was much higher than at the end of June, the figure being 579 against 538. The rise was due chiefly to depreciation of the franc last month.

Thousands of ill and crippled men and women joined in the annual pilgrimage to the beaches yesterday to immerse themselves in water, on the holy day celebrated by Roman Catholics as the Feast of the Assumption.
Government authorities predicted today that the upward spiral of industry and commerce-which had leveled off in recent monthswould be resumed about the end of this year.

Chinese forces met their most severe attack today, starting at dawn, when twenty Japanese airplanes bombed the air fields near the city and Chinese entrenchments. Soon after the airplane raids Japanese warships and land forces shelled the Chinese defenses in Shanghai. Chinese artillery replied, but the fighting did not result in appreciable gains by either side.

A new form for annual reports for Class A and B electric utility companies, worked out by State and Federal regulatory agencies, was hailed today by Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, as a major step toward the goal of nation-wide uniformity in public utility accounting and reporting.
Colonel and Mrs. William Hayward gave a large luncheon today at Clarendon Court for Mr. and Mrs. Frederic: Sigrist and others of the English yachting contingent.

Because of Congressional fears of what may happen to the farm vote if agricultural prices decline as a result of the large crops, the country is in danger of being stampeded into a repetition of the loan, price guarantee and artificial shortage policy that has already done so much damage to the position of the American cotton farmer.
Viscount Hidemaro Konoye, who resigned from Japan's House of Peers to follow music, arrived today to show Americans how a Japanese would conduct their symphony orchestras.

The National Socialist leaders seem to have hopes of making pan-Germanism a political weapon to be employed in internal American politics. A revealing editorial appeared in the National Socialist Kurier, the official party organ for Stuttgart-center of the Reich's pan-German agitationwhich city Chancellor Adolf Hitler gave the title of "Headquarters of Germans Domiciled Abroad" and which is the seat of the Institute for Germanism Abroad.

Traveling by rail, steamer and bus, 2,500 pilgrims from widely scattered points assembled at the Mount of Atonement on the top of the mountain at the Graymoor Monastery, five miles north of here, this afternoon, to witness the "clothing" of twenty-six young men in the graybrown habit. of the Franciscan Friars of the Atonement.

The Santa Barbara four of California continued its winning streak today, defeating the Meadow Brook Pelicans, 13-3, in the final of the Rathborne Memorial Cup Tournament. A crowd of 2.000 witnessed the game.

A large number or East tiampton's Summer residents attended the exhibition of flower paintings by Mr. and Mrs. Albert Herter, held at their estate, the Creeks, this afternoon. The exhibition will also be open tomorrow.
While a crowd estimated by police at 130,000 cheered lustily, 12-yearold Robert Ballard of White Plains, WN. Y., won the fourth annual AllAmerican Soap Box Derby here today;

The shrill of fifes, the call of bugles and the roll of drums esounded yesterday as thirty-eight bands took part in the second annual drum and bugle corps competition of the New York Veterans of Foreign Wars at Manhattan Beach.

Michael W. Conway, for many years active here in the Republican party, died today at the age of 80. Under the direction of George W. Aldridge, Rochester political leader, Mr. Conway dominated politics in three wards.
A contingent of fifteen Maryknoll sisters left the mother house of the Catholic Foreign Mission Sisters of St. Dominic at the Maryknoll Seminary here tonight for duty in the Orient.

The Board of Trade's index of wholesale prices, based on the average of 1930 as 100, stood at 111.5 for July, compared with 110.6 for the preceding month and 93.6 for July, 1936. With the exception of the slight setback in June, therefore, prices have been rising continuously since March, 1936, and the present level is the highest since these records of the Board of Trade were begun in 1930.

Employers and employes were warned yesterday morning in a sermon at Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twentyninth Street, by the Rev. Dr. David Deforest Burrell of the First Presbyterian Church of Williamsport, Pa.,

The Cardinals' three most dependable pitchers of late-Lon Warneke, Johnson and Lefty Bob Wellandlooked very much like the Cards' second-stringers to the Pirates today as Pittsburgh swept a doubleheader, 8 to 4 and 4 to 0.

Ten members of an American Oriental tour party that was caught in the Shanghai fighting prepared today to depart home Thursday without their leader, Dr. Robert Karl Reischauer of Princeton University. He was killed by a bomb explosion yesterday.

A smart-passing Fort Hamilton quartet put up a splendid battle before succumbing to the league-leading Evergreen Farms team, 7-6, yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn in an Eastern circuit game. Undefeated in six starts, the Eatontown, N. J., combination was hard pressed before triumphing, Milton Untermeyer Jr.'s short thrust early in an extra period ending the struggle.
The American Federation of Labor's drive to organize performaers in radio was opened yesterday with the announcement that thirty-five stars of stage, screen,

George R. Bott, chief engineer and a director of the Norma-Hoffmann Bearings Corporation, manufacturers of anti-friction bearings, of Stamford, Conn., died at his Summer home here yesterday of a heart attack. He was 58 years old.

Frank A. Hancock of Polytechnic Preparatory School in Dyker Heights, New York, and leader of the Bretton Woods choir boys during twenty-eight Summers of choral singing in the White Mountains, brought his youthful charges this evening to sing in the Chase Barn Theatre as the second feature of

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday the reorganization of its engineering department, by the appointment of Othmar H. Ammann as Director of Engineering and John C. Evans as chief engineer.

Representative Martin J. Kennedy, in a statement issued last night at his Summer home in Spring Lake, N. J., challenged Thomas E. Dewey to produce proof of an alliance between Tammany Hall and the underworld.
Mgr. Edward J. Ellard of the Church of the Assumption of this city died at the rectory this morning after a short illness. Mgr. Ellard was born in New York City 65 years ago.

The city and county of Santa Barbara collaborated today by marking the second anniversary of the death of Will Rogers. Residents gathered about a chuck wagon at the camp of Rancheros Visitadores in the heart of this city and spent an hour swapping Rogers yarns after a brief service of reverence.

Dan Hinckley Arnold, retired importer and brother of Dorothy Arnold, whose mysterious disappearance in December, 1910, has remained unsolved, died yesterday at Framdan, his estate here. His age was 49.

With simple ceremonies, to which the band and t a troop detachment of the scarletcoated Welch Guards lent color, the new chapel of Brookwood Cemetery f was dedicated today to the memory of the 568 American soldiers and sailors of the World War buried there.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,719,266,400. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:
Two important transfers of East Side properties in the midtown district have been concluded, according to papers just filed in the Register's office.

Mass was celebrated openly here and in Madrid today for the first time in Spanish Government territory since the Government closed all Catholia churches at the outbreak of the civil war thirteen months ago.

State officials, members of the Supreme Court and of the present and preceding Legislatures gathered today at Old Bennington for the dedication of the old First Church as "Vermont's Colonial Shrine." The edifice, successor to the first house of public worship in the New Hampshire Grants which later became the State of Vermont, was built in 1806.

Another impressive exhibition of polo power and finesse was given by the San Jose quartet on the Meadow Brook Club's Cochrane Field today as the visitors from Argentina galloped to a 14-to-2 victory over a 26-goal Delray combination before 3,000 spectators.

Mrs. Joseph Friedman of New York was robbed this afternoon of a diamond ring she valued at $3,500 by a bandit who was waiting in the vestibule when she returned to the apartment of her sister, Mrs. Edward L. Siegel. whom she is visiting.

Aerial warfare raged throughout the lower Yangtze Valley yesterday as Japanese bombing squadrons raided Nanking, Hangehow and even distant Nanchang, in Kiangsi Province, and many Chinese aviation and army bases in Kiangsu and Chekiang Provinces.

Congress has granted the Pacific Refrigeration Company permission to import, duty free, ammonia for its plant at Puntarenas. Operation of the plant was held up because the company contended it was unable to operate profitably and pay the duty.

Dein Bacher. designer and fur fashion originator, addition to shop in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Levin Bros., importers of notions and novelties, store in 3 W. 20th St.; the M. M Shulman Co., broker. Catherine Gilberg and Dells Goldber millinery, store in 137 W. 72d St.; Shirley Levine ano Florence Isaacs, dresses, in 238 W. 72d St.; Slawson Hobbs, brokers.

The engagement of Miss Mary Elizabeth Thatcher, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles J. Thatcher of this place and New York, to T. Philbrick Hasler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Hasler of Little Silver, has been announced by her parents.

The United States Steel Corporation Officeially confirmed yesterday the sale to the Dominion Steel and Coal Company of a group of Canadian properties which are to be transferred to the new owners on Sept. 1.

A medical report declaring that Morton D. Wainwright, 72, of Winthrop, ardent Townsend plan advocate, arrested on a charge of sending threatening letters to President Roosevelt, is sane will be filed in Federal court tomorrow by Richard B. McSweeney, chief probation officer.

Mrs. Elizabeth Boody Firuski of Windy Hill, Taconic, Conn., was married yesterday at noon to Dr. Joseph A. Schumpeter of Cambridge, Mass., Professor of Economics at Harvard University, in the Community Church of New York by the associate minister, the Rev. Leon Rosser Land.

Eugenie Leontovich appeared at the Westchester Playhouse tonight in her favorite role, the famous opera star in Edward Sheldon's play "Romance." It was the ninth production at the Barn Theatre this Summer and a capacity audience was present.

3d St. 133 W. 25x100; Alice Peppe to Livia Peppe, 30 W 11th St (50 cents). 15th St, 434 E, 25x103; Alfred H. Lang to Barbara Reinhart, 1,998 Morris Ave; mtge. $10,500 ($1). 48th St, 163 W, 25x105.3x25.2x108.7; Greenwich Savings Bank to Solmee Realty Co, 570 7th Ave ($70).

The exquisite furnishings, including many antiques and valuable pieces of American and English furniture, rare silver pieces and Chinese porcelains which filled the residence of the late Marie Louise le Bel Knight (Mrs. Edward Collings Knight Jr., formerly of Philadelphia) went under the auctioneer's hammer this afternoon.

The American national sport of baseball; which looks like the simplest thing imaginable from the sheltered confines of the press boxes at the Polo Grounds, Yankee Stadium and Ebbets Field, proved to be a highly involved and intricate game today as the Brooklyn and New York chapters of the Baseball Writers Association met in the annual battle for the John J. McGraw memorial trophy.
Jimmy Dykes, manager of the White Sox, signed today to pilot the club in 1938 and 1939. Dykes, 41 years old, assumed management of the club in 1934, succeeding Lew Fonseca.

The Mack Acceptance Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Mack Trucks, Inc., filed yesterday in the Supreme Court an application for permission to dissolve voluntarily. The petition said the company was wholly solvent and proposed to transfer all its property to its parent.

In the absence of Premier Camille Chautemps, as well as Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos, Alexis Leger, general secretary of the Foreign Ministry, is in charge of French diplomatic action in the Far East. M. Leger spent a number of years in China and is considered the best French expert in this field.

The report of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries (exclusive of the operations of all British and two American subsidiaries but including income received from such companies) for the twelve months to June 30 shows a consolidated net loss of $2,318,962 after provision for retirements, amortization, depreciation, Federal and Dominion Income taxes, minority interest charges and other expenses.
Strong but unconfirmed rumors are circulating here to the effect that serious disorders have broken out in the Iraq Army.

Thirteen scholarships and fellowships, carrying a total cash value of $6,600, were awarded today to students at Harvard University. The awards were made as follows: Class of 1897 Scholarships-Branford P. Milar of Cambridge, Mass.

Although it was one of the hotter days of the Summer, harbingers of approaching Autumn made an appearance in the form of flying footballs today at the Blue Hill Country Club as the New York Giants, twenty-seven strong, reported to Coach Steve Owen for their initial drill.

Onethird of the applicants for road tests during the first six months of this year failed to qualify for motor vehicle operators' licenses, William F. Dinneen, deputy commissioner of motor vehicles, said today.

Quincy Howe, editor for the publishing firm of Simon Schuster, has written a study of British propaganda in the United States, declaring that a "British network" is manipulated by a few key persons in London, Washington and New York.

Joseph Brody, Jewish composer and choirmaster and former associate of the late Cantor Joseph Rosenblatt, died yesterday at his home, 130-14 229th Street, Laurelton, L. I. He was 60 years old. At his death Mr. Brody was choirmaster at the Montefiore Congregation, Macy and Hewitt Places, the Bronx.

The unsold balance of the 60,828 common shares of the Cornell-Dubilier Electric Corporation recently offered to stockholders of the Dubilier Condenser Corporation and the Cornell Manufacturing Company, Inc.,

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted the following securities to the list: Commonwealth Edison Company new capital stock, par value $25, issued in accordance with notices to stockholders of the company which provide that each share of old capital stock, par value $100, shall be split up into four shares of new capital stock;
Seven-hit pitching by Rollie Stiles was too much for the Rochester Red Wings tonight and they dropped the first engagement of their series with- the Jersey City Giants, 7 to 3.

" A continuous flow of fashion inspiration" has been the product of closer understanding between Paris style creators and American apparel manufacturers and retailers, according to W. M. Holmes, vice president and general manager of Bonwit Teller, Inc., who returned from Europe yesterday on the Normandie after viewing the midseason Paris collections.

Bumper grain crops throughout the United States are being reflected by a rush of business for the farm-equipment companies, with orders in some divisions so heavy that production cannot keen up with them.

Settlmeent in full of the Federal Government's obligation for the Grand Central Postoffice Station at 452 Lexington Avenue, New York City, was recommended today by the House Appropriations Committee, which included an amount of $10,107,065.94 for this purpose in the Third Deficiency Bill it reported.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 11:

President Lazaro Cardenas, in a speech at Yucatan late last night, said that he would cut his own salary and the salaries of other high government officials next year. The President declared this was being done to permit raising salaries of school teachers.

The following substitutions of candidates for party nominations were filed yesterday with the Board of Elections: Abram Goodman for Republican nomination for Municipal Court Justice, Fifth Manhattan District, in place of Justice Joseph S. Rosalsky.
Business was described yesterday as unusually brisk at the offices of the Motor Vehicle Bureau in the five boroughs where the new operators' license forms were being issued for the first time.

Kings County Judge George W. Martin directed a jury yesterday to acquit Anthony Boccaetti, 25 years old, of 1,040 Seventieth Street, Brooklyn, of a charge of seconddegree robbery after the State's two principal witnesses testified that they had never seen the defendant before.

A large apartment house in the Bronx changed hands yesterday when the five - and - a - half - story building at 2,676 Grand Concourse was sold by the A. F. Building Corporation to an investing client of Berg Berk, attorneys.

Maurice Barnett Jr. has joined the S. W. Gordon Company as head of the retail department. Alexander Eisemann Co. announced yesterday that Howard T. Lassner had become co-manager of the 1,501 Broadway branch and that Edward Ravener had joined the firm as a customers' man at its 29 East Fordham Road office.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals heard argument yesterday and reserved decision on-the appeal of the State Attorney General's office from Federal Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo's temporary injunction restraining State authorities from interfering with the operation of the Nassau County Kennel Club.

Eddie Cantor was named president of the American Federation of Radio Artists yesterday to head the American Federation of Labor's organizational campaign among performers and announcers in the broadcasting industry.

Japan ordered its embassy at Nanking closed and its consuls throughout China withdrawn today. Officials said it was "not yet known" whether this constituted severance of diplomatic relations with China.
David Nemerov, executive vice president of Russeks, Fifth Avenue, returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie from the Paris Exposition and London, where he attended the fashion openings.

T'S too bad about those Yankees. They are I only ten games in the lead, poor fellows. But there's no immediate need of taking up a collection for Colonel Jacob Ruppert so that he can go into the market and buy half a dozen more players for Marse Joe McCarthy. They can worry along with what they have and trust to luck, somehow.

The Ohio Public Utilities Commission issued an order yesterday requiring thirty-four independent telephone companies to reduce from an unlimited period to two years the 25 cents monthly charge for hand-set telephones.

Two members of the visiting American ski team, Richard H. Durrance, United States open champion and leading runner of the 1936 Olympic team, and Dave Bradley of Dartmouth College, have been injured in accidents.

Mrs. Anna Hahn accepted service in Hamilton County jail today on indictments accusing her of slaying with poison two elderly Germans. Gone was the laughing, nonchalant air she displayed last Friday, when her attorneys lost a legal move to obtain her release on a habeas corpus. She did not smile.

Six hundred children were guests of the Mayor's Community Planning Committee at the second annual Kiddies' Day bus outing held yesterday at Rockaway Beach. Members of the outing committee were from Blissville, Laurel Hill, Thomson Hill, Sunnyside and Woodside.

Retired Lieutenant Oscar Hoeffling, formerely a member of Engine 293. residing at 86-02 91st Ave., Woodhaven, Queens, died Aug. 13. Funeral will take place from Walker's Funeral Parlor, 86-07 Jamaica Ave., Woodhaven, at 10 A. M., Tuesday, Aug. 17, thence to St. Matthew's Church, 85-37 Ninety-sixth St., Woodhaven. Interment at Evergreen Cemetery.

Mrs. and Mrs. P. J. Carroll, who set out by dog-team from their Ootsa, B. C., home on March 9, 1936, to advertise Tweedsmuir National Park in the Pacifio coast Province, were in Montreal today at the 5,500-mile mark in a projected coast-to-coast trip from Ootsa. From here they plan to go east to the Maritimes.

Among the many luncheons before the races today were those at the Gideon Putnam given by Mrs. W. Scott Cameron of Southampton for Mr. and Mrs. Blaine Webb of New York and Palm Beach; by Mr. and Mrs. A. W. Johnson for Major and Mrs. Thomas McCreery, and by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Bishop Shepherd of New York.

Three convictions within eighteen months for reckless driving or comparable violations of motor vehicle laws make revocation and surrender of a driving license mandatory, Attorney General Bennett ruled today. The opinion was. asked for by the Motor Vehicle Bureau, which cited provisions of the law which became effective May 22 last through a section enacted by the last Legislature.

Premier Duplessis of Quebec, in a public address at Knowlton today, declared that striking workers in the Quebec textile industry had undoubtedly been exploited by their employers, but he warned them that he would not countenance sabotage or intimidation.

Peter Walter Claassen, Professor of Entomology at Cornell since 1926, died today of a heart ailment after a week's illness. He was 51 years old. Professor Claassen first came to Cornell as a graduate student seeking his Ph. D. degree and instructing in biology.

Fresh dissension has broken out recently among. the followers of Father Divine, according to an affidavit filed yesterday in Supreme Court. The reported rift is being made the basis for a renewal of the move to have receivers appointed for all property of the Peace Mission movement which Divine heads.

Miss Kay Winthrop and Mrs. Virginia Rice Johnson, both of Boston, led a parade of favorites through first-round play at the Essex County Club's annual women's invitation tennis tournament today, but last-minute withdrawals robbed the affair of some of its strongest players.

In a letter to the Board of Estimate James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx, suggested yesterday that the Mayor be authorized to appoint a commission of psychiatrists, medical men, clergymen and social workers to cope with "this dreadful problem" of sex crimes. Mr. Lyons recommended an initial appropriation of $25,000 to finance the commission.

Wheat showed a much easier undertone today, with the markets in Winnipeg and Liverpool leading the decline. Winnipeg lost 1 3/4 to 2% cents a bushel and Liverpool declined 1 3/4 to 2 5/8 cents on reports of highly beneficial rains in parts of Australia.

Max Berger, a wizened man of 70, sat in a subway train early last evening, his right hand darting up and down as if he were stitching on a garment. Every time his hand came up he would chortle with glee.

A. L. Ferguson today sailed Buza to victory by 88 seconds over Vice Commodore Thomas W. Russell's Katydid in the Twenty-six Foot class as the annual three-day cruise of the Fishers Island Yacht Club ended. The fleet raced here from Three-Mile Harbor at East Hampton. L. I.

Financing of a proposed building for a downtown site was announced yesterday by the Charles F. Noyes Company, Which obtained for Beardleston Woerz a loan of $400,000 for erection of a three-story and basement commercial building at Charles, West Tenth and Washington Streets.

Maurice Mandelbaum of Harris Maurice Mandelbaum, Inc., operators, purchased yesterday the fivestory apartment and store building at 323 West Fifty-seventh Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, from the Burgess estate. The house,

A combination airplane and steamship service between Chicago and China was announced today by Harold Crary, traffic vice president of United Air Lines, which is cooperating with Pan American Airways and Pacific steamship companies in providing the all-expense trip.

Included in the deals in New Jersey reported yesterday was the sale of the one-story business building on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 791-795 Bergenline Avenue, Union City. The estate of Edwin B. Young was the seller. Liberty Realty Company, Inc., purchased the property for investment. J. I. Kislak, Inc.,

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 10,000, including 2,500 directs. The market was 10c to 25c lower than Friday's average; top, S13.45; bulk good and choice 180-230 pounds, $13-$13.35; 240-300 pounds, $12-$12.85;

An older has been issued by the Securitfes and Exchange Commission approving a declaration by the Kansas Power Company covering the issue and sale of $376,000 of first mortgage twenty-year 5 per cent bonds. Series A, due on March 1,
It is but a matter of months since transatlantic flight was still an adventure and one, despite the rapid improvement of aircraft and of engines, weighted with heavy risks.

The trial of the Rev. Verlynn Sprague, pastor of the Memorial Methodist Church of Nepperhan Heights on a charge of disorderly conduct was adjourned here today in Yonkers City Court until Monday after an informal hearing before Judge Charles W. Boote.

The Senate Judiciary Committee, after a stormy two-hour session, voted approval today of the nomination of Senator Hugo L. Black of Alabama as an associate justice of the Supreme Court. Senator Barkley,...

Several sales of residential plots in Yonkers featured the deals involving Westchester properties reported yesterday. In the Colonial Park section of that city three plots on Colonial Parkway North were sold and each will be improved with a residence.

The Associates InvestmentCompany of this city reported today a profit of $1,701,020, or $4.07 a share, applicable to the 418,152 shares of common stock outstanding for the six months to June 30. Gross business in the six months amounted to $83,047,618.
The Colonial Parliament convened today in a special session to consider a five-year contract with Furness, Withy Co., Ltd., for a steamship service to New York.

Michael J. Mulhearn, 82 years old, active in Democratic politics here for a half-century, died at his home here last night following a stroke suffered last Tuesday. Born in this city, he retired six years ago following fifty-four years of service with the Singer Manufacturing Company here.

The marriage of Miss Sarah Lee Perot, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Perot of 2 Beekman Place, this city, and Washington, to Harvey Wright Branigar Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey W. Branigar of Chicago, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents here. The Rev. Frank Moss performed the ceremony.

Holding tight to a brown paper bag that contained gifts for a cousin she expected to visit in the Bronx, Josephine Quinn, 8 years old, enjoyed the hospitality of the police of the East Fifty-first Street station for four hours yesterday while detectives tried to find her home.

The refugee relief committee here tackled yesterday the problem of accommodating the million persons who had fled into the foreign concessions from outlying districts. A hundred thousand of these are homeless and 40,000 are even without shelter, roaming the streets and sleeping in the open.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a supplemental summary of transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations for June, which included also some delayed reports for earlier months which had been held for correction.
Another social experiment suffered a setback today when the House Appropriations Committee refused to approve $20,000,000 for the new program to aid farm tenants.

A special meeting of stockholders of Technicolor, Inc., has been called for Sept. 9 to consider an increase in authorized common stock from 1,000,000 to 1,500,000 shares, without par value, none of which shares would be subject to any preemptive rights.

Lack of wind caused postponement of the second of the five scheduled races for the Sears Cup off the Pequot Yacht Club today after the Jane from the Richmond County Yacht Club of Staten Island had captured the opening six-mile race.

The House Banking and Currency Committee made public today its favorable report on the Wagner-Steagall Housing bill, now considerably changed, and urged its immediate enactment as a means of clearing slums and providing clean, bright quarters.
ARNOLD--Dan Hinckley, 49, Aug. 14. in Washington, Conn., husband of Mildred Culver. Funeral Tuesday, Aug. 17, 11:30 at St. John's Church, Washington, Conn. Burial Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, N. Y.
Veteran horsemen appealed today to town officials to save a cement monument to a famous race horse on the historic Charter Oak Park racing grounds here. The park was sold recently.

The men of China and Japan fought on and died today in a ceaseless battle that rocked Shanghai. There was no way accurately to estimate the dead and dying that have littered the outlying scenes of war since misplaced Chinese aerial bombs killed more than 1,000 and wounded even more than that in the International areas on Saturday.

Straight from the China war zone, through which he passed en route home, President Manuel Quezon was greeted here today with the usual tumultuous welcome of the Filipino people, to whom he reiterated that his petition for independence in 1938 or 1939 still stood.
Marcel Thil, the Parisian boxer who is recognized by several European commissions as the world's middleweight champion, arrived in New York yesterday aboard the French liner Normandie. Thil,
Australia's loss of trade through the staples dispute with Japan amounted to more thah [Pound]6,000,000.

Harold Bradley, 7 years old, of 2A Edgewater Camp Park, the Bronx, fell off a pier into Long Island Sound yesterday at Edgewater Camp Park, a Summer colony. John Madeau, 10, of 95C Edgewater Camp Park,
Describing himself as "broke, but not discouraged," Francis 0. French, father-in-law of John Jacob Astor 3d, tonight announced his intention of "writing himself" out of his financial difficulties.

In accordance with agreements reached over the week-end in New York between the Textile Workers Organizing Committee, C. I. O. affiliate directing the general strike' in the silk and rayon industry and the employers, 2,000 striking workers were ordered yesterday by the union to report for work' today.

Estate, about $11,000. To St. Nicholas Roman Catholic Church, 135 2d St., $2,000; three specific bequests; Sisters, Servants of Mary, 3,237 Rawlins Ave., Bronx, residue. Mother Corazon Lopez, Superior of the order executrix.

Professor William Crain Raymond, headmaster of Stevens-Hoboken Academy, died today of a heart ailment at his home here. He had been ill for more than a??ear. Born in Oxford, N. Y., the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Crain Raymond, he was graduated from the Norwich (N. Y.) Academy and the University of Rochester.

Representative J. Parnell Thomas of Allendale, N. J., a Republican, blocked House consideration today of the Helium Export Bill for the second time and asserted that he would fight any attempt to pass it under a special rule.

As an aftermath of the recent charges of rowdyism hurled by Bolton Road property owners against campers at Hearthstone Park, the Lake George Association at its annual meeting today named James L. Hand chairman of a committee to seek an abatement of the alleged nuisance.

Returning to theatrical production this season after an absence which has extended since January, 1936, and "O Evening Star," will be Harry Moses, who has acquired a new play by one Richard Carlson, an actor, which he intends to have ready for Broadway early in October.

Establishment of a national registration bureau for shorthand reporters to facilitate selection of qualified candidates for court posts was urged yesterday by Grant M. Raymond of Los Angeles at the opening business session of the thirty-eighth convention of the National Shorthand Reporters Association at the Hotel Astor.

Aside from the various candidates for county office and for borough office, there are three municipal officials for whom the people of this city as a whole will vote in the primaries and on Election Day. One of these is, of course, the Mavor.

To determine whether it should certify the result of the recent election of Horn Hardart employes conducted by the State Labor Relations Board on their choice of collective bargaining agencies, the board held a hearing yesterday at 80 Center Street.

Two events of interest to Summer residents of the lower Berkshires will take place this week at the Girls Service League's Hillcrest Camp at Twin Lakes near here. Tomorrow afternoon a bridge party and program of outdoor sports will be held for the benefit of the camp.
In some of the more totalitarian countries they have a new and simple test for insanity. It consists of calling the dictator a

Fear that the sale at one time of 2,645 Newark properties for unpaid taxes would demoralize the real estate market in this city was expressed in a statement today by Edward Cohan, president of the Essex County Building and Loan League.
An admittedly bewildered membership of the House passed today the Administration bill to plug loopholes in the income tax laws by which wealthy individuals have been able to avoid and evade taxes.

Miss Style, Inc., coats and suits, additional space in 230 W. 38th St.; Onyx Pleating Novelty Co., pleating and stitching. additional space in 330 W. 38th St.; James Bayer. piece goods, in 270 W. 38th St.; Slender-Maid Dresses, Inc., in 101 W. 37th St.; Herman Boskowitz, textiles, in 270 W. 39th St.; Unity Frocks,

Oliver E. Sweet, director of the finance division of the Interstate Commerce Commission, told Philip J. Roosevelt of 30 Pine Street, New York, chairman of the reorganization committee of the Minneapolis St. Louis Railway, in a letter dated Saturday,

The Federal Reserve Board, taking cognizance of the undeclared war in China, authorized national banks today to suspend operation of their branches in foreign countries when "disturbed conditions" arise.

The stock market suffered yesterday its first decline of any consequence in more than a week. It was the first lower closing since Wednesday. Although the selling movement was light, it enveloped most sections of the list, with steel, copper and railway issues in particular showing substantial losses.

Germany made a new bid in the international competition for airplane trade in the North Atlantic when the seaplane Nordmeer alighted in Long Island Sound yesterday with a bag of mail from Europe. Shortly after the arrival of the German plane a friendly competitor, the Pan American Clipper, took off on its third flight for Europe.
