Mrs. Julia Healy, 68 years old, who registered at the American Women's Association Club Hotel, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street, at 5:10 P. M. yesterday, jumped to her death from the twenty-first-floor hall window thirty minutes later. The police listed her death as a suicide.

Despite reports of a "definitely developing- shortage" of registered pharmacists, warnings against any lowering of the requirements for registration were given yesterday at the opening of the eighty-fifth annual convention of the American Pharmaceutical Association and related groups in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Seventy-year-old Miss Annie Harrison Lewis tried again today to prevent the HOLC from evicting her from her home. Seeking to raise funds to pay back part of the $3,700 mortgage on the rambling house, she applied through a friend to the Wake County Welfare Department for an old-age pension.

Automobile production increased sharply last week against a downward seasonal trend, and the adjusted index has spurted to 158.7 from 117.8 (revised). This is in all-time high for the period back to January, 1929, which is covered by the index.

Stocks closed lower in light trading; turnover, 618,690 shares. Bonds irregularly lower with Government obligations firmer; transactions, $5,216,525. Curb Exchange Stocks lower in dull trading; 188,350 shares traded. Bonds irregular; sales, $834,000.

Activity in apartment leasing for Fall occupancy continues at a rapid pace, reports from brokers in scattered parts of, the city revealed yesterday. Many leases in the Greenwich Village and Washington Square section were among the large list of
About two hundred shots were fired at dawn today as Catholic and Socialist students clashed at the University of Mexico, only four blocks from the central zocalo (or main) plaza. No one was injured,

The United States, which formerly obtained the bulk of its mercury from Spain, was Italy's largest single customer for the first quarter of the current year, the Chemical Division of the Department of Commerce reported today.

Two former emloyes of the Weirton Steel Company testified today that they were discharged after they had refused to sign pledges of loyalty to the company and of opposition to the Committee for Industrial Organization put before them by their foremen.

Dr. Eugene Colligan, president of Hunter College, revealed while visiting Selznick International that he will add a course in motion picture production to the university's curriculum. While no date was disclosed for the installation of the course, Dr. Colligan stated that it would embrace every department of picture making.

Miss Solita Arbib, 21 years old, of 112 West Seventy-second Street, was selected yesterday from 652 contestants for the Bloomingdale Scholarship at the School for Fashion Careers, 9 Rockefeller Plaza. The course takes a year and has a value of $700.

Foreign trade figures for July issued by the British Board of Trade are as follows: Total imports f85,500,000; exports of British products [Pound]47,560,000; re-exports [Pound]6,800,000; total exports f54,360,000; excess of imports [Pound]31,140,000.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Johnes of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Johnes, to Victor Stanley Reynolds, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley V. Reynolds, also of Newark.
Four more world records for driving power boats were hung up today by daredevil pilots on the North Shrewsbury River in the closing third day of the national sweepstakes regatta.
The booming of army guns and the roar of airplane motors echoed across the reclaimed Flushing Meadows yesterday afternoon at exercises dedicating the "theme center" of the New York World's Fair.
Maine voters rejected in a Statewide referendum today a proposed 1 per cent retail sales tax to finance old-age assistance and education equalization.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It is difficult to be impressed by one of the chief arguments made against the appointment of Senator Black to the Supreme Court.

Repeating the rambling, incoherent story he told at the time of his arrest, Joseph Cortese, 38 years old, was arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Solomon in Brooklyn Felony Court for murdering his wife, Shirley, 28, with a hammer in their home at 74 Avenue U, Brooklyn, on Sunday. He was held without bail for a further hearing tomorrow.

Biennial convention, Sigma Nu fraternity, Waldorf-Astoria, 10 A. M. Address by Dr. Orren C. Hormell. Dr. LeRoy E. Kimball will preside. Dedication, Holy Cross Church playground, Forty-third Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, noon. Speakers: Mayor La Guardia, Borough President Samuel Levy, Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

Pleas of guilty to smuggling and conspiracy indictments returned recently against fifty-four persons accused of bringing $1,000,000 worth of diamonds illegally into this country were entered yesterday by five of the defendants.

Inclusion of gas interests in the membership of the Electrical Association of New York, Inc., and a change in the name to the Electrical and Gas Association of New York, Inc., was voted yesterday at a meeting at the Electrical Institute at Grand Central Palace.

Simon Elmore, who, according to the police, confessed Saturday that he killed 4-year-old Joan Kuleba in a deserted shack in a marsh near South Beach, S. I., was indicted for first-degree murder yesterday by the Richmond County Grand Jury after sixteen minutes' deliberation.

Martin H. Meaney, Fifth Deputy Police Commissioner, released statistics yesterday showing a decrease in the number df those killed or injured in automobile accidents during the last week as compared with the same period in 1936.
A new governmental reorganization bill was approved today by the Senate Reorganization Committee and will be formally reported by Senator Byrnes, chairman.

Bernard W. Kearney, national commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, and Harry W. Colmery, commander of the American Legion, returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie after attending the dedication of the
With five of the America's Cup size sloops ready to race, the New York Yacht Club cruise will get under way tomorrow and yachtsmen gathered here tonight talked, about the spectacle of the century.

The George Washington Bridge set a record for traffic last Sunday that was second only to the one made in the twenty-four hours immediately following its opening six years ago. A total of 54,030 motor oars crossed the bridge on Sunday, according to the Port Authority.

Licensed and junior engineers employed on New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company vessals have been ordered by the National Labor Relations Board to vote their preference, for purposes of collective bargaining, between the United Licensed Officers of the U. S. A. and the National Marine Engineers' Beneficial Association.

Mrs. Wright D. Goss Jr. of the Baltusrol Country Club led the field of fifty in the qualifying round of the annual Shawnee women's invitation golf tournament today with a fine card of 41, 37-78. Mrs. Goss played flawless golf, going out one stroke over women's par and coming home in perfect figures.

Finishing powerfully through the stretch, the On Watch filly Watchcase today captured the $3,115 Kentucky Claiming Stakes by three lengths before Mr. and Mrs. Alfred E. Smith and one of the largest Monday crowds in years. The Sage brothers, A. G. C.

While a truck driver dozed on the seat of his cab at 5:15 A. M. yesterday outside of 52 West Fifteenth Street, waiting for the building to open to deliver some merchandise, two men held him up at pistol point and forced him to drive to Park Place, between West and Washington Streets.

Miss Lillian Elizabeth Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Edwin Taylor of this place; Wings Neck, Pocasset, and Runaway Lodge, Farmington, Me., has chosen the evening of Sept. 18 as the date for her marriage to Norman Middleton Appleyard Jr. The ceremony will take place in the First Church of Newton here and will be performed by the rector, the Rev. Russell Morrison Boynton.

Forty-three yearlings passed through the sales ring tonight as light bidding accounted for a total expenditure of $24,625, an average of only $573. The highest price was $3,000, paid by the Millsdale Stable of Chicago, for a chestnut colt by Greenock out of Char Lady. This makes the youngster a half brother to Red Ensign and Santa Marita. The seller was H. C. Ragan.
Richard Strauss has completed his new opera, "Friedenstag," and it will be performed next Summer in the Munich State Opera. The librettos are by Josef Gregor of Vienna.

Two Commissars of the Soviet Union were deposed today and their successors named. Two Vice Commissars also were ousted and others appointed. Gregory T. Grinko, Commissar of Finance, was relieved of his duties and replaced by Vlas Y. Chubar. A. B. Grizhmanoff, little known in politics, was named as Mr. Chubar's assistant.

Application by the International Safety Razor Corporation to withdraw its no-par value, class B, common stock from listing and registration on the Boston Stock Exchange has been granted by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Twelve "color highlights" in woolens for late Fall and early Spring have been isued to members of the Textile Color Card Association, Margaret Hayden Rorke, managing director, announced yesterday.

EUROPE IN ARMS, by Liddell Hart. (Random House, $2.50.) A leading expert discusses European armaments today. EPILOGUE: A CRITICAL SUMMARY, edited by Laura Riding and Robert Graves. (Random House, $2.50.) A volume of criticism.

Declaring that "it is only the clod who may speak of his education in the past tense," Surrogate James A. Delehanty, in a decision, ruled yesterday that a "proper education" is an unending, life-long process of development.

A crew representing the Shinnecock Yacht Club, skippered by Miss Elisabeth Guile, assumed the lead today in the annual Morgan Bowl series when she piloted her boat to two firsts and a second in the three races sailed. The Westhampton crew is second.

Divorces were granted here today to Mrs. Margery Jarvis Ferris from William H. Ferris of 179 East Seventy-ninth Street, New York, and to Mrs. Patricia Allen Gott from Donald Hutchinson Gott of Rye, N. Y.

Exports of medicinal and pharmaceutical preparations from the United States gained almost 30 per cent in value during the first half of the current year compared to the corresponding period of 1936 and were only 19 per cent below the peak level in the same period of 1929, the Department of Commerce announced today.

A suit was instituted yesterday in Supreme Court by the Municipal Civil Service Commission to determine whether the canvassers to be appointed by the Board of Elections to tally the vote for members of the new City Council shall be required to pass a civil service examination.

Smoke from a burning air compressor backed into the Eighth Avenue subway station at Columbus Circle just before 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon. It delayed trains about twelve minutes and sent fumes into the street, but there was no sign of panic.

The fishing over the past weekend, according to reports from all parts of Long Island as well as the New Jersey and Maryland ports, was just about as good as anyone could want, and most anglers want a lot.
Congress learned today of Agriculture Department hopes of turning the southwestern "dust bowl" into a huge pasture.

Stan Horne of Ottawa today putted himself toward his second Canadian Professional Golfers Association championship with a sparkling 144 that placed him at the top of the heap at the half-way stage of the seventy-two-hole tournament.

Unanimous House passage of the Administration's eight-point tax loophole plugging bill, after only two hours' consideration and without bothering to have it read, set a faster pace today for the adjournment drive,

An unidentified man, who pretended to faint in the Harlem Opera House, 211 West 125th Street, to enable his companion to snatch purses yesterday afternoon, caused a stampede for the exits by more than 1,000' persons when some one -shouted "Fire!" During the commotion, which lasted nearly twenty minutes, twenty-five persons were slightly injured. None of them required hospital attention.

Baltimore's Washington Monument was the scene of a seventh suicide today when an 18-year-old girl leaped from the top of the 180-foot shaft. Harriet Poole, a Y. M. C. A. business school student, remained conscious for almost two hours before she died in Mercy Hospital.

The gallery at the Newport Casino today for the initial play in the annual invitation tennis tournament was much larger than usual. All of the boxes in the big grandstand and practically all of the umbrella boxes were occupied.

Trading was only fair to slow. Price trends were mixed, steer hinds and ribs steady to strong, steer cuts mostly steady to higher, veal steady, calf weak to lower. lamb higher, pork loins steady to lower, other fresh pork cuts steady to higher. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be steady with last Friday, veal and calf weak, lamb strong to higher, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

A lone, mysterious light on top of the Soviet Consulate, on the Whangpoo waterfront, one block from the Japanese Consulate, was spotted by Chinese gunners and used as a guide for a firing range of the Japanese area last night. It was the only light burning in the Hongkew district of the city.

Samuel L. Fox, probably the last surviving member of the crew that manned the history-making frigate U. S. S. Constitution, died today at the age of 75. Just eight months ago, the veteran sailor and peace officer told the story of his life in the navy of the past century.

Six buses filled with 190 members of the Workers Alliance left at midnight from the organization's quarters, 101 West Twenty-eighth Street, for Washington, D. C., where they plan a demonstration in support of the Schwellenbach-Allen resolution to halt dismissals of needy WPA workers.
Sunbronzed Mrs. Lenore Kight Wingard added the world's professional open water half-mile swimming championship to her world's halfmile pool record late today.

The will of Eleanor Elkins Rice, leaving an estate estimated variously at from $5,000,000 to $50,000,000, was filed today in Probate Court. Under its terms a trust fund was set up, the income going to her husband, Dr. Alexander Hamilton Rice, and to her children on his death.

Arthur Byron. making his first appearance with the Lakewood Players in four seasons, is an urbane and amusing parent in "The Prodigal Father," William E. Barry's new comedy which was staged for the first time last night at the Lakewood Theatre.

United States Senator Royal S. Copeland, candidate for both the Democratic and Republican nominations for Mayor, yesterday rejected "good government" as the issue in the local Mayoralty campaign, stating that everybody was for good government, "just like the Ten Commandments."
On His Own Application PATROLMAN-Matthew J. Cullen, 106th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 27, 1911.

Dr. Frederick D. Bullock of Larchmont, N. Y., pathologist at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York, died suddenly during the night at a Dubois tourist camp. His age was 58. Dr. Bullock, his wife and a nephew were returning to New York from a visit at Lexington, Ky. The body will be sent to his home in Lexington.

Miss Angela Lertora, 32 years old, of 106 Thompson Street, New York City, was killed in an automobile accident late this morning while on the way to visit her sister, Mrs. Louis Darco of Post Avenue, Lyndhurst. Cars operated by her father, JOhn Lertora, and Armando Ottalagan of Newark, collided at PasSafe Avenue and Allwood Road, Clifton.

E. Donald Sterner, State Highway Commissioner, announced today a reconstruction program calling for a divided highway over a five-mile stretch of Route 29 in Union County, with a safety island separating opposing traffic.

Thirty-two members of the New York League of Physically Handicapped, who arrived here Saturday to protest alleged discrimination in WPA employment, presented their charges and proposals today to Aubrey Williams, acting administrator, and will see him again tomorrow.

An important statement of United States policy in the Far Eastern crisis either by President Roosevelt or Secretary of State Cordell Hull was indicated today after the Chief Executive had devoted the afternoon. to discussion of the situation with the administrative, military and naval authorities immediately concerned.
The famous Seaview Golf Club on the Shore Road here may secede from Galloway Township and organize a borough of its own to reduce its taxes, township officials revealed tonight.

The league-leading Newark Bears lost a 3-1 twilight game to Montreal tonight but came back for an easy 6-1 triumph under floodlights. Helped by fine support, Marvin Duke of the Royals pitched his seventeenth victory of the season in the opener.
An all-star Japanese swimming team will be sent to the United States next August, directors of the Japan Swimming Federation decided today. The team will consist of fourteen men swimmers.

Winding up a discussion of Germany's expulsion of Norman Ebbutt, its Berlin correspondent, The Times' of London concludes its leading editorial today with. a statement that the incident will not be allowed to "deflect the main purpose of this paper" in working for improvement of Anglo-German relations.
The first concerted efforts of the anthracite fields to recapture its markets in the Middle West and South lost during the war will be made this Fall, when Anthracite Industries, Inc.,

The report of the Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months to July 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, of $10,883,134.

Steel operations for the current week are scheduled at 83.2 per cent of capacity, a decrease of 1.4 points, or 1.6 per cent, from last week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. A month ago the rate was scheduled at 82.5 per cent of capacity.

A railroad exhibit car designed to illustrate the versatility of the soy bean plant and the uses of its products in agriculture, human consumption and industry started here today on a tour of eight States and the District of Columbia.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. declared yesterday a dividend of $1.50 a share on the common stock, payable on Sept. 15 to stock of record of Aug. 25, compared with $2 paid on June 15 and 75 cents on March 15. On Sept. 15 and June 15, last year,

Declaring that Spanish Government forces were "communistic Reds out of sympathy with the Government of the United States," Governor Charles F. Hurley today turned down an invitation to a reception Thursday in honor of three Boston brothers who fought with the Abraham Lincoln Battalion.

Twenty-four girls comprising the Tip Top unit of Girl Scouts and Girl Guides at the international encampment here arose at 5 A. M. today and hiked two miles through dark woods to Sunrise Hill in Chappaqua to watch the sun come over the hills. After cooking breakfast over a camp fire they returned to Camp Andree.

For three years now this village has been annually visited and looked over by the winner of a contest for the nation's best country correspondent. It is no reflection on rural life and letters in other sections of the country that all three prize-winners to date hail from points west.

Efrem Zimbalist was soloist with the Philharmonic- Symphony Orchestra under Willem Hoogstraten last night at Lewisohn Stadium. The event was the last one of this, the twentieth season of Stadium concerts.

The elimination of Miss Elaine Fischel, Southern California star, by Miss Nellie Sheer of Miami, Fla., featured the initial day of play in the Long Island open junior girls' championship at the Bayside Tennis Club yesterday.

Charging an "invasion" of its jurisdiction by John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization, the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America ordered members of all its local unions in the United States and Canada today to refuse to work with materials furnished by unions affiliated with the C. I. O.

Joseph C. Halbleib, automotive pioneer and Rochester industrialist, died here today after an emergency operation. He was 58 years old. He was sales manager of the Delco Appliance Corporation, formerly the North East Electric Company, which he helped found with his brother, Edward A. Halbleib, and of which he was a director until it was purchased by the General Motors Corporation in 1929.
Rain today again interfered with first-class cricket and there was no play in the county match between Glamorgan and Surrey at Neath. The closing scores in matches ending tomorrow:

Responding gamely to skillful riding by Jockey George Woolf, C. M. Willock's Torolee defeated H. E. Enger's Zoic in a photo finish in the six furlongs of the Blackstone Valley Handicap today as Narragansett Park opened its thirty-day Summer meeting.

Maurie O'Connor and Mike Cestone of C Branch Brook and John Hocter and William Donahue of Locust Grove d led twenty-eight teams today in the qualifying round for the New Jersey State Golf Association and New Jersey P. G. A. second annual championship. They turned in best balls of 70.

Pedro Montanez of Peurto Rico, leading contender for Lou Ambers's lightweight title, knocked out Freddie (Red) Cochrane of Elizabeth in the second round of a scheduled ten-round boxing bout at Braddock Bowl tonight. Montanez weighed 137, Cochrane 139.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Aug. 14 unless specified: At San Pedro: Arizona, Astoria, Arctic, Brant, California, Chicago, Colorado, Concord, Idaho, Indianapolis, Louisville, Mississippi, Maryland, Minneapolis,
Alfred E. Smith Jr. faces punishment for contempt of court unless he pays back alimony of $1,200 to his wife, Mrs. Bertha Gott Smith of Syracuse, Justice Abram Zoller held in motion term here today.

Every honest citizen must approve carefully considered changes in the tax laws designed to halt evasion. But the changes that are now being rushed through Congress are not of this type. They are not carefully considered.

A Bureau of Air Commerce Advisory Board to consider "important national aeronautical problems and the formulation of national policies with respect thereto" has been formed by the Department of Commerce and has held its first meeting, according to an announcement today in the current issue of the Department's Air Commerce Bulletin.

The State Mediation Board's efforts to end the nine-week-old strike of shipyard workers here met with a rebuff yesterday from the two large companies that had been invited by the board to attend its hearing.

Some twenty-five policemen in six radio cars and a police emergency squad were called to rescue a white WPA worker from a menacing crowd of about 500 Negroes at Albany Avenue and Fulton Street, Brooklyn, about 10:30 o'clock last night.
All sailings of missionaries for China and Japan were canceled by the United Church of Canada today. Plans for the return of missionaries here on furlough will be decided at a conference later.

The average export price of Canadian wheat in the crop year ended on July 31 was $1.13 a bushel, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. For the two preceding years it was 82 cents and in 1934, 71 cents.

Despite the commendable record of Japan in servicing in full all of its outstanding dollar debt obligations, investors both here and abroad are experiencing some anxious moments as they follow the course of events in the Sino-Japanese struggle.

The dramatic side of old Spanish days in Santa Barbara was revived tonight at the historic Lobero Theatre when Arthur J. Beckhard revived "Spring in Autumn," a comedy drama of old Spain by Martinez-Sierra.
James MacCallum, an executive of the Celanese Corporation of America, died on Sunday at the Fifth Avenue Hospital after a brief illness. He was 68 years old and lived on Ravine Avenue, Wyckoff, N. J.

Headed by J. Donald Budge, Wimbledon champion, and including every member of the first ten, as well as representatives of Great Britain, France and Japan, a field of ninety-three players started out today in the fifty-seventh annual Newport invitation tennis tournament at the Casino.

Mrs. Mary T. Ryan, widow of Thomas Fortune Ryan, who died on July 2, left her entire estate in trust to her son, J. Couper Lord of Southampton, L. I., it was learned yesterday when her will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court. The estate was formally valued at "more than $100,000."

Unfilled orders for men's wear fabrics at the end of June totaled 33,200,000 yards, including almost 5,250,000 yards of orders from government agencies, the National Association of Wool Manufacturers announced yesterday.
" Of Thee I Sing," the GershwinKaufman musical comedy, opens tonight at Randalls Island Municipal Stadium for a week's engagement, ending with a performance on Sunday evening.
Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek told the Ambassadors of five nations today that China would do her utmost to insure safety of the lives and properties of foreigners in Shanghai.

Henry Hollister Pease, retired lawyer and member of an old New York family, died today at his Summer home, the Orchard. He was 68 years old. Mr. Pease was born in New York, a son of Walter A. Pease and Mary L. Hollister Pease. He was graduated from Harvard in 1891.

Passengers arriving from Europe today on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania include Arthur Curtiss James, banker and former commodore of the New York Yacht Club; Mrs. Carl Boy-Ed, Miss Ida Boy-Ed, Dr. Allan J. Roos, Mr. and Mrs. T. L. Hames, A. H. Johns, Gus Gillerman, C. E. Simpson, Frank C. Atherton and Coolidge Alden.

In granting an injunction against any adoption at stockholders' meetings of the proposed consolidation plan of the Chesapeake Corporation and the Alleghany Corporation, former holding companies of the Van Sweringen interests, Chief Judge Samuel K. Dennis in circuit court

Business failures in the United States numbered 153 for the week ended on Aug. 12, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The figure compared with 156 for the week before, and with 149 for the corresponding week a year ago.

General Saturnino Cedillo, head of the last private army in Mexico, tonight resigned as Secretary of Agriculture, widening the breach between conservatives and radicals in Mexico. It is also rumored General Francisco Mujica will resign as Secretary of Communications.

James McIntyre, beloved "Alexander" of the old vaudeville skit, "The Ham Tree," and for sixtythree years a member of the famous vaudeville team of McIntyre and Heath, lay dying here tonight on Todanna Island. He celebrated his eightieth birthday a week ago Sunday.

Gold engaged abroad yesterday for shipment here, as reported to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, amounted to $5,074,000, of which $3,400,000 was bought in Belgium and $1,674,000 in Canasda. The engagement in Belgium is interpreted by bankers as due to arbitrage operations

John J. Hickey, who at one time served as the only Democratic member of the Board of Aldermen from the Bronx, died today at his home here, at the age of 80. He was stricken several weeks ago at Sayville, where he had been employed as a timekeeper with the State Hiighway Department.

Mr. Butkovitch, leader of a delegation of Croatian Americans visiting here, was escorted to the railway station by Zagreb police last night and told to leave the country immediately. He was interrupted while delivering a speech attacking the Yugoslav regime at a farewell dinner given to the delegation by Zagreb Croats.

Putting two fine rounds together for an aggregate of 151, John Masley, home club caddie master, annexed the crown at the Metropolitan Golf Association's annual championship medal competition for caddies and caddie masters over the Sunningdale Country Club course today.

Mrs. Robert J. McKeon, who is at the Meadow Club, gave a luncheon followed by bridge there today for Mrs. Walter James Clarke of Squirrel Island, Me., who has joined her brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. George Frederick Burt, at Exstance Cottage.
Funeral services were held yesterday for ten victims of the building collapse Wednesday night in New Brighton, S. I., in which nineteen persons were killed and five injured.

The first rainfall of importance in Texas in several weeks and predictions of showers in both Texas and Oklahoma for today caused yesterday a decline of almost $1 a. bale in prices on the Cotton Exchange.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday at the Summer City Hall that he would appoint Byrnes MacDonald, now sixth deputy police commissioner, as first deputy commissioner in the Department of Public Welfare.

NIOBRARA, Neb., Aug. 16.-Dust from a pile of bleached Indian bones swirled out of a long, deep trench today to disclose the story of an Indian "Helen of Troy" who won the hearts of her ancient Ponca captors.

Queen Mother Marie, after four and one-half months of serious illness, appeared publicly for the first time yesterday at a Treadeal sports meeting. She went by automobile from her palace to the field, leaving her car without assistance and walking to the grandstand, where she was greeted with cheers.

A general air of nervousness over developments at Shanghai hung over the foreign trade community yesterday as shippers worried over the fate of thousands of dollars' worth of merchandise en route to the Chinese port and also speculated upon the possibility of losing new business running into thousands if President Roosevelt invokes the Neutrality Act on sales to China and Japan.
Ed Oliver, Central Pennsylvania open champion last year, and Dave Douglass of Wilmington, Del., won the second annual pro-amateur golf tournament at the Lancaster

Three youthful Stamford yacht sailors, Skipper John Wrightson, John Pitt and Alex Stewart, got off to a flying start today in the twelfth annual Long Island Sound midget championship series held by the Knickerbocker Yacht Club.

Insurgent troops entered Reinosa today and advanced beyond it along the main road toward Santander, forty miles northeast. The Basques thus lost their only important arms manufacturing centc- in Santander Province.

Striking employes of the International Ticket Company of Newark petitioned the Court of Errors and Appeals today for reversal of a Chancery Court decision holding closed shop contracts illegal. The case was set down for oral argument at the October term.

Paragraph 14, Special Orders 179, Aug. 4, 1937, relating to Capt. William E. Boone, Inf.-Res., is revoked. Capt. William E. Boone, Inf.-Res., 277 Park Ave., New York, 16th Infantry, is ordered to active duty Aug. 23 at Fort Hamilton, N. Y., for training. On Aug.

Realization both here and abroad of the probable effect upon the Japanese financial situation of the apparent extension of hostilities in the Far East caused yesterday a sharp drop in Japanese dollar obligation drop in Japanese dollar obligations here, forcing them down to new low levels for the year to date.

Another Hollywood actress entered the Cape Play House season tonight. Gertrude Michael, leading lady of the Shopie Lang Pictures, appeared in "Damn Deborah," a new comedy of Revolutionary War days, by Walter Charles Roberts.

Turpentine firm, 32c; sales, 125 barrels; receipts, 354 barrels; shipments, 328 barrels; stock, 36,240 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 486 barrels; receipts, 2,339 barrels; shipments, 4,486 barrels; stock, 58,498 barrels. Quote: B, D, E, $7.50; F. G, H, I, K, M, $7.65; N, $7.70; WG, $7.75; WW, X, $8.50.

Automobile drivers suffering from diabetes are "potential killers" on the road, Magistrate Charles Solomon declared yesterday in Felony Court, Brooklyn. Magistrate Solomon criticized at the same time the Motor Vehicle Bureau for laxity in issuing drivers' licenses to men and women who are victims of diabetes.

Alona Wentworth Friend, the former Mrs. Edgar Troy Allen of Marblehead and Melrose, Mass., was married here this afternoon to Daniel Rogers Pinkham of Boston and Lynn, Mass. The ceremony was performed at the home of Dr. and Mrs. A. J. Hood by the Rev. P. H. Willis. Dr. and Mrs. Hood and a few close friends were the only attendants, the bride having been a guest of Mrs. Hood for several days.
Playing over the difficult Fresh Meadow golf course at Flushing yesterday, fifty-five teams battled for prizes in pro-amateur and propro golf contests under the auspices of the Long Island P. G. A.

Walter William Shannon, a former star baseball and basketball player here, died yesterday at Effingham, N. H., where he was on vacation. He was 40 years old and had made his home for the last few years at Daytona Beach, Fla. Mr. Shannon was born and educated in the Bronx.
The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue $501,000 of general mortgage bonds,

The Treasury today sold its weekly issue of 273-day bills at an average rate, on a bank discount basis, of 0.459 per cent. This is markedly less than last week's 0.478 per cent on a similar issue. On the other hand, an average rate of 0.216 paid on an issue of 122-day bills,

Private funeral services were held here today for Gertrude Boyle Kanno, American sculptress, who died in St. John's Hospital on Saturday. She was 61 years old. Mrs. Kanno, wife of Takeshi Kanno, Japanese poet-philosopher, was stricken with a heart ailment while en route from Japan and was rushed to the hospital on her arrival here last week.

The story of a Japanese marine officer who waded into a battle at Shanghai and fought the Chinese with his sword until he was killed was reported here today. The Chinese attack, launched at 9 A. M., yesterday between Patzukaio and Chih Chih University, was pressed for three hours before the Chinese withdrew under the marines' deadly sustained machine-gun fire.
Congress learned today that the National Labor Relations Board, created to enforce employes' rights, had been working its stenographers "sixty or seventy hours a week."

Grand St, 494-8, 50x100; Meyer London, Inc, Kopel London, president, to Merchants and Newark Trust Co of Newark, N. J.; due Aug. 20, 1938, 6 per cent; $12,750. 48th St, 163 W, 25x108.2: Solmel Realty Co, Joseph Melcer, president, to Greenwich Savings Bank; purchase money mtg. $60.000.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt made a surprise visit to Camp Jane Addams at Lake Tiorati, in Bear Mountain Park, this afternoon and told the directors and 130 campers that it was her "unofficial" opinion that the camp would be closed next month for financial reasons.

The Westchester County Bible Society, organized in 1814 by John Jay and other county residents for distributing Bibles, offered today to present a number of copies to Westchester County. A shortage in the Court House was discovered last week when an attorney tried to find one.

Talks are proceeding between Americans of Jewish and of Arab origin with a view to-exploring the possibilities of bringing peace between their peoples in Palestine by applying the American federal principle, it was revealed by Adil Arslan, one of the Arab High Committee's two delegates here.
Ice floes of the Arctic echoed the roar of rescue planes today as the search for six Russian fliers gained new impetus from reports that radio signals had been received from the missing airliner.

A draw in the third and final test cricket match between England and New Zealand seemed inevitable tonight, the match ending tomorrow. Hampered by rain from the start Saturday, the score stood at 249 for New Zealand's first innings; England 86 runs for three wickets.

Norman Thomas, as chairman of the Public Affairs Committee of the Socialist party, urged the Senate Judiciary Committee in a letter yesterday to inquire and report on the attitude of Senator Hugo Black, nominee for the Supreme Court, toward equal justice for Negroes.

Speyer Co. announced yesterday that they had received the following announcement from the League Loans Committee of London in relation to the Greek external loans. "With reference to their communiqu6 of March 31, last, the Council of Foreign Bondholders and the League Loans Committee regret
Half a hundred tanned young athletes battled through the first round of men's singles in the fifteenth annual national public parks championships today with only one casualty among the favorites.
Senator Borah in the Judiciary Committee today voted to confirm a man-Senator Black-to fill a vacancy on the Supreme Court which last week he argued does not exist.

The National Maritime Union announced last night that it had filed charges with the National Labor Relations Board against the Clyde Mallory Line and the Colombian Line as a result of recent efforts of the International Longshoremen's Association to win away its members.

Extracts from correspondence between Klopstock Co., underwriters of the stock of the Austin Silver Mining Company, and L. R. Leeby of L. R. Leeby Co., investment dealers of Washington, D. C., were introduced into evidence yesterday by counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission as the SEC

Cloudbursts have swelled the BioBio, Laja and Cautin Rivers and threatened many towns in the valley districts. Many residents in the areas are reported preparing to leave their homes as the floods continue to grow.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for a seventeen-story apartment house on Central Park South. The structure will accommodate sixty-five families and will cost $650,000.

The Third Deficiency Bill was reported to the House today without a $10,000,000 appropriation for the new merchant marine construction program for the coming year. Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission, had urged the committee to strike out the item.

Encouraged by the fact that the anticipated Summer slump has not materialized, Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, views with optimism the outlook for business generally during the remaining months of the year, in the bank's Business Bulletin just released.

Almost unrelieved dullness ruled in the stock market today, with gilt-edge investments sharing the generally easier tone. Far Easterns, as was to be expected from the trouble in the Orient, were weak.

Daily average sales of chain grocery stores for the first seven months of this year have been 2 1/2 per cent above those of the corresponding period last year, but in July they were 3 1/2 per cent below the dollar volume for July, 1936, the Department of Commerce reported today.

James Armstrong Renwick, retired lawyer and member of an old New York family, died at his farm here yesterday in his eighty-first year. Mr. Renwick, who had lived here for the last twenty-five years, had been active in political affairs of the old village of Flushing, Queens, and was president of the village before it became a part of the greater city.

The Bethlehem Steel Company has ordered ten oil-electric engines from the American Locomotive Company. The company also has received orders for a switching engine from the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, an oil-electric locomotive from the United Fruit Company and one rotary snow plow from the Northern Pacific Railway.

A 1 per cent tax on the gross receipts of utility companies operating here was voted tonight by the White Plains City Council. Proceeds from the tax will be used exclusively for the benefit of persons on relief.

Sixteen persons were slain, including eight women, and twenty were seriously and eighty slightly wounded last night in a clash at Campos, in Rio de Janeiro State, between Integralistas [Brazilian Fascists] and anti-Fascists.

Four basic reforms which would affect New York State's civil service system are to be introduced by Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh, when the 1938 Legislature convenes, he said today just before sailing for Europe.

Delegates to the annual convention of the Postal Workers of America voted at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday to recall their recent application for affiliation with the C. I. O. Representatives from various sections of the country explained that while they favored the industrial union principle, they were averse to becoming involved in any labor disputes at this time.

Supreme Court Justice John McCrate denied yesterday in Brooklyn an application of the State Mortgage Commission to make the provisions of the Stack act applicable to the reorganization proceedings of the Home Title Insurance Company of Brooklyn.

Adolph Kiefer of Chicago tonight won the 100-meter back-stroke final in a United States-Japan swimming meet, setting a foreigners' record of 1 minute 7 seconds and clipping two-tenths of a second off the mark set by Masaji Kiyokawa, who placed third behind him in the Olympic final last year.

George E. Wells, 20-year-old Berea College senior, who is said to have wanted to marry pretty Opal Sturgill, 18, since they went to the same mountain high school, five years ago, was charged today with murdering her.

Two "guys named Joe" who are better than raw hands at baseball and boxing, met today when Joe Louis, who is training for his heavyweight title bout with Tommy Farr, entertained the New York Yankees' sophomore slugger, Joe DiMaggio.
As the House ordered the Sugar Control Bill sent to conference tonight, some advocates predicted modification of features which President Roosevelt has said would make him veto the legislation.

Former Mayor James J. Walker was appointed yesterday by the Transit Commission to a $12,000 a year job as assistant counsel to the commission. He is to act in the coordination of the commission's grade-crossing elimination activities in New York City, according to an announcement by the State body.

Applications by several companies for confidential treatment of certain data filed in annual reports under the Securities Act of 1934 have been denied by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Included in the information thus made a matter of public record were the following:

Harris, Hall Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $500,000 of water certificates of indebtedness of Chicago, Ill., on a bid of 103.137 for a fixed rate of 3 per cent. The certificates are to be dated May 1, 1937, and to mature on May 1, 1951.

John Hay Whitney, a member of The Jockey Club, of the New York State Racing Commission and of perhaps the best-known family on the American turf, today called $100,000 events "sucker handicaps" and termed them "an outrageous travesty on the turf's great races."

Treasury agents in Arizona reported today to Joseph E. Murphy, Acting Chief of the Secret Service, the seizure of more than $56,000 worth of gold and the arrest of four men on charges of filing false affidavits with the San Francisco Mint and violations of the Gold Reserve Act of 1934.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals, in a 2-to-1 decision, reversed the District Court yesterday in its dismissal of a suit brought by the Federal Government to collect more than $11,000,000 from the Guaranty Trust Company, as a depository for the State of Russia, under the Litvinoff agreement.
Former Finance Minister Raul Gurdian of Costa Rica arrived here with his wife today en route to Japan as the guest of the Japanese Importers and Exporters Association.

The Standrad Oil Company of Indiana reported yesterday for the six months to June 30 a consolidated net income of $27,904,211 after charges, depreciation, depletion and normal income taxes, but before provision for surtax on undistributed profits. This was equal to $1.83 each on the 15.235,323 shares of $25 par value capital stock outstanding.

Edward G. Hogan, title clerk and accountant in the Westchester County Attorney's office at White Plains, died here yesterday at his home at the age of 41. He was a brother of Sergeant Jerome Hogan of the Greenburgh police, who died last week. Surviving are his widow, a son, Edward G. Jr. of Hastings; two sisters,

William E. Winters, the best known Yuletide "Santa Claus" in this section of Westchester County, died on Saturday in the Mount Vernon Hospital at the age of 69. Mr. Winters had been appearing for more than twenty years at Christmas parties given by war veterans and community organizations.

Cleveland Livingston Waterbury, 50 years old, member of an old New York family and a former resident of this city, died yesterday at Tyler, Texas. He formerly was in the advertising business in New York. He attended Groton School and served in the World War.

Ellen Tucker, 31 years old, a Negro maid, of 388 Classon Avenue, Brooklyn, took a police escort along when she slashed another Negro in a bar and grill late Sunday night, it was testified in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday by Detective Arthur J. De Marrais.

The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill authorizing an increase in the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico to seven justices. Five are now provided. Introduced by Resident Commissioner Santiago Iglesias, the bill involves an amendment to the Organic Act of Puerto Rico.

The Department of Agriculture favors and probably will insist upon 9-cent loans on cotton, but in view of the possibility that loans on this basis might involve subsidy payments totaling about $200,000,000, the department will provide for some form of limitation of the subsidies, it was learned today.
A month in bed recovering from injuries suffered in a fall down stairs last Jan. 4, cured Mrs. Nellie De Lade of using snuff. She celebrated her 103d birthday anniversary today.
The National Youth Administration will discontinue all girl camps Oct. 1, it was announced tonight by Richard R. Brown, deputy executive director.

Employment in private industry in this State through public job agencies for the first seven months this year shows a substantial increase over any similar seven-month period, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, reported yesterday.
House passage sent to the White House today legislation that would permit the Treasury to construct facilities on the West Point military reservation in New York for silver storage.
Paraguay has followed Bolivia's example in abandoning her experiment with State socialism and announcing a return to a constitutional representative republican form of government.

Baldur von Schirach, Nazi youth leader, addressed warm greetings to a Japanese youth delegation at a sport festival here today. He said: "When I think of Japanese youth training I realize how many points of likeness it has with the fashion in which we train our youth.

John Harry Campbell, concert singer, music teacher and choral society director, died at Elmira, N. Y., on Saturday following a tonsillectomy. His age was 52 and he lived at 32 Glen Avenue, Mount Vernon. For fourteen years Mr. Campbell was a tenor at the Marble Collegiate Church in New York.

More than 1,000 American and. British refugees set out this morning in frail tenders for a perilous journey down the Whangpoo River to the sea-endangered by falling shells from embattled Japanese warships. There were 337 American women and Children in one tender.

It was reported here that Dr. H. H. Kung, Chinese Minister of Finance, who recently visited Prague, had arranged a $50,000,000 credit arrangement with the Skoda armaments firm. It was learned, however, from well-informed sources that the report was incorrect, or at least premature.

An allegation by Mrs. Mabel M. Cutler of Chatham that her husband, Harold Cutler, a semi-pro ball player, was more interested in baseball than his wife, won her a divorce in Chancery Court here today on a charge of desertion. Mrs.
A capacity audience of Cape Cod Summer colonists at the Mary Young Theatre tonight witnessed the world premiere of "At Your Service," a new comedy by Fred Eisman.

The wedding of Miss Gertrude Mary Vert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Wade Vert of this place, to Robert Thompson Breed, son of Dr. Nathaniel Pope Breed of Lynn, Mass., took place today in the Presbyterian Webb Memorial Chapel. The Rev. John W. Parks, pastor, officiated. A reception followed at the Vert home.
President Roosevelt conferred on "all phases of the Far Eastern crisis" with Secretary Hull, General Malin Craig, Chief f Staff of the army, Rear Admiral James O.

I boarded this tender at 8 A. M. today, the time set for its departure with refugees to the President Taft. While we were waiting for a United States naval guard to arrive we saw seven Chinese planes sweep in and out of the clouds.

Plans for the Republican primary campaign, with special reference to bringing about the active participation of Mayor La Guardia, were discussed last evening at a conferrnce in New York County headquar??ers, 560 Fifth Avenue.

In her first address on a legislative subject since coming to the Senate in 1931 Senator Caraway, Arkansas Democrat, said today that she was "content" despite President Roosevelt's veto of a resolution she had introduced.

Lloyd's announced today substantial increases on war-risk insurance on cargoes bound to or from ports in China. Previously the rate on cargo bound for Yangtze River ports and ports north of Shanghai was 5 shillings per [Pound]100 in addition to general coverage but excluding all risk on shore after discharge or before landing.

Shooting in evening shadows against a strong cross wind, Stanley Remsen, assistant pro at Bethpage State Park, took the lead in the opening day's play of the Long Island sector of the World-Telegram's sixth annual hole-in-one tournament today on the Bavside links.

172d St (11-3000), s e cor of Bryant Ave, 100x25; William P. Thomas to Elbert S. Kip, 26 Madison Ave, Morristown, N. J. Adee Ave, 1,306 (16?4587); Charles Donivan to Carl F. Eller, 512 Jackson Ave. Briggs Ave, 2,654 (12-3294): Grace Dorrie to Florence Mason, 2,654 Briggs Ave.
Of Eicials of the international printers baseball tournament threw out Chicago's victory over St. Louis tolay and awarded the game to St. Louis as the first round of the Lournament was played.

Cole Porter's musical comedy, "Anything Goes," the eighth in the season's schedule of Shubert productions of musical plays and operettas, was presented here tonight on the gigantic water stage in Zach's Bay, by Fortune Gallo, director of the San Carlo Opera Company. A gathering of 9,000 persons welcomed the production.

Miss Mary Pamelia Turner, daughter of Mrs. Robert Nathaniel Turner of this place and the late Mr. Turner, was married here this afternoon to Hugh Montell McNeill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis B. McNeill of Huntington, W. Va., in the First Parish Church, which has been attended by the bride's family for eight generations, ever since its founding. The Rev. John Nicol Mark performed the ceremony.
Budget requests for the Dock Department and the Municipal Courts were presented yesterday to Deputy Budget Commissioner Kenneth Daytop.

Milton J. Nichols, an employee of the Hudson Terminal Postoffice and a World War veteran, died yesterday at Veterans Hospital No. 81, the Bronx. He lived at 2,505 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn. Mr. Nichols served in France with Company A, First Ammunition Train, and was gassed in action.

The conservatory garden, one of the newest beauty spots in Central Park, is nearing completion and the Department of Parks tentatively plans its formal opening the first week in September, it was learned yesterday.
I have left a Japan which is preparing for war in China grimly and on a huge scale but without popular enthusiasm.

The In terstate Commerce Commission today reversed a decision by its Division 4 which held that the railroad freight rates on prepared and pea sizes of anthracite coal from Pennsylvania to Bayonne, Hoboken, Weehawken, Secaucus and other points in Hudson County, N. J.,

Philip F. Donohue, who since the turn of the century had been treasurer of Tammany Hall and a prominent figure in Democratic city politics for several decades, died Sunday at his home, 223 East Seventeenth Street. He was 79 years old.

Albert J. Headley, formerly Assistant Superintendent of the Metropolitan Police Department of Washington, died today at his home here. He was 67 years old. Mr. Headley was appointed Assistant Superintendent of Police in 1935, after being a member of the department since 1896.

Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of the Journal of the American Medical Association, returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie after attending the convention of the British Medical Association and studying social medicine in Sweden.
Monroe C. Alesker, a lawyer with offices at 545 Fifth Avenue, died Monday at New York Hospital after an illness of two months. He lived at 110 West Eighty-sixth Street and was 32 years old.
Running back to his fine race of last Saturday, Buckley Byers's Thorson today won the thirty-fifth Champlain Handicap in a fashion far easier than was expected, even by stable connections.

Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said today that payment of claims of insured depositors in the defunct Fort Greene National Bank, Brooklyn, N. Y., would begin at 9 o'clock Thursday morning and that the depositors would be notified by mail of the days on which to present their claims for verification and payment.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses chased a driver who was "weaving" through traffic on the Triborough Bridge yesterday morning and ordered him arrested for dangerous driving.

President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nomination of Mary W. Dewson of New York, director of the women's division of the Democratic National Committee, to be a member of the Social Security Board, succeeding Vincent M. Miles of Arkansas, whose term expired last Friday.

Jacob Wilk, head of the story department of Warner Brothers Pictures, returned from England yesterday in the Aquitania, bringing word that the Warners would be associated in the production of at least two English plays on Broadway this season, as well as continuing with those plans for several London productions.
Charges by John D. Rockefeller Jr. that he had been discriminated against by North Tarrytown tax officials were sustained today by Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief. Approving a report

Lewis Wetherell and Miss Elizabeth Deike, California's defending champions in the men's and women's singles; led the seeded players inr a solid front Tin through the second day's play in the il National Public Parks tennis championships today.
Donald M. Davidson, a 15-yearold New Rochelle schoolboy who was stricken recently with infantile paralysis, has received a letter from President Roosevelt, it was learned today. The letter follows:

John Van Druten's new period piece, "Gertie Maude," which opened at the St. Martin's tonight, is about a prewar .promoted chorus girl who fell in love with the man who kept her and killed herself when he married into his own class.

The east side of the midtown section took the lead yesterday in the large volume of Summer leasing of apartments for Oct. 1 occupancy, reports from brokers disclosed. Buildings on side thoroughfares from East Thirty-seventh Street up to Eighty-sixth Street figured prominently in the leasing activity.

Akexander Antonio, youngster from Linden, N. J., who won the qualifying medal yesterday, got started in the right direction toward the national left-handed golfers title today by defeating Walter Masse of Green Bay, Wis., 3 and 2, in the opening round of match play at Olympia Fields.

Trading continued only fair to slow. Steer hinds and ribs were held at strong prices but demand was slow. Calf hindsaddles were sharply lower and veal weak to lower. Lamb sold slightly below Monday's early quotations. Fresh pork cuts were uneven; loins were sharply lower and other cuts steady to slightly stronger.

The House Rules Committee today adopted a resolution permitting three hours of debate tomorrow on the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill. The committee action came after a hearing at which testimony indicated a sharp difference of opinion regarding some features of the bill.

On the eve of Mrs. Anna Hahn's arraignment on charges of poisoning two aged Cincinnatians, police revealed tonight that jewelry, money and a $1,000 bond, reported stolen from one or more of her men acquaintances, had been found in the Hahn home. The two poison victims were said by police to be Jacob Wagner and George Gsellman.
John G. Jackson of New York, president of the United States Golf Association, announced today the 1938 national open championship will be played June 9, 10 and 11 on Denver's Cherry Hills course.

Monmouth and Evergreen Farms, leaders of the Eastern Polo League. galloped into the final round of the Monmouth County Country Club's annual ten-goal tournament today as they won their semi-final matches in hard-fought contests.
Robert Ballard, 12 years old, winner of the All-American soap box derby at Akron, Ohio, on Sunday, returned to his home here today and later rode in a one-mile parade through streets of the city.

Several secondhand American-built airplanes consigned to Spain but held under guard since April owing to the arms embargo secretly left Paris Sunday. Two of them crashed, were badly damaged and were abandoned in fields near Paris.
The roll-call on confirmation of Senator Black as Associate Justice of the Supreme Court follows:

Questions of physical or mental disability in relation to safe auto driving, which were precipitated on Monday by the suspension of the license of a diabetic driver suffering from "insulin shock" by Magistrate Charles Solomon in Felony Court in Brooklyn, received further airing in automobile circles yesterday.
Secretary Ickes announced today that rents would range from $17.75 to $23.85 monthly at the Public Works Administration's $4,775,000 Kenfield Housing Project in Buffalo, N. Y.

Baptist and Episcopalian missionaries en route to China or scheduled to depart in the near future were advised yesterday by their respective executive boards not to proceed to Shanghai, but to "await developments."

The engagement of $1,963,000 of gold abroad for shipment here, $1,123,000 in India and $840,000 in England, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. In London gold bullion was quoted at the equivalent of $34.7599 an ounce, which was below the New York shipping parity of around $34.77.

Thomas E. Dewey's name as a candidate for the Republican nomination for District Attorney of New York County was substituted yesterday in place of Irving Ben Cooper's. The substitution certificate filed with the Board of Elections was signed by Mr. Dewey and dated Friday, Aug. 13.

Miss Joan Todd of Red Bank, N. J., was upset by Miss Jane M Millen of Great Neck in the second round of the Long Island open laI junior girls' championship at the the Bayside Tennis Club yesterday. di/ Miss Todd, seeded fourth, bowed, an 6-1, 6-4.

Anthony Vitelli, 43 years old, of 301 Sackett Street, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty yesterday in Kings County Court to an indictment charging him with second degree rape and second degree assault involving an 11-year-old girl.

The first playground to be built in the Times Square section was opened yesterday afternoon by Mayor La Guardia in the presence of other city officials, leaders of civic and business groups and 1,000 cheering residents of the neighborhood. The play area is owned by

Directors of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation declared yesterday an extra dividend of 50 cents as well as the regular quarterly disbursement of 25 cents on the common stock. The regular quarterly dividend of $1.50 a share was voted for preferred shareholders.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 14: CAPTAIN Smith, C. G., Med. Corps, 3d Naval District. New York, about Sept. 1, to home, relieved from all active duty.
The on Treasury Procurement Division today invited bids for 1,116,750 yards of textiles, the bids to be opened Aug. 25. The specifications follow:

George F. Shecklen, vice president and China representative of R. C. A. Communications, and C. T. McClellan, Mackay Radio representative here, announced today that the control and management of China's international radio stations and the

The Chemical Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, reported yesterday that about $6,820,000 of the Republic Steel Corporation's general-mortgage convertible 4 1/2 per cent bonds, Series A, due in 1950, remained outstanding.
Formation of a new Cabinet headed by Senator Eamil Midfai, succeeding that of Hikmet Beg Suleiman was completed today.
For the second straight night Newark and the second-place Montreal team split a double-header, the Bears winning the first game 10-6, and the Royals the afterpiece, 7-1, tonight.

New York and Washington-each with two victories and no lossesled today in the second round of the annual international printers' baseball tournament. Pittsburgh and Indianapolis-with two straight losses apiece-were eliminated.

Notice Company commanders shall forward separate reports, on Aug. 21, relative to hydrants in their company district. Pensioned Pilot James J. Gully of Engine 223 having performed duty continuously for more than twenty years is, on his own application. retired on an annual pension of $1,750.
The Pan American Clipper was eastbound over the Atlantic last night while a British and a German plane were in port here preparatory to resuming their test flights across the Atlantic.

Pat Coffey, Louisiana State University fullback, today joined the New York Football Giants at the Blue Hill C. C., where the pros are preparing for the game with the Eastern college all-stars on Sept. 8. The arrival of Coffey gave Coach Steve Owen twenty-eight players in could camp, sixteen of them rookies.

A shake-up and general house-cleaning in the Federal Communications Commission was presaged today when President Roosevelt sent to the Senate the nominations of two new members of the commission, one of them Frank R. McNinch, temporarily transferred from his position as chairman of the Federal Power Commission, according to Stephen T. Early, the President's press secretary, to "put the commission's affairs in order."

The first formal complaint by the New York State Labor Relations Board was issued yesterday. It was against Davega-City Radio, Inc., operating a chain of retail sporting goods and radio stores in this city.
Johnny Rinaldi, 1361/2, Bronx, outpointed Rubin (Bus) Breese, 138, Manhattan, Kan., in the eight-round feature bout before 6,000 spectators at the New York Coliseum last night.

Fine pitching in the pinches by Lefty Ed Brandt and a brilliant ninth-inning catch by Lloyd Waner helped the Pirates beat the Cubs, 4 to 2, today. It was the fourth straight victory for Pittsburgh and reduced Chicago's lead over the Giants to three games.

The first of the four Fall horse shows on the North Shore will take place on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, when the North Shore Horse Show will be held at the Old Field Club with attendant luncheons, dinners, house parties and dances.
Led by Frenchy Bordagaray, the Cardinals scored twice in each of four innings tonight to defeat the Reds, 8 to 6, in the fourth floodlight contest of the major league season.
Harry Stanley Scrivener, referee of Wimbledon tennis championships and one of the founders of the Lawn Tennis Association, died in Wimbledon today at the age of 71.

Miss Eleanor Dommerich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Louis Dommerich of Greenwich, has completed plans for her marriage to Robert Morris Schmeltzer, son of Mrs. John R. Schmeltzer, also of this place, and the late Mr. Schmeltzer.

John Cudahy, new United States Minister to the Irish Free State, arrived here this evening after having landed at Cobh from the liner Manhattan this morning. He said he thought he was the first American Minister to Ireland with an Irish ancestry, and

A lease of an entire floor containing about 10,000 square feet in 826 Broadway, taken by L. Heumann Co., Inc., patent medicines. was a feature of the contracts for commercial space reported yesterday. Adams Co., Inc., negotiated the lease.

As a forerunner to the Westchester open golf championship tournament, which starts here at Green Meadow tomorrow, the county proamateur two-ball best-ball title test was conducted today, with the veteran Hudson River pro, Alex Watson, and his amateur partner, George Tamblyn Jr., returning 31, 37-68 to win the crown.

NEW efforts to simplify land-title registration in this State to protect a property owner against unforeseen claims or clouds on his rights and to make the transfer of land almost as easy as the transfer of stocks or bonds, have been started with promise of wide support.
Two persons were overcome by the heat yesterday as the mercury climbed to 87 degrees at 5 P. M. The average temperature was 77 degrees, 4 above normal. The low was 67 at 5:20 A.M.

Middlesex was toppled from the top of the county cricket table today by Yorkshire, after leading for weeks. Yorkshire scored a full victory over Worcestershire while Middlesex could take only first innings points from Warwickshire. Rain interfered with
A Japanese military spokesman denied today reports from Nanking that the Chinese forces had won a sweeping victory at Nankow Pass, near the Great Wall, twenty-five miles northwest of Peiping.

183d St. 68 W (11-3208): Valcon Realty Corp to East River Savings Bank; extends mtgs to Aug. 1, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent; $65,000. Merriam Ave (9-2535), n e cor of 170th, 224x72; Cornell Housing Corp to David H. Sherman. 597 Lefferts Ave., Bklyn; clue on demand, 6 per cent; $16,800.

The stock market here was dull today, most sections being influenced by the news from the Far East. Gilt-edge issues fell off, while among the foreign loans Chinese and Japanese bonds lost ground. International issues weakened on lower quotations from Wall Street; United States Steel and International Nickel shares turned downward.

Charges of traitorous sabotage are now leveled at the State Planning Commission, which as the institution entrusted with framing the Five-Year Plan in detail, may be called the brain of this planned economy.

The White House announced today the appointment by President Roosevelt of Secretary Ickes as Puerto Rico Reconstruction Administrator to fill a vacancy created by the resignation of Dr. Ernest Gruening. Miles Fairbank, Assistant Administrator, has been Acting Administrator.

The Interstate Commerce Commission suspended operation today of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad's announced fare increase from 6 to 10 cents between lower Manhattan and points in Jersey City and Hoboken pending a public hearing and investigation to open in New York on Sept. 15, it was announced this afternoon by Corporation Counsel James A. Hamill.
Waldemar Kaempffert, science editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, has been elected president of the National Association of Science Writers, it was announced here yesterday by the organization.

Spanish refugee children have rebelled at their relief camp at Suresnes, demanding their return to Spain. Two policemen were injured when the refugees attacked them with stones after smashing windows. More police had to be summoned, and some of the more troublesome boys were sent to other camps.

Mrs. Carrie Guggenheim, widow of Isaac Guggenheim, New York copper man, had a net estate of $623,268 at the time of her death on Jan. 5, 1933, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. It consisted chiefly of cash, jewelry and stocks and bonds.

Six masked men, shouting "to hell with the law," seized Albert Gooden, a Negro, accused of slaying a white officer, from Sheriff W. J. Vaughan today and left his body dangling at the end of a frayed rope after riddling it with bullets.

Arthur (Tootsie) Herbert, business agent of the. Chicken Drivers Union, Local 167, and two of the union officers, who had pleaded guilty to charges of embezzling union funds brought against them by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, were sentenced to prison yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora.

Share prices moved narrowly for the most part yesterday and closed lower. Trading continued slow, the volume on the Stock Exchange being 658,000 shares, against 618,000 on Monday. The feature of the bond market was a break in Japanese bonds, following severe weaknesses in these issues on the day before.

Essex St, 166, 25x100; Margaret Folsom Corp (George W. Haight, pres) to Winthrop Properties, Inc, 32 Liberty St ($10). Essex St, 176, 25x100; Winthrop Properties, Inc (Bronson Winthrop, pres), to Margaret Folsom Corp, 55 Liberty St ($10). Lispenard St, 7-9; Irving R. Kass, ref, to Irving Savings Bank; foreclosure ($20).

After a two-day discussion of pedagogical methods in four branches of science the sixteenth annual convention of the American Association of Jesuit Scientists closed yesterday afternoon at Fordham University.

The Hongkew and Yangtsepoo districts of the International Settlement-now completely held by the Japanese and most likely to be battlefields-have been almost wholly evacuated by Chinese and others. Previously they had a million or more inhabitants.

The twentieth season of the concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium came to an end last night with an audience of about 8,000. The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra was directed by Willem van Hoogstraten and there was a prolonged tribute for conductor and orchestra at the conclusion of the program.

The proposed change in the Protestant Episcopal Church's canon on marriage to liberalize divorce "would nullify completely all- that is of value in our present canon and on the practical side it would leave us in chaos," Bishop William T. Manning declares in an article in the coming issue of The Living Church.

The Ways and Means Committee approved today a bill to abolish a $5 stamp tax on steamship tickets to Puerto Rico. Santiago Iglesias, Resident Commissioner, told the committee that his proposed amendment to the Revenue Act of 1926 was necessary because the stamp tax "constitutes a discrimination against Puerto Rico."

The Boston Elevated Railway Company has filed with the Department of Public Utilities of Massachusetts a petition for authority to issue $4,800,000 of bonds to refund a similar amount of bonds due on Oct. 1. A hearing on the request will be held on Sept. 13.

A counter-movement against the Textile Workers Organizing Committee, C. I. O. affiliate, in the current strike in the silk and rayon industry, was started here yesterday by a group of mill owners who said they had the backing of mills employing 21,000 workers in Pennsylvania.
Stockholders of the Parker-Wolverine Company at a special meeting on Sept. 20 will consider a proposed increase in authorized no-par

Hubert Austin Heath, former publisher of The Kansas Farmer, a weekly publication now owned by Senator Arthur Capper of Kansas, died here last night in the United Hospital at the age of 80. He had lived in Larchmont four years.

The appointment of James J. Walker to a Transit Commission post that will permit him to qualify for a pension drew an ironic letter yesterday from Samuel Seabury, reviewing the charges that led up to the former Mayor's resignation and suggesting that the commission find "an equally comfortable place" for Russell T. Sherwood, Mr. Walker's one-time financial agent who retired to Mexico during the Hofstadter committee's investigation.

Nothing short of a direct demand from President Roosevelt that Congress stay on the job and complete other Items in his legislative program was regarded today as sufficient to prevent adjournment of the present session by Saturday night.
The Senate, by a vote of 63 to 16, late this afternoon confirmed the nomination of Senator Hugo L. Black of Alabama to be an associate justice of the Supreme Court.

Manhattan Cherry St, 327-35; 124x144 feet: for 1-story garage; Stoker Realty Co, 290 South St, owner: Philip Bardes, 230 Grand St, architect; cost $25,000. Essex St 166-68; 50x70 feet; for 1-story stores; Winthrop Properties, Inc, 32 Liberty St, owner; Seymour A. Mitteldorf 286 5th Ave, architect; cost $15,000.

More than 100,000 children flocked yesterday to the wading pools operated in ninety-seven parks and playgrounds throughout the city, where special programs had been prepared under the direction of James V. Mulholland, Supervisor of Recreation.

While agreeing that the combination of fairly high inventories in some lines, price softening and spotty August sales response due to hot weather offer some justification for cautious Fall buying, merchandise executives here feel that the delay in placing orders at this time may well lead to delivery difficulties next month, particularly in women's garment and accessory lines.

Despite charges by Representative Snell, the Republican leader, that publication of the "Democratic Register" under the auspices of the Democratic National Congressional Committee, is a technical violation of the Corrupt Practices Act, Charles S. Hayden, executive secretary of the committee, said today that the register would appear about Oct. 1.
Dr. Hiram W. Evans, Imperial Wizard of form the Ku Klux Klan, said today that Senator Hugo L. Black was neither a Klansman nor, so far as he knew, "a sympathizer."
A PWA allotment of $29,100,000 was approved yesterday for the completion of the Lincoln Tunnel under the Hudson River at West Thirty-eighth Street.
Apartment property in the Bronx continues to attract the realty investor. This type of buyer figured in several of the transactions reported in that borough yesterday.

William Hull, 19 years old, of Lancaster, Pa., drowned yesterday in the Salzbach River near Hallein when he tried to retrieve a canoe in which he and Rhodes Willard of Columbia University had made a trip from Golling.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney deplored in an interview yesterday the injection into the local primary campaign of the Ku Klux Klan issue by his opponent for the Democratic Mayoralty nomination, United States Senator Royal S. Copeland.
Announcement has been made of the marriage last Thursday in Maryland of Mrs. Angeline Krech James of New York to Harrie T. Lindeberg, also of New York.

A large number of the Summer colony of Mount Desert Island attended the piano recital this afternoon by Lee Gron, American pianist and composer, at Bogue Chitto, the Summer residence of Dave Hennen Morris.

Business failures decreased in three groups in the week ended Aug. 12 in comparison with the figures for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Manufacturing failures.

Officials of Palisades Interstate Park system announced today that the famous Storm King Highway, hewn years ago out of rock on the face of Storm King Peak, about 400 feet above the Hudson River, is to be turned over by the State to the park system.

Holders of American certificates representing Belgian National Railway Company participating preferred stock have been notified by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, depositary, that there has been drawn for redemption on Sept. 1, at par of 500 Belgian francs each, 726 Belgian shares underlying the outstanding American certificates.

Bruce Barton, author and advertising specialist, was designated yesterday by the Republican organization as a candidate for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Theodore A. Peyser, Democrat.

The Chesapeake 'Ohio Railway Company announced today for the first seven months of 1937 a net income of $18,474,452, a decrease of $2,525,982 under the corresponding period of 1936. Net operating income was

R. J. Cullen, president of the International Paper and Power Company, announced yesterday that the directors had taken final action to put into effect the plan for change in capitalization of the company and that no further action by the company was required.

An extraordinary session of the Diet will be summoned for Sept. 3 to reorganize Japan's financial and economic system on a war basis. The Cabinet today approved in principle the financial measures to be submitted to the five-day session. The newspaper Asahi announces that the administrative machinery is being prepared.

Official announcement was made today that trade between Canada and the United States for the first six months of 1937 had reached the best total for any similar period since 1930, the goods having a value of $475,175,000.

The War Department released the following orders today dated Aug, 16: LIEUTENANT COLONEL Sawyer, H. P., Med. Corps, detailed as a member of Board Officers appointed for the purpose of examining applicants for Commission in the Medical Department, Regular Army. Vice Captain F. W. Seymour, Medical Corps, hereby relieved.

There was excitement for 25,898 fans, an unusually large midweek gathering, at the Stadium yesterday as the Yanks shook off their losing habits and snapped an eightgame winning streak of the Senators by taking both ends of a double-header.

Tillman Carter Benson, chairman of the board of Stewart, Warren Benson Corporation of this city, and Miss Lisbeth Patricia Lee, an artist of 7 Park Avenue, will be married on Friday afternoon at the Chelsea Presbyterian Church, 208 West Twenty-third Street.

Mrs. Rose Frankel of Brooklyn, who searched more than four years for her 12-year-old son, Howard, lost a fight for temporary custody of the boy today when Dougal Herr, Advisory Master of Chancery, announced that the child preferred to live with his father, Julius, and his stepmother in Linden.

Issuance of the new three-year automobile operators' license forms continued yesterday at a brisk pace, the Motor Vehicle Bureau announced. The demand for the new forms is much greater than expected, I. J. Brody, deputy commissioner, said, 7,051 being issued Monday, the first day they were available.

President Roosevelt started tonight for Roanoke Island, N. C., to speak tomorrow at ceremonies commemorating the 350th anniversary of the birth of Virginia Dare, the first white child born in North America.

E. S. French received $60,039 remuneration as president of the Boston Maine and the Maine Central railroads in 1936, according to a report to the. Interstate Commerce Commission made public yesterday. .The two railroads have common officers for the most part.

MANHATTAN DOMI, MARIANNA (July 30, 1935). Gross assets, $23,101; net, $15,852. To Gerardo Domi, husband, residue; Robert Foi, nephew, $5,000. Chief assets, jointly owned property, $14,601. Francis J. Carlucci, attorney, 12 E. 41st St.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament at the Braidburn Country Club course today developed into a close battle for low gross honors between Miss Laddie Irwin of Glen Ridge and Mrs. William Hockenjos of Crestmont.
A revision of the emergency law for defense of the State was published tonight, conceding some points put forward by German interests.
The Dodgers were singing a deep and discordant bass last night from the depths of the National League cellar, into which they either fell or were pushed by the Phillies at Ebbets Field yesterday.

Stan Horne, 25-year-old home club assistant professional, today retained his Professional Golfers' Association crown with a seventy-two-hole total of 288 at the Ottawa Hunt Club. Bob Gray Jr. of Windsor finished second with 290. The sensational bid of Gray overshadowed Horne's victory. He was seven strokes behind the winner when he started the final thirty-six holes today.
