THE armadillo school of thought has found another advocate in Quincy Howe, able editor for the firm of Simon Schuster. Like certain other students of contemporary affairs, Mr. Howe argues that the United States ought to spend the dangerous days of the twentieth century curled up in its protective shell while the less fortunate creatures of the globe claw and bite one another to pieces.
Manufacturers of low-price chinaware will make a strong bid for premium business this Fall seeking orders from manufacturers of grocery products, theatre owners and B retailers in a number of lines.
Laurence A.Steinhardt, Ambassador to Peru, and Mrs. Steinhardt are expected today at the Savoy Plaza.
Senator Borah, often cited as an authority on constitutional law, has puzzled some of his colleagues by his votes on the nomination of Senator Black.
An audience of approximately 10,000 last night filled the Randall's Island Stadium for the production of the Pulitzer Prize winner "Of Thee I Sing." The play, the fourth

Wearing ramshackle slacks, an old sweat shirt and a pulled-down cap, Devereux Milburn came .off the eighteenth green complaining bitterly that Stewart Iglehart had holed three putts of horribly illegal length on the last three holes against him and he didn't want to hear any more talk about golf. So all hands adjourned to the dining

Charged with being a fugitive from justice in Dallas, Texas, Glenn Salmon, 44 years old, of 4,401 Normandie Street, Dallas, described as having once been prominent in the stock brokerage business here and in Philadelphia, was released in $1,500 bail by Magistrate Abeles in Yorkville Court yesterday.

With 3,439 more births recorded in this city in the first thirty-two weeks of this year than in the corresponding period last year, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, predicted yesterday that 100,000 babies would be born in 1937.
The relentless manner in which Colonel Bill Terry pursues an idea even when expert opinion almost unanimously considers the whole thing a lost cause continued to pay dividends today.
The Securities and Exchange Commission's inquiry into the affairs of the Austin Silver Mining Company in an effort to prove
A special Senate committee recommended today enactment of modifled legislation to reorganize the executive branch of the Government.
Miss Solita Arbib of 112 West Seventy-second Street won a scholarship valued at $700 for attendance at the School for Fashion Careers for one year in a contest conducted by Bloomingdale's.

'Henri de Jan, a leading American business man of Latin America, died here last night of heart failure at the age of 61. Born in Grand Island, La., he came to Panama thirty years ago with the United Fruit Company at Bocas del Toro.

William Silverman, former president of Williams Co. and former vice president of Adams Co., real estate, has formed a new realty firm under the name of Herbert Lawrence Co., with offices at 1,170 Broadway.

Roy Staley of Los Angeles made the -best showing of 'any United States athlete in a track and field meet today, taking the 11O-meter Br high hurdles in 14.4 seconds. Mel Walker, Ohio State high jumper, who has twice bettered the world record, could leap only 6 feet 5 9-16 inches.

The Shinnecock Yacht Club crew of Miss .Elizabeth C. Guile, Miss Anetta C. Schroeder and Miss Susan V. Guile, won the right to represent the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association in the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Trophy tests by capturing the Morgan Bowl, emblematic of the women's championship of the bay, in the series closing today.

Harris, Hall Co. and the Milwaukee Company, successful bidders out of a group of ten for the new issue of $500,000 of city of Chicago 3 per cent water works system certificates of indebtedness due on May 1, 1951, have reoffered the certificates at 104 1/2, to yield 2.60 per cent to maturity.

The Pittsburgh Forgings Company has bought all the outstanding preferred stock of the Greenville Steel Car Company, comprising 6,296 shares of $100 par value. It owns also all the common stock of the company.

Four new pictures will come to Broadway between now and nightfall. The morning openings are "Confession," featuring Kay Francis, Ian Hunter, Basil Rathbone and Jane Bryant, at the Strand; "One Mile From Heaven," with

Five American Newspaper Guild pickets, including H. Richard Seller, president of the Seattle chapter, were arrested today after a free-for-all fight with union printers as the latter were on their way to work at The Seattle Star, against which the Guild has been on strike since July 3.

Coincident with considerably enlarged advertising campaigns for Fall, leading liquor distillers are planning to introduce several new brands, reports here yesterday indicated. Based on sales increases, Fall budgets will probably run 10 to 15 per cent ahead of a year ago, it was said.

Reports of steady deterioration in dry areas west of the Mississippi River where predictions of rain failed to materialize exerted yesterday a steady influence on prices of cotton, and the list on the Cotton Exchange ended 1 point lower to 3 points higher.

Miss Jean Forbes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John McHale Forbes of Montreal, was married to Robert Thayer, son of Mrs. Brooks Thayer of Aiken, S. C., and the late Eugene V. R. Thayer of this town, on Sunday in the Unitarian Church. Dr.

Luncheon meeting, Kiwanis Club, Hotel McAlpin, 12:30 P. M. "Causes of Depressions," "General" Jacob S. Coxey. Luncheon, Bronx Lions Club, Schnorer Club, 163d Street and Eagle Avenue, 12:30 P. M. Address by Mike Supa.

Steel ingot output was unchanged for the third consecutive week in face of a declining seasonal trend and the adjusted index has advanced to 128.7 for the week ended Aug. 14. It was 128.4 for the previous week and 105.2 for the corresponding week last year.

Trout-fly tossers cast their lines to such record lengths today as to overshoot the banks of a new WPA municipal casting pool-believed to be the world's largest. Several times the heavy trout lines curled across the 150-foot pool and dropped before gently on the opposite bank.

Dr. Charles Sheppard Hearne, a retired physician and teacher, died at his home in Swarthmore today after a long illness. He was 74. Dr. Hearne practiced medicine in this city for forty-five years, specializing during part of the time in diseases of the nose, throat and ear. He had been a member of the faculties both of Jefferson Medical College and the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine.
President Lazaro Cardenas told Yucatan farm workers last night that the Mexican revolution was only 30 per cent completed, indicating bigger steps yet to come. This has caused

British commercial communications with China were further disrupted today by an announcement that the long-established Peninsular Oriental Company had decided that its mail and passenger steamers would omit Shanghai.

The text of an analysis of the economic service rendered by free securities markets, based on studies made by a special committee of the New York Stock Exchange and included in the annual report of the Exchange, follows virtually in full:

Prohibitor, a bay colt from E. Roland Harriman's Arden Homestead Stable at Goshen, N. Y., captured the featured Times Herald Stake for 2-year-old trotters at the Harry Clay Oval today as light harness racing made its 1937 debut here. The nurse was $800.
Uptown properties furnished the bulk of activity reported in Manhattan real estate yesterday. The sales were mostly of multi-family houses.
Apparently the rumors of two and three story trailers with elevators which alarmed Nassau and Queens officials are
One of the high spots of last night's fighting here was a daring attack by two midget Chinese torpedo boats on the cruiser Izumo, the Japanese flagship.

The Richmond County Yacht Club of Staten Island, the Westhampton Beach Club and the Watch Hill Yacht Club entries qualified for the Sears Cup finals at Marblehead, Mass., here today as the semi-finals were concluded off the Pequot Yacht Club.

The establishment of a research laboratory in Washington next year as a "final link" in a program to assure the public of drugs and medicines of the highest quality was announced last night at the convention of the American Pharmaceutical Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday fell below that for the preceding week but rose slightly above the corresponding week of last year, according to the listings published in THE TIMES.

The Oliver Cromwell, twentyseven-story hotel structure at 12-18 West Seventy-second Street, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. The Oliver Cromwell bondholders committee bought in the structure for $252,814, the upset price fixed by the court.
The following is the text of the letter written yesterday by Samuel Seabury to the three Transit Commissioners with whom former Mayor James J. Walker will serve as an assistant counsel:

A group of persons interested in world peace will sail up the Hudson River from the Battery to Bear Mountain on Sunday in a "peace ship" chartered for the day by the Biosophical Institute, an organization devoted to character and peace education.

Two odds-on choices triumphed today when P. B. Codd's Devil's Mate annexed the third race at five and a half furlongs for 2-year-old fillies and T. P. Morgan's Heelfly captured the Lexington Handicap, mile and one-sixteenth feature for 3year-olds at Narragansett Park.

A strike of longshoremen was called yesterday on the piers of five coastwise lines as the aftermath of a contest between the International Longshoremen's Association and the National Maritime Union for control of the unlicensed personnel of Atlantic and Gulf shipping.

Stocks closed irregularly lower in dull trading; turnover, 658,060 shares. United States Government obligations easier, domestic corporation bonds firm, foreign issues, mixed with Japanese loans weak; transactions, $5,317,950.

Immediate United States policy in the Far Eastern crisis was outlined today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull as a middle-of-the-road course designed to provide adequate protection for American nationals in Shanghai and other danger zones until they all have had an opportunity to be evacuated.

John Roosevelt, youngest son of the American President, city officials said tonight, squirted champagne in the face of Mayor Pierre Nouveau and roughed him with a bouquet of flowers during the annual battle of flowers Sunday night. The Cannes fete committee, including the Mayor's aides, issued an official statement.
The Securities and Exchange Commission turned today to 0. Kelley Anderson, probably the youngest president of an investment trust in this country, for advice on regulatory legislation.
Meetings at which holders of securities of the Alleghany Chesapeake corporations were to have approved a plan for their merger were adjourned yesterday in Baltimore to Sept. 16.
A lone Canadian pilot, Bob Randall, dared frowning northern skies today to search the Arctic Ocean rim for the lost Soviet transpolar plane that carried Pilot Sigismund Levanevsky and five comrades.

President Roosevelt vetoed today a bill which would have granted a $1,575 gratuity to Agnes Ewing Harter, widow of First Lieutenant Albert E. I. Harter of the Army Air Corps Reserve, who was killed while voluntarily participating in a training flight.

Offering will be made today, by means of a prospectus, of 88,333 shares of $5-par-value common stock of the General American Oil Company of Texas by Russell Maguire Co., Inc. The price will be $6.50 a share.

Joseph Martin, 36 years old, known also as Joseph Ogden, Joseph Oslin and Joseph Marshal, was under arrest in West Thirtieth Street police station last night on a charge of slaying Oliver George Sinecal, 32, a small-time thief and narcotic peddler.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Aug. 16 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

MANHATTAN BARTLETT, JOHN W. (July 13). Estate, less than $10,000. To Sarah A. Bartlett, widow, executrix, 149 W. 94th St. BASCH, SAMUEL H. (Aug. 5). Estate, less than $5,000. To Hanna Basch, sister, executrix, 905 West End Ave.
The House version of the WagnerSteagall Housing Bill, scheduled for debate today, contains one great improvement over the measure as passed by the Senate.

Miss Isabel Phillips, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry H. Phillips of 911 Park Avenue, was married to Harold Vineberg of this city, formerly of Montreal, Canada, yesterday morning at the Waldorf-Astoria by the Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise.

Navy's 1937 football practice got under way today with approximately 250 plebes answering the opening call. The varsity players are on leave and will report for practice Sept. 6. By that time the plebes will have had sufficient work for use in scrimmage with the varsity.
Sten Suvio, 152, Finnish middleweight, outpointed Eddie Guerra, 152%, of New York, in six rounds at the Coney Island Velodrome last night, The Associated Press reports.

The authority of the State Mediation Board to intervene in the strike of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers was challenged in court yesterday by the Todd Shipyards Corporation and its subsidiary, the Robins Drydock and Repair Company, both of which had been summoned by the board to appear before it at a hearing scheduled for this morning.

The executive board of Labor's Non-Partisan League of New Jersey is opposed to the candidacy of United States Senator A. Harry Moore, Democrat, for the Governorship, Carl Holderman, chairman of the league, announced here today.

The new building code is a striking example of how the thing ought not to be done. It is an attempt to do the impossible--to specify for every contingency--a manifest absurdity. This way of making the law is a survival of primitive methods.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Anne Halle, daughter of Mrs. Helen B. Halle of the Hotel Ambassador and of Stanley J. Halle of Chappaqua, N. Y., to Ford de Villers Seymour, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Ford Seymour of 315 East Sixty-eighth Street.

The B. F. Goodrich Company earned a consolidated net profit of $4,010,697 in the first six months of 1937, according to a report issued yesterday by David M. Goodrich, chairman of the board. These earnings compare with $2,727,606 in the same period of last year.
A stubborn blaze yesterday morning destroyed the interior of a twostory building in the Betsy Head Park at Livonia Avenue and bouglass Street, Brooklyn.

32d St, 157-159 E, and 33d St, 156-158 E; Alma K. Apoulos to Bank for Savings; 5 years. 4 1/2 per cent ...............$15,000 72d St. 111 W; Preston Holding Co, Harry L. Hackett, president, to Land Properties. Inc., 391 E 179th St; p m, mtg, $45,950, 3 years, 5 1/2 per cent ....... $6,000 Irving P1, 3, and 14th St, 115-117 E:

Invitations have been sent out by Mr. and Mrs. Chester B. Kellogg for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Eunice Jayne Kellogg, to William King Laird, son of Dr. and Mrs. George S. Laird, which will take place on Sept. 4 in the First Congeregational Church.

The final session of the Saratoga yearling sales was held tonight and thirty-four head were auctioned for a total of $26,450, of an average of $778. The highest price realized was $2,100 for a gray yearling colt by Imp. Sir Greysteel out of Peeping Star. James Healey, father of "Bim Jim" Healey, well-known traines was the purchaser.
The House approved today a section of the third Deficiency Bill appropriating $3,000,000 for Federal participation in the New York World's Fair.

United States INSTRUCTOR OF WEAVING, $2,000 a year. Indian Field Service (including Alaska), Department of the Interior. Applications must be on file not later than Sept. 13, if received from States other than those named; Sept. 16, if received from Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho. Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming; Dec. 6, if received from

Mrs. Sidney E. Goldstein, wife of the associate rabbi of the Free Synagogue, died here this afternoon of a heart attack. She was 51 years old. Mrs. Goldstein was stricken while taking a driving lesson on the old Mamaroneck Road. She had been visiting her daughter, Mrs. Hugo L. Nichthauser, at 10 Wyndham Road, Greenburgh. Her home was at 312 West Ninety-third Street, New York.
It is frankly recognized, in the annual report by the president of the Stock Exchange, that good has in some directions resulted from Government supervision and regulation. But the burden

The deeply disturbing fact about the appointment of Hugo L. Back to the Supreme Court of the United States is not that some of his colleagues regard him as a radical, and not that he has sponsored some unwise legislation, and not that John L. Lewis was happy to endorse him.

The marriage of Miss Mary Long Hanlon, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Patrick James Hanlon of Louisville, Ky., to Frank D. Burke, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John D. Burke, also of Louisville, took place here yesterday morning in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

Court orders have been issued for a hearing on Oct. 4 of creditors and stockholders of Continental Shares, Inc., of Cleveland, an investment trust incorporated in Maryland to determine whether more than $11,500,000 of the net assets of the corporation should be distributed among its preferred stockholders.
Before the races today, Mrs. Payne Whitney gave a luncheon marking the birthday anniversary of her son, John Hay Whitney.

The Insurgents have taken twenty villages, 2,000 prisoners and large quantities of arms and stores in the first three days of their Santander offensive. The prisoners are mainly Asturians from Aviles and Gijon.

The time limit forced a Hen draw in the final-test cricket match in n between England and New Zealand today at The Oval. England declared the first innings early, but even so the New Zealanders had a fighting chance for their first victory in test cricket against England 193 except for the time limit.
Senator Royal S. Copeland was charged yesterday by the National Maritime Union with attempting to stampede Congress into passing B two bills of an alleged "strike breaking nature." The bills would
The House Rules Committee provides a typical cross-section of the Democratic elements which will come to grips for party control hereafter.
Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Dr. Thomas Robinson Moore, retired Professor of English History at the College of the City of New York and a member of the faculty of that college for nearly thirtythree years until June, 1937, died yesterday at his country home, Villamoore, Shekomeko, N. Y. Dr. Moore, whose last home here was at Hudson View Gardens, Pinehurst Avenue and 183d Street, the Bronx, was 67 years old.

The tuna just couldn't see things our way today. We left this, port at sunrise aboard the Caliban II with Captain Buddy Merritt, one of the youngest boat captains on the Long Island coastline, but who certainly knows where to fish.

Miss Teresa Riley O'Donohue, widely known for her work for Catholic charities, died yesterday at her home, 130 East Sixty-seventh Street, after a long illness. She was 72 years old. Her sister, Mrs. Jose M. Ferrer; three nieces, Mrs. Alwyn Ball 3d and the Misses Marie Irene Ferrer and Terry Ferrer, and two nephews, Jose M. Ferrer Jr. and Melchor G. Ferrer, were at her bedside.

The two brick dwellings at 232-34 High St, Newark, N J, were sold by the W E Morton Estate to Helen Mueller. The property had been owned by the Morton family for more than fifty years. Robert B. New Stoutenburgh was the broker.

Financing by the Schenley Distillers Corporation which may take the form of an issue of $25,000,000 of convertible debentures is under discussion, it was reported yesterday in the financial district. Official confirmation of the reports was lacking.

President Roosevelt has approved 280 allotments for school construction projects totaling $18,033,458, Secretary Ickes announced today. The allotments begin the fourth construction program of the PWA and provide grants of $17,091,658 and loans of $941,800 for school construction in forty-one States.

After twice overriding appeals from its Appropriations Committee to economize on Federal expenditures and help President Roosevelt to balance the budget, the House today passed the Third Deficiency Appropriations Bill, carrying $100,000,000.
Sally Solminen, the Aland Island girl who worked as a domestic servant in Massachusetts while writing the novel "Katrina," will have her book published here in America by Farrar Rinehart next month.

Japanese and Chinese, seated side by side, applauded and toasted each other heartily as Minister of Education Jean Zay lauded the idea of universal peace at a dinner here tonight marking the close of the nineteenth annual international students convention.

Frisco Dale, a chestnut colt from the stables of Pearl S. Hunderfbord at Indianapolis, set a new track record for 3-year-old pacers today I in the Illinois State Fair Graid Circuit meeting, but lost the race on the flin of a coin.

Steady progress is being made with harvesting of wheat on the prairies, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. In Manitoba more than half the crop has been cut. Mid-week showers halted threshing operations last week but the work is in full swing again, with no scarcity of labor.

Hope for an effective method of protection against infantile paralysis was expressed yesterday by Dr. Sidney David Kramer, director of the Infantile Paralysis Commission of the Long Island College of Medicine. In its report for the

The warning sounded yesterday by Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, in his annual report, against excessive governmental regulation of securities exchanges and the effect of such regulation and restriction upon the quality of the market, will undoubtedly come as a complete surprise to the financial community. No point, however,

Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the first production of the apprentice group of the Southampton Players, who tonight presented "Spring Dance," a comedy by Philip Barry, at Parrish Memorial Hall under the direction of Elia Kazan of the Group Theatre in New York.

Two petitions signed by Judge Carroll C. Hincks in Federal Court today authorized trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad to accept a compromise on a claim against the New York, Westchester Boston Railway Company and to issue equipmenttrust certificates amounting to $1,660,000.

Great Britain tonight took forthright steps to protect British interests alike in the Shanghai war zone and in the Mediterranean. Following an extraordinary meeting of Cabinet Ministers, hastily assembled by Anthony Eden, the Foreign Secretary, the Government announced two highly important decisions as follows:
Members of the Manhattan Borough President Post of the American Legion presented yesterday morning a silver loving cup won at the State Legion bugle and

According to preliminary reports from ninety Class I railroads, representing 78 per cent of the total revenues, made public today by the Association of American Railroads, the estimated operating revenues of those roads in July amounted to $280,041,407,

Monroe C., Monday, Aug. 16, aged 32, beloved husband of Mareaner Simms, devoted son of Maria and Simon and loving brother of Beatrice Wiman. Funeral 3 P. M. Wednesday, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St., Amsterdam Ave.

For the third successive week, crude oil production in the United States last week reached a record high level. The daily average gross production of crude oil was 3,718,600 barrels, an increase of 67,450 from the 3,651,150 of the preceding week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

Pathos characterized the evacuation of hundreds of Americans, Britons, Hollanders, Hungarians and Japanese yesterday. [Two hundred and ninety-four more American women and children were evacuated from Shanghai today, embarking by tender in the forenoon for the liner President McKinley, off Woosung, an Associated Press dispatch said.]

Phil Weintraub's long home run over the right-center field wall at the 354-foot mark in the eighth inning provided the margin for the Jersey City Giants to notch their second successive victory over the Red Wings tonight, 3 to 2.

The hundred thousand Chinese refugees in the foreign concessions now constitute the latter's most acute problem. Sleeping on mats in the streets unprotected from air bombs and shells and begging and whining, they are menacing the lives and peace of foreign and Chinese residents.

An increase of about 4 per cent dollar volume for average daily sales on general merchandise in small towns and rural areas during July of this year as compared with the corresponding month of 1936 was reported today by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Commerce Department.

Detroit's Tigers added a game to their margin over Chicago in the battle for second place in the American League today by winning a freehitting match from the White Sox, 11 to 7, in the series opener.

In line with the growing tendency of banks to dispose of their real estate holdings, the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn has just sold several more properties in Brooklyn and Long Island, it reported yesterday.

Suggestions for the improvement of thoroughbred racing were made by Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the New York State Racing Commission; Joseph E. Widener, vice chairman of the Jockey Club, and Marshall Cassidy, steward for the State Commission, at the second session of the National Association of State Racing Commissioners' convention today.
New York is a cosmopolitan city, and one of Dr. Copeland's obvious qualifications to be its Mayor is his intense realization of the existence of so many groups with ties across the seas.

Norman Beach Conger, retired "grand old man" of the United States Weather Bureau office in Detroit, died today at his home of a heart attack. He was 78 years old. Mr. Conger entered the Government service as a meteorologist fifty-four years ago.

St. Ignatius College, a seminary for the training of Jesuit priests, will open on Sept. 6 in Inisfada, the former estate of Mrs. William J. Babington Macaulay, it was announced here today. The 131-acre estate was the gift of the former Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady.

There was joy up in Boston town tonight-the mighty Ranger struck out. On the first run of the New York Yacht Club cruise, that today from New London here, the America's Cup defender was pitched down to her second defeat, and by none other than the veteran Yankee, which pulled a-sweeping curve on her.
Jefferson Caffery, the new United States Ambassador to Brazil, presented his credentials to President Getulio Vargas this afternoon.

A three-cornered battle for primacy in the organization of technical workers in the radio broadcasting industry developed yesterday with the American Federation of Labor, the Committee for Industrial Organization and independent em,ploye groups seeking to enroll members in studios throughout the country.

Mrs. Theodore M. Edison of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, daughter-inlaw of the late Thomas A. Edison, will begin a six-month interneship in October in the pharmacy of Orange Memorial Hospital, it was announced today by F. Stanley Howe, director of the institute.

Sir Herbert Marler, Minister for Canada to the United States, and Lady Marler; Grover A. Whalen, president of the 1939 New York World's Fair, and State Senator Thomas G. Desmond of New York, with Mrs. Desmond are among the passengers booked to sail today for Europe on the French liner Normandie.

The first renewal of interest in men's Fall clothing in several months was reported here yesterday, when retailers started sending in requests to manufacturers and resident buyers to start shipping the new styles.

Miss Helen Detweiler of Washington, Maryland State champion, set a new women's record for the Shawnee course when she shot a 75, two under women's par, to defeat Miss Eliza Todd of Philadelphia, 8 and 6, today in the first round of the Shawnee Country Club golf tournament.

Donald Budge appeared on the grand stand court at the Newport Casino this morning for his first MI singles match since his return from abroad. The red-headed young giant who brought the Davis Cup back to the United States received a warm reception from the gallery and in the afternoon he got another of a Ca different kind from Herbert L. Bowman of New York.

A remarkable document, purporting to give a confidential report by Dr. Chaim Weizmann, Zionist president, of a conversation he had in London with William G. A. Ormsby-Gore, British Colonial Secretary, on a plan for the partition of Palestine, has been published by The Jewish Chronicle here.

Having had one ordinance against the wearing of scanty attire on the streets invalidated by the Court of Appeals because of vague phraseology, the city of Yonkers seemed headed toward further legal difficulties today when Mayor Joseph F. Loehr signed a new "modesty ordinance" which some observers also declared to be vague and widely inclusive.
The Senate Finance Committee adopted a favorable report tonight on the Administration's tax loophole legislation, after a three-hour night session with Treasury experts.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Catty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Douglas Catty of Highfields Farm, this place, to Brian Hutton Dulanty, elder son of John W. Dulanty, High Commissioner in London for the Irish Free State, and Mrs. Dulanty, took place this morning in St. John's Roman Catholic Church.

Eric Seelig, 1631/4, Germany, received credit for a knockout over Frank LoBianco, 1601/4, Brownsville middleweight, in the feature bout listed for eight rounds at the Queensboro Arena last night. A crowd of 2.000 was present.

The legislative committee to investigate the sufficiency of parole, probation, mental hygiene and correction laws will be named shortly by Speaker Oswald D. Heck of the Assembly and Senator John J. Dunnigan.
Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt entertained at dinner at Beaulieu this evening before taking her guests to the Casino Theatre for the first performance of "Inconstant Moon," starring Dorothy Sands.

A move to aid investors in "guaranteed" mortgages generally and creditors of the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company specifically will be advanced tomorrow when Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, will appear before the State Banking Board to urge the granting of a charter for a company to act as trustee for guaranteed mortgage certificates under court order and to carry on the work of the Mortgage Corporation of New York.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John A. McEveety of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Elizabeth McEveety, to Stewart Woodruff, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. David Woodruff of Philadelphia.

Beside the barn she drowses in the sun, The placid guardian of all she sees, And watches where her kittens roll and run And pounce and play in youthful ecstasies. She seems the picture of a quiet dame With not a thought beyond the corn-crib mice,

Only occasional shelling by Japanese warships last night broke a lull that had settled over the Shanghai war fronts after a day of intermittent bombardments by artillery, warships and airplanes. The comparative quiet permitted neutral observers to check up more thoroughly on the results of five days of intensive Sino-Japanese fighting here.

The University of Rochester announced today extension of its "social security" plan to provide benefits for more than 1,000 faculty and non-faculty employes covering their service prior to 1936, when it inaugurated the plan.

Knowledge of the course proved, valuable to Frank Graven today as; the Long Island Golf Association held one of its one-day amateur events over the Plandome Golf Club layout. Graven, one of the star performers of the home club, walked away with the event by turning in a 70, two under par figures.

The Government was informed today via Compania Electro Siderurgica de Valdivia, Chiles' only iron-smelting and steel-rolling mills, which operate with government aid, that production had reached a point both in volume and quality affording a prospect of Chile's early independence of purchases abroad.

A record Long Island entry for the tournament could not equal the aces scored in the New Jersey and Westchester divisions of the sixth annual World-Telegram hole-in-one golf competition, which was concluded yesterday on the Bayside links. An eight-inch shot made on Monday by Stanley Remsen, Bethpage assistant professional, topped the Island's two days of play.

Excessive governmental regulation is threatening a "broad, liquid market" for securities and has already created "abnormal market conditions," Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, says in his annual report, released for publication today.
James McIntyre of the famous vaudeville team of McIntyre and Heath was still critically ill and in a coma today at his home on Fish Cove Road, Noyack, three miles from here. He was 80 years old

The block front of land on the north side of Twenty-ninth Avenue between Parsons Boulevard and Louis 146th Street, in the Old Country Club Estates, Flushing, L. I., has been sold to the J. B. Holding Company, Benjamin Strizver president. Klein Jackson were the sellers.
As a benefit for the State's blind, Mrs. William Ellery Sedgwick opened the Sedgwick mansion at Stockbridge for a sale today.

A large audience attended the benefit given for St. Luke's Episcopal Church here tonight at Wyandanch Farm, home of Judge and Mrs. Samuel Seabury. Mrs. Seabury showed slides of English gardens and explained points of interest about them.

Additional evidence designed to show that the Horn Hardart Company, operator of a chain of automats and cafeterias against which a strike is now in progress, had sought to influence the election of its employes in the poll conducted by the State Labor Relations Board on July 16, was presented yesterday at the board's hearing at 80 Centre Street.

The Buick division of the General Motors Corporation will ship this week the last of the 220,353 cars produced during the 1937 model year, a gain of 51,757 units, or 30 per cent, over production in 1936.

Lester E. Wurfel Sr., vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America here, died today in the Whitefield Hospital, Whitefield, N. H., according to word received at the insurance company offices. He was spending his vacation in New Hampshire. He-was 52 years old and lived at 255 Forrest Avenue, Glen Ridge.

The brakes on the gasoline-driven miniature train that fatally injured a 3-year-old girl at a Rockaway Beach concession on Aug. 8 were defective, policemen of the Queens motor vehicle squad testified yesterday in Queens Felony Court at the hearings of three men held on charges growing out of the accident.

W. G. Maguire was named president of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company at an organization meeting today. Other officers are: A. F. Dixon and H. P. Childs, vice presidents; H. L. Tower, treasurer and William Tringham, secretary. Mr. Maguire, Mr. Dixon and J. R. Mellor were named to the executive committee.

The decline in Japanese dollar bonds was accentuated yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange as the Sino-Japanese struggle again served as the dominating influence on the bond market here.

Mayor La Guardia took the first definite step yesterday in his new plan to protect society from sex criminals when he committed Christopher Kiesel, a 38-year-old prisoner, to Kings County Hospital for observation.

In one of the largest leases of office space negotiated in several months in the Wall Street district, Haskins Sells, accountants, have taken about 25,000 square feet of space, comprising the seventeenth and eighteenth floors of the International Telephone and Telegraph Building at 67 Broad Street. Schlang Brothers Co. acted as brokers in the deal.

National lumber consumption this year is expected to reach between 26,000,000,000 and 26,500,000,000 feet, the special survey committee on lumber consumption, lumber stocks and anticipated lumber consumption, headed by Thomas S. Holden, vice president of the F. W. Dodge Corporation, has reported to the Department of Commerce, it was announced yesterday.

Outsiders failed again today to dent the seeded list in the Essex County Club's women's invitation tennis tournament as the two topseeded Boston stars, Miss Kay Win. throp and Mrs. Virginia Rice Johnson, swept into the quarter-finals, seeking the honors undefended by Miss Alice Marble, national champion.
Frederick H. Somerville, a former teacher and author of school textbooks, died of a heart attack last night at his home in Lansdowne in his sixty-sixth year.
Following months of study and discussion, the Board of Regents announced today that it had reorganized the personnel and work of the State Education Department. This was

The German Government announced today another public loan, this time of 700,000,000 marks. It is the third such loan thus far this year and the tenth since the Government began to mobilize the public capital market for its purposes in 1935, the total of these loans, including the present one, amounting to 6,518,000,000 marks.

Train service on the Sixth Avenue elevated was disrupted for two hours yesterday when the base of a steel support for the structure was shifted about four inches following a blast set by the workers excavating for the new Sixth Avenue subway.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Cox Judge, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Judge, to W. Joseph White Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. White of Lynchburg, Va., took place today at SS. Philip and James Catholic Church here.
Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank of New York, complained to the Supreme Court today against a $728,709 Federal income tax levy for 1929.

Because war between China and Japan may interfere with heavy shipments to the latter country, one of its best customers for dissolving pulps, the Rainier Pulp and Paper Company has filed an amendment, setting forth the facts, to a registration statement previously filed under the Securities Act of 1933.

Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., Chief City Magistrate, yesterday filed with the Bureau of the Budget a request for an appropriation of $1,708,225 to cover the expenses of the city magistrates' courts for the coming year. This sum is an increase of $36,090 over the current vear.

Goods are still being moved from this country to Shanghai despite the fact that most export houses handling orders from China have suspended shipments for the time being, according to information brought out at a round-table discussion of Far East problems at the Export Managers Club luncheon in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

Effective on Sept. 1, brokers will require a minimum of 50 per cent margin on stocks carried for customers having a market value of $1 to $3. Stock purchases under $1 will have to be paid in full, the managing committee of the Toronto Exchange has ruled, but brokers will have the option of carrying on the 50-per-cent basis stocks which fall below $1 after purchase.
Former President Herbert Hoover said today the Supreme Court is "one-ninth packed" with the selection of Senator Black as a Supreme Court Justice.

The first local tryout of the season, "Never Trouble Trouble," a comedy by Katharine Hilliker and H. H. Caldwell, was presented last evening at the Brighton Theatre, Brighton Beach, under the sponsorship of John Golden. Peggy Wood,

Templeton, with Raymond Guest in an unusual position for him-No. 1--rode against Aurora today on Cochran Field at the Meadow Brook Club-and triumphed, 13 to 12, in a game that moved very fast at times. The two teams, preparing

The marriage of Miss Doris Marion Kappel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Kappel of 101 Central Park West, to Hyam S. Morrison, son of Mrs. Edith Morrison of London, England, and the late Maxwell Morrison, took place yesterday afternoon in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Boston Rd (10-2621), e s, 58 ft n e of Teasdale Pl, 29x83; Me-Har Construction Corp to 962 Boston Rd Corp, 18 East 41st St. Cruger Ave (16x4509), w s, 392 ft s of Arnow Ave, 29x100; Paul Gordon to Flora Meyers, 2,731 Cruger Ave.

Two former employes of the Weirton Steel Company declared today that they were discharged after they refused to become members of the "hatchet gang," allegedly maintained by the company for purposes of terrorization.

A TIMES reader wants to know what has happened to our Mayor's anti-noise campaign, and warns Mr. La Guardia grimly that "election is near." There is, of course, a certain incongruity between the idea of an anti-noise campaign and an election campaign.
The executive committee of the National Automobile Dealers Association today

Rodolfo Chiari, former President of the Republic of Panama, died in a hospital here last night. He came to California a year ago for his health. He was 67 years old. Mr. Chiari was President from 1924 to 1928 and served as Vice President of the republic for two terms. The body will be taken to Panama tonight for burial.
Americans and Filipinos alike made room in their homes, hotels and apartments tonight for American refugees from Shanghai.

Oversize stocks of peas and tomatoes will soon be absorbed by heavy consumption resulting from offprices, the American Institute of Food Distribution reported yesterday. Sales in one chain store have run four times as great in July as a year ago, and standard tomatoes in the Tri-State area have sold in greater quantities than during the peak of the 1936 buying period.
Approval of a reorganization plan for the 85year-old Brown Company, rayon pulp and paper manufacturer, was urged today by a general creditors' advisory committee.

Contributors to private charity are more numerous now than in the boom year of 1929, Charles P. Taft, chairman of the 1937 Community Mobilization for Human Needs, said in a statement released yesterday at the organization's offices, 155 East Forty-fourth Street.
The Red Sox had little trouble taking the first of a three-game series with the Athletics today, supporting Jack Wilson's eight-hit pitching with a fourteen-hit assault to win, 6 to 1.
Dr. H. H. Kung, the Chinese Minister of Finance, during his sojourn in Vienna has negotiated with armament concerns for the delivery of war matrial to China.
Annual scholarships and prizes given by the New York Library Association, a state-wide organization, were announced here today by Miss Marie D. Loizeaux, publicity chairman of the organization.
Edwin Doak Mead, author, lecturer and noted worker on behalf of peace, died today after a long illness at the age of 87. He was a former director of the World Peace Foundation.

Seven of thirty-nine men indicted on July 3 in the Federal Government's investigation of the disability insurance racket, including an attorney, pleaded guilty yesterday when they were arraigned in Federal court before Judge Murray Hulbert.

Patrick Brown of Scarsdale, N. Y., was killed today when his automobile plunged off a curve under a railroad trestle sixteen miles west of here, and two companions, also of Scarsdale, were sent to a hospital in serious condition. The three were homeward bound.

Gaining a first and a third in today's two races, the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club crew of Burton Morris, Arthur Barlow and Rodman De Kay sailed into the lead in the annual midget championship series of the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.

A. I. Namm Son's new 6 per cent sinking fund debenture bonds of 1947, offered in exchange to holders of the outstanding mortgage certificates, are now available to subscribers at the offices of the Manufacturers Trust Company, exchange agent.

Twenty authors, including Sinclair Lewis, Theodore Dreiser, Robert Benchley and Joseph Hergesheimer, wrote on how they managed to have their first work published in "Breaking Into Print," which will be published by Simon Schuster on Sept. 10. Elmer Adler.

Two Detroit aviators, Charles Davis and Gottlieb Bauer, landed their monoplane at 6:21 P. M. (Eastern standard time) tonight after surpassing the unofficial refueling endurance record for light planes.

The Port of New York Authority awarded yesterday a new issue of $15,000,000 of its general and refunding 3 1/4 per cent bonds, dated Aug. 15, 1937, and due on Aug. 15, 1977, to a banking group headed by the National City Bank of New York, Brown Harriman Co., Inc.,

Brazil's debt negotiations with the United States, it was learned today, have been concluded. Announcement of a new scheme for payments is due soon. The proposals are directly between Brazil and the United: States and are free of any arrangement with Brazil which may later enter with other coun-tries.
The Suffragan Bishop of Middleton, the Right Rev. Cecil Wilfred Wilson, was found dead at his home last night. He was 62 years od.

In the second quarter of this year, Great Britain was busier than it had ever been before, according to the official "industrial activity" figures published tonight. The boom is helping most industrial districts.

Captain Ludwig Schlimbach, who retired from the Hamburg-American Line six years ago after making fast trips across the ocean as master of the liner Hamburg, sailed slowly up to Quarantine last night in his thirty-three foot yawl, Stoertebeker, in which he crossed the ocean alone in fifty-seven days.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had denied a petition of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, a subsidiary of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, for authorization of a revision of its capital.

Movements of the livestock on Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 9,000, including 3,000 directs. Market uneven, steady to 25c lower than Tuesday's average; most loss on weights from 210 pounds down;

Atley Donald, Newark's sensational rookie hurler, squeezed through to his seventeenth victory of the season today when the Bears defeated Montreal, 7-6. The triumph gave the Bears the series, 5 to 2, and boosted their league lead to 25 1/2 games.

Slaughter In China, on a major scale, is inevitable now. So long as the Sino-Japanese conflict was confined to North China, there was a good chance that a peaceful adjustment could be made. The events of the last few days in Shanghai have changed all that.
Preparations are now being made on a large scale which can hardly be explained by assuming any lesser objective than the complete defeat of China.
Kid Chocolate, former featherweight champion of the world, will return to the scene of some of his greatest feats tonight when he appears in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.

The State Department announced today that eighty-six Americans, evacuated from Shanghai, arrived at Kobe, Japan, on the President raft, which left Shanghai Monday. Winthrop R. Scott, United States consul at Kobe, said usual formalities were waived by local officials and that no landing difficulties were experienced.

Miss Helen Detweiler of the Congressional Club, Washington, continued to set the pace in the Shawnee women's invitation golf tournament today, beating Miss P. Laros of Saucon Valley, Bethlehem, Pa., 8 and 7, in the second round over the Shawnee Country Club course, scene of the 1938 national P. G. A. championship.

Republican resentment against Mayor La Guardia's "do nothing" attitude toward the party nomination flared openly for a short time yesterday when Joseph D. McGoldrick, organization designee for Controller, termed the Mayor's attitude "very unsatisfactory and very indefinite."

After Howard Krist won the first game for them, 4 to 1, with a fourhit pitching performance, the Rochester Red Wings took the second part of tonight's twin bill from the Jersey City Giants, 3 to 1, as Lefty Bill Walker pitched steady sevenhit ball.

More than 8,000 office workers were delayed for hours in getting to their work and suffered other inconveniences when elevator and other service employes went on strike at 8:45 A. M. yesterday in the twin twenty-two-story Hudson Terminal Buildings at 30 and 50 Church Street.

American-Canadian trade agreements have placed the Bermuda farmer in a worse position than ever before. Last year, as far as export markets were concerned, was the most disastrous year on record, says the Bermuda Department of Agriculture's 1936 report.

" Old Music," by Keith Winter, proved at the St. James Theatre tonight to be a period piece of the Crimean War extremely well told with studies of men and women that are neither commonplace nor superficial.

Premier Benito Mussolini today praised the high degree of efficiency reached by Italy's military machine as shown in the Sicilian manoeuvres just concluded, in a short address to all the officers who participated in the war games.
After deliberating for six months on the new Constitution, the Estonian National Assembly completed its work yesterday, celebrating the occasion with a special meeting.
Mrs. Dixie Graves, wife of Governor Bibb Graves of Alabama, will be appointed by her husband to the seat vacated by Senator Black, the Governor telephoned Senator Bankhead today.

Mayor La Guardia made a group of sixty-six local government officials from Great Britain chuckle at the Summer City Hall yesterday when he told them there was nothing like visiting other cities "to take the conceit out of a man."

The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows: Temperatures in the Cotton Belt during the week ranked from much above normal in the northwest to about normal in the more eastern sections.

Overlooked in the betting by a midweek crowd of 15,000 most of whom put their money on either the Le Mar Stock Farm entry or W. C. Stroube's Huskie Boy, the Paragon Stable's Bold Turk stood out plainly at the finish of the six-furlong Shawomet Stakes today at Narragansett Park, winning by a length.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The discrimination in business and industry against persons "too old" at 35 or even younger represents a serious problem for a large proportion of the working population, and calls for vigorous and organized action on the part of the victims of this narrow-minded and anti-social prejudice-for prejudice
The White Sox climbed back to within a half game of the second-place Tigers today when Vernon Kennedy held Detroit to four hits for a 6-to-O triumph in the second game of the series.

Mr. and Mrs. Moncure Biddle of Philadelphia are at the St. Regis. Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ord Bretherton, who have been for some time at Cape Cod, are at the WaldorfAstoria before returning to Sunnybank, their home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. Mr. and Mrs. Duncan A. Holmes are at the Pierre.

Andrew J. Allen of this place, principal for more than thirty years of the David E. Rue Junior High School in Hoboken, N. J., until his retirement in 1933, died yesterday at his Summer home in Mongaup, N. Y. His age was 74.

The investment possibilities of improved real estate along Fiftyseventh Street in the Columbus Circle area were emphasized again yesterday when it was learned that another property in the section had passed to new control.

The Transport Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, announced last night the signing and ratification of a closed shop contract with the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, which controls or operates nearly all surface transportation in Manhattan.

Business on the stock market here today was on an extremely small scale, but prices were steadier in some sections. Gilt-edge issues did better while among, the foreign loans Far Eastern bonds finished well. Transatlantic securities rallied and the leaders went ahead.

The Japanese market for steel has changed from scrap to a preference for the finished product in the last few weeks, according to shipping men. The outbreak of hostilities with China, creating need for munitions, and the fact that finished steel may be used immediately and scrap must first be processed and purified are considered the principal causes of the change.

The factory building at 139 Thirty-seventh Street and the one-family house at 143 Thirty-seventh Street, Union City, N. J., have been sold by Albert Meyers to the Tiffany Embroidery Works, Inc., and Charles Steller respectively. Otto E. Reimenschneider acted as attorney in the transactions. J. B. Wolfe, Inc., was the broker.

Orders taken in July by the Baldwin Locomotive Works and subsidiary companies, including the Midvale Company, amounted' to $2,375,589, compared with $2,663,136 for July, 1936, the company announced today.

Students gifted in music or art show superiority in academic studies and do better than average work in the classroom, Frederic Ernst, assistant superintendent of schools, declared in his annual report on the Music and Art High School, made public yesterday.

The non-Zionists, headed by the Americans, led a heavy attack on the British proposal for the partition of Palestine at the opening here today of the debate of the council of the Jewish Agency for Palestine on the Zionist resolution to authorize negotiations for a Jewish State on this basis.

The text of former Mayor James J. Walker's statement in reply to Samuel Seabury follows: I have read Mr. Seabury's gratuitous communication to the Transit Commission and note that it was done in a truly Seaburian manner.
Buoyed by the "hope that springs eternal," Max Schmeling arrived in this country again yesterday in search of a match with Joe Louis for the latter's heavyweight championship of the world.

The Gotham Credit Corporation of New York, an automobile financing concern, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement for 200 shares of Class A convertible capital stock, no par value, to be offered at $62.50 a share, and 115,000 shares of Class B $5-par capital stock.

The Bermudan House of Assembly today approved the recently negotiated contract with Furness, Withy Co., Ltd., for a steamship service to New York. Under the contract, which is to run for five years, Bermuda will pay an annual subsidy of ??26,000 and [Pound]1,000 for each additional sailing over 100, the additional sailings being limited to 100.

A stocky, red-headed steel mill employee swore here today that he was rebuked by the chairman of the Weirton Steel Company's employe representation plan, alleged to be a company union, for having failed to "get" a union organizer.

James McIntyre of the old vaudeville and minstrel team of McIntyre and Heath, died at 6:30 A. M. today .on his estate in Noyack, near here, in his eighty-first year. He had been unconscious since last Friday; remained so to the end.

Storms that come in the night wash out ball games that are scheduled in the daytime--in Brooklyn. The Dodger officials called off yesterday's game between their cellar dwellers and the seventh-place Phillies and arranged for a doubleheader today.

A request for $4,390,000 in the 1938 city budget will be made for City College early next month. The budget estimate was adopted yesterday at a joint meeting of the finance committee and the executive committee of the Board of Higher Education, held at the City College School of Business and Civic Administration, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

John Roosevelt, the youngest son of President Roosevelt, denied today that he had squirted champagne in the face of Mayor Pierre Nouveau of Cannes or slapped him with a bouquet of flowers at a Cannes battle of flowers last Sunday.

Plans are being made for a Georgian tea party to be given on Sept. 23 at the home of Miss--Miriam Walker here, under the auspices of the Connecticut committee for the preservation of Stratford Hall, ancestral home of the Lees in Virginia.

This morning's brightest news is that Ina Claire will be back on Broadway this season, appearingfor the first time in her careerunder the management and direction of Guthrie McClintic in a new dramatization of Anthony Trollope's famous novel, "Barchester Towers."
CONFESSION. from a screen play by Hans Rameau; adaptation by Julius J. Epstein and Margaret LeVine; directed by Joe May; a First National production. At the Strand.

The first of the major entertainments of tennis week took place tonight at Beach Mound, where Mrs. Skirvin Adams gave a dinner for about seventy-five guests and it was followed by dancing for which fully 200 other guests came in.

Wool growers are optimistic about the future outlook for their product, Walter K. Porzer, general director of Associated Wool Industries, said yesterday. He has just returned from a four weeks' trip to Arizona, Colorado, Utah and Wyoming. "Growers feel that the close of the year will see them well along the road out of debt," Mr. Porzer said.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York yesterday requested an addition of thirty days to the time limit, Sept. 1, for the exchange of its $5 preferred stock for the $6 and $7 preferred issues of its affiliate, the New York Steam Corporation. In so doing,

As a Democratic caucus was summoned to meet tomorrow night to force the Black-Connery Wages and Hours bill to a vote, Representative Shannon of Missouri reminded the House that it was paying its waiters only $35 a month, and fining them $2.50 every time a guest walked out of the restaurant without paying his check.

Albert Levitt, former Federal judge in the Virgin Islands, filed a petition in the Supreme Court today in which he asked that Senator Hugo L. Black of Alabama, confirmed by the Senate yesterday as an associate justice of the court, be required to "show cause" that he is eligible for the office before he is permitted to take his seat. Mr.

FROM now on the Compleat Letter Writer, Clark Calvin Griffith, owner of the Washington Senators, can rest on his epistolary oars as far as this observer is concerned. His help is no longer needed and any volunteer contributions from his pen will be scanned with a cold eye.

The Federal Trade Commission today made public a list of trade practice rules for the wholesale jewelry industry, proposed by the National Wholesale Jewelers Association, and invited persons to express approval or disapproval not later than Sept. 3, 1937.

The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated Aug. 17: b: LIEUTENANT COLONEL Cocroft. R. B., C. A. C., name placed on detached officers' list, effective upon reporting for duty at Fort Monroe, Va.

Cardinal Dougherty, Count Theo Rossi, well-known Italian sportsman; Guido Cattaneo, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Johnson, Marchese Rossi Longhi, Count and Countess Soranzo, Mr. and Mrs. Ellory Stone and Mr. and Mrs. Martin Greenwald are passengers due today from Mediterranean ports on the Italian motor ship Conte di Savoia, which is bringing a total of 1,495. Also on board is Mrs. Maryl Lednicka.
Under the leadership of Dr. Herman F. Reissig of New York a delegation of eleven persons left Paris today to visit Loyalist Spain in behalf of the North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee failed to act today at its final scheduled session on Secretary of State Cordell Hull's request for legislation to permit the lease of decommissioned destroyers to Brazil.

Samuel D. Bleich of 88 Seventyfirst Street, Brooklyn, a civil engineer employed by the city or State for thirty-three years until his retirement in 1936, died yesterday in the Madison Park Hospital, Brooklyn, after a year's illness. His age was 57.
The Cinderella of the current festival-Webers "Euryanthe" --was brought forward at the Festspielhaus tonight for the first of two performances.

Prices of wheat were on the down grade today. At no time were they above yesterday's closing level and final trades were at practically the bottom. Net losses of 1 7/8 cents were recorded on the Board of Trade here, while Winnipeg declined 2 1/2 to 2 5/8 cents and Liverpool 1 7/8 to 2 3/8 cents.

Colonel Jacob Ruppert took a holiday yesterday and made one of his infrequent visits to the Stadium. The millionaire owner of the Yankees saw a convincing demonstration of why his club is so far ahead in the American League pennant race.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt acquired a new sobriquet today"the sweetheart of all the world." It was gallantly conferred on her by Michael Karpelman, a policeman. The President's wife, driving a coupe, had pulled up to the curb to ask him the way to Providence.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. McAdams of this place and Belle Harbor, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth McAdams, to Raymond A. Dillon of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Dillon.

David Meade of the White Plains Y. M. C. A. tonight broke the Westchester County junior 100-yard free-style record, clipping one and eight-tenth seconds off the mark of 1 minute which he set a year ago.

A new method of extracting alkaloids in toxicological analysis that has enabled toxicologists to prove or disprove more definitely that poison was the cause of death, was reported yesterday at the scientific section of the American Pharmaceutical Association in convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Degnon of New York gave a large cocktail party in the Cave Grill here tonight. At the Mount Washington are Mr. and Mrs. Russell H. Tucker, New York; Mr. and Mrs. R. A. Hall and Robert Townsend, Great Neck, L. I.; Miss Grace A. Roach, Hampton Bays, L. I.; Mr. and Mrs. John J. Loftus and Miss Katherine Loftus, Brooklyn; Dr.

New York State authorities, intent on carrying out Governor Lehman's orders to stamp out dog race gambling, were faced today with a new Federal court writ directing them to show cause why they should not be restrained from interfering with a track at Syracuse.

A message from Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Minister, was received today at the Virginia Dare celebration on Roanoke Island, at which President Roosevelt spoke. Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, relayed the message. Sir Ronald wrote:
Six hours after she plunged into a cistern filled with eight feet of water to rescue her 2-year-old daughter, Mrs. Glen McGow of Clinton gave birth to a son. Both mother and son are doing well.

The engagement of $660,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of this amount $210,000 was bought in London yesterday while $450,000 was secured at some previous time.
Dr. Everett Willoughby Gould, physician and alumni trustee of Columbia University, died suddenly yesterday at the Forest Lake Club, Hawley, Pa. He was 63 years old.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum in the United States on Aug. 7 were 307,922,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented a net decrease of 328,000 barrels in a week, comprising a decrease of 530,000 in stocks of domestic petroleum and an increase of 202,000 in those of foreign oil.

Price movements of commodity futures were irregular in active trading on the local markets yesterday. For the third successive day the volume in world sugar futures reached record-breaking proportions. On the cash markets corn, oats and raw sugar advanced, but wheat, rye, flour, cocoa, lard, tins and cotton declined.

The International Longshoremen's Association called off its strike on the piers of five coastwise lines yesterday afternoon in return for a conference on its demands with the executives of the lines. A meeting will be held this morning in the offices of John E. Craig, vice president of the Clyde Mallory Lines, at Pier 34, North River.
A high-ranking Army Air Corps officer and a staff sergeant were burned to death today when their plane burst into flames in a cow pasture.

Thoroughbred racing in the United States represents an in,vestment of around $125,000,000 and pays a total tax in excess of $10,000,000, Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, told the National Association of State Racing Commissioners in his review of the sport at the concluding session of the organization's convention in the Grand Union Hotel today .

The four three-story structures at 120-126 Thirty-third Street, Brooklyn, have been sold for cash by Henry E. Elfmont and William Perry Doing, operators, to a client of M. B. Sief. The structures on a plot 100 by 100 feet and the entire parcel is assessed at $26,000. Samuel Morse was the attorney for the sellers. The Tallo Realty Company, Inc., were the brokers in the deal.

William P. Farnsworth resigned yesterday as New York administrative officer of the Federal Theatre Project, a post he has held since last March. He will continue in office until his successor is appointed.

State Senators Clifford R. Powell of Burlington County and Lester H. Clee of Essex County, candidates for the Republican nomination for Governor, tiled their nominating petitions today at the office of the Secretary of State at the Capitol here.

A solemn high mass of requiem was celebrated yesterday in St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church, Twelfth Street near Fourth Avenue, for Philip F. Donohue, treasurer of Tammany Hall, who died Sunday at the age of 79 years.

Mrs. Anna MarieHahnkissedher 12-yearold son Oscar today as she pleaded innocent in Common Pleas Court to indictments charging her with murdering two Germans, Jacob Wagner, 78, and George Gsellman, 67, by poison.
There is great excitement in Canton over a report that Japanese planes circled overhead. The Chinese, in panic, have rushed to Shameen, where police are striving to restore order.

Old Westbury scored another victory today as test matches among teams preparing for the open polo championship were resumed. The victors turned back Aknusti, 10 to 5, in a hard-fought match that saw the big field of the Piping Rock Club opened for practice sessions.

The German Davis Cup player, Heinrich Henkel, almost missed the liner Queen Mary, which sailed today for New York, when at the last minute he discovered he had forgotten his passport at his Paris hotel.

Several hundred delegates to the annual convention of the National Shorthand Reporters Association unanimously approved yesterday proposals of their legislative committee to establish professional standards for persons engaged in that service and to oppose existing practices in the Federal courts and Government bureaus.

Walter Spence, New York A. C., added the New York State outdoor 400-meter free style championship to his extensive list of honors by capturing the feature event at the A. A. U. water carnival held in the Ravenhall A. C. pool, Coney Island, last night.

A committee of railroad executives cited 1936 deficits of forty railroads toda in answer to the request of the five operating brotherhoods for a 20 per cent wage increase. The committee, headed by H. A. Enochs of the Pennsylanvia road, informed representatives of the 300,000 brotherhood members that the forty roads had a combined loss of $112,000,000 last year.

Proposed waterfront park development at Canarsie and at Dyker Beach, Brooklyn, will have to wait a long time before the water in those areas is "suitable for bathing," Parks Commissioner Robert Moses told the Interstate Sanitation Commission yesterday.

The University of Pennsylvania received $100,000 and the Playground and Recreation Society of America, with headquarters in New York, received $50,000 through a life-insurance trust upon the death on June 30 of Clarence Munroe Clark, banker, utility operator and sportsman, it was disclosed today. The estate was estimated at $5,000,000.

Shattering the course competitive record of 68 with a morning round of 66, which he followed with a 72, Frank Moore, assistant pro at Quaker Ridge, forged to the front in the Westchester open golf championship at Green Meadow today.

Unseeded and unranked nationally, Mrs. Bonnie Miller Blank of Los Angeles scored the first major upset of the Essex County Club's women's invitation tennis tournament today when she vanquished the nation's eleventh ranking player, Mrs. Virginia Rice Johnson of Boston, 4--6, 6--2, 6--4, in the quarter-finals.

THE backwardness of the military mind, according to Liddell Hart, is one of the hopes of civilization. It is conceivable that, could full use be made of the new weapons made available by science, another great European war would come near destroying Western civilization.

A fabric identification and certification program is being launched by the Neva-Wet Corporation of America that will feature the use of tags specifying the construction of fabrics processed and the establishment of a modern testing laboratory in display space, which has been leased at 500 Fifth Avenue.

The Board of Governors of the New York Curb Exchange approved yesterday the application of the International Paper and Power Corporation to list purchase warrants for 1,347,748 shares of common stock upon official notice of issuance pursuant to the company's plan for change in capitalization.
The Rev. Alfred Newbery, rector of the Church of the Advent, Boston, and nationally known Episcopal clergyman, died suddenly last night of a heart ailment. He was 46 years old.

Continuing to stress defense against a left hook, Tommy Farr, heavyweight titleholder of the British Empire, boxed six fast rounds today in preparation for his title bout with World Champion Joe Louis at the Yankee Stadium Aug. 26.
Joseph C. Marks, engaged in the brokerage business for more than thirty years, died today at Christ Hospital at the age of 52.

The Pan American Clipper III alighted at the Azore Islands at 6:45 A. M. (New York time) yesterday after an uneventful flight from Bermuda, Harold E. Gray, captain of the flying boat, reported to the Pan American base at Port Washington, L. I.

For more than four hours the Senate wrangled today in an effort to get a vote on the bill placing regulation of the transportation of passengers and property by air in the Interstate Commerce Commission.

A motion for a special panel from which to select the jury for the trial of Robert Irwin, accused of the murder of Mrs. Mary Gedeon, her daughter Veronica and Frank Byrnes, their lodger, will be made Tuesday by District Attorney William C. Dodge in General Sessions, it was announced yesterday by Albert B. Unger, Acting District Attorney. Judge John J. Freschi also will be asked to set a date for the trial.
Mrs. Jonas B. Frenkel, leader in local and national Jewish philanthropic organizations, died today at her home after a long illness. Mrs. Frenkel had been ill for two years. She was 69 years old.

Senator Royal S. Copeland and his running mates, Frank J. Priai and Borough President Samuel Levy, won first place on both the Democratic and Republican primary ballots yesterday in the drawing for positions held in the offices of the Board of Elections in the Municipal Building.

The Treasury Procurement Division invited bids yesterday on 150,000 yards of fancy chambray, 50x38, 4.5 ounce, 28-inch, for delivery by Sept. 25 to points in Massachusetts. Bids will be opened Aug. 27.

The captains and crews of the three transatlantic planes in Port Washington were the guests last evening of the Sands Point Bath Club after the arrival of the Cavalier, the Bermuda plane of the Imperial Airways yesterday afternoon.

The probable effects on American commerce of any application of the Neutrality Act to the Far Eastern crisis are receiving the careful attention of the Administration, Secretary of Commerce Daniel C. Roper indicated at his press conference today.

Exasperated by sit-down strikers who have occupied his plant night and day for more than four months and avowed they will stay until "doomsday," Ernest Eckes, president of H. Anton Bock Co., cigar manufacturers, of 1,230 Second Avenue, summoned a dozen of his 130 employes to Yorkville Court yesterday on charges of conspiracy.

When the United States liner President Harding sailed yesterday for Germany via Ireland, England and France, her freight cargo included about two tons of frozen foods consigned to Hamburg, where it will be loaded on the four-masted sailing yacht Sea Cloud, owned by Mrs. Joseph E. Davies, wife of the United States Ambassador to Soviet Russia.

In the face of protests to Secretary Swanson and an announced boycott by the Committee for Industrial Organization, civilian employes of the Philadelphia Navy Yard went to the polls today to choose collective bargaining representatives for the yard's forty-two departments.
President Roosevelt scolded Congress today for what he termed its "vicious" action in tacking a pricebolstering rider on an essential tax bill.

The Fred F. French Building at 39 Broadway earned at the rate of 6.19 per cent before interest, depreciation and amortization on the $4,595,500 of outstanding first mortgage bonds in the year ended April 30, 1937, according to a study of the property by Amott, Baker Co.

Senator Borah asked President Roosevelt today to organize a campaign against monopoly. He said that the President could use his "tremendous power" to start "the greatest crusade since the American Revolution."

The reverse suffered by Santander's defenders in the last few days has not been confined to loss of territory. Government troops of a strength variously estimated between eight and twenty battalions, with equipment and stores, are now falling back toward Santander.

State Motor Vehicle Commissioner Arthur W. Magee reported today that automobile registrations show an increase of 60,825 in New Jersey this year, with 64,689 more licensed drivers and revenues $1,427,768 above last year.
Dr. A. Lawrence Lowell, president emeritus of Harvard University, today lost his license to operate a motor vehicle on Massachusetts highways.

Developments in the Far East continued yesterday to be an important influence on bond prices. Japanese issues, which have declined sharply since the situation became serious about ten days ago, suffered further losses of 2 1/2 to 12 points. Bonds of United States companies operating in and around Shanghai also were lower.

Mrs. James M. Cleary of New York gave a dinner at the Berkshire Hunt and Country Club, Pittsfield, in honor of Mrs. Thomas T. Eckert of New York and Pittsfield. Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Toole of Pelham, N. Y., are at the club.
Japanese fighters blasted tonight under a bright moon against overwhelming numbers of China's strongest troops on both bides of the Whangpoo River.

Mrs. Eni Baszarab, 48 years old, died here today of injuries received Saturday night when she was struck by an automobile at the Freeman Street grade crossing of the Pennsylvania Railroad, where she was employed as a flagman. Railroad officials said she had worked there twenty years, and there never had been an accident at the crossing while she was on duty.
Howard Ferguson today sailed Buza to victory by almost 2 minutes over Mariette, sailed by George Haines, in the H-23-foot Class of the Wednesday Fishers Island Club regatta.
The Japanese beetle scourge that has been particularly severe in New Jersey this year has extended its depredations to penthouse gardens in New York City.
Mrs. Harry L. Hamlin opened her home, Windward, this afternoon for a piano recital and talk on Russian music by Lydia Kniagevitch, and entertained at tea afterward.

Howard N. Lary, a mining engineer for the Securities and Exchange Commission, was crossexamined yesterday by Frank L. Miller of defense counsel as the SEC continued its hearing into the affairs of the Austin Silver Mining Company on charges of a faulty registration statement and alleged manipulation of stock.

The twice-amended and long-delayed plan of reorganization of the $900,000,000 Standard Gas and Electric Company is to be changed once again, according to a statement made yesterday afternoon by Bernard W. Lynch, president of the company.
A movement to recall Governor William Langer, storm center of North Dakota politics for nearly five years, was revived today with organization of the Good Government Cooperative Association.
When the last Chinese Emperor was toppled from his throne Chinese art went into the discard. The new republic
The House Military Committee made public today a War Department letter opposing a bill to make Lincoln Ellsworth, Arctic explorer, a lieutenant-colonel in the Officers' Reserve Corps.

The President and the Secretary of State have made it clear that for the present the Neutrality Act is not to be invoked by a Presidential declaration that a state of war exists between Japan and China.

The engagement of Miss Eleanor B. Collins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Collins of this place, to John Haselton Read, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Read, also of New Bedford, has been announced by her parents.

While mechanics labored over the flying boat Guba at North Beach the Airport last night, Sir Hubert Wilkins and his chief pilot discussed flight plans that will take them overland to the icy waters of the Arctic in search of the six Russian transpolar fliers missing there since last Saturday.

On the fifteenth morning after departing from Tientsin for Shanghai, the writer finally reached this warwrecked, terrorized city after an unparalleled series of transportation frustrations and after traveling nearly 3,000 miles on nine trains and four steamers.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull and other officials were not disposed today to discuss the reported British plan for inducing the Japanese Government to remove its troops from Shanghai, in return for an undertaking by Great Eritain, France and the United States to protect the lives and property of Japanese nationals in the International Settlement there.

The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the Louisiana. Southern Railway Company today to reduce the par value of its first-mortgage refunding gold bonds from $1,000,000 to $200,000 and the interest rate from 6 to 4 per cent.

Attempts to draft a common doctrine for Christianity having failed, an affirmation stating a desire for unity was unanimously approved today at the closing public session of the World Conference on Faith and Order, at which virtually every Christian Church except the Roman Catholic was represented.

The Stamford Yacht Club today won its third leg on the Scovill Cup, emblematic of the midget sailing championship of the Sound, when its crew of John C. Wrightson, Alex Stewart and John Pitt took the last race of the series and the title.

An "exploratory" meeting of the committee of drug and cosmetic retailers, wholesalers and manufacturers, appointed recently to study the effects upon retail prices of the fair trade laws, now effective in forty-two States, was held here yesterday. Milton S.
Patronesses for the subscription dinner dance Monday at the Piping Rock, sponsored by the Saratoga Golf Club, were announced today by the general chairman, Mrs. E. Vassar Baker.

Objections have been filed in Surrogate's Court in connection with the will of Frank Lambert, Brooklyn manufacturer, real estate owner and civic worker, who died in his eighty-sixth year on June 21, leaving his estate of several millions to his widow, Jeanette Lawson Ebbets Lambert, forty years his junior, to the exclusion of his family.
