The National Lead Company has provided for its 5,000 employes approximately $18,000,000 of group life insurance, it was announced yesterday. The plan was underwritten by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

McKesson Robbins, Inc., had a net profit of $1,750,271 after minority interests, for the six months to June 30, according to a report issued yesterday. After preferred dividend requirements, the profit is equivalent to 74 cents a share on 1,282,983 shares outstanding.

Seventy per cent of the island's arable land has a grade exceeding 15 per cent, while 40 per cent of the farming land has a 40 per cent grade or more, George W. Crawford, in charge of the Soil Conservation Service, today told the island's agricultural extension agents, whereas in the United States land with more than 15 per cent grade is regarded as unsuitable for cultivation.

Six "Trotskyist spies," convicted of poisoning Soviet Army soldiers in White Russia "under orders of the Fascist Intelligence Service," were reported today by the Minsk newspaper, Rabochi, to have been shot.
The Customs Service reported today a marked increase in its activities for the fiscal year 1937, with duties collected aggregating $486,356,599, an increase of 25.7 per cent over the preceding year.

The majority of the trustees of the stock of Henry C. Bohack, Inc., under the will of the founder of the company, the late Henry C. Bohack, have the right to dispose of that stock as they deem best, but must be ready to accept responsibility for financial loss accruing from a mistake, in the opinion of Surrogate John Hetherington of Queens, handed down yesterday.
Girl Scouts and Girl Guides attending the international encampment at Camp Andree here are familiarizing themselves with the slang expressions of various nations, it was revealed today.

The life story of Adolph S. Ochs, late publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was dramatized by a group of twenty-four WPA players in a broadcast over WLTH last night. The broadcast was the tenth of the series of twenty entitled "Great Men in History."

Sanitation Commissioner William Carey and Police Commissioner Valentine unveiled yesterday horseshoe, set up in a garden o?? the seventh floor of the Department of Sanitation offices. 121 Worth Street, officially starting the campaign to raise $100,000 for the department's honor relief fund
It takes five years' service in the House before a Representative really begins to have a voice in what is going on, according to Mayor La Guardia, who spent ten years in Congress himself.

The new six-room house at 25-28 100th Street, East Edmhurst, L. I., was sold by the Nineteenth Ward Realty Company, Richard M. Lederer, president, to Arthur and Marie Rivera through Schechter Winston, brokers.

Until recent years history was taught as a series of facts and dates. Today we are beginning to look more closely Into the events which preceded those great social and economic and political changes which have deeply affected the known history of the world.

The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for the twelve months to July 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, of $25,505,542. This. was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.84 a share on the common stock, and compares with a net of $23,174,109, or $2.42 a common share, in the twelve months to July 31. 1936.

The two remaining representatives of England and France were eliminated from the invitation tennis tournament at the Newport Casino today as six Americans and two Japanese earned places in the quarter-final brackets.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that thirty-seven Federal savings and loan associations in Pennsylvania had increased their assets $2,954,542 to a new high record of $14,451,993 in the six months ended on June 30. Invested savings increased $1,087,173 to $5,868,368 and mortgage loans $3,119,978 to $11,818,711.

Mrs. Ethel Mars today revealed the West's best juvenile to the keenest judges of horse flesh in the country, and there were many who said after the finish of the Rossignol Purse that Tiger would go on to prove himself the best two-yearold in the nation.

At the tag end of the long session of Congress now nearing its end the House of Representatives has thrown away its last opportunity to take a stand in favor of economy. Disregarding the advice of its own Appropriations Committee.
The city of Shaker Heights, Ohio, has called for tenders on Sept. 13 on an issue of $300,000 of refunding 3 per cent bonds to be dated Oct. 1, 1937, and to mature on Oct. 1, 1944 to 1951.

The first annual Starlight Symphonic Festival of the Silvermine Artists Guild will be inaugurated tomorrow evening, 8:30 o'clock, on the Guild's grounds between New Canaan and Norwalk, Conn., with a concert by seventy-five members of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Jose Iturbi.

The expulsion of "Trotskyist" elements from the Socialist party took on a national aspect yesterday when it became known that the national executive committee of the party had suspended the charter of the party organization in California.

The screen's musical fashion revue of the year, "Vogues of 1938," will go on exhibition this morning in the Radio City Music Hall. Bella and Samuel Spewack are the authors of the piece, and chief among the players are Warner Baxte, Joan Bennett, Helen Vinson, Mischa Auer, Alan Mowbray, Marjorie Gateson and a dozen-odd professional models ... Opening at
The League of Nations mandates commission, which has been meeting in extraordinary session here since July 30 to consider the Palestine question, completed its work this morning and adjourned.

The British aviation world learned today that the Air Ministry had acquired the rights to a French balloon with which it can raise a screen to protect London against bombing attacks, to the height of 40,000 feet. Disclosure of the information resulted from the breaking of a cable by which experts were experimenting in raising the balloon at Cardington, Bedfordshire.

Formal complaints will be made today to United States Consul General Clarence E. Gauss and to Japanese Ambassador Shigeru Kawagoe, concerning repeated searches of THE NEW YORK TIMES'S office and the apartment residence of its chief correspondent by Japanese soldiers.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Lillian Elizabeth Melnick, daughter of Nathan Melnick of this place and the late Mrs. Melnick, to Morris Winetsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Winetsky of Linden, N. J.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas increased 5 per cent for the week ended Aug. 14, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The gain is slightly under that noted for the preceding week, when the delivery organization reported a rise of 6 per cent over a year ago in the number of packages handled.

James L. Smith Jr., 24-year-old racing automobile driver, of 371 Hamilton Street, Hewlett, L. I., was killed last night at the Crossway Speedway, Crossway Boulevard and Sunrise Highway, Ozone Park, Queens, when his racing car crashed through the fence at the southern curve of the track.

Germany's foreign trade drive, which had shown signs of slowing during the last few months, was able to score a new success when exports climbed to 530,000,000 marks .during July. This was an increase of 10 per cent over the preceding month and of 34 per cent over July of last year and a new record high since Adolf Hitler came to power.

The Musicians Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy has been organized and will be affiliated with the North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy, it was announced yesterday. Pablo Casals, noted Spanish 'cellist and conductor, will be honorary chairman of the new group.

A 1938 budget request for $582,137 was submitted to Kenneth Dayton, Assistant Budget Director, yesterday by James E. Finegan, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission. The amount represented an increase of $220,174 over the 1937 total. Of the sum requested,
Nazi charges that Britain had defeated Germany at a track meet last Saturday by "unfair methods" created a stir in the British Amateur Athletic Association today.

A steam pipe explosion aboard the destroyer Cassin, drydocked at the Philadelphia Navy Yard, sprayed jets of live steam over fifteen men trapped, in the vessel's narrow, steel-walled fireroom today, scalding seven of them to death and causing critical injuries to four of the others.

The Australian 1936-37 wool season which ended June 30 recorded the second highest income in the history of the Commonwealth, the Commerce Deapartment has been advised by its Sydney trade commissioner.

After scooting out into a lead in the race today for the Astor Cup for Sloops, the America's Cup defender Ranger was shanghaied in the empty wake of a wandering breeze, but Harold S. Vanderbilt, at her helm, nursed her along to defeat the other American and English cup class sloops and capture his eighth one of the successive Astor prizes.

A contra-seasonal increase in electric power output last week caused the adjusted index to spurt to 109.6 from 106.8. This is the highest figure since the week ended Feb. 27. For the week ended Aug. 15, 1936, the index stood at 105.1.

This session of Congress, one of the longest in recent years, will cost about $12,000,000, or $50,000 a day. Clerks made this estimate today on the basis of an eight-month session. They explained, however,

Three thousand and fifty foreigners of ten nationalities, including 294 American women and children, were evacuated from Shanghai yesterday. They sailed from five ships off Woosung. Most of those evacuated were women and children.

We have heard all kinds of tales from hunters and anglers. Many fell into the big-one-that-got-away classification and some concerned the occasional "sport" or freak turned out by Nature in one of her careless moments.

Your Uncle Theodore and your Aunt Emma must heave a nostalgic sigh when they read in the accounts of the American Pharmaceutical Association's proceedings that the old-fashioned pharmacist may reassume his old importance.

The Bureau of Mines estimated today a daily average production of 3,509,300 barrels of crude oil would be required to meet the nation's demands for September. The estimate was 46,400 barrels higher than for August and 476,900 higher than a year ago.
A building in the Times Square area figured in Manhattan realty trading yesterday. Some of the properties sold were owned by banks.

Father Divine, whose peace of mind has been upset by legal complications since Mrs. Verinda Brown, a former "angel," demanded the return of $4,400 she says she invested in his "heavens," won a slight victory in court yesterday when the amount of cash he must raise to prevent his Peace Missions from being put into the hands of receivers was tentatively reduced from $20,000 to $5,000.

Seeded players continued their display of superiority, but a thunderstorm swept down from the hills surrounding South Park today to interrupt play in the national public parks tennis championship with only half the scheduled twentyeight matches completed.

An effort by the Senate leadership to contribute a new burst of speed to the adjournment drive' was blocked temporarily late today when a welllaid scheme to jam the loophole plugging tax bill through that body in record time went awry.
The Athletics broke a season-long jinx held over them by the Red Sox by taking a 4-to-2 decision at Shibe Park today. It' was their first victory in thirteen games with Boston this' year.
Alexander Antonio of Linden, N. J., the medalist, took the long way around today but squeezed into the quarterfinals of the second annual lefthanded golfers championship tournament at Olympia Fields.
Dr. Hugh Parshall brought home the winners of the two opening events to claim driving honors for the Illinois State Fair's third Grand Circuit harness-racing program today.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had ordered Arpul Company, Inc., 333 West Fifty-second Street, New York City, to cease and desist from unfair methods of competition in connection with the sale of Ortosan, recommended as a facial treatment preparation.

Indications that the Consolidated Edison Company of New York is being stymied in its plans to consummate the projected merger of its affiliate, the New York Steam Corporation, were given yesterday when it applied to the Public Service Commission for an extension of time within which the preferred stocks of the steam company must be deposited in exchange for the preferred stock of Consolidated Edison.

The draw for the Wightman Cup matches between the United States and Great Britain took place yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, where the contests will be held tomorrow and Saturday.

Three times the President, and twice the New Deal, have been issues before the American people. On each occasion they were victorious by a landslide. But since the landslide of 1936 Congress has ceased to go along with the President, and the prospect therefore is that Mr. Roosevelt next year, in Congress and at the primaries and elections, will have to seek another referendum on the New Deal-in its extended form.

Chief effect on advertising of passage of the Miller-Tydings bill and the expected increase in fair trade contracts will not be in consummer copy but in trade advertising. and display material, according to agency executives here yesterday.

A large audience filled Parish Memorial Hall tonight when the Southampton Players, under the direction of Theodore St. John, opened their sixth production for this season with the presentation of Noel Coward's comedy "Private Lives," with Muriel Kirkland in the leading role.

A bill to reorganize the Civil Service and to bring within it some 305,000 Government workers in addition to the 515,000 already classified, was reported favorably today by the House Governmental Reorganization Governmental studying President Roosevelt's recommendations along that line.
The Soviet Union celebrated today its annual Aviation Day with an aerial show at Tushino Airdrome, near Moscow.

Mrs. Guy B. Bostwick, Mrs. Arthur Macpherson, Mrs. Jannis Parker and Miss Marie Ballin, members of the women's advisory committee of the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens, gave a luncheon there yesterday for the British and American teams competing in the Wightman Cup matches tomorrow and Saturday.

Roaring over a measured mile course, Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's new fourteen-passenger transport today sped more than 250 miles an hour to achieve the official Department of Commerce rating of "fastest transport in the world." The plane,

Several residential sales in Westchester were reported by brokers yesterday. For improvement with a residence and a five-room guest cottage, a plot of two and one-third acres in the Croton Farms development on Pequenaconck Road, Croton Falls, was purchased by Dr. Earl C. Chesher of New York City.
The skidding Cubs saw their National League lead whittled to two games today as they dropped their fifth straight contest, the suddenly aroused Pirates winning, 7 to 6.

Before sailing on the French liner Normandie yesterday, Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, announced the appointment of chairmen in fortyfour States and 4,500 committeemen in forty-eight States.

The current quip about Stalin, that having bumped off all his friends he is now at work on mere acquaintances, contains too much sardonic truth to be amusing. The Soviet purge goes on with a dreadful rhythm, a muffled drum-beat of peculiar horror under all the brazen savagery of our time.
The House drove through a night session to pass the $500,000,000 Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill tonight the "gag" rule was adopted at times to force a vote on many amendments.

The annual report of Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, was received today by officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System without comment and there was nothing to indicate that as a result of its critical note there would be any immediate change in the policy of watchful waiting that is being followed by those agencies.

The Committee on Local Laws of the Municipal Assembly reported out favorably yesterday the bill sponsored by Alderman John J. McManus calling for a five-day week for all municipal civil service employes except members of the uniformed police and fire forces.

Acting by cablegram from Europe, where he is passing a vacation, Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania yesterday intervened in the strike of silk and rayon workers, affecting plants in that State, New York and New Jersey.

Government authorities asserted today they had found a document purporting to show that a movement to overthrow the Spanish regime was begun in 1934 at a Rome meeting between Premier Benito Mussolini and heads of Spanish Conservative parties.

Persistent rumors that Government officials had virtually agreed upon authorizing a loan of 9 centsa pound on cotton of the growing crop and beneficial rains in various parts of Oklahoma, exerted a depressing influence on prices yesterday.

About 11,000 State employes will benefit by salary increases ranging from $10 to $20 a month, retroactive to July 1. The State House Commission, charged by the Legis. lature with apportioning lapses from last year's appropriations among employes - not covered by line items in the annual appropriations act, approved the plan for distribution today.
The Netherlands Government considered today the possibility of sending warships from Netherland India to China to protect the nation's interests during Chinese-Japanese hostilities.

A turning point for the better seems to be indicated in the volume of new steel business this week, according to Iron Age, which says that the improvement, while moderate, is extended to all territories and has been brought about largely by an increase in buying for automobile production and by replenishment orders from miscellaneous users who have been drawing upon inventories during recent weeks.
The monthly one-day golf tournament of the New York A. C. attracted ninety-three entrants today at the Bonnie Briar Country Club. Competition began early and ended at nightfall.

Among the contracts for commer cial space reported yesterday was a lease on the entire top floor of 605 Madison Avenue taken by the Converse Studios, Inc., photographers. Byrne Bowman, Inc., negotiated the lease. Other rentals were:

The Internal Revenue Bureau ruled today that foreign corporations operating apartments, or other real property, in this country for profit were subject to a 22 per cent tax on net income from United States operations.

Applications for Social Security account numbers were filed last month by 274,000 persons in this State, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, announced yesterday at the formal opening of the board's fifth New York City field office at 330 West Thirty-fourth Street.

A charge of third-degree assault against Mrs. Carmen I. Kennedy, wife of Walter B. Kennedy, former director of Fordham Law School, was withdrawn today just before Mrs. Kennedy was to have had a hearing before City Judge Jacob A. Bernstein.

President Roosevelt charged the critics of his administration today with a distrust of rule by the majority because "an enlightened majority will not tolerate the abuses which a privileged minority would seek to foist upon the people as a whole."

Settlement of anti-trust suits for treble damages totaling some $6,000,000 has been made between a group of plaintiff corporations which make and sell sound equipment and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Western Electric, Inc., and Electrical Research Products, Inc., all of which were named defendants in 1934 in anti-trust actions.

The Chrysler Corporation announced today that three of four members of the United Automobile Workers of America whose discharge preceded a shut-down of the Plymouth plant Aug. 4 would not be re-employed.

After a brief ownership the two five-story walk-up apartment houses at 2,356 to 2, 366 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, have been resold by the Pelemes Realty Corporation to an investing client of Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., brokers. The houses occupy the entire block bounded by the Concourse, Ryer Avenue, Field Place and East 184th Street.

New York and Washington scored their third straight victories, against no losses, in today's round of the international printers baseball tournament. Three teams, Boston, Detroit and Twin Cities, were eliminated. Pittsburgh and Indianapolis bowed out yesterday.

James J. Walker, who was appointed assistant counsel by the Transit Commission on Monday, seventeen days before his pension rights would have expired, struck back yesterday at Samuel Seabury, whose letter to the commission on Tuesday characterized the former Mayor as "Captain of the Tin Box Brigade" disclosed by the Seabury investigation of the Walker administration.
Growing interest in the slum problem in America has led to broader studies recently of the housing programs developed abroad, particularly in Europe.

Miss Mary Mandeville, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert C. Mandeville of Elmira, N. Y., was married here yesterday at noon in the chantry of St. Thomas Church to Sherman P. Voorhees of this city, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Sherman Voorhees of Elmira.

Litigation was begun in the Supreme Court here today to prevent Yonkers from having another referendum on a city manager charter this Autumn. Justice Raymond E. Aldrich signed an order directing the City Clerk and other Yonkers officials to show cause on Aug. 31 why a court hearing should not be held to determine the validity of a petition asking for the referendum.

The Browns and Athletics twice changed positions at the bottom of the National League standing today. Losing to the Indians in the first game of a twin bill, 5 to 2, the Browns dropped into the cellar behind the Athletics, who defeated Boston.

A chill wind swept out of the east today, abruptly ended Boston's heat wave and simultaneously cooled the Bees to such an extent that the Giants had scarcely any trouble recording another important victory in their mad scramble to climb back into the National League flag race.

Pneumatic tire casings to the number of 5,389,274 were shipped in June, compared with 5,374,654 in May and 5,793,014 in June, last year, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association. Production in June was 5,339,238 casings, against 5,351,638 in the preceding month and 5,612,284 in June. 1937.

The Portuguese Government has broken diplomatic relations with Czechoslovakia because she refused to let Portugal buy arms and because of the Czechoslovak attitude toward non-intervention in Spain, an official announcement said today.

Kink Richards, one of the leading ground gainers of the National Football League for the past two years, arrived at the Blue Hill C. C. today to join the New York Giants in preparing for the game with Eastern College All-Stars on Sept.

Eight policemen, five from Nassau County, two from Queens and one from Brooklyn, testifying yesterday at the hearing into charges of unprofessional conduct filed by the Queens County Bar Association against Scott Sanders, Jamaica attorney, denied that they had ever received money from Mr. Sanders for recommending cases, although two admitted that on several occasions they had borrowed small sums from him.
Republicans held a margin of 88,231 over Democrats in the official returns of the city's first-voter enrollment under the Permanent Registration Act, final tabulation showed today.

Miss Josephine San Filippo of Brooklyn, top-seeded entrant, yesterday advanced to the semi-final round of the Long Island open junior girls' tennis singles championship at the Bayside Tennis Club. She defeated Miss Betty Greene of Bronxville, 6-2, 6-1.

Leon Sanders, 67 years old, former Municipal Court justice of New York City, died in a hospital here yesterday of injuries received in a collision between his automobile and another car last Friday forty miles east of Barstow, Calif.

Mrs. Helen Ramsey, 35 years old, a nurse at Sydenham Hospital, was severely beaten with the butt of a pistol last night- when she fought two. holdup men who attempted to rob her in her sixth-floor apartment at 439 West 123d Street.

Despite a firm start, the stock market drifted lower yesterday and final prices were close to the day's low marks. Many of the leading issues of the railway, utility, petroleum, rubber and metal groups were among the principal losers, while steel stocks generally resisted the downward trend.

While it is possible to make further progress toward the safeguarding and promotion of public health, there is little likelihood that such progress can come through laws alone, Dr. Haven Emerson, Professor of Public Health at Columbia University and director of the Hospital Survey, 'declared yesterday at the dedication of a public health exhibit at the Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center.

In July Senator Duffy on behalf of the subcommittee on copyright of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations submitted a report to that committee recommending a favorable report on the Copyright Treaty and action by the

G-men began to scrutinize certain German-American camps today to discover whether any were being operated in violation of Federal law. "It is really more of a check-up than a formal investigation," Attorney General Cummings told reporters, "but I have asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation to make a cursory examination to ascertain if there are any facts warranting further investigation."

Several Important leases to business executives were among the contracts for apartment space in various parts of the city reported yesterday. Among those taking space were Bryan Holme, publisher of Studio Magazine; Frank D. Hyde,
An underground North China separatist movement, encouraged by Japanese, came into the open here and in Peiping today. It sought separate peace with Japan.
Dr. Fred Morgan Barney, who served as a medical officer in five campaigns, died of a heart attack here last night. He was 74 years old.

Ground was broken by Governor Hoffman today for the $2,000,000 plant of the Ternstedt division of the General Motors Corporation in Ewing township. Thomas P. Archer of Detroit, director of operations for the Fisher Body Division of General Motors; S. E. Skinner,

Dr. John C Murphy, medical referee of the United States Veterans Bureau, Ninth Avenue and Thirtieth Street, and one of the bestknown gynecologists in the United States, died yesterday at Polyclinic Hospital of coronary thrombosis after an illness of ten days. Dr.

Thirty-three starters took part in the Women's Long Island Golf Associtation one-day tournament at Lakeville today, with Mrs. Sylva Annenberg of Fresh Meadow, former New York State titleholder, winning the low gross prize with a score of 42. 44-86.
The Most Rev. Walter A. Foery, parish priest in Rochester for twenty-one years, today was consecrated the fifth Bishop of the Syracuse Roman Catholic diocese by Archbishop Edward Mooney of Detroit.
Stockholders of the Campbell, Wyant Cannon Foundry Company will act on Sept. 21 on a proposal to authorize the issuance of preferred stock and to offer to

The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C. I. O. affiliate, by a vote of 632 to 567, decided early today to end the strike of 15,000 workers that began more than nine weeks ago. The men were to return to work this morning.

William Silas Maxson of Yonkers, author of "Maxson's Number Work," a widely used text, book, died here today of angina pectoris. He had been principal of schools in Somerset, Ky.; Chicago, Alfred, Yonkers and Sacket Harbor, and retired in 1926 as principal of a White Plains school. He was 70 years old.

James J. Walker resigned as Mayor of New York City on Sept. 1, 1932, the very night before the day which Franklin D. Roosevelt, then Governor, had set for him to stand examination on his financial accounts. The law provides that if a person is off the city payroll five years he loses his pension rights.
Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek granted the Chinese air force an extra month's pay today "as an encouragement and reward" for their showing against the Japanese.

Arroz con frijoles [rice with beans] the staff of life for working people in Costa Rica, has doubled in price recently. As a result the government has begun selling these necesseries at half the current prices to reduce the cost of living.

Fixtures, stock, good-will and trade-marks of the London Character Shoe Company, which for seventeen years has operated a chain of men's shoe stores in New York and Brooklyn, have been sold to a new corporation to be known as London Character Shoes Corporation, a subsidiary of the Commonwealth Shoe and Leather Company, it was announced yesterday.

Intricate methods employed to distribute the stock of the Trenton Valley Distillers Corporation were unfolded yesterday as the Securities and Exchange Commission resumed its inquiry into the affairs of the company in an effort to obtain a stop order.

After a study of the economic status and living conditions of 11,500 families applying for apartments in Harlem River Houses, the $4,219,000 PWA housing project overlooking the Harlem River at 153d Street, the New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it had selected the 574 families who will occupy the suites.

James J. Dooling, Tammany Hall leader, who died on July 26 at his Summer home in Belle Harbor, Queens, left his estate, formally valued at "more than $10,000," to his three sisters. This was learned yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogates' Court.

Hollyrood Audrey II, a brown filly owned by Dunbar W. Bostwick of Old Westbury, L. I., trotted the third heat of the $800 Mitchell Inn Purse in 2:06 1/4 today. Then, to climax her performance, she went on to beat the favored Farr and Schnapps in an extra brush to capture the feature at the Harry Clay Oval. Harry Whitney handled the reins.
A young engineer from Huntington Beach, Calif., Richard G. Miller, put both hands on a fifteen-foot fly rod today and whipped a tufted fish hook 177 feet to win the national salmon fly-casting crown.
Herman Frankfort, a real estate broker in the Rockaways since 1906, died yesterday at his home, 11-60 Sage Street, Far Rockaway, after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

The appointment of former Mayor James J. Walker as special assistant counsel to the Transit Commission was laid on the doorstep of the forces backing Jeremiah T. Mahoney for Mayor yesterday when Benjamin F. Schreiber, campaign manager for Senator Royal S. Copeland, Tammany candidate, said he understood Mr. Walker would campaign for Mr. Mahoney in the primary.

Harry Krellberg, alias Harold Berg, 51 years old, of 109 East Thirty-fourth Street, who had been posing as representative of a London motion picture company, was sentenced yesterday to from two and one-half years to five years in prison for attempted grand larceny by General Sessions Judge Cornelius F. Collins.
Chinese Finance Minister Dr. H. H. Kung postponed his return to Shanghai in order to visit Bad Nauheim, Germany, for his health, his secretary announced tonight.

Elvira Apartments, Inc., sold to the Rabow Realty Corporation the six-story apartment house at 463 East 178th Street, corner of Washington Avenue, for cash over mortgages of $119,000. Thomas Moffa and Sigmond Orbach were the brokers.

After having flown 940 miles from New York, partly through clouds and rain, the URSS-L2, which was the flying boat Guba before its purchase by the Soviet Government, settled down on Thunder Bay here at 9:21 P. M., New York time, on our search for the six Russian airmen lost nearly a week in the Arctic.

Senator Black received from President Roosevelt his commission as a justice of the Supreme Court today and resigned from the Senate. Governor Bibb Graves of Alabama, who arrived here last night with his wife, Mrs. Dixie Graves, appointed her to the vacancy as soon as he got Mr. Black's letter of resignation.

The 1938 budget request of the Department of Public Welfare, on which a hearing was held yesterday before Assistant Budget Director Kenneth Dayton, is $3,337,056 greater than the 1937 budget. This is largely due to the recent reduction of the age limit for old-age assistance.
The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee approved today the nomination of Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Power Commission, to be chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

Unexpected revival of the controversy over leasing old American destroyers to the Brazilian Government for training purposes came late today in the form of a joint statement by the Governments of Brazil and the United States, made public by the State Department.

The Rev. Gerald L. K. Smith, who launched the Committee of One Million to war on radicalism after Huey Long's Share - the - Wealth movement died, was named yesterday as defendant in an action filed in Supreme Court for an accounting of the profits of his new organization.

The four top-ranking tennis players of the country came through to the semi-final round of the Newport invitation tournament today as Jiro Yamagishi, the champion of Japan, fell an unexpected victim of Bryan M. Grant Jr. and Frank Parker turned back the surprisingly strong challenge of Fumituru Nakano of Japan.

Kid Chocolate, former featherweight champion of the world, hurdled another obstacle in his comeback path when he outpointed Johnny De Foe of the West Side in the ten-round feature bout at Madison Square Garden last night. The Havana warrior, facing a tough, game foe, was extended to gain the award, but there was no doubt of his superiority.

An all-day attempt to avoid the split threatening the Jewish Agency on the Palestine partition issue culminated dramatically after midnight when Felix M. Warburg, Dr. Judah L. Magnes and all but one of the American non-Zionists left the hall where the political committee was secretly sitting.

Mike Jacobs, promoter of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club enterprises, visited Max Schmeling at the latter's headquarters in the Essex House Hotel yesterday, in an endeavor to sign the German for a world heavyweight championship fight.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry William Voege of Brooklyn and Garden City, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anna May Voege, to John J. Tunmore, son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Tunmore of Garden City.

The execution of thirty-four more employes of the Far Eastern section of Trans-Siberian Railway was announced in the Aug. 14 issue of the Far Eastern Pravda reaching Moscow today. The trial was held at Irkutsk.

Praising the keen rivalry between warships in the engineering competition during the past year, Secretary Swanson today sent letters of recognition to twenty-seven commanding officers of vessels which stood first or second in their respective classes.

Greentree, winner of the national open polo championship for the past two years, and the Aurora quartet battled to a thrilling 6-to-6 deadlock today in the first match of the season on J. H. (Jock) Whitney's beautiful polo field.

County and borough officials from England and Wales were guests yesterday of Controller Frank J. Taylor and Assistant Budget Director Kenneth Dayton, who explained to them the city's methods of financing and budget control.

An inquest into the death of Leon Sanders, 67, judge-referee of the Muncipal Court of New York City, was set today for tomorrow afternoon. Mrs. Sanders, who was injured in an automobile collision forty miles east of Bastow, Calif.,

Plans for an eighteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 965 Fifth Avenue, corner of Seventy-eighth Street, were filed yesterday by Kensington Estates, Inc., Aaron Simon president, of 22 East Fortieth Street.

The following joint statement of the Governments of Brazil and the United States, relative to the leasing of over-age American destroyers to the Brazilian Government for training purposes, was made public by the State Department today:

Hollywood's major motion picture producers today reiterated their opposition to a proposal by directors, assistant directors and unit managers that they negotiate with a professional guild representing these employes, but expressed a willingness to negotiate with independent groups.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date, while total bills discounted reached a new high figure for the year.

To the Roxy this morning will come the new Jessie Matthews song and dance opus, "Gangway," featuring Nat Pendleton, Barry Mackay, Noel Madison and Olive Blakeney.... The Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse will reopen at noon today for 'the first public showing hereabouts of "The Spanish Earth,"
The sixteenth annual flower show of the Elberon Horticultural Society closed at the Deal Casino tonight with the judging of twenty-eight classes.

How American workingmen must find new jobs as the country develops was shown today by a Labor Deapartment survey of employment. It disclosed, for instance, that airplane factories now employ 828 men for every 100 they employed from 1923 to 1925.

James Short, a Portage, Pa., youth, who won $149,000 in the Irish Sweepstakes in 1936, -asked the Board of Tax Appeals today to help him hold his winnings. The $149,000, it seems, consisted of $71,306 in Irish Free State bonds and an equal amount in cash, with the remainder going to pay court costs.
Joseph Asscher, who cut the Cullinan diamond and other famous stones, is dead in Deauville, France, according to word received here today. He was 66 years old.

Verbal barrages by opposing counsel, with continual interruptions of the proceedings and a warning from Richard Townsend, trial examiner of the Securities and Exchange Commission, that he would eject one of the attorneys from the hearing, punctuated yesterday the most hectic session which the commission's inquiry into the affairs of the Trenton Valley Distillers Corporation has yet produced.

Thirteen planes stand ready to take off between 6 and 10:30 tomorrow night in a race to Damascus, Syria, and back to Paris, 3,800 miles. This will substitute for the Lindbergh memorial race from New York to Paris, banned by the United States Government as too risky.

Japan is about to begin a drive for the development of its machine tool industry through which it hopes to attain a production value in this field of about $40,000,000 annually, by 1941, an amount equal to the output of the same industry in the United States in 1933, according to information received by the Machinery Division of the Department of Commerce and made public today.

The wildness of Lefty Lee Grissom in the first contest and two rallies in the second gave :the. Cardinals both ends of a double header with the Reds today and a clean sweep of the three-game series. The scores were 6 to 2 and 5 to 1.
"Story to Be Whispered," William Hurlbut's drama of Virginia City (Nev.) during the bonanza mining days of the Eighteen Seventies, had its premiere at the Curran Theatre here this evening.

As a dramatic and effective "offset to attacks on the toilet goods industry, which have resulted in "sales resistance and needless and dangerous State and Federal legislation," plans are being considered by a committee of the Toilet Goods Association for a display at the New York World's Fair in 1939 to demonstrate to the public "the true importance of perfumes and cosmetics in commerce."
Except Tom Moore, San Francisco Olympic Club hurdler, America's track and field team which will compete in a series of meets in Japan arrived today in good condition.
Legislation to outlaw child labor shot through the Senate today in an eleventh-hour effort to save that phase of the administration's buried Labor Standards Bill.

To WNYC The following-named members shall be excused for one day, from 9 A. M., Saturday, Aug. 21, and shall be directed to report to Fireman Harry F. Guerin, at Station WNYC, Municipal Building, Manhattan, at 10 A. M. on that date:

Appointment of two new Roman Catholic Bishops was announced here today by the Papal Legation. Mgr. Leo Nelligan of Edmonton was named Bishop of Pembroke and Mgr. J. F. Ryan of Hamilton was named Bishop of Hamilton.

Elmer Rice's "Judgment Day," which was produced in London in June, will not be produced here because of Mayor de Monchy's decision that the play, being a dramatization of the Reichstag trial, is liable to provoke trouble with Germany.

Miss Marjorie Harrison, 18, of Ausable Forks, N. Y., the Vermont State champion, carded 42, 40-82 today for a one-stroke lead in the first round as wind sent scores soaring in the women's invitation fifty-four-hole golf tournament of the Ekwanok Country Club.

Mr. and Mrs. Marion Eppley were host and hostess of the principal entertainment here tonight. They gave a dinner dance at the Clambake Club, it being one of the largest parties held at the club this Summer.

Mr, and Mrs. J. Macy Willets, who have been in Great Barrington, Mass., are expected today at the Carlyle. Mrs. Richard A. Peabody, who has been visiting in Quebec, will return soon to the Ritz Tower.

While the sun was shining early yesterday afternoon at Ebbets Field, the Dodgers were encouraged by the shutout pitching of Waite Hoyt to stick their heads out of the National League cellar with a 3-0 triumph over the Phillies and Hugh Mulcahy.

Prince Pierre d'Orleans and Braganza, pretender to Brazil's imperial throne, was married today in the private chapel of Nymphenburg Palace near here to Princess Maria of Bavaria, niece of Bavaria's former Crown Prince Rupprecht.

Chinese troops have repeatedly advanced measurable distances in the Yantzepoo district of the International Settlement in the last twentyfour hours, but they have been finding it difficult to hold their gains.

Harry Grindell-Matthews, genial 57-yearold "death ray" inventor, said today that he would marry Ganna Walska, Polish opera singer whose fourth husband was Harold Fowler McCormick, Chicago harvester magnate.

The eighteen-story apartment hotel building at 275 Central Park West, southwest corner of Eightyeighth Street, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street sales rooms. The New Deal Holding Corporation, plaintiff, bought in the property for $1,000 over a mortgage of $2,183,175.

The directors of the E. W. Bliss Company are forwarding to stockholders a plan of recapitalization providing for payment of arrears of dividends on outstanding preferred shares in cash and issuance of new convertible preferred shares bearing lower dividend rates to present preferred holders.
Lumber production increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 92.4 from 91.8. For the week ended Aug. 15 last year it was 84.8.

In an agony of doubt shortly before noon today Charles. Dempsey of 411 Twenty-first Street, Union City, confided his dilemma to the conductor of the westbound Lackawanna train just before it reached Summit.

Civic and commuters' organizations appeared yesterday at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing to fight a move by a dozen New Jersey bus lines using the George Washington Memorial Bridge to increase fares by reverting to schedules in force prior to a rate war that was recently ended.

Wallace T. Macrery, husband of Mary Nolan, former Ziegfeld Follies girl and motion picture actress, also known as Imogene Wilson, was sentenced yesterday to a term of not more than three years in the penitentiary by General Sessions Judge Owen W. Bohan for unlawful entry.

Senator Wagner introduced a new housing measure today designed to better conditions for apartment renters. Officials said that the measure would expand authority of the Federal Housing Administration to insure mortgages on big-scale apartment projects undertaken by corporations.

The lack of knowledge on the part of the average sales person of the value-giving quality of the merchandise he sells and his confusion over the terminology used by competing manufacturers are the "missing links" in sales training which have fostered the growth of so-called consumer organizations, whose propaganda has tended to discredit industries' own statements, James L. Fri, managing director of the Toy Manufacturers of the United States of America, said here today.

Investigation of "mass murder" widened tonight as Loyal Martin, Assistent Prosecutor, revealed that Mrs. Mary Arnold told him she believed her sister, Mrs. Ollie Luella Koehler, 79, who died today, "was poisoned by Mrs. (Anna) Hahn."

The Victor Chemical Works of Chicago has started construction of a $1,000,000 plant at Mount Pleasant, Tenn., which will be operated by power obtained from the Tennessee Valley Authority, August Kochs, president, said today.

Bishop Edwin V. Burne of San Juan has ordered posted in Catholic churches a pastoral letter condemning three laws passed by the last Legislature and effective this week. These laws legalize birth control propaganda and practice and compulsory sterilization of insane and epileptic persons or sexual perverts confined in institutions.

Gold to the value of $3,764,000 was engaged abroad yesterday for shipment here, according to reports received by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of this amount $3,204,000 was engaged in Canada and $560,000 in England. In London the price of gold was equal to $34.7637, which was again at a level permitting a bare profit on shipments.
Congress will have appropriated $1,290,089,000 more this year than last, exclusive of the 1936 soldiers bonus, Chairman Glass of the Appropriations Committee told the Senate today.

Hugh R. Wilson, who has been United States Minister to Switzerland for ten years, returned yesterday on the United States liner wit Washington to take over his new duties as Assistant Secretary of State.

The number of Government troops cut off, captured or killed in the south of Santander Province in the present Insurgent drive is officially estimated at twenty-two battalions, or more than 10,000 men.

The Rev. Gerald L. K. Smith, who launched the Committee of One Million to war on radicalism after Huey Long's Share - the - Wealth movement died, was named yesterday as defendant in an action filed in Supreme Court for an accounting of the profits of his new organization.

The trend of world industry and trade remained somewhat hesitant in June and early July, according to the monthly review of foreign economic conditions in the current issue of The Annalist. "International trade recovered only a part of its May loss, although it remained at the highest levels in over five years," according to The Annalist.

The Summer estate of Mrs. John T. Dorrance of Philadelphia was the scene of one of the largest dinner parties of the season, preceding the annual costume ball which was held at the Bar Harbor Club this evening for the benefit of the Mount Desert Island Hospital.

A slight increase in the general level of wholesale prices was recorded by the Bureau of Labor Statistics during the week ended on Aug. 14. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, rose to 87.5 from 87.4 the preceding week. It compared with 81.1 on Aug. 15, 1936.

That apartment leasing for Fall occupancy is maintaining the rapid pace set earlier in the Summer is indicated by reports from brokers yesterday. Many new contracts for residential space were reported as having been signed.

The Yamashita Steamship Company, Ltd., of Kobe, Japan, which operates a service between Japan and the United States in conjunction with the Kokusai Kisen Kaisha Line, will start independent operations in October, it was announced yesterday.
Activity on the stock exchanges was greater in July than in June, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

In a wholly perfunctory manner, without a record vote, and with no more real debate than the House of Representatives had previously given to the matter, the Senate adopted yesterday the new revenue bill designed to prevent avoidance in the payment of income taxes.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

Miss Gertrude Robinson Smith of this city and Stockbridge, Mass., has agreed to head the campaign for $100,000 with which a permanent music shelter will be erected at Tanglewood, between Stockbridge and Lenox, Mass., for the annual Berkshire festival 'by the Boston Symphonv Orchestra.

The Cunard White Star liner Berengaria will arrive today from France and England. On board are Miss Anita Lizana, Chilean tennis champion; the Most Rev. John J. Glennon, Archbishop of St. Louis; Sir Frederick Pascoe Rutter governor and chairman of the London Lancashire Insurance Company;

The key to the diagram follows: (1) Anchor hatch. (2) Seaman's compartment. (3) Bridge (where flying controls are located). (4) First pilot. (5) Second pilot. (6) Radio direction finder "loop." (7) Navigation compartment. (8) Radio officer's post. (9) Chart room, navigator's post.

President Lazaro Cardenas has publicly defied his conservative enemies, warning them that "no armed movement can prosper in Mexico." He made this statement as a special train rushed from this capital to bring him back from Yucatan.
Mimic air war began at 5:30 o'clock tonight over all of South France. It involves 600 French military planes and presents the first phase of a hypothetical enemy invasion.

Gerald de Courcey May, retired mechanical engineer, died today in his apartment at the Irving House after an illness of six weeks. He was in his fifty-first year. Mr. May was the second son of the late. Colonel Henry May- of Washington, D. C.,.a descendant of a family which had been prominent in American affairs for more than 300 years.

Nearly 100 horses were entered in the eighth annual Pocono Mountain horse show which opened today and will continue for the balance of the week. There were many entries from the metropolitan area and near-by New Jersey. Society was well represented at the initial - session.

Two of the fastest six-furlong sprints of the meeting featured today's Narragansett Park card when the Lemar Stock Farm's Mightily captured the fourth race, the Kirkland purse, and the Dixiana Stable's Shootin' High took the fifth, the Lincoln purse.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 8,000, Including 2,500 directs. Generally l0c-15c nigher than Wednesday's average; butchers from 250 pounds up, 15c25c higher; top $12.90;

The SinoJapanese conflict has gone so far now it will be impossible to settle it by means of diplomacy, and the only settlement eventually possible will be between the Japanese military and naval commanders and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek or the Chinese Central Government.

Eric McNair, who entered the game as a pinch-hitter in the eighth inning, slammed the first pitch of Harry Kelley into the left-field stands for a home run, giving the Red Sox an uphill 5-to-4 victory over the Athletics today.
The mysterious submarine that has been harassing Spanish Government shipping in the Eastern Mediterranean has claimed another victim off the Dardanelles.

Degrees from six universities, together with medals and other honors for scientific work, do not help provide the necessities of life, Dr. Simon Robert Klein, pathologist, has decided. He faces eviction from his second-story apartment at 31-67 Forty-fourth Street, Long Island City, for failure to pay $70 due for two months' rent.
Sep Palin drove Lulu Strong, owned by Lee C. McNamara of Indianapolis to victory today in the 2:11 class pace, feature event on the Grand Circuit program at the Illinois State Fair.

Senator Clark of Missouri protested today against the purchase by the United States of any more oil paintings of six-toed Indians. He voted to authorize the purchase of a $35,000 canvas depicting the signing of the Constitution, to be hung in a Capitol corridor, but warned his colleagues:

The protective committee for the $4 preferred stock of the Standard Gas and Electric Company through its counsel, William M. Chadbourne, announced yesterday that the new plan of reorganization filed in the courts on Wednesday met the objections that the committee had raised against previous plans.
The death of James McIntyre of the famous old minstrel team of McIntyre and Heath puts a period to the art of black-face.

Johnny Pena, veteran West Side battler, knocked out Willie Davis of New Mexico in thirty seconds of the second chapter of the main tenround event last night at the Fort Hamilton Arena in Brooklyn. The victor, who dropped his rival for, the full count with a left hook to the chin, scaled 128 pounds and Davis 130.

Dominion Government deposits with the Bank of Canada in the week ended yesterday increased to $26,202,944 from $22,180,559, it was shown in the bank's weekly statement, issued today. Total deposits rose from $197,279,203 to $199,272,485. The reserve continued steady.
During the week ended Aug. 18 member bank reserve balances increased $63,000,000. Additions to member

To the Vice President, the President is still "the boss." He means it politically and he means it personally. As this session of Congress ends the heart of Mr. Garner beats with warm affection for the man whose national ticket hr shared in 1932 and 1936.
A mite of a woman from Kansas City and a durable veteran male from Buffalo captured top honors today in the national fly and bait casting tournament.

Department store sales for the metropolitan area for the first half of August scored an increase of 2.2 .per cent over the.comparative period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Oil executives from Mexico have been meeting this week here to discuss the crisis precipitated by the high increases in pay and pensions recently recommended by an investigation commission of the Mexican Government and to decide on a future policy in Mexico.

The report of the Connecticut Light and Power Company for the twelve months ended on July 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses, of $4,637,888.

Miss Adelaide Hughes, 20 years old, of 424 East Fifty-second Street was found dead late last night in the kitchen of her apartment where police reported two burners of the gas range had been opened. A note also was found.

An extraordinary situation has developed in this State. The State is helpless to enforce its own penal laws against gambling at dog tracks. It is restrained by an injunction issued by a Federal court.

A little river of fresh water, flowing over the floe in front of their tent, is the latest geographic novelty which the Soviet scientists now at the North Pole have reported to Tass, Russian news agency.

Senator Bankhead of Alabama asked President Roosevelt today to authorize a government loan of 10 cents a pound on cotton. The Senator, saying Secretary Wallace had advocated a nine-cent loan, told newspaper men that 10 cents would be best for both the Government and the farmer, because the farmer actually was "going to get twelve-cent cotton anyway."

Accused of accepting money to obtain jobs and political favors, Arthur Gladstone, 38 years old, of 868 East Seventh Street, Brooklyn, who said he was executive member of the Wastminster Democratic Club at 408 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, pleaded not guilty yesterday before Kings County Judge George W. Martin

The Yankees, who prefer the bludgeon to the rapier any day in the week, had to do some nimble fencing to beat the Senators at the Stadium yesterday, 4 to 3. They scored the winning touch in the twelfth inning.

For the first time the Turkish Republic has invited all foreign military and air attaches to attend the annual army manoeuvres. Military missions from all countries signatory to the Balkan and Asiatic pacts, many headed by their Chiefs of Staff, have been invited.

Employes of the Bridgeport Brass Company voted today to make Local 203 of the International Mine, Mill and Smelters Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, their sole bargaining agency. In an election conducted by Allen J. McAdams for the National Labor Relations Board the C. I. O. affiliate polled 1,566 votes,

The two top-seeded doubles teams-Mrs. Dorothy Andrus of New York and Mme. Sylvia Henrotin of France and Miss Kay Winthrop and Mrs. Virginia Rice Johnson, both of Boston-reached the final round of' the Essex County Club women's invitation tennis tournament today.

With two new scripts in his baggage, neither of which has been Identified, Harold Clurman of the Group Theatre will arrive from the West Coast on Monday for a conference with other members of the group governing board to lay plans for the coming season.
For the fourth consecutive week bank clearings of the twenty-two principal cities throughout the nation continued to show an increase over the corresponding 1936 period.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Prices of commodity futures were generally lower in less active trading on the local markets yesterday. Coffee futures were sharply lower on selling attributed to the failure of the Havana conference to agree on export quotas, price parities or control of production. On the cash markets all the grains, cotton, silk, rubber, printcloths and lard declined. Butter was higher.

Nearly 1,400 teachers have filed applications for the license examinations for elementary school principals and first assistants in high schools which will be held the first two weeks in September, Dr. Joseph K. Van Denburg, chairman of the Board of Examiners, disclosed yesterday.
According to The Daily Express epidemics are sweeping the Chinese seaboard. Cholera has spread from Canton to Hong Kong and nearly 200,000 persons have been inoculated.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An unemployment census will be useful, but a census of both those at work and those out of work will be much more useful and the added usefulness will outweigh the additional cost. Employment is not a static thing.

Theodore S. Watson, vice president of the Manhattan Railway Company, in a signed statement yesterday called for an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into the accounting methods and practices of the Interborough Rapid Transit System.

More than 500 attended tonight's gala social event of the racing season given by the Turfwriters Association at Arrowhead Inn. The dinner honored Mrs. Payne Whitney, Joseph E. Widener, James Fitzsimmons and Johnny Gilbert.
Stocks closed lower for fourth consecutive day; turnover, 762,540 shares. United States Government, corporate and foreign bonds lower, Japanese issues weakest; transactions, $7,416,750.

Demonstration against Chancellor Adolf Hitler's "Mein Kampf" occurred yesterday at Innsbruck. Members of the Patriotic Front assembled before book stores displaying the book, whose sale is now allowed by the Austrian Government following an agreement with the Reich.

Plans have been completed for the wedding of Miss Sara Rosalie Wheeler, daughter of Mrs. S. Maguire Wheeler of Forest Hills, Queens, to John Edward Hessian, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Hessian, also of Forest Hills, which will take place the morning of Sept. 18 in Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church.

Five policemen shot it out this afternoon with five bandits, armed with sawed-off shotguns, in North Philadelphia after the hold-up men had seized more than $700 in cash and jewelry in a book-making establishment over a tap-room.

Two world-famous speed-boat drivers, three of their crew of mechanics and two brand-new Italianmade craft that are admittedly faster than any Gold Cap ships ever constructed in this country arrived yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia.

Groping her way for the larger part of thirty-two miles through a spongy fog, Harold S. Vanderbilt's Ranger today defeated the other American and the English America's Cup class sloops. It was the second squadron run of the New York Yacht Club cruise, that from Newport here.

Samuel (Chowderhead) Cohen, the 47-year-old ex-convict whose strikebreaking activities have on three occasions brought him before Federal investigating committees in less than a year, was a very docile prisoner in Bronx Magistrate's Court yesterday when he and his wife, Sadie, were arraigned on a charge of defrauding the ERB of more than $700.
Following is the text of the Portuguese Government communique announcing the severance of diplomatic relations with Czechoslovakia:

Major Green, 34-year-old Negro porter, went to his death in the electric chair in Sing Sing prison here tonight for the murder last January of Mrs. Mary Harriet Case in Jackson Heights, Queens. He entered the execution chamber at 11:04 and was pronounced dead at 11:07 o'clock.
The San Jose riders from the Argentine suffered their first setback since their arrival in this country as Templeton won a seven-period polo thriller, 10-9, on Cochran Field at Meadow Brook today.

Alexander Antonio, high school student from Linden, N. J., and tournament medalist, entered the semi-finals of the left-handed golfers' second annual national championship today, defeating Roy Ridelin of Dallas, Texas. 4 and 3. at Olympia Fields.
Premier Benito Mussolini's wife is reported seriously ill at Rocca delle Caminate, the Mussolini estate near Forli, where she was taken some time ago to receive medical treatment for lung infection.

In the Summer the urge seizes us to be where we aren't. We never get there, but we try. Down the rivers and up the mountains, up and down and across and back, we follow the roads and trails hopefully.

Railroad management representatives dedared in wage conferences with 300 leaders of the "Big Five" operating brotherhoods here today that the average hourly wage now paid to members of the unions was higher than ever before, while operating revenues were a third smaller than eight years ago.

Although officials of the Department of Agriculture denied that a 9-cent lending figure for cotton had already been agreed upon and Senator Bankhead visited the White House to urge a 10-cent loan, prices on the Cotton Exchange sold at new low levels yesterday.
Joe Louis could go into the ring tomorrow night and defend his title. That is the impression the champion made today at Dr. Bier's training camp in this valley of the Ramapo Mountains.
Two of the Indians'. leading batters, Earl Averill and. Bruce Campbell, smashed seven hits good for eighteen bases today as Cleveland downed the Browns, 9 to 1.

A workman was slightly injured about 10:30 yesterday morning when some ninety square feet of newly mixed concrete that had been poured into forms for flooring fell from the fifth to the fourth floor of a building under construction at 1 East Thirty-ninth Street, on the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue.

Miss Catherine Palmer Robinson, director of the University of Delaware foreign study group, has been appointed dean of residence at Mount Holyoke College to succeed Dr. Mary Ashby Cheek, now president of Rockford College. Dr.

A meeting of the House Democrats, which because of a lack of eight votes failed to become an official caucus, obtained from the leaders tonight a promise that the Black-Connery Wages and Hours Bill would be placed on the preferred list of legislation, along with the farm bill, at the next session of Congress.

Estate, $20,000. To William M. Butler, husband, petitioner, Ridgewood Rd., Rye, N. Y., one-half estate; Catherine Begg, petitioner, 157 E. 81st St., all jewelry other than pearls and one-fourth estate; Barbara Mahoney, niece, 812 Park Ave., pearls and one-fourth estate.

Fall advertising budgets of large building material and equipment manufacturers, now in the process of being approved, show only nominal increases over those of a year ago, according to comment among agency executives yesterday.
The Mutual Brief Case Company, 133135 Kossuth Street, Newark, N. J., was ordered today by the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue the misbranding of certain leather luggage.

After a decline of $105,000,000 reported a week ago, member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City showed a gain of $7,000,000 in the total of their loans and investments in the week ended on Wednesday covered by their condition statement Issued yesterday.
Abbott Chapman of the Glens Falls Country Club took qualifying honors in the seventh annual Sagamore invitation golf tournament today with a 73 in a field of seventy-three entries.

The strike of elevator operators and other service employes in the twenty-two-story twin Hudson Terminal Buildings, 30 and 50 Church Street, continued yesterday after the State Mediation Board had failed to bring about an adjustment of the dispute.
Miss Helen Detweiler of Washington, the favorite, was eliminated today by Miss Alice Rutherfurd of Baltusrol in the Shawnee women's invitation golf tournament. The score was 1 up.

The Japanese Government has declined to accept the British proposal that Japanese and Chinese forces withdraw from the vicinity of Shanghai on the condition that foreign powers undertake responsibility for maintaining peace and order and insure the safety of Japanese residents.
Opposition to the Jewish colonization scheme in Guana Caste, where a 50,000-acre estate has already been purchased, was revealed by the newspaper Diario de Costa Rica in a front-page story.

Borough President Joseph A. Palma of Richmond, it was revealed yesterday, has called upon Mayor La Guardia and Frank H. Innes, District Attorney, the former through Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, to conduct investigations of charges made editorially by The Staten Island Advance that building inspection in the borough was a "racket" and that a corrupt alliance existed between politicians and borough office holders.

While a small group of strikers revolted for a few hours yesterday against the calling off of the shipyard walkout by the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C. I. O. affiliate, and continued picketing, the mass of employes who had been out for nearly ten weeks accepted the situation and reported for duty.

Mr. and Mrs. Marion Eppley were host and hostess of the principal entertainment here tonight. They gave a dinner dance at the Clambake Club, it being one of the largest parties held at the club this Summer.

Dr. Charles W. Higgins, surgeon in the gynecological department of Rhode Island Hospital for eighteen years and on the consulting staff of the institution since 1925, died today in his sleep at his home here. He was 71 years old.

The Verplanck Water District of the Town of Cortlandt has a new $85,000 network of water mains but no means of obtaining water to run through them, attorneys told Supreme Court Justice Raymond E. Aldrich here today.

Anti-New Deal Democrats in the Senate were quick today to reply to President Roosevelt's "Lord Macaulay" speech yesterday at Roanoke Island, interpreting it as a direct challenge to them for their opposition to his Supreme Court Reorganization Bill and other legislation.

The House put aside precedents today to recommit to its Elections Committee the election contest of Alphonse Roy, who seeks to unseat Representative Arthur B. Jenks, Republican, of the First New Hampshire District.

Stephen Jay, from the stable of Joe W. Brown, today captured the Consolation claiming stakes, an event for juveniles eligible to run in the big stakes of the Spa meeting, but not now considered formidable enough.

Ezra Lake, descendant of a pioneer family in this section and a well-known contractor and builder, died last night at his home in Pleasantville, near here, at the age of 64. He died in the same house in which he was born.

Mrs. Nona Sigmund Sauer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Sigmund of Great Barrington, Mass., was married to John Turner Atterbury Potter this morning in the Town Hall here by Justice of the Peace Eugene L. Flanagan. Miss Lily Keating of North Egremont, Mass., and Eliphalet N. Potter of Syosset, L. I., brother of the bridegroom, were witnesses.

VOGUES OF 1938, from a screen play by Samuel and Bella Spewack; music and ?rics by Lew Brown and Sammy Fain. ??ank Loesser and Manning Sherwin and Louis Alter and Paul F. Webster; directed by Irving Cummings; produced by Walter Wanger and released by United Artists. At the Radio City Music Hall.

In the presence of Mayor La Guardia, who came to Washington for the occasion, Secretary Ickes signed today the lease which turns over to the New York City Housing Authority the $13,500,000 Williamsburg Housing Project, the record achievement thus far of the Government PWA slum-clearance and low-rent housing program.
The stock markets here were generally steady today, although business was on a small scale.

Tenders will be considered on next Tuesday by officials of Haverhill, Mass., for a new issue of $300,000 of temporary loan notes. The notes will be dated Aug. 25, 1937, and become payable on June 24 and Aug. 15, 1938.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 17: CAPTAINS Haigler, F. H. (M.C.), Naval Hospital, Portsmouth, N. H., to Naval Hospital, Newport, R. I.
There was an increase of 1.6 in the index of business activity in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh.

Herbert D. Copeland of Anacostia, D. C., was elected president of the Northeastern Poultry Producers Council at the closing session today of the seventh annual Summer meeting of the organization at Rutgers University.
Two unseeded players won semi-final places in the national public parks tennis tournament today.

In a decision filed here today Supreme Court Justice Raymond E. Aldrich refused to enjoin authorities of the State and Rockland County from interfering with the operation of a dog race track at the Orangeburg Fair Grounds in Orangetown.

Liquidation was under way in the leading wheat markets today. With a lack of aggressive support and the uncovering of stop-loss orders, prices dropped to new low levels on the current downturn. May wheat prices on the Board of Trade here and December and May at Kansas City sold at new low levels for the season.

Rallying after taking a near-disastrous 75 in the morning, Frank Moore, assistant professional at Quaker Ridge, bounded back with a par-equaling 71 in the final round and annexed the Westchester open golf championship at Green Meadow today, posting a total of 284 for the seventy-two hole test.

Charles E. Seaman, educator and civic leader, died here today after a brief illness. He was 70 years old. Mr. Seaman was born in Nova Scotia in 1866, graduated from Harvard in 1894 and soon afterward established the Department of Political, Science in the University of Vermont.

Miss Rose Weld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Balch Weld of this city and Wareham, Mass., will be married to Ian Baldwin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Clark Baldwin Jr. of Mount Kisco, N. Y., on Sept. 18 in the Church of the Good Shepherd, Wareham. The Rev. Dr. Samuel S. Drury of St. Paul's School, Concord, N. H., will perform the ceremony.

Two survivors of the recent convention of State racing commissioners here at the Spa were seated on the clubhouse porch in earnest conversation. One of them had a copy of the local gazette, The Saratogian, opened across his knees and was consulting it from time to time.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Wilsey of State Road, Croton Falls, N. Y., were killed instantly late this afternoon when the automobile in which they were riding was struck by an express train of the Long Island Railroad at a grade crossing on the Napeague Bay Road, five miles west of here.

The appointment of twenty-one educators from colleges in all parts of the country to the teaching staff of Queens College, which will open in September, were announced yesterday by Dr. Paul Klapper, presiient of the new city institution.

Robert F. Pack, president of the Northern States Power Company, Minnesota, appeared today before the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with an application to reclassify 275,000 shares of no par value $5 preferred stock into an equal number of no par $5 preferred shares which would be convertible into common stock at the option of the holder.
The Rev. Abraham Duryee of Saugerties, N. Y., retired minister of the Dutch Reformed Church of America, died today of a heart attack at his Summer home near Tobyhanna. His age was 70.
United States authorities firmly rejected yesterday Japanese and Chinese measures that would impede the evacuation of Americans from Shanghai.

The form of a new food, drug and cosmetics bill drafted by a subcommittee of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee as a substitute for the Copeland, measure passed earlier in the session by the Senate, was made public today by Chairman Lea. It was unanimously approved by the subcommittee.

Following a day in which a fairly heavy shower in midafternoon served only to drive the humidity up to 98 per cent of saturation, the temperature was rising slowly last night, after touching 77 degrees at 6 P. M. At 10 P. M. it had reached 79, and at 11 P. M. it was 80.

The Japanese believe they see signs of the Chinese offensive crumbling after five days of furious but fruitless attacks. The Navy Office announced that Chinese soldiers are offering to sell ammunition or to exchange it for food.

Japanese Ambassador Mamoru Shigemitsu was accused today by Pravda, the official Communist party newspaper, of abusing his diplomatic rank by spreading secret anti-Communist propaganda in the Soviet capital.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 18: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Scott, N. M., Medical Corps, one month extension, on account of sickness. Longino, O. H (G. S. C.), C. A. C., promoted to Colonel, Aug. 3. Ottosen, P. H., C. A. C., promoted to Colonel, Aug. 7.

Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the annual exhibition of paintings and sketches by a group of Southampton artists which opened this afternoon with a private preview, reception and tea at the studio of Miss Rachel. Hartley in Hampton Park.
Suspension of further printings of the controversial Massachusetts WPA Guide Book will be sought tomorrow by Governor Hurley pending a full review of its text by Dennis A. Doolev. State Librarian.

Max Breitung, president of the Alfol Insulation Company of New York, was stricken with a heart attack here this evening while playing tennis on a court adjoining the Gramatan Hotel and he died five minutes after being admitted to the Lawrence Hospital.

The stage was all set for the presentation of a skit entitled "Mistress Mary" at the annual lawn party given yesterday afternoon for physically handicapped children at the Wave Crest Convalescent Home of the Brooklyn Children's Aid Society at Far Rockaway.
The Japanese command officially claimed today Its heavily reinforced North China Army had battered its way five miles into strategic Nankow Pass, the gateway to Mongolia.

Boynton Ave (14-3773), w s, 737 ft s of 172 St, 28x100: Fanny Bedick to Estelle Kapner, 1,219 Boynton Ave. Dyre Ave (17-4947), w s, 100 ft n of Light St, 50x104; Dyrewood Realty, Inc, to Max Rosenkranz, 15 Crary Ave, Mt. Vernon.

A proposal to widen the inquiry into the business practices of delicatessen owners and certain retail grocers in the city was made by members of women consumers' organizations yesterday at an informal hearing before Major William J. Mack, arbitrator appointed by Mayor La Guardia to settle the problems of these groups concerning hours of business on Saturdays and Sunday.

The Newark Bears halted the Red Wings, 7-2, in a night game tonight. Vito Tamulis held the home team to seven hits, while the International League leaders pounded Andrews, Kaufmann and Moore for fifteen. Babe Dahlgren drove a home run for the winners.

An increase of more than $1,500,000 in capital stock was proposed today by the Bullard Company. Stockholders at a special meeting on Sept. 7 will be asked to increase the common stock from 300,000 to 330,000 no-par shares, and to issue 40,000 shares of $40-par convertible stock. to pay a 5 per cent cumulative dividend.
The Marine Corps announced the following changes for week ended Aug. 16: MAJOR Mixson, J. A., Quantico. Va., to Fourth Marines, Shanghai, China, via the President Pierce from San Francisco, Nov. 20.

Active opposition to the re-election of Speaker Bankhead to the House from Alabama and the election of Senator Moore as Governor of New Jersey is promised by Labor's Nonpartisan League, recently taken over by John L. Lewis and the C. I. O., on the basis of their alleged hostility to the Black-Connery Wages and Hours Bill.

The International Printers Baseball Tournament today was reduced to four teams-New York, Baltimore, Chicago and Washington. Chicago, again staging strong batting rallies, eliminated Cincinnati from the tournament, 9 to 2. St. Louis was eliminated when it lost to Baltimore's long-distance sluggers, 8 to 2.

Loft, Inc., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission details of modifications of an option originally granted to the Phoenix Securities Corporation on June 9, 1936, covering the purchase of 300,000 shares.

Off-shore fishing has been remarkably like a roulette game during the past four days, with the various ports along the coast serving as numbers on the wheel. As to just where the fish-tuna, albacore, marlin, blues and weakswere one man's guess was as good as another's.

The last of the realty holdings of the old Nassau Ferry Company changed hands yesterday when a client of J. P. McCann, broker, bought the vacant plot 100 by 100 feet at the southeast corner of East Houston and Mangin Streets.

Yorkville properties passed to new control in deals reported yesterday by brokers. The five-story tenement house at 319 East Seventy-first Street, between First and Second Avenues, was sold by Charles Zeman to Maria Campagna for cash over a first mortgage of $10,500 at 5 1/2 per cent held by the Central Savings Bank.

Surprised that President Roosevelt, who four months ago warned Congress against passing any price-fixing measures, should have signed the Tydings-Miller bill yesterday, even though it was offered for his signature at the end of the session as a rider to a "must" appropriations bill, Administration officials concerned with enforcement of the Anti-Trust Laws asserted today that the new legislation crippled some of their activities.
The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation will announce today plans for raising additional working capital through the issuance and sale of its common stock.

While manufacturers who have been delaying issuance of pricemaintenance contracts until signing of the Miller-Tydings bill planned to issue them as soon as details could be completed within the next few days, some retailers here yesterday began adherence to the suggested price levels on branded products of manufacturers located outside of New York State.
