Order of Matches Miss R. M. Hardwick, England, vs. Miss Alice Marble. Miss Kay Stammers, England, vs. Miss Helen Hull Jacobs. Miss Evelyn Dearman and Miss Joan Ingram, England, vs. Mrs. Sarah Paltrey Fabyan and Miss Marble.

Peter M. Archdeacon, head of Archdeacon Co., produce brokers of New York City, died yesterday at his home here following a two days' illness. Born in Union City eightyone years ago, Mr. Archdeacon had lived in Hoboken for many years prior to coming to Montclair.

Leslie Leroy England, 36, a confidence man and swindler with a long criminal record dating from 1915, was arrested late yesterday in the Mid-Town Bus Terminal at 143 West Forty-third Street while inserting "slugs" in a public telephone.

The Texas Company leased to Norman Lila Estates, Inc., operators, the northwest corner of Tenth Street and Seventh Avenue in the Greenwich Village section. The lease is for twenty-one years at a net rental of more than $105,000 for the full term and contains an option to buy the fee up to Jan. 1, 1939.
Lieutenant William H. Ledbetter, whose career took him to many parts of the world, died yesterday at the home of his sister, Mrs. James M. Smith, at Ridley Park. He was 75 years old.

A determined drive by the C. I. O. to enroll the white collar workers of Wall Street into the Bookkeepers, Stenographers and Accountants Union has been slowed down by poor business, brokerage house employers said yesterday.

International. trade, The London Economist concludes as a result of careful statistical study, is hot only expending rapidly despite the numerous artificial obstacles, but is now in volume "about equal to what it was before the great depression, eight years ago.

Purchase by the city of the North Beach Airport in Queens at a cash price of $1,300,000 is recommended in a report to be submitted to the Board of Estimate today by Controller Frank J. Taylor. The transaction would be the first step in the development of a transatlantic air travel base at an estimated total cost of $12,000,000.

Receivers of the Seaboard Airline Railway Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to advance to the Tampa Northern Railroad Company sufficient funds to enable the latter to pay interest on its $1,258,000 first mortgage 5 per cent bonds.

A strike to bring about a tie-up of the metropolitan milk supply was threatened tonight unless New York City distributors agreed to farmers' demands for an increase of 40 cents a hundredweight in the price of fluid milk.

The Mutual Telephone Company of Honolulu, a telephone and radio company, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 67,569 shares of $10 par value capital stock to be offered first to stockholders at $10 a share.
The Treasury announced tonight two $50,000,000 bill offerings, tenders for which will be received at Federal Reserve Banks or their branches until 2 P. M. (Eastern standard time) Monday.
As soon as President Roosevelt returned to the White House from Roanoke Island today Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles reported to him the developments in the Far Eastern situation.

Marking the second consecutive monthly decrease, retail credit collections in July declined 0.46 per cent under the same month a year ago, according to the index of twenty local key stores, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc.
Capitol Hill sought today to compromise a long dispute with the Administration over sugar control legislation. They conceded, however, that the measure's fate at the White House was uncertain.

American Girl Scouts attending the international encampment at Camp Andree here conducted a round-table discussion today and agreed that there should be new activities in Girl Scouting, designed for Scouts more than 14 years old.

Pensioned On his own application: PATROLMAN George B. Wolsey, 50th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Aug. 7, 1912. Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN-Andrew P. Betso, from 7th Precinct to 18th Division, for five days. From precincts indicated to Police Academy, for nine days:

Expulsion warrants served today on nine Spanish partisans of General Francisco Franco living in this district are explained by the police as an aftermath of last week's Government decision to request Baron me Franz von Goss, Berlin newspaper man accredited to Salamanca, to transfer his activities from SaintJean-de-Luz to Insurgent territory.

Development of character was the keynote stressed yesterday at the opening of the twenty-fifth biennial session of the Supreme Court, Foresters of America, at the Hotel Astor. Nearly 200 delegates, representing every State, attended.

Federal and city health authorities went into action yesterday to guard the port against the importation of a contagious disease from a South American city, holding the Furness liner Northern Prince at the Government quarantine station for six hours after a case of smallpox had developed on board.
Member banks of the Federal Reserve System regained another $40,000,000 of excess reserves in the week ended on Wednesday, making the rise of the last two weeks double that amount.

John M. Franklin, president of the United States Lines, returned yesterday on the liner Washington after a visit to the company's European offices. He also opened a new office in Havre, supplanting the agency that has conducted its Havre business heretofore.

The marriage of Miss Louise Davis Catherwood of Millbrook Farm, this place, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. D. B. Cummins Catherwood, to Charles Clifford Gordon Chaplin of London, son of Mrs. Stanley Greenfield and the late Colonel Charles Slingbuy Chaplin, took place here today at Valley Brook Farm, the home of the bride's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Cummins Catherwood.

MANHATTAN BRAND, ANNA (March 12, 1937). Gross assets, $86,211: net $81,561. To Viola Eisner, sister, $4,112; three grandnephews and three friends, $1,000 each; Lena Cohn, sister, life estate in residue; Adele Greenberg and Harriet Baehr, nieces, and Jerome A Eisner, remainders in residue;

OF the many novels this reviewer has read, or conscientiously tried to read, in the past six months, Eric Knight's "Song on Your Bugles" (Harper-Story Press, $2.50) is one of the best. It is cleverly written, thoughtful, humorous and contemporary in substance-a fine job, in short, and worth hanging out a few flags for.

Charged with being one of two men who entered the apartment of Mrs. Helen Ramsey, a nurse, on the top floor of 439 West 123d Street and beat her with a pistol in an attempted hold-up, Joseph Reich, recently released from Sing Sing Prison, was held without bail yesterday in Felony Court by Magistrate Leonard McGee.

Mack Trucks, Inc., reported yesterday a net profit of $645,961 for the quarter ended on June 30, last, after normal Federal income tax, depreciation and other charges. No provision was made for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

Vivian Leftwich of Hewlett, L. I., entertained here today for Mr. and Mrs. George F. Smith, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Sanchez, Theodore Schuman, C. V. Morrill and Nicholas Sverino. Mr. and Mrs. George J. Trumbull of Forest Hills, L. I., gave a party for Mr. and Mrs. George G. Blaire and Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Ballinger.
All classes of domestic bonds joined the Japanese dollar obligations yesterday in the broadest and most extensive decline in values in several weeks in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

John Howard Jordain, American manager of the Vacuum Oil Company in Spain, was killed today in an automobile accident. Two American employes of the company, accompanying him on a drive from. Valencia to Barcelona, A. F. Jones and a Mr. Sauerwein, were not injured.

The Association of United Retail Drug Store Employes of Greater New York, the employes' organization of the United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation. defeated the C. I. O. affiliate, Local 1,199 of the United Retail Drug Store Employes Union of Greater New York, in an election yesterday to determine the organization to act as bargaining representative for the workers.

Mrs. George E. Kirsten of Mine Hill Road, Greenfield Hill, entertained at tea this afternoon at her home to announce the engagement of her daughter, Miss Carolyn H. Kirsten, to William Forrest Davenport, son of Mrs. Peter Johnston Davenport of Abington, Va., and the late Mr. Davenport, a member of the Virginia Legislature.

Records of business activity increased last month because of substantial gains in steel ingot and pigiron production and freight-car loadings, and the Annalist index of business activity for July rose to 108.9 (preliminary) from 106.7 for June. For May it was 110.0.

Middlesex went to the top of the county cricket championship table again today with a victory over Somerset. Should Yorkshire win tomorrow, however, Middlesex will be edged out of the leadership. Only two of the eight county matches were finished today, Worcestershire winning the other over Hampshire.

Coach Steve Owen of the New York Football Giants has one less worry today with the arrival in camp of Lester Corzine, veteran fullback. The squal of twenty-nine players put in another day of double drills preparing for the Eastern College All-Star game on Sept. 8.
An order of expulsion from German territory effective midnight Sunday was served today on Norman Ebbutt, principal correspondent of The Times of London in the Reich at his home here.
A heavy storm stopped a rain of Tiger base hits today, 'but not in time to save the White Sox from a six-inning 12 to 4 defeat in what was to have been the first game of a double header.

ORDEAL IN ENGLAND, by Philip Gibbs. (Doubleday, Doran, $3.) On the exciting events of the last twelve months in England. THE CRISIS OF CIVILIZATION, by Hilaire Belloc. (Fordham University Press, $2.50.) Catholicism and other forces in the world today.

Continued liquidation of Jewish business enterprises in Germany is illustrated anew by an official announcement that the Wertheim department store has become "Aryan," like the Ullstein and Mosse publishing houses, the Kempinski restaurants and other famous Berlin institutions.

The Giants, behind lean Harry Gumbert, played another one of their airtight games today. However, so did the Bees behind the slightly more robust Jim Turner, with the result that the whole thing ran into a stifling contest that simply could not go on forever -without somebody going under.

Fred Brandt, former reporter and contest promoter for The New York American before that paper was merged with The Evening Journal, committed suicide yesterday in Central Park. He shot himself in the head while sitting under a tree near the Fifty-ninth Street entrance.

Approval by President Roosevelt of fifty-nine PWA school-construction projects, including eight in New York State and one each in New Jersey and Connecticut, was announced today by Secretary Ickes. Today's allotments, for building in twenty-seven States, totaled $3,428,303, with grants amounting to $3,341,703 and loans aggregating $86,600.

Movements of vessels follow; al' dates are Aug. 18 unless specified: Acushnet, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk. Arctic, San Pedro to San Diego. Clark, Boston Yard to sea, Aug. 19. Cormorant, Washington Yard to Quantico, Va., Aug. 19. Cummings, Bar Harbor to Rockland, Aug. 19.

President Roosevelt returned from Roanoke Island; gave Senator Hugo L. Black his commission as a member of the Supreme Court; received from Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, a report on the Chinese situation; and discussed legislative matters at different times with Senator Barkley, Speaker Bankhead and Senator Bankhead.

The race for the presidency of the Young Democrats of America, in national convention here, became a wide-open contest tonight with the announcement that James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, would take no part in the election when he arrives tomorrow.

Miss Lucille Bauer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bauer of this city, was married yesterday noon at the Pierre to Henry Stanley Mandel, also of New York, son of the late Mr.- and Mrs. Louis Mandel, by the Rev. Dr. Louis I. Newman.

A test of the Federal Social Security Law, ?? determine if firms undergoing reorganization must pay Social Security taxes was taken under advisement today in Federal Bankruptcy Court by Arthur Black, referee.
Mixed commodity trends again resulted in a minor recession in The Annalist index of wholesale commodity prices last week, the index declining on Tuesday to 94.7 from 94.8 the week before.

An appeal will be made in the forthcoming issue of The Churchman, liberal journal of the Protestant Episcopal Church, to clergy and laity of the denomination for their support of the proposed change in this church's canon which would liberalize divorce.

Harry E. Weisgerber, hotel man here for many years, died of a heart attack in Absecon last night. He was 63 years old. Mr. Weisgerber came here from Philadelphia first to operate a rolling-chair business founded by his grandfather.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed--Against KATZ BROS. BAKING CO., INC., 94 Pitt St.--By J. G, Flour Corp., for $880; Coast Flour Corp., $60; Lustigman Flour Corp., $300. M. SUSSER SCHWARTZ, INC., furs, 145 W. 28th St.--By David Rosner, for $370; Gewirtz Egert, Inc., $500;

Congress was coasting today toward apparently certain adjournment by Saturday. The remaining important items of legislation on which the leadership had promised action this session were all nearing their final stages.

A patent example of how a little selling in a thin market can send prices off easily was afforded by yesterday's stock market. Share prices drifted downward from the start and closed near the day's lowest levels, with many leading issues off 1 to 3 points.

Pyramid Sales Co, Salsbury Motor Glide distributors, in International Telephone Building, 67 Broad St; Schlang Bros. Co, broker. Morris Nightingale, furs, floor, in 236-40 West 27th St; Leo Weinstein, popcorn, in 693-97 Broadway; M and L Hess, Inc, broker.

Supreme Court Justice Timothy A. Leary refused yesterday to restrain the distribution of the Sears, Roebuck Co. 1937 Autumn catalogue despite charges made by Town Tailored, Inc., wholesale distributors of women's dresses, that parts of the book infringed on their trade-mark.

New Yorkers who feel that they have accepted a "blind date" in having the American Legion here next month for its annual convention were reassured yesterday by Henry W. Colmery, national commander of the Legion.

The books recommended by Cardinal Hayes's literature committee for this month are: "The Crusades--The World's Debate," by Hilaire Belloc (Bruce Publishing Company); "The Face of Ireland," by Michael Floyd (Scribner); "Disciplinary Decrees of the General Councils," by H. J. Schroeder (B. Herder Book Company); "Marconi:

Miss Mary Babcock Smith, daughter of Mrs. Edmund Beardslee Smith of Los Angeles, will be married Thursday to Kyrill Sidney Schabert of this city, son of Baroness Faber de Faur of Florence and the late Paul Schabert. The ceremony will be performed in the chapel of the Church of the Intercession here by the Rev. Roger A. Walker of Pikesville, Md.

From 9 A. M. until 3 P. M. yesterday depositors of the closed Fort Greene National Bank, 118 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, filed past the tellers' windows while agents of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation swiftly paid out the deposits due them.
The supreme council of the Knights of Columbus voted unanimously today to levy upon the membership for a war chest to continue its "war of extermination" against communism.

Several large luncheons were given at the Devon Yacht Club today. Mrs. Gardner Pattison had a party of thirty and Mrs. Joseph Reynolds Guernsey and Mrs. W. W. Battle entertained eighteen; Miss Rosamond Roberts had ten and Miss Mary Pruyn fifteen guests.
The Senate passed and returned to the House today for action on amendments legislation which would change the method of computing Panama Canal toll charges.
The Tennessee Valley Authority announced today the purchase of turbines for powerhouses at Chickamauga and Guntersville Dams on the Tennessee River at a cost of more than $2,000,000.

White Knob, a ghost town sprawled dustily over eight miles of ore tunnels, was offered for sale by Custer County today. Ray Webber, receiver, said a publie auction of the famous old Central Idaho town and mine seven miles west of here was scheduled, but was postponed indefinitely for lack of bidders.

Three C. I. O. organizers, two of them discharged employes of the Weirton Steel Company, testified here today that they were badly beaten at various times during their efforts to organize the company's workers.

The Shop Employes' Committee, a longestablished independent organization of navy yard civilian workers, won over the American Federation of Labor in a majority of departments in the collective-bargaining election at the navy yard yesterday, a count of ballots showed today.

The Cubs got out 'skid chains today in time to prevent a rout by the Pirates in their three-game series, winning the final contest, 7 to 3. The triumph, achieved while the Giants were losing, gave Chicago a lead of three games in the National League race.
In the Prairie Provinces of Canada grain cutting is well advanced and threshing has begun in Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Southern Alberta, according to the crop report of the Bank of Montreal.
The Portuguese Government explained today that it had severed diplomatic relations with Czechoslovakia because a Czech arms concern had failed to deliver a Portuguese machine-gun order.

Merchandise exports from Germany to this country will top the $100,000,000 level for the first time in more than five years this year, Dr. Albert Degner, secretary of the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce, Inc., predicted yesterday.

Behind a rigid censorship imposed by navy yard officials, a board of inquiry sought today to ascertain the cause of the steamline explosion aboard the destroyer Cassin yesterday, resulting in the death of six civilian employes and one enlisted man.

Because of the rapid scientific development in the drug field, revisions of the United States Pharmacopoeia, which heretofore have appeared only once every ten years, will be issued in supplemental form periodically in each decade, it was announced yesterday at the convention. of the American Pharmaceutical Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

So much of Paragraph 29. Special Orders 181, Aug. 6, 1937, as relates to 1st Lt. Charles E. Hastings Jr., Air-Res., is revoked. So much of Paragraph 3, Special Orders 186, Aug. 12, 1937, as relates to 1st Lt. Philip F. Betette, Cav.-Res., is revoked.

Trading was fair to mostly slow. Steer cuts were steady to sharply higher, veal and calf cuts weak to sharply lower. Lamb and fresh pork cuts were mostly unchanged. Kosher business was confined largely to lamb at about steady prices, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Judge Charles Boote in Yonkers City Court today granted the request of the Rev. VerLynn Sprague for a jury trial of the disorderly conduct charge growing out of the minister's dispute with a policeman here last Saturday night. The trial will be held Tuesday before Judge Boote in the same court.

Wool goods markets this week were slow, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday, but sentiment improved as the trade learned stocks of piece goods were far from burdensome and the heavy liquidation period that had been feared will not be necessary.
Engineering construction awards for the week total $43,341,000, a decrease of 5 per cent from last week and 14 per cent from the corresponding week in 1936, according to Enginering News-Record.
The serious crisis following the assassination of the virtual dictator of Iraq, General Bakr Sidki Pasha, is resolved by the formation of a new Cabinet, accepted by the mutinous army corps of Mosul.

Notices to the trade that the annual Spring furniture market in the New York Furniture Exchange, Inc., will be held from Jan. 17 to 29, next, were sent out here last night. The dates selected bring the opening immediately after the Spring showings in Chicago.

In reporting the termination of anti-trust suits against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Western Electric, Inc., and Electrical Research Products, Inc., in connection with the sound-picture business, THE NEW YORK TIMES erroneously stated yesterday that the suits were settled for $6,000,000.

After a full throttle test of 150 hours and flight tests, an Approved Type Certificate for aircraft has been granted to Waldo Waterman on a stock Studebaker six-cylinder automobile engine used in his combined flying and road machine.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today took direct action in the case of Michael J. Meehan of New York, the broker, who was found guilty by it on Aug. 2 of engaging in the manipulation of stock of the Bellanca Aircraft Corporation on the New York Curb Exchange, By issuing an order expelling him from membership in the New York Stock and New York Curb Exchanges and the Chicago Board of Trade.

The President leaves little doubt in his message reluctantly approving the Tydings-Miller Price Maintenance Bill that he would have vetoed it if it had not been tied as a rider to the tax measure carrying funds for the District of Columbia.

A tie-up of coastwise shipping today seemed almost certain last night as the rival National Maritime Union and International Longshoremen's Association submitted demands to the seven coastwise operators accompanied by threats to order their members to cease work if conditions were not satisfactory.

William (Bunk) Congalton, outfielder for one of Cleveland's early major league baseball teams, died here today at the age of 59. Congalton, who played outfield for Cleveland in 1906 and 1907, died at his home here following a heart attack suffered last Sunday while watching the Cleveland Indians play.

About 1,500,000 workers have left WPA employment in the last eighteen months and 1,527,450 were reported at work on projects during the week ended Aug. 14, a decrease of 129,000 in the last four weeks, according to Harry L. Hopkins, Administrator.
Realty men in New York and elsewhere are finding food for thought in the contest being staged by Florida realtors, in which civic pride and small-scale community planning are the moving forces.
Miss Muriel Honey Johnson, New York society girl, who has been reported engaged to David Mdivani, denied the rumor yesterday on her arrival form Italy on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia.

The business outlook for Fall and Winter is highly encouraging and Christmas trade this year should be equal to or better than that of last year. Henry H. Heimann declared yesterday. He listed four stimulants to better business.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hoving gave a large dinner tonight at the Port of Missing Men, their home at North Sea. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson and Charles Hanson Towne, who arrived today to pass the weekend with Mr. and Mrs. Robertson at Wyndcote;

Punishment meted out to New Jersey in the form of a deduction of $250,000 from current Federal aid road funds is a significant straw in the wind that is rising against the diversion to other purposes by the States of tax money drawn from motorists and assigned by law to highway uses.

Dr. Maximilian Goldstein of 829 Park Avenue, one of the thirtynine defendants named in indictments charging mail fraud and conspiracy in connection with the disability insurance racket, pleaded not guilty yesterday before Federal Judge Hulbert and was held in bail of $1,500 pending trial, which was scheduled tentatively for Sept.

Irving Reynolds, a partner in the law firm of Mudge, Stern, Williams Tucker, 20 Pine Street, who was the successful bidder for blocks of stock controlling the Federal Match Corporation and the Union Match Company in a sale before Referee Oscar W. Ehrhorn on July 29, has completed payment of the $996,000 purchase price and received the shares.

The Czechoslovakian Government said today it clung to hope for an amicable settlement of its dispute with Portugal. Powers friendly both to Czechoslovakia and Portugal, which broke off diplomatic relations with Prague over non-delivery of an armaments order, are seeking an agreement, informed sources said.
Hour by hour, as the scale of operation widens and the fighting becomes more intense, the possibility of a compromise solution of the unacknowledged Sino-Japanese war lessens.
The first six railroads to report for July showed increased revenues but decreased net operating incomes. Their earnings are about 11 per cent of the total for rail carriers of the country.

A divorce was granted here today to Mrs. Katharine A. Morgan Evarts from Jeremiah M. Evarts, a New York attorney, on "cruelty" charges. An agreement was reached as to the custody of their five children.

Mgr. William J. Convery of Charles City, Iowa, collapsed and died in a hotel here yesterday. He came to his native county of Derry three months ago to visit a brother and had come to Belfast to bid farewell to a niece going to school in England.

Taking such action for the first time under Section 7 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an order calling upon the People's Light and Power Company,

In a challenge to all sponsors of general pensions for World War veterans, and particularly at the Veterans of Foreign Wars, who are expected to demand "jobs or pensions" for all veterans at their Buffalo encampment late this month, Major Maple T. Harl, National Comwander of the Disabled American Veterans, said today he had found that "no real" veterans' organizations were agitating such legislation.

Twelve hundred Allegheny County aliens have been removed from Works Progress Administration rolls in the last two weeks, James E. Kesner, district director, revealed today. Within a few weeks 800 more will receive pink slips, he said.

Enrollment in the city vocational schools last year was 20 per cent above that of 1936 and 40 per cent greater than in 1935, according to figures released yesterday by Morris E. Siegel, director of the New York City Evening and Continuation Schools.
Jess W. Sweetser led a record field of 136 golfers in the qualifying round of the annual Maidstone Bowl tournament today. He scored a par 73, going out in 37, two over par.
A resolution calling for sine die adjournment of Congress tomorrow was adopted by the House late today.

Fresh from the war in Spain, where he fought with Government forces, Edward C. Flaherty went to the House of Correction today for three months. Last night, after being feted at a reception with his two brothers, who also served with the Spanish, he was arrested on a default warrant issued nearly four years ago.

Mrs. Georgia Williams Warren, wife of George Henry Warren, a director of the Metropolitan Opera Association, left a net estate of $2,294,569 when she died on Feb. 21, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

An unusual feature of the activity in tenement modernization on the lower East Side of Manhattan is the number of ground-floor stores being remodeled into apartments. This is a reversal of the accepted trend in alteration projects involving old houses.

The compilation of an international cook book, containing recipes representative of twenty-six foreign countries and of the twelve Girl Scout regions of the United States, was completed here today at Camp Andree by Girl Scouts and Girl Guides attending the international encampment.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: During the week the National ASsociation of State Racing Commissioners met in Saratoga and among other things made it known that 'the racing of thoroughbreds in this country represents an investment of about $125,000,000.

A check for $1,425,000 received from the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey in payment in full for the 1937 tax on the $75,000,000 personalty assessment levied several months ago on the company's tangible assets, was deposited today by Tax Collector Herbert D. Banta in the Linden Trust Company.

Police raiding the Villa la Grande Fregate at Biarritz today are reported to have found voluminous correspondence from former King Alfonso of Spain as well as letters from his agents in Britain and Switzerland, the Leftist paper Ce Soir of Paris reported today.

Stepan S. Dybetz, former American labor agitator and one time I. W. W. leader who came to Russia in the early days of the revolution, became a Soviet citizen and rose to be the head of the Soviet automobile tractor industry, was denounced today in Za Industrializatsiu,

Mrs. Ruth Helen Archibald, 52-year-old playwright, whose pen name was Ruth Helen Davis and who was the widow of Dr. Charles Harvey Archibald, an early leader in the development of the X-ray, was killed yesterday in a sevenstory fall from a room in the Hotel Astor, where she had been staying.
Fourteen tourists who were not permitted to land in Russia while on a North Cape cruise returned yesterday on the Holland-America liner Rotterdam.

Plans for an audit of milk dealers' books to determine the margin between the price which the farmer receives for milk .and the cost to the consumer were discussed today at a conference 'called by Holton V. Noyes, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets.

Congress, responding to President Roosevelt's request that it stop the use of "clever little schemes" for tax dodging, sent to the White House today a bill to close some of the major loopholes in the revenues laws.

Directors of the Air Devices Corportion yesterday approved the. transfer of general offices from Chicago to Meriden, Conn., and ratified the consolidation of the Connecticut Telephone and Electric Corporation with Air Devices and the decision to consolidate all future manufacturning activities at Meriden.
Sep Palin's horses from the stable of E. J. Baker, St. Charles, Ill., triumphed in the two-feature events of the closing grand circuit harness racing card at the Illinois State Fair today.

China had reached the peak point of recovery from the depression which started there in 1933 when the unofficial warfare with Japan started, according to a cabled report dated Aug. 13 from Commercial Attache Julean Arnold at Shanghai made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Three children were burned today in an explosion on a motor boat on Lake George at Big Woods Point. The children, Earl Brownell, 15, of Hoosick Falls; Carol Brentano, 10, of 34 North Maple Avenue, East Orange, N. J., and Stewart Beckwith, 12, of 440 222d Street, Bayside, L. I., were taken to Glens Falls Hospital.
A sensational round of 65 by Victor Ghozzi, tall New Jersey pro, set the pace for the first eighteen holes of the second annual Lake Placid open golf tournament today.

The marriage of Miss Anne Halle, daughter of Mrs. Helen B. Halle of the Hotel Ambassador, New York, and Stanley J. Halle of Chappaqua, to Ford de Villers Seymour, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Ford Seymour also of New York, took place at noon today in the chapel of St. Mark's Episcopal Church here. Canon H. Ayde Prichard performed the ceremony in the presence of the immediate families.

The shelling of the U. S. S. Augusta in Shanghai Harbor will be treated as an unfortunate accident, and will have no direct effect on - the determination of American policy in the Far Eastern crisis, President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Hull indicated today.

Mrs. Helen Godey Wilson, widow of Alan D. Wilson, an insurance broker, and granddaughter of Louis A. Godey, publisher of Godey's Lady's Book, died at her home, Pear Grove, Villanova, today. Her age was 59.

Tie-up of the metropolitan milk supply, threatened yesterday, apparently was deferred temporarily today when the board of directors of the Cooperative Milk Producers Bargaining Agency, Inc., announced that a meeting had been called here tomorrow to consider a 35-cent increase in the price proposed by dealers.
L. D. Harkrider, president of the General Malleable Corporation of Waukesha, Wis., announced yesterday a triple coverage group Insurance program for employes.

Asked about accounts of the recent exploit of her son, John, in France, when he was reputed to have tossed champagne into the face of the Mayor of Cannes, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who is attending the Young Democrats meeting here, said today:
A baby girl was born to Mrs. E. C. Misler aboard the President Jefferson as the liner neared Manila today with the first American refugees evacuated from Shanghai.

Detective Sergeant James P. Currier, oldest member in point of service in the New Haven Detective Bureau, died at his home early today after a long illness. He was 55 years old. He had been in poor health since 1920 when he was shot while making an arrest.

A troubled conscience, coupled with the knowledge that detectives were searching for him, according to the police, led Carl Silesia, 24 years old, to surrender here today as the hitrun driver of an automobile that fatally injured a girl and hurt a boy in Branch Brook Park Aug. 8.

Any unemployment census under a bill which has passed the Senate and may be jammed through the House during the last hours. of this session will be on a purely voluntary basis and will merely provide an opportunity for those capable and in need to procure work, President Roosevelt said today.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Stevenson entertained with luncheon today at the Kebo Valley Golf Club, preceding the weekly tombstone tournament. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. E. Gerry Shadwick, Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Pike,

A charge that Senator Hugo V. Black was illegally appointed to the Supreme Court, and therefore is a "usurper" under the law, was filed with the court in Washington today by Patrick Henry Kelley, a Boston lawyer.

New developments in the proposed plan of reorganization of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, a $900,000,000 public utility holding company, appeared yesterday with lightning-like rapidity. Three distinct but interwoven events took place in what appeared to be a race against time. They were:

Doubles partners for four years, Mrs. Dorothy Andrus of New York and Mme. Sylvia Henrotin of France will clash tomorrow in the Essex County Club invitation tennis singles final as the result of hardfought victories today.

The management of the twin twenty-two story Hudson Terminal Buildings, 30 and 50 Church Street, reportedd elevator service operating normally yesterday afternoon despite the insistence of the Building Service Employes International Union, Local 32-B, that its strike had put out of commission all but ten' of the thirty-nine elevators.

Lieutenant Jack Morris had the mount on the veteran black gelding Come On and lifted him over the jumps of the outside course to win the Smithtown Hunt Cup, the chief event of the opening card of the eighth annual North Shore horse show, today.
Two Los Angeles players swept everything in sight today in the women's division of the fifteenth annual public parks tennis tournament.

Back from London on Thursday night came Jed Harris, all set for a courageous tussle with the new theatrical season. What his local producing schedule will be was not definite, however--"Just give me forty-eight hours to get straightened out," was the way he put it.
Catello Como, 22 years old, drew $506 from the Public National Bank at Twenty-fifth Street and Broadway yesterday for his employer, the Berger Machine Company of 540 East Twentieth Street.

Mr. and Mrs. H. Raymond Eisner of 791 Park Avenue and Red Bank, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarann Eisner, to Jerome L. Burnham, son of Mrs. Hermine Burnham of 1,016 Park Avenue.

Word has been received here of the marriage of Miss Mary Elizabeth Kemper, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Clarence W. Kemper of Denver, Col., to Albert S. Davis Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert S. Davis of Bound

Miss Cecil Valentine Hodgman, daughter of Mrs. Charles Cecil Hodgman of Glen Brook, was married to William Robinson Clapp, son of Mrs. Stuart Harold Clapp of Pittsfield, Mass., and the late Mr. Clapp, this afternoon in Darien Congregational Church.
There is nothing like a good game of bridge to take the mind off outside events. In Shanghai the other day a number of

Of strange precedents there is no end in these strange times. It is as if the world were one of those interlocking wheels that fit into a timepiece and just fail to click. Nothing moves quite on schedule.

Hot weather helped retail distribution this week, reducing inventories of Summer merchandise and singing gains in total sales over the previous week in all leading centers of distribution, ranging from 3 to 6 per cent, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
The fifteenth Earl of Perth died today in a local hospital after an operation. He was 66 years old. His half-brother, Sir Eric Drummond, British Ambassador to Italy, inherits the title.

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan in Brooklyn announced yesterday that his office is investigating complaints concerning a "health racket" that has mulcted many small food-store merchants of $1 each.

Representatives of the Astoria Pool, scoring 74 out of a possible 110 points in ten diving events, led a field of thirteen city pool teams yesterday in the first half of the second annual swimming and diving tournament sponsored by the Park Department.

In the setting of an old Russian religious ritual and the flashing bulbs of modern news photographers, the Right Rev. Damascionos Demesiones was consecrated as Greek Orthodox Bishop of San Francisco yesterday in the Russian Cathedral of St. Nicholas, 15 East Ninety-seventh Street.
The House today passed the RobertsonPittman bill authorizing Federal aid to States in improvement and maintenance of wildlife restoration projects, including refuges and breeding grounds.
The Maidstone Club gave a dinner dance tonight in honor of visiting golfers here taking part in the annual men's invitation golf tournament for the Maidstone Bowl.

In trading that at times resembled sessions during the period of downward readjustment of values last Spring, United States Government obligations underwent yesterday the sharpest decline in many weeks on the New York Stock Exchange.
The United States moved to the threshold of still another Wightman Cup victory at Forest Hills yesterday as American women stars routed the invading English forces, 3 to 0, in the opening day's play.

Manufacturers establishing re-sale prices for their merchandise under the Feld-Crawford Act, have no right to specify the exact amount to be allowed on "trade-in" merchandise, according to an opinion given by State Senator A. Spencer Feld, co-author of the State Fair Trade Law. In a letter to D. W.

Arthur Hamilton Hay, a member of the New York brokerage firm of Clark, Dodge Co., died at his home here yesterday. Born in New York fifty-three years ago, he was the son of the late James Bech Hay and Mrs. Annabella Taylo. Hay.

After tacking up signs reading "the end of the C. I. O." and "this plant is' operated by men who want to work," about 200 of the 300 employes of the Abrasisve Company went back to their jobs today, following ten days of idleness during which forty C. I. O. members seized possession of the property.

Abram Hussey, electrical engineer who for twenty-one years, until his retirement in 1934, was superintendent of distribution for the Brooklyn Edison Company, died on Thursday of a heart ailment at his home in Chester, N. J., after a brief illness. His age was 69.

Deputy Commissioner Harry M. Prince of the Tenement Hbuse Department announced yesterday that following an investigation his department had decided to order fiftyeight families to vacate a new $350,000 apartment house in the Bronx because it had become infested with millions of book lice.
John Sanderson Dalziel, noted wood engraver, died at his home here Thursday night after a brief illness. His age was 98. Mr. Dalziel's life was devoted to art and culture.
The uncertainty of the currency exchange here is resulting in skyrocketing prices and ruthless profsteering in things regarded as necessaries by foreigners and Chinese with foreign habits.

A request for $4,834,894 as its 1938 appropriation was submitted to Assistant Budget Director Kenneth Dayton yesterday by the Department of Correction. The sum sought is $1,440,572 greater than the amount allotted for 1937.

Operators of Pennsylvania silk mills and the textile workers organizing committee agreed tonight to end the textile strike affecting 1.5,000 to 18,000 workers in the State. Representatives of the operators and union immediately signed the compact.

William F. Humphrey, president of the Tide Water Associated Oil 11 Company, in a letter to stockholdera yesterday cited the progress made by the company in the last four years as being the best answer to a recent letter of the Mission Corportion criticizing certain actions and policies of Tide Water's management.

The Ambassador Hotel, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, earned for the first half of this year a net income of $51,421, after operating expenses and current taxes and insurance, but before interest on tax arrears, according to a study of the property by Eli T. Watson Co. This compares with a deficit of $3,187 for the first half of 1936.

Espionage in war-time London, Paris and Stockholm and its effects upon submarine warfare forms the basis for "Dark Journey," the London film production which arrives tonight at the Central, after the last showing of "Think Fast, Mr. Moto."

Many visitors arrived in the Berkshires today for the annual dog show of the Lenox Kennel Club, which will open at the Berkshire Hunt and Country Club tomorrow, and for Miss Kate Oglesby's debutante ball at Blantyre tomorrow night. In honor of Miss Oglesby's guests the Stockbridge Golf Club had an informal dance tonight.
Three Philadelphia district players, George Dunn, Gabe Levine and Herbert Laurence, today led the way into the second round of the annual Buckhill Falls tennis tourney.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajamas checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

The German Liberty League announced today that it had declined to participate in a "German Day" parade Sunday as a protest against the use of the German national flag, or swastika, at the celebration.
Another overturn came today in the closest duel for firstclass county cricket championship honors seen here in many seasons, when Yorkshire again displaced RUB Middlesex at the head of the standing.

L. B. Manning, president and principal stockholder of the Cord Corporation, announced yesterday that the company proposed to liquidate its miscellaneous security investments, amounting to about $2,000,000, and would concentrate attention in the future on the various operating units in which it holds substantial investments.

Miss Lucy Smoot, silvery-haired schoolmarm, the only woman student at Columbia University who dared to register for Physical Education s-160D, strictly male baseball course, learned yesterday that she had passed her 137-question final examination with flying colors.
Two heavy earthquake shocks struck Manila last night while 435 American war refugees from Shanghai were debarking from the Dollar liner President Jefferson.
The United States Embassy was rocked by bomb explosions and residences of Americans were struck by shrapnel today when fourteen Japanese bombing planes made a twilight raid on this city.

Painting against time in the patio of her woodland studio here, Mme. Elizabeth Shoumatoff, artist, had caught in water colors today a delicate, short-lived flower that blossomed on a seven-year, nightblooming cereus plant sent to her from Osterville, Mass., by Mrs. A. Felix du Pont.

Miss Adrienne Charles, daughter of Mrs: M. de Peyster Charles and 'of James M. Charles of New York, was married here this afternoon on the lawn of the Cedars, where her mother is passing the Summer, to Charles Henry Classen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Washington Classen of Roland Park, Baltimore. The Rev. Guthrie Speers performed the ceremony.

Trucks and tractors have replaced army mules and horses which used to pull supply wagons and field guns, until the army now has only 21,674, as compared with 39,461 ten years ago. In 1927 the army had 11,674 draft mules, but now there are only 3,542 left.

Former President Hoover said to- sands of day that proposals for a nationwide party conference to consider Republican principles had been discussed with both Alf M. Landon of Kansas, 1936 Presidential nominee, and Chairman John D. M. Hamilton.

The Board of Estimate struck out against crime in two directions yesterday, first by posting rewards of $5,000 each for J. Richard Davis, Jacob Shapiro and Louis Buchalter, missing fugitives, and then by authorizing the Mayor to appoint a commission to investigate the whole field of sex crimes against children.

In a calmer atmosphere and with more hope. of success, the negotiations continued today for a compromise to prevent a split between Zionists and American non-Zionists in the Jewish Agency on issues raised by the Palestine partition proposal.

Two motion-picture operators, on a sit-down strike, passed the night in the projection box of the Kameo Theatre, 180th Street and Third Avenue, last night in spite of the hot weather. Their action caused the theatre to close its doors after more than 300 patrons had been dismissed with passes.

Joe Beggs chalked up his eighteenth pitching triumph of the season as he hurled the league-leading Newark Bears to a 5-to-1 victory over the Red Wings tonight. The right-hander allowed three hits, setting Rochester down in order in seven innings.

George F. Palmer Sr., court crier of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn, with which he had been connected for more than thirty years, died yesterday morning at his home, 125 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, after a brief illness. He was 72 years old.

It seems likely that Congress will adjourn today with a highly disappointing record from the President's point of view. Of the five chief measures whose enactment at this session was desired by the Administration, only one will apparently become law.

An agreement was reached tonight by Congressional conferees on the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill. The agreement represented compromises on nearly all the major differences between the bill as originally passed in the Senate and that approved by the House.

One of the smallest fields on record took part in the one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association at the Green Meadow Country Club today. The oppressive heat was the reason for the lack of entrants.

The Manufacturers Trust Company is trustee for $800,000 6 per cent debentures of A. I. Namm Son and transfer agent for 300,000 shares of common stock and 100,000 preferred shares of the American Car and Foundry Motors Company.

Miss Muriel Gordon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Holdsworth Gordon Jr. of Flushing and this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Bard Pendleton Rogers, son of Mrs. E. Victor Loew of Tuxedo Park and the late John Shillito Rogers.

Brought up in the House and quickly passed under a suspension of the rules, the controversial and hard-fought Sugar Control Bill Was sent to the White. House today, where it faced almost certain veto, either in written form tomorrow or by the pocket method later.

More than 250 owners, trainers and riders have received entry books during the past few days for the seventh annual race meeting of the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association, which is to be held at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club, Rye, N. Y., on Monday, Sept. 6.

James McIntyre, who entertained the American public for over sixty years as one of the best of the black-face comedians, was buried today in a Catholic cemetery after simple funeral services in his Summer home, Tiana, on Noyback Bay. He died Wednesday, after a brief illness, at the age of 80.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tombrrow: "The wool market continues very quiet. Semi-occasional sales are reported here and there but for small quantities and the surface indications are that the market is weaker.

Twenty thousand inhabitants of the historic south Swedish town of Kalmar are hunting for a 25-yearold fire fiend who has lit fifteen fires in the old wooden parts of the town and endangered numerous lives.

There was a time when default in a tennis match under any circumstances was considered little short of a disgrace. A man was supposed to play to the end, even if he were dying on his feet. The theory was that it was unsportsmanlike to deny one's opponent the satisfaction of winning in the prescribed manner.

An air duct in the yard of the home of Herman Altgold at 253 Lafayette Avenue, Brpoklyn, part of the air conditioning system of the house, proved to be a man trap early today when it caught John Woods, 31 years old, a bill poster of 121 Hall Street, Brooklyn, who was trying to enter the Altgold home.

The American Federation of Labor is to be urged next week by its general counsel, Charlton Ogburn, to move at the next session of Congress for the enactment of a bill to establish a permanent national board of arbitration for industrial disputes.

The annual invitation old white fancy dress ball, for many years an outstanding event of the Summer season here, was held tonight in the Cameo Ballroom at the Greenbrier. More than 500 colonists attended. Prizes were awarded for unusual costumes.

Maurice Vasseur, French airplane propeller manufacturer, who is admittedly the best and most experienced speedboat driver in France, arrived in New York yesterday on the French liner Paris with a. ninety-mile-an-hour boat.
Still recuperating from an illness attributed to too much golf, Miss Pamela Barton, Britain's girl golf star who holds the United States title, caused two sensations in the sporting world tonight.

An examination today of the cut under the right eye suffered by Tommy Farr in training yesterday satisfied Bill Brown, member of the New York State Athletic Commission, and Dr. William Walker, commission physician, that the .injury was slight.
Announcement was made yesterday by the Millinery Stabilization Commission that it had fined the Lena Hat Company $250 for attach the "consumer protection"

An additional 100 United States marines were brought to Shanghai from the Philippines by the liner President Hoover today. As the liner turned outward to sea the marines were brought up the Whangpoo under the continuing Japanese and Chinese fire.
The Census Bureau announced today the cotton spinning industry operated during July at 121.0 per cent or capacity, compared with 137,0 during 3une this year and 119.8 during July last year.

Upon retirement here today from the Prudential Insurance Company of America, Miss Augusta T. Herzog of 463 Abington Avenue assumed the status of being the only woman who ever reached or ever will reach membership in Class J of the Prudential Old Guard, an organization of veteran employes.

In addition to releasing its semiannual statement, the Timken Detriot Axle Company announced yesterday to its stockholders an interim dividend of 50 cents each on the common shares. This is payable on Sept. 20 to holders of record of Sept. 10.

Many leases for new quarters in apartment buildings on the West Side were reported by brokers yesterday. Suites in the Riverside Drive and Central Park West sections figured in several of the leases. Details of these and other rentals follow:

Members of society who are exhibitors in the three-day benefit North Shore Horse Show for the Society of St. Johnland, together with judges and directors of the show, opened the social program that accompanies the sporting event by attending a luncheon today in the tackroom of Wide Waters,

Railroads in the United States put in service 41,630 bought or rehabilitated freight cars in the first seven months of this year, the largest number for a like period since 1930, according to the Association of American Railroads.
The Chinese Embassy today called the attention of the German Foreign Office to what it termed "onesided reporting" of the SinoJapanese conflict in several German newspapers.

A crowd of 18,448 persons saw Pitcher Paul Derringer help the Reds to a 6-to-4 victory over the National League-leading Cubs in a floodlight contest tonight. He drove in five runs with two doubles and a single.
Reversing the order of things, the Browns took an early lead over the Tigers today and built it into an 11-6 victory.

John Montague, wizard of the golf links, waived extradition today and prepared to leave for New York to face a charge of participating in the holdup of a Jay, N.. Y., roadhouse in 1930. Municipal Judge Dawson then released Montague's $10,000 bond.

Life has never been very bright for Pete and Butch, members of a family of seven living on Manhattan's East Side, but they and twenty-four other New York children were enjoying activities in the country today because enough persons wanted to save the brothers from having to sell their pet bull pups to raise money to go to camp.

Detectives of the main office division were confident last night that six arrests which they had made early in the day would lead to the solution of a series of recent holdups in which wealthy women hadbeen followed from night clubs and robbed of their jewelry.
Arthur R. Denman, a lawyer, who was active here for many years in Hos church and political circles, died today in the Hospital of Barnabas. He was 81 years old.
A riderless. automobile careening down the hill on East 173d Street, the Bronx, crashed into a group of persons sitting in front of 333 173d Street last night and injured ten, two of them seriously.

Mrs. Imogen Reeve Snowden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Livingston Reeve of 455 East Fiftyfirst Street, was married yesterday to Arthur Sullivan of Winthrop, Mass., son of Mrs. H. W. Davis and the Late Daniel V. Sullivan, at the home in New Milford, Conn., of her brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. John A. Goodwin.

Miss Jane Davis, 18-year-old daughter of United States Senator and Mrs. James J. Davis of Pennsylvania, carried off the blue ribbon in the hunters and jumpers class at the Pocono Mountain Horse Show today when she won from a field of sixteen entries over the four-foot inside jumps.

Still smarting from the three straight defeats they suffered at the hands of the Athletics last week, the Yankees strove yesterday to put the American League cellardwellers in their proper place. They succeeded.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 14 totaled 775,382 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 7,676 cars, or 1 per cent more than for the preceding week, 40,804 cars, or 5.5 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 163,377 cars, or 26.6 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Struggling desperately in what bore all the appearances of a blast furnace, the Giants fought off the Phillies for more than three hours today, finally flattened them with a five-run explosion in the ninth inning and made off with the opening contest of a four-game series, 13 to 6.

Miss Marjorie Harrison, 18-year-old Ausable Forks (N. Y.) golfer, holds a three-stroke lead over a field of sixty-seven in the annual 54-hole Ekwanok invitation tourney as a result of touring the ancient mountain layout in 85 today, giving her a total of 167.
After a hearing lasting several days Francisco Marin Cafias was convicted of violation of the law which prohibits criticism of foreign friendly governments.

Miss Lucile Thornton Thieriot and her fiance, Elisha Walker Jr., arrived today to be guests of Mr. and Mrs. Seth W. Morton at Blowing Park, their Summer home. Mr. and Mrs. Morton are giving a large luncheon tomorrow for them.

If the "New Folies Bergere" revue, which sky-rocketed onto the stage of the French Casino last evening and burst in a thousand brilliant colors, may be taken as a fair indication of what the coming night club season has in store, it is safe to foretell that the citizenry will shortly be turning into owls.

The contest between the Committee for Industrial Organization and the American Federation of Labor for control of the waterfront resulted yesterday in the calling of strikes on the ships of five lines operating in the coastwise trade and two in the foreign service.

Paul B. Hoeber, one of the leading publishers of medical books, died yesterday morning at the Lenox Hill Hospital after an illness of nine weeks at the age of 53. His firm, Paul H. Hoeber, Inc., was absorbed by Harper Brothers in 1935 and became the medical book department of that house, but Mr. Hoeber continued as president of the division and its publications bore the imprint of both names.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 152,000 bales, against 765,000 a week ago, 780,000 two weeks ago, 819,000 three weeks ago and 737,000 a year ago; of which American 258,000 bales, against 269,000 a week ago, 278,000 two weeks ago, 284,000 three weeks ago and 252,000 a year ago.
Chicago and Baltimore were eliminated today from the twenty-seventh annual International Printers baseball tournament, leaving New York and Washington to battle for the championship.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the retirement of Young, Kolbe Co..from membership in the Exchange and the formation of a new partnership, Robert R. Young Co., with offices in Jersey City.

An American sailor aboard the United States cruiser Augusta, anchored in the Whangpoo River, was killed and eighteen other American sailors were injured at 6:30 P. M. yesterday when a shell or aerial bomb hit the deck of the warship and exploded.
Premier Benito Mussolini's terms for peace with Britain were clearly heard over the radio here early enough for those newspapers so desiring to frame editorials on the speech.

The Rev. Dr. W. Graham Scroggie of Edinburgh, who has been preaching here this Summer, will speak four times during the sessions of the twenty-eighth annual General Bible Conference which tomorrow will begin a week at Stony Brook, L. I.

Questioning the claims of the Board of. Trade for German American Commerce, Inc., that German exports to the United States have risen sharply in the first six months of this year, the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League, of which Samuel Untermyer is president, issued a statement contending that German exports to this country actually indicate a relative decline compared with previous years.
The Chinese Finance Minister, H. H. Kung, summarized the results of his European mission before sailing for China aboard the German liner Scharnhorst from Genoa, Italy, yesterday.
Internal Revenue collections for July were reported today to have exceeded those in July, 1936, by $87,747,037, a gain, according to Treasury officials, that conformed to estimates.
Alvin Everett of Rome, Ga., and Arthur Thorner Jr. of Detroit qualified for the final round of the national lefthanded golf championship at Olympia, Fields today.

Half an hour after suit was filed today the marriage of Wrigley Offield, grandson and heir of the late William Wrigley Jr., chewing-gum manufacturer, and Edith Margery Haldimand of New York was annulled by Judge Harry M. Fisher.
Heeled over in a smoky sou'wester that blew up silver clear, Harold S. Vanderbilt's America's Cup defender Ranger led the fleet in the New York Yacht Club's annual regatta today out on Buzzards Bay.
I. Ira Foster, retired importer, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a brief illness. He was 54 years old and lived at 600 West 116th Street.

Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoe told the Japanese press today that the Government is prepared for a long war and for the financial sacrifices it will involve and further that Japan must settle it without foreign intervention for the sake of her future relations with China.

Though he was warned yesterday by Mayor La Guardia and Controller Frank J. Taylor that further delay in developing the North Beach Airport in Queens was dangerous, Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan cast the single vote in the Board of Estimate which held up the project.

Contingent rights on a manuscript entitled "The Newport Idea," on which no valuation is placed, and cash on hand of $1.95 are among the assets listed by Francis O. French, father-in-law of John Jacob Astor 3d. in a detailed schedule filed in Federal District Court this morning in connection with Mr. French's voluntary petition in bankruptcy, filed a week ago.

A condensed financial statement by the Atlas Corporation as of July 31, issued yesterday, showed an asset value of about $18.17 a share. Cash, dividends receivable and interest accrued amounted to $7,826,951; investments based on market value were $74,086,914, compared with a cost of $77,236,242 based market values of Oct. 31, 1936;

President Roosevelt nominated Justin Miller of North Carolina to be an Associate Justice of the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. Mr. Miller, a native of California and 49 years old, is now a membr of the Board of Tax Appeals.
Senator Guffey, an Administration stalwart, predicted "oblivion" tonight for Senate "ingrates" who fought President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganize the Supreme Court.

Retail trade activity here yesterday was substantially curbed by the high temperatures which prevailed and the poor showing will materially affect comparative results for the week, retail executives said yesterday.

The second world conference of the Religious Society of Friends will be held at Swarthmore and Haverford Colleges, near Philadelphia, from Sept. 1 to 8. Only three sessions will be open to the public.
Cy Blanton won his twelfth game today as the Pirates rallied behind his six-hit pitching to defeat the Cardinals, 7 to 4, and move to within a half game of third place in the National League.

Cotton mill activity increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index has advanced to 135.0 from 131.5 (revised). For the week ended Aug. 15, 1936, it stood at 136.9. Uncertainty over: the final form of the pending cotton loan plan held down gray goods sales this week, but volume was above that of the
Harold Haskins, insurance broker, died today at Bryn Mawr Hospital at the age of 55. He was a partner in Platt, Yungman Co. of this city. His home was in Ithan, a suburb.

In a fluctuating battle that had the gallery almost limp from excitement and suspense in a magnificently fought fifth set, Robert L. Riggs came from behind to defeat Frank Parker of New York today to gain the final round of the Newport in??vitation tennis tournament with Donald Budge.

There is no gallantry in the Dodgers. It was ladies' day at Ebbets Field yesterday, but even that was no inspiration for the Flatbush athletes, who subsided before the Bees by a score of 6-5, thus insuring their occupancy of the cellar for at least another day.

Among the contracts for commercial space reported yesterday was a lease for -two floors, comprising 30,00 square feet of space at 151-63 Wrest Twenty-sixth Street, taken by the Paris Decorators Corporation, draperies and furniture. The Rosenberg, Murray Company, Inc., negotiated the lease in conjunction with Adams Co. Other leases reported were:
A charter has been granted to the Frontier Broadcasting Company, Incorporated, of this city, with capital stock of $10,000, for operation of radio stations in Texas.
General Chang Chi-chung, Commander in Chief of the Chinese Armies defending Shanghai, said tonight that the Sino-Japanese conflict would end soon with a smashing victory for China.

THAT sometimes the world does get on is well demonstrated, though not for the first time, in Harvey O'Connor's "The Guggenheims" (Covici, Friede, $3). Once upon a time a book like this would have been impossible; for as recently as 1900, when Gustavus Myers was assembling the facts for his sober.

(Nevada) On every acre of this parched terrain The ox-drawn caravans of pioneers Printed a testament of blood and tears Across the salt plateau and sagebrush plain. On every foot of this wide scarred domain.

As broiling heat overcame Umpire Clarence (Brick) Owens in the seventh infling the Washington Senators today took the series opener from the Red Sox, 3 to 1, for their tenth victory in fourteen games with Boston.

Miss Helen J. Davenport, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Hills Davenport of this city, has chosen Sept. 11 as the date of her marriage to Dr. James Barton Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Taylor of Berwick, Pa.
Lord Ventry, wealthy industrialist, confirmed that tonight that he is a member of a British syndicate planning a new transatlantic and empire airship service.

Alice Endres, actress, died yesterday morning in St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness. She was 73 years old. Miss Endres was born in London on Jan. 13, 1864, and came to this country at the age of 15. She appeared first with Catherine Lewis in "The Royal Middy" and "Pinafore,"

Proposals for tapering off and eventually lifting the mortgage moratorium were discussed yesterday at a meeting of the committee headed by Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York. The committee was appointed last Spring to represent the Metropolitan Association of Real Estate Boards to work out this problem as well as that presented by the prospect of legislation on judgments on bonds supporting mortgages on real estate.

Miss Barbara Wiley, daughter of Mrs. Albert Bruton Strange of this city and Bernardsville, N. J., and the late Channing Price Wiley of Salem, Va., has chosen the afternoon of Sept. 10 for her marriage to Edwin Lex Bacon, son of Marshal Chandler Bacon, also of this city, and the late Mrs. Bacon.

More than 2,000 persons, including many in the clergy and executives in Catholic charitable and social service work, attended a solemn mass of requiem in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday for Miss Teresa Riley O'Donohue, head of the Ladies of Charity of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York for the last ten years.

The resale by Mandel Herman of 211 East Third Street, Manhattan, of the Old Stockade apartment house on the southeast corner of Van Reypen and Academy Streets in the Journal Square section of Jersey City to the Criterion Management Corporation of 507 Seventh Avenue, New York, was the outstanding realty transaction in New Jersey yesterday.

Canada's exports to the United States for the first seven months of the current fiscal year. had a, value of $271,124,289, or an increase of $74,770,818 over the same period of 1936, according to a report issued today by the. Dominion Bureau of Statistics.

The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System approved today reduction of the discount rates from 2 to 1 1/2 per cent by the regional banks at Chicago and Atlanta, effective tomorrow, in carrying forward its easy-money policy and to make money more readily available in connection with seasonal crop movements and expanding business.

Mrs. Dixie Bibb Graves, wife of the Governor of Alabama, was sworn in today as a Senator from Alabama to serve until a successor is elected to Hugo L. Black, who took the oath of office last night as an associate justice of the Supreme Court.

The State Department said today 256 American refugees from Shanghai were aboard the Dollar liner President Jefferson, which arrived at Manila today. The American Embassy in Nanking, meanwhile, informed the department that seventeen Americans had left Nanking on a British ship bound for Hankow.

All of the players in the Casino invitation tennis tournament were the luncheon guests of Countess Laszle: Szechenyi at the Breakers today. Countess Szechenyi was assisted in receiving by her daughters. Mrs. Eugene Bowie Roberts and Miss Sylvia Szechenyl and by Mr. Roberts.
Cleveland pounded out fourteen hits off Thornton Lee and Clint Brown today to beat the Chicago White Sox, 7 to 6, in the opener of the four-game series.

Invitations have been sent out for the wedding of Miss Jane Clarke Spalding, daughter of Mrs. Jesse Spalding and the late Mr. Spalding of New York and East Hampton, to Allison Ripley Maxwell Jr., son of Mrs. Allison Ripley Maxwell of Pittsburgh and the late Mr. Maxwell.

Army recruiting headquarters in the Whitehall Building announced yesterday that bandsmen are wanted for the regimental band of the Fifteenth Infantry, stationed at Tientsin, China. The announcement listed among the types of musicians wanted a bells player, saxophonists, bass horn players, flute, piccolo, clarinet and snare drum players.

Japan has resumed shipments of gold to this country after a lapse of about three weeks, it was disclosed yesterday when the engagement of $6,055,000 of the metal in Tokyo for transfer to San Francisco was reported to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Former Mayor Walker returned. to City Hall yesterday for the first time in five years to confer with Mayor La Guardia and other city officials in his new capacity as special assistant counsel to the Transit Commission.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria sailing today for Southampton via Cherbourg includes Mr. and Mrs. J. Edward Byrnes, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Stetson, Mrs. Claude Beddington, Robert S. Drummond, S. T. Roberts.

Mrs., Kenneth Seggerman of the home club posted a 96, low gross score in the weekly tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association today at the Rumson Country Club. The intense heat kept the field down to twelve -players, and only nine posted cards.

The death rate from the cholera epidemic at Hong Kong and other sections seemed to be diminishing today, and authorities here believed that the epidemic, which was confined mostly to the poorer Chinese, had reached its peak.
Eager to repay his own rescue four years ago, America's James Mattern soared out of Fairbanks toward the Arctic coast today to take up the week-old search for six lost Russian transpolar fliers.

Resolutions recommending formation of a council to study cosmetic formulae and material "to properly and honestly guide and protect the public"; endorsing the United States Public Health Service's campaign against venereal disease and criticizing Congress's failure to enact desired food, drug and cosmetio legislation, were adopted by the house of delegates of the tee, American Pharmaceutical Association here last night.

The final draft of the new Sinclair Lewis novel, "The Prodigal Parents," "a story of the revolt of the older generation against the revolt of the younger generation," is expected to be completed early in October, and will be published by Doubleday, Doran on Jan. 21, 1938.

Even hope was lost today for a destitute, friendless old lady who was once beautiful Wilhelmine Adamovic Woelfling, the postmaster's daughter for whom Archduke Leopold Ferdinand sacrificed his royal rights.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In his Virginia Dare address the President sounded the praises of democracy-and, inferentially, of his own devotion to its principles and perpetuation.

The talk of the stables is that the West is winning the war. Every year there is the same friendly strife at Saratoga, the best of the West against the best of the East, and so far in this meeting {the outlanders or 'invaders have been running well ahead of the defenders of the home soil.

The report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months to June 30, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income, after interest, delpreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, of $8,025,800, as compared with a net of 8$,38,613 in the twelve months to June 50, 193, an increase of $1,487,187 for the year.
Mrs. Frederick Wead Drury and Miss Frances Sands Drury have gone to Halifax, N. S., for a visit. Otto Wadsted, the Danish Minister, has arrived at the Ritz-Carlton from Washington.
The State Public Utility Commission made a tentative report today in which it held certain freight rates in the anthracite district "unreasonable."

Fund raising by groups sympathetic with Loyalists in Spain is condemned in an editorial to appear in today's Catholic News, in which Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt is criticized for having been listed as a patroness last week of a carnival on the estate of Adolph Zukor at New City, in Rockland County, for the benefit of Spanish refugee children.
Chinese armies were reported to have launched a general offensive on three fronts today to wrest North China from its Japanese conquerors.

The marketing of an issue of $15,000,000 of Port of New York Authority 3 1/4 per cent bonds, due 1977, featured another quiet period in the new investment field, but lifted the total of new bond offerings for this week to $16,925,000. This compares with only $8,076,500 in new loans placed last week, and with a total of $120,545,000 in new bonds offered during this week a year ago.

LONDON.--An outburst today by Lord Nuffield, multi-millionaire automobile manufacturer, against what he termed the "British steel ramp," run by "gentlemen with big cigars and nothing to do," has astonished the public, which believed that steel prices were subject to Government supervision.

Further light on the 2-year-old championship will be afforded tomorrow when John Hay Whitney's Pumpkin is tested by three juveniles to be saddled by the veteran trainer, Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, as well as others in the Featured Grand Hotel Stakes. featured Grand Union Hotel Stakes.

Shanghai tonight is a city of anxious minds and aching hearts. Nearly a full moon looks down from a cloudless sky upon the terrific scene of devastation symbolic of the human fury which has let loose nearly all the modern engines of destruction here.

Grenville T. Emmett, concluding his work as -United States Minister to the Netherlands before leaving with his family by automobile for Vienna tomorrow, said today that his last action here had been the arrangement of an exhibition of modern American art, to be held shortly in Amsterdam. Mr. Emmett will become Minister to Austria.

Dr. Leonidas Le May Mial died yesterday after a short illness at his home in Morristown, N. J., at the age of 75. Born in 1862 in Roanoke, N. C., he was an eye, ear, nose and throat specialist. For a number of years he was, connected with the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital.

Senator Robert F. Wagner is expected to take an active part in the Democratic primary campaign in support of his former law partner, Jeremiah T. Mahoney, former Supreme Court justice, and in opposition to his colleague, Senator Royal S. Copeland,

President Roosevelt indicated that the shelling of the cruiser Augusta in Shanghai would be treated as an incident only, and said that any census of the unemployed would be on voluntary registration basis.

The telegraph wires at Ellis Island were taxed yesterday when a flood of congratulatory messages poured in for Byron Hamlin Uhl, district director of immigration and naturalization, who had rounded out forty-five years of service with the bureau.

Members of the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association, Inc., have agreed to remain closed all day Sunday, instead of opening until 10 A. M. as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, according to Major William J. Mack, special arbitrator appointed by Mayor La Guardia to settle trade disputes in this field.
The French Naval Ministry today ordered planes as well as warships to protect shipping in the Mediterranean against unidentified raiders harassing vital sea lanes between France and her colonies.

Charles Hilton Brown of New York died early this morning of a heart attack near here at his Summer home on Diamond Point. A retired lawyer, he was in his eightysixth year. He made his home in in New York at 31 East Seventysecond Street.

General liquidation developed in the wheat market today following a fair rally early, and prices on the Board of Trade here declined nearly 3 cents a bushel at the extreme with all deliveries selling at new low prices for the season.
When official thermometers In New York reached 93.3 degrees at 4 P. M. yesterday, a record of fiftythree years standing as shattered. On Aug. 20, 1884, the temperature we t to 92 degrees.

By noon yesterday the Japanese forces had completely driven out effective Chinese troops from the Yangtzepoo area of Shanghal, where the Chinese have repeatedly endeavored to outflank the Japanese position in Hongkew, and the only Chinese now in the area are numerous snipers, a Japanese spokesman said yesterday afternoon.
Mrs. Florence Linder McColl, for fifty years a resident of Brooklyn and said to have been the first whist teacher in that borough, died Thursday at the age of 75 at the Long Island College Hospital.
Stocks closed lower for fifth consecutive day; turnover, 799,170 shares. Bonds irregularly lower, with United States Government issues weak; transactions, $9,575,900.
Stirling B. Parkinson, war-time aviator and former newspaper man, died of a cerebral hemorrhage in the Henrotin Hospital last night. He was 54 years old. His home was in Branford, Conn.
Mrs. Wright D. Goss of Newark, N. J., the medalist, won the Shawnee women's invitation golf tournament today, defeating Miss Alice Rutherfurd of Baltusrol, 4 and 3, in the 36-hole final.
Attorney General Cummings today began an examination of the evidence submitted to him by Representative Snell, Republican leader, relative to the sale of 1936 campaign books by the Democratic party.

Speaking before several hundreds of thousands of wildly enthusiastic Sicilians in Palermo this evening, Premier Benito Mussolini delivered an unusually peaceful speech in which, after declaring that Italy is ready to colelaborate with all powers and launching an appeal for peace to all countries with interests in the Mediterranean, he held out an olive branch to both Britain and France.

Delegates to the annual convention of the National Shorthand Reporters Association elected Hall Etter of Houston, Texas, president of that organization, at the closing session held yesterday in the Hotel Astor.

Of 2,055 accidental deaths reported by the New York City Health Department for the first six months of 1937, more than 30 per cent occurred in homes and about 21 per cent in streets and highways, according to a composite report of New York City accidental deaths from January to June, inclusive, made public yesterday.

More than 100 real estate holdings of six closed national banks in Westchester will be offered at auction at 2 P. M. today in the New York Naval Militia Armory at White Plains. The sale will be conducted by Joseph P. Day, Inc.; William A. White Sons and Albert M. Greenfield Co., Inc., of New York and Philadelphia.

Armond Farina of Western Pike, N. Y., made an unusually fine medal score in the quarter-final round of the seventh annual Sagamore invitation golf tournament today, being four under par for thirteen holes, as he defeated C. Everett Bacon of Montclair, N. J., 1936 winner, by 6 and 5.

Senator Connally, one of the Democratic Senators who led in the fight on President Roosevelt's Supreme Court reorganization plan, introduced an amendment to the Constitution today which, if ratified, he said, would make unnecessary such legislative batts as revolved about the Court Bill.
