Two young women declared from the witness stand at the National Labor Relations Board hearing today that they were beaten during an attack by employes of the Weirton Steel Company on a C. I. O. organizer in whose car they were riding.

One of the first Protestant clergymen to return from a trip abroad is the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, who came back this week from a six weeks' sojourn in England, where he attended sessions of the. second World Conference on Church, State and Community, at Oxford last month.

Postmaster General Farley declared that reports of a rift in the Democratic party were "pure politics, nothing but politics, and, to my mind, stupid politics," in a speech tonight at the convention of the Young Democratic Clubs.

Distilled spirits and malt liquor production and withdrawals generally declined during July, compared to the same month last year, as stocks at the end of the month showed substantial increased over their status at the same time in 1936,

The Alliance Realty Company, which owns the two five-story apartment houses at 338-40 East Fifty-second Street, added yesterday to its holdings by purchasing from Henry M. Schwarzchild, trustee, the two five-story buildings at 336 and 342 East Fifty-second Street.

Oswaldo Aranha, Brazilian Ambassador, said tonight it was too early to judge the reaction of other nations to the joint statement issued by the United States and Brazilian Governments yesterday on the proposal to lease destroyers to Brazil and other American nations.

The R. L. Watkins Company, 170 Varick Street, New York, engaged in the sale of Dr. Lyon's tooth Powders, has agreed in a stipulation with the Federal Trade Commission to "discontinue certain false and misleading representations in advertising such dentrifice," the commission announced today.

Harry Fogel, 34 years old, of 1,719 Quentin Road, Brooklyn, plunged te to his death early yesterday afternoon from the roof of a thirty-fourstory building at 1,441 Broadway. in The body landed on the roof of a four-story building at 147 West Fortieth Street, which is around the corner.

Two publications closely identified with Father Divine's Peace Missions have suspended and transferred their assets to Hy Emanuel of 334 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, for the benefit of their creditors, according to an assignment filed yesterday with the County Clerk.

The Buick Motor Division of the General Motors Sales Corporation will expand its advertising budget for the 1938 model year, in anticipation of an increase in retail volume, T. H. Corpe, director of advertising and sales promotion, announced from Flint, Mich., yesterday.

A hearing on a motion to confirm the general plan of reorganization of Prudence - Bonds Corporation which was scheduled for yesterday was adjourned until Oct. 15 by Judge Robert A. Inch in the Federal court, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Fines ranging from $1,000 to $5,000 were imposed today by Federal Judge Phillip Forman here when seven wholesale egg merchants pleaded guilty to obtaining railroad freight rebates through falsified data in violation of interstate commerce regulations.

The Board of Estimate, sitting as the upper branch of the Municipal Assembly, approved yesterday the bill passed by the Board of Aldermen which would give a fiveday week to all municipal civil service employes except members of the uniformed police and fire forces.
The Big Istres - Damascus - Paris round-trip flight race is on. Thirteen planes of French, Italian and British registry took off this evening from the Istres military airfield near here.

Production of pig iron and ferroalloys in the United States in the first half of 1937 totaled 19,975,500 gross tons, compared with 17,277,055 tons in the second half and 13,752,132 tons in the first half of 1936, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports. Pig iron alone was 19,482,002 tons, against 16,848,762 tons and 13,367,785 tons in the earlier periods.
Three labor leaders, including John L. Lewis, denounced the Democratic leadership today for its failure to bring about enactment at this session of Congress of the Wages and Hours Bill.

Alfred L. Hammett, vice president of the People's Bank for Sav- t ings in New Rochelle, died today at his home, 1,030 Clay Avenue, after a long illness. He celebrated his eighty-seventh birthday on Aug. 11.

Thick fog in the Santander Mountains hindered artillery and air operations, but the Nationalist [Insurgent] advance nevertheless proceeded. Yesterday a Foreign Legion column on the Burgos-Santander road progressed in a northeasterly direction toward the valley of the Pas River.

While China's soldiers and aviators continued their slashing attacks against Japanese positions in Central and North China today, the republic's poets and musicians wrote new battle songs to inspire the Army to drive Japan out of China.

The high bid of $250,000 for the well-known Garden Pier was rejected at the auction of the property here yesterday. Edward Ayres, who represented the estate of Alfred and Louis Burk, late Philadelphia meat packers and owners of the pier, said that he did not know what plans would be made for disposal of the place now.

After voting amendments which increased the total appropriations carried by the Third Deficiency Bill to about $150,000,000, or more than $52,000,000 in excess of the amount voted by the House, the Senate passed the bill today.

More than 4,000 persons tramped to a dell here tonight to hear a concert by seventy-five members of the New York Symphonic Orchestra conducted by Jose Iturbi in the first annual Starlight Symphony Festival of the Silvermine Guild of Artists.

John C. Strang, a retired New York jeweler, died last night of a heart attack here at his home, 315 Tecumseh Street. Born in New York in 1857, he had planned to celebrate his eightieth birthday today with a family party.
Two of the factors behind the persistent liquidation of government bonds by banks over the past year have been the reduction of excess reserves and the increased demand for business loans.

The wedding of Miss Margaret Harding Zimmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Zimmer of this city, and George Sims Casebolt, son of Mrs. George'+ H. Casebolt, also of Newark, will be performed Sept. 11 in the First Methodist Protestant Church, Newark. The Rev. John N. Link will officiate.

Mr. and Mrs. Northam Warren of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Agnes Warren, to Karl Illigen of Harrisburg, Pa., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Wilhelm Illigen of Alfred, Me. The announcement was made this afternoon at a tea at the Warren home.

Indifferent Catholics were scored by the Rev. Henry F. Hammer in a sermon yesterday morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Loyalty to the church and its ideals was also stressed by Father Hammer, assistant rector, who preached at high mass.

President Roosevelt described the late Governor Olson of Minnesota as "a gallant leader, a distinguished public servant, a hard fighter and a fast friend," at memorial services today on the first anniversary of the Farmer-Labor leader's death.

The Yankees had played slightly more than one hour in the first game of their scheduled doubleheader with the Athletics at the Stadium yesterday when the elements spoiled a perfectly hilarious time for some 28,705 fans.

Fully 5,500 terrified Chinese prisoners must remain in the Ward Road jail, which is almost encircled by burning buildings with street fighting raging on all sides of it.
Joseph Irvine Hobson, who retired one May 1 as treasurer of the Canada Steamship Lines, with which firm he had been associated since he came here in 1910, died here today at the age of 65.

Firemen searched the smoldering ruins of the New Monmouth and Park Lane Hotels today in an attempt to ascertain if any one had been killed in the blaze which swept through the buildings Saturday night causing a loss estimated at $200,000.

Bishop Ernest Lynn Waldorf of the Northern Methodist Episcopal Church said today that completion of constitutional processes in that branch of the church leading to its unification with the Southern and Methodist Protestant divisions had been assured.

Christopher Daughty, 12 years old, of Franklinville, N. J., died here at noon today in the Underwood Hospital of burns received last evening when gasoline he was pouring into his father's automobile tank exploded.

Resumption of large gold imports, after decrease in the movement between the middle of July and the middle of August, again directs interest to the Treasury's "inactive gold fund," which now, after eight months of purchases with borrowed money, exceeds $1,278,000,000.

Twenty - one persons received minor injuries at 2:05 o'clock this morning when the second car of a five-car Hudson Manhattan subway train, pulling into Hudson Terminal at Cortlandt Street after coming through the Hudson Tube from Newark, was derailed twenty feet outside the station platform.

A long-distance telephone call today ended the search by the Warren County Sheriff's office for John R. Cochrane, 209 Olean Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., who had become separated from his wife Friday while stopping here.

While the Canada Steamship liner Toronto formed a shelter for six hours until relieved by the Coast Guard patrol boat Jackson early this morning, eight Brooklyn residents, including four women, went through hours of terror as waves buffeted their cabin cruiser Zephyr II, forty miles out on storm-lashed Lake Ontario.

Mrs. Emily Holt of Fort Worth today denied she had refused an offer to assume duties of Frank Gillmore, president of Actors Equity Association. She said that the proposition is still under consideration and that a definite decision may be made within the next two weeks.

Joseph P. Ryan of New York, president of the International Longshoremen's Union, told the State convention of the Union Label Trades Department tonight that "Communists are behind the C. I. O. movement in New York City."

The Most Rev. Nicholas Kedroff of New York, Archbishop of North America and the Aleutian Islands, made a personal appeal yesterday to all ministers in his large diocese to enlist the cooperation of all Russion Churches in America in a campaign for funds to repair the mother church, the Russian Cathedral of St. Nicholas, 15 East Ninety-seventh Street.

An almost uninterrupted ten-month decline in the number of job-seekers registered with the United States Employment Service continued through July, with fewer than 5,000,000 persons in search of work registered at the end of the month. The number is the lowest for any time since establishment of the present service, Secretary Perkins announced today.

By relating its work to all phases of the adult education movement, the church can function "as the leading potential educator," it is suggested by a seminar group of graduate students at Teachers College, Columbia University, in a fivepoint program of recommendations submitted yesterday to national departments of religious education.

Clams, lobsters, chickens. sweet corn, sweet potatoes and watermelons combined to make a clambake at Wyantenuck Country Club last night one of the feasts of Lhe Summer. It was the fifth annual bake arranged by Frederick A. Pearson and 200 members and their guests enjoyed it.

China should abolish all her armament and entrust her protection to Japan. That would be the ideal solution of the Sino-Japanese problem, in the view of Toshio Shiratori, former Foreign Office spokesman and candid exponent of Japan's new nationalism.
The Czechoslovak Government has formally denied to Great Britain the charge made in Lisbon that pressure from Moscow had caused it to forbid delivery of Portgual's now famous machine-gun order.

At Creedmoor, L. I., just sixtyfour years ago, less than a score of men were gathered to fire the first National Rifle Association match, with twelve events on the program. Six men and three women in lifebelts floated helplessly through a stormy sea for more than half an hour off here tonight as mountainous waves washed them half a mile to shore after they had been thrown from a fishing boat.

Rain did not prevent the New York Football Giants from staging the first scrimmage of their training campaign at the Blue Hill Country Club today. The squad of 30 players is preparing for the clash with the Eastern College All-Stars at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 8.

Clinton S. Golden, regional director of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, said tonight that the Committee for Industrial Organization was preparing a legal drive against boycotting activities of American Federation of Labor unions.

Peasant riots in various sections of Southern Poland today were reported spreading following a series of strikes. Many were killed and wounded. In the Jaroslaw district some 5,000 peasants attacked the police while attempting to raid police headquarters for arms and ammunition.
The Hebrew Actors Union, considered one of the most powerful in the entertainment field, announced yesterday the leasing of two out-oftown theatres in a move to spread employment among 300 members.

Johnny Kinder, State P. G. A. champion, added another title to his growing list today when he teamed with Charley Whitehead of Plainfield to win the New Jersey State Golf Association and State P. G. A. pro-amateur championship at the Hackensack Golf Club.

The Right Rev. John Thompson Dallas, Bishop of New Hampshire, officiated today at the Joseph Stickney Memorial Church of the Transfiguration, where a memorial service for the Princess Aymon de Faucigny Lucinge was attended by a large group of her friends.

General hearings starting tomorrow before the full membership of the Maritime Commission will conclude the commission's investigation into employment and wage conditions in ocean-going shipping preparatory to determining minimum manning scales, minimum wage scales and reasonable working conditions on all vessels receiving Government subsidies.

The theft of about fifty automobiles during the last few months in the Canarsie-East New York section of Brooklyn was believed solved yesterday with the arrest of three youths on -charges of grand larceny and the arrest of a usedcar dealer and his helper on charges of receiving stolen goods.

Lack of aggressive foreign demand for American cash wheat has been counting heavily against the price of that grain in the last few weeks, and the weight of hedging sales was reflected last week in a decline to a new low level for the season on all deliveries.

Although oceans can now be flown on schedule in a matter of hours, it is good to know that they can also be sailed by tiny craft, with crews as small as one man, in a matter of as many weeks as it takes. Captain Ludwig Schlimbach, former master of a Hamburg-American liner, is a man for such a job.

V. I. Chebethes of New York City was elected supreme president of the American Hellenic Educational Progressive Association at closing sessions of the fourteenth annual convention here today. He won, 1191/2 to 651/2h votes, over George Ellades of Lowell, Mass., after protracted balloting.

In the second attack within twenty-four hours on a young woman in a hospital, Miss Florence Swanson, 34 years old, superintendent of nurses at the Jefferson Park Hospital, was slashed with a razor by an intruder early today.

Thousands of sharp green flies swarmed up from the South Jersey marshlands today and harassed some seventy-five nudists who were perfect targets while listening to speakers at the sixth annual national convention of the American Sun Bathing Association convention at Sunshine Park, near here.

New Jersey drivers captured six of the seven Delaware River outboard and speedboat championships in the ninth annual West End Boat Club regatta held in a steady rain today.

A man identified by police as Carlino Franco, 26 years old, a nephew of Vice President Sergio Osmena of the Philippine Commonwealth, was shot to death tonight in a scuffle in front of a downtown restaurant.

In learning to interpret the Bible, begin not with Genesis but with Jesus, begin with the person and not with the book, the Rev. Edwin H. Carr declared yesterday in his sermon as guest preacher at the Metropolitan Temple Methodist Episcopal Church, Seventh Avenue and Thirteenth Street.

On a wooded hillside in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, which figured in the Battle of Long Island in the Revolutionary War, there gathered yesterday afternoon in the rain a small group of World War veterans paying tribute to the men from Maryland who fought under Washington.
Commodore Richard Morris Hughes, U. S. N., retired, died yesterday in the Naval Hospital, Brooklyn, after an illness of more than a year. He was 78 years old and had been in retirement since 1912.
About 800 "job marchers" reached Washington tonight to augment a contingent already encamped here. The marchers arrived in a driving rain, by trucks, buses and automobiles.

Hackett Jr.secretary, said that letters would be sent this week to 3,500 East Side real estate owners and agents urging them to take "precautionary measures" to prevent the practice.
