The French Navy and naval aviation have received orders to take forceful action to protect French shipping in the Mediterranean, a communique of the Ministry of Marine makes known tonight.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Barbara Beard, daughter of Mrs. Walter Kozak of Flushing, and E. Leonard Beard Jr. of New York and Palm Beach, to Therit Rankin Towles 3d, son of Therit R. Towles Jr. of Forest Hills and the late Mrs. Towles.

The national anthems of this country and other international powers that express a purely individual conception of patriotism could bear a great change in their wording and thus help to bring a universal peace to a world sadly in need of it, the Rev. Henry H. Tweedy

The four-story .apartment house at 2,239 Eighty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, was sold by Hy. D. Agar, Inc., for Ivor B. Clark, Inc. It contains twenty-three apartments and was held at $60,000. The buyer, an investor, paid cash for it.

Scotland Yard today struck hard at gangsters and other villains appearing on the London stage, forbidding them to brandish pistols or any other weapon in the face of the hero until they had obtained licenses to possess firearms.

Multitudes of people have become "indifferent to the Christian gospel" because they believe it has "ceased to be contemporaneous," the Rev. Dr. William Hiram Foulkes, minister of the Old First Presbyterian Church, Newark, N. J., declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Twentyninth Street and Fifth Avenue.

Transported by train and motor truck, 2,200 infantrymen of the Eighty-seventh Brigade of the State Guard, commanded by Brig. Gen. Walter A. Delamater, moved into Camp Smith here today for a fifteen-day training tour of rifle practice and tactical manoeuvres in the field.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Cyril Rothwell and Mr. and Mrs. Allan L. Melhado gave a large reception this afternoon at the Westhampton Yacht Club. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. O'Brien, Dr. and Mrs. Clement B. P. Cobb, Captain and Mrs. Roger Wisner, Mr. and

A consolidated net profit of $12,433,473 after all charges was shown by the National Dairy Products Corporation in its report for the twelve months ended on June 30, 1937. The period began after the effective date of the corporation's registration statement, under which its 3 3/4 per cent debentures due in 1951 with common stock purchase warrants attached and common stock reserved against such

There is less vandalism and scattering of litter in public parks than ever before, according to Commissioner Robert Moses. In a letter made public yesterday he said the improvement was a consequence of the expanded playground system.

People who cannot see the forest for the trees are equaled in numbers by those who cannot see the Church of God for the churches, the Rev. Dr. Harry Lathrop Reed, president of Auburn Theological Seminary, Auburn, N. Y., said in a sermon yesterday morning at the West End Collegiate- Reformed Church, Seventy-seventh Street, west of Broadway.

All education teaching man "to subordinate himself to any, human force as the final authority" should be opposed by the church, the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie, rector of Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning. Dr. Bowie returned to his pulpit from a six-week trip to England.

When the Caracas of the Red D Line arrived at its Brooklyn pier last night from La Guayra, Venezuela, seventy members of its crew refused to accept their pay and started a sit-down strike. The 138 passengers left the ship without interference.

Undeterred by the approaching visit of the, Abbiey Piayers, Eddie Dowling, who returned Thursday from a trip abroad, said yesterday that he would import an equally well-known Irish company, the Gate Theatre group, also from Dublin.

Joseph J. Bruno, who last December walked away from the Pennsylvania jail where he was beginning a life sentence for his part in the killing of five Democratic marchers at Kelayres, Pa., the night before election day in 1934, was arrested here yesterday after a nation-wide search.

Mrs. Thomas S. Barber gave a luncheon today at Claverack House for her niece, the Marchesa Lelio Pellegrini-Quarantotti of Rome, Italy, who is visiting her. Among the other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Edward Purcell Mellon, Miss Lizbeth E. D. Thayer, Mr. and Mrs. Edgar H. Curry of Ryart, Cold Spring Harbor, and Francis Hartman Markoe.
Three men were seriously injured yesterday in two airplane crashes. Both planes involved left Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, within a half hour of each other.

Playing in intermittent rain, the top-seeded doubles team of Mrs. Dorothy Andrus, New York, and Mme. Sylvia Henrotin, France, defeated Miss Kay Winthrop and Mrs. Virginia Rice Johnson of Boston, 6-2, 6-4, to win the Essex County Club's invitation tennis tournament today.

Colonel Albert William Goodman, sturdy backbench M. P. who devoted most of his parliamentary career to asserving the rights of the House of Commons against both Conservative and Labor Governments, died today at the age of 57.

Holding that steel-making is at the crossroads for this season, the magazine Steel says the next ten days or two weeks are expected to indicate the trend for the Autumn. The publication believes most signs point to a turn to the right, with resumption of satisfactory buying and an active period.

Louis Mylord, 36 years old, of 133-05 226th Street, Laurelton, N. Y., was injured fatally here early this morning when he was struck by a automobile by David Cohn, 22, of 248 Van Sicklen Street. Brooklyn. Mylord was walking along Tonnele Avenue at 2 o'clock when he was hit by automobile.

Mrs. John Hay Whitney is expected from Hollywood to pass the final week of the racing here with Mr. Whitney at their estate. State Controller Morris S. Tremaine and Mrs. Tremaine will give a large luncheon tomorrow at the Gideon Putnam.

A bucket brigade which ineluded 'Evalyn Pierce, director of the New York: Federal Theatre; Madalyn O'Shea, an actress, and members of The 'Forty-Niners, a Summer-play group, today saved the Chase Barn Playhouse from destruction by fire.

A Newton policeman was fatally shot, another was so seriously wounded that he may die, and their wounded assailant was driven into hiding early today, all because a girl let a strange man take her for "an automobile driving lesson" last night. The girl, 17, of Cambridge, was arrested on suspicion that she helped the killer disarm his victim.
John Pritchard, 31 years old, of 351 West Fifty-seventh Street, a Horn Hardart striker charged with malicious mischief in allegedly throwing several bottles through windows of the Automat at

The festival here is entering its last lap. Excitement still to come centers principally on two Toscanini concerts-one a special program to be given Tuesday afternoon under the sponsorship of the National Broadcasting Company, the conductor donating his share of the proceeds to the Festspielhaus building fund; and the visit next Friday of

Prices of cotton continued to move downward last week. Those for middling spot cotton in the South broke through the 10-cent level and at the close of the week were at the lowest level since December, 1933. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures lost 59 to 71 points in the week.

Ben Johnson, lithe American - Negro runner who captained -Columbia University's track team last season, today bettered the world record for the 100meter dash when he ran the distance in 10.2 seconds in an International track meet.

A heavy downpour of rain, starting shortly after noon today and continuing for two hours, curtailed the final practice rounds for the national amateur golf championship which starts tomorrow on the Alderwood Country Club course.

LIFE WITH MOTHER, by Clarence Day. (Knopf, $2.) A companion volume for "Life With Father." AMERICAN STUFF: AN ANTHOLOGY. (Viking, $2.) Work by writers and artists who have jobs in the arts projects of the WPA.

The tendency on the Stock Exchange here was completely reversed this week, the rise of the previous week having been checked. Prices declined sharply among foreign as well as French securities, mining shares only being firm.

Hillbilly orchestras and barber shop quartets from various parts of Queens will take' part in a contest this evening at Music Grove in Forest Park, sponsored by the recreational division of the Department of Parks.

The heat wave that had oppressed the metropolitan area for a week was broken yesterday when rain and east winds sent the mercury toppling from the record 93 and 92 degree maximums for the two days preceding to 61 degrees, the lowest temperature recorded in a month.

A Bayside Y. C. navigator, John B. Dawson, came from Long Island Sound to Princess Bay, S. I., yesterday and despite a propeller that bent when his boat Melba hit a chunk of driftwood off Midland Beach carried off the Captain Billopp Trophy for winning the second annual motor cruiser race around Staten Island.

Recalling a statement some months ago by Postmaster General Farley which contained an expose of the "fake eye specialist racket," in operation in this country for about twenty years, at a cost to the public, particularly aged farm people, estimated at several million dollars, the Postoffice Department's information service made public today some details of how this "most inhumane racket" works.

A strong northeast wind which swept the ocean dune course of the Maidstone Club failed to halt the game of Jess Sweetser, who won the Maidstone Bowl today by defeating John E. Parker of Essex County, former metropolitan champion, 5 and 4. Sweetser's par 73 led

The Montreal Royals managed to escape elimination from the International League pennant chase today by coming from behind to take both ends of a double-header from the Jersey City Giants, 5 to 4 and 2 to 1.
The increase in foreign-exchange purchases contributed to strengthening slightly the money market's tendency here this
Finance Minister Georges Bonnet announced -in a speech at Dinard today that the French Treasury could easily meet all its obligations between now and the end of the year.

Testimony by which attorneys for-the-National Labor Renations Board hope to substantiate its charges that the Weirton Steel Company maintained an elaborate espionage system among its employes, will he presented tomorrow when the hearing on the board's complaint against the company resumes here.
Scanning a study by the New York City Health Deapartment of 2,055 accidental deaths, one might suspect that the American home was

Two marksmen from Iowa captured the honors today in the prologue to the thirty-eighth annual Grand American-trap-shoot program which gets under way in earnest tomorrow with five championships up for decision.
Gaining the lead in the third round today, Vic Ghezzi, 25-year-old Deal, N. J., pro, shot a 72 on the final eighteen and captured the Lake Placid open golf tourney with a 72-hole score of 277.

The Far Eastern crisis was the main problem facing President Roosevelt today, and will be for many days to come, now that Congress has adjourned, relaxing the domestic political tension at least momentarily.

Samuel Griss, an American citizen, general superintendent of the Bruck Silk Mills here, was abducted on the Cowansville golf course this afternoon and all but railroaded over the United States border by seven men in an automobile, one of them a discharged employee of the factory.

The official report for the beginning of August shows an improvement in the root crops and in sugar beets and potatoes. A record high yield is promised in potatoes, but no improvement is seen in the fodder crops and meadows, which suffered from the drought earlier in the year.

Dr. Cecil H. Bagley's speedy hydroplane Wilmer III sank today during a grueling contest in the 225 cubic-inch class of the first annual Solomons Island regatta, throwing the Baltimore yachtsman and his mechanic into the Patuxent River.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 91.9, which compares with 91.9 a week ago, 91.8 two weeks ago, 92.8 three weeks ago and 92.3 four weeks ago.
Charles F. Thompson, State Director of Conservation, died at the Presbyterian Hospital today after an illness of five weeks. He was 73 years old.

Leland P. Carpenter, 39 years old, of 7 Glenridge Parkway, Montclair, a New York produce merchant who attempted suicide last week in a Newark hotel, was found dead this morning in a room at the Alexander Hamilton Hotel here. His body was found suspended by a piece of clothes line.

Local contributions in the administration of the Wagner-Steagall Housing Act should be in the form of cash obtained through special tax levies and not through tax exemptions or remission of taxes, Clark G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, said yesterday.

The purchase by the Port of New York Authority of three parcels in Union City in connection with the new Lincoln Tunnel to midtown Manhattan was the outstanding realty transaction in New Jersey over the week-end.

Gerhard Wagner, Reich Medical Fuehrer, warns German women to refrain from smoking until they are over 50. He says that smoking may affect their capacity to bear children. He also warns them to let alcohol alone, except in very small quantities.
The national capital displayed today the usual calm, relieved gratification with which it habitually celebrates the departure of the Congress.

Sailing through a thirty-mile northeaster, raging seas and pelting rain, Cornelius Shields brought his Aileen home at the head of a fleet of eight International Class sloops today in a Royal Bermuda Yacht Club Trophy series race held in conjunction with the special regatta of the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club.

The funeral of Judge Leon Sanders of the Municipal Court of New York, who was killed in an automobile collision in California last Wednesday, will be held at 2 P. M. tomorrow at Temple Beth-El, Cedarhurst, L. I. Edward T. San-. drow, spiritual head of the temple, will officiate. Burial will follow in Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Myrtle Avenue, Ridgewood, Queens.

Fiscal officials said today that the Government's September borrowing might approximate $1,200,000,000. A $1,170,000,000 financing operation will be necessary to meet note and discount-bill maturities on Sept. 15. Authorities said the aggregate

Education was advanced as the medium for promoting international good-will at the opening of the third Pan-American conference on education here today. Nearly 500 delegates from the United States and Latin-American countries attended the first session.
William Henry Gunlocke, treasurer and managing director of' the W. H. Gunlocke Chair Company, died today of a heart attack. His age was 65.

John Tyler, a 90-year-old Negro, this village's last surviving veteran of the Civil War, died last night at the Brunswick Hospital. His death was attributed to old age. He had been in the hospital two weeks.

Great Britain's foreign trade statement for July made a particularly favorable impression not only because exports were the highest since July, 1930, but also in that their expansion was proportionately as large as the rise in imports. This affords no small

Despite the recovery on Saturday, stocks were lower for the week; turnover, 3,821,030 shares. Bonds were lower; Japanese issues broke sharply; United States Government obligations easier; transactions, $36,499,300.

The general French wholesale price index for Aug. 14 stood at 580, against 582 on Aug. 7. Native products stood at 584, against 582; imported products at 573, against 580; foodstuffs 546, against 550, and industrial materials 610, against 609.

Mr. and Mrs. Olney B. Mairs have as their week-end house guests Miss Edwina Atwell, daughter of Mrs. George J. Atwell of Roslyn, L. I., and Philip Fell, son of Mrs. Ogden Livingston Mills of Westbury. Mr. and Mrs. Mairs gave a dinner for twenty in their honor tonight.

The Giants' drive in pursuit of the front-running Cubs struck another annoying snag today when rain wiped out the afternoon's doubleheader with the Phillies after only two innings of the scheduled first game had been played.
Exhibiting his penchant for stealing the show, Max Baer almost got himself punched on the nose in plain view of about 500 fight fans this afternoon. The former
The index of Germany's wholesale prices on Aug. 11 was 106.9, compared with 106.8 the preceding week.

Joe Louis, the king, played second harmonica to the pretender, Max Schmeling, right in his camp today as the German fighter visited Pompton Lakes for his first good close-up of Louis since he smashed him into that surprising knock-out defeat at Yankee Stadium a year ago last June.
California completed its unprecedented sweep of the fifteenth annual national public parks tennis..tournament today with three additional championships.
Miss Jennie Abbott Brown, a founder of the Young Women's Christian Association and wartime director of the Americah Red Cross here, died yesterday at the age of 89.

The stock market. here this week opened quietly. There was, however, a demand for machinery and armament securities which continued throughout the week, causing sharp advances in Deutsche Waffen and Schubert Salzer as well as minor gains in some other engineering stocks.

Word comes from Paris that President Roosevelt has been more successful in influencing the budget-makers in France than in the United States. For France, according to Finance Minister Georges Bonnet has balanced the budget on the advice of Mr. Roosevelt.

A young Brooklyn surgeon who successfully performed two delicate operations at sea, one to. save the life of a stricken passenger and the other to thwart what was said to be a suicide attempt by a stowaway, was hailed as a hero by passengers and officers of the United States Liner

The Louisville Gas and Electric Company (Delaware) and subsidiaries report net income of $1,527,848 for the twelve months ended on June 30, after deductions for interest, amortization of debt discount and expense and flood expense, other income deductions, and dividends on the preferred stock of the Louisville Gas and Electric Company (Kentucky).

Last week was a period of lower markets. Even steel output was reduced, and the spinning and cottonconsumption reports for July testified to unusually large decrease. Nevertheless, the weekly car-loading figures continued to make good comparison with 1936; notably in ore, coke and lumber loadings, whose large increase ought to reflect expectation for Autumn steel and building activities.
Mrs. Harriett B. Austin, for many years active in church and civic affairs here, died at her home today after a long illness. Mrs. Austin, widow
The New York Gospel Center held its first service yesterday morning in its new quarters in the Eighteenth Street Methodist Episcopal Church, 305 West Eighteenth Street. The Gospel Center, a Baptist

Dry and hot weather has taken a heavy toll of the corn crop in the last few weeks, and the corn trade has largely discarded its ideas of a big yield this year. However, the harvest still is expected to exceed 2,600,000,000 bushels, or be 1,000,000,000 bushels in excess of that of last year, when it was far below domestic requirements.

Bob Eisner's goal in an overtime stanza, the only goal of the game for the Princeton University star, gave the Monmouth (N. J.) polo team a 9-to-8 victory today over Santa Barbara, Calif., in the national intercircuit tournament at the Oak Brook Polo Club.

A call to the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization to unite in forming a third party to fight both Democrats and Republicans in the Congressional elections of 1988 was issued yesterday by the national executive committee of the Social Democratic Federation,

The Sea Cliff (L. I.) seniors captured the Long Island Sound team championship of the Snipe Racing Association for the third successive year as the annual regatta ended today with two races off the New Rochelle Yacht Club.

Public Works Administration announced today the completion of a $50,000 water supply project at Charlotte Amalie in the Virgin Islands for utilization of salt water from the Caribbean for sanitation and for fire-protection purposes.

The enactment of the housing bill was "the only thing of importance to organized labor" accompolished .by the recent session of Congress, William Green,-president of the American Federation of-Labor, declared here tonight.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor against Senator Royal S. Copeland, Tammany's choice, declared yesterday, in explaining his opposition to American participation in the Olympic games in Germany that he had fought Nazi persecution not only of the Jews but of Protestants and Catholics.

For the second time in four weeks, Italy today launched a 35,000-ton battleship. The Littorio slid down the ways to ride upon an angry sea, while a throng estimated at 100,000 cheered. Her sister ship, the Vittorio Veneto, was launched at Trieste July 25. Their completion, perhaps

Officers using an airplane, gas grenades,. machine guns and fast footwork drove Ygnacio Ayerza, alleged slayer of his daughter and her fiance, into the arms of a posse today thirty-five miles east of Los Banos.

Gold imports by Great Britain in July totaled [Pound]44,055,856, making [Pound]211,985,158 for the first seven months of this year, against [Pound]135,453,828 correspondingly in 1936. Exports of the metal in July were [Pound]18,887,757, making the seven-month total [Pound]155,529,037, against [Pound]30,394,190.

A bit ter factional struggle, the outcome of which will have an important bearing on the union's relationship with the motor car manufacturers, was in prospect tonight as delegates arrived on the eve of the second annual convention of the United Automobile Workers of America, which opens here tomorrow.

The White Sox lost ground in their battle for second place in the American League today, defeating the Indians, 5 to 2, in the opener when Bob Feller walked seven men in two innings and then losing the nightcap, 3 to 2, when Mel Harder pitched five-hit ball for the Trib.

Three rules for utilizing tO the full one's "hidden resources" were listed by the Rev. Dr. James Gordon Gilkey, minister of South Congregational Church, Springfield, Mass., in a sermon yesterday morning at Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

Fedoral contracts for supplies in the amount of $5,229,220, were awarded under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Aug. 19, the Department of Labor has announced. Twelve agencies made seventy-eight contract awards the report said.
Bob Weiland and Jerome (Dizzy) Dean pitched and batted the Cardinals back into third place in the National League today with a pair of victories over the Pirates, 12 to 0 and 9 to 7.

The Dodgers were practically rained out of the National League cellar yesterday. Scheduled to play two games with the Bees at Ebbets Field, they succeeded in winning the opener, 5-1, in six innings before the downpour became so intense that even the umpires couldn't stand it any longer.
The Japanese Embassy announced today its government has proof that the shell which struck the United States cruiser Augusta at Shanghai last week was of Chinese manufacture.

The steady rain today kept about everybody indoors. However, there were a number of luncheon parties, including those given by Mrs. Herman Oelrichs at Rosecliff, Mrs. Forsyth Wickes at Zeerust, Dr. and Mrs. Truman Laurence Saunders at Plaisance and the Misses Wetmore at Chateau Sur Mer.

To make the public more "Godconscious," the Rev. John R. Atkinson advocated yesterday that the advertising signs marring the beauty of the countryside be replaced by signs bearing the words: "Worship God." Preaching at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine,

With a tsk-tsk over the fact that the -Britons are .apparently still fighting the World War, let it be reported that the Central's "Dark Journey," a British-made spy melodrama centering around England's most charming screen actress, Vivien Leigh, and that bulwark of villainy, Conrad Veidt, is a swift, colorful and engagingly tangled cinema matter of virtually no importance whatsoever, except that it does bring to light one or two hitherto unlisted espionage devices.

Three disillusioned stowaways, including a mystery woman whose case attracted the attention of the press on both sides of the Atlantic and a girl novelist, were aboard the Anchor liner California when it arrived here today from Glasgow, Dublin and Cobh.

Continental Roll and Steel Foundry Company-Six months to June 30: Net profit, all charges, including . Federal and State income taxes, but without provision for undistributed profits, $560,475, against $383,247 in same period last year. J. T. Osler, president, said in connection with the renort that sinking-fund arrearages

For the first time since the World War, St. Louisans of German birth or parentage gathered today to celebrate "German Day" and speakers predicted that the return of democracy to Berlin was "only a matter of time."

A group of 500 leaders in industrial, religious and professional fields has been organized to sponsor the Good Neighbor League dinner to be held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on Sept. 17, it was announced yesterday. General John F. O'Ryan will be toast master.

Alabama people as a whole deplore--and many of them openly resentthe appointment of Mrs. Dixie Bibb Graves for the interim term in the United States Senate occasioned by the elevation of Senator Black to the Supreme Court.

Connected with the show business for fifty-six years and in other days known to show-goers of the continent as manager of the Marks Brothers Theatrical Company, Robert W. Marks, Canada's oldest impresario, died yesterday in the Perth Hospital at the age of 84.

The situation now is entirely different from what it was when the Sino-Japanese incident broke out. We are thus faced with the necessity of adopting an entirely different policy from that of non-aggravation and local settlement.

Speaking before an audience of more than 250 socially prominent residents of this community today, the Rev. Gerald L. K. Smith, national leader of the Committee of 1,000,000, bitterly assailed the New Deal in general and John L. Lewis and Supreme Court Justice Hugo Black in particular for Communist leanings.

-Gerald Balding, the British internationalist, was painfully but not seriously injured while riding with Jock Whitney's Greentree side against Aknusti in a test polo match on Bostwick Field today. The game was played despite a heavy rainstorm and attracted a sizable gallery.

General liquidation developed last week in the lard market here, and all deliveries reached the lowest levels for the futures since July, 1936, when the January delivery touched $10.071/2 a 100 pounds, which was 15 cents under the inside figure for the September contract yesterday.

An official announcement today said that banks insured with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation must cease making interest payments on demand deposits of States, municipalities and other public agencies at midnight tonight.

Purchasing of Fall dresses slackened somewhat last week as retailers awaited delivery. The four to six week delivery period which is general in the better price ranges has led a number of resident buying offices to caution accounts against insufficient stocking of Fall dresses, as consumer demand is expected to spurt immediately after Labor Day, and there is a possibility of retailers being unable to obtain goods at short notice.

A movement among the Arabs here for an understanding with the Jews is growing rapidly. The attitude of the non-Zionists headed by Felix M. Warburg in opposing a Jewish State and calling for an understanding with the Arabs is regarded by the 'Arabs with great satisfaction.

Confessional church pastors announced in Berlin pulpits today that the number of Protestant pastors under arrest had increased by twenty-three-from eighty to 103--during the last ten days. Thirty-one prohibitions to preach, twelve expulsions from pastorates and thirty-one police decrees exiling pastors from their parishes also were reported.

After holding the Tigers to one run for eight innings, Bill Trotter weakened in the ninth to allow the Detroiters to score two runs, and another tally in the tenth was enough to win the final of a doubleheader with the Browns today, 4 to 3. The Tigers easily captured the first game, 11 to 3.

Net earnings of the Jewel Tea Company for the twenty-eight weeks ended on July 17 amounted to $767,073, or $2.74 each on 280,000 shares, after providing for Federal taxes, depreciation and all other operating charges, but without provision for possible surtax on undistributed income. In the same period of 1936 earnings were $875,851, or $3.13 a share.

A revision of the "weather permitting" clause in the employment of motion picture extras, allowing the player one-fourth of the day's pay if calls are canceled because of the weather, will take effect this week as the result of conferences between the Screen Actors Guild and the Producers Association.

Audiences totaling 4,346,705 persons listened to 4,360 programs and performances by music units of the Works Progress Administration during July, according to statistics made public yesterday by Dr. Nikolai Sokoloff, director of the Federal Music Project.

Picketing was continued yesterday in front of the Hudson Terminal Buildings at 30 and 50 Church Street by members of the Building Service Employes Union, which called a strike in the buildings last week. According to the

George Rasely, tenor of the Metropolitan Opera, sang this afternoon in the fourth White Mountain Music Festival at the Chase Barn Theatre. Mr. Rasely, who before has visited the mountains on vacation, offered his first recital here for the benefit of the local hospitalks of Whitefield and Lancaster, next neighboring town at the north.

Eight men have been shot at Leningrad on charges of Trotskyist counter-revolutionary activity in two factories there. They were accused of committing sabotage and terrorism, including assassinations of workers and of preparing for similar crimes at a third factory.

As Congress rushed to adjournment in the last few weeks many important bills never came to a vote; some were passed by one house and buried by the other; most of the legislation that did pass was ill-digested.

The Federal Trade Commission said today that Les Parfums Marly, Inc., New York, had agreed to stop using the words "Paris" or "France" or the phrase "made in Paris" on its packaged perfume products to imply that the products were of French origin.

Mr. and Mrs. John Magee will return from Pebble Beach, Calif., this week and will be at the SavoyPlaza before going to Southampton for the remainder of the season. Senator Joseph F. Guffey of Pennsylvania is at the Ambassador with his sisters, the Misses Ida V. and Pauleztta Guffey.

Miss Laurette Carroll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Firmin Carroll of this city, was married to Thomas Patten Doubleday of Hempstead and Cooperstown, N. Y., this afternoon in Christ First Presbyterian Church by the Rev. J. Milton Thompson. Miss Genia Carroll was her sister's only attendant.

Harbored in a snorting nor' easter which swept in from the sea, the fleet of the New York Yacht Club rode at anchor here today. Its cruise is scheduled to be resumed tomorrow with the run to Newport, but the outlook for anything like America's Cup class sloop racing was not altogether bright.

The chief of the National Socialist party's foreign section, Ernst Wilhelm Bohle, has announced his intention of forcing foreign governments to recognize and protect National Socialist party officials and groups in their territories.

Tommy White, captain of the Pennsylvania Military College team, poked in a 70-yard shot from the center of the field in 1:54 of the "sudden death" period to give the Bethpage Polo Club a 5-4 victory over Fort Hamilton today in an Eastern Polo League contest.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amounted to $4,769,249,400. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 83 per cent of capacity, down 2 points from the week before. Mills that have had backlogs are getting to the end of them, while there is no distinct increase in the volume of buying.

More refugees from Shanghai poured into-Manila today as officials revised estimates of the damage from last week's Philippine earthquakes upward to $1,500,000. The liner Victoria docked this morning with sixty Italian refugees and the American liner President

Richard Ritchie's Kestrel and William A. Richardson's-Leif were established yesterday as the respective winners in the City Island Yacht Club's annual overnight race to Cornfield light vessel and return for auxiliaries and to Stratford Shoal and return for sailing craft.

Cargo through the Panama Canal to Japan showed a sudden increase last week. In two days, eight ships, all from ports in the United States, passed through the Canal to the Pacific Ocean with 63,148 tons of cargo, largely scrap metals, bar steel and pig iron.

Closing ceremonies of the jubilee encampment marking the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Girl Scout movement in the United States were held here today at Camp Andree by Girl Scouts from all sections of the United States and twenty-six foreign nations who are attending the celebration. The girls will leave the camp tomorrow morning at 7:30 o'clock.

The resolution adopted here last night by the Jewish Agency authorizing two sets of negotiations, one with the Arabs for an "undivided Palestine," the other with the British for a Jewish State formed by the partitioning of Palestine, is being contradictorily interpreted in Jewish and other circles.
Two of the test-matches set for Long Island fields today, the Sands Point encounter between Old Westbury and Templeton and the Meadow Brook game between the Argentines and Aurora, were rained out,
Britain's proposal that Japan and China both withdraw their reinforcements of troops from Shanghai has been approved by Nanking "in principle," British official sources disclosed tonight.

William Halpin, father of the consolidation bill which united the five boroughs of the city almost forty years ago, died yesterday afternoon at his home, 677 Macon Street, Brooklyn. He was just one day short of 72 years of age.

Mayor La Guardia's proposal to seek abolition of the Transit Commission and place jurisdiction over grade-crossing removals in the city in the hands. of the Board of Transportation will serve merely to delay the elimination of the Long Island Railroad crossings from Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn,

The Cubs increased their lead over the Giants to four games today by taking both ends of a double-header tic from the Reds while the New Yorkers were rained out at Philadelphia. Chicago won the opener, 4 to 1, and the final, 5 to 2.

J. B. Priestley's return with "Time and the Conways" next Thursday and Percy Robinson's melodrama, "Wanted for Murder," opening on the preceding night, are the only events of interest in the theatre for this week. Later there will be Ivor
A heavy artillery shell crashed into the heart of the International Settlement today, killing an estimated 400 persons and wounding 400.

For seven hours today 117 patrolmen and detectives of four Westchester County police departments and an unknown number of rain-soaked civilians staged an oldfashioned man hunt in the thickly wooded Wilmot Woods section of the Hutchinson River Parkway here for a 40-year-old Negro who was wanted for murder.

Public support for an amendment to the New York State Constitution to permit county Sheriffs to succeed themselves will be sought by members of the New York State Sheriffs Association at their annual convention opening tomorrow.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange last week; also the new highs and lows and total number of issues for the last three weeks:

Frank Van Dyk, executive director of the three-cents-a-day hospital plan, announced yesterday that the organization would pay hospital bills totaling more than $3,000,000 in 1937. He said the non-profit plan would hospitalized its 33,000th patient today.
Jeffreson McGrath, American business man, died yesterday after a brief illness. He had been an executive of the Philippines Refining Company for eight years.

Congress. has voted 500,000 contos (about $35,000,000 American) for coffee defense. About 15,000,000 bags of coffee will be withdrawn from the domestic market until next December -for destruction as part of the program urged by the Brazilian Coffee States Convention recently held here.
Delegates of furniture workers' unions from six States in the Middle West met here today and organized a Midwest advisory council of furniture workers.

Daniel Frohman, whose career as a producer would form a considerable part of the story of the modern American stage, passed his eighty-sixth birthday yesterday. Much of the day he spent with his sister, Miss Etta Frohman, in their apartment at 30 West Fiftyfourth Street. Numerous telegrams reached him from persons in the theatrical world, especially members of the Actors Fund, of which he is president.

When a soda-fountain repairman left the candy store of William Jacobs at 570 Seventh Avenue, South Brooklyn, on Saturday, he left a small bag halffilled with plaster of paris on the counter. Some one thought it was flour and put it in the Jacobs pantry at the rear of the store.

Representative William I. Sirovich will return today on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary after a tour through Europe. Four German tennis stars, Baron Gottfried von Cramm, Heinrich Henkel, Heinrich Kleinschroth and Miss Marie Louise Horn, are also on the liner.

Decreased speculative interest in corn was largely responsible for a decline in trading in grain futures on the Chicago Board of Trade last week. Aggregate sales of the five grains were almost 12,000,000 bushels less than the previous week and 28,000,000 bushels under the corresponding week in 1936.

The first major jungle exploration expedition- equipped to be guided by radio direction bearings and to make broadcasts from the heart of the jungle will leave for British Guiana Friday under the leadership of Dr.. William Hall Holden, chief surgeon of the-American Museum of Natural History.

The fifth annual cruiser race of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association was won today by Commodore Robert S. Haight, sailing his Crosby Cat Cataumet, although Ferdinand Wycoff's Falcon finished first. Haight won on corrected

The fortnightly Stock Exchange account which has just ended opened with the promise of an unusual degree of Summer activity and buoyance. The settlement day came, however, amid pronounced quietude and a somewhat heavy tone.
The first major-scale battle in the seven weeks' North China conflict was raging today about thirty miles southwest of Peiping on the Peiping-Hankow Railway.

Holders of city of Carlsbad, Czechoslovakia, external thirty-year 8 per cent bonds of 1924 due on Jan. 1, 1954, have been notified by C. B. Richards Co., fiscal agents, that funds are available at the office of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, paying agent, to pay the balance of interest due on Jan. 1, 1935, amounting to $15 for each $40 coupon and $7.50 for each $20 coupon. Holders who have

An assertion that the power of John L. Lewis and the Committee for Industrial Organization started to wane when the steel strike passed its peak, was made tonight by Senator Holt of West Virginia in a radio speech.

The fact that many thousands of working men are receiving paid vacations this year for the first time is responsible for a substantial decline in passenger traffic on the subway and elevated lines of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, according to a report made public by Thomas E. Murray Jr., Federal receiver.

Harpers announce that it has been decided to postpone indefinitely the publication of "The Song the Summer Evening Sings and Other Novellas," edited by Whit Burnett and Martha Foley of Story Magazine.

Gar Wood Jr. of Detroit, son of the world speedboat champion, won major honors in the sixth annual Chicago Gold Cup regatta on Lake Michigan's Burnham Park lagoon today before an estimated crowd of 150,000 spectators.
Mystery surrounding the disappearance of a man and a woman from this village May 5 was dispelled today when berry pickers stumbled across their bodies in a near-by woods.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Percy Edward Anderson of this place of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jane Caryl Anderson, to Charles Henschel Conland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Holton Conland of Hartford.

While it is somewhat difficult at all times to determine whether the British Exchange equalization fund is following any definite policy on gold, recent indications point to the development of a greater control over the bullion market.
William Brosmith, dean of insurance counsel in the United States, died today at his home here following a heart attack on Aug. 5. He was 82 years old.
Activity prevailed in the cotton market here last week and prices sagged to the lowest levels of the movement, the near positions dropping below 10 cents a pound for the first time in several years.
Twelve men were burned to death and at least forty-eight injured when fire fighters were trapped by flames that raced through tree tops in-the Shoshone National Forest.

An organization to support Municipal Court Justice David C. Lewis of the Fifth Manhattan District, candidate for renomination in the Democratic primary, will be formed Wednesday evening at a meeting at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth

Captured by a posse of local police and citizens in the swamps of the Jersey meadows just east of here, a man who described himself as Gustav Gehn, 32 years old, of 36 Hope Street, Jersey City, was booked at police headquarters thi afternoon on charges
We are fast nearing the area where our search for Sigismund Levanevsky, the Russian flier, and his five companions, believed down in the Arctic wastes, will begin in earnest.

No matter how much we may want a man to serve in public office, we have to convince him that he should serve. We can't compel him. So the question becomes a permanent one, if we desire honest and capable government: How are we going to make it worth while for the best men to take office?
An analysis of the leading causes of death in this city in 1936, classified by age and sex, is included in the Department of Health's quarterly bulletin, to be mailed to physicians today.
Senator Burton K. Wheeler is preparing to return home to Montana, behind him the Congressional session in which he led a successful revolt against the Administration's Supreme Court plan.

High officers of the Chinese air force declared today that their airmen had proved superior to the. Japanese and that nearly fifty enemy planes had been shot down or captured. They said the swift, powerful American-built bombing planes used by the Chinese Army were superior to Japanese craft.
General Erich Ludendorff, who always refers to himself as "the warlord," again attacked the late President Paul von Hindenburg in the latest edition of his "At the Holy Well of German Power."

Finance Minister Georges Bonnet is promulgating the 1938 budget and even, taking into account the new taxes, the striking of a balance will be difficult, more so if the industrial decline should grow larger as feared, and the tax revenues should fall below the official estimates.

Miss Eleanor Hutchings Crosby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Crosby of this place, and Arthur C. Stevens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Stevens of Ithaca, N. Y., were married yesterday at the Summer home of the bride's parents in Clinton.

The jingle of cold cash provided a strong overtone today to Chinatown's chorus of jubilation over "victory news" from the Shanghai front. Leaders estimated the settlement of 17,000 persons had contributed spontaneously about $1,250,000

The eleventh International Dairy Congress opened here today with 3,000 delegates from fifty-three countries attending. Among the fifteen delegates from the United States were representatives of the Department of Agriculture led by O. E. Reed.

Sergeant Alfred Sichinger, on desk duty at the Bay Street police station, had quite a shock here tonight when Randolph Golden, 63 years old, of 95 Montgomery Street, a waterfront lodging house, walked into the station and declared that two unidentified men had attempted to "beat me up and steal my money, my life's savings."

The men in charge of the four local fire engines felt fine today, and it was all because of Spot. Spot is almost sure to recover, and some day soon she will be back at the firehouse, where she has been friend and mascot for nearly four months.

The Federal Symphony Orchestra, directed by Louis Kroll, with Erno Balogh as the piano soloist, presented a varied program at the WPA Theatre of Music last night before a large and appreciative audience. Mr. Balogh was heard in

The nine-inning, three-hit relief pitching of Lefty Herb Moore gave the Rochester Red Wings an 8-to-4 verdict over the Newark Bears in the final game of the series today, Rochester's only victory in the fourgame group which ended the season's warfare with the Bruins.

Chatterton Ave, 2.146-48, (14-3806): Catherina Maniaci to Rondout Savings Bank, instAllmenta, 5 per cent; $14,000. University Ave, 2,725, (12-3248); 2,725 University Ave, Inc, to Bowery Savings Bank, extends mtg to Aug. 12, 1942 at 4% per cent; $177,000. Washington Ave, 2,115, (11-3037); Pasem Realties, Inc, to N. Y. Life Insurance Co, 51 Madison Ave, installments, 4 to 5 per cent; $21,300.

It takes a stout heart, a strong stomach and a truly inordinate love of fishing to lure a man out on the open sea in a small boat these days. A few die-hards tried it Sunday morning from various seaboard ports, but most of them scurried back to shelter around noon.

Helen Wills Moody, tennis star and artist, received a divorcee this afternoon from Frederick S. Moody Jr., San Francisco broker. The decree was granted behind closed doors by Judge Clark J. Guild of Ormsby County Court.
The Bacardi Corporation of America won the right today to ship Puerto Rican-made rum to the United States under Bacardi trade-marks or in bulk.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull, in a new declaration of policy, tonight called upon China and Japan to "refrain from resort to war." Mr. Hull made the appeal "without attempting to pass judgment regarding the merits of the controversy."

Miss Dorothy Clark Bellah, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robbe married Sept. 13 to Henry Orlando Marcy 3d, son of Mrs. Henry Orlando Marcy Jr. and the late Dr. Marcy of Newton, Mass., in St. James's Episcopal Church here.

The longest sit-down strike on record continued at the plant of H. Anton Bock Co., Inc., 1,228 Second Avenue, yesterday when Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in Yorkville Court refused to interfere. Yesterday was the one-hundredand-thirty-fourth day of the strike.
Police engaged in a widening search tonight for a 3-month-old girl who disappeared from her carriage outside a North Side grocery store late this afternoon.

Captain Harold E. Gray of the Pan American Airways clipper now en route from New York to Southampton, England, via Bermuda, the Azores, Lisbon and Marseilles, announced tonight that he would avoid flying over war-torn Spain.

The amount of fat that should be placed in hamburger meat is scheduled to be determined Wednesday by the members of the Newark City Commission, it was learned here today when Joseph Brody, attorney for the New Jersey Retail Butchers Associations, announced his clients would protest the enactment of a proposed ordinance regulating the ingredients of hamburger, frankfurters and. sausages.

William Fayal Clarke of Scarsdale, N. Y., former editor in chief of St. Nicholas Magazine, died at his Summer home here yesterday of heart disease. His age was 83. Mr. Clarke joined the editorial staff of the St. Nicholas in 1873. He became associate editor of the magazine in 1893, and in 1905 was made its editor in chief.
Mrs. James Roosevelt, the President's mother, will have an authentic fish story to tell her fisherman son when she returns to the United States from her European trip.

Testimony that he was paid by the Weirton Steel Company to join a labor union so that he might spy on its activities, and that he was also paid by the company to take mill workers to the polls with orders to vote for Hoover against Roosevelt, was offered by a witness at the National Labor Relations Board hearing here today.

A new highway patrol of 500 Sheriffs' deputies was urged by Carroll T. Mealey, Deputy State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, in an address before the New York State Sheriffs Association today at the start of its two-day convention.

The Police Department sent out a hurry call today for an animal trainer to deal with its traffic problems. The trouble all started yesterday afternoon when a live monkey leaped from an automobile and bit Anna May Wilson, 11, on the knee.

Sally Eilers, screen actress, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary from a tour through Europe with her husband, Harry Joe Brown, director. Miss Eilers said she was going to Hollywood to begin work on her next picture, "The Perfect Stenographer."

Three thousand union men rallied around an anti-C. I. O. banner tonight and marched by torchlight in the first parade ever staged at a State Federation of Labor conven tion. The 700 delegates, bulwarked by members of more than thirty local unions and paced by a half dozen bands and drum corps, paraded twenty blocks through downtown streets.

The following Ordnance Department Reserve Officers, recently released for assignment to Third Military Area, are assigned to units therein as indicated: TO 9TH ORDNANCE CO. (HM) RAI(Newark District)--Capt. George W. Bingham, 90 Floyd St., Belleville, N. J.: 1st Lt. Ernest H. Behrens, 278 Park St., Mentclair, N. T.; 1st Lt. Starling Winters, 182 Main St., East Orange, N. J.,
Alexandre Israel, French Senator who, as President Herriot's general secretary, played an important role in the Herriot Cabinets of 1924 and 1926, died in his Paris home today. His age was 68.

The telegraph office here was kept busy today as Matthew J. Doyle, 65-yearold retired city official of Holyoke, Mass., joyfully dispatched messages to the scattered members of the Doyle clan, summoning them to a family reunion early next week at the home of his son Herbert, at 17 Fourth Avenue, Nyack.
Father Charles E. Coughlin began a vacation today, necessitated, an assistant said, by nervous indigestion which forced him to curtail a sermon before 4,000 persons yesterday.

A natural amphitheatre, rising from the harbor in front of the Longshore Country Club here, will provide the setting for the audience for a production of Gilbert and Sullivan's "Pinafore" to be held here the evening of Sept. 3.

A special session of Congress this Fall for enactment of "temporarily shelved" Administration measures Was forecast today by Speaker Bankhead. En route to his Jasper, Ala., home with his brother, Senator John Bankhead, he said:

Another airplane rained death and destruction yesterday upon one of Shanghai's busiest traffic intersections, with a toll, counted up to last midnight, of 195 dead and 475 wounded. [An Associated Press dispatch put the casualties at 400 dead and 1,000 wounded.]
Dr. and Mrs. Beeckman J. Delatour, who have been visiting Miss Edith Grinnell Bowdoin in Bar Harbor, will return on Thursday to Pawling, N. Y., where they have been passing part of the Summer.

Three jockeys were injured slightly and a horse was killed in a spill on a turn during the running of the fifth race at the Thistledown track today. Taxpayer, a 4-year-old gelding, was killed instantly when his neck was broken in a fall.

Now that the real estate market is on the upgrade, realty interests more than ever are anxious to guard against any possible setbacks, and have recently been watching with interest the plans advanced for disposal of properties under the control of Government agencies.
Raging, destructive fire became an offensive weapon today against the Japanese Army, reinforced by fresh troops who had landed yesterday under a hail of gunfire.

The jubilee encampment marking the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Girl Scout movement in the United States broke up early this morning, when the Girl Scouts from all sections of the United States and twenty-six foreign countries left Camp Andree here for Massachusetts.

Following his victory over William Woodward's Perifox at Hurst Park Saturday, Prince Aly Khan's colt Sultan Mahommed tonight was made second favorite for the St. Leger, last of the season's classics at Doncaster, Sept. 8.

Homer M. Choate, Civil War veteran, died today a few hours after receiving congratulations at his ninety-fourth birthday celebration. Mr. Choate was at one time cashier of the First National Bank at Oil City and had served as paying teller at the Seaboard National Bank of New York.

The resignation of General Wilhelm Faupel'as Reich Ambassador to the Franco Government in Spain was officially announced today. Health considerations were given as the reason for retirement, which it was stated at the Foreign Office has neither'political nor other significance.
Chicago at New York-Lee vs. Hubbell. St. Louis at Brooklyn (2)Warneke and Ryba vs. Cantwell and Mungo. Cincinnati at Philadelphia-Derringer vs. LaMaster. Pittsburgh at Boston-Blanton vs. Turner.

More than 1,000 Rockaway-bound passengers were delayed about twenty minutes late yesterday. af'ternoon when the front truck of the first car of a Rockaway Park train of the Long Island Railroad was derailed at Beach 114th Street, Rockaway Park, two blocks from the Rockaway Park Terminal.
WINFIELD SCOTT: THE SOLDIER AND THE MAN, by Charles Winslow Elliott. (Macmillan, $5.) A scholarly biography. No ROYAL ROAD, by Edgar A. Custer. (Kinsey, $3.50.) The autobiography of an industrialist.
The story of the rescue of five men trapped at the bottom of a 300-foot pit as it filled with rain water during the storm Saturday night, was learned here today.
The program of the American Legion national convention, to be held in New York City Sept. 20 to 23, was announced last night at a dinner of committee chairmen and guests in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The new Palisades Interstate Park Commission, established when President Roosevelt signed a bill recently permitting a compact between New York and New Jersey, will hold its organizational meeting at noon on Sept. 3 in the State Office Building, 80 Center Street, it was announced yesterday.

In a judgment handed down today, Justice E. R. E. Chevrier dismissed suits brought by Lorrin A. Herkins, New York, against the Porcupine Lake Gold Mining Company, Ltd.; H. H. Sutherland, Toronto, its vice president, and Ewart L. Petley, New York.
The budget request made yesterday by Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx before Kenneth Dayton, assistant director of the budget, was $481,859 less than the sum received last year.

Benjamin N. Freeman, 80 years old, a Denver banker who for many years was head of the bond department of the Cities Service Company in New' York, was killed yesterday in an automobile accident near Blythe, Calif., while returning from a fishing trip in Colorado.

A dispute between the Central Railroad of New Jersey and the Pennsylvania Railroad over the right to place spurs in certain areas of the industrial section of Linden reached the Federal Court here today.

Clashes between striking peasants and police occurred again today in various parts of Poland. At four different places in the Cracow and Lwow districts, peasants barred roads leading to the towns and refused passage for any farm produce.

Miss Elizabeth Taylor Sullivan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Phillips Sullivan of Windhurst, Elkins Park, has completed plans for her marriage on Oct. 1 to Newlin Fell Davis Jr. of Mount Airy. The wedding will take place in the Abington Friends Meeting at Jenkintown.
Colonel Horatio B. Hackett, assistant PWA administrator, announced today that he had resigned his post, effective Sept. 1, in order to return to private business.

The United States Treasury borrowed a little more from the banks yesterday, and the consequence is that for the first time in this country's history the national debt has crossed the thirty-seven-billion-dollar mark.

Whether a parking space for automobiles should take precedence over a- tree-planted oasis and a tribute to the discoverer of America is the question that has been referred back to the merchants of Orchard Street here by the village Board of Trustees.

Though "Brother Rat" had firmly expected to close here Sept. 4 and open two days later in Providence, it has decided not to. Or, as a fellow in the George Abbott office puts it, it "definitely continues indefinitely."
The international stock market indices for Aug. 21 with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 192-7:

Movements of livestock . on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 11,000, including 3,500 directs. Market 15c to 25c lower than Friday's average; closed mostly 25c lower. Top, $12.65; bulk good and choice 180-230 pounds, $12.50$12.60; 240-300 pounds, $11.85-$12.40; most good packing sows, $10.35-$11; shippers 1,500; estimated holdover, $2,000.
Following is the text of a statement issued tonight by Secretary Hull concerning the policies of the United States Government in the Far East:

Tommy Farr had a rest today, thanks to a steady downpour that made it impossible for him to work. The Welsh heavyweight, who will attempt to lift the world's heavyweight championship from Joe Louis at the Yankee Stadium on Thursday night, had planned to do a little sparring and light exercising, but canceled this program early this morning when it was apparent that the rain would not let zip.
The Negroes on the levee were singing "Looking for the Bully of the Town," ragtime's rhythmic ancestor, when young William C. Handy, Negro who later composed the famous "St. Louis Blues,"

Mrs. Opal Hill of Kansas City made the youngsters sit up and take notice today when she blasted a 75 for a new women's competitive course record at the Town and Country Club to win medal honors in the thirty-seventh annual women's Western golf tournament.

The new account on the stock market began inauspiciously today if viewed in the light of activity, for the volume of business was unusually small. The general dullness was reflected in all sections, although a firm undertone was readily discernible.

Coward Shoes, Inc., will hold a fashion show and cocktail party at 4 P. M. today at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria. Sam Klempner has been appointed manager of the candy department of E. W. J. Hearty, Inc., 99 Hudson Street, food importers.

J. Rosser Venablie, recently an aspirant to the Senate seat of the late Joe T. Robinson, said today that he planned to take the Arkansas Democratic party squabble over the Senate vacancy -into the courts.
Joseph J. Bruno, fugitive from three life sentences for murder, who was recaptured in New York yesterday, was locked up in Eastern State penitentiary here at 3:22 o'clock this afternoon.

When Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, Foreign Sedretary Anthony Eden and discount Halifax, Lord President of ;he Council, get together in London Wednesday for a mid-holiday, offthe-record talk on the international situation,
Weary men were near victory tonight in their struggle to extinguish the forest fire which burned to death fourteen of their fellow fire fighters and injured more than forty others.

" A million marks will be rolling into Hungary from Germany in the next few weeks," Count George Szechenyi, a Deputy belonging to the Christian National party, said today during a political tour of Western Hungary.

Announcing an increase in stake and overnight purse distribution to $425,000, President Joseph E. Widener of the Miami Jockey Club today made known his plans for the forty-six-day Winter meeting at Hialeah Park, Fla. The sum is approximately $25,000 more than last season.

There was a surprise in today's Syracuse Handicap when the Western 3-year-old Woodberry, running in the colors of L. B. Combs, accounted for the main event in a head finish at 8 to 1. Genie Palatine was the 11-to-10 favorite in the six-furlong dash, but could do no better than third.
The Chilean Government will at a cost of 8,000,000 pesos purchase three American amphibian multi-motored planes to resume the Puerto MonttMagallanes passenger, mail and cargo service.

While some workers in the silk and rayon industry returned to work yesterday, most of those covered by the agreement signed last Friday in Harrisburg, Pa., are expected to return today, it was disclosed here yesterday by Sidney Hillman, chairman of the Textile Workers Organizing Committee of the C. I. O.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that savings invested in Maine's six Federal savings and loan associations increased from $38,432 to $116,591 in the year ended on Aug. 1. Assets of the six associations, the board said,
Work will be begun soon on a general program of expansion by the Chrysler Corporation, it will be announced today. The cost will run to several million dollars.

Our first flight in search of Sigismund Levanevsky, the Soviet flier, and his five companions was foiled by weather and trouble with our engine and instruments after we had gone 750 miles, 300 miles of the distance above the clouds.

Stephen Ruf, 41 years old, a truck driver for the Department of Sanitation, was killed by an automobile last night as he stepped out of his car on Sunrise Highway at Hawpree Creek Road, Ozone Park, Queens.
The Federal Reserve Board approved tonight a reduction from 2 to 1% per cent in the discount rate of the Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank.

Talk of a special session of Congress in November, accepted as a foregone conclusion by some officials in the administrative branch, was stimulated today by statements from two White House visitors, Secretary Wallace and Representative Miller of Arkansas.
In a brief ceremony in the Hall of Mirrors in the Presidential Palace today Joshua Butler Wright, the new United States Ambassador, presented his credentials to President Federico Laredo Bru.

Samuel Untermyer, New York lawyer and a leader of the American Jews, said in a letter to the world conference of the Federation of Polish Jews here today, that Americans would refuse to aid Poland economically "so long as programs are tolerated by the Polish Government."

Community advertising campaigns to promote installment selling were advocated yesterday by H. Blumberg, director of the Bureau of Service of the Credit Retailers Association, at the opening session of that group's third annual convention at the Hotel New Yorker.

The greatest array of international tennis luminaries ever to gather here idled away indoors as rain held up the opening round of the national doubles championships at the Longwood Cricket Club today. The turf courts were barren of any activity, with a steady rain falling.

With the rush of American tourists to Canada -now at its height, D. Leo Dolan, director of the Canadian Travel Bureau, estimated today that August figures would be 1,000,000 automobiles carrying 3,500,000 passengers and predicted that the 1937 aggregate would be 20,000,000 visitors spending about $300,000,000.

Scribners has set Oct. 15 as the publication date for Ernest Hemingway's new novel, "To Have and Have Not," his first full-length novel in eight years. It is the story of a Key West boatman who goes outside the law to keep himself, his wife and children out of the abyss of the "have-nots." Philandering writers and idle yachtsmen appear through the story.
An Insurgent Black Arrow division, in an important operation westward from Somorrostro, today entered the port of Castro-Urdiales, about thirty miles east of Santander.

Members of the Maritime Commission, at their first meeting as a group with the seamen whose welfare they are supposed to promote, were told today that the sailors of the Pacific Coast do not want the Federal Government's aid.

The Public Utility Commission refused today to permit the Northern Pennsylvania Power Company to sell its properties to the Metropolitan Edison Company. The companies attempted the sale in 1936, but the old Public Service Commission denied the application on Sept. 21, 1936.

A modified form of nationalization of railroads will be the principal subject of a Cabinet council tomorrow. The matter in hand is chiefly to make the railroads pay. The label of private or State ownership is secondary.

Business failures in the United States numbered 159 for the week ended on Aug. 19, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The figure compared with 153 for the week previous and 135 for the corresponding week a year ago.

When the junior rifle corps matches open tomorrow there will be 166 boys and girls from all parts of the country entered for the matches which will continue until Saturday. These boys and girls, some of whom were here last year, are as anxious to get into action on the firing line as the old-time rifle and pistol shots.

The State of Mississippi will consider proposals on Sept. 10 for a new issue of $4,000,000 of highway bonds to be dated Oct. 1 and to mature on Oct. 1, 1938 to 1955. Bidders have been asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent.

Announcement yesterday by the A. S. Beck Shoe Corporation of a reduction in the retail price of women's shoes to $3.98 a pair from the $4.45 price which had been named last May threw confusion into chain retailing of women's shoes, and executives of other companies were at a loss to meet the new situation immediately.

Major Alford J. (Al) Williams, former crack stunt pilot of the United States Navy and pioneer in the study of inverted flight, who has defied death in the air for more than twenty years, crashed to the floor of a Pullman car last Saturday night and injured his left knee in the twenty-inch fall from his berth.

The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation, Bethpage, Long Island, N. Y., manufacturer of airplanes and parts, has filed a declaration in conformity with the Securities Act of 1933 covering 140,000 shares of $1-par common,

The Sperry Corporation reports in its semi-annual statement released for today a net profit from operations amounting to $1,186,672. Including profit of $183,794 on sales of securities, the net income for the six months to June 30 was $1,370,467.

More than $150,000,000 will be disbursed by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration throughout the Cotton Belt in price-adjustment payments under a decision today calling for cotton loans at the rate of 9 cents a pound with the additional adjustment payment equaling the difference between 12 cents a pound and the average prices in the ten spot markets on the day farmers dispose of their cotton.

Objections to the petitions designating Aldermanic President Wil- for liam F. Brunner for the Democratic nomination for Borough President of Queens were dismissed yesterday by the Board of Elections. The objections, filed by James A. Burke, Mr. Brunner's opponent, had not with been substantiated by the filing of specifications within six days, as required by the Election Law.
John W. Goodwin, former Democratic County Committeeman from this village and president of the J. W. Goodwin Motor Van and Livery Company, Inc., died on Saturday at the age of 84.

KINGS COLE, IDA I. (Dec. 7, 1936). Gross estate. $5,910; net, $5,151. To Edna B. Curry, Chief assets, real estate, $5,000; miscellaneous property, $910. Farmer Robert Dulin, 25 years old, was milking the last of six cows when the storm broke . A lightning bolt struck the barn, set it afire, killed the cow he was milking and left Dulin pinned beneath the animal's dead weight.

Some time between 3 and 7 o'clock Sunday morning-a time when policemen and detectives of the West Forty-seventh Street Station pass back and forth on the block-burglars entered the Ethel Barrymore Theatre,

Northeast Harbor held its annual costume ball tonight. Aviation was the theme of the affair for which the Summer colony from all over the island turned out. Prizes were presented by Dr. James B. Murphy of New York. Mrs. Henry Rawle Geyelin and Mrs. W. Rodman Fay of New York were judges of the costumes.

A program for rejuvenation of the Republican party will be discussed here tomorrow by Republican State chairmen of some fifteen States, who will meet with John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the party's national committee. This is one of a series of conferences with various groups of leaders which Mr. Hamilton will hold here and in other parts of the country.

The Athletics clowned their way to a 10-to-7 exhibition victory over the Centre County All-Stars tonight before 2,000 fans. Almon Williams blanked the All-Stars with two hits in six innings. Bob Johnson, outfielder; Chubby Dean,
After ten years in the United States Marine Corps-three of which were spent in the Far EastAnthony Billingham entered newspaper work because his love of adventure was not yet satisfied.

Excepting a few miscellaneous cuts which were active, trading opened slow. Salesmen predicted a more active trade later this week, however, if the cooler weather which arrived yesterday continues. Steer beef opened strong to higher; cow, bull and fresh pork steady to lower; other classes unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated lamb to be higher; beef and veal steady to strong, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The Westinghouse Electric Manufacturing Company transferred to the Westinghouse Electric Elevator Company of 150 Broadway, New York, the plant of the A. B. See Elevator Company, a one and two story brick manufacturing building and a two-story brick office building on a tract 1,060 by 460 feet at 100-176 Pacific Avenue, opposite the foot of Forrest Street, Jersey City.

The Hayden Planetarium announces that it will show the awful end of the world. And the particular scenario that will be dramatized is to be found in the mathematical work of the late Sir George Darwin, amplified by the late Henri Poincare.

A decrease of 23 per cent in the number of deaths from auto accidents in the- five boroughs during the week ended Sunday as compared to the -similar period last August was recorded by the Safety Bureau of the Police Department in statistics issued yesterday.

Tonight's event, the opening of Samuel Goldwyn's "Dead End," will take place at the Rivoli at 8 o'clock or thereafter. The film was adapted from the Sidney Kingsley drama by Lillian Hellman and was directed by William Wyler.

Louis Wagner Sr., president of the New York State Association of Retail Meat Dealers, died yesterday morning at the Midtown Hospital. He was 64 years old and had been in the meat business since he was a boy.

Many prominent old time and modern sportsmen as well as representatives of the sporting goods industry attended funeral services here today for George Wright, captain of Boston's first National League baseball team and pioneer golfer, at the Church of the Immaculate Conception.

Burton Tucker, 30, went back to clam digging tonight, freed of his 60-year-old wife's charge that he failed to support their three children, but informed that the obligation to support the children rested on him.

The Wages and Hours Bill, an issue that has rivalled the court reorganization measure-as a divider of the Democratic party, will be discussed in a radio speech by Senator Guffey of Pennsylvania tomorrow.

Greenwich St, 761, 21x70.9; Frank B. Scofield to Edw. Swann, 132 W. 23d St. ($3.50). 97th St, 329 E, 25x100.11; Esther Isaac to Metropolitan Savings Bank; mtg, $13,375, held by grantee ($14). 118th St, 448 E, 17x75.7; Murray L. Watt, referee, to Giuseppe Di Mella, 220 B. 115th St: foreclosure ($1).

The Texas Pacific Railroad has ordered 500 box cars and has obtained an option on 500 more from the Pullman-Standard Car Manufacturing Company. The railway ordered also one hundred hopper cars from the Bethlehem Steel Company.

Following the attempted dynamiting of the railway near Tongshan, the tracks between Lofa and Langfang were torn up this morning at 4 o'clock, disrupting traffic which already was badly disorganized along the Peiping-Tientsin line.
Miss Nora Elizabeth Ryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Ryan of this place, was married to George B. Grant, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Grant of Oswego this morning in St. Joseph's Church.

The marriage of Miss Casse Lehmann, daughter of Mrs. Casse Affeld Lehmann of this city and of Otto William Lehmann of Chicago, to Henry Wilkins Rustin, son of Mrs. William G. Doane of Berkeley, Calif., took place yesterday afternoon at the Ambassador. The Rev. Frank Murtfeldt performed the ceremony.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Rogers Lhowe of 1,185 Park Avenue and Purdys, N. Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Lhowe's daughter, Miss Rosalind Mendelson, to Leonard Zalkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Zalkin of Woodmere, L. I.
It will be virtually now or never at the Polo Grounds today and tomorrow when the Giants meet the league-leading Cubs in single encounters which may go a long way toward deciding the pennant race.

A sit-down strike of sixty seamen on the Red D liner Caracas which was called Sunday night on the arrival of the ship from La Guayra, Venezuela, was settled last night a conference kt the office of Herman Goldman, 120 Broadway. The tha line agreed to retain the crew, it was announced.

Tomorrow is the final day in which Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company 31/2 per cent debentures due 1951 may be converted into sixteen shares of common stock- of the company, since the small remaining amount of the bonds outstanding have been called for redemption as of Aug. 25.

Pensioned ON THEIR OWN APPLICATIONS PATROLMEN-Christian R. Wackerly, 61st Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Feb. 27, 1912. Edgar D. Crouse, 52d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 30, 1902. Transfers and Assignments Third Grade Detective Charles J. Schlegel, from 18th Division, 16th Detective District to 23d Precinct, designation as third grade detective revoked.

Miss Dorothy Wood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Wood of this place, will be wed to Malvern Jewett Mather, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Mather of West Hartford, Sept. 11 in the Talcottville Congregational Church.

Pedro Montanez, Puerto Rican lightweight, continued his lengthy winning streak tonight by stopping Lew Massey, Philadelphia, in 1 minute 50 seconds of tire third round of their ten-round bout. Montanez weighed 139 and Massey 137 1/2.
Strife between Alaskan and Japanese fishermen "is graver than you suspect," Mrs. Helen Troy, wife of Governor John Troy of Alaska, said today.
A rough-legged hawk which had lived for more than twenty years with a bell fastened to his neck, and had ranged widely over the continent, was found dead recently at Strongfield, Sask.

Bus service over the former trolley route between Flushing and College Point, Queens, was opened yesterday in the presence of about 500 persons by Edward A. Roberts, president of the Queens and Nassau Transit Lines, assisted by Borough President George U. Harvey

The $44, 234,000 issue of $100-par value cumulative preferred stock which will be offered by the Pure Oil Company to common stockholders of record of Sept. 3 will bear a 5 per cent dividend rate and an initial conversion price of $22.22 2-9, Henry H. Dawes, president, today informed the stockholders. formed the stockholders.

The Public Service Commission has extended to Oct. 1 the period within which the Consolidated Edison Company may issue its preferred stock in exchange for New York Steam Corporation preferred stock, it was announced yesterday.

Morris Littman, 45 years old, of 313 East Fourteenth Street, Brooklyn, indicted for grand larceny, was permitted yesterday by Kings County Judge George W. Martin to plead guilty of petit larceny and was remanded for sentence.

William Norwine of 2 Garth Road, Eastchester, was under a physician's care at his home tonight after having been dragged for 200 feet this morning by a New York Central Railroad train when he attempted to board it as it was pulling out of the Scarsdale station. He was suffering from severe shock and bruises.
James Levy, who until recently was James Murphy, was married here tonight to Miss Eleanor Meyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Meyer of 68 Bayswater Boulevard, at the bride's home.

In honor of the Right Rev. John Thompson Dallas, Bishop of New Hampshire and of the Right Rev. Benjamin M. Washburn, Bishop of the Newark, N. J., Diocese, Colonel and Mrs. William Andros Barron entertained at dinner last evening at the Crawford House, Crawford Notch.

Miss Katherine Moir Thomas, daughter of Mrs. George Lloyd Thomas of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Edmond L. Prince of New York, formerly of Baltimore, son of Mrs. Horace C. Prince of Wilmington, N. C., and the late Mr. Prince.

Dr. George Draper, associate professor of clinical medicine of the College of Physicians and Surgeons and associate attending physician at the Presbyterian Hospital, New York, has purchased a site on the Yale Farms property, Greenwich, and is erecting a country home from plans drawn by Holland White.
Swift homing pigeons sped from various points in Steuben County today, bearing news of outlying communities for publication in The Hornell Evening Tribune.

Richard O'Connor, whose address was given as 60 East Ninety-sixth Street, New York City, leaped into Block Island. Sound tonight from the steamer Pemaquid on the trip between Block Island and New London.

Kansas City Power and Light Company-Year ended June 30: Net income $4,648,035, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $8.40 a share on 525,000 common shares, compared with revised net income of $4,182,423,

Submarine pirates and airplane pirates, flying no flag, international as Captain Kidd, wage a new sort of undeclared war in the Mediterranean. The British and French Governments have at last been goaded to order their ships to fire at the anonymous marauders.

Pouncing on Leo Mangum, relief pitcher, for three hits in the ninth inning, the Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Jersey City Giants, 5-4, tonight. Jimmy Walsh's single scored Frank Madura with the winning run after two were out.

A storm out of the northeast prevented the opening of the 1937 Sears Bowl regatta for the junior championship of this port today. The crews waited all day for the wind and seas to moderate so that the Pleon Yacht Club,

Yesterday's report of space leased for business purposes included two units in Rockefeller Center which were taken for New York offices by firms which heretofore have had no metropolitan headquarters.
