Charged with kidnapping and illegally transporting their employer, Samuel Griss, out of the Province, seven employes or former employes of Bruck Silk Mills were brought back from the United States border tonight and locked in jail for court arraignment.

Senator Winant Van Winkle, Ber- A gen Republican, asked Governor advised. Harold G. Hoffman tonight to call that to the Legislature into special session support "at once" to consider changes in instructed Court of Pardons procedure.

The dispute between the American Federation of Teachers and the Committee for Industrial Organization came to the front today at the opening of the convention of the federation here, with 400 delegates present.
Movements of vessels follow (all dates are Aug. 22, unless specified): At San Diego, Aug. 21. Antares, Brant, Elliot.
His face and body swollen beyond recognition from the stings of thousands of angry honey bees, 6-year-old Clifford Fabricius died today.

The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Aug. 20: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Cook, S., the Tuscaloosa; to First Naval District, Boston, Mass. Brady, E. J. (M.C.), orders of Aug. 11 revoked; detached from Naval Hospital, San Diego, Calif.; to Fleet Marine Force, San Diego, Calif.

Techwood Homes, the only low-cost housing project which has been in operation for a full year, reported rentals totaling $159,161 and arrears of only $244 on Aug. 15, its first anniversary, the Public Works Administration announced today.
A movement toward the old floater type ball for championships has been launched by Max Behr of California, a nationally known authority on golf and runner-up to Jerry Travers at Garden City in 1908.

Frederick H. Prince, financier, and Mrs. Prince; Rene Tanquerey, French Consul in New York, and Mrs. Tanquerey; Judge Frank T. Meaney, George T. Cameron, publisher of The San Francisco Chronicle, and Mrs. Cameron, are among the passengers due to arrive today from Europe on the French liner Ile de France.

Baby Yack of Toronto, Canadian bantamweight champion, won a tenround decision from Henry Hook of Indianapolis tonight. The decision was unpopular with 5,000 fans, who apparently thought Hook's harder punching had earned him the victory.

Reports that Russian-made military airplanes have been delivered, by way of Mongolia, to the Chinese Central Government in the last week have served to confirm the Japanese public's worst fears. Serious as is the conflict between Japan and China, the real shadow looming over Japan and darkening hearts and thoughts is that of Russia-Japan's potential enemy for a century and her active one during various periods.

The jewelry trade is expected to show gross retail sales of $350,000,000 to $375,000,000 this year, according to William D. McNeil, president of the American National Retail Jewelers Association, which opened its thirty-second annual convention yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

A sharp increase in actual orders coming into manufacturers and predictions of an excellent Fall and holiday volume at retail were linked yesterday at trade shows of gifts and luggage, held simultaneously at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Rebel, slender, gray six-meter yacht sailed by Cornelius Shields and owned by his brother, Paul, was named today to meet the Royal Norwegian Yacht Club's Burl in the international match for the Seawanhaka Challenge Cup, which will be held off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club on Sept. 7.

The revival of "Nina Rosa," which was scheduled to begin at Jones Beach last night, will start tonight. The postponement was necessitated by rain. "Anything Goes" will begin a week's run at Randalls Island Stadium tonight. The production,

Coincident with a slump in the sale of tickets for the world heavyweight title bout between Joe Louis, the champion, and Tommy Farr, British Empire titleholder, which is to be held Thursday night in the Yankee Stadium, Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century
Miss Ida Ikelheimer, a retired public school principal, died yesterday in her seventy-third year at her home, 1,295 Madison Avenue. She had been ill for three years and had been retired since 1923.
Child refugees screamed today as welcoming airplanes swooped low-over the liner President Hoover, bearing 871 persons fleeing from the Shanghai war zone.

Police accompanied Randolph Golden to a twenty-five-cent-a-night room in a Montgomery Street hotel today, saw that he got his .traveling bag and escorted him to a ferry which he boarded and left for New York.

The Essex County Democratic Committee endorsed tonight unanimously the slate for the primary and November election presented to it by Felix Forlenza, chairman of the county executive committee, at. a meeting in the Central High School.
Phil Bieber's Dunade and W. Elliott's Careful Miss won the two allowance races for $1,200 purses which featured today's Narragansett Park card.

On the thirty-second anniversary of the marriage of the bridegroom's parents, Miss Audrey Lucille Thomas of Providence, R. I., last night was married to William Lea Taylor, son of R. L. Taylor and the late Mrs. Taylor.

Inspectors for the Transit Commission reported yesterday that the Hudson. Tube crash in which thirty persons were injured near the Cortlandt Street station early yesterday morning was caused by the excessive speed with which the train was driven over the switches at the track approach to the station.
A House-Senate committee started today a nation-wide survey of the judicial system, with particular reference to congestion in the courts and the need for new judges.
The famous exploit of Blondin in walking over Niagara Falls on a tight-rope with a man on his back took place seventy - eight years ago this month.

Italian civil and military authorities carried out a carefully guarded investigation tonight of a head-on train collision that killed ten sailors of the second naval squadron. A trainman also was killed and numerous sailors hurt.

Rev. Dr. Clifton H. Mix, retired pastor, who served in Pilgrim Congregational Church, in Lincoln Square Baptist Church and in Pleasant Street Baptist Church in this city, died today in his home here. His age was 71.

Admiral Harry E. Yarnell, Commander of the Asiatic Fleet, reported to the Navy Department today that a special board of investigation had not been able to determine the origin of the shell that had fallen on the flagship Augusta near Shanghai last week.
The Japanese Government today made public plans to tighten its control over the private wealth of the empire to further its program for placing Japan under a wartime economic regime.

Discussion in Wall Street over the New York Stock Exchange's move for higher commissions reveals a considerable body of opinion against it, with some prophets freely predicting its defeat. The Exchange's committee on the constitution is to report to the governing committee Wednesday, when a decision is expected.

An old-timer and a flock of up-andcoming youngsters plowed their way around the rain-drenched Alderwood Country Club course today, setting the pace in the first 18-hole qualifying round of the forty-first annual national amateur golf championship, held in the Northwest for the first time in history.

Two Philadelphia men, trailed over two States for questioning in the slaying of Private John Broski of the Pennsylvania motor police, were arrested today and Captain William A. Clark said "they made statements admitting their guilt."
Mrs. Eliot Betts Hoadley gave a dinner and bridge tonight at the Mallows for Mrs. Henry White of Elm Court, Lenox, Mass., who is passing the late season at the Meadow Club.

With the opening of Puerto Rico's public schools today, Governor Blanton Winship, just back from Washington, made known that plans worked out for Federal aid to the schools, calling for the expenditure of $36,000,000 in six years largely for construction had been submitted to President Roosevelt.
Word has been received here of the arrival today at Valencia of James Maxton, member of the House of Commons and chairman of the Independent Labor party, accompanied by a number of French delegates.
Thirteen persons drowned in the Alexandria Harbor early this morning when two sailboats carrying about forty excursionists were rammed by a steamer while entering the harbor.

Governor Lehman was shaken and his car was badly damaged early last night when it and another automobile collided at Sedgwick Avenue north of West Tremont Avenue, the Bronx. The Governor was on his way from Purchase, N. Y., to his home at 820 Park Avenue.
ASSOCIATE BACTERIOLOGIST, $3,200 year; Assistant Bacteriologist, $2,600. Optional branches: brucellosis, anaerobes, physiology of bacteria, viruses. U. S. Public Health Service, Treasury Department.
Many society people here for the races entertained at the annual dinner dance tonight at Piping Rock, Saratoga Lake, for the benefit of the Saratoga Golf Club.

Three thugs, one of whom held a revolver, yesterday morning entered an A. P. store at 979 East 233d Street, the Bronx, robbed the manager, Thomas Canning, of $360, forced him to remove his trousers and enter a rear room, where they had already locked two women customers. The robbers left Canning's trousers in the street and escaped in an automobile.

Leon Barzin, a musical director, filed suit for divorce here today against Mrs. Marie Vandeputte Barzin, charging cruelty. She is expected to file a cross-complaint and take a decree. They were married in New York City on Dec. 15, 1926.

William B. Paul, counsel for the Follansbee Brothers Company, announced in Pittsburgh yesterday that no appeals had been filed within the statutory thirty-day period allowed for appeal from the Federal court order confirming the plan of reorganization.
A dozen miners dug frantically tonight in an attempt to reach Allenti Warholick of Exchange, buried as a section of ground fell into a mine. They had little hope of finding him alive.
The leasing of a six-story building in the heart of the Fifth Avenue shopping district to provide room for-expansion by an old established art firm was disclosed yesterday.

Chicago's highest ranking law enforcement officials agreed with State's Attorney Thomas J. Courtney today upon a four-point practical campaign to be started at once to halt the series of brutal attacks upon women by perverts.

About 2,700 Americans are now fighting with the Spanish Loyalist Army and they were "a major factor" in the success of the recent Government offensive on the Madrid front, Phil Bard, former commander of the Abraham Lincoln

With the drought in Oklahoma broken by three consecutive days of rain from half an inch to more than four inches at twenty-nine stations in Texas, the general relief in the dry areas brought another decline in cotton prices here, yesterday.

Representatives of the governments of Cuba and Nicaragua have been in Washington studying various aspects of the United States banking and credit system, Wayne C. Taylor, Acting Secretary of the Treasury, said today.
Many members of the Summer colony were present this afternoon at Chateau Sur Mer, the home of the Misses Wetmore, for the annual piano recital by Miska Merson, Hungarian pianist.

Manhattan Alterations Waverly Pl, 144, to 4-story tenement; Andrew Sharboro, 14 Franklin St, owner; M. Bernstein, architect; cost, $5,000. Broadway, 1,641-9; to 6-story offices, stores and theatre; Mordedall Realty Corp, 1,540 Broadway, owner; Otto H. Spin, architect; cost, $3,000.

SILVESTRO DI NICOLA, salesman, 780 Morris Park Av.-Liabilities, $21,839; no assets except insurance. NATALIE FREEMAN, unemployed, 865 E. 167th St.-Liabilities, $1,388. She formerly conducted business under the style of N. F. Lutz Co. MAYER MARSHALL, painter, 31 West Mosholu Parkway-Liabilities, $684; no assets.

The Government has a real financial stake in agricultural prosperity, according to figures made' public here. About $3,000,000,000 of mortgage money and other loans have been advanced by Federal agencies Repayment depends upon profits in corn, cotton, wheat, hogs and other major farm products.

The Securities and Exchange Commission in an opinion handed down today permitted effectiveness of amendments made in July by the Equity Corporation to a registration statement filed in February, 1934, under the Securities Act of 1933 by that investment trust.

ARENS-Sylvia (nee Waldman), beloved wife of Harold, devoted mother of Margo, and darling daughter of Barnet and Rebecca Waldman; sister of Joe, Max, Herbert and Myron. Funeral services at Chapel, 187 South Oxford St., Brooklyn, on Wednesday, Aug. 25, at 11 A. M. Interment Acacia Cemetery.

I saw the busiest corner in China turned into a scene of carnage today when a heavy projectile plunged into the heart of Shanghai's Nanking Road shopping district. At least 400 persons were killed and probably 1,000 wounded. The toll easily may go higher than that.

With the catcher and first baseman accounting for all twenty-seven putouts, the Berwyn, Ill., junior American Legion baseball team routed South Bend, Ind., 17 to 3, today, and reached the final of the Northeastern regional championship.

The Census Bureau reported today that cotton of this year's growth ginned prior to Aug. 16 totaled 514,675 running bales, counting 5,094 round bales as half bales. Ginnings to Aug. 16 last year amounted to 208,509 running bales including 487 round bales.

Miss Helen Anderson of 229 East Seventy-ninth Street and W. Gordon Dean of Sanford, Fla., obtained a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building and said they would be married Thursday at Southampton, L. I.

Representative William I. Sirovich, champion of Federal subsidies for culture and art, returned on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary yesterday from a tour of the principal cities of Europe to study what they were doing for art.

Theft of jewels, valued at $10,000, from the Summer home of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Smith of Brookline, Mass., was reported to State Police today. State Patrolman Tristrum Eaton said the Smiths believed the jewels, consisting of rings, bracelets and pins, were taken early last night.

The Eastern College All-Stars of 1937 will begin preparations tomorrow for their game at the Polo Grounds the night of Sept. 8 against the New York Giants, standardbearers of professional football. Coach Andy Kerr of Colgate will have two practice sessions, the first at 10 A. M. and the second at 3 P. M.

Dr. James E. West, Chief Scout Executive of the Boy Scouts of America, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary from Holland, where he was camp chief of the 814 American boys at the fifth international jamboree.

J. D. Phillips, correspondent in Cuba for THE NEW YORK TIMES and dean of the American newspaper corps in Havana, was killed instantly this morning when his automobile and a heavy truck were in collision here. Mr. Phillips, his wife, daughter and sister-in-law were driving East after a vacation visit to his parents in Los Angeles.

A drizzling rain whipped in by a chilly northeast wind drove some 100 back-to-nature lovers attending the sixth- annual nudist convention back into their clothes today. But just to prove that they were not afraid of showing their naked bodies,

The State Labor Relations Board reserved decision yesterday on the application of the Hotel, Restaurant and Cafeteria Employes Association, representing eleven locals affiliated with the A. F. of L., for certification, as the collective bargaining agency for employes of the Childs restaurant chain.

Slight rallying tendencies were discerned in the bond market yesterday, but the volume, which fell to the smallest total since last Wednesday, was not sufficient to give a general uplift to prices. Closing quotations in issues traded on the New York Stock Exchange were firm and irregularly higher on the average.

Barnes Ave (17-5049), e s at w s of Boyd Ave, 113x145; Milton Hart to Sylvia A. Hart, 22 Watson Ave, Ossining, N. Y. Morgan Ave (16-4476), e s. 334 ft n of Mace Ave, 36x100; Brim Realty Corp to Charles M. Radice, 3,435 Olinville Ave; mtg S7,100.

Instead of by dignified official order, the New York Yacht Club cruise racing was broken up this morning out on the island of Martha's Vineyard by a northeast blow. With little sign of its abatement as the yachts lay in the harbor of Edgartown, rain washing their decks and overrunning their scuppers, the order was sent forth from Commodore W. A. W. Stewart's flagship, the schooner Queen Mab, to "proceed at will."

A larger decline than called for seasonally was registered in automobile production last week, and the adjusted index has dropped to 147.5 from 158.7. This compares with 130.8 for the week ended Aug. 22 last year.

An injunction restraining the Shuberts and the Select Theatres Corporation from interfering with the American production, of plays written by Luigi Pirandello, 1934 Nobel prize winner in literature, was granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer.

Hale C. Jones of Wood River, Ill., giving one of the greatest trapshooting exhibitions of his career, broke 325 targets without a miss from the 116-yard line as the thirty-eighth Grand American program opened today and retained his "championof-champions" title in a race with thirty-one other State titleholders.

The housing measure finally passed by Congress marks a historic step in providing for the ill-housed portion of our people, though the bill is far from an ideal one. It was saddled with some bad amendments both in the Senate and in the House, and in the compromise between the houses, it was not always the less objectionable amendment that was retained.

Member companies of the Dominion Mortgage and Investments Association, holding first-mortgage bonds of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, will support the bondholds' plan of reorganization of the Abitibi company, It was indicated by an announcement, following a meeting today by J. E. Fortin, secretary-treasurer of the association.

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 83.8 per cent of capacity, a gain of .6 point, or .7 per cent, from last week, when operations were scheduled at 83.2 per cent of capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute records. A month ago operations were 84.3 per cent of capacity.

Cliff Olson, 215, Minneapolis, pinned Bill Sledge, 218, Houston, Texas, after 30:06 of the feature finish wrestling match at the Hippodrome last night. A crowd of about 1,500 saw Olson triumph with a body hold.

Trade between the United States and the United Kingdom during the first half of the current year showed a marked increase, Alfred Nutting, American Consul General at London, has reported, the Department of Commerce announced today.

New low levels for the season were established today on all deliveries of wheat on the Board of Trade here and at Duluth and on the December and May futures at Kansas City as a result of selling induced by weakness in Liverpool, where the March contract dropped into new low ground for the fourth straight day.
The City Health Department reported today five new cases of infantile paralysis, a total of thirteen cases and two deaths since Aug. 14.

A rock-carrying throng muttering threats against police gathered early today around the main gate of the strike-closed Heppenstall Steel Company plant, scene of a riot in which thirteen men were injured yesterday.

France is on the verge of Communist-inspired revolution, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of Catholic University, Washington, D. C., declared here tonight in an address to some 300 persons at St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church.

The fundamental cause of all Sino-Japanese trouble is the antiJapanese policy pursued by the Kuomintang in China and the sentiments fostered by its agents among the Chinese people for unification of the country, Sadayoshi Hitotsumatsu,
The State LiquorAuthorityadopted a regulation yesterday limiting the period in which wholesalers may extend credit to those selling liquor at retail.

Tired of Congress and its delays and bickerings, Representative Samuel B. Pettengill of the Third Indiana Congressional District, a Democrat, announced today that he would not seek re-election. He will return to the practice of law.

WITH a drenching rain watering his rolling acres at Garrison, N. Y., Farmer Brown sat indoors and talked of the big fight coming up and other little matters. "That Farr, now," said Farmer Brown, who is also ex-Private Bill Brown of the New York State Athletic Commission along with his military confreres, Colonel D. Walker Wear and General John J. Phelan, "he's a pretty well set-up young feller."

Albert J. Steurer, who operated a travel and advertising agency at 592 Newark Avenue, died this morning in Fairmount Hospital following an operation for appendicitis. His age was 49. Mr. Steurer was born in Jersey City and was active for many years in fraternal and civic circles.

MANHATTAN Estate, more than $10,000. To Novitiate of St. Andrew-on-Hudson,. Poughkeepsie, N. Y., residue; Sisters of Charity of Mount St. Vincent-on-Hudson, clothing and personal effects. The Fulton Trust Co., 149 Broadway, executor.

Rain gave the New York Football Giants squad a short respite today in its preparations for the game with the Eastern College all-stars to be contested Sept. 8. Coach Steve Owen held the morning work indoors as a blackboard drill, but when the rain stopped at noon had the thirty players out for a two-hour work on the field.

More than 2,000 "job marchers" from twenty-five States, called to Washington by David Lasser, national president of the Workers Alliance of America, held a "protest" mass meeting here tonight, and will appeal to President Roosevelt tomorrow for continuance of WPA employment for all those unable to find other work and reinstatement of those already dismissed and now unemployed.

Alleging that Examiner R. W. Snow misrepresented the views of employes in his report to the Interstate Commerce Commission and that some of his descriptions of the work of truck and bus drivers constituted an "insult" to such drivers, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers of America today filed exceptions to the report.

Miss Grace A. Lounsbury has chosen Sept. 15 as the date for her marriage to Robert N. Ferry of West Hartford. The wedding will take place in the First Methodist Church here. A reception will follow at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Elmer H. Lounsbury of this city.

The Mandates Commission of the League of Nations in its report on Palestine approves in principle attempting to solve the problem by partition, but insists that the Jewish and Arab States should continue under mandate until ripe for statehood, according to the official summary of the report issued today.

The $4 condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 18: Increases of $32,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans and $22,000,000 in holdings of United States Government direct obligations;

The British Government is considering approaching the Mexican Government regarding the position of foreign oil companies in Mexico, although no decision has been reached on the form of the representations.

The season's first northeaster lashed the metropolitan area Sunday night and yesterday morning, whipping inland and ocean waters into foaming fury, making scores of small pleasure craft and one commercial boat helpless, forcing some to sea and disabling others.

Anthony James Billingham, 35-year-old American, a correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was one of the foreigners seriously injured when an airplane bomb hit Sincere's department store at about 1 P. M. today.
Brig. Gen. Frank Percy Crozier, brilliant war leader who turned pacifist and whose recently published "Men I Killed" caused more controversy than any book of this year, is gravely ill.

Police today attributed an attempt to bomb Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, Premier of Portugal, on July 4 to a Communist plot to overthrow the Government. Captain Lourenco, director of the State's Security Police, said that evidence of widespread subversive activities had been uncovered through the arrest of five men, all Portuguese, who were said to have confessed they had tried to kill the Premier.

Miss Dorothy Alyse Unger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Unger of New York and Woodmere, L. I., was married here at noon today in the Cadet Chapel to Lieutenant M. Arthur Preston, U. S. A., son of Mrs. James Preston of Tulare, Calif., and the late Mr. Preston. The ceremony was performed by the cadet chaplain, the Rev. H. Fairfield Butt 3d.
53d St, 209-215 E, 85x100.5; 209-11-15 East 53d St Corp (Murray Weinberg, president) to Murray Weinberg, 68-17 Groton St, Forest Hills, L I; due and interest as per bond, $33,000.

Fears that the Spanish Insurgents' success at Bilbao might endanger Britain's access to raw materials, especially for the steel industry, where a shortage is said to exist, have proved groundless -because imports from Bilbao are to be resumed immediately.
A five-day stoppage by 800 glove workers came to an end today with ratification of an agreement calling for graduated wage increases for the employes of the Crocetta Brothers plant. Carl Gerstl,
The American Gas Association has allocated approximately $458,000 for its 1937-38 advertising campaign, the second to be conducted by the group. Of this amount,

Police stationed outside the Mount Royal plant of the Dominion Textile -Company called firefighters today to fight a couple of swarms of bees dropped from speeding automobiles just before the mill's scheduled opening.
Beginning tomorrow, Pan American Airways will double the number of regular scheduled passenger flights between New York and Bermuda, according to officials of the company.

Frank Travers, retired building manager, died yesterday at the Deer Park Hospital in Port Jervis, N. Y. He was 81 years old. Until his retirement in 1929, Mr. Travers was in charge of The Apthorp, a Vincent Astor apartment at Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street.
John S. Newberry of Detroit, brother of former Senator Truman H. Newberry, died tonight at his Summer home, Ridge End. He had been ill for several days. His age was 71.

When Mr. and Mrs. John Elder, Presbyterian missionaries in Iran, and their six children, return tomorrow for Mr. Elder's sabbatical year in America, they will find a completely furnished and equipped home for them here, established cooperatively by the Women's Guild of the West Side Presbyterian Church.

In the old days it was not called a harmonica. It was called a mouthorgan. Every boy in town had one, sooner or later, and most of them imagined, as they sauntered along drawing it across their faces like an ear of hot buttered corn, that the effects they were getting out of it were admirable.

The New York Nursery and Child's Hospital, 161 West Sixtyfirst Street, receives a legacy of $30,000 in the will of Miss Emma Elizabeth Conner, which was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Her estate was valued at $69,000. Miss Conner,

The engagement of $8,508,000 gold abroad for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of this amount $5,390,000 was obtained in England, $490,000 yesterday and $4,900,000 at some previous date; $2,250,000 was taken in Belgium and $868,000 in India.

Miss Phyllis Ivins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Haddon Ivins of this place, will be married on Sept. 25 to Konrad W. Valentin, also of Englewood, son of Mrs. Wilhelm J. Valentin of Berlin-Dahlem, Germany, and the late Major Valentin. The ceremony will be performed in the First Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Carl H. Elmore.

Eighth annual convention, American Association of Water Well Drillers, Hotel Pennsylvania, 11 A. M. Continues Wednesday and Thursday. Luncheon, Lions Club, Hotel Astor, 12:30 P. M. Address by Irene Kuhn.

A resolution criticizing the Secretary of Labor, Frances Perkins, for her "failure to administer immigration laws" was among others considered today by the resolutions committee as Spanish American War veterans gathered

Moscow gave a boisterous reception to Mikhail Gromoff, Andres Yumasheff and Sergei Danilin, who arrived home today from their record-breaking flight to America across the North Pole. But close to the surface,

Cooler weather yesterday produced better activity at buying offices here, where mail and telegraph orders ran to good volume. Better priced merchandise continued to lead in the coat and suit market and popular-priced goods were selling in less than satisfactory levels.

Death Announced Retired Fireman Anthony Youngsworth, formerly a member of Eng. 2, residing at 421 W. 43d St., Manhattan, died Aug. 22. Funeral will take place from the above residence, at 9:30 A. M., Wednesday, Aug. 25; thence to Holy Cross Church 333 W. 42d St., Manhattan. Interment at St. John's Cemetery. The Deputy Chief of the 3d Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen, as funeral escort.

According to amendments made to the registration statements covering additional securities to be offered by the Rainier Pulp and Paper Company, Grays Harbor Pulp and Paper Company and Olympia Forest Products Company,

John Montague maintained his- role of the silent man today as he and three New York State police officers boarded a train after a stopover of several hours, to continue their trip from Hollywood to Elizabethtown, N. Y., where Montague will stand trial on a seven-year-old robbery charge.
Word was received here today of the death Sunday at Grand Isle, Vt., of James Monro Blain, superintendent of the Tuckahoe plant of Burroughs, Wellcome Co., manufacturing chemists. His age was 62.

Senator Royal S. Copeland, arriving here yesterday to direct, from now until primary day, his campaigns for both the Democratic and Republican nominations for Mayor, outlined yesterday in a press interview what he considers to be the chief issues of the campaign.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 21: Wainer, Col. M. R., Q. M. C., one month and 24 days' leave, Sept. 7. Middleton. Lt. Col. T. H. (Inf.), Inspector General's Department, to retirement upon own application. Duckworth, Major J. F., Moed. Corps, to retirement.

The Interstate Commerce Commission gave notice today to all common carriers by railroad and agencies interested in rail movements of refrigerated products of an investigation to be undertaken by the commission into the rates on perishable freight.

New York County headquarters for Mayor La Guardia and other candidates endorsed by the Republican county. organization were opened yesterday on the twelfth floor of 41 East Forty-second Street, with William M. Chadbourne,'treasurer of the county committee, and 1933 La Guardia campaign manager, in charge.

Miss Susan Tracy Rice, sister of Colonel William Gorham Aice of Albany, former president of the State Civil Service Commission, died late last night in the Albany Hospital. She was born in Albany, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Rice, and attended the Charlouis School.

Several leases of apartments in buildings in the West Eighties were included in the contracts for residential space reported by brokers yesterday. Among those taking space was Louise Nunberg, jewelry designer, who leased an apartment in the multi-family dwelling at 140 West Eighty-sixth Street through the Apartment Loeating Bureau. Details of other leases follow:

His body saturated with cleaning fluid from his own shop, with flames creeping up the wooden partition, Jacob Wender, 57 years old, was found murdered yesterday morning in the washroom of his dry-cleaning establishment at 1,064 Lexington Avenue, near Seventyfifth Street.

George H. Farley, postmaster of this village from 1923 to 1932, died early today at his home on Bayonne Avenue. He was 75 years old. Mr. Farley was born in Sag Harbor and at the age of 21 became associated with the Joseph Fahys watchmaking company.

On the day preceding the adjournment of Congress the General Court of New Hampshire, the largest of all American legislative bodies except Congress itself, was prorogued by the Governor after a session of record-breaking length-thirty-two weeks.

Mrs. Earl Potter of Brookville, L. I., caught a 757-pound tuna in Shelburne Harbor today, a world record tuna catch for women. Mrs. Potter, a guest with her husband aboard the yacht Pegasus, fought the fish for more than two hours before landing it.

Professor Hugh D. Reed, head of the Department of Zoology at Cornell, died early today at Memorial Hospital at the age of 62. He was born at Hartsdale, N. Y., March 4, 1875, the son of Charles Hart Reed and Sarah Acker Reed. He received his B. S. degree at Cornell in 1899 and his Ph. D. in 1903. During-1909-10 he studied in Frelburg, Germany.

Mrs. Wanda Kwasniewski, a pioneer worker among the Polish people of Milwaukee, active in the Catholic Church, the Polish National Alliance and Polish Women's Alliance, died today. She was 67 years old. She was born in Chicago, the daughter of Wladyslaw Byniewicz, publisher of The Gazeta Polska, the first Polish weekly published in America.

Daniel Demarest, believed to be the oldest Civil War veteran in New Jersey, died here today at the home of his son, Daniel Demarest Jr. He was 99 years old. Mr. Demarest was also the oldest living member of the New York Volunteer Fire Department.

Repeal of prohibition has so increased the duties of a dining car steward that he must now have the skill of a top-notch bartender in mixing cocktails and at the same time possess the qualities of an Old World diplomat in soothing

The Treasury announced today that it would restrict its Sept. 15 financing program to an offering of securities in exchange for $817,483,500 of 3 1/4 per cent Treasury notes which mature on that date.

Student duels, conforming to the National Socialist code of honor, which demands sword-point satisfaction for the slightest reflection on personal honor and extends the same right to the entire German population, was forbidden in a decree issued today.

Miss Edna Mae Johnson, daughter of the late Frank O. Johnson of East Northport, and Francis A. Jackson, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Jackson of Huntington, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's brother, Frank O. W. Johnson, by the Rev. Charles Frederick, pastor of St. Paul's Lutheran Church here.

Greve failed to get a hole-in-one when he played the 167-yard eleventh hole at the North Hills Club on his 167th round of golf, but here's what happened when he reached it yesterday on his 168th round:

With the the so-called "progressive" and "unity" factions claiming a majority of votes, the United Automobile Workers Union of America opened its annual convention here today with a message of greeting from President Roosevelt, who wrote to Homer Martin, presiden of the union:

The executive council of the American Federastion of Labor, in annual session at the Hotel Ambassador, voted today to investigate the status of Labor's Nonpartisan League, which supported President Roosevelt in the campaign of 1936, to determine if it has now become a C. I. O. unit.

The betrothal of 18-year-old King Farouk became known today, less than a month after his investiture as monarch. His fiancee is Miss Sasi Naz Zulficar, 16-year-old daughter of Youssef Bey Zulficar, judge of the Alexandria Mixed Court of Appeals, and Mme. Zeinab Zulficar, lady-inwaiting to the Queen Mother.

A peace conference of war veterans of all nations was proposed yesterday by the Veterans Division of the World's Fair in a request to President Roosevelt to call such a gathering in Washington "at the earliest practical date."

Members of the American track and field team invading Finland won every event they entered in a meet before 4,000 spectators at today. The outstanding- performances were by Cornelius Warmerdam, San Francisco pole vaulter, and Mel Walker, Negro high jumper from Ohio State University.

While pickets continued to demonstrate in front of the Hudson Terminal Buildings, 30 and 50 Church Street, and while the building management arranged for outside contractors to take care of elevator maintenance and clean the buildings, the strikers proposed to submit their grievances to the arbitration of the structures' tenants.
No scholar has been more painstaking in sifting evidence than Anthony Billingham, correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who was gravely wounded by a deadly aerial bomb in Shanghai yesterday.

An increase of one cent a quart in the price of milk and a rise of one cent a half pint for heavy cream, with other cream items "raised proportionally," effective tomorrow, were announced yesterday by the Sheffield Farms Company.

Baron Gottfried von Cramm, one of the world's ranking tennis players, arrived in New York on the Cunard-White Star liner Queen Mary yesterday and lingered in town hardly long enough to get a good look at the skyline.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Whitney Forbes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Forbes of Ridgewood, N. J., and Madison, Conn., to the Rev. Cary Nelson Weisiger of Philadelphia will take place on Saturday in the First Congregational Church, Madison.

Bill Klem, dean of National League umpires and veteran of 33 years in that circuit, was guest of honor at a "Bill Klem Day" luncheon at the Chamber of Commerce today given by life-long Rochester friends. John A. Heydler,

Two Fran Englishmen who befriended the Duchess of Bedford, Great Britain's "Flying Peeress," when she was forced down in an Iraq oil field nine years ago, today received bequests of [Pound]2,000 each in her will.

Freedom, which Ernest Booth, 39, convict author, failed to achieve by strategy or risk of life in repeated escape attempts, became his today because of illness and his prison success as a writer of fiction.

Driven to the verge of madness by devastating earthquakes that convulsed their tiny island three days, the 2,000 residents of Alabat today awaited response to their plea that they be evacuated by the Philippine Government.
No meetings have taken place here between United States Ambassador to Russia Joseph E. Davies and J. P. Morgan, as has been rumored in British papers.

Clark Witbeck, prominent in the business life of Schenectady for lore than half a century and preslent of the hardware company hearing his name, died yesterday t his residence on the Troy Road. lis age was 85.
Fulfilling a personal ambition, Eva Le in Gallienne appeared here tonight in the title role of "Hamlet," presented by Raymond Moore at his Cape playhouse.

New York and Illinois sent twenty of the total of thirty-nine players to the annual meeting of the American Chess Federation, the first session of which was held today in the Congress Hotel. Eight other States were represented.

The sale of St. Patrick's Cathedral and adjoining Catholic property to the Eastman Kodak Company for $350,000 was confirmed today by the Catholic Diocese of Rochester, following approval by the Vatican.

The text of the speech delivered tonight by Senator Pittman, chairman of' the Foreign Relations Committee, in explanation bf President Roosevelt's delay in declaring a state of war to exist in China, follows:

FOR what this country has been spared her citizens should be duly grateful. To this day the United States might have stood a confederation of republics, each with a pride even loftier than its tariff walls. It might have remained, had Napoleon been better fixed for cash and Jefferson less cavalier in his treatment of the Constitution,

Inspector Daniel J. Kiely of the local Police Department died early today at his Summer home in Avon of a heart attack. Apparently in good health yesterday afternoon, the inspector went to Avon and was stricken a few hours after retiring.

The Valencia Spanish Government has appealed to the League of Nations against "additional particularly flagrant aggression by Italy." It accuses Italy of sinking four of its merchant ships. Its long telegram, dated Aug. 21, was published by the League Secretariat today.

Moses W. Epstein, founder and president of the Peerless Smoking Jacket Company, 16 East Thirtyfourth Street, died yesterday at the age of 70 at his home, 215 West Ninety-second Street, after a long illness.

Six men were reported killed and two others injured when a navy flying boat crashed into the bay here tonight. Fragmentary reports indicated that the flying boat's tall struck a partly submerged boat hull and the boat tipped over on its nose.

Meeting yesterday for the first time since the national theatre convention in May, some thirty representatives of the groups that constitute the American Theatre Council attacked three of the problems they set for themselves at the Spring session.

Among the passengers who arrived from Europe yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary was Dr. Joseph Tannenbaum, chairman of the Joint Boycott Council of the American Jewish Congress and Jewish Labor Committee.

New ark clinched the International League pennant in anything except championship style tonight when it dropped a second straight game to Buffalo, 9-7. Montreal's split in a double bill with Baltimore made the pennant a mathematical certainty for the Bears.

National Economy League studies have shown that not more than $2,000,000,000 can be realized in the immediate future on the recoverable assets held by government agencies, E. Roland Harriman, chairman of the managing committee of the league, declared last night in a radio address over Station WEAF.

Organized labor in the city and throughout the nation was urged last night by Mayor La Guardia to develop intelligent leadership to take full advantage of the existing favorable Federal and State legislation to consolidate its gains and broaden its activities.

An aerial bomb in Sunday's fighting at Shanghai destroyed the Chengfu radio station from which Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, American-educated wife of the Chinese generalissimo had been scheduled to make a short-wave broadcast to this country yesterday over the WABC-Columbia network.

Hugh R. Wilson, former American Minsister to Switzerland, took the oath of office today as Assistant Secretary of State. His appointment was part of the reorganization of the State Department which has been going on for several months. Mr.

Developments yesterday in the Securities and Exchange Commission's stop-order proceedings against the Austin Silver Mining Company included testimony that Austin shares had been bought on the New York Curb Exchange to "get a print"
James D. Chaplin, for eighteen years Member of Parliament for Lincoln and a former Minister of Trade and Commerce, died at his home here today after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

The American Institute of Banking, the educational section of the American Bankers Association, will hold its annual radio commencement exercises on the evening of Sept. 10, according to an announcement yesterday by Frank R. Curda, president of the institute.

The body of David G. Baillie, newspaper man here and abroad for fifty years, who died on Aug. 14 at the age of 71 at Taymouth Castle, near Kenmore, Scotland, arrived yesterday on the Queen Mary. Accompanying the body were his widow and a son, Hugh Baillie, president of The United Press.

Oliver Joseph Thatcher, historian and formerly Professor of History at the University of Chicago, died last Thursday at his home in San Bernardino, Calif., according to word received here yesterday by a relative. He was 79 years old.

Thomas O. Burnett, Cobbleskill's last surviving Civil War veteran, died here yesterday on his ninety-fourth birthday. Mr. Burnett served in the war as a member of Battery N of the First New York Artillery. In addition to his distinction as the village's last veteran, he was its oldest resident.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Regarding the threatened tie-up of the metropolitan milk supply on Sept. 1, may I, a producer of Grade B milk, comment?

Viscount and Viscountess Mandeville of Brampton Park, Huntington, England, who have been visiting friends here, are at the Waldorf-Astoria before returning to their home in England. Mr. and Mrs. James Harrington Stark, who have been passing the Summer at Brookwood, their country place in Darien, Conn., will be at the Carlyle for the Winter.
Al Roth, Bronx lightweight, will seek his ninth straight ring victory tonight at Dyckman Oval, where he is to tackle the rugged Frankie Wallace of Cleveland in the feature bout of ten rounds.

The onrushing season: When the Theatre Guild's "Madame Bovary" opens on Oct. 18 it will be at the Broadhurst, not the Plymouth, as previously announced by the Guild. As the Plymouth's next tenant, there is talk of "Susan and God" the week of Sept. 27.

Some poet has said that "three can make the planets sing." It has been demonstrated in a very practical way that three cents a day can make people in sickness sing, knowing that they are able to pay their hospital bills.

The British flotilla leader Keith left Saint-Jean-de-Laz at 8 o'clock tonight for cabo Mayor, near Santander. There she will try to pick up President Jose Antonio Aguirre and the members of the Basque Government still at Santander, seventeen Insurgent political economists

The voters of the Central School District expressed themselves here tonight in support of James E. Wardle, whose forced resignation as principal of Central High School caused a three-day strike of its pupils last April, by electing to the school board the three candidates running on the "Wardle vindication ticket."

The bodies of Jhon Komaha, 52 years old, a WPA laborer, and a woman about 45 years old, identified only as "Paula," or "Pauline," were found last night by the police after Paul Dowgardi, superintendent of the building at 603 East Fourteenth Street, between Avenues B and C, had summoned them to break down the door of Komaha's apartment at that address.
The marriage of Miss Louisa Frances Bruce to Lieutenant (J. G.) Morton Sunderland, U. S. N., took place today in the chapel of the United States Naval Academy.
The largest opening-day crowd in years turned out at the Longwood Cricket Club this afternoon as ranking tennis players from eight nations began quest for the national doubles championships.

THE other day, apropos of the activities of the Federal Writers' Project, some one suggested over a dinner table that there was no valid reason for using the phrase "unemployed author," since those who relied upon their pens for a living were always "unemployed" so long as they produced no marketable work, and never "unemployed," even in the worst depression days, when they produced work of superior grade.

Motion picture operators of two more theatres, the Granada, 346 East Seventy-second Street, and the Heights, 150 Wadsworth Avenue, went on strike last night, but at the latter house a settlement was quickly reached.
Favorites breezed through first-round matches in the thirty-seventh annual women's Western golf tournament at the Town and Country course today.

Middlesex climbed to the top of the English county cricket championship table today, replacing Yorkshire. With only two more games scheduled, the race is shaping up as the most bitterly fought in years.

A conference in the executive chamber at noon tomorrow on "enforcement of the penal law with regard to gambling in Cheektowaga," Erie County, was called today by Governor Lehman, who telegraphed to District Attorney Walter C. Newcomb, Sheriff William M. Eberhardt and Police Chief Charles Wohlford Jr. asking them to meet with him.
Several leases on Fifth Avenue were included in the contracts for commercial space reported yesterday. Among those taking space were milliners, men's clothiers and novelty firms.
The stock market herd continued to be extremely quiet today but a firmer tendency developed in some sections. Gilt-edge issues did well;

Phil Miller of French Lick, Ind., broke 275 clays in a row today to capture the North American target championship, but the day's story of the thirty-eighth Grand American program belongs to Mrs. Lela Hall of Strasburg, Mo.

The Belmont Theatre at 121-25 West Forty-eighth Street has been sold to the Joan of Arc Pictures, Inc., motion-picture producers, was announced yesterday. Bank for Savings was the seller. Situated on a plot 56.8 by 100.5 feet between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, the property is assessed at $190,000.
Employment in retail stores in New York State showed a seasonal drop of 5.9 per cent from June to July, while payrolls fell off 3.9 per cent, Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews reported today.

The Bergen County Holding Corp of Brooklyn, Abraham Glickman, president, obtained from Helen Walton a demand loan of $150,000 at 6 per cent for the construction of a motion-picture theatre on the southwest corner of Bergen and Glenwood Aves, Jersey City.

About 200 students have passed the State examination for dental licenses, the Department of Education reported today in making public a list of the successful ones. The licenses will be issued at once to the following:

El Lagarto, the 15-year-old speedboat that has won three legs on the Gold Cup, will make an attempt to regain the prized speed trophy at Detroit on Labor Day, her owner-driver, George Reis, announced tonight.

While the tragedies of war multiply daily here, with terror too choking to find voice and grief too deep for tears, the situation nevertheless does not lack absurdities. Because of the existence of the International Settlement and the French Concession, Chinese and Japanese leaders are able to carry on their activities separated by only a few city blocks.

A plan of reorganization for the Warner-Quinlan Company under which unsecured bondholders and creditors will receive 70 per cent of their holdings in bonds of a new company, or 55 per cent of their claims in cash within sixty days, was approved yesterday by Federal Judge Murray Hulbert.

Julian Olney has been appointed assistant to Allen Wardell in the preparation of plans for the music festival to be held in connection with the New York World's Fair in 1939, it was announced yesterday.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Beebe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lucius Beebe of Hilltop, Wallingford, Pa., was married this afternoon to Leslie Quentin Miller of Bronxville, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. A. S. Miller of Spokane, Wash.
Broadway theatrical managers are now asking the stagehands' union for a two-year contract to replace the one-year agreement that will expire on Sept. 5, it was learned yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia of New York City today proved to be the center of attraction at the United Spanish War Veterans encampment. From the time he arrived here at 3 o'clock this afternoon, he participated in a round of activities ending with a speech at a dinner of the Eleventh Regiment Association tonight. Later he left for New York by plane.
Turpentine firm, 33 1/4c; sales, 159 barrels; receipts, 576 barrels; shipments, 75 barrels; stock, 37,435 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 510; receipts, 1,917; shipments, 1,325; stock, 62,585.
The American labor movement took on new life "in backing the New Deal," United States Senator Joseph F. Guffey, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, declared in an address broadcast last night over WEVD.

Modern civilization is "on the toboggan" largely because it selects improper foods, according to Dr. Weston E. Price, Cleveland diet specialist, who returned from Peru yesterday with Mrs. Price on the Grace liner Santa Barbara.

Mrs. Charles G. Proffitt gave a dinner, followed by bridge, tonight at her place in Hampton Bays. Among the guests were Mrs. Charles Banks Belt, Mrs. Joseph Bradley Murray, Mrs. Charles H. Higgins, Mrs. Hudson Budd, Miss Dorothy Cockshaw and Mrs. John F. Donoho.

Mr. and Mrs. Monroe C. Gutman of 31 East Seventy-second Street, New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Gutman, to Milton L. Bernstein Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton L. Bernstein of 885 Park Avenue New York.
The quest of Charles A. Harnett for the oldest automobile is bearing fruit. He wishes to exhibit it at the automobile show in New York City in November.
There will be general approval of the President's message in vetoing the bill providing $500,000 for the erection

The large number of new apartment leases. reported yesterday extended to practically all residential sections of the city. West Side suite's were in equal demand with quarters on the East Side, the choice of the latter centering in the Seventies.

Announcement has been made by Gurden Edwards of 77 Park Avenue of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Dorothy Edwards, to Francis Edward Drake Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. Drake of Pelham, N. Y.

Mrs. Emily Brown Thompson, vice president of the board of managers of the Hospital and Home for Crippled Children, Newark, and long interested in philanthropic work, died today at her home, 436 Ridgewood Avenue, after a short illness. She was 66 years old.

The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals vacated yesterday an injunction barring State and county officials from interfering with the operation of a dog-racing track at Mineola, L. I., and the whole issue of the legality of the option type of betting at dog tracks was thrown back into the State criminal courts.
Vice Chancellor W. Frank Sooy made permanent today the receivership for the Admiral Holding Company, which earlier in the Summer operated the Admiral Hotel, 350-room fireproof structure at Cape May.

President Roosevelt commended today the contributions of life insurance toward safeguarding the security of the American home. In a message to Theodore N. Riehle of New York, president of the National Association of Life Underwriters, which is meeting in convention here, he said:

Edward Franklin Zieger, formerly with Maurice Wertheim, has opened his own realty and insurance office in the Chrysler Building. The Cross Brown Company acted as brokers in the recent sale of 11 East Fifty-first Street.

Mrs. Calista Stout Struby, widow of Walter Vanderveen Struby and a daughter of Mrs. Frank Deming Stout of Chicago and Santa Barbara, and the late Mr. Stout, was married yesterday afternoon to August Kern of this city in the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest. The Rev. Lyman C.

"The worst thing on a birthday is to give a man a present; he probably does not want it or need it," explained August Heckscher, the capitalist and philanthropist, who will celebrate his eighty-ninth birthday tomorrow.
Aided by a swift-moving tide, Charles Zimmy, 46-year-old legless swimmer, paddled by here tonight about twenty-six hours after he dove off a pier at Albany in an attempt to swim to New York.

Because of the large list of competitors entered, the small-bore matches of the Junior Rifle Corps program went unfinished today, but Richard Johnson, 16, of Plainfield, N. J., was leading in Group A with a score of 200 over the 50foot range.
Clearing weather in the Arctic encourage hopes of aviators here today that they soon would be able to fly over the polar ice fields in search of six lost Soviet airmen.

The hearing on Emperor Haile Selassie's petition for permission to sell Ethiopian shares in the Jibuti-Addis Ababa Railway, which has been opposed by Italy, was set down today in the Paris courts for Oct. 12.
Valentine C. Brueckmann, Atlantic City real estate operator, died at Margate today at the home of his son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Shinn. His age was 89.

Mrs. Sylva Annenberg of Fresh Meadow led a small field of 26 starters, who braved a cold drizzle, to win low gross with a score of 45, 41-86 in the women's metropolitan one-day tournament over the Pelham Country Club course today.

Albert Roussel. one of the best-known French composers, died today at the age of 68. M. Roussel was born at Tourcoing and became a professor at the Schola Cantorum. His compositions became a popular feature at symphony concerts and at the opera following the success of his choreographic and symphonic poem, "Festin de l'Araignee," in 1913.
Introducing some baseball parlance into his first charge to a new group of jurymen, Superior Court Judge Ernest E. Hobson told them to call them as they saw them.

President Roosevelt signed today a bill to authorize transfer to the jurisdiction of the Secretary of the Treasury of land within the Camp Dix military reservation in New Jersey for a depository for the nation's silver supply.
District Council 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, A. F. of L., announced yesterday that it had completed plans for a walk-out of 15,000 painters voted last week.
Luncheon forum, committee on port Development, Progressive City Committee. the Town Hall Club, 12:30 P. M. Speakers: Howard S. Cullman, John A. Wilbur, Maurice P. Davidson.

The Republic of Peru, in default in interest and sinking-fund payments on its outstanding dollar bonds since 1931, took definite steps yesterday toward the first payment of any kind on those obligations since the initial default, by depositing $500,000 here to the order of its paying agent for the purchase and cancellation of certain coupons of three outstanding loans.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petition BELLE KNITTING CORP., 261 5th Ave., and Sayre, Pa.--Voluntary proceeding under section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $882,416, exclusive of capital and surplus, and assets of $1,675,295, including current assets of $674,834. The company's plant at Sayre has been operating at a profit but lack of liquid assets necessitates refinancing. Judge Patterson approved the petition and continued the debtor in possession and operation.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Cairns, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Cairns, to William T. McCutcheon of Louisville, Ky., son of Mrs. John McCutcheon of Scarsdale, N. Y., and the late Mr. McCutcheon, will take place on Sept. 11 in the Union Congregational Church here.

Hard-working burglars drilled and forced five safes in the'building at 840 Broadway early yesterday but found only $71 in cash and a small quantity of gold leaf for their trouble They left their tools behind. them when they. fled.

An apology and promise of restitution for smashed furniture and lack of a formal complaint for wifebeating almost erased the case of Jack Bradley, 30-year-old WPA electrician, from the records of Jefferson . Market Court yesterday.

Joe Louis put on a show for one of his baseball heroes, Babe Ruth, today as he did his last ring work in preparation for Thursday's title fight against Tommy Farr. The champion was in fine form as he chased Pal Silvers around the ring for two rounds, then took on Tiger Hairston and George Nicholson for two rounds apiece.

The National Maritime Union demanded yesterday that the American Export Lines pay a bonus of $100 a trip to each seaman employed on its ships because of the danger attendant upon the operation of the ships in Spanish waters.

La Verne Moore, alias John Montague, Hollywood's golfer extraordinary, was committed to jail here today by Supreme Court Justice 0. Byron Brewster, after the Court reserved decision on Moore's application for bail.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence A. Bill of Hempstead, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Vernette Bill, to Alton Austin Cheney of this city, son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Austin Cheney of New Haven and Litchfield, Conn.
Assurance was given yesterday by Tammany Leader Christopher D. Sullivan that Tammany Hall would not bolt the ticket if defeated in the September primary.

The Progressive City Committee announced yesterday that it has endorsed for re-election Municipal Court Justice David C. Lewis. Judge Lewis was turned down for renomination by Tammany because, Judge Lewis has charged, he. refused to take orders from district leaders affecting cases coming before him.
Details of the spy system allegedly maintained by the Weirton Steel Company among its employes were put in the record of the National Labor Relations Board hearing here today by several witnesses.

On a stage set for the first act of tonight's "Der Rosenkavalier," Arturo Toscanini led the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra from 4:30 to 5:30 o'clock this afternoon in a special concert sponsored by the National Broadcasting Company and transmitted not only to American but also to various foreign stations.

The United States Circuit Court has unanimously set aside the temporary injunction which for the last month has restrained the police and Nassau County authorities from interfering with the dog races being conducted at Mineola.

The scheduled trial by jury of the Rev. Verlynn M. Sprague, pastor of the Memorial Methodist Church of Yonkers, was canceled in City Court here today when a disorderly conduct charge against the minister was withdrawn by Assistant Corporation Counsel Harold Garrity before a talesman was called.

Mrs. Walter Atherton of Boston had eighty members of the Lenox Garden Club as her tea guests at Highwood, Windsor, this afternoon. Mrs. John Bross Lloyd, Mrs. George B. de Gersdorff, Mrs. Samuel Frothingham and Miss , Marian Hague assisted.
Big Jim Turner, holding the Pirates to five hits, shut them out, 1-0, today, as the Bees won the opener of a twogame series.
Braving the rain that prevented the opening of the Oyster Bay carnival for the benefit of the Roosevelt Memorial Park fund yesterday, Mrs. Edith Kermit Roosevelt,

The condition of Martha Jean Phillips, 12 years old, seriously injured yesterday in an automobile accident which was fatal to. her father, James Doyle Phillips, Havana correspondent for THE NEW YORK TIMES, was reported today by hospital attendants to be "fair."

A petition nominating six Democrats from the Nineteenth New York Assembly District was forwarded to the District Attorney yesterday after A. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections, had said that it "reeked with forgery and fraud."

For several weeks reports from Washington have been foreshadowing a definitive statement of American policy in the Far East. Secretary Hull has now made such a statement. It notes the steps which have been taken to evacuate Americans from Shanghai.

A committee for Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company refunding 5 per cent sinking fund bonds due in 1973, headed by N. E. Waldman, issued a statement yesterday in which it asserted that it was possible that the company could be reorganized before a complete revival in the anthracite industry.

Bonds followed a rather uncertain course yesterday in lighter trading on the New York Stock Exchange. While the domestic corporate section maintained a steady to firm undertone as prices fluctuated narrowly, the market for United States Government issues turned highly irregular although trading in them dwindled to $1,850,125, compared with $2,862,500 on the preceding day.
President Lazaro Cardenas is expected in Mexico City tomorrow, returning from Yucatan after having started distribution of lands among peasants. Yucatan estates produce mostly sisal.

Sir Gervase Beckett, noted banker, died here today at the age of 71. When his firm, Beckett Co., was incorporated with the Westminster Bank, he became a director. He also was chairman of the Yorkshire Post Company and former proprietor and editor of The Saturday Review.
Chauncey E. Donkelberger, onetime Surrogate Judge in New York State, died here today at the age of 74.
A single by Roy Hughes, pinch hitter, ended a thirteen-inning pitching duel between Bob (Lefty) Grove and Johnny Allen today and gave the Indians a 4-to-3 decision over the Red Sox.

Deaths Announced Fireman 1st grade William F. Sweetnam, of H. L. 147, died Aug. 22. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 707 St. John's Place, Brooklyn, at 9:30 A. M., Thursday, Aug. 26. Interment at Calvary Cemetery, Borough of Queens.
Two vessels for government service, one a submarine of 1,435 tons. displacement, the other the largest seagoing ocean hopper dredge ever built, were launched today in New England vards.

Alexander's Department Stores, Inc., New York, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 350,000 shares of $1 par common stock, of which 210,000 shares are outstanding.

A total of nine Manhattan properties changed hands yesterday through auction sales in the Vesey Street salesrooms. Among them was the ten-story apartment and stores building at 3,770-78 Broadway, corner of 157th Street. The Manhattan Company, plaintiff, bought the parcel for $100,000.
The Underwear and Negligee Stabilization Board has received its certificate of incorporation, Matthew G. Tooran, counsel, announced yesterday.

Bulwark, from the stable of Hugh W. Jackson, captured the thirty-fifth running of the $3,775 Amsterdam Claiming Stakes at a mile and a furlong today. At the end of the route over a fast track, Bulwark was in a full drive to score by a length over Twice.

Oregonians who found no reason to be proud of their weather Sunday and yesterday, when it rained and rained, were happier today as gorgeous sunlight flooded the golf course where the national amateur is being played and made conditions ideal.

High school allotments totaling $8,156,250, a reduction of $2,918,750 from last year's budget, and special grants amounting to $310,650 for additional young people in the ten Mid-Western States affected by this Summer's drought, were authorized today by the National Youth Administration for. the part-time employment of needy high school students during the coming academic year.
New Yorkers competing in the annual tournament for the championship of the American Chess Federation at the Hotel Congress took a- full share of the honors in the second round.

A large group of Senators and Representatives will sail for Europe today on the Washington of the United States Lines as delegates to the Congress of the Interparliamentary Union, opening in Paris Sept. 1.

The three-family dwelling at 14426 Barclay Avenue, Flushing, has been sold by the Queens County Savings Bank to Edna Hansgen through the Halleran Agency, broker. The house is three stories in height, contains twenty-one rooms and five baths and stands on a plot 50 by 100 feet.

The death of 5-year-old Oneta De Young last night resulted from her apparent attempt to rescue her unconscious mother from the fumefilled bathroom in the De Young apartment at 942 De Mott Street here, physicians and detectives decided today after an investigation.

Charles B. Hall, former President of the City Council and one of the most prominent of Philadelphia's active Republican leaders ten years ago, died at his seashore home in Ventnor, N. J., today of a heart attack. He was 75 years old.

Vocational training for those entering the retail field Would reduce the distribution costs and help to solve many economic problems for producer and consumer, Dr. Paul H. Nystrom, Professor of Marketing. at Columbia University, told delegates to the annual convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria.

As a stockholder of the corporation, Robert C. Kewley, an attorney here,.filed suit today against Swift Co. and nine individuals on charges based on the purchase of $3,000 worth of Democratic national campaign books.

Warners will offer at the Criterion today another of their musical shows, namely, "Dance, Charlie, Dance." In it are Stuart Erwin, Jean Muir, Glenda Farrell and Allen Jenkins. ... The Rialto's new tenant this morning is "Bad Guy," a Metro film once known as "High Voltage" and featuring Bruce Cabot, Edward Norris, Virginia Grey, Jean Chatburn and Charles Grapewin.

Trading continued slow on most classes. Steer cute sold steady to higher and other classes steady to lower. Early trading in kosher meats indicated prices to be about in line with Monday's close, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture:

11th St, 619 E, 25x163.3; Bella Remnek to Samuel E. Remnek, 656 E 12th St. 13th St, 539 E, 25x103.3; Sam Nazar et al to George Sachs, 1,472 Bway; mtg, $7,000 (50c). Same property; George Sachs to Anastasia Nazar, 539 E 13th St; mtg. $7,000. 27th St. 228 E, 25x98.9; Edna R. Adrian to Cyril J. Adrian, 309 Sterling P1, Bklyn. 149th St, 452-64 W, 150x99.11; Ethel S.

The vast and spreading scope of the Sino-Japanese conflict is clearly revealed by the records of yesterday's bombings. Scores of planes dropped bombs from the Seaport of Ningpo, south of - Shanghai, to points in the Kalgan region north of Peiping, 1,100 miles away.

As a protest against the minimum price set by the New Jersey Board of Milk Control for milk consumed in schools, the Board of Education here announced today that it would suspend "for the present" its tenyear practice of allowing milk to b served in classrooms.
Today the big distributors are simultaneously raising the price of milk 1 cent a quart and the price of heavy cream 1 cent a half pint. Various explanations are offered for the increase.

State Institutions Commissioner William J. Ellis reported today that 10,031 New Jersey recruits. were enrolled in the Civilian Conservation Corps in the four enlistment periods from October, 1936, to last July.
Louis Smitchel, wounded in the Battle of Black Hill when his company was sent to the relief of General Custer during the Indian War, died today at his home near Rock City Falls. He was 86 years old.

The eleven-day strike at the plant of Rockwood Co., manufacturers of chocolate products, at 88 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn was settled yesterday, and the 1,000 employes of the company will return to work this morning.

Satisfaction with the leadership and policies of the Committee for Industrial Organization was expressed yesterday by Earl Browder general secretary of the Communist party in the United States, and Israel Amter, the party's chief organizer in this State.
John L. Lewis, chairman of labor's Non partisan League, declined today to discuss the investigation authorized by the American Federation of Labor into the relations of the league with the C. I. O.

After Francisco Marin Canas was sentenced recently to ten days in jail on charges that an article he wrote insulted Premier Benito Mussolini, the Italian Minister, who brought the charges, asked President Leon Cortes to pardon Senor Canas.

Farm marketing in July amounted to $740,000,000, the largest amount for any month since May, 1930, the Department of Agriculture announced today. The figure was $30,0O0,000 more than the income of July, 1936, and was the largest for any July since, 1929, when farmers received $846,000,000.
The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Aug. 15 showed that the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation was 128.98 per cent, against 130.99 per cent on July 31.
The original copy of the statement of Far Eastern policy made by Secretary of State Cordell Hull last night bore upon its face the inscription, "O. K., I heartily approve. F. D.
Twenty Bellanca airplanes designed for either military or commercial use were shipped to China within the last few days from New Castle, Del., it was reported here yesterday.
Edward Henry Heed, former assistant auditor of the Studebaker Corporation in South Bend, Ind., died suddenly here last night at the home of his sister, Mrs. Guy C. Mariner of 130 Country Club Lane.
For the fourth consecutive week production of crude oil in the United States last week again reached a new high record, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

The Grand Opera Artists Association of America held a meeting in Steinway Hall last night to protest against charges designed to deprive it of its A. F. of L. charter on the ground that it had failed to organize its field thoroughly.

Peasants sentenced to death by the hundreds under a Soviet decree of Aug. 7, 1932, for such crimes as stealing grain or "missing stalks of grain in the cutting" were the victims of Trotskyists, wreckers and traitors in the intelligence service and the Department of Justice.
Gustav Schlieper, one of the directors of the Deutsche Bank, died here today. He was chief of the foreign department of the bank and well known to many New Yorkers.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the listing, on official notice of issuance, of 102,526 additional $5-par capital shares of Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc. An underwriting agreement is to be effected.

Call it emancipation or mark it down to plain sporting instinct, but whatever term you employ the answer is the same: women are rapidly showing a high degree of proficiency in those sports which formerly were almost exclusively masculine.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage of Miss Ruth Dresser to William K. Metcalfe of this city, which took place on Saturday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Dresser of West Medford, Mass.

Japan will find stronger opposition in her present fight with China than she has ever encountered before, in the opinion of Colonel Fritz Neidholdt, former officer in the Imperial German Army, and recently a military adviser to the Nanking Government.

Broadway, 2,783-87, (leasehold); Athens Trading Corp, Alex C. Xynos, president, to Frankwall Corp, 1,819 Broadway; due Sept. 13, 1937; Int per check; $1,100. Harrison St. 14-16, 37.5x166.4: to Franklin St, 179; 183xirreg; Red Diamond Realty Corp, William F. Heide, president, to Guardian Life Ins Co of America; due as bond; $30.000.

Roger Kelly, law student from Los Angeles, put California in the golfing limelight today when he smashed his way around the tricky Alderwood Country Club course in 70 strokes, two under par figures, to lead the qualifiers in the fortyfirst annual amateur championship of the United States.

James L. Phelan, a former Irish agitator who twice was sentenced to death and for fourteen years was confined in English prisons, will have a first novel, about prison life, published by Morrow this week Mr. Phelan wrote the novel "Museum" while in orison.

Robert Irwin, 29-year-old sculptor and former theological student indicted for the murder of Mrs. Mary Gedeon, her daughter, Veronica, and their boarder, Frank Byrnes, will be tried for the death of Byrnes, District Attorney William C. Dodge disclosed yesterday in applying for a special panel of talesmen.
The City Fusion party of Brooklyn has named Mrs. Genevieve B. Earle, a member of the commission which framed the new City Charter, as a candidate for member of the City Council.

While some phases of governmental simplification and economies planned under the new city charter have been receiving wide attention, a major change which this charter will bring in the system of control of buildings and building plans has been largely overlooked.

The Farragut Players tonight presented the premiere of "God Innis" in the Farragut Playhouse before a large and enthusiastic audience. The play, a three-act comic fantasy on Irish life, was written by George Dowell and Helen Williams, and it is planned to present the production on Broadway this Fall.

Salvagers hacked their way into the wreckage of a partly submerged naval flying boat in San Diego Bay today and recovered the bodies of two of the six crew members killed when the plane crashed into the hulk of the Narwhal, an old whaler.

The world's production of tin in the first half of this year amounted to 92,303 tons, an increase of 9,415 over the corresponding period of 1936, according to the International Tin Research and Development Council. World consumption was 94,863 tons an increase of 14,944.

General agreement that retail credit sales prospects for Fall are excellent was voiced at the merchandising sessions yesterday of the annual convention of the Credit Retailers Association of America at the Hotel New Yorker.

Park Dr (18-5652) n e cor of Edgemere St, 100x100; Railroad Federal Savings Loan Assn to Thomas F. Kearns, 2,720 Grand Concourse. White Plains Rd (15-3949), e s 119 ft a of Guerlain St. 31x90; Vito Durso to Arkro Holding Corp, 50 Broadway; mortgage 59,000.

Objections to the petitions of Aldermanic President William F. Brunner and James A. Burke, his opponent, for the Democratic nomination for Borough President of Queens have been dismissed by the Board of Elections.

The German Embassy announced today that Rear Admiral Erwin Wassner, its Naval Attache and a U-boat commander in the World War, had died at The Hague, Netherlands. He was on his way to London to resume his duties when taken ill.

The city death rate dropped to 8.3, per 1,000 of population during the week ended last Saturday, decline of two-tenths of, a point from the figure for the preceding week and the second lowest death rate to be recorded for any week this year, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Edwin George White of Geneva, N. Y., rector of Episcopalian parishes in Willowdale, Kendaia and Romulus, N. Y., died yesterday in London where he was visiting relatives. He was 59 years old.

Sterilization 'of certain types of sex delinquents brought into custody through the Children's Court was recommended yesterday by Justice Jacob Panken of that court in an address at City Hall before sixteen "career students" working in city departments during their Summer vacation so they may study government at first hand.

Walloping two Toronto pitchers for fourteen solid blows and a 7-1 trimming in the nightcap of a double-header tonight, the Jersey City Giants gained an even break after the Maple Leafs had scored a 4-3 victory in the opener, which went nine innings instead of the scheduled seven.

The opening of the operetta "Nina Rosa" at Jones Beach Stadium has been postponed a second time because of unfavorable weather and will be given tonight. Tickets for last night and Monday night will be exchangeable for any performance during the week.

The War Department released the following order. dated Aug. 23: COLONELS Jones, C. (C. A. C.), Gen. Staff Corps, one month leave, Sept. 4. FitzGerald, S. W. (Lt. Col.), (Air Corps). Gen. Staff Corps. one day leave. Aug. 30.

United States ASSISTANT MARKETING SPECIALIST (fruits and vegetables), $2,600 a year; Assistant Marketing Specialist (canned .fruits and vegetables), $2,600. Bureau of Agricultural Economics. Department of Agriculture. Applications must be on file not later than (a) Sent. 13.

Officials of the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturing Group, Inc., today endorsed a set of proposed fair trade rules drafted by the Federal Trade Commission after a previous conference with members of the trade. The officials suggested two new rules and an amendment to one of those proposed.

Between dusk and midnight today, President Roosevelt wrote the concluding chapter in a story of the most decisive legislative defeat dealt to a Chief Executive since the Senate, twenty years ago, blocked Woodrow Wilson's dream of American participation in the League of Nations.

James N. MacLean of Massapequa, formerly active in Republican politics in Nassau County, announced today that he would act as campaign manager for Rayford W. Alley of Syosset, Democratic designee for the office of county executive, a post created under the new Nassau County charter.

The American Federation of Teachers will take no more decisive stand on the controversial issue of affiliation with the Committee for Industrial Organization than ordering the question to a national referendum, an. official spokesman for the annual convention announced tonight.
