Faced with the threat that the Interstate Commerce Commission would end four years of delay and prepare a plan of reorganization on its own motion for the Missouri Pacific Railroad, a group of insurance and savings bank officials conferred yesterday with some of the railroad's officials in an unsuccessful attempt to break the deadlock that has until now prevented them from reaching an agreement for rehabilitating the Western line.
The Chinese Embassy gave out the following statement tonight: "Shanghai is still in the grip of terror when several Japanese bombs were dropped in the International Settlement yesterday afternoon.

The decline registered in steel ingot production last week was less than seasonal, and the adjusted index has advanced to 131.4, a new recovery high. It was 128.7 for the previous week and 112.0 for the week ended Aug. 22, 1936.

A hearing has been called for Sept. 21 by the Securities and Exchange Commission on an application by the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the $100-par common stock, the 7 per cent cumulative Class A preferred stock and the 6 per cent cumulative Class B preferred stock of the Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation of Virginia.

Hosinger Bode, Inc, placed a $20,000 loan at 4 1/2 per cent on the 3-story store and office building on the s w cor of Roosevelt Ave and Broadway, Jackson Heights, Queens, for the Einsidler Holding Corp. through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc, agents for the Union Central Life Insurance Co.

Mrs. Florence Temple, 45-yearold former wife of Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, was killed yesterday morning in a ten-story plunge from her room in the Buckingham Hotel, 101 West Fifty-seventh Street.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, demanded in a letter made public today that the new Maritime Commission abandon its declared attitude of neutrality in. the American labor controversy and recognize the Federation union in the merchant marine field.
Joseph Cook, attorney and president of the First National Bank of Fort Lee, died this morning at his home at 250 Myrtle Avenue, Coytesville, N. J. He was 53 years old.

Coincident with the appointment of Harry Singer as advertising director, Simplicity Magazine, the national monthly fashion publication with more than 8,000,000 circulation, will launch an aggressive promotional campaign, Joseph M. Shapiro, president of Simplicity Pattern Company, announced yesterday. Mr. Singer, formerly on the advertising staff of The American Weekly and national advertising manager of.The New York Mirror, has been with Simplicity Magazine since the first of the year.
The prolonged negotiations reviewed at today's meeting of the French Cabinet have failed to patch up the split over nationalization of French railways.
Rudy York, hard-hitting Tiger catcher, hammered out three home runs today as Detroit and the Athletics split a double-header.

Cancellation by the United Air Lines Transport Corporation of a second daily round-trip passenger and express service between Philadelphia and Cleveland, inaugurated on July 20, was ordered today, as recommended in a memorandum submitted to Postmaster General Farley by Karl A. Crowley, Solicitor of the Postoffice Department.
Plans for the construction of a new public administration school and a new gymnasium were announced at Harvard University today.

Seattle Chinese today had contributed $50,000 to aid their embattled brothers across the Pacific. The money was collected by the Chinese Benevolent Society, whose membership includes virtually all of Seattle's 1,500 Chinese.
Gold to the value of $2,122,000 was engaged yesterday in England for shipment to this country. The price of gold in London was slightly under the shipping parity at pricefixin time there.

The Casino Theatre was well filled tonight for the opening of "As Husbands Go," by Rachel Crothers, and starring Cecilia Loftus and Edith Barrett. Among those who entertained with box parties were Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mrs. Hamilton McK. Twombly, Mr. and Mrs. Maxim Karoilk, Mrs. W. Harry Brown, Mrs. Moses Taylor and Mrs. Reginald Norman.

Rioting on the island of Great Inagua last Thursday caused the death of one man and the deporting of Josiah Erickson of Swampscott, Mass., part owner of the salt plant, Commissioner Fields and thirteen others in a motor boat, according to a report to the Government today.

The 1938 budget request of the Department of Parks of New York City will be $11,228,238, which is more than $3,500,000 above last year's figure, due largely to the withdrawal of relief workers from park maintenance and operation jobs,

ABOUT all that anybody in this vicinity could know about Tummas Farr from Tonypandy is that his passport must have been in good order or they wouldn't have allowed him to land on these shores. Further than that he is a sizable gent who has been in the fighting game for some years and should know something about it by this time if he is ever going to learn.

Emil Bildilli, new pitcher acquired by the Browns from the Middle-Atlantic League; failed in his major league debut today as the Senators blasted him from the mound in the fourth inning and coasted to a 9-to-6 victory.
Chicago at New York (2)--Lee and French vs. Hubbell and Gumbert. St. Louis at Brooklyn (2)--Warneke and Ryba vs. Mungo and Cantwell.
The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $15,660,911 after all deductions for the twelve months ended on July 31.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 21: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Graham, J. J., the Sturtevant, to Third Naval District, New York, N. Y., in October.

The Territory of Hawaii will enter the market about the middle of next month with a total of $4,500,000, comprising two issues, according to word received here yesterday from W. C. McGonagle, Treasurer of Aawaii.
William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, charged tonight that there were Communists operating the ranks of the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Stockholders of the Spencer Chain Stores, Inc., approved yesterday a change in name to the Spencer Shoe Corporation and authorized the issuance of 60,000 shares of new $20-par cumulative convertible $1.50-dividend preferred stock as well as 120,000 additional common shares, for conversion purposes.

Former State Senator Charles C. Pilgrim of Essex County was elected today as chairman of the Newark Constitution Sesquicentennial Committee, which will function with national and State groups set up for the observance of the anniversary of the adoption of the United States Constitution.

Charles E. Ames of Cold Spring Harbor outsailed six rivals in Egret today to take the first of three races for the national championship of the Atlantic One-Design Class. A raw easterly, heavy with fog and rain, made conditions for the test miserable.

It is reported on good authority that twenty-five Protestant pastors and lay leaders have been released from prison recently. The latest report read from Confessional Synod pulpits indicated that 103 were under arrest.
A woman who for twenty years nursed a brother afflicted with diabetes gave $1,000,000 today for a "never-ending medical war" against the disease in children.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Jean Nash, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Nash of 35 Fifth Avenue and Short Hills, N. J., to John P. Beresford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Percival Beresford of Edgartown, Mass., formerly of Short Hills.

Denouncing Mayor La Guardia as a supporter of President Roosevelt and of the President's unsuccessful attempt to "pack" the United States Supreme Court, the newly formed Republican Committee for Copeland issued last night a statement urging Republicans to vote
Fort Sill, Okla., advanced to the final of the national intercircuit polo championship today by conquering Monmouth County of Eatontown, N. J., 14 to 4, at Oak Brook Field.

Grayson M.-P. Murphy, president of the Kreutoll Realization Company, Ltd., announced yesterday that negotiations for selling for $4,400,000 the company's holdings of $22,000,000 principal amount of Yugoslav Monopolies 6 1/4 per cent bonds had been expected.
Exploiting their well-founded theory that the best defense in the world is a grand offense, the Yankees swung with great fervor today, and, as usual, directly from the floor.

Appointment of Thomas Bayard McCabe, president of the Scott Paper Company of Chester, Pa., as a Class C director of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia was announced yesterday by the governors of the Federal Reserve System.

DEAD END, as adapted by Lillian Hellman from Norman Bel Geddes production of the Sidney Kingsley drama: directed by William Wyler; a Samuel Goldwyn production; released by United Artists. At the Rivoli.
40,000 AGAINST THE ARCTIC, by H. P. Smolka. (Morrow, $3.50.) A first-hand report on Russia's new Arctic Empire.

In the fading remnant of a northeaster, the King's Cup, premier American yachting trophy, was raced for today, and Harold S. Vanderbilt's Ranger, the more than successful America's Cup defender, won it hands down.

Seventeen-year-old Roger Wilcox, national Comet Class ruler from the Richmond County Yacht Club on Staten Island, sailed a fine race today in the first contest of the 1937 national junior sailing championships, staged by the Pleon Yacht Club, to overhaul the defending Vineyard Haven crew on the two leeward legs.
Police and marines are standing by to render assistance if a hurricane strikes here following the hoisting of a storm warning over historic Christians' Fort.
Retail dealers in liquor and beer must pay for their stock within twenty-one days of delivery under a new ruling of the State Liquor Authority.
Japan's Chinese conflict is already being presented to the Germans as another crusade against bolshevism on the same order as General Francisco Franco's war in Spain.
Navarre brigades under the Insurgent General Solonaga entered Torrelavega today, thus cutting the main road from Santander, twelve miles northeast.
A new type of death notice expressing veneration of Adolf Hitler and nationalism is being used in the German press.

Mr. Alfred G. Gardiner, "Alpha of the Plow," that veteran journalist and biographer, tells The Baltimore Sun as news a sad or merry old tale that in one shape or another is recurrent, periodical and probably immortal.

The publication, on Monday, of a summary of the Mandates Commission report to the Council of the League of Nations on the British proposal for partition of Palestine marks a further stage in the development of that program.
The Rev. Cyrus Rosser James, grandson of the Rev. Cyrus Bayse James, one of the founders of the Methodist Church of Virginia, died here last night after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

Recently Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and two of her grandchildren stopped at an antique shop on the Morristown-Mendham road. In front of the place is a large wooden horse, which the children wanted their grandmother to purchase.

The combined rolls of the Emergency Relief Bureau and the Works Progress Administration in this city, which reached a peak of 425,229 cases in February, 1936, now include fewer than 300,000 cases, according to statistics made public yesterday by the two agencies.
If it will stop raining long enough the Giants and Cubs will attempt to do something about the National League pennant race today.

Japan's bombing planes, big guns and war fleet massed their fire early today on the shores of the Woosung and Yangtze Rivers, Shanghai's outlet to the sea, to cover the landings of more reinforcements.

Bide-a-While, the Summer residence of Theodore Marburg, was the scene of a violin recital this afternoon by Miss Margaret Sittig. She was accompanied by Frederick V. Sittig. Among those attending were Miss Frances Coleman, Dr. and Mrs. Walter Damrosch, Mrs. A. Murray Young, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Morgenthau, Dr. and Mrs. William Procter, Mrs. Olga Samaroff Stokowski and Mrs. James Byrne.

The management of the Hudson Terminal Buildings, 30 and 50 Church Street, has replaced 189 of the elevator operators and other service employes who went on strike last Wednesday, Walter F. Brown, chairman of the board of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company, testified yesterday at a hearing before the State Labor Relations Board, 80 Center Street.

The declaration that the Roosevelt Administration will press the fight for the Wage and Hour Bill was made by Robert H. Jackson, Assistant United States Attorney General, in an address today at the opening session of the seventyfourth annual convention of the State Federation of Labor.

Surrogate James A. Foley recognized yesterday the status of five persons claiming to be the nearest of kin to the late Ida E. Wood, widow of Benjamin Wood, publisher of the old New York Daily News, and eliminated the claims of seventy-four others as heirs to her $877,500 estate.
Although the Japanese expect no serious military difficulties in China, undercurrents of uneasiness regarding the present conflict's ultimate economic consequences cannot be concealed.

Japanese forces claimed possession of Kalgan, gateway to Mongolia through the Great Wall of China, and a "potentially decisive" victory tonight on a front stretching 150 miles from the coast across Chahar and Hopeh Provinces.

Joseph J. Nazarre, Commissioner of the Monroe County (Mich.) Circuit Court, accepted yesterday a bid of $2,500,000 made by the Central National Bank of Cleveland for the Newton Steel Company plant at Monroe.

A hold-up gang, which included a woman, held up Gordon Carpenter of Augusta, Ga., partner in an enterprise at a night club, early today and robbed him of $7,500 in cash and two diamond rings worth $1,000.

Homicide squad detectives said yesterday that they had learned the identity of the man who killed Jacob Wender, 57-year-old tailor, in his shop at 1,064 Lexington Avenue Monday, soaked the body in cleaning fluid and set it afire.

Retail buyers from stores in the farm districts are supplying the most active demand at the New York Gift Show running through Friday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, it was indicated yesterday. Local and other Eastern buyers showed some tendency to "tighten up on orders," according to exhibitors. Aggregate volume, however, is holding up to the Chicago show gain, when the average was better than 30 per cent over last year.

Mrs. Walter Draper of the Sugar Hill cottage colony gave a tea today at Pecketts in honor of Mrs. Frank Hogan of Washington, D. C., who is visiting her daughter, Mrs. John W. Guider, at Arden,Littleton.
Harold M. Thomas is with E. P. Frazee Co. The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, has notified holders of Sauda Falls Company, Ltd., of Norway,

The case of Antoine Lembrecht, a German woman who arrived today at Hamburg, Germany, aboard the steamship Caparcona from Rio de Janeiro, whose return has been asked by the Brazilian Foreign Office, has taken a complicated angle because of the disappearance here of a German male associate.
Holders of bonds and preferred and common shares of McCormick's, Ltd., approved today the proposal to merge the company with George Weston, Ltd.

By means of a new device, developed after two years of research by Army Air Corps engineers, a large cargo plane has been landed several times in tests at Wright Field, Dayton, Ohio, under full automatic control, the War Department announced today.
"Gee! I'm glad that's over," said Tommy Farr today when he finished his last workout for his heavyweight championship fight with Joe Louis, whom he meets at the Yankee Stadium on Thursday night.

Herbert E. Wadsworth, Executive Councilor of Maine and president of Wadsworth Woodman, oilcloth manufacturers, died of heart disease in his home here today. He was 69 years old. He had been ill since June.

President Roosevelt denied with "regret" today an appeal presented to him by a group of "job marchers," who asked that the Government reinstate to relief rolls all ousted WPA employes unable to find work.

Apparently undecided on the question of a special session of Congress in November to resume consideration of controversial matters, President Roosevelt today sought the counsel of party leaders in the House and Senate and at the close of business for the day announced that the matter was still under advisement.
Twenty more were injured today in disturbances at Buczacz, Poland, when. the police repulsed peasant strikers who refused to heed the local Governor's exhortations to peace in the market place.

Otto H. Falk, chairman, and Max W. Babb, president, of the AllisChalmers Manufacturing Company, have advised holders of its common stock that the subscription price to the new issue of $25,321,500 of fifteen-year 4 per cent convertible debentures will be 102 and interest accrued to the date on which the new securities will be deliverable, which will be about Sept. 23.
Charles B. Whittemore, former Mayor of Marengo and for twenty years City Attorney, died this morning following an extended illness. His age was 70.
School book covers as an advertising medium will be tested by wheat men this Fall when 5,000,000 covers will be placed in the hands of school children.
Shipping and export firms here have decided not to apply the force majeure clause in their contracts to deliver goods to China. What solution will be sought is not known.

William Crow, residence of A. A. Collings at Cowles Ave and Hillcrest Lane, Rye; E. V. Siedle, broker. William Mapel, at 172 Hillair Circle, Saxon Woods, White, Plains, from United Hospital Fund; Paul L. Kohns, renewal at 155 Locust Ave, Rye, from Mrs. Elizabeth Pugh Dennison; Robert A. Burlen, renewal at 200 Brewster Road, Scarsdale,

The funeral of former Municipal Court Justice Leon Sanders, who died Aug. 18 in San Bernardino, Calif., of pneumonia resulting from injuries sustained in an automobile accident, was held here this afternoon at Temple Beth-El, of which he had been president for sixteen years.

For the second successive day America's track and field invaders scored a sweep of every event they entered in a meet at Viipuri. Fine performances marked all of their four individual victories and one relay triumph.

Rain again canceled the high-goal polo trial matches on Long Island yesterday, leaving tomorrow as the first day when they can be played. If the weather is dry today four games will be contested on Long Island fields tomorrow.
Awards of two four-year scholarships, granted specifically for the first time to a son of an army officer and a navy officer, were announced today by Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.

The Regent, Prince Paul, today received in audience the Minister of the Interior, Father Anton Koroshetz, and the Minister of Transportation, Mehmed Spaho, the latter representing the Moslems in the Cabinet, as well as several other political leaders.

Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church yesterday ordered the 180 sit-down strikers at the plant of H. Anton Bock Co., cigar makers, 1,228 Second Avenue, to show cause on Friday why they should not be restrained from continuing their occupancy of the premises, begun on April 15.
President Roosevelt has approved a bill passed by Congress to permit aliens to re-enlist in the army provided they agree to expedite their naturalization as citizens.
"Waning of the Summer finds the level of business operations throughout Canada being maintained at a stable and satisfactory level," according to the current business summary of the Bank of Montreal.

Wilbur Lawson, 37 years old, of 3,306 Canal Streetm Brooklyn, who told police that he left his home in Hammond; Ind., after reading a magazine article describing New York as "quite the easiest city in which to commit burglary,"

The young blond stowaway who described herself as Mrs. Henry Mollison, divorced wife of an actor when she returned here on Monday as a stowaway on the steamship California was seized with wander lust again early yesterday.

The Newark Bears reverted to peak form tonight to take the second skirmish of the series with the Bisons, 6 to 2. Lefty Tamulis, allowed eight hits to notch his sixteenth triumph of the year and his eighth in a row.

The Elder family came home yesterday from Iran, known in Occidental geographies until recently as Persia. They landed from the French liner Ile de France after an exciting trip by car, train and ship from the far-off town of Hamadan,

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher in training in day secondary other than Junior high schools, In the subjects indicated, be issued, as of Aug. 20, 1937, to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefore:

Fugitive from the Great South Bay fleet, skippered by T. T. Everitt, with W. G. Tuttle as crew, won the first of a series of five races for the Star class Atlantic Coast championship off the Pequot Yacht Club today.

Foggy weather with a drizzling rain and temperatures in the lower 60's continued here yesterday. The Weather Bureau promised that the cool weather would continue today, adding that the drizzle probably would too.

Robert Engert, 10-year-old deaf and dumb boy who became lost in New York City early Sunday morning after he had run off alone to Coney Island, was safe at home here today with his parents, Mr. and Mrs.

A regulation promulgated on Monday by the State Liquor Authority, limiting the period in which wholesalers may extend credit to liquor stores, brought sharp protests yesterday from retail dealers, and will be the subject of a meeting this afternoon of the Metropolitan Council of the New York State Organization of Retail Liquor Dealers Associations, Inc., at which consideration will be given to a proposal to request the Liquor Authority to revise the regulation.

The marriage of Miss Jeanne Ellen Lewis, daughter of Mrs. Rose Marie Lewis of Chicago and Los Angeles and the late Mr. Lewis, to H. Frederick Feinstein, son of P. Feinstein of the Ritz Tower and Woodmere, L. I., took place yesterday morning at Temple B'nai Jeshurin in Newark. N. J.

Frank Converse, 18 years old, was critically wounded yesterday by a policeman who pursued him for several blocks and into a cellar at 559 West 139th Street after the youth had allegedly snatched a pair of trousers from a man returning from a tailor shop.
The first crisis in the United Automobile Workers' convention came today on a report of the credentials committee, and a deep cleavage was revealed among the delegates.

A movement to place the Pan-American Educational Conference on record against war was begun tonight. A pacifist resolution submitted by Professor Amada L. de Becerra of Mexico was approved by the ninth section.

American men's wear advertisers might well adopt some of the humorous copy that appears to be the chief feature of English men's store advertising, Morton Freund, head of the advertising agency that bears his name, remarked here yesterday.

The Republican campaign to take advantage of Democratic discord and score a comeback next year got under way today as party officials from fourteen widely scattered States met with John D. M. Hamilton, their national chairman.

With emphasis shifted from relief to training, the National Youth Administration in this city has made substantial progress in the development of an apprenticeship program for unemployed young men and women, Mark A. McCloskey, regional NYA director, declared yesterday in his second annual report.

Included in the deals in Westchester reported yesterday was the sale of the multi-family house at 8 Longview Avenue, White Plains. An investing client of Samuel Gunn, attorney, purchased the property for cash over a first mortgage of $102,500 at 4 per cent.
Horace K. Devereaux, organizer of the first polo teams ever to play in the Mountain West, died today after a long illness. His age was 78.

Miss Estelle E. Doremus, descendant of one of New York's oldest families, died Monday afternoon at her home in East Orange, N. J., at the age of 77 years. Death was caused by acute appendicitis, with which she had been stricken two days previously.

Serve, Inc., reported yesterday for the three months ended on July 31 a net profit of $2,158,946 after depreciation, bond interest, Federal income and estimated undistributed profits tax and other charges. After dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock, the profit was equal to $1.20 each on 1,781,426 shares of $1-par common stock.
Financial circles are speculating now as to the course which the New York Federal Reserve Bank will follow in considering any change in its discount rate.

Willis Van Devanter, retired Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, paused here today while visiting his native city to say he "would be glad" to continue his public service by accepting an assignment in "some Federal circuit."
The Essex County Republican Committee, meeting here tonight, designated seventeen candidates to run in the primary. The slate follows:

Nine more members of Leningrad factory personnel have been executed on charges of murderous sabotage involving the lives of workers, according to-the Aug. 23 issue of the Leningradskaya Pravda, reaching Moscow today.

MANHATTAN BAERMANN, ANNA HERMINE (Nov. 7, 1936). Gross assets, $76,239; net, $69,045. To Josephine Katzenstein, cousin, life estate in $20,000; Martha Fleisch Weis, cousin, $10,000, personal property and onethird residue; Henry Katzenstein, cousin, life estate in $20,000 and two-thirds

Mrs. Julian S. Myrick gave a dinner and bridge tonight at her home on Apaquogue Road. Mrs. George White Baxter has as her guests at Cherokee Cottage, Mr. ad Mrs. C. Perry Beadleston and Miss Edith Beadleston.

Richard A. Hohfeler has given up his post with the Cavendish Trading Corporation and has been appointed to the management board of the Interstate Department Stores, Inc., it was announced here yesterday.
The Central Bank of Argentina, as financial agent for the Federal Government, has been authorized by Dr. Acevedo, Minister of Finance, to import 1,920,000 ounces of gold, valued at 200,000,000 pesos,

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 23 unless specified: Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, to Annapolis, Aug. 24: Arkansas, New York, Wyoming. At Panama Bay Area: Charleston, Mallard, S-42. 44. 46.
An explosion in the Carolina Aluminum Company's plant killed seven men today and injured four others, one seriously.

Revenues of the electric light and power industry in June amounted to $178,538,700, a gain of 8.9 per cent over revenues of $164,007,200 in the same month last year, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

On the eve of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's visit to London to discuss the Shanghai situation with Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary; Viscount Halifax, Lord President of the Council, and possibly other members of the Cabinet who happen to be in London, the National Council of Labor has issued a manifesto urging the Government. to take the initiative in measures in China to enforce international law and treaty rights.

Monk Meyer, Army's powerful lightweight back; Jim Hauze, burly Pennsylvania center, and numerous additional reinforcements joined the Eastern College All-Stars today for their first workout in preparation for their charity game with the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds the night of Sept. 8.

Miss Caroline Clapp Sherman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Sherman of Hastings-on-Hudson, was married here yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, to Oscar E. Lanford, son of Mrs. Ruth E. Lanford of Louisa County, Va. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. G. E. Reilly and Chaplain Raymond C. Knox.
Traditions founded in Ireland 500 years ago are being renewed in Rochester this week at the four-day State convention of Hibernians, which will map a program for the coming year.

A reported Federal decision that 9 cents a pound would be the basis for loans on this year's cotton crop brought an early decline in prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, October contracts reaching 9.50 cents.

Brenda, a bay filly from the J. B. Gilligan South Orange (N. J.) stable, proved a superior mudder by winning three straight heats in the 3-year-old-and-under pace, the initial race on the four-day program at the eighty-fifth annual Suffolk County Fair, which opened today.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, Republican designee for Controller on the La Guardia ticket, made it clear yesterday that he had no desire to wind up as a running mate of Senator Royal S. Copeland, who is opposing the Mayor for the Republican nomination.

Painstaking efforts to get Lawrence R. Leeby of Washington, a dealer in securities, to answer the questions addressed to him occupied most of the Securities and Exchange Commission's hearing yesterday on stop-order proceedings against the Austin Silver Mining Company.
Dr. John J. Buchanan, nationally known surgeon and one of the founders of the Allegheny County Medical Society, died today. He had been ill a short time. He was 82 years old.

Joe Louis, holder of the world heavyweight crown, and Tommy Farr, British Empire champion, will wage their title struggle tomorrow night in the Yankee Stadium before a crowd that will pay in excess of $300,000, according to the statement yesterday of Promoter Mike Jacobs.

Business failures increased in three groups in the week ended Aug. 19 in comparison with the figures for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc, Manufacturing, wholesale and retail divisions showed sharp increases against a year ago, while construction and commercial service groups' declined slightly.

The number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday fell somewhat below the preceding week and for the corresponding week last year, according to the listings published in THE TIMES.

Pensioned On police surgeon's certificate: SERGEANT--Charles N. Overbeck, 71st Precinct, $1,750 per annum. Appointed Aug. 15, 1917. Transfers and Assignments PATROLMEN--Henry Yost Jr., Motor Cycle Precinct 1, assigned to duty as attendant.

Despite an increase in net earnings from operations, net profits of State banks and trust companies in New Jersey for the six months to June 30 were $1,765,328 less than for the corresponding period last year,
Leonard Gilbert Wilson, last Civil War veteran in Jersey City, died in the Medical Center today after a week's illness. His age was 89.

From 60 to 75 per cent of Far Eastern toys, earthen and chinaware and novelty goods for Fall and holiday selling has already been delivered here, or is en route, on orders placed early this year, but direct importers and chains and other large retailers were concerned yesterday about the receipt of the remainder of the merchandise needed.
Joyce Coles will be premiere danseuse of the Hippodrome Opera Company's new season, which begins Friday and Saturday nights with "Traviata" and "Aida."

Willem H. de Monchy of Rotterdam, managing director of the Holland-America Line, announced plans here yesterday for the construction of five new ships in the next two years, for operation in the North Atlantic trade.

President Roosevelt will leave here Thursday night for his Hyde Park home, and a week later will witness the yacht races of the annual Governor's regatta on Long Island Sound from the Presidential yacht Potomac.

The marriage of Mrs. Anna Christian Auchincloss, former wife of the late Samuel Sloan Auchincloss, to Roderick Don O'Connor of New York, took place at noon today at Tower Cottage, the home of the bride.

Manhattan Alterations 35th St, 30 E; to 4-story furnished rooms; United States Trust Co of N Y, 45 Wall St, owner; S. Walter Katz, architect; cost $6,500. Broadway Terrace, 2; to 6-story tenement; Sadie B. Morgenstern, 1,440 Broadway, owner; I. L. Crausman, architect; cost $3,000.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 15,000, including 5,000 directs. Uneven, 25 to 40 cents lower than Monday's average; top, $12.35; bulk good and choice, 180-230 pounds, $12-$12.30; 240-300 pounds, $11.75-$12: most good packing sows, $104,500; estimated receipts tomorrow, 10,000,

Passenger revenues of the New York Central Railroad in the first seven months of this year were $37,544,804, against $35,090,232 in the same period last year, a gain of about 8 per cent, the company reported yesterday. Freight revenues rose from $143,614,314 to $155,475,283.

Mr. and Mrs. James Willits of the Duck Pond Road colony of this community announced at a luncheon today at the Nassau Country Club the engagement of their only daughter, Miss Florence Elizabeth Willits, to Dr. Henry A. Rusch Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Rusch of Centre Island, Oyster Bay, and 21 East Sixty-sixth Street, New York.
A physician gave his own blood today to save the life of a baby girl found on the doorstep of Frank Trill, a city employee. Dr. Leonard S. Fullerton, realizing the child's critical condition,

Several luncheons were given today before the races. Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart, Mr. and Mrs. Fitz Eugene Dixon and Joseph E. Widener gave small luncheons at the Gideon Putnam and former Supreme Court Justice Norman Staunton Dike and Mrs. Dike gave another at their Summer home.

155th St, 420-26, 3-story and 5-story frame tenements, 75x100; North Side Savings Bank against Pasquale Vitelli;due, $53,466; taxes, etc., $6,743; to plaintiff for $50,000. Webster Ave, 2,089, 4-story tenement, 33.9 x80; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank against Antoinette Orrigo; due, $16,589; to plaintiff for $1,000.

What was reported to be a crucial problem within the Actors Equity Association was suddenly solved yesterday by the appointment of Paul Dullzell to take over the administrative duties of Frank Gillmore, Equity president, on Nov. 1.
Miss Lucie Du Bois, daughter of Mrs. Gertrude VanCortlandt Du Bois, was married to Everett Lee Nichols of Phoenix, Ariz., at noon today at the home here of the bride's mother.

Eager to tour the metropolis, Don Rinkle, an Eskiimo sled dog, slipped away from his master after arriving from. Portland, Me., early yesterday morning. He pattered off confidently through the East Side, but the .new sights and scents proved baffling, and Don Rinkle wound up floundering in Dead Man's Basin at the Battery.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell W. Becton of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Prentiss Becton, to William Lansing Chapman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Chapman, also of Rutherford, and Saybrook, Conn.

A prohibition of Rotary Club membership for National Socialist party members, German officials and soldiers, announced last night, attracted widespread attention today because of the far-reaching implications for the Rotary Clubs and all Germans.

The wheat market on the Board of Trade here fluctuated today in an uncertain manner, advancing 1 1/2 cents a bushel in the early trading on short covering and buying by commission houses which were recently active sellers.

The rapidity with which depositors in the Fort Greene National Bank in Brooklyn, the first national bank for which a receiver has been appointed during the current year, are being paid off was reported today to President- Roosevelt by J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency.

Walls that once echoed the voices of Sarah Bernhardt and Edwin Booth fell today as workmen dismantled the Broad Street Theatre. Within sixty days the site of the historic playhouse is to be a parking lot.

State Senator Clifford R. Powell, candidate for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination, declared here tonight that tolls on motor cars and trucks using the Holland Tunnel and the George Washington Bridge were excessive and that he would seek to have the rates reduced to a "reasonable and fair figure."
Governor Hoffman telegraphed today to Senator Winant Van Winkle of Bergen County an invitation to confer on the latter's request for a special session of the Legislature to change parole procedure.
Eddie McGeever, 136, Scranton, Pa., was awarded the decision over Carl Guggino, 132 3/4, Hartford, in the feature eight-round fight at the New York Coliseum last night before a crowd of 6,500.

The marriage of Miss Juliet Ethel Shaw, daughter of Commander Charles Harlan Shaw, U. S. N. (retired), and Mrs. Shaw of this place, to William Roderic Bliss, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Bliss of Springfield, took place here at noon today in Grace Episcopal Church.
Parliament reassembled today for a short pre-election session, including the delivery of the budget, which Treasurer R. G. Casey will present Friday.

In the three years since enactment of section 77B of the Federal Bankruptcy Act providing for corporate reorganizations, 106 business houses of Massachusetts have been completely reorganized and are now operating under new set-ups which were confirmed by the Federal District Court.

Legislative leaders named a ten-member committee today to recodify New York's insurance laws. The work will be financed under "a certificate of intent" for $7,500, the Senate leader, John J. Dunnigan, a Democrat, and Speaker Oswald D. Heck, a Republican, said in a joint statement.

William H. Hyland, who served on the City Board of Finance and the Board of Park Commissioners for several years, died at his home here yesterday. He was 71 years old. Mr. Hyland was born in Greenwich, Feb. 4, 1866, a son of the late William and Margaret Powers Hyland, and had made his home in Stamford for thirty-six years.

With the Richmond County crew from Staten, Island leading the Pequot Yacht Club trio, champions of Long Island Sound, by one and a quarter points, the New York district appears to have its best chance to capture the coveted Sears Cup for the national junior
The British Government echoed today the appeal made Monday by Secretary of State Cordell Hull of the United States that Japan and China should settle their differences without further bloodshed.

The Shuberts, ever loath to pass a good thing up, have decided to reopen "The Show Is On," the same to occur at the Winter Garden on Monday evening, Sept. 20. Willie and Eugene Howard have been prevailed upon to return to the cast and Chic York and Rose King will be among the principal replacements.

When the chips were down and the stakes highest the Giants, opportunists as they have proved themselves, arose to the occasion yesterday at the Polo Grounds, downed the league-leading Cubs twice and in the space of five hours bounded right back into the thick of the national circuit pennant race.

A unified campaign against gambling in Erie County was pledged to Governor Lehman today by three county law enforcement officials. The three, District Attorney Walter C. Newcomb, Sheriff William M. Eberhardt and Chief of Police

Described by police officials here as "one of the most dangerous men who ever walked the streets of Newark," Julius Malicky, alias Andrew McCrea, 31 years old, was arrested in Irvington today on a charge of criminally assaulting a 15-year-old Newark girl several weeks ago.

The number of air-conditioning units installed in the first seven months of 1937 was 2,734, against 1,816 in the corresponding 1936 period, a gain of 50.55 per cent, the publication Automatic Heat and Air-Conditioning reported yesterday.
A moratorium on debts, directed at the prevention of collection of money for transfer outside the Province, became effective in Alberta today.

Charging breach of contract, Lucius T. Russell, former publisher of The Newark Morning Ledger, a daily newspaper here, filed suit today for $300,00O in State Circuit Court against the present management of the publication.
Following is the text of the statement issued by President Roosevelt upon signing the bill changing procedure in the lower courts:

A strike of all union painters in Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens, Richmond and Nassau County is scheduled to become effective today. Officials of the Brotherhood of Painters and Decorators, an A. F. of L. affiliate, predicted last night that more than 16,000 men would respond to the strike call.

The German takes as naturally to the Rotary idea as the American. Any traveler who happens to strike Stuttgart, Munich, Hanover, almost any German town, on the day red-lettered by the Rotary luncheon can see how the business leaders love to get together.

Another shipment of gold from Japan to the United States, amounting to $5,810,000 and bringing the total of such shipments since March to $141,800,000, was arranged for yesterday, according to reports received by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Scoring six runs in the first two innings, the, Pirates blanked the Bees, 6 to 0, today before 3,500 fans. The biggest factor in the game was the 12-hit attack of the powerful Pirates led by the big stick of Lloyd Waner, center fielder.

Higher costs converted an aggregate increase in gross into a decrease in net for the first eleven railroads to report for July. These railroads reported gross of $68,933,000 in July, against $67,372,000 in July, 1936, a gain of 2.3 per cent.

ABRAHAMS-Esther, wife of the late Abraham, devoted mother of Ray Fresco, Sadie Stoeth, Caroline, Mildred, Samuel and Solomon; Aug. 24. Funeral from her late residence, 813 Eagle Ave., Bronx. Friday, Aug. 27, at 10:30 A. M. ADAMS--On Aug. 25, 1937, at Maplewood, N. J., Harold C. Funeral from the Maxwell Funeral Home, 10 West End Ave., Somerville, N. J., on Friday, Aug. 27, at 2 P.M.
Two days of rain weren't enough, so far as the ill-fated Dodgers are concerned. Forty days might have given them time enough to build at least a raft to float out of the National League cellar.

Informed by the Emergency Relief Bureau that there are no longer any skilled construction workers among the citizens on home relief, the Works Progress Administration was forced yesterday to turn to non-relief sources for 100 mechanics needed to construct a new studio in the Municipal Building for Station WNYC and to complete work on the merchant marine academy building at Fort Schuyler.

The Adjutant General released the following orders today: Retallick, 2d Lieut. George F., having qualified, is placed on duty. He is to report to commanding officer, 174th Inf., for assignment to Headquarters Co. Sullivan, 1st Lieut. Howard Jr., having qualified, is placed on duty. He is to report to commanding officer, 174th Inf., for assignment to Company B.

Buddy Rosar led off the ninth inning with a homer over the left-field wall tonight to break a tie and give the champion Newark Bears a 5-to-4 victory over the Bisons. His circuit clout defeated Bill Harris, who was tagged with two unearned runs that meant the ball game.

The Ludlum Steel Company notified stockholders yesterday of its plan to raise from $2,500,000 to $3,500,000 of additional capital for expansion through the issuance of not more than 125,000 shares of common stock to be offered to present stockholders on a pro rata basis.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Aug. 24 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Miss Virginia Lee Duncan, daughter of Mr. Charles H. Duncan of Pasco, Wash., and the late Mrs. Duncan, was married yesterday to John Becker Lucke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Lucke of New A York, in the Princeton University chapel. Dr. Robert Russell Wicks, dean of the chapel, officiated.

Over the objections of Mayor La Guardia, the Sinking Fund Commission voted yesterday to cut fares in half on the Staten Island ferry line for the benefit of Staten Island residents who come into Manhattan every day.

A story that a Negro woman tenant farmer was chained to a bed in a Mississippi sharecropper cabin was related today by Sheriff H. H. Dogan. Federal authorities investigated peonage charges against the landlord, J. S. Decker, 30, operator of a 200-acre farm near Sumner, Miss.

A storm of protest arose yesterday from artists, illustrators and sympathizers as the result of a decision by the Appellate Division that artists must pay a city sales tax on their work even when it is lent to publishers for reproduction.
Fifty painters and sculptors are represented with 128 items in the annual exhibition of Pittsfield Art League, which was opened this afternoon at the Berkshire Museum here with a tea.

Mrs. Delia E. Sinnott, widow of Christopher Sinnott, for thirty-five years an employee of the New York Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, and mother of Detective William Sinnott, who was wounded in the attempted assassination of President Roosevelt in Miami in 1933, died Monday at her home, 327 Euclid Avenue, Brooklyn, after a short Illness.

Miss Rhoda Reynolds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank V. R. Reynolds of Old Greenwich, will be married on the afternoon of Sept. 11, to Arthur Edward Sutton, son of Mrs. Walter J. Sutton and the late Mr. Sutton of Port Chester, N. Y.

The New York State Labor Relations Board began hearings yesterday at the State Office Building, 80 Center Street, on the complaint of the Retail Employes Union, Local 830, C. I. O., against the Davega-City Radio, Inc.

The Wheeling Steel Corporation declared yesterday an initial quarterly dividend of $1.25 for holders of its $5 preferred stock. A dividend of $1.50 was voted also on the 6 per cent preferred stock. Both dividends are payable on Oct. 1 to stock of record of Sept. 24. On July 1, $1.50 was paid on the 6 per cent stock.

Replying to the demand of William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, that the Maritime Commission recognize the federation's maritime union as the sole representative of Atlantic and Gulf seamen, the National Maritime Union yesterday countered with a demand that the commission ignore the federation as a factor in shipping.

Two months after he won the title, Joe Louis, Detroit's famed Brown Bomber, tonight will defend his world heavyweight championship against Tommy Farr, product of the Welsh coal mines who holds the British Empire crown.

Unqualified opposition to the C. I. O. and equally positive support for the A. F. of L. were expressed yesterday by Senator Royal S. Copeland, who with Tammany and independent Republican support is seeking the Mayoralty nominations of the two major parties,

In the three months ended with June, the Bulova Watch Company and subsidiaries had an estimated net profit of $566,351, after provision for depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, according to a report issued yesterday.

Catherine Hopkins, 48 years old, a domestic, of 122 East Thirtyeighth Street, was arrested yesterday on a charge of stealing a purse from a woman who was kneeling in prayer during funeral services at the Roman Catholic Church of St.

The marriage of Miss Bernice Ruth Willson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay G. Willson of 8,019 Eleventh Avenue, Brooklyn, to Matthew Logan Wilson, son of Mrs John L. Wilson, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Wilson, took place last night in Union Church, Bay Ridge.

Further expansion of retailer interest in the California ready-towear market was indicated here yesterday with the announcement that the four affiliated stores of R. H. Macy Co. will be represented in Los Angeles by Harry and Sidney Arkin, resident buyers of that city.
Queena Mario gave a surprise tea in celebration of the birthday of her sister, Mrs. B. S. Van RensseIaer, who with Mr. Van Rensselaer is visiting Miss Mario at the Aymar Embury House.

The Black bill, to provide for the taking of a census of partial employment, unemployment and occupations, passed the Congress with clarifying and liberalizing amendments on the closing day of the session. Early approval is anticipated, and under the act there will undoubtedly be a voluntary selfregistration of the unemployed.

Bob Feller, his curve ball streaking across'. the outside corner, today struck out sixteen men- one less than the major league record he shares with Jerome (Dizzy) Deanand carried the Indians to an 8-1 victory over the Red Sox.

The Maritime Commission will -not differentiate - between the American Federation of Labor, the Committee for Industrial Organization or any other labor organizations Joseph -P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission, told William Green tonight.

A three-way compact involving the President, the House and the Senate by which Congress was pledged to consider general farm legislation as the first order of business at the next session was among a large batch of bills -made law today by President Roosevelt.

The Westchester County court house, which was ransacked in vain two weeks ago for a Bible, received a supply today, and for the first time in some fifteen years a witness was sworn with his hand on the Scriptures.

Formation of a Center party composed of Liberals and Radicals is predicted as a result of the nomination today of the Sociaist, Colonel Marmaduke Grove, by the Left Wing Popular Front as candidate for the Presidency.

The committee for $6,000,000 of Midland Utilities Company 6 per cent debentures, headed by Melvin L. Emerich, will file today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan of reorganization for the company, which is in bankruptcy.
An issue of $2,000,000 of ten-year 4 per cent collateral trust convertible notes of the LeTourneau Foundation will be offered publicly today by Dean Witter Co. at 103 and accrued interest.

Senator Moore of New'Jersey made public today a letter from John J. Conlin, vice president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which denounced William C. Montrose, an official of Labor's NonPartisan League, as a "radical," affiliated with the communistic movement."

A pair of unranked college tennis players who have been winning laurels all season distinguished themselves in the national doubles championships at the Longwood Cricket Club today as the favored teams came through to the

Commissioners of Coos County, N. H., in which the Brown Company has a large paper manufacture ing plant, adopted today a resolution approving proposed reorganization of the eighty-five-year-old company.
Richard M. Levy announced yesterday his resignation as general merchandise manager of Oppenheim, Collins Co., Brooklyn, a post he has filled for the last four years. No successor has been named.

With 201 policy cases on the calendar for Special Sessions yesterday, James J. Wilson, assistant district attorney, declared in a statement that the policy racket was flourishing widely despite the efforts of "special prosecutors, regular prosecutors, the Mayor and the Police Department."

Cardinal Hayes has completely recovered from his illness and will leave St. Vincent's Hospital this afternoon, his secretary, Mgr. John J. Casey, revealed yesterday. The prelate will go to his residence at Madison Avenue and Fiftieth Street, staying there a few days and possibly returning to St. Joseph's Camp at Monticello, N. Y.
Continued rains caused a postponement of tonight's football game between the College All-Stars and the Philadelphia Eagles of the National League at the Temple Stadium until Friday.

An organization for renomination and re-election of Municipal Court Justice David C. Lewis of the'Fifth Manhattan District was formed last night at a rally at the Bar Association Building 42 West Fortyfourth Street.
Eyewitness accounts of Santander's last hours under Loyalist rule were given tonight by British refugees when they arrived here aboard the British flotilla leader Keith.

Prominent members of the Summer colony who have long taken active interest in the work of the Southampton Fresh Air Home for Crippled Children attended the annual entertainment and exhibition of the children's handicraft this afternoon at the headquarters of the home here.

The Rev. Francis J. Flanigan, who since his ordination by Cardinal Gibbons in 1904 had been pastor of Catholic churches in Washington and Baltimore, died here today, aged 58. It was before going to the Washington pastorate that he marked his twenty-fifth anniversary while serving as pastor of the Church of the Ascension, Halethorpe, near Baltimore, where he was ten years.

Stockholders of the Niagara Hudson Public Service Corporation, which was formed last month as a consolidation of twelve electric and gas companies in Central and Northern New York, will meet on Sept. 15 in Syracuse to approve changing the name of their company to the Central New York Power Corporation and to authorize a new mortgage.

Charle' Gehringer, leading batter of the American League, added six points to his average with a perfect day at the plate, and Rudy York, rookie catcher, continued his home-run hitting today as the Tigers defeated the Athletics, 10 to 4, to take the series, two games to one.
The marriage of Miss Virginia Kelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Kelly of New York and this community, to Luke A. Burke, son of Mrs. Luke A. Burke

Disciplinary troubles aboard the battleship Warspite on June 30 were disclosed tonight with the publication of findings by a naval court of inquiry which recommended that three officers be removed from their posts.

Catherine St, 21, 23x100.2; Paul J. McCauleY, referee, to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; foreclosure; (1.50). Columbia St, 99, 25x75; Rachel Rappaport to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; mtg $5,850 held by grantee ($6.50). Sickles St, 14-28, 200x170 Rhinelander Improvement Co, Charles Kimmelman, president, et al, to Elizabeth Richmond, 560 W 180th St. ($1).
Legislative leaders today started an exhaustive investigation to determine whether New York's parole methods had contributed to the recent wave of sex crimes against children.
Pittsburgh at New York (2)Weaver and Lucas or Brandt vs. Castleman and Melton. St. Louis at Philadelphia (2)Ryba, and Dean vs. Passeau and Mulcahy.
A plot 202 by 145 feet at the northwest corner of Ryer Avenue and East 181st Street, the Bronx, was bought by the Davro Realty Corporation, David Markbreiter, president, from Ida C. Butterworth.

Production of steel ingots this week remains at 83 per cent of capacity, unchanged from last week, The Iron Age Summary reports. This is considered the most important element in the present situation, as there is no evidence that consumers are adding to their steel inventories, but on the contrary are reducing them.

Singer Sewing Machine Company, through Holman Holman, Inc., store in 2,534 Broadway; Forrest Branch, luncheonette. store in 1,141 Broadway; Armstrong Armstrong, broker. New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, Inc, in 118 E 28th St; Robert Altshuler, advertising. in 369 Lexington Ave; Francsica Bolles, art studio. In 118 E 28th St; William Solerwitz, interior decorator,
Sister Veronica Eich, former head of the Home for Aged at Mary J. Drexel Home here, died on Monday in the Mary J. Drexel Deaconess Home following a long illness. She was 80 years old.
Senator Minton of Indiana predicted today that Paul V. McNutt, American High Commissioner to the Philippines, will be nominated by the Democrats in 1940 to succeed President Roosevelt.

A pet show was the feature this afternoon of the Oyster Bay carnival, a five-day fete planned to raise $100,000 for the development of an athletic center in Roosevelt Memorial Park and which was formally opened yesterday by Mrs. frc Edith Kermit Roosevelt.

Behind the scenes at the United Automobile Workers' convention today strong efforts were made to solve amicably the foremost problem confronting the delegates, a breach in the union's ranks which has divided the gathering into two factions.

Asserting that the country is now enjoying nearly as much prosperity as in the ante-panic, days of 1929, Postmaster General Farley, as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, in a wide discussion of political questions, declared today that President Roosevelt was just as popular now as in November, 1936, and could be elected by the same majority.

Stowing away was a "great mistake," the blond young woman who calls herself Mrs. Henry Mollison and who hid on the California for a free ride to London said yesterday in the observation ward of Bellevue Hospital.

Lighthorse Harry Cooper of Chicago, the year's top money-winning golf pro, also heads the race for the Harry Vardon Memorial Trophy, Fred Corcoran, head of the Professional Golfers Association tournament bureau announced tonight.

60th St, 25 W, running through and including 16-22 W 61st St; 12-story brick garage, Central- Savings Bank in the City of New York against Amos R. E. Pinchot; due, $675,281, taxes, , $112; to plaintiff for $10,000.

Threat of a strike of about 250,000 railroad operating department workers was raised today after the managements had refused to meet the employes' demands for a 20 per cent wage increase, or any part of it.
(Canadian Press).

A new policy of booking legitimate theatrical attractions and concerts in the film houses of its circuit "whenever it is convenient" has been announced by the National Thleatre Corporation, a subsidiary of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, through Aubrey of Schenck, local head of the booking department of the firm.

Bernie (Schoolboy) Friedkin, 1301/2, Brownsville, outpointed Rubin Breese, 1371/2, Kansas, in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Carnasie Arena last night. In two sixes, Harry Ginsberg, 1354, Brownsville, knocked out Patsy Sylvestri, 134, Harlem, in 35 seconds of the second chapter, and Bernie Miller, 129, Harlem, defeated Alex Yanez, 137%, Havana.

The Japanese Navy yesterday instituted a partial blockade of Chinese shipping to increase economic pressure on Nanking and show the Chinese people in the whole Shanghai-Nanking area that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's armies are impotent to protect them.

Retired Lieutenant Louis Sleckman, formerly a member of H. L. 34, residing at 5,008 Broadway, died Aug. 22. Funeral will take place from Herlich's Funeral Parlor, 332 E. 86th St., Manhattan, at 2 P. M., Thursday, Aug. 26. Interment at Lutheran Cemetery, Middle Village, L. I.

The National Labor Relations Board today certified the American Radio Telegraphista Association, a C. I. O. affiliate said to have signed agreenments with about fifteen stations, am the exclusive bargaining agency for the radio broadcasting engineers at Radio Station WVIN, New York, operated by the Marcus Loew Booking Agency.

The declared purpose of the FeldCrawford act and the policy of the United States as declared in the Miller-Tydings act would be contradicted if radio manufacturers were not permitted to arrive at maximum allowances for trade-ins,

Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, will leave his government post early next month to become vice president in charge of labor relations of the Radio Corporation of America, it was learned last night.

The decision as to whether Surrogate William J. Sheils of Westchester was elected for a six-year term when he was named to that office two months after the death of Surrogate George A. Slater will be determined by Justice Francis Bergan of the Supreme Court after Sept. 8, it was stated today at the end of a hearing which began three weeks ago.

The bond market settled deeper into the doldrums yesterday as trading on the New York Stock Exchange dwindled to a turnover of $5,803,500, compared with transactions of $6,935,125 on Tuesday. Price movements generally were mixed and, except for a few selected issues, restricted to relatively narrow fluctuations.
Buddy Myer drove in four runs with three singles as Washington won from St. Louis today, 7 to 6, and swept the two-game series.

More than 100,000 targets were thrown today at the Grand American Trapshoot, but after all that shooting no one knew who won the Class AA championship-the day's top honor. The mixup, first in years at the big trapshoot, left it up to the executive committee to decide whether Charles Bogert of Sandusky, Ohio, or Hale C. Jones of Wood River, Ill., was the victor.

Actions to compel the Board of Elections to disqualify two candidates for the Democratic nomination for Assemlyman in the Nineteenth Assembly District and one in the Seventeenth Assembly District and to restore other canadidates for similar nominations to the ballot in the Nineteenth and Ninth

Although the American Federation of Teachers is pursuing a "unity" course designed to prevent an outright'vote by this A. F. of L. group on affiliation with the Committee for Industrial Organization, delegates to its annual convention here will face the issue tomorrow in the election of officers.

Tanks and armored cars of the Insurgent Spanish Army, under bitter machine-gun and rifle fire from hills to the west, moved this afternoon into Santander, the last important seaport in northern Spain of the Madrid-Valencia regime.

The American Water Works and Electric Company, which fought the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 in the courts but finally registered last February, has submitted to the Securities and Exchange Comnmission a voluntary plan to simplify its system so as to meet the requirements of the socalled "death sentence" section of the law.

As a crude study of homicidal mania, Percy Robinson's and Terence De Marney's "Wanted for Murder" fulfilled all that the audience at the Lyceum Theatre usually demands in the way of sensational melodrama.

A proposal of the State Mortgage Commission to raise about $3,800;000 for its expenses through a series of service charges on mortgages which it has administered came under severe attack yesterday before Supretme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler in Supreme Court.
Police added one arrest and one discharge each to the already long records of Abe Reles,

We print on this page today a letter from Stuart A. Rice, chairman of the United States Central Statistical Board, replying to General Johnson's objections to the forthcoming "census" of the unemployed.

A sealed bottle crossed the Atlantic Ocean from Newfoundland to Ireland in slightly less than seven months, E. Thomas Gilliard, ornithologist of the American Museum of Natural History, said yesterday.
Chicago's Catholic Youth Organization boxers conquered South America's amateur champions, 11 bouts to 5, tonight before 45,000 spectators at Soldier Field,
Five Senators and six Representatives sailed for Paris yesterday on the Washington of the United States Lines to attend the thirty-third annual congress of the Interparliamentary Union Sept. 1 to 8.
Stocks closed irregularly lower in dull trading; turnover, 497,310 shares. Bonds irregular; transactions, $5,803,500.

Jersey City gained an even break in the season's series against Toronto, trouncing the Maple Leafs, 10-6, today. Charley Wilson paced the Giants' 14-hit assault on five hurlera, contributing two of his four hits to a seven-run uprising in the sixth inning.

" Black Wednesday," scourge of many a linksman in the past, proved ominous to one of amateur golf's "big three" as Albert W. (Scotty) Campbell of Seattle, former public links champion and previous holder of the Canadian amateur crown, fell by the wayside at the first burst of gunfire as match play started in the national amateur championship today.

Only about 3,000 uniformed patrolmen now are available at any one time to protect the city's 319 square miles of streets and waterfronts, Commissioner Valentine declared yesterday at a hearing before Kenneth Dayton, assistant budget director.

Count Otto Hagenburg of Germany, noted European stunt flier, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa on his first visit to this country to compete in the national air races at Cleveland Sept. 3 to Sept. 6. He was accompanied by the Countess.

Replying to John D. M. Hamilton and other Republican critics, Senator Barkley, the Democratic leader, declared today that there had been "no breakdown in the President's leadership nor In the ability of the Democratic party to work out the nation's great economic and social problems under that leadership.'
With a priest doing a large part of the preparatory work, officials forged ahead today with plans to reopen the war-closed University of Madrid in October.

The War Department released to following orders today, dated Aug. 24. Turner, Lt. Col. E. W., C. A. C., Phillippine Dep't, to 6th Coast Artillery, Ft. Winfield Scott, Calif. Ryan, Chaplain W. J. (Maj.), promoted to grade of lieutenant colonel, with rank from Aug. 24.

Jacob Kaufman and his wife, Ida, proprietors of a pharmacy at 482 Sixth Avenue, were held in $10,000 bail each yesterday by Magistrate Ford in Felony Court on a charge of suspicion of grand larceny after Irving Mendelson, Assistant District Attorney, declared they had been connected by the police with four men accused of having stolen jewelry and clothing from women.

After an absence from the firm of six years, Ruford D. Franklin, for many years a director and department head, has rejoined Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc. When Mr. Franklin resigned in 1931, he took a position with the real estate department of the Manufacturers Trust Company.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Hallen of Monterey Park, Calif., formerly of Balboa, Panama Canal Zone, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Priscilla Hallen, to Charles Pitman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Uriah Pitman of this city.
The Federal grand jury returned indictments today against thirty-four WPA workers in this area for "chiseling" on Government projects.

Trading improved in most classes of fresh meats. Steer cuts were strong to higher and lamb prices steady to slightly higher. Veal and calf cuts were unchanged, while fresh pork cuts were steady to lower. Kosher business has improved considerably over last week and today's early prices were steady to somewhat stronger on all classes, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Knox L. Garvin of Duncan, Okla., an oil operator, died today in Johns Hopkins Hospital, where he had been under treatment for a kidney ailment. He was 46 years old and a member of the Oklahoma State Senate.

The engagement of Miss Marian Gassaway Clark, daugther of Mr. and Mrs. Louis T. Clark of Ellicott City, near Baltimore, to Robert Farnsworth Howard, son of Brig. Gen. Harold Palmer Howard, U. S. A. (retired), of Minneapolis, and Mrs. Howard, ha been ??nnounced.
James. A. Farley, Democratic State and National Chairman, will come out for Jeremiah T. Mahoney for Mayor before. primary day, it was indicated in Washington yesterday.

In France they pride themselves on their sense of measure. The philosophers who fish so disinterestedly in the Seine or read the moldy books they never sell in the near-by bookstalls will explain for hours, to anybody who has time to listen, that only in France is there a remnant of the feeling for proportion, the "nothing too much," that made the Parthenon, the logic of Aristotle, Plato's dream republic.

Perry M. Duncan, New York architect, has obtained first prize in the first annual architects' competition sponsored by House and Garden. Entries were divided into two classes according to size. Class I included houses of seven to ten rooms and Class II houses of six rooms or less.
By withdrawing from the conference with the unions yesterday, the railway managements acted to place the demands for higher wages within the jurisdiction of a Federal mediation board.

Leading from flag fall to finish, Hal Price Headley's Sparta, a 4-year-old St. Germans filly today won the Mary Dyer Handicap by two and a half lengths at Narragansett Park. In second place at the end of the mile and seventy yards was Joe M. Brooks's Boston Mary, who had a length on the favored Chilean invader, Clarence Shockley's Sahri II.

Pennsylvania will use airplanes, cruiser cars and the radio to keep traffic moving safely over the long Labor Day week-end. The planes will sight traffic jams and communicate with broadcasting stations.

The list of the French liner Ile de France, leaving today for Havre via Plymouth, includes Yves Meric de Bellefon, French Consul General in San Francisco; Charles Sawyer, Sidney Alderman, Rene Thery, Andre Thery, Mr. and Mrs. James C. Ames, Gabriel Varvat, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Carron, Mr. and Mrs. Gregory Tobin, Dr. Walter Heil, Graham H. Parker, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Rolland and George Manderveld.

Two dwellings in the retail shopping district of midtown Manhattan will make way for a modern business improvement as the result of the purchase yesterday by Frederick Brown, operator, of a site in East Fifty-fourth Street.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, has announced that under an order of the United States District Court in the proceedings for reorganization of the Prudence-Bonds Corporation holders of first mortgage collateral bonds, eighteenth series, will receive $5 on each $100 of original principal amount of the bonds.

The first definite step toward making the North Beach Municipal Airport in Queens what officials assert will be the finest airport for land and sea planes in the country was taken yesterday by the Board of Estimate when it approved the purchase

Reduction of their rediscount rates from 2 per cent to 11/2, by the Reserve banks of Chicago, Minneapolis and Atlanta, does not mean a lessening commercial use of credit. On the contrary, the Reserve board's explanation indicated, as motive for the change, belief that the season's great agricultural production, coming along with maintenance of industrial activities, would impose much larger requisitions on the banks;

E. T. Lay, manager of the Associated Industries of Florida, said today that "there are good prospects" of a new steamship line starting regular freight service between Cuba and points along the lower eastern seaboard between Charleston and Miami.

Holding charges of irregularity in the proceeding to be unfounded, Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme authorized today the sale by mortgage trustees of the Saxon Woods Hunt Club here to Mrs. Lois B. Wright for $17,500. Mrs. Wright is the wife of Gordon E. Wright, present tenant of the property, which is assessed at $34,000.
After almost two hours of discussion yesterday afternoon, the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange declined to make a decision in the matter of higher commissions.

Four hundred and sixty lots, comprising about twenty-seven acres on the east side of Little Neck Parkway, between Grand Central Parkway and the Long Island Motor Parkway, have been purchased by the Lewis Land Corporation from the Vanderbilt estate.
Commissioner Harnett of the Motor Vehicle Bureau is looking for old automobiles-not used cars,

Because of fog we have landed for the night at Walker Inlet, Prince Patrick Island, after further search for the six missing Russian transpolar fliers headed by Sigismund Levanevsky. We flew as far as Latitude 82.10 North, Longitude 145 West, but clouds prevented our making a close search.
Henry Canby Biddle, member of an old Philadelphia family and head of a wholesale woolen firm, died today at his home, Green Gardens, at St. Davids, after an illness of more than a year. He was 57.

United States authorities perfected plans today for the defense of Americans in Shanghai and, "if the worst comes," for their-complete evacuation. 'Twenty-five hundred Americans remain here, of whom 700 are women.

Movements of Vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 24 unless specified: At Annapolis: Arkansas, New York, Wyoming. At Annapolis Roads, Aug. 25: Claxton Erie, Jacob Jones, Manley, J. Fred Tall bott. At Mare Island Yard: Detroit, Pompano. At Rockland: Downes, Dunlap.
La Verne Moore, alias John Montague, seven years a fugitive from an indictment charging firstdegree robbery, brooded in a cell of the red-brick jail here today-his thirty-second birthday.

Two sensational sprints for scores on three attempts today established Jim Neill, Texas Tech rookie, as one of the best new backs the New York Football Giants have seen in several seasons. Neill broke loose twice in the scrimmage session at the Blue Hill C. C. where the Giants are preparing to meet the Eastern College All-Stars on Sept. 8.

Hunter McDonald, a nationally known civil engineer who for fifty-two years was connected with the Nashville, Chattanooga St. Louis Railway, died last night after an illness of several weeks. His age was 77.
The Youngstown Steel Door Company's directors have recommended to shareholders a two-to-one split of the common stock. The shareholders are to act on the recommendation on Sept. 10.

Mrs. Ray Slater Murphy, wife of Dr. James B. Murphy of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, who fled from Shanghai at the height of one of the battles there, arrived in New York yesterday after a trip across the Pacific by plane and an air dash across the United States.

Miss Fannie Hurst, the novelist, gave a birthday dinner last night for August Heckscher, 89-year-old financier, and Daniel Frohman, 86-year-old play producer, at 7 East Twentieth Street in the restaurant of Billy the Oysterman. There were twenty guests.

Lufthansa, Germany's leading airline, reports from Kabul, Afghanistsn, that its JU32 Danoy, named Rudolf von Thuna, made the first flight over the wild Pamir Mountains, the northeastern range of the Himalayas, en route to the Pacific exploring a new air route to the Far East.

Miss Frances Isabel Tomes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Austen Tomes of this place and Brooklyn, N. Y., has completed plans for her marriage to Paul Sanford Lee Seward of Brooklyn, which will take place here on the afternoon of Sept. 18 in the First Congregational Church.

Since there has been no reason to believe that the long debate over the Supreme Court plan altered the President's position on that issue, there is no reason for surprise that he has chosen an appropriate occasion-his signature of the "Lower Court Bill"-to reaffirm his faith in his own original proposal.

Hugh J. McClearn, a leading lawyer and financier of Duluth, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital after a heart attack suffered several days ago. He was 59 years old. Mr. McClearn was president of the Duluth Glass Block Store Company and of the Duluth Steam Corportion, secretary of the Dewitt Seitz Company and proprietor of the Cascade Hotel.

The Forward Follies, the annual frolic conducted for its children's Free Vacation Fund by The Jewish Daily. Forward, was.,pyresqnted at the Public Theatre last night. As usual, the participants in the variety program, comprising one-acters, song, dance, declamation and xylophone, were pretty nearly a Who's Who of the Yiddish stage, too numerous to mention, the variety being provided by a number of wellknown outlanders from uptown.

Carried away on the running board of her father's motor car, 20month-old 'Odette LeTourneau clung to her perch while her father drove eight miles over bumpy roads and her mother pursued them in a neighbor's car.
The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the following additional applications from New York City for registration as brokers and dealers in the over-thecounter markets:

Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Reynolds of this place have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ann Reynolds, to Stephen William Hamilton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen W. Hamilton of Babylon.

Production of gold in Canada in June amounted to 344,895 ounces, compared with 340,125 in May and 316,670 in June 1936. In the first six months of 1937, Canada produced 1,973,251 ounces of gold compared with 1,767,590 in the same period in 1936.

BRANDT, HENRY (Aug. 15). Estate, $1,600. To Margaret Schmidt, friend, 515 E. 6th St., residue; two minor bequests, Anton Kirn, 514 E. 6th St., executor. DOUGHERTY, KATHERINE (July 10). Estate, less than $5,000. To John Murphy, brother, executor, Chester, N. Y. GOULD, EVERETT W. (Aug. 18). Estate, more than $10,000. To Jessie G. Bird, sister, 161 W. 86th St., $5,000; Frances Cole Gould, Redwood, N. Y., $300 annuity; Katherine L, Gould,

In childhood and youth such is the eagerness for added years that the "going-on" year is proudly named rather than the year that has been passed, or if the latter is mentioned it is but to give a sure footing for the leap into the future. The grammarians have a name for this tense or mood:

Flavel M. Williams, 47, former navy captain and an inventor, was held in county prison tonight in default of $10,000 bail on charges of bigamy and adultery. Williams was arrested early today at his home in Kingston by County Detective John Loughney after a complaint had been filed at the District Attorney's office by Mary Wattsfeld of Brooklyn, who declared she was one of his three wives.

Three hundred Puerto Rican policemen, approximately one-third of the force, who are receiving special training in a thirty-day encampment under "G men" detailed by J. Edgar Hoover and army officers, were inspected today by Governor Blanton Winship and praised by him as the best police force he had ever seen.

A suit in Federal court for $1,000,000 was filed today against the Wrought Iron Range Company, its affiliate, the Southern Malleable Iron Company, and four of their officers by Votaw S. Durbin of Eyansville, Ind., an inventor, who was general superintendent of the Southern company from 1924 to 1936.

George C. Warren of Summit, president of the New Jersey Fish and Game Commission and prominent Yo in Republican politics in the State for many years, will not be a candidate for Governor, it was revealed today by political associates when his nominating petition for member of the Republican State Committee was filed at the court house here.

In the absence of official advices Secretary of State Cordell Hull and other State Department officials expressed no opinions today on the announced blockade of Chinese shipping by Japanese naval forces off much of the coast of China, but it was evident that they viewed the matter seriously in view of its possible implications in relation to the Neutrality Act.

The sixth annual Long Island women's three-day medal play golf championship started today at the Cherry Valley Club, with Mrs. Marion Turpie, defending champion, gaining a great advantage on the field by scoring a fine 38, 41-79.

On their own applications: PATROLMEN--Morris M. Melzak, 7th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed May 23, 1910. Alexander J. Schmidt, 52d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Sept. 22, 1905. August J. Ranft, 92d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum Appointed April 6, 1912.

When realty experts from all parts of the country gather in Pittsburgh two months hence for the convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, they will get for the first time a full picture of the program. to be carried out by a new branch of their organization aiming to emphasize the principles of good design and construction and to reduce residential building costs.
Ranger, the wonder yacht, today wound up her performances off here with an overwhelming victory over the' other America's cup sloops.

A nurse's story of the garrulous reminiscences of a dying old woman, who interspersed recollections of her family's adventurous life with violent biting and scratching attacks upon the nurse, was injected yesterday into Surrogate Foley's attempt to determine which of 542 claimants are entitled to the $877,000 estate left by Mrs. Ida E. Wood.

Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin gave a luncheon today at her cottage for Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Goodwin, Mr. and Mrs. Burton Hart Jackson, Mr. and Mrs. D. Walter Mabee, Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Howard and Robert White.
