Twenty men and four women who were indicted last 'June 23 with thirty-one other defendants as members of a smuggling ring which brought more than $1,000,000 worth of diamonds into this port illegally in the last several years pleaded Guilty yesterday before Federal Judge Murray Hulbert.

The Idaho Power Company, a subsidiary of the Electric Bond and Share Corporation, has filed with the Federal Power Commission an application for authority to issue $18,000,000 of first-mortgage 31/4 per cent bonds due in 1967.

Pending official announcement of the Government's plan for loans on cotton of this year's crop, prices of that staple held within narrow limits yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and ended with losses of 5 to 11 points.

The new French weather ship Carimare took up a position on the transatlantic air route between the Azores Islands and New York yesterday to assist aircraft scheduled to fly the route in the next several weeks, it was reported by radio to Pan American Airways at Port Washington, L. I., yesterday.
Scoring his second straight victory in Egret, Charles E. Ames of Cold Spring Harbor today stood on the threshold of the national championship of the Atlantic OneDesign Class.

Senator Bronson M. Cutting of New Mexico, who died on May 6, 1935, in an airplane crash, left a net estate of $3,299,725, exclusive of his real estate in Washington, D. C., and New Mexico, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. The most valuable assets of the estate were stocks and bonds.

The Rev. Frederik J. Bakker, retired minister of the Seventh Day Baptist Church, died last night at his home here. His age was 95. Born in Rotterdam, Holland, Dec. 2, 1841, he was pastor of the Denominational Church there for eighteen years.
The executive council of the American Federation of Labor, in annual session at the Hotel Ambassador, today moved to force the West Virginia Federation of Labor back under its wing.
A 1 per cent tax on wages in excess of $2,500 a year and on the net profits of businesses was proposed today by Mayor Wilson to avoid an increased real estate tax rate next year.

The purge in the vicinity of Leningrad continues. Today seven important figures of agriculture in that district went on trial at Ostrov, near the Finnish border, on charges of counterrevolutionary efforts to disrupt collective farms.

George W. Lang, a contractor who resided at 191-17 110th Road, Hollis, Queens, suffered a heart attack today while driving to visit friends at Great Neck. He died at the wheel of his car. His age was 34.
Never over par in three days of play, Mrs. Opal Hill of Kansas City,made a heartbreaking exit today from the thirtyseventh annual women's Western golf tournament.

The Cunard White Star Line fired a shot yesterday for which the traveling public and steamship men have been listening for years. As the liner Queen Mary prepared to sail for Channel ports with 1,200 passengers, special policemen emplayed by the line herded two score autograph hunters from the ship and told them to leave the pier.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., heading a group of twenty-seven underwriters, will offer today an issue of $28,900,000 of the Ohio Public Service Company first mortgage 4 per cent bonds, dated Aug. 1, 1937,

The second World Congress of Polish Jews ended tonight after stressing that the condition of the 3,500,000 Jews in Poland was daily growing worse. Anti-Semitism, it was declared, was spreading over all Polish territory, resulting in violence in several towns and villages.

Following the death of Frank Converse, 18 years old, of 66 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, who was wounded Tuesday when he attempted to elude two policemen after he had snatched a pair of trousers, two investigations into the shooting cleared the policemen involvedJohn Music and Herman Faust ef the West 152d Street station.

Two claims for property damages, based on the removal by the village of a 130-year-old oak tree on Myrtle Drive, were denied tonight by the Village Board and Mayor Alfred E. Jordan announced that a third claimant had withdrawn his petition. The three claims totaled $16,000.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Margaret Douglas Gribbel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Griffin Gribbel of this place and Chestnut Hill, Pa., to Cortlandt Van Dyke Hubbard of Philadelphia, son of Mr. and Mrs.

A diplomatic situation of some embarrassment to the National Socialist regime and to the embassies of the three great democratic powers represented here has been solved by a compromise initiated by the recently appointed British Ambassador, Sir Nevile Henderson.

A general plan for the proposed Midtown-Manhattan underpass to link the new Lincoln Tunnel and the Queens-Midtown tube was submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday by Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan.

The eight-room brick Colonial residence at 146 Elderwood Avenue, Pelham Heights, Westchester, has been sold by H. J. Wright to Dr. E. J. Campbell, director of the New York Life Insurance Company, for occupancy. Chauncey B. Griffen was the broker.
Miss Virginia Golden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Eugene Golden of this place, was married here tonight in the chapel of the Munn Avenue Presbyterian Church to Donald Frederick Kent, son of Mr.

Plans have been completed for the wedding of Miss Irene Susan Winslow, daughter of Mrs. Irene Gillespie Winslow and of Dr. Paul V. Winslow of this city, to John J. Campagna, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Campagna of Riverdaleon-Hudson.

Postmaster General Farley cited increased receipts of the Postoffice Department as a barometer of business conditions and an indication of increased prosperity, in a radio ad dress tonight in which he reviewed the progress and accomplishments of the postal service in the last five years.

The combined index of deliveries of rayon woven cloths stands at 148 for July, compared with 154 for June and 151 for July a year ago, according to the compilation based on data from the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., and the National Rayon Weavers Association.

The second important step in the movement which began early this month for downward revision of staple dry goods prices developed yesterday when Riverside and Dan River Cotton Mills announced lower quotations on sheetings, sheets,

The protest of the Honduran Government against the recent issue of a Nicaraguan airmail stamp showing as Nicaraguan territory an area in litigation between the republics was discussed today at a meeting of leaders of the Conservative and Liberal parties.

Ambassador Pictures, Inc., of this city has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for 1,176,000 shares of $1-par capital stock. When the statement becomes effective, 600,000 shares of the stock will be offered to the public by C. B. Ewart Co., Inc., it was announced yesterday.

Charges that the American Guild of Musical Artists, which includes many stars of .the operatic and concert stage, was a company union for the Metropolitan Opera Company were dismissed as "sheer and absolute nonsense" yesterday by Leo Fischer, the guild's executive secretary.

Professor Henry M. Robert Jr., nationally known parliamentarian and teacher of mathematics and economics at the Naval Academy for twenty-one years, died today at his horle here after a long illness. He was the son of the late Brig. Gen. Henry M. Robert, former chief of engineers of the United States Army.

On the application of four foreign corporations which deal in securities, Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson yesterday signed an order requiring the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company to show cause on next Wednesday why it should not be restrained from canceling and satisfying a mortgage and from delivering to the Bethlehem Steel Company the stocks pledged under it.

With the two-month introductory advertising campaign for the new Goodyear "R-1" tire completed, officials of Arthur Kudner, Inc., the company's advertising agency, said yesterday that the results had been "highly gratifying."

Testifying today at the Labor Board's hearing against the Weirton Steel Company Lawrence Wilson declared that a night I superintendent named Ray brought Landon and Knox campaign buttons into the plant and told the workers to wear them.

Mr. John D. McQueen, chairman of the Alabama Democratic Executive Committee, differs with Governor Bibb Graves on a point of chronology. When the Governor appointed his wife Senator he expected that the special primary to nominate a candidate to fill the unexpired term of Mr. Black would be held in February.

Down in New Jersey the boys are again sorting through their fly books and looking over lines in preparation for the Fall trout fishing, which will open for a thirtyday period next Wednesday. Here is one State that takes its trout fishing seriously. Not only seriously, but in numbers.

Seaman Ave., 116-18; 50x85; for 6-story ten.ement; Sam Ruth, 365 East Penn St. Long Beach, L. I., owner; Miller Goldhammer, architects; cost, $110,000. Alterations 3d Ave, 426; to 5-story tenement; Bessie Rosen, premises, owner; Samuel Roth, architect; cost $5,000.

BERGHORN, FREDERICK W. (Sept. 1, 1936). Gross assets, $25,125; net, $23,284. To Madeline K. Berghorn, widow-Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $24,116- Abberley, Bryde, MacFall Amon, attorneys, 42 Broadway. CULLINANE, PATRICK (Dec. 18, 1936). Gross assets, $10,521; net, $8,733.

Close-of-play scores in English county cricket matches started today follow: Hampshire, 371 (Pothecary 79, Creese 61, Aird 60, Herman 56, Partridge four for 75); Northhamptonshire, 10 runs for two wickets; at Bournemouth. Nottinghampshire, 316 (Staples 58, Heane 55, Haristaff 51, Owen-Smith five for 91; Middlesex, 25 runs for no wickets; at Nottingham.

Robert Bell, New Zealand newspaper proprietor and director of the New Zealand Press Association, died here today at the age of 74. He became indisposed during a voyage from South America to London and on his arrival three weeks ago entered a hospital.

An extension of the National Stamping Law for the protection of articles manufactured from gold, silver and platinum was advocated by G. H. Niemeyer, chairman of Vigilance Committee, Inc., at yesterday's session of the annual convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
Winston Churchill has written a book on his contemporaries that has been added to the Putnam Fall list for publication on Nov. 1. He writes of twenty-one men, most of whom he has known.

Applying the criminal provisions of the Securities Act of 1933 for the first time, the Securities and Exchange Commission caused the arrest and detention yesterday of Harry Low, former president of the Trenton Valley Distillers Corporation of Detroit.

General Francisco Franco, the Insurgent leader, in a blunt communique apparently aimed at Great Britain and other neutral powers, threatened today to continue his campaign against ships aiding the Madrid-Valencia Government.

The engagement of Miss Peggy Carry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Charles Carry of this city, to Lewis Hudson Durland 3d, son of Mrs. Lewis H. Durland of Ithaca, N. Y., has been announced by her parents.

At tonight's session of the American Chess Federation's championship tournament Charles Jaffe of New York became the first to win four - straight. He conquered M. C. Stark of Washington in the fourth round.

Flashing a performance that surprised even experienced observers, Sky Larking from the Milky Way Farm today captured the $4,050 Albany Handicap and thrust himself into the forefront of the juvenile championship picture. This colt, a son of blue Larkspur-Risk is a stable-mate to the formidable Tiger who previously had been considered the best colt the West had to show.
B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., and John Nuveen Co. of Chicago obtained yesterday the award of a

Three battleships, a gunboat and six destroyers brought about 1,200 midshipmen back today from Summer practice cruises to Europe and along the Atlantic Coast. The midshipmen making the cruise to Europe left the naval academy June 4, the day after the annual graduation ceremonies.

William Whitfield Rutter, retired banker of South Orange, died here tonight at the Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 68 years old. Mr. Rutter was born in Buffalo, but he began his banking career as an office boy in the Securities Savings Bank of Newark.

" Unfair treatment" of the Irish in the. American histories as usedin publie schools was charged today at the State convention of Hibernians here. 'Patrick J. Walsh, historian, declared the histories failed to show the contribution of the Irish to'. American Government and progress.

The Host, Inc., a restaurant chain, leased from Mrs. Julia C. Hornor the one-story building on a lot 28 by 100 feet at 32 East Twenty-third Street. Stephen B. Haynes and Dwight, Voorhis Perry were the brokers. The tenant, will open its first unit in the building under the supervision of the Childs Company.
Adams Co., Real Estate, Inc., and Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., were co-brokers in the recently reported leasing by Peikin Galleries of the six-story building at 664 Fifth Avenue.

Bryant Ave, 870-880 (10-2761C); Norador Properties, Inc, to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, extends mtg to July 1, 1942, at 5 per cent; $203,000. Jerome Ave (9-2504), w s, 382 ft n e of Anderson Ave, 152x100; 1,001 Jerome Ave Corp to Prudential Insurance Co, 763 Broad St, Newark, N. J.; installments, 5 per cent, building loan $300,000.
The Morrissey reached her farthest point north yesterday at Lat. 78.45 degrees N. Here, David Munsell of Maryland hoisted his State flag only 675 miles from the North Pole.

A special Statutory Court upheld yesterday in a unanimous decision the right of the Interstate Commere Commission to order railroads to stop the practice of furnishing storage facilities to favored shippers at rates that have been termed non-compensatory.

Lt. Col. Frank E. Bonney, 28th Inf., is detailed as a member of Central Marking Committee for purpose of conducting instructions in Command and General Staff Extension Courses for personnel of the 28th Inf., Fort Niagara, N. Y., vice Lt. Col. Hugh B. Keen, 28th Inf., relieved.
Julius Streicher recently received at Nuremberg a delegation of twenty Mosley Fascists from London and urged them to stand firm in "the worldwide battle against the world enemy-the Jews."

COMFINE PUBLISHING CORP., 95 Broad St.-Liabilities $8,191, assets $1,071. GUISEPPE DONADIO, carpenter, 1,228 Commonwealth Ave. -- Liabilities $2,615, no assets. MARY DONADIO, housewife, 1,228 Commonwealth Ave.-Liabilities $2,615, no assets.

Endorsement for re-election of Mayor La Guardia of New York by the convention of the State Federation of Labor appeared probable as a result of moves made today by delegates from New York unions seeking to swing the entire labor movement of the State behind the Mayor.

President Roosevelt gave notice today that he would continue to fight for a "thoroughgoing reformation of our judicial processes" and laid claim to the support of most Americans who, he said, were "restive under the slow and uncertain processes of the law."

The stock market here made a firmer showing today and a cheerful tone prevailed in most sections. One of the best features of the day's trading was the strength of gilt-edge issues while among the foreign loans, Chinese and Japanese bonds rallied.
Captain G. E. T. Eyston, tall 40-year-old British racing motorist, sailed for the United States today on the gamble of his life.

Frank Margulies, 39 years old, who fifteen years ago was well known as a bantamweight boxer, died suddenly of a heart attack while visiting friends at the Hotel Paramount, 235 West Forty-sixth Street, last night.

J. J. Schubert and Fortune Gallo finally succeeded in presenting Sigmund Romberg's "Nina Rosa"-the ninth and penultimate production of the season's schedule of musical comedies and operettas-here tonight on the marine stage in the quiet lagoon of Zach's Bay after a two-day postponement.

Shucks and Jay, the Western Long Island Sound fleet entries, were tied for the lead for the Atlantic Coast Star Class championship after the second of five title races sailed off the Pequot Yacht Club today.

121st St, 228 W, 18x100.11; George Tesla and another to Sarah H. Curran, 28 8th Ave, Brooklyn; p m mtg 4 per cent $3,750. 1st Ave, 1,124-1,128 s e cor 62d St; 71x 131.16; Rose Schmuxmacher to Melville N. Rothschild, 160 No. La Salle St, Chicago, Ill., $12,000.

With a parade this afternoon, the encampment of the United Spanish War Veterans came to a virtual close. Thousands who lined the streets saw members of the auxiliary and other affiliated units march in the procession. New York's contingent was the largest outside of Ohio's.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange adopted yesterday the recommendation of the committee on stock list to list 500,000 shares of common stock of Simonds Saw and Steel Company. The committee on stock list authorized the listing of the following securities:

Turpentine firm, 32 c; sales, 132 barrels; receipts, 454 barrels; shipments, 30 barrels; stock, 37.859 barrels. Resin firm. Sales 507; receipts, 1,406; shipments. 100; stock, 63,891. Quote: B, D, E, $8 F to K. $8.10; N, $8.15; WG, $8.30; WW, X, $8.90.

Contracts for textile supplies for the army were awarded at the quartermaster depot today as follows: Invitation No. 9, for cotton and woolen cloth for the Civiliam Conservation Corps, including the following items: Silesla uniform lining, 26-inch, (1) olive drab, 20,

District Attorney Martin W. Littleton of Nassau County announced-today that the trial of Percy Campbell Reed and Richard Roberts, officers of the Nassau Kennel Club charged with violating the State gambling laws through the operation of a

Three young hold-up men robbed a Brooklyn bookkeeper and her escort of a $3,800 payroll in a halffilled B. M. T. subway car yesterday afternoon and did it so quietly that none of the thirty other passengers saw the robbery occur.

The Japanese plan of advance against the Chinese forces on the outskirts of Shanghai is not a strategy of pushing forward on five or six relatively small fronts from separate landings but rather a welding of their landed units into one great semicircle.
The total foreign trade of Canada during the first half of this year amounted to $907,000,000, exceeding the record of any corresponding period since 1930, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Employment in regular non-agricultural industries in May had reached 34,722,000, a gain of 8,800,000 over March, 1933, the low point of the depression, and only 655,000 below the figure for March, 1929, Secretary Frances Perkins declared at the annual banquet of the Credit

A rather widespread view here of Secretary of State Cordell, Hull's peace appeal to China and Japan is expressed by the Tribune de Geneve. After calling it "another purely platonic gesture" the newspaper continues:

Ray Korndorfer Jr. of Scarsdale, runner-up in the New York State junior championship, fired birdies on the fourteenth and sixteenth holes to tie Wilson Flohr, New Jersey junior champion, for the qualifying medal in the metropolitan junior golf tourney at the Englewood Golf Club today. The leaders were deadlocked at 75.
Naval Cadet William R. Staggs, who aided in the search for Amelia Earhart in the Pacific, has won the $100,000 Old Gold puzzle prize, it was announced yesterday. His present salary is $135 a month.

Harmonica music wafted pleasantly through Central Park last night as the Department of Parks assembled young players from various parts of the city for the finals in a contest that has been going on for five weeks.

Aldermanic President William F. Brunner, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Borough President of Queens, won first place on the primary ballot for that office in the drawing held yesterday in the offices of the Board of Elections in the Municipal Building.

Vast arid regions of this country can be converted into rich, productive farm land by tapping the tremendous reservoirs of water underground, F. W. Lee, chief of the Geophysical Prospecting Section of the United States Geological Survey, declared yesterday at the eighth annual convention of the American Association of Water Well Diggers at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Council of Ministers added further to the cost of living in France today by decreeing an increase in the price of wheat and bread. The decree, to be issued tomorrow, fixes the price of wheat at 180 francs a quintal [220.46 pounds] and provides for future monthly increases.

Earl C. Thompson, former insurance broker here and one of the nine original backers of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh in his non-stop flight to Paris, died shortly before midnight Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 59 years old.

Burlesque theatres now operating or eligible to operate, under ninetyday licenses are by no means certain to have these permits renewed upon expiration, it was indicated yesterday in official circles.

Governor Lehman in a proclamation today calling for the observance of Constitution Day on Sept. 17 declared that when the-instrument, which was signed on that date 150 years ago, was ratified by the several States "the dream of political philosophers became a reality."

A belief that the Hawaiian Islands are "impregnable" to enemy attack and will become even stronger as the army and navy spend more millions in their defense was voiced here yesterday by Governor Joseph Boyd Poindexter of Hawaii.

The fighters who will meet in tonight's bout at Yankee Stadium with the world heavyweight championship at stake and their managers yesterday expressed confidence in victory for their side in statements made for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Joseph Geraldi, French tenor, will make his debut with the Hippodrome Opera Company Saturday evening, Sept. 4, in the title role of "Faust." Helen Enser will be soloist with the Westchester Philharmonic Orchestra, a WPA unit, tonight at Tibbetts Brook Park, Yonkers,
Chief among the dinners given here tonight was that at which Mrs. James Laurens Van Alen was hostess at Wakehurst. She was rejoined by her son and daughter-inlaw, Mr. and Mrs. James H. Van Alen.

Small-bore shooters on the junior ranges today had to fight it out for first honors, and Norman Sawyer, 15, of Queens Village, N. Y., came. through with flying 'colors after shooting off a tie with Richard Johnson, 16, of Plainfield, N. J.,

Five Americans and nine British West Indian Negroes are under arrest at Mayari, Cuba, after their escape in a small motor launch from Great Inagua Island of the Bahamas where a native uprising broke out last Thursday.

The Sixteenth United States Infantry will lose one of its oldest fighting men on Tuesday with the retirement of Sergeant John Bray of Company I, who has served thirty-one years. Now that he will shed his uniform, at 50 years of age, he will seek a job in civilian life.
Polish-German relations are suffering a severe setback because of renewed Nazi repressive measures against Poles in German Upper Silesia and Danzig.

Following the lead of White Plains, the New Rochelle City Council took the first step tonight toward the introduction of a 1 per cent tax on the gross receipts of public utilities. The council set Sept. 10 as the date of the public hearing required before it can pass on the proposal.

The so-called German penetration of Chile's southern provinces threatens to become a political issue as angry arguments involving the Nazi party here, headed by Jorge Gonzalez von Maree, stir Congress.

THE SEVEN WHO FLED, by Frederic Prokosch. (Harper, $2.50.) The Harper Prize Novel for this year. LOOK ELEVEN YEARS YOUNGER, by Gelett Burgess. (Simon Schuster, $1.96.) By the author of "Are You Bromide?"
Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed an increase of 8 per cent for the week ended Aug. 21, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service, Inc.

Warrants for the arrest of two men, one a resident of New York, were issued tonight by Alderman Robert S. Kalback on charges that they aided in the escape from a prison guard in 1936 of Joseph E. Bruno, sentenced to life for his part in the Kelayres massacre in November, 1934.

Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary for his annual leave at home. He said he would return to this country in about two months and denied that he was hurrying home because of any crisis in the Far East situation.

A bit of an actor as well as an amateur magiclan and a very great baseball manager, Marse Joe McCarthy wore his very best frown this morning as his athletes assembled round their breakfast table and the result this afternoon was quite magical.

The force that has been attacking Santander totals 30,000 men and consists of three Italian divisions, two Navarre divisions, two battalions of Moorish regulars and six or seven squadrons of cav alry commanded by General Fidel Davila.

Although the out-of-town patrons for tonight's heavyweight championship fight will in no way compare with those at the Louis-Baer encounter in point of numbers, a fair share of visitors will witness Tommy Farr's attempt to lift the heavyweight championship of the world from Joe Louis.

A special session of the Legislature to consider abolition of the Transit Commission is asked by Newbold Morris, Republican candidate for President of the City Council, in a letter sent to Governor Lehman on Tuesday and made public at the Morris headquarters yesterday.

The crude oil reservoir in the Yates Field, Pecos County, has again been tapped by the Ohio Oil Company for a natural flow of 59,256 barrels daily in one well and 17,355 in a second new well, according to a report to the Oil and Gas Division of the Railroad Commission today.
Santander's fall is hailed tonight throughout Italy as an Italian victory. It has created as much enthusiasm as though it were an episode in a war that Italy was fighting as a nation.

Alfred J. Baffa of this city, superintendent and general manager of the Schenley Products Import Warehouse in New York, died yesterday of a heart attack at his Summer home at Lake Lenape. He was 40 years old.

The increase in electric power production last week was smaller than called for by seasonal and long-term factors and the adjusted index has receded to 108.5 from 109.6. It was 105.8 for the week ended Aug. 22, 1936.

Herman B. Walker, executive secretary of the Newark Teachers Association, labeled as "rather extreme" today the action of the Board of Education here in discontinuing the service of milk in classrooms as a protest against the minimum price set by the New Jersey Board

SOVIET Russia has spent a billion dollars-in rubles-in an attempt to "develop" the Arctic. One-quarter of the Soviet Union's territory has, in effect, been handed over to a "modern socialist equivalent to the East India Company." That territory is one and one-half times the size of England's Indian Empire and is mostly hidden under ice, snow and muck.
Japanese strategists admitted tonight that they were worried about Chinese resistance in North China as their offensive remained without decisive result.
The Board of Tax Appeals reduced to $81,857 today a $386,432 deficiency in 1933 income taxes assessed on William R. Timken of New York City by the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

Lessees of new apartments listed yesterday by brokers showed a preference for locations on the East Side, between the Fifties and the Nineties. A large majority of the suites reported taken are in houses on the side streets within those boundaries.

The Republican supporters of Mayor La Guardia continued yesterday to express confidence that the Mayor would win the Republican mayoralty nomination from Senator Copeland, in the face of the "Public Enemy No. 2"

Wheat prices were erratic within a range of nearly 2 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade here today. They were somewhat higher earlier on the failure of the Liverpool market to fully reflect the weakness in North America late yesterday but weakened
Laurence A. Steinhardt, newly appointed Ambassador to Peru, and Mrs. Steinhardt are sailing tomorrow on the Santa Barbara for Lima, where he will assume his post.

The Japanese freighter Arimasan Maru arrived yesterday morning at Brooklyn, completing her maiden her pier at Thirty-first Street, voyage from Yokohama in 25 days 5 hours and 30 minutes. She carried a full complement of silk, tin and other materials, and had ten passengers.

The grand larceny indictment against Peter F. Colleran, former Mayor of Massapequa Park, L. I., and Frank Cryan and Michael Brady, former officials, growing out of a realty deal, was dismissed yesterday by General Sessions Judge John J. Freschi on consent

The American Woolen Company, largest unit in the woolen and worsted industry, has agreed to a National Labor Relations Board election to determine whether the 10,000 workers in its Lawrence, Mass., mills wish to be represented in collective bargaining by the Textile Workers Organizing Committee of the C. I. O., Sidney Hillman,

As slim as Tommy Farr's chances of defeating Joe Louis may be, betting on the outcome of tonight's fight suddenly has become surprisingly active. Louis, of course, is a top-heavy favorite, being quoted at 1 to 6 and 1 to 7 in most books and as high as 1 to 10 in a few.

Filing of a plan of reorganization for the Norfolk Southern Railroad in the Federal court in Norfolk, Va., was announced here yesterday by a committee for the company's first and refunding 5 per cent bonds of 1961 headed by Carrol M. Shanks,

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 23: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Weber, H. M., Med. Corp, Naval Hospital, Pearl Harbor, T. H., to instruction at the Naval Hospital, Philadelphia, Pa.

Another pedestrian traffic jam was caused last night between 7 and 7:45 o'clock in Broadway between Forty-seventh and Fortyeighth Streets when 250 pickets, marching behind a man carrying an American flag, paraded in front of the Horn Hardart Automat Cafeteria at 1,557 Broadway.

Playing each vagrant puff of a light and variable easterly wind for its full worth, Leonard Romagna, the talented young skipper from Manhasset Bay, gave six rivals in the Meteor Class a sound thrashing in the junior regatta held off the Port Washington Yacht Club today, scoring with his Windward II.

Miss Elsie Reid Stewart, a public school teacher, daughter of the late William H. and Annie Anderson Stewart, died on Monday in the Moses Ludington Hospital, Ticonderoga, N. Y., of a heart attack. She had been vacationing on Lake George. She formerly taught in Public School 41, Brooklyn, and at her death was a teacher in Public School 134 in Hollis.

Adolfo Kay De Lemos, owner of a music store in Newark for fifty years, died yesterday at his home here after a four-year illness. His age was 87. Mr. De Lemos established his store in Newark in 1879, specializing in selling classical music, and it was a meeting place for music teachers, conductors and composers in the North Jersey area.

The exact whereabouts of Charles Zimmy, 46-year-old legless swimmer attempting a non-stop swim from Albany to New York City, was uncertain late tonight. Zimmy reached here this morning, lost six miles to an incoming tide during the afternoon and

For the first time in the history of the New York City school system, recording machines will be used this Fall to test applicants for high school teaching positions, Dr. Joseph K. Van Denburg, chairman of the Board of Examiners, announced yesterday.

George W. Norris, the Alava, Okla., grocer who was convicted of perjury in the aftermath of his attempt to oppose Senator George W. Norris in the 1930 election, will finish a three-month term tomorrow.

Leading from the start, Forrest (Spec) Towns beat out a prize cavalry horse in a 120-yard hurdle race today. The horse Tommy Roberts and the Olympic hurdles champion competed in a field day program at near by Fort Oglethorpe, where Towns is a C. M. T. C. enrollee.

Memories of contests of the old clipper ships were revived today when the two square-riggers Seven Seas and Joseph Conrad started their match race to Bermuda. It smacked of romance and adventure and of the rivalries in the grain and tea trades, and no clouded commerce carriers of old, bound on voyages around Cape Horn, could have received a more watchful send-off.
Two new expeditions for September were announced yesterday by the American Museum of Natural History. Michael Lerner; field associate, will leave today with Mrs. Lerner for the Cassiar Mountains

Roxie Lawson batted in the ninth-inning run that gave him his sixteenth victory of the season and the Detroit Tigers a 6-to-5 triumph over the Boston Red Sox today. Hank Greenberg got his twentyeighth home run in the fifth inning with two Tigers on the paths. Eric McNair hit a homer for Boston with two on in the seventh.
The Spanish ship Motomar, now on the way from Veracruz loaded with guns and ammunition for the Valencia Government, is to be drydocked in the naval dockyard here toward the end of September.

During the week ended Aug. 25 member bank reserve balances decreased $14,000,000. The reduction in member bank reserves resulted from increases of $16,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and $5,000,0000 in Treasury deposits with the Federal Reserve Banks, offset in part by decreases of $5,000,000 in money in circulation and $3,000,000 in Treasury cash other than inactive gold.

A divorce was granted today at Carson City to Mrs. Marie Vandeputte Barzin from Leon Barzin, director of the Minneapolis Symphony last Winter. The grounds were "cruelty." An agreement was reached as to support and custody of their

A hold-up man who used a sign language to order his victims about escaped yesterday morning after obtaining $700 at pistol point from two women employes in the cashier's office of the Long Island College Hospital, Henry and Pacific Streets, Brooklyn.

The marriage of Miss Helen Anderson of New York, daughter of the late Colonel and Mrs. Henry Warren Anderson of Exeter, N. H., to W. Gordon Dean of Sanford, Fla., son of Simpson Bobo Dean of Miami and the late Mrs. Dean, took place here this afternoon at the home of Mrs. William L. Donnelly.

Mr. and Mrs. Edmund C. Lynch gave a dinner tonight at Lyndune, their place on the ocean, for Mr. and Mrs. Cuthbert Stewart of London and George Fowler of Havana, who have joined them for a visit. Earlier in the day Mrs. Charles Edward Merrill entertained at a luncheon at the Orchard for Mr. and Mrs. Lynch and their guests.

In reducing its official rediscount rate yesterday afternoon from 1 1/2 to 1 per cent, the New York Reserve Bank fixed not only the lowest rate in its history, but the lowest ever established by any of the world's central banks.

Thinking in terms of automatic industrial control is having a profound effect upon the chemical industry and a special branch of chemical science is being created which will be made the basis of a symposium to be held by the American Chemical Society in Rochester from Sept. 6 to 10, it was announced yesterday by Charles A. Thomas, director of the Thomas Hochwalt Laboratories, the research division of the Monsanto Chemical Company.

Reduction of the commutation and vehicular fares on the Staten Island ferries by the Sinking Fund Commission on Wednesday was "a scandalous appeal to sectionalism" and "an outright bid for Staten Island votes at the .expense of the rest of the city,

Miss Nancy Grey MacDonald, only daughter of Mrs. Heber Dowling MacDonald of 82 West Twelfth Street and the late Mr. MacDonald, was married yesterday morning in St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church, 110 East Twelfth Street, to William Jordan 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Jordan Jr. of Margate, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas McCarthy.

The Public Service Corporation of Texas, Fort Worth, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a declaration with respect to its assumption of liability for a demand note of $56,234 of its subsidiary, the Mobeetic Gas Company, in connection with the acquisition of the assets of the subsidiary.

The Annalist index of wholesale commodity prices broke away in the week ended on Tuesday from the plateau on which it had been for two months, under the weight of lower wheat, cotton and hog prices, and declined to 93.7 from 94.6 (revised) on the Tuesday previous.
Jay of the Western Long Island Sound fleet took the lead for the Atlantic Coast Star Class championship today by winning the third in a series of five races off the Pequot Yacht Club.

THAT was a stunning blow struck by Jimmy the Red Ripple at the Polo Grounds the other day. Fervid Giant fans believe that the effect will be felt as late as October. It's their opinion that Ripple's grand slam put the Cubs in the barrel for the season and the Giants on the road to another pennant.

Three hundred persons are expected to attend the annual bridge and dance to be given by the Huntington section of the Smith College Club of Long Island at the Crescent Athletic Club here tomorrow evening.

The recent meeting of Premier George Tatarescu of Rumania and Premier Milan Hodza is reported to have been satisfactory to both parties as far as it concerned the rearmament of the Rumanian Army by Czechoslovak industry.

The Beech Creek Railroad Company, the Beech Creek Extension Railroad Company and the New York Central Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to abandon 17.21 miles of railroad in Pennsylvania.

The strip tease charges made during a National Labor Relations Board hearing on alleged Wagner act violations by the Clover Fork Coal Company were made the basis today of a $50,000 suit against the board in Circuit Court.
News of the wounding of Sir Hughe Knachtbull-Hugessen, the British Ambassador to China, was received with regret by State Department officials. some of whom know him.
Hard-hit transpacific ship operators have adopted a policy of watchful waiting here since the intensification of hostilities in the Orient.

Painting and decorating jobs throughout Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and Nassau Counties were brought to a standstill yesterday as nearly 15,000 members of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, an A. F. of L. affiliate, went on strike for more pay.

A net rise of $10,000,000 in the total of their loans and investments, resulting from a gain of $15,000,000 in loans and a drop of $5,000,000 in investments, was rereported for the week ended on Wednesday by member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City in their condition statement, published yesterday.

After spending two days in jail, La Verne Moore, alias John Montague, was freed by Supreme Court Justice Brewster this afternoon under $25,000 bail. Moore said he would leave at once to visit his ill mother in Syracuse, but as it turned out, instead of rushing off to Syracuse he was driven to Otsu, home of Otto Kruger, the actor, in Elizabethtown, where he was hailed as a guest at a cocktail party.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, told the United Automobile Workers Union convention today that there would be no peace between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization until the federation conceded the principle that there must be industrial organization in the mass-production industries.

That some international action should be agreed upon providing for armed measures or other restraints to prevent irresponsible Chinese aerial bombing and the killing of helpless civilians in Shanghai's International Settlement and the French Concession is the consensus of foreign consular, naval and military officials in Shanghai.

Charles Zimmy, 40-year-old legless swimmer, started the second half of his 155-mile attempted non-stop swim from Albany to New York tonight. After battling heavy running incoming tides for five hours, the New Yorker passed under the Mid Hudson Bridge, about the halfway point between Albany and New York, at 8:21 P.M. daylight saving time. An hour later he was reported two miles farther downstream, swimming well with the tide.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reduced its rediscount rate yesterday from 1 1/2 percent to 1 per cent, thereby establishing the lowest charge for loans to its member banks ever posted by any central bank, here or abroad.

Final arrangements ha-re been announced for the fourth annual convention of the National Security Traders Association, to be held in Atlantic City and Philadelphia on Sept. 8, 9, 10 and 11. Headquarters of the convention will be in the Hotel Traymore in the former city, with the auxiliary headquarters in the Hotel Claridge.

The executive council of the American Federation of Labor, in annual session at the Hotel Ambassador, hopes to be able to announce tomorrow its policy to be followed in future dealings with the martime situation on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts.

Miss Elizabeth Parsells was hostess at the annual dinner in honor of the children and young people of the Mount Washington Hotel tonight. Miss Parsells entertained after dinner at the Ballroom Theatre, where they saw "Saratoga," Jean Harlow's last film.

The Department of Plant and Structures, which will become the Department of Public Works on Jan. 1 under the new city charter, submitted to Assistant Budget Director Kenneth Dayton yesterday a 1938 budget request for $2,840,047 less than it was allotted in 1937.
Fog and rain caused such heavy congestion of airplane traffic at Newark Airport yesterday afternoon that two planes had to be landed at Floyd Bennett Field while another was grounded at Camden, N. J.

The engagement of Miss Dorothy Alix Searle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander H. Searle of Greenwich, to John Carroll Caldwell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Sleeper Caldwell of Island Falls, Me., has been announced. The wedding will take place in the Spring.

At a meeting of Summer and permanent residents of the Berkshire communities held yesterday afternoon at the Stockbridge, Mass., home of Miss Mabel Choate, daughter of the late Joseph H. Choate, Ambassador to the Court of St. James, it was revealed that about $30,000 has been raised toward the erection of a permanent shelter for the concerts of the Berkshire Symphonic Festival. A campaign for $100,000 is now in progress.

The marriage of Miss Mary Babcock Smith, daughter of Mrs. Edmund Beardslee Smith of Los Angeles, to Kyrill Sidney Schabert of this city, son of Baroness Faber de Faur of Florence and of the late Paul Schabert, took place here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Church of the Intercession. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Roger A. Walker of Pikesville, Md.

International complications over the wounding of the British Ambassador to China, coupled with apprehension over the consequences of the Japanese blockade of the China coast, jarred Manila today from its normal complacency by the realization that the Sino-Japanese conflict may be brought to Philippine shores.

Indignant artists, illustrators and publishers united their forces yesterday in preparation for a concerted legal attack on the recently made known decision of the Appellate Division that artists must pay a city sales tax on their work even when it is lent to publishers for reproduction.

Several hundred persons ignored a steady drizzle last night to occupy wet benches in Washington Square and hear musical presentations by aspirants in the Manhattan finals of the barber-shop quartet and hillbilly contests arranged by the city Park Department.
" And All the King's Men: Roosevelt.and After," is to be the title of Stanley High's new book, now scheduled for publication by Harpers on Oct. 20.
The British Government today sent General Francisco Franco a firmly worded warning that further attacks on British shipping in the Mediterranean would not be tolerated.

The New York Stock Exchange committee on admissions will ballot on Sept. 9 on proposals to transfer the membership of Herbert L. Jones to William J. Denman, who will become a general partner of Graves, Banning Co.;
The Coast Guard said today that aviators in the Eastern States probably were the senders of radio signals which were reported as possible distress calls from Amelia Earhart.
The police today discovered an arms smuggling gang engaged in traffic to Spain and arrested two Frenchmen and three Spaniards involved.

The village of Sag Harbor has leased to the Sag Harbor Guild, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Bulova Watch Company, a portion of the second floor of the local watch case factory occupied until six years ago by Joseph Fahys Co., the owners of the plant,
A medical referee's report of "accidental drowning" today wrote an end to the career of M. Leone Bracker, 52, artist whose World War posters were shown to millions.

Delays and discontinuance of specific and contemplated programs of expansion have resulted from the fact that capital goods expenditures have been rendered prohibitive in cost, the National Association of Manufacturers declared yesterday in a ninety-ninepage survey on the practical effects of the undistributed profits tax submitted to the Treasury Department.

The faded pages of a letter written in strict confidence to a Catholic priest fifty years ago disclosed yesterday another secret in the mysterious life of Mrs. Ida E. Wood, the belle of Civil War days, who died. an aged and wealthy recluse in 1932.
Sir Hughe Montgomery Knatchbull-Hugessen, British Ambassador to China, lies today in the Country, Hospital here critically wounded by machine-gun bullets that struck his spine and liver.

The engagement of $665,000 gold in India for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The price of gold bullion in London continued at a slight premium over New York shipping parity so that engagements in that quarter again were unprofitable.

Mayor La Guardia will campaign for the Republican nomination for Mayor, and will not give the appearance of letting it go by default to Royal S. Copeland, it was said yesterday by close friends of the Mayor.
President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Mrs. Roosevelt are expected to attend the first concert to be given Sept. 5 at the Little Theatre at Saratoga, opening a music festival sponsored by the State.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the Year to date.

The fifth Fall season of the New York Hippodrome Opera Company will begin tonight with a performance of Verdi's "La Traviata." The cast will include Norina Greco, soprano, who has not been heard under these auspices; Lawrence Power and Mario Cozzi. Eugene Plotnikoff will conduct.

Mr. and Mrs. Roger W. Cutler opened their Bellevue Avenue home this afternoon for a tea, reception and fashion show at which more than 300 colonists had an opportunity to view for the first time an advance exhibition of what is to be worn this Fall and Winter in day dresses for the country and town, dinner dresses and evening gowns.
W. E. Page of Columbus, Ga., newspaper publisher and former Collector of Internal Revenue for Georgia, was killed today in an automobile accident near Camilla.

Norman Sawyer, 15, Queens Village, N. Y., shot his way to the top again today in the Junior Rifle Corps small-bore matches when he took the group A, three-position match, with a total of 287 out of a possible 300.

After rising irregularly since early July,- business in the Pittsburgh district showed a severe setback last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The bureau's general index of business, adjusted for the usual seasonal changes, fell from 121.1 per cent of the 1923-25 average in the week ended Aug. 14 to 117.8 per cent last week.

Robert E. Kennedy of New York has been elected president and general manager of the recently organized American Bowling and Billiard Corporation, a manufacturing and merchandising firm at 50 West Seventeenth Street.

Flat rejection of Nazi support in his campaign to win the Republican and Democratic Mayoralty nominations was announced yesterday by Senator Royal S. Copeland. He will not accept the support of followers of any alien doctrine, the Senator declared.
Sammie, the Man o' War colt named for Samuel D. Riddle, owner of Man o' War, scored handsomely for Joseph E. Widener in the thirty-fifth Huron Handicap today.
Accentuated by a fresh break in United States Government issues, the decline in bond values spread over a broad list in heavier trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Lombardo Toledano, General Secretary of the Mexican Labor Federation, said today that proof of anti-Government activities that he denounced recently in the workers' convention was contained in a leaflet against President Lazaro Cardenas, which was part of the alleged Fascist propaganda that has been widely circulated in Northern Mexico.

J. P. Morgan Co., as sinking fund agents, have notified holders of New York Central Railroad Company's ten-year 3 3/4 per cent bonds, due on April 1, 1946, that $475,000 of these bonds have been drawn by lot for redemption out of the sinking fund on Oct. 1, at par.

The Rev. Dr. Llewellyn L. Henson, retired Baptist minister, died at his home here last night at the age of 75. Dr. Henson, a former missionary, served as a Y. M. C. A. secretary in Cannes, France, during the World War.,

In the fiscal year ended on July 31, 1,074;000 bales of raw cotton were landed on the docks at Manchester, England, establishing a new high record for cotton importations to that port, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Prince Fumimaro Konoe, .the Premier, in a press interview today said that further moves by foreign powers in connection with the Chinese conflict were probable, but"Japan does not attach much importance to those moves, which come from lack of proper understanding of Japan's policy."
That world employment is almost up to the point where it was when the depression began is indicated in figures published today by the International Labor Office in its yearbook of labor statistics.

Judge Robert E. Lamberton, in Court of Common Pleas, dismissed as lacking "a valid cause of action today, a bill of-complaint against four of seven defendants named in a suit based on alleged undistributed earnings of $13,600,000 of the Philadelphia Inquirer during the time the newspaper was under control of the Elverson family.

A plan of reorganization for the Midland Utilities Company, which has been in reorganization proceedings under the Federal Bankruptcy Act since 1934, has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the committee of holders of the company's 6 per cent, Series A, gold debentures.

Tenacity is an English characteristic much admired, but there are cases. in which it may be carried too far. Some time in the reign of Edward I, who died 630 years ago, he swiped certain documents of the twelfth and thirteenth centuries precious to the history of Scotland, royal and ecclesiastical.

LIKE certain other novelists of whom we have heard, Thornton Wilder for one, Frederic Prokosch, versatile son of a Yale professor, is able to say little in a highly distinguished manner. This doesn't mean that little he says is highly distinguished; quite the opposite.

Nation-wide advertising and promotion campaigns for three food products, lamb, apples and tea, will be undertaken this Fall by various organized retail groups, the National Association of Retail Grocers announced yesterday.

Retail sales of new passenger automobiles in July, according to preliminary figures made public today by the Department of Commerce, were 5 per cent above July, 1936, and about 39 per cent greater than in July, 1935.
Trade authorities said today that the nation may buy more in foreign markets than it sells during 1937, chalking up its first unfavorable trade balance in forty-four years.

A building service strike in the Professional Building, 2,021 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, which houses a hospital, was threatened yesterday by Local 32 E of the Building Service Employes International Union in a telegram to Mayor La Guardia. The Mayor was asked by the union to intercede and-prevent the walkout.

The report of Sears, Roebuck Co. for the twenty-four weeks ended on July 16, last, announced yesterday, showed a net profit of $15,190,441 after depreciation, interest, special reserves contribution to employes' savings and profit-sharing fund, and Federal normal income taxes.

Faithful Mary, erstwhile archangel of Father Divine's cult in Harlem, made her debut in the realm of literature yesterday as author and publisher of "'God' He's Just a Natural Man." The book is not only the story of her own life but an expos of "that man Divine's Heaven"-she does not call him God any more.

Maxwell E. Bublitz of Fort Lee, N, ., has sold to the Ascione Motor Sales and Service, Inc., the one-story auto showroom and garage covering a plot 72 by 182 at 3,885 89th Boulevard, North Bergen, for an indicated consideration of $39,000. The buyer gave back in part payment a purchase money mortgage for $34,750, due Sept. 1, 1947, at 5 per cent.

The Catholic Church and the Quebec Government intervened today to prevent the twenty-five day strike of 10,000 Quebec textile workers from developing into the race, religious and political struggle which it threatened to become.

A hearing on charges of insubordination on the part of the crew of the Seatrain liners Havana and New York, based on the alleged refusal of the crews to take the ships to sea on the order of their masters, was opened yesterday morning by the Department of Commerce at the Federal Building, 45 Broadway.

Doubles by Luke Appling and Tony Piet gave the White Sox a ninth-inning 4-to-3 triumph over the Senators in the first game of the series today. More than 4,000 fans saw Vernon Kennedy score his tenth victory of the season, although yielding ten hits.

Jean Harlow, whose earnings were $4,000 a week when she died at the height of her film career, left only $41,000. That estimate of the estate was made today when her mother, Mrs. Jean Harlow Bello, asked to be made administratrix. Mrs. Bello, whose daughter died June 7 after a brief illness, said the actress left a small amount of cash, three automobiles, some jewelry and a few heirlooms.

With a $500,000 revolving fund at its disposal, the Tenement House Department is preparing to proceed at once on a broad scale to make improvements in old tenements which do not meet the requirements of the Multiple Dwelling Law with respect to fire prevention and sanitation.

Strengthening of installment credit terms which began some months ago in the automobile trade is now being felt in the appliance field, John R. Walker, executive vice president of the National Association of Sales Finance Companies, declared in a statement issued here today.

The marriage of Miss Laura Caroline Dahlen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Dahlen of this place, to the Rev. Albert Louis Neibacher will take place on Sept. 28 at St. Luke's Lutheran Church in New York City.

The extent to which larger expenses recently have offset increased revenues was emphasized by the statements of the first twenty-five railroads to report for July. These companies had an aggregate net operating income of $28,098,000 last month, against $32,621,000 in July, 1936, a decline of 13.8 per cent, and against $16,374,000 in July, 1935, an increase of 71.6 per cent.
Covering a distance of 2,300 miles, if we get back to Coppermine today, with the wings of our plane intermittently covered
Acting Chairman Cannon of the House Appropriations Committee predicted today a balanced budget next year through reduction of all appropriations.

Stephen G. Crabb, photographer, baritone and officer of fraternal organizations, died today at his home after an illness of more than a year. He was born in this city sixty-eight years ago and was for many years a partner in the Phelps Photographic Company.

United Spanish War Veteran delegates, at the final session of their encampment today, adopted a resolution denouncing communism, nazism and socialism, and took a stand against Secretary Perkins. The immigration-policy measure was adopted almost unanimously, despite the protests of A. P. Entenza of Los Angeles, past national commander in chief.

Italy is still be flagged from one end to the other for the "great Italian victory" of Santander. It is now revealed that four Italian divisions probably aggregating more than 40,000 men participated in the battle and bore the brunt of the fighting.
James L. Houghteling of Chicago was sworn in today as Commissioner General of Immigration and Naturalization, succeeding the late Colonel Daniel W. McCormack.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. M. McCready have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret McCready, to Leonard R. Penton of New York and London, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Walter George Penton of London.

Mervyn Rathborne, secretary of the C. I. O. maritime committee, announced yesterday that twentyone delegates from seamen's and fishermen's unions would meet Monday at the Capitol Building, Chicago, to draft plans for the organization of a national federation of seamen.

An effort to prevent injury to a dog put Dian Manners, screen actress, in a hospital today with a broken arm. Miss Manners was posing for still pictures with an Afghan hound when a huge arc light was knocked over. Fearing the dog might be injured, she threw herself in front of him.

Delegates to the State convention of the Ancient Order of Hibernians tonight by resolution requested ExJustice Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Mayoralty candidate in New York, to stop using the term "mick" in his campaign speeches.

Patrick J. Hurley, Secretary of War in the Hoover Administration, today was quoted by The Boston American as saying: "Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. has the opportunity to become the youngest President the United States has ever had."
Renting agents of apartment houses on the upper West Side and Washington Heights announced yesterday several additions to their tenant rosters.

The Communist party came out officially yesterday for the re-election of Mayor La Guardia and pledged its support to him. The party's stand was announced by Earl Browder, Communist candidate for President in the last election, and was confirmed in a formal statement issued by Israel Amter, State chairman of the party.
Rumors were current tonight in the Rumanian capital that Nicholas Brana, formerly Prince Nicholas, the brother of King Carol, had suddenly returned to his country last night.

Mrs. Marion Turpie, defending champion, today added an 83 to her 79 of yesterday for a thirty-six-hole total of 162 and a lead of six strokes in the Long Island women's threeday medal play golf championship at Cherry Valley.
The members of the Department Band shall be directed to report. in full uniform, to Captain Julius A. Unrath at Station WNYC. Municipal Building, Manhattan, at 5 P. M., Saturday, Aug. 28.
Forces which have reduced the price of cotton about $15 a bale in two months were outlined today in a study of the cotton situation issued by the Department of Agriculture.

Deputy Petrescu, a member of the radical Peasant party, questioned the Government today regarding the recent statement by the Rumanian Orthodox Patriarch Miron Christea, attacking Jews and urging that they be made to leave the country because they are "corrupting the nation's morals." M.
How ten Nationalists conspired to take the life of United States District Judge Robert A. Cooper on June 8 was told late today in a sworn statement by Jesus Casellas Torres, one of the conspirators.

Engineering construction awards in the week ended yesterday reached a total of $37,338,000, which represented a drop of 22 per cent under the 1936 week, when the figure was $47,710,000, according to The Engineering News-Record.
The two-family stucco dwelling at 421 Beach Thirty-eighth Street, Edgemere, L. I., has been sold by Clark-Robinson Co. to H. Taub for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $2,250.

The Rev. Joseph H. Borgmann of Saratoga, N. Y., died of a heart attack at St. Peter's rectory here tonight. His age was 76. He was in St. John to join in honoring the Rev. James Woods on the fiftieth anniversary of. the latter's membership in the Redemptorist order.

Forty new designs in Fall lingerie were presented in a fashion show held yesterday at the showrooms of Lande Misken, Inc., manufacturers of Yolande lingerie. The showing, attended by more than 100 fashion writers, was preceded by a motion picture explaining Puerto Rican methods of manufacture.

Plans have been completed by Miss Ruth A. Gomery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Gomery of Overbrook, for her marriage to John M. Mackie of Englewood, N. J. The wedding will take place on Sept. 11 in the Memorial Church of St. Paul, Overbrook.

A sweeping reduction in the number of August sales of cloth coats next year was predicted in nerchandising circles here yesterday as the result of the disappointment experienced by many retailers with these promotions this year.

Japanese naval authorities threatened today to include American and other foreign shipping in the 800-mile blockade of China's seacoast established by Japan as a stringent measure to relieve the pressure on her embattled land troops in the Shanghai area.
The poet's spirit does not lie beside The mangled flesh. Within the trembling heart Beauty and Truth still passionately abide, Though some machine has torn the body apart.

The Chinese Government in an official announcement today charged that the Japanese Army used gas bombs in attacking Nankow Pass yesterday, The Japanese have bee trying to force their way through the pass, thirty miles from Peiping, for several weeks.

Eighty women pickets participated in a protest yesterday against the 1-cent-a-quart increase in the price of milk at the offices of the Sheffield Farms Company, 524 West Fifty-seventh Street, and at the Borden Company's offices, 110 Hudson Street.
Although so far the news has been published only in the relatively obscure Rheinische-Westfaelische Zeitung, German embassies, legations and consulates in the future will have "cultural attaches."

Andrew W. Wellon's art collection will form a memorial to him such as few men in this country have created. His discriminating taste and vast fortune enabled him to form a collection of masterpieces of past centuries now so rare as to discourage less affluent and persistent men.

Government troops swept to within four miles of heavily fortified Saragossa, the Ministry of National Defense announced tonight, in a continuation of their Aragon offensive. Crack troops moved from the north and south to squeeze the city, provincial capital and one-time capital of the old kingdom of Aragon.

A mortgage to secure a loan of $250,000 to permit immediate operation of the Penn Anthracite mines in Lackawanna County was authorized yesterday by Federal Judge Murray Hulbert, on the application of Frederick E. Lyford, trustee for the New York, Ontario Western Railway Company, which is being reorganized.
A jury convicted Albert Dyer, 32, today of murdering three young Inglewood girls and. made no recommendation for life imprisonment. This means that the death penalty for him is mandatory.

Talk is growing in some Democratic circles of the possibility that President Roosevelt will seek a third term. The action of John L. Lewis, head of Labor's Nonpartisan League, in advising his followers in Pennsylvania to favor the President for another term, has been supplemented by later political moves, observers say, while many Democratic Senators are reported to feel that the President harbors a desire to break precedent and be three times the Chief Executive.

The Roxy will provide Broadway with its only new film today, "Love Under Fire," a Twentieth CenturyFox production. Gene Fowler, Allen Rivkin and Ernest Pascal wrote the screen play which features Loretta Young, Don Ameche, Borrah Minevitch and his harmonica rascals, and Frances Drake, Walter Catlett, John Carradine and Harold Huber....
France will not recognize the right of blockading Japanese warships to search foreign ships in Chinese waters, sources close to the Foreign Office said today.

Building in-the metropolitan area is running well ahead of the average for the thirty-seven Eastern States, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation, which reports the total in New York City and vicinity for the first seven months of this year at $515,532,400, a gain of 45 per cent over a year ago.

This Government's "watching position," as one Cabinet member called it, in regard to the Far Eastern crisis will be maintained, without any immediate steps in prospect, President Roosevelt and his Cabinet decided today.

Miss Mira H. Hall, founder and principal for thirty-seven years of Miss Hall's School for Girls at Pittsfield, died suddenly of a heart malady today at a hotel in York Beach, Me., where she was accompanied by Mrs. William R. Barnes of New York, a former instructor at the school.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Jones W. Mersereau points out in his letter to THE TIMES that the total of real estate taxes was limited by the O'Brien bankers' agreement, which is true. But as a taxpayer who would welcome reduction in real estate taxes,

Members of the American National Retail Jewelers Association, in a resolution adopted at yesterday's session of the annual convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, invited the cooperation of manufacturers and jobbers in that industry to protect trade-marked products under the fair-trade laws.
Pablo de Churruca will present his credentials tomorrow to Cardinal Eugenic Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, as the Burgos Government's unofficial charge d'affaires.

Hearing on the reorganization of the Consolidated Textile Corporation was adjourned yesterday until Sept. 8, when, it is believed, Referee Peter B. Olney Jr. will receive a modified reorganization plan, substituting a loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for the present underwriting proposal.

Arguments by counsel over the admissability of evidence again consumed almost the entire day yesterday at the Securities and Exchange Commission's hearing on stop-order proceedings against the Austin Silver Mining Company.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Aug. 14 amounted to 308,737,000 barrels, according to datacompiled by the Bureau of Mines.
Senator Borah said today that he and Senator O'Mahoney had agreed to collaborate in writing a new Federal incorporation bill for the next session of Congress.

Ned Lilly, 21, of Stanton, Mich., won the North American doubles championship at the thirty-eighth grand American trapshoot today, but the preliminary handicap winner was still a toss-up between John W. Egermann of Naperville, Ill., and B. V. Christie of Houston, Texas.

A protein, extracted from bacteria, which is capable of destroying the germs from which it comes, has been isolated by Dr. John H. Northrop of the Rockefeller Institute of Medical Research at Princeton.

Austrians are gleefully contrasting the Baireuth and Salzburg music festivals this year. Baireuth attracted a total of 11,600 visitors, of whom 430 were Americans, while Salzburg in the first half of July and the first week of August registered 25,595, of whom 1,984 were Americans. The Salzburg festival will continue until the end of the month.

Although improved trading in women's wear wool goods is expected in the next ten days as cloak and suit manufacturers resume buying of Fall fabrics, men's wear trading is likely to drag until clothing manufacturers dispose of their finished stocks, the New York Wool Top Exchange reported yesterday.

Mrs. H. H. Dietrich of the Gedney Farm Country Club, White Plains, N. Y., who won the championship of the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association at Westchester Hills last June, returned the low gross score in a one-day tournament of the association today over the course of the Round Hill Club.

Figures showing a decrease of nearly $2,000,000 in real estate valuations for the coming year in White Plains were announced today by City Assessor William J. Weise. The total real estate valuation was $148,741,403.

German exchange students, who will leave early next month for univerities and colleges in various foreign countries, including the United States, were mobilized here yesterday for a week of final intensive training in National Socialism.

An action designed to unseat Representative Christopher D. Sullivan as Tammany leader of half of the Second Assembly District was started yesterday in Supreme Court by Bernard H. Sloane of 208 Forsythe Street, an adherent of the district insurgent faction headed by Harry Nieberg.
This city joined today the growing list of Westchester municipalities which are considering the imposition of a 1 per cent tax on the gross earnings of utilities.

The 1 1/2 per cent rediscount rate that had been in force at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York since Feb. 2, 1934, was far out of line with open market quotations. The new rate of 1 per cent is somewhat closer to the market, but is still above it.

Financing for the Hamburger Distillery, Inc., of Pittsburgh is expected to be done soon in the form of an issue of 40,000 shares of convertible preferred stock entitled to cumulative annual dividends of $1.38 a share and 10,000 shares of

Dizzy Dean suffered a renewal of his sore arm today and was left at the post as the Phillies sloshed to an 8-to-5 triumph over the Cardinals in what was to have been the first game of a double-header. Rain, which sprinkled the proceedings, caught up with all concerned finally and forced postponement of the nightcap.

Marshal Demid, War Minister of the Mongolian Republic, died on a train near Tomsk last Sunday, it was reported today. He was en route to Moscow, which he had visited frequently since a mutual assistance pact between the Soviet Union and Outer Mongolia was signed.
Members of a legislative commission have approved an inscription for a $75,000 State memorial to be erected here to the memory of Father Isaac Jogues, seventeenth century Jesuit explorer.
Unanimous endorsement of Mayor La Guardia for re-election was voted today at its concluding session by the convention of the State Federation of Labor.
Two New York representatives, Charles Jaffe and George N. Treysman, and Donald MacMurray of Chicago tonight qualified for the finals in the championship tournament of the American Chess Federation.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. H. Heyward Burnet of Waco, Ga., and Charleston, S. C., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Emory Burnet, to Dr. Frederick A. Steele of Summit, N. J.

Police of the Missing Persons Bureau investigating the mysterious disappearance of John G. Lowe, wealthy retired manufacturer of Dayton, Ohio, and 116 East Sixtyeighth Street, expressed the belief last night that he might have walked overboard from a Bostonbound boat he boarded Tuesday night. His disappearance became known yesterday when a sevenState alarm was broadcast.

Mel Harder coasted to his tenth 1937 victory today as the Indians defeated the Philadelphia Athletics, 10 to 5, in the opener of a threegame series. The visitors reached Harder for eleven hits, but the Cleveland lead was never endangered.
The question on all lips, Chinese and foreign, in Shanghai now is, "When can we go home and resume what is left of normal business." To this only the most enigmatic answers are given.

The second phase in the financing by the Ohio Public Service Company will take place today with the public offering by Otis Co. of 16,000 shares of 5 1/2 per cent cumulative first preferred stock of the company.

The call of the five railroad brotherhoods for a strike on Sept. 6, to enforce their demands for a 20 per cent pay increase, has brought the prompt intervention of the National Mediation Board. Thus there is promise that any tie-up of the railroads through labor difficulties will be averted.

An injunction to prevent Transradio Press Service, Inc., from supplying to broadcasting stations a blow-by-blow description of the heavyweight fight between Tommy Farr and Joe Louis was asked yesterday of Supreme Court Justice Pecora by Mike Jacobs, promoter of the fight, and the National Broadcasting Company, which has bought exclusive broadcast rights.

A slight decline was recorded in the level of wholesale prices in the week ended on Aug. 21, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average at 100, dropped to 87.3 per cent from 87.5 the preceding week.

Sandy McDonald, the Austin (Texas) heavyweight who recently scored two surprise victories over Eddie Hogan, will meet Emil Scholz, a newcomer from Germany, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.
It is surmised by a contributor to The (London) Observer that "the Long Vacation," which has existed for those engaged in

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher in training of accounting and business practice in day secondary other than junior high schools, be issued, as of Aug. 24, 1937, to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefore:

Michael Lerner of New York, field associate of the American Museum of Natural History and one of our foremost big game hunters and fishermen, will leave this afternoon on a hunting expedition to Canada that will make you big game men green with envy.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Nelson Peck of Peekskill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Eloise Peck, to George Douglas Gould, son of Mrs. James S. Gould of Brooklyn and Halesite, L. I., and the late Mr. Gould.

Governor Lehman today dismissed a petition filed by William H. Allen of New York City seeking the removal of Mayor La Guardia. He did not announce the text of charges on which the Mayor's removal was asked, but made public a letter to Mr. Allen, who is director of the Institute for Public Service, 5 Beekman Street, New York City.
An Associated Press correspondent, surveying the countryside north of Shanghai yesterday morning, found the Chinese dug in heavily over the entire area to within a few miles of Liuho.

The City Council took steps today to finance improvements to the philadelphia water works with the adoption of a resolution at the request of Mayor Wilson directing City Solicitor Sharfsin to petition the courts to free from the city's indebtedness, in computing the borrowing capacity, a bond issue of $2,500,000 to be floated for water plant and sewage disposal purposes.

Yesterday's inclement weather and advice from the Weather Bureau that today promised little, if any, relief caused a postponement to Monday night of the heavyweight championship battle scheduled for last night in the Yankee Stadium between Joe Louis, the titleholder, and Tommy Farr, British Empire champion .
The Morning Post, recently purchased by Lord Camrose, and which was expected to be merged today in its successful rival,

Trustees of the estate of Cyrus H. McCormick today filed an inheritance tax return with the Collector of Internal Revenue, calling for the payment to the Federal Government of an estimated $10,333,000.

Bicycles come under provisions of the Vehicle and Traffic Law on Oct. 1, Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, said today. Every bicycle operated on a public highway must be equipped with adequate brakes and steering mechanism,

Yesterday, Wednesday. For the best names ......... 1% 1% The quotations are for four-six months' paper. Buying Delay Aids Prices With retail buyers having delayed so long on Fall purchases, their necessity to obtain goods as the new selling season approaches may have a strengthening effect on some markets, manufacturers here said yesterday.

Wet grounds and threatening weather yesterday caused the postponement of the scheduled doubleheader between the Giants and the Pirates at the Polo Grounds, so the clubs have arranged twin bills for today and tomorrow, which may and may not be a break for the Giants, depending on how one regards the situation.

Princess Natalie Paley of New York, daughter of the former Grand Duke Paul of Russia, and John Chapman Wilson of Southport, theatrical agent and producer, filed their marriage intentions here today at the Town Hall.

Athletic circles here are criticizing the action of the Austrian Athletic Association in dropping Herr Kaiser, the champion, last Sunday from the 800-meter run from the national team meeting German athletes at Nuremberg. The champion belongs to a Jewish club.
Reorganization of the Propper-McCallum Hosiery Company, employing almost 800 persons, was completed today, after six months' operation under the Federal Bankruptcy Laws.
The twenty-eighth annual Smithtown Horse Show will take place on Saturday at Fifty Acre Field in St. James under the auspices of the Smithtown Club.

A great golf warrior, Charles (Chick) Evans of Chicago, winner of one open and two national amateur titles, came to the end of his trail in the national amateur championship today, missing his chance on the home green of the Alderwood Country Club by making one of the game's worst errors-lifting his head.

The tangled situation within the Republican organization in the Ninth Assembly District, which takes in the West End Avenue area, grew even more complicated yesterday when I. Arnold Ross, the titular leader of the district, moved in Supreme Court to remove from the ballot the name of the Republican candidate for Municipal Court Justice in the district.
Large apartments in buildings on Park, Fifth and Madison Avenues and adjacent streets were in good demand yesterday, according to lists of latest rentals issued by brokers and managing agents.
Deposits of chartered banks with the bank of Canada increased $4,000,000 in the week ended yesterday, the bank's weekly statement revealed today. Note circulation rose $2,000,000.

The polo players, held off Long Island fields by inclement weather since last Friday, finally went out on the rolling, uneven practice ground on the Phipps estate today and put in a twelve-period round robin, part of it played in a driving rain.

Appointment of Dr. Hugh S. O'Reilly as vice dean of the Fordham University School of Business, in the Woolworth Building, was announced yesterday. The Rev. Thomas J. Murray, dean of the school, said that "all business studies grouped in the Division of Business Economics will be under Dr. O'Reilly's direction."

A new clash between Arabs and Luo tribesmen in Mombasa today resulted in the deaths of nine Arabs and serious injuries to many Arabs and Luo. The Luo have now been as joined by other sections of the Kavirondo tribe and by members of the Wachagga tribe in their long feud with the Arabs.
Louis Apicello, 40 years old, a Brooklyn bartender, was put to death in the electric chair at Sing Sing tonight for the murder of Albert Haglund in Brooklyn last Dec. 22.
The extremely popular United States track team, under the leadership of John Magee, lent added interest to today's meet, which was one of the season's biggest sport events in Finland.
