Prices on the Cotton Exchange broke yesterday below the low records established earlier in the week and ended with losses of 4 to 7 points.

The light cruiser Honolulu, which incorporates in her design many new features in naval construction, was launched at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn at slack water yesterday afternoon before 15,000 persons, including Governor Joseph Boyd Poindexter of Hawaii; his daughter, Miss Helen Poindexter, the sponsor; Mayor La Guardia, and naval officers.

The Hamburg-American liner Hansa arrives today from Hamburg and Channel ports. On board are the Rev. and Mrs. Rockwell H. Potter, Otto Ballin, Martin Hamann, Mr. and Mrs. Georg Conrad Kissling, Charles G. Murray, Dr. Herbert Knothe, Mr. and Mrs. Diedrich W. Geck, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Diefenthal, Mr. and Mrs. Max Donner, Oscar S. Shirk, Lieutenant James O. Curtis Jr. and Dr. Louis C. Baker.

Miss Jane Appleman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Appleman of Omaha, was married yesterday at the Pierre to John Henry Phillips, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry H. Phillips of 911 Park Avenue, by the Rev. Dr. Jacob P. Rudin of Great Neck, L. I.

Assets of the Phoenix Silk Manufacturing Company, which is in process of reorganization, were reported yesterday to Federal Judge Patterson as $1,534,681 on March 31 last. Current liabilities were reported as $120,636 and current assets as $87,936.

Seasonal declines in July in employment and payrolls, with slight gains, however, in the manufacturing industries, including both durable and non-durable goods, were reported today by Secretary of Labor Perkins.

Funeral services were held here today for John Anderson Francis, who helped Eugene O'Neill during the playwright's early struggles for recognition. Mr. Francis, who died Tuesday at the age of 64, counted among his friends, besides Mr. O'Neill,
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

A "pay-asyou-go" method of dealing with relief and other depression problems .was advocated today by O. J. Arnold,- president of the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company of Minneapolis, in an address before the annual convention of the National Association of Life Underwriters.
The general city-wide presentations which the Federal Caravan Theatre will offer tonight free of charge are as follows: Manhattan, "Pirates of Penzance," at Washington Square Park; Brooklyn,
With a drizzling rain falling most of the afternoon, three teams were inducted into the semi-finals of the national tennis doubles championships today on the turf courts of the Longwood Cricket Club.
The British Government hinted tonight that it might have to call Japan sharply to account for the attack on Sir Hughe Montgomery Knatchbull-Hugessen, its Ambassador to China.

The Manufacturers Trust Company is depositary under a plan of recapitalization of the E. W. Bliss Company providing for conversion of the three classes of preferred and the common stock into new stock.

President Roosevelt departed tonight on a special train for Hyde Park, where he plans to stay for a month away from the ?? of White House routine, although he expects to reach a decision on some of the questions confronting his Administration.

The sale of 60,000 shares of common stock of the El Paso Natural Gas Company by the Engineers Public Service Company to a banking group comprising White, Weld Co., Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., and Lehman Brothers, was consummated this week following the effectiveness of a post-effective amendment to a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in May. Public distribution of the shares is expected.

Charged with beating his 19-yearold sister with leather straps in the cellar of their home, Charles Campizi, 29, a WPA worker, of 490 Cleveland Street, Brooklyn, was held in $1,000 bail for the grand jury yesterday by Magistrate Solomon in Pennsylvania Avenue court, Brooklyn.

Miss Frances Foley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank F. Foley of this city, will be married to Theodore Leroy Chamberlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Chamberlin of Glastonbury on Sept. 4 in the rectory of St. Joseph's Cathedral.

Pittsburgh at New York (2) Swift and Brandt vs. Melton and Schumacher. Cincinnati at Brooklyn (2)-Derringer and Grissom vs. Frankhouse and Hamlin. St. Louis at Philadelphia (2)Ryba and Harrell vs. LaMaster and Passeau. Chicago at Boston (2)-Carleton and Root vs. Fette and Lanning or Bush.
The Chinese Government announced tonight that eighteen persons, including three women, had been convicted of "espionage on behalf of the enemy" and executed. All were Chinese.

Officials of the city of Boston awarded yesterday $5,500,000 of securities, consisting of $3,000,000 of short-term notes and $2,500,000 of serial bonds, to two banking groups. Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.,
Cardinal Hayes left St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday morning. He had been a patient there since Aug. 12, recuperating from an attack of indigestion.

Harry Barth, for thirty-five years a leader in the hotel supplies business, died on Wednesday night at Presbyterian Hospital after an illness of five weeks. For a time Mr. Barth was president of a chain of hotels. He was 59 years old.

Northamptonshire's hopes of winning one game in the English county cricket competition were exploded today when Hampshire pulled out an innings and 133-run victory over the county in its last scheduled match of the season.

Industrial production and distribution of commodities to consumers showed little change from June to July when allowance is made for the usual Summer decline, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System said today in its monthly summary of general business and financial conditions.

To perpetuate and extend the scientific research work done by Dr. George Washington Carver at Tuskegee Institute, Alabama, in the last forty years, plans have been completed to establish the Carver Creative Research Laboratories, it became known yesterday. A. W. Curtis Jr. of Tuskegee Institute is in this city to seek an endowment fund of $1,354,290 for the purpose.

Billy Rohrey of Swimming River supplied the fireworks in the metropolitan junior championship today when he rallied after being four down to Ray H. Korndorfer of Scarsdale on the tenth, to win the match, 1 up, on the eighteenth at the Englewood Golf Club.

Albin Johnson, New York newspaper man who once wrote articles the Italians regarded as anti-Fascist, found himself temporarily on the Fascist blacklist today when he tried to enter this country to transact New York World's Fair business.

Trading was more active. Steer cuts were strong to higher and some lamb sales 50 cents to $1 higher. Fresh pork cuts were weak to lower and other classes unchanged. Thursday being an off kosher day. the slaughter of those classes, generally dressed kosher, was light. Practically the only kosher business was confined to lamb at strong to slightly higher prices, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

From the point of view of the Western nations which are anxiously watching the course of events in the Far East, the situation at Shanghai has unquestionably entered a more hazardous phase. The Japanese Government has expressed its regret over the wounding of the British Ambassador to China,

Formation of a new investment fund of the "open-end" mutualfund type, headed by Edward E. Spafford, a former National Commander of the American Legion and for many years a manager of estate funds, was announced yesterday by the First Mutual Corporation, national distributor of the new fund. The name selected for the new company is Listed Securities, Inc.

One of the dramatic moments in man's conquest of the globe is that in which Bob Bartlett, who had accompanied Admiral Peary farther north than any one had been at that time, turned back with the last relief party, leaving Peary to go on. As Bartlett himself describes the moment:

Members of the American colony attended the dancing contest of the Coral Island Club last night, contributing 10 cents a dance to the benefit of the Lady Cubitt Community Fund, a local charity established by a previous Governor's wife.

The "Big Five" railroad operating unions and the railroad managements agreed today to accept the services of a mediator for the National Mediation Board in an attempt to settle differences between them arising over the refusal of the railroads to grant the employes demands for a 20 per cent wage increase.

District Attorney William C. Dodge, in a surprise move yesterday, filed notice in General Seslions that on Monday he would apply to Judge John J. Freschi the appointment of a lunacy commission to examine Robert Irwin, sculptor and former theological student indicted for the murders of Mrs. Mary Gedeon, her daughter, Veronica, and Frank Byrnes, their lodger.

The uniform practices committee of the New York Security Dealers Association yesterday ruled that transactions in Follansbee Brothers Company's first mortgage 5 per cent bonds due in 1947 may be settled either by delivery of bonds stamped as to proof of claim filed or unstamped bonds, interchangeably.
The death of Andrew W. Mellon in Southampton came as a shock tonight to his host of friends and associates in this city, which remembered him as its most loyal native.

The Public Works Administration allotted $20,000,000 today toward what may become a part of the first State-wide, publicly owned power system in the country. Secretary Ickes approved a loan of $11,053,000 and a grant of $9,043,000 to the "tri-county project,"

J. B. Priestley's "Time and the Conways" provided an extremely unusual evening for first-nighters at theDuchess Theatre tonight and there was some difficulty, gathering from criticisms, as to whether this play about a well-to-do provincial family is merely unusual or going to be an unusual success.

Two national champions were among the nation's golf stars who unlimbered their heaviest guns today for firing tomorrow in the $4,000 Glens Falls open, one of the few remaining major money events of the season. Topping the select field were Open Champion Ralph Guldahl and the P. G. A. king, Denny Shute..

Robert K. Straus, son of the late Jesse I. Straus and grandson of the late Oscar W. Straus, filed with the Board of Elections yesterday his petition as a candidate for the City Council on the American Labor party ticket.

Deals in Brooklyn properties announced yesterday by brokers principally involved small dwelling properties. The three-family apartment at 1,324 Seventy-third Street was purchased by E. Polumbo through Clark-Robinson Co., broker, for cash subject to a purchase-money mortgage of $4,000.

In a telegram to Secretary of State Cordell Hull, the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League, of which Samuel Untermyer is president, today protested against the decision of the National Government to send a representative to the convention of the German National Socialist party at Nuremberg on Sept. 10.

Miss Flora Jane Engel, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Engel of this city, was married to Maurice C. Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard L. Levy, also of New Rochelle, this afternoon at the Engel home here.
The first tenants will move next Tuesday into Harlem River houses, the $4,219,000 low-rent apartment project at 153d Street overlooking the Harlem River.

Andrew W. Mellon, Secretary of the Treasury in the Cabinets of Presidents Harding, Coolidge and Hoover, former Ambassador to Great Britain and one of the nation's leading financiers and industrialists, died here at 8:30 o'clock, Eastern daylight time, tonight. He was 82 years old.

The situation in the Far East came to the fore as a market factor in wheat today, and, taken in connection with strength in Liverpool and an estimate by an English authority that approximately 10 per cent of Argentina's wheat acreage had been lost due to the prolonged drought, prices on the Board of Trade here advanced around 2 1/2 cents a bushel at the extreme, while Winnipeg was up 3 1/3 cents.
A contra-seasonal decline in lumber production last week caused the adjusted index to slump to 84.8 from 92.4. It was 87.2 for the week ended Aug. 22, 1936.

Block's, Inc., and Jay-Cobbs have opened an independent buying office at 225 West Thirty-fourth Street. Lewis Block will buy coats and furs, Miss Evelyn Block will buy dresses and Mac Goldberg will buy smallwares.

Governor Leslie Jensen calls his Gubernatorial mansion "The Berries." He explained the title at a Rotary luncheon today. "I wanted a suitable name, so I wrote all the Governors in the United States and Canada," Mr. Jensen said.
Citizens of Linton are incensed because of the theft of the shaft which marked the center of population of the United States.
The Board of Tax Appeals reduced to $3,389 today an aggregate deficiency of $368,073 in 1926 and 1927 income taxes assessed against the General Gas and Electric Corporation of New York City.

Thomas J. France, for many years a leading figure in the Brooklyn College, of Pharmacy and a charter member of the Kings County Pharmaceutical Society, under whose auspices the college is operated, died yesterday at his home, 2,705 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn.

The Chase National Bank, as trustee, has sold to the Bropin Realty Corporation, Albert H. Pincus, president, the two five-story apartment houses at 164-66 East Ninetieth Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues.

Miss Martha Blake, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Minot Blake of this city, will be married on Sept. 11 to William W. Walcott, son of former Senator Frederic C. Walcott and the late Mrs. Walcott of Norfolk.

Mr. and Mrs. Myron Turner Townsend of this place have announced the engagement of Mrs. Townsend's daughter, Miss Barbara Baldwin, to Lawrence A. Coleman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Coleman, also of Pelham.

A proposal by the Hungarian Government to resume part payments of installments due on its indebtedness to the United States was accepted today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull in a note to Anthony de Balasy, charge d'affaires ad interim for Hungary.

Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine became movie actors yesterday. For two hours - they acted out their roles at the Fourth Avenue police station at Fourth Avenue and Forty-third Street, Brooklyn. The "March of Time" obtained the sequence and it is understood that it will be' used in a forthcoming version.

Extension of its marketing research facilities to sixteen foreign countries in both hemispheres was announced yesterday by Ross Federal Research Corporation. The new service is the result of Ross's affiliation this month for foreign research with the Market Research Division of Might Directories, Ltd.,

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today that the assets of the twelve Federal Home Loan Banks had increased from $146,204,678 to $196,363,808 in the year ended on July 31, and that during the same period their capital had risen from $132,099,426 to $158,318,127.
Lord Robert Criohton-Stuart, son of the Marquess of Bute, arrived from London and is at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mr. and Mrs. George M. L. La Branche are at the Madison.

Tributes to the career of Andrew W. Mellon were expressed last night by leaders in political life, banking and industry. They follow: Former President HERBERT HOOVER, at Los Angeles (By The Associated Press).--Mr. Mellon's public service will be told by historians. My greatest impression of him was his innate modesty.
The case against communism is the theme of Sinclair Lewis's new play it was learned authoritatively yesterday. At the same time the title was revealed for the first time as "Publish Glad Tidings."

A specially organized opera company with a cast of eighty-nine, including several members of the Metropolitan Opera Association, will sail today for Caracas, Venezuela, where it will present a threeweek season at the invitation of the Venezuelan Governments According to Georgio d'Andria, executive director of the company, the Venezuelan Government provided $75,000 for this project, whose repertoire includes fourteen operas.
Acquisition of Carstairs Brothers Distilling Company, Inc., of Philadelphia by Distillers CorporationSeagrams, Ltd., was announced yesterday by Samuel Bronfman, president of Distillers.

In a 500-word statement, Governor Lehman this afternoon put blame for the continued operation of the dog race track at Mineola on Judge Abruzzo of the Federal District Court, who on July 23 issued an injunction enjoining State and Nassau County officials from interfering with the operation of the Mineola track.

Dr. Frederick W. Parsons, Commissioner of Mental Hyrgiene, resigned his post today. Governor Lehman in accepting the resignation, which is effective Oct. 1, stated that he would name Dr. William J. Tiffany, superintendent of Pilgrim Hospital, as Parsons's successor.

Andrew W. Mellon gave millions of dollars' worth of stocks to his two children, Mrs. David K. E. Bruce and Paul Mellon, in 1932. This was disclosed by Howard M. Johnson of Pittsburgh, Mr. Mellon's financial secretary, in 1935.

The Thew Shovel Company has called a special meeting of stockholders for Aug. 31 to vote on changes in capital structure which will free 48,018 shares of new common stock for sale in the open market to provide funds for working capital and other purposes.

Foreigners walked Shanghai's streets today wearning "bargain basement" steel helmets. Chinese stores even pushed the sale of gas masks with vividly illusrated advertisements of Chinese men and women wearning them and the slogans:

The British patrol sloop Leith left tonight for tiny Canton Island with two wireless operators, building material and equipment to establish a radio station in the Equatorial Phoenix group midway between Fiji and Hawaii.

After a generally firm opening, the stock market was subjected to selling with the result that most sections lost ground. Gilt-edge issues were not immune to the liquidation, and yet, in contrast, both Chinese and Japanese bonds recovered from an early dip and some of them showed slight gains at the close.
Infantile paralysis had taken nineteen lives in Ontario tonight, as health, hospital and civic officials joined in combatting the disease.

Many visitors attended the Masonic Temple, Pittsfield, this afternoon for the opening of the two-day Pittsfield Garden Club Flower Show, which has 250 entries in fifty-one classes from 175 exhibitors.

The Sears Cup appeared bound for Long Island tonight for the first time since 1922 as Charles Stetson and his Pequot crew assumed a 7 1/4point lead on the fleet in today's racing. The Sound champions only captured two third places in the contests held today but their rivals fell by the wayside even harder, with the result that the Southport crew's lead, while not invulnerable, seems safe.

Miss Helen Lawson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Lawson of Brooklyn, has chosen Sept. 25 as the date for her marriage to Frederick Van Duzer Longacre Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick van Duzer Longacre of Yonkers.

Although clearings for the week ended on Wednesday receded from the preceding week, the comparison s with the total for 1936 was quite favorable. For the first time in many weeks every city reported larger transactions than a year ago, ii which maintained the aggregate above last year for the fifth consecutive week.

William F. Sturm, auto racing director of The Indianapolis News, died today in the Noblesville Hospital of a throat ailment. His age was 53. Twenty years ago Mr. Sturm held the coast-to-coast record for crosscountry driving,

Mills H. Husted of Indian Harbor today won the national championship of the Atlantic onedesign class in Rumour. Seaweed had an indirect connection with the winning yacht, but directly accounted for its victory.

A. loan of $1,225,000 for the construction of a large-scale housing project in Montgomery County, Md., has been closed by Richard C. Hollyday, president of Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., for the Falkland Company.

The swankiest-thing in gas 'masks is the latest inducement offered customers of one of Italy's big insurance companies. Smartly designed masks, differing for men and women, are displayed in a prominent shop window on central Via Tritone.
Johns Hopkins Hospital surgeon today planned a further operation to remove the second of three bullets which wounded a Federal agent in the Kansas City massacre of 1933.

Fred D. Fagg Jr., director of the Bureau of Aeronautics of the Deapartment of Commerce, headed a group of Federal officials who inspected North Beach Airport in Queens yesterday with Mayor La Guardia and several city officials.

Announcement today that Lieut. Gen. Shinroku Hata has been appointed inspector general of military instruction, thereby becoming one of army's big three, is accompanied by complete silence regarding the next post of Genera Count Juichi Terauchi, whom ,he succeeds.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday that John H. Morris had been appointed Sixth Deputy Police Commissioner in charge of the Juvenile Aid Bureau to fill the vacancy created by the transfer of Byrnes MacDonald from that position to First Deputy Commissioner in the Department of Welfare.

Crowds in two boroughs threatened yesterday two men suspected of vicious intentions toward young girls. In Brooklyn, tenants of an apartment house at 724 Franklin Avenue chased for several blocks a man who had dragged an 8-year-old child into a cellar.

The Colombia Bondholders Committee, in a letter to the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, fiscal agent and trustee for the Department of Antioquia, Republic of Colombia, 7 per cent bonds, Series A, B, C and D, due on July 1, 1945, urges the bank to take definite action to prevent the diversion of pledged revenues by the Department of Antioquia as authorized recent legislation passed by the Deapartment.

Mrs. Darwin P. Kingsley entertained at luncheon today at the Maidstone Club. Among those invited were Mrs. John W. Griggs, Mrs. Robert W. Paterson, Mrs. Eugene Hodenpyl, Mrs. Henry Dater, Mrs. William Whittingham Battle, Mrs. Victor Harris, Mrs. Joseph Reynolds Guernsey, Mrs. John B. Carse, Mrs. John Vernou Bouvier Jr., Mrs. Cortlandt Godwin, Mrs. Frederic Fuller and Mrs. Frederick Kellogg Hollister.
President Roosevelt will sign the Black bill calling for a voluntary registration before April 1 of the unemplayed and part-time unemployed, it was indicated at the White House today.
Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

The city's new traffic code, which went into effect Feb. 21 particularly the regulation prohibiting a turn on red lights, has "materially reduced street accidents and fatalities," according to a report made public yesterday by the Safety Bureau of the Police Department, on a "probationary period" for the code of five months from March 1 to July 31.

The board of directions of the Wayne Pump Company adopted yesterday a plan to give stockholders rights to subscribe to one additional share for each ten shares held, at a price to be fixed by the directors, not to exceed $40 a share.
The business property known as the Swiss Chalet, on the Boston Post Road in the Village of Larchmont, Westchester, has been sold by the Midfield Realty Corporation to Edward Acuri.

Colonel Robert T. Barton declared today that the present members of the Governor's staff were unable to joust with a julep in proper manner. The city Democratic committee chairman wrote a letter to James H. price, who,

Rabbi Moses Shochet, Philadelphia Jewish and civic leader, died tonight in the Skin and Cancer Hospital after an illness of six months. Rabbi Shochet, who was 67 years old, was stricken shortly after leading his congregation at B'Nai Arron Temple,

The "Armored Cruiser Squadron," famous in decades long ago, and remembered by the modern navy chiefly because of the rollicking verses of the ditties to which it gave birth, is experiencing a reincarnation these days.

Foreign Minister Koki Hirota today instructed the Japanese Ambassador to China, Shigeru Kawagoe, to extend Japan's warmest sympathy to Sir Hughe Knatchbull-Hugessen, the British Ambassador, who was wounded gravely by Japanese airplane bullets at Shanghai today.

While nurses and doctors hovered about, a hearing by the Securities and Exchange Commission was conducted yesterday in the sickroom of Colin Melhado, security dealer, in the New York Hospital. Two weeks before Mr. Melhado had fainted on the witness stand at a hearing at 120 Broadway. His testimony yesterday was interrupted on several occasions, and once the room was cleared to allow doctors to give him medical aid.

The convention of the American Federation of Teachers voted late tonight, 285 to 227, to conduct a national referendum of its membership on the question of abandoning the American Federation of Labor and affiliating with the Committee for Industrial Organization.

The auction of real estate owned by closed National banks in Westchester County, the first session of which was held last week, will be resumed this afternoon at 2:30 P. M. in the New York Naval Militia Armory, 270 Main Street, New Rochelle. Other sessions will be held on Tuesday and Thursday nights.

Nearly 1,350 Bronx children went on record to support the SOS-Stay on Sidewalk - safety campaign which is being led by Uncle Robert, children's radio entertainer. Singing songs and carrying banners, the children marched through Bronx streets to the Vogue Theatre, Tremont Avenue, near Daly Avenue, where they attended a theatre party.
Spanish Government and Insurgent sympathizers fought a gun battle in the streets of this Moroccan seaport today. One person was killed and several wounded.

Two hundred and twelve skilled typing hands, some of them the world's swiftest, after six months of intensive training, are ready to race away to anticipated new speed records and six major touch-system championships in tomorrow afternoon's International Typewriting Contest at the Canadian National Exhibition.

Stuyvesant Van Veen, 27-year-old artist of 24 West Ninety-sixth Street, early yesterday morning finished a huge mural, "Pittsburgh Panorama," just in time to make the deadline of its unveiling in the Pittsburgh Postoffice-court house on Monday.

In a seventeen-hour continuous session, the House of Representatives today approved "in principle" the sugar bill, the cornerstone of Colonel Fulgencio Batista's "three-year plan." It then approved more than half of the fifty-five articles of the bill and adjourned until Monday night.

Carrying equipment for sending and receiving radio direction bearings in the jungle, an expedition of six scientists under the auspices of the American Museum of Natural History sailed yesterday on the Royal Dutch steamship Van Rensselaer for British Guiana.

Two square-rigged yachts with canvas stretched on their tall masts tonight were on the high seas in a 660-mile race to Bermuda. A noon-day freshening wind cleared fog and sent the ships, the Seven Seas, owned by Walter S. Gubelmann, and the Joseph Conrad owned by G. Huntington Hartford, on their way.

The creator of that madcap, of the comic strip, "Happy Hooligan," died here today. He was Frederick Burr Opper, dean emeritus of the comic artists of America. Death came to him in his eighty-first year, after a week's illness of heart disease.

Mr. and Mrs. H. Lester Cuddihy gave a large dinner tonight at their place in Water Mill for Miss Janice Kennedy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Charles Kennedy, and John Homer Winters Jr., whose marriage will take place tomorrow afternoon at Kennedune,

Jack Wilson pitched almost airtight baseball after a shaky start today as the Boston Red Sox pounded out an 8-to-5 victory, evening the series with the Detroit Tigers. Rookie Rudy York's twenty-seventh home run of the season-and his seventh in the last seven games
Philip Scott Tyre, a Philadelphia designer, died Wednesday night at his home in the McCallum Apartments after being stricken at his Summer home near New Hope several days ago. He was 56 years old.

Officials of the Farm Credit Administration said today that the number of prompt installment payments by Federal Land Bank borrowers increased from 55 per cent in 1932 to 87 per cent for the first half of 1937.
Although Thomas Alva Edison has been dead nearly six years, his knowledge about technicalities concerned with his inventions still continues to guide the destinies of the enterprise he founded.

The New York and Texas and the Decatur and Leary stood into the Navy Yard in Brooklyn yesterday. The Texas and the two destroyers completed a two weeks' training cruise with naval reservists aboard from Jersey City and Brooklyn.
President Roosevelt arrived at his mother's house here early this morning, planning the most extended holiday from his desk since he went to South America last Fall.

The diplomat in this brave new world is rather like the actor of the silent screen when he first met the talkies. Some day a candid reporter will tell the story of the sheer bewilderment of diplomacy during the last few years.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull announced today that the Government of the United States has formally served notice on the Governments of Japan and China that it reserves all rights on its own behalf and on behalf of its nationals for damages to American lives or property growing out of the operations of their military forces.
Legislators and realty interests in various parts of the country are giving their attention to plans for strengthening the regulations governing sale of lots in suburban subdivisions.

French authorities cancelled today the remainder of the French fencing tournament because of the death of Rene Monal, 23-year-old medical student, who was fatally wounded during his match against Haro Oliva, Mexican opponent.

Wilbur Glenn Voliva, who believes the world is flat, was declared "flat broke" today. Federal Judge Charles G. Briggle confirmed a bankruptcy composition taking all the property of the former business dictator and religious leader of Zion City.

Heedless of the threatening weather and a tinny piano accompaniment, twenty-four children competed' in the finals of the. Park Department's children's amateur singing contest yesterday afternoon on the Mall in Central Park.

Part of Japan's North China army of 120,000 men was reported officially tonight to have broken through the Great Wall and to be closing a vise on Chinese forces in Nankow Pass and at Suanha and Hwailai, sixty miles northwest of here.

John Russell Pope, noted architect, died at 8:15 o'clock last night in the Harkness Pavilion of Medical Center. Sixty-three years old, Mr. Pope was taken ill at his Summer home in Newport, R. I., and on Aug. 9 entered the New York Hospital.

The Japanese Ambassador, Shigeru Yoshida, visited the Foreign Office this afternoon to express his Government's deep regret at the wounding yesterday of Sir Hughe Montgomery Knatchbull-Hugessen, the British Ambassador to China.

A strong second-innings' offensive by Nottinghamshire was enough to hoist Middlesex out of the leading position in the English county cricket competition today. Although beaten on the first innings, Nottingham hammered Middlesex offerings for 447 runs for six wickets when stumps were drawn.

John Ordney, a WPA worker, was shocked to death this afternoon when he accidentally touched a live wire while repairing an electrical transformer at Fort Slocum, on David's Island, off New Rochelle. Ordney,

The crown that Johnny Fischer won in such brilliant fashion at the Garden City Golf Club a year ago by staging a never-to-be-forgotten comeback against Jack McLean, British Walker Cup invader, fell of its own accord today as the tall Cincinnati law student was badly beaten in the semi-final round of the national amateur golf championship by little Ray Billows, Poughkeepsie (N. Y.) printing salesman.

John Lewis, head of the Committee for Industrial Organization, said here tonight that millions of Americans in all walks of life desired the fornation of a third party. He was interviewed as he paused on his way back to Washington from the United Automobile Workers convention in Milwaukee.

The marriage of Miss Martha Lourana Lowry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hiter H. Lowry of East Orange, to Dr. Charles Montanye Franklin, son of Mrs. Charles Montanye Franklin of Hightstown and the late Dr. Franklin,

Miss Frances Lewis Gifford, daughter of Benedict Gifford of Hudson, N. Y., and Mrs. Beverly Gordon Mills of Kinderhook, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to George Lerch Cummings of Mount Vernon, N. Y.

Samuel Untermyer returned on the Swedish liner Gripsholm yesterday from a cruise to Scandinavia and Russia. Pointing out that the few days allotted to the cruise members for Russian sightseeing had been obviously inadequate for a "valuable conception of the revolutionary, stupendous and kaleidoscopic changes" taking place there, the lawyer praised the "palatial" Moscow subway and said it made New York's underground a "tawdry, tinsel affair."
Not the least of the risks Japan runs in its undeclared war against China is the possibility of seriously alienating Great Britain at the moment when British friendship would be most valuable.
Japanese bombers, in the most destructive air raids yet suffered by Nanking, killed nearly 150 Chinese civilians and wounded scores more today in the poorest quarters of the capital.
Stockholders of the Dewey and Almy Chemical Company of Cambridge, Mass., yesterday approved a plan for simplification of the company's capital structure by authorizing 350,000 new common shares,

Several hundred children of the lower East Side vehemently objected to leaving the open roof garden of the Educational Alliance when a rainstorm yesterday afternoon interrupted a juvenile performance of the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta, "H. M. S. Pinafore."

Wilhelm Furtwaengler appeared in Salzburg for the first time this morning, conducting Beethoven's Ninth symphony before an audience which filled the Festspielhaus and gave the German guest conductor a considerable ovation at the concert's close. Members of the Austrian. Government, diplomats, conductors, Italy's Crown Princess and the wife of the former German Crown Prince were among those on hand.

Mass picketing, called by the Joint Boycott Council of the American Jewish Congress and Jewish Labor Committee, took place yesterday afternoon in front of the Mills Sales Corporation, importers, 901 Broadway, as a protest against the sale by this concern of Germanmade merchandise.
Mrs. George W. Blabon 2d, of Ardmore, Pa., and East Hampton, L. I., gave a surprise party here tonight at the Montauk Island Club in celebration of Mr. Blabon's birthday.

Gold imports by the United States in the week ended on Aug. 20 were valued at $28,516,898 compared with $27,405,820 in the previous week, and consisted of 15,013 ounces of ore and base bullion, and 800,562 ounces of refined bullion, according to a Department of Commerce announcement today.
A "national fast" on Sunday, accompanied by prayer to God to deliver the Jews from oppression, was proclaimed here today. Poland's 3,500,000 Jews will fast and pray from sunrise to sunset.

A study of mortgages placed on real estate in Manhattan since January, 1935, conducted by the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., indicates that there is a growing interest in this type of investment, it was announced yesterday.

The entire front of the former S. W. Straus Co. Building at 565 Fifth Avenue is undergoing alteration and the space occupied by the grand staircase which led from the street level to the banking floor of the investment firm will be conaverted into a store, it was announced yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn denied yesterday the application of William H. Jackson of 2 Hardy Place, Great Kills, S. I., for an order to direct the Board of Elections to print his name on the Republican primary-ballot as a candidate for the nomination for Borough President of Richmond.
When the two-story brick dwelling at 265 West 254th Street, Riverdale, was offered at auction in the Bronx salesrooms at 3,208 Third Avenue yesterday, a spirited competition ensued.

Twenty-five men and women, members of two rival smuggling rings which illegally imported more than $2,000,000 worth of unset diamonds into the United States during the last several years, received prison sentences ranging from thirty days to fifteen months and
George Michael Prendergast, former Premier of the State of Victoria and for many years leader of the Labor party, died today. His age was 83.

The American Federation of Teachers ended its five-day convention today with the adoption of a resolution calling for the establishment of State Farmer-Labor-Progressive organizations and a National FarmerLabor party.
The custom, or rather the business, of sending kisses by telegraph seems to have sprung up overnight. A lady in Atlantic City has

Japan sold and shipped yesterday another consignment of $5.865,000 of gold to the United States, according to reports received by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This made a total of $147,600.000 of the metal shipped by Japan to the United States since the middle of last March.

Because of the persistent rumors that ex-Prince Nicholas has returned to Rumania, the official news agency, harried by correspondents, finally issued tonight the announcement that Nicholas Brana (the Prince's new name) is not at the present in his native country.

In a statement yesterday Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo, in the Federal court, in Brooklyn, replied to criticism of him by Governor Lehman for his-issuance of an injunction restraining State and Nassau County officials from interfering with the operation of a dog racing track conducted at Mineola, L. I., by the Nassau County Kennel Club.

Paper and paperboard produced in the United States in 1936 amounted to 11,975,552 tons compared to 10,479,095 tons in 1935, a gain of 14.3 per cent, according to preliminary figures. made public today by William L. Austin, Director of the Census.

Cotton-mill activity increased last week when the seasonal trend was unchanged, and the adjusted index has moved up to 144.3 from 140.4 (revised). This compared with 134.5 for the week ended Aug. 22, 1936. Some mills began curtailment this week by eliminating third shifts,

Member trading in round lots for own account and total volume on the New York Stock Exchange showed substantial decreases in the week ended on July 31, compared with the previous week, according to the weekly analysis made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

John Taylor Arms 3d sailed Andiamo IV of the Pequot Club, representing Central Long Island Sound, home third today in the fourth race of the series for the Atlantic Coast Star Class championship to tie Jay of the Larchmont Club from Western Long Island Sound for the lead in point scoring.
That Japan will win a decisive, shattering victory over China within three or four months is the prevailing opinion among foreign military and naval experts in Shanghai.

Robert K. Straus, son of the late Jesse I. Straus and grandson of the late Isidore Straus, filed with the Board of Elections on Thursday his Petition as a candidate for the City Council on the City Fusion group.

Verne Moore, Hollywood's John Montague, came home today after seven years. His "Hello, mother darling, how are you?" easily carried down the high terrace from the porch at 2,115 South Geddes Street to the sidewalk in front of the house.

The State of New Jersey asked the In terstate Commerce Commission today to reopen the lighterage cases that it decided in 1934, holding that "the State of New Jersey did not receive even-handed justice in the commission's decision."

Charles Zimmy, 46 and legless, who is attempting to swim non-stop from Albany to New York City, was hidden by fogs over the Hudson River last night, but his manager asserted he was nearing Peekskill "feeling fine."

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it obtained yesterday in Philadelphia an injunction against the Pennsylvania Finance Company, Inc.; Howard J. Levitt, William H. Victor and Samuel Sussman, enjoining them from further sales of Class A 8 per cent preferred stock and common stock issued by the Pennsylvania Finance Company, Inc., until there is an effective registration statement on file covering the securities.

THE late Field Marshal Earl Roberts, who died in 1914, is said 'to have made only two prophecies in his life. The first was that war between Great Britain and Germany was inevitable. The second was that the history of the world would some day, be decided at Singapore.

Eight thousand employes of the Delaware and Hudson Railroad will receive a five cents an hour wage increase, retroactive to Aug. 1, Edwin C. Laperche, assistant supervisor of wages and working agreements for the railroad, said today.

Believed to have been overcome by carbon monoxide gas, Joseph Raymond, 56-year-old shoemaker, and his daughter, Anna, 21, were found dead yesterday at noon in their flat at 263 Floyd Street, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

Sanction of the use of sleeper cabs on trucks in the highway-safety regulations proposed under the Motor Carrier Act by Examiner R. W. Snow of the Bureau of Motor Carriers, Interstate Commerce Commission, was severely criticized as a menace to highway safety in a brief filed with the commission today by four large railroad employes' unions.

MANHATTAN BERGHORN, LOUIS F. H. (Feb. 19, 1937). Gross assets, $52,827; net, $48,690. To Margaret Berghorn, widow, household, personal effect, and one-third residue; Elsa, 'Louis, George and William Berghorn, children, one-sixth residue each. Chief assets, mortgages, notes cash and insurance, $28,301. Abberley, Bryde, MacFall Amon. attorneys, 42 Broadwa.

Mr. and Mrs. William Halsted Vander Poel have arrived for the final racing events here and are occupying the box which belonged formerly to Mrs. Vander Poel's father, the late Cornelius C. K. Billings.

The Journeyman Barbers International Union's nine locals in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn have voted to shift their allegiance from the American Federation of Labor to the Committee for Industrial Organization, it was announced yesterday.

Mrs. Dorothea Griffin Perry, daughter of Mrs. Lillian BenjaminGriffin of this city and of Robert Griffin of Jersey City and Miami Beach, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria to Lawrence G. Preston, also of New York, by the Rev. Martin D. Hardin.

A woman pilot identified from papers on her body as Mrs. Genevieve Savage, wife of Major C. M. Savage, U. S. A., crashed to death today in an isolated mountainous area three miles over the Mexican border when her airplane's engine failed.
Scholarships totaling $60,000 have been awarded by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to fortyeight students from New York and New Jersey who are entering the institute this Fall.

A syndicate of New York operators leased from the Wiss Realty Corporation of Newark the property at 552-4 Central Avenue, northeast corner of Evergreen Place, East Orange, N. J. Two frame houses on the plot will be razed and the site improved with a onestory store building.

Social credit cannot conceivably work, and even if every possible factor were favorable to its operation the end would be inflationary chaos, said Reginald McKenna, former British Chancellor of the Exchequer and present chairman of the Midland Bank, on his arrival here yesterday.

Holders of common stock of the Emerson Electric Manufacturing Company of record May 5 have received rights to purchase 80,000 additional shares at $9.37 1/2 a share, in the ratio of one share for each three and three-eighths common shares held by them. The rights will expire on Sent. 9.

The committee on quotations and commissions of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that applications for the admission of partners to existing member firms would be considered on Sept. 9 in

Eight of the original forty entries in the tournament for the championship of the American Chess Federation had qualified for the finals tonight. Four of the qualifiers were from New York City. Those to advance were S. S. Cohen of New York in Section 1;

Charges of attempted robbery brought against John P. Knapp, 38 years old, a financial writer on the Wall Street Journal for eighteen years, after he had been beaten by a mounted patrolman while in the corridor outside his own apartment at 319 West Eighteenth Street, were dismissed yesterday in Felony Court by Magistrate Michael A. Ford.
The American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on June 30 a total income of $9,855,558, compared with $10,336,999 in the preceding year.

The Rev. Leonard M. Outerbridge, general secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the Congregational and Christian Churches, has purchased from the Home Savings Bank of White Plains a ten-room residence at 120 Old Mamaroneck Road, on the corner of Stratford Avenue, in White Plains, Westchester.

Mayor La Guarda disclaimed interest yesterday in his endorsement by the Communist party, which was announced Thursday night by Earl Browder, its candidate for President last year. "I am not concerned or interested in what the Communist party does," the Mayor said.

Mrs. James Mott Hartshorne of New York entertained with a dinner at Balance Rock. Guests include d Mr. and Mrs. George Batcheller, Mr. and Mrs. Henry O. Tallmadge, General James W. Kilbreth and Mrs. Kilbreth, Theodore Marburg,

The Red Cross emblem and its Chinese equivalent, the red swastika, are being abused and misused on a large scale in Shanghai by the Chinese. Countless trucks flying Red Cross flags not engaged--on any errands remotely related to Red Cross work constantly ply in and out of the International Settlement and French Concession carrying supplies to the Chinese armies in the area between Shanghai. Hangchow and Kashing.
Following is the text of the address broadcast by Assistant Secretary of State George S. Messersmith today on the occasion of the anniversary of the signing of the KelloggBriand Pact:

Miss Marion Miley of Cincinnati and Miss Betty Jameson of San Antonio advanced into the final of the thirty-fifth annual women's Western golf tournament at the Town and Country Club today with victories over Miss Marian McDougal of Portland, Ore., and Miss Beatrice Barrett of Minneapolis.

Cooler weather stimulated retail trade here this week, with more active interest in Fall apparel and home wares reported by retail executives. A gain of about 4 per cent in sales volume over the corresponding period a year ago was estimated, which would show a fair degree of improvement over the first portion of the month.

The Post-Intelligencer said President Roosevelt intends to visit the Pacific Northwest late in September "to secure first-hand information on the accomplishments in this area under his Administration."

Miss Isabella Markell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Markell of New York and Gibson Island on Chesapeake Bay, has set Sept. 11 for her marriage to Arthur Hamilton Clephane of Washington, D. C., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Allan C.
The downward movement in cotton prices continued yesterday until all three near deliveries on the Cotton Exchange sold below 9 1/2 cents a pound and the list ended with losses of 12 to 17 points.

A plan of reorganizing for the Akron, Canton Youngstown Railway Company and the Northern Ohio Railway Company, and which provides for merger of the roads, was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

An unemployed seaman and a machinist yesterday averted what might have become a major disaster at West and Cortlandt Streets, when sewer gas overcame seven workmen excavating for the West Side Highway extension.
Stocks closed lower in less active trading, rails at new lows for years; turnover, 889,700 shares. Bonds steady to irregularly lower; trading smallest since Aug. 17; transactions, $5,737,450.

Pete Appleton limited the White Sox to three hits today to give the Senators a 5-to-0 victory in the second game of the series. Washington made only eight hits off Bill Dietrich and Thornton Lee, but bunched four of these in the second inning to count three runs and collected three more hits in the fifth to score twice.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Leave of absence for four days, effective on or about Sept. 1, is granted Capt. Frank J. Turck, Q.M.-Res. 1st Lt. John J. Freeman, Med.-Res., now a patient at the Station Hospital, Fort Jay, N. Y., is relieved from further active duty with the CCC, and will proceed to his home, 160 E. 105th St., New York.

Invitations have been issued by Mr. and Mrs. Kendrick R. Wilson of 589 Westminster Avenue for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Jane Douglas Wilson, to Charles Clark Stover Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark Stover of Providence, R. I.

President James Madison Wood of Stephens College, Columbia, Mo., disclosed yesterday that Maude Adams, who retired from the stage in 1918 and has made only two brief reappearances since, had accepted the post of Professor of Drama at Stephens and would take up her duties there with the beginning of the school term in September.

Mr. and Mrs. A. Felix du Pont Jr. of Wilmington, Del., and Marion, Mass., have announced here the engagement of Mrs. du Pont's sister, Miss Virginia Hoyt of 10 Gracie Square, this city, to Charles Lawrence Peirson, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Lawrence Peirson of Essex Fells, N. J.

Ist St, 13 E, 19.8x77xirrg; Louis Grossman to Celia Well, 109 W 53d St, p m mtg due Aug. 1, 1945, int per bond; $5,250. 55th St, 68 E, 20x100.5; 68 E 55th St Corp. (Lawrence N. Levine, pres.) to Jacob R. Schiff, 575 Park Ave, due Jan. 1, 1938, 6%; $8,000.

Death Announced Retired Firemen Andrew Thornton, formerly a member of H. and L. 137, residing at 45 South Elliott Pl., Brooklyn, died Aug. 26. Funeral will take place from the above residence, at 10 A. M., Monday, Aug. 30, thence to the Church of the Queen of All Saints, Vanderbilt and Lafayette Avenues, Brooklyn.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 26: COLONEL Bryden, W. (F. A.), General Staff Corps, relieved from detail as a member of the General Staff Corps and from assignment on War Department General Staff, and from further duty in the office of the Chief of Staff, Washington, D. C., effective Sept. 1 assigned to Sixteenth Brigade, Ft. George G. Meade, Md.

The Federal Power Commission will resume hearings here on Sept. 14 upon the petition of certain Associated Gas and Electric Company subsidiaries for a rehearing of the commission's order setting down for hearing its proceeding to ascertain and determine matters regarding the ownership, operation, management and control of numerous servicing and management companies in the system.
More than 400 residents of the Saugatuck Valley and Redding Glen protested at a meeting tonight condemnation by the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company of land in the Saugatuck Valley, Redding and Easton.

The New York Labor Mediation Board undertook yesterday negotiations between Local 32-E of the Building Service Employes Union and the owners of the Professional Building, 2,021 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, in an effort to avert a threatened strike in that building which houses the Royal Hospital.

Word was received here today that Edwin Clement Merrill, secretary of the Charles E. Merrill Book Co., and for many years a resident of this city, died yesterday at the home of his son-in-law and daughter, the Rev. and Mrs. Arthur Beale, at Waterville, Me. His age was 86.

Highest salaries paid by Paramount Pictures, Inc., during the year ended on Jan. 2 went to actors, according to a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Gary Cooper received $265,454 and George Raft $202,667. Wesley Ruggles, a producer, was paid $188,809.

White Plains Rd (17-5107), w s, 176 ft s of 242d St, 43x64: Emigrant Industrial Savwings Bank to Chesterfield Fireproof Storage Warehouse Co, Inc, 4,761 White Plains Rd; mtg $63,000. 139th St, 360 E (9-2301); Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to 1,432 Bryant Ave Realty Corp, 1,432 Bryant Ave; mtg $19,500.

Frankie Parker of Milwaukee, United States Davis Cup star, reached the quarter-final round of the Seigniory Club invitation men's singles tennis tournament today with the loss of only one game to Leo Leblane of Montreal.

Ethnological research by the Smithsonian Institution of Washington will figure largely in a hearing before the Canadian Supreme Court here in October to decide whether an Eskimo is just an Eskimo or also an Indian.
There was an air of good cheer about the proceedings in Sportsman's Park today which stood out rather incongruously in an arena renowned for some of its tempestuous scenes on other occasions.

The Phillies climbed into undisputed possession of sixth place in the National League today by beating the Cardinals twice. The victories, by 4 to 1 and 6 to 3, gave the Phils three in a row over the St. Louis Club.
Lawyers estimated today that the Federal inheritance tax on the estate. of Andrew W. Mellon would exceed $15,000,000 and might run as high as $35,000,000.

The body of John G. Lowe, who was missing Wednesday morning when the steamer on which he had sailed from New York docked at Boston, was found floating in Long Island Sound today about a mile and a half off East Marion by Coast Guardsmen from Northport.

Frederick Adams, 61-year-old sign painter, who has served more than ten years in Sing Sing prison for pathological offenses against young girls and is wanted in New York for violation of parole, is under arrest here.

Among those dining with 'guests tonight at the Devon Yacht Club were'Mr. and Mrs. Berwick Lanier, Mr. and Mrs. Dickson Bayard Potter, Dr. and Mrs. Ogden M. Edwards Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Reid, Mr. and Mrs. Theodore P. Dixon and Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Gill Wylie.

Grand Concourse, 1,750 (11-2825); Concourse Properties, Inc, to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, due on demand, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent; $35,000. College Ave, 1,429 (11-2786); Lingate Realty Corp to Protective Indemnity Cb, 80 Maiden Lane, installments, 4 1/2 per cent; $29,500.

The strike of 15,000 painters in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond has been extended to many other cities where New York City contractors have construction and alteration jobs, it was announced by the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers yesterday.

The convention of the United Automobile Workers today adopted unanimously a motion calling for a special assessment of $1 on each of She 400,000 members to raise a "war chest" for the campaign to organize the Ford Motor Company employes.
Grover A. Whalen completed arrangements today with the Italian Government, represented by Dr. Orazio Pedrazzi, for Italian participation in the 1939 World's Fair at New York.

Manhattan Chambers St, 99, and Reade St, 83; 25.1x 151.2; for 6-story factory and stores; D. F. Harris Hardware and Manufacturing Co. Inc, premises, owner; Jardine, Murdock-Wright, W. M. H. Wright, successor, architect; cost $10,000.

September corn declined the permissible limit of 4 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade here today and new crop months dropped 2 1/4 to 2 1/2 cents to new low levels since July 1, 1936, on general liquidation and stop loss order selling which disclosed a lack of aggressive support. The close was at the bottom.

A dinner was given last night by Mr. and Mrs. Charles K. Duryea on the Roof Garden of the Astor. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Symonds Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Philmore W. Cornish, Mr. and Mrs. William J. Lawrence, Mr. and Mrs. Karl Russell Shaw, Mr.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market is stagnant. Here and there a small lot of wool is moved for some necessity, but the mills are showing the utmost indifference to offerings, and the trade on both sides of the Atlantic is waiting for the opening of the new Australian season on Monday at Sydney.

Prospects of completing the development of North Beach Airport in time for the opening of the New York World's Fair in April, 1939, dimmed considerably when it was brought out at a public hearing before United States Army engineers yesterday that the city had applied to the Government for permission to fill land in Bowery Bay which the city does not own or control.
The Indians regained the 500 bracket in the American League today with a 5-to-3 victory over the Athletics in which Earl Averill rifled his thirteenth home run of the season.
Average daily sales of chain drug stores in July were 4.3 per cent higher than in July, 1936, according to preliminary estimates made public today by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

Accused of inflicting wounds with a leather strap and several household utensils which caused the death here of Leonard M. Macali, 7 years old, Mrs. Esther Brodsky, alias Anna Smith, housekeeper for the boy's father, Michael Macali,

To the editor of The New York Times: Allow me to protest against two views of the Sino-Japanese situation expressed in letters to THE TIMES by Robert Branch and Gilbert Stinger. Mr. Branch thinks China is "not fit" to develop her own resources and that Japan is "logically assuming a paternal
Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 728,000 bales, against 752,000 a week ago, 765,000 two weeks ago, 780,000 three weeks ago and 748,000 a year ago;

H. W. Clark, the Carrie M. L Olmstead residence at 490 Midland Ave, Rye, Westchester; E. V. Siedle, broker. Jack Weiss, in 604 Beach 19th St; Far Rockaway, L. L; Irving Hacker, in 2920 Healy Ave; May Bell, in 1, 116 Roanoke Ave, Harold Lasker, in 1,100 Gipson St; Samuel S. Garmise, in 1,127 Grassmere Terr; Rubin Weinstein, in 1,125 Regina Boulevard; Abraham Shur, in 4 Hurley Court; Lewis H. May Co, broker.

The eight Sea Scouts of the Rockville Center Ship who rescued five fishermen from drowning Aug. 17 when their sea skiff was swamped in the rough waters of Peconic Bay, will be honored here Wednesday night at a dinner of the Rockville Center Post of the Amerclan Legion, Pierre E. Peets, Post Commander, announced tonight.
Fashionable Havana society was stirred today by the report that the second Countess of Covadonga had demanded an immediate divorce from the eldest son of former King Alfonso of Spain.

The attack on the British Ambassador to China, Sir Hughe Montgomery Knatchbull-Hugessen, has upset the whole picture in the Far East from Japan's viewpoint. This empire is most anxious to avoid any foreign complication in the present conflict, which has distinctly entered the war stage whether the word is used or not.

Federal grants for potato growers on condition that they confine cultivation to a Government-specified acreage had the approval of representatives of 200,000 Northeastern farmers meeting yesterday in the Barbizon Plaza Hotel to work out a stabilization plan under the AAA.
Miss Dorothy Jamin, young White Beeches star, shot a 94 to capture low gross honors in the one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association today at the Yountakah Country Club.
The famous Soviet icebreaker Krassin won through Arctic ice and adverse winds to reach here today and become the pivot in a search for the six lost transpolar aviators.
Two British steamers were bombed today as they left Gijon, a Government-held. port on the North Spanish coast, by war planes reported to belong to Spanish Insurgents.

Commonwealth Treasurer R. G. Casey has announced that, owing to an increase in the defense appropriation to [pound]11,500,000, compared with [pound]8,809,000 for 1936-37, and an increase in the cost of old-age and invalid pensions amounting to [pound]2,000,000, there would be no fur their reduction in taxation.

Pre-publication orders have sent A. J. Cronin's new novel, "The Citadel," into a third printing, bringing the total number printed to 45,000 copies, though the book will not be published until Sept. 10, Little, Brown report.

The radio in the closed coupe belonging to James R. Turner, 38 years old, of 215 Prospect Street, was playing this morning when Harry Nord of 156 West Post Road went to the open shed behind St. Thomas's Church, where both men have kept their cars.

The 4,000,000th automobile passed over the Henry Hudson Bridge at 2:50 P. M. yesterday. In accordance with an established custom, a fifty-trip book was given free to William A. Ohisen, the driver, with the compliments of the Henry Hudson Parkway Authority.

Turpentine firm, 31 1/2c; ales, 224 barrels; receipts, 330 barrels; no shipments; stock, 34,525 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 622; receipts, 1,674; no shipments; stock, 64,892. quote: B, $7.80; D E, $7.85; F, $8: G, H. I, $8-$8.02 1/2; K, M, $8-$8.05; N, $8.05-.10; WG, $8.20-.25; WW, X, $58.80-.85.
Mrs. Wanden Mathews La Farge received a decree of divorce here today from Oliver La Farge of New York on grounds of cruelty.

Republican legislative leaders are not inclined to go along with a request by Governor Lehman that they jointly pledge themselves on a $25,000 note to pay expenses of the Governor's unofficial committee to prepare data for the next Constitutional Convention.
The door of baseball's hall of fame swung wide for Frederick Malloy Frankhouse, 33-year-old veteran right-hand Brooklyn pitcher, yesterday-and then it had to be closed on account of rain!

Betting on the horse races at Narragansett Park dropped during the first ten days of the 30-day meeting now in progress, a comprison of figures for this season and for the Summer meeting last year revealed today.

Reenactment by hilarious cowboys of a chapter from the Old West proved so realistic today that a party of tourists for whose benefit the performance was staged spread the word that four men had been killed in a cattle rustlers' raid.

Some Democratic members of Congress who during the recent session opposed Administration measures, particularly the proposal to change the Supreme Court, are encountering hostility from local party leaders since returning home, according to reports reaching here.

MANHATTAN Estate, more than $20,000. To William H. Adams, Cedarhurst, L. I., and Elbridge Adams. New Canaan, Conn., brothers, one-half residue each. Fiduciary Trust Co. of New York, 1 Wall St., executor.

James Maxton, a member of the House of Commons and chairman of the Independent Labor Party, cabled. today from Valencia, Spain, that he had been allowed to visit Jose M. Escuder and other imprisoned members of the P. O. U. M.,. the left-wing Communist faction.
The Giants apparently became entangled in a revolving door yesterday in their frantic pursuit of the Cubs and came out of a doubleheader with the Pirates at precisely the spot where they started.

Miss Frances Studwell Mead of Lake Waccabuc, N. Y., died at the New York Hospital yesterday after a brief illness at the age of 75. She was born in Brooklyn and long was active in church and social work.

Dismissal of 800 aliens from WPA rolls and their replacement by American citizens was announced today by--Harry R. Halloran, WPA director here. Mr. Halloran said that every worker employed by WPA was subjected to a questionnaire several weeks ago to determine his citizenship status under new regulations of the work relief organization.

Representative Emanuel Celler of New York today sent to Secretary of State Hull the following protest against American official representation at the forthcoming Congress of the National Socialist Party to be held at Nuremberg:

Miss Victoria Corse Thorne, daughter of Dr. Victor Corse Thorne of this place and the late Mrs. Thorne, has completed plans for her marriage to Albert Bruce Matthews, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Matthews of Toronto, Canada, which will take place here the afternoon of Sept. 25.

Josephus Daniels, United States Ambassador to Mexico, will return on the United States liner President Roosevelt today from Europe, where he headed a group of delegates to the dedication of American battle monuments in France, England and Belgium.

A record fleet of twenty-two Snipes from all over the country was led home by Bill Leo's Mary Too of Norwalk, Conn., today in the first race of the fourth annual international championship of the popular little class off the New Rochelle Yacht Club.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 5,000 including 2,000 directs. The market was generally steady to 10 higher than yesterday's average;
David F. Riordan, a prominent resident, brother of the late Mayor Joseph P. Riordan, died yesterday in his home here at the age of 79. He had been in ill health since Christmas.

THEY will be running the Hopeful at Saratoga today, which brings up a little matter that has always puzzled this casual and non-expert racegoer. It seems that everybody at Saratoga is talking about the Hopeful and nobody gets around to mentioning the Saratoga Cup. Or at least it isn't mentioned above a whisper. All the shouting is for the Hopeful candidates.

A charity bridge and fashion display given at the Monmouth Hotel here for the benefit of Pitkin Memorial Hospital at Neptune tonight concluded the Summer social schedule of the Ann May Alliance of Spring Lake.
It was a pretty frantic occasion, even for Harlem, when the Government's Negro Theatre unit last evening opened up "Horse Play" at the Lafayette.

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson yesterday directed that a proposed reorganization plan for the Phoenix Silk Manufacturing Company, Inc., calling for a loan of $185,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and the issuance of new capital stock, be submitted to creditors.

Railroad executives and leaders of the "Big Five" operating unions conferred in separate closed sessions today prior to the opening tomorrow of proceedings by a Federal mediator, Dr. William M. Leiserson, who will attempt to iron out the differences arising from the refusal of the roads to grant a demand for a 20 per cent wage increase.
Acting Judge Frank H. Brown ordered four youthful Negroes to roll the dice in Police Court here today to determine their fines for shooting craps.

About 550 allegations of error will be filed Sept. 13 with the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in the appeal of Ellis H. Parker, Burlington County detective, and his son, Ellis H. Parker Jr., who were convicted here June 30 of conspiracy in the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, it was said today by Harry Green of defense counsel.
The marketing of $30,500,000 of bonds and notes of The Ohio Public Service Company swelled the total of new bond offerings for this week to $39,675,000, the largest for any similar period this month.

Summer is drawing to its fitful end: so are the schedules of the rural playhouses. At least eleven are closing after their performances this week-end, not bothering to stick around for such Labor Day trade as there may be.

The prison ward of the psychopathic division of Bellevue Hospital held last night a record number of men detained as suspects in sex offenses. Of a total of sixty prisoners, twenty were of this type. Of these thirteen were admitted yesterday.

As was expected, the money market gave yesterday no positive response to the establishment by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York of a 1 per cent rediscount rate. Quotations on all forms of openmarket credit were unchanged. When a change does come, it is the general expectation that it will be toward higher levels.

Samuel (Chowderhead) Cohen, professional strikebreaker, and his wife Sadie pleaded guilty in the Bronx Court of Special Sessions to a charge of defrauding the ERB of more than $700. Justices Dresser, Salomon and Hackenburg paroled Mrs. Cohen in the custody of her lawyer and remanded her husband to await sentence Friday.

The Brooklyn entrants for the third annual city championships for "barber shop" and "hillbilly" quartets, conducted by the Park Department, were selected last night in a competition held in the Picnic House in Prospect Park.

Though leaves are still green on the bough and the thermometer holds its own, the New York Hippodrome Opera Company last night inaugurated its Fall season-the fifth-and, in so doing, may also be said to have inaugurated the 1937-38 local music season.

The resumption of part-payments on its debt to the United States does credit to the honor and good faith of the Hungarian Government. It means more than the amount involved that a nation in circumstances as difficult as Hungary's, still suffering acutely from the losses due to defeat and partition,
Seamen on American ships calling at ports in the Chinese and Spanish war zones have served notice on their employers that bonuses must be paid as compensation for the wartime hazard.

The Bituminous Coal Commission has set for itself the goal of establishing minimum prices by the first week of October. Since approval of the Guffey-Vinson act, four months ago, the commission has virtually completed the set-up of a nation-wide organization and waded through a mass of preliminary work.

The appointment of James J. Tierney, former secretary and assistant treasurer of the New York Giants, as business manager of the Manhattan football team was announced yesterday by Brother Patrick, president of the college. Mr.

Miss Minnie ?? Tilden gave a luncheon in honor of Mrs. William H. Nichols of New York and Francis T. Nichols of Glen Head, L. I., at Heaton Hall today. Arrivals at the hall include Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Jenks, who are visiting Mrs. Horace R. Shares of Washington;

The Labor Board's hearing into charges that Weirton Steel Company "intimidated" its employes against joining the Committee for Industrial Organization will drag into next year, counsel predicted tonight. W. C. Fahey, counsel for the Employes' Security League, which C. I. O. members have charged with anti-union attacks, said:

The net operating income of the first sixty-one railroads to report for July amounted to $46,970,000, against $51,906,000 in July, 1936, a decrease of 9.5 per cent, and against $22,115,000 in July, 1935, a gain of 112.4 per cent.

Wallace J. Grove, formerly associated with the United Cigar Stores and the Whelan Drug Company, as well as with Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., and Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., has formed a real estate firm to be known as Wallace J. Grove Company, with offices at 17 East Forty-second Street.
President Manuel Quezon said today he was planning development of the rubber industry in the Philippines to make the islands one of the world's leading producers.
Dr. Daisy Newborg Cone, a psychologist who gave much of her services free, died yesterday at her home, 970 Park Avenue. She was 59 years old.
The task of feeding and harboring refugees from Spain has become too difficult and France can no longer handle it.

The transcontinental automobile trip of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Pusey, who have been preaching the gospel and quarreling as they traveled between California and New Jersey, ended here tonight in the murder of the woman.

Pittsburgh at New York (2)-Weaver and Blanton vs. Hubbell and Schumacher or Castleman. Cincinnati at Brooklyn (2)-Derringer and Grissom vs. Hamlin and Butcher. Chicago at Boston (2)-Carleton and Root vs. Fette and Lanning or Bush.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 21 totaled 781,247 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 3,865 cars, or one-half of 1 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 45,771 cars,

The whole of Santander Province is undergoing a cleaning-up, and the Nationalists [Insurgents] are taking many prisoners and much war material. It is said 35,000 prisoners have been taken in the last three days, including 10,000 in Santander.
Contracts closed for fabricated structural steel during July amounted to 160,970 gross tons, compared with 175,552 in June, and to 199,057 in July, 1936.

Equaling the course record, Jack Patroni of Shawnee-on-Delaware, Pa., led the strongest field that has ever competed in the Glens Falls open golf tournament by scoring a 65 in the initial eighteen-hole round today.

Harold M. Butler of Hempstead and Garry Ketcham, playing unattached, posted a brilliant 68, four under par, to lead home a field of eighty-eight pairs today in the qualifying round of the third annual invitation four-ball golf tournament for the Arthur Man trophy at the Seawane Club.
One of the permanent policemen guarding Diego Rivera's residence in the suburb of Coyoacan, where Leon Trotsky is staying, was shot and severely wounded Wednesday night.

A communique announces Italian losses in the battle for Santander from Aug. 14 to 23, ending two days before the Insurgents' entry into the city, numbered 341 killed, of whom 16 were officers, and 1,676 wounded, of whom 60 were officers.
Frederick Pegram, illustrator and poster artist and creator of the famous "Kodak Girl," died here today at the age of 68.
Kenkichi Yoshizawa, head of the American section of the Japanase Foreign Office, sent to the United States Consulate yesterday the following explanation of the blockade of China's coast:
Every polling place in Manhattan will be guarded primary day by watchers for the Mahoney-TaylorSchneider ticket on the alert for irrgularities, Mahoney campaign headquarters announced last night.
More than 300 persons attended the dance held this evening at the Belle Haven Beach Club to aid the children's surgical and orthopedic wards of the Post-Graduate Hospital of New York.

A deed filed for record today shows that former Representative Perry Belmont of New York, now a legal resident of this city, is again in possession of Belcourt, the old Belmont residence located at Bellevue Avenue, Lake View Avenue and Ridge Road.
The Spencer Shoe Corporation, Boston, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 60,000 shares of $20 par

Frank B. Kellogg, former Secretary of State, in a message last night on the anniversary of the signing of the Kellogg-Briand pact designed to outlaw war, declared that "in spite of the spirit of violence which today moves some of the nations who were signatories,

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Thomas A. Mathis, New Jersey Secretary of State and long a political power in the State, was accused of income-tax invasion for 1930 and 1933 in an indictment returned today by a Federal grand jury here.

Domestic sales of household refrigerators to distributors and dealers in July totaled 179,414, valued at $14,823,327, compared with 186,639, valued at $14,860,337, in July 1936, the National Electrical Manufacturers Association reported yesterday.

The listed bond market looked moderately better yesterday in comparison with recent sessions. This, however, was largely attributable to a drying-up of offerings. It was clearly evident that some fresh support had entered the market.

Counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission spent yesterday in filling in their picture of the deal surrounding registration and sale of 273,000 shares of Trenton Valley Distillers Corporation stock in 1935 and 1936.

Andrew W. Mellon was not, as political and business bodies sometimes acclaimed him during his official term, the greatest Treasury Secretary since Hamilton. He would have been the first to deprecate such eulogy.
Delegations of Germans from all parts of the world will assemble here tomorrow to hear the Nazis' highest leaders enlarge on the dictum that "Germans abroad exist for the Reich."
The body of a comely woman, was found crammed into a barrel on the rocky shore line of Queens, about 500 feet east of Hell Gate Bridge, yesterday.

The quest for apartments, many of which will be occupied on Oct, 1, shifted partly to the West Side yesterday when brokers and renting agents signed up many tenants for rooms in houses on Central Park West, Riverside Drive and adjacent streets.
Menacing flood waters were receding tonight in Southern New York and Northern Pennsylvania after threatening for a time to repeat the havoc wrought in the flood of 1935.

Declaring that Governor Lehman "would not wish me to discriminate in his favor," Magistrate Mogilesky imposed a five-day sentence yesterday on Herman Gamb, 35 years old, who last Monday damaged a car in which the Governor was riding when he drove

The right of employers to counterpicket, subject to the same limitations placed upon picketing by labor unions, has been upheld by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine in a letter to the National Citizens Committee, made public yesterday by Ormsby McHarg, executive secretary of the committee.

Mrs. Winifred Young Foster, widow of General J. Clifford R. Foster, who was for many years adjutant general of the State of Florida and at one time manager of the Broadway Improvement Association of New York, died at her home here today.
The disturbed condition in the Far East together with that in Spain will be discussed tomorrow in many pulpits. Especially will the situation of the American missionaries in the Orient be dwelt upon.

Nine persons, including the masters and passengers of two cabin cruisers which collided in the Manasquan River Inlet, and a lone lobster fisherman who had spent a solitary night at sea in heavy fog, were saved from injury or drowning here today.
Willem van de Wall, New York musical educator, received a divorce today from Mrs. Blanca F. van de Wall of Allentown, Pa., on grounds of five years' separation.

An independent body known as the Brotherhood of United Aircraft Workers of America, Inc., has opened headquarters in the National City Building, 17 East Forty-second Street, It was revealed yesterday, with plans to organize the airplane industry on a vast scale.

William H. Hahn of 25-80 Thirtyeighth Street, Astoria, died yesterday after a short illness. He was a resident of Astoria for more than fifty years and was employed for many years until his retirement several years ago by the United States Malt -Company, Greenpoint.

A high Nanking Government spokesman admitted to the writer last night that the Chinese troops were now engaged in a general withdrawal from the Woosung area, near the mouth of the Whangpoo River, and also from the immediate vicinity of Shanghai, falling back gradually with minimum losses to well-prepared lines.

The Duplan Silk Corporation announced today a new wage scale that will add $250,000 a year to the pay checks of 6,000 employes. The scale will be put into effect Sept. 1 in Duplan mills in Wilkes-Barre, Kingston, Hazleton, Nanticoke and Berwick.

In the same Federal Court House in Canandaigua in which Susan B. Anthony was convicted for voting in 1873 will sit the first women jurors impaneled in New York State under the Woman Juror Law which becomes effective next Wednesday.

Two lifeboats have been provisioned with emergency rations as terrific ice pressure following a heavy snowstorm and gales that swept the vessel bearing the MacGregor Arctic Expedition off her course, has forced the expedition to consider the necessity of abandoning the ship.

Young persons from all parts of this city, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and New England will attend a conference arranged as a special feature of the Berkshire Bible Fellowship at Chestnut Hill, Monteray, Mass The conference will begin this evening and continue through Labor Day.
