Finnish foreign shipping is threatened with a serious stoppage as a consequence of the sailors' unions decision to call out on strike all engine room, deck and kitchen hands on Sept. 1.

Charley Stetson, 17-year-old Star boat sailor from Southport, Conn., and his Pequot Yacht Club crew of Bob Gordon and Bill Watkins, both 16, today took the Sears Bowl, emblematic of the national junior sailing championship.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 25: Carr, Capt. G. W., Med. Corps, Medical Officer in command of Naval Hospital, Parris Island, S. C., to National Station, Guam.

C. W. Wildrick, vice president of Klopstock Co., Inc., occupied the stand yesterday for the fourth successive day in the Securities and Exchange Commission's hearing of stop-order proceedings against the Austin Silver Mining Company.

Results of a three-year study of suicide, conducted under the auspices of the Boston City Hospital, were revealed tonight, yielding as the major conclusion that suicide was a disease which in a majority of cases was preventable.

Resolutions endorsing fair trade practices by all branches of the jewelry industry, including an extension of the Federal stamping laws, were adopted yesterday by members of the American National Retail Jewelers Association at the closing session of the annual convention held at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria.

When the SinoJapanese conflict comes before the League of Nations again, France will suggest that the League Council take parallel action with the United States, it was learned tonight on the best authority.

Mrs. John H. Livingston and Miss Janet Livingston have arrived at the New Weston from Clermont, their place in Tivoli-on-Hudson. Mr. and Mrs. Winston Guest have joined Mr. and Mrs. Wyllys R. Betts at the Carlyle.

Directors of Amoskeag Industries, Inc., which acquired the assets of the liquidated Amoskeag Manufacturing Company, textile mills, last October for $5,000,000, today declared a 125 per cent dividend to its stockholders. The payment is to be $25 a share in cash and 100 per cent in five-year notes bearing interest at 6 per cent.

It would be easy to cast a stern, adult glance at the Messrs. Walter Hackett, Gene Fowler, Allen Rivkin and Ernest Pascal (any more, gents?) for trifling with the Spanish civil war as they do in "Love Under Fire" at the Roxy, but for any except the most priggish it is going to be hard indeed to conceal a glint of amusement. In fact,

Eighteen lines of tender verse, penned eighty years ago in the weeping willow mood of the day, produced an effect yesterday almost like music on the ears of the numerous Mayfield claimants for the $877,000 fortune left by Mrs. Ida E. Wood, the aged Herald Square recluse.

Renewed uncertainty today over the Far Eastern situation caused the stock market to weaken. Business, however, was on an extremely small scale, but most sections lost ground. Giltedge issues were dull. Chinese and Japanese bonds, on the other hand, improved slightly.

Mrs. Emma Rockefeller McAlpin, widow of Dr. David H. McAlpin and daughter of William Rockefeller, left a net estate of $5,648,350 when she died on Aug. 11, 1934, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

The Hamburg-American Line was deprived yesterday of its privilege to enter the liner Hansa in this port without the formality of medical examination at Quarantine, after the vessel passed through the public health-station and went to her pier with twenty-four cases of suspected paratyphoid in her crew.

The Hotel Le Marquis and annex at 12 East Thirty-first Street and 11 East Thirtieth Street have been sold by the Seaman's Bank for Savings to a company headed by S. L. Lebis. Adams Co. were the brokers.

Melvin Fine, Republican State Senator, was presented by the grand jury today on a charge of conspiring to take two women to Annapolis during the last Legislature for the "purpose of prostitution, lewdness and assignation."
Eighteen persons were wounded, some seriously; thousands of gallons of milk were spilled, and a train starter narrowly escaped lynching in a triple Central Railway train collision today.

Under the chairmanship of Arthur Winslow, son of Mrs. Cameron McR. Winslow and the late Admiral Winslow, there was a ball at Newport Beach tonight in the interest of the National Civil Service Reform Association, of which Mr.

Thetford Academy paid tribute today on its annual alumni day to its oldest alumna, Mrs. Abbie F. (Porter) Bond, whose name appears among the students listed as "English Department-Females" in the 1857 catalogue.

Briggs S. Cunningham's six-meter yacht Lulu will begin racing today against the challengers of Finland, Norway and Sweden in defense of the Scandinavian Gold Cup. The series will be held off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club at Oyster Bay, L. I. Today's race will start at 2:10 o'clock, with the course a triangular one.

A Congressional committee investigating the loss of thirty-four ballots in last November's disputed election for Representative-In the First New Hampshire District threatened today to subpoena citizens unless they appeared voluntarily to say whether they voted.

Pritchard H. Strong, youthful Republican Assemblyman of Rochester, was killed early today along with Mrs. Strong and two other persons when his new five-passenger airplane overshot the Albany Airport and tore through the treetops a mile and a half to the south.

With volume of sales increasing, Victor Fischel, vice president of Lincoln Inn Distilling Company, announced yesterday that his company has now under consideration a large advertising campaign which will begin in the Fall.

F. G. Carroll, 35-year-old hardware merchant of Brecksville, Ohio, emerged from the greatest scoring spree in trapshooting history today with the thirty-eighth annual Grand American Handicap championship, smashing 100 straight targets from the 19-yard line.

Playing before a home crowd for the first time this season in the role of league champions, the Newark Bears tonight uncorked a fifteen-hit attack and trounced the Jersey City Giants, 11 to 2. Bob Seeds and Nolen Richardson, with three hits apiece, paced the barrage off three Jersey City pitchers.

Nearly three-fifths of the cases which have come before the National Labor Relations Board since it began operations in the Autumn of 1935 have been closed, it was stated today in a board report showing that in that time it had handled 6,479 disputes, involving 1,944,088 workers.

Operations of the F. E. Myers Bro. Company in the nine months ended on July 31 resulted in a net profit of $987,580 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges. No provision, however, has been made for Federal surtax on undistributed income.

The Eastern college all-stars held their first regular scrimmage on the Peddie School field this morning in preparation for their game against the New York Giants in the Polo Grounds Sept. 8. It was a short session and when it was over Andy Kerr of Colgate, the coach, expressed satisfaction with the resuits.

Mrs. Jane Baker Lindsay, daughter of Mrs. William Hogg Baker of Montclair and the late Mr. Baker, was married today to William George Volkmann Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. W G. Volkmann of Piedmont, Calif.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: In a letter to THE TIMES last week some one criticized the New York Yankees baseball club for disregarding Ladies' Day. There was nothing said in defense of the Ruppert organization.

Thomas E. Rohan, Democratic candidate for Municipal Court jus twice in the Seventh district, is not "seeking restoration" to the ballot, as indicated in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Friday. The Board of Elections records show that Mr. Rohan has never been off the ballot. The action brought on Mr.

Boscawen is a New Hampshire village on the Merrimac whose name, one is happy to learn from The Gazetteer, is pronounced "Boskwoin." A dispatch from there in The Manchester Union has its charm not only for those of us who take delight in little things but for students of demonology, heredity,
The exhilaration and grief of war marched hand in hand today as trains bearing new troops for the China front made way for others bringing back Japan's dead and wounded.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Manson Weir, daughter of Mrs. David Manson Weir of Steubenville, Ohio, to William Prescott Bonbright 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Bonbright of Grosse Pointe, Mich., took place here this afternoon at the Lodge,

Some anglers, it seems, fail to realize that an activity which means sport to them means bread and butter to others. It is in connection with this that we received a letter from Francis H. Low, president of the Beach Haven Tuna Club and the Manasquan River Marlin and Tuna Club.

The effects of the Federal tax on undistributed profits are proving a serious obstacle to recovery, particularly in the capital goods industries, and tend to affect retailing adversely, H. I. Kleinhaus,

A shortage of rice in Costa Rica has stimulated a movement in Panama for the establishment of nationally owned and operated rice mills,. A. R. Randolph, American trade commissioner in Panama, said in a report made public today by the Department- of Commerce.

Miss Mary Fay Skelton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John William Skelton of 110 Ryerson Street, Brooklyn, was married last night to Andrew McLean, son of Mr. and Mrs. David J. McLean of Brooklyn and Eatontown, N. J., in the Clinton Avenue Congregational Church.
Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine and Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, conferred yesterday on plans to prevent, fraudulent registration of voters from hotels and lodging houses.
Regent Admiral Nicholas Horthy of Hungary, in the role of special peacemaker and international fence-repairer, began an "unofficial vacation" today in Austria.

Mexican women today had the promise of President Lazaro Cardenas that they will soon enjoy equal political rights with Mexican men. President Cardenas in a speech at Veracruz last night announced that he would send a bill to Congress when it opens next month to grant women the right to vote and to participate fully in the country's political life.
The State Banking Department today announced that it had authorized the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company of New York to open a branch office at 453 East Eighty-sixth Street on, or after, Oct. 1.

Passing of the heat wave veered consumer interest more to early Fall promotions this week, but reduced sales at so many key cities that the increase in retail sales for the country averaged barely 2 per cent over the previous week, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Premier Hendryk Colijn, in a written answer to a NationalSocialist member of the Lower House, indicates the Netherlands Government for reasons of an international political nature is unwilling to state whether it is ready to recognize de jure General Francisco Franco's government in Spain.

The aircraft carrier Ranger, the navy's newest and swiftest craft in that category, will be sent to Callao, at the request of the Peruvian Government to give a demonstration of naval aviation operations.

The body of Andrew W. Mellon, banker and statesman and reputedly one of the world's wealthiest men, left here tonight in a simple, inexpensive coffin in the lounge of a private railroad car. He died here yesterday and will be buried tomorrow in Pittsburgh.

Track conditions tonight complicated the outlook for the $40,000 Hopeful Stakes feature of the final day of the Spa meeting tomorrow. Twelve of the best 2year-olds in the country were named overnight, making the dash a meeting of championship proportions between the best juveniles of the East and the West.

A perjury indictment against Henry Miro, formerly known as Harlem's "policy king," which grew out of his testimony before the Appellate Division's investigation of the Magistrates' Courts conducted by Samuel Seabury, was dismissed yesterday by General Sessions Judge John J. Freschi.

It is unnecessary to remark upon the irony of the fact that the anniversary of the signing of the KelloggBriand peace treaty fell yesterday upon a day which found the nations of the world deeply disturbed by war and threats of war.

Resumption of newspaper advertising by cigarette manufacturers on a large scale will help to boost linage, which has been lagging, during the coming months, according to comment here yesterday. Old Golds will resume in an extended list on Monday to announce a new campaign, Chesterfield returned to newspaper this week, while Camels continue their large space testimonial copy.

Eight hundred persons tonight honored the membry of Robert E. Lee-at the sixtyfifth annual Lee monument ball in the Cameo Ball Room of the Greenbrier. Proceeds are for the benefit of. the Lee Memorial Foundation, Inc.

Paul Pisculli announced today that drowning hereafter is going to be next to impossible, provided citizens susceptible to that form of demise take the precaution to swallow one of the pills he has invented.

Emil Scholz, a German heavyweight making his first ring appearance in this country, outpointed Sandy McDonald, rangy Dallas battler, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

A new and important archaeological zone has been discovered by Mexican scientists near the city of Chilapa in the State of Guerrero after a three-day horsebackjourney, according to an official announcement.

Albert Runge of 46-11 156th Street, Flushing, died Thursday night at Cumberland Hospital, Brooklyn. His age was 60. He was born in Brooklyn, a son of the late Edward and Louisa Runge. He came to Flushing when a boy and had lived here since.

Total- exports of hardwood and softwood lumber (including sawed timber) and logs for the first six months of 1937 totaled 838,587 M board feet as compared with 854,917 M feet for the corresponding period of 1936, a loss of 1.9 per cent, according to figures released by the Forest Products Division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

Captain George Fried, chairman of a special Department of Commerce committee hearing charges of insubordination on the part of crews of the Seatrain Line ships New York and Havana, suddenly adjourned the investigation yesterday afternoon after a sharp exchange between a union spokesman and a member of the committee.

Pablo de Churruca, Marquis of Aycenena, presented his credentials today as the Spanish Insurgent Charge d'Affaires to the Holy See. The formality emphasized the Vatican de facto recognition of the Spanish Insurgent regime.

Two short forward passes in the last period went for touchdowns and enabled the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League to defeat the Eastern College All-Stars at Temple -Stadium tonight, 14 to 6, before a crowd of 20,000 fans.

Mrs. Tristram R. Coffin of Wakefield, R. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Trelsie Potter Coffin, to Thomas Arnold Buffum, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Potter Buffum of Providence and Sakonnet.
For the second time within two weeks two gun crews of the Sixty-second Coast Artillery from Fort Totten have broken world records for fast and accurate firing of antiaircraft guns.

The American Federation of Labor is making what William Green, president, says are satisfactory strides in the organization of workers in the textile industry. He made the announcement at the Hotel Ambassador here tonight at the close of today's session of the executive council of the federation.

A petition seeking reorganization of the estate of Louis Bossert, Inc., owner and operator of the Hotel Bossert at Montague and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, was filed yesterday in the Federal court in that borough.

A peaceful settlement of the differences between the Grand Opera Artists Association and the American Guild of Musical Artists, who have been at odds for the last few months, appeared imminent yesterday afternoon as officials of the two organizations tentatively agreed on an amalgamation.

Tommy Farr yesterday hit the deck of his training camp ring in Long Branch, N. J., with a thud that was heard round the boxing world. But the occurrence only brought a laugh from Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S. C., who is conducting Farr's championship bid against Joe Louis, scheduled for Monday night in the Yankee Stadium.

Dr. Julius Milton Friedman, who was a Philadelphia automobile dealer from 1909 to 1922 and part of that time an executive of the Reo agency there, died of a heart attack at his residence in Ventnor today. He was 60 years old.
The Treasury has completed new simplified forms for Federal income tax payers which are expected to eliminate confusion when the time comes for the March returns.
Harry J. Socolow of New York and Cedarhurst, L. I., prominent in Jewish affairs, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after having undergone an operation for an infection. He was 65 years old.

The most gratifying thing about the "New Folies Bergere" revue, which popped its cork a week ago last evening at the French Casino, is the deliberate abandon with which it surrenders itself to comedy.
Federal officials who supervise speculative trading in farm commodities announced today a ruling which they said would facilitate trading for both commission houses and the public.

Substantial block of stocks .of the International Harvester Company and also other securities were liquidated by the Cyrus H. McCormick estate to meet the Federal inheritance tax of approximately $10,398,000, the trustees disclosed today. Judson F. Stone of the trustees said the sales of Harvester stock were made on the open market.
Another trial of employes on Far Eastern railways has resulted in the execution of thirty-two more as Trotskyists, Rightist terrorist "wreckers" in the service of Japanese secret agents.

Barrow St, 70, 20.10x104.5xirr; Velviei Realty Corp (Idel Wulf, pres) to John Grasso, 29-17 Broadway, Astoria, L. I. Mtg. $11,500 ($3.50). Water St, 440, 25x60; Tenement Renovation Contracting Co (Geo W Files, press, to Margt J Carlcato, 8,104 14th Ave, Brooklyn (50c).

State and municipal' financing scheduled for next week totals only $9,711,200, to be represented by 49 municipalities, as compared with the revised total of $15,652,298 for this week, a decrease of $5,941,098. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $25,570,975.

The Excelsior Savings Bank sold to West Harlem Estates, Inc., the five-story apartment house for t twenty families at 197 West 134th Street, near Seventh Avenue. Assessed at $40,000, the property was rehabilitated recently and sold for cash over a mortgage of $31,500. Darling McDonald were the brokers.

Lord Rothschild, head of the English branch of the famous banking family and equally well known as naturalist and philanthropist, died today at his home, Tring Park, Hertfordshire, after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

Indictment of Secretary of State Mathis, in the Federal court at Camden today on charges of attempted evasion of income tax payments, caused surprise to his home town folks of Toms River, seat of his Republican political dynasty for the last score of years.

The Western Hemisphere is the only quarter of the earth to which one may "point with comfort" as harboring pacific sentiments and giving "eloquent expression to its genuine desire for peace," George A. Messersmith, Assistant Secretary of State, told a radio audience tonight.

A House leader disclosed today that an investigation was under way of the reported recording of votes on House roll-calls of Representatives known to have been out of town. He was unwilling to be quoted by name, but insisted that there was "evidence of a major scandal."

The inventive skill of a hospital engineer, guided by a doctor's knowledge, tonight fashioned a homemade wooden lung and undoubtedly saved the life of a flaxen-hafred 4-year-old boy upon whose chest the grip of infantile-paralysis was tightening.
Consular requests that 14 British and United States citizens facing trial for possession of arms be transferred from military barracks to a hotel here were refused today by Cuban authorities.

" The Man in Blue," a Kubec Glasmon story which was known simply as "The Cop" before the Universal title-changers got busy, will replace "The Dark Journey" this evening on the screen of the Central Theatre. Robert Wilcox,
The New York Police pistol team put up a strong battle on the firing line today in the race for the Sobel Team Trophy, but finished third when it totaled 169 out of a possible 200.

Mrs. Marion Turpie of Plandome won the women's Long Island medal play golf championship at Cherry Valley today by the margin of seven strokes when she added an 82 to her first and second rounds of 79 and 83 for a total of 244. In taking the title for the third year in a row she retired the cup.

THE HAGUE. QUEEN WILHELMINA opens the new session of the Netherlands Parliament on Sept. 21, driving to and from the historic Hall of the Knights in the golden coach, one of the most gorgeous of all the State coaches which have survived on the Continent.

PERUGIA'S contributions to music culture will be resumed this Fall, under the title of "Sagra Musical Umbra" (Umbrian Music Festival), as an amplification of Guido Visconti di Modrone's annual illustrated lecture courses for foreigners.

To the Music Editor: There appeared in your columns of the Aug. 8 edition a letter by John L. Bawden which was such a basic denial of our times and our people (a la Spengler) that I feel impelled to send you this response.
Children from more than forty camps are returning to their homes this week, averaging three times as great gains in physical fitness as did the campers of yesteryear.

The executive council of the American Federation of Labor, in session at the Hotel Ambassador today, announced the opening of a vigorous organizing campaign in the maritime field along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.

Coach Elmer Layden issued a call today to eighty-four candidates for the 1937 Notre Dame football team to report for the first practice Sept. 10. For the first few days drills will be held twice daily.

The New York A. C. eight defeated the New Rochelle Rowing Club representatives by three and a quarter lengths today in the halfmile feature of the fifty-seventh annual regatta held by the New Rochelle organization on Echo Bay.

Josephus Daniels, former Secretary of the Navy and nowAmbassador to Mexico, returned yesterday onn the President Roosevelt of the United States Lines with other delegates to the dedication of fourteen monuments to the American war ist, dead in England, France and Belgium.

THE public school systems of the United States must not simply expand, as they will have to do to meet the educational needs of an increasingly large number of young people under 21 years of age for whom there is no place in industry, but they should do so in the light of changed conditions and the twofold requirements of the new crop of high school recruits.

Answering a written question put by the Socialist leader, M. Albarda, Premier Hendryk Colijn said instructions had been given to The Netherlands Minister at Berlin to ask an inquiry into the alleged ill-treatment of a Netherlands subject named Aalders during his imprisonment in Germany in an attempt to extract a confession of espionage.

THIS is the latest of an important series of popular science books published by arrangement with the University of Chicago Press. It has been written by thirteen authors, who, with one exception, all teach at the University of Chicago. Several of them have written for the public at large before.

In the last month and a half more has been achieved in the way of clarifying the situation of Palestine than in the last eighteen years. If the Royal Commission report has not offered a satisfactory solution of the Arab-Jewish impasse in Palestine it has at least opened a way for a more frank and open discussion of the fundamental factors and issues of this impasse.

Announcement was made today by Dr. W. C. Jackson, dean of administration of the Woman's College of the University of North Carolina, of the appointment of Dr. Elizabeth Duffy as Professor of Psychology.

IN announcing the specifications of its newest product, the Lock heed Aircraft Corporation of Burbank, Calif., last week emphasized publicly for the first time among American aircraft manufacturers the ease with which a commercial transport plane may be converted into a military bomber.

Square dances in the Berkshires district are popular with younger members of society, many of whom attended a fireman's ball at the near-by Town Hall, where 1,000 Summer residents and townspeople danced the. lancers, Virginia reel and moneymusk.

Henry M. Flagler, pioneer of Florida's east coast, closeted himself in his office one day in 1905, pored over architects' sketches of massive concrete viaducts spanning miles of open water and visualized trains running out to sea.

AS outspoken in his own way as a Faulkner or a Caldwell, Mr. Meloney has spared one nothing in this strange, powerful little story of a New York State farm family. "Rush to the Sun" is strong meat-a novel almost wholly concerned with sex and darkened frequently by violence.

Major Gen. Hugh A. Drum, who relinquished command of the First Division at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, seven years ago to become inspector general of the army and later deputy chief of staff at Washington, will arrive at the Brooklyn Army Base tomorrow aboard the transport U. S. Grant.

Briggs Cunningham made his first blow in defense of the Scandinavian Gold Cup a telling one today. In the opening race of the series for one of the world's greatest small-boat trophies, Cunningham handed the challengers from overseas, Finland, Norway and Sweden, a sound thumping with his six-meter yacht Lulu.

Charitable institutions in France, inmates of which received benefactions from the late Edith Wharton, novelist, after the World War, will share in her American estate, according to her will, filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

Cancellations of Shanghai-bound cargoes out of Pacific Coast ports continue. Dollar Company officials reported today that consignments on the President Garfield and other Dollar ships for the Chinese port have been canceled.

"OLD FUSS AND FEATHERS," as he was known in no unkindly spirit by the army, was a grand man, in size and heart, in integrity and patriotism. Major Elliott, as he makes plain on the title page, deals with the man as well as with the soldier.

WITH more than 200 agricultural experts, farm paper publishers, practical farmers and bankers from agricultural communities looking on, the new Graham Bradley tractor was formally presented at Washington, Ind., recently.

The marriage of Miss Carolyn Hodder, daughter of Mrs. Theodore P. Markwith of East Orange, to Walter E. Frohboese, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Frohboese, also this city, took place this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church here. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Charles E. Hutchinson.

David S. South, State registrar, today said there were 3,187 marriages in New Jersey last month, 635 more than in the same month last year. Births totaled 4,984, a rate of 13.6 per 1,000. In July, 1936, there were 4,990 births.

With auspicious opening this week of the fourteen markets of North Carolina's great new bright tobacco belt, prospects seem good for an even better season for the Southern growers of bright leaf than that of 1936.

Miss Ruth Hoerger, 14-year-old swimming star of the Miami Beach A. C., who was runner-up to Miss Mavis Freeman in the National A. A. U. senior long distance championship a month ago, scored today in 27:23.4 in the national junior one-mile free style title test, conducted by the Bayville Aquatic Club over a course of approximately half a mile in Long Island Sound.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation was accused today by the National Labor Relations Board of unfair labor practices and was cited to appear at a hearing to be held Sept. 8 at Franklin Boro, Pa., a community adjacent to the company's Cambria plant at Johnstown.

Mrs. Rose Michton, wife of Morris Michton, president of the Ideal Novelty and Toy Company of Long Island City, died Friday at her home, 180 Winthrop Street, Brooklyn. Born in Russia seventy years ago, she had lived in Brooklyn since 1892.

Formation of a provincial advisory council, consisting of four outstanding business men of Alberta, to advise and assist in joint action of Liberals, Conservatives and the United Farmers of Alberta in effecting "establishment of a sound business government at Edmonton" was proposed by E. L. Gray, provincial leader of the Liberal party, here today.
The Japanese Army today claimed smashing victories in its campaign to open a highway .into China's northwestern provinces.

A proposal that "every" single business association" in the nation join in a cooperative drive for cleaning up the unemployment problem within two years was put before the twentieth annual Conference on Industrial Relations today by Ernest J. Draper, Assistant Secretary of Commerce.

The marriage of Miss Mary Katherine Barrett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred W. Barrett of this place, to Frederick W. Knutson, son of Mrs. John Knutson of Boston, took place here at noon today in the Methodist Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Paul F. Douglass.

Launching by the Queens North Shore chapter of the Long Island Real Estate Board of a home sales campaign having a purchase plan designed for families able to make only a moderate down payment, featured the realty activities on Long Island last week.

The marriage of Miss Margot Agnes Nietsche, daughter of Mrs. Paul Ryder Bishop of Boston, to Alfred Frederick Melzig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred H. J. Melzig of Roselle, N. J., took place here yesterday at noon in the Church of the Transfiguration. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Pay.

THE 1937-38 season of the Youngstown (Ohio) Symphony Society, Michael and Carmine Ficocelli, conductors, will offer seven concerts, with the following soloists: Albert Spalding, Rosa Tentoni, Harold Bauer, Nino Martini, Hermann Gruss, Marion Stavrovsky, Grace Straw Wilson, Earl Hartland, Ralph Brown and others to be announced later.
The name of the Brazilian dreadnought Minas Geraes was changed overnight to Stalin. The ship was in drydock, undergoing repairs. This morning a naval inspector discovered
Ray Splivalo, State Railroad Commissioner and husband of Rheba Crawford, evangelist, died at Glendale Sanitarium today. He was 53 years old.

On Sunday, Sept. 12, the 170th anniversary of the founding of St. Peter's Episcopal Church in - the Manor of Cortlandt will be celebrated with an all-day program at the present St. Peter's church here and at the original church at Van Cortlandtville, a suburb of this village.

Letters from employes, anxious to safeguard their pension rights under the Social Security Act, have enabled the Bureau of Internal Revenue to put a stop to evasion of social security payroll taxes by 700 Manhattan employers, Joseph T. Higgins, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third New York District, disclosed yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Janet Tissot Coliett, daughter of Mrs. Samuel Dunlap Collett of 27 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, and Shelter Island Heights, L. I., and the late Mr. Collett, to Trafton Otis Badger, son of Mrs. Estelle Randall Badger of Forest Hills, Queens, and William Otis Badger of Brooklyn and Shelter Island, took place yesterday at noon at Sherry's.

The failure of the four walls of a house to provide protection from accidents was illustrated in the recent report of a committee of the Greater New York Safety Council that for the first six months of 1937 more than 30 per cent of 2,055 accidental deaths in the city occurred in homes.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. A. Francis Goodlove of this city of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jane Cornelia Goodlove, to Curtis Deitrich-Morgan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Henry Morgan of Tampa, Fla.

Popular tropical fish of the past decade, family members of the guppys, bettas (Siamese fighters), gouramis and feather fins, are being challenged in popular fancy by a strange assortment of newcomers, according to collectors at the tenth annual show of the Greater City Aquarium Society of Brooklyn, now on view at the Turn' Verein, Bushwick and Gates Avenues.
IT begins to appear as if music on a big scale will invade the peaceful Summer landscape in vacation land, just as the drama has moved into barns, town halls and old houses.

Miss. Carol Elizabeth Wheeler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar C. Wheeler of this village, and Donald William Easler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry D. Easler of Manchester, N. H., were married this afternoon in Trinity- Episcopal Church. The rector, the Rev. Dr. Hedley J. Williams, officiated.

Senator Royal-S. Copeland, Tammany's candidate for Mayor, attacked yesterday the Tammany district leaders who denied designation for renomination to Justice David C. Lewis in the Seventh Municipal Court District. Justice Lewis,

A protest by a group of Brooklyn moving van owners against the procedure followed by the City Housing Authority in receiving bids for transferring 1,471 families to the new Williamsburg PWA housing project next month was discounted by Langdon W. Post, chairman of the Authority.

The marriage of Miss Nancy Stevenson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Alston Stevenson of East Chop, Martha's Vineyard, and Yonkers, N. Y., to Peter Bulkeley Langmuir, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Herbert Laligmuir of East Chop and Englewood, N. J., took place here this afternoon in the First Church of Martha's Vineyard.

Miss Margaret Jamieson Hanemann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Hanemann of this place, was married this morning in the chapel of the Cathedral of the Incarnation here to Stanley Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Brown, also of Garden City. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. Arthur B. Kinsolving 2d, dean of the cathedral.

The first oysters of the season are due in New York markets and restaurants on Wednesday. Anybody's guess is good as to. their price, quality and quantity, for oystermen themselves have in advance no idea of what the beds will yield.

Stanley Wooderson, little, spindly, bespectacled bank clerk, smashed the world mile record today and became the first Englishman in more than fifty years to set a new international standard at that classic distance.

NOBODY knows exactly how many people in the country suffer from hay fever. The number cannot be far from 2,000,000. At least 9,000,000 cough and sneeze a little without being aware of their sensitivity. And this because ragweed, the chief offender, occurs in nearly all the territory east of the Rocky Mountains with the exception of the Northern Great Lakes region, Northern New England and Southern Florida.

The clash of arms in the undeclared war between China and Japan was last week heard around the world, echoing in chancellery and market place. As foreign powers watched anxiously, two armed forces battled in teeming Shanghai and, hundreds of miles northward, other forces struggled for advantage within the shadow of the Great Wall.

Undaunted by three crashes and failure to place in two major air races during the five years she has been piloting airplanes, Miss Jacqueline Cochran took off from North Beach Airport yesterday for Los Angeles, where she plans to start in the transcontinental race for the Bendix Trophy Friday.

THIS is the honest autobiography of one of industry's "money players." As Samuel M. Vauclain, chairman of the board of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, comments in a foreword, Custer was "the damnedest person to pin down * * *." He says also,

WASHINGTON. -- With approval by President Roosevelt of a $35,000 authorization, the Accident Prevention Conference, created in 1936, is assured of another year for its operations. The general chairman is Senator A. Harry Moore of New Jersey, and the work of the conference is carried on through about a dozen subcommittees.
James I. Roland O'Connor of 3367 160th Street, Flushing, mechanical engineer, died yesterday in Flushing Hospital at the age of 41. He had been a patient there since an operation Aug. 17.
Five miles below the tip of Manhattan, in the water of lower New York Bay, lies Staten Island, so christened by Henry Hudson for the States-General of the Netherlands.

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Francis Hodgdon of this city, formerly of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Carolyn Hodgdon, to William George Edinburgh Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Edinburgh of Brooklyn, N. Y., and West Hampton, L. I.

THE fifth annual conference of the Institute of Human Rela tions at Williamstown, Mass., held Aug. 29-Sept. 3 under auspices of the National Conference of JewS and Christians, will be covered in several broadcasts.

Eleven of the original forty entries in the open tournament of the American Chess Federation who qualified for the championship finals started play today and Erich W. Marchand of St. Louis, who played varsity chess for Harvard, where he was graduated in the class of '36, was the first to win a game.

On Oct. 6, only three years since he swept into power at the head of a Liberal government after almost thirty years of- Conservative rule in Ontario, Premier Mitchell Hepburn will go to the Province for a new mandate.
Before the outbreak of the Spanish civil war, life in the busy little port of Santander on the Bay of Biscay flowed around the Plaza de Velarde, a square in the center of the town.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Dr. Shatara's recent letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES is a typical example of the reasoning which is responsible for the gulf between Jews and Arabs. For in all sincerity and good-will, apparently, Dr. Shatara postulates the fair-sounding generalities of cooperation, friendship and peace upon assumptions which are precisely the points at issue.
The serenity of Joe Louis's final workout for his fight with Tommy Farr was disturbed this afternoon by an accident that for a time threatened to have serious consequences.

Getting nearer New York with every thrust of his sturdy arms, Charles Zimmy, 46 years old and legless, swam into port at Rockland Landing, about thirty miles from here, last evening, The Associated Press reported.
THIS caravan of the "off time creative work" of fifty writers and sixteen artists employed in the WPA has been selected for artistic excellence and to represent the range of interest covered.

The Department of Justice took a hand early today in the strange disappearance of Morris B. Close, 23, of Rochester, N. Y., a scoutmaster, whose abandoned automobile was found on a Memphis street on July 26.

ANTICIPATING that the socalled stamp illustration liber alization bill will be revived during the next session of Congress, after having failed of enactment by the House before adjournment, leading philatelic publishers are expecting to request that a publie hearing be held so they can present their ideas as to how virtually unrestricted reproducing of postal paper can be permitted without subjecting the Government unduly to risk of counterfeiting.

Franklin T. (Frank) McCracken, sports writer of The Philadelphia Evening Ledger, died last night in Jefferson Hospital after an illness of a week. Mr. McCracken, who was stricken with a heart attack at his home at Avalon, N. J., was 42 years old.

Before 30,000 spectators, air men of France, Canada and the United States joined today in an exhibition at St. Hubert Airfield, outside Montreal. Ideal weather conditions prevailed for the first half of the twoday show sponsored by the French Government.
THIS story of a macaw is original and charming, full of color as the bird it describes, and as unusual in our temperate latitude. Mrs. Von der Goltz describes the life of one bird (known as "arara"
Beneath cloudless skies and in the presence of a record crowd, which was admitted free, the twentyeighth annual Smithtown Horse Show was held today on Fifty-Acre Field.

The construction industry, which has lagged behind others in the recovery drive, is looking forward to the beginning of the Federal low-cost housing program as the greatest single stimulus it has had since the depression started nearly eight years ago. Leaders of labor, too, are jubilant at the prospects of putting to work many thousands of men who have had only spasmodic periods of employment during the past few years.
State Senator Clifford R. Powell of Burlington County, candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor, was feted tonight by 600 labor leaders, members of the American Federation of Labor.

EDMOND FLEG'S version of Goethe's "Faust," in spite of its conscientious attempt to maintain the philosophic spirit of the original, served as little more than an excuse for Gaston Baty's ingenious, detailed and often charming reproductions of. German fifteenth century backgrounds and costumes, with more than a suggestion of the paintings of some of the early Rhenish masters.

John Hamilton, Republican National Committee chairman, in an address before the Hamilton County Republican Club tonight denounced what he called "Rooseveltian personal government" and called on the President to announce whether he will seek a third term.

Miss Mary Patricia McKeefe, daughter of Edward P. McKeefe of this place and New York and the late Mrs. Mary Wilson McKeefe, was married here this morning in St. John's Roman Catholic Church to Cyril Lavelle McDermott, son of John J. McDermott, also of New York, and the late Mrs. Mary Lavelle McDermott.

Mrs. Blanche Best and Mrs. Carrie Harris, New York State's first women jurors, have done more than make history. They have probably set a precedent. After they had served on a mixed jury of six that acquitted a member of their own sex on a reckless driving charge the women demanded and got ice cream instead of the cigars which male jurors customarily receive.
A BOOK on Japan and China, by Bob Davis, is no guide to the intricacies and the distresses now afflicting a troubled world: it is an album of of agreeable snapshots instead, genial and entertaining.

New developments come so fast in modern horticulture that it is quite impossible for any one gardener to keep up with them all. But it does add a pleasurable zest to gardening to try to keep abreast of the changes the plant breeders are accomplishing in one's favorite flowers.
A petition for probate of the will of Mrs. Mildred Fuller Wallace filed today in District Court estimated her estate at more than $840,000.

THE lure of the desert, old missions, unsurpassed fishing,sea or sun bathing and a great variety of other at??ctions for both Winter and Sum-?? ?? visitors keeps a steady stream ??touristss moving south from Noga-?? on the Mexican border, to Her- ?? ??illo, the capital of Sonora and ?? ??ce an additional seventy miles ?? ??her south to Guaymas, the ?? ??rtsman's paradise on the Gulf of ?? ??ifornia.

Mr. and Mrs. Jacob W. Raden of 220 West Ninety-third Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Raden, tc Dr. Arthur Schifrin of 2 East Eighty-sixth Street, son of Adolp Schifrin of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Anna Oppenheim Schifrin.

THOUGH the aim of the silver screen is art, drama and entertainment-a mark that is hit upon occasion-because of the financial proportions of the medium it frequently requires courage to point the lens, and more to turn the camera's crank.

George L. Hossfield of West Englewood, N. J., set a new speed record in winning the international typewriting competition today at the Canadian National Exhibition. His speed of 139 words a minute for an hour's typing exceeds all former marks for speed under international competition rules.

EVER since "You Can't Take It With You" opened to the delight of the town's hilaritarians last December it has been pursued with intellectual dissent. A romantic farce frequently builds up opposition in proportion to its popular success, and the success of the Hart and Kaufman drollery has been, as the showmen say, "terrific."
With flags flying and band blaring, 1,200 United States marines today marched aboard the transport Chaumont, which leaves- tomorrow for Shanghai.

Miss Helen H. O'Leary, 17-year-old American girl, was killed here today when an automobile in which she was riding ran off the road near Madden Dam and overturned in the jungle. She was riding with Edward J. Gormely, 21. years old, an apprentice electrician at the Panama Canal. Miss O'Leary was the daughter of Mrs. Maria O'Leary, nurse at the Gorgas Hospital.
A police lieutenant entered a fashionable shore casino tonight, walked up to a table and singled out a bronzed, well-built member of a party.

IF you are a motorist who has traveled around the country much in your car--either on a vacation or on business-ypu have doubtless had the experience of beginning to search toward evening for a suitable place to stop for the night.

China is "as ready as ever to settle whatever differences she may have with Japan" by pacific means, in accordance with international law and the principles enunciated by Secretary of State Cordell Hull in his recent declarations of policy, Dr. C. T. Wang, the Chinese Ambassador, announced here today on behalf of his government.

The West Point, of the West Shore Railroad ferryboat fleet in the North River, broke from her moorings in the ferry slip at the end of West Forty-second Street yesterday at 10:30 A. M. and began floating away with an automobile, in which their were several passengers, poised half on and half off the deck.
EVERY Frenchman waxes philosophical about his food and Monsieur L. P. De Gouy, although a naturalized American, is no exception to this rule.

Stella Andreva, English soprano, who made her debut with the Metropolitan Opera Company last season, arrived yesterday on the Lafayette of the French Line for a vacation in this country. Ladislas Bartal, Hungarian pianist, who arrived on the liner as an immigrant, said he wanted to make America his home because he felt that there was more opportunity in this country and too many musicians in the Central European nations.

THE cooperation of State troopers, city police magistrates and justices of the peace in country towns throughout the State is aiding materially in the enforcement of the provisions of the Labor Law regulating the hours of labor of motor truck and bus drivers by the State Department of Labor and is making definite contribution to the State's highway safety campaign this Summer, State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews said last week.
A commission named in May by Bishop Edward Huntington Coley of Utica recommended today five candidates for the post of Coadjutor Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Central New York.

THE contemporary style in decoration is now finding its freest expression in semi-public places, such as restaurants and cocktail lounges, where tubular metal furniture, exotic wood paneling and walls of glass bricks greet the eye.

LAKE PLACID.--Preparations are under way at the Lake Placid Club for the annual Indian Council Fire ceremony next Friday, in which a cast of nearly 120 members and guests will take part. This will be- the thirty-fifth presentation of what is undoubtedly one of the most colorful events in the Adirondacks.

The Aqueduct race meeting, which will open tomorrow, will carry approximately $55,000 in added money in the nine stakes, according to the increased values established by President John E. Cowdin and his colleagues.

CHARLES DICKENS had a brother nicknamed "Mose" who frequently suffered from colds in the head that forced him to call himself "Boze." It always amused Dickens very much and when he was casting about for a name for his first article he thought of it and "Boz" became his pseudonym.

Fifty minutes after seven customers and the manager of the Midtown Social Club, 558 West 158th Street, had been held up and robbed of about $400 shortly after midnight yesterday, four men said by the police to have records were arrested and charged with the robbery.
Pete Borisoff, 48 years old, a Russian-born jeweler, pursued and beat to death with a pistol today one of two men who held up and robbed his shop. Police captured the other man.
Announcement has been made by Mrs. Ann Freshman of the Dorset of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ada Freshman, to Ernest Kirtz, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Kirtz of Cleveland.

AMTHOR--At Oslo, Norway, Aug. 13, 1937, Katherine A., beloved mother of Katherine Greenway Amthor. Services at the Fairchild Chapel, 86 Lefferts Place, Brooklyn, on Monday at 11 A. M. Interment Greenwood Cemetery. ANDERSON-Mary Eva, beloved wife of Frank E., and mother of Josephine. Services at Stolzenberger Chapel, 450 East 162d St., Monday, Aug. 30, at 9 P. M. Interment Lutheran Cemetery.
General Moses Gray Zalinski, retired army officer, died today after a long illness at the age of 74.

The engagement of Miss Sybil Gilmore, daughter of Mr..and Mrs. Robert. Newton Gilmore of Brooklyn and Babylon, L. I., to F. Howard Healy of this city, son of Mrs. Frank Langer of Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents.

Wheat futures in a majority of leading markets declined more than 2 cents a bushel today as the result of reports indicating that a three-month drought in Argentina had been relieved by fairly general rains.

Postmaster General Farley praised the "uprooting of old evils" by the Roosevelt Administration in a talk today at the dedication of a new Federal building and postoffice, costing $320,000, for this city today.
Stocks closed irregular; trading smallest for a Saturday since July 17; turnover, 254,300 shares. Bonds closed steadier; trading smallest for a Saturday since July 17; transactions, $2,473,400.

HOUSING in the Netherlands has won such world-wide fame among architects, town planners and housing experts that the foreigner who comes to see it today is likely to feel himself cast in the pious role of one who is making a pilgrimage.
The Pordham Business School curriculum will be broadened next month to allow specialization in any one of eleven business fields besides accounting, through election as a major.
Charges of "wrecking" by "enemies of the people" are now being made against certain sections f the Civil Aviation Administration, which conducts the Soviet Union's farflung airline network.
The Maritime Council of the Port of New York will open a drive immediately to obtain bonuses for seamen serving on ships that pass through "war-endangered" waters, it was announced yesterday.

Five girls won the first elimination of the State Fair essay and declamation contest in competition with winners from nearly forty-five high school districts and superintendencies, it was revealed today by the Department of Agriculture and Markets.

Thirty-seven homes have been sold by the "Easy-to-Own" Homes organization since July 1, according to Russell Page, sales director. Among them were the following: In Brooklyn, one-family houses at 2,161 Seventieth Street, to Rose Eneman, through the Clark Realty Company; 1,552 East Twenty-ninth Street, to Johan Moskowsky,

A. group of newly designed curved wrist watches for women is appearing in the jewelry cases of several New York shops. They might have been designed for the business girl who, while on her vacation, resolved to keep appointments on time hereafter, or for the college girl determined to reach her classes at the appointed hours.

Five naval vessels, two light cruisers and three destroyers, are to be put in commission during September, the Navy Daprtment announced today. They will be completed, or will be near completion within the next month, and after routine trials and shakedown cruises, will make their final acceptance trials before joining the fleet.
Gardeners who appreciate the presence of birds include the hackberry (Celtis occidentalis) in their planting. They are rewarded throughout September and October by numerous feathered visitors.

The Hamburg-American Line, fearing infection of passengers from an epidemic of typhoid fever among members of the crew, canceled the accommodations of 325 passengers last night on the liner Hansa. The vessel left at midnight, carrying only her crew and freight.
IN singing, supple prose, with an evocative power strange to our earthbound ears, with passion and often with fury, Frederic Prokosch takes us off to the vast, mysterious reaches of Central Asia.

PLYMOUTH, Mass. PLYMOUTH ROCK has been purified, thanks to a chemist's finding the proper antidote for a mess of viscid red paint smeared on it last May Day before dawn. Unidentified Communist demonstrators were blamed, as a matter of course;

RACING pilots hurtling across country and around pylons on the trail of new speed records and a share in $80,000 prize money will vie for headline honors with service fliers staging one of the nation's greatest peacetime demonstrations of military aviation when the National Air Races start Friday at Cleveland Municipal Airport.

OF most interest in current vocal lists is the first domestic release of Jussi Bjoerling, who displays his lyric and dramatic qualities in what are probably the two most frequently recorded operatic arias for tenor"Che Gelida Manina," from Puccini's "La Boheme," and "Celeste Aida" (Victor 12039).

An adequate supply of teachers to instruct the millions of public school children who will go back to their classes next month, was generally indicated today in reports from educational officials throughout nation.
Thousands of war-weary refugees from Santander and other Northwest Spanish Provinces were taken in trains across Southern France today into Catalonia, where they had a dubious reception.

PLYMOUTH, Vt.--As tourists flock to this little Vermont hamlet and as shrewd natives sell them all manner of souvenirs of the thirtieth President of the United States, the Calvin Coolidge Memorial Association turns to plans to preserve the village as a permanent shrine to the man who made it famous.

A decrease of $216,830,161 in WPA expenditures during the first seven months of this year below the amount expended over a corresponding period in 1936, was announced today by Aubrey Williams, Deputy Administrator.

An effort will be made before a Federal court in Delaware next month to separate from the reorganization proceedings the action seeking the appointment of a trustee to represent holders of securities of the Standard Gas and Electric Company in a $100,000,000 suit against certain officers and directors of the company, the Standard Power and Light Company, H. M. Byllesby Co., Ladenburg, Thalmann Co. and others.

Virginia Republicans nominated a full slate of candidates for State offices today and urged the National Republican Committee to call a national convention to work out "ways and means of leadership that will convince all true Americans that their only hope for political and economic salvation rests in a subjugation of partisan gain."

A Chautauqua Institution lecturer declared today that the Declaration of Independence was "a presentation of faith so far beyond the practices of those times that it is a miracle it was ever written."

Mrs. Elizabeth Sterett Sands Elliot, daughter of Mrs. Frederick P. Sands of this city and widow of Lieutenant Giraud F. Elliot of the British Royal Artillery, this afternoon became the bride of John H. O'Connell, New York attorney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel O'Connell of New York.

More than 400 exhibits were shown at the Autumn flower show which was opened at Roosevelt Hall this afternoon by the Bergen County Gardeners Society. Forty-seven exhibitors took part. There were entries in 108 of the 125 classes listed.
Miss Elizabeth Dixon Clar will be introduced to society here at a tea dance to be given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Austin Clark, next Saturday in the Colonial ballroom of the Meadow Club.

The American people are faced with "a railway crisis," according to a current editorial in Railway Age, dealing with rising costs to the carriers. The editorial traces recent developments to substantiate the statement.

Favorites and champions had to bounce around in the wake of lesser lights today and take second places, thirds or worse in the opening events of the twelve-day Connecticut Governor's regatta, which will have seen in racing rig nearly everything that floats before it ends on Sept. 8.

New Hampshire's record-breaking State Legislature, which ran from Jan. 7 to Aug. 21, failed to "modernize" the State's revenue system, but it did provide for the holding of a constitutional convention to consider tax reform changes and made a radical change in the State's inheritance tax policy when it removed charitable bequests from the list of exempted wealth transfers, unless to a. Government unit for public purposes.

In the third national skeet championships to be held at the Blue Rock Gun Club in Detroit, Tuesday to Saturday, a Detroit girl, Miss Betty Small, will be the defending champion in the women's division. Mrs. Sidney Small, who preceded her daughter as champion, also is listed to compete.
"Two men named Duvalier" were blamed for last week's disturbance on Great Inagua Island in a report to the Government here today by Commissioner Dudley Arthur Fields.

FIFTY years have passed since Zola's great novel of coal miners in Northern France was first published-a half century during which, despite numerous detours, the novel has returned with progressive intensity to the materials which Zola took up and the solutions which he suggested.

Simon Lake, submarine builder and head of the Lake Submarine Salvage Corporation of New York, is engaged in sweeping the ocean bottom off the New Jersey coast to locate coal barge cargoes, not gold, platinum and other more valuable minerals.

Despite the appeals by the Mufti of Jerusalem during the last six weeks to the kings and premiers of Arab countries to participate in an Arab congress, the leaders are not showing any willingness to attent officially.
SOUTHAMPTON.-Members of the Summer colony here seem bent upon crowding as many gay events- as possible into this last important week of the season.

WHETHER freedom of worship shall continue to be one of the fundamental rights of man or whether religion shall be added to the many other things that may be regulated by the totalitarian States is the main issue, according to the Vatican, that hangs in the balance of the conflict between the Holy See and the German Reich.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 27, unless specified: At San Clemente: Cincinnati, Humphreys, King. Lawrence, Sands. At New London: Cuttlefish, Hamilton, Roper (Aug. 28).

MERRY - GO - ROUND music and the stirring drone of calliopes are heard in the autumnal countryside, pounding hoofs of trotting horses swing around dusty race tracks, fat beeves parade for ribbons, judges smack critically of home-made jam and pickle exhibits-rural America's great Fall celebration, the country fair, is under way.

Nearly 300 elevator operators and other service employes who went on strike for higher wages and better working conditions on Aug. 18 at the twin twenty-two-story Hudson Terminal Buildings, 30 and 50 Church Street, will return to work tomorrow under a new contract for one year granting wage increases ranging from 5 to 7 per cent.

Gray-haired boatmen gathered their kinfolk and cronies about them again today, took a 'chaw" of their favorite tobacco, lighted their pipes and relived the old Pennsylvania Canal- days with song and story.

An all-American afternoon, to inelude a tour of the city, ice cream sodas, a cafeteria luncheon at the Central Park Zoo, and a meeting with former Governor Alfred E. Smith, is being planned on Tuesday for twenty-five foreign and sixtytwo American Girl Scouts, it was announced yesterday by the Girl Scout Federation of Greater New York. They have been camping at Briarcliff Manor, N. Y., and Plymouth, Mass.

Political observers regard President Roosevelt's remarks on signing the modified judiciary reform bill this week as the political keynote the country may expect to hear for the immediate future. His evident dissatisfaction with the measure and his public branding of it as a very short step along a far-reaching road lead them to interpret his statement as a rallying cry to the "liberal" elements of the electorate that, again, "we have just begun to fight."
Japan's major strategy in this tre mendous undeclared war against China is gradually becoming evident, in the opinion of foreign military experts who are watching the unrolling scheme with amazement.

Margaret MacFarlane, a Scottish-Canadian girl of 21, arrived here today after walking, hitchhiking and riding freight trains from Vancouver. She left Vancouver May 15 and said she way headed for Halifax, then through Maine and on to New York City.

There were signs tonight that the epidemic of infantile paralysis which in the last three weeks has spread rapidly throughout Ontario's thickly populated areas was easing, but Provincial and civic health authorities permitted no relaxation in the fight against the disease.

Miss Ruth K. Shaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Shaw of this place, was married today to Dr. John C. L. Blagg of New York, son of Mrs. George Blagg of Fayette, Iowa. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. A. G. Axtell of Williamstown, Mass.
Dodging light rain which fell before and afterward, 250 children went through their paces yesterday in Ocean City's thirty-first annual baby parade on the Boardwalk.

The desperate demands for scrap iron in England, probably due to the large-scale British armament program, recently caused the British Iron and Steel Federation and the National Federation of Scrap Merchants to launch a national campaign for the collection of scrap iron, which will be sold to British manufacturers after current export contracts have expired, said American Consul Harry E. Carlson at London in a report made public today by the Department of Commerce.
In the past few months operations of the Nationalists on the Northern Spanish front have gone steadily ahead in accordance with Generalissimo Francisco Franco's plans.
Steps are being taken toward the solution of a problem created by the reported invasion of Alaska waters by Japanese fishermen.

In the light of the conflict in the Far East, it is interesting to note the comparative effects on the stock markets in London and in New York. During the Italo-Ethiopian conflict and later during the early months of the civil war in Spain, the New York market was satisfied to take its cue in this respect from the action of stocks in London.

WHEN it opens. its doors early in November the Mercury Theatre will expect to play to the same audience that during the past two seasons stood to see "Richard II," "Doctor Faustus," the two "Hamlets," "Murder in the Cathedral" and the Negro "Macbeth."

F. M. E. Schaefer's Winfred defeated three rivals today as ;the New York Yacht Club Thirtytwo-foot Class made its first appearance on Long Island Sound in several weeks in the annual Y. R. A. regatta of the Port Washington Yacht Club.

Moscow is watching the Japanese developments in North China closely and with evident concern, but thus far without any visible indications whatever that the Soviet Government intends to take concrete measures.
A group of twenty-six Shanghai citizens is stranded here, unable to get back to their native land or to obtain news of their friends and families.

By way of demonstrating that they are far more versatile in their accomplishments than many suppose, Joe McCarthy's Yankees took an inelegant plunge from the sublime to the ridiculous today in a manner to provide royal entertainment for a gathering of 4,000.

A reception at the Warren Hotel in Spring Lake tomorrow evening will open the first Summer exhibition of works displayed by the New Jersey Chapter of the American Artists Professional League. Nearly 100 artists of the State will exhibit works during the week-long exhibition.

W. Seward Hamlin, for more than two decades Republican county chairman, died at Ellis Hospital today at the age of 82. He apparently had been recovering from an intestinal operation, performed on Thursday.
Two men were killed tonight and a third injured when their plane plunged into the Tuscarawas River from about 400 feet.

The plan of United Air Lines and Western Air Express to pool equipment for operation of a through sleeper plane service from New York to Los Angeles via Salt Lake City was held a violation of the Air Mail Act by Karl A. Crowley, solicitor of the Postoffice Department, in a memorandum made public today.

THOSE shadows that seemed to be hovering over the Theatre Union have finally closed in. After producing eight plays in four years, the organization has finally dissolved, ascribing its finish to the fact that the low prices it charged "made it impossible to recoup in successful periods the losses sustained at other times."
Senator Joseph F. Guffey, through his latest moves at Washington, has dramatically reasserted his leadership of the Democratic party in Pennsylvania.

China today is in travail-the travail of birth, or rebirth. The faraway observer of events in the Far East receives the impression of a prone, torpid, sprawling giant being pricked, goaded and galvanized into new life.

The Soviet Government has asked Japan to close her consulates at Odessa, on the Black Sea, and at Novosibirsk, in Central Siberia, on the ground that Japanese interests in those regions are not sufficient to justify consular representation.

The annual Nuremberg National, Socialist party congress will have a huge anti-bolshevist exhibition that will be open from Sept. 5 to Sept. 26. It will be staged by the Propaganda Ministry and is intended to be the biggest of the shows depicting the "frightfulness" of bolshevist methods.

The maritime career of Captain Antonio Hreglich, thirty-five years a shipmaster- with a-record of 332 transatlantic crossings, has been brought to a close by his enforced retirement under the Italian law that fixes the age limit for commanders at 60, the Italian Line announced 'yesterday.

Miss Miriam Greene, daughter of Mrs. William J. Greene of Cambridge, was married today to Donald Joseph Hurley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius J. Hurley of Gardner, Mass. The Rev. Timothy W. Sullivan, pastor of St. Vincent's Church, officiated.

The Rev. Michael J. Curley, Archbishop of Baltimore; Mgr. John Lyons, his secretary, and the Most Rev. James De Wolf Perry, Bishop of Rhode Island, and Dr. T. Tertius Noble, organist of St. Thomas Church, Fifty-third Street and Fifth Avenue, are among the passengers due to arrive today from Europe on the Cunard White Star motorship Georgic.

Harold M. Butler of Hempstead and Garry Ketcham, unattached, who led the qualifying field with a subpar 68, had to go an extra hole today to get into the semi-final round of the four-ball invitation golf tournament at the Seawane Club.

Mr. and Mrs. Axel Brynolf Lindstedt of this place have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Ruth Florence Lindstedt, to Joseph Bridger Ullman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Ullman, also of White Plains. The wedding will take Place here on Oct. 1.

Business, although it improved materially in the last year, continued to be largely "on the defensive," S. C. Mead, secretary of the Merchants Association of New York, declared in his annual report made public yesterday.

The weakness' in bar silver in the London market last week was the most pronounced in more than a year and brought the price down to 193-16d an ounce, or the equivalent of 42.89 cents in United States currency.

An injunction has been asked here to prevent Mrs. Rose Goldstein from keeping plumbers out of her kitchen. It will be decided upon Tuesday at a hearing before Vice Chancellor W. Frank Sooy. Then,, if he grants the restraint and she still locks out the repair crew, she will be in contempt of New Jersey Chancery Court.

After months of self-restraint intended partly as an example to other nations, the British Government has finally ordered counter measures against submarines and bombing planes which have been preying on foreign shipping in the Mediterranean.
After a four-day battle the Insurgents have finally rolled back the big Loyalist offensive on the front between Zuera and Almudevar on the main Saragossa-Huesca road in Aragon.

The Society of Friends, known as Quakers, will meet at Swarthmore and Haverford Colleges, Sept. 1-8, in the second world conference since the sect was founded by George Fox in England in the seventeenth century. The first was in London in 1920.

Miss Madelene Chapin Abernethy, daughter of Mrs. Alfred C. Abernethy of this place and the late Mr. Abernethy, was married to Achille Starace, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl S. Starace, this afternoon in the First Methodist Church by the Rev. C. W. Severance.

Permanent changes are due for retailing, in both merchandising and promotional practices, as the result of labor readjustments and the spread of unionization activities which, while showing more or less of a lull at this time, are likely to become a major factor again in many centers in the Fall, according to the head of a large out-oftown department store.

Asserting that he had acquired a valuable mining concession in Ethiopia, through an agreement with the Ethiopian Government before the Italian conquest, Leo Y. Chertok, a New York broker and representative of several American industrial concerns in Russia, disclosed yesterday that he had petitioned Secretary of State Hull to help him regain title to this land.

THE establishment this Summer by the sponsors of the Bennington Festival of three fellowships for young artists proved to be an innovation second in importance perhaps only to the idea of the festival itself.

President Roosevelt today gave a pocket veto to a bill increasing by $2,580,000 annual authorizations for assistance to States in agricultural extension work. The veto was on the ground that present authorizations for this purpose, $14,000,000. should suffice "in view of the very great demands upon the Treasury, present and prospective, in the interest of agriculture."

Political associates say that Representative Thomas A. Jenkins of Ironton, Ohio, is "considering seriously" a campaign for the Republican nomination for the Senate seat held by Senator Robert J. Bulkley, Cleveland Democrat.

Six minor officials of the national police were arrested yesterday following the alleged discovery of a plot among the police of Quito to seize President Federico Paez and members of Congress and set up a new government.
Twenty or more residents of this town received Pasteur anti-rabies injections today after it was learned that a puppy which had bitten them had suffered from rabies.

In England--as once in America--the tinted fingernail controversy is raging. To tint, or not to tint, is the question. The women who have so far shown a tendency to copy their American sisters, and lacquer their nails, say "Yes." Some men say "No."

AMERICA will be represented at Venice's fifth international modern music festival this September by Roy Harris's new trio for violin, cello and piano, in its baptismal performance. The complete program of this important event is given hereunder.

Sister Agnita Miriam of the New York Foundling Hospital, speaking today at the National Conference of Catholic Charities, urged institutions for children to develop programs for problem children who need specialized' care. 'Sister' Agnita Miriam is in charge of the boarding-out department at the New York Foundling Hospital, said to be the largest private agency of the sort in the United States.

Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe, who have been at their-ranch in Wyoming for most of the Summer, will return soon- to Planting Fields, their place in. Oyster Bay, where they will be joined by Count and Countess Leonardo Vitetti, who will arrive in a few days from Rome.
An unidentified woman flagged a Southern Railway freight train here with her baby and prevented it from crashing into a boulder.
Miss Marargaret T. Corwin, dean of the New Jersey College for Women, announced today the appointment of twelve members of the institution's faculty and administrative staff.

WASHINGTON. MAN in a greenhouse in St. Paul, Minn., bends over a wheat blade in flower. In his hands are a pair of ordinary small sewing scissors. Slowly he moves the scissors up and down the flowering stalk head. Most of the grain top is composed of rows of perfectly formed blossoms needing only a day or two of sun and sprinkler to reach their fertilization climax.
Steadily the army, of workers who toll for the executive branch of the Federal Government is marching toward the.1,000,000 mark. It needs now only about 150.000 recruits to reach that figure .
For a variety of reasons the eyes of the nation -were focused this-week on the convention of the United Automobile Workers of America.
Tokyo newspapers today devoted columns to glorification of Japanese dead in the China war and- gendarmerie warnings against sedition.

SECOND MILITARY AREA So much of Paragraph 3, Special Orders 64, dated Aug. 24, 1937, which reads Second Coast Artillery District, is amended to read Second Coast Artillery District Reserves. So much of Paragraph 3, Special Orders 64, dated Aug. 24, 1937, as pertains to 1st William C. Weinkauff, Engr. -Res., is revoked.

The Boerse closed the week firm, with moderate trading in major stocks. Potashes and lignites were lively, Kalischemie gaining 2 1/4 ponits. Heavy industrials were firm, Hoesch gaining 1 point and Deutsche Waffen 2 1/4.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler, official quarters hinted today, is on the verge of consummating a truce with the Vatican.

The galloping couriers of Napoleon and Wellington who carried verbal messages to subordinate units may return to the armies of the world unless-some speedier way is found for transmitting the orders to the front, Major Gen. Fox Conner, commander of the First Field Army and of the First Corps Area, told 400 regular, army, National Guard and Reserve officers here today.

The results obtained in Ohio through over-all limitation on real estate taxes will be shown by former Governor Meyers Y. Cooper at the thirtieth annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, which is to be held in Pittsburgh from Oct. 20 to 22.

Many persons of prominence have subscribed to boxes for the seventh annual race meeting of the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association, to be held on Labor Day, on the grounds of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club here for the benefit of the New York City Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.
Memorial services will be held throughout Belgium tomorrow for Queen Astrid, who was killed in Switzerland two years ago in an automobile accident.

Inquiries from persons on vacation at Summer resorts point to a good Fall market for the homes in Westchester County being offered by the Bowery Savings Bank. Raymond R. Beatty, one of the four agents commissioned to dispose of the bank's holdings, has received requests for information about the properties from New Hampshire, Vermont and other resort States.

John Ploshay, 51 years old, of 86-40 102d Street, Ozone Park, Queens, was arrested at noon yesterday on a charge of disorderly conduct when a crowd on the platform of the Fourteenth Street station of the crosstown line of the B. M. T. threatened him and accused him of annoying three girls and a woman.

History and Biography NO ROYAL ROAD. By Edgar A. Custer. 8vo. New York: H. C. Kinsey Co., Inc. $3.50. The. author's recollections of seventy-six years of railroading. WINFIELD SCOTT. THE SOLDIER AND THE MAN. By Charles Winslow Elliott. 8vo. New York: The Macmillan Company. $5. A biography.

Stamford will play host to several stars of the stage, screen, radio and literary world at Cummings Park tomorrow afternoon, when a softball game will be played for the benefit of the Needy Boys and Girls Camp Committee.
"It's too deep a question for me to decide," remarked Magistrate O'Connor today in dismissing

Miss Carolyn Flagler Morgan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Heber Morgan of this city, has chosen Oct. 15 for her marriage to Norman Brassler, son of Mrs. Otto Brassler of Englewood and the late Mr. Brassler.

The following Foreign Service changes since Aug 21 were announced today by the State Department: Henry P. Leverich of Montclair, N. J., Vice Consul at Berlin, assigned to the Embassy as Third Secretary.

MEMBERS of Congress, now at home for a long-awaited holiday after a barren session, know well that there is one moot question which has not been left safe in a pigeonhole at the Capitol. That question concerns the future of the Democratic party, and it is agitating Democrats and Republicans alike: the Democrats because it means their political life blood, and the Republicans because the right answer may enable them to return to power.
UNDER the heading "Mengelberg and Nazis," the Volksblad of Amsterdam recently published the following item:

Senator Royal S. Copeland, Tammany's candidate for the Mayoralty nomination in both Democratic and Republican primaries, was criticized yesterday by the New York State Executive Committee of the Socialist party for conducting "a red-baiting, issue-straddling, opera bouffe campaign in alliance with Tammany and the Bellinger Tories."

The fact that Edward F. McGrady is about to resign his post as Assistant Secretary of Labor to become labor adviser to the Radio Corporation of America gives occasion for further contention between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Warnings against the increase of drunkenness among Canadian youth were heard today from Archdeacon F. G. Scott, war chaplain with the Canadian Corps, who addressed the Canadian National Exhibition directors' luncheon.

Last Thursday President Roosevelt signed Congressional Enactment H. R. 8234, designed "to provide revenue, equalize taxation, prevent tax evasion and avoidance, and for other purposes," which will be known as the Revenue Act of 1937.

What is described by the owners as "the world's largest milk processing plant" has just been completed by the Borden's Farm Products Division of the Borden eompany at 615 West 131st Street, near Riverside Drive.

With business in the area showing a general improvement, store and loft rentals in the territory south of Fourteenth Street and east of Third Avenue and the Bowery rose during the year ended July 31, a survey of that section by the East Side Chamber of Commerce reveals.

The marriage of Miss Florence Miriam Baylis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvah M. Baylis of this community, to Robert Munshower Skelton, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Skelton of Indiana, Pa., took place this afternoon in the garden of the bride's home. The Rev. Dr. Edward Judson Humeston, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, officiated.
TINTING and toning, devices used to enhance the quality of scenes in motion pictures almost since the beginning of film making, are coming back into use after nearly a decade of disuse.
