Fire Captain Gustav Birmele, 47 years old, of Jersey City, was arrested last night on charges of attempt-to kill, atrocious assault and battery and carrying dangerous weapons after he had scuffled with a superior officer who, according to the police, found him intoxicated while on duty.

MR. MILLS undertakes in this book to point the way for the seventeen million voters who opposed President Roosevelt in November, 1936, and for a "revitalized" Republican party. The historic Democratic party, he maintains, has ceased to exist, and it would be "almost as true" to affirm the same thing of the Republican party.
Over the Labor Day week-end, when a good many metropolitan yachtsmen will take one last cruising fling for the season, a profitable three or four hours or more may be assigned to Jamaica Bay.

Mayor La Guardia and William Stanley Miller, president of the Board of Taxes and Assessments, will welcome the 300 delegates expected for the fourth annual convention of the National Association of Assessing Officers, to be held here Oct. 20 to 22.

The National Gallery of Art in Washington, which Andrew W. Mellon, former Secretary of the Treasury, gave to the nation with his $50,000,000 art collection, will be carried to completion under the direction of associates of John Russell Pope, architect, it was learned yesterday. Both Mr. Mellon and Mr. Pope died last week.
The Postoffice Department is wondering what to do about the middle-sized town whose airport facilities do not keep pace with aircraft development.

Two boys were almost instantly killed near here today while riding bicycles. They were struck head-on by an automobile, and their bodies were carried 150 feet before the car left the highway, smashed off a power line pole and turned over in the ditch.

AN unprecedented development in philately's history -has been uncovered through research. It is that more than half of all stamps being currently released, the world around, fall within the classification known as "commemoratives" -- which are postal adhesives issued primarily to recall happenings of historical significance or to publicize present-day activities, such as coronations, birthdays, dedications, sports, flights, international congresses and miscellaneous others.
William H. J. Ely, State WPA Administrator, announced today that about 1,500 WPA workers in New Jersey who have ben dropped since Aug. 21 are to be reinstated.

Winning all but two 'of the nine events, the United States gained a 47-to-37 lead over Japan today at the end of the first half of a two-day international track meet, but lost the services of Earle Meadows, crack Southern California pole vaulter. Ten. more:

Ellison N. Finckel, a representative of the National Cash Register Company, was seriously wounded early today when he went to the aid of his sister, Mrs. J. T. Townsend of Philadelphia as she was being terrorized by a Negro.

A special grand jury indicted nine men, including four legislators and Walter Lear, former secretary to United States Senator Ed C. Johnson, today. The legislators were charged with violating their oaths and with bribery in connection with activities in the recent Assembly.
Governor Stark finds himself in a muddle which represents what observers call his first serious mistake since taking over the reins of government last January.

The White House declared last week that WPA dismissals for economy reasons were at an end, but that the President could not heed a request to reinstate all dismissed WPA people who had been unable to find jobs.

Announcement of the opening of three new apartment houses was received yesterday. At 196th Street and Broadway, the Mayfair House, under construction by B. S. Moss, will be ready for occupancy early in September.

Miss Marjorie Stitcher Westgate, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph S. Westgate of Glen Ridge, was married tonight in the home of her parents to A. Benedict Doran, son of Dr. and Mrs. William T. Doran of Jackson Heights, Queens. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Robert J. Trevorrow, president of Centenary Collegiate Institute at Hackettstown.

Although notables of the so-called cosmopolitan set are gathered in numbers at Le Touquet, on the Riviera, and at Deauville, it is the latter spot which is thronged as it has not been for a decade. The reason is the Grande Semaine, or Big Week, of racing and general entertainment.

SHORTLY after Thomas E. Dewey was drafted by Fusion to run for the office of District Attorney of New York County, he decided that he would go away for a few days--his first vacation since he was appointed Special Prosecutor of the Racket and Vice Investigation.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company has sold to Louise Richardson Dodd the four-story building on a lot 20 by 100 feet at 442 East Fifty-eighth Street, near Sutton Place, it was announced yesterday. The building is assessed at $28,500 and will be altered for occupancy by the purchaser, according to Frank J. Welton Co., Inc., brokers in the transaction. Kurzman Frank represented the seller and Denis Madurothe buyer.

New trials for three Scottsboro prisoners were denied today by Judge W. W. Callahan, who said the six-year-old case was to have ended "for good" in July with the freeing of four of the nine accused Negroes "by agreement."

A twelve-acre site on Old Bedford Road in the Yale Farms development at Greenwich, Conn., has been purchased by Harold G. Pickering, New York attorney, who plans to erect a house on the property in the Fall. G. Dewey Swan will be the architect.

Colonel Roscoe Turner tuned up today a new racing plane in which he hopes to make 400 miles an hour and break a few aviation records. He wheeled the small silver ship Meteor out for a final test before flying to Burbank, Calif., starting point of the Bendix Trophy race Sept. 3.
The British freighter Bramhill flashed distress calls today, stating she had been fired on off the coast of Spain, The radio station at Land's End picked up the calls from the 1,281-ton freighter.

Clearings of the Westchester County Clearing House Association for the week ended on Friday amounted to $2,292,185, compared with $2.731,008 for the preceding week and with $1,924,057 for the corresponding week last year.

When the famous Leipzig Autumn Fair opens tomorrow Germany will display to the world her progress in developing and creating artificial raw materials. The fair will show a wider range than ever of synthetic products, designed to release the Reich from the "foreign thraldom" of having to import natural raw materials

MUCH has been written recently of the manner in which different bidding systems are coming increasingly close to one another. For at least two years the most popular systems have been nearly identical in essential respects.

Although business is now going through its "most tranquil period" in more than a year, industrial turnover will improve with thirdquarter activity and "the Winter months are looked for with hopeful anticipation," according to the monthly report on conditions by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, released yesterday.

Ralph Emerson, legislative representative of the National Maritime Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, characterized as "colossal nerve" today the recent appointment by Secretary Roper of a navy commander to the directorship of the Marine Inspection and Navigation Bureau.

The Government has granted the Carnegie Institute permission to export for study parts of skeletons found in recent excavations at Uaxactun and Kaminal. The shipment consists of thirtynine skeletons and six skulls, one of which contains teeth filled by a prehistoric dentist.

In a telegram sent to Secretary of State Cordell Hull yesterday, the American Society for Race Tolerance, 1,165 Broadway, urged withdrawal of United States diplomatic representation at the National Socialist party convention in Nuremberg, Germany, next month.

New England is waiting to see just what the Governor of Massachusetts actually will do about the WPA guide book which has caused a deal of commotion because of its treatment of the Sacco-Vanzetti case and its review of the labor history of the Commonwealth.
Roger Hughes, 17, Youngstown, Ohio, captured the national individual junior small-bore rifle championship today with a score of 372 of 400. Jack Polk of Troy, N. Y., was runner-up with 363.

Dr. Arthur W. Rogers, specialist in mental and nervous diseases, who last year gave to the State of Wisconsin his $1,000,000 sanitarium near here, died last night at the sanitarium. He was 67 years old.

Fed oral contracts for supplies amounting to $5,195,422 were awarded under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Thursday, the Department of Labor has announced. Nine agencies awarded eight-one contracts, the report said.

The Merniouse 1s only 16 feet 4, but she attracted just. as much attention at her launching yesterday in McWillians Shipyard, Staten Island, as the mighty ocean-going vessels which have slid down the ways there-even to champagne.
THE audience which applauded the first performance of the operetta that established Rudolf Friml as a popular composer, by now has. probably completely forgotten the story of "The Firefly."
The Spanish war comes up in the League for the fifth time in a year as a result of the Valencia government's telegram charging Italian warships with torpedoing Spanish merchantmen.

The marriage of Miss Nell Wattley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Berkeley Wattley of East Meadow, L. I., to C. Fletcher Donnocker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Fletcher Donnocker of Bellerose, took place here today in St. George's Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. John S. Haight.
All cables from Shanghai were disrupted this afternoon, presumably by shells from aerial bombs during the fighting in the vicinity of Woosung and Paochan at the mouth of the Whangpoo River.

A New York operator and builder has purchased from the Hastings Highlands -Company its remaining holdings, comprising about 212 lots in Riverview Manor, at Hastingson-Hudson and Dobbs Ferry. Many of the plots had been in the possession of the seller for more than twenty years.

Estate, more than $10,000. To Gerson J. Brown, son, executor, 1,185 Park Ave., residue; Kenneth M. Brown, Park Ridge, N. J.; Mabel Brown Pollock, Wyoming, Ohio; Elizabeth Brown Sherry, Milwaukee, Wise.; grandchildren, $1,000 each; Mina Brown, 1,185 Park Ave., $1,000; one minor bequest.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.
Frankie Parker, United States Davis Cup player from Milwaukee, and Arthur Hendrix of Lakeland, Fla., reached the final of the Seigniory Club invitation tennis tournament today.
Pine Needle Camp, the Adirondack property of Howell Van Gerbig at Upper Saranac Lake, N. Y., has been sold to John Loeb, according to Preview, Inc. Clinton J. Ayres, Inc., was the broker.

Private schools already report increased enrollments for this Fall. At least 15 per cent more schools than last year expect Capacity registrations, according to a survey of school information bureaus.

Miss. Elinor Mae Benson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Benson of this place, was married here this afternoon in St. Ann's Catholic Church to John J. Hyland, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Hyland, also of Ossining. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Arthur Tommasco.

The vacant seven-story building at 697-99 Madison Avenue,-- elected a few years ago for Fortnum Mason, is to be altered to provide a group of stores on the ground floor and professional suites on the upper floors, according to Alfred N. Williams Co., agents. The structure adjoins the former Louis Sherry building, recently purchased by Major Edward Bowes.
The current tendency toward welfare legislation in Federal, State and local governments was attributed this week by Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt in large part. to the influence of women's votes.

With various types of stores coming to their support, manufacturers of national brands will launch an enlarged number of cooperative advertising campaigns with retailers, according to comment here yesterday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved an application by the Middle West Corporation for permission to acquire 41,030 shares of no-par common stock and $54,600 of :first-mortgage 5 per cent bonds due on Aug. 1, 1960, of the Missouri Public Service Corporation and of $33,000 of first-mortgage twenty-year 5 per cent bonds, series A. due on April 1, 1947, of the Michigan Public Service Company.
The Japanese Navy, with vessels stretched along hundreds of miles of the China coast, closely watched shipping of all flags as it put into effect its blockade of Chinese shipping.
The Giants were not at all fooled by the cancellation of Bill Terry Day, which was to have been staged at the Polo Grounds yesterday. They celebrated it anyway

September brings renewed activity in the Eastern canine world. Vacation time is over. After a long absence the all-breed shows return to the metropolitan area, and a formidable schedule looms just ahead. It is only three weeks to the opening of the field-trial season for pointers and setters, while the spaniel and retriever folk, already in the field, are pointing their charges for the early Autumn events in those divisions.

The silver service of the old armored cruiser Brooklyn, famous in the Spanish-American War, will be presented to her successor of the same name, at the commissioning of the new light cruiser, now set tentatively for Sept. 24, it became known yesterday.
Andrew W. Mellon was buried today in a vault beside his brother, Richard B. Mellon, to whose partnership in life the former Treasury Secretary often referred as "my brother and I."

With the fair-trade laws now effective in forty-two States making price maintenance only permissive and not mandatory, well-informed quarters here hold that it will not be long before amendments are proposed compelling producers of branded goods to enter into fairtrade contracts and to determine their resale prices in advance.

Editorial mention was made in yesterday's TIMES of Mr. Mellon's official public service. But there should be an added word concerning his contributions to science and the arts as a private citizen-gifts which will no doubt be the longer remembered, though he asked no recognition for all that he did.

The Long Island Railroad's latest time-tables list a station near Flushing, Queens, as "World's Fair." Actually, there is no station as yet; the train simply stops on a stretch of track and the passenger debarks on an ash embankment.

Social aspects of housing, illustrated in the solutions to the housing problem attempted or proposed by private and public agencies in the United States and elsewhere, will be investigated in a new course to be given by Columbia University Extension, which opens its twentyseventh year on Sept. 24.

The German national exhibition of industrial progress currently being held in Duesseldorf lays great emphasis upon better housing, according to a report from Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association. of Real Estate Boards.

VIRGINIA-Tuesday evening at- the. Center Theatre. This, the season's opening attraction,. is a musical romance by Laurence Stallings and Owen Dayis, with music by Arthur Schwartz. The background is Colonial Williamsburg and the cast will include Anne Booth, Nigel Bruce, Gene Lockhart, Mona Barrie, Ronald Graham, Buck and Bubbles, Dennis Hoey, Bertha Belmore, Avis Andrews and Patricia Bowman.
The champion Newark Bears and the tail-end Jersey City Giants divided a double header today, Jersey City winning the first game, 6 to 3, and Newark the nightcap, 5 to 2.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following -orders today dated Aug. 26: CAPTAIN Furlong, W. R., to duty as Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance. COMMANDERS Smith, R. C., Jr., granted three months sick leave;

Miss Elinor Kirsten Jacobsen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Jacobsen of East Portchester, Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church to Arnold W. Lundell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Lundell of Greenwich, Conn., by the 'Rev. Georgen M. Whitmore.

The twelve Federal savings and loan associations of the Philadelphia district had combined assets of $6,062,113 on July 31, it was announced yesterday. This was an increase of $205,702 over the preceding month and of 47 per cent over July 31, 1936.

RADIO engineers at "the House of Magic" in Schenectady are ready after three months of soil testing to erect a new 625-foot vertical aerial mast expected to increase the signal strength three times. It will be ready for use early in 1938.

A house on Hewlett Point Avenue, Hewlett Point Park, L. I., has been bought by Mr. and Mrs. Vincent C. Behre of Brooklyn, according to an announcement by Philip J. Cahill, manager of Hewlett Point Park, Inc.

The Celotex Corporation reported yesterday for the pine months ended on July 31 a net profit of $1,035,798 after interest, amortization and depreciation but before Federal income taxes, for which the company claims statutory deductions.
Edward S. O'Connor, 69, known to postoffice employes throughout the nation as "Uncle Dudley," died last night from injuries received in an automobile accident Thursday.

Bonds called last week for redemption before their maturity dates again were in comparatively small volume and, except for several relatively sizable amounts of industrial bonds, consisted principally of odd lots of municipal issues.

In the quiet hours spent in the spacious showrooms of manufacturers of fabrics one learns the story of the colors and weaves and the weight and texture of the goods that have gone into making the couture collections.

Three automobile crashes in Delaware late today killed two persons and injured five, two of them gravely. A car left the road just outside Wilmington and plowed through three guard posts, killing Gwendolyn Moore, 22, of Washington, and injuring her companion, Robert Gates, 27, also of Washington.

FOLLOWING the general outline of American practice, but going far beyond it in at least one important respectthe building of mile-long runways and the zoning of areas adjacent to airports to reduce flight hazardsCanada is going steadily ahead with its Trans-Canada Air Lines, Philip G. Johnson, vice president of the Government-controlled airline, said last week.

A WOLF, says Mr. Thompson Seton, is "simply a big, wild, but very doggy dog, getting his living by his wits and the strength of his jaws"; and as in all highly specialized creatures, there is a vast difference between individuals.

BOTH Scotland and Ireland contribute their fair share to contemporary English literature, as is illustrated by the careers of such men as Barrie and Yeats, to say nothing of Bernard Shaw. But where is Wales?

A new plan of operation, in which the office of dean of women and those of her sister chaperones, the heads of college houses, are entirely abolished, will go into effect as a permanent policy at Stephens College this Fall, President James M. Wood disclosed in an interview yesterday, Stephens is a Missouri junior college of 1,170 students, to which, as announced yesterday, Miss Maude Adams will go this Fall as Professor of Drama.

With approximately half of the projected $400,000 fund collected, the National Association of Credit Men will launch its drive to "Guard the Nation's Profits" on Sept. 1, it was reported here yesterday.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Marie Hand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Homer B. Hand of Ramsey, N. J.,to Daniel Gerald Ferry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore L. Ferry of Rutherford, N. J. The announcement was made yesterday at a luncheon given by the bride-elect's parents at Sherry's.

Kazuyoshi Inagaki, Japanese vice consul-general in New York, is scheduled to speak today on "The Sino-Japanese Crisis" from station WQXR, beginning at 5:15 P. M. Kaname Wakasugi, consul general, previously had been listed to give the talk.

IT is a little like leading with one's chin to question the decision to film "Dead End" in one set, especially since Samuel Goldwyn and his staff, William Wyler, Lillian Hellman and the others, have brought the Sidney Kingsley drama of the slums to the screen with such sincerity and warmth of conviction.

After making new low records since November, 1933, during which October contracts touched 9.31 cents, prices on the -Cotton Exchange recovered sharply yesterday to the tune of almost $1 a bale, and ended with gains of 6 to 15 points.
Little Roy Henshaw pitched an eight-inning one-hit game against the Reds at Ebbets Field yesterday, but the Dodgers lost it and remained in the cellar.
Secret Service men, customs officers and other investigators of the Federal Department of the Treasury have been going to school in eighteen cities this Summer.

Explaining his bill proposing a tax on copper exports, Edmundo Fuenzalida, a prominent Liberal Deputy, publishes an article today in which he'proposed a sliding scale based on a tax of 150 pesos on each ton exported when the price of copper is [Pound]35 a ton.

Savings banks in New York received notice last week from the State Banking Department that in view of the cessation of interest payments on their demand deposits in commercial banks, under a provision of the Banking Act of 1935 which went into effect on Monday, the State Banking Board will permit the savings banks to maintain a portion of their uninvested funds in commercial banks as time deposits.
President Roosevelt, who travels much and likes it, was still nearly 10,000 miles shy today of equaling William Howard Taft's 114,000 mileage "while in office" record.

ON Sept. 17, the 150th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution of the United States by the members of the Federal Convention, the Yale University Press will issue a new and revised edition of "The Records of the Federal Convention," edited by Max Farrand.

The army's annual manoeuvres will reach a climax this week in widely separated sections of the country. The Fourth Army of some 56,000 "first line" regulars and National Guardsmen of sixteen States between the Mississippi and the Pacific will end a series of important training exercises and mobilization tests in which the new provisional division "set-up" has been tried out for the first time in actual manoeuvres.

AT a meeting of company executives with newspaper and technical men at South Bend last week, Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation, took a sharp rap at those prophets of gloom who insist that the coming of the machine age has been an evil thing for the condition of labor.

Some 500 furniture stores in greater New York which had closed on Tuesday and Friday nights in June, July and August will reopen on these evenings, beginning Aug. 31, it was announced yesterday by James B. McMahon Jr., executive vice president of the Associated Furniture Dealers of New York.

A bill was introduced in Congress at the last session to set aside land in the District of Columbia to establish a model driver training and testing center for applicants for driving licenses. The designer of that model here -describes its elements and proposed services, which he hopes to see widely adopted in the States.

Whenever Albertus Williams,. 70, feels out of sorts he takes a long walk. He felt all right today but he walked fifteen- miles from- Delphi' to Monticello to attend an old settlers' 'reunion. It is' the fortyninth consecutive year that he has made the jaunt on foot.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he had instructed police officials to pick up on sight Henry Miro, 34 years old, once known as Harlem's "policy king." A perjury indictment against Miro was dismissed by General Sessions Judge John J. Freschi on Friday on the recommendation of Frederick A. Sperling, assistant district attorney.

President Roosevelt's original courtreorganization plan, sent to Congress last Feb. 5, called for establishment of swifter procedure in the lower Federal courts, an increase of personnel, creation of "roving judges" and infusion of new blood into the Supreme Court.

Miss Eleanor Frances Waterman, niece of Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Newcombe of Saunderstown, was married this afternoon to Charles Jarvis Chapman 3d, son of Mrs. Charles J. Chapman of Portland, Me., and the late Mr. Chapman, in the Old Narragansett Church at Wickford. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harold C. Whitmarsh, rector of St. Paul's Church, Wickford.

With the clock turned back more than a century, history was reenacted here today when for the first time in many years the automobile was relegated to second place by the stage coach in a run made between Delhi, Delaware County seat, and Stamford, the socalled Saratoga of the Catskills, over one of the few clay roads left in this section.

Building construction throughout the country continues to maintain the gains made earlier in the year in spite of a decrease last month of 15 per cent under July, 1936, according to figures released yesterday by Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins.

More than 100 of the younger set from Connecticut, New York and Long Island attended the informal dance given tonight by Mr. and Mrs. John Holme Ballantine of New York at their Summer home, Ballamar Farm, in Southbury, in honor of their daughter, Miss Helen Ridgely Ballantine, a debutante of this season. Before the dance Mr. and Mrs. Ballantine entertained guests at a buffet supper.

Henry Janssen and Ferdinand Thun of Reading, Pa., honorary trustees of the Oberland Trust, today won the Goethe bronze plaque from the city of Frankfort in recognition of "meritorious services" for preservation of the historic Goethehaus on the Hirschgraben.

The marriage of Miss Jane Taylor, daughter of Mrs. Howard Metcalf Taylor of Brooklyn and the Halesite Summer Colony here, and Joseph Walter Miller Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Miller of Princeton, N. J., took place here this afternoon in the old-fashioned garden of the Summer home of the bride.
PARIS. DUE, no doubt, to the large number of visitors now in Paris on account of the Paris Exposition, the Theatre National de l'Opera has retained for the Summer season some of its best singers.

Early registration of students at the University of Pittsburgh has set a new record, with 17 per cent more applications for admission to campus schools than there were a year ago, and 19 per cent more students have been admitted to the freshman class.

After two months' experience as Minister of Finance of the French Republic, Georges Bonnet has reached the conclusion that "financial recovery and the success of the important social reforms recently set up cannot be maintained without parallel recovery of economic activity."
Frank Warren Cooper, an executive of the New Jersey Public Service Company in Newark, has purchased the twelve-room dwelling on a landscaped plot of 143 by 200 feet at 334 Woodland Road, Madison.

BRITAIN has received this Summer a steady stream of Americans, probably a good many more than the 76.000 who visited this country last year. Some were drawn by the season of exceptional pageantry which began with the coronation.

Manhattan opened its preparations for the forthcoming football season today when forty-one candidates for the 1937 Jasper varsity eleven reported to Coach John F. (Chick) Meehan at La Salle Military Academy for the initial drill of a two weeks' training camp session.

The influx of. American tourists visiting the Irish Free State has rapidly increased in the last few years, C. E. Reddin, president of the Irish Tourist Association and a member of the Dublin Chamber of Commerce, declared yesterday in an interview at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

THE Postoffice Department's description of the promised Constitution 3-cent purple stamp, to be released on Sept. 17 with first-day sales at Philadelphia, contains the interesting disclosure that a device familiar on the Fascist postal paper of Italy is to be illustrated.
Morris W. Clouse, a lifelong resident of this town and a general practioner for thirty-six years, died yesterday at his home at the age of 60. He underwent an operation last January.

The Walter C. Hewitt organization, developers, of Northport and Huntington, L. I., report that eight cottages and twenty-three plots have been sold in their various properties since the first of this month.

The marriage of Miss Alice Elizabeth Forstbauer of this place, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Forstbauer, to Woodrow Wilson Wibel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman J. Wibel of Boonton, took place at noon today in St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector,the Rev. Robert M. Olton, who was assisted by the Rev. L. Harold Hinrichs, rector of Grace Episcopal Church, Nutley.

When a party of twelve Zenda residents leave Sept. 1 for New York to view the premiere of "The Prisoner of Zenda," a film play, only one person will be left in the village of several homes, a dairy and a general store.

DESPITE the implications of the title, this book represents neither a cross-section of the poetry at present being written on the Pacific Coast nor a selection of work that can be regarded as predominantly regional in content.
A. delegate to the Veterans of Foreign Wars national encampment here promised today to ask his exsoldier comrades to vote on a resolution endorsing the nationalization of the arms industry.

Eight Manhattan properties, seven of which are located above 100th Street, will be sold at auction this week by B. Hollander Son, auctioneer. The sales, which will be held in the Vesey Street salesrooms, are as follows:

Mr. and Mrs. J. Howard Pew gave a luncheon at the White Elephant here for a group from the Mount Washington, Bretton Woods, including Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hulme, Mr. and Mrs. W. Ross Harper, Mr. and Mrs. G. Berry Beaumont, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene M. Ong, Miss Mary Hughes, Mrs. Roberta Pew McVey, Mr. and Mrs. j. H. Wall, Miss Bernice Wall and H. Clayton Wall, Howard Hughes and T. A. Budenbach.
Throughout the week interest has centered at Camp Wildair, upper St. Regis camp of Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Reid, where they have been hosts for a mixed doubles tennis tournament.
Built soon after the close of the Civil War by a migratory New Englander, an old white farmhouse

September flower shows in the metropolitan region begin with that of the Clinton (N. J.) Garden Club next Friday and Saturday at the local Community House. All entries will be amateur. Classes include dahlias, gladioli, annuals, perennials, roses, house plants, and nineteen are to be of arrangementsone to be in a 10-cent container.
JAMES AGATE has lately said that Mr. O'Casey's "Juno and the Paycock" is the greatest play written in English since the days of Queen Elizabeth.
Makale Fiore, 60, of Brooklyn was killed and two of his sons were injured, one seriously, in a head-on crash with Ohio motorists on the Allentown-Harrisburg highway today.

A third candidate for the Brazilian Presidency will appear before the election on Jan. 3, or even the withdrawal of the majority backing Candidate Jose Americo de Al- day meida, is reservedly predicted today by the Diario da Noite. The Diario is backing Candidate Armando de Salles Oliveira.

One hundred and seventy-two New Jersey boys and girls were named today as winners of State scholarships at Rutgers University and New Jersey College for Women by Dr. Fraser Metzger, dean of men at Rutgers and chairman of the State Scholarship Committee. e.

THE battle between the Italian Government, which is anxious to create a national mo tion-picture industry capable of standing on its own feet, and the American film producers, who are fighting against what they regard as unfair discrimination, is rapidly approaching a climax that may result in a complete boycott of the Italian market by the American producing companies.

A DRAWING by Watteau was sold in London earlier in the month. Various comment, passing quick judgment on the artist, used the word "artificiality." It was spoken, no doubt, from hearsay rather than from observation-too stale a piece of gossip to take seriously.

BROWNING'S immortal query, "What's become of Waring?" might be answered these days with the statement that he is out in the sticks somewhere cashing in on the talents of an orchestra which is equaled in versatility only by a Liggett's drug store.

Demand for men's Fall furnishings continued to broaden last week and encouraged manufacturers to believe that the lean period through which they have been passing has about ended, they said here yesterday.

Coincident with the drive to restrict extended terms to consumers in the installment selling field, manufacturers in a variety of merchandise lines have started to curb the extension of credit to their accounts, reports in the New York markets indicated yesterday.

Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Tomorrow Bridgeport Brass Co., corn, 3 P. M. Briggs Stratton- Corp.. com.. Consolidated Edison Co. of -N. Y, $5 pf., 9:15 A. M.

Miss. Emily Joy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Sumner Joy of Bristol, Conn., was married here this afternoon-in St. Peter's Episcopal Church to Harold Warren Cobb, son of Mrs. Sumner W. Cobb of Great Neck, L. I., and the late Mr. Cobb.

More than 250 members of the Summer colony have been invited by Frank Lee Connable of New York, president of the Saranac Inn County Club, to a buffet supper he will give in Saranac Inn Casino the night of Sept. 6 for Miss Eugenia M. Coleman, daughter of Mrs. F. Stokes Coleman of Chestnut Hill, Pa., and John Connable Bennett, nephew of Mr. Connable, whose engagement was announced this Spring.

Only two components of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity showed increases for the week ended Aug. 21, and the combined index has receded to 109.9. The revised figure for the previous week was 111.2. The index stood at 103.5 for the corresponding week a year ago.
Several sales of properties in the Weston, Westport and Fairfield sections of Connecticut have been made by the Burgoyne, Hamilton Company, Inc.

There were 707 train accidents in May, as compared to 555 in May, 1936; and 3,933 in the first five months of this year, as compared to 3,660 in the same period of 1936, according to completed statistics made public by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

MORE than 1,500 fires are burning today in the woodlands of the Far West. It is the season when each spark in the forests menaces trees and men. From the Bitterroot and Cabinet ranges of the north, on south through the Olympic and Cascades and Sierras reverberates the warning: "Stamp out that spark!" Only the other day such a warning came too late.
THE ballet has a bright future in television, according to reports from London, where the dance is winning a prominent place on the telecast programs.
Attractive ?? sound construction ?? safe system of financing ?? nation-wide acceptance ??come building ?? the Federal ??.
The text of the statement of Dr. Chengting T. Wang, the Chinese Ambassador, officially declaring China's willingness to settle its dispute with Japan by pacific means, follows:

Third'Assistant Postmaster General Clinton B. Eilenberger died at his Summer home at Minisink Hills, near here, this morning after more than a year's illness. He was stricken last August while working in his office in Washington. He was 61 years old.

After a year of preparation, Captain Alexander Papana, 30-year-old officer of the Rumanian Royal Air Force, has set "some time in September" for the start of his 5,200mile flight, from New York to Bucharest to "show the advancement of flying equipment in the ten years since Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh flew the Atlantic the first time."

Adelbert R. Floberg, president of the Rockford Park district and former president of the Manufacturers National Bank, died today of uremic poisoning at Rockford Hospital. His age was 53. He had been a member of the park board since 1925 and president since 1927.

Lloyd Pusey, 44-year-old itinerant lay evangelist arrested here last night on a charge of beating his wife, Mary Cannon Pusey, 43, to death in an automobile in which they were en route from California to Oakland, N. J., was arraigned in police court today and held without bail for the grand jury.

Mrs. John Van Ryn of Austin and Miss Carolin Babcock of Los Angeles, the defending women's title holders, were challenged to the full extent of their powers to gain the semi-finals of the national doubles tennis championship today as play was resumed at she Longwood Cricket Club before the largest crowd to gather here in ten years.

EWPORT, R. I.-Golf. has overshadowed tennis among the Summer colony members here this year. The Casino courts have been used only Intermittently, and not a single informal week-end of mixed doubles, always popular in the past, has been arranged thus far.

Planes will continue to roar through the gathering Arctic night all Fall and Winter, if necessary, in search of Russia's most famous flier, Sigismund Levanevsky, who came down in the Arctic Circle seventeen days ago while attempting a Moscow-toCalifornia flight.
B. C. Dow, general manager of The Sioux Falls Argus-Leader for the last twenty-seven years, died in a hospital here early tonight from complications following an operation. He was 66 years old.

ANADA is planning a powerful short-wave transmitter of 50-kilowatt power to give the Dominion a place on the international map of broadcasting. The installation will probably be located at Ottawa or Montreal, with the former city favored so that the "voice of Canada" will flash into space from the capital.

AS railroads serving New York prepare for two of the biggest traffic movements of the year next month--the Labor Day holiday and the American Legion convention-a survey of the local offices of Western lines shows that business this Summer has exceeded that of any recent year.
Madeira, Hill Co., an anthracite and bituminous coal selling agency, and six subsidiaries filed today petitions in voluntary bankruptcy in the United States District Court here.

The writer of the following letter, well known as the author of several works on farm problems and economics as related especially to agriculture, is Professor of Rural Economy at Cornell University, a chair which he has held since 1917.

The marked confidence which has been shown in retail quarters regarding the outlook for retail trade during the Fall and Christmas holiday. season clashed last week with the more cautious attitude of some retail merchants who are now inclined to reduce their estimates of a 10 per cent increase in retail sales to possibly 5 to 8 per cent.
Joseph W. Baker, architect and hanker and lifelong resident of this town, died today at St. James Hospital, Newark. His age was 48. He became ill three weeks ago at his Summer home in Avon.

Speed in amending the Multiple Dwelling Law to make effective the provisions for fire-protected housing under the new Building Code was urged yesterday in construction circles. The new code goes into effect Jan. 1, 1938, but the fire-protected type of construction will be ineffectual as regards apartment buildings because the Multiple Dwelling Law prevails and must, therefore, be changed.

Margaret Logan, 12 years old, the daughter of Dr. F. A. Logan and Mrs., Logan of Lindsay, Qnt., died in a hospital here today from a rare disease, acute lupus. Only eight similar cases have been known in Canada, physicians believe. The girl was treated by Canadian and United States specialists.

THREE exhibitions were added last week to the current attrac tions in local galleries. Louis Marotta, who is holding his first one-man show at the offices of Theodore A. Kohn Son, 608 Fifth Avenue, has surmounted the handicaps imposed by infantile paralysis, at an early age to become-largely self-taught-a painter and woodcarver.
Banking legislation, largely ignored in the last session of Congress, may take an important position on the calendar of the next session.
WITH Summer travel swelling pre-vacation figures, America's skyways seem headed for their greatest year in aviation history.
Home runs by Earl Averill and Hal Trosky gave the Indians their third straight victory over the Athletics today, 5--4. They made nine hits do more good than the Mackmen's ten.
Financial circles forecast today that Richard K. Mellon would take up the scepter of family fortunes dropped by his uncle, Andrew W. Mellon.

The twenty-first annual Summer session of City College, which closed after an eight-week semester on Aug. 18, was attended by 5,330 students, according to a statistical survey compiled by the Summer session office and released yesterday.

After much telephoning between Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain at Balmoral, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in Yorkshire and the Foreign Office in London, the form of the British protest to Japan on the machine-gunning of the British Ambassador to China on the NankingShanghai road was approved tonight.

Nomination of candidates for places on the Board of Estimate who are supporters of the new city charter was urged yesterday in an appeal to Republican voters by Joseph D. McGoldrick, candidate for Controller, and Alderman Newbold Morris, candidate for President of the City Council.

STROUDSBURG, Pa.--With the Summer season fast drawing to a close, every one is now planning for a strenuous Labor Day week-end and all resort houses in the Poconos report bookings that will practically fill their houses.

A person had to be a twin to get any attention in this Northern Indiana city tonight. The man, woman or child who could not point to a double was almost a forgotten citizen, at least for the week-end. Old twins, young twins, fat twins and slim twins were here, there and everywhere as about 3,000 from fifteen States gathered for their sixth annual national convention.

We print on this page today a letter from Professor Boyle of Cornell describing what he calls our "cotton revolution." As a result of the "strange bargain" entered into between a bloc of cotton Senators and the President, this country is once more to embark upon a scheme of loans, subsidies and restriction.

OTHER generations have furthered cultural movements, but it is doubtful if any has been as selfconscious as our own, in its transitional role. Many have grown weary of hearing vast changes enumerated, with little attention to objectives.

Johnny Goodman of Omaha, national open titleholder in 1933, won the United States amateur championship at the Alderwood Country Club in Portland, Ore., by defeating Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie, 2 up, in the thirty-six-hole final. Goodman gained a twohole advantage on the morning round and was 3 up after the twenty-seventh.

A warning that the class conflict is becoming more acute in the United States and that the people are being stirred by "deep-seated forces" was given yesterday by Rabbi Louis I. Newman of Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, in his Sabbath morning sermon.

Recent buyers of lots at Saltaire, the vacation community on Fire Island, include M. H. Haas, J. J. McDermott, Cornelius J. Donovan, Bertram L. Kraus, Roy H. Slack, Louis M. Faulkner, Dr. E. M. Josephson, Harry D. Horn, May R.

ENGLISH counterparts of the United States admirals who a decade ago fought off the drive of the late Brig. Gen. William Mitchell for a unified air force, have just won the first round here in their battle with the Air Ministry to regain control of naval-aviation.

The fifteenth "Lord Kelvin" house to be erected in the New York area will be opened for inspection next Sunday in the New Canterbury section of Rockville Center, L. I., where twenty-five homes have been completed and two more are under construction.
The strike against the Boardwalk Yellow Cab Corporation here brought a second outbreak of violence today that resulted in thirteen arrests.

To the Drama Editor: In the newspaper obituary notices of James McIntyre the distinctive characterization of this member of the celebrated black-faced team of McIntyre and Heath which will give him enduring rank in the hall of exquisite portraitures for the American stage was almost entirely overlooked.
The barber shop quartet contest held last night in the Music Shell at Jones Beach was won by the Jones Beach Deck Officers, who out-crooned the other two entries.

Armed with a refreshing drink in the clubhouse of the Alderwood Country Club immediately after his 2-up victory over Ray Billows, Johnny Goodman, new national amateur golf champion, declared today that he was never worried during the last crucial holes of the match.
China's American-educated First Lady came to Shanghai today, saw first-hand the ravages of warfare, and declared: "China is not afraid."

NEW JERSEY'S pine forests, which cover more than a million acres in the southern part of the State, are proving increasingly popular with motorists and vacationists in search of pleasant, leisurely drives through picturesque country.

PRIMARILY, the Boy Scout camping program seeks to give boys experience and selfreliance in "roughing it" out-ofdoors, to teach something of nature and to develop friendships. Entwined with these more serious aims, providing a sugar coating, so to speak, are provisions for games and fun.

The drug store, in former days a place given over almost wholly to the compounding and dispensing of medicines, isn't what it used to be, and an interesting legal opinion on this point recently was handed down in the Brooklyn division of the New York Supreme Court, points out Samuel R. Schneider, New York lawyer.

The formal endorsement of Mayor La Guardia by the Communist party drew the fire of W. Kingsland Macy, former Republican State Chairman, today at the outing of the Suffolk County Republican party at Timber Point.

Despite a daily downpour of rain, that at times caused almost flood conditions, the 2,200 infantrymen of the Eighty-seventh Brigade, commanded by Brig. Gen. Walter R. DeLamater, on a two weeks tour of training at Camp Smith here, ended on schedule today a week of marksmanship tests on the range with rifles and machine guns.

Plans to restore to its original setting the Jabez Howland House, the only residence now standing in Plymouth in which Pilgrims were known to have lived, were considered today by the John Howland Society of Pilgrlm Descendants.

Plans have been completed for the annual flower exhibition of the Old Greenwich Garden Club, to be held on Sept. 15, at the - June Binney Memorial Parish House, Old Greenwich, from 3 to 9 P. M. There are fifty-three classes scheduled. Competition will be open to every one in Greenwich, as well as visiting garden clubs.

ASTOR-High, Wide and Handsome, closing tonight; The Firefly: Jeanette MacDonald, Allan Jones, opens Wednesday night. CAMEO-Song of Ceylon, Fragment of an Empire and China Express.* CAPITOL-Reopening Thursday with Broadway Melody of 1938. CENTRAL-The Man in Blue: Robert Wilcox, Ralph Morgan. CINEMA DE PARIS--65,66 och Jag, Swedish comedy.

By taking advantage of the provisions of the Mortgage Commission Law permitting borrowing for taxes and arrears and the law enacted at the last session of the .Legislature providing facilities for the'reorganization of issues that have little or no present income, the State Mortgage Commission has been able to deal with many mortgages it otherwise would be unable to handle, it was learned yesterday.

While Congress is on vacation work will go on in Washington for the drafting of a bill to extend government control over the financing of American railroads. There is every indication that the bill will go to the Senate at its next session with the unanimous approval of the Committee on Interstate Commerce, of which Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana is chairman. Its passage, in the opinion of members of the committee, is certain.
William Walker Canfield, editor of The Utica Observer Dispatch since 1913, died tonight at his home, 1 Kenyon Court, after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

Hundreds of defenseless Chinese civilians were killed and hundreds more were wounded yesterday in raids by Japanese bombing planes over Nantao, part of the old Chinese city of Shanghai adjoining the French Concession.

American foreign traders seeking to maintain as much as possible of their commerce with the Orient despite hostilities there, were faced with a new difficulty last week when marine underwriters refused to insure cargoes "beyond sea-going vessels" to certain Chinese ports.

The Greenland Board reported today that Dr. Lauge Koch's expedition ship, the Gustav Holm, is in danger of being trapped in the ice off Scoresby Sound, from where Dr. Koch wired the board for permission to try to return to Scoresby Sound.
EDNA ST. VINCENT MILLAY has written a dozen books of verse and a handful of plays and already she has become the subject of a full-length bibliography.
RENAN exerted great influence over the general public in France by his bold thinking suavely told--a heavy mixture of scientific reasoning, fine sensibility and effective rhetoric.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Leonard R. Gracy of Montclair of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth R. Gracy, to T. Ramsey Kenny, son of Mr. and Mrs. T. F. Kenny of Buclkingham, Quebec.

The ruffed grouse and partridge situation is not only causing the Scotch gamekeepers to resort to large quantities of their national beverage but is bringing a troublesome problem to the New York Conservation Department.

Miss. Martha St. John Tourison, daughter of -Mr. and Mrs. Sedgwick C. Tourison of Mount Airy, was married this afternoon to Joseph Kenworthy Eddleman, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Eddleman of Roxborough. The ceremony took place in Grace Episcopal Church, Mount Airy.

Members of the North and South Shore Summer colonies have completed a program of horse shows, race meetings, steeplechase and fox hunting features for September that will make the month the busiest season horse fanciers have ever known on Long Island.

The Soviet authorities are increasing their corps of donors of blood for transfusions in peacetime treatments for saving wounded in the event of was. Moscow newspapers are now carrying want ads asking new blood donors to present themselves at the Central Institute of Blood Transfusion of the Commissariat of Health.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. G. LaRue Masters of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris Masters, to Frederick Orvis Church, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Orvis Church, also of South Orange.

CREMONA. THE magic name of Antonio Stradivari is a potent magnet that has been drawing to Cremona this Summer crowds of instrumental connoisseurs and art pilgrims from many lands to pay tribute to the "prince of luthiers" and the illustrious Cremonese viol school.
An adventure which probably sets the low record for a ransom is recounted by Hans Helfritz in the September issue of Natural Histoiy, official organ of the American Museum of Natural History. Mr.
To the select list of immortals who have won both the American amateur and open championships another name was added at the Alderwood Country Club today.

The regional office of the National Labor Relations Board cited the American Radiator Company today on charges of unfair labor practices in connection with the closing May 7 of its Litchfield, Ill., plant.

The New York Hippodrome Opera Company last night presented "Aida" as the second bill of its fifth Fall season. This ever-popular work attracted an audience of more than 5,000, who were generous in their approval of a cast of veterans.

Non-intervention and the Mediterranean bobbed up again today to vex the British Government with a report that the results of the naval patrol off Spain; whose cost is now shared jointly by France and Great Britain, do not justify the expense.
Acute differences between Right and Left Wing political groups in Chile are expected to be intensified with the proposed presentation in Congress of a bill sanctioning divorce, as announced today.

Three outstanding facts of the undeclared Sino-Japanese War, as far as it has gone, convince the Japanese that will be short and sharp and that organized military resistance Will be overcome before Christmas.

As the unemployed delegation of the Workers' Alliance plodded the streets of Washington during the past week to enlist the sympathies of an already adjourned Congress, Federal administrative officials charged with responsibilities under the bill calling for a "census" of the jobless tried to figure out what, if any, results might be expected from this last-minute. piece of legislation.
Police guarded the Beverly Hills home of Wallace Beery, screen actor, today while Federal authorities studied a note threatening Beery's adopted daughter with harm unless he paid $10,000.

Mankind's first joint official-report on one of the first concerns of all mankind-food-has been published by the League of Nations. Entitled "Nutrition," it is a comprehensive, 330-page final report by the League's mixed committee on the "Relation of Nutrition to Health, Agriculture and Economic Policy."

WHERE was Sally Lunn during the period covered by "Three Fevers," the fishing story in which Mr. Walmsley told of the rivalry between the Lunns and the Fosdycks of Bramblewick and of the mounting ambition of Henry Lunn and his two oldest sons, John and Marney?

Telegraph operators, roundsmen and servicemen employed by the American District Telegraph Company in the protection of hospitals, hotels and skyscrapers from burglary and fire by supervision of thousands of watchmen and by maintenance of automatic alarm systems staged a walkout last midnight.

This village's three-way controversy over "statue vs. park vs. parking place" in Columbus Square on Orchard -Street, the main business street of lower Tarrytown, was complicated still further this week with the withdrawal by ItalianAmerican groups of their offer to erect a statue- of Christopher Columbus in the square.
BAR HARBOR, Me.-The coming week will be particularly active on Mount Desert Island and its resort centers. including Northeast, Southwest and Seal Harbor.

Edward P. Jester, who established the automobile dealer's firm of E. P. Jester Son and was for many years active in business and in the Masonic fraternity, died today at his home here at the age of 69.

The controversy between estate owners of the community of Purchase and officials of Harrison and Mamaroneck over the construction of a new water system running through but not serving Purchase will reach the Supreme Court on Tuesday. Argument is scheduled in White Plains in an action to enjoin the erection of a 90-foot water tower near the junction of Kenilworth Road with Westchester Avenue.

BOTH white elephants and Siamese cats are virtually extinct in Siam, but the country is the most Oriental of all Far Eastern islands. The temples of Siam are as munificently dazzling as any dream of the Orient could be.

Floating floors and false ceilings occupy considerable space in the latest report of the British Research Board. Both are intended to reduce noise being transmitted from one flat to another in an apartment house, and in the last analysis both appear to be somewhat similar.
More than 40 per cent of the employes of General Electric have worked with the company for ten or more years, according to a recent survey.

Audrey Raymond, 4 years old, was fatally injured about 7 o'clock last night when she fell from her mother's lap out of the family automobile as it was approaching their home at 145 Marion Street, Brooklyn, according to the police.

In the South Serb village of Blase the Governmental party Deputy Ramadon Ramadanovitch was killed today as he was returning home from the fields. He represented the Albanians living in Serbia and his death is attributed to a blood feud.

Among the dwellings recently completed or now under construction by Equity Builders, Inc., are the following: For A. H. Barrett, on Alta Vista Drive, Yonkers, for Alfred Dyckman, on the west side of Ridge Street, north of Loomis Street, in Peekskill;

TODAY Paris Bound, one of Philip Barry's gayest comedies, will be presented as an hour production by the Radio Playhouse Acting Company. In "Paris Bound" Mr. Barry concerns himself with some of the perplexing social and moral problems of marriage: WNYC, 12 noon.
WASHINGTON. -- Chief of the United States Information Service since its organization in March, 1934, Miss Harriet M. Root knows better than any one else what questions . America is asking today.
It is unknown yet what effect the dissolution of German Rotary Clubs will have on Austrian ones whichh are grouped with them.

An advance in the sale of houses by operative builders in and near New York City during the past few weeks has been reported, according to Thomas G. Grace, State director of the Federal Housing Administration.

Many types of heating equipment and domestic fuels undergo exhaustive tests for efficiency in the laboratories of Anthracite Industries, Inc., at Primos, Pa., according to Allen J. Johnson, in charge of that organization's testing department.
Charlie Ames's Blue Nose led home the fleet of twenty-one Snipes today in the second race of the fourth annual international championship series off the New Rochelle Yacht Club.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it would admit to the list tomorrow Koppers Company first mortgage and collateral trust bonds, series A, 4 per dent, due on Nov. 1, 1951, and General Tire and Rubbet Company common stock, $5 par value.

A new type of fireproof paint, valuable in wartime as a protection against incendiary bombs, recently has been developed in Germany, according to a report made public today by the Chemical Division of the Department of Commerce.

Metl production in Ontario reached a new high level in the first six months of this year, being valued at $102,353,786, compared with $79,163,850 in the corresponding portion of 1936 and with $85,725,833 in the second half of last year. The largest increases were shown for copper and nickel, according to a production report of the Ontario Department of Mines, with gold and platinum also registering good gains.

Albert Arthur Tilney of 966 Central Avenue, this place, chairman of the board of directors and former president of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, died during his sleep last night in a fishing lodge while on a fishing trip in Eastern Canada, according to word received here today by his brother-in-law, Roger F. Murray. He was 69 years old.

WE learn from the writing of Mr. Gail Martin of The Deseret News that all was not light and peace for the music lover who attended a performance of Haydn's "Creation" at the Capitol Theatre of his city. This performance was marred for the reverent listener by "the wrigglers, the whisperers, the prancers, the talkers, the handholders, the yowlers and a multitude of other human pests."

Close-of-play scores in English County cricket matches started today follow: Surrey 448 runs for eight wickets (Fishlock 127, Barllng 114, Holmes 82), vs. Middlesex, at Lord's. Hampshire 93 (Bowes six for 36, Smales four for 40), Yorkshire 157 for eight, at Bournemouth.
At the end of the first thirty-six holes in the Glens Falls open golf tournament tonight the race for the leadership was very much in dispute with three players sharing first place at 135.
The news, or sometimes even the lack of news, from Callander, Ont., raises one of those questions which seem important out of all proportion to the numbers involved.

Miss Elisabeth Mathesius, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Mathesius of this place, was married here this afternoon in the garden of her parents' home to Dallas Blair-Smith of New York by the Rev. Merrill Fowler Clarke of New Canaan.
Grover Whalen, head of the New York world's fair of 1939, today took a ride with Italian authorities to see the site of the Rome world fair of 1941.

Pre-season conferences with spokesmen for representative retail organizations, including the chains, will be recommended as an established policy of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board at the semi-annual convention of the board's executive council to be held tomorrow and Tuesday at the Hotel New Yorker.

The real estate holdings of the East Lake Realty Corporation, comprising 456 plots in East Patchogue, L. I., will be sold at auction Saturday at 1:30 P. M. The lots are part of the old Wicham estate on Swan Lake and the north side of Montauk Highway.

That Mexico will soon be in a position to cut off two lower tributaries of the Rio Grande, drying up the Texas water supply for 100 miles along the border in the region southeast of Brownsville, was stressed today by Mexican reclamation officials as Finance Secretary Eduardo Saurez visited Azucar Dam, under construction in the San Juan River.

The death of John G. Lowe, whose body was found floating in Long Island Sound yesterday following his disappearance from a steamer bound from New York to Boston, was attributed to drowning while walking in his sleep.
The dining rooms of India House, the 100-year-old luncheon club at Hanover Square, have been altered to lessen interior sounds and exclude street noises.

A tour of nine gardens here will take place on Tuesday under the auspices of the Woman's Auxiliary of St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Noroton, of which Mrs. William Morris Meredith is president. Also on exhibition will be the Norton collection of early American glass and lustreware, which is housed in a pinepaneled room with wallpaper 200 years old.
IF "Museum" is to be classi fied as a novel, as the author wishes, then the protagonists of the drama are the convict Manzell and the prison wall. The tale is fiction, but only to that extent.

To the Art Zdftori: TrHE painter's art and the musician's are highly rarefied subjective impressions of the mind; and as no 'painter may' see with complete vision that which occurs in the electro-magneti6 atmosphere that enfolds us, we watch 'these mysterious worlds, as we: respond with our emotions and vision, anil we intuitively compose formulas, which serve as our directions toward the spheres we cannot see.

Less than a month after her impressive conquest in the women's Western Derby in Chicago, Miss Marion Miley of Cincinnati, Curtis Cup star, added another title to her imposing list today by winning the thirty-fifth annual women's Western tournament.

Asserting that "my friends of the Jewish faith advise me there is no need for a change," Governor Hoffman decided tooday not to call a special session of the Legislature to set back the date of the primary elections from Sept. 21.

The marriage of Miss Jean Kingsbury Carter to Andrew Barton Jones took place this afternoon at Green Pastures, Center Berlin, the Summer home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Samuel Green of Loudonville. The Rev. George A.

Sales of liquor at retail in the New York metropolitan area for July and August will show a dedine estimated in some quarters as high as 20 per cent from those months last year, and distillers yesterday were drafting plans for increased advertising promotions in an effort to recoup these losses in the Fall.
The Federation of Insurance Counsel will hold its first annual convention in the Hotel Chelsea here on Monday and Tuesday.

MR. HAWTREY, the wellknown economist and technical expert of the British Government in financial matters, has written a valuable book of expository criticism dealing with a few of the more important theories relating to the trade cycle.

The marriage of Miss Nancy Lord, daughter of Mrs. Harry Dimmock Lord of this city, to Gordon C. Knight, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Knight of New Haven, Conn., took place this evening at the home of the bride's mother.

IT is the time of year when city people in large numbers go camping. Of their own free will they forsake sumptuous homes, turn away from gas ranges, electric refrigerators and built-in showers, bid farewell to screens, awnings, air-conditioning, indirect lighting, telephones, elevator service and sanitary plumbing, and rush off to a lodge, tent, tepee or hut in some vast wilderness where the inconveniences of living would appall an Abyssinian.

A number of courses in real estate practice and procedure will be given in Columbia University Extension during the Winter session beginning on Sept. 23. DeWitt Van Buren, attorney, will be in charge.

In attempting to estimate the true significance of architecture (as of the fruits of all the arts) we cannot hope to escape the embarrassment of too close range. What--a troubling thought ever obtrudes--will be the attitude of men a century hence toward the structures we have builded and admired?

Declaring that the Italian Government, by its aid to General Franco's forces, is. "at war with Loyalist Spain," Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, announced yesterday that he had called upon President Roosevelt to invoke the Neutrality Law against Italy, "the invader."
Ninety-nine international student conferences are taking place in Europe this Summer, ranging from those of the extreme right to those of the extreme left, but mainly consisting of neutrals.

LAUNCHING: At the Brooklyn Navy Yard last week the new light cruiser Honolulu, first warship to be so named, slid down the ways. As East River tugs whistled salutes, Miss Helen Poindexter, daughter of Hawaii's Governor, smashed a bottle of champagne across the ship's bow, saying: "I christen you Honolulu. God bless you and keep you safe."

The court, now at Balmoral Castle, has assumed a Victorian atmosphere of quiet family life. The birthdays of Queen Elizabeth and Princess Margaret Rose have been celebrated, the latter spending her first birthday away from Glamis Castle, where she was born. All members of the royal family attend Sunday morning service at Crathie Church.

Holton V. Noyes, New York State Commissioner of Agriculture, warned dairy farmers today against taking advantage of rising prices to producers to flood the market with milk and thus "kill the goose that lays the golden egg."

Out in Utah the President has just set aside a 37,000-acre tract of land to be known as the Capitol Reef National Monument, thus preserving a notable open-air summary of an important section of American history from those who might want to pepper it with hot-dog stands or grind it up for road material.

The United States Government has been assured by the Government of Iran of the latter's determination to keep the peace particularly in Western Asia and in so far as it is able throughout the world, in accordance with Secretary of State Cordell Hull's statement of July 16.

Mr. and Mrs. Barnes Newberry will give a tea on Wednesday at the Dunes Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Helen Barnes Newberry. The debutante is a granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. Truman H. Newberry of Detroit and the late Mr. and Mrs. William Binney of Providence, R. I.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Aug. 25, aggregated $7,454,000,000, or 10 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 2 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

BOOKS on newspapers and journalism have fallen into three groups; general histories of the press, histories of single newspapers or biographies of editors and publishers, and books on the art of writing for newspapers.

An imposing array of speakers has been gathered to address the annual convention of the United States Building and Loan League in Los Angeles on Oct. 6-8. Included are leaders in the thrift and home financing industry, Federal Home Loan Bank presidents, representatives of several governmental agencies with which the league deals and advertising experts.

THE central character in this story is John Rutherford, the proprietor of a book shop and lending library in a little English village. It is Rutherford who discovers the body of Police Constable Johnson lying by the side of a country road and reports the matter to Johnson's superior officer.
Opening up a margin of 9 minutes 16 seconds, Harold S. Vanderbilt's American Cup defender Ranger took the first race today of the Eastern Yacht Club's series for the big sloops.
While Austro-German trade relations are considered satisfactory, the balance of payments is causing much concern to the Austrian National Bank.
The reception and dance given by Countess Laszio Szechenyi tonight at the Breakers, her Summer villa on Ochre Point, was one of the largest and most brilliant social events here this Summer.

Berkshire's blueberry crop this Summer, the largest in many years, is conservatively estinlated at 3,000 bushels. The high-bush harvest is now at its height and will 0ontlnue until frost. Por sweetness and flavor the luscious Berkshire blueberries are said to be unsurpassed.

The marriage of Miss Janice Chrystal Kennedy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Kenhedy, and John .Homer Winter, Jr., son of. Mr. and Mrs. John H. Winter of New York and this community, took place this afternoon in the boathouse of Kennedune, the bride's home. The Rev. Joseph A. Stronsky officiated.

A plea for financial and moral support of the Christian forces which are organizing relief work in China was issued yesterday. The appeal was sent to headquarters of various Protestant denominations by the Foreign Missions Conference of North America.
Attorneys withdrew today an application to punish.Alfred E. Smith Jr., son of the former Governor, for contempt of court on a charge that he failed to pay alimony to his wife, Bertha Gott Smtih.

The marriage of Miss Emily Fuller Campbell, daughter of Oscar James Campbell, Professor of English at Columbia University, and Mrs. Campbell, to George W. Meyer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Meyer of Edwardsville, Ill., took place here this afternoon in the garden of the home of Mrs. Henry C. Adams. The Rev. Frederick Leech of St. Andrews Episcopal Church performed the ceremony.

At a tea in their home here this afternoon, Dr. and Mrs. Donald B. Cragin announced the engagement of Mrs. Cragin's daughter, Miss Reata King Kimball. to Jerrems Chamberlain Hart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Hart of New Britain.

Two Bronx youths, who said they had paid a Brooklyn Negro $10 for a tip on the location- of buried money were taken into custody this afternoon as they were digging a shallow trench in Woodland Cemetery here. Pending further investigation and efforts to locate the Negro, the boys were held on an open charge.

The Weather Bureau said today the "slight tropical disturbance" discovered in the Atlantic Monday had "apparently spread out," with squalls covering rather an extensive area from the Bahamas to the Florida southeast coast. No strong winds were reported, but small craft were advised to continue caution tonight and tomorrow, meteorologists said.

LOUIS PERSINGER will conduct. the senior orchestra and head the violin department of the Music School of the Henry Street Settlement, it was announced by Grace Spofford, director of the school. Mr. Persinger will be assisted in his violin teaching by Dorothy Minty and Joseph Knitzer.

Further recovery in Japanese dollar bonds were the feature yesterday of another dull session in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange. Without any apparent reason or encouraging news from the Far East, most all of the issues of Japanese origin were bid up from 1 1/4 to 4 1/2 points on only a few sales. The government's 6 1/s were the only exception, these obligations closing a point lower.

With the season for evergreen planting here to hurry decisions, the home owner who is planning new landscaping or who expects to set out additional trees is confronted with the problem of selecting varieties that will give him just the effects he desires.
The naval situation in the Far East has been changed by decision of the Australian Government to create a naval fueling station at Darwin and to fortify the port.

CALIFORNIA'S mother lode of historical treasure shows no signs of petering out. Even where the vein has been worked before, such prospectors as George D. Lyman find pay dirt and more than an occasional nugget.

CANBERRA, Australia. -- In his report to the Council of the League of Nations, the Administrator of the Australian mandated Territory of New Guinea (Brig. Gen. W. Ramsay McNicoll) tells of a quaint experience in the course of a visit to the home of a settler in Belik, in New Ireland.

WASHINGTON.--With the alarms of war converting so large a part of the world into an armed camp, the War and Navy Departments are reading with quickened interest the reports reaching Washington almost daily from half a hundred or more military and naval attaches assigned to the principal foreign capitals.
A former Mellette County school teacher today returned her July and August old age assistance checks to J. W. Kaye, State Social Security Director, and asked to withdraw her application for aid.

The expulsion by Latvia of the well-known Estonian scientist, Dr. Oskar Loorits, head of the Estonian Folklore Institute, who visited Lavia in order to study the life of the Livonian population there, caused bitter resentment in Estonia, where a great number of leading university people announced their intention to discontinue cultural cooperation with Latvia.

President Roosevelt tonight questioned the attitude toward democratic government of "a small minority, powerful and articulate, which, paying lip service to democracy, seeks by every means within its power to thwart the will of the majority."

IN its rush to adjourn Congress failed to approve several bills which affect philately. Two concerned the airmail service. One would ha e extended the present domestic airmail system by about 3,000 miles.

The National Dress Manufatturers Association will conduct an active educational campaign, during the rest of the year to bring to the attention of dress manufacturers the cost of social security and unemployment insurance taxes in terms of cost per garment in the various price ranges and in relation to volume, it was announced yesterday by Mortimer Lanzit, executive director.

No single incident could have brought the Far Eastern war to England, and therefore to Europe, so effectively as the shooting of the British Ambassador in a British car flying the Union Jack. When struck down on the road to Shanghai Sir Hughe Montgomery Knatchbull-Hugessen was speeding to a conference to press the British plan to neutralize the Shanghai area.

AT Marlborough, Conn. (roadside signs and maps and atlases call it Marlboro, but natives insist upon ampler spelling), the Central Connecticut Art Center has put up the fourth and last Summer show of its second season, which will be current until Sept. 6.

Somewhere on the Atlantic Ocean the dry-cleaned suit of Rudolph Black secretary to Representative Lyle Boren of Seminole, Okla., is believed to be in the baggage of Justice Hugo Black of the Supreme Court, who is on his way to Europe.

Information received from three sources by the Bronx Board of Trade indicates an upswing in Bronx realty, particularly in the industrial field, Roderick Stephens, president of the board, declared yesterday.
Wilbert Lewis Smith, pioneer in the Syracuse typewriter industry and president of the board of L. C. Smith and Corona Typewriters, Inc., died at his home here tonight. His age was 85.

Many buyers are expected in the New York wholesale market right after Labor Day, in view of the light early-season buying, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. Stores now launching their September sales report results more satisfactory than in the advance August sales in many cities. The report continues:

NOWHERE else in the compass of one volume is there so vivid and rounded a picture of real life in Virginia during the generation that saw the gathering of forces which transformed an English colony into part and parcel of a North American nation.

By accepting a compromise proposal suggested by Committee for Industrial Organization spokesmen, the United Automobile Workers' Union convention today healed the conflict over the election of a staff of officers and other contentious major questions which had divided the union into two warring camps.

The Bureau of Investigation of the United States Department of Justice requested detectives of the New York City Police Department yesterday to furnish it with all available information concerning the murder of Mrs. Esther Gordon who was shot, stabbed ten times, stuffed in a barrel and tossed down an embankment near .the Queens end of Hell Gate Bridge Thursday night.
Fifty university and college presidents in this country and Canada have accepted invitations to attend the inauguration of Cornell University's fifth president, Dr. Edmund Ezra Day on Oct. 8.

The index numbers of the registered unemployed for sixteen principal industrial countries which appear in the 1936-37 edition of the I. L. O. Yearbook of Labor Statistics, just out, showed that on the basis of 1929 equaling 100 unemployment reached a peak of 291 in 1932 and by last April had dropped to 113.

Mayor Rolland B. Marvin of Syracuse will not be a candidate for Governor next year, he said today in an address at the field day of the South Utica Republican Club. He is now serving his fourth twoyear term as Mayor of Syracuse and is a candidate for re-election this Fall.

David Kilpatrick, 40th Precinct, assigned to telephone switchboard duty, tours 8 A. M. to 4 P. M. and from 4 P. M. to 12 midnight, for 30 days, from 8 A. M., Aug. 30.

Mrs. William Thompson Overton of Memphis, Tenn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Virginia Mathilde Overton, to Frank Lee Wesson of Wilson, Ark., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Wesson of Springfield and Cotuit, Mass.

Columbus, Ohio, and the late Mr. Meek, took place yesterday afternoon in the Marble Collegiate Church.
