As Promoter Mike Jacobs yesterday directed final plans for the world heavyweight championship battle between Joe Louis, the titleholder, and Tommy Farr, British Empire champion, which is to be held tomorrow night in the Yankee Stadium, he faced one very important defection from the ranks of the heavyweights he has under his control.

Mrs. Joseph E. Brown Jr., widow of Professor Brown, recently of Princeton, N. J., has announced at her Southwest Harbor home the en gagement of her daughter, Miss Janet Olcott Brown, to Julian Lake Nugent Jr. of New York, son of Mrs. B. Provost Traukman and of Julian Lake Nugent of St. Louis.
Because so many people have been absent from their homes this year on vacations, marketing surveys and sampling campaigns have been reduced sharply, according to research executives here yesterday.

A twenty-eight-page pamphlet explaining how proportional representation will operate in the election of members of the City Council this Fall has been prepared by the Municipal Civil Service Commission and can be obtained for five cents a copy at the offices of The City Record in Room 2218, Municipal Building.

BLOOMENTHAL--LEVY--Mr. and Mrs. Edward I. Levy of Woodmere, L. I., announce the engagement of their daughter. Miss Helene Levy, to Dr. Ernest D. Bloomenthal, son of Dr. and Mrs. J. Bloomenthal of Chicago.

John W. Edelman, regional director of the Committee for Industrial Organization, said today that Milton S. Hershey, founder of a model town near Harrisburg, had consented to the use of the Hershey Little Theatre for a State-wide labor meeting next Friday.

ONE wanders wide-eyed through Mr. Smolka's book with the faint impression that he is following Alice through Wonderland that there isn't any such place as the Soviet North, and that if there were it must be crazier than anything Alice ever dreamed of.

COLLEGE IN CRINOLINE" is a school story with a unique back ground one which so far as I know. has never been employed before in juvenile fiction. It is a story which well deserves the telling, this account of life during the first years on one of the earliest American co-educational campuses, in the days when young ladies chose haphazardly between a course in Greek and one in the modeling of wax flowers-in days, too.

RADIO'S "press-a-button season" is open. The complete line of 1937-38 receivers is on the market from coast to coast, featuring automatic tuners which bring in desired stations by merely pressing buttons.

Dr. Eric M. Matsner, medical director of the American Birth Control League and executive secretary of the National Medical Council on Birth Control, declared on his return from Europe on the French liner Lafayette yesterday that Americans and British were now equally convinced of the futility of legislation against birth control.

In reporting the dismissal of a charge of abduction which had been made against Mrs. Dottie Morris, 28 years old, THE NEW YORK TIMES incorrectly referred yesterday to Mrs. Morris as a Negro. Mrs. Morris is not Negro.

John McLennan Jr. of New York has bought for $18,000 the 800-acre estate Ashintully, at Tyringham, which was created by the late Robb De Peyster Tytus. Mr. McLennan is the son of a Canadian Senator, who married Mr. Tytus's widow, now deceased.

More than 100,000 residents of New York State had membership in the 356 credit unions operating in the State on Dec. 31, William Reid, president of the New York State Credit Union League and also New .York City tax collector, announced yesterday.

"First bale" cries are sounding in Dixie. That is the sign that cotton-picking time has arrived. This week thousands of men, women and children, both white and Negro, bent their backs in fields along the Cotton Belt's lower rim.

In a letter to the Board of Estimate James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx, yesterday approved the request made by the Greater New York Hospital Association for an increase in the rates paid by the city for the care of public charges in voluntary hospitals.
JAZZ: The New York Telephone directory lists twice the name of W. C. Handy. One is the residence, the other the office, of the man regarded as the father of the blues.

MORE than fifteen years ago a small group of Massachusetts trapshooters, grown weary of standing in one position for all their shots, struck upon the idea of moving about and firing at the clay pigeons from different angles.

Far from losing interest in the Bible, as many critics claim, young people evidenced a-growing interest in Bible study during the Summer conference season at' the Stony Brook Assembly here. Youths predominated at most of the gatherings with five of the eight conferences held under the direct auspices of young people's groups, the Assembly's manager, Gilbert C. Moore, said today.

Senator Burke of Nebraska declared today that if President Roosevelt toured the country in behalf of his defeated court bill it would be a final indication that he planned to purge the Democratic party of those unwilling to support "anything the President wants."
More and more land on Long Island formerly occupied as estates by well-known New Yorkers is being usurped to fill a demand for new suburban residences within commuting distance of Manhattan.
IN this army garrison are stationed the last of the Indian scouts, a vanishing remnant of what was once a valuable auxiliary of the "Old Army"--the army of the Indian campaigns.

DRAWING to the close of the Summer season, trade last week showed some signs of quickening, but the gain was not impressive. Clearances were patronized more freely and action was reported on back-to-school merchandise.

Miss Virginia Littlefield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Franklin Littlefield of New York and Swampscott, formerly of this place, was married here this afternoon in the Tabernacle Church to John Roderick Falby of Melrose and New York, son of Mrs. Henry C. Falby of Melrose and the late Mr. Falby. The Rev. Richard Bennett of Belmont performed the ceremony.

ROME. -- A campaign is under way to make the Italian airplane engine and automobile motor industries independent of foreign patents, and thus to prevent the exodus of millions of lire now being paid each year to foreign concerns for royalties.
A Lufthansa JU-52 plane similar to the one that performed the feat a few days ago has just flown from Kabul, Afghanistan, to Soochow, China, on a survey for a new airline.
The ten-story apartment house nearing completion at 160 Brooklyn Heights, corner of Clark Street, Brooklyn, is -70 per' cent rented from the plans, according to Silk Hitlin, the builders.
Doctors endeavored tonight to remove the deadly menace of lockjaw from Edward P. Simpson, 39, accused of killing Henry G. Bell, a Newton policeman.
THERE is a most unworthy character in Mr. Lincoln's new Cape Cod story. He is so gay and dashing, so unlike the more stolid youths of the Cape, that innocent Emily is fascinated by him.

Regulations to enforce the recently enacted city ordinance against "bootlegging" stolen coal by motor truck from Pennsylvania were published yesterday by the Department of Public Markets, Weights and Measures.

Police Lieutenant Thomas Kelly of Chicago stated today that Leonard Doxey, arrested here for questioning, had been identified as one of two men who fled from Chicago's Grant Park after Herbert W. Lee was shot and killed there early Sunday.

ANOTHER shrine of American history has been added to the wayside ports of call along the tourist highway route. The Squire Boone farm, birthplace of Daniel Boone, the great pioneer woodsman,. is to be purchased by the State of Pennsylvania, and a hard macadam road will be built in from the main highway to give visitors access to the memorial.

WELL, it took Joe Madden to disprove the old saying that lightning never strikes twice in the same place. Last year, Vulcan-like, he shot a bolt that struck its public halfway between the sentiment and the risibles, and he called it "What'll You Have, Boys?"

Overcoming a battering that would have left most colts floundering, Sky Larking today captured the thirty-third Hopeful Stakes before 20,000 persons in a manner to stamp himself a thoroughbred of the top class. If he is not the champion of the year, then there is in concealment some phenomenon the horsemen have yet to sight.
Another chapter in the stormy story of Van Lingle Mungo's adventures with the Dodgers was started at noon yesterday when the 26-year-old fireball pitcher was suspended indefinitely without pay.
A young girl has scaled the towering mountain which Alexander Mackenzie, first white man to cross the North American continent north of Mexico, named "Stupendous" in 1793.
Mr. and Mrs. James Robertson McKay of Riverdale have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Jean McKay, to Kermit T. Simons, son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Simons of Wilmette, Ill.
Mrs. William Thompson Overton has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss-Virginia Mathilde Overton, to Frank Lee Wesson of Wilson, Ark., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Wesson of Springfield, Mass.
The work of rebuilding the West End Synagogue, 160 West Eightysecond Street, will be completed early this Fall, Harry N. Wessel, president of the congregation, reported to its members yesterday.
Developers of housing projects in scattered sections of New Jersey are speeding up plans for new homes to meet a late Summer and early Fall demand.

With the better fields, drying-under the first sun in almost a week, being saved for tomorrow's important test matches, some of the players preparing for the national polo championship saw action today on Phipps Field and the No. 4 field in the hollow at the Meadow Brook Club.
Two venerable gentlemen of the White Sox, Manager Jimmy Dykes and Pitcher Ted Lyons, teamed up today to give Chicago a 3-to-2 victory over the Senators.

Among the amendments to the registration statement of the Equity Corporation, declared effective on Aug, 23 by the Securities and Exchange Commission upon dismissal of hearings on the original statement, filed in February, 1934, is much descriptive matter relating to control of the company and various of its relationships and contracts in 1933 and 1934.
WHEN a book carries so varied a cargo as "Blow the Man Down" the best that a reviewer can expect to do is to peck here and there at the succulent grains with which the pages are freighted.

The World Investment Trust, Boston, of which George B. Henderson is president, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 467,070 shares of beneficial interest to be offered at the market through underwriters for an estimated gross return of $4,553,933 and 32,930 shares now outstanding, which, if reacquired, may also be sold at the market for an estimated gross return of $321,067.
J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, defended his office today against allegations of mismanagement in the operation of receiverships for closed banks in Atlantic City, N. J.

A great racing throng saw the Hopeful, richest event of the season, close the races here this afternoon and scores of luncheon parties preceded the races. Mrs. Dodge Sloane entertained at the Gideon Putnam for Mr. and Mrs. Alan L. Corey, Mr. and Mrs. Jackson A. Dyckman, Mrs. Potter Bourne, Milton W. Holden and Douglass W. Paige.
Lewis R. McGee, District Deputy Grand Master of Greene-Ulster Masonic District, prominent Catskill business and fraternal man, died at his home here yesterday after a brief illness. His age was 70.

The present discussion regarding "non-crushable" velvets is providing an unmistakable impetus in the dress industry to the trend toward "fabric content-consciousness," according to Morris Kolchin, executive director of the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc.

THE Capitol Theatre, which is currently having its face lifted (it hasn't had more than a facial in eighteen years), expects to be able to take the bandages off by Thursday in time to welcome "Broadway Melody of 1938" with a Broadway smile.

The Miller-Tydings act, which became a law because it was attached as a rider to an unrelated tax bill, is being variously characterized as "merchandising dynamite" which will cause an increase in retail prices,- or as a "simple enabling act" making effective legislation of the States against "predatory pricecutting."

Miss Emily North King, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Burruss King of this place, was married to Melville Church 2d, son of Melville D. Church of Washington, this afternoon in St. James Church by the Rev. Paul Delafield Bowden.

Despite all that has been said and written concerning the advantages of making a lawn in the early Autumn rather- than in the Spring, most lawns are still made in the Spring. Innumerable tests made at experiment stations have almost invariably shown the advantages of Fall planting. Apparently this Spring lawn building is just one of those fixed garden habits which. it takes a long time to change.

Regulations governing the taking of photographs of naval subjects recently issued by the Navy Department contain the most stringent peacetime restrictions of this nature ever issued in the United States.

Nankow Pass, where the Japanese have been battering at the Great Wall of China, is one of the most accessible parts of that barrier of brick and stone and earth which stretches for 1,500 niles across Northern China.

Miss Mary Ellen Sheffield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Owen Arthur Sheffield of this place, was married today to Arnold Tulp of Hackensack at St. Stephen's Church, Beverly, N. J., by the Rev. Hollis W. Colwell.

FOREIGN stations operating on the 15-megacycle band have been loud and clear during the past week. Among the stellar performers are: GSI, London, on 15,26; DJB, Berlin, 15.2, and a Russian station clearly heard around 8 P. M., in New York, on 15.30 megacycles.
Mrs. Weda Cook Addicks, friend of Walt Whitman, died yesterday in Presbyterian Hospital at the age of 79.
Charges of union members that they were beaten in and about this Northern Alabama industrial city since April 1 drew the attention of the National Labor Relations Board today.

Dr. Robert F. Hyland examined the ailing right arm of Dizzy Dean, Cardinal pitcher, today and reported he was suffering from bursitis of the right shoulder. The bursa is a saclike cavity. This is inflamed.
Counsel for the Weirton Steel Company threatened today to summon 7,500 witnesses to a Labor Board inquiry into the company's labor relations.

Regulations governing the taking of photographs of naval subjects recently issued by the Navy Department contain the most stringent peacetime restrictions of this nature ever issued in the United States.

Nankow Pass, where the Japanese have been battering at the Great Wall of China, is one of the most accessible parts of that barrier of brick and stone and earth which stretches for 1,500 niles across Northern China.

Miss Mary Ellen Sheffield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Owen Arthur Sheffield of this place, was married today to Arnold Tulp of Hackensack at St. Stephen's Church, Beverly, N. J., by the Rev. Hollis W. Colwell.

FOREIGN stations operating on the 15-megacycle band have been loud and clear during the past week. Among the stellar performers are: GSI, London, on 15,26; DJB, Berlin, 15.2, and a Russian station clearly heard around 8 P. M., in New York, on 15.30 megacycles.

Attorneys for almost all interested parties in the $400,000,000 Utilities Power and Light Corporation litigation asked the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today to set aside an order appointing a trustee for the company pending reorganization under Section 77b of. the amended Bankruptcy Act.

Andrew W. Mellon left his entire personal fortune, except $180,000, to his educational and charitable trust, his attorney, D. D. Shepard, disclosed tonight. The estate of the former Secretary of the Treasury has been estimated high into the millions.
FOREIGNERS, as they travel through France, frequently express amazement and amusement at the names which they encounter on French railroad stations.

PARIS. ONE of the finest European radio orchestras, that of Radio-Luxembourg, gave a concert in Paris under the direction of its conductor, Henri Pensis, in the Theatre Champs Elysees, where it was enthusiastically acclaimed by a large audience.
BECAUSE of the improved roads to Mexico, tourist figures are mounting in many towns throughout the country.

Members of the Fur Dressers and Fur Dyers Association, an affiliate of the Fur Dressers and Dyers Board of Trade, Inc., have bound themselves to rigid compliance with a uniform code of credit terms, which will become effective on Wednesday, it was announced yesterday by Lloyd Graff, president of the association and executive director of the board.

MORNING EVENTS Class 37, Model Hunters (Shown in Hand and Judged Standing. Amateur Owners)--First, Rolling Rock Farms' br. g. Rector; second, Rolling Rock Farms' b. g. Sensatin; third, Mrs. S. C. Register's gr. g. Brookhaven: fourth, Rolling Rock Farms' gr. g. Night Flight.

Dr. Hugo Lange, practicing physician in Brooklyn for forty-five years, died on Friday at his home, 245 Dean Street. He was 68 years old. A native of Germany, Dr. Lange received his medical training at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University and later returned to Germany for post-graduate work in Munich and Berlin. He was a member of the Kings County Medical Society and other medical organizations.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Helen Elizabeth Healy, daughter of Mrs. Helen R. Healy of this place and of Henry W. Healy of Larchmont, N. Y., to John Lawson Dumbrille, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglass Dumbrille of Beverly Hills. Calif.

Ernest Rohr, general manager of the Duplan Silk Corporation, announced today a wage increase its 6,000 employes. The minimum wage will be raised from $13 to $14 for a forty-hour week, with corresponding increases in all piecework, hourly and weekly rates, he said.

From the time George Peabody of Massachusetts set up the first great educational foundation in 1867, the Peabody Education Fund, which amounted finally to $3,000,000, large educational trusts established by wealthy men have supplemented and assisted established institutions of learning throughout the country and the world.

THE Summer of 1937 is likely to be remembered by the broad casters not so much for its "dog days" as for Shakespearean hours, the final one of which is scheduled for tomorrow night at 9 o'clock with WABC presenting "Twelfth Night."

TO come after long years upon old friends is to renew one's youth. And that is what this republishing of Margaret Deland's "Old Chester Days" will mean for many. First published nearly forty years ago, "Old Chester Days" enfolded a small galaxy of characters who can never quite die: Dr. Lavendar.

IT is always difficult to judge impartially a poem so ambitious as "Prelude to 'Icaros"' for the reason that such a work is so certainly in the mind of the author a major opus, or an installment of a major opus, and the author has lived with his idea so intimately and worked upon it with such affection, that to be less than enthusiastic is to be discouraging.
George F. Machlet, an inventor for many years associated with the American Gas Furnace Company here, died last night at his home following a long illness.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Gustave Jaretsky of 37 West Seventy-second Street of the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Muriel Jaret, to Edwin A. Elbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. August Elbert of New Rochelle, N. Y. The marriage will take place on-Friday afternoon at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 270 West Eighty-ninth Street.
Rigoletto, " Tonight Mmes. Lucrezia Sarria, Lillian Marchetto (debut). Gina Castro, and Messrs. Claudio Frigerio, Lawrence Power, Norman Roland gelini. Conductor, Fritz Mahler.

The Home Savings Bank of White Plains, Westchester County, announced yesterday that it would dispose of its real estate holdings totaling about 165 properties, taken under foreclosure proceedings during the past seven years.
Mrs. Weda Cook Addicks, friend of Walt Whitman, died yesterday in Presbyterian Hospital at the age of 79.
Charges of union members that they were beaten in and about this Northern Alabama industrial city since April 1 drew the attention of the National Labor Relations Board today.

Dr. Robert F. Hyland examined the ailing right arm of Dizzy Dean, Cardinal pitcher, today and reported he was suffering from bursitis of the right shoulder. The bursa is a saclike cavity. This is inflamed.
Counsel for the Weirton Steel Company threatened today to summon 7,500 witnesses to a Labor Board inquiry into the company's labor relations.

MORNING EVENTS Class 37, Model Hunters (Shown in Hand and Judged Standing. Amateur Owners)--First, Rolling Rock Farms' br. g. Rector; second, Rolling Rock Farms' b. g. Sensatin; third, Mrs. S. C. Register's gr. g. Brookhaven: fourth, Rolling Rock Farms' gr. g. Night Flight.

Dr. Hugo Lange, practicing physician in Brooklyn for forty-five years, died on Friday at his home, 245 Dean Street. He was 68 years old. A native of Germany, Dr. Lange received his medical training at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University and later returned to Germany for post-graduate work in Munich and Berlin. He was a member of the Kings County Medical Society and other medical organizations.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Helen Elizabeth Healy, daughter of Mrs. Helen R. Healy of this place and of Henry W. Healy of Larchmont, N. Y., to John Lawson Dumbrille, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglass Dumbrille of Beverly Hills. Calif.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Bruce Ashley of 600 West 114th Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Lane Ashley, to James Paul-O'Connell of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. O'Connell of Holyoke, Mass.
The surprising Phillies stretched their winning streak to five straight contests today, scoring a 9-to-6 victory over the Cardinals to sweep a four-game series.

RING that one on the calendar, Friday,. Aug. 27, 1937. That was quite a day. Sun, rain and sun, with brisk winds for good measure. Fred Frankhouse of the doleful Dodgers had only four more men to extinguish in a bail game and he would have pitched himself into no-hit fame. But at Ebbets Field even the weather has dizzy spells.

After a period during which construction activity reached a high level, apartment builders in the Bronx have tapered off their operations and are concentrating their attention on filling up vacancies in new and old houses.

TO preserve relies and memories of its early days, Barba dos, British West Indies, recently opened a museum in Bridgetown, the capital. Exhibits of unusual variety are already in place. For the convenience of visitors who want to get an idea of Barbados activities models of its principal industries have been set up-a cane sugar factory, a rum distillery, a cotton mill.

The Rev. Augustine E. Martell, assistant pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Michael, 424 West Thirty-fourth Street, died early yesterday morning in the French Hospital of a throat malady after an illness of a fortnight. He was born in this city twentyseven years ago.

"Good colonels are scarce," Sergeant Robert Urquhart said April 28, 1916, when asked, as he lay wounded, why he had thrown his commanding officer to the ground and protected him with his own body as a German shell burst during bitter fighting for a hill in the World War. Sergeant Urquhart died here last night.

Twenty-four parcels of Westchester County property, assessed at $295,375, were sold for $158,300 at public auction in the naval militia armory on Main Street today at the second session of an auction being conducted by the receivers of six Westchester national banks that remained closed after the 1933 bank holiday.
C. I. O. leaders of maritime labor threatened today to call sit-down strikes if necessary to prevent war implements from reaching China or Japan.

A week's discussion of "Public Opinion in a Democracy" was opened here today in Williams College at the Williamstown Institute of Human Relations, with an attendance of 750 men and women from thirty States.

The church is not interested in "modernizing" in the sense of conforming to world standards as long as these standards are so far below the standards of the church, the Rev. Dr. Joseph B. Bernardin, assistant rector at the All Angels Protestant Episcopal Church, Eighty-first Street and West End Avenue, said yesterday in his morning sermon.

The Fraternal Order of Beavers, concluding its eighteenth annual convention here today, adopted an amendment to the by-laws providing that "The Star-Spangled Banner" be sung at future meetings instead of "America."
The American track team touring Finland split its forces today and turned in victories in exhibitions in three different cities.

Foreign and Chinese Christians packed churches of all denominations in this war-wrecked city today. Bombs, bullets and shells have effected probably an unprecedented religious revival throughout Shanghai.

Dingle Foot, Member of Parliament for Dundee, decided tonight that he had been a little too determined to leave no trash behind him after he and Mrs. Foot had their picnic lunch at Wooston Castle, famous South Devon beauty spot.
Teaching in Russia must be one of the most hazardous professions in the world. Every concept transmitted to the pupils

Lack of confidence and mutual distrust among the nations of the world is caused primarily by the inability of men and women to seek the confidence of God in their problems, the Rev. Dr. Norman G. Dunning declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

Douglas C. Fonda, the Orange, N. J., banker who two seasons ago decided to adopt a new hobby and spend his week-ends from May to September driving speed boats on the racing circuit and who has been so phenomenally successful that he now is leading the country in point scoring for 1937, captured major honors on the. Thames today, the second day of the Connecticut Governor's regatta.

The Newark Bears hammered out nineteen hits, including four home runs, today and drubbed the Jersey City Giants, 9 to 0, behind the fivehit pitching of Vito Tamulis: The victory was Tamulis's ninth in a row and his seventeenth of the season against six setbacks.

Weather permitting, F. William Zeloer, vice president of the Seversky Airraft Corporation, will take off from Floyd Bennett Field In Brooklyn at 6 A. M. today in an attempt to break the East-West transcontinental record.

Mexico has accelerated development of the largest artificial lake of its kind on earth in a move to control the flow of the Nazas River, "The American Nile," and, coincidentally, to assure the success of government supervised cooperative farms in this vast La Laguna district, where more cotton is grown per acre in good years than anywhere else in the world.
Great Britain demanded today the "fullest measure of redress" from Japan for the wounding of Sir Hughe Montgomery Knatchbull-Hugessen, the British Ambassador to China, by Japanese airplanes Thursday.

Henry Graves, formerly identified with large cement interests, has made an outright gift to Girl Scouts in the Oranges and Maplewood of an improved twenty-acre island in the upper part of Saranac Lake in the Adirondacks, it was disclosed today by Girl Scout leaders here. Estimates on the value of the gift range from $100,000 to $1,000,000.

Dr. William Lyon Phelps, professor emeritus of Yale University, named his "Books of the Year" here today, his own selection of the books he most enjoyed in the last twelve months and that he considers best worth reading.

Reports from virtually all industrial centres indicate a favorable outlook for Autumn trade. There has been the usual slowing down this month on account of the holidays, but order books, according to reports, are full in many trades for a long way ahead.
T. O. M. Sopwith defeated the other America's Cup yacht skippers today for the first time and, strange as it may seem, Harold S. Vanderbilt came in last. In fact it not only happened once, but twice.

Measures passed in the last ten months under pressure from groups of city employes will add $34,400,000 a year to the municipal payroll, with another increase of $29,075,000 threatened if pending legislation is enacted, Richard C. Patterson Jr., chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, declared yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Constance Lodge, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. James Thornton Lodge of this place, to John Stanley Dey, son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Dey of Newark, will take place Sept. 10 at St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church, of which the bride-elect's father in the rector. The Rev. Mr.

The Good Neighbor League announced yesterday the appointment of a national committee, representing Democrats and Republicans in twenty-six States, to sponsor the Good Neighbor League dinners on Sept. 17-in celebration of the sesquicentennial of the signing of the Constitution.

State Senator Lester H. Clee's Gubernatrial candidacy will be endorsed by Labor's Nonpartisan League of New Jersey if Senator Clee will publicly commit himself to a program of labor and social legislation, it was decided here today at the league's Statewide convention, attended by 119 representatives of fifty-five labor unions.

An appeal to 255,000 employes for whom employers are making contributions to the State Unemployment Insurance Fund, but who have failed to obtain Social Security account numbers, to get such numbers without delay was issued yesterday by the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Department of Labor.

For the first time since it arrived at Governors Island in 1921 for permanent station the Sixteenth United States Infantry, First Division, will withdraw its full strength from the Governors Island garrison this week, when the regiment, under command of Colonel Karl Truesdell, will depart for manoeuvres at Indiantown Gap, Pa.

Clifford M. Grover and Norman B. Smith sailed the Teaser to vietory today in the season's final test of the Sunday championship series of the Barnegat Bay fleet to annex the Grover Trophy for International Star Class yachts. The Teaser defeated Charles E. Lucke Jr.'s Nick Nack by six seconds.
The militant declaration that China would fight to the finish against enslavement by Japan-"a foe which owes its civilization to China"-came today from Mme. O. K. Yul, wife of the Mayor of Shanghai.

Mr. and Mrs. Timothee Adamowskl of Boston entertained with a buffet supper at the Bar Harbor Club this evening. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. William McNair, Mr. and Mrs. Lester Ledyard Heckscher, Mr. and Mrs. E. T. Stotesbury, Mr. and Mrs. A. Atwater Kent, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bell Sweeney, Mr. and Mrs. F. Hamilton McCormick-Goodhart, Mrs. H. Howard Ellison, Mrs. John T. Dorrance, Mr. and Mrs. John Hampton Barnes and Clarence Stetson.

Preparing for their important matches with the Evergreen Farms and Monmouth County quartets, respectively, next week in the Eastern Polo League, the Knights and Esquires battled to a 5-all tie today in a contest between mermber teams of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club.
Because several of last week's performances were canceled by rain, "Anything Goes" will be continued this week at Randall's Island Stadium, concluding its run next Monday night (Labor Day).

A 14-year-old boy and his 7-yearold sister were being held in children's shelters, in Westchester County yesterday as police and officials of the county Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children investigated the manner in which they became separated from their parents in White Plains Saturday night.

The Federal Music Project presented the first of a series of four concerts devoted to compositions of Tchaikovsky last night at the Theatre of Music. Those who conform to the fashionable snobbism regarding the Russian master would have found themselves in uncomfortable company. Both in size and enthusiasm, this was an unusual audience.

Near Madison Avenue, on an upper East Side street, is a little restaurant of the type that is almost as characteristic of New York as the neighborhood bistro of the Faubourg St. Germain or the Rond Point is of Paris.
Enterprising fruit growers of this community are answering a common complaint against peaches by "Shaving" the heavy fuzz off the fruit.

Harry D. Neach, founder and former owner of The Nassau Bulletin, who is reputed to have campaigned with Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1910 when the President was running for the State Senate, died today in the Belmore Nursing Home at Belmore from the effects of a paralytic stroke suffered a year and a half ago. He was 55 years old. His widow. Isabel Neach, survives.

Ever since the Boston tea party there has been an active rivalrysometimes good-natured, sometimes not-between Britain and the United States. Each claimed to have the better golfers, swimmers, yachtsmen or tennis players, and the numerous trophies awarded to the winners have shuttled back and forth across the Atlantic.

Determination to accomplish in any field combined with spiritual influence will leave a shrine after we are gone that will outlast the years, said the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie, rector of the Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

Arrowbrook (70)--Semi-final round. Governors' Trophy: H. Smallberg defeated P. Scharf, 1 up (36-hole match); R. Stevenson defeated H. Parker, 4 and 2. Bayside (71)--Quarter-final round for Lanzner Trophy: J. Schief defeated C. Beck, 5 and 4; Dr. C. Cohen defeated R. Solomon, 2 up; V. Celano, defeated H. Holtz, 1 up (20 holes).

Minister of Finance Georges Bonnet tonight announced that the 10 per cent deduction in interest on State securities, introduced by former Finance Minister Pierre Laval, would be suppressed on Sept. 1.

Robert G. Wetmore, in 21 Claremont Ave; Willard Waller, in 29 Claremont Ave; F. Ernest Johnson, in 35 Claremont Ave; Frederick V. Vogell Jr., in 460 Riverside Dr; Elizabeth H. Prince, Emma E. Kaiser, Allen H. Minor, Hattie E. Alexander, Henrietta Ward, Dr. Charles A. Ragan, in 70 Haven Ave: William James Blech,

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, predicted his overwhelming victory over Senator Royal S. Copeland, his Tammany opponent, at an outing of the Yorkville Magyar Democratic Club yesterday at Hoffman Park, Havemeyer and Havlland Avenues, the Bronx.

The Bankers Magazine's index of 365 representative securities, based on December, 1921, as 100, was 125 on Aug. 20, compared with 125.1 the month before, 131 a year ago, the high record of 133.9 last October and the low of 98.5 in December, 1931.

Liquidation was under way in the lard market here last week, with all deliveries selling at new low levels for the season. The pressure was mainly the result of a further decline in cottonseed oil and in hogs, the latter declining as rapidly as they had advanced previously.
Funeral services for Wilbert Lewis Smith, chairman of the board of L. C. Smith and Corona Typewriters, Inc., who died last night, will be held at his home here Tuesday afternoon. The Rev. Franklin P.

Cotton futures declined last week 22 to 30 points on the New York Cotton Exchange, following losses of 59 to 71 points the week before, touching new low levels since the late months of 1933, and prices ruled below the 10-cent level throughout the period for all positions except the July, 1938, and, on one day, for May deliveries.

Cloaking his purpose with irony, that veteran Kansas City Democrat, Representative Wilson Shannon, has assaulted the greatest deliberative assembly in the world. He chides Congress for its inconsistency in seeking, not too hard as yet, to regulate wages and hours while it permits gross differences in the pay of some of its employes.

Four Americanbuilt airplanes, interned since April at a private airdrome near Versailles, were damaged by fire early today. The police seized time bombs that started the flames. These had been made with vacuum bottles and an inflammable liquid.
When Oliver Wendell Holmes was asked how hay fever could be cured he replied, "Gravel is an effectual remedy; it should be taken eight feet deep."

Kendall Chase, young Washington southpaw, outpitched Bob Feller to give the Senators a 6-to-2 victory in the second game of a doubleheader today, after Johnny Allen had defeated the visitors, 11 to 4, in the first.

Now that the drama of death and destruction in the immediate vicinity of Shanghai is lessening somewhat, although bombs and shells continue to fall in various parts of the city with ghastly effect, attention is being turned elsewhere in China to seek manifestations of the Japanese objectives.

The trend on the Stock Exchange here was much improved this week, especially among the renters, which registered increasing gains except yesterday, when the tendency was easier, following Wall Street's decline of the previous day. Chinese events also had an adverse effect.

Antonio Rivera Cordova, 19-year-old Nationalist from whom the police obtained information that led to the arrest of ten men who allegedly attempted to assassinate United States Judge Robert A. Cooper, committed suicide last night, twenty-four hours after being released from jail on bond.
Leaders in Republican State politics will attend private funeral services here tomorrow for Assemblyman Pritchard H. Strong and Mrs. Strong, victims of an air tragedy near Albany airport last Friday.
Christianity is losing its vitality, Dr. Herrick B. Young warned yesterday before the congregation of the Fort George Presbyterian Church, St. Nicholas Avenue and West 186th Street.

Sooner or later Johnny Goodman just had to win the United States amateur championship. Ever since Bobby Jones retired in 1930 after completing his "grand slam," the Nebraskan has been looked upon as our No. 1 amateur golfer, but it has taken him seven long years to break through.

The recently announced plans of the Progressive Education Association to foster, through a series of ten textbooks, a "higher morality" for the "turbulent younger generation" were criticized yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Andrew R. Osborn in his sermon at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

Miss Shirley Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Miller of Brooklyn, was married to Herbert Marks, son of Mrs. William Marks of Jamaica, Queens, yesterday afternoon on the Hotel St. George Roof by the Rev. Joseph H. Paymer.

The Dodgers may be hanging on the ropes nearly every time they square off against six other National League clubs, but when they meet the Pirates they seem to puff out their chests and say: "There's one guy I can lick!"

More than 10,000 Germans living in all parts of the world outside the Fatherland gathered here today for the opening of the fifth Congress of Germans Abroad. The rally was on a scale never attempted before, with high Government and party officials making keynote speeches.
The St. Louis San Francisco Railway Company reported today that total operating revenues for July were 4,869,079, an increase of $411,900 from the same month last year.

Historic Trinity Church this afternoon was filled almost to capacity with members of the Summer colony and others who attended the funeral services of John Russell Pope, distinguished American architect, who died in New York on Friday evening.

Justice, peace and a respect for every human personality must be the guiding principles for the church in dealing with such current issues as the crisis in the Far East, the church in Germany, municipal politics and industrial disputes, the Rev. Leland B. Henry,

Headed by the $2,500 added Woodmere Claiming Stakes, for which a capacity field of fourteen is named, the fifteen-day Fall meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club will begin today at Aqueduct. Seven races make up the inaugural program, with post time at 2:30 P. M.

That State public utility commissions are such an important factor in public-utility operations that they would be necessary even if all utilities were Government owned and controlled is contended by Professor C. O.

With Toscanini's Brahms concerto this morning, this year's Salzburg Festival reached its virtual close. The actual end comes Tuesday night with a final repetition of "The Magic Flute"-tomorrow evening being devoted to a last "Figaro."

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amounted to $4,819,293,400. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

" MUSEUM,". (Morrow, $2,50), by James L. Phelan, will leave any reader a little scared Not only sensitive readers. Any reader who is not hopelessly smug. But if a book Can be, this one is worth its weight of depression. In outline the book follows a pattern that has become moderately familiar.

The Rev. Joseph A. Tytheridge, preaching yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral, admonished Catholics not to be ashamed of miracles. "Miracles are not workings of the imagination," he said. "They are not pretty pictures presented so we might be entertained for a short time. They are facts. And we,
ANDERSON-Mary Eva, beloved wife of Frank E., and mother of Josephine. Services at Stolzenberger Chapel, 450 East 162d St., Monday Aug. 30, at P. M. Interment Lutheran Cemetery.
Carrying the colors of the Sixth Regiment, decorated by France in the World War, 1,308 marines left here today on the transport Chaumont and the light cruiser Marblehead for Shanghai.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 83.3 on Aug. 25, compared with 84.2 a fortnight before, 84.7 a month previously and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

The Eighty-seventh Brigade of the State Guard, now encamped here at Camp Smith, is made up of two infantry regiments, but virtually only one unit, the Seventy-first of Manhatan, commanded by Colonel that George F. Terry, is within the confines of the reservation today.

Miss Dorothea Loebmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter T. Loebmann of this place, was married here this afternoon in the chancel of the Cathedral of the Incarnation to William Howard Gengarelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Gengarelly of Glen Cove.

Health Department officials, busy yesterday attempting to locate New Yorkers who were passengers on the Hamburg-American liner Hansa, which put into New York City Saturday with twenty-four unreported cases of typhoid fever among the crew,

The 'Globe and Mail today says that threats to kidnap Premier Mitchell Hepburn's two adopted children and "to get him" also are being investigated by Ontario provincial police while special constables guard the Premier's home near St. Thomas.
Thousands of grief-stricken Chinese spent today searching smoldering ruins around the South Station in Nantao for loved ones, dead or missing in Saturday's devastating Japanese air raid.

WTHILE waiting for T. Farr of Tonypandy, Wales, and J. Louis Barrow of Detroit and Chicago to come up for their delayed debate at the Yankee Stadium, there popped into mind the thought that there may be the making of a good labor argument in the ring this evening, weather permitting.

The suggestion of a reunited church, "which ten years ago was whispered with misgiving and suspicion," became in the Edinburgh Conference on Faith and Order this year "an object of definite hope and confident expectation," the Most Rev. James De Wolf Perry, Bishop of Rhode Island and presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States, said yesterday on his return from the Oxford and Edinburgh conferences.

One hundred and nineteen offices in extra-curricular activities at Princeton University will be filled by ninety-five undergraduates during the college year 1937-38, which will open Sept. 28, it was announced today by Professor Christian Gauss, dean of the college.

Lucy Monroe, soprano of the Metropolitan and St. Louis Opera Associations and also of radio, sang here this afternoon in the Chase Barn Theatre, where the August high tide of motor tourists drew a large audience to hear her.

The Philadelphia Athletics set two American League records as they walloped the White Sox, 16 to 0, in the first game of a double bill today, but they couldn't hold that slugging pace and lost the nightcap, 5 to 3.

The gold stocks of the Bank of the Netherlands have been unchanged in the last few weeks, but money is increasingly abundant, private banks and other big money lenders and the Treasury showing overliquidity, so that money rates have fallen to fractions of 1 per cent.

The Government may announce tomorrow the terms of its program for stabilizing prices of this year's bumper cotton crop. For two reasons farm belt Congressman awaited the announcement with intense interest:

Wheat and fodder cereals are in great demand in the market here. Grain traders here are inclined to expect a further slight weakening in wheat, and in this connection, emphasis is put on the estimate that the world demand for the new crops this year will be 100,000,000 bushels below last year's.

The usual seasonal slackening in apparel purchasing, noted last week in the New York wholesale market, was welcomed by resident offices as giving manufacturers an opportunity of catching up on deliveries, Which are unusually slow in the majority of lines due to producers' reluctance to cut ahead before consumer preferences have been established.

President Roosevelt announced today that he had given a pocket veto to a bill authorizing appropriation of $294,852.97 now in the Treasury to various veterans' organizations for aiding unemployed or destitute veterans of the World War and their dependents.
In their argument last week for higher wages, the five railroad brotherhoods did not very seriously argue that their present wages were inadequate for decent living standards.

The touting United States track team defeated Japan, 94 to 84, in a two-day meet concluded today at the Meiji Shrine Stadium as Irving Folwartshny, burly weight tosser from Rhode Island State College, set a new Japanese international record in the hammer throw.
David S. Polland, New York State champion, suffered his first defeat in the American Chess Federation's championship finals tonight when he lost to W. W. Griegorieff of Chicago in forty-two moves.

A conviction that no institution comparable to the Christian Church to educate people for the great issues of the world today was brought out of the Oxford Conference by the Rev. Dr. Ralph Diffendorfer,
One transatlantic flying boat landed here today, another is due tomorrow, while a third is scheduled to take off for Germany via the Azores.
Four new appointees to the Fordham Graduate School were named yesterday. They are Dr. Anton C. Pegis, the Rev. Rudolph Arbesmann, Dr. Quinn McNemar and Andrew J. Torrielli.

A program of educational publicity in the home building field in an effort further to stimulate the sale of bituminous coal and of automatic coal-burning equipment in the domestic fuel market, has been undertaken by the National Coal Association, J. P. Williams Jr., president of the Association, announced yesterday.
John Hay (Jock) Whitney's Greentree quartet galloped to an 8-6 triumph over Aurora on Bostwick Field in one of two high-goal test polo matches played in this vicinity today..
In recent weeks a somewhat more skeptical view has developed concerning Autumn recovery in Europe and America; owing principally to many outside factors influencing the business cycle. These include,

Expressing unwavering loyalty to and devotion for Pope Pius XI, the twoday convention of the Catholic Central Verein of America, New Jersey branch, came to a close here tonight in Holy Trinity School.

The Boerse opened the week with prices somewhat lower, the main interest being confined to machinery and armament issues. Deutsche Waffen advanced 7 points but reacted later, and private rail shares were strong.

The Most Rev. Michael J. Curley, Archbishop of Baltimore, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star motorship Georgic from his annual visit to Ireland. He was accompanied by his secretary, Mgr. John Lyons.

The New York and Metropolitan. District Cricket Association match at the Stevens Institute grounds today resulted in a decisive victory for the Brooklyn C. C. Brooklyn declared its innings closed for 176, with only two wickets down. Veteran St. George was all out with 49.

How TO LOSE FRIENTDS AND ALIENATE PEOPLE, by Irving Tressler. (Stackpole, $1.49.) On how to bore a bore and similar advice. RUSE TO THE SUN, by William Brown Meloney. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50.) A first novel.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated' here at 84 per cent of capacity, up 1 point in a week but down 1 point in a fortnight. Fluctuations have been insignificant since about the middle of July, when recovery from the restriction due to strikes was virtually complete.

Toyotaro Yuki, governor of the Bank of Japan, conferred with Premier Fumimaro Konoe today and afterward told the press that he had informed the Premier he was optimistic regarding Japan's ability to provide for military expenditures over a long period. Mr.
No decision has been reached by the French Cabinet on a plan of coordination for the French railroads in a national company. Meanwhile,

Miss Ruth Leona Stern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Stern of 714 West 181st Street, was married to Harry Rubin of this city, son of Mrs. Anne Brussels Rubin of Wallingford, Conn., last night at the Hotel Astor by the Rev. Jerome M. Lawn of Temple Beth Sholom, Washington Heights.

Personal pride and an intricate economic life prevent the full measure of gratitude due God from man, the Right Rev. Dr. Stephen E. Keeler, Bishop Coadjutor of Minnesota, declared yesterday morning at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at Fiftythird Street.

In a match that was fought out to the last hole, Paul Cavanagh of South Bay and Bob McCollom of Timber Point defeated Carl Timpson and H. S. Sturgis of the Rockaway Hunt Club, 1 up, today to capture the third annual invitation fourball tourney at the Seawane Club.

The index of Germany's wholesale prices on Aug. 18 stood at 106.7, against 106.9 on Aug. 11. In the first seven months of 1937 Germany's wholesale price index, based on the average of 1913 as 100, ranged between 106.5 on July 21 and 105.2 in the first week of January.

Bronxdale Ave (15-4046), w s, 25 ft s of Morris Park Ave, 50x107; Jacob Rosenblatt to Philip F. Farley, 7 Acorn Lane, Larchmont, N. Y. 3d Ave, 2,997 (9-2376); Margaret Troy to T. A. Holding Corp. 3,120 3d Ave.

A report declaring that Jews in Poland are living in a "poisoned atmosphere," with tremendous forces aligned against them, was made public yesterday by the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee.

Although refusing to state definitely his opinion of the probable conclusion of the Sino-Japanese hostilities in North China, General Kiyoshi Katsuki, commander of the Japanese Army in the north, today dedared that the Japanese Army would continue removing Chinese forces as long as they evidenced any anti-Japanese sentiment or instigated any anti-Japanese movements.

A teletype alarm asking the police in the vicinity of Harrisburg, Lancaster and York, Pa., to notify Leon Neckritz of New York that his wove father, Jacob Neckritz, had died of a heart attack at their home, 1,305 Seventy-fifth Street,-Brooklyn, was sent out at 1:05 P. M. yesterday from Police Headquarters.

When the demand for money increases, it is usual for rates to rise and not to fall and the monetary policy which led to the decision to reduce the New York bank rate to 1 per cent monthly not only makes history, but appears here to be entirely unorthodox.

Flanked by a most extraordinarily enthusiastic capacity crowd of 40,750, Mickey Cochrane's fighting Tigers made another noble effort today to continue the illusion that battling the Yankees still carries with it an important bearing upon the outcome of this year's American League pennant race. e pennant race.

Charles Zimmy, 45-year-old legless swimmer, churned with powerful overhand strokes toward the 125th Street ferry landing on the Hudson River at 10 o'clock last night, and then was carried a mile below his goal by a strong tide.

Louis Waldman, attorney for the Joint Council of Drivers and Sweepers of the Department of Sanitation, speaking yesterday at the annual carnival and field day of the department employes, Challenged Dr. Royal S. Copeland and Jeremiah T. Mahoney, candidates for Mayor, to make clear their positions on such questions as collective bargaining .and wage increases.

Miss Margaret Ferguson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ferguson of Upper Montclair, has completed plans for her wedding to F. Arthur Mayes, son of F. W. Mayes of Montclair. The ceremony will take place Oct. 9 in Union Congregational Church. The Rev.
Frankie Parker of New York scored a smashing victory over Arthur Hendrix of Lakeland,

When the preliminary Dewar course small-bore match was finished late today, it required several hours of work in the statistical office before the winners were determined. Dave Bashline of Akron, Ohio, went to the top with a total of 798 out of a possible 800. He outranked Sam Moore of Orange, N. J., also with 798.

Success cannot be measured in terms of money, fame or pre-eminence, the Rev. Dr. James Gordon Gilkey, pastor of South Congregational Church, Springfield, Mass., said in a sermon yesterday at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

The number of persons employed in German industry in July was 10.2 per cent more than in the same month of 1936, but compared with June, there was a decline in the number of hours worked. Industrial employment for the first time exceeds 7,000,000.

The world heavyweight championship battle between Joe Louis, Detroit Brown Bomber who holds the title, and Tommy Farr, British Empire crown-wearer, will be held tonight at the Yankee Stadium, providing inclement weather does not again upset plans as it did when the bout was scheduled for last Thursday night.
A canoe carrying two young men and two women went over a six-foot dam on the Ramapo River here this afternoon and were trapped for several minutes in a whirlpool at the bottom of the barrier.

Postmaster General Farley, speaking today at an outing of State Democrats at Rocky Point, a Narragansett Bay resort, declared that President Roosevelt would carry on unswervingly to complete his program and win full victory over "anti-social forces."
Miss Lilla Price Renshaw, daughter of Mrs. Joseph G. Coleman Jr. of Montecito, will be married on Saturday to Phelps Stokes Hunter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hunter of Montecito and New York.

Mrs. Edward Van Ingen gave a luncheon today at the Maples for Mrs. Eugene Gifford Grace of Bethlehem, Pa., who has joined her for a visit. Among the other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue Livingston, Mr. and Mrs. Fulton Cutting, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Wright, Mr. and Mrs. Allan Appleton Robbins, Mr. and Mrs. T. Morrison Carnegie, J. Frederic Byers and Monroe D. Robinson.

WPA checks ranging from $60.50 1 to $103.40 a month are the chief support of 2,984 families of ten or more members, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, disclosed yesterday. One worker in the lowest classification of the security wage scale has twety-eight dependents, according to the WPA head.
The Manufacturers Trust Company is transfer agent, registrar and dividend-disbursing agent for 40,000 shares of capital stock of the Importers and Exporters Insurance Company.

The official opening yesterday of Faithful Mary's new mission failed to come up to expectations. The former archangel of Father Divine, now on her own, had anticipated a crowd of two or three thousand, but only a hundred or so drifted in through the day. through the day.

After bitter clashes between factions had jeopardized the harmony which the Committee for Industrial Organization had arranged at the United Automobile Workers Union convention, final and desperate efforts to reunite the gathering succeeded late tonight and the convention closed.

In an open letter to Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, Luigi Criscuolo urges that "the small and efficient Stock Exchange firm that can operate on a small overhead should not be penalized because houses with large overhead want higher commissions."

Through "persistent and continuous effort," the employers of New York State were able to obtain simplifications of procedure in connection with the administration of the Federal and State social security programs,

In a report which commended the judgment of Stephen Dunn, pilot of the Pan American-Grace airplane which crashed on Aug. 2 near Cristobal, C. Z., with a loss of fourteen lives, the official Board of Inquiry reported to Secretary of Commerce Roper that a faulty gasoline system in the plane was the probable cause of the disaster, it was announced today.

Struck by the automobile of a hifand-run driver, who escaped despite a chase in which three shots were fired by a policeman, Vincent Marino, 25 years old, of 327 East 112th Street, was killed about 10:45 o'clock last night at East River Drive and 111th Street.

One significant item in the budget of over-the-week-end news ought not to be permitted to pass by without receiving the attention it deserves. This is the adoption by the United Automobile Workers, in convention at Milwaukee, of a resolution asserting "the policy of the sit-down strike as a weapon in labor struggle."

God has a plan for us, to be folowed intelligently, the Rev. Dr. W. Graham Scroggie of Edinburgh, Scotland, declared in his sermon yesterday at the First Baptist Church, Broadway at Seventy-ninth Street.

This week's unfavorable turn given to the situation in China by the shooting of the British Ambassador cast another shadow over the financial markets here. Nevertheless, investors and traders are displaying commendable calm.

Gabriel Max Filler and his wife, Henrietta, both 78 years old, celebrated their sixtieth wedding anniversary yesterday afternoon at a dinner and reception' in Lou G. Siegel's reastaurant, 209 West Thirtyeighth Street, Manhattan.
Stock Exchange Stocks sharply lower; turnover, 3,750,550 shares . Domestic bonds down; foreign issues higher, with Japanese issues recovered; transactions, $35,678,475.

Postage stamps caused an international incident here today when Spanish Insurgents protested because letters bearing stamps of the Franco Government were marked "postage due" and the postage collected before delivery.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Temple Emmet Rand of this city yesterday at the New York Hospital. Mrs. Rand is the former Miss Margaret Astor Chanler Aldrich, daughter of Mrs. Richard Aldrich of 317 West Seventyfourth Street and the late Mr. Aldrich, who was music critic emeritus of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Commerce through the Los Angeles harbor reached $860,957,975 in value and 18,610,713 tons-in volume in the fiscal year 1936-37 despite the 100day marine strike, it was announced today in the annual report at Arthur Eldridge port manager.

An effort to settle the strike of 15,000 painters, begun last week by the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, District Council 9, will be made today as a result of intervention by the Federal Government. Representatives of the union will meet with officials of the Association of Master Painters and Decorators at 2 Park Avenue.

An 18-year-old Philadelphia youth, captured as a burglary suspect in the Bronx, was booked last night after all-day questioning as the slayer of Spero Zanaki, 42, an unemployed sailor, who was wounded fatally shortly after 8 A. M. yesterday in the rooming house at 434 West Twenty-third Street.

The Ad. miralty today called for a full report on an attack on the British freighter Braimhill yesterday off the northern coast of Spain. Early reports said Insurgent trawlers made the attack. The commander of the British destroyer Fearless, which went to the Bramhill's aid, stated the freighter, en route from Brest to Gijon, was sighted by the trawlers near Gijon, a government port.

Le Coyote, a 99-to-10 shot, owned by H. Randon, won the 20,000-franc (about $750) Prix de Senlis at Chantilly today. Le Coyote finished threefourths of a length ahead of Jean Couturie's Rinaldi, with Fairness, from the stable of Eduardo Martinez de Hoz, third in the 2,400meter race.

The Japanese Government will be aware of the injuries sustained by Sir Hughe Montgomery Knatchbull-Hugessen, His Majesty's Ambassador to China, as the result of shooting from Japanese military airplanes when motoring with members of his staff frond Nanking to Shanghai on Aug. 26 last.

Frederic F. Van de Water has expanded his story of Rudyard Kipling's quarrel with his brother-Inlaw, Beatty Balestier, to book length, and the Countryman Press of Vermont will issue the expanded account in October in an edition limited to 700 copies, illustrated by Bernadine Custer and signed by author and artist..

Miss Barbara Judkins of Boston, daughter of Mrs. C. O. Judkins and the late Rev. Dr. Judkins, will be married to Stephen H. Gow of Buffalo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Gow of this city, on Saturday.

Van Lingle Mungo, suspended pitching ace of the Dodgers, failed to appear at Ebbets Field yesterday, nor was there any word from him about his announced intention to take his case to Commissioner Landis.

Theodore Jannard, 45-year-old chauf feur, drowned this afternoon in an attempt to swim ashore after his outboard motor boat had been swamped by a wave 500 feet off Bayville Beach. Two boys, Robert Audrey, 11, and Robert Cotti, 9, of this village, who were Jannard's guests on the boat ride, reached shore safely.
Hundreds of Chinese noncombatants were killed today as Japan's great air bombers struck savagely at Shanghai, Nanking and Nanchang, far in the interior.

With the primary election on Sert. 16 only two and a half weeks away, the results of the contests between Senator Royal S. Copeland, Tammany's candidate, and Jeremiah T. Mahoney for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, and between Senator Copeland and Mayor La Guardia for the Republican nomination seem to be uncertain.

The general French wholesale price index on Aug. 21 stood at 586, against 581 on Aug. 14. Native products were 592, against 584; imported products, 583, against 585; foodstuffs, 557against 546; industrial materials, 610, against 611.

The New York Hippodrome Opera Company last night brought to a close its Verdi Festival with the presentation of "Rigoletto." Five thousand attended an offering whose only new element was the debut of Lillian Marchetto in the role of. Maddalena. For the rest,

Denials of un-American activities were mixed freely with swastika waving, heiling and Hitler praising today as 25,000 or more members and friends of the controversial German-American Bund celebrated "German Day of Long Island" at Camp Siegfried.

RepBrts that the National Socialist party congreas opening at Nuremberg Sept. 6 will devote a considerable part of its deliberations to discussion of the church situation apparently leaves both Protestant and Catholic opposition undaunted. Utterances by spokesmen for both faiths in various parts of the Reich today again left no doubt as to their intranslgence.

In the Gospel, God has given man all that is necessary for salvation, the Rev. Walton H. Greever, secretary of the United Lutheran Church in America, declared yesterday morning at the Lutheran Church of St. James, Madison Avenue at Seventy-third Street.
Threatening skies cut the crowds at the major beaches yesterday although the temperature was high enough to make a plunge in the surf agreeable.

German steel output in July amounted to 1,656,600 tons, and in the first seven months of 1937 to 11,202,900, against 11,035,590 in the same period in 1936. Because of the shortage in pig iron, imports have been resumed on a considerable scale.

The Cubs dropped out of first place for the first time since July 15 for a few hours today, but hopped right baek into the drivers seat when they divided a double-header with the Phillies, losing the first, 10 to 3, and grabbing the nightcap, 2 to1, before 15,000 fans at Baker Bowl.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. Sutphen gave a dinner tonight at the Maidstone Club for their week-end guests, Admiral William H. Standley, U. S. N., retired, and Mrs. Standley, Admiral Harold Bowen, U. S. N., and Mrs. Bowen and Miss Elizabeth Peet.

The gold and blue flag of Sweden fluttered over the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today and just below it was the pale blue and white of Finland. They were high on the yard arm because in the second race of the series for the Scandinavian Gold Cup the representatives of these two nations sailed to a wide lead over the yachts of the United States and Norway.

Mrs. Elsie Nollen, 30 years old, and her six children were found dead in their home from deadly exhaust gas from the family automobile early today. A fifteen-page suicide note, in which Mrs. Nollen told of marital trouble and "grief," was found in the home, situated fifteen miles west of Denison.

The American Federition of Labor has gained more than 1,000,000 new members in the last' year and a half since the 900,000 broke away to follow John L. Lewis into the C. I.-O. This was announced today by William Green, president of the federation. The executive council is holding its annual session in the Hotel Ambassador here. There was no regular meeting today.

Manuel Perez, 19, bespectacled pitcher for Long Beach, Calif., has accomplished twice in eleven weeks what every hurler dreams of-a nohit, no-run game. With the Palestine Pals of the East Texas League,
Old Westbury remained undefeated in the test matches for the national polo championship teams today, conquering the San Jose riders of Argentina at the Sands Point Club, 11 to 7.

The Spanish Embassy announced here today that the Hanover Sales Corporation has been appointed exclusive purchasing agent in this country for the Spanish Government. The announcement said that "this procedure will lead to a more effective use of its substantial purchasing power and facilitate direct business dealings with American manufacturers."

The Bethpage Polo Club avenged a previous setback by the South Shore quartet by conquering the Cedarhurst players, 14-8, today in a Long Island League contest. The winners overcame their rivals' twogoal handicap early in the contest and then proceeded to make a rout of it. Each member of the home squad scored at least three times.

The engagement of Miss Mollie Porter Cullum, daughter of Mrs. James Barlow Cullum of Riveredge Farms, Reading, and Pittsburgh, and the late Mr. Cullum, to Charles Freeman Shelden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles N. Shelden of 300 Park Avenue, New York, has been announced by her mother.

Julian W. Curtiss of Oak Farm Greenwich, chairman of the board of A. G. Spalding Bros. of New York, and a prominent figure in the field of sports, observed his seventy-ninth birthday today. He enjoyed a round of golf in the morning, and members of his family attended a dinner in his honor at his home this evening.
The Chinese Government announced today the conclusion of a non-aggression pact with the Soviet Union. The pact does not bind Russia to come to China's aid against Japanese aggression.

Advertising plans of retail shoe stores here for the Fall season have been somewhat upset by the possibility that prices may have to be reduced, according to comment here yesterday. Originally, stores had planned rather extensive newspaper drives to prevent any buying letdown as the result of higher prices, but the action of one chain in restoring the price of its women's styles to last Spring's level has upset the trade.

The Sino-Soviet non-aggression pact is received by the Japanese with the shock of a diplomatic defeat in the midst of military Victories. The pact is held to align China with the "have" powers-France, Russia, Britain and the United States-leaving Japan tied with the "have notes" through the German-Japanese "anti-Communist" agreement,

Portuguese infantry is being armed with a new-model Mauser rifle imported from Germany. The first consignment of the new weapons, costing [pound]700,000, has arrived from Germany and was being distributed today to Lisbon regiments.

Miss Dorothy Madeliene Lamb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Walter Lamb of this city, will be married on Sept. 7 to Raymond Cornelius Strassburger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter F. Strassburger of Butler, N. J., formerly of New York.
This city was in the hands of the Veterans of Foreign Wars tonight as the veterans, their wives and sons "marched in" for the beginning tomorrow of the thirty-eighth annual encampment.

Hailing the "significant advance in wider organization of workers" in the last year, the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America made public its annual Labor Day message yesterday with an appeal for the application of greater democracy in both political and industrial relations.

At the Lenox Club J. Woodward Haven and his daughter, Miss Ethel L. Haven, had as dinner guests last night Miss Mary Parsons, Mr. and Mrs. James Dwight Francis, Robert Talcott Francis and George L. Kingsland Morris.

The Giants rode baseball's scenic railway into first place and out of it again yesterday. They trounced the Reds, 7-2, before a gathering of 16,683 at the Polo Grounds while the Phillies flattened the Cubs in the first game of their double header.

The Rev. Dr. Thomas Arthur Smoot, one of the leading clergymen in the Virginia Methodist Conference and pastor of Epworth Church in Norfolk, died today after an illness of several weeks. He was 66 years old.

Mrs. Mary Kingsbury Simkhovitch, president of the National Public Housing Conference, announced here yesterday that she had addressed to President Roosevelt a letter commending the President's leadership and that of Senator Wagner in the cause of slum clearance and low-rent housing.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, was cut on the right hand and his running mates, Controller Frank J. Taylor and Max J. Schneider, candidate for President of the Council, were slightly cut and bruised when the platform on which they were speaking last evening collapsed.

No man can achieve spiritual strength without silence, but to know when to speak with conviction shows courage and wisdom, Bishop Adna Wright Leonard of the Pittsburgh Methodist Area said yesterday at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

Continuing the steady golf that had gained him a place in a triple' tie for the lead yesterday, Jimmy Hines, metropolitan open champion, won the Glens Falls open tournament today for the third time with a seventy-two-hole score of 274.

The three-family house at 9-11 Floyd Avenue, Bloomfield, N. J., has been sold by the F. F. Corporation of Trenton to Philip Pizzino through Louis Schlesinger, Inc. A new one-family house at 121 Oakdene Avenue, Leonia, was sold by the Homecraft Company to Nicholas Tsikouri. J. B. Wolfe, Inc., was the broker.
Thomas B. Sheehan, former general manager and a director of the Stratford Press, died Saturday of a heart attack at his residence, 3,830 Bronx Boulevard, Bronx, at the age of 56.

Strained relations existing between Warner Brothers and the studio's Cosmopolitan unit since the parent studio removed "Boy Meets Girl" from Marion Davies's schedule got an added wrench over the weekend when Miss Davies's supporters were accused of conducting a campaign to minimize the importance of the play, which cost about $100,000.

Maurice P. Davidson, chairman of the Progressive party, speaking yesterday at a German-American rally at Clason Point, the Bronx, expressed the belief that American citizens of 'German birth "do not believe in and will not support any political movement that is reactionary."

One might reasonably suspect that the large and decidedly informal audience which packed the erstwhile Nora Bayes Theatre, now called the Clemente Giglio Radio Theatre, was there at its reopening on Saturday evening more as devvotees of the drama which comes over the air waves than as patrons of the straight legitimate thing.
Two women were shot at Leningrad today after a court-martial had convicted them of having poisoned foods at a children's home.

Lew Hahn has accepted the offer of the National Retail Dry Goods Association to assume the management of that organization and has declined the invitation tendered him to become president of the American Retail Federation, he indicated in a statement released today.
New low levels for the season and since June, 1936, were established by both the December and the May corn last week, and the close yesterday was within a fraction of a cent of the inside figures.

Agents of German houses are attempting to control El Salvador's coffee business and one house has made an offer to buy the entire crop in exchange for German goods. German coffee buyers, who also are importers of German goods, already have made advance payments on the coffee crop about to be harvested. They are offering high prices.
The French Line flagship Normandie is due today from Havre via Southampton with 1,813 passengers, the largest number ever carried in the ship.

The Government forces have lost thirty planes on the Aragon front in the last five days of fighting, Insurgent headquarters said today. The Insurgents calculate that the Government forces suffered 15,000 casualties in their offensive which, it is said here; can now be considered a failure.

An expedition from the American Museum of Natural History is en route to North Dakota to obtain material for the "Roosevelt Ranch Group," to be shown on the first floor of the museum's new Roosevelt Memorial Building Dr. James L. Clark, director of the department of arts, preparation and installation, is in. charge.

American and British insurance underwriters estimated the total war damage to Shanghai since Aug. 13 at $275,000,000. After a survey of Shanghai and its suburbs the insurance men divided the losses as follows:

Arthur M. Deacon, the 17-yearold Horseshoe Harbor skipper representing the Western Long Island Sound junior fleet, climaxed a season of brilliant sailing today by capturing all the remaining Snipe Class trophies for which his Armade II was eligible.

After Buck Newsom had stifled St. Louis with four hits and pitched the Red Sox to a 2-to-0 victory in the opener, the Browns routed three Boston pitchers with seventeen hits to take the second game of a double-header today. 8 to 3.

Funeral services for Albert Arthur Tilney, New York financier, will be held at his Plainfield, N. J., home on Wednesday at 11 A. M. Mr. Tilney, chairman of the board of the Bankers Trust Company, New York, since 1923, died on Friday night of a heart attack at a fishing lodge on Lake St. John, Roberval, Que.

The backyards of New York City, particularly those in which the odorous Ailanthus ("Tree of Heaven") grows, are in the grip of a de-' termined invasion by an army of web-worms, which, according to the Department of Parks, is the worst epidemic of its kind in seven or eight years.

The first scheduled flight on the new Transcontinental and Western Air route between New York and Chicago will be made Wednesday, Jack Frye, president of TWA, announced yesterday. Sleeper planes will be operated on the new line, which is by way of Dayton, Ohio, and Fort Wayne, Ind.

Dr. Charles L. Browne, retired New York dentist, died here this afternoon. His age was 87. He was formerly chairman of the Ophthalmic (New York) Hospital board of directors, commodore of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club and a member of the Corinthian Yacht Club.

Among those entertaining at luncheons today were Countess Altonso P. Villa at Fairholme, Mrs. Verner Z. Reed Jr. at Terra Mare, Mrs. Drexel Dahlgren at Champ Soliel and Mrs. Ogden H. Hammond at the Whitney Warren cottage.

Social and economic reforms can be accomplished by men and women who are willing to defy scoffers who hold that reformation is impossible, Professor Henry H. Tweedy of Yale Divinity School declared yesterday morning at Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

An analysis by the National Industrial Conference Board of the number of persons involved in strikes and lockouts in relation to total population shows that industrial disputes have in general been less widespread in this country than in other countries, with the exception of Canada and the Irish Free State.

We are comfortably housed in the cabin of the plane anchored in Walker Inlet, Patrick Island, awaiting the clearance of fog before proceeding on our search for Sigismund Levanevsky and his fellow. Russian .fliers lost in the Arctic.

The aid of the United States destroyer Kane, which is at Gijon, Spain, taking off American refugees. has been requested by the British Embassy in the search for Rupert Bellville, wealthy young Londoner, who landed lis private plane at Santander Wednesday under the mistaken impression that the city had already been captured by the Insurgents.
Mr. and Mrs. Laurence V. Benet will return from Europe this week and will be at the Plaza before going to Washington. Mrs. Sterling Postley will come to the Towers of the Waldorf-Astoria today.

5th St, 232 E, 21x96.2; Bertha P. Bier, administratrix of Jacob Goldenberg et al, heirs of Jacob Goldenberg, to Gustav Schwartz, Inc, 108 Park Ave; 'mtg, $14,000 (50 cents). 81st St, 164 W, 18.9x102.2; Carolyn R. Merriam, formerly Carolyn M. Reynolds, to Benjamin Basken, 501 W 139th St; mtg. $9.000 ($2).
Firmin Kugler, New Jersey junior bike champion, last night annexed the one-mile national amateur sprint held by the Amateur Bicycle League of America at the Coney Island Velodrome.

Despite the absence of most of London's population and the usual Summertime emptiness in this city, the Autumn theatre season got off to a good start last week with two openings The return of cooler winds will bring John Gielgud in "King Richard II" and Peggy Ashcroft as his queen.

Bernard Fowler Rogers Jr., an insurance executive, died today of a heart attack in his cabin aboard the American steamship Excambion at Naples, Italy, according to cable advices received here tonight. His age was 45.

The powerful Evergreen Farms quartet, apparently on its way to its second straight Eastern Polo League championship, rolled up the largest score in the two-year history of the tournament today at Hilltop Field by crushing the Ramapo Greens, 24-12.

J.Edgar Hoover, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, staged simultaneous vice raids in cities of three States this morning in which 137 persons, all but twenty-two of them women, were arrested.

In protest against the recently adopted ordinance against topless bathing suits, about a dozen prominent residents of this incorporated village appeared on the fashionable bathing beach at the Municipal Center in bathing suits of the Gay Nineties and flaunted themselves before the eyes of Herbert Bell, Village Trustee, who led the majority vote in favor of tops.
