For the second year in a row, oarsmen from the New York Athletic Club gathered most of the laurels in the Metropolitan Championship Rowing Regatta held yesterday on the Harlem River under the auspices of the New York Rowing Association. Representatives of the club won eight of the eleven events on the program, including the first five races.

The foreign exchange market here was firmer this week, especially in the forward franc, following the action of the French control. Premiums on the dollar and sterling have fallen, although the improvement was not quite maintained at the end of the week, chiefly because of technical factors.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Andrews of Penn Yan, N. Y., and Daytona Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary J. Andrews, to George A. Hamilton of Rochester, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Hamilton of Flushing, Queens.

Man must change his mind about God, the Rev. Austin Pardue, rector of Gethsemane Church, Minneapolis, said in his sermon yesterday at St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, where he has been guest preacher for the month.

Some mysterious force halted a flight of eight starlings over Fifth Avenue between Twenty-ninth and Thirtieth Streets at 7:30 A. M. yesterday and sent the birds, plummeting in death, to the feet of Patrolman Anton Vodrazka.

United States foreign trade developments have assumed new significance in the last several months because of a merchandise import surplus of an unprecedented size, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York says in its monthly review. This surplus,

The walkout of signalmen and other technical employes of the American District Telegraph Company, which went into effect without previous notice at midnight Saturday, continued yesterday but without serious effect on the

William W. Holmes, Negro doorman at a downtown night club, was fatally injured early today when a bomb exploded in a car bearing license plates issued to Harry Millman, former member of Detroit's "purple" gang of the prohibition era.

The art of living life to the full is acquired through unselfishness, the Rev. Edward J. Bubb, chaplain of the Seventy-first Infantry, New York National Guard, said at its regimental service at Camp Smith here this morning.

Only one hit separated young Ray Harrell, the Cardinals' 25-year-old Byers (Texas) rookie, from a no-hit game today as he mowed down the Bees, 3 to 0, in the nightcap of a doubleheader that saw St. Louis run its losing streak to five by dropping the opener, 3-2.

Three hundred and ten university scholarships have been awarded by the State Department of Education to high school pupils in Greater New York, it was announced today. The scholarships were awarded in the city at large, on the basis of five for each Assembly district, but without regard to the boundaries of the Assembly districts.

Two men, attempting vainly to extinguish flames enveloping the thirty-foot launch Owl II in the Hudson River about 300 feet off 165th Street, had to jump for their lives and swim to shore yesterday afternoon when the blaze destroyed the boat.
The Restigouche Company, Ltd., a subsidiary of Fraser Companies, Ltd., has notified bondholders of the payment to be made on Oct. 2 of the four remaining installments on account of deferred interest.

The financial press here had forecast the cut in the New York Federal Reserve rediscount rate, believing it would be necessary in order to support government securities and to encourage the taking of discount credits as a means of financing further trade recovery.

Miss Elsa Dommerich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis W. Dommerich of Round Hill Road, Greenwich, will be a luncheon hostess tomorrow at the Field Club, Greenwich, for the concert committee of the local unit of the New York Junior League, which has arranged to give three concerts in Greenwich for students of the public and private schools. The concerts,

Nantao witnessed today the execution by decapitation of two women and seven men, all Chinese, found guilty of treason. This correrespondent, who saw the executions, was told more than 100 persons had met a similar fate in Nantao since the Shanghai conflict began.

Mark Twain's complaint that, although every one talks about the weather, "nobody does anything about it," is hardly reasonable nowadays. Gustav Lindgren, director of the United States Weather Bureau here, has proof that many people do lots of things about the weather. About its effects, that is.

The Wisconsin Federation of Labor has gained 75,000 new members since July, 1936, or six times the number of those quitting to join the Committee for Industrial Organization, J. J. Handley, secretary, has informed the executive board. William Green,
Analysis of the Senate line-up on recent issues showed today that the bulk of opposition to President Roosevelt's policies came from New England, the "Solid" South, and the Pacifi Coast.

Having glorified at party rallies in the past four years such spirit-stirring achievements as the "victory" and the "triumph of the will" of the National Socialist party and the "freedom" and "honor" of the Third Reich, Chancellor Adolf Hitler has decided to dedicate this year's party

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 91.7, which compares with 91.9 a week ago, 91.9 two weeks ago, 91.8 three weeks ago and 92.3 four weeks ago.

Donald Budge of California and Baron Gottfried von Cramm of Germany stand at the crossroads and tomorrow afternoon the two foremost amateur tennis players of the world will come to grips for the first time in America.

" Virginia," scheduled to stare the theatrical season tomorrow night, was postponed yesterday to Thursday evening at the Center Theatre. The possibility of sUch a delay was forecast on Saturday, when the previews scheduled for last night and tonight were canceled.

Detective Thomas Coote of the Queens homicide squad left Newark Airport by plane yesterday for Kansas City to consult with the police in that city on the activities of Mrs. Esther Gordon, whose body was found in a barrel near the Queens side of Hell Gate Bridge on Friday.

Patrolman Raymond Albee and Patrolman William Prescott were assigned today to enforce Alderman William Slater's anti-shorts ordinance, this being the first Sunday since the revised law became effective, but they found nothingto do.

" The city's finances are in good shape today, but it will take good piloting to keep them there," Joseph D. McGoldrick, candidate for the Republican nomination for Controller, declared in a statement, issued yesterday. Mr. McGoldrick, who was Controller for about eight months in the La Guardia administration, said he favored a "planned course" of public expenditures as the only safeguard against financial trouble.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Hallock Webb of this place and New Brunswick of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara St. John Webb, to Edward Nichols, son of Mrs. Thompson Barker of Morristown and Colonel J. Brooks Nichols of Detroit, Mich.

Five thousand six hundred and fifty. young men now enrolled in Civilian Conservation Corps camps in New York, New Jersey and Delaware will not be permitted to reenroll when their terms expire on Sept. 30, it was learned yesterday at the headquarters of the Second Corps Area on Governors Island.

Extension of the competitive class of municipal employment, with wider opportunities for promotion, improvement of examining technique and increased efficiency and morale of public service were the prinicpal accomplishments of the Municipal Civil Service Commission in 1936, according to the report for the year made public yesterday.
A. B. Aldridge, Birmingham coal operator, died in a hospital here tonight at the age of 57. He had been ill for several weeks.
The new Reich loan subscriptions and the Chinese situation dominated the week's markets, the former impeding Boerse activity and the latter causing intense nervousness.

Carmine St, 70; 21.4x59.9; 49 Leroy St Realty Corp, Bertram Plante, president, to 70 Carmine St Corp, 70 Carmine St; p m mtg 5 years, 4 per cent; $8,000. Downing St, 12-20; Downing-Sixth Realty Corp, Frank S. Verro, president, to Caroline E. Crane, et al, Scarsdale, N. Y.: mtg Jan 31, 1947, 5 per cent; $17,000.

The master of Jedburgh Grammar School, on his recent visit to Canada, stated that the kilt is "coming back" in Scotland. This, he seemed to think, had some political significance as indicating a sympathy with the Nationalists' purpose to secure to Scotland a greater measure of "home rule." Thrift,

A canvass of world trade policies and a session on international reciprocal agreements, at which Dr. Henry F. Grady, vice chairman of the United States Tariff Commission, and Harry C. Hawkins, chief of the division of trade agreements of the Department of State, will lead the round-table discussion, will be an outstanding feature of the twenty-fourth National Foreign Trade Convention to be held in Cleveland on Nov. 3, 4 and 5, it was announced yesterday.
In the first seven months of this year the building of 107,290 homes costing $431,053,900 was authorized in cities of 10,000 population or more, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today.
Financial circles here are glad to note that the Government recognizes the fact that financial recovery cannot go further unless economic recovery accompanies it. It is wondered,

The severity of the British Government's note to Japan on the wounding of its Ambassador to China by a Japanese airplane attack, while not totally unexpected here, caused some stir in official circles as its contents became known today.

The Rev. Ferdinand Schiverea, an evangelist who was for many years an associate of the late Dwight L. Moody, died Saturday of heart disease at his home, 90-01 170th Street, Jamaica, Queens, at the age of 82.
The new American merchant marine will consist entirely of ships as fireproof and foolproof as they can be made, the Maritime Commission announced today.
Dr. Charles F. Thwing, president emeritus of Western Reserve University, died today at his home here. His age was 83. H. had been in failing health for several years.

John Pollotos, known to detectives for sixteen years as "Jerry the Jump," because of a windowclimbing technique, even for a burglar, dived to his death yesterday in Sedgwick Avenue police station in the Bronx.

The Little Entente conference opens at Sinala, near Bucharest, tomorrow. It will last only a day and a half. Kamil Krofta, Czechoslovak. Foreign Minister, and Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch of Yugoslavia will arrive tomorrow and immediately thereafter Premier George Tatarescu of Rumania will inform Stoyadinovitch of his recent conference with Dr. Milan Hodza, Premier of Czechoslovakia, in Bukovina.

Daniel Dimichiel, 27, of New Canaan was most impatient at 2:30 A. M. today so he pulled a firealarm box which brought out two pieces of apparatus, two companies of firemen, the fire chief and, four policemen.

On last week's financial markets, outside news cut the larger figure. Thursday's dispatches, not only intimating Japan's purpose of preventing foreign ships from reaching Chinese ports but describing the aerial Japanese attack on the British Ambassador to China, and following the announcement by the railway brotherhoods of a strike for higher wages, gave sufficient material for unsettlement.
The President's veto of a bill increasing annual authorizations by $2,580,000 for assistance to States in agricultural extension work must hearten the friends of Federal economy.

After twenty years at 191 Broadway, corner of Dey Street, the L. E. Waterman Company, fountain pen manufacturers, will move to 55 Broadway, southwest corner of Exchange Alley, where the concern has leased the store, basement and second floor.

On Nov. 17, 1935, you published a letter from me under the caption "Railroad Needs" with respect to important roads then and for a long time (in one case since 1923) in receivership. Now, nearly two years later, they are all still in receivership and heaven only knows when they will get out. The situation is little less than scandalous.

The State Department and the Department of Justice have been asked by John J. Bennett Jr., State Attorney General, to take adequate measures to protect American business men from the activities here of questionable foreign money-lending companies.

The county government reorganization .bills offered by the Democratic majority in the Municipal Assembly were termed "a hypocritical gesture," in a letter sent yesterday by the City Affairs Committee to the joint committee of the Municipal Assembly now considering the bills.

Three. peasants were critically wounded and twenty were less seriously hurt last night in Valjevo, Yugoslavia, when gendarmes fired on a crowd of Serbians who threatened. a political meeting of government supporters, according to reports received here.

Mr. and Mrs. Fitz John Porter of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Peggy Porter, to Nicholas Vedder Poole, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Poole, also of New York, and Franconia, N. H.

Cornelius Shields again showed the way to the International Class in his Aileen as nineteen of the new one-design yachts raced in a Royal Bermuda Y. C. trophy series contest held in conjunction with the special regatta of the Echo Bay Y. C. today.

Judge Michael A. Musmanno, deprived of speech by a throat ailment, will conduct court this Fall with a pad and pencil. The judge, now on a 30,000-mile ocean voyage for his health, wrote to friends here that he would return in time for the September term.

General Sessions Judge Freschi at the request of District Attorney Dodge appointed a lawyer and two psychiatrists yesterday a commission to inquire into the mental conedition of Robert Irwin, 29 years old, sculptor and former theological student, awaiting trial on one of three first-degree murder indictments in the so-called triple Gedeon slaying.

With a driving rain drenching the course, a field of 126 women golfers teed off at five-minute intervals today in the fifth Mason-Dixon golf tourney. The weather was enough to discourage the most optimistic player, but after an hour's wait this morning most of the amateurs decided to go into action.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel McCrea Cavert, general secretary of the Federal Council of Churches in America, told of a plan for uniting all the Christian churches of the world, with the exception of the Roman Catholic, .upon his arrival from abroad on the Volendam of the Holland-America Line last night.
The list of the Canard White Star liner Aquitania, arriving today from Southampton via Cherbourg, includes Mr. and Mrs. Roscoe Pound, Mr. and Mrs. Everett Sanders, Dean Everett V. Meeks.

Evidently stung by the bitter foreign criticism of their killing of hundreds of civilians by the bombings of the Nantao section of Shanghai, the Japanese announced formally today that "at the present time we will refrain from the bombardment of civilian populations, but will continue bombing Chinese military concentrations and establishments."

The five-story building formerly occupied by the National Navy Club of New York, Inc., at 93-5 Park Avenue, which passed into the hands of the Y. M. C. A. in February of 1936, has been sold by the latter organization to the City of New York.

Several large suites were reported yesterday to have been leased 'to new tenants. Mrs. Edward Titus leased an apartment of sixteen rooms and six baths in the house at 300 Park Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman and Byrne Bowman, Inc., who report additional rentals to Frank Chalmers, in 115 East Eighty-ninth Street, to Monroe Plons and Charles Bauer in 65 East Ninety-sixth Street, and to Conrad Kremp in 245 East Twenty-first Street.
Mr. and Mrs. E. Magawly Banon entertained with a luncheon today in the woods on their estate, Lily Pond Park, and tonight gave a dinner in honor of their house guest, Edward Nugent of Philadelphia.

With an estimated net decrease of more than 6,000 pupils, the second such decline in enrollment on record, the city's public schools will reopen for the Fall term on Sept. 13. In the regular day sessions there will be an estimated registration of 1,145,000. About 80,000 in classes mainly for adults will make a total enrollment of 1,225,000.

Major General Hans Busse, who during the World War held the East Prussian fortress of Boyen against invading Russians, died today at the age of 80. General Busse, at the outbreak of the World War, was a colonel in the Imperial German Army, and as commander of the fortress Boyen withstood the onslaught of the Russians under General Rennenkampf despite the much smaller German force.

Miss Mary Virginia Bolgiano, daughter of Mrs. Charles J. Bolgiano of Roland Park, and the late Mr. Bolgiano, was married to Edwin Walter Filler, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Filler of Homeland, Baltimore, this evening in Grace Methodist Episcopal Church. The Rev. Robert L. Wright performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at the Baltimore Country Club.
Dr. Robert Ley, head of the German Labor Front, made several demands on the Catholic Church here today that were in the nature of an ultimatum. They included:
Foreign diplomats said tonight that the new non-aggression pact between China and Russia had spiked any chance for Japan to use China as a catspaw in her anti-Communist crusade.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board of the General Motors Corporation, returned yesterday on the Normandie from a vacation in Europe. He was optimistic over the business outlook for his company both at home and abroad.

Insurance companies may rightfully avoid the payment of millions of dollars in unemployment insurance taxes to the State of New York if they will put their agents under contract rather than listing them as employes, according to David B. Sugarman, prominent insurance counsel of Syracuse, N. Y.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers, explained today at a meeting of delegates. from General. Motors locals, his acceptance of a compromise with the rival faction. at the. union convention which closed here last night.

James Briggs filed suit for $85,000 against the United Automobile Workers of America today, charging that fears of violence from union members drove his son, Robert, to suicide. Robert Briggs, 22, was described by his father as an unwilling participant in a ten-day sit-down strike at the Bohn Aluminum and Brass Corporation plant which ended Jan. 6. The youth died of poison on April 22.

John Smiuski who in August, 1935, was arrested and later deported for tearing caricatures of the Roosevelt family from the walls of a Westchester art exhibit, received a letter yesterday from Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt in the Flushing Hospital, where he is a patient.

Miss Elsie Louise Morrison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Morrison of Huntington Station, was married to Martin Graeber, son of Mrs. Dora Graeber of Port Jefferson, yesterday by the Rev. William Mitchell, pastor of the Northport Presbyterian Church.

Sidewheeling his big bay horse, Lew Hal, first under the wire in three successive heats, Doc Parshall, veteran reinsman of Urbana, Ohio, took the feature event of the opening day of Grand Circuit races at the Ohio State Fair today, the 2:19 class pacing stake with a $1,000 purse.

The prediction that Mayor La Guardia would "sweep the city" in the general election in November was made yesterday by Samuel Seabury, who as counsel for the Hofstadter legislative investigating committee laid the ground for the Mayor's election four years ago.

Mayor La Guardia, addressing 5,000 members of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers from the steps of City Hall yesterday afternoon, urged organized labor to discipline itself, to exhaust legal processes before resorting to strikes and to avoid situations which might undermine the neutral position of governmental agencies in disputes between employers and employes.

Just as a physician protects. the secrets of a patient, so the fingerprints of presumably honest citizens, recorded in the civil file at Washington, are. protected against criminal check-up, according to Inspector L. C. Schilder, chief of the Division of Criminal Identification of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Department of Justice.

The fun started under cover of darkness at the Yankee Stadium when Harry Balsamo, the battering brakeman from the subway shops, popped into the ring and popped over one Chris de Rosa from Boston before the Hub Town visitor had time to get acquainted. Balsamo seemed to be in a great hurry. Maybe he was due back at the shop by 10 o'clock.

The Namsolk Realty Corporation has purchased the vacant plot of 123 by 152 feet on the north side of Forty-seventh Avenue, 143 feet east of Eightieth Street, Elmhurst, L. I., from the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company.
Treasury officials said today that they probably would ask Congress in January for at least $450,000 to employ more than 100 new tax investigators.

A new curriculum-the life arts and science course-designed to appeal to the student who is not bookminded but who has talents at crafts or at certain fine arts, will be offered in the Senior High School here this Fall.
Baron Eberhard von Stohrer, who once was named Ambassador to Madrid, today became Germany's second Ambassador to the Spanish Insurgent regime.

Henry Dobbs and long hitting Henry Ciuci of Fresh Meadow teamed to win the Long Island P. G. A. one day pro-amateur best-ball tournament over the North Hills links today with a record score of 32, 33 65, seven strokes under par.

The Little Entente conference began here today in an apparent spirit of solidarity belying constant rumors of the impending dissolution of the ties binding its members--Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia and Rumania.

Gerard Ave, 710 (9-2473); Joslan Realty Corp to Green-Wood Cemetery, 170 Broadway, extends mtg to Sept. 1, 1942, at 5 per cent; $100,000. Bainbridge Ave, 2,977 (12-3298); 2,977 Bainbridge Ave Corp to Sadie B. Morgenstern, 286 Ft Washington Ave; installments, 6 per cent; $20,000.

Mrs. Levin Rothrock Marshall of 49 East Eighty-second Street and Glen Head, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Trina Calhoun Marshall, to Nathaniel Read Norton Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Read Norton of 111 East Seventy-eighth Street.
President Roosevelt was informed at once of the bombing of the President Hoover in Chinese waters today but made no comment on that or any other developments in the Far East.

Anthony J. Billingham, a correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who was seriously wounded on Aug. 23 when a Chinese airplane dropped a bomb on a department store here, was released from the hospital today but confined to his hotel.

Francis Hartman Markoe gave a supper and entertainment known as a "fearful party" tonight at Shelmar House, his place in Water Mill. Guests had been requested to wear costumes suggestive of persons or things they feared the most.

To a tolerably large schedule Dwight Deere Wiman has just added another item, this one the play called "The Nuremberg Egg." Adapted by Winifred Katzin from the German of Walter Harlan, it was tested Aug. 17 at Surry, Me., and some time ago was held by Hortense Alden and Sam Jaffe. Whether it will begin Mr. Wiman's season is not yet known.

The plane of Sir Hubert Wilkins landed here at 9:28 P. M. [12:28 A. M., Tuesday, Eastern daylight time] after a fruitless flight over the Arctic today in search of the lost Russian transpolar fliers headed by Sigismund Levanevsky.
When the pen of Dr. Charles F. Thwing lingered over the last pages of copy for his book on The College President, he found his mind "reflecting on the characteristics of the perfect president."

The unemployed in Sweden, not including members of trade unions, declined to a record low of 11,429 persons at the end of June, according to figures by the Swedish Unemployment Commission reported to the Department of Commerce.
Resigned to the fact that the conflict between Japan and China will be prolonged, exporters and importers interested in trade with the Orient yesterday took stock of their positions.

The Brainard Steel Corporation of Warren, Ohio, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement for 116,000 shares of common stock, $1 par value, the issuer's part of the proceeds to be used to pay bank loans and for machinery, equipment, plant additions and working capital.

Irregular fluctuations in a considerable volume of business characterized trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, and after several rallies, a late decline left the list with losses of 10 to 18 points.

The British Government has decided to build a central camp at Isiolo, 150 miles south of the Ethiopian frontier, for 1,000 Ethiopian refugees, half of whom are women and children who have arrived in Kenya recently after one of the most remarkable treks in the modern history of Africa, it was learned today.

Administration of State and national fair trade acts as applied to the drug industry should be coordinated by the industry itself through a national board composed of representatives of the two big retail drug associations, John W. Dargavel, executive secretary of the National Association of Retail Druggists, asserted today at the opening session of the national fair trade conference.

That the Maritime Commission's attempts to restore our blue-water glories of the days of sail is at least finding some public response, and public appreciation of the issues involved is evidenced by the September issue of Fortune, out last Thursday.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Tompkins Coldwell of Alplaus, Schenectady, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Coldwell of this city, to Martin B. Keenahan of Batavia, Java, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Keenahan of New York.

Charles A. Levine, the former an junk dealer who was the first passenger to fly across the ocean in an airplane back in 1927, arrived in New York yesterday from Mexico, pleaded not guilty to an indictment charging conspiracy in a smuggling plot, and received twenty-four hours to raise bail of $2,000 or be held in jail.

New York railway policemen shot their way to the top of the list to win the center-fire team pistol match today. James H. Overbaugh and James R. Herron, both of the Delaware and Hudson railway police of Albany took first place with rc 562 out of a possible 600, beating Harry J. Russ and Crit E. Hill,

Mrs. Mary Adelia Bond, widow of Joseph Bond, president of the American Radiator Company, died yesterday after a brief illness at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Joseph F. Rhodes, in Pasadena, Calif. She was 78 years old.

Farmers in the sparsely settled Province of Guanacaste are making war on hordes of monkeys which greatly exceed the human population in the jungle. After a hard struggle against the jungle, the farmers succeeded in clearing small patches for cornfields, which they are now hard. pressed to protect from marauding monkeys.
Benny Kaufman of New York captured the feature event, a scratch race at three-fifths of a mile,

A new type of Pullman sleeping car, called the "Roomette," was exhibited yesterday afternoon by the New York Central in the Grand Central Terminal. Designed for greater comfort of the single passenger, the sleeping car is made up of eighteen small rooms, or comapartments, about the size of an ordinary section and containing one bed.

The Mutual-Sunset Lamp Company of Brooklyn has been ordered by the National Labor Relations Board to bargain collectively with Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an A. F. of L. union, as the exclusive bargaining agency for its Brooklyn employes.

The forty-five-foot cutter Spookie, owned by Harold White Jr. of Bedford Hills, N. Y., held a twelvehour victory today over its nearest rival in the Portland Yacht Club's 120-mile Monhegan Island race.

The premiere of "The Miles of Heaven," a character drama in five scenes, by David Hertz of New York and Hollywood, starring Walter Huston of "Dodsworth" and "Othello" fame, taxed the capacity of Lobero here tonight. Arthur J. Beckhard was producer and director, and the featured players were Nan Sunderland (Mrs. Huston) and Barbara O'Neil.
Directors of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company called today a special shareholders' meeting for Oct. 19 to act on financing for plant improvements in Youngstown and Chicago mills of the company.

Five United States subjects and nine British subjects, arrested by Cuban authorities after they fled from a native uprising in the Bahamas, were acquitted in Urgency Court here today on charges of possessing war materials.
The rate paid by the Treasury on its. short-term discount bills advanced sharply with the sale today of a combined offering of about $100,000,000 of bills with 273-day and 110-day maturity.

Details of the 1937 cotton-loan program officially fixing the loan rate at 9 cents a pound on cotton classing seven-eighth inch middling or better were announced today by the Commodity Credit Corporation.
Although he had bad cuts under both eyes and a swollen third finger on his right hand, Tommy Farr was as happy when he went to his dressing room as though he had been the victor in the fight.

Joe Louis, Detroit's famed Brown Bomber, retained the world heavyweight boxing championship last night at the Yankee Stadium in fifteen fast, bruising rounds against Tommy Farr, but he caught a tartar in the British Empire titleholder.

Plans were filed yesterday for two new six-story apartments, one in the Bronx, on East 206th Street near the Grand Concourse, which it is estimated will cost $140,000, and the other in Brooklyn, on Brighton Eleventh Street, costing $125,000.

A banking group composed or B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc.; John Nuveen Co., Chicago; the Natco Corporation, Miami, and Robert H. Cook, Inc., Miami, will offer today a new issue of $913,000 of Dade County, Fla. (Miami),

General Tire and Rubber Company common stock, $5-par value, and Koppers Company first-mortgage and collateral-trust bonds, Series A, 4 per cent, due in 1951, have been admitted to the New York Stock Exchange list.
Mrs. G. Butt Miller's Derby winner, MidDay Sun, maintained his place as favorite for the classic St. Leger in tonight's call-over of odds at the Victoria Club. The colt was backed at 3 to 1.

The stock market was extremely quiet today, with prices sagging all around with absence of supporting bids. Giltedge issues lost ground along with the speculative equities. Renewed selling further depressed Far Eastern obligations.

109th St, 167 E, 25x100.11; Irving Anzelowitz to Rose Melinkoff, Paterson Plank Rd, North Bergen, N. J.; mtg, $9,000 (50c). 140th St, 604 W, 41.8x99.11; Edw. J. Chapman, ref, to Citizens Savings Bank ($1). Lafayette St, 241; 21.4x99.1; Elsie H. Tietz to Hugo Heilprunn at Wagenfeld-Foerlinger, Province of Hanover, Germany ($15).

Joseph W. Dawson, president of the Dawson Brothers Construction Company, died today at his home at the age of 73. Active in civic and fraternal affairs, Mr. Dawson was a charter member of the Rotary Club, a member of the Chamber of Commerce, Elks Club, Knights of Columbus and theBellevue Country Club.

The National Labor Relations Board certified today that a majority of shoe workers of twelve firms in Lewiston and Auburn, Me., had voted for the United Shoe Workers of America as the exclusive bargaining agency for all employes of the plants.

Dr. Arthur Bruckner, head of the Department of Mechanical Engineering at the College of the City of New York, died here last night, at his home of a heart attack. Dr. Bruckner, who was 65 years old, had been in ill health for some time, and was on leave of absence from the college since last February.

President Roosevelt, in an effort to bring Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Hampshfre and Vermont within the provisions of the Flood Control Law of 1936, has suggested that their Legislatures meet in special session and approve a new compact that will follow the letter of the law and make possible prompt construction of flood control projects in the basins of the Connecticut and Merrimac Rivers.

Lord Edward Montagu, second son of the Duke of Manchester, married Miss Dorothy Vera Peters, playwright and theatrical producer, on Saturday at Brighton Register Office, two hours after his divorce from his Canadian wife became absolute.
Miss Mary Theresa McDonald, daughter of Mrs. Wiliam Francis McDonald of this city and the late Mr. McDonald, will be married to Paul Thomas Sheridan on Sept. 9 in the Church of Our Lady of Lourdes.

The Dallas Federal Reserve Bank cut its discount rate from 2 to 1 1/2 per cent today, following the lead of five other banks which took similar action in the last two weeks. The reductions are designed to make vast reservoirs of credit available to member banks in the affected districts at cheap interest rates.

With more than 300 persons attending the opening session, the third annual Herald Tribune football coaching school got under way yesterday at that newspaper's auditorium. The principal speaker was Dr. John B. (Jock) Sutherland, head coach at Pittsburgh. Other speakers were Lou Little. Columbia mentor, and George H. Daley, Tribune sports editor.

Common Pleas Judge William R. White in an order today enjoined the United Shoe Workers of America and its local officers from attempting to prevent fulfillment of individual working contracts which 870 employes have with the Williams Manufacturing Company plant here.
The American Theatre Council's board of directors yesterday authorized the first expenditures for the projects designed to revive the legitimate stage.

Miss Elizabeth Colton Nichols, sister of Miss Ruth Nichols, the aviatrix, died this morning at the United Hospital in Port Chester after a week's illness, of double pneumonia. Ruth had come by plane from a Wyoming ranch to be at her sister's bedside.

Lawrence Hoover Seager, Bishop of the Evangelical Church from 1915 to 1934, and Bishop emeritus since that time, died here today at the age of 77. Bishop Seager was born in Fremont, Ohio, and in 1886 received his A.B. from Ohio Northern University, which made him a Doctor of Laws forty-two years later.

Hoo Chai-tsai, director of the permanent bureau of the Chinese delegation to the League of Nations, forwarded to the League today a statement from his Government on the events in China since the Lukouchiao incident of. July 7 with the request that it be communicated not only to League members but also to the advisory committee set up by the Assembly in 1933 at the time of the Manchurian incident.

The quality of the imagination was found in a study reported today to be the only basic difference between 100 men who made $5,000 a year all through the depression and 100 who did not make more than $35 a week.

Turpentine firm, 31 1/4c; sales 247 barrels; receipts 537 barrels; shipments 165 barrels; stock 35, 705 barrels. Resin firm; sales 155; receipts 1,890; shipments 1,447; stock 65,638. Quote; B, $7.80; D, E, $7.85; F, G, H, $7.90; I, K, M, N, $7.95; WG, $8.05; WW, X, $8.70.

National headquarters of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee stated today that its organizers . had been instructed to arrange for the simultaneous expiration of allcontracts with steel producers next March 1.

Business failures in the United States numbered 155 in the week ended Aug. 26, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., announced yesterday. The figure compared with 150 a week earlier and with 138 in the correspending week a year ago. Last week's figure was 12.3 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of 1936.

Several thousand office workers were inconvenienced yesterday noon, many being compelled to walk the stairs, when the sixteen elevator operators in the twentystory Bartholomew Building, 205 East Forty-second Street, staged a sit-down strike for more wages and shorter hours.

Approximately 1,300 shop and outside ironworkers will return to work here tomorrow as a result of a successful conference today between employers and union officials, it was announced by Harry Katchen, secretary of the employers association. The conference ended a monthold strike.

Loans disbursed by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in July aggregated $37,985,687, as compared with repayments of $16,176,141, thus marking a break in the trend over the last few months during which repayments have exceeded loan advances, according to the corporation's monthly report to Congress.
A small tropical storm dissipated itself in rain squalls over Northeast Florida and Southeast Georgia tonight after crossing the Atlantic coast line north of here this morning.

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation are seeking to determine how the thirteen alleged vice resorts they raided in Atlantic City early Sunday morning could have operated so "blatantly," J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the bureau, said here yesterday.
The speaker at Williamstown, Mass., who linked plutogogues and theogogues with demagogues for popular disapproval may have gone a bit too far. Not all words ending in "gogue" are to be condenied.

Slipping through on the siae wnen the leaders went wide at the head of the stretch, the Lemar Stock Farm's Mightily ran to a halflength victory over seven 2-year-old rivals in the six-furlong Putnam Purse at Narragansett Park today.
An unloaded naval torpedo ripped through the harbor here today for the second time in eighteen days, this time sinking a small fishing boat.

Miss Jane Louise Warren, daughter of Mrs. John Brush Warren of this city and Philadelphia, has chosen Sept. 24 as the date for her marriage to George Starr Scofield 4th, son of Mrs. George S. Scofield of Geneseo, N. Y., and the late Mr. Scofield of Staten Island. The wedding will take place in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

Getting up in the last stride in the $3,650 Woodmere Claiming Stakes, the Maemere Farm racer Go Home made things easier for the favorite players who turned out for the opening of the Aqueduct Fall meeting yesterday. Overcoming interference and receiving a fine ride from the youthful W. E. Snyder, Go Home showed unusual courage as he drove through the long stretch to score by a nose over Hugh Jackson's Bulwark.

Preferred and common stock issues led all other types of securities for which registration statements filed under the Securities Act of 1933 became effective in July, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Maurice Vasseur, French speedboat ace, unloaded the hydroplane Rafale VI from a freight car today and arranged to put it in the water within the next day or so for tests for the Gold Cup Trophy race on Labor Day.

As an immediate result of the bombing of the liner President Hoover off Shanghai Harbor, American merchant vessels have been warned to stay away from that port, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today.
Motor vehicles took 2,270 more lives in the first seven months of this year than in the corresponding period of 1936, the National Safety Council reported today.
Luther Day, counsel for the Republic Steel Corporation, said today that he would file a motion for dismissal of the National Labor Relations Board's charges of unfair labor practices.

Information received here indicates recruiting by Honduras of mil itary forces along the NicaraguanHonduran frontier. The Vice President of Honduras is reported to be inspecting Fort San Marcos, near the Nicaraguan frontier.

Horace Willard Hooker, vice president, treasurer and director of the. Hooker Electrochemical Company of New York,-Niagara Falls and Tacoma, Wash., died early yesterday at his Summner home at Canandaigua, N. Y., in his sixtyfirst, year. He maintained other homes at Bronxville and at 277 Park Avenue.

Max Baer, former world's champion heavyweight boxer, did not appear in City Magistrate's Court tonight to answer a summons served on him Saturday for wearing shorts in the business district here and Judge Eldon C. Presbey issued a bench warrant for his arrest on a charge of contempt of court.

Information reaching Germany from abroad today indicates a certain amount of hostile interpretation of yesterday's speeches at the annual congress of Germans Living Abroad at Stuttgart, which this year has attained special importance.

William Beckly Gower of New York died yesterday at Garden Cottage, Lake Placid Club, of a heart attack suffered a week ago. His age was 63. He had been a member of the club since 1933. His wife and daughter, Mrs. Northrup Dawson of New Canaan, Conn., were at his bedside.

Government forces tightened their siege of Insurgent-held Belchite tonight in preparation for a general offensive to drive a steel wedge between Saragossa and Teruel, the most important Insurgent strongholds on the northeastern Aragon front.

Representatives of employers and employes in the leather, suitcase and bag trade signed al agreement yesterday in Mayor La Guardia's office at the Summer City Hall. The agreement provides for a forty-hour week during the first year of its life, and a thirty-sevenand-a-half-hour week for the second year.

The American steamship Manhattan was rushing today to the assistance of the Danish freighter Sonja Maersk, reported in distress 500 miles east of Belle Isle, according to a message received by East Coast Radio Signal Service here.
Influential speakers who agreed on little else about "public opinion in a democracy" expressed the common belief here today that Americans were a most propaganda ridden people.

Miss Irene Elizabeth Hulse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sylvester Hulse Jr. of this city, has completed plans for her wedding on Sept. 10 to William McGhee Wingfield of Newark, son of Mrs. George Dawson Wingfield of Bedford, Va. The ceremony will take place in St. Mark's Episcopal Church here with the rector, The Rev. John Ner Borton, officiating.

The Securities and Exchange Commission granted exemption today to the Tidewater Electric Service Company, a subsidiary of the Virginia East Coast Utilities, Inc., from the necessity of filing a declaration in respect to the sale by it of a first-mortgage note of $125,000, dated July 1, 1937, to evidence a loan from the Federal Government through the Rural Electrification Administration.
Settling down to serious work, Manhattan's football squad went through two fast drills today at its La Salle Military Academy training camp.
CLAUDE, by Genevieve Fauconnier. (Macmillan, $2.50.) A prizewinning French novel. THE LOST KING, by Raphael Sabatini. (Houghton Mifflin, $2.50.) About the lost Dauphin of France.
An American Federation of Labor charter was granted last night to the American Guild of Musical Artists following earlier action by which the Guild and the Grand Opera Artists Association merged.

Jurisdictional disputes took up most of the time of today's session of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor in the Hotel Ambassador. Meanwhile, however, there was much speculation as to what action would be taken by the council regarding the ten unions which were suspended last Sept. 5 because of C. I. O. affiliation.

Seven college and preparatory school students and their director, John Dallavo, an instructor at the Horace Mann School for Boys at Riverdale, returned yesterday from a 12,798-mile automobile trip through the United States and in parts of Canada and Mexico.

Application by the New York Curb Exchange to withdraw from listing and registration Ulen Co's. 6 per cent convertible sinking fund gold debentures, due Aug. 1, 1944, bearing three stamps, has been granted by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Lewis Charles Ruch, former president of the Philadelphia National League Baseball Club, died today in his home after a long illness at the age of 75. Mr. Ruch, for many years connected with the. General Outdoor Advertising Company of New York, came here five years ago from Brooklyn soon after retiring as president of the Phillies.

Three passengers and six members of the crew of the Dollar liner President Hoover were wounded when the ship was bombed yesterday.by Chinese planes. One of the injured members of the crew, S. Haskell, died today of leg and stomach wounds.

Joe Turnesa, Rockville professional, teamed up with his brother Willie, metropolitan amateur champion representing Briar Hills, to take first honors in the weekly proamateur best-ball tournament held under the auspices of the Westchester Amateur Golf Association at the Winged Foot Club today.
The Adjutant General released the following orders today: Ruddy, Capt. Daniel A.. Finance Dept., State Staff, having qualified, is placed on duty. He is to report to the Adjutant General for duty.

Miss Beatrice Barrett of Minneapolis led a field of forty today to win the qualifying medal with a two-overpar 78 in the opening round of the Canadian women's open golf championship at the St. Charles Country Club.
J. Welles Henderson of Chestnut Hill, Pa., entertained a large group of the younger set at the Kimball House in Northeast Harbor this evening before the weekly dinner dance.

Among those reported as having taken commercial space yesterday was the Chalif School of Dancing which leased quarters on the fourth floor in the International Building, Rockefeller Center. The school, one of the foremost of its kind in the country, was founded in 1905 by Louis Chalif, formerly prominent in the Russian ballet.

Art Straub and Robert Riddle of Manasquan returned a best-ball score of 65 today at the Manasquan River Golf Club to win the pro-amateur event of the New Jersey State P. G. A. Straub and Riddle were out in 32 and came back in 33.

Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan said here tonight that President Roosevelt might well be a candidate for President in 1940, despite the thirdterm custom. The Governor was returning from a vacation in California, en route to Detroit.

Efforts made yesterday by the State Mediation Board and the labor relations. department of the PWA to end the strike of 15,000 painters in-Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond ended in failure after many hours of negotiation between representatives of the Master Painters Association and the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, District Council 9, the strike organization.

In the fiscal year ended on June 30, taxes charged to operations of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System were equivalent to $8 a common share and were about 11.3 per cent of operating revenues, compared with 6.5 per cent for the fiscal year 1930, Gerhard M. Dahl, chairman of the board, said in his annual report issued yesterday.

Organization of the Citizens Com mittee for WPA Re-employment by a small group of WPA employes who will undertake to find jobs in private employment for men and women now on WPA rolls was announced yesterday by Hawthorne Winner, chairman of the committee.

Miss Josephine San Filippo of Brooklyn and Miss Judith Lachenbruch, Pleasantville, N. Y., seeded third and fourth in that order, led the field into the semi-finals as play in the Richmond County Country Club's second girls' Eastern grass court tennis singles tournament began on the club's courts in Dongan Hills, S. I., yesterday.

A strike of 4,500 taxicab drivers of the Sunshine-Radio, Liberty and Atlas Systems was threatened yesterday in a conflict between the companies and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, over enforcement of an agreement reached a month ago.

Business in the various departments of the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., showed a substantial increase for the year ending April 30, 1937, as compared with 1936, McGrath, Doyle Phair, the realty firm's auditors and accountants, reported yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia intervened yesterday in an effort to settle the strike of the signalmen and other technical employes of the American District Telegraph Company, which supplies fire and burglary protective service to 4,500 buildings, including banks, hospitals, hotels and apartment houses.
The Soviet purge, having disposed of many high personages, is now combing the lower categories of officials and Communist party leaders in widely separated Darts of the Soviet Union.

Two groups of about twentyfive children, most of whom were between 8 and 12 years old, put up barricades of cobblestones and scrap wood on Wales Avenue and on Wright Avenue here today in what police said was a protest to the city against the lack of play space in the Marion section.
The War Department released the following orders, today dated Aug. 28: Cummings, Lt. Col. C. W., Med. Corps, three months' leave, Dec. 27.

Catapulted from the deck of the mother ship Schwabenland off Larchmont in Long Island Sound yesterday at 3:07 P. M., the German ocean survey plane Nordmeer was winging over the Atlantic last night on the second leg of the first round-trip flight for a German seaplane this year between New York and the Azores.

The Polish Government has vigorously protested for the second time against the "persecution" of Poles by the Nazi authorities of Danzig. Special reference was made to their compelling all children to attend German schools.

Prospective brides and bridegrooms hurried to the Marriage License Bureau in the Municipal Building yesterday in a final rush to get married before the new law reluiring a three-day wait goes into effect tomorrow.

A bid for private operation of the city's foreign trade zone on Staten Island has been submitted to Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Estimate by Harry Shanks, president of the Manhattan Lighterage Corporation, it was learned yesterday.

Herman Steiner of Los Angeles and George N. Treysman and Charles Jaffe of New York were setting the pace today in the finals of the annual tournament for the championship of the American Chess Federation.
Bryant B. Newcomb, business manager of the Monmouth County Publishing Company, publisher of The Daily Record, was retired on pension today after twenty years' association with the company. Mr.

Estate, more than $10,000. To Rene Fricot, 107 Rue de Dole, a Saint-Ferjeux, BesaconDoubs, France; Gilbert Fricot, a SaintFerjeux, Besancon-Doubs, France, and Julia Sergent, 19 Ave. de Joinville, St. Dizier, Haute Marne, France, one-third residue each; Leontine Baget, friend, 121 W. 61st St., $1,000: two others, $500 each; Philip Krakower, friend, executor, 1,327 Grant Ave., Bronx. $5.000.
Miss Harriet Schurz Tompkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie J. Tompkins of 1,165 Fifth Avenue, New York, has completed plans for her wedding to John Kempster Thomas, son of Mrs.

Students of political penology are following with interest the case of Senator Van Nuys of Indiana. His term ends next year. He fought tooth and nail Mr. Roosevelt's scheme to reorganize the Supreme Court. The engineers of the Democratic machine in his State were quick to threaten him with punishment.
Evelyn Scott has written a new book, "Background in Tennessee," which will be published early in September by Robert McBride.

July sales of reporting wholesale concerns in this district averaged 8.2 per cent below last year, the first decrease since May, 1936, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve agent here.
The latest tra step in Britain's campaign to attract recruits to the army was announced today, when the War Of- tra: fice raised the age limit in combatant regiments from 25 to 28 years.

Captain Colon Eloy Alfaro, the Minister from Ecuador, has come from Washington to the Commodore. Mr. and Mrs. Stuart G. Gibboney are returning tomorrow to their home at 160 East Seventy-second Street from The Greenbrier, White Sulphur Springs, where they have been passing the Summer.

" Pat O'Brien has been removed from the lead of "Swing Your Lady" at Warners and assigned to the top role in Kay Francis's "Return From Limbo," which started shooting today. In all probability Humphrey Bogart will succeed him in the story of the female wrestler in which Joan Blondell will star.

A new organization of silk and rayon dyers and printers, comprising members of two former groups, is in process of formation and will put into effect the major recommendations submitted some months ago by General Hugh S. Johnson, former NRA Administrator.

The State Commission to Study the Economic and Social Conditions of New York's Urban Negro Population will hold its first meeting at 10 o'clock this- morning in the Bar Association Building, 36 West Forty-fourth Street, to appoint an executive director, assistant director and counsel. First testimony will be taken at a hearing within a month.

Daily average retail sales in small towns and rural areas during July showed a larger increase in the Far West than in any other part of the country, as compared with July, 1936, the Department of Commerce announced today.
Miss Frances Waitt entertained with a luncheon yesterday at the Weylin for Mrs. Louis Edmond Dean, the Misses Frances Godfrey, Dorothy Hilles and Virginia Randolph.

Appropriations made by the last session of Congress, including reappropriations and permanent appropriations, reached $10,252,892,556.60, and the net national debt was $38,590,293,658.98, as of June 30, according to tables compiled by Representative Taber, Republican, of New York, a member of the Appropriations Committee.

A petition asking law enforcement agencies to end "threats of violence" in the month-old Northern New York milk boycott was drafted here today by directors of the Sheffield Producers Cooperative Association.

The engagement of $1,847,000 of gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of this amount, $364,000 was bought in London yesterday and $1,483,000 on some previous day.

Corrington Gill, assistant administrator of the WPA, could save a lot of time and money if instead of trying to dig up new reasons for our abnormal unemployment he accepted those that are known to almost every American.

Gilbert Miller, theatrical producer, returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie after spending three months in London producing "Victoria Regina," "Yes, My Darling Daughter" and "Old Music." He said his first New York production would be "French Without Tears" and that he has engaged the Parisian actress, Jacqueline Porel, for the leading role.

Harlem was almost as dejected last night as when Joe Louis was knocked out by Max Schmeling. Lenox and Seventh Avenues wer crowded with about 75,000 Negroes between 115th and 145th Streets during and after the fight but most of them took the decision in favor of Louis in silence.

Recovery by easy stages yesterday lifted many leading stocks fractions to about 3 points. This improvement, together with the slight rise on Saturday, did not, however, completely nullify last Friday's drop in share prices.

Yorkshire today won the first-class county cricket championship for the nineteenth time since the inauguration in 1873, after the closest duel in many years. Yorkshire, which last won in 1935, defeated Hampshire and captured the title regardless of the outcome of the Middlesex-Surrey match ending tomorrow.

Operations of the steel industry are scheduled at 84.1 per cent of capacity this week, against 83.8 per cent last week, a gain of .3 point, or .35 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports. One month ago the rate was 85.5 per cent of capacity.

The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Aug. 27: Low, Commander F. S., staff of the Commander of Submarine Squadron 6, to Commander Submarine Division 13 and on board a submarine of that division.

Broadway's theatrical managers are prepared to rescind the wage cut taken by the stagehands' union in 1932, but only on the condition that the union drops its request for an increase in the scale for overtime, it was disclosed yesterday.

Two leading American Zionists, Robert Szold, former chairman' of the Zionist Organization of America, and Dr. Abba Hilel Silver of Cleveland, returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie after attending Jewish conferences in Europe.

Speaking at the concluding session of the World Lutheran Convention, Dr. Frederick H. Knubel of New York stressed Lutheran unanimity throughout the world. Bishop August Marahrens of Hanover, Germany, who presided at the Convention,

On condition that the cotton planter agrees to abide next year by whatever acreage reduction program is proposed by Congress and the Department of Agriculture, the Government will lend him up to 9 cents a pound against his crop this year. It will guarantee him, in addition, a price of 12 cents a pound on 65 per cent of this year's crop.

Despite advice from physicians, who were concerned over his temperature of 100 degrees, Charles Zimmy, legless Albany-to-New York swimmer, left Harlem Hospital yesterday, saying he would proceed with his plans to swim from Key West to Havana next Winter.

Arnold Moser retired lace and embroidery manufacturer, died yesterday at his home here after an illness of three weeks His age was 70. Mr. Moser was born in Switzerland and received a technical education in Zurich.

Fortune Gallo, director of the San Carlo Opera Company, and J. J. Shubert brought their season's productions of operettas and musical comedies to the closing week here tonight on the mammoth water stage on Zachs Bay with the presentation of Emmerich Kalman's gay comedy, "The Circus Princess." There were about 5,000 in the audience.

Charging that the prosecution had made a "Roman Holiday" of his case and that "behind the evidence there is personal bias and political ramifications," Scott Sanders, Jamaica attorney, opened his defense yesterday at the hearing into charges of unprofessional conduct filed against him by the Queens County Bar Association.

There is much local criticism of the Japanese naval authorities who, still persist in their refusals to permit foreigners to cross the Garden Bridge and enter the Hongkew and Yangtzepoo areas to learn-the fate of their homes and business properties there.

Joseph Harold McNamara, one of Canada's best professional hockey players more than two decades ago, died Saturday at Lima, Peru, according to word received by his family here. His age was 50. He had been engaged in construction work in Lima for two years.
John Kroner, Cleveland second baseman, made two successive errors today, but redeemed himself by driving in the winning run with a single to defeat the Senators, 7-6, in the ninth.

Mrs. Harold Ferris White of this city has announced the engagement of her niece, Miss Elaine Clark Buell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dexter C. Buell of Omaha, to Albert E. Koehl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert R. Koehl of Jersey City, N. J.

Paul Mellon, son of Andrew W. Mellon; his brother-in-law, David K. E. Bruce, and Donald D. Shepard, his father's attorney, were officially named today as trustees of the A. W. Mellon educational and charitable trust.

Miss Hope Gimbel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel, has completed plans for her wedding to David M. Solinger of New York, son of Mrs. Morris D. Solinger and the late Mr. Solinger, which will take place on Sept. 16 on the lawn of the Gimbel place here.

Request for confidential treatment of certain data filed under the Securities Exchange Act by additional companies has been denied by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Among the information made available was the following:
Wheat futures declined around 1 1/2 cents a bushel in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today to new low levels for the season, with scattered liquidation and stop-loss selling a factor.

John Dox of the Essex Parks Golf Club, Newark, shot a 73, three over par, to annex the qualifying medal in the third annual New Jersey State public links golf championship today at the Spring Brook Country Club.

The date of expiration for subscription warrants for purchase of bonds and common stock of the Follansbee Steel Corporation has been extended from Aug. 30 to Sept. 27 by order of the Federal Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania.
Royal S. Copeland, candidate for both the Republican and Democratic nominations for Mayor, injected yesterday into the local campaign the issues of the five-cent fare and the high cost of living.

A conference of Maritime Union representatives sponsored by John Is. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization opened here today with the objective of bringing maritime workers of all classes into one big industrial union under the C. I. O.

Eight residents of New York and vicinity and three from points in New Jersey were among the following passengers evacuated from Shanghai for Manila and Hong Kong aboard the steamer President Lincoln on Aug. 28, the State Department announced today:
The city Department of Health began yesterday its widespread surveillance of persons here who arrived recently on the German steamship Hansa. They may have been infected with typhoid when they

Dr. and Mrs. Leslie A. Spelman of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Alice Spelman, to Dr. Richard Bayliss Schutz of Kansas City, Mo., son of the Rev. and Mrs. Edward G. Schutz of Buffalo. N. Y.

The Interstate Commerce Commission informed Luther M. Walter, trustee of the Chicago Great Western Railroad Company on Aug. 24 that it had "no knowledge of any facts nor any information" pertaining to any "irregularities, fraud, misconduct or mismanagement" which

Pelham Parkway South (15-4330), s e cor of Lurting Ave, 105x157; Miriam Goldfarb to Kallenko Estates, Inc, 2,140 Williamsbridge Rd. Hoe Ave (11-2990), e s, 60 ft s of 174th St, 65x100; Louis Levy to Vahen Holding Corp, 1,355 Shakespeare Ave; mtg $69,000. Crotona Park North, 843 (11-2957); Joseph G. Hunt to Henry Sachs, 47 Vernon Place, Fleetwood, N. Y.; mtg $15,400.

To say that Freeport is all agog is to make a gross understatement. Since Robert Fisher of Great Neck hauled in a 502-pound tuna while fishing with Captain Buddy Merritt on Saturday, this Long Island town has gained a star position on the fishing map.

Former Alderman Lambert Fairchild and Norman C. Norman, an attorney, staged a two-man revolt last night against Mayor La Guardia's candidacy for the Republican Mayoralty nomination at a meeting of the Republican Club of the Seventh Assembly District, held at the clubhouse, 270 West Eighty-fourth Street.

John A. Sheeran, a member of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Slepack Co., died today at his residence, 351 Grove Street, after a long illness. A native of Brooklyn, he was educated in New York public schools.
Stocks closed higher in the second slowest trading day since April 1, 1935; turnover, 455,130 shares. United States Government and Japanese issues lower, with other bonds irregular;

Several aged Negroes who remember, as slave boys, how the shells whistled over Chappapela Creek in Louisiana during the Civil War, wracked long memories in the Surrogate's Court yesterday to recall the face of a pretty Southern belle who wore hoopskirts and called for new tunes at plantation balls.

A charge of bigamy against Flavel M. Williams was dropped by Judge W. A. Valentine today when the former navy captain and inventor was arraigned on a writ of habeas corpus to obtain his release from Luzerne County prison, where he had been held for a week in default of $10,000 bail.

The departure of reservists for the front is a daily event providing well-planned stimulation for the martial feelings of the public. One or two reservists leave each city block throughout Tokyo, doubtless throughout the country, every day.
Welsh miners in Tommy Farr's home town, Tonypandy, today hissed and booed the radio announcement that Joe Louis had beaten the one-time pit boy and then turned to cheering "Our Tommy."

Advices received here yesterday indicated the completion of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's foreign financing, consisting of the placement of about $30,000,000 debentures of the United River Plate Telephone Company, Argentine subsidiary, with Swiss and other foreign interests.

An injunction barring Transradio Press Service, Inc., from supplying broadcasting stations with a running description of the Tommy Farr-Joe Louis fight was granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora a short time before the scheduled start of the bout.

Aaron Sapiro, who was disbarred from practice in the Federal court of this district after contempt of court proceedings growing out of his alleged unethical conduct in a criminal case, filed a notice of appeal yesterday with the United States Circuit Court.

Highly selective operations were the rule in an extraordinarily dull session in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Domestic corporation loans held firm to slightly higher on the average, while United States Government obligations continued to drift to moderately lower levels.

Fire, discovered by a watchman, at 1:15 A. M., destroeyd stable Al at Belmont Park, L. I., early this morning. Fire apparatus from Elmont and Floral Park prevented the spread of the flames to adjoining structures.

The new eight-story HearnsNewark department store at Broad and Cedar Streets, Newark, has arranged a preview of the establishment for residents and public officials tomorrow evening from 7 to 9 o'clock preliminary to its formal opening for business on Thursday morning at 10 o'clock.

Mrs. Edna Chapin Close, president of Barnard-in-Westchester and life president of the class of 1905 of Barnard College, died here Saturday at her home, 53 Carswall Avenue. She was 57 years old. Mrs. Close had served as treasurer of the Visiting Nurses Association and had been active in other civil fields.
Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Roberts of Minneapolis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Florence Isabel Roberts Benson, to Samuel Walter Hawley of this city.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 11,000, including 2,000 directs. Market generally steady, spots 10 cents lower than Friday's average; top, $12; bulk good and choice 180-250 pound, $11.75-$12; comparable 260-300 pound, $11.50-$11.75;

The bombing of the American liner President Hoover by a Chinese airplane off Shanghai will undoubtedly increase the pressure now being brought to bear on the Administration by those who believe that the Neutrality Act should be invoked at once.

The Gloucester schooner Gertrude L. Thebaud, carrying Lieut. Commander Donald B. MacMillan and his Arctic expedition, put in here late today for a brief stay on the return trip from Labrador and the Arctic Circle regions.
More babies was the cure proposed for crop surpluses and unemployment tonight at the second general session of the National Conference of Catholic Charities.

A series of recommendations seeking further to reduce returns, which in the first six months of this year in the coat and suit industry amounted to $7,100,000 out of total volume of $106,000,000, or slightly under 6.7 per cent, was submitted yesterday to the executive council of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board at the opening session of its semiannual convention, and will be acted upon today.

Howard Mackenzie, president of the Bridgeport Public Market and of the Hartford Market Company and a resident of this city for many years, died yesterday at his home here after a long illness. His age was 72.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 28 unless specified: At Boston Yard, Arkansas. Wyoming. At Charleston Yard, Aug. 29, Badger, Herbert Leary. Manley. Tattnall, Tillman.

Donald Budge and Gene Mako went down in defeat today. The great California combination that had stood invincible against all comers on both sides of the Atlantic, that brought home the Davis Cup and the British championship and had not lost a match on turf all year, finally met its master in the team it had beaten twice in Europe.

A special public auction of unclaimed and abandoned merchandise, including champagne and straw hats, brought the Government $3,263 yesterday at the United States Customs Appraiser's Stores, 201 Varick Street.

Representatives of Corporation Counsel Paul Windels filed yesterday with Queens County Clerk Thomas Towers in'Jamaica orders signed by Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood directing the eviction of thirty owners from their properties in Whitestone and Flushing within the lines laid down for the Bronx-Whitestone bridge and its approaches.

All Panama paid tribute today to the late President Chiari, who died Aug. 16 in Los Angeles, when his body arrived on the liner Santa Paula today. The Canal Zone joined in the tribute and a squadron of United States Army airplanes escorted the ship to the pier while guns at Fort- Amador, named in honor of Panama's first President, fired a twenty-one gun salute.
The Stakhanoffites, Russia's high-production workers, were urged today to make their second anniversary an incentive for new output peaks in lagging factories and mines.

Two Californians, Donald Budge of Oakland and Miss Alice Marble of San Francisco, yesterday were seeded first in their respective divisions of the national amateur singles championship tournaments, which will get under way on Thursday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

Miss Elanor Carberry, 24, of New York City, was pulled to safety from the blazing wreckage of her airplane today when it crashed as she tried to land here. She was taken to Fairfield State Hospital with minor head injuries.
Sumner Welles, United States Under-Secretary or State, on his arrival here today denied reports that he had come to Europe to negotiate on the Far Eastern situation or on any official mission.

Winning the second race of the Eastern Yacht Club series today, Harold S. Vanderbilt's Ranger scored her twenty-fifth triumph of the Summer's formal racing for the America's Cup sloops. She has been beaten twice.

The City Island Board of Trade complained yesterday of a general paralysis of business caused by the Park Department's recently opened Orchard Beach development on Pelham Bay which has been hailed as a blessing by thousands of city residents enjoying its boating and bathing. and cooling breezes.

The Securities and Exchange Commission ruled today the General Management Corporation of Philadelphia had been so organized as to comply with requirements of the Public Utility Act. The corporation is a subsidiary of the States Electric and Gas Corporation of Philadelphia, a registered holding company.

Miss Jane Holzman, daughter of Mrs. Asher Holzman of 480 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Holzman, was married last night at the Sherry-Netherland to William J. Bratter, son of Mrs. David Bratter of 20 East Seventy-sixth Street and the late Mr. Bratter.
Until further orders from the Tifton Superior Court moviegoers here must refrain from booing commercial advertisements flashed upon the screen.

To offset the attacks of consumer groups and also the effect of the many Federal Trade Commission complaints and orders now being issued, the insurance of advertising claims may offer possibilities. A shampoo manufacturer has led the way. In a campaign just started the offer is made to remove dandruff with the first application, and Lloyd's of London backs the guarantee.

The bombing of the American Dollar liner President Hoover in China was as disagreeable to Great Britain as to the United States, for it showed that foreign lives and property were at the mercy of both sides in the Far Eastern war.

The writer today visited former Prince Nicholas's country estate at Snagov, thirty miles from Bucharest. He found it guarded by gendarmes whose obvious task is to prevent the entry not only of intruders but of the former owner should he appear.

8th Ave, 2,704; 25x100; Beddy Curry and Lloyd Maloof to Mary Ellis, 344 Northern Ave, due Sept. 1, 1938, 5 per cent; $6,600. West End Ave, 356, 19x46xirreg; Sarah R. Kelman to Gus Fuld, 55 West 42d St, 5 years, 5 per cent; $9.500. 74th St, 43 W, 20x102; Julia E. Ford to Marine Midland Trust Co ano, trustee, 5 years, 5 per cent; $12,000.

Holding both hands above his chest as if trying to push back an invisible weight, Joe Louis lay on the rubbing table in his dressing room after the fight. He was a disconsolate figure, and it was plain to see that he was far from satisfied with his showing against Tommy Farr.
The Span- ki ish Government, charging the Insurgents' capture of Santander was a victory for Italian soldiers, dedared today that foreign troops have created a "critical" situation for the defense.

A "sitdown" strike of union seamen on the freighter Wichita, China-bound, unless their demands for a $250 "war zone" bonus are granted before the ship leaves American waters, was predicted today by Ralph Emerson, legislative representative of the National Maritime Union, a C. I. O. affiliate.

The beautiful setting where King John granted the Magna Charta 700 years ago is to be fully preserved as a result of the purchase today of a halfmile frontage on the Thames River by the Buckinghamshire County Council.

An offering will be made today of 57,500 shares of $10-par value common stock of the Lionel Corporation, at $12 a share, by a group headed by Granbery, Marache c Lord, and including Emanuel Co. and A. C. Allyn Co.. Inc.

The W. T. Grant Company, department store chain, and its subsidiaries, reports a net profit of $1,394,976 for the six months ended July 31. This is after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and also after providing a reserve of $83,615 for the Federal surtax on undistributed profits.
A coordination of the bus lines of the New England Transportation Company, a subsidiary of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, and those of the New England Greyhound Lines, Inc.,
Miss Jean Newhall Willetts and Lieutenant Walter D. Coleman, U.S.N., whose engagement was announced in February, will be married on Oct. 2 in Trinity Church, Roslyn, L. I.
After one alarming splutter that seemed to check its flight, the Giant rocket zoomed into first place at the Polo Grounds yesterday on the impetus of a 4-3 victory over the Reds.

Major General Hugh A. Drum returned with his family yesterday from Hawaii on the army transport U. S. Grant. He said the islands' chief defense needs were provision for storing seed reserves on the island of Oahu, strategical capital of the Hawaiian Islands, an increase in "small farming" on the

Mount Sinai Hospital receives $918,579 from the estate of Marco Fleishman, leaf tobacco merchant, who died Feb. 17, 1936, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Mr. Fleishman's net estate, according to the appraisal, amounted to $1,170,482.

A permanent injunction was obtained today by the Securities and Exchange Commission in the United States District Court for the Western District of Virginia, at Harrisonburg, to prevent violation of the Securities Act of 1933 by Walter P. Spielberger, C. E. Wheeler and Roland H. Spielberger in the sale of oil royalty securities, the commission announced today.
The statement of condition of weekly reporting member banks in 101 bank leading cities, issued today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended on Aug. 25:

Captain Albert R. Francis, master of the Furness liner, Monarch of Bermuda, reported this morning on arrival from New York that he had neither seen nor heard anything of the square-rigged ships, Joseph Conrad and Seven Seas.

Jimmy Crowley began to play with his "blocks" again yesterday. Even though he has only four of the alleged granite variety this year, nevertheless he feels pretty certain that they will serve as a solid foundation for his contemplated structure.

Announcement was made here last night of the death last Thursday at Dublin, Ireland, of the Most Rev. Peter Elias Magennis, former Prior General of the Carmelite Order, who was president of the Friends of Irish Freedom in the World War period. Father Magennis died following an operation at the age of 69.
NEW AIDE TO CUMMINGS

Four high staff members of the Securities and Exchange Commission are to be the guests of the National Security Traders Association at its convention Sept. 8. 9. 10 and 11 at Atlantic City. They are David Saperstein, Sherlock Davis, John H. Kelley and C. H. Staples.

Although the number of buyers in the markets here yesterday was smaller than a week ago, sales showed a distinct improvement, as buying offices received a heavy volume of orders by mall. Resident office executives said stores in wide areas experienced good business on Friday and Saturday and were replenishing stock over the week-end.

Several authorities in their respective fields have been scheduled to address the New York Stock Exchange Institute at its Thursday morning lectures in the coming year. They will include Arthur A. Ballantine, former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury;
Mrs. Eunice Clark Rodman obtained a divorce here today from C. Selden Rodman of 315 Fourth Avenue, New York City, on charges of desertion. Mrs. Rodman will resume her maiden name of Clark.

There is a distinct possibility, even a probability, that Japan will continue a combined naval and military pushup the Yangtze River clear to Nanking. The decision in this matter, according to Japan, rests with China and depends- upon whether China will fundamentally change her attitude toward Japan.

Dr. Robert L. Thompson, a former superintendent of the Albany district of the Troy Conference of the Methodist Church and a former principal of the Troy Conference Academy at Poultney, Vt., died yesterday at his home in Dalton, Mass., after a short illness. He was pastor of the Dalton Methodist Church. His age was 65.

More than twenty letters and postcards seized in the Revere, Mass., apartment of Mrs. Esther Gordon, who was murdered here last Friday, were delivered early this morning to the Queens homicide squad by Police Inspector William C. Gibson of the Revere police.

The State will offer testimony here today in the County Court before acting County Judge Richard W. Hawkins and a jury in an effort to show that Percy C. Reed, proprietor, and Richard F. Roberts, racing secretary of the Nassau Kennel Club, are guilty of bookmaking and gambling in their conduct of greyhound races at the Mineola Fair grounds.

The New York Society for the Suppression of Vice urged a war on obscene magazines yesterday as an aid in checking sex crimes against children. The society said it had received numerous complaints that pornographic magazines and other objectionable literature were an incentive to such crimes.
Either the Finnish Inga Dill XXVI or the Norwegian Buri won a day's reprieve from elimination in the Scandinavian Gold Cup series for six-meter yachts today.

Dr. William F. Rienhoff, for many years prominent in Western surgical and medical circles, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 80. A graduate of the University of Berlin, Dr. Rienhoff took up the practice of surgery more than sixty years ago in Springfield, Mo., and practiced in Springfeild more than a half century.

Not since the sinking of the Lusitania showed that British supremacy at sea had been threatened by the ruthless and illegal use of the submarine has Britain's complacency been so shaken as it has been by the shooting of her Ambassador to China, Sir Hughe Montgomery KnatchbullHugessen.
