Mr. and Mrs. Willem Willeke gave a dinner and musical tonight at Mountain House, Pittsfield. Mrs. Charles L. Safford, contralto, of Williamstown, sang.

Authority to abandon its Attica Branch Line extending 10.67 miles between Batavia and Attica, N. Y., and to operate under trackage rights over the Erie Railroad line between the same points was granted to the New York Central Railroad today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

" The World's Natural Resources and Living Standards" is the subject of the conference of members and their guests at the International Industrial Relations Institute opening here today and last- I ing until Sept. 1.
The fear expressed yesterday that the murder of a bus passenger on the Jerusalem-Tel Aviv road was a signal for a new political murder campaign against Jews in Palestine already has been borne out.

Joe Louis and Tommy -Farr entered the ring simultaneously for their world heavyweight championship bout at the .Yankee Stadium last night, to the accompaniment of few cheers. These came in abundance later, when the warriors were introduced.

Robert W. Bingham, United States Ambassador to London, was amused today by reports from London that he had been asked by the State Department to surrender his London post because of his failure to notify Washington of the approach of the crisis that ended in the abdication of Edward VIII and his marriage to Mrs. Wallis Warfield.

Discovery of another supernova, a star that "commits suicide" by explodding, was announced today by Dr. Fritz-Zwicky, astrophysicist of California Institute of Technology. Dr. Zwicky said the star was invisible on a photograph made May 31, but subsequent search disclosed it on several other photographs

Formal notification of intention to negotiate a reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and Czechoslovakia was made today by Secretary Hull. The announcement listed the products on which this country would consider granting concessions.

John J. Quinn, a former Mayor and for many years a leader in civic affairs of this borough, died at his home today of a heart ailment at the age of 66. Mr. Quinn, prominently identified with the Democratic party here, served one two-year term as Mayor in 1934 and 1935.
Detroit's astounding spirit of enthusiasm in behalf of a lost cause produced another amazing spectacle today, which most anywhere else would surely have been nothing more than a blue Monday.

Announcement was made yesterday of the approaching marriage of Miss Mildred Barry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Barry of 31-20 Thirtieth Street, Astoria, Queens, to Bernard J. Ferguson of 144-23 Thirty-fifth Avenue, Flushing, Queens, which is set for Sept. 25 in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church Astoria.

Gross assets, $128,830; net, $98.482. To Pauline Baumann. widow, life estate in residue; Edith B. Baumann Benedict, Blanche Baumann Frank, daughters, and Walter S. Baumann, son, remainders in residue. Chief assets, mortgages. notes, cash and insurance, $51,057. Steckler, Frank Steckler, attorneys, 11 Broadway.
Carol Brentano, 10, member of the Brentano publishing family, died suddenly in Glens Falls Hospital late tonight from burns received Aug. 20 in the explosion of a speedboat on Lake George.

Sales of goods by both manufacturers and wholesalers showed increases in July over the corresponding month last year, but percentage of collections on accounts receivable were slightly lower, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Court action to determine whether under the Feld-Crawford act manufacturers may stipulate fixed tradein allowances or merely require "reasonable" trade-in allowances, is contemplated by retail groups as a means of halting the wave of sales in disregard of fixed allowances which has assumed the proportions of a price war, it was learned yesterday.

President Roosevelt today signed the bill providing for a registration of the unemployed on the understanding that there would be no compulsion or house-to-house canvass. The President and the Administration forces, while unable to stop the bill adopted by Congress, were able to prevent the passage of a real census bill.

Luncheon, Lions Club, Hotel Astor, 12:30 P. M. Address by Senator Lester H. Clee. Metropolitan Museum of Art, "Digging Into the Past; Daily Life of the Egyptians," motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "The Egyptian Collection," Margaret B, Freeman, 4 P. M.
The decline in automobile production last week was smaller than allowed for seasonally, and the adjusted index has moved up to 155.2 from 147.5. It was 96.8 for the week ended Aug. 29, 1936.

Mrs. Ellen T. Mangan of 45-40 Eleventh Street, Long Island City, widow of James F. Mangan, died early yesterday in St. John's Hospital, Long Island City, at the age of 74, after a long illness. Mrs. Mangan's husband was custodian of the Queens County Court House in Long Island City for twenty-six years.
Hug Conway, 67, railroad towerman, threw the last lever and retired today with a half century record of "not a nickel's worth of damage" on tracks his switches and semaphores controlled.

The mystery of eight starlings that fell dead together while flying over Fifth Avenue between Twentyninth and Thirtieth-Streets Sunday morning was partly solved yesterday when the A. S. P. C.A. determined that the birds were not poisoned.

Domestic retail sales of Buick cars in the second ten days of August totaled 5,612 units, against 6,144 deliveries in the second ten days of July and 5,359 in the second ten days of August, 1936. For the first twenty days of the month sales were 11,510 units, against 12,238 in the July period and 9,013 in the first twenty days of August, 1936.

Democratic voters of the Second Assembly District were threatened with the loss of WPA jobs if they declined to sign petitions designating candidates for county committee posts who are favorable to Representative Christopher D. Sullivan, it was charged yesterday at a hearing before Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente.

A seven-State alarm was broadcast yesterday morning by the police for two young boys who had been missing since Sunday afternoon, when they left their home in Brooklyn after being locked in a room by their grandmother for taking 25 cents from her purse.

Cardinal Gaetano Bisleti, prefect of the Congregation of Seminaries and of the University of Studies, died tonight at Grotta Ferrata, a small town about twenty miles from Rome where he was vacationing. His age was 81. His death brings the number of Sacred College vacancies to five.

A 5,000,000-peso credit has been opened for the Government by banks here to aid in marketing of cotton by Government-managed collective farms in North-Central La Laguna region. The Government first asked 15,000,000 pesos but later reduced its request.

The condition of Mrs. Harriet Cusick, 28 years old, who was allegedly shot by her husband, William, in front of their home at 5 Walnut Street, South Farmingdale, early Saturday morning, was said to be improved in Meadow Brook Hospital here tonight after her right leg was amputated.

Trading opened more active in the wholesale markets than in several Mondays. Steer beef, though somewhat uneven, was generally steady to higher on grain feds. Lamb prices were strong to higher and fresh pork steady to lower. Veal and calf sold unevenly. Early trading in kosher meats indicated prices to be slightly stronger than last Friday's opening market, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Asserting that absolute neutrality would take "the dollar signs off our battle flags forever," and that the modern armament race threatened civilization, Senator Vandenberg of Michigan today outlined a four-point policy he told the annual encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars would "Insulate" the United States from war.
Seven Japanese bombing planes attacked the fortified area outside Canton soon after dawn today and dropped two bombs on gun emplacements at Shaho near the airdrome. The bombs did little damage.

Twenty-five thousand posters warning motor ists that their licenses will be suspended for seven days if they exceed forty-five miles an hour at night or at any time of day when pavements are wet are being distributed throughout the State, Frank A. Goodwin, Registrar of Motor Vehicles, announced today.
Major Thomas S. Martin, for - the last forty-four years secretary of the Fairmount Park Commission, died today at his home in the park after a heart attack. He was 75 years old.

Miss Marion Thorp Little, daughter of Mrs. Edward H. Little of Boston, was married here Saturday afternoon in St. Paul's Church to Dr. David Woolfolk Barrow, son of Mrs. D. W. Barrow of New Haven. Conn.

THE boxers had weighed in for the big bout and everything was set except the weather. Promoter Mike Jacobs went out to the curb to take an upward and disapproving glance at some threatening clouds and said: "There's nothing to do except wait."
St. Louis at New York--Weiland v. Castleman. Chicago at Brooklyn--Carleton vs. Frankhouse. Cincinnati at Boston--Grissom vs. MacFayden.

Patrolman George Mackey of Traffic D disarmed Dominick Jiaquinto yesterday in the I. R. T. station in the Chrysler Building and, after a tussle watched by scores of subway users, arrested him on charges of robbery, assault and violation of the Sullivan law.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Mrs. Gail Kingsley Ward, widow of J. Carlton Ward of this city, to Dr. Milton E. Dickerman of Whitneyville, Conn.

While their countrymen were fighting in the Orient, Chinese and Japanese delegates to the Friends World. Conference greeted one another with handshakes and words of good-will today at Swarthmore College.

A special Department of Commerce committee under Captain George Fried completed its questioning yesterday of thirty-five members of the crew of the seagoing ferry carrier Seatrain, Havana, who are charged by the American Steamship Owners Association with insubordination because they failed to take the ship out on Aug. 18.
Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, returned yesterday on the Normandie after a vacation spent in Florence, Italy, where he has a villa, and in Paris and London.

MANHATTAN ADLER, ANNA E. (April 26, 1937). Gross assets, $34,405; net. $28,713. To Simon Adler, husband, household, personal effects and residue; Sylvia Adler, daughter, $5,000, jewelry and specific household effects: Beatrice Proops, daughter, $2,000 and specific jewelry;

Begun already is the season of State fairs, county fairs, town fairs. In the last variety New Hampshire, providently hoping to catch the lingering tourist, has hurried up some of its dates. We love best the old term, "cattle show."
James C. Davis of Des Moines, who was Director General of the United States Railroad Administration after the World War, died here early this morning. He would have been 80 years old on Thursday.

In his first address here since becoming president of Yale University, Dr. Charles Seymour said to the New Haven Rotary Club today, in an address on "Political Impressions of Europe," that hope of continental peace existed.

More than fifty new laws become effective today, including statutes permitting jury service by women, barring hasty marriages, allowing five-sixths jury verdicts in civil cases and tightening prohibitions against payroll envelope coercion in political campaigns.

A proposal that all persons who wish to marry undergo a civil ceremony before asking the blessing of the church was made yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Howard Chandler Robbins, Professor of Pastoral Theology at General Theological Seminary, upon his return from abroad on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.
Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Regent of Hungary, left Austria today, crossing Lake Constance to Switzerland. Contrary to rumors he did not go to Berchtesgaden, Germany, to see Chancellor Hitler.

Manhattan Alterations Mott St, 260; to 5-story tenement and store; Antonio Gulli, premises, owner; W. C. Sommerfeld, architect; cost $15,000. 58th St, 442 E; to 4-story dwelling; Norman Dodd, 432 E 58th St, owner; S. Talcott, architect: cost $3,000. 12th St, 18 W; to 3-story residence: W. B. Osgood Field Jr, premises. owner; Wil- 2 liam Lescaze, architect; cost $5,000.
A reinforced Japanese Army in North China is awaiting orders for a concentrated drive against Chinese forces barring the way south to China's defense line along the Yellow River.

The Forty Niners presented the final play of their fifth season tonight, George Haight and Allan Scott's comedy, "Goodbye Again," before one of the largest audiences of the Summer at the Chase Barn Playhouse. The presentation was the group's fortieth production before White Mountain audiences.

The Tennessee Valley Authority announced today that it had signed a contract for sale of electricity to the Electro Metallurgical Company, which plans to build a plant near Wilson Dam in Alabama. The company was described as a subsidiary of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation.

The marriage of Miss Helene Madden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Coleman Francis Madden of 19 East Eighty-eighth Street and Northport, L. I., to Joseph Michael Stehlin, son of Mrs. Joseph Stehlin, also of this city, and the late Mr. Stehlin, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.

One thousand service employes of the William Penn and Fort Pitt hotels struck tonight a few hours after the hotel managements signed contracts granting exclusive bargaining rights to two A. F. of L. unions.

A common carrier is not the insurer of the safety of its passengers and its drivers are not bound to anticipate violation of the law by others, according to William A. Porteous Jr. of New Orleans, Southern counsel for the Greyhound Lines. He addressed the closing session of the annual convention of the Federation of Insurance Counsel, an organization of lawyers, in the Hotel Chelsea today.
Roberts Everett, a New York publicist and writer, obtained a divorce today from Mrs. Evelyn Clay Everett. An agreement was made for support of a daughter, Helen, 18 years old.
The list of possible starters in the Gold Cup speed boat race on Labor Day was raised to ten today with the entry of J. C. Fisher's Miss Cincinnati Jr.
The management of the New York World's Fair has effected savings of $160,000 in the cost of constructing the Administration Building, it became known yesterday.

For the fifth consecutive week crude oil production in the United States last week reached a new high level. The American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday that the daily average gross output of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,731,450 barrels, an increase of 2,100 over the 3,729,350 of the preceding week.

The recently enacted law requiring municipal employes to be residents of the city will not apply to the public school personnel, according to an opinion of the Corporation Counsel announced yesterday at the Board of Education.

Military adventure on the scale of Japan's present invasion of China is an expensive business, and it is not surprising that the Japanese Parliament has been sunumoned to meet this week in special session.

Several-members of the resort colony entertained at dinners this evening before the weekly cabaret at the Bar Harbor Club. Henry H. Ellison 3d of Philadelphia was host to a large group at a dinner at the club. His guests included Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Howard, Mrs. Warren Ingersoll,
Frank Pritchard, 25-year-old Buffalo lifeguard, won the Canadian national exhibition's annual marathon swim for the second year in succession today.

WHEN a very rich man dies, it is usually pretty hard to decide whether or not he is going to heaven. There are, of course, authorities ready to say both no and yes, some pointing to a famous passage in Holy Writ, others to a catalogue of oil paintings, girls' dormitories and other public gifts. But the question itself is not so lightly settled.

About 270 delegates from twentythree foreign countries joined with scores of American Quakers today in informal discussions preliminary to the Friends' World Conference which begins formally tomorrow evening at Swarthmore and Haverford Colleges.
Once more we have searched the Arctic for Sigismund Levanevsky and his party. Yesterday we flew over the ice as far as Lat. 80 degrees 30 minutes N. and Long. 135 degrees W. in fairly clear weather.

Affidavits of fellow passengers tonight indicated Norman G. Harris, an American resident of Shanghai, leaped overboard to his death yesterday shortly before this American liner was bombed by Chinese planes.

In play and opera the Soviet Union will commemorate the Bolshevist revolution of twenty years ago in its fifth theatre festival, opening tomorrow night. The first performance of the tenday festival, which again has attracted hundreds of tourists, including many Americans, will be devoted to folk music, songs and dances of the various national republics in the Soviet Union.
Governor Frank Murphy, described by a physician as "just tired out," entered the University of Michigan Hospital today for several days of rest and observation.
Reports that a large building eration was in prospect for the Forty-eighth Street block between Sixth and Seventh Avenues have gained credence with the announcement of another deal in that block.

Demanding the return of the halfdollars they had invested in a round-trip voyage from the Battery to Keansburg, N. J., fifteen passengers refused for more than an hour to leave the excursion steamboat City of New York last night.
Five peace societies formed today a joint board of strategy to direct public opinion in the direction of invoking the Neutrality Act by a Presidential declaration that a state of war exists in China.

With the acceptance of a report today by Vice President Matthew Woll, the executive council of the American Federation of Labor completed the last formality for the federation's re-entry into the International Federation of Trade Unions, which it left before the World War.

The prosecution attempted to prove that a "synthetic" pari-mutuel wagering system was in operation at the Mineola dog track as its first witnesses were called today in the trial of Nassau Kennel Club officials on gambling charges. The trial is being held before Acting County Judge Richard W. Hawkins and a jury.

More than 12,500 employes of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company will receive checks today for sums totaling $885,000, or one-half of $1,770,000 they contributed to the company's old pension fund under an agreement signed in 1934.

Senator Royal S. Copeland, candidate for both the Republican and Democratic nominations for Mayor, said yesterday that he did not expect to run as an independent candidate for Mayor if he is defeated in the two primaries by Mayor La Guardia and Jeremiah T. Mahoney.

Dr. and Mrs. Dudley Roberts will give a dinner for their week-end house guests, Mr. and Mrs. F. Luis Mora, on Friday evening before Miss Cornelia Otis Skinner's appearance at Guild Hall in her solodrama, "The Loves of Charles II."

Turnentlne firm 31 3/4c: sales, 188 barrels; receipts 767 barrels; shipments, 2,983 barrels; stock, 33,489 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 481; receipts, 2.609 shipments. 10,789: stock. 57.458. Quote: B. $7.80; D, E, F. G, $7.85; H, $7.90; I, K., M, $7.95; N, $8.00; WG. $8.05: WW. X. $8.65.

Establishment of permanent machinery for stabilization activities which this season brought price increases of $1 a garment on most of the popular-price coats manufactured in this market, was voted yesterday by the executive council of the National Cloak and Suit Industry Recovery Board, which concluded its convention at the Hotel New Yorker.

The Rev. Dr. Henry J. Johnston, superintendent of the Paterson district of the Newark Methodist Episcopal Conference from 1924 to 1930, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home here, where he had been living since April, when he retired as pastor of Grace Church, Kearny. He was 67 years old.

Seventy wholesale bakery concerns, their trade association and some of its officers, a group of flour manufacturers and a service company were accused of violating the RobinsonPatman act through unlawful payment and acceptance of brokers' fees, in a complaint issued by the Federal Trade Commission today.

Led by John Dox, the medalist, five representatives of the Essex Parks Golf Club of Newark marched into the third round of the third annual New Jersey State public links championship today at the Spring Brook Country Club.

For the first time since February, 1937, the average bid price for 250 real estate issues used in the Eli T. Watson real estate bond index showed an increase during August. The bonds are secured by properties in thirty-nine cities and fourteen States.

Smoke Ejector and Foamite Truck 1, made of spare parts by Fire Department artificers who toiled more than a year on the job, was displayed yesterday at 87 Lafayette Street, headquarters of Engine Company 31.

Leading a field of sixty-eight contestants, Mrs. Sylva Annenberg, Long Island match play champion, scored 41, 41-82, equaling the women's competitive record in the metropolitan women's one-day tournament at the Hempstead Golf Club today.

Official announcement of the provisions under which the Government will extend loans to cotton producers this year failed yesterday to halt the general downward Movement in prices which has been under way for several weeks. New low prices since October, 1933, were recorded on the Cotton Exchange, and, under a large volume of business, quotations lost $1 a bale, to close 14 to 21 points lower than on Monday.

The marriage of Miss Mary Mowry Spear to Lieutenant Frederick S. Rooney, U. S. N., will take place Sept. 11 at the Naval Academy chapel. Miss Dorcas Tuck will be Miss Spear's maid of honor. The bridesmaids will be the Misses Anne Claude Howard of Augusta, Cary Melvin of Annapolis and Virginia Turner of Washington.

Having decided that motorists put a higher value on comfort than on traffic regulations, officials here, under orders of the Council, will rip up a smooth pavement on a curve in the city's residential section,

Tony Sarausky, former Fordham luminary, took over the spotlight as the New York Giants today held a double practice session at the Blue Hill C. C., where they are preparing to meet the Eastern College AllStars on Sept. 8.
Investment Activity

An Army amphibian Douglas-Dolphin plane with five men on board was being towed here tonight after it had been forced down and had drifted in a foggy sea for four hours about eighteen miles south of Montauk Point, L. I.

Two bench warrants have been issued for the arrest of important figures in the vice ring alleged to have been operating in Atlantic City, Philadelphia and Wilmington, Del., and others will be drawn in the near future, it was revealed yesterday by William Smith, assistant Federal Attorney in Trenton, N. J.

Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Edward B. Smith Co. will be joint underwriters of the new stock financing projected by the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company to yield proceeds of about $30,000,000, it was learned yesterday in Wall Street.
Several hundred people visited nine private gardens here today, which were thrown open to the public under auspices of the woman's auxiliary of St. Luke's Episcopal Church of Noroton.

The ratio of excess reserves to reserve requirements of twenty-one large banks in this city fell from around 45 per cent at the endn of February to between 2 and 6 per cent in August, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in a discussion of the money market in its current monthly review issued yesterday.

Leonard M. Thomas, formerly of Philadelphia, long a Summer resident of this city and a legal resident of the city since October, died suddenly at his home, Brick House, on Red Cross Avenue, this afternoon from a heart attack. He was 60 years old.

The French Foreign Ministry was reported today to be indignant over the recent "fraternity of arms" telegrams exchanged by Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy and General Francisco Franco, leader of the Spanish Insurgents.

Russell R. Brown, president of the American Commercial Alcohol Corporation, announced yesterday that the corporation and its affiliate, the American Distilling Company, but not the Kessler Chemical Corporation, had agreed to transfer all of their business and

Three thugs who displayed no pistols held up a 58-year-old messenger at noon yesterday and escaped with a $2,000 payroll of the Lord Taylor department store intended for employes at the company's warehouse 331 East Thirtv-eighth Street.

Peace conferences in the strike of 15,000 painters in the city were broken off for the second time in two days last night when the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, District Council No. 9, and the Master Painters Association were unable to agree on a union demand for shop control.

Perhaps cats are not the only creatures entitled to the reputation of having anywhere from one to nine lives. Chow Chow, a 1-yearold chow dog, or his master may have something to say about this in a few days.

Talluiah Bankhead, actress and daughter of Speaker William B. Bankhead of the national House of Representatives, was married here tonight to John Emery, New York actor. She was given in marriage by her father.

Captain Neville Cumming, commander of the Imperial Airways plane Cavalier, arrived this afternoon from Port Washington, L. I., reported sighting a black-hulled, square-rigged ship, presumably the Joseph Conrad, at 11:45 A. M. Eastern standard time, about 200 miles from New York. Light northerly winds prevailed at that time, Captain Cumming said.
Twirling eight hitless innings, Danny MacFayden today hung up his eleventh victory of the season and seventh in eight starts as the Bees took the series opener from the Reds, 7 to 2.

Delegates representing organized women, organized youth and students and graduates of 150 colleges will gather in this city next month to attend the seventh annual Forum on Current Problems of The New York Herald Tribune under the theme "The Second Discovery of America."

Miss Laura Eugenie LaFond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest LaFond of North Smithfield, was married here this afternoon in the Church of the Holy Family to Seward Wright Livermore, son of Mrs. Seward Bucknam Livermore of Cambridge, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Arthur Gervais, assistant pastor.

At a meeting with Arturo Toscanini members of the Salzburg Festival management today decided to produce Wagner's "Tannhaeuser" under Mr. Toscanini at next Summer's festival, barring unforeseen delays in the reconstruction of the Festspielhaus.
Confronted with one of the worst outbreaks of infantile paralysis in twenty years, Chicago authorities postponed indefinitely tonight the opening of public and parochial schools.

Trading in cow and bull was slow: lamb only fair other classes fair. The veal market was higher steer cuts steady to higher; lamb about steady; other classes steady. Early trading in kosher meats was steady on all classes. as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

An investing client of the Robert R. Rainey Company has purchased for cash from A. E. Crawford, trustee of the estate of James A. MacDonald, the four-story dwelling and store at 85 Murray Street, on a lot 23.5 by 50 feet. The assessed valuation is $21,000, of which $18,000 is on the land. This is the first change in ownership for the property in twenty-nine years.

Once in rippling Kipling rhyme Rudyard sang in his good time Of a stubborn gallant fighter that he knew; So for Thomas Farr today, May'I borrow Kipling's lay? And, Thomas, here's my best respects to you!

David C. Brandt of Schenectady, N. Y., tied for third place in the Camp Perry Instructors' rifle match with Clarence Ripley of Dennison, Ohio, and Walter H. Shanessey of Brooklyn when each had a possible score of 50, with 5 Vs in the center ring of the bullseye today.
Seiyukai [political party] leaders at a meeting last night decided to ask the Government during the special session of Parliament to state its objectives in China.

The construction of two new school buildings has been delayed by the refusal of union plasterers to work under specifications calling for concrete instead of plastered ceilings in classrooms, it learned yesterday.

It is understood that Senator Arturo Bocchini, head of the Italian police, who is now in Berlin, has completed arrangements to protect Premier Benito Mussolini during the visit he expects to pay Chancellor Adolf Hitler in the near future.
Appropriations in the last session of Congress, Representative Cannon of Missouri, acting chairman of the House Committee on Appropriations, declared today, totaled $9,355,595,892.57.
Weber Heilbroner, Inc., opens today its new store at Fifty-seventh Street and Madison Avenue, which was leased several months ago and has been extensively altered and redecorated.

American travelers aboard this bombed liner told today of their hairbreadth escape from death when the peace of the afternoon tea hour yesterday was suddenly blasted by a squadron of four Chinese air raiders.

Miss Gladys M. Freeman gave a dinner last night on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis for Miss Muriel Gordon and her fiance, Bard Pendleton Rogers, who will be married on Sept. 18. Other guests included the bride-elect's parents, Mr. and Mrs. J. Holdsworth Gordon Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Clarence C.

Wampus, the John Magee estate in North Castle and New Castle, Westchester County, has been sold to Eldon Bisbee. The property comprises 185 acres of land with a twenty-seven-room residence, five cottages, a greenhouse and a farm building.

In the presence of 300 persons, including William S. Knudsen, president, and other officials of General Motors, four boys received $5,000 scholarships tonight for winning models in the seventh annual competition of the Fisher Body Craftsman's Guild.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized a protective committee of holders of common Stock of the Chicago North Western Railway to Intervene in the carrier's pending reorganization proceedings.

It was announced tonight that Prime Minister Mackenzie King had sent a written reply to Premier Aberhart's declaration that his Government would force the Alberta banks to institute social credit despite disallowance by Ottawa of Alberta legislation to that end.
Last week's heat and humidity had no apparent adverse effect on the general city death rate or on the infant death rate, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, reported yesterday.

An unidentified man leaped last night from the municipal ferryboat Queens as she was passing Robbins Reef Lighthouse, one mile off St. George, S. I. The man had boarded the boat at Whitehall Street a few minutes before it left at 8 o'clock.

National Socialist group leaders from seven foreign countries today described their work among their compatriots at the Congress of Germans Living Abroad. Another group of leaders representing seafarers spoke enthusiastically of the spirit of unity and loyalty to the Fuehrer that sailors under the swastika flag were manifesting everywhere.

Over a breezeless, idle ocean, Ranger drifted to victory today. They called it a race, the third in the Eastern Yacht Club's series for the America's Cup sloops, but only twelve miles were covered, and it took Harold S. Vanderbilt's ordinarily fleet cup defender 3 hours 32 minutes 26 seconds to negotiate them.

Fire Commissioner, John J. McElligott, in promoting fifty-seven firemen yesterday in his office in the Municipal Building, told them they owed it to the taxpayers who approved the three-platoon system to work for the best disciplined and trained fire department in the world.
Richard E. Weber, well known in Brooklyn Republican circles, who was head of the Medical Tea Company, founded by his father, died on Monday at his home, 1,014 Bushwick Avenue, at the age of 65.

Mrs. Donald B. Sinclair gave a dinner this evening at her home here, at which she announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Alice Crosby 'Sinclair, to - Peter Aston Schwartz, eldest son of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Schwartz of Wynnewood, Pa.

Stockholders of the Hawaiian Pineapple Company approved today plans to raise $14,451,520 new capital. Sale of preferred stock will provide $10,000,000, while $4,451,520 will come from a sale of common stock.
In 1932, at the low point of the depression, when Germany was still powerless abroad and threatened with civil strife at home, she appeared to be prostrate politically and economically.

The Little Entente conference ended today at Sinaia with all differences smoothed out. The final communique stressed as usual the solidarity of the three member States, Czechoslovakia, Rumania and Yugoslavia;

A longrange program of agricultural reconstruction, Federally financed and nationally coordinated "down to the county" for continuing action according to basic regional plans, was recommended today by Harry

Class I railroads had a net railway operating income of $357,899,351 in the first seven months of this year, an increase of 19.4 per cent over that of the corresponding period of 1936, the Association of American Railroads announced today on the basis of reports from 138 roads operating a total of 235,872 miles.

Mr. and Mrs. John Lord Boatwright' of 829 Park Avenue have announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of Mrs. Boatwright's daughter, Mrs. Clara Barclay Gilbert of Hewlett, L. I., to Paul Frederick Bubendey of this city and Cedarhurst, son of Mrs. Rudolf Epple of Brooklyn and of the late Karl Frederick Bubendey. The wedding will take place on Oct. 15 in this city.

The first twenty-seven families moved yesterday into their new apartments in Harlem River Houses, PWA low-rent housing project at 153d Street and the Harlem River. In many cases the tenants, all of whom came from "substandard" living quarters, were on hand ahead of time in happy mood to await the arrival of their household goods.
To DRINK OR NOT TO DRINK, by Charles H. Durfee. (Longmans, Green, $2.) On alcohol and its effects. 16 RUE CORTAMBERT, by Anne Green. (Dutton, $2.50.) A light novel of Paris.

riage of Miss Elizabeth Manly Whedbee to George Webb Constable, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Pepper Constable, will take place Oct. 1 in the Catholic Shrine of the Sacred Heart, Mount Washington, Baltimore.

Gloucestershire defeated Nottinghamshire as the county cricket season closed today, while Lancashire and Warwickshire won on the first innings only. Surrey won on the first innings from Middlesex, which trailed Yorkshire by a narrow margin for the county title.
Five persons were killed and twentyseven others were injured today when a crowded Greyhound bus bound from Chicago to Cleveland hit a large sedan at an intersection five miles east of here.
Joseph Maniscalco's preference for long underwear, even on a hot day such as yesterday, saved him $6,700. Maniscalco, 60 years old, a druggist, was able to laugh at four thugs.

The outstanding money market developments in August were the reductions of the rediscount rates of six of the Federal Reserve Banks. Open-market quotations of call and time money, bankers' bills and commercial bills were unchanged through the month.

Captain George E. T. Eyston of London, who has set more records with different types of automobiles than any other driver in the world, arrived yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania for another series of attempts to lower the existing standards for various long-distance tests.

The Air Reduction Company, Inc., has acquired two subsidiaries of the Coca-Cola Company, both of which make and sell liquid carbon dioxide, it was revealed yesterday when the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange approved an application of Air Reduction to list 36,790 additional shares of common stock.

Scott Sanders, Jamaica attorney, who is receiving a hearing into charges of unprofessional conduct filed against him by the Queens County Bar Association, occupied the witness stand throughout yesterday's session, denying that he had ever employed "runners" or given money to policemen for recommending cases.

Visitors to the exhibition of "degenerate art" here reached the million mark today. Paintings and statuary pronounced "decadent, disgusting and degenerate" by official word of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's mouth attracted more visitors than the art exhibition officially sponsored by the National Socialist party.
Maurice Manasse anounoed yesterday the formation of Manasse Co. to act as brokers in tax-exempt and other high-grade securities.

In connection with its program to prevent large retail buying groups from forcing manufacturers to make unwarranted concessions, the Dress Returns Bureau, in a letter sent to members yesterday, announced the extension of its "control system" for the Fall season through which

In order to provide more than 100 per cent additional floor space for his business, to take care of expansion needs, Louis H. Clark of the Famous Paper Box Company and the Interboro Container Corporation has leased the five-story and basement building at 113-21 West Twentieth Street through Spear Co., acting for the trustees of Series F-1 of the New York Title and Mortgage Company.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-By GEORGE H. ATKINSON, consulting engineer. 137 W. 38th St.-Liabilities $104,986, no assets except securities listed as worthless and insurance. Principal creditors listed are Conlew, Inc., $35,074 on judgment claims; County Trust Co., $11,878, also on judgments.

115th St, 114 E, 25x100.11; Uxors Corp, Louis Zubar, pres. to New York Savings Bank; p m, 5 years, 4 per cent; $24,500. 121st St, 345 W, 16x100.11: Eugenia J. Alves to Ulric C. Morgan, 676 St Nicholas Ave; p m, installs, 6 per cent; $1,000. 122d St, 265 W, 20x100.11; Geo Tesla and Thomas Geogas to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; p m, 5 years, interest as per bond; $4.000.
Steel ingot production was unchanged last week in face of an upward seasonal trend, and the adjusted index was eased to 130.3 from 131.4. It was 112.8 for the week ended Aug. 29, 1936.

Ruffed grouse must maintain a wary watch for hunters if New York's conservation officials follow the almost unanimous advice against a closed season expressed today by representatives of sportsmen's clubs in twenty-five counties.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "Mass Purchasing Power" omits some rather important considerations. At least three focal problems of significance can be listed: (1) Increase in the national income through increased productivity;

The extreme tension that has prevailed here for three days is increasing and some fear a repetition of last Summer's disturbances. A 55-year-old Arab was found shot today near Haifa and died soon after in a hospital.

After a week's sifting of evidence, Surrogate Foley ruled yesterday that the late Mrs. Ida E. Wood, wealthy Herald Square recluse, was born Ida Ellen Walsh, daughter of an immigrant English-Irish family that settled in Malden, Mass., shortly before the Civil War.

John I. M. Hamilton, Chairman of the republicann National Committee, called upon the Democratic party day to support an amendment to ie Corrupt Practices Act by which he raising of campaign funds rough the sale of books to cororations would be prohibited.

The Wellington Foundation, Inc., Philadelphia, an investment trust, of which Alvin J. Wilkins is president, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering the issuance of 22,914 of Wellington Foundation trust certificates for an aggregate of $25,000,200.

The program of the ninth congress of the National Socialist party, opening at Nuremberg Sept. 6, was announced today. Chancellor Adolf Hitler is again down for nine formal speeches, not counting extemporaneous interludes which have become features of these gatherings.
Deaths exceeded births in France by 19,000 during the first six months of this year, according to official statistics just issued, showing that the population continues to decline.

A distress warrant for the sale of property belonging to the Rev. R. Anderson Jardine to pay [Pound]9 10s 8d in overdue rates (taxes levied by local authorities) was issued today by magistrates at Darlington, Durham.

Harry Moses, producer of the Pulitzer prize-winning play, "The Old Maid," and co-producer, with Howard Shumlin, of "Grand Hotel," died last night at his home, 105 East Fifty-third Street, of a heart ailment. He was 64 years old.

Federal Judge Philip L. Sullivan approved today a settlement under which members of a syndicate holding stock of the Central Republic Trust Company paid $200,000 on their liability to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

It will be welcome news to motorist and pedestrian alike that on and after Oct. 1 bicycles will come under the provisions of the Traffic Law in this State. In many sections of the country, notably the Middle West, there has been a marked growth of late in the use of the vehicle so popular at the turn of the century.
The Webster Cigar Company yesterday signed a contract under the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act, establishing minimum resale prices on all of its cigar brands.

John Hughes Curtis, Norfolk, Va., shipbuilder, who was convicted in Flemington, N. J., five years ago of perpetrating a hoax in connection with the Lindbergh kidnapping, has applied to the New Jersey Court of Pardons for a full pardon, it became known tonight.
The attempt by Japanese planes to bomb Canton today brings the war for the first time to South China, and Chinese commentators observe that Japan is determined to intimidate the whole of China.

Frank Cavanna, 145 1/2, east side, stopped Johnny Horstman, 146 1/2, east side, in 1:03 of the fifth round at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx before 5,000 spectators last night when Referee Frank Fullan intervened.

The situation in the Six-Meter yachting series for the Scandinavian Gold Cup remained in statu quo for the second straight day as lack of wind on Long Island Sound today prevented the holding of the third race in the international competition.
State Labor Commissioner John J. Toohey Jr. announced today approval of minimum wage rates for the laundry industry in New Jersey and ordered them to be effective Sept. 6.
Jeremiah T. Mahoney, candidate of the Roosevelt wing for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, last night termed his opponent. Senator Royal S. Copeland, the candidate of the Liberty League.

St. Louis at New York-Warneke vs. Smith or Schumacher. Chicago at Brooklyn-Davis vs. Henshaw. Pittsburgh at Philadelphia-Bauers vs. Passeau. Cincinnati at Boston (2)-Schott and Derringer vs. Fette and Hutchinson.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Standard Steel Spring Company has been called for Sept. 8 to consider reclassification of authorized capital into 12,500 shares of $100 par preferred stock and 287,500 shares of common stock.
Army Medical officers said today they were preparing 300,000 doses of a new anti-pneumonia vaccine to be tested on volunteering members of the Civilian Conservation Corps.
Unemployment is still the greatest single problem facing our Government. Upon it depends, among other things, the size of the relief burden and the fate of the Federal budget.
Professor Herman Diederichs, dean of engineering at Cornell University, died this afternoon at Clifton Springs Sanitarium. He was 63 years old. He became dean of the college last year.

Using its power to govern by decree for the last time, for these special powers expire tonight at midnight, the French Cabinet today set up the National Railway Company, for the eventual fusing of the six big systems of the country.

Business failures increased in four divisions in the week ended Aug. 26, compared with the figures for the corresponding period last year, but there was a slight decline in the retail group, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 30. unless specified: Algorma, at Aare Island Yard, Aug. 31. Antares, at Mare Island. Arctic, San Diego to San Pedro. Bagley, at Quantanamo Bay. Bridge, at San Pedro.

Liam O'Flaherty, author of "The Informer," has written a new novel, "Famine," a story of Ireland in 1845. Random House will publish the book late this month. It is the Literary Guild selection for October.
Brig. Gen. Frank Percy Crozier, brilliant war leader who turned pacifist and wrote several controversial books, died at Walton-on-Thames today after a long illness at the age of 58.
Coinciding with the lull in new bond financing, the total of bonds called for redemption prior to maturity for payment in August was

The champion Newark Bears broke even with Syracuse tonight before 9,000 fans, winning the second game, 1 to 0, on Babe Dahlgren's triple and Charlie Keller's single, after dropping a 9-to-2 decision in the opener.
William Comes, who set type for the first edition of The Newark Evening News, on Sept. 1, 1883, retired today after fifty-four years of continuous service on the newspaper.

Many out-of-town guests will arrive here Friday for the large dinner dance which will be given Saturday by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Murray Jr. at Wickapogue, their home on the ocean, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Marie Brady Murray.

Applications by the West Penn RailWays Company for an order declaring it not to be a holding company in the meaning of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 and by the West Penn Power Company for an order declaring it not to be a subsidiary of West Penn Railways were considered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission at a public hearing.

The Treasury announced tonight that ships." tenders would be received on a combined offering of about $100, 000,000 of Treasury bills at the Federal Reserve Banks and their branches until 2 P. M., Eastern standard time, on Friday. One series will be 104-day bills and the other 273-day bills.

Heroes of the nation's collegiate gridirons last Fall will demonstrate their individual qualities against the champions of the professional football world, the Green Bay Packers, at Soldier Field tomorrow night before more than 85,000 spectators, a record for the series, which began three years ago.

Stockholders of two underlying companies of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company voted yesterday to merge with the parent concern, it was announced here today at the offices of the Public Service Company. The underlying concerns involved were the Hudson County Gas Company and the Essex and Hudson Gas Company. Both companies have been under a long-time lease to Public Service Electric.

Sharply increased budget estimates for 1938 were submitted yesterday by the Department of Health and the Department of Hospitals. Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, backed by ten of his bureau heads, asked $6,963,816, an increase of $2,108,252, or more than 43 per cent.

Members of the visiting German, French and English tennis teams entered in the national singles championships at Forest Hills starting Thursday played the leading roles in an international club match at the Rockaway Hunt Club today.
Queen Wilhelmina's fiftyseventh birthday was celebrated here today with a military parade. There were festivities throughout the country.
Premier Paul van Zeeland has decided to call Parliament for a special session, in which he will answer attacks that have been threatening a Cabinet crisis.

Charles Henry Zeltner of 48-34 Ninety-first Place, Elmhurst, for more than thirty years a broker for the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, died suddenly yesterday from a heart attack while walking in Dey Street near Church Street, Manhattan.

The Dodgers' winning streak of three games was snapped at Ebbets Field yesterday when Charley Grimm's desperate Cubs came from behind to win, 4-2, and, thanks to the Cardinals' treatment of the Giants, the Bruins went back into first place with a full game lead.
Two upsets marked the first round of match play in the fifth annual Mason-Dixon golf tournament today.

Bucky Walters, former third baseman turned pitcher, put the sixthplace Phillies back on the winning road today, shutting out the Pirates, 3 to 0, with five hits for his fourteenth victory of the season. The game, played in one hour twenty-six minutes, was the fastest at Baker Bowl this year.

Dividends declared in August aggregated $389,022,270 for 880 corporations, the largest amount in four months and the largest total for an August since 1930, when 927 companies declared dividends aggregating $447,689,154. Last month's figure compares with $281,481,096 in dividends declared by 984 companies in the preceding month and with $334,649,487 in dividends for 721 companies in August, 1936.

Carl K. Withers, State Banking Commissioner, said today that State-chartered banks had reported the first decline in several years in the acquisition of real estate other than holdings necessary for the transaction of business.

Presentation, National Safety Council plaque to the Bronx Board of Trade by Captain Frank Riley, representing Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler, Bronx County Trust Company, 148th Street and Third Avenue, 10 A. M.

The law of averages and the Cardinals finally caught up with the fast-moving Giants yesterday. So, for that matter, did the Cubs. After five straight victories the New -Yorkers were routed at the Polo Grounds, 8 to 1, by the Gas House Gang and unceremoniously' toppled from first place, the Cubs vaulting over the Stoneham clan to a one-game lead.

Insurance companies were warned yesterday by State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews that a specific form of contract made with an agent would not necessarily exclude the agent from classification as an employee for whom contributions must be made under the State Unemployment Insurance Law.
Despite the Sino-Japanese crisis, plans for holding the 1940 Olympic Games in Tokyo are going forward.

Mrs. Gladys Mate Cullen, daughter of Mrs. Louis Weber and the late Mr. Weber, and widow of John Cullen, was married to Joseph H. Freedlander, well-known architect, yesterday afternoon in a private suite at the Weylin. The Rev. Dr. George Caleb Moor performed the ceremony in the presence of a few relatives.

To Aknusti and Old Westbury will go the honor of opening the national polo championship, because Devereux Milburn drew them from a hat at the meeting of the tournament committee in the Meadow Brook Club tonight, when the draw was made.

Dominion Grattan, a sleek little bay owned by Paul Bowser, Boston wrestling promoter, overcame a 140-foot handicap today in the Grand Circuit program at the State Fair Grounds and paced a mile over a half-mile track in 2:04.

The first round-trip flight this year of the Deutsche Lufthansa's Diesel-powered seaplane Nordmeer over the Atlantic between the Azores and New York was completed yesterday at 7:45 A. M. (New York time) when the big seaplane came to rest alongside the mother ship Friesenland off Horta.

Tommy Farr hasn't brought the boxing world to his feet, but he is more firmly established as a challenger for the world heavyweight title, is slightly more than $50,000 richer and is in a position to become independently wealthy-all because he survived fifteen fast rounds against Joe Louis, world champion.

The Mexican Government has failed to renew its air-mail contract with the Pan American Airways' subsidiary, the Compania Mexicana de Aviacion, it was revealed today. The contracts of Pan American Airways proper were not affected.

Don Sperry, a 38-year-old coal dealer from Flint, Mich., today accomplished what no other gunner has ever been able to do when he won both the sub-small gauge and the small gauge events in the third annual national skeet championships at the Blue Rock Gun Club.

Constantin Brunner, philosopher, critic and writer, died today. He would have been 75 years old tomorrow. An adherent of Spinoza's system and ardent opponent of the Kantian school, Mr. Brunner built up an explanation of State and society based on egoism.
Movements ot livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
The long list of apartment leases submitted yesterday reflected a further increase in the heavy demand for living quarters in the city which has been felt in recent weeks.
Johnny Pena, Washington Heights featherweight, received credit for a knockout victory over Willie Felice, Ridgewood, in the scheduled eightround feature bout at the Queensboro Arena last night.

Today we enter upon the month of the sesquicentennial of the drafting and signing of the Constitution of the United States by members of the convention organized in May of 1787 with the election of George Washington as its president.

Pensioned On his own application: LIEUTENANT--Otto D. Steinway, 83d Precinct, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed June 7, 1901. Temporary Assignments LIEUTENANT-William J. A. Ford, from 120th Precinct to 9th Division, assigned to duty as supervisor of patrol in uniform, for 18 days.

Japanese authorities proclaimed today that all United States citizens and Europeans here must observe Japanese military rules. Americans 'and other foreigners who are subject to extraterritoriality rights in China will be tried and punished by their own national courts.
Hot and oppressive to the last, the month of August took a final fling at perspiring New Yorkers yesterday by registering a high temperature of 90 degrees at 5:20 P. M.

Templeton and Aurora galloped through seven periods of a test match at Piping Rock today, with Templeton winning, 11 to 8. Templeton's power carried the team through, the two Guests, Raymond and Winston, and young Earle Hopping hitting very hard in front of Earle W. Hopping, filling in for Captain Humphrey Guinness, who has yet to arrive in the United States. F. Skiddy Von Stade Jr.

The board of directors of the Third Avenue Railway Company announced yesterday that there was "no available surplus income for the period of six months ended on June 30 applicable to the payment of interest on the company's 5 per cent adjustment bonds," and declared no interest on the bonds.

President Vargas sanctioned today a law voted by Congress creating a credit of 500,000 contos (about $35,000,000) for the National Coffee Department. It was recommended by the national coffee convention which recently met here.

Samuel Leibowitz arranged a meeting yesterday between reporters and his client, Robert Irwin, 29-year-old sculptor about to stand trial for the murder last Easter of Veronica Gedeon, her mother and a lodger in their East Fiftieth Street home.
Forty-three German Rotary clubs, with about 1,400 members, voted to dissolve following the recent National Socialist proscription of them as part of an international organization.

The Chinese Government has offered a formal apology for the bombing of the Dollar liner President Hoover in the China Sea, has assumed complete responsibility and has offered full financial reparations for personal and property damages that resulted, Secretary of State Hull announced today.

Exceeding preliminary estimates by a wide margin, a total of more than 215,000 suggestions were made in the contest for a name for the new magazine to be issued by the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, it was learned here yesterday.

The metallic rattle of falling jackstones and the thudding of balls bouncing on wooden tables resounded for more than two hours yesterday afternoon as the finals of the ninth annual interborough jacks championships, conducted by the Department of Parks, were being decided at the Heckscher Playground in Central Park.

Four thousand persons, most of them children, crowded around the bandstand in Poe Park, the Bronx, last night to hear young singers compete for the honor of singing in the Interborough Hill Billy and Amateur Barbershop Quartet contests which will be held later this month by the Park Department.

William Ziegler Jr., former treasurer of the Republican State Committee, declared yesterday that a canvass of up-State Republican county committee members and officials had shown that 80 per cent were opposed to the renomination of Mayor La Guardia on the Republican ticket.

Jimmy Foxx's thirty-third home run with one on gave the Red Sox a one-run lead in the ninth today, but the White Sox came back with two in their half to win, 7 to 6, and thus maintain third place. Luke Appling's double and singles by Jimmy Dykes and Luke Sewell produced the tying and winning runs.

The Quantico Marines have canceled their football schedule, with the exception of one game, because of military training schedules. Officers said today that a team would be "whipped together" in late October to play the Baltimore firemen in that city Nov. 13, but that the other eight games had been called off.

Many construction experts interested in eliminating shoddy construction and faulty building designs long have argued that lending institutions should exercise closer supervision of the types of structures they finance.

The University of Hawaii has won the "Warrior of the Pacific" Trophy for the tenth consecutive year, the War Department announced today in naming the winners in competition for the best rifle marksmanship for each corps area.

Stein-Mechutan Corporation, furriers, have leased through Gold Leasing Corporation a store and mezzanine and the second floor in the two-story taxpayer now nearing completion at 143 West Thirtieth Street.

Dr. C. V. Akin, chief quarantine officer at the United States Public Health Station on Staten Island, issued new instructions yesterday to all steamship companies using radio pratique, tightening regulations pertaining to the clearance of incoming liners without the formality of regular medical examination.

Almost before you could say John Brown, George Abbott yesterday changed his mind about his first production of the new season. Same author but a different play, the winner in either case being Mrs. Bernie Angus, whose works apparently are to go in one-two order on the Abbott lists.

Included in the fifteen Manhattan properties sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms was the fifteen-story apartment building at 116-118 Riverside Drive, southeast corner of Eighty-fourth Street. The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, plaintiff, bought in the structure on a bid of $700,000.

Directors of the Phillips Petroleum Company have authorized the filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 444,905 shares of common stock to be offered to stockholders in the ratio of one share for every ten held, according to a letter being sent by the company to stockholders today.
Al Roth, 135, New York, knocked out Chang Collura, 128 1/2, Newark, in the third round of a scheduled eight-round boxing bout tonight.

Another WPA Federal Theatre executive, Frank Merlin, yesterday announced his resignation from the project. The resignation will become effective Oct. 14, at the end of his annual leave. Mr. Merlin, who did not explain the reason for his resignation, has been assistant director of production for the Federal Theatre in New York and for sixteen months has been managing producer of the variety units.

Williamson S. Howell, first secretary of the United States Embassy in Paris; Hon. Ronald Tree, Parliamentary Secretary of the Overseas Trade Commission, London; Vincenter Barletta, consul of Panama in Puerto Rico;

The two-story taxpayer at 652 Bergenline Ave., West New York, N. J., has been purchased for investment by the Ventura Realty Company from the Provident Institution for Savings. The structure is on a plot 25 by 186 feet and contains two stores and one apartment. J. I. Kislak, Inc., negotiated the deal.

Announcement by the Department of State of the list of products upon which it will consider granting tariff concessions in forthcoming reciprocal trade treaty negotiations with Czechoslovakia, stirred protectionists and industrial trade associations to action here yesterday.

MANHATTAN BAUMANN, BERENICE L. (Aug. 26). Estate, more than $10,000. To Elizabeth B. Sternberg, daughter, executrix, 70 E. 96th St.. $26,000. oil painting by Emmet, jewelry, household, personal effects, onehalf residue and contingent remainder in one-half residue;

Hill, Gerhard Co, rugs and floor coverings, Scott Marion, dresses; Westport Silk Hosiery Co and additional space to A. H. Jacobs Co, wallpaper, in 509 Madison Ave; Butler Baldwin, Inc, broker. Madame S. Schwartz, corsets and gowns, in 666 madison Ave; Eugene E. Bogart, broker.
Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the lightest since June of this year; the turnover was also the smallest for August since 1934.

The charge of Senator Royal S. Copeland, Tammany's candidate for Mayor, that "Republican backers of Mayor La Guardia stood to benefit by $1,000,000 if the Seabury-Berle transit unification plan were to be adopted" was characterized yesterday as "a mare's nest" by Samuel Untermyer, formerly special counsel to the Transit Commission. Mr.

ALBERT--Adam F., on Tuesday, Aug. 31, 1937, beloved husband of Emma (nee Steinert) and brother of the Rev. F. X. E. Albert. Funeral from his late residence, 21-40 37th St., Astoria, L. I., on Friday, Sept. 3, at 9:30 A. M.;

Miss Ruth M. Gaudnier, 38 years old, of 919 Constant Avenue, Peekskill, has lost an eighteen-year battle against sleeping sickness. Miss Gaudnier, daughter of a building contractor, died yesterday at the Marr's Nursing Home, Lake Mohegan, about five miles from here.

The Yankees might have handled the Indians gently today inasmuch as the team, from Marse Joe McCarthy down the line, is a companionable lot, and what with the Indians having no end of troubles these days, it would have been nice to go easy with them.

While her children were busily engaged in making preparations for her ninety-fourth birthday tomorrow, Mrs. Susan Cleveland Yeomans, last of the five sisters and three brothers of President Grover Cleveland, issued a brisk birthday statement yesterday in which she upheld President Roosevelt's New Deal and made a plea for Democratic party harmony.

Mrs. Amelia Garcia, 31 years old, was shot three times and killed in the flat in which she lived at 1,528 Minford Place, the Bronx, shortly before 1 A. M. today by a man who then shot himself and leaped to his death from a fifth-floor window.

R. P. de Negri, Mexican Ambassador to Spain, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania after passing a year in Valencia and Madrid. The diplomat said he was confident that the Rebels would never take either of the cities.
Mayor La Guardia today formally invited the Veterans of Foreign Wars to hold their 1939 encampment in New York City, "where we are going to have a little fair."

Our intellectual leaders agree that we are a most propaganda-ridden people. "We flatter ourselves," remarks one of the speakers at Williamstown, "with the thought that in this Republic the majority of the citizens understand and shape national policies, when as a matter of fact there are few nations more propaganda-ridden, more thoroughly in the hands of sinister minorities."

Wilson Flohr of Canoe Brook captured the medal of the metropolitan junior golf championship today when he defeated Raymond Korndorfer Jr. of Scarsdale by nine strokes in their second play-off at the Englewood Golf Club.

Maitland L. Griggs of Ardsleyon-Hudson, N. Y., and his children will be at Seven Gables for September. James C. Warren of New York and members of his family are at the Mansion House to remain until after Labor Day.

Intervention foreign powers to halt the Sinoapanese war was urged today by eneralissimo Chiang Kai-shek. The apreme army commander declared le Chinese were fighting not only their own battle but also for the nations who place faith in the sanety of treaties.
Rookie Rudy York, hitting his twentyninth and thirtieth home runs of the season, topped orie of Babe Ruth's records today as he led the Tigers in a 12-to-3 victory over Washington.

Mrs. Marietta Collins of this city, who was engaged in social work for forty-five years, the last seven of which she was assistant headworker at the Orange Valley Social Settlement here, died of a heart attack yesterday. Her age was 70.
Dick Harlow, head coach at Harvard, was the principal speaker at yesterday's session of The Herald Tribune Football School in The Tribune Auditorium.
Henry Armstrong, Pacific Coast featherweight, scored a technical knockout victory over Orville Drouillard from neighboring Windsor, Ont., in the fifth round of their ten-round fight tonight.

The reciprocal trade agreement being negotiated between Washington and Prague arouses special interest for two reasons. The first is that business is extensive and brisk between the United States and Czechoslovakia.
The perils of war were aggravated tonight by an outbreak of cholera in this conflict-ridden city where Americans are stranded by a ban on American shipping.

Retail liquor package stores and bar and grill operators are compelled by law to sell only for cash and therefore will suffer no undue hardship in complying with the State Liquor Authority's order restricting credit terms in the liquor industry to twenty-one days, Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the Authority, said yesterday in denying pleas for modification of his board's ruling.
Loyalty Days will be observed on Saturday and Sunday, Oct. 2 and 3, it was announced yesterday by the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery.

After a number of informal dinner parties there was a large attendance of the Summer colony members at the Casino Theatre tonight for the opening of the final week of the theatre season, when "The Dramatist," starring Alexander Kirkland, was presented.

The Misses Helen Bernhard and Patricia Cumming, ranked first and second in that order, gained the final round in the Eastern grass court girls' tennis singles championship at the Richmond County Country Club in Dongan Hills, Staten Island yesterday.

Williamson Whitehead Fuller, former general counsel of the American Tobacco Company, left a net estate of $2,150,677 when he died on Aug. 23, 1934, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

Approval of the application of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway for authority to acquire control of the New York, Chicago St. Louis, or Nickel Plate, and the Erie Railroads by purchase of stock was urged today upon the Interstate Commerce Commission by Ralph H. Moister, examiner.

The British government not only stands back "every word" of the editorial in he Times of London, viewing with rave misgivings the Stuttgart Conress of Germans Living Abroad, It will refuse to accept the renrted plan to install three "culral attaches" at the German Emssy in London, official quarters id tonight.

Freshened up with a rest of two months, Myron selznick's fast two-year-old colt Can't Wait came back to the races at Aqueduct yesterday and gave a yesterday and gave a sparking performance o win the featured Pharos Purse at five furlongs.

Thwarted in the final a year ago, Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan and Donald Budge ascended the vacant national mixed doubles throne by defeating the French team of Mme. Sylvia Henrotin and Yvon Petra in the final at the Longwood Cricket Club today, 6-2, 8-10, 6--0.

Roscoe Pound, former Dean of the Harvard Law School, returned on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania yesterday from a tour around the world which began last January. During the tour he lectured in Tokyo, Shanghai, Peiping and Nanking.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 30: MAJOR GENERAL Boschen. F. W., Chief of Finance, 5 days' leave, Sept, 7. BRIGADIER GENERAL Grueger, W., General Staff Corps, 14 days leave, Sept. 1, with permission to visR foreign countries.
The possibility of a special session of Congress to pass New Deal legislation not adopted during the session just closed remains under advisement, President Roosevelt said today.
David S. Polland, New York State chess champion, today halted the winning career of Herman Steiner of Los Angles in the annual tournament for the championship of the American Chess Federation.

The higher price lines made much sharper gains than lower price numbers in the sales of men's clothing in July, when price lines at $35 and more increased 24 per cent over July, 1936, while the total clothing group was only 3 1/2 per cent ahead of last year, it was shown in preliminary estimates of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce today.
Spanish Insurgents announce they hurled a smashing counter-attack at Government positions on the Aragon front today in a campaign to relieve the pressure on Saragossa.
A luncheon was given today by Mrs. Henry G. Bartol at Harbor House, her home here, at which plans were discussed for the special Autumn opening of the West Side Thrift Shop.

Reporting requirements under the Commodity Exchange Act were extended by Secretary Wallace today to include all commodities covered by statute "to prevent large operators from manipulating prices by making a concerted drive on the market through several different commission houses." The new rules were designated Articles III through VII and relate to cotton, butter, eggs, potatoes and mill feeds, and become effective on Oct. 1.

Bids as high as $777,245 were submitted to the Maritime Commission today for fifteen steel cargo vessels, aggregating 125,754 tons, built during the war-time program and now lying obsolete in three ports of the United States.

-For the International Settlement area yesterday was the most peaceful day since the beginning of hostilities, but the people here, having become accustomed to the continual bombardment by big guns and aerial bombings both from Chinese and Japanese, were unable to relax.

In a sharp conflict of opinion at the Institute of Human Relations today, spokesmen for the motion picture industry told leaders of Jewish, Protestant and Catholic groups that film producers would not allow the role of educators to be thrust on them.
The Browns and Athletics, who occupy seventh and eighth places respectively, remained in the same positions today after a double-header of the "cellar series."
The text of the State Department's official account, issued today, of the course taken in regard to the bombing of the Ziner President Hoover in the China Sea follows:

Continuing the financing of construction and improvement, an offering of $3,000,000 Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation general mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, due in 1967, will be made today at 102 3/4 by the First Boston Corporation,

Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church dismissed yesterday a suit brought by the Municipal Civil Service Commission to compel the clerks who will tally the vote for City Councilmen to pass a qualifying examination.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Dana will give a small dance on Sept. 17 at Brookwood, their home in Bernardsville for their debutante daughter, Miss Agnes Dana. Mr. and Mrs. Henry DrummondWolff of Newport, R. I., and Liphook, England, are at the Plaza.
Freddie Haas Jr., lanky Louisianan, drove into the lead of the Western amateur golf championship late today, shooting a sub-par 68 to take the lead in the first round of qualifying play.

Ramsay C. Hoguet of 59 East Eightieth Street, senior member of the law firm of Hoguet, Neary Campbell, 90 Broad Street, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at his Summer home in Stockbridge, Mass. He was born in this city fifty-seven years ago.

As the Aquitania puts out to sea this morning, an airplane swooping above it will signal a final farewell from American Girl Scouts to most of their twenty-five foreign visitors for the silver jubilee encampment. Three weeks of furious activity for the group ended officially yesterday with a hop, skip and jump tour of New York City.
The touring American track and field team, making its last appearance before leaving tomorrow for Sweden, turned in another series of fine performances at Turku today.

For the next seven months the New York trout will be able to take in every fly or worm that floats down the stream without worrying whether they conceal hooks, for last night the anglers of this State wrapped up their trout rods and stored their flies where the moths can't get at them.

Deere Co. announced yesterday in Chicago that, in connection with a special meeting of stockholders called on Sept. 15 to increase the authorized common stock from 1,005,000 to 5,000,000 shares, it was proposed to double or increase otherwise the number of shares outstanding by declaring a stock dividend and to offer for sale some of the additional shares.
Six years ago come Sept. 18, the wicked Chinese blew up a section of the Manchurian railway south of Mukden.

A single railroad system in the United States, as a "logical solution of railroads' difficulties," was proposed here today by Carroll Miller of Washington, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, in addressing the opening session of the forty-ninth annual convention of the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners here. Mr. Miller said his views were his own.
The volume of new securities offered to the public here during the month of August was greatly reduced from recent periods both in respect to the number of issues and in the principal amount.

The wheat market on the Board of Trade here today was a small affair, fluctuating erratically within a range of around 1 1/2 cents a bushel and closed unchanged to 1/2 cent lower, the latter on the September, which suffered from liquidation induced by,the delivery, including retenders of 2,471,000 bushels of cash wheat on future contracts.

The first American performance of Keith Winter's comedy, "Worse Things Happen at Sea," was the final bill presented by Robert F. Cutler at the County Theatre here tonight. The comedy is based on the conflict between an elderly patroness and a young girl for the affections of a sycophantic novelist.

The threatened strike of 4,500 taxicab drivers employed by fleets combined in the Sunshine-Radio and Atlas-Liberty systems was averted yesterday when the emplayers and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, agreed to a one-week truce during which efforts will be made to adjust their differences.

Joe Louis, back in Detroit today after his fifteen-round-decision victory over Tommy Farr, said he "didn't feel good about being unable to knock him out" but explained he was handicapped by an injury to his right hand in the third round.
President and Mrs. Roosevelt were guests this afternoon at the ringside of the eighteenth annual Rhinebeck-Dutchess County Fair Horse Show, remaining a little more than an hour.

Net income of the Continental Can Company for the twelve months ended on June 30, as reported to the New York Stock Exchange, amounted to $13,761,779, which, after providing $4,486,847 for depreciation and Federal income tax and the surtax on undistributed profits, left net earnings of $9,274,932 available for the common stock. This was equal to $3.25 each on 2,853,971 common shares outstanding.

The National Labor Relations Board offered direct defiance today to the Federal District Court for the Northern District of Pennsylvania and ordered an election for collective bargaining in the face of a ruling by the court that an American Federation of Labor union had a valid closed shop contract.

THE FRONTS--In the Shanghai area Japanese preparations are complete for the long-heralded "big push." The Japanese claimed capture of the village of Woosung, north of Shanghai, but this was disputed by the Chinese.

Imports of gold received at this port in August amounted to $47,551,500, the smallest sum in thirteen months. They compared with imports of $67,204,900 in July this year and $58,752,100 in August, 1936.

The Committee for Industrial Organization scored an overwhelming victory in its fight for maritime supremacy yesterday when Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick announced that the National Labor Relations Board election on ships of the International Mercantile Marine had given 2,563 votes to the National Maritime Union and only 170 to the International Seamen's Union.

A marriage of interest to North Shore and Chicago society and to literary circles of Paris and New York took place this afternoon wher Mrs. Elizabeth Chapin was wed to Harold E. Stearns at Frost Pond, the country home of the bride in the Piping Rock Colony.

Closer cooperation between France and the United States, not only in international relations but in fashions, was urged by Lucien Lelong, Parisian couturier and perfumer, at a luncheon given in his honor yesterday by Adam Gimbel, president of Saks Fifth Avenue, Inc.,

From 7 o'clock in the morning until 8 at night traffic injuries in New York City follow the clock, rising steadily every hour, except at mealtimes, according to figures released yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine. The hourly record was tabulated by the Safety Bureau of the Police Department for the first six months of this year. The study shows that accidents occur in greatest number between

The United States Consul General at Hong Kong reported to the Bureau of Mines, in a dispatch received today through the State Department, that the Chinese Government contemplates establishing a monopoly or otherwise assuming control of exports of antimony ore and other minerals with the exception of tin.
The Port of New York Authority purchased from Louis Kuchemeuther the three-story flat at 608 Bergenline Avenue and the threestory flat at 515 Thirty-first Sereet, Union City.
Ottar Davidson, master or the Norwegian sealing ship Gudrun, which arrived at Tronsoe yesterday from Spitsbergen, brought here today a relic of the ill-fated Andree balloon expedition.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Goelet, who are to give a dinner at Ochre Court on Friday night before the dance at The Glen, home of Mrs. Moses Taylor in PortLmouth, are being joined on Sept. 11 by the Duke and Duchess of Roxburghe and will give a dinner in their honor during their stay. The Duke is a nephew of Mr. Goelet.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hunter Wanzer of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Ellis Wanzer, to T. Russell McKay, son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. McKay of Hempstead. The announcement was made here this afternoon at a tea at the Cherry Valley Club.
Governor Rivers today, paroled Fleming Willis, Atlanta Negro serving a chain-gang sentence for lottery, on condition that he go to Massachusetts.

The strike of signalmen and other technical employes of the American District Telegraph Company was settled yesterday with the announcement by the company at its offices at 155 Sixth Avenue that it has recognized Electrical Workers Union, Local 3, as the sole collective bargaining agency for employes in the operation and plant departments.

Harold E. Dahl, 28-yearold American aviator captured by Spanish Rebel forces on the Madrid front July 12 when the plane he was flying for the Spanish Government was shot down, has been sentenced to death by an Insurgent court-martial.

John B. Berger, prominent in legal, social and fraternal circles, died last evening at his home here, aged 67. He received his law degree from the University of Maryland in 1915. Formerly a manufacturer, he became more interested in law in his later years, maintaining, however, his business connections.
