The Dun-Bradstreet index number of average commodity prices on Sept. 1, published yesterday, was the lowest since Nov. 1, 1936. During August the decline in the index number was only six-tenths of 1 per cent, but since Jan. 1, the high average of the period, the decline was 6 3/4 per cent.

W. A. Taylor Co., 15 Laight Street, will become sole distributor in this country for Guinness Stout on Oct. 1. Ralph J. Cordiner, assistant manager of the appliance and merchandise department of the General Electric Company, has assumed the additional duties of general manager of appliance sales, taking over the work of P. B. Zimmerman, who is joining the Norge division of the Borg-Warner Company.

Four college boys sat in judgment yesterday on the styles girls will wear this Fall and Winter to classrooms and to campus events. At Arnold Constable Co., where girls from Eastern schools modeled ensembles for football games, for classes, for fraternity dances and sorority teas, the judges,

President Horace Stoneham yesterday announced the signing of Bill Terry to a new five-year contract as manager of the Giants and boss of the club's growing farm system, thereby setting at rest rumors relating to a change in management.

Physicians fighting handicaps to keep two girl victims of infantile paralysis alive with the only "iron lung" in the Rocky Mountain region feared tonight that a crisis might force them to decide which shall live.

Authority for the Central Railroad of New Jersey to pledge and repledge $1,074,000 of its general mortgage 5 per cent 100-year gold bonds as collateral security for short-term notes was granted today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Sale of a New York Stock Exchange membership for $75,000 yesterday placed on record the lowest price since April 9, 1935, when three seats were sold for $73,000, $74,000 and $75,000. Six days earlier, on April 3, the low point for the entire depression had been touched at $65,000.

Leading home a large and colorful field of 152 players, Mr. and Mrs. Ray Torgerson of Queens Valley walked away with the title in the tenth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association husband-and-wife tournament yesterday at the Pomonok Country Club.

A summary of transactions in equity securities in July by officers, directors and principal stockholders, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, showed an unusually large number of changes, with sales predominating. and many substantial gifts.
Reuben Fine, the American chess master, married Miss Emma Keesing of The Netherlands here today. The Netherlands chess champion, S. Landau, was best man.

A report has reached London of a mutiny by Manchukuoan soldiers against Japanese officers at Mukden a few days ago. Many officers were reported killed and there was said to have been sharp fighting for some time between Japanese and Manchukuoans outside the city.

James R. Ullman, former Broadway producer, who formally renounced the commercial stage several weeks ago because, he said, "I like to eat," will soon take a post with the Federal Theatre Project, it was learned last night.

The French Ministry's decree for merging all the country's railways into one large holding company, of whose stock the Government should retain a majority, will be recognized first of all as a political compromise. The proposal has yet to be ratified. by the national legislature.

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek has added his personal apologies for the bombing of the American liner President Hoover to the formal and official regrets expressed by the Chinese Government, the State Department announced today.

The fourth of a series of international conferences dealing with cultural changes among non-Western peoples as a result of the influences of Western civilization began today under the auspices of Yale University, Hampton Institute and the Institute of North Carolina.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Kipling, as a rugged British imperialist, appreciated the economic profit of war. He wrote: Ow the loot! Bloomin' loot! That's the thing to make the boys git up an' shoot!
Mrs. Harry L. Hamlin gave a luncheon today at the Hedges for Queena Mario, Metropolitan Opera singer. The party included Mrs.

Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday the appointment of 293 young probationary firemen. After a training period of ninety days the men will be assigned as regular members of the department,

Premier Koloman Daranyi today informed the German Minister to Hungary Herr von Erdmannsdorf, that the Hungarian Government would no longer tolerate pamphlets attacking the parliamentary system and advocating the establishment of a dictatorial regime to be imported from Germany.
A preview of the new Hearn department store at Broad and Cedar Streets, which is to open for business at Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein, Paul Block, publisher,

Seeking to develop the "badly neglected" field of whisky exports, Theo C. Wiehe, president of the Schenley International Corporation, accompanied by William E. Rapp, special Schenley representative, sailed yesterday aboard the Normandie for a trip that will include personal surveys in Russia, Tiurkey, Germany and sixteen other European countries. Advertising of Schenley products already has been initiated in a number of countries abroad, Mr. Wiehe said, but has been mainly along educational lines.
Treasury officials expressed confidence today that this fiscal year's deficit will be under the predicted $410,000,000 despite a $357,923,000 "red ink" balance for the first two months.
An attempt will be made for the first time in this country to run the business of an entire community of 900 families strictly without making any profit.
E. Osborne Smith, Inc., has placed for William Barkin a first mortgage of $215,000 on the six-story apartment at 1,750 Grand Con- S course with the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.

David S. Polland of New York, New York State victor at Cazenovia, moved into an undisputed lead today in the championship finals of the American Chess Federation at the Congress Hotel when he defeated Donald MacMurray of Chicago in the seventh round after fifty moves, while Herman Steiner of Los Angeles dropped his first full point as he lost an adjourned game from the sixth round to Harold Morton of Providence in sixty-three moves.

The election of Felix Morley, editor of The Washington Post, as a member of the board of visitors and governors of St. John's College was announced today by Dr. Amos F. Hutchins, president of the board.

Four Arabs were murdered today, two near a Jewish colony of Karkur, the others near a Jewish settlement of Gordonia. Opinions differ regarding assailants. Some see retaliation for the killing of three Jews since Sunday; others think the murders are the work of provocateurs.

That torrid National League flag race underwent another change yesterday when the Giants bounded back into the lead, thanks to a bruising attack Bill Terry's men visited upon two Cardinal pitchers and a delectable bit of neighborly aid from the war-worn Dodgers.

The Nationalists [Insurgents] announce they have now taken the offensive and are driving a wedge between Fuentes and Belchite, southeast of Saragossa. Three crack Loyalist battalions named Steel, Durruti and Zuera, hastily drafted for service on this front, were reported decimated yesterday.

Dr. George H. Simmons, editor and general manager emeritus of the Journal of the American Medical Association, died in St. Luke's Hospital today at the age of 85. He failed to rally from an abdominal operation performed last Wednesday.

Three men, one of them an exconvict, who are said to have confessed that they had been hired by members of the National Maritime Union to hold up an organizer of the International Longshoremen's Association, an A. F. of L. union, in the Plymouth Hotel, in West Forty-ninth Street, on Aug. 9, were indicted with an unidentified fugitive yesterday by the New York County grand jury.

The spiral nebulae, giant galaxies of star systems outside the solar system, some of them more than a hundred million light years distant, will be featured in the September presentation at the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History.

The general volume of production and trade was maintained at a relatively high level in August, the National City Bank finds in a review of business conditions contained in its monthly bulletin issued yesterday. Judging by preliminary figures, the bank says, the indices of industrial activity will show a fair margin of gain over a year ago, notwithstanding a moderate decline from the high levels of the Spring.

Three of the United States Army riders who are expected to compete in the international military jumping contests at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden on Nov. 3-10 returned yesterday after an extended foreign invasion. They were aboard the Hamburg-American liner St. Louis.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had granted applications for the withdrawal of registration statements filed under the SecuritiesAct of 1933 by Hearst Magazines, Inc., and Hearst Publications, Inc.

The troubled observer who is searching the world horizon for a glimmer of light, should not overlook the latest meeting of the Little Entente at Sinaia. The encouraging thing about this gathering in the storm center of Europe was its harmony. Czechoslovakia,

William P. Clarke, a former Mayor of this city, in recent years chairman of the Public School Committee, died at his residence today. He had been ill since he suffered a heart attack on July 4. He was in his sixty-seventh year.

Nineteen awards for contracts for textiles for the Works Progress Administration were announced today by the Procurement Division of the Treasury Department. A total of 1,241,750 yards was involved. The awards were:

Coach Gar Davidson called candidates for Army's football team today for their first practice. Forty varsity men reported. Using a carefully prepared schedule, calculated to waste no precious minutes, Davidson immediately lined up the squad for calisthenics. Then a drill in fundamentals was held.
Sir Hubert Wilkins's party searching for the six missing Soviet polar fliers took off today in its flying boat and headed for Baillie Island, off the Arctic coast, 400 miles northwest of here.

The resignation of Rhea Whitley as a special agent in charge of the New York division of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was announced yesterday by J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the bureau. He said that Reed Vetterli, now stationed in Newark, would take Mr. Whitley's post.

Dr. Frederick H. Nies, who had practiced dentistry for forty-eight years in Brooklyn, died yesterday of heart disease at his home, 12 Schermerhorn Street, at the age of 69. His wife, Abby Ware Nies; a son, Frederick J.; two daughters,

The extent of the Autumn demand for steel is not clearly indicated by present conditions, but there is a growing disposition to question whether the aggregate volume will be as large as was expected earlier in the Summer, The Iron Age says this week.

President Roosevelt today signed the sugar bill extending the life of the Jones-Costigan act with modifications, but he did so reluctantly, because of its restrictions on the importation of refined sugar from Cuba, Puerto Rico and Hawaii.
The bond market weakened yesterday in sympathy with the general decline in the stocks, and prices on the New York Stock Exchange were off 1 to more than 2 points in the active issues.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Burt Fontaine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn E. Fontaine of Linford Road, here, and James Redmont Howlett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Howlett of Hempstead, took place this afternoon at the home of the bride.

Hundreds of autograph seekers, film first-nighters, and strollers in Times Square, waiting for the opening of a new picture, "The Firefly," at the Astor Theatre, Broadway and Forty-fifth Street, about 7:30 o'clock last night, were shocked to see one of the workers, on the huge electric sign above the theatre, fall to the street.

A sharp Increase in infantile paralysis cases inspired prompt action today to forestall the spread of the disease. The Board of Education met in an emergency session and ratified a Health Department order deferring the reopening of Chicago's schools.
Men in white replaced spangled cabaret girls in all of Shanghai's Chineseowned night spots today. Every such cabaret was ordered converted into a hospital.
The City Physician of Garfield, N. J., and a Hasbrouck Heights insurance agent were held today on the charge of an insurance company that they collaborated in a fake death insurance policy racket.

In solemn ceremony of the Catholic Church the Most Rev. Walter A. Foery, former parish priest of Rochester, was installed today as the fifth Bishop of Syracuse before a throng of Catholic clergy, laymen and high State officials.

Condemning the Sullivan-Lyons bills for county government reorganization as Tammany "political decoys," Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, appealed yesterday to progressive voters to "capture the new City Council" and thus make county reform possible.

Application blanks for the renewal of automobile operators' licenses for three years will be available in all police stations beginning next Tuesday and continuing to Sept. 30, when current licenses expire, Motor Vehicle Commissioner Charles A. Hartnett announced yesterday.

While racing airplanes roared overhead today in qualifying trials for the opening on Friday of the National Air Races, scores of workmen were putting finishing touches on the newly enlarged airport which now boasts the largest air-racing facilities in the world.

Indicating that the State law on the subject of gambling was obscure, Acting County Judge Richard W. Hawkins dismissed today an indictment charging bookmaking and gambling against two officials of the Nassau Kennel Club, operator of the greyhound racing track at Mineola Fair Grounds.
Faith in the parliamentary system of government was the keynote as the congress of the Interparliamentary Union was opened here today by Senator Jules Jeanneney in the French Senate Building.

The will of the late John Russell Pope, architect, who died on Aug. 27, was filed in the Surrogate's Court yesterday, bequeathing his entire estate to his widow, Mrs. Sadie Jones Pope of 4 East Eighty-first Street.

As a result of the success of recent conferences held by officials of the Federal Housing Administration with builders, architects and representatives of lending institutions in twenty-two cities, the FHA is reported to be planning a new series of similar meetings this Fall in all parts of the country.

Contending that the State Liquor Authority ruling limiting credit extensions to bars and grills and to retailers to twenty-one days is both discriminatory and unconstitutional, John J. Daley, president of the United Restaurant Liquor Dealers of Manhattan, Inc.,

Dizzy Dean tossed a few balls with his ailing right arm in a light workout at Sportsman's Park today and complained the arm still hurt. The Cardinal pitcher said he would visit Dr. Robert F. Hyland, club surgeon, again tonight or tomorrow.
Two gunmen escaped yesterday afternoon with a $2,300 payroll which they took from a girl bookkeeper as she entered an elevator at 45-51 West Twenty-fifth Street after returning from a bank.

Miss Eleanor Wilhelmina Edel, daughter of Mr; and Mrs. Albert H. Edel of East Orange, was married to Robert Ogden Condit, son of Mr. and Mrs. Watson W. Condit of this city this afternoon at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit, Verona.

The Detroit police team returned a score of 1,400 out of a possible 1,500 for a new world record over this course in taking the Interstate and Interservice pistol team match today. The previous mark of 1,396 was made by the Los Angeles police outfit at the Southwestern international matches fired at San Diego this year.

Millinery manufacturers producing hats wholesaling at $7.50 per dozen and below will be asked to sign an agreement banning sales below cost, requiring the filing of cost sheets, and providing penalties for violations, it was announced yesterday by 0. W. Pearson, director of the Millinery Stabilization Commission, at a special meeting of producers of this merchandise held yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

The Fusion batteries swung into action yesterday for the first time since the beginning of the primary campaign. Mayor La Guardia himself headed the attack on his political opponents with a statement terming the Transit Commission "discredited and useless" and recalling, by implication, its appointment of James J. Walker as assistant counsel at $12,000 a year.
A contract was awarded today to the Pratt Whitney division of the United Aircraft Corporation, Hartford, Conn., for 455 aircraft engines for the army. The price, to include snares. was $4.153.938.06.

The Federal Power Commission reported today that the production of electricity for public use in the United States reached the unprecedented total of 117,994,000,000 kilowatt hours in the year ended July 31. This was an increase of more than 11,000,000,000 kilowatt hours over the previous year.
A defense of his heavyweight title against Max Schmeling this Fall was announced as definitely out of the picture for Joe Louis today.

Supreme Court Justice John H. McCooey in Brooklyn has been restrained from interfering in a labor dispute between the waiters and the management of Joe's Restaurant in Brooklyn under the terms of a writ of prohibition granted Tuesday afternoon by Justice George H. Taylor Jr. of the Appellate Division in his chambers at Mount Vernon.
Miss Helen Barnes Newberry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barnes Newberry of Providence, was inproduced to society at a tea in the Dunes Club today.

There is a spread of about a billion dollars between Republican and Democratic estimates of how much money Congress has authorized the Government to spend. This is due chiefly to a disagreement as to whether "reappropriations" as well as new appropriations should be counted.
China's military chieftains turned to a woman-Mme. Chiang Kai-shek-today for help in framing a plan of defense against Japan's threat to bomb airports and military concentrations throughout China.

Joseph P. Ryan announced last night that he was "in the maritime picture" on a purely temporary basis and that he would "get out" as soon as the American Federation of Labor committee of which he is a member had achieved the reorganization of seamen as planned by William Green, head of the A. F. of L.

Dr. John L. Tildsley, Associate Superintendent of Schools, retired yesterday from the New York City school system, at the age of 70 after forty years of continuous service. Leading educators here and elsewhere joined in paying tribute to a man who has become known as a "non-conformist" and an outspoken critic of many current educational theories.

The Montreal Light, Heat and Power Company has been refused permission by the Canadian Government to export 40,000 horsepower to the Aluminum Company at Massena, N. Y. It has this surplus as a resuit of the cancellation by Premier Hepburn of Ontario a year ago of 1 contracts for power with four companies in Quebec.

After a week of extensive interior remodeling, including the installation of oversized chairs and other innovations, the Capitol Theatre will reopen this morning with the Metro musical "Broadway Melody of 1938," featuring Robert Taylor, Eleanor Powell, Sophie Tucker, Robert Benchley. Buddy Ebsen, George Murphy, Judy Garland and Willie Howard.
No more fit appellation could be found for an all-embracing organization to help the world into a state of friendliness than that which is now given to the sometime Quakers.

A former industrialist preclpltated a wordy battle today, at an outdoor session of the Institute of Human Relations under the peaceful elms of the Williams College campus, between the "right to strike" and the "right to work."

The undefeated trail Old Westbury has been blazing through the ranks of the polo teams in test matches came to ar end today. Jock Whitney's team, which for the past two years has won the open championship, came to life with a vengeance in the fifth period and triumphed, 13 to 8.

Frank R. Kelly of West Orange, N. J., recognized as one of the country's leading skeet shooters, although he never had held a national title, finally crashed the throne room today when he won the 20-gauge crown in the third national skeet championship at the Blue Rock Gun Club.

Fearful casting that groups in New York, Pennsylvania, Illinois and other large taxpaying States may seek to change State laws to allow "community property" in a manner to divert hundreds of millions of dollars from the Federal Treasury, tax experts have begun work to plug this loophole in the income and estate tax structures before it grows larger.

Miss Sylvia Harwood Crandall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee S. Crandall of Larchmont, was married to John Leonard Dudley 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Leonard Dudley of Pleasantville, this afternoon at the home of her parents here.

The deep South again stole the thunder of the Western amateur golf championship today when Charles Yates, cotton-topped shotmaker from Atlanta, Ga., walked off with medal honors with a 36hole qualifying score of 137.
The Securities and Exchange Commission had amended four of its rules under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935. Rule 9 C-3-(9),

The defeat of the medalist in the third round and two thrilling extrahole matches in the quarter-finalsi featured the third annual New Jersey State public links golf championship today at Spring Brook.

A rapprochement between Hungary and the Little Entente now appears imminent. An official statement by the Hungarian Telegraph Agency tonight says Hungary does not doubt the Little Entente's desire to improve relations with her. However,

Miss Lydia Field Emmet 2d, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Le Roy Emmet of this city, has chosen the afternoon of Sept. 18 for her marriage to Lewis Croxton Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Blair Williams of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. The ceremony will take place here in St. Paul's Cathedral.

The skies over China are freighted heavily with death and destruction. Besides the many scores of Japanese naval planes that have been fighting and bombing in the last fortnight, bombers and fighters are now beginning to raid China's mainland from Formosa, and in the Shanghai zone Japanese Army planes, which will number 200 eventually, are beginning flights.

Mrs. Robert W. Bingham, wife of the United States Ambassador to Great Britain; F. Mott Gunther Minister to Rumania; Princess Miguel de Braganca, Colonel and Mrs. John Thomas Taylor, Mrs. Max Annenberg, First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler of New York and Count and Countess Leonardo Vitetti are among the 1,802 passengers due today on the Italian liner Rex from Mediterranean ports.

Some 60,000 bushels of meaty oysters were unloaded this afternoon and evening from sixty boats arriving from the beds in Delaware Bay and 12,000 bushels were on their way to market tonight by train and truck as the oyster season opened today.
Baltimore shoved over four runs in the last two innings tonight to take a double-header from the Jersey City Giants. The first score was 13-5 and the second 4-3.

Details regarding the two bond issues to be offered by the Territory of Hawaii were announced yesterday by W. C. McGonagle, Treasurer of the Territory. Sealed bids will be received on Sept. 14 for proposals as to interest and price, which shall not be less than par, for $1,500,000 of short-term refunding bonds and $3,000,000 of public improvement bonds, both of which will be noncallable.

Obstetrics was part of the police routine yesterday for Patrolman Louis Cicardo, 29 years old, of the Ralph Avenue precinct, Brooklyn. Shortly after 10:30 A. M. he successfully delivered an eight-pound, ten-ounce boy. The mother was Mrs. Anna Malone, 34, of 1,516 Broadway, Brooklyn.

George W. Webster, vice president of the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie Railway, was elected president of the company yesterday to succeed Clive T. Jaffray, who became chairman. The company is a subsidiary of the Canadian Pacific Railway.

With the marketing of the new crop increasing daily and only about 1,000,000 bales moved into sight thus far, prices on the Cotton Exchange declined into new low territory under heavy selling pressure yesterday.

The New York Giants' hopes of beating the Eastern College AllStars next Wednesday night were raised today when Coach Steve Owen received word from President John V. Mara, who is in Chicago, that Ed Widseth, Minnesota tackle and the outstanding college lineman of the country last Fall, probably would return to New York in time to join the Giants for the All-Star game.

After a conference this morning between President Roosevelt and Admiral William D. Leahy, the Chief of Naval Operations, the temporary White House offices here indicated that no expansion or strengthening of the United States naval forces in the Far East was contemplated as a result of the Sino-Japanese dispute.

George H. John Jr., 44 years old, a member of the Board of Education here and a mechanical engineer associated with the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, died this morning in the Elizabeth General Hospital, Elizabeth, of blood poisoning resulting from an infected bite beneath the right knee, believed to have been inflicted by a black widow spider.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and adjacent suburban areas declined 1 per cent under those for the corresponding week a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The figure compares with a rise of 8 per cent for the previous week.
It is true that the National Socialist regime has spent an estimated 31,000,000,000 marks in labor creation and military "investments," but it is also true that it has received its money's worth.

Canadian halibut fishermen operating on the banks off British Columbia and Southeastern Alaska landed 9,757,000 pounds, the greatest catch since 1915, according to figures compiled today by the Fisheries Department for the 1937 season, which closed July 27.

Harry McCoy, actor and director and composer of "Pagan Love Song," died of heart disease here today. He was 43 years old. In the early days of motion pictures he was cast as a Keystone comedy cop and as "Hallroom Boy."

The stock market moved lower from the outset yesterday and closed near the lowest levels of the day. The decline enveloped virtually the entire market, so that it was not particularly significant to note that the steels, coppers, motors, farm equipment, mail order and railway issues were particularly weak.
One of the nice things about elections is that the eternal verities get their innings. Every candidate is for them.

President Roosevelt once more honored with his presence the Dutchess County Fair horse show today. It was the first time he had given two afternoons to the exhibition and he seemed to enjoy getting away from affairs of State at Hyde Park, watching the ring competitions and greeting neighbors and old friends.

Publication of "The Turning Wheels," by Stuart Cloete, once postponed because it was selected by the English Book Society, has again been put off by Houghton Mifflin owing to its selection as a Book-of-the-Month Club choice. The publication date will be announced later. This is a first novel by a South. African farmer who is just celebrating his fortieth birthday.

A casual landing, a locked brake and a sudden ground loop off the concrete runway at Floyd Bennett Field yesterday morning wrecked the. plane and hopes of Major Alexander de Seversky for a new eastwest transcontinental record and the coveted Bendi?? Trophy for 1937.

Judge Knight demonstrated his belief today that things are not always what they seem in the movies, not even the pay checks. Alice White, film star, asked for $1,000 a month temporary alimony and $2,500 counsel fees pending trial of her divorce suit against Cy Bartlett, screen writer.

The executive council of the American Federation of Labor "condemned" unanimously today the action of the National Labor Relations Board in declaring void the agreement between the National Electric Products Company of Ambridge, Pa., and announced that its affiliate, the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, would take immediate legal steps to counteract the board's decision.
Lightweight Champion Lou Ambers of Herkimer, N. Y., outpointed Howard Scott of Washington in a ten-round non-title fight tonight befor 7,500 fans. Ambers weighed 135% and Scott 138.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora declared void yesterday an injunction granted by Supreme Court Justice Lewis L. Fawcett in Brooklyn restraining strikers from picketing the plant of Wheeler Shipyards, Inc., at Cropsey Avenue and Coney Island Creek, Brooklyn.

The marriage of Miss Pauline Bleeker Ripsom, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Newland Ripsom of this place, to Arthur J. Dolan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Dolan of San Francisco, took place here this afternoon in the garden of the home of the bride's parents.

President Lazaro Cardenas curtly announced today Mexico's intention of continuing the social revolution on the industrial and commercial fronts, as well as the agricultural. "We are going forward," he declared as he opened the new Mexican Congress.

The report of the Torrington Company and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended on June 30, issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $3,262,516 after depreciation, Federal and foreign income taxes and other charges.

Federal Judge Oliver B. Dickinson confirmed today the reorganization plan of the Baldwin Locomotive Works for a recapitalization of its financial structure. The plan has been in litigation for two and onehalf years.

Sir Malcolm Campbell today biloted his two-ton single-engine draft Bluebird through the Alpine waters of Lake Maggiore at an averagee of 126.325 miles per hour, taking the world speed boat record from Gar Wood of the United States by a margin of nearly two miles an hour.

The Electric Bond and Share Company, a $554,000,000 public utility holding company, together with twenty-six affiliated utility companies filed a brief yesterday afternoon in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here seeking a review of the decision of the lower court upholding the registration provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935.

Miss Eleanore May Eccles, only daughter of Governor of the Federal Reserve Board and Mrs. Marriner Stoddard Eccles of Ogden and Washington, D. C., was married here tonight to Harold J. Steele of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Harold Steele of Idaho Falls, Idaho.

Standard Dredging Corporation $1.60 cumulative convertible preferred stock, $20 par value, has been admitted to dealing on the New York Curb Exchange as a security exempt from registration. This stock was issued under the merger agreement dated May 5, 1937, between the Standard Dredging Company and the National Dredging Company. Dealings have been suspended in the common and
Wes Ferrell set down the Tigers with five hits today as the Senators were pounding three pitchers for an 8to-2 victory, evening the series at a game apiece.

A "freshman" member of the House, Representative Jerry J. O'Connell, was reported today to have been selected by the Administration to tilt the first lance in Montana in opposition to Senator Burton K. Wheeler, Democrat, for his fight against President Roosevelt's plan to reorganize the Supreme Court.

An assertion that the Postoffice Department's action in forbidding a through air sleeper service from New York to Los Angeles, over two connecting airlines, was another move to raise "an unsurmountable barrier" against the progress of aviation in the United States was made today by Senator McCarran.
It was hot and sultry in the Forest City today. Moisture dripped from the leaves, clothes stuck to one's back like a wet blanket, and the Indians stuck even closer to the Yankees.

Canadian wheat in store jumped from 30,769,031 to 39,479,062 bushels in the week ended on Aug. 27, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. A year before it was 135,170,109 bushels. Canadian wheat in the United States was 2,604,000 bushels, against 2,601,000 in the week before and 18,309,313 a year ago.
All the members of the Hitler Youth will in future answer an annual health roll-call. This great gathering of boys and girls for medical inspection will be held each year the first week in April.

The British flotilla leader Broke was dashing from Plymouth to the Bay of Biscay off Spain tonight in answer to a radio call from the captain of the South African steamer Sherard Osborn, who reported trouble "almost amounting to mutiny and sabotage" aboard his ship.

Lane Bryant, Inc., operator of a chain of women's apparel and shoe stores in New York and other cities, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement for $2,000,000 of 5 per cent sinkingfund debentures, due in 1947, with warrants to be offered first to common stockholders at 100 and any unsubscribed debentures to the public at the same price.

Armand (AI) Weill, well-known figure in boxing circles, yesterday was named matchmaker for the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, which will conduct bouts at both the Hippodrome and Madison Square Garden in the Winter.

The death of Angus D. MacLean, former Assistant Solicitor General and former Assistant Attorney General of the United States, was announced from his home here today. Death was attributed to a heart attack. He was 60 years old.

Blame for the crash of an Eastern Air Lines plane at Daytona Beach Aug. 10, when four persons were killed and five injured, was laid by the Commerce Department today upon the Florida Power and Light Company for failure to notify the air line that a telegraph pole had been temporarily erected overnight.

Variation in details rather than radical change in silhouette characterizes the shipments of coats, suits an ensembles selected by Deitsch, Wersba Coppola, Inc., and P. Mangone Co., which arrived Monday on the Normandie.

Maurice Coster died Tuesday at his residence in Magog, Que., at the age of 82. He was vice president of the Westinghouse Electric International Company from its formation in 1919 until his retirement in 1930, and had been associated with the Westinghouse organization since 1888.

Motorized picket lines of A. F. of L. teamsters virtually isolated the waterfront here today from inland commerce and threatened coast, wide shipping complications in an effort to force a showdown in a controversy with C. I. O. elements.

Another windless session today spoiled the fourth race of the Eastern Yacht Club's series for the America's Cup class yachts. They did manage to cover twelve miles, at which stage the race committee called a halt. There Harold S.

One of the most prominent. dinner parties of the season was given this evening at the Bar Harbor Club by Herbert Lancaster of Rye, N. Y., and Frank Bain of Chestnut Hill. Guests included Mr. and Mrs. Cummins Catherwood, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Hamilton, Mr. and Mrs. James Large, Mr. and Mrs. George V. Marston, Mr. and Mrs. Beauveau Borie, Mr. and Mrs. William G. Foulke and many of the young set.
Electric power production declined less than seasonally last week, but adjustment for long-term trend caused the index to ease to 108.4 from 108.5. For the week ended Aug. 29, 1936, it was 106.4.

Operations in the wheat market today lacked conclusive results, a feature being the relative strength in the September delivery, due to short covering. Prices on the Board of Trade here fluctuated within a range of 1 3/4 cents a bushel and, while bulges were hard to maintain, there was good buying on the breaks.

Plans have been completed for the wedding of Miss Elaine Terry Wesley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph John Wesley of Douglaston, Queens, to William John Stokes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Stokes of Great Neck, which will take place at Douglaston Sept. 18 in the Community Church.

Another voluntary exile has come to this country from Germany; he is Professor Lasslo Moholy-Nagy, painter, sculptor and photographer, who was Walter Gropius's chief aide at the Bauhaus, a famous art and craft school in Dessau, Germany, which was closed by Hitler in 1933 and which is now a school for the training of Nazi officials.

The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today an application by the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago for approval of the acquisition by it of all or any part of the outstanding common and 6 per cent and 7 per cent preferred stock of the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois.

The wedding of Miss Barbara Rising, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Rising, to Kirk Willis of Cleveland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rolla G. Willis of Delaware, Ohio, took place here this noon at the bride's home.

Federal Judge John W. Clancy, after hearing arguments yesterday in a suit by four foreign corporations to compel the redemption of Lackawanna Steel Company bonds in Dutch guilders, instructed the attorneys to file briefs but indicated that he believed the Central

Supreme Court Justice Thomas C. Kadien in Brooklyn awarded yesterday to Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, as rehabilitator of the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company, a judgment of $850,000 against the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, an affiliated concern.

Plans by several hotels here to conduct private services during the coming Jewish holidays have brought protests to the borough commission from representatives of the Congregation Agudath Achim. The commission was told last night

One of the worst typhoons in the history of Hong Kong struck early this morning and lashed the colony and harbor for six hours. Before noon at least fifty deaths of Chinese had been reported, including fifteen men and women who were trapped when a block of buildings caught fire.

The Phillies won their eighth game in nine starts today, making it two straight over the Pirates, 5 to 3, behind the seven-hit pitching of Claude Passeau and a timely homer by Catcher Earl Grace. It was Passeau's twelfth victory of the season.

The recent discovery of a process to prepare fish skins as a substitute for staple hides and skins for leather has attracted the attention of the German Government, according to a report today by R. V. Heingartner, United States Consul at Frankfort on the Main.

Recent evidence of the existence of "prophetic instincts" among living creatures of the lower orders on an evolutionary scale offers incontrovertible proof in favor of Darwin's theory of natural selection as the underlying cause in the process of evolution, Sir Edward Poulton, president of the British Association for Advancement of Science, stated here tonight in his presidential address opening the annual meeting of the association.

Deflection of large quantities of American merchandise destined for various Chinese ports to Hong Kong has caused a shortage of warehouse space, with the result that large amounts of goods now are stored either in buildings without adequate protection or out in the open, subjecting them to serious risk, according to information reaching marine underwriters here yesterday. Meanwhile,
The Domei (Japanese) News Agency reported today that radios in Korea had intercepted broadcasts from Vladivostok stating that the Soviet's Far Eastern army was manoeuvring at Possiet Bay.

Miss Elizabeth Rich, daughter of Representative Robert Fleming Rich and Mrs. Rich of this place, was married here this afternoon in the Methodist Episcopal Church to Sheridan Watson Bell Jr., son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Sheridan W. Bell of Buckhannon, W. Va. The ceremony was performed by the bridegroom's father.

Miss Gladys Rockefeller, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Percy A. Rockefeller of New York, was married here today to Dudley F. Underhill of New York. Mr. Underhill formerly lived in California and is a member of a well known West Coast and New York family.

Expediting of the Atlantic Avenue improvement in Brooklyn and Queens was pledged yesterday as Frank J. Taylor, Controller; former Mayor James J. Walker, Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, and others conducted a tour of twenty grade crossings on the Long Island Railroad.

At Warren, R. I., Tuesday, the New England oyster. season and a goodly number of oysters were opened by the New England Oyster Growers Exchange, Inc. In two oyster boats an official party of 150 went down Narragansett Bay to the oyster beds.

Dean Hanover, the former Mr. Watt, the outstanding bay colt who was sold for $410 and repurchased by his original owners, the Hanover (Pa.) Farms, for $20,000, embarrassed a small but select field in the outstanding race of the Grand Circuit's program at the Ohio State Fair today.

Engagements of gold abroad for shipment here were resumed in large amounts yesterday following the temporary stoppage of the movement on Tuesday. A total of $11,935,000 of the metal was reported to the Federal Reserve Bank as having been engaged yesterday. Of this amount, $5,800,000 was obtained in Japan, $3,236,000 in Canada and $2,899,000 in England. No imports of gold were received here yesterday.

New Rochelle police and members of her family searched unsuccessfully today for Constance Lyman, 13 years old, who left her home at 5 Antler Place, Beechmont, at 8 A. M. yesterday and was last seen riding a bicycle. Her father,

Miss Mary A. Kevin of Brooklyn was honored last night with a cocktail and dinner party at Heaton Hall in observance of her birthday. The party was given by Mrs. Wesley Houser of Palm Beach, Miss Alice Phillips of New York, Mrs. Joseph J. Davis of Waterbury, Conn.;

Mrs. Mary Bernard of 31-21 Eightyseventh Street, Jackson Heights, known as May Dean on the stage, where she had appeared since her sixth birthday, was buried yesterday in Cedar Grove Cemetery, Flushing. She was the original "colored mammy" for "Aunt Jemima," pancake flour advertisement.

Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., testified yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission that he believed the company should be permitted to take advantage of cheap money rates in order to refund obligations and borrow money for additional capital expenditures in order to meet the increased demand for electricity in this city.
Chasar and Parscout were the winners of yesterday's feature races at Aqueduct, and each had to come from behind the pace to score in the Val d'Or and Poitrel Handicaps respectively.

All parties to the dispute prepared today to make a test of the decision yesterday of the National Labor Relations Board in the "closed-shop" case of the National Electric Products Corporation at Ambridge, Pa., in which-the authority of the board is pitted against that of the Federal District Court.
Mrs. William Corcoran Eustis of Washington has announced here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Anne Livingston Eustis, to Grenville Temple Emmet Jr. of this city.

The marriage of Miss Caroline Massman Potter, granddaughter of Mrs. Frederick Massman of Montclair, to Robert Bruce Moon, son of Mrs. J. R. Moon, also of Montclair, took place this afternoon at a candlelight service in the chapel of St. Luke's Episcopal Church here.
George Zengaras, Greek lightweight, and Frankie Wallace, Cleveland veteran, will furnish the action in the feature ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Nine hundred employes ended a twentyfour-hour strike today and went back to work in the William Penn and Fort Pitt Hotels. A contract was signed with two American Federation of Labor service employes unions, granting a wage increase, paid vacations, the preferential shop and a pledge of no discrimination against union members.

LOLLING back in a deep chair at high noon Yesterday, Manager Charley Grimm of the Cubs was talking about his club and the remainder of the pennant race as it looked from where he sat at the moment. It was good to see "Butch, the Banjo Man" around again.
Dr. Wallace E. Gonsalves sold to Thomas P. McLoughlin Jr. of New Rochelle the new residence at the corner of Ridge Street and Betsy Brown Road, Rye, N. Y., through Blakeman Quintard Meyer, broker.
The Athletics today defeated the Browns, 5 to 2, to move from eighth to seventh position in the American League.

The Manhattan Concert Band, Anthony Giammatteo conducting, was heard last night at the Theatre of Music in the first program of "The Federal Music Project in Review." It was the first time a band had been heard in concert at the Theatre.

Going to windward like a streak in light air, Sir Henrik Ramsay's Inga Lill XXVI, representing Finland, earned a belated victory and the right to continue in the six-meter series for the Scandinavian Gold Cup by capturing the third race of the quadrangular international competition today.

Among lessees of space for business uses in the list furnished yesterday by brokers and rental agents was Moss Hart, playwright, who took space in the Bush Building at 130 West Forty-second Street, through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc.
A new multiseater army plane known as the XFM-1, which is expected to be capable of giving battle to the biggest "flying fortresses," passed its first flight test here today.

The referendum conducted among members of the Newspaper Guild of New York on affiliation with the C. I. O. overwhelmingly ratified the action of the American Newspaper Guild Convention at St. Louis in June in joining the Lewis organization, it was announced last night following the count of the ballots.

Mr. and Mrs. Horace K. Moore gave a dinner last night on the Roof Garden of the Astor. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Frank Yates, Mr. and Mrs. George D. Paine, Mr. and Mrs. Wells Burd, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hayes Trudell, Mr. and Mrs. Havens L. Perry, Mr. and Mrs. John C. Karp and Mr. and Mrs. Willard V. Cornish.

More than a thousand women stood patiently in line yesterday, on the day the new law, became effectiye, to file with their respective Commissioners of Jurors in the various boroughs their applications for service on juries.

Although the heat yesterday, the first day of September, was three degrees lower, at its peak, than the high of the day before, reaching a maximum of 87 at 3 P. M., a fairly high humidity combined with it to make the day uncomfortable.

Joe Burk, Philadelphia, won the Joe Wright Challenge Trophy in the one-mile sculling race at the Canadian National Exhibition tonight. Using his choppy stroke, the United States champion posted the good time of 5 minutes 57 seconds.

It is better to work for Utopia than for hell, Chicago University's dean, Shailer Matthews, advised the World Conference for International Peace through Religion in opening as its president its three-day session here today. He declared the great danger in the world was the growth of nationalism. This, he said, gave those with religious ideals a great field of work.

FABLES FOR PARENTS, by Dorothy Canfield. (Harcourt, Brace, $2.50.) Short stories about children, parents and, sometimes, grandparents. HARBOR NIGHTS, by Harvey Klemmer. (Lippincott, $2.50.) A realistic book about sailors.

Lack of funds in the last few years has prevented the purchase of sufficient new books and the proper replacement of worn-out volumes, the trustees of the city's public libraries declared yesterday in appealing for 1938 budget appropriations far in excess of those granted for 1937.

Plans for widening the Henry Hudson Parkway north of the Henry Hudson Bridge across the Harlem, to prevent a traffic bottle neck after the completion of the second level of the bridge, were revealed yesterday by the Parkway Authority.

Miss Marion E. Martin, National Committeewoman from Maine, was appointed today by John D. M. Hamilton, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, to be his assistant in charge of the woman's division.

Mrs. Fannie Harrington Ellis Humphreys, wife of Richard Duane Humphreys, president of the Mississippi Glass Company, whose offices are in New York, died here this morning at her home, Barnstable, after a long illness. Mrs.

The Rev. Howard Robert Weir, rector of the Church of the Holy Trinity in Philadelphia, died here today at the age of 52. He became ill a week ago at Cornwall, Conn., where he was spending the Summer with Mrs. Weir, and was admitted to a New Haven hospital for an operation.

Current loans by chartered banks in Canada on July 31 were about $6,000,000 larger than at the end of June and about $88,000,000 greater than on July 31, 1936, according to the monthly report to the Finance Minister.
T. V. Soong, former Minister of Finance and chairman of the Chinese war loan committee, announced today that $30,000,000 of China's first $150,000,000 war loan had been subscribed.

Publication by the Municipal Civil Service Commission yesterday Of a list of 170 men eligible for promotion to captaincies in the Police Department paves the way for some sixty general departmental promotions to be announced soon by Commissioner Valentine. The high man was William A. Turk, with a general average of 90.55.

There's no doubt that there are some big trout in New Jersey streams, and after a long day of throwing flies up, across and down several miles of the Musconetcong and the south branch of the Raritan we are convinced of the truth of this. The big trout were there today-and tomorrow they'll still be there.

Friedrich Adler, secretary of the Socialist International, was arrested last night at a railway station near the Belgian frontier as he was about to leave The Netherlands. He is held here, charged with entering this country on a false passport.

Many dinner parties will precede the large costume entertainment to be known as "The Longshoremen's Ball," which will be given Friday night by Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hoving at the Port of Missing Men, their place at North Sea.

No upsets were recorded as play in the women's Mason-Dixon golf tournament reached the third round today. The championship flight saw Miss Virginia Guilfoil of Syracuse, N. Y., advance by routing Mrs. Neil Wessels of Roanoke, 9 and 7.

Eight-hit pitching by Lou Fette, 30-year-old rookie, gave the Bees a 4-to-1 verdict in the nightcap of a doubleheader today. The Reds took the opener, 5 to 1, behind Paul Derringer's six-hit performance.

Another attempt to settle the strike of 15,000 painters in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond Hill will be made today. Officials of the New York Master Painters Association, representing the employers, and the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, District Council No. 9, will meet again at the office of the Building Trades Employers Association, 2 Park Avenue.

Lieut. Commander William F. Hamberger of the Construction Corps, U. S. Navy, retired, died here today at Naval Hospital. Full military services will be held in Arlington National Cemetery tomorrow at 11 o'clock.

RION BERCOVICI has written an ugly farce about press-agentry, an old crone's tale of the prostitution of lively wits. It is reminiscent of one of last year's burlesque shows. It is irritating, indecent, slanderous, but interesting. Exaggerated beyond the limits of the politer descriptive phrases, it unfortunately has a kernel of truth. The title is, "For Immediate Release:"*

" The Great" Paris, hirsute strong man of the WPA circus, which began a Brooklyn series of eighteen performances last night on a lot at Forty-eighth Street and Glenwood Road, pitted his strength yesterday afternoon against two two-horse teams as a prelude to the opening of the show, while 300 youngsters of the Police Athletic League roared their disapproval.

Charley Grimm's mood last night must have been what his name implies. His supposedly potential champion Cubs, playing with all the finesse of a hippopotamus at a grand piano, yesterday tossed away a game to the Dodgers by a 6-4 count and again turned first place over to the victorious Giants.

Two physicians, seized in Atlantic City in connection with the vice raids conducted there by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, were questioned here tonight by Federal authorities. They are charged with withholding knowledge of a felony.

By a vote of 2,181 to 493, the employes of the Childs Company, restaurant chain, indicated yesterday their wish to be represented by the Hotel, Restaurant and Cafeteria Employes Organizing Committee, an A. F. of L. union, in collective bargaining with the company.

Exasperation and anger blazed up in official London today over the news that the British destroyer Havock had been attacked without warning during the night by an unidentified submarine off Cape San Antonio between Alicante and Valencia, Spain.
Commander Heliodoro Saenz, Minister of Finance, issued today a decree fixing rates of exchange for payment of Ecuadorian customs duties, but the effective date of the decree was not announced.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Insley Blair of Tuxedo Park, who have been passing some time in London, will be at the Carlyle for the Winter. Mrs. Ellicott Douglass Curtis has returned to the Croydon after passing the Summer at Aimes Point, West Haven, Conn.

William J. A. Caffrey, former New York State Senator and former assistant district attorney of New York, died at Monterey today of a heart ailment. His age was 68. He had been in poor health for some years.
The Japanese army now controls all of the Peiping-Suiyuan Railway from Peiping to Kalgan, it is claimed here, and is contemplating a push to the south, perhaps as far as the Yellow River.

Broadway will be "blowing its trumpets and sounding its brasses" this evening for the opening of the new theatrical season. The occasion, of course, will be the premiere of "Virginia," the musical romance by Laurence Stallings and Owen Davis, with music by Arthur Schwartz and lyrics by Albert Stillman, at the Rockefeller Center Theatre.

Recording their best gross score as team-mates and aided by the maximum handicap, Perley Boone and his 13-year-old son, Olin, today won the principal laurels in the Long Island Golf Association's fourteenth annual father-and-son tourney over the links of the Garden City Country Club.

Savings banks figured yesterday as the sellers of housing properties in the Bronx. The Dollar Savings Bank sold to Hyman and Lena Weiss the threestory brick tenement house at 1,129 Morris Avenue for cash over a purchase money first mortgage.

With the strongest international field to gather in this country in ten years, the national championship singles for men and women will start today on the turf courts of the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills.
Slingin' Sammy Baugh, gridiron hero from Texas Christian University, flung America's collegiate All-Stars to a 6-to-0 victory over the professional champions, the Green Bay Packers, tonight.

Before the eyes of a night watchman and a scrub woman who tried to stop him, a man jumped last night to his death from a sixteenthstory window in the Paramount Building, Forty-third Street and Broadway. The police identified him by a card in his possession as Frank B. Bomono, about 40 years old, of, Astoria, Queens.

Although the new law requiring a wait of seventy-two hours between the issuance of a marriage license and the performing of the ceremony went into effect yesterday, the Marriage License Bureau in the Municipal Building issued 123 licenses, as compared with only 111 issued on Sept. 1, 1936.
The transcontinental commercial air service was ten years old yesterday and aviation heads reviewed the advances made since the flight of a Liberty-Douglas biplane or Sept. 1, 1927.

Supreme Court Justice Peter P. Smith in Brooklyn denied yesterday the application made in behalf of the Manufacturers Trust Company to dismiss the first of four causes of action in a suit to recover $1,163,772 brought by Fred L. Cole of Pasadena, Calif, as assignee of his father, Thomas F. Cole,

The Resettlement Administration became the Farm Security Administration today, and Secretary Wallace announced that the agency, under the new name, would administer the Bankhead-Jones Farm Tenancy Act.
This country is only awaiting the opportunity to enter upon any genuine effort that may be made toward disarmament, a radio audience was told tonight by Secretary Hull.

With the traditional Fall moving day in the apartment field only four weeks away, many families that have delayed selection of new living quarters now are busily engaged in a search for suitable space.

Senator Royal S. Copeland, aspirant for both the Republican and Democratic Mayoralty nominations, centered his attack for the first time yesterday upon his opponent in the Democratic primary, Jeremiah T. Mahoney.

The Engineers Public Service Company reported yesterday operating revenues of $4,426,756 for July, against $4,094,108 in July, 1936, and net income of $1,220,198 after interest and amortization, against $1,147,067. For the year ended on July 31 operating revenues were $50,577,788, against $46,341,741 in the preceding year, and net income applicable to the parent company's stocks was $3,392,970, against S2,668.401.
Stocks closed with losses of 1 to 5 points; turnover, 819,910 shares. United States Government issues higher; corporate and Japanese bonds lower; transactions, $5,547,700.

The stock market here was dull in general today and most sections lost ground. Gilt-edge issues improved after early weakness, while among the foreign loans, Far Eastern bonds fell off. Transatlantic shares sagged under the influence of reports from Wall Street, and United States Steel and International Nickel turned downward.

Considerable attention was attracted in Wall Street some weeks ago by reports that, because of the lightness of markets on the New York Stock Exchange, dealers were rushing to seek permission to market large blocks of securities "off the Exchange." In some cases permission was granted.

Crop restriction to keep pace with dwindling demand was condemned by the International Institute of Agriculture tonight in a report branding the. world's present economic recovery as largely artificial.

World peace emerged as the imme diate concern of Quakers everywhere as messages from foreign lands were presented to opening sessions today of the World Conference of the Society of Friends at Swarthmore and Haverford Colleges.

Detective Matthew Sheehan of 1,040 Nelson Avenue, the Bronx, who worked in the record room of the Criminal Identification Bureau at Police Headquarters, died yesterday morning in Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital after a week's illness. He was 33 years old.

Total deliveries of sugar for the first seven months of this year were 3,964,131 tons, a gain of 26,779 tons over the same period last year. The Department of Agriculture reported today that refiners supplied 2,552,176 tons, beet sugar factories 684,055, importers 427,677, and Louisiana and Florida cane sugar mills 71,657.

Federal Reserve member banks increased their loans substantially between March 31 and June 30. The Federal Reserve Board reported today the 6,357 banks had loans of $14,284,875,000 on June 30, the date of the last bank call.
Natorma Estates, Inc., Aaron Simon, president, announced yesterday plans for a nineteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 100 Riverside Drive, north corner of Eighty-second Street.

Two months' operation over the North Atlantic by the leading international airlines of Great Britain and the United States, coupled with coordinated information supplied by similar interests in Germany and France, have proved the transatlantic airline projects feasible, it was announced yesterday by spokesmen for the four companies.

In an attempt to broaden the scope of New York City's educational program to place greater emphasis upon the family, the school system plans to employ eighteen psychiatric social workers in the next three years as permanent members of the teaching staff, Dr. Joseph K. Van Denburg, chairman of the Board of Examiners, disclosed yesterday.

Harry Sayre Schott, vice president in charge of sales and advertising of the National Carbon Company, Inc., died last night in a hospital of an embolism following an operation a week previously. His home was at 99 Undercliff Road.

Employes of the East Side Omnibus Corporation and the Comprehensive Omnibus Corporation, who recently voted 3 to 1 for an independent union as their bargaining agency, have since voted to join Transport Workers Union and have asked the State Labor Relations Board to recognize that organization as their sole agent for collective bargaining.

THE FIREFLY, suggested by the book and lyrics by Otto A. Harbach; adaptation by Ogden Nash; screen play by Frances Goodrich and Albert Hackett; music by Rudolf Friml: additional lyrics by Gus Kahn, Bob Wright and Chet Forrest; musical direction by Herbert Stothart; dances staged by Albertina Rasch:

The American Rolling Mill Company has declared a dividend of 50 cents on the common stock and an initial quarterly dividend of $1.12 1/2 on the new 4 1/2 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock. On July 15, 50 cents was paid on the common stock.

Hsu Shih-ying, Chinese Ambassador to Japan, saw Foreign Minister Koki Hirota last night and explained that China's non-aggression pact with the Soviet Union was not only a purely pacific instrument but, according to the newspaper Asahi, stated that China was ready to conClude a similar pact with Japan.
It took two thunderstorms and Lefty Grove to stop the White Sox, 2 to 0, today after six innings of the first game of a scheduled double-header with the Red Sox. The second contest was postponed.
James F. Shaw retired on Tuesday from Fenner Beane. The interest of the late Siebel C. Harris in Harris, Burrows Hicks, ceased on Tuesday.

The newspaper Izvestia announced today the summary dismissal of one of its leading editorial employes, Mikhail Suvinsky, for writing an article, published Aug. 26, accusing authorities of the Saratov region of raising a cry of sabotage at a delay in harvesting when their own inefficiency was to blame.

It is impossible to lay down Sir Edward Poulton's reflections before the British Association for the Advancement of Science on the part that Darwin's theory has played in the biological discussions of the last fifty years without a sense of deficiency. True,

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date, while bills discounted and the reserve note circulation were at a new high figure.

Hank Greenberg put a home run over the scoreboard in the tenth inning of the game with the Senators today to give the Tigers a 9-to-8 victory. It was the second homer of the day for the big first baseman and his thirty-second for the year. Billy Rogell, Tiger shortstop, also got a home run.

The Italian Government will not be represented at the Nuremberg Congress by Dino Alfieri, Italian Minister of Press and Propaganda, as was at first reported, but by Guiseppe Bastianini, Foreign Under-Secretary.

Miss Arlene Eade will be married on Sept. 20 to Thomas J. Qualters, personal bodyguard to President Roosevelt. James Roosevelt will officially represent his father at the ceremony. Mr. Qualters has been an aide to the President since December.

The Catholic peoples are wont to help one another mutually in days of affliction, thus practicing the law of charity and brotherhood which joins in one mystical body all of us who hold communion in the thought and love of Jesus Christ.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Mrs. Louise King Reckford, widow of Louis J. Reckford, lead pencil manufacturer, died yesterday at her home, 7 East Eightysecond Street. She was in her sixty-sixth year. Born in New York, Mrs. Reckford was the daughter of David James and Adelaide Ballin King. She was a descendant of Gershon Mendes Seixas, Revolutionary patriot and a founder of Columbia University. She studied abroad and was married in New York in 1890.

Irwin Shaw, who introduced himself to Brdadway with "Bury the Dead" and thereby won much acclaim, is ready to enter the lists again. This time it is with a fulllength play, "Siege," for which Irving Cooper said he (Mr. Cooper) had signed a contract only yesterday.
Mr. and Mrs. Thornton Chard of this city and Cazenovia, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beatrice Barclay Chard, to George B. Carpenter.

Domestic customers served by manufactured and natural gas utilities numbered 15,787,500 on June 30, an increase of 223,000 during the first six months of this year, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Gas Association.

The American Federation of Labor, through its executive council, threw in its lot today with the teamsters union on the Pacific Coast in a "fight to the finish" against Harry Bridges, West Coast representative of the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Purchases of securities in lots of less than 100 shares on the New York Stock Exchange continued to exceed sales in the week ended on Aug. 28, according to the weekly analysis made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

With the President's signature the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill becomes law, and America at last makes a real start toward wiping out its city slums. The President's next step is the appointment of a Housing Administrator, and upon this appointment much of the success of the program must depend.

Only seven players reported at the Women's National Club today for the annual metropolitan girls' golf championship, which produced a new champion in Miss Helen Reynolds, the 17-year-old White Beeches representative, who posted a neat 84 to win rather handily.
The Internal Revenue Bureau reported today there were 881,158 purchasers of special-tax stamps for the privilege of doing business in certain taxable occupations in the 1937 fiscal year.

Frank Kelly of West Orange, N. J., and Odis Walding of Los Angeles, two of the best-known gunners in the nation, and Don Searls of South Lyon, Mich., a "dark horse," shot their way into the lead in the allgauge event of the national skeet championships at the Blue Rock Gun Club today by breaking 100 targets each.

Fifteen natives were killed, scores wounded and about fifty police and soldiers were wounded after fighting at Meknes in French Morocco, where natives staged a demonstration against the authorities today.
Arthur W. Millhauser, copper broker, died at his Summer home in Asbury Park, N. J., yesterday after a long illness. About eighteen months ago Mr. Millhauser, who retired.

W. C. MacFarlane, president of the Minneapolis-Moline Implement Company, has addressed a letter to stockholders outlining a plan for recapitalization and the discharge of accumulated dividends of $3,800,000 on the $6.50 preferred stock.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 7,000, including 2,500 directs. Market steady to 10c lower than Wednesday's average; top $11.70; bulk good and choice 190-240 pounds, $11.40-$11.70; few sales choice 150-180 pounds, $10.65-$11.50;

Mrs. James Mortimer Winchester of Birmingham, Ala., will be married to Clark Irvin Scott of Freeport, L. I., on Saturday afternoon in the chapel at the Lake Placid Club. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Malcolm F. Kelly, pastor of the Adirondack Community Church here.

Word has been received here of the marriage of Miss Helen Lucile Yetter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Austin Yetter of Binghamton, N. Y., to Dr. Gerald Edson Kohler of this city, which took place yesterday in Paris.

As the Japanese still struggled to get a foothold on the south bank of the Yangtze River above Shanghai, Chinese planes bombed them, while the defending land forces waged bitter battle along a twenty-mile front from Woosung to Liuho. The Chinese airmen also raided the foe's air base on Tsungming Island in the Yangtze estuary.
Repercussions from the labor rivalry in the United States between the American Federation of Labor and the C. I. O. have come out into the open here for the first time.

Ignace Jan Paderewski, ex-Premier of Poland, caused a sensation in Poland today by issuing a manifesto in grave, admonitory language warning his countrymen against the introduction of totalitarianism in Poland, which, in his opinion, would lead to civil war.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Sept. 1 unless specified: At Shanghal: Bulmer. Stewart. At Poughkeepsie: Potomac, Selfridge. N. O. B., Norfolk to Washington Yard, Sept. 2: Decatur, Dickerson. Acushnet, Norfolk to Washington Yard via Potomac River points. Alden, at Peltaiho. Sept. 2.
Edward C. Gude, a partner of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Gude, Winmill Co., died yesterday at the age of 66. His home was at 117 East Seventy-second Street.

The children of crowded Chinatown and vicinity got their second playground yesterday. But-it's not exactly in Chinatown. It's a stone's throw away, at the Bowery and Bayard Street, adjoining Manhattan Bridge, on the site. of. a former "trolley turn-around."

The Lincoln Building Corporation, owner of the 53-story Lincoln Building at 60 East Forty-second Street and 303-305 MadisonAvenue, has bought the adjoining five-story structure at 301 Madison Avenue from the Henry William Company.

Charles Yates, Atlanta, Ga., defeated Tommy Goodwin. New York, 3 and 2; Hunter Hicks, Chicago, defeated Chick Harbert, Battle Creek, Mich., 5 and 4; Charles Kocsis, Detroit, defeated Bob Conliff Jr., Oklahoma City, 1 up; Roger Kelly, Los Angeles, defeated Leo Martin, Boston, 6 and 5.

Twenty-one persons, including two attorneys of Boston, Mass., and two convicted associates of Wallace G. Garland, former student of Yale University, who was found guilty recently of mail fraud, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on a charge of swindling the public of $500,000 three years ago in the sale of 40,000 shares of stock of the Bradford Oil Company of Palmer, Mass.

Under a contract signed yesterday between the General Theatres Equipment Corporation and Electrical Research Products, Inc., a subsidiary of the Western Electric Company, General Theatres Equipment will have a full but not exclusive license under all "Erpi" patents on sound-recording equipment and will both manufacture and distribute that equipment through its subsidiaries.

Trading in some cuts was active. Business, as a whole, was only fair. However, steer beef was strong to higher; cow, bull and fresh pork cuts steady to lower; veal and calf steady; lamb steady to strong. Due to the holiday next Monday,

Bob Feller, boy wonder of the pitching industry, definitely re-established himself today as the potential mound wizard of the future, and a gathering of 15,000, after suffering through several agonizing moments in the sweltering heat, thundered its approval when the performance was over.

Management of the Roxy Theatre will pass to the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation today when Howard S. Cullman, as receiver and trustee, relinquishes his stewardship of nearly five years through which he has successfully rehabilitated a major business enterprise.

Building construction awards in the week ended yesterday, totaling $41,625,000, were 11 per cent above the same week of 1936, when the figure was $37,730,000, according to the Engineering News-Record.
From all along the salt-water front come reports of good catches. It doesn't seem to matter which port you select, you're practically assured of good sport from all.

Bond values declined over a broad front in somewhat more active trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Leadership in the downward movement was shared by United States Government loans and railroad bonds as the lack of support in these groups resulted in rather sharp declines on only a moderate turnover.
Bamberger, Amy V. Krickser, Blume, Sophie E. Boehm, Rebecca Brokaw, Daniel DeW. Buel, John Laidlaw Burg, Elizabeth C. Burke, John W. Carter, William D. Collins, Joseph D. Conroy, Mary M.

Terrific winds, which descended from the Greenland Ice Cap Wednesday at 2 A. M., forced the schooner of the MacGregor Arctic Expedition from her moorings. The winds were estimated at a velocity of from 80 to 100 miles an hour.

Secretary Wallace today announced the first of the quota regulations under the new Sugar Act, signed yesterday by Presidcnt Roosevelt, and in accordance with its terms, determined the consumption requirements for continental United States for this year to be 7,042,733 short tons, raw value, as compared with 6,812,687 short tons established in 1936.

Maybelle Outcalt, 15, one of two girl victims of infantile paralysis for whom artificial breathing devices were rushed to -Denver from the East, died today, physicians at Denver General Hospital reported.

Koki Hirota, Japanese Foreign Minister, invited foreign correspondents to meet him, yesterday and parried with the coolness he is accustomed to display when answering questions in Parliament, all efforts to obtain from him a comprehensive statement on Japanese objectives in China.

Estate, less than $500. To Elizabeth Ament, mother, petitioner, 3,317 Wisconsin Ave., N. W., Washington, D. C., onefourth residue; Gertrude R. Keller. friend, 111 E. 48th St., three-fourths residue; several other bequests.
In a game which was slow to reach a galloping pace, Argentina's San Jose polo team moved to a 14-to-4 victory over Aurora in a test match at Mitchel Field today.
Two United States marines ran into trouble today when they sought to take pictures outside the embassy quarter as Japanese troops were marching through Peiping.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Stearns of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Annis Burnham Stearns, to Frederick Spofford Gilbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Spofford Gilbert of Englewood.
The engagement of Miss Joan Corboy Strahan to Edward Daniel Hurley of Belmont, Mass., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. J. Strahan of 161 East Seventy-ninth Street.

William Darrow Carter, an auditor for the last fifteen years with the Charles Hellmuth Ink Company in New Gud York City, died today at his home here after a four-month illness. His age was 70. Born in Waterbury, Conn., Mr. Carter attended Williams College and was graduated from Yale.
The four-family frame dwelling at 132-4 Goodwin Avenue, Newark, N. J., has been sold by the Paramount Building and Loan Association to Max Sabin for investment.

Charles H. bartlett, lecturer and authority on the American Inaidan, died today at the home of his daughter, Mrs. George T. Rogers, in Lake Forest, near here. He was 83 years old. Mr. Bartlett resigned as a high school principal at South Bend, Ind., in 1903 to manage the New England office of Charles Scribner's Sons, a position he held until 1927.
Mrs. Opal S. Hill's 66, turned in during tournament play yesterday, received tentative recognition by the United States Golf Association today as a world record for women.

The PierceArrow Motor Corporation's stockholders approved today a reorganization program which provides for a new company to take over the present business and raise $10,700,000 through sale of stock.

The National Electric Products Corporation of near-by Ambridge appealed today to the United States Circuit Court at Philadelphia for a solution of its perplexing labor situation created by clashing opinions of the National Labor Relations Board and the Federal District Court here.

Fireman First Grade Michael J. Murphy of Engine 97 died Sept. 1. Funeral will take place from Boyerton Funeral Parlor, 188th St. and Webster Ave., Bronx, at 9:30 A. M., Saturday, Sept. 4. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

Prelates disclosed tonight that the Holy See "sympathizes" with a long pastoral letter signed by two Spanish Cardinals and forty-six other prelates of Insurgent Spain, which declares the revolt of General Francisco Franco to be a "legitimate" one.

Federal Judge Albert L. Reeves ruled today that the Washburn Crosby Flour Mills may retain about $2,000,000 in refunded processing taxes and need not redistribute it among bakers. Washburn Crosby has headquarters in Minneapolis.
The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System today approved the action of the Federal Reserve Banks of Kansas City and San Francisco in reducing their discount rates from 2 to 1 1/2 per cent.

Four new pictures will have Broadway premieres today. They are Sonja Henie's "Thin Ice," featuring Tyrone Power and Arthur Treacher, at the Roxy; "Bulldog Drummond Comes Back," with John Barrymore, John Howard and Louise Campbell, at the Criterion; "Borneo" the Martin Johnsons' jungle epic, at the Rialto, and the Russian "Baltic Deputy," which comes tonight to the Cameo...

The New York Stock Exchange has been notified by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation that holders of common stock of record of Sept. 8 will receive rights to buy fifteenyear convertible 3 1/2 per cent debentures due in 1952 at par to the extent of $15 of debentures for each share of stock held.

Frankie Wallace, veteran Cleveland lightweight, outpointed George Zengaras of the East Side in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 3,500 persons saw the Ohio battler bring all his ring craft and generalship into play to defeat the sturdy New Yorker.

26th St, 127-33 W, 12-story brick loft and store building, 87.6x98.9: Metropolitan Life Insurance Co against Plymouth Fund, due, $345,600; to plaintiff for $240,000. Eldridge St, 197. 5-story brick tenement and stores, Michael H. Cardoze Jr. trustee, against Nicola Mauro, individ and as execr, due, $10,021, taxes, $717; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Domestic sugar futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange made yesterday the sharpest gains in more than ten years on overnight news that President Roosevelt had signed the bill governing the nation's supply of sugar.
Felix M. Warburg will return today on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. He attended sessions of the Jewish Agency for Palestine at Geneva.
Lumber production ?clined more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index has receded to 82.9 from 84.8. It stood at 86.9 for the week ended Aug. 29, 1937.

Scoring twice in the second half, the veterans of the Brooklyn Football Dodgers defeated the newcomers on the squad, 14 to 0, in an exhibition game before a crowd of 3,000 at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, last night.

Heavy investments in short-term securities were made by the Bank of Canada in the week ended yesterday, the weekly statement indicated today. Holdings of Dominion and Provincial Government short-term securities were increased nearly $12,000,000.
President Roosevelt left here this afternoon on board his yacht Potomac to spend five or six days cruising on Long Island and Block Island Sounds.

To provide room for expansion of its business the 0. Z. Electrical Manufacturing Company, Michael J. Cafiero, president, has purchased from John, Elmer and Elizabeth Zimmer the two-story factory building at 262-66 Bond Street, Brooklyn.
