Rapid expansion of foreign sales of airconditioning equipment was indicated by figures made public today by the Machinery Division of the Department of Commerce, which showed such export sales for the first six months of this year valued at $704,756, compared with $863,482 for all of 1936.
The Spanish Government mustered an array of its leading statesmen today to present charges of aggression against Italy before the Council of the League of Nations.

Owing to sharp decreases in the wholesale prices of farm products and foods, there was a decline in the level of wholesale commodity prices in the week ended on Aug. 28, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

The committee on securities of the New York Curb Exchange has ruled that transactions in new $1.60 dividend convertible preferred stock of Standard Dredging Corporation must be settled by delivery of permanent certificates.

Miss Theodosia Burr Andrews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Andrews of this place and New York, was married at noon today to Earl Seaton Neal, son of Mrs. Helen A. Neal of Berkeley, Calif., in the Englewood home of the bride's parents. The Very Rev.

Mike Petrone, unattached Morristown shotmaker, annexed the third annual New Jersey State public links golf championship today when he defeated Joe Sage, Bronx boy representing Teterboro, 2 up, in the eighteen-hole final at the Spring Brook Country Club.
Senator Borah predicted guardedly today that the Senate would go on record against a Presidential third term if the issue reached a vote.
The body of Daniel De Witt Brokaw, son of Mr. and Mrs. De Witt Brokaw of Plainfield, N. J., who was drowned yesterday while swimming in Mecox Bay, was recovered last night by State police.
With all the Graustarkian punctilio this corner can muster up, we rise, click our heels, toast the Selznick International production of "The Prisoner of Zenda" and smash the glass.
Because they bore the legend, "Made in Germany," Borough President Samuel Levy yesterday indignantly rejected a shipment of twenty-four cuspidors sent to his office from the Department of Purchase.

Miss Isabella Markell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Markell of 10 Gracie Square and Gibson Island, Md., has completed plans for her marriage on Sept. 11 to Arthur Hamilton Clephane of Washington, D. C., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Allan C. Clephane. The ceremony will take place in St. Christopher'sby-the-Sea, Gibson Island.

2d Ave, 1,534-6; 52.16x100; for 1-story stores; Mrs. Alice M. Scully, 234 Westchester Ave, Crestwood, N. Y., owner; E. L. Chisling, architect; cost, $20,000. Alterations 8th Ave, 851-865; to 1-story stores; Franklin Savings Bank, 8th Ave and 42d St,, owner: Corbett MacMurray, architects; cost, $40,000.

Posting a sparkling round of 70, two under par, Robert Grant of the Wethersfield Country Club, Hartford, captured the medalist honors in the qualifying round of the annual Torrington invitation amateur golf tournament on the Torrington Country Club links today.

New York University's squad of forty-three football candidates arrived today to begin a three-week period of preparation for the appreaching campaign. The grou was headed by Coach Mal Stevens and his staff.

FROM time to time within the past year and a half the press has carried stories of the Senate civil liberties investigation. It has been, perhaps, the most fully reported of all official inquiries since that involving Teapot Dome, and certainly one of the most sensational.

Miss Anne Margaret Ebsen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lydig Ebsen of this place became the bride tonight of John Lewis Buckley, son of Mrs. Thomas J. Buckley of Tenafly and the late Major Buckley. The ceremony was performed at St. Paul's Episcopal Church here by the Rev. J. Jack Sharkey, curate.
Stocks closed steadier at lower levels after early weakness; turnover 1,204.400 shares. United States Government and corporation bonds lower; foreign issues irregular; transactions $6,629,950.

Philip Frederick Andress and Robert Allen Andress are twins, but do not nave the same birthday because Philip Frederick is nearly sixteen hours older than Robert Allen and was born on Aug. 31 at 10:30 A. M., whereas Robert Allen was not born until 2:14 A. M. on Sept. 1.

The marriage of Miss Clarice Beatrice Alexander, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. I. Henry Alexander of this city, to Arthur G. Reisman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Reisman, also of New York, took place last night at the Hotel Olcott. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Louis I. Newman of Temple Rodeph Sholom.

The Federal Reserve System got quick action last week in its new campaign to make discounting attractive to the member banks. Member-bank borrowings from the system rose about $5,000,000 to a total of $24,000,000, which was a gain of about 26 per cent.
In Kalgan, gateway to the northwest and capital of Chahar Province, a Japanese-fostered "Peace Maintenance Commission" has been established.

Winning for the third time in three weeks, Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden overcame the terrific heat and the rolling hills of the Wykagyl course today to card a fine 42, 42-84 for the low gross prize in the women's Westchester and Fairfield one-day golf tournament.

The State Department has asked its consular officers in Northern Spain to ascertain the fate of Harold E. Dahl of Champaign, Ill., who was captured by the Franco forces while flying as a military aviator for the Valencia Government.
The Phillips Petroleum Company, New York City, has filed a registration
With only one dissenting voice the Veterans of Foreign Wars voted today to call upon the nation to establish a policy of mandatory neutrality, to outlaw war, except against invaders;

Mrs. J. Henry Alexandre and Miss Cathleen Fox gave a large reception this afternoon at the Irving. A feature of the entertainment was a showing of the latest costumes for Autumn and Winter wear, in which young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons acted as manikins.

A warrant was issued tonight for the arrest of Supervisor Arthur J. Kreutzer of the town of Huntington, Republican member of the County Board of Supervisors, on charges that he had obtained an order to sell boilers and radiators to the plumbing and heating contractor on the $600,000 county home and infirmary under construction at Yaphank.

With a patience that was quite extraordinary in the face of previous lost opportunities, the Giants waited until the tenth inning to bowl over the Cardinals at the Polo Grounds yesterday and then, in a complete about-face, punched over two runs to win, 5-4, and stretch their lead over the beaten Cubs to one game in the sizzling National League pennant race.

The engagement of Miss Mildred Mari Singer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry R. Singer of Highland Park, this place, to Samuel Stephen Colman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Goodman Colman of Newark, has been announced by her parents.

The store which recently was constructed in the center of the driveway of the Montana apartment house, at 375 Park Avenue, with show windows on four sides, has been leased by the 375 Park Avenue Florist, Charles Pappas, proprietor, by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., for the 373 Park Avenue Corporation.
Joe Bernard, senior guard on the Fordham varsity football squad, was injured during a practice session at Fordham Field yesterday and was removed to Fordham Hospital.

Two quietly determined servants, an English butler and a maid, astounded this exclusive colony today by stepping out of their downstairs role to claim, over the heads of a number of socially prominent friends and relatives, the $1,000,000 fortune left by their mistress, Mrs. Frederic de Puyster Foster.

Frazier Jelke opened his Summer home, Eagle's Nest, tonight for a violin recital by Alessandro Niccoli, who was assisted by two members of the colony, Mrs. Reginald B. Lanier as soprano soloist and Mrs. Lewis A. Armistead as piano soloist and accompanist. There were more than one hundred present.

Counsel for the Austin Silver Mining Company labored yesterday to demonstrate that Klopstock Co., bankers for the company, had made no deal for favorable publicity with Albert K. Ettlinger, a financial writer for The New York WorldTelegram.

All but about $1,500,000 of Republic Steel Corporation 41/2 per cent Series A general mortgage bonds, due in 1950, of which $24,000,000 was offered late in 1935, had been converted or retired by the sinking fund up to the close of business on Wednesday, when the conversion rate changed from forty-five common shares for each $1,000 bond to forty common shares for each bond.

Mayor La Guardia issued a call yesterday for the city's Banking Commission to meet next Tuesday to adopt a resolution increasing the city's income from interest on its deposits by about $200,000 a year.
The City Bank Farmers Trust Company has been made transfer agent for 500,000 common shares of Philip A. Singer Bros., Inc

Although outhit, 12 to 7, the Athletics retained their slim hold on seventh place in the American League race by defeating the Browns today, 5 to 3. A defeat for the Mackmen would have pushed them back into the cellar.

For more than two hours yesterday more than 200 Bronx boys and girls between the ages of 12 and 17 dodged the heat by participating in a water carnival sponsored by the Police Athletic League at the Cascades Swimming Pool, Jerome Avenue and 168th Street, the Bronx.

A trade practice conference for producers of rayon or cellulose yarns, one of the purposes of which will be to formulate rules for the designation and describing of such yarns and fibers, will be held by the Federal Trade Commission about Sept. 16 in New York, the commission announced today.

The Trans-Canada Air Lines, the Government controlled service now being established, will have at least one terminal in the United States and two American citizens are helping to put it into operation.
Italian circles today continued to declare they had no information on the attack by an unidentified submarine on the British destroyer Havock.

Professor Magnus MacLean, Professor Emeritus of Electrical Engineering at the Royal Technical College of Glasgow, who in his earlier career was associated with the late Lord Kelvin in scientific research, died here today at the age of 80. Among his best known achievements was a scientific contribution in connection with the laying of the transatlantic cables.

A substantial increase in retail combinationn deals in drug items under the fair trade acts was foreseen here yesterday as several manufacturers pushed plans for combination offers at prices lower than those set in the price-maintenance contracts for the individual products.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Sept. 1 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:
John Drake, former Purdue backfield star, signed a contract today to play with the Cleveland Rams, youngest member of the National Professional Football League.

William H. Brown, chief clerk of this city's engineering department, and oldest municipal employee in point of service, died last night at Mountainside Hcspital in Montclair, after a four-month illness. His age was 62.
Approaches to world peace, spiritual and economic, were under discussion at today's sessions of the Friends' World Conference at Swarthmore and Haverford Colleges.

Turpentine firm, 31c; sales 89 barrels; receipts 464 barrels; shipments 140 barrels; stock 34,216 barrels. Resin firm; sales 61: receipts 1,076; shipments 940; stock 97,839. Quote: B, $7.80; D, E, $7.85; F to K, $7.95; M, $7.95-$8.05; N, $8.05; WG, $8.10; WW, X, $8.75.
Lord and Lady Fairfax of Cameron, who have been visiting here from London, are at the Ritz-Carlton, accompanied by Lord Fairfax's sister, Mrs. Clarence M. Roberts of Landover, Md.

Mixed movements in commodity prices were responsible for The Annalist's index of wholesale commodity prices remaining unchanged at 93.7 on Tuesday. Textiles declined, but all other component groups advanced, notably food products.
The Orioles defeated Newark, 7 to 6, tonight in a fifteen-inning thriller before 15,000 fans, largest local baseball crowd in a decade.

Show time having arrived again in this laggard town, the Rockefellers have filled their cavernous Center Theatre with a musical romance, "Virginia," which opened amid the accustomed splendors last evening.

Today, on its thirtieth anniversary, the Hupp Motor Car Corporation, which has been out of productive activity for more than eighteen months, unveiled its 1938 car, details of which will be made public on Sept. 12. Today's event was for about 150 automobile editors and technical writers.

A new "protective committee for holders of preferred stock of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company" filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission an application for authority to solicit and use authorization from holders of the stock and to represent their interests in the pending reorganization of the railroad.

It is not surprising that the President should have signed the Sugar Bill, in spite of his strong objections to certain provisions in it. If he had vetoed the measure, the entire system of quotas and control would have automatically terminated at the end of the year.

A hearing has been called for Sept. 22 by the Securities and Exchange Commission on an application by the Illinois Power Company, Monticello, Ill., a subsidiary of the Illinois Traction Company, for approval of its acquisition of $25,000,000 par value of common stock and $15,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds 4 per cent series,

Thomas J. Hamilton Sr., postmaster and civic leader of Augusta, died at his home here last night of a heart attack. He was 51 years old. In 1919 Mr. Hamilton became editor and president of The Augusta Chronicle. He sold his interest in The Chronicle in 1929 but remained as editor until Aug. 4 this year. In 1924 he directed the McAdoo-forPresident campaign in Georgia.

This sturdy vessel conducting the Government's eastern Arctic patrol swung at anchor tonight in Bellot Strait far up in Canada's northern islands with all hands aboard mystified by strange flares seen in the southern sky early this morning.

In its complete report on our balance of international payments for 1936 the Department of Commerce shows that, although a small surplus of merchandise exports existed, it was far more than offset by other trade and service items.

A crowd of 3,000 broke through police cordons today to greet the bride and bridegroom after Dorothy Round, all-England tennis champion, was married to Dr. Douglas Leigh Little in Wesley Methodist Church here.

The two physicians who were arrested in Atlantic City yesterday by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as an aftermath of the vice raids conducted Sunday in three States by Federal authorities were released here tonight in their own custody.
Ten Tacoma department stores, closed by a strike since July 23, reopened today. The stores signed a working agreement with the clerks and thirteen other craft unions.
Charles Co. will retire from the wholesale liquor business on Oct. 1 and the sales staff will be merged with the liquor division of R. C. Williams Co., Inc., it was announced yesterday. Arthur P.

Countess Gianguilio Rucellai of Florence, Italy, has come over on the Rex and will visit her mother, Mrs. George Higginson, and sister, Mrs. John H. P. Gould, at Mahkeenac Farm, Stockbridge. The Countess is the former Miss Theresa Higginson.
Tammany Hall struck sharply yesterday at the Manhattan Democrats backing the candidacy of Jeremiah T. Mahoney.

Realization of the plan for a ninety-three-acre East Bronx Park, at the mouth of the Bronx River, will come a step nearer today when the city expects to take title to the land, it was announced yesterday by the Department of Parks.
A new oxygen mask, which looks like a tightly rolled towel tied over the mouth, protects mental workers from fatigue caused by thinking.

While the remnants of the Government's northern army, mostly Asturians, are in full flight toward Gijon and negotiations for the surrender of that port, according to trustworthy reports, are already proceeding,

The Eastern College All-Stars sharpened their weapons for the game with the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds next Wednesday night in a two-hour scrimmage against the Manhattan College squad at Peddie School today.

Though the city campaign is still in its early stages, more than the usual number of irrelevant issues have already made their appearance. Thus Mr. Mahoney and Senator Copeland are busily debating the New Deal: Mr.

Mr. Frank Polk in his 1938 budget request for the Public Library (serving Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond) asked for what seems a modest increase in the grant for the library staff, described by him as "the lowest-paid group in the city service."

Trading in the wool goods markets continued slow this week and, with backlogs diminishing repidly, a number of manufacturers shut down machinery as contracts expired, according to the report Issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

Charles W. Lange has resigned as executive secretary of the Park West-Riverside Associates to become vice president and general manager of Earle Calhoun, wellknown West Side real estate firm, effective Nov. 1. Creation of the new office was reported to be the result of expansion of the firm's business.
Robert P. Allen, director of sanctuaries for the National Association of Audubon Societies, 1,775 Broadway, predicted yesterday a record Autumn bird migration for Southern New Jersey.

Supreme Court Justice John H. McCooey declined yesterday to comment on allegations made by striking waiters of Joe's restaurant, 8 Nevins Street, Brooklyn, that he and his family were served food and liquor there for many years without paying a cent.

A total of 1,405 first year students will arrive at the Pennsylvania State College Wednesday for a week of instruction before the Fall semester begins. Thousands of other qualified students applied for admission, but the entering class was limited to 1,405 by action of the board of trustees because of the limitations of the present physical plant and the teaching staff.
Otis Montrose, owner and publisher of The Cold Spring Recorder, weekly newspaper published here, died here this morning at the home of his daughter, Mrs. A. E. Cooley. He was 73 years old.

Ten minutes after the start the Swedish six-meter Tidsfordrif II had the fourth race in the series for the Scandinavian Gold Cup won today. All she had to do after that was to protect her lead and she did it handsomely, even though the well-known reaching and running qualities of the American defender Lulu cut down a lot.

Of many events planned for the Labor Day week-end in Easthampton, probably the largest number will attend the two performances of the musical production of Aristophanes' "The Birds," being given in the water garden of Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse's Greycroft at 5 o'clock on Saturday and Sunday afternoons.

Before President Roosevelt left here for a vacation cruise on Long Island Sound today he had completed action on every bill passed at the last session of Congress, approving 897 and vetoing 40 of the 937 sent to the White House.

The Bank of Frane lowered today its discount rate from 4 to 33 per cent to make loans cheaper in keeping with Finance Minister Georges Bonnet's plans for rebuilding the nation's economic and financial structure.

Automotive advertising, with a gain of 29.87 per cent, led the major classification increases in Manhattan newspapers in August, according to a statistical survey here yesterday. The automotive total was 212,797 lines, against 163,856 in the same month a year ago.

Grave anxiety is felt here for Dr. Thomas G. Masaryk, former President of Czechoslovakia, who was taken seriously ill early this morning with internal pain, accompanied by a weakening of his heart action. On receipt of the news, Dr.

The newspaper Pravda, official organ of the Communist party, announced today that Panas Petrovich Liubchenko, Premier of the Ukrainian Republic and an old-time Bolshevik, had committed suicide because he was involved in anti-Soviet activities.
Attorney General Bennett ruled today that "only in cases of emergency" can employes of State institutions be required to work more than eigh' hours daily.
The Board of Elections announced yesterday that 2,030 persons had taken advantage of the central registration law in July and August. Of these, 1,335 were men and 695 were women.

Mayor La Guardia has formally accepted an invitation to speak at a luncheon of Republican women at the Hotel Commodore on Monday, Sept. 13, three days before the primary election, it was announced yesterday by the La Guardia campaign headquarters.

At a hearing before Charles Moore, trial examiner of the Securities and Exchange Commission, on an application by the Los Angeles Stock Exchange for unlisted trading privileges in sixteen securities registered on the New York Stock Exchange,

The report of the New York City Omnibus Corporation and subsidiaries (consolidating Madison Avenue Coach Company, Inc., and the Eighth Avenue Coach Corporation) for the month of July shows a net income after interest, depreciation, amortization and Federal income taxes, but before surtax on excess profits of $97,023.
One way of putting it would be to say that we live in an "un-" world. There is raging in China an undeclared war.

HARRY BARTH, INC., hotel supplies. 404 4th Ave.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of $160,517 and assets of $238,500. Harry Barth, founder and president of the corporation, died on Aug. 25.

The marriage of Miss Mary Elizabeth Scranton, daughter of William D. Scranton, to James Thomas O'Connor Jr. of this city took place today in St. Joseph's Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Matthew Brady of Spring Glen. The bride was given in marriage by her father.

Senator Wagner, as author of the National Labor Relations Act, was urged today to take issue with the board charged with its administration and join with the Brotherhood of Electrical Workers in protesting the NLRB decision in the National Electrical Products case.

The Federal Home Loan Bank of New York announced yesterday the admission to membership in the system of Aetna Permanent Savings and Loan Association of Buffalo, N. Y., County Federal Savings and Loan Association of Rockville Center, L. I., and the Lackawanna Building and Loan Association of East Orange, N. J.

Federal Judge Carroll C. Hirfcks ruled today that the Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company .might recover $1,847,715 of claims aggregating more than $43,000,000 against the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company and its trolley and bus subsidiary, the Connecticut Company.
Elmer D. Hays, assistant counsel for the Federal Communications Commission; his wife, their son and the youth's school chum died today in the collision of his automobile and a bus.

Admiral Harry E. Yarnell, Commander in Chief of the United States Asiatic Fleet, announced today that when American merchant vessels call at Shanghai in the future each will be escorted by at least one naval convoy.

The stock markets, influenced by the break in Wall Street prices and uncertainties over the international situation, suffered a further setback today. Gilt-edge issues and foreign loans were dull. International stocks, although rallying from the lowest levels, closed weaker, and United States Steel and International Nickel were off.

The Treasury ended the first two months of the fiscal year on Aug. 31 with a deficit of $352,144,659, compared with $349,745,334 a year ago, according to figures available today, but officials apparently were convinced that there was substantial hope of reaching a balance, exclusive of sinking-fund require. ments on the public debt, by the end of the fiscal year on June 3C next.

Thomas Joyce, a builder of one and two family homes and apartment houses in Woodside, Elmhurst and Jackson Heights for the last fifteen years, died yesterday a heart ailment at his home, 83-51 Vietor Avenue, Elmhurst. He was 68 years old.

Scoring a major upset, Bill Holt of Syracuse, N. Y., defeated defending champion Paul Leslie of Louisiana State University, 1 up, on the twentieth hole in the second round of the Western amateur championship at Los Angeles Country Club today.
The old specter of port paralysis loitered today behind the stiffening lines of a C. I. O.-A. F. of L. controversy, suddenly placed before the National Labor Relations Board.

Of the 841,664 civil employes in the executive branch of the Governnent at the close of the fiscal rear, 682,164, or 81 per cent, were men, and 159,500, or 19 per cent, were women, the Civil Service Commission reported today.

Representatives of the Suit Case, Bag and Portfolio Makers Union ratified a two-year contract with the Luggage and Leather Goods Manufacturers Association at a mass meeting held last evening at the Irving Plaza, Irving Place and Fifteenth Street.

With thousands of tourist trailers, automobiles and huge floats rolling over the nation's roads toward New York City for the American Legion's national convention, the Bronx and several communities in New Jersey were planning in a big way yesterday to absorb the vehicles in free camps and parking grounds.

All schools in Upper Bavaria as well as in Munich and its suburbs will be closed until Sept. 15 because of an epidemic of infantile paralysis. The Munich health authorities have declined to supply figures, but it is reported that 38 have died thus far and 305 are affected.

Cornelea St, 21, 20x97.6; Harry Casper to Central Hanover Bank Trust Co. and another, trustee of Lorillard Spencer 2d, p m mtg, 5 years, 3 to 4 1/2%, $10,000. Thompson St, 105, 24.10xl00; William J. Ryan to Albert H. Cross, trustee of Amelia B. Lockwood, 20 Claremont Rd. Scarsdale, N. Y., to Building Loan, due Sept 1, 1942; 5 1/2%, $5,000.

As a result of Dr. Wilhelm Furtwaengler's now sensational Salzburg colloquy with Arturo Toscanini last week when Maestro Toscanini told the German conductor in no uncertain terms that the Prussian State Councillor, who conducted at Baireuth and thus embodied a certain ideology, should not try to extend his artistic activities to Salzburg, Dr. Furtwaengler will not conduct at Vienna next month as he planned.

The generally believed theory that it's bad luck to be medalist was refuted by curly-haired Jack Gerlin, 18-year-old Garden City High School graduate, in today's opening round of the annual Long Island junior golf championship.

H. D. Powell, Manhassett, L. I., today captured the New York State rifle medal when he shot 93 out of a possible 100 in the civilian club members' match. The winning score in this match was 97, made by Clifford Anderson, Provo, Utah.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Field Haviland of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Adine Antoinette Haviland, to Roger Garis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard R. Garis, also of East Orange. Miss Haviland, who is an artist, has been associated with the Artists' Gallery in New York for the last year.

The Western racer, Woodberry, who was a surprise victor in his previous start at Saratoga, performed just as well at Aqueduct yesterday when he was made the odds-on favorite at 9 to 10 in a field of four.

A war scare came to the fore today as the main influence in the grain markets and brought in sufficient short covering to lift wheat prices around 3 cents a bushel at the extreme on the Board of Trade here and in Winnipeg.

Realty and construction experts are watching with more than usual interest the statistics on building operations at the approach of the Fall season, in an effort to ascertain whether the recent decline in this field has been merely a temporary setback or the beginning of a period of slackening activity.

Statements of earnings of twenty-three major oil companies for the six months ended on June 30 show an aggregate net income of $187,239,539, compared with $124,460,410 in the same period of 1936, a gain of 50.4 per cent, according to Carl H. Pforzheimer Co.
Ninety-nine striking painters were arrested yesterday as they picketed hotels in the midtown section of Manhattan. Three were arrested in Brooklyn.
CHINESE BOMBS UPSET JAPANESE PLANS TO LAND TROOPS AND GUNS FOR DRIVE; WARSHIPS WILL ESCORT OUR SHIPPING

The Allied Stores Corporation reported yesterday for the year ended on July 31 a net profit of $4,166,552 after depreciation, interest and other charges but before Federal income taxes and the surtax on undistributed profits.

IT was a good year for tomatoes and Onkel Franz Frisch, the New Rochelle farmer, admitted as much. He had just come out of his garden. Beans wer epretty good. Corn was just so-so. Late rains hadn't helped it any. There were grubs in it.
The East Lynn (Mass.) Junior American Legion baseball team took a two-game lead in the "little world series" today by beating New Orleans, 5 to 0.

Addressing himself to the "30,000,000 Germans living in all parts of the world," Col. Gen. Hermann Goering told the Congress of Germans Abroad today that they must always consider themselves National Socialists. A world-wide radio hook-up was arranged for the benefit of these unseen millions.
Thousands of New Yorkers, taking advantage of the three-day Labor Day week-end, will start flocking out of the city today to spend the last Summer holiday in other sections of the country.

After declining more than 1 1/2 cents a pound since Aug. 14 until near months sold within a few points of the 9 cents that the Government will lend on cotton this year, prices of cotton recovered $1.50 a bale yesterday.

Announcement has been made by the Rev. William Neely Colton, rector of St. Barnabas Church here, of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Margaret Williamina Colton, to Joseph Gaston McMahon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. McMahon of Ossining.
Sixty-seven pounds of raw opium, valued at $8,375, was found on board the Manhattan of the United States Lines at Quarantine yesterday.

Axel Wenner-Gren, the wealthiest man in Sweden, announced today that he and his wife had established the Wenner-Gren Society for scientific research and furthering inter-Scandinavian cooperation. They have contributed stocks worth 25,000,000 Swedish kroner.
Evidently disregarding the claim of Max Schmeling to a fight with Joe Louis, Mike Jacobs yesterday announced he will go through with plans to conduct a heavyweight elimination tournament to provide

The French Government announced yesterday that Marcel Olivier, chairman of the board of the French Line, had been appointed French Commissioner General to the New York 1939 World's Fair, according to a cable message received yesterday by Jean L. Artur, assistant general manager of the line here.

Lee Miles, former United States airplane racing champion, was killed just before dark this evening in a crash during a test flight preliminary to the National Air Races here. Miles dived across the starting line from a height of about 900 feet. As he banked the plane for the turn at the first pylon on the edge of the airport the wings of his racer folded. He was then about 200 feet high.

Only $312,000, or about 1 per cent, of the $30,000,000 of Youngstown Sheet and Tube convertible 3 1/2 per cent debentures sold in April, 1936, was not converted into common stock prior to the redemption of the bonds at 104 and accrued interest on Aug. 25, last.

Apartments in buildings on Fifth and Park Avenues continue to attract tenants seeking new quarters on the East Side for occupancy in the early Fall. The approach of the traditional moving day finds brokers and renting agents adding many names to tenant rosters, and some agents report that buildings in their care are filling up early in the seasonal rush.

Employment in the steel industry during July recovered completely from the effects of the June strikes, and rose to 594,000, only 0.25 per cent below the record total of 595,000 employes in May, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

A news sensation here today was the announcement from Tokyo that the Chinese Ambassador, Hsu Shihying, had spent a half hour conferring with Foreign Minister Koki Hirota and had expressed readiness on behalf of China to conclude a non-aggression pact with Japan.
Edward F. Sharpless, 66, who for more than twenty years was an internationally famous ventriloquist known as "The Great Reynard," died at hi home today of annpoplexy.
Dr. Edward G. Dolan of Manchester, Conn., was sworn in today as Register of the Treasury, succeeding the late W. W. Durbin. Dr. Dolan,
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:

The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Aug. 31: Walter. Commander E. L., Naval Training Station, San Diego. Calif.; to the Nevada. Saunders. Lt. Comdr. F. A., the Wright; to 14th Naval District, Pearl Harbor. Butterfield, Lt. H. B., VB-3 (the Saratoga); to command the VCS-3.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended Aug. 21 totaled 309,699,000 barrels, according to the Bureat of Mines. Compared with the previous week, this is a net increase of 962,000 barrels, 534,000 and 428,000
Lazard Freres Co., Inc., headed a successful syndicate in the purchase yesterday of a new issue of $930,000 of water works, hospital, sewer, prison and street bonds of the city of Augusta, Ga.

Municipal bond issues aggregating $6,612,200 were approved by voters of forty-seven municipalities in thirty-one States in August, compared with $10,017,836 of bonds approved in July, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The total for August, 1936, was $7,186,700.
Mari Sandoz, author of the prizewinning biography, "Old Jules," will have a first novel published by Little, Brown in November. The title is "Slogum House." It is an Atlantic Monthly Press book.

Edmund J. Tinsdale, referee of the New York Superior Court for forty years, and a former Acting Justice of the New York Supreme Court, died at a sanitarium here today. He had been ill since Saturday. His age was 87.

Relatives and friends of a $2,300a-year WPA aide, who died Monday in St. Vincent's Hospital, were being sought by the police yesterday when the man's death revealed that he was an engineer, once the head of two corporations and a former instructor at Stevens Institute of Technology.

Sir Malcolm Campbell gave the motor boat world a new international record really worth shooting at today. For the second time in two days the British sportsman, holder of the land speed record of 301.13 miles per hour, smashed Gar Wood's 5year-old standard of 124.86 m. p. h. for unlimited hydroplanes.

Slippery Ranger, Harold S. Vanderbilt's phenomenal big sloop, won her twenty-eighth race today in the wind-up of the season for the America's Cup craft. With only two losses against her, and those anything but black marks, she stands out pre-eminently as the fastest of ships under sail.

A "Spend your parole at Cape Cod" movement was reported under way in Georgia today following Governor E. D. Rivers's release of a prisoner on the condition that he would spend the remainder of his sentence in Massachusetts.

Glass Winer, investors, represented by Hyman Wiener, attorney, bought from Louis Friedenreich the apartment house for twenty-seven families at 2,075 Grand Avenue, the Bronx. They paid cash over a mortgage of $56,500.

Split by a controversy over the propriety of permitting distillers to help defray expenses of annual conventions, the executive committee of the National Conference of State Liquor Administrators will meet here Sept. 21, in an attempt to settle the question.

Shattering par by six strokes to equal the course record of 67, Ralph Guldahl of Chicago, national open champion, and Ray Mangrum of Dayton, Ohio, tied for the lead today at the end of the first round in the seventy-two-hole $5,000 Hershey open golf tournament.
In a session devoted to the public service of the press, the Institute of Public Relations concentrated attention today on the American Newspaper Guild.

I read with great interest your editorial "The Quintuplet Problem," and I thoroughly agree with you that the chief problem facing Dr. Dafoe and the other guardians of the famous sisters is that of giving the five youngsters opportunity to develop as normal individuals.

Columbia St, 132. 24.11x100: Sadie Krakauer to Col-Mor Realty Corp, 132 Columbia St. Cornelia St. 21. 20x97.6; Central Hanover Bank Trust Co et al., trustees Lorilliard Spencer 2d to Harry Casper, 482 7th St, Brooklyn; p m mtg, $10,000 ($12). Same property; Harry Casper to Edw H Romaine, 123 Vaverly Pl; mtg, $10,000 (50c).

Uruguay has decided to recognize Spanish Insurgent General Francisco Franco. The action was determined upon regardless of the general response of other American republics, which have been consulted. Venezuela, for one,

The Netherlands passenger steamer Van Heutsz was driven ashore by the typhoon that struck here early this morning and had a bad hole ripped in her, but every one, including 1,200 Chinese in the steerage, was rescued when the storm abated later in the day.
The British Government lost no time today in replying to the submarine attack which almost sent the destroyer Havock and her 145 men to the bottom of the Mediterranean.

The Rev. Charles W. Gulick, for sixteen years pastor of the. New York Manor Church of the Reformed Church in America, died of a heart attack at his home here yesterday. Mr. Gulick, who retired last year, was 71 years old.

A threatened epidemic of infantile paralysis in Chicago, with disturbing outbreaks in large cities of many Middle Western States, led today to further drastic steps by law enforcement and health authorities to combat spread of the disease.

The marriage of Miss Jane Taylor Whitney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Taylor Whitney of Miami Beach, to Geoffrey V. Azoy, son of Mrs. A. C. M. Azoy of East Orange, N. J., and the late Mr. Azoy, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Ascension.

Rising loans and falling investments again distinguished the movement of bank credit here in the week ended on Wednesday, covered by the condition statements of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, which was issued yesterday.

Mrs. Huntington Clark of Roxbury, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mrs. Eunice Clark, to John Knox Jessup of this city. The prospective bride was graduated from Rosemary Hall, Greenwich, and in 1933 from Vassar College, where she was editor of the Miscellany News.

The Phillies rallied in the eighth inning and apparently scored enough runs to win, but the Pirates stole their thunder in the ninth, tallied five times and won the final game of the series today, 11-8.

During the week ended Sept. 1 member bank reserve balances increased $1,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from increases of $14,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and $8,000,000 in Treasury currency, and from decreases of $21,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and $5,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, offset in part by increases of $37,000,000 in money in circulation and $11,?00,000 in Treasury cash other than inactive gold.

Frank J. Sellmayer Jr., former confidential secretary and farm manager for Pritchard H. Strong, Assemblyman killed in an Albany air crash last week, will be a candidate to succeed Mr. Strong in the Fall election.

George W. Stevenson, retired New York City police lieutenant, died yesterday afternoon at his home in this village, where he had been a resident for twenty years. Mr. er Stevenson, who had been ill for several months, was 63 years old.

Domestic sugar futures dominated the trading in the commodity futures markets yesterday. Prices scored the best advance for a single trading session in more than ten years on the news that President Roosevelt had signed the Sugar Control Bill.

In preparation for what it presumably hopes will be considerable public exposure this season, the Theatre Guild has just about completed a thorough refurbishing of the interior of its favorite house, the Guild Theatre.

Reports that the United States Government has been cool toward British suggestions for cooperative action in regard to the Far Eastern crisis have been received with considerable surprise by State Department officials in close touch with the situation.

British approval of what is set forth here as the French plan for a Mediterranean conference. was received at the Foreign Office with satisfaction. It is hoped that the conference will be called as soon as possible in connection with the Sept. 10

The Fourth day of firing in the women's Mason-Dixon golf tournament assed without an upset today, Miss Virginia Guilfoil of Syracuse scoring a 3-and-1 victory over Mrs. Jack Hoblitzell after losing the first hole when her rival sent an approach shot dead to the pin, leaving a one-foot putt.
Eugene D. Gardner, dean of wood carvers in the United States, died today at Altamont at the age of 76. He was a contemporary of the late Timothy Cole of Poughkeepsie, a noted engraver.

Leaders in every type of sport have been drafted by the Police Department for the Police Athletic League show to be held before 60,000 children next Tuesday in the Yankee Stadium. The sports circus will mark the culmination of the league's Summer activities in the interest of child guidance.

Nanking, which three weeks ago was the prosperous and growing capital of New China now is a stricken city, partly in ruins from a series of ten airplane raids by the Japanese, according to two Americans who arrived here by train from Hangchow and sailed to America on the steamer President Hoover Tuesday.
The Japanese Consulate General here reported today a fleet of seventytwo Russian airplanes had arrived at the North Central Chinese Province of Shensi, 500 air miles from Tientsin.

Cadets of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy demonstarted their skill in operative details of the Empire State, their training ship, before representatives of the State Education Department, school and civic officials yesterday in Long Island Sound off Fort Schuyler.
Thomas Qualters, President Roosevelt's bodyguard and a former Massachusetts State trooper, will be married to Miss Arlene Eade of Lynn at St. Mary's church here Sept. 20.

The police have opened a quiet campaign to rid the city of petty racketeers and criminals who habitually prey upon tourists, it war learned yesterday, before the American Legion convention begins on Sept. 20.

Tier Ave. (18-5632), s s, 53 ft w of William St, 53x100; Henry L. Borland to May Miller, 651 E 165th St. 203d, 255 E (12-3309); Jacob Platt to Joseph Rocco, 3,126 Jerome Ave. Walton Ave (11-2835), n e cor of 172d St, 100x100; L J Trading Corp to Rebecca Aberle, 1,950 Andrews Ave; mtg $155,750.
August brought the end of the regular dog days but September seems to have marked the beginning of the under-dog days, at least in Flatbush.

An increased trend toward reducing the import balance of United States foreign trade was indicated in preliminary foreign trade statistics for July made public today by the Department of Commerce, which showed a merchandise export balance of $1,836,000 for July.

Slight fluctuations in recent months in the cost of construction in the United States, as reflected in the construction cost index of the American Appraisal Company, may be taken to indicate that these costs are becoming relatively stable, according to Lyle H. Olson, vice president of the company.

Members of the Pot and Kettle Club held their monthly luncheon meeting at the clubhouse today. Charlton Yarnall, club president, presided at the affair, while De Forest Grant of New York acted as caterer and host. Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes was present as an honorary guest.

Baron fierre de Coubertin, promoter and organizer of the modern Olympic lames, died here tonight. He was 4 years old. Death followed a troke of apoplexy. He suffered he stroke as he was walking with friends in La Grange Park. He had nly recently moved to Geneva rom Lausanne.

Miss Elisabeth Otis Powel, daughter to Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Powel of Providence, was married to Edward Gifford Crosby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Gifford Crosby of Oconomowoc, Wis., this afternoon in the garden at Annandale, the Powel Summer home in East Greenwich, R. I.
Although higher than the aggregate for the preceding week, bank clearings for the current period fell below the comparative 1936 period for the first time in six weeks.

The finest array of talent to gather for the national tennis championships in years was assembled at Forest Hills yesterday, but the opening session failed to provide anything in the way of an exceptional skirmish as forty-five matches were run off in the men's and women's singles.

Commodities were higher yesterday and securities were lower, and trading was unusually active all around. The stock market followed an uncertain course, weakening early, rallying moderately in the early afternoon and declining once more in the final hour.

Retailers here continue confident that Fall trade will open up favorably with the passing of the Labor Day holiday, despite the comparatively poor results encountered during August. The merchants will test their idea that much of the Summer slump was due to the concentration of consumer attention upon vacation plans, which held interest in merchandise offerings to a minimum.
Robert F. Hendrickson of the Consolidated Edison Company has purchased the two-story brick and frame colonial residence at 35-12 159th Street, Flushing, from Helen Hocking.
Completing his twenty-fifth expedition for the New York Zoological Society, Dr. William Beebe, accompanied by five aides, returned yesterday aboard the liner Monarch of Bermuda from Bermuda. Dr.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente granted yesterday an application to direct the board of elections to include the name of Thomas E. Rohan as a candidate in the Democratic primaries for Municipal Court justice in the Seventh district.
Business in the Pittsburgh district last week gained nearly all the ground lost in the week ended Aug. 21, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.
Mrs. Lenore Knight Wingard, Homestead (Pa.) swimmer, won the women's professional three-mile swim and first prize money of $750 today.

Judge J. Lyles Glenn of the Federal District Court refused today to issue a permanent injunction sought by power companies against construction of the $37,500,000 Santee-Cooper River navigation and electric project.

The engagement of $504,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. London's gold-bullion price worked out at $34.7618 an ounce at the time of the fixing of the price, which was about half a cent under the shipping parity.
The Red Sox, making their last appearance of the season at Comiskey Park I today. lost both ends of a doubleheader to the White Sox, 4 to 2 and 10 to 8.

John William Burke, a New York engineer who specialized in utility and industrial properties appraisals and reports, and who was former president of the Yonkers Board of Education, died early today in Manchester, Vt., of heart disease. He was 72 years old.

The opening of the Hearns Department Store here today drew a crowd of such proportions that fifteen policemen were detailed there as a precaution against disorder, it was reported by officials of the store and the Newark Police Department.

A 1938 budget of $20,558,324, or $3,275,707 more than its 1937 allotment, was asked yesterday by the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity at a hearing before Kenneth Dayton, Assistant Budget Director. The increase in the personal service request was $1,037,276.

A rescue fleet saved nine members of the crew of the sunken steamship Tarpon today, two others swam ashore and two bodies were recovered as frantic efforts were made to account for all aboard before nightfall.

Shipping men expressed approval yesterday of a proposed shipping compact between Brazil and the United States under which cargoes moving between the two countries would be carried only in vessels of the two nations.
H. G. Wells today presented before the annual meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science the outline of a new and revolutionary system of education.

With Elbridge T. (Ebby) Gerry as the scoring star, Aknusti rode to a 9-to-5 victory over Templeton today at the Piping Rock Club in another test match preparatory to the national open polo championship slated to start at the Meadow Brook Club on Sept. 11.

Fresh from a 15,000-mile journey through Arctic waters, the schooner Morrisey, Captain Bob Bartlett, docked here today after her fourteenth journey into the polar wastes for scientific and biological data and specimens.

Miss Betty Rae McCall, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. J. Oppie McCall of this place, was married to George Mahlon Knapp, son of Dr. and Mrs. Karl Knapp, also of Larchmont, this afternoon in the Larchmont Avenue Church here. The Rev. Dr. Robert Russell performed the ceremony. .

The Allis-Chalmers Company has declared a dividend of $1 on the common stock. Dividends of 50 cents each were paid on June 30 and March 31. Deisel-Wemmer-Gilbert The directors of the Deisel-Wemmer-Gilbert Corporation have dedared an extra dividend of 25 cents, and the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents.

Capt. Horace C. Hale, J.A.G.-Res., 78 Main St., Canton, N. Y., 61st Cavalry Division, is ordered to active duty Oct. 3 at Governors Island, N. Y., for training in the office of the judge advocate general. He will be relieved from active duty Oct. 16.
Mrs. Helen Brooks Scott today obtained a divorce from Martin Lebling Scott of New York. They were married at Ripley, N. Y., Dec. 27, 1923, and have two children.

A little bay filly listed on the odds board as a 50-to-1 shot, won the Governor of Ohio Stake, a $1,500 event for Ohio owned 3-year-old trotters, featured race of the Grand Circuit's Ohio State Fair program today.

"A general ignorance * * * of some of the most elementary realities of the political and social life of the world is, I believe, mainly accountable for much of the discomfort and menace of our times," remarked Mr. H. G. Wells in his address before the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

The Works Progress Administration will spend $7,000,000 on educational projects in the New York City school system next year, a 30 per cent decrease from the sum available last year, Irving Gerdy, director of the WPA education and recreation departments, announced yesterday.

Lou Holtz, preparing to leave last night for Hollywood and a screen test, was muttering of a "business deal" with Selznick-International. The deal: if the screen test satisfies, he will be under long-term contract to S-I, and in any case he is due to perform at the Dallas Exposition for two weeks beginning Sept. 18, with an option on his services for two weeks more.
Willie Fool, 147, Flatbush, outpointed Sten Suvio, 147, Finland, in the star attraction of eight rounds at the boxing show at Fort Hamilton in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, last night.

David S. Polland of New York went right on winning tonight in the American Chess Federation championship, defeating S. S. Cohen of New York in a queen's pawn opening lasting 27 moves. Polland's points were increased to 7 1.2.
The Chinese air force has struck telling blows at the Japanese expeditionary forces in the last twenty-four hours, according to wellauthenticated reports.

A resolution endorsing the stand taken by John J. Daley, retiring president, against the State Liquor Authority rule requiring bar and grill owners and package store retailers to pay liquor bills within twenty-one days, was adopted yesterday at the annual meeting of the United Restaurant Liquor Dealers of Manhattan, Inc.
Construction of a new approach for the second level of the Henry Hudson Bridge across the Harlem River has involved the cutting down of a number of trees in Inwood Hill Park.

J. M. McKibbin Jr., associated with the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company since 1922, has been appointed apparatus advertising and sales-promotion man.ager of the company, it was announced yesterday by S. D. Mahan, general advertising manager. Mr.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher in training in day secondary other than junior high schools, in the subjects indicated, be issued to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefore:
Jeremiah T. Mahoney, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, was asked last night to declare himself on the candidacy of Municipal Court Justice David C. Lewis.

The newly created Palisades Interstate Park Commission held its organization meeting yesterday in the State Building. The following officers were elected: J. Du Pratt White, Nyack, N. Y., president; George W. Perkins, Cold Springs, N. Y., secretary;

Otto Raphael, a retired police lieutenant, of 1,953 East Ninth Street, Brooklyn, protege and boxing instructor of President Theodore Roosevelt, died on Wednesday in Coney Island Hospital after a brief illness. He was 66 years old. Theodore Roosevelt, in his "Autobiography," telling of the time he was Police Commissioner and his selection of men for the force, wrote as follows about Mr. Raphael:

The marriage of Miss Gladys Bennett, daughter of Curlis Newman Bennett of East Orange, to Herman Clyde Collier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Collier of West Frankfort, Ill., took place this evening in St. Agnes Episcopal Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Theodore Andrews of Grace Episcopal Church, Madison.

Leading a small field of thirty contestants, Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches renewed her rivalry with Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr., New Jersey State champion, to win low gross honors with a card of 40, 41-81 in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament at the Hackensack course today.

The Chilean racer, Caballero II, this afternoon will come back to the Aqueduct course over which he first raced in this country, and where he began the successful career that has placed him near the top of the handicap division.

The reasonableness of the present economic system has come in for a good deal of battering in recent years, and so it is reassuring to conservative minds to learn from a study just reported by Dr. F. L. Wells of the Psychology Laboratory, Boston, that in many cases men receiving $100 a week are really worth more than those receiving $35 a week.

Apartment houses on the East and West Sides shared the long list of new tenancies announced yesterday by brokers and renting agents. The rush for rooms on the West Side was featured by a demand for new living quarters along West End Avenue, Riverside Drive and adjacent streets. Agents continue to report that buildings in their care are filling up as the result of contracts for rooms to be occupied in the early Fall.

For the first time since he took over the coaching job at Fordham in 1933, Jimmy Crowley donned a complete football uniform yesterday at Fordham Field and showed the Maroon squad a few real blocks and passes. The former Notre Dame star proved he has lost little of his skill since he was one of the famous Four Horsemen.

Price and style trends will be discussed at the semi-annual style conference directed by the National Shoe Retailers Association in conjunction with the showing of American leathers by the Tanners Council of America at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, next Thursday and Friday.

On application of Paul J. McCauley, chairman of the law committee of the campaign committee of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora signed yesterday an order directing the Board of Elections to show cause why a peremptory writ of mandamus should not be issued to compel the board to reinstate 456 inspectors of elections removed by Tammany Hall.

In celebrating Germany's military and economic recovery, most National Socialist speeches are based on the keynote "Germany shall become better, stronger, happier and more beautiful." To this Dr. Robert Ley, head of the German Labor Front, adds the exhortation of a popular song, "Freut Euch des Lebens," the German version of "Eat, Drink and Be Merry."

As thousands of persons in every section of the country are sending in answers to the second puzzle contest of P. Lorillard Co., manufacturers of Old Gold cigarettes, a staff of nearly 900 men and women has been assembled to assort the replies, it became known yesterday.
Optimism as to the future of democracy in this country was expressed here tonight by Governor Herbert H. Lehman of New York at the closing session of the Institute of Human Relations.

Five thousand Ontario children under 14 years of age are being treated this week, in a vast clinical test, with the Peet zinc sulphate nasal spray-classed by many as the most hopeful preventive measure yet discovered in the war against infantile paralysis.

A controversy that had been slumbering for years broke out again yesterday when the Governors of Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont and Massachusetts were authorized to intervene in the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad bankruptcy.

Frederick H. Stinchfield of Minneapolis, president of the American Bar Association, today praised Senators Wheeler of Montana and O'Mahoney of Wyoming, who opposed President Roosevelt's court reform proposal.

Mrs. Marshall Potter of 174 East Seventy-first Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mrs. Catharine Potter Watson, to Albert E. Heymann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Heymann of 530 West End Avenue.

Stockholders of Cutler-Hammer, Inc., manufacturer of electricalcontrol equipment, voted today to split the common stock two for one and to issue $2,500,000 in convertible cumulative preferred stock. The proceeds from the preferred issue will be used for working capital and payment on $600,000 of bank loans.

Max Schmeling, who has been given the run-around for many months, finally caught up with the fistic parade yesterday. After a conference with Mike Jacobs, promoter for the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, that lasted four hours, Schmeling emerged with a contract to fight Joe Louis for the world heavyweight championship next June in New York.

The National Maritime Union sent a delegation to offices of the National Labor Board in the Woolworth Building yesterday, to tell Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, Regional Director, that its members had been discriminated against on two steam ship lines.
French troops were erecting barricades around the Arab section of Meknes today as a precaution against further rioting following disorders yesterday in which ten natives were killed.

Salvadorean Consuls no longer collect fees for their services to exporters, according to a new law which centralizes all the collections of the National Government here. Consuls will compute the amount of fees in dollars but collections will be made at the time goods are entered here by importers.

Clarence Edwards of Hempstead, L. I., took medal honors in the annual men's international invitation golf tournament today with a brilliant 73, one over par. One stroke behind him was William Taylor of Montreal, while third was Bobby Loree, New York, with 75.

Miss Nancy Moller, daughter of the late Kenneth Moller and the late Mrs. Elizabeth Sweetser Moller, was married to David Howland, son of Mrs. Charles P. Howland of Walpole, N. H., and the late Mr. Howland, at noon today in St. Stephen's Church here. The Rev. Charles C. Wilson performed the ceremony.

Trading in wheat futures today on the Board of Trade was the smallest in some time. There was nothing in the news to induce operators to take a decided stand on either side, and with a double holiday ahead many professionals evened up their positions in the market.

Mrs. Adelia M. Corbin, widow of Floyd Stewart Corbin, real estate broker, died on Thursday in her apartment at the Hotel Dorset, 30 West Fifty-fourth Street, after a long illness. Born in Augusta, Ga., Mrs. Corbin was a member of the United Daughters of the Confederacy. She was interested in Y. W.

Officials of the Tennessee Valley Authority said today that contracts already signed for power sales to private industry eventually would bring a yearly income of $4,300,000. Four industrial contracts recently were added to the two already in effect.

A. Felix du Pont of Elton, near Wilmington, Del., obtained a divorce at Carson City Jate today from Mrs. Mary Chichester du Pont, to whom he was married at Philadelphia on April 9, 1902. The grounds were mental cruelty. The case was heard in private.
The British Columbia Power Corporation, Ltd., has declared a quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share on its Class A stock. Previously it paid 45 cents quarterly.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente dismissed yesterday a suit brought to eliminate from the Democratic primary in the Second Assembly District all the candidates for county committeemen who are pledged to support Representative Christopher D. Sullivan for re-election as a Tammany district leader.

The best way to trap Secretary Edward Aloysius McGonigie Brannick of the Giants is with a cup of coffee and any mention of the Stoneham team. He rises to both baits with a rush. "The pennant!" said Mr. Brannick, over a cup of coffee. "It's a pipe. In fact, it's a collection of pipes. Tobacco Road!

Rather than give up grouse shooting for one year, New York sportsmen seem perfectly willing to risk the possible extinction of this game bird in the State. More than 1,000 letters were sent to sportsmen's clubs by the Conservation Department, explaining to these groups that their willingness to have a shorter or closed season on grouse might be the means of preventing a continuance of the present downward cycle.

With the exception of about a dozen of the most hardy, the remaining Summer theatres are folding up their seasons along with tonight's final curtains. The list includes the Summer Theatre, Skaneateles, N. Y.;
The State Department announced today that the following Americans have left Yangtze River ports on the British steamer Whangpoo: From Nanking - Edwin Marx, Robert S. Norman, Berkeley, Calif.

The marriage of Miss Katherine Jane Weinman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph A. Weinman of Forest Hills, Queens, to Dr. Freeman Brooks of this city, son of Mrs. Walter F. Brooks of Chicago and the late Mr. Brooks, took place last night in her father's studio in Forest Hills.

The Federal Trade Commission, represented by Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney, began suit yesterday in Federal court to collect a penalty of $40,000 from the National Biscuit Company for its refusal to supply to the commission data sought under authorization of a Congressional resolution adopted in 1935 and amended a year later.

MANHATTAN BOETTGER, HENRY W. (April 1, 1934). Gross assets, $1,407,563; net, $1,136,625. To Louise M. Boettger, widow, jewelry, personal effects and life interest in residue; Theodora B. Topping, daughter, William M. and John P. Boettger, remainders in one-third residue each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds. Bandler, Haas Collins, attorneys, 11 Broadway.

Samuel (Chowderhead) Cohen, professional strike-breaker, and his wife Sadie, who on Aug. 27 pleaded guilty to a charge of defrauding the ERB of more than $700, were sentenced yesterday in Bronx Special Sessions. Cohen received an indeterminate term in the penitentiary, while his wife received a suspended sentence from Justices Gresser, Hackenburg and Salomon.
The culinary abilities of the wives of the two candidates for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination became "issues" in the campaign today.
Having rejected the high bid for $3.000.000 of refunding bonds submitted on last Tuesday, officials of Cuyahoga County, Ohio, have set Sept. 25 as the date for reoffering of the bonds.
Calvin Griffith, president and manager of the Chattanooga Baseball Club, announced today that the Washington club of the American League had exercised its option on six Chattanooga players.

Five men were arrested here early this morning after police investigated stories told by three local girls, two of them 12 years old and the third 13 years old. The prisoners, four of whom are married and three of whom are fathers, were held without bail to await action by the grand jury when arraigned before Police Recorder Michael A. Lepore.

ON BOARD PRESS BOAT With President Roosevelt, Montauk, L. I., Sept. 3.-Three fish fell to the rods of his party today as President Roosevelt spent the first day of his short vacation cruise off Montauk Point and along the surf shore of Eastern Long Island.
New bond financing this week dwindled to $4,785,000, the smallest for any week since that ended on Aug. 6. It compared with $39,675,000 of bonds placed on the market last week.

The Jewish New Year will begin with sundown tomorrow. In the Hebrew calendar year the new year will be 5698. The Jewish name for the festival is Rosh ha-Shanah. In Reform temples the observance will close at nightfall on Monday, Labor Day.

Patrons of the Hotel Chesterfield, 130 West Forty-ninth Street, were inconvenienced by a four-hour strike of fifty-nine employes who returned to work early yesterday afternoon after Lewis Goldman, proprietor, had agreed to a tentative settlement.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 2: COLONEL Jarman, S. (C. A. C.), General Staff Corps, one-day leave, Sept. 3. LIEUTENANT COLONEL Mahon, H. W., Med. Corps, Panama, to Fitzsimons General Hospital, Denver, Col., for duty.
The text of the radio address of John L. Lewis tonight was as follows: Out of the agony and travail of economic America the Committee for Industrial Organization was born.

Howard E. Beedy, vice president and treasurer of the Oxford Paper Company, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 480 Park Avenue. He was 47 years old. Mr. Beedy was born in Phillips, Me., and was educated at Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass., and at Yale University, graduating from Yale in 1915.
Robert Hunt Lyman, newspaper executive and for fifteen years the editor of the World Almanac, died yesterday at his home, 114 East Eighty-fourth Street. He was 73 years old.
Count Otto Hagenburg, European airplane acrobatic champion from Germany, crashed but miraculously escaped serious injury at the close of the first day of the National Air Races today.

The State Department is doing all it can to prevent the execution of Harold E. Dahl, American aviator, captured by the Spanish Rebels, Secretary of State Cordell Hull telegraphed today to Mrs. Ida Dahl of Champaign, Ill., the prisoner's mother. Dahl was flying as a military pilot for the Valencia Government when he was captured.
Chahar. as represented by 100 influential persons who met at Kalgan th yesterday, declared its independence and decided to set up an autonomous Government entirely separate from China.

The Treasury seems to be concerned about some more "channels of tax avoidance." These are the "community property" laws that already exist in eight States. Under these, long held valid by the Supreme Court, a wife is automatically entitled to half of the property of the husband, whether that is real or personal property or income, and the husband is entitled to the same share of the wife's property.

96th St, 230-4 E; to three 5-story tenements; Naal Realty Corp, 44 Greenwich St, owner; M. Exerjian, architect; cost, $20,000. 130th St, 499 W; to 5-story tenement and stores; Catherine Surowiec, 220 Franklin St, Brooklyn, owner; F. J. Wasselle, architect; cost, 4,500.

Mrs. Delphine Dodge Cromwell Baker Godde, who is here to divorce Timothy Godde, London and Paris merchant, announced tonight that she would marry Jack Doyle, Irish pugilist and opera singer, when she obtained her decree and Doyle obtained a Nevada divorce from Judith Allan, film actress.

The Cabinet today approved an increase of Japan's war fund for the campaigns in China. With more than 500,000,000 yen already appropriated, the Ministers approved a third supplementary budget for 2,042,000,000 yen, more than the empire spent altogether on its wars with China in 1894-95 and Russia in 1904-05.

For the first six months of this' year net income of the Continental Oil Company was $7,884,529 after all charges, according to a report issued yesterday. This was equivalent to $1.68 a share on the 4,682,594 shares of capital stock outstanding.

Three hundred farmers routed pickets today from the local plant of the Morgan Packing Company without serious violence, and plant operations were resumed with between 300 and 400 employes back at work.

Counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission in stoporder proceedings against the Austin Silver Mining Company devoted yesterday to gathering up loose ends. The comimssion's case is almost complete.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I am not an "I-told-you-so," for I, too, followed the New York sports writers out onto the precarious limb and I, too, fell when the limb broke and Joe Louis lost ground in his bout with Tommy Farr.

Because the insurance companies appear to have been making inroads recently into the mortgagelending business of the savings banks, officials of the latter institutions are studying a proposal for legislation to liberalize the New York laws permitting them to advance a higher percentage of the appraised value of property.

Frank Boucher, one of the National Hockey League's greatest players, today was appointed assistant manager and coach of the New York Rangers. Manager Lester Patrick, announcing the appointment, said it was made in recognition of Boucher's playing ability and sportsmanlike character.
Moderate support in certain sections of the domestic corporate list gave a slightly firmer appearance to the bond market yesterday.

A syndicate composed of Joseph L. Rhodie and Louis D. Berger has purchased the two-story taxpayer at 275 Fulton Street, 100 feet from the corner of Main Street, in the heart of the business section of Hempstead, L. I.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, will arrive home next Friday on the French liner Normandie from attending a meeting of the executive committee of the Lutheran World Convention, of which he is first vice president.

Scott P. Squyres, 42-year-old Oklahoma City lawyer, who proudly boasts of his Indian blood, was unanimously elected Commander in Chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars today as the national encampment closed. He succeeded Brig. Gen. Bernard W. Kearney of Gloversville, commander of the Fifty-third Infantry Brigade, New York National Guard.

Small bore shooters continued to register record-breaking scores today, with long strings of possibles being made despite the intense heat. In the 50-yard any sights for allcomers match the first fifteen competitors finished with possible scores of 400 each.

The activities of the American Lutheran missionaries in China will continue as usual in spite of disturbed conditions there, it was announced In a statement issued yesterday at the Lutheran Church House, 39 East Thirty-fifth Street.

Brazilian exports amounted to $177,323,848 and imports $149,477,396 during the first half of the current calendar year, leaving a favorable trade balance of $27,846,452, according to a report from Rio de Janeiro, made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Several hundred members of the Summer colony and their holiday house parties attended the large costume entertainment known as "the longshoremen's ball," given tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hoving at the Port-of-Missing-Men, their place at North Sea.

Henry Picard, home pro, turned the $5,000 Hershey open golf tournament into a one-man show today. He set a new course record of 65, eight under par, to take the lead at the half-way mark of the four-day tournament. His thirty- six- hole total of 135 was eleven under par.
The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System approved today action by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reducing its discount rate from 2 to 1 1/2 per cent.

Emulating Federal agents, who raided seventeen alleged vice establishments last Sunday, local police made a carefully-timed descent on another section of the underworld today, looking for bookmakers and other gambling operators.
Selden Rodman, editor and writer, and Miss Hilda Clausen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George U. Clausen of 823 Park Avenue, obtained a marriage license at the Municipal Building yesterday.
As if to compensate for the plainness of the opening day menu, the national tennis championships provided a bountiful repast of excitement and thrills yesterday.

Roundlot trading by members of the New York Stock Exchange for their own account in the week ended on Aug. 7 changed little in volume from that in the preceding week, being 19.60 per cent of the total, compared with 19.57 per cent, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday a net gain of 2,118 telephones in service during August, as compared with a gain of 9,855 instruments in August, 1936. In August, 1935, the company had a net loss of 1,987 telephones and one of 4,868 units in August, 1934.
The National Broadcasting Company petitioned the Federal Communications Commission today for authority to construct and operate a portable television broadcast station in and about New York City.

Amid sweltering weather the first contingent of the Dartmouth football squad arrived today and had its first workout of the season. Forty invited players, who will form the nucleus of the 1937 team, this afternoon were sent through a spirited workout by Red Blaik and his assistants.

The resignation of Archbishop Leopoldo Ruiz y Flores as Papal Delegate to Mexico, which was confirmed here this afternoon by the Bishop of Mexico, is seen in religious circles of Mexico as foreshadowing the informal resumption of long-broken relations between the Vatican and the Mexican Government.

Jim Turner of the Bees won his sixteenth victory of the season today, but he had to have a lot of help from Roy Johnson and Vince DiMaggio before he turned the trick by a 7-to-2 margin over the Phillies in ten innings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3.-Cuba exported 1,966,885 long tons of raw sugar from Jan. 1 to Aug. 15, compared with 1,899,311 in the same period of 1936, according to a report from Walter J. Donnelly, American commercial attache at Havana, made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Miss Louise Wheeler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight C. Wheeler, was married to Bishop White von Wettberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. F. von Wettberg, in the gardens of the home of her parents at Fairnold. Easton. this afternoon. The Rev.

Mrs. Maryon Hewitt, a widow, of Atlantic Beach, L. I., who in recent years was involved in civil and criminal proceedings in San Francisco over an alleged sterilizing operation on her daughter, appeared yesterday as a complainant in District Attorney Dodge's office.

The Stamford Yacht Club's annual Vineyard race was off to a flying start tonight with twenty entries in two classes crossing the line off The Cows. As they started the long sail up the Sound, Robert P. Baruch's cutter Kirawan from Manhasset Bay set the pace.

The reported landing today of additional large Japanese reinforcements at Tangku is causing speculation in foreign circles in Tientsin regarding the total Japanese strength in North China and the probable destination of the new reinforcements.
There are five of those Dionne girls, but they make enough noise L for seven. That is what G. W. C. Kaye, British physicist, told the British Association for the Advancement of Science today.

The petitions of four Governors of New England States to intervene as parties to the reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad was granted today by the interstate Commerce Commission.

The State Department's decision to permit Prentiss Gilbert, American charge d'Affaires in Berlin, to accept Chancellor Adolf Hitler's invitation to attend the forthcoming congress of the National Socialist party at Nuremberg was taken against the strong advice of William Edward Dodd, the American Ambassador to Germany, it was admitted in official circles tonight.
Joseph N. Pew Jr., one of the heads of the Republican party in Pennsylvania, joined today in the oral attacks on Mayor Wilson, begun yesterday by Jay Cooke, Republican City Chairman.

The Maine Central Railroad Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue 100,000 shares of its priorpreference stock, with an aggregate par value of $10,000,000, for the sole purpose of exchanging the new stock for general-mortgage bonds, Series A, 4 1/2 per ent., due on Dec. 1, 1960, at the rate of five shares of stock for each $500 principal amount of bonds.

Baron and Baroness d'Epremesnil of Washington have come to the Waldorf-Astoria from their country home, Edgewood, in Upperville, Va. Mrs. Milo M. Belding, who returned on the Berengaria, is at the St. Regis.

Benjamin A. Rowe, former president of the W. T. Grant chain stores, died here suddenly just before noon today as he was giving his deposition in a divorce suit filed on June 15 against his wife, Mary Edna Rowe.

About a quarter of City Island was plunged into darkness for several hours last night and early this morning when a major power transforrer of the Consolidated Edison Company in Pelham Bay Park was short circuited, causing short circuits in four small transformers on telephone poles on City Island Avenue at Ditmars, Bridge, Cross and Fordham Streets.

The pound sterling and the franc continued yesterday to become cheaper in terms of the dollar under the influence of the disturbed political situations in Europe and the Far East. The pound fell to $4.95 3/4, its lowest price since July 9, and closed at $4.96, off 3-16 cent.

Mrs. Anna S. C. Sneath, widow of Professor E. Hershey Sneath, who was a member of the Yale faculty, left an estate of $800,000, the application for probate of her will disclosed today. Mrs. Sneath died Sunday.

Renewed interest in Summer merchandise, generous purchases for trips over Labor Day, and the widening purchases by students preparing for school reopenings advanced retail sales totals this week, the gains over the previous week at leading centers being estimated at 1 to 4 per cent, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Brooklyn at New York -Butcher vs. Hubbell or Smith. Pittsburgh at Chicago-Brandt vs. French. Boston at Philadelphia-Gabler vs. LaMaster.
A contra-seasonal recession in cotton-mill activity last week caused the index to slump to 134.5 from 144.3. This compares with 136.9 for the week ended Aug. 29, 1936.
Three new titleholders, two of them girls in their early,teens, were crowned today in the opening program of the women's national senior A. A. U. swimming and diving championships.
Mrs. Edith Norton Reusswig Griffith of Utica and New York died last night in a hospital here. She was born April 2, 1872, the daughter of Frederick H. and Matilda Gray Norton Gouverneur.
