Transactions on the Chicago Board of Trade in the first eight months of 1937 were 561,000 bushels in excess of business transacted in all of 1936, it was disclosed today.

The Rev. Dr. Abraham J. Muste will begin tomorrow his duties as pastor of the Presbyterian Labor Temple, Second Avenue and Fourteenth Street. Dr. Muste and his family moved to the parsonage apartment of the temple this week.

Charles St, 115, 25.1x95; Clara Kritzer to Central Savings Bank: purchase money mtg 5 years, 7 per cent; $28,000. 76th St, 325 W, 20x102.2; Mary Authen to Central Savings Bank; purchase money mtg 5 years, 5 per cent; $23,000.

Miss Jane Margaret Cullen, daughter of Mrs. Edward Everett Cullen Jr. of Rosemont and the late Mr. Cullen, was married this afternoon to Robert Wilson McKee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Wilson McKee of this city.

The huge estate left by Andrew W. Mellon and the laws of Pennsylvania requiring administrators to furnish bond equal to twice the value of the personal estate when they are non-residents of the county entail many difficulties in the settlement of the estate.

Dr. Frank Herbert Gorham, a former Brooklyn dentist, died yesterday of blood poisoning at his home in Alexandria, Va. The son of Dr. and Mrs. H. M. Gorham, he was born in Brooklyn in 1901 and was graduated in 1919 from the Manual Training High School.

Friedrich Adler, secretary of the Socialist International, who was arrested Tuesday night at a railway station near the Belgian frontier as he was about to leave The Netherlands, was released today by a Rotterdam police court. He continued his journey to Belgium.

Rumors of an attempt on Premier Benito Mussolini's life began to spread in Rome yesterday and are still circulating today with great insistence. It is whispered that four airplanes flew over the Villa Torlonia, Mussolini's Rome residence, and dropped a bomb which exploded in an adjacent street.

C. W. Campbell, oil drilling contractor and bird dog fancier, died at his home here last night after a two years' illness. His age was 60. Mr. Campbell came to Tulsa from Marietta, Ohio, in 1913. He was a former president of the Izaak Walton League of Oklahoma and owner of Inquisitor Blade, a North American champion bird dog.

The first architectural plan of the protein molecule, nature's most intricate labyrinth of living matter, was presented here today before the annual meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.
Isaac Kaplan, founder of the Shirtcraft Company, one of the country's largest manufacturers of shirts and pajamas, died today at Sinai Hospital. He was 75 years old.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
Until the eighth inning today the Browns offered some opposition to the Indians, then the cellar dwellers of the American League cracked, the Indians scored nine and won, 15 to 3.
The many conflicting rumors about Premier Benito Mussolini's long-expected visit to Chancellor Adolf Hitler were dis posed of tonight by an official announcement made simultaneously here and in Rome.

The Japanese forces in and around Shanghai found themselves in difficulties as the Chinese showed more power both in attack and defense. Big guns in Pootung, across the river, forced eight transports to retire and Chinese fire prevented the landing of enemy troops in that city. In the greatest artillery battle yet fought shells landed in the International Settlement. Chinese soldiers in plain clothes made much trouble for the -Japanese in Hongkew.

William Green and other American Federation of Labor officers were denounced here today as "palsied traitors" to the cause of labor as the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America began a fourday convention.

Miss Virginia Guilfoil of Syracuse, N. Y., and Miss Dorothy Traung of San Francisco came through long hard battles today to gain the thirty-six-hole final of the annual women's MasonDixon golf tourney.

The baseball teams of the Department of Sanitation and the Police Department paraded to City Hall yesterday to invite Mayor La Guardia to attend their game at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 12. Commissioner William F. Cary of the Department of Sanitation gave a short address.

Taking advantage of three bases on balls and five hits in the fifth inning of their final floodlight game of the season, the Reds scored seven runs and went on to beat the Cardinals, 9 to 1, tonight before a crowd of 11,384 persons.

Mr. and Mrs. W. John Wadsworth of 580 Park Avenue, New York, have announced the engagement of Miss Fannie Robb Carvin, daughter of Mrs. Wadsworth and of the late B. Depew Carvin, to Felix Magnin of London.

China bought more American aircraft than any other foreign country during the first six months of 1937, the Commerce Department reported today. Sales abroad up to July 1 reached $16,290,580, an increase of 90 per cent. Monthly shipments averaged $2,715,097, compared with a monthly average of $1,928,600 for all of 1936.

All State scholarships for Catholic theological students were withdrawn today by a decree issued by Minister of Education Bernhard Rust unless such students "show themselves exceptionally active in the National Socialist movement by making themselvcs useful within the party or its branches."

While expressing disappointment that President Roosevelt did not veto the 1937 Sugar Bill, Samuel W. King, delegate in Congress from Hawaii, said today that the act represented new gains for Hawaii and added that he hoped that at the next session legislation could be passed eliminating the provision which prohibits his Territory from refining sugar.

The intensification of military operations in and around Shanghai has caused the State Department to issue new and urgent warnings to American nationals to quit the region, Secretary of State Hull said today.

Panama wants the United States to construct a transportation tunnel under the Panama Canal. Minister Boyd told State Department officials today that his Central American republic, divided by the canal, needs greater transportation facilities between the two parts.

Augustus C. Bedell, for many years prominent in the flour business, died yesterday at the home of his brother in East Brookfield, Mass. His age was 78. From 1912 to 1926 be was chief floor inspector of the Produce Exchange.

Dr. Lucy L. W. Wilson, noted educator, author and the only woman to receive the Philadelphia Award for Outstanding Civic Service, was found dead tonight in her room at the Lake Placid Club, Lake Placid, N. Y. She was 73 years old. Her death was attributed by physicians to a heart ailment from which she had suffered for many months.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Nancy Lee Byers, daughter of J. Frederic Byers of Goodwood, Sewickley, Pa., and the late Mrs. Byers, to John William Young Martin of Glyndon, Md., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel K. Martin of New York and Chicago.

State Senator John J. McNaboe of New York City, at a meeting yesterday in the Empire State Building, was elected chairman of the joint legislative committee to investigate the sufficiency of parole, probation, mental hygiene and correction laws in the light of recent sex crimes.

John L. Lewis served all but open notice on President Roosevelt tonight that he had better continue his allegiance to the mass labor movement in the United States or face the political consequences. Labor next year, he said "must determine who are its friends in the arena of politics as elsewhere."

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Jones Harrison of Washington announced today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Benedict Harrison, to Eugene Franklin O'Connor 3d, son of Judge and Mrs. Eugene Franklin O'Connor of Garden City, L. I.
Newark swept both ends of a twin bill with Baltimore tonight and dropped the Orioles into fourth place in the International League. The scores were 9 to 7 and 6 to 3.

Thomas C. B. Snell, a descendant of Robert Treat, a founder of Newark in 1666, died yesterday at his home here, 62 Stengel Avenue, after a long Illness. He was 66 years old. Born in New Haven, Conn., Mr. Snell was the son of the late Adolphus Gaylord Snell, an inventor, who is credited with making the first telephone switchboard in this country.

The wedding of Miss Alexandra A. Lewis, daughter of Mrs. Harvey K. Lewis of Cooper Top Orchards, Orrtanna, near Gettysburg, Pa., and Bermuda, and the late Mr. Lewis, to Philip Woodland Schindel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy S.
The rate paid by the Treasury on its shortterm discount bills advanced again today in the sale of a combined issue of about $100,000,000, with maturities of 273 and 104 days.

A pepper-throwing incident in which two electrical union strikers are alleged to have painfully burned the eyes of a policeman, caused a small riot and a bad traffic snarl at Broadway and Spring Street yesterday noon, and led Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in Tombs Court to warn strike pickets that they must respect the police uniform if they hope to invoke protection of the courts.

It was revealed today when communications were restored that during the typhoon and tidal wave an entire Chinese coastal settlement and a portion of a village on the mainland had been swept away and at least 300 had been killed.
The Tigers increased their second-place margin over Chicago today by defeating the White Sox, 4 to 3, in the first game of a series.
A "labor war" was carried to the bedside of Archie M. Andrews of Rock Ridge yesterday as "strikers," armed with placards, demanded 100 per cent wage increases.

Potes, an Asturian town of strategic importance, fifteen miles west of Santander, Spain, was occupied at 6 o'clock this evening by the Nationalists [Insurgents]. They report they found the retreating Government forces had massacred a large number of their political prisowners before fleeing toward Gijon.

The $ Commodity Exchange Administra- d tion called today upon the approximately 900 futures commission merchants registered under the Commodity Exchange Act to report every commodity account controlled through power of attorney or otherwise by any person other than the owner, under threat of prosecution for failure to make the report.

Terming the present tax situation "intolerable," August Heckscher, philanthropist and large realty owner, said yesterday that if the city is to escape bankruptcy the municipal tax base must be broadened and economy enforced in its government.
Can a gentleman participate in an unholy alliance? It would be nice to hear from Emily Post on the subject.

Walter O. Reed, president of the Borrowers Building and Loan Association, died early today of a heart attack at his home, 83 Van Winkle Avenue. He was 70 years old. Born in England, Mr. Reed came to this country as a child and lived here most of his life.

In connection with the ninety-fourth Orangeburg Fair, the annual twoday horse show opened today under excellent conditions and with a good entry. While the heat was oppressive during the running of the morning program, there was a brisk southwest breeze during the afternoon that was hailed with delight by exhibitors and officials.
A couple of high school buddies recently reunited by their quest for golf laurels led the way into the semi-finals of the Western amateur tournament today.

United States exports of farm equipment in July were valued at $8,186,409, the highest monthly value since February, 1931, and 108 per cent above the value of shipments in July, 1936, which amounted to $3,926,140, the Machinery Division of the Department of Commerce announced today.

Memhers of the American Psychological Association, in convention here, turned their attention today to the light thrown in the past year on the emotional maladjustments of the child and the adolescent.

A second Northwest Passage across the top of the world was charted today when two ships met in the waters of Bellot Strait. The meeting of the vessels, fulfilling the 400-year-old dream of Elizabethan explorers, marked the discovery of a new and shorter water route between Eastern and Western Canada.

Japan's suddenly renewed demands for scrap metals and other basic materials have become so insistent that the premiums offered are inducing owners to detach ships from regularly scheduled services for trip charters.

Incomplete registration figures gathered by The Associated Press from all, except three, of the sixtyseven counties indicated today that less than three and a half million Pennsylvanians are qualified to vote under the new election code.
An initial step toward ending the troublesome agrarian situation in the Philippines was taken by Commonwealth President Manuel L. Quezon today in a recommendation to the National Assembly.

Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Hall of Peckett's Cottage colony gave a cocktail party and dinner in the Stube tonight for Mr. and Mrs. Walter A. Draper, Miss Isabel Draper, Mr. and Mrs. J. E. McCauley, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Cone, Mrs. George Dent Crabbs,
The legality of dog race betting will be brought before the United States Supreme Court under a writ obtained by Joseph F. Meyers, operator of the Orangeburg Kennel Club, it was learned today.

The failure of capital and labor to recognize and discharge to the full their moral obligations "has produced the present crisis, one of the gravest industrial crises in the history of America," the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church declared in a Labor Sunday message made public yesterday.

A new twofold policy for peace through rearmament which incidentally seems to show an attitude of frank hostility toward Germany, Italy and Japan was issued tonight by the National Council of Labor, the highest organ of political opinion in the British labor movement.

Two men struck Miss Augusta Kraner of 615 Crown Street, Brooklyn, as she was entering the Martin J. Koehler Corporation at 21-16 Fortieth Avenue, Long Island City, and robbed her of a payroll envelope containing $1,005. Miss Kraner, secretary of the Koehler company, had received the money at a near-by bank ten minutes before the thugs felled her.

George W. Histed, who was John L. Sullivan's sparring partner more than half a century ago, died today in the Edgerton homestead here. His age was 84. Mr. Histed, a member of a family which came to Western New York as pioneers after the Revolution,

Lieut. Comdr. Donald B. MacMillan said tonight that his scientific expedition into the Arctic regions had scaled Mount Brave, 4,390-foot peak on Baffin Land, named by a Harvard expedition in 1900. This he thought one of the noteworthy accomplishments of his sixteenth invasion of the northern lands, since there is no previously known record of its ascent.

A wreath from President Roosevelt was placed yesterday at the base of the Benjamin Franklin statue in Park Row opposite City Hall Plaza during exercises in connection with the nation-wide celebration of the 150th anniversary of the adoption of the Constitution.
A decision to convoke a world conference for international peace through religion was reached today in a committee that has been considering that question. Then the committee adjourned.

The Amateur Athletic Union yesterday started its search for candidates for the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy that annually goes to the athlete who "by his performance as a competitor and by his example and influence as an amateur did most to advance the cause of sportsmanship during 1937."

Taking notice of recent statements of State officials in North Carolina that they were in possession of "information" indicating that the proposed power project of the Carolina Aluminum Company on the Yadkin River near Tuckertown, N. C., would "not affect the interests of interstate commerce and, therefore, is not a proper subject for Federal jurisdiction," the Federal Power Commission announced yesterday that the case would be reopened and set a further hearing for Sept. 13.

The Chiefs divided with Jersey City tonight, scoring, 6 to 5, after dropping the opener, 7-5. Two errors by Al Glossop with two out in the seventh, sandwiched around a bace-cleaning triple by Joe Dwyer, gave the Jerseys four runs, enough to win the opener.

The stock market here opened the last day of the account uncertainly today, under the influence of the break in Wall Street prices which resulted in heavy losses to operators, but liquidation was extremely small and general improvement was shown later.

Miss Marjorie Mehl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Mehl of South Orange, was married this evening to Beverly Allen Lundy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Beverly A. Lundy of Larchmont, N. Y., at the home of her parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Fred

Streaking through space at an average speed of 260 to 270 miles an hour, Frank W. Fuller, San Francisco sportsman pilot, bested six competitors yesterday and won the grueling Bendix trans-continental race, the country's most famous air derby.
Four hold-up abductors matched pistol fire against police machine guns today in a sizzling battle that left two officers and a bandit dead, another robber dying and a third officer wounded.

Being a team that revels in doing the unexpected, the Dodgers continued to show their disrespect for the pennant contenders yesterday by handing the Giants an artistic thumping at the Polo Grounds, 15 to 7, and thereby whittled the lead of the New Yorkers over the idle Cubs to half a game.

Robert Rogers, 7 years old, of 1,245 Ogden Avenue, the Bronx, was killed yesterday when a driverless truck parked on the east side of Ogden Avenue, north of 168th Street, rolled across the street and against a wooden porch on which the boy was seated with two other children.
With fingers ostentatiously crossed, in the light of many previous defections, Broadway is looking forward with keen anticipation to the opening of the new International Casino on Thursday night.

Owner Phil Wrigley of the Cubs, the team that dropped to second place in the National League on a trip from which the players returned today, announced tonight that Manager Charley Grimm had signed a contract to pilot the club again in 1938. Salary terms were not disclosed.
Appointments to a municipal labor board, created here by the City Commission to arbitrate Newark labor disputes, were announced today by Mayor Ellenstein.

"Labor Sunday" will be observed in virtually all the churches in the city tomorrow. Sermons will be preached on "How the Church Should Help Labor." In Protestant churches generally, the annual labor message of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America will be read in whole or in part and prayers will be offered for the end of all strikes.
Retail trade again suffered this week from the effects of high temperatures and sales results were about on a par with last year or showed a slight increase, according to retail executives.

Although showers occurred over a large area of the Cotton Belt, the rainfall proved less heavy than recently, and predictions of fair weather in several States brought about a downward trend in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Following Thursday's stampede by extensive short interests, the market met on increased supply of contracts and a setback of $1 a bale left the list with losses of 13 to 20 points.

An action under the brokerage clause of the Robinson-Patman Act was instituted today by the Federal Trade Commission against the United Buyers Corporation of Chicago and six wholesale grocery concerns as representative of the forty-six such firms which are its members and for which it makes purchases and supplies market information service.

FIRST ROUND Upper Half Miss Helen H. Jacobs, Berkeley, Calif., defeated Miss Helen Bernhard, New York. 6-2, 6-1; Miss Millicent Hirsh, New York, defeated Miss Margaret Jessee, San Francisco, 6-3, 6-3: Miss Barbara Winslow, Hollywood. Calif., defeated Miss Patricia Cumming, Westfield. N. J., 6-2. 6-2; Miss Joan Ingram, England, defeated Mme. Sylvia Henrotin, France. 6-3, 0-6, 6-4.

Week-end guests arrived today, to attend a round of gay parties planned for over the holiday. Tomorrow night's "Gone With the Wind" costume ball at the Maidstone Club will be the most brilliant affair of the Summer here.
The Chinese Government spent a busy hour today denying war bulletins broadcast by Japanese radio stations. The Government denied: That seventy-two Russian planes bombarded Japanese lines.

Gounod's "Faust" will tonight open the second week-end of popular-priced opera at the Hippodrome. Joseph Geraldi, French tenor, will make his debut in the title role. "Carmen" will be given tomorrow night.

Odis Walding of Los Angeles and Dr. C. W. Scranton of East Orange, N. J., shared the lead with identical scores of 198 as the three-day 250target all-gauge event of the third national skeet championships reached the 200-target mark tonight.
Cooler weather for the week-end, with showers today and fair skies tomorrow and Monday, was predicted last night by the United States Weather Bureau.

With Oscar Johnston, the world's largest cotton planter and manager of the AAA cotton pool, as keynoter, a drive was launched here today to unite the South behind a plan for reviving world markets for United States cotton, with the complete revision or junking of the SmootHawley Tariff Act as the ultimate goal.

The advantages of minding one's own business, particularly in a three-boat race, were forcibly dem onstrated in the fifth contest for the Scandinavian Gold Cup today, when the Finnish six-meter craft Inga Lill XXVI came up from a presumably beaten position to win in a startling about-face.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 5,000. including 2,000 directs. Market was uneven, good to choice 230 pounds down, steady to 10 cents up; good sows steady: others steady to 10 cents lower; top $11.75: bulk good and choice 180-230 pounds, $11.50-$11.75; bulk 240-300 pounds $10.85-S11.40; bulk good packing sows $9.50-$9.90. Shippers 1,000; estimated holdover 1,000.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Rose, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bedell Rose of Lido Beach, L. I., and Philadelphia, formerly of this city, to George Lodge, son of Louis Lodge of Akron, Ohio.

Trading was generally only fair although some cuts were fairly active. Fresh pork prices were steady to lower, cow and bull weak to lower, lamb cuts uneven and other classes unchanged. Due to the Jewish holidays (rosh hashanah) next Monday and Tuesday, yesterday was the last kosher kill until next Wednesday. Kosher business opened slowly, with beef about steady, lamb and veal weak to lower as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
An airplane, motor stalled and out of control, nose-dived into the side of a house at Gibson here this afternoon, killing the two occupants of the craft almost instantly.

The Mexican Government has contracted a debt of more than $2,000,000 with the Bank of Mexico, it was revealed by financial circles here today. While the Government announced the largest tax collections in Mexican history in July, the expenses of the social revolutionary program are apparently running beyond income.

The Grand Circuit concluded its Ohio State Fair program today with Symbol Hal, driven by Dr. Hugh M. Parshall of Urbana, Ohio, and owned by E. R. Dail of Tarboro, N. C., taking the featured $1,000 2:I3 stake for pacers.

The Bronx Republican organization, of which John J. Knewitz is the leader, has decided definitely to support Senator Royal S. Copeland against Mayor La Guardia for the party nomination for Mayor, it was learned yesterday.

The three-story brick apartment house at 116 Sixteenth Street, near Park Avenue, West New York, N. J., was reported sold yesterday to the B. L. Management Company for investment by the Hudson Trust Company.

NEARLY every other reviewer in the neighborhood has praised Carl Crow's book on China,* and here is more fuel for the blurb-fires. "400 Million Customers" is a much-better-thanaverage volume of reminiscence, light, amusing and still sensible.

The Nicaraguan Congress, orators and the press stepped into the dispute with Honduras over a picture on a postage stamp tonight as invective and protest overflowed the borders of the two countries and the Nicaraguan Postmaster General declared the offending engraving was here to stay, Raliable sources 3.

The four-story apartment house at 1,409 St. Johns Place, Brooklyn, has been purchased from the Citizens Savings Bank by Max Gelles and Irving Honigsberg through their St. Johns Equities, Inc., which several months ago bought an identical building at 1,415 St. John's Place.

The sinking of the Soviet vessel Timirazef off the Algerian coast has caused an outburst of fury throughout the U.S.S.R. Newspaper headlines, which often are more indicative of Soviet opinion than editorials, show unexampled violence like Pravda's, "Reckless Pirates Must Be Called to Order," Izvestia's "Unprecedented Banditism," and the army organ, Red Star's "Unprecedented Act of Fascist Banditism."

President Roosevelt ordered the importation of Canadian red cedar shingles held to 892,373 squares during the last six months of the present year. The action was automatic as under the Revenue Act of 1936 he must, while the trade agreement with Canada is in effect, limit the imports to 25 per cent of the combined shipments by American producers and the Canadian imports during the proceeding half year.

Cooperation of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company in the development of rubber plantations in the Philippine Islands was promised to President Quezon of the Philippine Republic on his visit here, the Goodyear Company announced yesterday.

Lewis N. Cotlow, insurance broker of 77 Park Avenue, returned to New York quietly last week from a new type of expedition in Africa. According to The Uganda Gazette, a copy of which he had in his pocket, Mr. Cotlow was the first man to face the gorilla unarmed under the recent edict of the Belgian Congo Government.

The American Committee for Spanish Relief of New York accepted $30,753.96 in contributions, sent nothing to Spain, spent $25,793.72 on "administration and publicity" and had $3,340.22 in cash on hand July 31, according to a summary of contributions and their disposition made public by the State Department today.
Illness of the daughter of Governor Hurley of Massachusetts brought a halt today to the convict-extradition feud between Georgia and the Bay State.

Miss Muriel Jaret, daughter of Mrs. Gustave Jaretsky of 37 West Seventy-second Street, was married yesterday afternoon in the reception room of Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 270 West Eighty-ninth Street, to Edwin A. Elbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. August Elbert of New Rochelle. The Rev. Dr. Israel Goldstein performed the ceremony.

The Whitney Blake Company, Hamden, Conn., manufacturer of insulated wires and cables, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 50,000 shares of $5-par value common stock to be offered at $11 a share.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 702,000 bales, against 728,000 a week ago, 752,000 two weeks ago, 765,000 three weeks ago and 748,000 a year ago; of which American 235,000 bales. against 239,000 a week ago, 258,000 two weeks ago, 269,000 three weeks ago and 235,000 a year ago.

Officials of the Standard Steel Spring Company explain the company's delay in paying the 100 per cent stock dividend ordered for distribution last month by asserting that certificates representing the dividend could not be issued until the listing of the additional shares had been approved by the Exchanges.

Formal organization of Greenbelt Consumer Services, Inc., the subsidiary corporation which will operate on a cooperative basis all of the business services in the new Resettlement Administration town of Greenbelt, Md., was announced here yesterday by officers of the Consumer Distribution Corporation, founded by E. A. Filene, Boston merchant.

New York City is facing financial disaster as a result of the seizure of so many avenues of taxation by, the Federal Government, Senator Royal S. Copeland, aspirant for the Demoeratic Mayoralty nomination, asserted yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Katherine Corney, daughter of Mrs. Arthur Corney and the late Mr. Corney of Glen Ridge, to Alfred I. Manson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred I. Manson of East Orange, took place at noon today in the parish house of Sacred Heart Church, Bloomfield. Mgr. T. M. Donovan performed the ceremony.

The third annual Herald Tribune football school course was concluded yesterday in the Tribune auditorium with a high school coaches' forum. Informal talks were given by Eddie Mahan, Eddie Tryon, Al Fabbri, Walter Muller, Don Duncan and Zev Graham. The various aspects of high school football were discussed, including safety measures and conditioning methods.

The Federal Trade Commission today ordered Trade Laboratories, Inc., 412 Halsey Street, Newark, N. J., and its officers to cease and desist from certain unfair methods of competition in the sale of toilet articles.

The State Labor Relations Board announced yesterday that it had certified the collective bargaining election held July 16 by Horn Hardart employes in which the Cafeteria Employes Union, Local 302, and the Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union, Local 87, both A. F. of L. organizations, failed to poll a majority of the workers.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, which recently denied a request by the American Car and Foundry Company that its top salaries for the fiscal year ended on April 30, 1936, be kept confidential, received today a plea that the company's salaries for the last fiscal year be held secret.

The estimates of the New York City Department of Education, down to the last pupil, indicate, as announced in THE TIMES of last Tuesday, a decline in enrollment in the public elementary schools of 17,349 pupils. Diminished immigration and the low birth rate are two of the factors responsible for the decreased register.

The 1937 English county cricket season, featured by a slambang first-position battle in the later stages, officially ended today when Surrey gained a seven-wicket victory over Sussex. Yorkshire, returned champion for the nineteenth year, went to the top soon after the campaign opened and held the spot until replaced by Middlesex, Aug. 5.

Under a new decree, Germany has continued indefinitely the reduced import duty of 1 reichsmark on each 100 kilos of wheat, rye, barley and oats according to a cable dispatch to the Department of Commerce.

If the British Government will suggest a conference to bring together the representatives of the Jews and the Arabs in Palestine, an understanding probably will be reached, in the opinion of Felix M. Warburg, who returned from Europe yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria.

Nine new cases of infantile paralysis, thirteen suspected cases and one death were recorded in Chicago today as health and municipal authorities took additional precautions to prevent an epidemic of the disease.

Announcement was made today that the General Motors plant here would reopen Nov.,15 and employ 400 men until June on car production. At least $700,000 will be spent in modernizing the plant, which has been closed since 1930.
The Yanks quite definitely are not over the bumps yet. The closer they get to home, the rockier becomes the road. At least this was the impression the McCarthymen left today at Griffith Stadium.

General wage increases this Fall are the only alternative to further increased prices, the American Federation of Labor said in its monthly survey of business, made public today. Organized labor, said the bulletin, is going to do industry a favor "by seeing to it that wages continue to advance substantially this Fall."

Various geographical campaigns for spurring the sale of electrical appliances this Fall are now being developed. One of the largest of these drives, which is expected to produce $2,000,000 worth of business on a $100,000 promotional expense budget, will be staged in the Rocky Mountain area by the Rock Mountain Electrical League.

The peace overtures made to the ten suspended C. I. O. unions by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in Atlantic City on Thursday aroused only slight interest in Sidney Hillman, president of the Textile Workers Organizing Committee, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and one of the leading figures in the C. I. O. movement
San Marino, a thirty-eight-square-mile republic surrounded by Fascist Italy, today unveiled a bronze bust of its honorary citizen, Abraham Lincoln.

The return to active duty of Princeton's Fred Ritter, Temple's Bill Dogherty and Holy Cross's Ecio Luciano, forwards, plus the arrival of Bobby La Rue, Pittsburgh's great running back, brought the Eastern College All-Stars close to war strength when they turned out on Peddle School field this afternoon. The three linemen had been on the inactive list for several days with minor injuries.

Charles B. Stetson, the talented young skipper from Pequot, added another prize to his imposing 1937 collection today when he made good his challenge for the Gregory Taylor trophy for junior Atlantic Class sailors by leading home six rivals in a race off the American Yacht Club.

Roscoe Harold Peck, president and principal of Brown's Business Colleges in Davenport and Galesburg and for many years president of a chain of twenty-two business colleges in the Middle West, died last night at his home in Bettendorf, Iowa. His age aws 62.

Irving (Little Itch) Halper, who was sent to the Federal Penitentiary in Atlanta in 1932 as the head of one of the largest narcotic rings in the city, one that had been financed by the late Arnold Rothstein, was taken into custody last night for questioning in connection with the murder of Mrs. Esther Gordon of Revere. Mass., whose body was found in a barrel on Aug. 27.

Stopping in New York on a roundthe-world trip during which he is visiting his former pupils, the Very Rev. J. A. Graham, superintendent of St. Andrew's Colonial Homes at Kalimpong, India, declared yesterday that increasing prosperity was enabling the institution for the first time in years to find places in industry for its Anglo-Indian charges.

Albert E. Wackerman has been appointed to the new position of industry forester of the Seaboard Air Line Railway, with an office in Norfolk, Va., it was announced yesterday. The appointment is an initial step in the company's program to assure supplies for wood pulp mills along the line.

A practical tie-up of the whole port of San Francisco, the nation's second largest, appeared inevitable tonight when the A. F. of L. teamsters' union extended its waterfront blockade to transbay Oakland in its "finish fight" against C.I.O. forces.

Ending a hurried trip from China, 7,000 feet of film, said to be the first motion picture of the warfare in Shanghai and the two major bombings in the city's streets, arrived here by airplane yesterday morning for distribution by Universal Newsreel.

A wedding ring worn by his waitress girl-bride brought about detention of a man today on a charge of being an escaped Idaho prison farm convict. Detective Sergeant Frank Wyllie said the man gave his name as Benjamin Canton, 26, and was known to Warden W. H. Gess of the Eagle Island prison farm at Boise, Idaho, as "Jack La Beef."

Fass Wolper, Inc. real estate, in 7 E 42d St: Thomas J. O'Reilly. broker. J. Gilmore Fletcher, in Nine Rockefeller Plaza, Rockefeller Center. John S. Suarez, exporter, in 362 Fifth Ave; James Felt Co, Inc, broker.

Thomas Franklin Manville Jr., heir to the Manville asbestos fortune, last night announced that he had engaged a new attorney to represent him in his marital disputes, but apparently only as an indirect result of full-page advertisements he ran in some New York City newspapers yesterday.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 28 totaled 787,373 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 6,126 cars, or 0.8 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 33,276 cars, or 4.4 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 106,525 cars, or 15.6 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

About $50,000 has been spent since last Spring to improve property used by Father Divine's Peace Missions, Ralph Meyers, the Harlem preacher's new attorney, asserted in an affidavit submitted yesterday to Justice Philip J. McCook in Supreme Court. Such expenditures,

Recent events indicate that the Mexican radical movement has regained under President Cardenas the momentum lost under some of his predecessors. A leading "conservative," General Cedillo, has been forced to resign from the Cabinet, and Cardenas himself has declared that the Mexican revolution is only 30 per cent completed.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Schulte will entertain for Miss Hope Gimbel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel of Chieftains, Greenwich, and her fiance, David M. Solinger, son of Morris D. Solinger and the late Mrs. Solinger, on Sept. 10 at their Summer home in Port Chester.

More than threescore pilots of speed boats ranging in class from the tiny bobbing outboards to the hydroplanes capable of speeds up to ninety miles an hour, cast anxious eyes tonight on week-end weather forecasts as they prepared their craft for the Gold Cup Regatta that starts off the Detroit Yacht Club piers tomorrow and continues through Labor Day.

Although idle, because of the bye he had drawn for the tenth round, David S. Polland, New York State titleholder, automatically became the champion of the American Chess Federation tonight when George N. Treysman of New York, his only remaining rival for the prize, lost to Donald MacMurray of Chicago in thirty-five moves.
The Greyhound Corporation today filed notice with the Interstate Commerce Commission of its withdrawal of an application for authority to issue $240,000 of five-year serial equipment mortgage notes.

Mrs. Jean Gibbons Edson of Greenwich, Conn., widow of Franklin Edson 3d and daughter of Mr. -and Mrs. Lee Wallis Gibbons, also of Greenwich, was married here today in St. Matthew's Church to Henry Hotchkiss Garrison of Greenwich, formerly of New Haven, son of Mrs. Elisha Garrison of Greenwich and the late Mr. Garrison.

In August, domestic relations cases represented by the Legal Aid Society, 11 Park Place, increased 15 per cent over the monthly average for the year, it was reported yesterday. August, 1936, showed only a 4 per cent increase over the monthly average.

Three Canadian anglers were nominated tonight to represent the British Empire on the seven-man team which will fish against the United States in the international tuna angling matches at Wedgeport on Sept. 11, 12 and 13.

Henry W. Boettger, former president of the Silk Finishing Company of America, left a net estate of $1,136,625 when he died on April 1, 1934, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. The chief beneficiaries are the widow, a daughter and two sons.

No invitation to participate in the proposed conference of Mediterranean powers interested in Spain had yet been received by the Italian Government this evening and some fear was expressed that the conference's organizers may be planning not to invite Italy at all.

To eliminate "misfits" from the classroom, the twenty-four New York City vocational high schools will give a series of psychological and mental guidance tests to all entering pupils this Fall, Morris E. Siegel, director of continuation and evening schools, disclosed yesterday.

Canal St. 342. ?? cor Church St, 26x51x25x 57.11; Franwil Corp, Frank Josser, president. to Michaels Service Industries Corp, 342 Canal St; mtg $32,750 (50c). 17th St, 40-42 W, 50x92; D. Robert Kaplan referee, to Brooklyn Savings Bank, 141 Pierrepont, Bklyn; foreclosure ($15).

A "peace parade" of nearly 1,000 striking painters wound through the Streets of Harlem from 1 until 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Then the ranks of the marchers were reduced about one-half by the heat. Preceded by radio cars, the paraders carried placards listing the complaints of the 15,000 painters who are on strike in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond.

It will not be a best-seller, few may read it, but if the test is elemental human interest and bearing on the basic problems of our time, by all odds the most important book of the year is the 330-page report on "Nutrition," just published after years of research by the mixed committee of the League of Nations.

Surprisingly enough, since it was made to order for a prima donna, "Thin Ice," the new -Sonja Henie vehicle, at the Roxy, is one of the brightest comedies of the year-as swift as a bobsled, as full of frost and glitter as an ice carnival.

Elmer F. Andrew, State Industrial Commissioner, announced yesterday that an agreement had been signed between the National Lamp and Shade Manufacturers Association and Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Lamp Shade Division.

Receivers of the Wabash Railroad today filed incorporation papers with the Secretary of State in Columbus, Ohio,' taking the first tangible step in the corporate reorganization of the road pursuant to a plan filed in Federal court here on July 14.

Slender Fred C. Tanner, Yale student and member of the Creek Club in Locust Valley, and sturdy John Humm of the Rockville Club, AllLong Island football guard while on the Chaminade High School team in Mineola, today reached the final round of the Long Island junior championship.

Eugene Carlsen and Guy Fultz, ends, arrived at New York University's football training camp today to boost the squad's personnel to forty-five candidates. Both took part in the morning and afternoon practice sessions.

Anincrease in. Presbyterian Church membership and an increase of more than $2,000,000 in contributions of the churches were noted by the Rev. Dr. Lewis Seymour Mudge, stated clerk of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, in his annual report issued today.

Contracts aggregating $360,0000 for equipment for new army airplanes have been awarded to manufacturers in Brooklyn, Newark and Hartford, Conn. A contract of $82,291 was awarded to the Pioneer Instrument Corporation, Inc., of Brooklyn, for bank and turn and air speed indicators.

The Pettingill Long-and-Short-Haul Bill, long debated in Congress, today split delegates to the annual convention of the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners into arguing factions.
Georges Bonnet, Minister of Finance, who recently announced the success of his conversion plan for the treasury bonds of 1934, tonight made his second offer to test the market's powers of absorption.

Isaac Green, pioneer lumberman in this section and president of the Green-Hagerman Lumber Company, died at his home here last night at the age of 82. He was born in Princeton, N. J., on Feb. 23, 1855.

Forstmann Woolen Company of Passaic has filed suit in the United States District Court, Newark, against the Gera Mills, also of Passaic, to restrain the latter from manufacturing and selling a cloth said to be so similar to a patent Fortsmann design that only an expert can tell the difference. New Jersey Worsted Mills, holding company for Gera, was also named defendant in the suit.
If no last minute objections are raised, Joan Blondell will be borrowed by RKO from Warner Brothers to appear with Ginger Rogers in "Having Wonderful Time."

Dr. Julian S. Duncan, one-time Research Fellow at Brookings Institution; Wilson F. Payne, previously with the National Bureau of Economic Research and other groups, and John K. Horner, a member of the School of Business at Northeastern University, have been added to the faculty of the Babson Institute for Business Education.

Sales of houses in Harlem formed the bulk of realty activity in Manhattan yesterday. An investor bought three houses' from the Board of Christian Education of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America in a transaction negotiated by Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc. The properties are:

Kay Francis today brought suit to cancel -her film contract with Warner Brothers, charging that in 1935, when an option clause of her contract was due to expire, Jack Warner persuaded her to extend the contract by promising her the 1ead in "Tovarich."

A drive against "all company unions" was urged tonight at what was announced as a joint meeting of representatives of Pennsylvania branches of the Committee for Industrial Organization and the American Federation of Labor.

The Commerce Department announced today Japan produced 161,067,000 pounds of rayon during the first six months of 1937 compared with 120,211,000 pounds for the corresponding period of 1936, a gain of 34 per cent.

Captain Lindley of the steamship Kirkingsbury reported to the Federal Weather Bureau here that he felt two shocks, apparently from an earthquake, today at 18:50 Greenwich mean time 2:50 P. M. Eastern daylight time], 375 miles southwest of Dutch Harbor, Alaska.

The condition of Dr. Thomas G. Masaryk, ex-President of Czechoslovakia, is further improved but it was declared officially -that the critical phase will continue until midnight tomorrow. Until then it is impossible to say whether he can survive the attack.

The undeclared war in the East begins with unexampled carnage and fury, but it is new compared to the undeclared war that has been raging for two years now in the Mediterranean. The Sino-Japanese clash is new, and as yet it cannot long distract the attention of European powers from the home front.

While the heavy shelling was going on in Shanghai yesterday the Chinese said they had driven Japanese forces out of two-thirds of the area of Lotien, about seventeen miles northwest of this city, and that Japanese troops that had remained in the area were wiped out.

Ten days in advance of the opening of the University of Puerto Rico, Registrar Maura figuratively has removed the "Standing Room Only" sign and replaced it with one substantially stating "No Admittance."
Chief among the entertainments in the Summer colony tonight was the dinner and dance given by Mrs. Moses Taylor at her home in honor of her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. James Cameron Clark.

Surrounded by their handiwork, ranging from airplane models to necklaces made of noodles, several hundred children of the lower East Side gathered on the roof garden of the Educational Alliance yesterday afternoon to close a two-month program of Summer activities with Lan exhibition of arts and crafts.
Four of Great Britain's speediest destroyers steamed away from Chatham and Portsmouth today to reinforce the anti-"pirate" patrol in the western Mediterranean.

The Department of Agriculture announced today that a special certificate service had been arranged to facilitate grain exports from this country shipped from the Great Lakes through Canadian seaports.

Lord Rothermere's Daily Mail, which for some time has been advocating Anglo-German friendship, publishes today an extract of a letter from Chancellor Adolf Hitler to Viscount Rothermere. The letter, which is undated, says in part:
The interest of the estate of the late W. C. Atkins in Atkins, Hamill Gates ceased on Aug. 31. The New York Stock Exchange partnership of Sivin, Franklin Co. was dissolved on Sept. 1.

Passengers leaving today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Rex include Henry de Forest Baldwin, Mr. and Mrs. Paul S. Brinsmade, Henry B. Ivers, Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Hoffman, Mr. and Mrs. Perry D. Richards, Dr. and Mrs. George Gray Ward and Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Youngblood.

Max Kurzrok of 267 Brevort Street, Kew Gardens, Queens, formerly a manufacturer and builder doing business as the Max Kurzrok Realty Company, Inc., filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in the Federal Court, Brooklyn. He listed liabilities of $3,149,171 and no assets.

Associate Justice William F. Hagarty of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn vacated yesterday writ of prohibition restraining Supreme Court Justice John H. McCooey from punishing thirty-two striking waiters for violating an injunction prohibiting the picketing of Joe's Restaurant, 8 Nevins Street, Brooklyn.

A few of the leading domestic sugar refiners announced yesterday new quotations for refined sugar as a result of the new Sugar Act. The Pennsylvania Sugar Company announced late in the day that its new base price for refined sugar was 5.15 cents a pound, effective as of the opening of business on Thursday.

Miss Margaret Janet Frank, daughter of Mrs. David C. Frank of this city, formerly of White Plains, and the late Mr. Frank, was married yesterday afternoon to Christian Frederick Piehl of the Ambassador in the chapel of Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. The Rev. Benjamin F. Saxon performed the ceremony.

Japan's formidable war machine around Shanghai was stalled today by a Chinese counter-offensive. The Chinese struck effectively with artillery at Japanese naval concentrations on the Whangpoo River, Shanghai's outlet to the sea. Eight Japanese troopships fled down the river to escape destructive Chinese gunfire.
George W. Gray's book, "The Advancing Front of Science," has been made the September choice of the Scientific Book Club it was announced yesterday. The book is published by Whittlesey House.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week total $12,550,027, to be represented by on State and fifty-three municipalities This compares with the revise total of $12,731,200 for this week The weekly average of new offer ings for the year to date now stand at $27,146,982.

Funeral services for Otto Raphael, retired police lieutenant and friend of President Theodore Roosevelt, were held yesterday at the West End Funeral Chapel, 200 West Ninety-first Street. Mr. Raphael died Wednesday in Coney Island Hospital.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a very enlightening radio address recently, Japanese Vice Consul Kazuyoshi Inagaki revealed to American listeners that his country's sole aim "in the undeclared war in China was to bring about a permanent cooperation between the two countries."

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The course of the foreign wool markets this week has not been very reassuring to the local trade. On a very ordinary selection, with little suitable for this country, prices at Sydney, Australia, opened slightly off from the June level. Since the opening, prices have shown further decrease to about 5 per cent under June.

The engagement of Miss Carol Goldburg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Goldburg of New Rochelle, to Harvey J. Kern, son of Mrs. Samuel Kern of Yonkers and the late Mr. Kern, has been announced by her parents.

The Minsky brothers, erstwhile .urlesque impresarios, who split into two camps five years ago and felt separately the curbing censorship of the Commissioner of Licenses four months ago, are united gain.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor entertained at Wasserleonburg Castle last night former King Alfonso of Spain, who drove there from Poertschach on the Woerthersee.

We are being visited by the family of Thomas Gordon and Eskimos, some of whom say they distinctly heard a plane pass here on Aug. 13, when the six Russian fliers disappeared on their flight from Moscow to the United States. They were roping reindeer when the engine's noise attracted their attention. All stopped work to listen.

Victor Pohjola, 62 years old, of 605 East Forty-first Street, Brooklyn, who operates a steamship agency at 23 East 125th Street, was named in two grand larceny indictments handed up to Judge Freschi in General Sessions yesterday.

Miss Marjorie Mae Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Clark of Scotch Plains, was married here this afternoon in All Saints' Church to Kennard Hart Kyte, son of Robert L. Kyte of Fanwood, by the Rev. William F. Bassill.
The engagement of Miss Martha Johnson to John Howard Saunders Acheson, son of Dr. and Mrs. John H. Acheson of New Rochelle, has been announced. The wedding will take place on Oct. 23.
The general reaction among landowners to the Government's nine-cent cotton loan is that it is satisfactory, although ten cents was expected.
Diplomatic sources disclosed today that a British and an Italian subject had been arrested in Leningrad in the past few days in the Soviet drive against foreigners suspected of spying.

Lord Britain, upstanding chestnut gelding owned by Carleton H. Palmer of New York and ridden by Jack Prestage in all of his classes, today won the hunter championship of the annual Orangeburg open air horse show. Reserve was awarded to the bay mare, Gar Ann, entered and ridden by Miss Catherine Morgan of Tarrytown, N. Y.

Captain Hans Martin Larsen, for more than forty years commander of boats of the Central Railroad of New Jersey running between Sandy Hook and New York, died on Friday in Norwegian Hospital after a short illness. He was 78 years old and lived at 249 Ninety-third Street, Brooklyn.
Moscow. ALL effort is being directed to further the success of the forthcoming twentieth anniversary of the November revolution.

Albert H. Bumstead, chief cartographer of the National Geographic Society, expressed doubt today that a new Northwest Passage from the Atlantic to the Pacific had been established by the Canadian vessels, meeting in Bellot Strait.

Mr. and Mrs. Allan Johnson of Akron, Ohio, have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Baird Johnson, to James M. Cecil Jr., son of James M. Cecil of 507 East Fifty-fifth Street, New York, and the late Mrs. Cecil.
The percentage of collections on installment accounts of department stores in July was 15.4, compared to 16.3 in June and 16.2 in July, 1936, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Loans for the construction of sixstory apartment houses in Jackson Heights, L. I., taken by the Queensboro Corporation from Jan. 1 to Aug. 31 this year, amounted to $2,500,000, Frank R. Howe, vice president, announced yesterday.

The second dress collections of the Fall season will be presented shortly, and will be more extensive than those shown in past seasons, but the new styles will not impair consumer acceptance of models in the opening lines that gained favor, Morris Kolchin, executive director of the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc., declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON.--WPA funds, on projects staffed by white-collar relief workers, have helped about fifty American museums to overcome the depression curtailment of activities, a House committee was recently informed. Before the WPA program was started many museums had valuable exhibits in storage.

VISITORS drawn to Kentucky by horse-racing events in September and October often remain to relish the food of the State. At the many social events which accompany the Fall season they find it served to them usually in the manner and by the recipes of generations of Kentucky hostesses.

Miss Mary Anna Laycock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Harold Laycock of Wilkes-Barre, was married to H. Lee Scott Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Lee Scott of Dallas, at Glen Summit Chapel today.

Four dances tonight enlivened this week-end. These were held at the Pittsfield Country Club, Wyantenuck Country Club, Great Barrington; the Stockbridge Golf Club and the Berkshire Hunt and Country Club at Lenox.

Mrs. C. Phillips Hill of Washington has announced today that Miss Frances Montague Hill would be married next Saturday to Captain Edward Colston Dyer of the Marine Corps, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. E. Dyer of Ruxton, Md. The ceremony will take place in the Rappahannock County, Va., home of the bride-elect's aunt, Mrs. George Barnett.
The Spanish steamer Escort Mendi, which arrived here Aug. 17 from Buenos Aires, escaped today and sailed to Spain. The vessel was detained here owing to a disorder in the crew.
PLANS to make Venice a more modern and sanitary city, without impairing its artistic beauty, recently have been approved by the Government.

Amateur horse racing, which has been dormant for more than two months, will come into prominence again tomorrow with the annual meeting of the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association at Rye, N. Y. The one-day session will usher in the Autumn season which will close Nov. 20, with the meeting at Montpelier, Va.

Cloudy and cooler weather for today and tomorrow was predicted last night by the United States Weather Bureau as a heavy electrical storm broke over the city, bringing welcome relief from the sultry heat wave that had gripped the city for eight days.
Mounting concern for the future of American cotton exports, No. 1 on the nation's list of agricultural surpluses, found expression on two fronts this week.

Vigorous protest has been made by the National Association of Retail Grocers against the agreement entered into by the Resettlement Administration and the Consumer Distribution Corporation providing for operation by the latter organization on a cooperative basis of all the business enterprises in the government's new model suburban community at Greenbelt, Md.

England is carrying forward its housing program with "unchecked vigor and speed," and buying of homes there is proceeding at a rapid rate, reports Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, who returned recently from a study of housing conditions abroad.

Announcement last week of the products upon which concessions will be considered in negotiating the proposed trade treaty with Czechoslovakia has precipitated a tariff controversy which promises to last through the Fall and, in the opinion of foreign traders, may bring a rush of protectionist bills at the next session of Congress.

DEVELOPMENT of a television camera with its light sensitivity surpassing that of the photographic camera is a possibility heralded as "of greatest importance to the future of telecasting," according to Dr. P. C. Goldmark, engineer of the Columbia Broadcasting System, recently returned from a five-week tour of European television stations and laboratories.

PANAMA CITY. THE waves lapping gently at the feet of the stately palms along the Panama Canal here give the impression of tranqzillity. Far to the northwest the breeze in the pines along the mountainous lower border of Mexico gave the same tranquil feeling.

Plans for substantial expansion of production of pulp in this country, resulting from the existing shortage which has carried prices upward as much as 50 per cent over a year ago, may result in an oversupply within the next year unless there is a considerable increase in the annual use by the rayon industry, paper interests here said yesterday.

THE opening Thursday of the new International Casino on the east side of Broadway, between Forty-fourth and Fortyfifth Streets, marks another chapter in the history of a block which has played an integral part in the theatre annals of New York.

LINKED with a larger reform movement is a renewed campaign to save the sea birds from their worst fate. There is quickened activity in several seaboard States and more effective cooperation with the Federal Government.

Barrow Cadbury, British authority on housing, here to attend the world conference of Friends, believes that recent movements undertaken in the United States will be as successful in providing low-cost housing as English projects have been.

From now until well after the beginning of October thousands of New York housewives are faced with the problem of moving into new apartments. Twenty-five or thirty years ago the first of May was the popular date in New York for moving. Since then Oct. 1 has become the conventional moving day, for which there seems to be no particular reason except that most leases terminate Sept. 30.
Rotary clubs of Germany, meeting in special sessions today, decided to disband voluntarily on Oct. 15, provided the Nazi Government's attitude toward them remains unchanged.

John L. Lewis's plea for a union of labor and farmers met a chilly reception today among some of the Senators and Representatives remaining on Capitol Hill. Senator Burke, Democrat, of Nebraska, commented that if the leader of the Committee for Industrial Organization "tries to organize the farmer he will have one of the biggest disappointments of his life."

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-From the time the shrieking of sires and the tooting of whistles announce the arrival here next Tuesday morning of the American Beauty Special until the crown is placed on the head of "Miss America 1937," on Saturday night, Atlantic City will be cloaked in a carnival atmosphere.

Debits to individual accounts as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Sept. 1 aggregated $8,474,000,000, or 14 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 3 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

With every intention of duplicating, at least, the 6-0 victory the All-Stars scored over the champion Green Bay Packers at Chicago last Wednesday, a powerful group of Eastern All-Stars will engage the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds on Wednesday night under floodlights in the second annual battle for the benefit of the New York Herald-Tribune Fresh Air Fund. The start is scheduled for 8:45 P. M.

Creation of a University Council at Fordham, composed of faculty members, invested with authority to advise the president on all problems of faculty activity, was announced yesterday by the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of the university.

VIENNA. FROM rugged Albania two types of "story." and two only, can be relied upon to catch the eye of the world press, on an average once a year--an unsuccessful local revolt against the King and the King's pending marriage.

Combat, both armed and otherwise, between the forces of the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization, has the basic industry of the Pacific Northwest in what observers regard as a hopelessly chaotic tangle.

Manvers N. Prescott, 60, who was critically wounded last night fighting off two robbers who held up his grocery store at Orford, died today at Hanover Hospital. He was shot in the chest, mouth and head.

The United States Lines anbounced yesterday that plans were being made in France to welcome several thousand American Legion members expected to make a pilgrimage to war battlefields abroad after the three-day national convention in New York this month.

William Volk of Weehawken, N. t J., real estate man and restaurateur, died on Friday in Lenox Hill Hospital of a heart ailment. He was 73 years old. In the course of fifty years in the restaurant business in downtown New York,

The following foreign service changes since Aug. 28 were announced today by the State Department: C. Burke Elbrlck of Louisville, Ky.. third secretary of legation and vice consul at Port Au Prince, Haiti. assigned to Warsaw. Poland, as third secretary of embassy.

THIS is the story of the men with the big hands, the migratory laborers of the sea and the woods and their uglier women. It is the detailed but dramatic account of the way of life that these men take who never gain by a boom, have nothing much to lose in depression, have no homes or hope.

Tense feelings between South America's two largest republics were dissipated tonight when this capital completed plans for an enthusiastic reception of Argentina's Vice President, Julio Roc, tomorrow.
WASHINGTON.--With the publication of the fifth volume of its treaty edition, the Department of State has brought its printed record of our international agreements down to 1852.

THERE need be no concern over the list to port noted as the Georgic shoved off yesterday for Europe. It was simply Mr. Alfred Hitchcock, Britain's Falstaffian pundit of the melodrama, leaning over the rail and rocking the boat ever so slightly as he enjoyed a parting glimpse of the Manhattan skyline (of which this department unfortunately forgot to ask his opinion during his ten-day sojourn here).

Financial arrangements were completed today for the international trotting race between Greyhound, United States Grand Circuit star, and Muscletone, European champion, at the Illinois State Fair track Oct. 8.

Check exchanges at the principal clearing houses of the country in August totaled $24,763,333,696, a decrease of 14 per cent from the preceding month but a gain of 5.1 per cent over that in August, 1936. The turnover was the smallest since that month.

Public utility executives are keeping a weather eye on the development of Nebraska's "Little TVA," which recently received a Government loan and grant of about $20,000,000, to determine whether the Administration has changed fronts and is experimenting with the idea of buying out private utilities in fields to which it is sending a sizable amount of cash.
With plans and blueprints completed and approved, THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair of 1937, to be held Nov. 5 to 21 at Rockefeller Center, reached the construction stage last week.

Herman A. Acker, president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York, announced yesterday that plans had been well advanced for the association's convention in Niagara Falls Sept. 30 to Oct. 2. Describing it as a "trail blazer convention," Mr. Acker said the meeting would "herald and celebrate the birth of a new era" of real estate activity and prosperity.
Harold E. Dahl, American flier, who was jailed by Spanish Insurgents, is in no danger of death by execution, said a spokesman close to the Insurgent regime today.

The Diario Ilustrado said today that although some groups of Nazi supporters headed by German agents have been carrying on propaganda the outstanding elements in the German colonies in Chile did not support this propaganda.

HERE in Japan, even more than in China, one has the feeling of a country being carried along by a kind of fatality. For years a certain school of Japanese has talked grandiosely of Japan's destiny. Now all Japanese are learning that destiny is by definition something that cannot be commanded.

John Torrio, a former associate of Al Capone and ranking public enemy in New York City since Charles (Lucky) Lucania was sentenced to jail, was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday with three of his associates for income tax evasion and conspiracy.

Homers by Bill Werber and Bob Johnson with men on gave the Athletics their second victory of the season over the Red Sox, 10-4, today in the second half of a double-header. The home forces took the first game, 5-4, in ten innings.

The Japanese armies in North China are at present operating in a vast triangle from Machang southward to Tientsin, thence westward to points near Paoting, thence northward in Chahar Province and thrusting into Northern Shansi Province, an official Japanese military spokesman explained to this writer Saturday afternoon after spreading many maps upon two tables.

WHEN the Board of Estimate recently took the first definite step toward making the North Beach Municipal Airport in Queens what officials claim will be the finest airport for land and sea planes in the country by approving the purchase of the field from the CurtissWright interests for $1,300,000 it
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow:

IN the heart of the Cascade Mountains, deep in the canyon of the turbulent Skagit River, the city of Seattle has linked the generation of hydroelectric power with one of America's most unusual travel resorts.

State and municipal financing for August aggregated $53,771,264, compared with $67,447,141 in August, 1936, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The total for the first eight months of 1937 was $728,910,782, compared with $746,129,668 for the same period of last year.

CARPENTERS, painters, electricians, weavers, seamstresses, sheet metal workers and many other artisans have begun work on the decorations for the 1937 Automobile Show to be held in Grand Central Palace, here, Oct. 27 to Nov. 3, it was reported last week.

ASSCHER-LEVENE-Mr. and Mrs. Albert Levene, 760 Riverside Drive, announce the engagement of their daughter, Rhoda, to Joseph Asscher Jr. of Amsterdam, Holland. FIXLER-BLUMBERG--Mr. and Mrs. Louis S. Blumberg, 1,960 Ocean Parkway, announce the engagement of their daughter,

Furman Kugler of Somerville, N. J., took the spotlight in the national amateur bicycle races today by taking two junior championships in quick succession. His brilliant lastminute sprints over a wet track won both the two-mile and ten-mile tests.
Das Deutsche Haus and Le Foyer, wo new language houses at Mount Iolyoke College, will serve as soial centers for German and French ife of the community during the oming academic year.

Jean Renoir, a son of the impressionist painter, the late Pierre Auguste Renoir, directed the film version of Maxim Gorki's play "The Lower Depths" in France this year. It will reach this country via the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse Friday.

A Fall electrical housewares campaign, one of the most ambitious ever undertaken by the industry, will be launched this week under the joint sponsorship of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association and the Edison Electric Institute.

ONE of the most important conservation measures ever voted upon by Congress, a bill providing for the establishment of the Cape Hatteras National Seashore in North Carolina, has just been approved by President Roosevelt.

It's costing Max Schmeling two years of waiting and perhaps $100,000 in cash to get his long-sought chance to regain the world heavyweight boxing championship, in the return match with Joe Louis that is now definitely set for next June.

A buffet supper to which Frank Lee Connable of New York, president of the Saranac Inn Country Club, has, asked 250 members of the Saranac Inn colony to meet Miss Eugenia M. Coleman of Chestnut Hill, Pa., and her fiance, John Connable Bennett, nephew of Mr. Connable, in Saranac Inn Casino on Monday night will be one of several events of Labor Day here. Many house parties are being held and guests arrived today.

SEOULD protests in bridge tournaments be encouraged or discouraged? At every tournament there is a director, or manager, who is called upon every time some rule of the game is infringed, and who assesses penalties against the offending players.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates being Sept. 3 unless specified: At Coco Solo: Babbitt, Mallard, S-42, 44. 46. Bremerton to San Diego: Humphreys, King. At San Pedro: Kanawha, Sept. 4, Utah. Acushnet, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Sept. 4. Badger, Charleston Yard to Washington Yard.

Homes in various parts of Westchester County have been attracting buyers in large numbers during the late Summer season, and several such sales were listed yesterday by brokers active in that county. Several of the deals were in and near Scarsdale.
Sol Zito of Egg Harbor, N. J., driving his home-made boat Zito Plane IV, captured the free-for-all race at the ninth annual regatta of the Yacht Club of Stone Harbor today.

With the undeclared Sino-Japanese war almost two months old it became increasingly apparent last week that its duration-and perhaps even its outcome-was dependent largely upon the extent of Japanese aims in China and the ability of the Japanese Government to hold the army it has unleashed to the aims defined.

An overcast sky and occasional showers restricted attendance and somewhat cramped the style of participants in the National Air Races here today, but weather prospects were better for tomorrow and airmen were looking forward to the Thompson Trophy Race which will close the four-day show on Monday.

RADIOLYMPIA, London's annual exhibition of all that is new in radio receivers and television, closed yesterday, leaving little doubt that "the chief features are television sets and allwave receivers," according to The London Times.

Several large and hitherto undiscovered ruins of a civilization which is said to have existed in Southwestern United States long before the discovery of the New World were sighted by the Rainbow BridgeMonument Valley expedition while engaging in aerial reconnoissance of the etched mesas of Southern Utah and Northern Arizona, it was learned here today.
SINCE Og, the hairy one, hauled in his first fish on a bone hook and a rawhide line, fishing has been an individual pastime.
THE Wagnerian Festival Singers, making their first American tour, will be heard in New York for the first time on Sunday afternoon, Oct. 24, at the Town Hall.

Newbold Drayton, railroad construction engineer and member of a prominent Philadelphia family, died today at his home in Gwynedd. He was 54 years old. Mr. Drayton underwent an operation for an intestinal ailment six weeks ago in the Pennsylvania Hospital.
With the harvest work almost over, convicts on this wall-less prison farm are lining up for books, tablets and pencils. Their own school and college will start Oct. 1.

About 16,000 square feet of space in the Aeolian plant at Garwood, N. J., has been leased by the Omaha Hat Corporation of New York for five years beginning Nov. 1. Peterson Stalford negotiated the deal, with the Rosenberg-Murray Company as co-brokers.

Experimental flights by Imperial Airways across the Atlantic will be continued during the Winter on the North Atlantic route instead of being switched to the South Atlantio route via Bermuda and the Azores as was expected.

The 161st anniversary of the meeting at the Billopp-Conference House, Tottenville, S. I., between representatives of the Continental Congress and spokesmen for the British Crown, when the Americans rejected a British bid for peace, will be celebrated at the house on Saturday at 2 P. M., it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Newton D. Chapman, president of the Conference House Association, Inc.

THE pilgrimage is to Mecca, the pilgrim an English Muslim, the story well tod, interesting and not overremotional. The young Englishman who is the book's protagonist was a restless, high-spirited, energetic lad who came to know the Malays when he worked among them under the rule of the Brooke family, the famous "white Rajahs" of Sarawak.

ROME--Despite the Government campaign, pressed with renewed vigor at the beginning of this year, Italy's birth rate, in the six months ended June 30, showed a slight decline from the corresponding period of 1936.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Brewster Mack of New York gave an aperitif party at the Mount Washington here today. Miss Helen M. Donahue, the Misses Agnes, Madeleine, Louise and Florence Holden, Mr. and Mrs. John Ahern, William Gleason and Miss Elsie Quinn of New York are at the Mount Pleasant.

STATIC is atmospheric electricity "full of sound and fury signifying nothing." Wireless operators call it "QRN." Broadcast listeners call it noise. It interferes with wireless and annoyingly scratches programs, especially during local thunderstorms.

The text of Foreign Minister Koki' Hirota's speech at a special session of the Parliament in Tokyo today, as made public here by the Consulate General of Japan, follows: Ever since the beginning of the present China affair, the Japanese Government, in pursuance of its policy of local settlement and non-aggravation, exerted every effort to effect a speedy solution.

R. PRMIESTLEY'S new play has not yet appeared, but the past week has given us meanwhile two pieces by dramatists of reputation, "Gertie Maude," by John van Druten, and "Old Music," by Keith Winter. Both conform to the prevailing fashion for period plays.
Three members of the gang recently convicted of participation in the 1933 kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr. won the right today in Federal Court here to confer privately with their attorney.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Frances Carlene Haines Waitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Weymer Hinckley Waitt of this city and Ardsley-onHudson, to Esmond Brown Gardner, soh of Mrs. Isaac B. Gardner, also of New York, and the late Dr. Gardner.

The oddest anachronism in New. York City, perhaps, is the vanishing horse-drawn cab driver. Once there was a proud and strong army of them; today, some sixteen or seventeen are left-old men who, in rather morose and rococo fashion, are making a last stand at flicking their buggy whips into the face of a high-powered gasoline age.

Improvement in rental conditions during August in its properties at Forest Hills, L. I., is reported by the Cord Meyer Development Company. New leases drawn in August were 50 per cent more than during the same month of last year and fewer apartments are left for Oct. 1 occupancy than this time last season.
To the Music Editor: I should like to answer briefly a letter in THE TIMES of Aug. 29, by Roy Harris, in response to mine of three weeks earlier.

Miss Evelyn A. Jordan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Jordan of 759 Vine Street, and Charles J. Winter Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Winter, also of this city, were married this afternoon in St. James Methodist Episcopal Church here.

Among the rank and file of the crowds attending races only a few know how difficult it is to win a race and how seldom an owner is lucky enough to get a really good race horse. But there is an even smaller number of racegoers who know that it is more difficult, and certainly it costs more, to win a jumping race than one on the flat. In the first place,

Walter Cummings now knows it is easier to ride than walk. The British Guiana champion traveled 4,000 miles to compete in the London-Brighton walk but retired from the racing today after footing it for 16 miles.

The high level of apartment renting activity during the past few weeks on both the East and West Sides of Manhattan is indicated in a report by Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., showing 100 per cent occupancy for the large houses. at 450 West End Avenue and 730 Park Avenue.

THE city's first trailer show of the season will open Friday. The date, earlier than usual, was set at least in part because the trailer travelers are going South with the first of the birds, long before the short-term Winter vacationists have even made their plans.
America's touring track and field athletes won eight of the first nine events in a meet with Japanese intercollegiate stars in Meiji Stadium today, The competition will be concluded tomorrow.

Remarks made by President Roosevelt accompanying vetoes of Congressional bills and a dispute between Republican and Democratic spokesmen over just how much money the last session of Congress did appropriate have served to revive interest in the "economy drive" of the Administration.

ELIZABETH K. STEEN, one of the few anthropologists to take two expeditions into the Araguayan River region of Brazil, has brought more than reference-book knowldge from that little-known and dangerous land.
EDMUND BLUNDEN'S book "charles Lamb and His Contemporaries," although published in England in 1933, has just been re-issued as the nine-teenth volume of the "Cambridge Miscellany,"

Martha Raye. screen commedienne, filed suit today to divorce Hamilton Westmore. Miss Raye's complaint asserted that her husband was guilty of extreme cruelty, that he once threatened to shoot her and himself, that he slapped her, showed "extreme jealousy" and interfered with her career.

Five million new homes will be required to care for increased population in the United States during the next fifteen years, according to Blaine A.
