Davis, research assistant to the chief appraiser of the Equitable Life Assurance Society. The figures, based upon the trend of immigration, the falling birth rate and the increased death rate, are given in an article in the current issue of The Journal of Real Estate

Appointment of thirty-three committees to aid the board of directors of the Merchants Association of New York in the work of the ensuing year was announced yesterday by Louis K. Comstock, president of the association.
The Mortgagees Realty Service, Inc., real estate division of the Home Title Guaranty Company, as agent for individual and institutional investors, has reported the following recent sales:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Nothing of its kind can be more regrettable in this period of industrial unrest than the threat of a quarter of a million railroad operating department workers to strike in protest against the refusal of their employers to concede their demand for a 20 per cent wage increase.

HERE, in fictional form, is an amusing, but in its implications, a deeply disturbing picture of the publicity business as it is pursued (and that goes for the client as much as for the agent) in New York today.
Some 5,000 persons of Italian descent in Pennsylvania's lower anthracite region will assemble here on Monday to honor the memory of Senator Marconi, who died at Rome in July.

Mrs. Frank Kerby Fergusson of Fort Totten has announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of her daughter, Miss Dora Margaret Fergusson, to Albert Edward Posener of Great Neck, Queens, son of Mrs. Theodore Coleman of Punta Gorda, Fla., and Philip Posener of New York.

FOR Miss Baldwin's host of women readers she has provided an even more absorbing story than usual in her latest novel For what woman will not be fascinated by an intimate view behind the scenes in a fashionable dress shop?

The question whether to bring the Neutrality Act into play against China and Japan is the major item on President Roosevelt's agenda. To invoke the act the President would have to declare that a state of war exists between the two countries at a time when both of the principals in the current dispute deny that there is any such situation.

Complete electric light service was restored at 2 P. M. yesterday afternoon in the City Island area which was thrown into darkness at 9 P. M. Friday night when a transformer of the Consolidated Edison Company in Pelham Bay Park was short-circuited.

Expressing the belief that trade unionism offers an opportunity "to further the work of God," Jerome Davis, president of the American Federation of Teachers, urged the Second World Conference of the Religious Society of Friends here today to encourage the labor movement.

HE well-known road, which has manifested remarkable recuperative powers of late, will be swinging into vigorous stride this season considerably ahead of Broadway. And so, to indicate the extent of this activity, the following schedule has been prepared, listing the attractions which will open those more familiar out-of-town houses.

Eight hundred wounded legionnaires arrived today from Spain aboard the hospital ship Gradisca. They were cheered by crowds and the Chief of Staff of the Italian militia, General Alfio Russo, and then were transported in ambulances to various hospitals.

Miss Eunice Jayne Kellogg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester B. Kellogg of this place, was married to William King Laird, son of Dr. and Mrs. George S. Laird, also of Westfield, in the First Congregational Church here this afternoon.

In an effort to determine the relative prophetic ability of various groups of individuals, mainly specialists, scholars, and men of affairs, Dr. Hadley Cantril, Associate Professor of Psychology at Princeton University, has circulated a questionnaire among several hundred persons asking for seventy different predictions.
So many unidentified submarines have been firing torpedoes in the Mediterranean that our readers may welcome a little more

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today that United States flax growers were receiving lower prices for flaxseed than a year ago, but some rise in price was possible before the Argentine crop began to move to European markets.

History and Biography ASTROPHEL. By Alfred H. Bill. 8v0. New York: Farrar Rinehart. $3.50. The life and death of Sir Philip Sidney. SIR MALCOLM CAMPBELL'S BOOK OF FAMOUS MOTORISTS. Edited by Sir Malcolm Campbell. Written by R. S. Lyons. 8vo. New York: Hillman-Curl. $1.75.

Standings of Naval Reserve battalion and division units throughout the United States, as determined by the annual inspection of the Naval Reserve Inspection Board, have been announced by the Navy Department.

THE Times Literary Supplement devotes its leading article this week to an elaborate discussion, running to nearly two pages, of "Marxism and Literature." It opens by calling attention to the recent movement among the younger English poets and critics to apply Marxist conceptions to literature, and indeed to art in general.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Katharine Roosevelt, only daughter of Mrs. Harry Latrobe Roosevelt of Skaneateles and Washington, D. C., to Reverdy Johnson Wadsworth, son of Representative and Mrs. James Wolcott Wadsworth of Hartford House, Geneseo, took place at St. James Episcopal Church, Skaneateles, at noon today.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Lobdell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Whitney Lobdell of this place, was married to Henry C. Meyn of Pleasantville, formerly of Henstedt, Germany, and her sister, Miss Hazel Bater Lobdell, became the bride of Reginald A. White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. White of Chappaqua, this afternoon in a double wedding.

The world of science was still unconvinced today that Paul Pisculli's mystery pill would prevent drowning. In fact, the anti-drowning experiment staged off Convention Hall here this morning, with Gene Tortariello as the subject, ended somewhat disastrously, with lifeguards rescuing not only Tortariello but two other persons who accompanied him to sea in a small boat.

Wilford Wehrle of Racine, Wis., and Charles (Chuck) Kocsis of Detroit walked out of a broiling sun late today, hard-pressed victors in the thirty-six-hole semi-finals of the annual Western amateur golf championship.
TO this chronicler of scientific events the current meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science at Nottingham, England, seems unusually dull.

Plans to start construction of a large new school building within thirty days in the Manor Woods section of Hartsdale, Westchester County, have served to focus attention on this residential section and have brought promise of increased realty activity there, according to the Dorolyn Building Corporation, which announced last week the sale of three of the five homes built by the company in its Manor Woods development. The homes are of Colonial and English design.

The American Bureau of Shipping announced yesterday that on Sept. 1 105 vessels of 100 gross tons or more were being built to bureau classification in United States shipyards. The construction represents an estimated total gross tonnage of 306,000, a slight drop under the figures of a month ago.

Petey Sarron, the world featherweight champion from Birmingham, Ala., did everything but score a knockout tonight as he outpointed a former titleholder, Freddie Miller of Cincinnati, to retain his title in a 12-round bout.

Mrs. Marguerite Skirvin Adams surprised her friends here today when she was quietly married to George Tyson, Boston broker. The marriage, witnessed only by members of the families, took place in the bride's Summer home, Beach Mound, at noon.
Faculty changes for the coming year at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, Broadway and 122d Street, have been announced by Dr. Cyrus Adler, president.

PIERRE MONTEUX, who has completed his second season as conductor of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra, has been conducting performances of Debussy's "Pellas et Melisande," with Dutch casts, in Amsterdam.

AUSTRALIANS are becoming worried about the future of the black aboriginals. A check-up on the Northern Territory, where the native population outnumbers the whites four to one, shows that each year more of the blacks are drawn into contact with the white men and that dire consequences follow to tribal culture.

Popular indignation against "Fascist pirates" was redoubled today by the sinking of the Blagoef by a submarine officially described here as "under Franco's flag." The greater parts of the front pages of all newspapers today were devoted to reports of protest meetings and resolutions throughout the country.
A miniature automobile show will be held Oct. 5 to 12 on the mezzanine floor of the International Building, Rockefeller Center, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Robert Gilmour Swan, the director.

Defying State decrees and repressional measures enacted since the beginning of the year, leaders of the Protestant Confessional Church will go before their congregations tomorrow with a ringing appeal to resist to the uttermost the State's ever-expanding efforts to dominate the church and silence its voice.
A man who informed his wife that he was going fishing, but went to a party instead, gave the Conservation Division a problem today.
The White Sox sliced a game off the Tigers' second-place lead in the American League today, pounding Tommy Bridges and Slicker Coffman for sixteen hits and a 9-to-1 victory.

In line with their desire that the World's Fair represent the "World of Tomorrow" the fair board yesterday announced that the buildings already rising on the Flushing Meadows for the exhibition of 1939 were being designed and decorated by the architects, sculptors and mural painters of tomorrow."

Candidates for the Columbia varsity football team will begin practice at Baker Field on Friday. Coach Lou Little has asked thirtynine men to report on Wednesday and Thursday for routine physical examinations.

Current problems affecting real estate will be discussed Sept. 15 at a one-day conference of the Long Island Real Estate Board in the Garden City Hotel. The committee appointed by Governor Lehman to study the mortgage moratorium and deficiency judgment laws will hold a public hearing in connection with the conference.

Miss Josephine McDuffee and Lindely Bynum, of the staff of Huntington Library here, were married today. The bride became an authority on the Sierra Nevada Mountains and Western Indian ceremonials after graduating from the University of California.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Morton Chase of Beaufort, S. C., have announced the marriage of Mrs. Chase's daughter, Miss Mary Abercrombie Lengnick, to Robert Yates Phillips, son of Mrs. Osmund Phillips of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Phillips. The ceremony was performed yesterday morning in the Lutheran Church of the Redeemer, Brooklyn, by the Rev. Ralph Larson. Only relatives were present.
Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Francis D. McCann of Brooklyn of the engagement of Mr. McCann's sister, Miss Rita McCann of this place, to Ludwell A. Larzelere Jr. of Detroit, Mich.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Arthur Krock, according to your issue of Aug. 31, stated at the Williamstown Conference of the Institute of Human Relations, as follows:

The question is so vast and so complex and so many individual opinions have been expressed by the members of the commission that they cannot all be summarized in a necessarily brief report. To learn these opinions in detail it is necessary to refer to the minutes of the commission's proceedings, communicated to the Council together with this report.

The Northwest Territory Celebration Commission is ready to receive applications from men who wish to participate in a historic caravan that will leave Ipswich, Mass., Dec. 3, to re-enact the trek westward of the original settlers of the Northwest Territory.

PEOPLE interested in trends might have captured one in these pages last Sunday. In the "Gossip of the Rialto" the Theatre Union announced that it had decided to conclude its affairs. In an adjoining column Orson Welles and John Houseman drew up their prospectus for the Mercury Theatre which they intend to open in November.

Secretary Morgenthau, who returned yesterday from a vacation in Hawaii, conferred today with the executive committee of the Federal Reserve Board Open Market Committee and with other Federal Reserve officials preparatory to an announcement on Tuesday morning of the Treasury's plans for financing.
The recent operations of mysterious submarines in the Mediterranean represent the first effective use-and by far the most serious use-of sea power during the Spanish civil war.

Admiral Billard Academy, naval preparatory school, which had its main building gutted by fire at Easter vacation has completed an entirely new and modern building this week. The damaged upper story of the original building has been rebuilt.

The Indians sloshed through rain and mad today to take the opener of a double-beader with the Browns, 5 to 1, and with the score tied, 3 to 3, to 3, the scored game was called at the end of the sixth loning because of darkness.

A rush for entry blanks in the Freeport (L. I.) Chamber of Commerce prize contest which closes at midnight, Sept. 15, was reported yesterday by Milton Danziger, chairman of the chamber's contest committee. The contest consists of writing the best letter of not more than 250 words on the subject, "Freeport as an Ideal Home Community."
A great central library building, differing in nearly every respect from the old familiar New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue, will be started in a few weeks on Grand Army Plaza, Brooklyn.

Maternal deaths in the United States in the decade 1926-35 more than equaled the population of Albany, Miami or Norfolk, and infant deaths in the same period more than equaled the population of Los Angeles, Miss Katherine Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau,
Travel agents at this port report an unprecedented demand for space in the combination freight and passenger carriers in the West Coast to Europe trades, via both Africa and the Suez.

The Dodgers, who seem to catch most everything these days, either on a line or on the first bounce, caught Carl Hubbell at his very best yesterday at the Polo Grounds and the result was a crushing silence that enveloped the entire Flatbush cast on the bench and that portion of it which helped swell the crowd in the stands to 14,000.

The marriage of Miss Evelyn Mae Cross, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David McClenahan Cross of this city, to Valentine Payne Rader, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin F. V. Rader of Fleetwood, N. Y., will take place next Saturday in the North Presbyterian Church, West 155th Street. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Dr. Merlp H. Anderson.

Four hundred delegates were arriving today for the tenth International Congress of the Anti-Tuberculosis Association which will be held here beginning tomorrow. Delegates represented all nations of the world, with Nationalist Spain sending thirty, the largest delegation.

THIS is a war diary. It is the diary and recollections of a British private;s front-line service for five months in 1917. He was in the Ypres salient. He was 16 years old. The book is dedicated to "the volunteers under military age of all the belligerent countries" who served in 1914-1918, and at first galance it is this boy's extreme youth that strikes the reader bardest.
Golfers from New York, New Jersey and Canada moved into the semi-finals of the annual men's international invitation tournament today after winning hard-fought second-round matches.

Among the features of Hampshire House, the new thirty-seven-story apartment hotel on Central Park South, which will open early, in October, will be a glass wall to separate the main dining room from a garden restaurant. The wall, measuring 27 1/2 by 13 1/2 feet, comprises the entire western end of the main restaurant.

An educational policy board, headed by a chancellor, to integrate the cultural program of the four city colleges without robbing them of their individual identities was proposed yesterday by Maurice Deiches, member of the Board of Higher Education.

Preparations to house and feed 300,000 National Socialists and visitors attending the party congress here next week have now been completed. Statistics show that 3,300,000 food rations will be distributed during the meeting. Some will be served on special trains and others distribute from field kitchens.

Alarmed over "popular misrepresentations of social security and similar protective legislation," Dr. Henry E. Hoagland, a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, issued today a call for individuals to save their own money.

Panama has 114 merchant ships with a net tonnage of 306,687 and a gross tonnage of 532,576, according to figures from A. R. Randolph, -Assistant American Trade Commissioner, Panama City. Since Jan. 1 twenty-three ships registered, bringing into the Panama treasury $53,500 in fees and $22,556 in taxes.

Miss Ruth Ethelwyn Soden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Soden of this city, was married today in St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church here to the Rev. Archibald Basil Smith of Hope, N. D., son of the Rev. and Mrs. Archibald N. Smith of Pearl River, N. Y.

Twelve Scandinavian freight ships have "beached" their Unionized crews in New York in the last five months and signed on "cheap labor" imported from abroad, it was charged yesterday by Gustav Alexander of the National Committee of Scandinavian Seamen's Clubs,

REMINDER: Forty years ago the Swedish explorer, Major Salomon August Andree sought to fly over the North Pole in a balloon. On his way he dropped several buoys recording the flight. Ultimately the expedition was forced to land on an Arctic island, and there, in 1930, the remains of the explorers were found.

The Bethlehem Steel Company alleged today that the National Labor Relationa Board had made "vague and indefinite statements," called a hearing over the Labor Day weekend with short notice and unreasonably demanded a mass of data which would need a week to compile.
THE title is somewhat ambigous, "Design," as the word is used here, means rhythm and order in life itself, not visual pattenr.

THEY have the heavyweight program straightened out at long last, as the Duke of Windsor would put it. Herr Max Schmeling is to get a chance to regain the heavyweight championship and Shufflin' Joe Louis is to get that return bout with Schmeling of which he has been mumbling for some time.

Difficulties in learning to read, which today plague hundreds of thousands of children, are due to muscular lesions of the brain and have no necessary connection with general intelligence, research workers at the Psychiatric Division of Bellevue Hospital announced yesterday.

International Field at the Meadow Brook Club will be the gathering place for members of society from the North and South shores of Long Island on Saturday, when the national open polo championships start.

Railroad employes who grow flowers as a hobby are being invited to send exhibits to the second annual Fall Flower, Show of the Pennsylvania Railroad, Sept. 18 and 19, in the new Thirtieth Street passenger station in Philadelphia. Pennsylvania Horticultural Society and Pennsylvania Garden Club Federation will act with the railroad as joint sponsors. Besides railroaders, competitors for prizes will include garden clubs, civic associations, seed houses and commercial growers.

RICHMOND, RICHMOND, in Virginia, named, some say, on account of a fancied likeness of the site to that of Richmond on the Thames, is a city that climbs steeply up from the Falls of the James River to the overlooking hills and from their crests spreads out in leafy avenues.

VENEZUELA recently issued new postage and air-mail values. In the postage set the 5 centimos (purple), 25c (red) and 5 bolivars (brown) picture a nurse holding a child. The 50c (olivegreen) and 3b (carmine) show oxen.

Miss Eleanor West Watson, daughter of Mrs. Hugh Smith Watson of this place and the late Mr. Watson, was married today to Donald Archer Holden, also of Newport News, son of Mr. and Mrs. Archer Harvey Holden of Cambridge, Mass.

The real estate holdings of the closed First National Bank and Trust Company of Yonkers will be sold at auction by order of Arthur E. Muth, receiver, on Sept. 18 and 25 in the State Armory, 127 North Broadway, Yonkers, it was announced yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Betty Devine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Devine of Pelham, N. Y., to George Byron Smith 2d of New York took place here yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. John Howie Wright, 10 East Seventy-seventh Street.

Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Roger Cambon, counselor of the French Embassy, spent some busy hours over the telephone with Paris today in an effort to hammer out some scheme to combat the menace of attacks by airmen and "pirate submarines" on neutral shipping that would stand a chance of acceptance by a conference of Mediterranean powers which Britain and France hope to call next week-end.

The advance guard of the nineteenth annual national 'convention of the American Legion is arriving in New York City over the Labor Day week-end. The convention will open on Sept. 20 and will last for five days.

PIERRE, S. D.--The Sioux Indians, apparently influenced by the unrest elsewhere in the United States, are threatening to stage a "walkout" of a sort unless certain of their demands are met by Uncle Sam.

The Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club had plenty of activity around Center Island today, for in addition to its six-meter race for the Scandinavian Gold Cup and the Long Island Yacht Racing Association championship regatta, it ran its eighteenth annual Stratford shoal race, a drag of approximately fifty miles around Stratford Shoal light and return.

Henry N. Wightman of Montclair, representing the University of Michigan Glider Club, opened his defense of the New Jersey gliding title on Schley Field here today by breaking the record in the duration contest for utility gliders.

OUT on the edge of the New Mexico desert, fifteen miles from the nearest town, stands a lone, tapering framework tower. From it, with a loild, steady roar and a continuous belch of white-hot flame, rises a long, streamlined metal rocket; Leaving a trail of smoke in its swift vertical wake, it goes up until it is lost to sight, and then floats back to earth under a parachute.

Following in the footsteps of the faculty of medicine, Montreal University's faculty of sciences announced yesterday that it had decided to refuse registration of students unless the university's administrative committee made settlement of all salary arrears and

Miss Elroy Bradford, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Earl Bradford of New Rochelle and niece of Mrs. Frederic McLaughlin (Irene Castle), was married here yesterday afternoon in the chancel of Grace Church to Donald Joseph Setter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Setter of Buffalo.

Federal Circuit Judge John Biggs Jr. refused today to halt a National Labor Board employee election at the plant in Ambridge. Pa., of the National Electric Products Company which recently signed a collective bargaining agreement with an American Federation of Labor union.
Discovery of iron, sulphur and copper deposits on Baffin Land and the eastern shore of Northern Labrador, hitherto considered barren Arctic waste, is reported by Professor Martin J. Buerger.
Seth T. Cole, retired counsel to the State Department of Taxation, was retained today by New York State to press its fight for taxes due from the estate of Colonel Edward H. R. Green.
The woes of Fall movers in Brooklyn were increased yesterday by a strike of 900 moving van drivers and helpers. Most van owners,

Miss Katherine Rawls of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., successfully defended her American 300-meter medley crown today for the sixth consecutive time when she scored an easy victory in the women's national senior A. A. U. swimming championships.

Engagement of $6,305,000 gold abroad for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of this amount $5,800,000 was engaged in Japan, $224,000 in England and $281,000 in India.

Two occupants of a small cabin plane were killed when the craft nose-dived into a house near Minneapolis today. The dead are Glen Chase of Minneapolis and Miss Harriet Frost of Robbinsdale, who was taking flying lessons from him.

Otis Walding, 38-year-old Los Angeles dry cleaning plant operator who competed against the advice of his physician, today won the premier title of American skeet shootingthe 250-target all-gauge championship.
EXPRESSIVE: The Veterans of Foreign Wars, meeting in Buffalo last week, listened to a speech by Mayor La Guardia.

General Water, Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries-Twelve months to June 30: Net income after interest, depreciation, taxes, and other charges, $504,431, comparing with $375,075 in preceding twelve months. Six months to June 30:

Maybe we should never have brought up this matter of the worm--versus the fly-fisherman: there are too many arguments on both sides. The percentage of true sportsmen is as high on one side as it is on the other, but the weight of numbers favors the worm advocate.
A "Boston tea party" marked by the pomp and splendor of a royal court rather than the Indian feathers and grim determination of the historic "party" in 1775, will be held here Tuesday.

The Governors of four New England States, Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont and Massachusetts, have been granted a petition to intervene in the proceedings now pending before the Interstate Commerce Commission for the reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, which now is in receivership under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

Mr. and Mrs. George Roberts of New York have Mrs. G. B. Middleton of Florence, Italy, as their guest at their cottage. Henry L. deForest, president of Ausable Club and Mrs. deForest have arrived from Plainfield, N. J. They occupy Heboma cottage.

A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board ruled today that the Fansteel Metallurgical Corporation of North Chicago was guilty of "unfair labor practices." He recommended that the company reinstate employes evicted with tear gas in a sit-down strike in February.

Now and then something happens to make us realize how sick and tired the Spaniards are of their civil war. The apparent joy with which the inhabitants of Santander greeted Generalissimo Francisco Franco's troops last week was one of those incidents.

Miss Mary Draper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Draper of this city and Norfolk, Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church to Dr. Gilbert F. Boeker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Boeker of New York.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Burrell Shaw, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Larned Keith Shaw of this city and Guilderland, to Archibald Carr, son of Mrs. Archibald Hamilton Carr and the late Mr. Carr of Derramore Park, Belfast, Ireland, took place this afternoon in the Hamilton Presbyterian Church at Guilderland.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary, Ralston Anderberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Anderberg of this place, to Richard Pinkerton Heppner, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Heppner, also of White Plains.

Controversies arising in the liquor industry as a result of the State Liquor Authority's order limiting credit terms to retailers and wholesales to twenty-one days revived the demand last week for a trade committee to consult with the Liquor Authority on its rulings.
SEPTEMBER and October promise to bring two of radio's Sunday evening symphonic hours back to the air under the sponsorship of motor cars. Both will present noted instrumental and vocal soloists.

ATKINS--Mr. and Mrs. Sol Atkins (nee Ruth Levine) wish to announce the birth of a daughter on Sept. 3 at Sydenham Hospital. BARATZ-Mr. and Mrs. Max Baratz announce the birth of a son at Hunts Point Hospital.

Check clearings for the Poughkeepsie Clearing House Association for the week ended on Sept. 1 were S2,869,754, compared with $2,964,989 in the preceding week and with $2,744,867 for the corresponding week last year.

Dr. David A. De Vanny of 75 West Beach Street, Long Beach, former medical director of the BrooklynManhattan Transit Company, died here last night in the Farmingdale Sanitarium after a three-month illness at the age of 56.
A reshuffling of American foreign trade involving millions of dollars' worth of both exports and imports appeared certain here yesterday as a result of the Sino-Japanese war.
MANY airports are now crowded, not only on the ground but also in the air. The development of a Flight Strip program is aimed to give more ground space where there is more air space.

An analysis of the combination of loans and subsidies for cotton produced in the United States this pear, announced last week by the Commodity Credit Corporation and the Department of Agriculture, shows that it is designed to interfere as little as possible with the normal marketing of the crop.

American citizens of German birth, as well as all other naturalized American citizens, are expected as a matter of course to give their full allegiance to the United States, Secretary of State Cordell Hull declared today in response to a question as to the Administration's attitude toward recent German declarations regarding the alleged duties of Germans living abroad.

The American Federation of Labor's fight to purge itself of Committee for Industrial Organization affiliates continued in the executive council meeting just closed, with the revocation of the charter held by the West Virginia Federation of Labor, which had refused to oust C. I. O.

The Arts Theatre Club will open its season next .Sunday with "Van Gogh," a play by Dan Burke on the life of the painter. The artist will be played by Esmond Knight, and Dorothy Black is cast as a model who sat for Van Gogh's picture "Sorrow."
Industrial employment this Summer moved above normal and toward the peak of 1929, but Government analysts will not say the nation's unemployment problem has been reduced in the same proportion.

The marriage of Miss Anne V. Fowler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Fowler of this city, to Roger F. P. McMahon, son of Dr. and Mrs. John J. McMahon, also of New York, took place yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

IN the fragrant meadows and up land farm country of New York State big "sucker" dredges and dragline machines are moiling away at a $27,000,000 job that is bound to attract the interest of salt water yachtsmen.
S there anybody, old or young, who does not enjoy a spirited animal story that is well told? And the test is the author's knowledge of the habits and psychology of the animal he writes about.
Dr. FredericK W. Derby, ophthalmologist and director of the eye department of the Boston health units for twelve years, died today at his home here. He was 62 years old.
HE happy hunting ground of films that are gone but not forgotten has been located. Pictures of a decade or more ago that are still remembered are yet available in the last stand of the single bill.

Miss Mary Kemp Blagden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus Silliman Blagden of Ambler, Pa., formerly of Greenwich, Conn., was married to the Rev. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Barksdale Kinsolving of Baltimore, in the Chapel of the Ascension here, this afternoon.

Dr. Thomas G. Masaryk, former President of Czechoslovakia, was further improved today and according to his physicians he now has considerable chance of passing through the illness without serious consequences.

The Ludwig Baumann nine, winner of the city crown for the past two years, bowed to the Hotel New Yorker in the final of the open division of the New York City Baseball Federation's annual amateur tournament at Ebbets Field yesterday. The score was 12 to 3.

The DiMaggio - Crosetti - Lazzeri combination on the Yankees seems destined to lose its oldest member after this year. Beating the critics to the punch, Tony Lazzeri today announced his intention of retiring from baseball after this season unless he can get a major league job as pilot, preferably in the American League.

Some 250,000,000 light-years-that is the distance -to which space has been plumbed. The huge mirror of 200 inches diameter, now being ground at the California Institute of Technology at Pasadena, Calif.,

With its theme given as "Distribution Costs-Prices-Manpower," the detailed program of the Boston Conference on Distribution to be held Sept. 20 and 21 in the Hotel Statler of that city was announced yesterday. A highlight of the luncheon on the first day of the conference will be an address on "International Trade Pacts" by Secretary of State Hull.
Japan's punitive expedition in China has become financially a first-class war. A special session of the Diet today voted for the biggest war budget in Japan's history.

The marriage of Miss Lilla Price Renshaw of Montecito and New York to Phelps Stokes Hunter of San Francisco, grandson of the late Mr. and Mrs. Anson Phelps Stokes of. New York, took place this afternoon in the Montecito Vallev Club.

Miss Lucinda Lee Kinsolving, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Kinsolving of this city, has set Nov. 6 as the date for her marriage to Egbert Giles Leigh 3d, son of Mrs. Egbert G. Leigh Jr. and the late Mr. Leigh of Richmond and Orange, Va.

Followers of the Yale football team believe that Head Coach Raymond (Ducky) Pond and his associates, Earle Neale, Marshall Wells, Ivy Williamson, Bill Renner and Gerry Ford, will turn out for the 1937 season a playing combination equal to the team of a year ago.

Miss Suzanne Louise Warriner, daughter of Mrs. Ruel C. Warriner of Glen Ridge, N. J., was married here this afternoon in St. Paul's Church to Theodore Monell Jr., son of Mrs. Elinor Haight-Brush of New York and of Colonel Theodore Monell of Southampton, L. I.

Germany's drastic campaign against waste was emphasized today when police jailed a farmer for failure to harvest his wheat and rye crops. The arrest of Fritz Langrock and the placing of a government inspector in charge of his 214-acre farm near Weissenfels pointed to the seriousness of the warning of Col. Gen. Hermann Wilhelm Goering,

AN exhibition of paintings by Waldo Peirce has opened at the Midtown Galleries and will be current there through Sept. 18. The same group of pictures (twentyseven oils and eight water-colors) was shown this Summer at the Addison Gallery, Andover;
He Did, Gean Canach and Yemasee were the stake winners at Aqueduct, where 15,000 persons watched seven races on the first Saturday of the Queens County Jockey Club's Fall meeting yesterday.

Ontario's gold mines set a new high monthly production peak in July, when bullion produced was valued at $7,530,394, compared with $7,404,834 in the previous month. Production for the first seven months of the year amounted to $50,554,623, compared with $45,911,114 in the corresponding period of 1936.
Lieut. Col. Masao Hideshima and four other Japanese aviators died in action today following a forced landing about nineteen miles west of Changpei, Chahar Province, China.

Implying a rebuke to President Roosevelt for his "fine impartiality" in the steel strike, and forecasting a possible attempt to put a new FarmerLabor party into the field of national politics, Mr. John L. Lewis used most of his radio time on Friday evening to herald the gains which C. I. O. has achieved and to denounce the opposition with which it has met.

A group of Green Bay residents were discussing the 80-degree heat here yesterday when their conversation was interrupted by the arrival of Ray Rassmussen, 33 years old. Mr. Rassmussen's head was swathed in bandages.

Dr. Walter Jarvis Barlow, former vice president of the American Medical Association and one-time Dean of the University of California Medical College, died yesterday at his home here of bronchial pneumonia. His age was 69.

Buses will start running Sept. 8 on Northern Boulevard, Queens, and this will be the signal for removal of the old car tracks, which will be ripped up partly with WPA funds and partly with an appropriation by the city. Repaving will be started after removal of the tracks and is expected to be completed in the Spring.

CURRENT announcements by the publishers of the British and American standard stamp catalogues convey to the philatelic world the news that certain types of so-called postal paper which some foreign governments are endeavoring to foist on collectors will be denied recognition in the 1938 editions and may never be chronicled at all.

Hesitancy in advance buying which has developed in the last two months, as distributors at first feared and later found public resistance to higher prices caused by increased cost for raw materials and labor, has forced many industrial companies to formulate plans for extensive rehabilitation of plant facilities in order to increase opereating efficiency, it was reported here yesterday.
Little interest in grains was shown today in North American markets, traders being disposed to even-up commitments rather than expand operations, in view of the double holiday ahead.

FREDERIC PROKOSCH, whose recently published "The Seven Who Fled" won the Harper Prize Novel Contest, was born in Madison, Wis., twenty-eight years ago, the son of Edard Prokosch, who is at present Sterling Professor of Linguistics at Yale University. His first book,

AARONSON--Mr. and Mrs. Harry, wish their friends and relatives a very happy New Year. AJAX FURNITURE COMPANY. 40 East 30th St., wishes to extend greetings and best wishes for a happy and prosperous New Year to all its patrons and dealers. CHARLES DIAMOND. President.
IF the term "horse and buggy age" has suffered odium of late, Edwin Valentine Mitchell has gloriously rescued it, at least for New England. But interest in these artless,

GOTTLIEEB-Simon and Ruby Pinkus Gottlieb of 83-20 St. James Ave., Elmhurst, L. I., happily announce the bar mitzvah of their son, Stanley Jerome, Saturday, Sept. 11, at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83d St., New York. Reception Castleholm, 344 West 57th St., Saturday, after 8:30 P. M. No cards.

The British Association for the Advancement of Science is in session at Nottingham. Of course, I regard this as an important event. I shook the economic section to its foundations fifty years ago with a Fabian essay.
Thomas R. Kemper, Virginia's first Bertillon expert, died today at a hospital here after a brief illness. He was 88 years old.

The dollar continued bid in the foreign exchange market here today, but after fluctuating between $4.95 3/4 and $4.96 to the pound, closed unchanged at $4.95 7/8. Spot francs were steady at 13231-32 to the pound although weakness in the forward position was shown by the three-month discount widening sharply from 3 13-16 to 4 1/8 francs.
With the recent passage of the "Matrimonial Causes Bill" which liberalizes divorce in England attention has been directed to the divorce question there and in other countries.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Guthrie Hill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Hamilton Hill of this place and Elmira, to John Meredith Graham Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Graham of Hillcrest, Rome, Ga., took place here this afternoon in the gardens of The Gateway, the Summer home of the bride's parents.

No street or building in the International Settlement and French Concession is safe from rifle fire, machine gun bullets and bursting shrapnel, so the United States, British and French Consuls General asked the Chinese and Japanese today to withdraw to lessen the danger to millions of Chinese and thousands of foreigners.
Foreign military observers today attributed to a German military mission a large share of the credit for China's thus far firm resistance to Japan in the present conflict.
Featuring a slow mile victory by Glenn Cunningham and a sprint double scored by Eddie O'Sullivan, United States entrants took major honors today in the Canadian National Exhibition track meet.

Francis Wright Fabyan, former president of the Algonquin Club, prominent Boston business man and trustee of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died this morning at his Summer home on Buttermilk Bay at the age of 66.

A "war bonus" demand by the crew of the Orient-bound Dollar liner President Wilson held up the ship's departure for several hours today, but the employers finally announced a settlement and the vessel sailed at 6:40 P. M. [10:40 P. M. New York daylight time].

UNDER a project fostered by the Governor's Highway Safe ty Council in Pennsylvania a test highway will be the subject of scrutiny by every agency of the State Government concerned with safety, the Keystone Automobile Club reports.

Armed with a force of State police and backed by the Governor and a court ruling, the Rhode Island Racing Commission tonight held it had successfully removed Walter E. O'Hara, publisher and track owner, as managing director of his milliondollar Narragansett Park.

Details of a harrowing trip through Arctic waters never before navigated by white men were told here today by Lorenzo Learmonth, Hudson's Bay Company agent, who made contact with the Nascopie yesterday.

Miss Marianne Steene of 144 East Fortieth Street, New York, a member of the Studio of Acting- here, today received the Percy Hammond Medal from Grantland Rice, for many years a friend and neighbor here of the late dramatic critic.

Through depressions and wars the business of patching Bibles holds steady, Arthur Eggeling, who has been rebinding books for nearly forty years, remarked yesterday. No sudden dips mark the business charts, he said as he surveyed a stack of Bibles in his workshop at 55 East Eleventh Street.
Baroness Ottily de Ropp, exiled Russian noblewoman, died at her Glendale home today following a stroke suffered last Monday.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harold William Paine of this place and Upper Montclair, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cecile Beatrice Paine, to John Donovan Simmons of Canton.

Governor Clyde Hoey, who as an an attorney assisted in the prosecution of Fred Erwin Beal, asserted today that he would issue extradition papers to bring the Communist leader of the 1929 Gastonia textile strike back to North Carolina to serve a seventeen to twenty year prison term.

Miriam Hopkins of the stage and screen, and Anatole Litvak, her film director, were married here tonight by Justice of the Peace Ed Winn about forty-five minutes after their arrival by special plane from Hollywood.

Man Seized Here as Vagrant Not Linked to Woman's Murder Irving Halper, 43 years old, of 161 West Seventy-second Street, was cleared of suspicion yesterday in the death of Mrs. Esther Gordon of Revere, Mass., who was found murdered in Queens on Aug. 27.

PARIS. A VISIT to the Sainte Chapelle, always a rewarding Paris experience, becomes doubly significant when to the spectacle of sunlight pouring through the incomparable walls of stained glass is added the delight of listening to music such as that which was played there recently by the Cantoria.
Inclusion of the public utility companies in efforts to reduce the period on credit purchases of home electrical appliances was forecast here yesterday.

To the Art Editor: IT seems that the pro-abstrac tionism artists and critics justify their contention (when they attempt justification) by stressing the analogy between their medium of expression and the medium of music.

European Governments now have two wars to watch and to localize, one in Asia and one in Europe, and their fleets must strive against heavy odds to protect lives and property against bombs and torpedoes throughout the Mediterranean and in the still vaster coastal waters of China.

Professor J. E. Duerden, noted authority on wool, died here today of injuries received in a fall. He was 72 years old. Professor Duerden, who was an honorary fellow in zoology at the University of Leeds, had been attending the meetings of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.
BAR HARBOR, Me.--A full schedule of events is on the Labor Day program of Mount Desert Island and the resort centers, Northeast Harbor, Seal Harbor and Southwest Harbor.
Federal aid to supplement State funds has been offered to Minnesota, Wisconsin and North Dakota under the Wild Life Restoration Act, which President Roosevelt has signed.

With the best army riders in North America and Europe as well as. the leading men and women civilians in this country being brought together, twenty-one military and open-jumping contests will feature the 119 competitive tests in the prize list for the 1937 National Horse Show, which will be held at Madison Square Garden, Nov. 3 to 10.
Drought returned to the far western end of the Corn Belt during August and destroyed not less, probably more, than one hundred million bushels of promising corn.

Abandonment of the "archaic and unfair" system of assessments for local improvements, levied directly against separate pieces of property, was urged yesterday by Frank J. Taylor, Controller. Characterizing the system as "vicious" and without scientific or equitable foundation, he advocated the substitution of a system to absorb the burden of such assessments into the borough tax rates.

With ninety manufacturers now having fair trade contracts effective in this State under the terms of the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act and also the enabling MillerTydings bill, the New York Pharmaceutical Association, through its fair trade committee, plans to police the enforcement of the act through paid shoppers who will check on violations.
MANCHESTER, Vt. BY Labor Day the Summer season of our Eastern art colonies may be written off as finished or designated as in the concluding - stages.

After two sons and a daughter of Peter Di Pasquale refused to join the C. I. O., the family home in Berwick was bombed today. The bomb, apparently thrown from an automobile, landed on the front porch and caused extensive damage, but the family escaped injury.

Dr. Walter S. Harban, 80-year-old former personal dentist to President Theodore Roosevelt, was married today to Miss Caroline Robinson Hughes, 36. The ceremony was performed by Bishop Edwin Holt Hughes, the bride's father, who is resident Bishop of the Washington area of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

Miss Doris Quick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Quick of Westfield, was married to Edward P. Fleuren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Fleuren, also of this place, this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church.

Commonwealth statisticians' analysis of the trade between Great Britain and Australia discloses that as a result of the trade diversion policy imports of British cotton piece goods for the year ended June 30 amounted to [pound]4,242,000,

The recent Pan-American educational conference at Mexico City, sponsored by the Pan American Union, is called a Marxist manoeuvre, cleverly directed by revolutionary Mexico, by El Criterio of San Salvador.
A record total of 134 boats sailed today in the first session of the annual three-day Labor Day week-end invitation regatta of the Bellport Bay Yacht Club.

For the first time since the World War official Budapest has acknowledged the Little Entente's good-will in Hungarian matters by expressing a readiness for a round-table conference with members of the Entente without raising territorial claims.

The reigning favorite of small garden pools is still the water lily, and, while one never wearies of it, there is another water plant that might well be considered-the East Indian or Rose Lotus, Nelumbo nucifera. Many persons have been fortunate enough to see it in bloom in the late Summer at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.
Japan today extended her naval blockade of the Chinese coast to include new waters through which Chinese shipping is forbidden to ply.

To almost anybody soon or late in this Northern clime may come the urge to raise avocados (alligator pears) in his house, conservatory or yard. Many people in fact are so tempted, for the New York Botanical Garden and Museum in Bronx Park is besieged for information on local avocado culture.

Members of the American Chemical Society will begin assembling here tomorrow for their annual meeting, beginning Monday and continuing until Saturday. Most of the sessions will be group symposia at which hundreds of papers will be read on research activity and discoveries in this science which touches practically every phase of life.

Although the Third Reich has no overseas possessions, the Nazi scheme of things makes provision for a foreign province, or Gau. In this realm are organized German citizens living abroad. The organization's headquarters are in Berlin;

Civil War soldiers assembled with five affiliated groups today for the seventy-first national encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic. Of the many thousands who fought to save the Union in the war of 1861-65 less than one full company had registered today for the meetings beginning tomorrow and ending Friday.

A bargain in plants is a bargain only if one gets quality varieties. Especially is this true with iris. "Rare Value! 25 roots, our selection, for $1!" may not be a value at all. It depends upon what varieties make up the twenty-five.
Scott P. Squyers, newly elected head of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, said today that three principal objectives would be the aim of his administration during the coming year. These were:

The flags of four nations-Italy's, the tri-color of France, the British ensign and the Stars and Stripes-whipped straight out today in a fresh nor'wester from staffs on the Detroit Y. C. to signify that for the first time in its thirty-four years' history America's premier speed boat trophy, the Gold Cup, would be raced for Monday by foreigners as well as the home-breds.

To the accompaniment of renewed bloodshed in Palestine and the incessant discussion by Moslems and Jews throughout the world, the proposed partition of Palestine moves forward toward ultimate enactment in one form or another.

Housewives who have been complaining about the high cost of meat had the word of Government experts today that prices had reached a peak and that declines would follow soon. Charts on retail meat prices at the Bureau of Agricultural Economics showed they held had touched seven-year highs recently-especially for steaks and pork chops.
The square-rigged ships Joseph Conrad and Seven Seas apparently are having a drifting match in their race from Newport, R. I., to Bermuda.

THE Society of American Etchers, of which John Taylor Arms is president, will hold its annual exhibition in the top-floor galleries of the Maison Francaise, along with the National Exhibition of Contemporary Swedish Prints-the Swedish section of the International Exchange Exhibition of Prints sponsored by the society in cooperation with the Swedish National Fine Arts Association of Stockholm.

WASHINGTON. -- Although the per capital quota of rats has been halved in our larger cities during the past twenty years, in small towns and on farms there still are as many rats as there are human beings, the Department of Agriculture reveals in a recent circular, "The House Rat."
The Bees made it two straight over Philadelphia today with an 8-to-6 victory earned on a four-run rally in the eighth. Lamaster and Johnson were routed and Mulcahy pitched the ninth for the Phils.

Bayside (71)-Semi-final round for Lanzner Cup: Dr. C. Cohen defeated V. Celano, 4 and 3: A. Cunningham defeated T. P. McGirr, 1 up. Brookville (72)-First round for club championship. second flight: S. Mott defeated D. Coughlin. 1 up (19 holes). Third flight: R. McNaughton defeated H. Switzer, 2 up (36-hole match).

The National Labor Relations Board served a complaint on the Ford Motor Company today charging intimidation of employes at the Somerville plant in their attempt to organize, and alleging that representatives had been threatened with bodily injury if they sought to pass out handbills.

The seventeenth annual reunion of the Society of the Fifth Division, a nationwide organization of A. E. F. veterans, opened yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker with 250 members present. The New York camp of the society, with headquarters in the Hotel Lafayette, is host.

Miss Anne Marie Causey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Beverley Douglas Causey of St. Augustine, Fla., was married to Max Abramovitz of New York this afternoon at Elsing Green, Summer home of her parents, in King William Colinty, nearhere, by the Rev. Dr. Oscar De. Wolf Randolph of Lynchburg.

A total of $113,123,600 was loaned to some 48,600 home owners during July by the savings, building and loan associations throughout the country, according to the United States Building and Loan League.

Edgar Chiott, keeper of the lights on the Burlington harbor breakwater for thirty years, retired Aug. 31 from the service at the age of 65. He has been succeeded by Rolla W. Hill, 45, of this city, who has been a boatman on Lake Champlain more than twenty-five years.

IN Poland's program of national rebuilding the cosmopolitan orientation of the men and women who brought Poland back to Statehood is being abandoned and an intensely national orientation is being encouraged. "Study thyself" is the slogan given the nation, examine Polish corporate life, of yesterday as of today, look in it for the elemefits that are essentially Polish, cherish them and build upon them the new national structure.

Veto of the McManus bill establishing a five-day week for 65,000 city employes at an estimated annual cost of $6,000,000 has been asked of Mayor La Guardia in a letter from Richard C. Patterson Jr., chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission.

Mrs. Charles Astor Bristed has returned to 14 East Sixtieth Street. Mr. and Mrs. Earl E. T. Smith, who returned on the Bremen, are at the Pierre. Rear Admiral Robert WitthoeftEmden, naval attache of the German Embassy at Washington, is at the Ambassador.

The list of the Holland-America liner Statendam, due to arrive today from- the Channel ports, includes General and Mrs. Robert C. Davis, Miss Peggy Ann Landon, daughter of former Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas; Mrs. Meyer Davis and Miss Virginia Davis. The North German Lloyd liner Breman sailed last night for the Channel ports with 675 passengers, of whom 355 were in the cabin class.

Flames visible as far as Coney Island, Sandy Hook and lower Brooklyn destroyed 300 bathhouses, the Harris Bathing Pavilion and a frame structure formerly used as a hotel at South Beach, Staten Island, shortly after 11 o'clock last night. For a time the fire,

Miss Algenia Fowler Warner, daughter of Mrs. John Irving Warner, was married here this afternoon at the home of her mother to Cornelius Mooney Milmoe, son of Mrs. Patrick Francis Milmoe, also of Canastota.

Mr. and Mrs. Allison E. Woolsey of Jackson Heights have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Marie Woolsey, to Charles Ruthven Denny 3d, son of Charles R. Denny 2d of Washington, D. C., and the late Mrs. Denny.

AN increasing number of "previews" staged by motor car companiese to show their new cars to members of the press indicate that the 1938 automobile season is near at hand. Studebaker started the previews with a party for automobile editors at South Bend, Ind., and Hupmobile joined the procession the past week. Many other previews are scheduled for the next few weeks.

Germany's military and economic reconstruction carried the National Socialist regime and its totalitarian State to the peak of power and prestige and thereby gave a boost to the national morale with which all European statesmen must reckon.

Dr. Ned H. Dearborn, dean of the New York University Division of General Education, declared yesterday that three factors were largely responsible for the rapidly growing adult educate movement in the United States.

When this is read in the United States the cohorts of National Socialism will be swarming to Nuremberg to answer the party's ninth annual roll-call. The summons has gone out, the program for a week's sessions has been drawn up and all is ready.

Governor William Langer issued a proclamation today designed to prevent seizure of this year's crops to satisfy creditors. His moratorium, he said, would apply in all cases "where after deducting the cost of threshing and labor there shall remain not more than enough to sustain the grower and his family on a standard of living which will preserve their health."

Federal contracts for supplies of a value of $5,216,458 were awarded under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Sept. 2, the Department of Labor announced today. Eleven agencies made ninety-five contracts.

Miss Harriett Jackson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Jackson of Providence, R. I., and New York, who are passing the Summer at Northeast Harbor, gave one of the largest parties of the evening at the final dinner dance of the Bar Harbor Club, which was held there this evening.

Signing of the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill by President Roosevelt is expected to mark the beginning of a new era of slum clearance and low-cost housing in this country. Now for the first time a broad Federal program has been approved in which many of the objections aroused by previous experimental programs have been removed, those who have studied the act point out.

In relation to price levels of four basic commodities, the buyer of building materials today gets more for his money even than at the low point of the depression, according to articles appearing in the current issues of Building Supply News and Practical Builder, two building industry publications.

Drastic changes in the statutes dealing with sex degeneracy will be recommended to. Governor Hurley and the Legislature by a committee of four named today at a conference of two dozen police, correctional, probation and religious officials.

Nearly 23,000,000 cubic yards of ashes, garbage, rubbish and waste are collected each year by the Department of Sanitation-an amount that would make a tower three times the height of the Empire State Building or would. fill a train about 3,500 miles long.

Senator Burke of Nebraska, one of the leaders in the fight which defeated President Roosevelt's Supreme Court Reorganization Bill, backed Vice President Garner today for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1940.

THERE is the tang of robust Americanism in the trend of hobbyists toward sea special ties. The romance of the clipper ships first set the drift in this direction and resulted in the spurt in model-making.

Both sides in the current labor disputes have made mistakes and the "age-old contest between capital and labor has been complicated in recent months through mutual distrust and bitter recrimination," President Roosevelt said in a Labor Day statement issued today.

The acquisition of 108 more lots comprising the property known as the James Madison Manor in the Marine Park section of Brooklyn was announced yesterday by James Dorment and Robert L. Goetz, builders, who have completed and sold more than 200 homes in that vicinity.

New Jersey has become the forty-fifth State designated as a modified accredited area, free of cattle with tubercular infection. The cattle of Salem and Middlesex counties were declared Sept. 1 to have passed the tests needed to gain the status for the whole State.
Bob Pastor, heavyweight boxer who once, went ten rounds with Champion Joe Louis, nursed a bruised left shoulder today as the result of an automobile collision. Pastor's companion,

FOR months travel companies have been checking itineraries and chartering ships, large and small, to take care of travelers who, each year as winds grow cold, turn eagerly to warm countries and new scenes.

A NEW class of eighty-two flying cadets arrived at the United States Naval Air Station here last week to begin flight training which, if successfully completed, will qualify them as naval aviators and lead to three years of active duty with the navy.

Shooting in a field of ninety-four teams of two men each in the .45 caliber interstate and inter-service pistol match today, J. R. Herron, Albany, N. Y., and J. H. Oberbaugh, New York City, totaled 534 of.a possible 600, landing in third place and winning bronze medals. This total score also brought Herron and Oberbaugh second place in the Class B event.

One to three years in jail for unauthorized press reports on matters affecting Brazil's defense is the penalty named in a bill introduced in Congress today. Reporters are forbidden to divulge without approval data on troops' mobilization, acquisition of armaments or military manoeuvres.
After threatening to kill his victim, a man snatched a $1,000 payroll yesterday morning from two employes of the Dixie Novelty Company, 529 Eighth Avenue.
Pope Pius today, in a letter addressed to Cardinal Pacelli, the Papal Secretary of State, announces that he does not intend to nominate a successor- to Cardinal Bisleti, who died last Monday,

Autumn flower shows are claiming the attention of many members of North Shore society, and there is a growing tendency to extend interest in horticulture and floral arrangement to the younger generation as evidenced by the sections for juniors on almost all schedules.

The New York Trust Company, in the current issue of its publication, The Index, predicts a rise in the wages of unskilled labor which will compel widespread readjustment of costs throughout the country.

Ernest L. Conant announced yesterday that the Old Farms Road, which will make accessible approximately 750 acres of interior farm and wood lands on his property at Pound Ridge, is now open. The property is part of the 1,800-acre Old Farms Riding Country which he purchased last year from Harvard University.

Joe Beggs scored his twentieth victory for Newark today, holding the Orioles to seven hits while his mates batted out a 5-to-2 victory. He became the second International League pitcher to hang up twenty triumphs. Marvin Duke of Montreal won his twentieth last night.
A twentieth-century Magellan and a Mrs. Magellan will set sail here next month on a scientific cruise around the Horn.

A blow to the chin, delivered by a priest, and the opportune presence of a police radio patrol car resulted last night in the capture of a burglary suspect near the rectory of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Angela Merici, 917 Morris Avenue, the Bronx.

Churchill is the greatest frozen asset in all Canada. This is quite appropriate, because it is built on the edge of the polar cap. The ground has never thawed, except in Summer for a few feet on top, since the last glacier receded.

Blond Miss Virginia Guilfoil of Syracuse, N. Y., administered a 10-and-9 defeat to Miss Dorothy Traung of San Francisco, the worst ever suffered by a finalist in the event, to capture the Mason-Dixon golf crown today. The New York girl had only one bad hole in the twenty-seven over which the championship was decided on the historic old white course.

The opening of new developments in Queens and many sales of completed houses and others which are under construction, marked the realty activity on Long Island during the past week. One of the new projects will comprise 200 dwellings. It has been started by Fellows Friese, builders, on 228th Street, near Foch Boulevard. St. Albans.

The Bureau of Navigaton released the following orders today, dated Sept. 2: CAPTAINS Baker. C. S., Philadelphia, Pa., to Bureau of Supplies and Accounts, Navy Department, Washington, D. C., in December. Hoopes, E. T., Navy Yard, Boston, Mass., to duty as General Inspector, Supply Corps, West Coast, San Francisco, Calif., in November.

Miss Mary Pierce Hammond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lyman Pierce Hammond of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Edward Hawley Roper, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Charles Roper of New York and Riverside, Conn. The wedding will take place on Sept. 25 in the Saugatuck Congregational Church in Westport. The Rev. Richard T. Elliott will perform the ceremony.

The press urges the Government today to continue exploration work in Search of oil in the Magallanes Area, where numerous wells already are being sunk with satisfactory results reported in some cases.

If a modern Rip Van Winkle had fallen asleep just after The Hague Conference of 1899 and had slept, not twenty years but nearly forty, he would certainly have to conclude that civilization had lost ground by the most searching test he could apply to it--its recognition of the sanctity of the individual human life.

Explosion of gasoline aboard a 50foot yacht, the Truant, a few miles off shore early this morning cost the lives of three small girls and caused serious burns to four parents and two other passengers.

To prevent hasty marriages and especially "those which follow cocktail parties, nocturnal joy rides and alcoholic overeffervescence," Assemblyman Jane Todd of Westchester last Spring successfully sponsored in the Legislature a law requiring a three-day period for

Sweet clover-seed production this year probably will exceed that of 1936 by as much as 25 to 35 per cent, the Department of Agriculture reported today. Economists said this season's marked increases in yields in the principal north central producing States would more than offset the reduction in acreage resulting from last year's drought.
William A. Cornell, a former New York exporter and for the last eight years a resident of Albany, died on his seventy-third birthday last night. He had been ill for several months. His mother,

A QUIET observer of the Broad way scene these two years since he came from Paris has been Dr. Saul C. Colin. President of the Intercontinental Productions, Inc., is his official title, though the theatre has known him better as the agent and pert sonal representative of well-known foreign artists and authors, among them Marta Abba and the late Luigi Pirandello.

The Chase National Bank has been appointed registrar for common stock of the Lionel Corporation. The Outboard, Marine and Manufacturing Company has appointed H. Biersach, W. C. Clausen, F. T. Irgens, E. H. Millet, J. S. Rayniak and P. A. Tanner vice presidents.

Bobby Saill of Paterson, N. J., won the fifteen-mile feature automobile race in the A. A. A. dirt track contests at the Flemington Fair today after Tony Willman of Milwaukee, Wis., cracked up while leading in the early laps. The victor's time was 14:47.7.
Mrs. Olive Borcia, 20, missing since Thursday night and reported to officers as kidnapped, returned today to her mother's Summer home. She was near collapse but unharmed.

A fifty-year course, so planned that a person of 20 will enter upon some well-conceived scheme of study and carry it through as long as he lives, was advocated by Professor Alexander Meiklejohn of the University of Wisconsin, in an interview recently, at the close of the third year of his experiment in adult education at the San Francisco School of Social Studies.

Terminating forty years of continuous service with the same company, Andrew Pendleton, 73-yearold chief receptionist to executives of the International Mercantile Marine Company, retired last week after an informal ceremony in the offices of P. A. S. Franklin.
Cosmopolitan society tends more and more, especially during the month of August, to divide itself according to the kind of diversion offered by the principal resorts:

The engagement of Miss Mary Virginia Louis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Karl Louis of Omaha, to Vincent Joseph Brosnahan of Westport, Conn., and New York, son of Mrs. Timothy Joseph Brosnahan of Westport and the late Mr. Brosnahan, was announced at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Louis tonight at their home.
New Hampshire put into operation on Sept. 1 what Insurance Commissioner John E. Sullivan described as "one of the most drastic motorvehicle financial-responsibility laws in the United States."

NIKOLAI CHERKASSOV, who steals a whole motion picture from a couple of Honored Artists of the Republic in the Cameo's current Soviet importation, "Baltio Deputy," once stole a scene from the great Chaliapin and was fired for his impertinence.
Thirty-one Chinese seamen, the entire crew of a Japanese freighter, deserted it today "rather than serve Japanese," United States immigration authorities said.

The Far Eastern policy of the United States, at this juncture, is directed toward demonstrating to Japan, Italy and Germany that the war-threatening countries of the world cannot obtain their objectives by default because of the unwillingness of the peace-loving nations to insist on respect for their rights and for the sanctity of international obligations, according to an authoritative source today.
Miss Elizabeth Dixon Clark was introduced to society at a large tea dance given this afternoon by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Austin Clark, in the Colonial Ballroom of the Meadow Club.

The rapid filing of complaints in three cases under the RobinsonPatman Act last week by the Federal Trade Commission was seen in trade circles here as indicating the commission is intent upon eliminating the impression that the brokerage clause of the law is dead pending the appeal in the Biddle case.

Despite a pick-up in buying activity during the closing days of August fur sales, business throughout the country was generally unsatisfactory, and sales volume for the country at large was reported as well behind last year's.

Most Chinese leaders pin their hopes of ultimate victory upon Japan's financial position, believing Japan will be bankrupted before a year's fighting has ended. But these same leaders always fail to consider China's financial plight, which, in the opinion of foreign bankers here, is worse than Japan's.

CENSUS takers of creatures of the wild indicate that practically every species of America's wild animals is on the increase. From assembled reports of rangers in the 23,000,000 acres of national forest land in Oregon and Washington the regional forester recently tabulated the figures.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in slightly greater volume than in the preceding period. Payment dates for most of the new retirements, however, were for future months, only a few small lots of municipal and foreign bonds being posted for actual retirement in September.
A teamsters' union threat to "close every port on the Pacifio Coast" served today to move San Francisco's A. F. L.-C. I. O. "finish fight" toward a crisis embracing possible Labor Day complications.

PARIS, WOMEN will present a wellgroomed appearance in their Fall and Winter suits--every line just so, figures and sleekness counting for a lot. From top of high-crowned hat to tip of well-chosen shoe every accessory will be picked out with an idea of its relationship to the silhouette.

The rearmament of the Portuguese Army is proceeding actively. Last week a new type of rifle was distributed to the soldiers. The new type differs from any heretofore used by the Portuguese, and it is stated to be of exactly the same type as that issued to the German Army today.

The Keiper Memorial Liberal Arts Building will be dedicated on Saturday, Oct. 16, in connection with the Sesquicentennial celebration at Franklin and Marshall College, Dr. John A. Schaeffer, president, announced today. Dr. Roy F. Nichols,

The marriage of Miss Margaret Lilian Scholle, daughter of Mrs. C. B. F. Brill of New York and of Hardinge Scholle, also of New York, to Lindley Bronson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bennet Bronson of Waterbury and Litchfield, Conn., took place here today in St. John's Church.
Japan's purpose to compel China to submit to her will was made clear by Foreign Minister Koki Hirota yesterday in a statement of policy to a "war session" of Parliament.

City officials of Philadelphia are considering proposals to lease the city's gas works plant to a syndicate at a yearly rental of $2,500,000, it was learned yesterday. A proposal has been made by Cornelius Bodine Sons Co., dealers in commercial paper, who are reported to have the backing of a syndicate of Philadelphia bankers.

The formal opening of the Autumn season at the Elizabeth Town and Country Club will take place on Sept. 18, when the annual invitation tennis dance will be held in connection with the third annual Eastern New Jersey clay-court ten-

Miss Laura Gray Gibson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julian Gibson of Gray Gables, Moylan, was married this afternoon to Dr. Thomas Parker, son of Mrs. Thomas Fleming Parker of Greenville, S. C., and the late Mr. Parker, in Christ Church, Media.

Miss Marjorie Varick Pell, daughter of Mrs. Twachtman Pell of this place and of Richard Varick Pell of New York, was married here this afternoon in St. Bede's Chapel, Rosemary Hall, to L. Emery Katzenbach 2d, son of Mrs. L. Emery Katzenbach of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Katzenbach.

IN a musty garret of an old stable in Hopewell Village, Pa., a National Park Service research worker recently chanced to discover a "blast" book. The volume reveals the detailed story of how iron was made in the famous Hopewell cold iron charcoal furnace between the years 1852 and 1875.

KINGS BERRY. ANNIE (Aug. 15). Estate, $6,000 real and $1,000 personal. To son, Frank G. Berry. $1,000; daughter, Mary Clark, $1; granddaughter, Anna May Clark, $200 when she marries and residue to son, Nicholas J. Berry, executor, all of 418 Forty-third St.
Everybody (It seems like everybody) in London goes to work at the same time, and the best minds of the British Government are trying to do something about it.
SOME movie people, like Gary Cooper and Wallace Beery, won't submit at all-others try to sneak out the back way, plead nervous headaches, previous engagements, anything.

Thomas King of Lavallette, with Barnegat Belle, was the first winner of the Barnegat Bay Y. R. A. Trophy for Class B Sneakboxes today, leading Ludwig C. Lewis with the Wig Wam. The event, in which the youngest sailors of the local waters competed, featured the annual Lavallette Y. C. regatta. Governor Hoffman presented the prize to the winner.
The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today that tentative approval had been given to four potato-marketing agreements designed to increase returns to potato growers in nine States.
Hidden for more than a thousand years on the shores of Oneida Lake, a "mystery" Indian civilization has been turned up by a field party from the Rochester Museum of Arts and Sciences.

SEPTEMBER'S arrival dropped the curtain on radio's Summer of Shakespeare with the final production, "Twelfth Night," staged during the past week in New York instead of Hollywood, as were the other performances.
Jeremiah James MacDonald, Canadian engineer, died in London today, according to word received here. Born at Vernon River, P. E. I., Mr. MacDonald, a graduate of McGill University,

The land planning section of the FHA now is prepared to offer assistance to municipalities and planning and zoning commissions in setting up city planning, zoning and subdivision control programs, it was announced yesterday by Administrator Stewart McDonald.
Difficulties with labor and with "squatters" on company property are discussed in the pamphlet report of the National Railways of Mexico by Eduardo Suarez, chairman.
THE other day this department received a call from one seeking information. That in itself is in no way unusual, but this particular visitant will be remembered longer than most.
Business conditions were spotty last week, taking the country as a whole, with abnormally hot weather retarding the early movement of all lines of Fall merchandise in many sections of the country.

Two big innings in each of which they scored three runs, were enough to give the Syracuse chiefs a 6-to-2 triumph over Jersey City in the final home game of the International League season here tonight.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago market today, as reported. by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

A rescue by the excursion steamer Smithfield, effected during a violent thunderstorm that obscured vision and caused watchers to believe mistakenly that the steamship was in distress, saved three men from an overturned sailboat in the Lower Bay last night.

The top-ranking representatives of the United States, Poland, England, France, Germany and Chile are taking part in the women's national tennis singles tournament on the turf courts of the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills. Of the sixtyfour women competitors, only fortyeight were unseeded.
James S. Stokes Jr., for many years a New York City stock broker associated with the firm of Van Wyck Sterling, died tonight at his home on West End Avenue here at the age of 52.

RADIO'S long lines from almost every quarter of the globe, especially in the 20 to-50-meter wave band, are pulsing with loud signals. Aided by favorable atmospheric conditions many of the foreign stations which increased their power outputs during the Summer are extremely clear, proving the old theory that Summer is a poor time for long-distance reception is all wrong in this era of short-wave broadcasting.

Miss Roberta W. Devoe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Devoe of this place, has chosen Oct. 9 as the date of her marriage to John L. Carnie, son of Mrs. Sarah Carnie, also of this city. The wedding will take place in the Epworth Methodist Episcopal Church here with the Rev. John Hill officiating.
It is useful sometimes to see ourselves as others see us, and readers of THE TIMES last week had an opportunity to note how we appear in the eyes of a group of foreign scientists.

The purchase by the Brooklyn Color Works of the entire block front on Norman Avenue, between Sutton Street and Morgan Avenue, Brooklyn, was announced yesterday by Frank R. Fischer, Inc., broker in the transaction.
CARL CROW Is an Amerlcan advertising man who has lived in Shanghai, and done business among the Chinese peple, for twenty-five years.

Undeclared war in China has already brought its colleges and universities face to face with a precarious future, Chih Meng, director of the China Institute in America, asserted in an interview yesterday.
China gradually is expanding production of iron and steel, despite the fact that two of its four steel mills are Japanese-owned, the Commerce Department reported today.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor will leave for Hungary tomorrow. They will entrain at the village of Villach and proceed directly to Northern Hungary for a hunting party.
A resumption of extensive army training manoeuvres on the broad plains of Pine Camp was dedared a possibility today by Secretary of War Woodring.

Lucky Concord to have been so lovingly chronicled! To the local writings of Emerson, Thoreau, Alcott, Sanborn, Channing and Hawthorne the bird journals of William Brewster must now be gratefully added.

Joseph Laronge of Cleveland will address the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers at its sessions as part of the annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, to be held at Pittsburgh in October, the institute announced yesterday. Mr. Laronge will discuss the appraisal of business and office properties under long-term leases.

After having terminated a two-week training session at Camp Smith, the 2,200 members of the Eighty-seventh Brigade, commanded by Brig. Gen. Walter A. Delamater, packed up today for the return trip to home armories.
