Work already completed and that to be undertaken in the near future in improving Bronx waterways was hailed yesterday by William E. Matthews, executive secretary of the Bronx Board of Trade, as fostering the industrialization of channelfront property in that borough.

The remaining months of 1937 will bring a notable bid for the attention of the woman driver. For more than a decade the automobile manufacturers have been giving more and more time to her needs and demands.

The War Department released the following orders today dated Sept. 3: MAJOR GENERAL Gibbins, H., the Quartermaster General, one day leave, Sept 5. COLONEL Campbell, S. A., Inf.. Manchester, N. H., to retirement, upon own application. Nov. 3.
CONTRARY to general belief the average attitude toward the tryout of a new play in a Summer theatre is one of mistrust.
A thrilling test of speed and stamina between the Derby winner Mid-Day Sun and the Aga Khan's Sultan Mahomed is expected in next Wednesday's St. Leger.

TWO years ago Italy's African army was standing at the border of Ethiopia, ready for the invasion that began on Oct. 2, 1935. Seven months after that date the precipitate flight of Emperor Haile Selassie from Addis Ababa and the triumphant entry of General Badoglio's motorized troops into that pillaged capital convinced a somewhat incredulous world that Benito Mussolini had conquered the ancient kingdom.
War clouds, threatening a devastating and general storm, have become an old story to the world. For a decade now men have been asking not will the storm break, but where and when.

LABOR is the theme of several broadcasts tomorrow, with Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, and William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, prominent among the speakers who will go on the air from various parts of the country.

The Autumn field-trial season for pointers and setters in the metropolitan district will open next week with the meeting of the Babylon Hunt Club at Babylon, L. I., the dates being Sept. 18 and 19. From that time until well into November there will be an almost continuous program.
Student leaders of campus organizations at Woman's College, University of North Carolina, will assemble Wednesday for a three-day conference on student activities and plans for the coming year.

AS indicated in these columns last week, Paramount has reached an amicable settlement out of court with Samuel Goldwyn and has canceled the $5,000,000 action which was instituted last Winter after Gary Cooper went under the Goldwyn banner.

MIDGETS Won by Quarter Pint, Molly Tyson, Chestnut Hill second, Cross Patch, Frances Defibaugh, Woodside, Del.; third, Maggie's Pup, Irene Defibaugh, Woodside, Del.; fourth, Chato, Richard McFadden, Montclair, N. J.; fifth. Dixie, Clara Bell, Lynchburg, Va.; sixth, Hangover, Elsie Tyson, Chestnut Hill. Time-7:29.1. (3 1-3 miles).

France and Britain have announced that a conference of Mediterranean powers will be held in Geneva during the sessions of the League of Nations. Italy, aloof from the League, was not included in the original invitation. Mussolini countered Friday by announcing his long-delayed visit to Hitler would take place soon, and Rome expects the "Berlin-Rome axis" to be strengthened as the Reich displays its armed might.

WILL be home by Labor Day." So they wrote, and now they are keeping their promise-thousands upon thousands of them, pouring in on ships, wheels and wings. This week-end witnesses the greatest travel movement of the year.

The Beauty Tea Corporation, 565 Fifth Avenue, New York, selling Beauty Tea, has stipulated with the Federal Trade Commission to stop representing that its product provides a safe, sure and reliable way to reduce weight; that it cleanses the system and prepares it for loss of weight, and that it enables one to reduce without resorting to strict diets or exercise, the commission announced today.

Husky Ralph Guldahl of Chicago, splashing through a rain that drenched the 7,017-yard course of the Hershey Country Club, shot a fourunder-par 69 today to lead the field at the end of the third round in the Hershey open golf tourney.

CAUGHT between the crossfire of the motor carrier industry, which insists upon reasonable hours compatible with revenues, and the labor organizations within the industry, which demand the shortest possible work period, the Interstate Commerce Commission is in the midst of the monumental task of fixing maximum working hours for truck and bus employes to promote highway safety.

One of the tragedies of our present era is the dividing of society into lower and higher classes, with the laboring classes given a lower status in life, Rabbi Samuel.H. Goldenson said yesterday in his Sabbath morning sermon at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.
The new Interior Department Building, regarded as one of the handsomest Federal structures in Washington, is to have a broadcasting studio.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petition NOVMET PRODUCTS, INC., manufacturers of ladies' handbag frames, 4 W. 32d St.. with factory at Bethlehem, Pa.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $31,534, exclusive of capital and surplus, and assets of $173,084.
Turpentine firm, 31c: sales. 169 barrels: receipts. 671 barrels; shipments, 40 barrels; stock, 35,038 barrels.
Mexico's new Department of Publicity and Propaganda employs 1,100 persons, it was revealed today. It controls all official information and Government printing.

Municipal Court Justice Joseph S. Rosalsky died during his sleep Friday night at his home, 200 West Eighty-sixth Street, after an illness of four months. He was 60 years old. A sister, Mrs. Bella I. Shapira discovered his death early yesterday morning.

Miss Jean Harriet Doll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Doll of this place, was married here this afternoon in the chapel of the First Presbyterian Church to H. Menard Everitt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Everitt of Mamaroneck.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it could not accept rules of fair trade practice sought by the petroleum and petroleum-products industry and said the industry had failed to abide by the spirit of rules that were adopted in 1931.
Traffic to the State Fair grounds increased steadily all day today on the eve of the opening of the annual State Fair, which will be held here all next week.

Looking back through a year of strife and turmoil, labor leaders agreed tonight that the Supreme Court's decision on the Wagner Act topped the list of important developments affecting the American workingman.

In observance of Labor Day, all security and commodity exchanges in the United States and Canada will be closed tomorrow. European markets will be open as usual. Wall Street will not be entirely deserted, however.

A register of refugee aid organizations in various parts of the world, just compiled by the European executive council of the American. Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, indicates that 125,000 persons have fled Germany since 1933.

Because Saturday is the traditional movie day, more than 100 children ranging in age from 8 to 14 years abruptly stopped their picketing yesterday afternoon of the Rosedale Apartments at 1.025 and 1,035 Boynton Avenue, the Bronx.

Homers by Jerry King and Sid Lipson featured the 14-to-4 victory of the Rutland Wildcats over the Procter Gamble Soapmakers in the senior metropolitan amateur softball championship final at the Yankee Stadium yesterday as 20,000 looked on.

Miss Christine E. Diener, daughter of Mrs. Irwin A. Diener of this city and the late Mr. Diener, was married here this evening in the First Reformed Church to Robert George Lenhart Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Miller, also of Hamburg.

Exasperated by the refusal or Governor Hurley of Massachusetts to return a Georgia fugitive from justice, Governor Rivers released a prisoner on condition that he would spend the time equal to the remainder of his sentence in Massachusetts.

By next Tuesday most of the truant New Yorkers who have been vacationing all Summer will be back in town facing life in an apartment. There are enticing new things in the shops to brighten up a city home and to make it seem less of a let-down-after the open country.

WITH the reopening of last season's surprising success scheduled for this month, Columbia issues an album of excerpts from Shakesperre's "King Richard II," featuring Maurice Evans together with Abraham Sofaer and members of the company.

Many sales of residential properties in several developments featured the real estate activities in New Jersey, according to reports received from developers and brokers in that State yesterday. In the Clinton Manor development on West Clinton Avenue near Knickerbocker Road, Bergenfield, eleven sales of dwellings were made during August, setting a new monthly high.

The protective committee for the preferred stock of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, now in reorganization proceedings under Section 77B of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, said yesterday in a letter sent to holders of the preferred shares that need for independent representation "is now more apparent than ever."

How seven Japanese airplanes first bombed and then, flying about 100 feet above the housetops, machinegunned the walled city of Changshu was described here today by the Rev. Hollis Samuel Smith of Binghamton, N. Y., who reached Shanghai after a circuitous, dangerous two-day trip through the fighting zone.

A good collector is not a hit or miss seeker of rare, high-priced books and prints, but one who develops a sort of sixth sense by careful analysis and by planning his own collection, according to Elmer Adler, editor of The Colophon.

A new Nazi experiment in community effort begins here tomorrow when 900 citizens, bringing their own spades and furnishing their own lunches, start building a flood control dyke and digging drainage ditches.

The right of the Public Works Administration to use Federal funds in the construction of parks and recreational facilities was challenged today in the Federal District Court. The Girard Trust Company, as trustee for the estate of Louise C. Brooke, asked the court to quash a petition by United States Attorney J. Cullen Ganey to condemn 459 acres of land in Chester and Berks Counties owned by the Brooke estate.

Dismissal of Matt Leach, captain of the Indiana State Police, was announced today by Donald F. Stiver, State Safety Director, after Captain Leach refused a request of the Indiana State Police Board that he resign.

Although the opposition of the Indiana Democratic State Administration to the return of Frederick Van Nuys to the Senate is publicly based on the Senator's failure to support the Roosevelt court plan, it predates the last session of Congress.

The new Duluth, Missabe Iron Range Railway Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue $30,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds as part of a plan under which the Duluth Iron Range Railroad Company would be brought under joint control with the Interstate Transfer Railway Company.

Miss Barbara Judkins, daughter of Mrs. Charles Otis Judkins of this place and the late Rev. Dr. Charles Otis Judkins, and Stephen Hathaway Mott Gow of Buffalo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Archibald Gow of Glens Falls, were married today in Christ Church.

IF motion pictures like "The Firefly." which came to the Astor Wednesday night for the New York engagement of its road show career, make no other point, they do argue for the cinema as the form for the dramatic pressentation of music.

The Foster Wheeler Corporation of New York has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 41,820 shares of $10 par common stock. All but 511 of the shares are to be offered first to holders of common stock.

Estimating that exports of coffee will comprise 14,000,000 bags of the crop for 1937-38, a near equilibrium statistical will be reached, it was stated today by Fernando Costa, president of the National Coffee Department. This is a situation unequaled in Brazil in many years.

The home owner usually thinks of Winter or early Spring as gardenplanting time. There is, however, one kind of gardening-and a most important one-which must be planned now, because the planting for it will have to be done within the next few weeks.
As the primary election on Sept. 16 approaches, there is unhappiness in most of the Tammany clubhouses, those former political strongholds from which once came the rulers of New York City.

LABOR DAY, 1937, finds organized workers contemplating the momentous events of the last twelve months and speculating on the twists and turns which the labor movement may take in the next year. In September, 1936, only a seer could have predicted the course which large masses of American workmen have followed since then.

Professor Henry Reiff of St. Lawrence University, writing for the September International Conciliation Document, issued yesterday, reviews the history of United States participation in international agreements covering social and economic problems and finds that the

The six-story apartment house at 2,275 University Avenue, the Bronx, has been completed and is ready for occupancy, Morris Shaknow, president of the Shakbro Realty Corporation, builders, announced yesterday.

The price of land on the Nanking Road in Shanghai is $1,500,000 an acre. The bombs falling in the International Settlement are not only destroying life; they are also devastating millions of dollars' worth of property which represents a three-generation-old struggle for the control of China.

Miss Helen Mount, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Mount of Montclair, has completed plans for her marriage next Saturday to Frederick C. Marston Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Marston of Montclair. The ceremony will be performed in the First Congregational Church here.

In line with the trend of the current season, purchasing activity in the wholesale market last week was spotty, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevy, Werring Howell, Inc., resident buyers. Some lines were very active, while others were rather quiet. The report continues:

STOCKHOLM. IN the showing of Swedish art and antiquities that opens Rockefeller Center Sept. 24 the emphasis is on historical developments, a continuing purpose of beauty through art as traced within a long succession of centuries.

One of the most controversial measures passed in the recent session of Congress, surpassed perhaps in wrangling and bitterness only by the plan for reorganization of the Supreme Court of the United States, was the sugar bill of 1937, signed reluctantly by President Roosevelt last week.
The Save the Children Fund of America, Inc., 1 Madison Avenue, will hold a "Southern Mountain Child Service Conference" in New York City Oct. 4 to 6, it was announced yesterday.

The mystery of the thirty-four missing ballots on which depends the possession of the seat of the first New Hampshire district in Congress is still unsolved. House committee number three, headed by Representative Ben Cravens of Arkansas, has spent four days in the little town of Newton, and taken the testimony of practically every voter therein without finding a single clue.

The Nassau Driving Club's 2:15 Class Trot and Pace was captured today by the chestnut gelding Colorado Scott, driven by H. C. Cornwell. Second was Highland Bob, owned and driven by W. T. Hutchinson of Hempstead. Dr. Watts, C. N. Bliss Jr.'s bay, was third.

The annual Cosmo Villa barn dance will be held on the night of Sept. 24 at the Schmidt Farm here as a benefit for Irvington House, a nonsectarian' sanatorium for child heart patients, which is situated in Irvington-on-Hudson. Mrs. John Jay Wyle is chairman of the committee arranging the fete and with members of this group will meet on Thursday afternoon to discuss further arrangements for the benefit.

IN these days of pressure-books that batter our intelligence, attempting no make us believe that Russia is a Garden of Eden or an Inferno of Cruelty, that the Loyalists or the Revolutionists are the only patriots in Spain, that the American workingam is exploited or that capitalits are all ogres,

Joe DiMaggio lost an extra-base hit, Jack Saltzgaver lost a run and a victory was eliminated from Pitcher Johnny Murphy's record as results of the protested game between the New York Yankees and Cleveland's Indians on Aug. 6, which has been ordered replayed by President Will Harridge of the American League.

If there were any doubt about the tremendous importance the German Government attaches to the impending visit of Premier Benito Mussolini or the satisfaction it feels over Duce's acceptance of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's invitation such doubt was dispelled today by the manner in which the entire German press and the whole governmental publicity apparatus mobilized to emphasize the "unique and surpassing significance of that historic event."

Once more with a flying range of twenty-two hours for our plane we are waiting at the edge of the Arctic Ocean ready for a dash, as soon as the weather man says go, to the area where Sigismund Levanevsky and his five companions may have descended on their flight from Moscow on Aug. 13.
The freighter Wichita, with twenty airplanes for Shanghai, passed through the Panama Canal today along with five freighters bound for Japan.

Values of bonds continued yesterday to drift to lower levels on the New York Stock Exchange in the slowest trading in more than nineteen years. Taking advantage of the final extended week-end of the Summer season, few traders were at their desks in the two-hour period, with the result that the turnover in all bonds amounted to only $2,000,500, compared with sales of $2,473,400 a week before.

Superintendent of Schools School will open this Fall under the most auspicious conditions we have faced since the depression. Smaller classes in the elementary schools, additional adjustment classes and classes for physically and mentally handicapped children and increased housing accommodations, offering some measure of relief from overcrowding, are in definite prospect for the new school term beginning Monday, Sept. 13.

ROMAN CATHOLIC biographe's of Martin Luther have hitherto been accustomed to approach the story of the Reformer's life in the role of prosecuting attorney. From John Cochlaeus in 1549 to Denifle and Grisar in our own time, they have invariably denounced him.

OPTIMISTS will draw comfort, as is their custom, from reflection on the London auction season which ended a few weeks ago. High prices, if not exactly prevalent, were at least in evidence, and some of them were mildly sensational.

Uniform seasonal openings for coat and suit manufacturers in the various price classes will be recommended as a feature of the stabilization program projected by the National Coat and Suit Industry Recover Board following its executive council convention here last week.

Invitations have been sent to leading Republican women throughout the city for the luncheon-rally for Mayor La Guardia to be held at the Hotel Commodore on Sept. 13, Mrs. H. Edward Dreier, chairman, announced yesterday.

Capt. Charles J. Saunders. Inf.-Res., 276 Riverside Dr., New York, N. Y. (D), 18th Infantry, is ordered to active duty, effective Sept. 5, at Fort Hamilton., N. Y., for training. Captain Saunders will rank from May 7, 1937 and will revert to inactive status Sept. 18.

The most colorful ball of the season here took place tonight at the Maidstone Club. Designated a "Gone With the Wind" party, to which guests were invited to "Open House at Scarlett O'Hira's Plantation," the event attracted several hundred members of the Summer colony and their guests, the majority of whom attended in costumes of the Civil War period.
Max Ignatz Fischel, violinist and teacher, many of whose pupils became members of BLA American symphony orchestras, died tonight in the Grant Hospital. He was 59 years old.
SALZBURG. WEBER'S "Euryanthe" is one of those unhappy masterpieces of operatic literature which cannot live and cannot die.

Taxes are the second largest item of expenditure made by the companies in the system of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, according to Ralph H. Tapscott, president, who discusses "Cost of Taxes" in the September issue of the company's magazine, Around the System.
THERE is a touch of the romantic in the publication of this novel, for it won for Genevieve Fauconnier the Prix Femina not so many years after her brother, Henri,

In its report upon foreign personal holding companies, the Congressional Committee on Tex Evasion and Avoidance admitted that the method of taxation recommended "is a departure from any previously used with respect to corporate income."

Only two of the components of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity moved upward for the week ended Aug. 28, and the combined index has eased to ?09.4 from 109.9. For the corresponding week last year the figure was 102.7.

Near the end of a session of comparative calm and of uninterrupted progress by the favored array in the national tennis championships yesterday, Charles Hare of Great Britain and Donald McNeill of Oklahoma City provided a lively finish to a day of sultry weather and desultory skirmishes at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.
H. G. Wells presented before the British Association for the Advancement of Science last week a kind of blueprint of a new system of "informative education," ranging from childhood through adulthood.

The Seaboard Finance Corporation reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $156,715 for the nine months ended on June 30. This was equivalent to $3.13 a share on 50,000 preferred shares and to 75 cents a share on 109,641 common shares outstanding at the end of the period.

Rules for the use of flags by individuals were issued today. With certain unspecified exceptions, which may be granted solely by the War and Interior Ministries, only the national or Swastika flag may be flown.

There are probably more women in industry this Labor Day than ever before, say Government economists who study the trends of industrial production and employment. These economists report a 10 per cent increase in factory employment of both men and women as compared with 1930, when the Census Bureau said that nearly 11,000,000 women were gainfully employed in more than 500 different occupations.

A riflebullet throw from deep left field by Jake Powell saved another sparkling pitching performance by Lefty Vernon Gomez from being marred by the Senators at Griffith Stadium as the Yankees ended a three-game losing streak today.

Superintendent of Schools School will open this Fall under the most auspicious conditions we have faced since the depression. Smaller classes in the elementary schools, additional adjustment classes and classes for physically and mentally handicapped children and increased housing accommodations, offering some measure of relief from overcrowding, are in definite prospect for the new school term beginning Monday, Sept. 13.

Uniform seasonal openings for coat and suit manufacturers in the various price classes will be recommended as a feature of the stabilization program projected by the National Coat and Suit Industry Recover Board following its executive council convention here last week.

The most colorful ball of the season here took place tonight at the Maidstone Club. Designated a "Gone With the Wind" party, to which guests were invited to "Open House at Scarlett O'Hira's Plantation," the event attracted several hundred members of the Summer colony and their guests, the majority of whom attended in costumes of the Civil War period.

Taxes are the second largest item of expenditure made by the companies in the system of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, according to Ralph H. Tapscott, president, who discusses "Cost of Taxes" in the September issue of the company's magazine, Around the System.

There is a boom market for old millstones in New England. If one wants one as an ornament for lawn or for any other purpose it will cost plentymaybe $50 or, if it is a specially fine specimen, as high as $100.

Miss Mazie Hanson Ballard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Harrison Ballard of this place, was married to Ensign Albert Roth Weldon, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert B. Weldon of New York, this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church here.

Mrs. Mary Whitford, 87 years old and once a schoolmarm herself, has finally brought her four schoolteaching sons and her one schoolteaching daughter together for a family reunion after fifteen years of trying.

Having clinched the championship of the American Chess Federation as a result of last night's play, David S. Polland of New York weakened in the eleventh and final round today and lost to Hermann Hahlbohm of Chicago in thirty-seven moves. Thus Polland finished with a score of 7 1/2--2 1/2.

Because of wide divergencies between religious and national usages the time has not arrived to convoke a world conference on calendar reform, the League of Nations committee on communications decided today.

This year's honors in the Thorn Memorial, annual polo tournament for players under 21, went to Broad Hollow tonight when they came through hail and rain to the hardest sort of a victory over the Meadow Larks on Whitney Field at the Meadow Brook Club.
The spread of infantile paralysis took on larger proportions in Chicago today as fourteen new cases were reported in the twenty-four hours ended at 9 o'clock this morning.
Armed with power clippers, Mexican shearers this week neared the peak of activity in lifting nearly $5,000,000 worth of mohair from 3,000,000 Texas Angora goats.
Nick Nack of Barnegat Bay, sailed by Charles E. Lucke Jr. and William Turbett, today took the first contest of the ninth annual Jersey Coast challenge series for International Star Class sloops.
Paul and Gertrude Noulens, Belgian Communists, who were sentenced to death and then received commutations to life imprisonment in 1932, left Nanking for Shanghai last night.

Parents of Constance E. Lyman, 13-year-old junior high school student who disappeared on her bicycle last Tuesday, today broadcast an appeal for the girl to communicate with them by telephone, as her mother is in a state of collapse.

Those emergency powers which the French Parliament granted to the Chautemps Cabinet .in June after the Senate had refused them to Premier Blum and his Finance Minister, Vincent Auriol, have now expired and from the first of this month the machinery of democratic government in France has begun functioning normally again.

FOR veteran Scout campers throughout the country there has been this Summer a full schedule of trail-blazing and mountain-climbing expeditions. On the 13,000-acre Ten Mile River Reservation in Sullivan County of New York City Scouts a trail forty miles long built by the boys connects the various units of the camp.
An aged Negro woman died today after sixteen days of a selfimposed religious fast. The woman, Annah Ransom, started her fast on what she said were "orders from the Lord."

Invitations have been sent to leading Republican women throughout the city for the luncheon-rally for Mayor La Guardia to be held at the Hotel Commodore on Sept. 13, Mrs. H. Edward Dreier, chairman, announced yesterday.

Capt. Charles J. Saunders. Inf.-Res., 276 Riverside Dr., New York, N. Y. (D), 18th Infantry, is ordered to active duty, effective Sept. 5, at Fort Hamilton., N. Y., for training. Captain Saunders will rank from May 7, 1937 and will revert to inactive status Sept. 18.

Nine high school students of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, who qualified from an original field of 150,000 for the grand finals of the 1936-37 Constitution Essay Contest, will hear the final decision of the judges at a special Constitution Day celebration to be held at the Town Hall here on the afternoon of Sept. 17.

GOLDSTEIN--BURKE--Mr. and Mrs. Alred Burke announcnce , marriag of their daughter, Frances, to Mr. Edward Goldstein of New York and Tilton, N. H. LANE--ROSEN--Mr. and Mrs. Morris Rosen, 576 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, Lillian, to Miton Lane. son of Mrs. Hattie Lane, taking place Setp. 16.

Accused of luring to his apartment at different times twelve girls ranging in age from 8 to 15 years, a man who described himself as Paul Hizsa, 53, of 330 East Forty-eighth Street, a slaughter house employee, was arraigned yesterday morning before Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in the Felony Court and held in $25,000 bail for examination next Tuesday.

AS an aid to the various countries whose commercial planes are now making survey flights across the Atlantic between the United States and Europe, the French vessel Carimare, first floating weather bureau,

Establishment of a United States cotton committee to unite the South on a program intended to re-establish United States supremacy in the world's cotton markets was decided upon here today at the concluding session of the Southern Agricultural Commissioners Association.

Mr. and Mrs. William Augustus Gill of South Orange and Westhampton Beach, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Gill, to William Sterling Roby Jr., son of Mrs. William Sterling Roby of the Hotel Delmonico, New York, and Rochester, and of the late Mr. Roby.

Through the rain-swept Genesee Valley, farmers and gentlemen breeders brought their prize horseflesh to the historic Avon Springs Paddock today for the Autumn show of the Genesee Valley Breeders Association, but a steady downpour put a damper on the exhibition.
Two golfers and two caddies were killed by lightning today at the Longue Vue Country Club near Verona. The bolt also felled three others, a golfer and two caddies.

Supplies of sherry remain safe in war-ridden Spain and normal shipments should continue from that country without interruption, Leslie Konza, sales manager for W. A. Taylor Co., wine and liquor importers, said here yesterday on his return from a business trip to Europe.

The Wagner-Steagall Housing Act, signed last week by President Roosevelt, presents a challenge to architects, builders and manufacturers to provide the materials and methods permitting the construction of adequate homes within the cost range set by the Government, ac??ng to B. G. Dahlberg, preside?? the Celotex Corporation. He beli?? that this challenge will be met successfully.

"Carmen," tonight. Mmes. Maru Castagna, Ivy Dale, Nina Quartin and Mildred Ippolito, and Messrs. Aroldo Lindi, Claudio Frigerio, Foster Miller, Norman Roland, Alfredo Neri and Angelo Angelini. Conductor, Mahler. "Aida," Monday afternoon.
Within the financial and industrial empire of the Mellons of Pittsburgh the occupant of one office carries the weight and authority of the head of the family and of the business.

Announcement has been made of the engagements of the Misses Priscilla and Barbara Thomas, daughters of Mrs. Leon Irving Thomas of Upper Montclair and the late Mr. Thomas. Miss Priscilla is engaged, to Marston Stickney Leonard, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Marston Leonard of Cambridge, Mass., and Miss Barbara to John Fisher Graham, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Graham of Lynn. Mass.

After a 10-point improvement under week-end covering, prices on the Cotton Exchange here moved lower in the second hour yesterday to end with net changes ranging from a gain of 6 to a loss of 9 points.

Leaves Without Pay PATROLMEN Harry Goldman, 13 Precinct, for 1 day from 8 A. M., Sept. 6. Frank R. Siekmann. 19 Precinct, for 3 days, from 12:01 A. M.. Sept. 4. Henry Levy, 25 Precinct, for 1 day, from 8 A. M., Sept. 6. John J. O'Connor, 25 Precinct, for 1 day, from 4 P. M., Sept. 4.
