James H. McMahon, who retired almost a year ago as a vice president of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, 1,775 Broadway, Manhattan, died tonight at his home here at 2 Ellison Place. He was 64 years old.

Recently the Hamburg-American liner Hansa arrived in New York harbor with an unwelcome passenger aboard--the typhoid germ. Having previously obtained medical clearance by, radio, the ship slid past Quarantine without stopping, despite the fact that more than a score of her crew had been stricken.
FROM Paris comes word that a world-wide organization is being formed among the friends and admirers of La Argentina to honor her memory in some suitable manner.

Miss Kay Brace, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Brace of RockLedges, Riverside, Greenwich, will be married to George Garrison Backhouse Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George Garrison Backhouse also of Riverside, on Oct. 2 in the First Congregational Church, Old Greenwich.

A citizens joint committee of inquiry on the Memorial Day riot near the Republic Steel plant in South Chicago has issued a report condemning the police in vigorous terms. In particular it called for the dismissal of Captain James L. Mooney, who was in charge of the police detail which clashed with strikers and sympathizers in a melee that resulted in the death of ten civilian demonstrators.
The search for two men who shot their way out of a police trap after two officers and one bandit were slain narrowed tonight after one was found seriously wounded in a Marshall, Mich., hospital.

Evidence that fish have a mentality similar in every important category to that of man was presented today by Professor James Gray, eminent Cambridge University zoologist, before the annual meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

The season's second week-end of popular-priced opera by the New York Hippodrome Opera Company opened last night with Gounod's "Faust." Despite the severe storm a few hours before the performance, an audience of some 3,000 was present.

WASHINGTON. -- Americans are becoming aware that their fingerprints are an asset. The Federal Bureau of Investigation recently revealed that it is receiving an average of 1,000 sets of fingerprints daily from citizens who, for their own protection, want the bureau to have a set of their prints on file.

Leo Tilson, 40 years old, proprietor of the Vienna Restaurant near here, was killed instantly early this morning when the driver of his car lost control and the automobile turned over three times on Grand Street,

This typhoon-swept city struggled to right itself today and strove to count its hundreds of dead. The typhoon, which beached great liners in the harbor, crushed houseboats and fishing fleets and rolled tidal waves over maritime villages, disrupted communications for miles.

POSTMASTER ALBERT GOLDMAN'S office has suggested to the Postoffice Department at Washington that an official ruling may be advisable for the guidance of postmasters with regard to delivery of mail received from Spain and franked with postage stamps issued by the Spanish Insurgents.

HOT and humid weather in many sections of the country made for sluggish trade last week in all but a few instances. Apparel sales suffered chiefly but home furnishings also felt the influence of highly unfavorable shopping weather. Former increases were cut sharply.

The early recall from Spain of the shattered remnants of the British battalion of the International Brigade fighting for the Loyalists has been decided upon by the British Communist party, The Sunday Dispatch says today.

The North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy, which is headed by Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the Methodist Episcopal Church, and two other large relief organizations sympathetic with the Loyalist cause in Spain yesterday issued a joint statement that their administrative costs had been only 13 per cent of moneys and relief commodities collected since they started their campaigns in 1936.

It's too bad, but a fact, nevertheless, that most metropolitan yachtsmen-barring a few exceptions, of course-act as if a fence divided their near-by waterways. And to borrow a thought from Kipling: Rarely the twain shall meet.

UTAH in 1937 is setting an alltime record for tourist travel. Railroads, sightseeing companies and the national parks in and adjacent to the State are experiencing the greatest vacation activity in years, officials report.

Jacob Grab of 126 Remington Place, proprietor of Grab's, the city's oldest restaurant, which for thirty-two years has served as a rendezvous for city officials, died at New Rochelle Hospital today after a long illness. He was 70 years old and a native of Germany.
The text of the report of the Mandates Commission of the League of Nations on Palestine was made public by the League today. An official summary of the report had been issued Aug. 23.

The first printed copy of the Federal Constitution, set up in proof sheets by the publishers of The Pennsylvania Packet and Daily Advertiser Aug. 1-3, 1787, has been found in the archives of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania.
Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute officials said today that the attitude of applicants for admission this year "gives rise to the hope that passing from the campus is the playboy College Johnny."

Miss Janet Meyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred R. Meyer of this place and Greenwich, Conn., was married here this afternoon at Eel River Hill, the Summer home of her parents, to Frederick Parsons Lowrey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Dwight Lowrey of Honolulu.

Secretary of Labor Perkins declared in an interview today: "I believe that we are started upon a policy of cooperation between employer and employee that will be the means in this country of achieving peace, with justice, in the industrial world.

The Navy Relief Ball was the chief social event tonight. This ball has become an annual event of the Summer. It is for the benefit of the Rhode Island branch of the Navy Relief Society, which works among the families of naval men who are in need.

The Danish missionary C. Bolwig, 71 years old, has been kidnapped from Takushan, Manchuria. He has been a misisonary in Manchuria since 1893. He founded the missionary station at Takushan in 1896. Mr. Bolwig learned Chinese and lived as a Chinese.
No two people have ever come to quite the same conclusions about Swift, which is perhaps why no one person has ever composed about him a completely satisfactory book.

While disputants in the various Democratic factional rows were back in their bailiwicks this week, be they at Yeller Rabbit or Hyde Park, each meditating methods of purging the other out of the party, Republican leaders were laying definite plans to take advantage of the made-to-order opportunities served up to them in the record of the last session of Congress.

Much of the impetus in the residential construction field in and near New York City manifested within the last six weeks is due to a new cooperation among the various factors in this activity. according to Thomas G. Grace State director of the Federal Housing Administration.
The largest electorate in the history of Argentina heard speeches ending the Presidential campaign tonight and will vote tomorrow to elect a successor to the retiring President, Agustin P. Justo.

John K. Evans of Bloomingburgh, who represented Sullivar County for five consecutive terms in the Assembly, 1909-13, died here this afternoon in the Horton Memorial Hospital. He was about 74 years old. For many years he had owned a general store in Bloomingburgh.

American Y. M. C. A. secretaries will stand by their posts with their Chinese colleagues in the present crisis in China as they have in the past, it was said yesterday by Eugene E. Barnett, general secretary of the International Committee of the Y. M. C. A. and former associate general secretary of the National Committee of the Y. M. C. A. in China.

A year ago today the American Federation of Labor suspended ten of its unions for affiliation with the Committee for Industrial Organization. By that action the A. F. of L. lost, it was estimated, about 900,000 members, and the stage was set for the most bitter union rivalry recorded in the half century since the A. F. of L. wrested labor leadership from the Knights of Labor.

MUSKETS cracked on a Honduran beach one September day in 1860, and after the firing squad, for it was an execution, had hurried away some priests remained to bury in the sand the crumpled figure of William Walker.
Plans for a self-operated joint pension system for the banks of this State, upon which the New York State Bankers Association has been working more than two years, have reached completion.

WITHIN a year or two this far Northern capital may become a smokeless city, the first smokeless capital in the world. Iceland now expects a substantial reduction in the need for coal, which ranks high on her list of imports, through utilization of her hot springs, one of the country's leading natural resources.

Fifty-nine scholarships, whose total value is $17,975, have been awarded for the academic year 1937-38 by the Columbia University School of Medicine, it was announced yesterday by Dean Willard C. Rappleye.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish.

Miss Elizabeth Dewing, daughter of Mrs. William Kaup, author, who writes as E. B. Dewing, was married yesterday in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building to Scudder Middleton by Deputy City Clerk Philip A. Hines.

The engagement of Miss Jane Kessler, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George L. Kessler of 1,119 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, to Ira Kendell Hearn Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira K. Hearn of Norfolk, Va., has been announced by her parents.

SYDNEY, Australia.--In most of the North Australian aborigine tribes the woman who bears twins is seldom allowed to keep both her babies. One new-born. infant is about all she can manage and do all her work, which amounts to practically everything about the camp.

The Scandinavian Gold Cup was not sailing back to the Baltic Sea today, but was still held at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club because Briggs Cunningham and his American defender Lulu came through after a lean week.

Berlin's civilian population has received warning and instructions regarding the mock air raids that will be made on the capital between Sept. 20 and 26. The air raid tests will be held in connection with the army and navy air force maneuvres, which will take place in Mecklenburg and Pomerania.
Robert R. Haas, a janitor at the teamsters union headquarters, was shot and seriously wounded today as he grappled with a man who broke into the union office.

Mrs. Everett Frooks, president of the Frooks Realty Company, reported yesterday the sale of the following one-family Long Island homes: 51 Gaynor Avenue, Manhassett. to G. M. Sacerdote; 121-11 195th Street. St. Albans, to Bernard J. Brown; 38 South Eighteenth Street, New Hyde Park, to Harry Stark;

School days will begin again next Tuesday for some 200 persons over 70 years old when a school founded by Dr. Charles E. Sharpe, 78 years old, opens in a renovated sixteen-room mansion here. Its sole purpose, according to its founder, who continues to practice medicine after forty-eight years, is to arouse a new zest for living among elderly men and women.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James David Howlett of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Townshend Howlett, to John Cranston Heintzelman.

The Nicaraguan Legation here repatriated large groups of Nicaraguans tonight as demonstrations against Nicaragua increased in intensity and number. The dispute was over a postage stamp. Both the Honduran and Nicaraguan Governments were understood to have exchanged representations, Honduras contending a recent Nicaraguan stamp included part of Honduras In the engraved map of Nicaragua and the latter contending "it portrays the official map of Nicaragua."

Fruit stands all over the city, from those at the fancy greengrocer's to those pushed about on wheels, are now groaning under nature's most lavish harvest in four or five years. Prices are about as low as they can go; the quality of most fruits is superb-an exceptional situation.

In the account of Friday's sale of discount bills by the United States Treasury which appeared yesterday in THE NEW YORK TIMES, it was stated that the average discount of 0.711 per cent a year at which an issue of 273-day bills was sold compared with a rate of 0.524 per cent on a similar issue last Monday. This was an error.

Van S. Merle-Smith's twelve-meter sloop Seven Seas led a fleet of 174 craft that competed today in the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club's sixty-fifth annual Fall regatta. It was the largest turnout of the season with the exception of Larchmont race week.
When he enters the Dayton School of Engineering in the Fall, 18-yearold Johnny Humm, 6-foot 183-pound football star, will take along with him the Long Island junior golf championship.

Moving steadily through the last half mile, Savage Beauty carried the red and yellow silks of the Branncastle Farm to a length victory in the second running of the New England Oaks before 30,000 spectators today at Narragansett Park. Eight fillies competed.

Because their occupation is hazardous, guards at Government prisons are entitled to retirement at 62 years of age instead of 70 as fixed in the Retirement Act, the Civil Service Commission informed Attorney General Cummings in a ruling today.
Fredrick Schnepper, a farmer from the fiddle West "Dust Bowl," has taken up a farm in this village. At st, he says, "we are on a farm at pays."

WHILE radio is a valuable adjunct to religion, it is imperfect, the Rev. James M. Gillis, who has been on the air regularly for twelve years, reported at the Institute of Human Relations held during the past week at Williamstown,

Nineteen college clubs have accepted the invitation of the Union College Outing Club to the third annual "College Week" which it is sponsoring in behalf of the Intercollegiate Outing Club Association in the Adirondacks from Sept. 11 through Sept. 18,

A runaway bakery truck today swept away a baby carriage from a Roxbury sidewalk and finished its course in a field by crushing out the life of Robert Laird Jr., 9-month-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Laird, Roxbury, who was in the carriage.
HERE we have another version of the locked room murder, only this time it is a trailer that is locked from the inside.

ARNOLD-Walter C., in his seventy-eighth year, son of the late David and Rlcka Arnold. Funeral from Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., on Sunday, Sept. 5, at 11:30 A. M. BACH-Arthur, in his sixtieth year. beloved brother of Otto, Herman and. Ella. Services at the Stolzenberger Chapel, 450,

The real estate market this Summer has been the most wholesomely active since that of 1928, according to a market study by William J. Brede, title research director of the New York Title Insurance Company.

IT comes as a distinct surprise to be informed that the volume of tales which Edith Wharton, at the time of her death, had finished proofreading, and which is now shortly to appear, is her fifty-third.
Stocks closed firm; trading second slowest since October, 1934; turnover, 229,980 shares. United States Government obligations fractionally lower; other bonds steady; transactions, $2,000,500.

Relatives of Mrs. Frederic de Puyster Foster, who left two wills and in the second gave all her property including a house in this exclusive colony to two servants, began today preparations to fight for a share of the estate.

Dr. Juan Campisteguy, presi dent of Uruguay from 1927 to 1931, died tonight. He was 80 years old. Dr. Campisteguy was born in Montevideo of Basque descent. He fought in the Quebracho Revolution of the 80s, and afterward, in 1886, founded a newspaper.

One of the highest dividends ever paid to creditors was delivered last week when checks for 118.66 per cent of outstanding bills were sent to creditors of Walker's, Inc., a Los Angeles department store.

Many of the clubs in Westchester held dinner dances tonight, inaugurating the Labor Day week-end. One of the largest took place at the Beach Club of the Apawamis Club here. The Westchester Country Club here opened its holiday festivities tonight with a dinner dance on the outdoor terrace of the main clubhouse.

One question of considerable importance, both to our own country and to the outside world, will presently be answered. It is whether the United States, as a result of various circumstances, is destined in the coming season to regain its old-time position as great wheat-exporter.

Nearly a half-century ago two young lovers quarreled on their wedding eve. Pretty Athalinda Theresa Stillwagon, who was 20, stamped her foot and returned her engagement ring to Aaron Lieberger. They parted, and until a few weeks ago did not see each other again.
Asa Long of Toledo added the United States checkers championship to his world title today when Willie Ryan of New York withdrew from the finals after he and Long had played eight drawn games.

Despite efforts to keep the shipment secret, it was learned yesterday that 80,000 drums of aviation gasoline are to be shipped to Japan from this port within the next fortnight. The contract is being bought through Mitsui interests but is believed intended for military use.

The Norwegian Government announced today that unless conditions in Europe grow worse Foreign Minister Halvdan Koht would visit the United States in October to discuss Norwegian-American problems with President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

The wedding of Miss Dorothy Claire Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis W. Thompson of this city, to William L. Globwacki, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Glowacki of Hamden, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.

Judge Theodore Forby of Zion, Ill., who sentenced thirty-nine men to jail for violating an injunction against occupying the plant of the Fansteel Metallurgical Corporation in a sitdown strike at North Chicago last February,

Miss Manie Hetherington Connor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Powers Connor of Maplewood, will be married Sept. 23 to Walter Robertson Williams Jr. of Maplewood. The ceremony will take place in St. George's Episcopal Church here. The rector, the Rev. Francis H. Richey, will officiate.

Berlin health authorities have traced the widespread epidemic of enteritis--inflammation of the intestines-to duck eggs that had been insufficiently cooked. Many cases were reported here and in the surrounding country.
Some ninety crews enjoyed the experience today of sailing over the seldom announced Course No. 4 of the Bellport Bay Yacht Club on the second day of its annual three-day Labor Day week-end regatta.

John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, will be the principal speaker at a labor rally in Madison Square Garden the night of Oct. 4, on the eve of the first national convention of the Transport Workers Union of America, it was announced yesterday.
Two Johnson City (N. Y.) policemen held prisoner at the point of an automatic pistol for twelve hours by a calm-voiced desperado. were released unharmed by their kidnapper near here tonight.

The greatest triumph for organized labor in the last year was the enforcement of the Wagner Act, Jeremiah T. Mahoney, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, declared yesterday in a Labor Day greeting to the people of the city.

Eugene Merz, a manufacturer of chemicals and dyes, died at his home this morning after an illness of several weeks. He was born in New York sixty-eight years ago. In 1892, the year of his graduation from the Columbia School of Mines, Mr. Merz helped establish the firm of Heller Merz of Newark, of which he was a partner until 1930.

The Cubs, who led the National League for eleven weeks, at one time by seven games, continued their collapse today by scoring only one run in a double-header against Pittsburgh and dropping both contests, 7 to 0 and 4 to 1. The twin defeats, suffered before a homecoming throng of 34,091, dropped the Chicagoans to two full games behind the idle Giants.

Continuous bad weather here prevents our search for 'the missing Russian plane, but with full fuel tanks giving us a range of twenty-two hours we are ready to go when the weather clears. There have been rain and fog for the last two days and now a strong northeast wind is clearing the skies.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, urged a realignment of political parties to be divided on liberal and radical lines today in his annual address at the Parrish Art Museum.

The next step in the goal of scientific eugenics toward the production of a better race of men will be the application to human propagation of the very same artificial methods now employed in breeding thoroughbred horses and cattle,

Albert W. Jaeger has announced the engagement of his sister, Miss Eleanor T. Jaeger, to John E. M. Enroth, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Enroth of this city. The announcement was made at a tea held yesterday at Mr. Jaeger's home, 1,610 Mahan Avenue. the Bronx.

(Figurds in parentheses indicate par.) Engineers (70)-Second round, club championship, Class A: Burton Braun defeated B. Wolff, 5 and 4; J. H. Kayton defeated B. J. Mattuck, 4 and 3. Class B: E. L. Rosing defeated H. F. Freedman, 1 up. Class C: A. L. Sachs defeated Dr. M. Gittelson, 2 and 1.

Mrs. Carrie Hutchinson Ryerson, widow of Martin A. Ryerson, art collector and philanthropist, died today at her Summer home at Lake Geneva, Wis., after a brief illness, at the age of 78. Her husband, who was President of the University of Chicago Board of Trustees from 1892 to 1922, and honorary president of the Art Institute, died in 1932.

The story of a successful emergency mastoid operation on board ship was told yesterday when the Holland-America liner Statendam docked at Hoboken. The patient was Edward Webster Scott, 21 years old, a Princeton University senior. Dr. Thomas N.

Duncan Sterling Jr., who ran the Scandinavian Gold Cup series all week in his capacity of chairman of the race committee, took time out long enough to win the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club's eighteenth annual fifty-mile event to Stratford Shoal and return, which was finished today.
French financial circles do not feel that reduction of the official discount rate of the Bank of France will really cause much change in the tendency of the French capital movement.

German railroad freight traffic in July was 14.4 per cent larger than in July, 1936. The Reich Railroad Corporation's report for 1936 shows an operating surplus of 472,000,000 marks, against 152,000,000 in 1935.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company has sold to a client of George Fass the two five-story apartment houses on a plot 52 by 75 feet at 70 and 72 East 112th Street. The houses contain eighteen apartments and four stores and are assessed at $35,000.

The second program of the Federal Music Project's all-Tchaikovsky series was heard last night at the Theatre of Music by an enthusiastic, near-capacity audience, happily paralleling the conditions of last Sunday's opener.
Justin Callahan, unattached, won the Metropolitan A. A. U. senior 440-yard free-style crown today at the swimming meet held in the 25yard indoor pool of the Lido Country Club.
Bradford Washburn Jr., back from scaling Alaska's Mount Lucania, highest unclimbed peak in North America, left Newark by airplane tonight for Boston and a visit with his-familv at Cambridge, Mass.
The downward trend in cotton prices continued last week. Net losses in prices for active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 27 to 39 points.

Italy, Germany and Russia will be among the nations invited to attend a conference somewhere near Geneva at the end of this week in an attempt to stamp out submarine and airplane "piracy" in the Mediterranean.

Wilford Wehrle, 22-year-old wax worker from Racine, Wis., won the thirtyeighth Western amateur championship today, defeating Charles (Chuck) Kocsis of Detroit, 1 up, in thirty-six holes of golf. Kocsis, trailing by four holes as they started the afternoon round, outshot his young foe and whittled the lead but couldn't match Wehrle's phenomenal putting.

Edward Hudson Booth, for mor than fifty years a member of the firm of A. W. Booth Brothers, Bayonne, N. J., lumber dealers, retiring ten years ago, died today at his home here. He was born in Jersey City and was 81 years old.

PHYLLIS M'GINLEY is a Utah girl who grew up in a canyon and who writes* as though she had started practicing with verse foims when she was no older than Shirley Temple's doll. This early environment fitly conditioned her for her later career as a star performer in the exacting sport of Manhattan light-verse writing.
The week's Boerse was dull for all securities. the most noteworthy feature being a general reaction in stocks with bonds inclined to firmness.
Joseph Hipp, 12, who was lost in the mountains six foodless days and nights and slept in a cave, but "wasn't scared," ate ice cream cones and told of his experiences at a hospital today.

Hardy survivors from the ranks of the "boys in blue" paid tribute today to the thousands for whom taps has been sounded. Fewer than 200 veterans of the war between the States answered the roll-call for the seventy-first annual encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic.

New capital issues in August amounted to [Pound]7,141,184, compared with [Pound]20,305,459 in July and ??6,194,413 in August a year ago. The total for eight months is [Pound]124,862,513, against [Pound]139, 580.964 similarly in 1936.

The eighth annual West Park dahlia and flower show, given for the benefit of the Church of the Ascension in West Park, N. Y., will be held on Thursday in the parish house. Mrs. Alton Brooks Parker of this city and Esopus, N. Y., for several years active chairman of the flower show committee, will officially open the event.

Miss Frances Foley and Theodore L. Chamberlin were married here yesterday morning in St. Joseph's Cathedral by the Rev. John F. and Hannon. Miss Geraldine Foley was her sister's only attendant. William Chamberlin was best man for his brother.

The MacGregor Arctic expedition is back at its base here after having the experience of actually being blown out of anchorage. Winds of from 80 to 100 miles an hour, which descended from the Greenland ice cap early Wednesday, had carried the expedition's ship, the schooner General A. W. Greely, from her moorings.

One Canadian girl acting as mechanic for her fiance and sixteen young, middleaged and even graying older men of the United States, France, Italy and the Dominion in ten highly tuned speed boats will race fifty, sixty, perhaps eighty miles per hour on the Detroit River tomorrow for a $750 plated trophy known as the Gold Cup.
The nation's efforts to escape Summer heat have almost doubled sales of air - conditioning equipment this year, according to a summary today by the Census Bureau.
As spokesman for the Southern Agricultural Commissioners Association, Lawrence Westbrook, former aide to Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator,
The general gloom cast over the financial markets by the situation in China and the new Mediterranean submarine outrages deepened in the last few days. In addition,

William T. Spencer Jr., 155 Ridgewood Avenue, member of the lighterage and stevedoring firm of William Spencer Son Corporation, New York, died last night at his Summer home at Sea Girt. His age was 64.

While changing a tire early yesterday morning on Grand Cen- at tral Parkway, just east of North Beach Airport, Edward Roth, 34 years old, of 20 Eastchester Road, New Rochelle. was killed by an automobile driven by Albert Dempsey of 153-16 Forty-first Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

The official provisional crop estimate is rather better than was expected. Except for Winter barley, which deteriorated badly, the yields per hectare are little changed and the declines in the total yield are moderate compared with 1936: Rye, from 7,380,

In spite of light buying, steel production is holding fairly steady at the rate prevailing through late July and August, according to the magazine Steel. The publication states that producers apparently are not concerned at the small volume of current bookings and are seeking to clear their books of backlogs, which are heavy in some products and light in others.
Japan's Navy today clamped its blockade against Chinese shipping on the whole length of China's 2,150-mile coastline.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ellis Brown of this city and Tuxedo Park, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their eldest daughter, Miss Helen E. Langdon Brown, to John H. Claiborne, son of Mrs. J. Herbert Claiborne of 145 East Fifty-second Street and the late Dr. Claiborne.

Mr. and Mrs. John Gilbert Holtzclaw of Whitcomb, West Hampton, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Adora Evelyn Holtzclaw, to John Aaron Prevost, son of Mr. and Mrs. R. T. Prevost of Waynesville, N. C.
Governor Quinn tonight announced that State auditors, ordered to examine the books of the Narragansett Racing Association, Inc., at the $1,000,000 Pawtucket horse race track, had been "locked out."

Quietly, but with a keen interest for everything about them, a party of 130 Londoners arrived here yesterday morning to find it rainy and gloomy but, above all, "nippy." We have, they decided, a "nippy" way of doing things.

Strategic considerations, some well-informed circles here believe, had much to do with the Royal Commission's Palestine partition proposal and the British Government's prompt acceptance of it, and are likely to have much to do with its future in the League of Nations Council session opening Friday.

Professor Errett Weir McDiarmid, head of the Department of Philosophy at Texas Christian University since 1918 and president of the Southwest Athletic Conference, died today. His age was 60. Dr. John McDiarmid of Princeton University, one of America's leading tennis players, is a son.
A crowd of 25,000 spectators saw a team of American track and field stars capture first places in seven of thirteen events in a meet with Italian champions today.
Chinese in the United States have given at least $1,500,000 to aid the land of their ancestors in the fight with Japan.

R. A. Kling of Lemont, Ill., won the Louis W. Greve Trophy and a purse of $4,500 at the National Air Races today when he flew his Folkert Speed King twenty laps of the five-mile course at an average speed of 232.2 miles an hour.

Somehow, this year just hasn't been such a good one for the British. Too many cups have been going to the Americans. There's a strong possibility that Britain had this in mind when she selected her tuna team for the international tuna angling matches to be held off Wedgeport. Nova Scotia, beginning this Saturday.

The problems confronting Jews here and in Europe and also the recent recommendation of the British Royal Commission for the division of Palestine were the themes of sermons last night at Rosh haShanah services in Reform temples and Orthodox synagogues to usher in the Jewish New Year.

The International Harvester Company has modified its pension plan to coordinate it with the Social Security Act, Sydney G. McAllister, president, informed the company's 65,000 employes today. The changes will provide a larger measure of old-age security for employes with long service records, he said.

Sing Sing Prison attaches disclosed today that in August Kings County alone contributed thirty-two lawbreakers out of 101 received there from twelve counties, or more than 31 per cent. There were no commitments from Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
Stocks lower, steel shares weakest; turnover, 3,903,030 shares. United States Government and Japanese Issues lower; other bonds irregular; transactions, $28,003,300.

Dominic Pompeo, 32 years old, of 127-20 161st Street, Springfield, Queens, told Magistrate Anthony P. Savarese in Flushing Court yesterday that he mistook a fire-alarm box for a letter box and had thus turned in a false alarm from New York Avenue and Baisley Boulevard, Jamaica.

Miss Marjorie Ruth Woodworth, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Arthur Vyne Woodworth of Alton, N. H., was married to Richard H. Herter, son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Herter of Hartford, yesterday afternoon in the Congregational Church here by her father and the Rev. Edwin R. Carter of Westbrook, Me., brother-in-law of the bridegroom.

A movement will be put under way this week by prominent members of the Westchester Historical Society and civic organizations to petition the Westchester County Board of Supervisors to appoint a committee to urge John D. Rockefeller Jr. to transform Kykuit, home of John D. Rockefeller Sr., into a shrine and museum in memory of his father.

Under heavy bond and guard, 100 Chinese sailors passed through Los Angeles yesterday bound for Norfolk, Va., on a secret and unannounced mission. All the sailors were required by bond to maintain silence regarding their stay in this country.

The French wholesale price index stood at 589 on Aug. 28, against 586 on Aug. 21, 581 on Aug. 14 and 400 on Sept. 12, 1936. The rise in the food index in the week ended on Aug. 28 was due to the increase in the price of wheat.

Mrs. Ellen O'Neill, 71 years old, of 188 Helen Street, Binghamton, N. Y., was found dead early yesterday on the sidewalk at the foot of the flight of stone steps leading to the home of her son, Gerald, 16509 116th Avenue,. Jamaica, Queens.

A plan for reorganization designed to give to the bondholders complete ownership of the Hotel Drake at Park Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street, against which a first mortgage 6 per cent bond issue of $3,750,000 was sold in 1927 and is outstanding for $3,417,000, has been prepared by a committee of bondholders.

Heavy seas following in the wake of storms that swept the Atlantic coast late Saturday night and early yesterday morning played havoc with pleasure craft in coastal waters yesterday, while the weather generally put a decided damper on week-end holiday-making.

Dr. David Hendricks Bergey, research biologist and former Professor of Bacteriology and Hygiene at the University of Pennsylvania, died tonight of nephritis at his home, 206 South Fifty-third Street, after a year's illness. He was 76 years old.

Four out of five middle-class families have increased their annual income an average of $437 since the depression. according to a survey just completed by the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company.
Five deaths today increased to eight the fatalities from a collision between a passenger automobile and a truck three miles east of here last night.

Charges of widespread violence today marked Argentina's election of a successor to President Agustin P. Justo, which Dr. Roberto M. Oritz, candidate of President Justo's party, was believed to have won.

Archaeological research in the Far North during the past Summer uncovered an early American culture which probably antedates the Christian era, according to the Rev. Rayinond W. Murray, head of the Department of Sociology and Professor of Anthropology at the University of Notre Dame.

New York State's ninety-seventh annual exposition, a huge combine of agricultural and industrial exhibits, was opened today with a double plea for greater unity and selfreliance on the part of the American people.
Mr. and Mrs. John V. Bouvier 3d, as Rhett Butler and Scarlett O'Hara, received the prize at last night's "Gone With the Wind" costume ball at the Maidstone Club.

The setting-up of the National Railway Company was intended principally to satisfy Socialist members of the Government who long had been demanding railway nationalization. Like other steps taken along this line, it is a compromise, because the companies remain autonomous and the shareholders are not wholly stripped of their prerogatives. Nevertheless.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amounted to $4,869,336,400. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

State Senator Winant Van Winkle has been elected to the advisory board of the American Citizens League, formed last Spring by a group of Essex County residents to end employment discrimination against citizens past the age of 40.

The concrete stadium of the West Side Tennis Club stood bleak and empty in a driving downpour yesterday and down below tarpaulins were pulled over the velvet carpet of turf. The fourth day of play in the national championships was washed out, and it was feared that unless the rain subsided before this morning operations in the tournament would be at a standstill until tomorrow.

With all our advancements of modern science, we are "just about one mile ahead of the inquisition," the Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman, pastor of St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, said in -his sermon yesterday morning at the joint services of St. Paul's and St. Andrew's Churches, West End Avenue and Eighty-six Street.

Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, joined with leaders of organized labor today in lauding the gains made by the movement to better working conditions and to raise wages and salaries. John L. Lewis,

The city, which for the eight preceding days had sweltered in the grip of a sultry heat wave, shivered yesterday as drizzling rains continued the chilly weather brought on by the storm of Saturday night.

Lieut. Col. Nathaniel A. Jones, U. S. Army, and Mrs. Jones of Mitchel Field, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mildred Ruth Jones, to Lieutenant Audrin R. Walker, U. S. Air Reserve, stationed at Kelly Field, Texas. The marriage will take place in the Officers Club at Mitchel Field on Oct. 14.

Cardinal Hayes will complete on Wednesday forty-five years in the priesthood. The day in the ecclesiastical calendar is the Feast of the Nativity of the Blessed Virgin. It is expected that he will observe the day quietly because of his recent illness.

The United States Government has warned the Mexican Government in diplomatic language that it will not tolerate the squeezing out of existence of American oil companies with an investment between $200,000,000 and $300,000,000 in Mexico.

H. B. Atkin's Jubilee and Leonard Romagna's Windward II were the, winners today in the regatta held by the Port Washington Yacht Club in Manhasset Bay. Jubilee won in the Star class and Windward II took top honors in the Meteor class, to win also the Charles E. Hyde trophy, with a point score of 19.

The old marching song, "Victorious we will defeat France," was prohibited today by an order inspired by the army. The decree, signed by Rudolf Hess, vice leader of the National Socialist party, also forbids the singing of a more recent version, "Victorious we will defeat Russia."

Hitch-hiking from Pennsylvania, a mall who gave his name as Paul Hefflefinger, 34, appeared at the county farm yesterday, said he had just completed a seven-year prison term and would like to complete an old sentence here.

If proof were needed of the gravity of the situation in Poland, it is found in the manifesto addressed to his countrymen by the first Premier, the man chiefly responsible for the creation of the new Polish republic.

With more than seventy entries received for the six-race card, the Adjacent Hunts Racing Association will hold its annual meeting at Rye today. Except for the opening and closing contests, the program is made up of jumping races.
The Diet listened today with profound approval to the opening speeches that affirmed Japan's determination to wage war for so long as might be necessary to attain her objects.

Horace E. Dodge, Detroit, owner; F. G. Ericson, driver; Ed MacKenzie, mechanic; representing Detroit Y. C.; 6-cylinder Packard motor. EL LAGARTO George Reis, Bolton Landing, N. Y., owner and driver; Anderson Bowers, mechanic; representing Lake George Club; 6-cylinder Packard motor.

Fifteen persons were believed killed and eighteen severely hurt today when a train carrying 800 pilgrims to the medieval shrine at Kevelaer was wrecked as it entered the station here. Many others received cuts and bruises.

Miss Louise Williams Heim, daugher of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar V. Heim f Montclair, has completed plans or her wedding to Harvey S. Hopns Jr. of New York, son of Mr. nd Mrs. Harvey S. Hopkins of Newton. The ceremony will be perormed on Oct. 12in the First Conregational Church here, with the astor, the Rev. Dr. Archibald Black, officiating.

Domei, Japan's national news agency, in a dispatch from Seishin, Korea, reported today the seizure of five small Japanese or Korean fishing boats by Soviet authorities in waters near the Korean-Siberian boundary.
Mrs. Philip Lustig of East Haddam, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Helen Marie Lustig, to Henry Frank Stocek, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alois Stocek of Deep River, Conn.
A course entitled "war and peace" will be introduced at Hobart College this year as part of a new program which requires a four-year study of citizenship as a prerequisite for a decree.

Miss Alicia Cano de la Vega, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emeterio Cano de la Vega of this city and Bolivia, was married to Jaime Gutierrez Guerra, secretary of the Consulate General of Bolivia in New York, yesterday afternoon in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Harvey Conover's 45-foot sloop Revonoc. carrying the colors of the Larchmont Yacht Club, tonight captured the honors in the annual Stamford Yacht Club-Vineyard race.
The double-header scheduled at the Polo Grounds yesterday between the Giants and the Bees sprouted into two twin bills because of the all-day storm. After the postponement had been announced at noon,

Labor's gains in France, under the social legislation of the past year or more, have been partially offset by rising living costs, but the real income of the worker is higher than before the Popular Front took power, the Foreign Policy Association found in a bulletin made public today under

God does not deal with human beings in the mass but individually and He wants to give to each one the best that can be given, the Rev. Dr. Frederick F. Shannon, pastor of the Central Church of Chicago, said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue at Forty-eighth Street.

Dr. Robert E. Speer, who retired last May as secretary of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, plans to celebrate his seventieth birthday on Friday. A daughter, Miss Margaret Bailey Speer, dean of women at Yenching University, Peiping, China, who is to arrive in the United States tomorrow on furlough, will be among the members of the family present.
The charge that the Nanking Government is going Communist is repeated in a Shanghai dispatch to the newspaper Asahi, which alleges that power has slipped from the hands of General Chiang Kai-shek.

President Roosevelt announced at a press conference today aboard the yacht Potomac, which is stormbound here, that he was eager to make a trip West, but that the Sino-Japanese crisis stood in the way at the moment.

Lulu reveled in heavy going today, with the result that Briggs Cunningham became the first American ever to make a successful defense of the Scandinavian Gold Cup. Thus the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club has the world's outstanding Six-Meter trophy in its possession for at least another year and the Swedish yachtsmen and the Finns return home empty-handed.

Funeral services for Robert H. Lyman, newspaper executive and for fifteen years the editor of the World Almanac, were held yesterday at the Universal Chapel, 597 Lexington Avenue. Mr. Lyman died Friday at his home, 114 East Eighty-fourth Street, at the age of 73.

Daniel Alexander Cameron, Liberal Member of the House of Commons for Cape Breton NorthVictoria, died in a hospital here yesterday at the age of 66. He formerly was Provincial Secretary of Nova Scotia.

Breaking par by one stroke, on the final round, despite an all-day rain, Henry Picard, hometown pro, today won the $5,000 Hershey open golf tournament for the second straight year. He shot a 72 for a 72-hole total of 280, 12 under regulation figures.
Miss Sadie G. Emanuel of this city was married to Nathaniel Lewis yesterday noon at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel by Dr. Solomon Lowenstein in the presence of relatives and a few friends.

Business and financial developments, which have been marked by a substantial increase in the growth of commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, were reviewed today by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in its monthly bulletin for September.
The rocking chair fleet had all the best of it today as the forty-sixth annual renewal of the Middle States Regatta was held over a raindrenched course off the Arundel Boat Club.

Eleven new cases of infantile paralysis were reported in Chicago in the 24-hour period ending at 9 A. M. todaythree fewer than the preceding twenty-four hours. Two deaths were reported, the same number as the day before.

Various entertainments were held throughout the day at estates in the Summer colony for holiday guests. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bradley Murray gave a large buffet luncheon at Ilex House for their debutante daughters, the Misses Therese and Rosamond Murray, who will be introduced formally to society on Thanksgiving Day at their home in New York, 11 East Ninetieth Street.

Eighteen hundred persons, including choruses from eight States, were in attendance at the ninth annual Gymanfa Ganu, Welsh songfest, held here today. The States were Pennsylvania, Ohio, Virginia, West Virginia, Indiana, Illinois, New Jersey and New York.

William H. Marcussen has been elected president of Borden's Farm Products Division to succeed Harry A. Cronk, who has been appointed to the newly created position of chairman of the directing board of the division, according to Arthur W. Milburn, president of the Borden Company.

The Dodgers proved to have the better aquatic ability today in what had been scheduled to be the first game of a double-header with the Phillies at Baker Bowl and practically swam into sixth place as the Quakers sank to seventh.

John Woodruff, University of Pittsburgh Negro, won the 800-meter run in 1:54.5 today in the second day of a track meet between American and Japanese teams in which the invaders took six first places, although no formal point score was tallied.

The Railroad Credit Corporation will distribute 1 per cent on Sept. 15 in liquidation of the proceeds of the surcharges on freight revenues imposed by the Interstate Commerce Commission in 1931. The amount of the dividend will be$735,115, of which $604,340 will be cash and the remainder credits on account of loans made to needy railways by the corporation.

Liquidation was on in the lard market here early last week and early deliveries were sold at the lowest prices of the season, but the pressure let up despite deliveries of more than 22,000,000 pounds on contracts.

A brilliant opening is forecast for one of the most important events of the Autumn to members of society-the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden. Announcement has just been made by Whitney Stone, secretary, that only a few boxes are available for the show, which will be held from Nov. 3 through Nov. 10.
A trailer equipped as a church has just been finished for the Paulist Fathers and will leave Friday on its first mission among the mountain people of Tennessee.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated at 84 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the preceding week, and approximating the average in August, 84 to 85 per cent, the highest since May, production in the two intervening months having been curtailed by strikes.
Senator Connally defended today the right of husband and wife in the eight "community property" States to file separate instead of joint come-tax returns and therefore pay a smaller rate.

The Reds scored three runs on four hits in one inning to take the opener from the Cards by 3 to 2 today, but dropped the second game of a double-header, 1 to 0. The first contest was delayed until 3 P. M. because of a wet field.

Press releases indicate that some excitement has been whipped up in England by the disclosures of medical practices in A. J. Cronin's novel, "The Citadel," now a London best seller, due to be published here by Little, Brown this week.
The Japanese launched a tremendous offensive at dawn today, turning the full might of their land, air and naval forces against the Chinese throughout the Shanghai battle area.

Money is in demand here for quarterly income tax payments. That the market is fundamentally tight is shown by a drop in the promissory notes of the Gold Discount Bank to below 600,000,000 marks and expansion in Reichsbank credits in the last week of August by 638,000,000 marks, which is 20 per cent above the corresponding figure in 1936.

Summing up the fundamentals of the policy of the United States in its relations with other peoples, Alben W. Barkley, Senate majority leader, addressing the Inter-Parliamentary Union today, stressed opposition to the use of force.

A taxicab rolled into the Chicago River late last night from the lower level of Wacker Drive near La Salle Street. The plunge was seen by Vivian Hervig, 23, a graduate of North Western University, who was crossing the Clark Street Bridge.

Virtually all the primary election candidates, except Mayor La Guardia, will swing into action, tomorrow. With the Labor Day holiday over, they will continue a speaking campaign until the election on Sept. 16.
Florida's star mermaid, Miss Katherine Rawls, climaxed a sensational individual performance today by winning her third title in the Women's National A. A. U. swimming championships.

Leningrad firing squads today executed ten more Russians convicted of being enemies of the Soviet regime. Among the ten were three restaurant cooks from Leningrad Province who were accused of serving spoiled pork. It was charged that fifteen persons had been poisoned by eating pork cutlets served with what the court called

Secretary of State Cordell Hull issued the following message today on the occasion of the celebration of Rosh ha-Shanah tomorrow: "I am happy to join with others in extending to our fellow citizens of the Jewish faith cordial greetings
Steel authorities stress the falling off in export demand as a result of the conflict in the Far East, but even so a summary indicates an even greater difficulty in supplying the home market.
Japanese army officers who "borrowed" the Y. M. C. A. building here for thirty-six days, returned it today to its secretary, Charles Hall of Worcester, Mass.

Brig. Gen. Cornelius Vanderbilt, 64 years old today, was feted at a birthday dinner tonight at Beaulieu, given by Mrs. Vanderbilt, who was assisted by their daughter, Mrs. Vanderbilt Davis, and their son, Cornelius Vanderbilt Jr. Among the guests were all of the Vanderbilt family now here.

Miss Margaret Trefry Stafford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Stafford of 66 Sayre Street, this city, will be wed on Oct. 2 to Oliver G. Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Lewis of Indianapolis. The ceremony will be performed at the Stafford home by the Rev. Stewart M. Robinson, pastor of the Second Presbyterian Church.
Bank reports here foreshadow a substantial further trade recovery in Europe in the Autumn, chiefly in heavy industries and machinery.

ALPER-Mr. and Mrs. I., of 383 Broadway, Lawrence, L. I., wish to extend to their friends and relatives a happy New Year. ALPERT-Alpert Brothers and families extend New Year greetings to all their relatives and friends. ALTMARK-Mr. and Mrs. Seymour D., and son, wish their relatives and friends a very happy New Year.

Bucky Harris, pilot of the Senators, picked today to give Dick Lanahan, recent acquisition from Clark Griffith's Chattanooga farm, his initial major league chance against the Yankees, but the fork-handed hurler failed in his debut.

Charles Hansen, an agent of the National Maritime Union of the C. I. O., charged tonight thirtyseven of the crew of the freighter Oakmar, tied up in a strike here, had been aboard without food and water for three days and that Bethlehem Steel Company police threatened to shoot a crew seeking to get food to the men.

The Eastern College All-Stars will hold their last practice at their Peddle School training camp tomorrow and will leave for New York at noon Tuesday to have a final dress rehearsal under the Polo Grounds floodlights that night for Wednesday night's charity game against the New York Giants.

Henry C. Graves, former holder of championship rowing honors, died last night at the age of 80. As a boy he joined the Mutual Boat Club of Albany. In August, 1877, with Charles Bulger of Albany, he won the double oar championship at the regatta at Newark, N. J., setting a record that was not lowered for ten years. Mr.

Another Mediterranean mystery was reported tonight by fishermen living in villages along the eastern coast of Tunisia. They told of the mysterious torpedoing or shelling of a strange ship by an unseen attacker just off the coast last night. The ship sank,

Yesterday's cold rain brought suspension of polo activity among the high-goal players preparing for the national open championship which starts Saturday. Test matches were postponed at Sands Point, where the Argentines were to have met Greentree;

The largest group of women ever to visit this city at one time and for a single purpose is expected within the next two weeks when an estimated 50,000 to 75,000 women will arrive from all parts of the country for the American Legion convention opening Sept. 19.

Traditionally, the week before Labor Day reaches a year's low point of financial and commercial activity. Last week not only displayed the lethargy familiar to the period, but produced a declining market.

The entries for the Larchmont to Cornfield lightship vessel race, which will be conducted by the Larchmont Yacht Club starting Friday night, were announced today by John S. Dickerson Jr., chairman of the race committee.

Surely our citizens cannot so soon have forgotten the Potato Control Law passed by Congress in a hurried moment two years ago. Under it the Secretary of Agriculture was authorized to say just how large the potato crop should be. Then individual allotments were to be figured out for each State and for each farmer.
The square-rigged ship Joseph Conrad, which departed from Newport, R. I., Aug. 26 on a race to Bermuda against the Seven Seas, is expected to cross the finish line off St. Davids Head tomorrow.

Among the festivals in the folk life of different peoples (a handbook of which has just been published), there is one whose observance this year was doubtless prevented by the conflicts in the cities and fields of Spain and the menace in her skies.

George Manson Eames, works manager of the Singer Company and one of the city's leading industrial and civic figures for many years, died shortly before midnight at his suite in the Stratfield Hotel. Mr. Eames had been in ill health for several months. His age was 78.
Easier moneymarket conditions were accentuated last Thursday following reduction by the Bank of France of its official rate.

More gold was mined in California in 1935 and 1936 than in any year since 1862, according to a report by Walter Bradley, State Mineralogist, made public today. Figures for the two years were $31,165,050 and $37,710,470, respectively. In the eight years since 1929, when the depression revived mining activity, the State produced a total of $150,247,633 in gold, the report said.

Miss Madeleine Lenane, niece of Miss Eleanor Lenane of 310 Riverside Drive and daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer V. Lenane of this city, will be married to Sylvester Wilson Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Murphy of Fieldston, this city, on Saturday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of the Ascension, 215 West 107th Street. The ceremony will be performed by Mgr. John F. Brady.

Britain's transatlantic flying boat Cambria will remain at Toronto ten days for repairs to the craft, damaged late Friday when landing before 15,000 persons at the Canadian National Exhibition wa- I terfront.

Dr. y Don H. Hinckley, widely known Chicago surgeon, died tonight in the Victory Memorial Hospital from injuries received a short time earlier when he fell forty feet from an oak tree at his Summer home in Withrop Harbor, near here. He was 59 years old.

Labor controversies in the United States should be ended by peaceful means and under the guidance of Christian teachings, it was urged in many pulpits throughout the city yesterday in Labor Day sermons. The need for better understanding by labor and capital of each other's problems was stressed. Several clergymen warned that the rights of labor must not be taken away.

Nearly one-quarter of the complaints against employers that unions or individual employes filed at the New York office of the National Labor Relations Board in July were dismissed after investigation as being without merit, Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the board, reported yesterday in a speech over Station WEVD.

An audience of 5,400, the largest of the current season of the New York Hippodrome Opera Company, attended last night's performance of "Carmen." Maru Castagna took the title role, Aroldo Lindi was the Don Jose.

Bishop Thomas E. Molloy presided this morning at the solemn high mass of thanksgiving commemorating the sixtieth anniversary of the founding of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church here. "Persons of all faiths have reason to be grateful for the benefits of sixty years of Catholic faith and practice in this village," said Dr. James H. Griffiths, vice chancellor of the Brooklyn Diocese, who preached the sermon.

French and American flags will be flown side by side today in observance of the 180th anniversary of the birth of the Marquis de Lafayette and the twenty-third anniversary of the beginning of the Battle of the Marne during the World War, it was announced yesterday by Maurice Leon, chairman of the National LafayetteMarne Day Committee.

Labor is coming into disrepute because of the "godlessness" of its leaders, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer said yesterday morning in his sermon at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

There will be no peace, success or qualities making for a fuller life if Christians do not strive for steadfastness, Bishop-elect Richard Robinson declared yesterday in a sermon at the Holy Cross Pro Cathedral of the African Orthodox Church. 122 West 129th Street.
The establishment of a woodland "Alcatraz" gave Georgia a start today toward evolution of its old chain gang into an industrial penal system.

Failing Premier Benito Mussolini, who has discovered good political reasons for delaying his visit to Germany until after the National Socialist congress opening here tomorrow, the star attraction of the congress probably will be Japan's Prince Chichibu, brother of the Emperor.

Donald Shea of Baltimore, founder of the National Gentile League, Inc., got as much applause as mention of the name of Hitler this afternoon when he announced before some 12,000 members and friends of the German-American Bund that his organization was going to boycott Jewish enterprises.
The American League Against War and Fascism, the Committee for Cultural Organization and the American Music League have announced joint sponsorship of a song contest open to all composers.

After easily defeating the Browns in the opener of a doubleheader, 9 to 5, the Indians encountered more stubborn opposition in the second game with their former pitcher, Oral Hildebrand, but won with the aid of a double steal, 2 to 1.
The White Sox broke away from a sev- ea enth-inning 2 to 2 tie today to beat the Tigers 5 to 2 and lower to one game the margin the Tigers hold on second place in the American League.

Frank H. Brooks, long a Los Angeles real estate developer, died yesterday at the Glendale Sanitarium, after a long illness. He was 74 years old. Mr. Brooks was president of the Los Angeles Realty Board in 1928. He had been connected with real estate activities here for nearly half a century.

A picture of the Emperor's arduous daily life was given by the Asahi as a commentary on his imperial message to Parliament yesterday. Clearly manifesting his wish for stabilization in East Asia, it has, says the newspaper, profoundly impressed 100,000,000 Japanese [Japan's population is 66,000,000].

The Dewar small-bore trophy, held by American riflemen since 1926, will now be returned to England. The United States team recorded only 7,854 out of a possible 8,000 today, far below the record British score of 7,896 made on the English ranges in August.

Benjamin H. Green, Democratic leader of the Twenty-eighth Ward and a member of the Board of Mercantile Appraisers, died today at his home, 2,225 North Twenty-ninth Street, at the age of 70. He suffered a stroke three weeks ago.

All hope of a near bumper corn crop has been abandoned by the trade as the result of recent weather conditions. About the best that is expected at the present time is for a yield slightly better than the 1928-32 average of 2,555,000,000 bushels, although the estimate made early this week by local statisticians was for 2,625,000,000 bushels.

President Roosevelt holds that collective bargaining, "as usually understood," cannot be exercised by Federal Government employes and he regards as "unthinkable and intolerable" any militant tactics, such as strikes, by these workers.

The volume of freight passing through the union inland station in the Port Authority Commerce Building at 111 Eighth Avenue in August established new high recwords, passing the previous record for a month's business. The station's best previous day was also topped during the month, the Port Authority announced yesterday.

Jack Rutherfurd of Miami and Port Washington captured the freefor-all speed boat race, the feature event of the third annual regatta of the Absecon Island Y. C. today. Rutherfurd drove Miss Palm Beach to take the ten-mile test by more than a lap from Sol Zito of Egg Harbor, N. J., who was at the wheel of his Zito Plane IV.

A Christian perspective whereby man's real and imaginary worries can be viewed in their true light was urged by the Rev. Dr. Granville Mercer Williams, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of Saint Mary the Virgin, 139 West Forty-sixth Street, in his first sermon at that church in five months.

The German wholesale price index on Aug. 25 stood at 106.7, unchanged from a week earlier. The index on the cost of living in August was 106, against 106.2 in July. In the first eight months of 1937 Germany's wholesale price index, based on the average of 1913 as 100, ranged between 106.9 on Aug. 11 and 105.2 in the first week of January.

Net gains in group life insurance amounting to $200,000,000 for the first eight months of 1937 have been reported by the Equitable Life Assurance Society, bringing the total of employee protection to nearly $2,000,000,000.

Chisholm St (11-2970) s w cor of Freeman St. 75x24; Henry B. Albert, referee, to Ella Murphy, 1,865 University Ave. 203d St, 278 E (12-3308), Palazza Realty Corp to Ella Palazza, 278 E 203d St; mtg. $7.400. Hatting P1 (18-5524), s s. 237 ft e of Pennyfield Ave, 35x100; Locust Point Estate, Inc, to Helen Gould. 3,098 Hatting P1.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of St. Mary's Protestant Episcopal Church here was observed this afternoon with a jubilee service attended by many permanent and Summer residents of the Hamptons. The sermon was preached by the Right Rev. Dr. Frank Du Moulin, a retired Bishop of Southern Ohio who is now rector of St. John's Church at Lattingtown.

Union teamsters, pressing their "finish fight" against C. I. O. longshoremen and warehousemen, today led a bolt of many American Federation of Labor units from San Francisco's projected Labor Day parade tomorrow.

Cheering word comes from the banks of the Mississippi that the showboat is not altogether a glamorous memory. Even now the S. S. Goldenrod, a pleasure barge in the old tradition, is tied up for repairs at the St. Louis docks, the first seen there in more than three vears.
Rope spinners, Indians, political leaders and common folk, all friends of Will Rogers, will ascend Cheyenne Mountain tomorrow to dedicate a shrine to the cowboy-humorist.

Unless man works six days a week and devotes the Sabbath solely to religion, he "inevitably damns himself," the Rev. Dr. William H. Rogers asserted yesterday in a sermon at the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street. Only through religion can the labor problem be solved, he held.

The average wage the German worker finds in his pay envelope after all compulsory deductions is 29 marks weekly. Actual gross earnings prior to deductions vary from 20 a week for male assistants in the linen indutry, the lowest paying industry of all, to 110 marks a week for skilled linotype operators on newspaper, night duty.

The French Government desires to reduce money rates in order to increase production and business activity, as it realizes that the program of fiscal recovery cannot succeed without increasing production and trade and checking the price rise.
President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull have expressed their pleasure at the forthcoming visit to the United States of Dr. Halvdan Koht, the Norwegian Minister of Foreign Affairs,

Major and Mrs. George G. McMurtry of New York entertained with a luncheon at the Pot and Kettle Club today, their guests including Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert H. Montague, Mr. and Mrs. E. T. Stotesbury, Mr. and Mrs. A. Atwater Kent, Mr. and Mrs. J. Brooks Fenno, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hill Thorndike, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Burrall Pike and Mrs. Stanley M. Rinehart.

Kid Chocolate, Cuban, featherweight, brought his come-back campaign to the home folks today and outpointed Phil Baker of Norwalk, Conn., in a ten-round bout before a wildly enthusiastic crowd. Chocolate weighed 125 1/2 and Baker 134.
Mr. and Mrs. W. Ross Harper entertained here with a party for twenty-six guests at the Mount Washington, honoring Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Behr of Plainfield, N. J., who are visiting them.

The political pot is beginning to boil in Westchester County because of the battle between Republican organization and insurgent candidates for county committee posts and for city offices here in the coming primaries.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Eleanor Herr Colt, daughter of Mrs. John Colt of 829 Park Avenue and Mr. Colt of Red Bank, N. J., to C. Alan Hudson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Alan Hudson of Rumson, N. J., and Miami Beach, Fla., on Sept. 23 in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.
The University of Pennsylvania announced today the appointment of John Scott Neill, former varsity end for Penn, and Frank Long, former Swarthmore guard, to the football coaching staff.

A Catholic prelate, one of President Roosevelt's stanchest supporters, said last night that the Chief Executive's prestige in Congress, and the country at large, was one of the nation's "important questions" at the present time.

Miss Janet Richardson German, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Richardson German of Maplewood, has chosen Sept. 25 for her marriage to E. Harris Harbison of Princeton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Warner Harbison of Sewickley, Pa.

The Japanese Army headquarters here declared today that its forces were slowly advancing toward Machang along the Tientsin-Pukow Railroad, although the advance was seriously hampered by the lack of highway communications through flooded areas. In some places the water was said to be more than waist high.

A 200 per cent increase in the output of essential oils is expected this year in Bulgaria because of its success in diverting rose acreage to the cultivation of aromatic plants, the Department of Commerce announced in its weekly summary of world chemical developments.

Dictators and their methods were denounced by the Rev. Robert E. Woods, who preached yesterday at the high mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street. Some 3,000 parishioners and holiday visitors heard Father Woods plead for industrial peace before he started his sermon on "Pride."

BACH-Arthur, in his sixtieth year, beloved brother of Otto, Herman and Ella. Services at the Stolzenberger Chapel, 450 East 162d St., Monday, Sept. 6, at 2 P. M. Relatives and friends, also members of Wigwam Democratic Club are invited to attend. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. BAKER-I. Webster. Jr., of Rye, N. Y., Sept. 5, husband of Laura M., and son of Mr. and Mrs. 1. Webster Baker, and brother of Barbara Baker.

Greenwich St, 400, 27x102; Edwin C. Schlecht to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; mtg $21,000, held by grantee (825.50). 89th St, 333-35 E, 50x100.8; Fansail Realty Corp. Fanny Sailer, president, to P. K. P. Properties, Inc, 333 E 89th St; mtg $30,000 ($2).

More than 300 persons were present here at the Wyantenuck Country Club's ball last night. Large dinners were given earlier by William Felton Barrett Jr., at Sky Hill Farm and John C. Downing at the Olde Egremont Tavern. Mr. and Mrs. Donald Worthington entertained at Birchwood in honor of Mr. and Mrs. George Worthington of Cleveland.
Lieut. Comdr. Henry C. Clayton and Lieutenant Herbert R. Schaeffer of the Navy Reserve were killed tonight in the crash of a navy plane at Friendsville, Md., a hilly section near Cumberland.

The Infantry Journal, long one of the most respected of our military publications, and Lieut. Col. G. L. Simpsonobviously inspired by the "All-American," "All-Star," "All-Time" teams which fill our sports pages at certain seasons-have selected, and paraded in their current issue for the shafts and arrows of outraged readers,

Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Propaganda Minister, wound up the fifth Contress of Germans Living Abroad by urging his listeners to go forth to all parts of the world to proclaim the greatness of the Third Reich.

The Socialist party has purged its ranks of the "Trotskyists," the party's National Executive Committee announced yesterday. The action in the national organization came after the expulsion of fiftytwo followers of Trotsky in New York and the suspension of the chapter of the California organization.

With ten days left before the primary election on Sept. 16, Jeremiah T. Mahoney seems to have a better chance of winning the Democratic nomination for Mayor than Senator Royal S. Copeland, Tammany's candidate. The result of the contest between Mayor La Guardia and Senator Copeland for the Republican nomination appears to be uncertain.

It is learned that a Japanese destroyer that had passed within sight of the Hong Kong mainland this morning commenced shelling Shekwan, a Chinese coastal town, and the Mirs Bay area close to British territorial waters. No details have been learned.

Denunciation of the "few prominent industrialists" who are opposing the established national policy of labor's right to collective bargaining, and an attack upon "mercenary and lawless labor leaders" exploiting the workers for personal aggrandizement featured the Labor Day addresses delivered yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
Constance Lyman, 13-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charlton E. Lyman of 5 Antler Place, was back home tonight after a "disappearance' lasting six days.
Support of the Committee for Industrial Organization was urged yesterday by Earl Browder, national secretary of the Communist t party, in a Labor Day statement.
Chinese defenders of this city showed little respect today for the Japanese soldier's reputed valor as a fighting man.

The Spanish Insurgents reported today that they had beaten back the big Government offensive on the Aragon front. This offensive has now died out after eleven days, they declared, and during this period the Government forces lost forty-nine planes, with twenty others probably shot down behind their own lines by Insurgent anti-aircraft guns. The Insurgents calculate the Government troops' casualties at 20,000.
The political situation in Europe and in the Far East has come to the fore in the last few days as a major factor in the world's wheat markets and has imparted some strength to futures.

The Henry Street Settlement Music School, 8 Pitt Street, which is holding daily registration for its eleventh season opening on Sept. 27, will hear applicants for scholarships Tuesdays and Wednesdays of this month.
Miss Edith K. Eyre of this city and London, who arrived recently from Europe, is at the Pierre. Mrs. Seth E. Thomas is expected to arrive tomorrow at the Berkshire from Morristown, N. J.
Thomas W. Lamont, Viscount Cowdray, Lord Barnby, Paul F. Warburg and Count and Countess Haugwitz von Reventlow are due to arrive today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.
Lewes hopes the navy will lose no time in reclaiming a depth bomb apparently laid by destroyers during the submarine scare in 1917.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Burger of this place have announced the coming marriage of their daughter, Miss Alice Jane Burger, to Lewis Pitkin Cheney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Cheney of South Manchester. The ceremony will take place here Saturday afternoon in Trinity Episcopal Church.

Rising domestic and foreign prices are operating in only an exceedingly slight degree in curbing consumptive demand, and these higher prices account largely for the promising revival currently experienced in international trade.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Montgomery Sicard of this place and Pelham Manor, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Williams Sicard, to Henry William Reis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Reis, also of Pelham Manor.

Each of the nine legitimate attractions now domiciled on Broadway will give a Labor Day matinee today, five of them abandoning their midweek afternoon performances in hopes of greater returns on the holiday.

The midsummer slump in building here, brought on, builders say, by the combination of increased costs of materials and the recent strike, continued through August, when operations totaling $192,850 were reported by Building Inspector Charles D. Crosby.

Professor Nelson C. Brown of the New York State College of Forestry, Syracuse University, has returned from Germany to express the conviction that wood has possibilities of becoming the most important single basic material for Germany and perhaps the world.

United States Senator Royal S. Copeland, candidate for both the Democratic and Republican nominations for Mayor, declared yesterday that in his opinion "the British have done a miserable job in their efforts or alleged efforts to maintain order" in Palestine.

For the first time a concrete suggestion that Soviet warships be used to convoy freighters in the Mediterranean has been made in an appeal to the Government by sailors of the Baltic trade fleet. A similar suggestion can be read between the lines of an editorial in the army newspaper Red Star, which concludes::

Sir Albert Levy, founder of the Ardath Tobacco Company, Ltd., and one of Britain's best known philanthropists, died here today at the age of 73. Sir Albert gave not only money but his time to the Royal Free Hospital, of which he was treasurer for many years.
The Pittsburgh Pirates smothered the Philadelphia Eagles under a barrage of long passes today to open the National Football League season with a sparkling 27-14 triumph.

Mrs. Susan P. Post, widow of Cornelius Van Horn Post, died here last night at the home her daughter, Mrs. Charles Barbier, at the age of 95. Mrs. Post was born in Jersey City and lived there until ten years ago, when she moved to Montclair and later to Glen Ridge.

In 135 motor trucks, 1,100 infantrymen of the Seventy-first Regiment of Manhattan, commanded by Colonel George F. Terry, moved out of Camp Smith here for home this morning, after two weeks of training, in a rainstorm that duplicated the one encountered upon entering camp.
Discovery of the fossilized remains of a heretofore unknown type of lizard, believed to be 55,000,000 years old, was announced today by Dr. G. L. Jepson of Princeton University.

Dr. Harold Clayton Urey of Columbia University tonight announced that a process for producing the heavy isotope of nitrogen in quantities sufficient for research experiments had been successfully devised.
